column2: CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The exciting joint debate looked for to-night between William J. Bryan and W. Bourke Cockran on trusts did not take place. Central Music Hall was packed with an eager audience, but the people present had to content themselves without the oratory of the famous Nebraskan, who, however, occupied a seat on the platform.

Will you permit me to venture a small piccolo note of delight over a typographic error in the SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 9? In an editorial article giving a list of books for girls' reading you quote Thackeray as saying: "Novels are secrets."

The opening of the New York art season is in sight. The cool weather of the past fortnight has brought so many people to town that the art shops have found themselves filled with visitors, and engravings and etchings in particular have been readily sold to Western and Southern house owners who are tarrying here on their way home from country resorts until after the Dewey celebration and the America's Cup races.

Poor "X.": Vacation, reinvigorating and exalting, is over. With a bound the happy scribe rushes into his sanctum sanctorum expecting to find there the fruit of his Spring toil -- a pile of coin-producing checks. Melancholy greeting! In place of the anticipated harvest he finds its unfertilized seed. There lie his manuscripts returned and rejected. Disappointing?

FISHKILL LANDING, Sept. 15. -- Gen. Daniel Butterfield, Chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements for the Dewey parade in New York, has now almost entirely recovered his health. He is still at his Summer home, at Cold Spring, opposite West Point, and is able to take an afternoon drive and walk about the grounds surrounding his residence.

All Weehawken was talking yesterday of the coolness and courage shown by William and Theodore Bollerman in rescuing two boys who had fallen from the Palisades and landed on a ledge ten feet below. The lads were George Heintzmann, five years old, of Union Hill, and Frank Clarkson, his cousin, six years old, whose home is in Jersey City.

The Committee on Plan and Scope of the Dewey Executive Committee again changed the route of the land parade to be held on Sept. 30, so that now the column, instead of branching off from Fifth Avenue at Twenty-third Street and making its way to the point of dismissal will continue on in a straight line to the Washington Arch.

This little book is intended more for a memorial of the places and objects connected with Shakespeare's country, its history, legends, and stories, than as a guide book, for which reason many stories and surmises connected with the poet have been included, even when they rest upon a very slight foundation of fact.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Senator Foster of Washington received a telegram from E.C. Bellowes, at Vancouver, saying that Corp. Damphoffer, Company B, Sixteenth Infantry, had been sentenced to be shot to death at Manila. The dispatch stated that Damphoffer was a resident of Vancouver and was only nineteen years old.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- American securities opened depressed on lower overnight operations from New York. The market remained weak, being controlled entirely by advices from Wall Street. The closing tone was steady.

Encouraged by the result of their attentions to fancy specialties in Thursday's stock market, operators massed their energies yesterday against Brooklyn Rapid Transit. That property furnished so good a target that no temptation appeared to attack anything else. Stocks put out through the house which fathered the Brooklyn enterprise seemed nearest the point of contagion and suffered somewhat.

" The Mirror of Perfection," the oldest life of St. Francis, was written by one of his contemporaries, Brother Leo, and translated from the Latin original recently discovered by Paul Sabatier, the well-known French author. The present translation is made directly from the mediaeval Latin of Brother Leo's manuscript, by Sebastian Evans, the author of "Brother Fabian's Manuscript and Other Poems," and "In the Studio," whose translations Joseph Knight calls "singularly happy ones."

EAST HAMPTON, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Dr. D.A. Williams, a patent medicine dealer of this place, to-day received a letter from Assistant District Attorney Osborne of New York, asking that a letter which Dr. Williams had received in April, 1898, requesting samples, and signed "Albert J. Morgan, 159 West Twenty-third Street, New York," be forwarded to him.
BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- Charles Allen, a mail robber, who escaped from Ludlow Street Jail, in New York, in 1895, and Sidney Wennie, a pickpocket, of Washington, have been arrested at Frankfort.

MANCHESTER, Sept. 15.--The Right Hon. John Morley, Liberal member of Parliament for the Montrose Burghs, while addressing a peace meeting in this city this evening, at which a son of the late John Bright, the distinguished British statesman and friend of peace, presided, was frequently interrupted by cries of "Majuba Hill" and other anti-Boer demonstrations. In retorting to the interruptions, Mr. Morley said:

In your issue of Sept. 9 "E.D.F." asks for a list of good books for a young woman of eighteen. May I add to the list you have published in response to this request? If the young girl in question has never read Mrs. Ewing, she has some delightful books in store for her. It is a matter of surprise that this charming writer is so little read, in this country at least.

The development of the Russian Empire is one of the most marvelous stories of national growth to be found in the annals of the world. The fusion of a few nomadic tribes soon after the Golden Horde of Tartars had overran Eastern Europe was maintained during the invasion of Tamerlane and the second Tartar incursion, and, finally under Ivan III, the monarchial system was established, he taking the title of Czar of Moscovy.

After two unsuccessful trials, the Shamrock, Sir Thomas Lipton's Irish cup hunter, was sent over a twenty-mile course outside of the lightship that marks the wreck of the Scotland. She covered the course in 3 hours and 50 seconds under the influence of a breeze that was soft in spots and blew at the rate of eight to ten knots an hour.

Mayor VAN WYCK was on the stand before the Mazet committee for some time and was asked to tell what he knows as to the Ramapo contract, and he was asked a number of specific questions. Stripping his replies of the ill-temper and impertinence shown, of which there were altogether too much, what do they disclose as to the knowledge of the Mayor in this matter?

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 15. -- After being appealed to by Attorney General Duncan G. Bellinger of South Carolina not to follow the example of the jury at Rennes and refuse justice to a Jew, a jury of white men sitting at Beaufort to-day found a verdict for $850 for the plaintiff in the case of David Schein against Don Cameron, ex-Senator of Pennsylvania.

Here is a matter concerning which THE TIMES ought to say a strong word, the last week's Collier's Weekly title page. It is a picture of the interior of a church (R.C.) in the Philippines, with a view of the altar. Before the altar is a writing table, placed where the priest stands to celebrate mass. At that table sits a uniformed man, with a cigar in his mouth, writing.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for James A. Frame Son, for $31,000, the five-story American-basement dwelling 259 West Ninetieth Street, 18 by 100.

" Parson Kelly: An Historical Story," by A.E.W. Mason, author of "The Courtship of Morrice Butler," and Andrew Lang, will be ready Sept. 22 from Longmans, Green Co.'s. The frontispiece is by Gordon Browne.

Reading lately an article on the "Binding of Books," the following paragraph attracted our attention: "Let me confess at once to being one of those who like to see books well bound. Paper covers, even on a rare Dickens, do not attract me. If I am going to read a book I would far rather have a volume bound in leather to handle than one in boards, as issued."

The election Oct. 4 of a successor to Secretary George W. Ely of the New York Stock Exchange, who retires Oct. 14 to become President of the Bankers' Trust Company, is exciting interest in the candidate who will be promoted as regular by the Nominating Committee of the Exchange. Several members have been named as likely to secure the nomination, but it is understood that the choice of the committee will be Chairman William McClure.
LONDON, Sept. 16. -- A special dispatch from Pretoria says that the Transvaal's reply will be on the following lines:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15. -- Ex-Secretary of the Treasury John G. Carlisle has been unwillingly dragged into the Kentucky Gubernatorial campaign. Some days ago a local newspaper published a statement that in 1898 Mr. Goebel was an ardent sound-money man and went to Washington to get Mr. Carlisle's help to secure a sound-money delegation from Kenton County to the State Convention to send delegates to the National Convention at Chicago.

In the review of the Rev. Mr. Waller's History of Flushing, in the issue of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 9, the writer quotes the author as saying the English settlers found the name Vlissingen, or Flushing, already given to the place before their arrival. The following extract from Miss Flint's "Early Long Island," Page 173, furnishes a more probable origin of the name:

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The papers are still flooded with Dreyfus letters, the most remarkable to-day being from Mr. Michael Davitt, the Irish Nationalist member of Parliament. Mr. Davitt says English sympathy for the prisoner is entirely due to the fact that Dreyfus is a rich Jew instead of a poor one, and to the desire to injure a rival nation.

The New Yorks easily outplayed the St. Louis team at the Polo Grounds yesterday, giving a good exhibition throughout. The locals' strong and timely batting was a feature. In fielding they did equally well. Five errors were charged against the team, but all these were made on difficult chances. Wrigley, who was signed on Thursday, did some clever fielding.

Weather conditions favored the riflemen at Creedmoor yesterday, and creditable scores were made in both events of the day, the Governor's and Adjutant General's matches. In the Governor's match, open to individual members of the National Guard, first place was taken by Sergt. W.S. Lamb of Company E, Twelfth Regiment, by a score of 88 out of a possible 100 points.

VIENNA, Sept. 15. -- The Danube is still rising and is now 476 centimeters above its normal level. As yet no serious danger threatens Vienna, but the railway station and the streets along the banks of the river are submerged.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 15. -- The crowning feature of the Lenox golf tournament was the final match for the Lenox Cup to-day between Chester Griswold, Princeton, and the George H. Cooke, Point Judith. They played excellent golf from start to finish, Griswold winning by 4 up and 3 to play. In the morning Griswold showed his superiority in driving and approaches.

Emil Paur, the famous musical conductor, arrived here yesterday on the Trave, after an absence of three months in Europe, where he visited France, Germany, and Austria. Mr. Paur was in excellent health and spirits, and said he came prepared to put in the hardest Winter's work of his life.

In one of the most successful books of the year -- "David Harum" -- the author is said to have portrayed a man well known to residents of Central New York. Not only by similarity of names and personal characteristics was this shown, but many of the incidents detailed were recognized as having occurred in connection with him.

Judge Addison Brown of the United States District Court yesterday handed down an opinion granting the motion of Edward Van Ingen, counsel for Willard Parker Butler, trustee in bankruptcy, in the case of John F. Baudouine, for an order permitting the trustee to determine the question of the amount of surplus of the bankrupt's income under the will of his grandfather, Charles A. Baudouine.

There was another hearing in the bankruptcy proceedings involving the firm of Horgan Slattery, architects, yesterday in the office of Referee Stanley W. Dexter at 71 Broadway. Since the failure of the firm its members and their wives have formed a Horgan Slattery corporation, and are now carrying on business, although both of the members have sought discharge from their debts contracted when they formed the copartnership.

A Harrow boy communicates to the July number of The Captain some curious rules laid down by Harrow boys, and more punctiliously enforced and kept, it is said, than many instituted by the headmaster himself. There are two distinct classes of Harrovians, i. e., those who have been in the school three years, and those who have not.

The petitions and appeals that are being sent to the President to take some action as to the Dreyfus case are wholly misdirected. The President can do nothing in the premises, and could not undertake to do anything without committing the gravest error.

In his letter of Aug. 15 your old friend "Cynic" objects to my use of the words "lovely frost-picture work" in writing of Henry James's book, "The Awkward Age." He likewise declares virtually that work to be detestable, erotic, vile, and so on and worse, for some of his adjectives are as displeasing as the book he pronounced to be.

The Mazet committee resumed its sessions yesterday with Maurice F. Holahan, President of the Board of Public Improvements, as the chief witness. His appearance gave the spectators an opportunity to hear more about the inner workings of the Ramapo deal. Mr. Holahan added some spice to the proceedings, which, however, seemed dull in contrast with the lively tilts of the day before.
LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The Macmillans will not issue their list for a fortnight, the time being a month later than usual.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The President received in audience at the White House this afternoon John George Leigh, who spent several months in Samoa as special correspondent of The London Times and is now on his return journey to England.

Mr. Frederick Palmer is putting the finishing touches to a Dewey book that will be presented in about ten days through the Doubleday McClure Com pany. It is to be called "George Dewey, Admiral: Impressions of the Admiral and the Olympia on Her Homeward Progress from Manila." Mr. Palmer has had exceptional opportunities for observing the Admiral, having followed the Olympia from port to port over Southern Europe.

It is not for us to enter into the merits of the contention now raging between the English and the Boers, only praying that wiser counsels may prevail and that some kind of a compromise be made. Mr. Howard C. Hillegas, in "Oom Paul's People," is the warmest advocate Stephanus Johannes Paulus Kruger has yet found.

Tears were shed by men and women of social distinction and of humble station in life at the funeral of Cornelius Vanderbilt in St. Bartholomew's Church yesterday forenoon. A large proportion of the persons assembled were relative, business associates, and employes of Mr. Vanderbilt, and most of them followed the services with visible emotion.

Assistant District Attorney James Joseph Grady died suddenly yesterday afternoon, in the office of ex-Judge Joseph Koch, of heart failure. Mr. Grady, who yesterday reported for duty after a month's vacation, went over to ex-Police Justice Koch's office, at 84 Elm Street, to consult with him about some cases.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15. -- By the order of President Arthur T. Hadley of Yale University, crape was to-day placed on the gates of Vanderbilt Hall in memory of Cornelius Vanderbilt. The building was given to the university by Mr. Vanderbilt.
LONDON, Sept. 16. -- The Paris correspondent of The Daily News says the Premier, M. Waldeck-Rousseau, has promised definitely to propose a pardon for Dreyfus at next Tuesday's Cabinet Council.
HAVANA, Sept. 15.--The Diario de la Marina says editorially to-day:

The independent distillers of Kentucky have notified the Kentucky Distilleries and Warehouse Company -- commonly known as the Whisky Trust -- that they propose to dominate the whisky trade. John F. Pogue, President of the committee of independent distillers, who recently visited New York and had an unsatisfactory conference with the officers of the trust, said yesterday:

A runaway horse caused much excitement at Broadway and Fourteenth Street yesterday afternoon. Two persons were injured, and they so slightly that they were able to proceed to their homes without receiving medical attendance. They were John Caprano of 233 East Forty-sixth Street, a real estate dealer, and Jerome Radley, seven years old, of the same address.

CAPE TOWN, Sept. 16. -- Further telegrams from Pretoria to-day confirm the forecast of the reply of the Transvaal, which does not accept the demands of the British Government as a whole. Great excitement prevails at Pretoria over the consequences which may ensue. The young Boers are asking to be led into the field immediately.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Cardinal Gibbons will officiate to-morrow at the dedication of the new monastery of the Franciscan Fathers, which has been erected on ground adjoining the Catholic University. The services will begin at 10:20 A.M., with a Pontifical mass, at which Archbishop Martinelli, the Apostolic Delegate, will be present.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- The suicide of Arthur E. Cobb at the home of Mrs. Blanche McKibbon here some time on Thursday night was the talk of the town to-day, as he had been a familiar figure on the streets with Mrs. McKibbon. They were reported to have been lovers.

The demand for American apples in Great Britain and other parts of Europe has been very large, and the exports during the past year were 1,217,767 barrels. They exceeded the exports of the previous year by 461,355 barrels. By far the greater part went to Great Britain, only 24,521 barrels having gone to Hamburg, and 58,710 to other European countries.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 16. -- The Horse Show next week will be an interesting and novel event and one that will in a measure take the place of some of the usual outdoor events which have been omitted this year. It will be held on next Friday, Sept. 22, and at Highlawn Farm, which was recently purchased from the estate of the late Elizur Smith by William D. Sloane.

Not the least interesting features of the presents public discussion of "trusts" (meaning thereby business consolidations) as a problem in modern economics are the various rational and irrational shades of opposition with which the subject is treated. It seems to me that there are many fallacies in the popular conception of the topic.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- At to-day's racing of the Lingfield Park Club September meeting "Skeets" Martin, the American jockey, won the Burton Midweight Handicap on the Duke of Westminster's three-year-old bay colt Scimitar. Tod Sloan had the mount on Mr. L. Brassey's Palmira, and finished third.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Nat Goodwin is in an angry state of mind. He received a cable from Charles Frohman refusing to free him from his American tour. Levenston and Lorillard also refuse to allow him to withdraw from the contract he signed, and say they will hold him financially responsible.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 16. -- The season here is practically at an end. There are few festivities to record, and entertaining has come to a standstill. The cottagers are still here. The exodus for the mountains has been remarkably small in comparison with other years, and very few have departed for good.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- The conference on the uses and abuses of trusts closed its session here to-day in a blaze of oratory in which Col. W.J. Bryan and W. Bourke Cockran were the central figures. Mr. Cockran followed the noted Nebraskan, but disclaimed any intention of debating the conclusions of his immediate predecessor and declaring his complete concurrence in much that Mr. Bryan had said.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 16. -- The weather was all that could be desired for the sixteenth annual tournament of the Canadian Amateur Athletic Union to-day at Rosedale. The Americans captured every event. Kraenzlein, Flanagan, Baxter, and Long, all of the New York Athletic Club, were the chief winners.

A cruising steam yacht will be the novel and next addition to the fleet of the Hamburg-American Line. The company has just placed an order for such a craft with the shipbuilding firm of Blohm Voss of Hamburg. The success of cruises in Northern waters in the Summer season and in the Mediterranean in Winter has led to the company's decision to have a vessel specially constructed for such service.

Henry Miller began an engagement at the Herald Square Theatre last night, presenting a drama in four acts and a prologue, founded on Charles Dickens's famous story of the French Revolution called "A Tale of Two Cities." The title of the play is "The Only Way," and its author is Freeman Wills, a brother of the celebrated dramatist who wrote "Charles I," and other plays for Henry Irving.
One of the most radical suggestions as to the trusts is that made by Mr. COCKRAN at Chicago, that corporations shall be subjected to full publicity.

No fact has ever excited as much interest and sympathy as the history of Capt. Dreyfus. Especially since the return from Devil's Island have its phases been followed by all the world with passionate interest, and his recondemnation has been received with astounded indignation. But although in respect to the fact itself sentiment appears to be unanimous, the superadded individual ideas and impressions seem to be singularly different.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- A fire which started in the boiler room of the Ira S. Disbrow box factory at 4 o'clock this afternoon destroyed that structure, together with the J.H. Chase flouring mills, and damaged surrounding property. Two firemen were injured.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 16. -- Prince Ranjitsinhji, the Indian cricketer, accompanied by the cricket team with which he is to make a trip to the United States, sailed this afternoon on the Cunard liner Etruria, for New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- A dispatch from Memphis, Tenn., says that Charles O. Summers, who was formerly a detective, an escaped convict, and a gold hunter of the Klondike, is again within prison walls in Mississippi. He journeyed all the way from Dawson City to New York, and from New York to Memphis, and Memphis to Jackson, Miss., to surrender himself as a safe robber.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 16. -- The officials of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association are highly pleased with the prospects for a fine meeting here Oct. 3 to Oct. 14. Last payments have been made on the entries in all the stakes save the Transylvania and the Tennessee, and these close to-day.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- The First Battalion of the Northumberland Fusiliers, 900 strong, and detachments of the Army Service Corps and Ordnance Corps sailed on the steamer Gaul at 2 P.M. to-day from Southampton en route to Natal amid great enthusiasm. The men appeared to be in splendid condition and openly anxious for fighting.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 16. -- The championship of the special "lark" class for a cup offered by The Rudder was decided over the triangular course of the Manhasset Bay Yach Club this afternoon. Mascot was the winner. There were three competitors -- Marcot, Thomas Clapham; Old Squaw, S.F. Carstair; Uneeda, Samuel Jackson.

Fashions are quick to take advantage of events which influence popular favor. No better illustration of this fact is afforded than in the yachting fervor incident to the coming race between the Shamrock and the Columbia. Hatbands, neckties, shirts, walking sticks, and many other articles of wearing apparel bear tokens of the racing yachts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- The Government has been cheated out of a soldier by Mrs. M.H. Barnett of Chicago, now on her way home from Fort Leavenworth, Kan., with her husband, who secretly enlisted in the Thirty-second Regiment, and would now be on his way to the Philippines had not his wife, through influential friends, secured his release by writing at the eleventh hour to President McKinley and Secretary of War Root.

John F. Carroll will have opposition in his race for re-election as Tammany leader of the Twenty-ninth District, in spite of the defection from the opposition ranks of Abraham Schwab and two other election district Captains.
Frank Moss, counsel for the Mazet investigating committee, said yesterday that he considered the testimony brought out last week in reference to the Ramapo water scheme of great value.

In Prof. John Fiske's admirable history of "The American Revolution," which was published in 1891, the following passages occur, and seem to bear directly upon one of the burning questions of the day. It is hardly necessary to add that Prof. Fiske is recognized as one of the best and strongest thinkers and writers of the time, or to ask why we should not profit by the "instructive example" of the English King's "short-sighted folly."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The Navy Department has transferred to the War Department the collier Cassius. She will be turned into a transport, and from her size will be able to carry a full regiment. She was formerly the German passenger steamer Raetia.

Charles P. Clark, for more than twelve years President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, informed the Board of Directors of that company yesterday that his health rendered it necessary for him to retire from the Presidency. No time was fixed for his resignation to take effect.

NEWBURG, N. Y., Sept. 16. -- By a vote of 160 to 15 the Milk Producers' Association to-day again refused to sign the contract for milk for the next six months which is offered them by the New York Condensed Milk Company. For a number of years past there has been dissatisfaction when the prices for milk were made public and contracts signed, but the farmers have invariably affixed their names to the contracts.

BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- When the Harvard football season opens on Monday it is expected that a large proportion of the seventy-five men invited to attend the opening practice will be present. Manager Spalding has not only asked many of the old men to return for the work, but notices have been sent to many of the stars of the preparatory school who are this year coming to Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The announcement that Admiral Schley was to command the South Atlantic Squadron was preceded and accompanied by a number of explanations to the effect that no slight to the Admiral was intended, and that the South Atlantic was a highly desirable station, all thing considered. These explanations were made before anybody had criticized the appointment, or had even had an opportunity to do so.

THE TIMES of this morning publishes the eloquent plea of Mr. Robert J. Thompson, Secretary of the Lafayette Memorial Commission, for gratitude to France and against the "shameful treatment" we are now, in common with all civilization, bestowing upon that miserable people. Mr. Thompson's memory must be very narrow, if he gives France all moral credit for her joining the United States in their Revolution.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16. -- September is half over but there are still many of the cottagers remaining at their villas who will be found here this time next month. During the week many entertainments were given in honor of Prince Cantacuzene and Miss Grant, while dinners and luncheons followed in rapid succession.

The St. Louis baseball team, largely through the good pitching of Young, easily blanked the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Young was invincible throughout, and only one local player reached third base, and few got as far as second. The visitors' fielding was fast and clean, Childs, Wallace, and Cross doing the best work.

CALAIS, Me., Sept. 16. -- At the yard of a local granite company there is a shaft that is attracting much attention. It was ordered by the Government and will be placed at North Perry, twenty-one miles from this city, on the spot marked by the geographical surveyors of Washington as being midway between the north pole and the equator.
LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Information from all sources points to the extreme gravity of the Transvaal situation.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 16. -- On the links of the Weeburn Golf Club this afternoon a thirty-six-hole competition was played for a prize presented by John F. Taylor. There were two classes -- one for those who had won a prize this year and the other for those who had not. The results:

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 16. -- During the coming Winter there will be great activity in railway construction in that part of Western Ontario and Northern Minnesota lying between Lake Superior and the capital of Manitoba. One of the chief links in Canada's rival transcontinental line, which is expected to reach from Quebec to the North Pacific within five years, is to be built there immediately.

The steamship lines are now in the height of one of the busiest seasons on record in the Transatlantic passenger business. Only in the year of an international exposition, such as that expected next year, is there such an increase over the normal business as that which has followed the war with Spain, which last year reduced the travel to a low ebb.

James Smith, a flour merchant at 31 Moore Street, was killed yesterday afternoon at his store by a barrel of flour falling upon him while he was engaged with some of his men hoisting it to an upper floor. He had adjusted the tackle to the barrel, and stood under the hatchway hauling on the rope.
" Do New York women have individuality in taste in their selection of wall papers?" some one asked the head man in a big paper house up town the other day.

The proposal of a sculptor to "perpetuate" the Dewey Arch, as it was published a day or two ago, must have horrified a considerable number of enlightened citizens. It must particularly have pained the proposer's fellow-sculptors, because the report described him as the "Secretary of the National Sculpture Society," which we believe he is not, though he used to be, and thus seems to give the sanction of that body to his proposal.
PROVIDENCE R.I., Sept. 16. -- The Grand Circuit races closed at Narragansett Park to-day with the best attendance and weather conditions of the week. The summary:

Wall Street presented last week the spectacle of declining prices in the face of general prosperity, Reports from all sections could hardly have been better. Increases of nearly 30 per cent. in bank clearings reflected the active employment of money in business. Such employment is, of course, profitable.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- Though the Government has taken pains to preserve its equilibrium the result of the Dreyfus trial has tremendously shocked the German people, irrespective of creed and politics. The bitter insult implied by the total disregard upon the part of the Rennes court of the official Reichsanzeiger's declaration of Dreyfus's innocence is deeply felt here.

-- A Frenchman, who probably voices the sentiments of a large majority of his countrymen, angrily asks if regard for personal rights is so unvarying and so perfect in lands of English speech that the inhabitants thereof have good reason to raise their hands in holy horror at a single disregard of such rights in France.

The racing at Gravesend yesterday was of the sort to be enjoyed for the finishes were lively and well fought, and there was little in any of the events to suggest "queer" work. There was, however, an accident that jarred the nerves of the women in the grand stand. This was a fall in the Prospect Handicap, which resulted in a broken leg for Sakhrat, a fair colt owned by Demiel Farrell.

Elm Street, about which so much has been written and said during the last few years, and the widening of which was deemed a grave public necessity in order to relieve the congestion on Broadway, will remain in its present unsightly condition for at least seven or eight months. It may stay just as it is, save for additions to its present heterogeneous collection of refuse, for an even longer time than this.

Though I guess you are receiving showers of suggestions re Dewey parade, I venture to add one which you may think worth calling attention to. It is that a few of the Jackies, particularly the stokers, coal passers, and other of that ilk, of the other ships of Dewey's squadron engaged on that May morning, be invited to participate in the land parade.

NORWAY, Me., Sept. 16. -- A few years ago the farmers in several sections of the State of Maine commenced raising barley for the breweries in New Hampshire, and simultaneously the Woman's Christian Temperance Union sent out circulars to those who had planted the grain on their farms asking them to kill the crop, for the barley, being used to make beer, would injure the rising generation.

The annual announcement of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, outlining the work of all its departments for the season of 1899-1900, has been issued. It contains a complete prospectus of the institute's anniversary meetings, addresses, lectures, , and special features of work to be introduced during the coming season, which extends from Sept. 28 to June 2.
SCOTTSBURG, Ind., Sept. 16. -- Undoubtedly the most valuable piece of wheat raised in the United States this year was that raised here by E.P. McCaslin, a scientific farmer and experimenter.

CHILDWOLD PARK, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- September in the North Woods, besides being the hunter's month, is far and away the most delightful month in the year -- the month of soft winds and ruffled water, of early frosts and pleasant sun baskings, of golden and russet woods, where there are few nuts and plenty of partridges.

The latest annual report of the Massachusetts Bureau of Statistics is devoted to the investigation of Sunday labor in that State. In 1898 an act of the Legislature directed the bureau "to investigate the subject of Sunday labor in this Commonwealth, with respect to the number of persons employed, the conditions of employment, and other facts relating thereto."

They are still telling stories about Verdi, as though a new opera by him were in rehearsal and he in need of a press agent. Here is one sent on from Rome to a London paper: "Verdi has left Montecatini, whither he went ostensibly for a cure, but as he hates medicine, has little faith in doctors, and has perfect health, one must suspect that it was simply for a change.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Commenting upon the difficulty experienced in finding a successor as Ambassador at Washington to Lord Pauncefote, a weekly paper says it is more than likely that Sir Thomas Henry Sanderson, K.C.B., Permanent Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs since 1894, will receive the appointment to Washington as a reward for his long services in the Permanent Under Secretaryship.

There was an interesting scramble for black-eyed Susans, recognized better by some observers as yellow daisies, in Mulberry Bend Park yesterday afternoon. There was a scramble also for other kinds of flowers, but somehow, perhaps because the black-eyed Susans came first, they were the most-sought-for flowers of those that were distributed.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 1. -- The Lenox golf tournament, which has been in progress all the week, closed to-day, with a very close and interesting match for the President's Cup, given by William D. Sloane. The first round of eighteen holes was played this morning, when Samuel Frothingham of the Lenox Club beat L.A. Laroque of Shinnecock 1 up at the sixth hole.

Nothing could possibly be more stupefying, as a sequel to the verdict condemning DREYFUS, on the part of the court-martial at Rennes, than the petition of the members of the majority pleading "extenuating circumstances" and recommending to mercy.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip witnessed Frederick Warde's presentation of "Romeo and Juliet" to-night, but between the acts he found time to discuss other affairs. In the course of a conversation he said:

Is it just to condemn a nation for the crimes of a few individuals? It is true that five of the seven Judges, together with the Commissary selected by the French Government, willfully and knowingly sentenced an innocent man to a punishment worse than death, and a number of its Generals perjured themselves to assist in bringing about this result.
NEWPORT, Sept. 16. -- Mrs. William Post entertained at dinner this evening.

In opening the Export Exposition at Philadelphia Gov. STONE explained to our guests from foreign lands and to the admiring natives that the reason why we could sell "our goods in every country on the globe" was that we "sell a better article for less money than any other country."

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Business at the United States Consulate is improving. Invoices are more numerous and valuable than for some time. The business year ends the last day of this month. How it will compare with other years will not be known accurately for two months, but it is expected that the business will have exceeded that of 1898.

This is the season of the year when cycling is really a pleasure. The cool and bracing air of the country brings out thousands of cyclists even on week days, while on Sundays the roads are alive with cyclists from early in the day until late at night. A noticeable thing last Sunday was the way machines were decorated with goldenrod.

United States Senator Marcus A. Hanna returned from Europe yesterday on the American liner St. Louis. He is greatly reduced in flesh, leaning heavily on a cane, and apparently is far from well. The Senator was seen by a reporter for THE TIMES at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Mark Hanna, like many Americans before him, said just before his departure that in home politics there would always be two widely divided parties, if not more, in England. But so far as foreign politics are concerned the nation is like one man. This is proved by the "volte face" of some ultra-radical journals in the last few days.

Anticipating a bank statement which would make a showing favorable to higher money rates and exhibit bank resources as having shrunk during the week a professional clique attack was planned for yesterday on the local traction stocks. When the manipulative scheme was sprung -- in the last hour of Stock Exchange trading -- all conditions favored its success.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 16. -- Alfred Day, representing a Philadelphia syndicate, is shipping men and material to Alaska, for the construction of the second railroad in that Territory. The road is to be fifteen miles long, and to be used in connection with the development of 25,000 acres of coal lands on Kachkemo Bay, Cook Inlet.

For three nights Policeman Shauer of the East Fifty-first Street Station has noticed what he called "a very strange" animal playing in Fifty-eighth Street. He chased it on several occasions, but the animal displayed unusual sagacity, and the first glimpse of the policeman's shield was sufficient to send it scurrying under cover.

The lives of more than fifty persons were imperiled early yesterday by a firebug's work in a double four-story brick apartment house, at Reid and Gates Avenues, Brooklyn. Only for William Trainor, who has a saloon on the ground floor, there might have been serious results.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The political situation here to-day differs little from that of a week ago. The Reichskanzler has issued a rescript to the provincial Presidents recalling the rebellious district Magistrates to their duty, saying, in a word: "If you are not in agreement with the ideas of the Government, get you hence!"

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Study of the drama is to be entered into earnestly by the members of the Chicago Woman's Club this Winter. Some attention was directed to this subject by the literature class of the organization last year, but the programme just prepared calls for more practical and elaborate research and analysis.

Justice Smith of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday handed down a decision setting aside the will of Ellen M. Murray, late of Brooklyn, and widow of Peter Murray. Mrs. Murray left an estate valued at about $500,000.

About 150 riflemen were at Creedmoor yesterday to try for marksmen's scores. Weather conditions were unusually favorable. As a result sixty-five aspirants qualified as marksmen and twenty-five as experts. Col. W.W. Ladd, Judge Advocate of the National Guard of New York, was one of thirteen to qualify as marksman in the pistol practice

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Many of the cottagers who have been summering here and expected to remain until quite late in the season took their departure this week on account of the cool weather. At Norwood Park, however, an "adult" children's party in the Casino last night, for the benefit of the Norwood Field Club, was in charge of Mrs. William D. Harper and Miss Norma Munro of New York.

I read your able editorial of Aug. 9, ult., under the foregoing heading, with much satisfaction. As one of the oldest readers of your valuable journal, starting with its first issue, I would like to say a few words in response to your remarks on the now retired skipper, "Hank" Haft. I will, therefore, confine myself chiefly to the race between the Volunteer and the Thistle, and the few incidentals which naturally flow therefrom.

FISHKILL LANDING, Sept. 16. -- The most aristocratic tramp in the United States holds a first mortgage on the route from Garrisons to Rhinecliff, along the Hudson River. For more than a score of years Henry Madison, known to every school boy and girl between these places as "Buttons," has journeyed along the river and levied tribute on the kitchens of the millionaires whose homes crown the hilltops of the Highlands.

Unless the organized labor men of Chicago can have their way, and compel the provision of a cornerstone for the new Post Office Building that has been cut by union labor men, it begins to look as if the proposed festivities to accompany that ceremony would have to be abandoned.

A murder followed by a suicide, supposed to have been due to jealousy, occurred yesterday at 136 East Tenth Street. The victim was Mrs. Laura Aster, and the murderer and suicide Alexander Wiser. Mrs. Aster, who is a widow and has kept a boarding house at the above address for a number of years, had been receiving attentions from Wiser.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Moran is still the amateur champion of America, and possibly of France. He won two races from the French champion, Albert Tallandier, and lost one. The race took place at Charles River Park this afternoon. It was cold and the small number present could not work up enthusiasm enough to keep warm.

I read your able editorial of Aug. 9, ult., under the foregoing heading, with much satisfaction. As one of the oldest readers of your valuable journal, starting with its first issue, I would like to say a few words in response to your remarks on the now retired skipper, "Hank" Haft. I will, therefore, confine myself chiefly to the race between the Volunteer and the Thistle, and the few incidentals which naturally flow therefrom.

FISHKILL LANDING, Sept. 16. -- The most aristocratic tramp in the United States holds a first mortgage on the route from Garrisons to Rhinecliff, along the Hudson River. For more than a score of years Henry Madison, known to every school boy and girl between these places as "Buttons," has journeyed along the river and levied tribute on the kitchens of the millionaires whose homes crown the hilltops of the Highlands.

Military men who will take part in the land parade in honor of Admiral Dewey on Sept. 30, and who viewed with many misgivings the multifarious changes in the route of that function, are now protesting against the late hour at which the column will move if present arrangements are carried out.

After the arrival of members of the company on the steamship Saale from Bremen this week, the entire Irving Place Theatre stock company, composed of over forty members, will be assembled, and Manager Conried will then begin immediately with the rehearsals for the new plays to be produced in the early part of the season, which will open on Saturday, Sept. 30, with Schiller's "Maria Stuart."

" Oh, dear," groaned the star of one of the most popular plays that has opened this season as she twisted her hair into position in her dressing room just before the opening of the matinee performance one day last week. "My hair simply will not act right, and this is the day when all the women come to criticise."

President Seth Low of Columbia University reached home yesterday on his return from the International Peace Conference at The Hague. He came on the St. Louis. His trip abroad, he said, benefited his health very much, despite the labors and anxieties at the conference. When asked about the fruits of the congress convened by the re-script of the Czar, Mr Low said:

Thirty-seven golfers out of an entry list of fifty-four turned in scores yesterday for the bogey handicap competition on the Morris County golf links at Morristown, N.J., for the silver cup presented by Frederick B. Richardson. James A. Tyng, the club champion, signalized his return to his home links by making the lowest gross score, 89 strokes, but it was 3 above bogey, and Tyng finished 3 holes down to the inexorable bogrey score.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 16. -- Half a million dollars loss was caused by fire which broke out early to-day in the North Block, which was occupied entirely by printing firms. The Masonic Temple, the Methodist Church, and the Webster Block, together with several smaller buildings, were also burned.

Thirty-seven golfers out of an entry list of fifty-four turned in scores yesterday for the bogey handicap competition on the Morris County golf links at Morristown, N.J., for the silver cup presented by Frederick B. Richardson. James A. Tyng, the club champion, signalized his return to his home links by making the lowest gross score, 89 strokes, but it was 3 above bogey, and Tyng finished 3 holes down to the inexorable bogrey score.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 16. -- Half a million dollars loss was caused by fire which broke out early to-day in the North Block, which was occupied entirely by printing firms. The Masonic Temple, the Methodist Church, and the Webster Block, together with several smaller buildings, were also burned.

Every day's association of the United States with Cuba strengthens the tendency toward annexation. Self-respect demands of us that we shall live up faithfully to our declaration that we disclaim "any disposition or intention to exercise sovereignty, jurisdiction, or control over said island, except for the pacification thereof."

Last week's market was an irregular one, and, as a whole, the prices were inclined to decline from the figures of the close of the previous week. On Monday, and for one or two days thereafter, the advance in the money rates, which affected the inside market, had an indirect bearing upon outside securities and tended both to decrease the amount of the transactions and to affect prices unfavorably. That the conditions prevailing

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 17. -- Fully 3,000 persons yesterday afternoon witnessed the imposing ceremonies with which the cornerstone of the new church edifice of the Church of the Assumption of Westport was laid. The Right Rev. Bishop Tierney of Hartford officiated, assisted by twenty-five priest from adjoining towns.

If it were certain that the perversities manifested in last week's stock market had worked themselves out, the widely heralded Fall boom in securities might begin at once. Conditions certainly seem ripe for it. With general business bowling along at a pace beyond all fore-shadowings and the earnings of securities multiplying dividend winners in all quarters, a lagging stock market is an anomaly.

Mr. HENRY CABOT LODGE, very close upon the suspension of hostilities between the United States and Spain, began the publication of a history of that brief conflict. It was published first on the installment plan and afterward as a book. As an example of good printing, spirited illustration, and lively writing it is calculated to attract the eye and afford satisfaction to those who are not averse to a certain amount of glorification of ourselves.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 17. -- The matter of choosing a successor to President Clark of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Road is now in the hands of the Standing Committee, consisting of President Clark, Vice President John M. Hall, William Rockefeller. J. Pierpont Morgan of New York, George J. Brush of New Haven, Henry C. Robinson of Hartford, Charles F. Choate of Boston, and W.D. Bishop of Bridgeport.
Several clergymen in this city and Brooklyn yesterday in the course of their sermons referred to the late Cornelius Vanderbilt in terms of eulogy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The War Department made public to-day the abstract of a report from Gen. James H. Wilson, commanding the Provinces of Matanzas and Santa Clara, Gen. Wilson gives a large amount of statistical information regarding the provinces and their products, which will be of interest to Americans intending to do business in the island.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 17. -- Many Yale football eleven candidates arrived in the city to-night for the preliminary practice to-morrow afternoon on Yale Field. Several of the leading candidates have been in the city for days getting into physical condition by doing gymnasium work.

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 17. -- The Columbia came here this afternoon under forestaysail, in a good southwest breeze. Her tender, the St. Michael's, preceded her. The plan is to step the Columbia's new steel mast about next Tuesday, after which the yacht will go to Newport, or possibly New York, and give the mast a thorough trial, returning here for a general cleaning and overhauling before her races with the Shamrock.

PRETORIA, Sept. 17. -- The reply of the Government of the South African Republic to the latest dispatch, dated Sept. 12, of the British Secretary of State for the Colonies, Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, after acknowledging the receipt of the British note, proceeds, in part, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The Secretary of War, in response to numerous requests, cabled Gen. Otis regarding the two men of the Sixteenth Infantry, who, according to the press dispatches, had been condemned to death in the Philippines.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- All the dispatches from South Africa this morning talk of the imminence of hostilities and the preparations for them. In Johannesburg it seems to be taken for granted that the Orange Free State has approved President Kruger's note and promised active assistance in the event of war.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 17. -- J. Cleveland Osgood, President of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, some of his friends say, reached Denver to-day, but whether he was accompanied by Mrs. McKibbon and Mrs. Shelgrim could not be learned. Neither could Mr. Osgood be located. At the Denver Club and the Brown Palace Hotel, where he usually stays when in the city, it was said he had not been there of late.

" An Ohio man," who has recently visited the Buckeye State, and who has apparently returned to it, and who has also become alarmed at the political conditions that he has discovered there, has written a dispatch from Columbus to The New York Tribune to suggest the great probability and danger of the election in that State in November of JOHN R. MCLEAN as Governor.

The Speedway was the scene of an unusually large and representative gathering of horsemen and horseflesh yesterday; in fact, it was a record-breaking day as far as the numbers of vehicles and the crowds were concerned. The weather was ideal for driving, and the roadbed, which was watered constantly, was in prime condition for fast brushes, and there were many of them.

BUFFALO, Sept 17. -- With a newspaper train carrying the New York Sunday papers, consisting of three baggage cars and a locomotive, the Lackawanna Railroad today beat all records between New York and Buffalo for a trip, covering the 410 miles in the actual running time of seven hours and twenty-three minutes.

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- Leaders of the opposition to the Republican organization in this city to-day sent several telegrams to Gov. Roosevelt asking him to enforce the White civil service law, and compel employes of the Public Buildings Department to desist from taking an active part in the primaries.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- A new baseball league, whose circuit will include cities in both the National and Western Leagues and which will be known as the American Association of Baseball Clubs, was formed here to-day at a meeting of baseball men and lovers of the National game.

On Tuesday last 8,000 men assembled to witness a prizefight, and this not far away in some Western State where the Indians still roam and some of the ancient savage instincts may be supposed to have sway, but here in the heart of our civilization, in the Empire State, almost within the limits of the metropolis of the Western world.

Mr. FRANK MOSS has issued a statement of what he claims that his committee has accomplished in the Ramapo matter. He thinks that the public do not make enough of it. He will allow us to say that he makes altogether too much of it.

AMENITIES OF THE SIEGE OF THE HOUSE IN THE RUE DE CHAMBROL, -- All but the more rabid journals of the anti-Semitic press in Paris, now contain humorous notes concerning the besieged Guerin and his followers in "Fort Chambrol." Various plans are now being suggested for his painless annihilation or his undignified exit from the premises.

The Cunard steamship Lucania, from Liverpool, which arrived off Fire Island at 9:45 o'clock Saturday evening, about twenty-four hours late, reached her dock early yesterday morning, and with a hard luck story of the gloomiest description. The vessel was nearly thirty hours behind her best record time from Queenstown, and finished the slowest passage made by her since she was put in commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Edwin A. Walkup, who claimed to have inherited a large estate from his uncle in the Philippines, was arrested to-night and locked up as being a suspicious character. Walkup, who is forty-eight, but who looks to be over sixty, acknowledged to the officers that he promised to pay $23,000 to the girl he married last April, provided she would marry him.

CARTERVILLE, Ill., Sept. 17. -- Carterville was the scene of a bloody riot about noon to-day, in which six negroes were instantly killed and one fatally wounded, while two others received slight wounds.

NEWPORT, Sept. 17. -- During the services at the First Fresbyterian Church, the pastor, the Rev. George Whitfield Mead, formerly of New York devoted his entire sermon to the great loss the country at large, and especially Newport, has recently sustained through the death of Cornelius Vanderbilt.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 17. -- A.J. Stone, corresponding member of the Zoological and Ethnological Museum of Natural History and New York Zoological Society, in studying the geographical distribution of animals, has just finished one of the most remarkable trips in the history of the North American continent.

I have read repeatedly of late, and mostly referring to it in a somewhat sneering way, of an anti-noise society started by some well-meaning friends of tortured humanity in Chicago, I think. The object in view seems to be such a praiseworthy one that I cannot refrain from tendering its promoters my heartiest wishes, hoping that they may be as successful in their crusade against unnecessary noises as their laudable cause deserves.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 17. -- Gov. Tanner has ordered two companies of the Fourth Regiment, under command of Col. Bennett, to Carterville. He received a telegram this afternoon from Samuel Brush, manager of the St. Louis and Big Muddy Coal Company, at Carterville, that five of a crowd of his negro miners, who had gathered at the station, preparatory to leaving, had been killed, a mob having fired upon them.

The Boers detest civilization. This is my opinion of them, after a residence in South Africa of eighteen years. A new situation is absolutely required. Boer poison is permeating the entire South African system. Boer rule must go, for they have not the ability to carry out reforms.

Opposition to the plan of starting the Dewey land parade so late in the day that it will be well along into the night before the military bodies can disband is growing, and it is now certain that steps will be taken to induce the Committee on Plan and Scope to make a change in the programme.

Golfers in local circles will have the greater part of their attention this week directed toward the Westbrook Golf Club links near Islip, L.I., where the annual tournament will begin Wednesday morning and continue through Saturday. The links have always been popular and a portion of the course passes over the old Pierre Lorillard racing track, where Iroquois and other speedy thoroughbreds were trained.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 17. -- The Press will print to-morrow morning the following from Thomas B. Reed:

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Our money market anxiously begins to reckon up war risks. All last week we were hoping against hope that peace might be maintained. As I write that hope has almost been abandoned, and rates for money are therefore tightening wholly irrespective of business demands.

There is little change in the condition of the men's wear department of the woolen goods market. Everything is quiet on the floors of the commission houses, but there is a little life in the offices when the mails arrive containing cancellations and revisions. As a rule, the commission men claim these are less than usual, and, considering the enormous business transacted this season, they show up very light.

-- Somebody who, to judge from the printing on his envelope -- and we have nothing else to go by -- studied navigation and the vocabulary of the sea in a hardware store, has taken the trouble to clip from THE TIMES its account of the Oceanic's maiden voyage, to mark thereon certain changes which he deems desirable, and to send the result of his generous labor to this office for our enlightenment and reformation.

OMAHA, Sept. 17. -- This week will be important in the political affairs of Nebraska, and the probabilities are that the campaign which begins here to-morrow will have considerable bearing on National politics.

Three of the largest hotels at Hammel's Station, Rockaway, were destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The flames were kept from adjoining cottages and buildings by hard work on the part of the firemen, who were hampered by a lack of water pressure.

The new first-class battleship Kearsarge, the most formidable war vessel yet built for the United States Navy, arrived here yesterday afternoon and anchored off Tompkinsville, near the flagship New York. She left Newport News at 2 P.M. on Saturday, and a great crowd witnessed her departure. She was not pushed on her way here, averaging 13 1/2 knots.

Grover Post, the fifteen-year-old son of Capt. Post, owner of the ice barge Topsy, now lying off the pier at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street, accidentally fell into the river yesterday morning and was drowned. The body was recovered. At the time of the accident the boy's father and mother were absent.

PONCE, Puerto Rico, Sept. 11. -- The recent hurricane, which so completely devastated Puerto Rico, was but the last, though perhaps the greatest, of the many misfortunes that have befallen the island.

MANILA, Aug. 3. -- The Seventeenth Regiment of United States Infantry, or that portion of it which could be spared from duty at the outposts, was paraded yesterday afternoon on the Plaza Santo Fernando to witness the official presentation of the medals of honor awarded by Congress for distinguished bravery in battle.

JACKSON, Miss. Sept. 17. -- Surgeon G.M. Magruder of the Marine Hospital Service, after consultation with the State Board of Health, has arranged a plan of train inspection over four of the principal railroads in Mississippi.

HAVANA, Sept. 17. -- The ceremony of exhuming the remains of Gen. Antonio Maceo and Francisco Gomez, son of Gen. Maximo Gomez, took place at Bejucal to-day in the presence of a large concourse. Two thousand persons went by special trains from Havana and as many more attended from the surrounding districts.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 17. -- Cold weather and absolute lack of fuel are causing an immense exodus of gold hunters from Cape Nome. Many of these men have been taking as high as a hundred dollars per day from their beach or creek claims. They have held on until nipping frosts appeared with stinging reminders that an arctic Winter is at hand.
NEWPORT, Sept. 17. -- Departures for New York include J.B. Eustis, Foxhall Keene, F.P. Garretson, and Whitney Warren.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Six thousand persons at the Vailsburg board track waited until nightfall to see five cyclers finish in the fifty-mile open amateur race to-day. They were the survivors of a group of twenty starters who lined up for the pistol. The time of the winner -- J.P. Jacobson of New Haven -- was 2:19, breaking the amateur record.

The deal involving the sale of a plot of six lots at the northwest corner of Central Park West and Sixty-sixth Street by the American Deposit and Loan Company is said to have been closed yesterday. The transaction involves a loan of $300,000, and the buyers will erect a seven-story apartment house on the plot in accordance with plans filed last week by James H. Camac of Trenton, N. J., who acted as their representative.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- " Those who are speculating as to the identity of the successor to C.P. Clark in the Presidency of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad might as well eliminate the name of A.J. Cassatt from their lists," said William A. Patton, assistant to the President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, to the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES this afternoon.

It should be an encouraging sign for the members of the Citizens' Union that the Republican organs have resumed their attacks upon the organization. The only danger the Union has lately incurred was the possibility that it might yield to the delusive propositions of Mr. QUIGG and Mr. PLATT with regard to a combination by agreement. That is now pretty well disposed of.

Charles P. Clark's proposed retirement from the Presidency of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is not likely to cause any change in the policy or methods of the management of the Consolidated system, according to some of President Clark's associates in the Board of Directors. The Standing Committee, to which was referred the matter of finding a successor to President Clark, will move deliberately and may not report for several weeks.

There was the air of the sales ring in the paddock at Gravesend yesterday, for sales were frequent, and among the purchasers of two of the horses sold was Richard Croker. From John E. Madden he purchased the two-year-old filly Calea, the full sister to Jean Bereaud, by His Highness-Carrie C. Mr. Madden purchased the filly at private sale about ten days ago from David Gideon, and was not anxious to part with her.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The special dispatches from South Africa confirm the report that the Boers are massing artillery in positions commanding Laing's Nek. Small Boer detachments occupy positions above Buffalo River.

MARION, Ind., Sept. 18. -- Arthur A. Brady of Muncie filed four suits in the Circuit Court here to-day to preserve to Indiana the benefits of natural gas and to prevent it being piped to other States, which, it is thought, will settle the question of whether or not the State's wealth can be taken in such a manner outside its limits.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day issued a proclamation setting apart Friday and Saturday, Sept. 29 and 30, as holidays to be observed throughout the State as days of general thanksgiving in honor of the return of Admiral George Dewey to the United States. The proclamation is as follows:
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The Daily Telegraph publishes a communication from a military correspondent who, discussing the effect of the Free State throwing its lot in with the Transvaal, says:

More than 6,000 persons yesterday took advantage of the opportunity of inspecting the biggest steamship in the world, and paid 50 cents to charity, the only condition of the White Star Line for the privilege of going aboard and through the new Oceanic. Thus something over $3,000 was raised, which will be given to the hospitals of New York.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- Superintendent of Insurance Payn to-day, under Section 207 of the insurance law, reported the result of his examination of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of New York to the Attorney General as of May 16, 1899. That date constitutes such a fiscal period in its transactions as is represented by audited or completed call No. 103 upon its membership for funds with which to meet death losses and expenses.

NEWPORT, Sept. 18. -- At the adjourned annual meeting of the Newport Reading Room, these officers were elected for the ensuing year: President -- Edward M. Neill; Secretary -- Roland King; Treasurer -- James A. Swan. Pembroke Jones and Winthrop Rutherfurd were elected stockholders.

Patrick Mangin, a boatman, living at 422 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, was drowned in the Harlem River last evening off One Hundred and Fourteenth Street. His body was not recovered. He was fifty years old. A scow upset his rowboat.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 18. -- Gen. Russell A. Alger and Gov. Hazen S. Pingree have come to the parting of the ways, and the famous alliance is now a thing of the past. Mr. Alger's formal withdrawal from the Senatorial race, despite the protests of the State Executive, shows that he has cut loose from the Pingree machine and is unwilling to take part in its fight on the McKinley Administration.

Mr. HENRY WATTERSON has been for so many years so prominent and so influential a figure in the Democratic Party, has been so accustomed to giving the step to those who marched to the polls inspired by his formulation of Democratic principles and purposes, that the latest appeal made by him to his former brethren in political faith ought to exert something of the old influence that his utterances were wont to produce among Democrats.

It was a busier day than usual in the building of the Board of Education, on Grand Street, yesterday. From early in the morning until late in the afternoon Principals from the various public schools in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx came with reports giving the name, address, and school grade of every child refused admission, and also the vacancies by grade in their respective schools.

The new first-class battleship Kearsarge was dry docked at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday, to be put in shape for her official trial trip off Cape Ann. The Kearsarge reached this port from Newport News Sunday afternoon and passed up to the navy yard yesterday morning.

A few weeks ago the country at large was inexpressibly gratified by the resignation of Gen. RUSSELL A. ALGER from the Cabinet. Even so insensitive a man as Gen. ALGER must have been impressed with the unanimity with which his withdrawal from public life was applauded.

The primary elections for both of the principal political parties will be held between the hours of 2 and 9 o'clock P.M. to-day. As was the case last year, the elections will be under the control of the Bureau of Elections, though the law was considerably amended by the last Legislature.

The first trial of the Shamrock over the full thirty-knot course over which the contests between the Columbia and the Irish aspirant for international yachting honors will be sailed next month was made yesterday under the influence of a breeze that, starting at eight knots, gradually increased until it swept the waters at a fourteen-knot clip.

PARIS, Sept. 18. -- The Senate met as a High Court of Justice to-day at 2 o'clock P. M. for the purpose of trying twenty-two politicians, including MM. de Monicourt, Deroulede, Marcel-Habert, Thiebaud, and Jules Guerin, and Baron de Vaux, on the charge of conspiring against the Government.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- William E. Dean, a prominent member of the Dutchess County bar, whose home is at Fishkill, was to-day committed to the Hudson River State Hospital, at Poughkeepsie. When he reached that city he refused to enter the hospital conveyance, appeared before Judge Bernard, and pleaded his own case for a writ of habeas corpus, which was granted and will be argued to-morrow.

CARTPIAGE,N.Y. , Sept. 18. -Forest fires are raging within the vicinity around Benson's Mines andNewton Fails. fifteen miles from here, on the edge of the Adirondacks. roar dwellings at Bensn's Mines have been destroyed and the flames threaten the plant of the Magnetic Ore Company. The company has been forced to shut down its plants, which recently started up after being idle for years.

Some few days ago a letter appeared in your correspondence column over the signature of "George W. Van Stelen," in which the writer made the assertion "that England demands naturalization and the franchise for the Uitlanders in the Transvaal without their forswearing aIlegiance to their respectlva Governments."

The Seventh Avenue division of the Broadway and Seventh Avenue Railroad was chartered to run from Central Park to Park Place and Broadway. Nevertheless, the company has not run its ears below Canal Street for years, but it gave transfers over the Eightb Avenue line.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Affairs of the new baseball league assumed a more serious aspect to-day, with the arrival of an Eastern representative, Frank Hough of Philadelphia. The delegates got down to business, canvassed the situation, figured up what financial power they could command, and discussed their circuit.

Ex-Police Justice Joseph Koch, who has been making a fight against the leadership of John F. Carroll and Rollin M. Morgan in the Twenty-ninth District, called his workers together last night at Tuxedo Hall and gave them final instructions for to-day's balloting. An anti-Carroll ticket has been mailed to every enrolled voter in the district, and preparations has been made to have the polls manned by watchers.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 18. -- J.C. Osgood, President of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, to-day gave to the press the following statement relative to his connection with Arthur E. Cobb, who committed suicide at the home of Mrs. McKibbon in Rye, N.Y.:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The number of enlistments to date is 6,685. The Thirty-ninth leads, with 981, and the Thirty-eighth with 926 men.

The disposition of Cornelius Vanderbilt's vast estate continues to be a matter of widespread curiosity and speculation. Although the lips of the members and counselors of the Vanderbilt family are apparently sealed for a month in consequence of their determination not to make the contents of the will public until Alfred Vanderbilt's return from China, gossip goes on as though some of the provisions of the will were already known outside the family circle.

My attention was drawn recently to the advertisements of the Liquid Air Power and Automobile Company of Boston, and in response to a letter addressed to the company, I promptly received a prospectus and a letter from the "Department of Finance," with a typewritten signature, stating that, the former issue of stock having been all subscribed, an advance will be made shortly to $4 a share.
One thing is to be remembered by all sensible men as to the excitement that swept over Wall Street yesterday. It was due wholly to speculation and was confined almost wholly to speculators.

Mr. CROKER continues his savage attacks on the counsel of the Mazet committee. It does not advance his own reputation in the community particularly, and if Mr. Moss were in private station the attacks probably would not do him much harm. If he had a clear conscience, he could, under those circumstances, afford to ignore them. At present he cannot.

Controller Color, in a speech before the Manufacturers' Association of New York, at its headquarters in Montague Street, Brooklyn, last night, spoke of the Ramapo water deal and hinted that other scandals of a similar character might be dug up by the Finance Department. The occasion was the first Fall meeting of the association, and the Controller was present by invitation.

Mr. JOHN MORLEY'S speech at Arbroath, like Mr. FREDERIC HARRISON'S open letter to Lord SALISBURY, upon which we have already commented, is one of the utterances which are worth reproducing, and worth pondering, they are so far above the plane of political discussion which seeks a cheap or temporary party advantage.

A numerous and friendly audience welcomed Mr. Francis Wilson last night at the Knickerbocker Theatre when he reappeared for the purpose of making his annual essay to amuse and interest the New York public with a new conceit. Mr. Wilson is plainly I believer in novelty, and whenever he comes to visit us he brings us something new.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 18. -- James Holm of Philadelphia, spokesman for seventy-five men who arrived to-day from the Edmonton trail, says:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Consul General Holloway of St. Petersburg has transmitted to the State Department a Ministerial order requiring all standard Russian railways to equip their freight cars and engines with Westinghouse air brakes, at a cost of several million rubles, by Jan. 1, 1903. This order provides that the introduction of other systems of continuous automatic brakes will only be allowed after a trial of three years.

Under the heading "Unsafe to Die in Paris," you publish the letter of a correspondent, who says that v:hen he was in France he was "disgusted on hearing that if any stranger died in Paris the landlord had a claim therefrom for damages to the property."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 8. -- A verdict for the defendant to-day, in the Supreme Court suit of George Allen against Olga Penitz. makes unnecessary the moving of the thr $.tory brick establishment of C. H. Guttrld:e. at 1,326 Atlantic Avenue, in order to place in Mr. Allen's posseesion a seven-inch strip of land claimed by both litigants.
The lower part of the body of an unidentified woman was found yesterday afternoon floating in the water at the foot of Kensington Walk, Coney Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Israel Zangwill's dramatization of his book, "The Children of the Ghetto," was produced to-night before an enthusiastic audience in the National Theatre. The enthusiasm broke forth at every possible point, and sometimes interrupted sentences. There were curtain calls after each act, the whole company being called out each time, except after the second act, when the call was for Blanche Bates and Frank Worthing.

A Dewey book appears from the press of Harper Brothers to-day. This is "Admiral George Dewey; A Sketch of the Man," by John Barrett. It is a volume of episodes gathered at first, second, or third hand. Some of the episodes are new; some are treated in a new fashion. All are more or less interesting, whether reviving half-faded memories or throwing fresh light upon seemingly trivial incidents.
NEWPORT, Sept. 18. -- At a meeting today of the Governors of the Newport Casino the following resolutions were adopted:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Arrangements for the National reception to Admiral Dewey in this city, Oct. 2 and 3, are being rapidly completed. Gen. Nelson A. Miles, the marshal of the parade, has announced the selection of Adjt. Gen. Corbin as his chief of staff, and Major John A. Johnson, Assistant Adjutant General, as chief aide de camp.

PARIS, Sept. 18. -- The High Court proceedings against the royalist conspirators for attempting to change the form of government were commenced to-day in the Senate, and they are almost certain to end in a fiasco for the Government. No serious charge is alleged against the accused.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18. -- Despite the statement that the Yale football management would to-night announce the name of the head coach for the football eleven, Capt. McBride and Manager Rockefeller did not make any announcement. It was practically admitted that the head coach had been chosen, but the management said that the appointment would not be made public at present.

A curious exhibition was given at Wallack's Theatre last evening when a comic actor and humorist of great renown, whose very voice and gait have been helping to drive dull care away for a whole generation, presented himself in a distressingly serious, not to say tragic, role.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The lull in the crisis gives opportunity for the continuance of unofficial negotiations. The Government of the Netherlands is privately exerting its influence in favor of a pacific solution, and it is understood that President Kruger, through Dr. Leyds, the Plenipotentiary of the South African Republic to the European Governments, has unofficially approached three powers with a view to their intervention.
The pardon of Capt. DREYFUS, though it cannot be regarded as doing justice, is an act of high expediency.

VALLEY STREAM, I. I., Sept. 19. -- Miss Jane Yatman, who is breaking all records for women in century road riding, reached her hotel here shortly after 9:50 o'clock to-night, having then ridden 675 miles. She then began a somewhat longer rest than usual, pending the start upon the last twenty-five miles of her race.

If many more such brutal exhibitions are given in New York as that which was seen last night in the arena of the Broadway Athletic Club when Kid McCoy knocked out Steve O'Donnell of Australia in the sixth round there will probably be a protest from indignant citizens as there was once before when the ministers of Harlem tried to have boxing at the Lenox Athletic Club stopped.

1=reward Gould and his party, who have [been cruising in the steam yacht Niagara Z tn European waters, returned yesterday. I The Niagara encountered moderate weathe coming across the Atlantic. Though the seas ran high at times, she proved a goodsea boat and eaxne through without discern-! fort to her passengers.

Everybody may cordially hope that Mr. T.B. REED'S assurance that "the First Maine District will always be true to the principles of liberty, self-government, and the rights of man" will never cease to be true. The sentiment is noble. Maine will never disown it while the State retains its proud motto.

A London Tory paper suggests that fighting in the Transvaal is not so imminent as may appear, and that the British Government will "protract negotiations" until the arrival of reinforcements now on the way to South Africa. The suggestion that negotiations are to be protracted, without any expectation that they will come to anything, is cynical, not to say Mephistophelean.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Lieut, Col. John D. Miley, Inspector General of Volunteers, died to-day at Manila. The information reached the War Department in a cablegram from Gen. Otis. His death was due to cerebral meningitis, attendant on typhoid fever.

Although I have read THE TIMES for twenty years and seldom miss a day, the interruptions of Summer travel are such that I was not aware of your obituary on Ingersoll of July 22 until a marked copy reached me in a belated mail.
