The New York baseball nine did some experimenting at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but this does not account for the easy manner in which St. Louis won the game, as the two new players tried in the outfield did not help the visitors any. It was the poor pitching of Seymour and Doheny that gave the visitors nearly all their runs.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 19. -- The Standard Oil Company to-day filed a spirited answer to the petition of the Attorney General which urged the expulsion of the company from the State under the anti-trust law of 1897. It denies that it is a trust, asserting that the trust feature was abolished in 1892.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Members of the Cornell University football team, which has been quartered at Tuller House here since Saturday last, indulged in lively practice this afternoon, preparatory to a game with Colgate University to be played here Saturday of this week.

-- Vigorous answer is made by The Coast Seamen's Journal of San Francisco, a paper that invariably shows knowledge and usually shows wisdom in its discussion of maritime subjects, to the explanation given by Mr. H.P. WHITMARSH, in the current Century, of the dangerously high speed maintained -- to put the case well within the bounds of truth -- sometimes by some Captains while passing through dense fog.

SARANAC LAKE, Sept. 19. -- Two industral events are exciting much interest in the northern part of this State. One is the determination of the management of the Benson mines to start working them again, and the second is the announcement of the purchase and intention of reoperating the Crown Point Iron Company's plant and Witherbee, Sherman Co.'s mines by the American Steel and Wire Company.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 12. -- Mail advices from Haiti up to Sept. 6 say that while the commercial and financial crisis remains acute, and is, in fact, at its height, the new Minister of Finance, M. Herard Roy, has succeeded in effecting notable reductions in the expenditures of the republic which must make for better conditions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Thomas E. Heenan, United States Consul at Odessa, in a report to the State Department says:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- A dispatch has been received at the War Department regarding Private Lawrence F. Hoon of the Fourth Infantry, who was the subject of a letter from Gov. Bushnell to President McKinley, protesting against the sentence of the court-martial at Manila. Gen Otis says that the petition presented by Hoon had the forged names of several members of his company attached to it, and it was for this that he was convicted.
PARIS, Sept. 19. -- M. Scheurer-Kastner, the former Vice President of the Senate, and champion of Dreyfus, is dead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The yellow fever situation at Key West is regarded as grave. Since the first case was reported about three weeks ago, the epidemic has been steadily growing, until to-day there are almost 400 cases.
The following letter has been addressed to me:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Rear Admiral Winfield Scott Schley will succeed Rear Admiral Howison in command of the South Atlantic station. He has no protest to make against the assignment which the Navy Department selected for him. As a sailor, he will obey orders without a murmur.

Meetings of the Trustees of the College of the City of New York and of the Normal College were held yesterday afternoon in the Board of Education Building. The City College opened for the new term on Monday with 1,732 pupils in their seats. The majority of these, about 1,000, were in the four upper classes.

It seems to me that if England makes war on the Transvaal she not only will accomplish nothing she could not attain by peaceful measures, but will hurt herself in the eyes of mankind, and will create race animosities that will live for generations, and will always be a source of weakness to her African empire.

The people who vote in Montana are so apt to be intense in their moods and tenses before election and to insist so dogmatically upon extraordinary beliefs as the test of political fidelity that it is difficult to avoid a feeling of concern about a newly organized association that has cropped up in Anaconda, the qualification for membership in this club being total abstinence from the wearing of mustaches.
PARIS, Sept. 19. -- The Ministers, after a Council to-day, authorized the statement that they had decided to pardon Capt. Dreyfus "in principle," and that the pardon would take effect in a few days.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- At the first day's racing of the Birmingham September meeting to-day the Avon Selling Nursery Plate was won by J.A. Miller's Doleful, ridden by "Tod" Sloan. Twelve horses ran five furlongs straight. The betting was 4 to 1 against Doleful.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 19. -- The attempt of the National Association of Master Plumbers to prevent non-members from getting supplies is likely to be futile in view of action taken at the recent meetings of jobbers and manufacturers of such supplies.

Edward M. Shepard, in an address before the National Civic Club, at 144 Montague Street, Brooklyn, last evening on "The Duty of Democrats to Their Party," declared his belief that the Democracy should take up as its dominating campaign issue persistent hostility to imperialism and militarism.

While Miss Lulu Glaser sang the role of Roxane, in the first performance of the opera "Cyrano de Bergerac," at the Knickerbocker Theatre on Monday night, few persons in the audience were aware that she was suffering greatly from a bad sore throat. At the conclusion of the performance she was completely exhausted, and was taken to the Manhattan Hotel, accompanied by her mother, and placed under the attention of her physician.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The Evening News declares that there is now no need to boycott the Paris Exposition.

In looking over the paper this morning, I noticed an article as regards a new dispensary law, which I think is a very good law in that it will close up a number of drug stores which are now being run as dispensaries. If you will kindly permit me, I would like to make a few corrections in the prices of prescriptions as quoted by Dr. Knapp.

HELENA, Mon., Sept. 19. -- Train wreckers who sought to ditch a through passenger train and probably cause heavy loss of life on the Great Northern Railway five miles from Helena were frustrated in their designs by the watchfulness of a freight engineer.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- 4:30 A. M. -- After a conference at midnight with his brother and M. Millevouye, M. Guerin promised to surrender at 4 o'clock this morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19. -- It was announced to-night that the Yale football management will make a radical departure in the methods of developing an eleven. In years past it has been customary to have a so-called university eleven and a scrub eleven, known as the "College side," to give the leading candidates or university eleven practice.

The State Commerce Commission held a meeting yesterday, when a hearing was given to Charles E. Wheeler of the Cleveland Steel Canalboat Company. This company was formed five years ago, and has taken an extremely important share of the Erie Canal trade. The company was the first to enter the field with steel boats, employing four steamers and fifteen consorts.

PASQUE ISLAND, Mass., Sept. 19. -- The Clyde Line steamship Cherokee, Capt. McKee, bound from Jacksonville, Fla., for Boston, with six passengers and a large cargo of miscellaneous freight, went ashore on the southeast end of Naushon Island, in Vineyard Sound, shortly after noon to-day. There was a dense fog at the time.

GEORGETOWN, Ky., Sept. 19. -- A sensational double murder was committed last evening at Stamping Ground, in Scott County. Tom Southworth, aged fifty-one years, and his son Luther, aged twenty years, came to Georgetown yesterday morning to attend a political meeting. It was County Court day at Georgetown, and a great deal of drinking was done.

The letter of your correspondent in to-day's TIMES, under the title of "Let Dewey Be Seen," touches a point in connection with next week's monster celebration which the Committee on Reception by its action yesterday, doing away with the Admiral's drive to Claremont and taking him by boat, seems to have carelessly overlooked or willfully ignored.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- President McKinley recently received a protest against the alleged desecration of Catholic Church property in the Philippines, submitted by an organization called the Metropolitan Truth Society. In considering the matter, the Government officials understood that this protest had some authoritative status, but it appears on inquiry that it does not come through the responsible official channels of the Church and is the individual representation of private parties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Secretary Root to-day received a cablegram from Gen. Otis that seemed to indicate a weakening On the part of the insurgents in Luzon. It contained a proffer to deliver the American prisoners who have been for so many months in the hands of the insurgents, and also sought permission to parley with Gen. Otis.

FALL RIVER, Sept. 19. -- The action of Dr. Robert T. Davis in abandoning the local mill combination movement and going over to the Barrow syndicate has caused the greatest sensation. His associates in the local combination scheme were greatly surprised, and now that they have heard his reasons, they are not satisfied with them, and are not ready to abandon the local movement.

In your editorial of to-day under the heading of "American Tact in the Philippines" you reprint an article from "Civis Americanus," and then proceed to enlarge thereon, ending by a wholesale condemnation of the American officers in those far-off islands, the supposed culprits in the picture in Collier's Weekly.

On a report from Boston to the effect that a dividend of 2 per cent., being 1 1/2 per cent. regular and one-half per cent. extra, had been declared on Amalgamated Copper, this stock was very strong yesterday on the curb. It opened at 89 and remained at about this figure for some time after the opening.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 19. -- The exercises of Dartmouth Night, held this evening in the Old Chapel, closed with the announcement by President Tucker of the transfer during the day of securities to the value of $300,000 to the Trustees. Edward Tuck of the class of '62 gave this sum as a memorial to his father, Amos Tuck, of the class of '35, and a Trustee of the college from 1857 to l866.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Mrs. Abigail Connors, a woman past seventy-five years of age, last night jumped from a passenger train on the New York Central Railroad which was moving at a high rate of speed, and, strange to say, was not hurt. Mrs. Connor resides at Moore's Mills, on the Newburg, Dutchess and Connecticut Railroad.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Frank Pugh, a grandson of the late John Stephenson, the well-known car builder, was found dead this morning. A bullet hole in his right temple and a revolver clasped in his right hand indicated the cause of death. The body was found in the Stephenson flats, a stretch of meadow and woodland near Larchmont Manor.

B.C. F.T. Barry have sold for Collins Collins the four-story 25-foot dwelling 645 Madison Avenue, 70 feet north of Fifty-ninth Street. The buyer will erect an eight-story fire-proof office building on the lot.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 19. -- The third annual convention of the League of American Municipalities opened here this morning at 11 o'clock at the Alhambra. Four hundred delegates were in attendance, and 400 more will arrive during the day. Mayor McGuire of Syracuse made the address of welcome to the city.

The Mazet committee resumed yesterday its investigation into the methods of administering the government of New York City. It was expected that it would take up the subject of rapid transit, but Mr. Most turned his attention to the Ramapo Company, and devoted four hours to the examination of witnesses as to the attempt to get the city to enter into a contract with the company to supply water for forty years.

A distinguished, respected, and useful personality in New York life was removed yesterday in the death of Charles P. Daly, ex-Chief Justice of the old Court of Common Pleas, which occurred at his Summer home, in North Haven, near Sag Harbor, L.I. Ex-Judge Daly's death was unexpected, although he was in his eighty-fourth year.
Clearly Mr. BRYAN went to the Chicago conference to see what there was in it for his political future.

Such an experience as the Brooklyn Jockey Club had with a hurdle stake race yesterday was enough to discourage the management and make it decide to do away with jumping races forever. For a stake with $800 added but three horses started, and none of these went the route, a mile and three-quarters, better than would a lot of absolutely untrained horses turned loose on the track.

Evelyn B. Baldwin of the United States Weather Bureau, and who was a member of the Wellman arctic expedition, is a guest at the Everett House. He reached Tromsoe, Norway, Aug. 17 and this city on the Anchor Line steamship Furnessia Monday night.

That is a wonderful exhibition that has been going on for a week in Philadelphia. Like everything else that admirable community undertakes to do in a corporate way, it is admirably done. A huge and handsome building, which is none the less imposing because it is temporary, houses it, and by day or in the evening, when it blazes with electric lights, is almost equally impressive to the passer.

NEWPORT, Sept. 19. -- Henry Waiters this evening gave a dinner on board his yacht, the Narada, in honor of Prince Cantacuzene and his fiancee, Miss Grant. The yacht was brilliantly illuminated with electric lights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The War Department has received a copy of a circular issued by Gen. Davis through Adjt. Gen. Hall, to the inhabitants of Puerto Rico, indicating how they might profit in some ways through the recent hurricane. Gen. Davis says there is now an opportunity afforded to beautify the villages and improve their sanitary condition.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The annual fair of the Society of Agriculture and Horticulture of Westchester County, which opened yesterday and will continue until the end of the week, has been held fourteen times, but, despite the experience taught by former shows, the vice of unpreparedness has not been overcome, so that even now the fair is only just issuing from the initial chaotic stage.

SANTO DOMINGO, Sept. 19. -- At a meeting of all the foreign Consuls, held yesterday in this city, a joint protest was drawn up against the action of the Government in destroying the value of the paper currency. This action was rendered necessary by the contradictory decrees issued on successive days.
NEWPORT, Sept. 20. -- Mrs. Theodore A. Havemeyer will close Friedheim on the 25th inst.

TRENTON, Sept. 20 -- The will of the late Rev. Thomas Herring Burchard, who made the "Rum, Romanism, and Rebellion" speech during the Presidential campaign of 1884, has been interpreted in a decision filed here by Vice Chancellor Emery. Mr. Burchard died in New York in 1896, and his will was probated in that city Dec. 6, 1896.

A young man, who gave his name as Perry Tiffany, and said he lived at Newport. R.I., was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night, charged with assault by William Bettger, a cabman of 428 West Forty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Despite all outward show of calm, Great Britain is in practically the same condition to-day as was the United States a few weeks before the opening of the war with Spain. Beneath the crust of diplomatic reserve the military officials are working night and day, preparing for the signal to begin hostilities, whether that comes or not.

There was much excitement in Sixth Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Twenty-second Streets yesterday, caused by a runaway horse. The street at the time was crowded with shoppers. The shouts of the people, combined with the clanging of street car gongs and clattering of horses getting out of the way, added to the general alarm.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Harry Faux, thirty years old, died to-night as a result of being trampled by a horse. He entered the animal's stall during the afternoon. The horse pinned him against the side of the stall and struck at him with his fore feet.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 20. -- Charles N. Haskell and W.B. Strang of New York to-day purchased the St. Mary's Division of the Detroit and Lima Northern, paying $1,100,000 for it. The sale was made by the receiver of the road, and was brought up in the United States court for approval. It is understood that the sale will be confirmed.
CAPE TOWN, Sept. 20. -- The Bund of Women is preparing a peace appeal to Queen Victoria.

The threats made by a few persons in England, Germany, the United States, and other countries to withhold patronage from the Paris Exposition of 1900 shows that there is a pretty widespread misapprehension of the object and effect of world's fairs. The persons who are making these threats evidently suppose that the benefits from great international expositions go to the city holding them, or at most to the country in which the city is situated.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 20. -- The mining property of the McHenry Coal Company has been absorbed by the Central Coal and Iron Company, a corporation which is gradually gaining possession of mines all along the Illinois Central Railroad in Kentucky. The Dupont heirs are behind the Central Coal and Iron Company, and it has almost unlimited capital.

The contract recently let by the Bureau of Steam Engineering of the Navy Department for the construction and installation of a complete electric power plant, buildings, boilers, engines, generators, cranes, and motors for operating the new machine shops to be built in the Brooklyn Navy Yard is causing considerable comment and adverse criticism among electrical manufacturers and contractors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Frederick J. Filbert, the aged cashier of the Palatine Bank in Palatine, Ill., twenty-six miles north of Chicago, is lying close to death as the result of an attack made upon him to-day by a young man who gives the name of Walter Lawton.

----- Some -- indeed, much -- light on the present highly unsatisfactory condition of affairs at Key West was to be obtained from certain sentences in the statement sent out from Washington yesterday, giving details of the situation as seen by the Federal health officials. "As Key West is situated below the frost line," to quote the most remarkable of these sentences first, "the epidemic will have to run its course."

Like a chapter from the "Arabian Nights" read the adventures of J. W. Young, a miller, of this city, who until a few years ago was a scout for the British Government and a prospector on his own account in the Transvaal country and in the land of the Zulus.

The consolidation known as the American Bridge Company has been completed, with twenty-eight of the thirty-one bridge-building concerns of the country included. The friends of the consolidation deny that it is a trust, but argue that the combination was made on a basis of net profits for the purpose of securing working capital and saving interest on deferred payments for material.
LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Several warlike speeches were made yesterday by members of the House of Commons.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- The refusal of the two men who headed last year's Democratic ticket, Augustin B. Bruce of Lawrence, and Edward J. Slattery of South Framingham, to run again this year, created a sensation at the preliminary gathering of the Democrats for the State Convention which will be held here to-morrow.

The new battleship Kearsarge will leave the Brooklyn Navy Yard this morning for Boston. The vessel was taken out of dry dock yesterday, and is now in first-class trim for her official trial, which will take place over the Cape Ann course on Monday. To-morrow or Saturday a private test of the ship's powers will be made over the course by her builders.

Details of the bitter fight in the Ninth Assembly District, in which John C. Sheehan won out against Crokerism as represented by Councilman Goodwin and Thomas F. Smith, Chief Clerk of the City Court, are coming to light. Many of these happened far into yesterday morning, and show that not only was a determined effort made to beat Sheehan at the polls, but that an effort was made to give him a physical beating afterward.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 20. -- A passenger train, north bound, on the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad, collided with a freight train fifteen miles southeast of this city this morning.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- The first International Congregational Council to be held in the United States and the second in the world began its session in Tremont Temple at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The first International Council of Congregationalism was held in London, July, 1891.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 20. -- Promptly at 11 o'clock Attorney General Crow of Missouri called to order in the ladies' ordinary of the Planters' Hotel the Anti-Trust Conference originated by Gov. Sayers of Texas. Gov. Lon V. Stephens of Missouri nominated Gov. J.D. Sayers of Texas as Permanent Chairman and he was unanimously chosen. Paul B. Moore. Private Secretary of Gov.

There was a lively time at the adjourned meeting of the School Board of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday over a report from the Board of Borough Superintendents, recommending changes in the system of licensing teachers. The present plan is based upon the system recommended by City Superintendent Maxwell.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 20. -- The Aftonbladet to-day received a telegram from the master of the Norwegian cutter Martha Larsask saying that he had found, Sept. 9, on the north coast of King Charles Island an anchor and a buoy marked "Andre Polar Expedition."

The body of Charles P. Daly, ex-Chief Justice of the Court of Common Pleas, who died Tuesday, arrived at his late home, in this city, 84 Clinton Place, from Sag Harbor, L. I., at 6:30 o'clock last night. The body was accompanied by members of the family. The funeral will take place to-morrow at 10 o'clock at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The following cablegram has been received at the Navy Department from Commander Hemphill of the Detroit. A few words are missing:

With her green topsides glistening in the sunlight and her swelling sails pulling with the weight of many tons, Sir Thomas Lipton's cup challenger Shamrock sailed an exhibition yesterday afternoon for the special benefit of Rear Admiral Sampson, commander of the North Atlantic Squadron, and Capt. Chadwick of the cruiser New York, both of whom had expressed the desire to see the Irish yacht under canvas.
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 20. -- Montylee A. Cole of Sherbrooke, Canada, was to-day indicted by the Grand Jury for murder in the first degree in the killing of William A. Montague on May 17 last.
H.F. Schellhass has sold for John L. Cadwalader to M.L. C. Ernst the plot of eight lots on the south side of One Hundred and Twelfth Street, 260 feet east of Eighth Avenue.

Lima (Peru) Letter to Chicago Record. The people of Peru are called "Peruanos," the people of Chile are called "Chillanos," those of Guatemala are known as "Guatmaltecos," those of Bolivia are "Bolivianos," and those of Uruguay are "Orientals."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Acting upon the recommendation of Gen. Miles, the Committee of Arrangements having in charge the National demonstration to Admiral Dewey in this city will probably make a change in the programme so as to have a civic parade on the night of Oct. 2, when the Admiral arrives, and a military parade the following day, when Secretary Long presents the sword purchased by Congress to the hero of Manila.

The Mazet committee again took up its investigation of the Ramapo water project yesterday, although it made short excursions into the general field of administrative work. It availed itself of the presence of certain witnesses to inquire into asphalt paving contracts and the purchase of material by the Dock Department, but devoted most of the day to Ramapo.

During most of yesterday's security market tendencies were altogether free from sensationalism, though much pressure was kept upon quotations by the bear contingent, which lately has been making substantial profits; but there was less following than has been the rule. Thus, with liquidation disappearing, sales to depress prices were rather readily traceable to short accounts.

It is perfectly evident that President McKINLEY, in sketching out his annual message to Congress, ought not to omit to provide a paragraph somewhere to counteract the distrust of our intentions that is being cultivated by the anti-imperialist press in those South American republics that have in large part adopted Constitutions resembling our own and have for many years entertained a feeling of fellow-republicanism toward the United States.

An effort was made during the annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic to secure the passage of a resolution to condemn the Commissioner of Pensions for his management of the Pension Bureau, which has not been conducted in a manner to meet with the unqualified approval of some pension claim agents.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- To-day's session of the League of American Municipalities was devoted chiefly to a discussion of the merits of city ownership of public utilities.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 20. -- At noon to-morrow the Republican State Convention will convene in Omaha. Senator John M. Thurston, Senator M.L. Hayward, and other prominent Republicans are to-night in session to devise plans for carrying on a vigorous campaign to oppose Bryan in Nebraska. A heated contest is certain.

Just after the battle in Manila Bay between the fleets of the United States and Spain Commodore DEWEY made several reports, and with a generosity of appreciation that is one of his noblest qualities he commended, without suggestion from anybody at Washington, his officers and men who had distinguished themselves and the officers and men of the revenue cutter McCulloch for the courageous and efficient manner in which they had supported him.

The statistics of our foreign trade which the bureau has just issued are even more encouraging than those that had preceded them. The total exports for the month of August are 25 per cent. higher than for the same month last year, when they were the highest known, and they are 33 per cent. higher than the average in the same month for the three years 1894-5-6.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- In an interview to-day, Senator Mason of Illinois said:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 20. -- Secretary Wilson announces to-night the entries to the Transylvania and the Tennessee Pacing Stakes and the purses to be trotted for at the October meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The President has issued a proclamation declaring that the local Hawaiian officials are without power to transfer title to public lands in Hawaii pending legislation by Congress.

Corporation Counsel Whalen last night made public a letter which he has sent to Alexander E. Orr, the President of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, suggesting modifications which Mr. Whalen desires to have made in the form of the contract for the construction of the rapid transit system.
The American Bankers' Association in its late convention resolved unanimously as follows:

When there are two parties to any public question, of which one produces its reasons fully and fairly, and seems to show that they are irresistible, and the other conceals its reasons, whatever they may be, the conclusion is inevitable that the party of the first part is in the right. If the party of the second part has anything to say for itself, decidedly it ought to say that thing.

The telephone figured largely in the capture of an alleged burglar at Bath Beach early yesterday morning. Albert Kohler, bartender in Robert Mitchell's saloon, at Bath Avenue and Bay Nineteenth Street, discovered two burglars at work in the grocery store of Edward H. Moloughney, on the corner opposite.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 20. -- The single scull race between James A. Ten Eyck of Worcester, Mass., and John Brennan of Halifax, for $200 a side, was rowed this afternoon on Bedford Basin in a heavy wind and rain storm. Ten Eyck won by a length. Time, 23.17. The slow time was caused by water being very rough.
TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 20. -- At Middlesex County fair, at Strathroy, yesterday, Premier Laurier said:

For the first time in several weeks the New Yorks gave an exhibition of real baseball yesterday, defeating the Pittsburgs at the Polo Grounds in a most decisive manner. The team played brilliantly. The Pittsburgs were also at top-notch form, but their game was amateurish compared to that of the New Yorks.

CAPE TOWN, Sept. 21. -- It is reported here that Sir Alfred Milner has wired a courteous message to President Steyn, assuring him that the northward march of the British troops is not meant as a menace to the Orange Free State, and requesting to be informed regarding the latter's attitude.

HAVANA, Sept. 20. -- The strike has assumed serious proportions. It is now estimated that there are 12,000 striking masons, painters, carpenters, cartmen, and laundry workers, and if, as is threatened, the hackmen, stevedores, and cigarmakers strike within the next few days, there will be another 4,000.

RENNES, France, Sept. 20. -- Capt. Alfred Dreyfus at 3 o'clock this morning left the prison here, in which he had been confined since his return from the Isle du Diable, and proceeded to Vern, where he took a train bound for Nantes. His departure was completely unnoticed.

AN important purehase of water-front property was announced in Brooklyn yesterday. The purchaser was said to be John . H. Starin. The property was formerly uhed by She Cross, Austin Ireland Lumber Company. It is bounded by Washington Avenue, Cross Street, and the Wallabout Canal, and consists of sixty-six lots. The property was put on the market three years ago, when the lumber company removed its buasine,ss to Newtown Creek.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- At Her Majesty's Theatre this evening Herbert Beerbohm Tree, the actor-manager, produced "King John" before a brilliant and crowded audience, including Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies; Gen. Lord Garnet Wolseley, Field Marshal; Rear Admiral Lord Charles Beresford; member of Parliament, and a host of persons prominent in literature and art.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21. -- The first of the many petitions filed by Mrs. Nettie R. Craven in her renewed attack upon the estate of James G. Fair was denied by Superior Judge Troutt to-day.

The investigation by the State Commerce Commission into the causes of the alleged decrease of the grain trade at this port and of the alleged excessive charges for handling grain by the International Elevating Company was continued yesterday in the board rooms of the Produce Exchange.

CARPENTRAS, Department of Vaucluse, France, Sept. 21. -- Former Capt. Dreyfus arrived here this morning and went to the home of M. Valabregue, his brother-in-law. Although the arrival of Capt. Dreyfus at the home of M. Valabregue, who has been established as a cloth merchant here for a quarter of a century, was soon known, no demonstration occurred.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 21. -- John Yober, a nine-year-old telegraph messenger in the little town of Newton, has become prominent in railroad circles. His business as messenger did not keep him fully employed, and, being full of energy and having the writing fever, he began about six months ago to answer newspaper advertisements. Soon his daily mail far exceeded that of any business man in town.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 21. -- The members of the Saengerfest Board acted upon a plan to lift the debt or deficiency of the Saengerfest at the meeting held Wednesday evening, when a committee to arrange preliminaries and to carry the scheme to a successful issue was appointed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- A dispatch received to-day at the Navy Department from Rear Admiral Howison is worrying the officials there.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Dr. Gilette, a physician of Turners, Orange County, is in this city looking for his adopted daughter, who left under mysterious circumstances within the past week.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 21. -- A suit to recover $25,000 was instituted to-day by Atwood Violet against E.C. Benedict, the well-known banker of Greenwich. There are also cited as defendants the members of the firm of Robert Wellstood Sons, real estate brokers, employed by Mr. Benedict.

The popular music hall or parody theatre of Messrs. Weber Fields was opened for the new season with the customary rites last night. The interior of the house has been vastly improved in various ways since the Spring, and the decorations are handsome and in keeping with the generally cheerful character of the entertainments that there prevail.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21. -- B.W. Schwab, who was killed in Van Cortlandt Park, New York, this morning, was engaged to be married to Miss Maria Trumbull Dana, daughter of Mrs. James D. Dana, and sister of Prof. E.S. Dana of Yale, who lives here. The wedding was to have taken place this Fall.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Martin Heermance, who has resigned as President of the State Tax Commission, said that he retired at the request of Gov. Roosevelt for what the latter termed "geographical reasons "; that is, the Governor wanted a representative of the western part of the State on the board. Mr. Heermance's term expired last Spring, and he simply held over until the other Commissioners became familiar with the routine of the commission.

Herbert M. Harriman, the United States amateur golf champion, and Gardiner G. Hubbard, one of Harvard's crack golfers, furnished the biggest sensation yesterday in the second day's play of the Westbrook Club tournament, near Islip, L.I. The champion only escaped defeat by the narrowest margin, just winning on the home hole.

Possibly it may be considered an impertinence for one outside of your State to criticise arrangements for the reception of Admiral Dewey, but as many Pennsylvanians hope to assist to honor his home-coming by their attendance, and because some regiments of our National Guard of Pennsylvania expect to march with the other thousands, we may properly ask that our, and their, convenience and comfort may to some extent be studied.

PARIS, Sept. 21. -- The Journal Official today publishes the decree granting a pardon to Capt. Dreyfus. In a report preceding the decree, the Marquis de Galliffet, Minister of War, points our that Dreyfus has already undergone five years' deportation, but that, as the law does not assimilate his deportation with five years' solitary confinement, the prisoner would have to undergo ten years' detention.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The firm of Barrett, Farnum Co:, a wealthy and Influential Board of Trade concern here, failed to-day. The firm had sold heavily short during th pt three day in the expectation t'hat the ]New York stock panic would result in a break in wheat.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21. -- Gov. Lowndes, who is a candidate for re-election on the Republican State ticket, to-day demanded the resignation of United Sates Senator George L. Wellington as Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, and it is understood that Senator Wellington will comply at once with the Governor's request.

The spectacle of a man endeavoring to drag a very unwilling mastiff of huge proportions along Columbus Avenue, near Ninety-third Street, last night attracted the attention of Policeman Phelan of the West One Hundredth Street Station, and he watched the struggle. The man struggled with the dog for two blocks and then the mastiff refused to go any further.

Despite the fact that a majority of the Committee on Plan and Scope of the Dewey Executive Committee favor the postponement of the breakfast until Monday, Oct. 1, there is a healthy minority in the committee which may arise at to-day's meeting and endeavor to prevent any change being made in the programme as already outlined.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- In the course of his address to-day at the Otsego County fair Gov. Roosevelt said:

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 21. -- The Republican State Convention to-day was one of the most harmonious gatherings ever held by the party in this State. H.B. Reese of Lincoln was nominated for Supreme Court Judge, and E.G. McGilton of Omaha and William H. Ely of Ainsworth for Regents of the State University on the first ballot.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 21. -- The Hospital of St. Vincent de Paul was almost totally destroyed by fire between 2 and 3 o'clock this morning. Four lives were lost, and the bodies were taken from the debris and removed to the City Morgue to-day for identification. They proved to be as follows:

Frank Moss, counsel to the Mazet investigating committee, announced yesterday he had come to the end of his resources as regards the Ramapo matter, and endeavored to put the onus on the officers of the company for his failure to bring out any new facts in connection with the scheme. So far in trying to bring out new phases of the plan from witnesses.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 21. -- A prominent Boston family in close relationship with E.C. Swift of this city, brother of Gustavus Swift, the Chicago meat packer, and associated with him in business, made a denial to-night of the report that Miss Mabelle Swift is soon to wed Prince Alexis Karogeorgevich of Servia.

NEWPORT, Sept. 21. -- To-morrow afternoon Mrs. Potter Palmer will give a tea for which many of the cottagers have been bidden to Beaulieu to see the many gifts to the bride of Prince Cantacuzene, which now nearly fill two rooms, and come from all parts of the world. All these gifts will be sent to the future home of the bride and bridegroom, in Odessa, during the week.

The caucus committee of the Republicans of the House of Representatives does not seem to share the feeling of the organ of Senator PLATT of this State that there is no need of currency legislation at the next session.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 21. -- The financial situation in Guatemala is about as bad as possible. Indeed, the one hope of the commercial community and the Government is that the Huntington purchase of the Guatemala Northern Railroad will be consummated in the near future in order that a few millions can be put at once into circulation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Princeton has sailed for Pagoda, the anchorage at Amoy, with United States Minister Conger aboard.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The Record to-morrow will say:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Miss Nannie Randolph Heth, who was sponsor for the entire South at the Confederate reunion at Charleston last May, has given to the President, in a pretty frame, the resolutions adopted by the sponsors at the reunion.

The council of the City Club last night took action looking to united effort for the election this Fall of judicial candidates pledged not to pay assessments to any political party. Resolutions were adopted inviting a conference of all individuals and organizations in favor of unassessed Judges and calling on the Mazet committee to summon all the Judges now on the bench as witnesses on the subject.

The third hearing against Horgan Slattery, the bankrupt architects, was held yesterday in the offices of the referee in bankruptcy, Stanley W. Dexter, at 71 Broadway. At the last hearing the firm had been directed by Mr. Dexter to produce the books yesterday. Again yesterday the same fight was made to keep the books from the creditors, although they were produced.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- A correspondent of The Daily Mail, who joined the Dreyfus party at Bordeaux and accompanied it to Carpentras, where the Captain now is, describes Dreyfus as "thoughtful, prematurely aged, with soft eyes, a smile like a woman's, and rather the appearance of a savant than a soldier." When told of the great wave of British sympathy in his behalf, Dreyfus wrung the correspondent's hand and showed the deepest emotion.

It may surprise some people to learn, on the authority of a Consular report issued recently, that Brazil can claim to rank as the greatest coffee-producing country in the world. We generally associate coffee with the East, but at the present day the New World grows a far larger quantity than the Old.

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- The riotous scenes and the bitter fights between the two factions of the Democratic Party in this State that characterized and made famous the all-night session in Music Hall here in 1896 and that at Worcester the following year were renewed with even greater bitterness at the annual convention of the State Democracy in Mechanics' Hall to-day.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Col. W.H. Dewey of Idaho, a cousin of Admiral Dewey, arrived in Chicago to-day. Col. Dewey is on his way to New York to attend the celebration in honor of the naval hero.

The report that Capt. DREYFUS and his family are about to come to this country is not confirmed It is extremely improbable that there is any foundation for it. The statement of DREYFUS in the Aurore yesterday is not consistent with an intention to leave France permanently or to resort to a distant land.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- At the first day of the Manchester September meeting to-day the De Trafford Handicap of 500 sovereigns, for three-year-olds and upward, was won by Scrivener. Red Queen, ridden by Tod Sloan, was unplaced. Ten horses ran one mile and a half.
CAPE TOWN, Sept. 20, (delayed in transmission.) -- At a meeting of the Afrikander members of Parliament to-day, Mr. Neethling presiding, the following telegram was dispatched to President Kruger:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21. -- It has been definitely learned to-day that the structure which is now in course of erection by ex-Gov. Charles Warren Lippitt on Ledge Road will be an apartment house, and this fact has caused a great satisfaction among the cottagers in that section of the cottage colony. Mr. Lippitt is hurrying the work so he can occupy one of the apartments this Fail or Winter.

BLOEMFONTEIN, Orange Free State, Sept. 21. -- The Volksraad met to-day with a full attendance. President M.T. Steyn read a carefully prepared speech. After welcoming the burghers, he expressed regret that the relations between Great Britain and the Transvaal had become strained.

The possible interference of steamboats with the racing yachts in the Columbia-Shamrock contests was the all-absorbing topic of interest in the inner circles of the devotees of the sport in the New York Yacht Club yesterday afternoon. A rumor that came from Bristol that the hour of starting the races would be altered from 11 o'clock in the morning to a time two hours earlier was the first inkling that reached the Madison Avenue house.

According to a correspondent in Washington of The Iron Age evidence is accumulating at the capital that an attempt is to be made to prevent the ratification, in the coming session of the Senate, of the reciprocity treaty recently negotiated by the United States and France.
Lowenfeld Prager have bought from Charles P. and John T. Murphy the front and rear old buildings 314 East Twenty-fifth Street, 25 by 98.9.

Benjamin W. Schwab, junior member of the firm of Oelrichs Co., agents for the North German Lloyd Steamship Company, was instantly killed early yesterday morning while horseback riding in Van Cortlandt Park. The horse on which he was mounted ran away, and, running under a tree, the rider's face struck the trunk with terrific force, shattering the bones of the chin and breaking the neck.

I have been asking myself lately what are the really funny books in English and American literature. I have asked some of my friends and some very intelligent booksellers. And I think we are all surprised to find short is the list. To simplify the search I confine my question to books in English, and exclude short stories.

In last week's SATURDAY REVIEW unusual attention was given to the article on "Magazine Editors," and parenthetically let me deny the charges against contributors in general and wish to refute the evidence. All that is rejected is not slush! The average beginner does not always imitate. There is no lack of literary talent.

Gen. Otis cables to the War Department this amazing news: "Referring to your cablegram of Sept. 18, sixteen churches, different localities, occupied by United States troops. Four only partially occupied, and religious services not interfered with. Also three convents occupied. These three and ten of the sixteen churches formerly occupied by insurgents.
The Brokerage Committee of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange at its meeting yesterday revoked the certificate of W.M. Reed.

State Tax Commissioner George M. Priest, who was in this city yesterday, pronounced the report that the board had decided to tax franchises upon a valuation computed by capitalizing the net incomes of the corporations a baseless fabrication. He expressed the opinion that the story was started to affect the stock market.

THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 9 was, without exception, the most comprehensive literary effort in serial form ever offered to book lovers. The page on "Read the Old Books" was a perfect feast, and while Helen Church is always delightful, the contribution of M. Van Duzer Heard met with appreciation from one reader, I can assure you.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- John Lane of the Bodley Head will publish, under the general title of "Flowers of Parnassus," a series of illustrated pocket volumes, each consisting of a single famous poem. Mr. Money Coults has selected the poems, one of which will be Stephen Phillips's "Marpossa."
" It is a principle of my life to cultivate indifference toward and independence of individual opinion."
LONDON, Sept. 22. -- A Cabinet Council was held to-day, beginning at 12:30 P.M.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- The State Tax Commissioners will meet on Tuesday or Wednesday of next week, at which time the Attorney General and J. Newton Fiero, special counsel to the board, will confer with the Commissioners upon a plan for submission to the Governor for enforcing the law. They will also order the sending out of a blank form to all corporations in the State holding public franchises.

The letters you so kindly print from your readers are always interesting, but those of your last issue were especially so, one set of letters commenting on the books of the day, the other, suggested by your article, singing the praises of the older books, thus unconsciously forming two sides of a very interesting controversy.

Funeral services for Charles P. Daly, ex-Chief Justice of the old Court of Common Pleas, were held in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday forenoon, and a large number of the older residents of New York were in attendance. The black cloth-covered coffin rested on a simple catafalque at the head of the main aisle, and it was covered with flowers and vines, in which pansies and lilies of the valley predominated.
BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- A naval officer on one of the ships at Cavite says in a private letter written to relatives here under date of Aug. 19, via Suez:

WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 22. -- Because he called the war in the Philippines a failure and demanded that it be abandoned, former Congressman Jerry Simpson was hooted from the platform at an Old Soldiers' reunion here this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Announcement is made of the engagement of Anand A. Advani, a millionaire indigo merchant of India, who has been in Chicago for a week, to Miss Virginia Tyler Hudson, well known, especially in Louisville, as a newspaper writer. The marriage is to take place in either Germany or London next June.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- A plan is under consideration at the War Department to create an army division of the Philippines and divide it into departments on a basis similar to that in Cuba.

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 22. -- The sloop Columbia left her moorings in Bristol Harbor at 9 o'clock this forenoon and stood away toward Newport under mainsail and club-topsail. As soon as she was but of the harbor she set her baby topsail and broke out the forestaysail and jib. When last seen from here she was footing fast on the starboard tack, with a good breeze from the westward blowing.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 22. -- Walter L. Ramsdell of Lynn, whom the Democratic Convention yesterday nominated for Auditor, tried to decline during the convention, but was refused recognition by Chairman McNary. To-day he sent to the State Committee his formal declination, and in the course of his letter he makes some sharp remarks.

After a brief discussion by the members of the Rapid Transit Railroad Commission, in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday afternoon, President Alexander E. Orr sent to Corporation Counsel John Whalen a reply to the suggestions made by that officer regarding the form of contract for the construction of the proposed underground railroad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Admiral Dewey is expected to arrive in Washington at 6:50 o'clock on the evening of Monday, Oct 2. An Admiral's salute will be fired at the station, and a troop of cavalry from Fort Myer will act as a body guard during the entire celebration.
NEWPORT, Sept. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Storrs Wells have arrived at their cottage after having spent the season in Europe. They will remain here for a month.

I depend upon THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW to settle this little dispute: My wife recently read "St. Elmo," by Augusta J. Evans, and I frequently found her weeping over some of its tender and sentimental passages. I thought the story must be a good thing, and one night pored over it for several hours. I unconsciously began to find myself skipping it like the mischief -- a sure indication it was not suiting me.
LONDON, Sept. 22. -- All the theatrical managers are praying for the advent of a new dramatist or the production of a real and vital play by some one of the present school.

In a copy of "Twenty Years Later" (translation unknown) I find what seems to be a curious blunder. D'Artagnan, endeavoring to induce Porthos to enter the service of Mazarin and picturing the joys and delights of Paris with Richelleu's edicts no longer in force, is made to say: "The Guise killed Coligny in the Place Royal and nothing was said about it."

When a week ago Albert Wayne received as a present from a relative up the State a fine young fox with a magnificent brush there was great rejoicing in the family, especially among the younger members thereof. A fox is an uncommon pet in New York private residences, even when these residences are as commodious as that of Mr. Wayne, which is situated in One Hundred and Seventy-fifth Street, near Amsterdam Avenue.

Much has been written and spoken advocating the practice of systematic reading, so that the basis of our knowledge of men and their doings may be more firmly established along certain lines. It seems to me, however, as if a course of reading in the older novelists, actively and faithfully pursued, may also be both profitable and entertaining.

PRETORIA, Sept. 7. -- His Honor did not desire to say much: "Everybody," he said, "would contend that right is might. Let us, therefore." he continued. "look well into our affairs in order to see whether we are right. For that reason I have wished to look into matters, and refer to certain points, knowing that the Lord giveth where there is justice.

At yesterday's meeting of the Committee on Plan and Scope of the Dewey Executive Committee the project of giving a breakfast at Claremont before the land parade starts was abandoned. In lieu of the discarded breakfast, a luncheon will be served on the boat which will carry Admiral Dewey and the city's gues's from down town to the neighborhood of Grant's Tomb.
Clarence B. Britton, twenty-eight years old, a United States soldier, is locked up in Police Headquarters here charged with homicide and arson. Britton is wanted by the Chicago authorities.

Two more desperadoes have been arrested by Pinkerton detectives and the police of this city on the charge of holding up, binding, assaulting, and robbing employes of the Massachusetts Electric Company, at Portsmouth, R.I., about midnight on July 30 last. The names of these men are John McAdams, alias "Massachusetts Joe," and James Kennard, alias James Murray, alias "Big Jim."
AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The Rev. George Black Stewart, D.D., was to-day inaugurated as President of Auburn Theological Seminary, to succeed the late Henry M. Booth.

Your correspondent, Annie S. Carman of Brooklyn, queries concerning a poem she found in her scrapbook. The poem was written by John S. Dwight, the musical enthusiast, editor, and critic. It has often been attributed to Goethe, from whom Dwight made many admirable translations. It made its first appearance in the first number of The Dial at the end of a sermon by Dwight, who was then a Unitarian preacher, on "The Religion of Beauty."

There was a time when to slander and malign the memory of Paine was a virtue. There was a time when, as a New York pastor publicly stated, every orthodox minister considered it his duty to preach against the "horrible infidel. Tom Paine." without taking the trouble to become acquainted with the life and writings of that remarkable man.

Further consideration of the report from Washington, to which we made allusion yesterday, of the determination of Switzerland to demand all the tariff concessions extended to France under the pending treaty between the United States and France, and of the purpose of Great Britain, Germany, Italy, and some other nations to demand equal or the same concessions, convinces us of the improbability of the report.

It is considered essential to every book to have a table of contents, and also an index of subjects, and several publishers have advantageously published in connection with their catalogues an alphabetical index of all subjects in all their books, as it increases sales, as buyers generally ask for all books the publisher issues relating to the subject of interest to them.

BLOWING ROCK, N.C., Sept. 22. -- Ogden E. Edwards, a resident of this place, has written to Secretary of War Root, attempting to point out the error of the Government in appointing negro company officers to command the two negro regiments now being raised. Mr. Edwards says:

The Mazet committee made a final attempt yesterday to get a glimpse of the stock book and options of the Ramapo Water Company and failed. Engineer Nostrand and President Dutcher were put on the stand, but both were impenetrable. Mr. Moss questioned them in vain, and then turned, baffled, to another field of inquiry.
PARIS, Sept 22.-- Gen. Brault, who succeeded Gen. Renouard as Chief of the General Staff Nov. 4, 1898, is dead.
In recent issues of certain New York newspapers I see startling headlines thus: "Kipling Wins His Suit Against Hubbard." And one paper was so unkind as to put it,' "The Sage of East Aurora Downed!"

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- The new bronze statue of Col. Thomas Cass, commander of the old Ninth Massachusetts Infantry in the civil war, was unveiled in the Public Garden this afternoon under most appropriate conditions. The exercises were held about the statue, which stands in the southeast side of the garden, near the entrance to the subway.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 22. -- The Lenox cottagers had their initial horse show to-day at Highland Farm, and the affair was a great success, the weather conditions proving favorable. Between 3,000 and 4,000 people were present.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The principal subject of discussion in social circles here and at Garden City is the trouble in the family of Richard Howland Hunt, who lives in Garden City, just outside of this village. The family is well known here and in Garden City, and both Mr. and Mrs. Hunt are highly regarded.

George Edward Pond, for many years an . ediorlal writer on the taff of The New York Sun. and at one time oonnected with' the editorial staff of THE iN'EW YORK TIw'S,. died of heart disease yesterday at his Sum- .i mer residence, Spring Lake, N. J.

The burglars who have been working with so much success in the Flatbush district of Brooklyn are believed to have extended their field of operations to the Park Slope section of that borough. Two daring burglaries and a highway robbery committed in that neighborhood recently became known yesterday. The police had kept the news of these robberies secret.

Herbert M. Harriman, the amateur champion, and Louis Livingston, Jr., were the survivors in the semi-final rounds yesterday for the Westbrook Cup, in the Westbrook Club's tournament, near Islip, L.I. Each of the matches was characterized by the same element of uncertainty and excitement that has been so marked ever since the contest began Wednesday morning.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 22. -- J.H.S. Eteen of Shreveport, La, has arrived here from Rennes, France, where he has been visiting his sister. He brings information that Capt. Dreyfus and Mme. Dreyfus, together with Mme. Bertha Morre, Lieut. Max Rance-Morre, late of the French Army, and the Misses Ida and Emily Morre will come to San Antonio and that Capt. Dreyfus will spend the Winter in this city for his health.

In reading the editorial page of my SUNDAY TIMES from the bottom up, as is my custom, attention was claimed by the sentence: "Take off the ban from ship buying, compel the builders to do their work better and cheaper than any one else, and they will win." The editorial was under the above-quoted heading.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Miss Telazel Gedney, a New York girl, was burned to death last night by the explosion of an oil lamp.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The Chinese Minister called at the State Department today and held a long conference with Acting Secretary Hill respecting the admission into the Philippines of some Chinese. The case is an exceptional one, and it is said that the general question of the validity and propriety of Gen. Otis's extension of the Chinese exclusion laws to the Philippines was not an issue in the conference.

Nobody need be surprised, nobody will be surprised, by the announcement that the Orange Free State has in effect cast in its lot with the South African Republic. No man of Dutch descent in South Africa, no Afrikander, has any reason to love the British. Every such man thinks he has good reason to hate them.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- To-day's session of the International Congregational Congress was devoted largely to papers and discussions on the war, and the new relations and responsibilities arising out of it. The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott delivered an address on "International Relations and Responsibilities; or, the War Question." Among other things he said:

GREENPORT, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The submarine torpedo boat made a remarkably good showing during the practice run today. The trials were made over the course in Little Peconic Bay, which will be used for the Government tests to be held later. The vessel was recently overhauled, and during the run of to-day showed a considerable increase of speed.

POINT PLEASANT N. J., Sept. 22. -- The body of Robert Adams was taken from this place to-day to New York. Adams killed himself yesterday afternoon, and effort were made to keep the circumstances a secret. Adams is said to have been a clerk in a New York wholesale dry goods house, but very little is known abandon here.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Sept. 22. -- The residence of Absalom Kesler, a farmer, aged eighty, reputed to be a miser, living on the West Virginia side of the river near Paw-paw, was discovered on fire at 1 o'clock this morning. Neighbors hurried to the scene and were horrified to find Kesler and Albert Gross, his farm hand, lifeless in the yard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The Navy Department to-day received a cablegram from Admiral Watson announcing the arrival at Manila of the marines under Major Elliott. They will proceed at once to police Cavite and vicinity.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 22. -- There is no longer a doubt that Congressman Hopkins of Aurora, Ill., and Senator Cullom have had a disagreement and Hopkins has joined the Tanner faction. The breach was conceded by friends of Hopkins to-day, and Senator Cullom's advisers in politics here admitted it a week ago.

Howard Suydam questions the accuracy of my statement in "The History of Flushing": "There appears to be no authority for the tradition that the incorporators chose the name [Flushing] because they had found refuge in the Holland town of the same name." He quotes the following passage from Miss Flint's "Early Long Island" in support of his position:

Instead of finding any body of evidence that the old favorites have become corrupt, almost the contrary appears to be the case, for their purity seems to have been generally preserved in quite a remarkable manner.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 22. -- Miss Julia Morrison, leading woman of the "Mr. Plaster of Paris" company, shot and instantly killed Frank Leiden, the stage manager, on the stage of the new Opera House to-night in view of an audience of fully 2,000 people. She and her husband, J.H. James, were taken to jail.

In the current number of Harper's Magazine, Mark Twain, in the course of a paper on the Jews, says that they "constitute but 1 per cent, of the human race." In reality they constitute less than one-half of 1 per cent., and not much more than 1 per cent, of the number of Buddhists and Brahmins.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22. -- This afternoon the many handsome gifts for Prince Michel Cantaeuzene and Miss Julia Dent Grant were shown at the residence of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Potter Palmer, where the gifts were arranged in two of the large rooms on the second floor, carefully guarded by Detective Richards of the local force and several other officials in plain clothes.

Some twenty Democrats of varying degrees of prominence met secretly at the Manhattan Hotel last night and took steps toward the formation of an Anti-Croker organization in this city. Among those who were present were ex-Justice Joseph F. Daly, Roger A. Pryor, Jr., Dr. William R. Pryor, ex-Congressman Edward J. Dunphy, and Andrew A. McCormick, formerly manager of the Broadway Theatre.

An interesting possibility is suggested by The Baltimore American, the paper which, with or without authority, has constituted itself the special champion of Admiral SCHLEY. It points out that among the places where the South Atlantic Squadron may soon have occasion to represent the power of the United States is Cape Town, and that on the way there it would not be at all inconvenient to call at a Spanish port.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Sept. 22. -- Senator J. B. Foraker delivered an address here to-day at the emancipation celebration on the Butler County Fair Grounds. Among the features of his address were his declarations for expansion and an exhaustive argument on trusts.

You say that if the cost enters into the problem, your correspondent would do well to obtain the Standard.

The extraordinary prices fetched at the recent sale of the library of Mr. William Wright, in London, recalls the growing interest in books which have some particular association connected with them. There were a number of books in this library which were presentation copies. Among the most conspicuous examples of prices were those paid for presentation copies of Dickens's and Thackeray's books.
With your permission I wish to add a short list of my favorites, which I think will be interesting to girls of eighteen, in reply to "E.D.F." of Sept. 9.

Mrs. Horace Chenery of Larchmont, who had been in the city for the past six weeks under treatment for nervous affection, threw herself from the window of her apartments on the fourth floor of the Hotel Majestic, Seventy-second Street and Central Park West, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning. She fell a distance of seventy feet to the pavement and was killed instantly.

The Central Puerto Rican Relief Committee has received and is tabulating bids for a large amount of medical supplies which were asked or by Major Hoff of the Board of Charities of Puerto Rico. There are over 200 items in the requisition.

PRETORIA, Sept. 22. -- A Green Book has been issued containing the report of State Attorney Smuts to the Government on the pourparlers between himself and the British Diplomatic Agent, Conyngham Greene, leading to the conditional five years' franchise proposal.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 22. -- Charlie Miller and his riding mate Joe Judge to-night defeated Fournier and Steenson at the Hartford Avenue Bowl track in a twenty-five-mile motor race for the championship of America.

Chairman Joseph M. Price's statement of he reasons for the withdrawal of certain members from the Citizens' Union Committee of the Nineteenth District on Wednesday night has provoked sharp replies from two of the withdrawing members. John C. Clark openly charged yesterday that one of the most active members of the present committee has arranged a deal with Tammany Hall and is endeavoring to effect one with the Labor Party.

The space to dispose of being very limited, the letters had to be light and small, and were written on thin paper, with almost microscopic handwriting. Perusing a letter, to be sent to an absent friend, and finding the same almost unreadable, somebody made the following post scripture:

Fire early yesterday morning destroyed nearly the entire block bounded by Ninety-third and Ninety-fourth Streets. First Avenue and the East River, occupied principally by Hencken Willenbrock's coal and lumber yard and the East River Mill and Lumber Company. The coal and lumber company has had several fires during the past five years, but that of yesterday entailed the heaviest loss it has had.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22. -- No new cases of yellow fever were reported to-day. This is thought to be due to the fact that the weather has turned very cool. The fact that two deaths occurred to-day is attrlb! uted to the change in the weather.

The life of Cromwell that Theodore Roosevelt is preparing for Scribner's Magazine will run through six numbers of the periodical next year. It will be illustrated by F.C. Yohn, E.C. Peixotto, Henry McCarter, and other well-known artists. There will also be many rare portraits, relics, and other valuable matter. It may be recalled that the first installment of Mr. John Morley's "Oliver Cromwell" will appear in the November Century.

LONDON, Sept. 23.-- The Government, it is understood, cabled Sir Alfred Milner, British High Commissioner for South Africa, yesterday afternoon, (Friday,) a message in accordance with the Cabinet's decision, as already outlined. It is said that the message also protests strongly against the accusation of bad faith on the part of Conyngham Greene.

Mr. Moore in his comments on Mr. Canfield's views has fallen into the old-line error of non-believers in a college education. Mr. Canfield cites the fact of the Ohio State University's lifting up of 1,700 young men and embracing them in the folds of a university opportunity as a boon to mankind. Mr. Moore fails to see "the beneficial results" of that act of the university.

The High School class of '99 wishes to acknowledge the friendly services of THE NEW YORK TIMES in the generous offer of guidance in our reading which appeared last week in THE SATURDAY REVIEW. We were highly gratified to find so much space devoted to a fellow-member, but on questioning the actual assistance gained by the one of our number whom you addressed, we became somewhat doubtful as to the suggestiveness of your advice.
Prices very generally strengthened on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Few stocks failed to advance. Some scored substantial gains.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 22. -- The Chronicle says: "Definite and reliable information from the East sets at rest the rumors about the sale of the Crocker holdings of Southern Pacific stock and ends speculation as to the purchaser. The Crocker shares, numbering 340,000, and valued, approximately, at $10,000,000, have been bought by a syndicate, of which C.P. Huntington is the head.

It was expected that sooner or later some attempt would be made to explain Joseph Smith, the "Mormon Prophet." Such was his character, such the impedance of the religion he founded, so remarkable and thrilling the history of his people, that he could not be ignored.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The opening of the Republican campaign in Ohio to-morrow is being awaited with great interest here. The report that Gov. Bushnell has refused to attend excites no great surprise.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22. -- The steamer Mariposa brings the following news from Apia. Samoa, dated Sept. 8:

The William Black memorial beacon which is to be erected at Duart Point, near the entrance to the Sound of Mull, on the Scotch coast, is to be no mere lighthouse or fantastic iron frame work, or even the conventional beacon. Its architecture will resemble the turret of a Scotch feudal castle, with battlements and port holes complete. It will be about fifty feet in height.

Julia Ward Howe and Prince Peter Krapotkin are the next of the notables whose autobiographical and reminiscent moods promise to enrich the end of the century literature with valuable and attractive volumes of this character. Edward Everett Hale's "James Russell Lowell," as well as Col. Higginson's "Old Cambridge" and "Contemporaries," have already delighted the reading people.

The letter from "Property Owner" on "the Seventh Avenue car line" in to-day's issue is a truthful statement of a large grievance. In the first place, the charter of the Seventh Avenue line is very valuable, and if the present custodians do not take good care of it and give the people proper service, it is the duty of the city authorities to compel them to give such service.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 23. -- Many of the Lenox cottagers and their guests will go to New York next week to attend the Dewey celebration, and some of them will remain over to witness the yacht races. On account of this temporary exodus, the entertainments for this week have been more numerous than they otherwise would have been.

A sad story was brought to Baltimore by the officers of the North German Lloyd steamer Willehad, from Bremen. It was the story of a wedding, the death of the bride, her burial, the death of the bridegroom and his burial, all within five days.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Nat C. Goodwin is not in the best of health. His part in "An American Citizen" has been filled on several occasions by Miller Hunt. Levenstein Lorillard, who secured a contract from Mr. Goodwin to play at the Comedy Theatre, say they will make him pay for his inability to carry it out.

BEAUFORT, N.C., Sept. 23. -- The Santification Band, members of which are popularly known as Lynchites, is a sect of religious fanatics possessing unique peculiarities. Their camping grounds are the waters along the coasts of Maryland, Virginia, and North Carolina, where they move from place to place in floats modeled, they say, after the original ark of Noah.
Under the supervision of Director William T. Hornaday, the New York Zoological Gardens in Bronx Park are rapidly approaching completion.

TURIN, Sept. 11, 1899. -- Turin has seldom presented a scene of such animation and brilliancy as during the great celebrations of the last three days in honor of the unveiling and inauguration of the much talked of monumen to Victor Emmanuel, first King of United Italy, which has been presented to the former Sardinian power by his son, Umberto, the present ruler of modern Italy.

SARANAC LAKE, Sept. 23. -- By common consent, the second half of the season in the Adirondacks seems to belong to the sportsmen. Instead of the dress-suit cases, guns and shawl straps line the aisles of the incoming trains. Year by year this period has become more popular with a certain class, and many are those now who prefer to take their vacation when the heat is over and they can enjoy some good sport.

All yesterday afternoon a rumor was afloat that the Bank of the Metropolis, at Union Square West and Sixteenth Street, had been robbed. The police, hearing of it, investigated, and reported a singular origin for the rumor.

SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., Sept. 23. -- The difference recently existing between the Erie Railroad Company and its coal miners in Forest City, Susquehanna County, which caused the company to close the mines on Monday last for thirty days, has been amicably arranged, and the 1,200 men will resume work on Monday next.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The Dreyfus excitement has largely subsided here since the pardon, though many papers express the belief that the mystery surrounding the case will be one day removed. Others say the end is wholly unsatisfactory. In military and diplomatic circles the opinion seems to prevail that Dreyfus was indeed a spy, but for Russia. This has found utterance in many papers.

The Bostons found the New Yorks formidable at the Polo Grounds yesterday and suffered defeat by a score of 5 to 2. Meekin pitched against his former clubmates, and the crowd was interested to see what kind of a showing he could make. He pitched a good game, but Seymour clearly outpitched him.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 23. -- The Reinhart Cup was contested for on the links of the Hillside Tennis and Golf Club this afternoon. It was a men's handicap competition, eighteen holes, medal play. J. Whitney Baker made low net score, with Morris Dumont one stroke behind.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The Boers must be a more trusting people than they receive credit for being in the English press. They are expected to remain quiescent while England is indulging in a diplomatic campaign of masterly inactivity, and in another campaign, which may have an indirect connection with diplomacy, but which is engineered by the Secretary of War.

In your issue of to-day Judge Van Hoesen is quoted as saying: "It is only a plain case of Great Britain robbing the people of the Transvaal. The Boer land has gold in it and the English want that gold. That is all there is to it."
As a constant reader of your paper, I would ask that you give the following your careful consideration:

William K. Vanderbilt is credited with having just directed some correspondence to financial interests in Boston which will be easy to understand. The New York Central management is resenting interference with its Boston and Albany contract, and Mr. Vanderbilt has notified parties in interest that he is ready to abandon the entire deal.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- An outbreak of war in the Transvaal is regarded here as a question of a few days, or, at the most, of weeks. The whole press devotes considerable space to the matter. Neither the attitude of the people nor press has changed materially. Without exception they disapprove of such a war, and blame Great Britain for badgering the Transvaal beyond endurance.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 23. -- H.F. Carleton, Master Commissioner of the Cleveland, Canton and Southern Railroad, to-day deeded the property to Myron T. Herrick and other capitalists representing the second mortgage bondholders for $1,950,000. Herrick then transferred his interest to the Wheeling and Lake Erie Road, thus consolidating the two properties.

Mr. Moss did not care to. The scheme, Controller COLER says, is not dead. President HOLAHAN insists that it will yet be adopted.

It is up to date and hygienic to bathe; in fact, it is next door to fashionable to take cold plunges or sponges or sprinkles. But there was nothing fashionable about this bath, and the bathroom was not one that could be recommended for general use.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Two Italians in this city ate toadstools in mistake for mushrooms yesterday, and as a result one of them died this morning, while the other is seriously ill.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 23. -- Six passengers were killed and five injured, one perhaps fatally, in a collision on the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad at Reno siding, near Florence, at 4:08 o'clock this afternoon.

A colored woman displayed remarkable heroism last night when, by thrusting her husband and two children cut of the way of a running horse, she got in the animal's way and was run down and trampled upon. She was taken in a dangerous condition to the New York Hospital.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- A meeting of the prominent knit goods manufacturers of this State was held at the office of Charles Brown Co., (Troy,) to-day for the purpose of furthering the formation of a knit goods trust or consolidation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The State Department has examined the charges made against United States Vice Consul Florschutz, at Coburg, Germany, of being a spy in the employ of the German Government, and has satisfied itself that there is no ground for the charges.
There is an old saying and a true one that the people admire wisdom and prudence, but they love courage and honesty.

The equality of opportunity and the equality of legal rights which The London Spectator lays so much stress upon unquestionably do work for that contentment with the gradations in English social life which is so apt to amaze the American traveler who thinks the masses and the classes ought to hate a Lord.

The outlook in the social world for the next fortnight is a pleasant one. Interest centres this morning in the future, and deals not with the retrospect. All is anticipation and excitement in New York and its suburbs over the festivities of carnival week, which term has been substituted for the longer ones of "Dewey celebration and the America's Cup races."

As had been foreshadowed by the published statements of bank Presidents in these columns on Saturday, the weekly statement of the New York Clearing House Association, issued just before the close of the Stock Exchange yesterday, was more favorable than its immediate predecessor, and, on the whole, produced a decidedly good impression.

Still but a mere shell and suggestion, the Dewey Arch already reveals, if nothing more, at least the magnificence of an opportunity, and the correctness of the artistic instinct which placed the arch where it is, instead of at the entrance to Central Park.

Although there will be an interval before the procession of tuneful events again takes up its march, the production of Mr. Francis Wilson's new opera comique may be regarded as the beginning of the musical season of 1899-1900. It is not often that this may fairly be said of the introduction of a new work in the field of light opera.

All the so-called "grievances" of the Outlanders are only checkers played upon that board. What are the facts as set forth in the convention of 1884 between Great Britain and the Transvaal, and what were the circumstances leading up to that convention?

An opportunity will be offered all riders to officially record their best performance for 100 miles on Oct. 15, when the New York division of the Century Road Club of America will hold its Fall century run. The run has been so arranged that any rider with a touring experience can take part.
LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The sands are running out much too slowly for the jingo party.
