LONDON, Sept. 23. -- There was a great crowd at Waterloo Station this morning to bid adieu to the passengers for the New York. The ship was crowded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The landing of the shipload of Chinese now at Manila will depend upon military expediency, which will be determined by Gen. Otis. If, in his judgment, the landing of the 700 Chinese will not interfere with the military conditions or disturb the situation they may land. The conditions in the Philippines, it is pointed out, are such as to make the entry of Chinese laborers a disturbing element.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Lord Chief Justice Charles Russell, Lord Charles Beresford, and the Right Hon. Arnold Morely of England will be Chicago's guests on Oct. 9. They will be in New York at the time of the yacht races and will come to Chicago with the Earl of Minto. Postmaster Gordon has received definite assurance of their acceptances of the invitations extended for the Fall Festival.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The committee of architects appointed to pass upon the plans and specifications for the new Custom House in New York have selected two plans. These are by Carrere Hastings and Cass Gilbert.

Ex-Justice Joseph F. Daly, who was present at the anti-Croker conference held at the Manhattan Hotel on Friday night, said yesterday that the promoters of the movement were much encouraged by the assurances of support received for it from influential quarters. They were so much encouraged by the attendance on Friday night, he said, that an adjournment had been taken until next week, so that men who could not be there that evening might attend.

A pauper's grave is not, after all, to receive the body of Mary E. McVicker, who committed suicide last Thursday in a tenement at 328 East Thirty-fourth Street. A middle-aged woman, dressed in black and wearing spectacles, called at the Morgue yesterday morning and saw Keeper Fane.

OWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- At the Tioga County Democratic Convention this afternoon Harry B. Winters of Smithborough was nominated for member of the Assembly. Mr. Winters was the Democratic candidate for this office last year, and his successful Republican opponent, Daniel P. Witter, will again enter the contest with him.

In a fresh breeze from the east that only varied half a point north or south during the day, the Shamrock gave yesterday the best exhibition of sailing that she has shown since she has been in these waters. She reached down the New Jersey coast, laying her course due south to a mark fifteen miles away, and made the distance in 1 hour 8 minutes 30 seconds.

Business of fair volume was done during the week, but it was of the same desultory character which has marked dealings throughout the month, and which bids fair to continue for some time to come. Brokers look forward to good demand for investment properties later in the season, but of this demand it must be admitted there has been as yet little evidence.

-- Vivisection's one good-natured foe, the Secretary of the New York Anti-Vivisection Society, has sent to us from Saugerties a somewhat laborious, but doubtless entirely sincere, letter, expressing her gratitude for the assistance certain paragraphs in this column have given to her cause, and thanking us especially for some recent remarks in which the would-be closers of a straight and easy road to knowledge were credited with "tireless volubility."

Everything points to a very large turnout of New York Guardsmen in the Dewey parade Saturday, and, despite the disorganization incident to the mustering of commands into the volunteer service, it will be found that the Guard has pulled itself to-gether to a remarkable degree, and that some organizations are even stronger than before they were broken up by recent unpopular methods.

ENGLAND AND DELAGOA BAY. -- The advices published yesterday from Allahabad, British India, that, owing to an agreement between Portugal and Great Britain, the latter would take posession of Delagoa Bay Nov. 1 give a certain confirmation to rumors that have long been prevalent in European diplomatic circles.

Mme. Camille Darville, the comic opera prima donna, has decided to abandon the vaudeville stage and again take up the operatic stage. This decision on her part at this time will not interfere with her present engagement, which she will continue for the balance of the time she has contracted for with Mr. Proctor, on whose circuit she will continue to appear for several months yet to come.

Comedy, primarily that branch of the drama which addresses itself to the sense of the humorous, as opposed to tragedy, is, in its restricted sense, as opposed to farce and buffoonery, humorous without being broadly or grossly comical. The very essence of comedy is wit, but as it aims to hold the mirror up to nature, pathos and the passions, as they are related to the ordinary affairs of life, are not foreign to it.

Unusually large attendance marked the regular supplementary rifle practice at Creedmoor yesterday. Nearly five hundred members of the National Guard were present during the day. Breeze and light were favorable for good scores, with the result that 112 aspirants qualified as marksmen and 75 as sharpshooters.

One of the few accidents in the history of the Creedmoor rifle ranges occurred during the supplementary practice yesterday morning. Ella Van Wyck, a colored girl, fourteen years old, was struck by a glancing bullet while driving with her father on a road one-quarter of a mile back of the long-distance targets.

I desire to thank you for your admirable leaders of the last two weeks about the Transvaal crisis. Their tone is admirable, reasoning most cogent, and I hope you will persevere; for, as you know, the English are thick skinned when engaged in the pursuit of their interests real or imaginary. The extracts which you gave in your issue of last Tuesday of a speech delivered by Mr. Morley at Arbroath were most opportune.

CAMBRIDGE, Sept. 23. -- The Harvard football candidates have now been practicing a week, and a bigger, healthier looking lot of men has never been seen on a Cambridge squad. If number and quality of candidates count for anything thus early in the season, Harvard should again have as good a team as was her champion team of 1898.

Archbishop Corrigan has received, in common with other American Archbishops, an invitation to be present in Rome at the opening of the year of rejoicing, to begin on next Christmas Day. The invitation comes from Cardinal Jacobini and through the Papal Delegate at Washington, and is all the more urgent to American Archbishops owing to the unusual honor which is to be accorded to American Catholicism this year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- A.A. Advani, who has been representing himself in Chicago to be a wealthy East Indian merchant, and whose engagement to Miss Virginia Hudson, a young newspaper writer, was announced yesterday, was arrested this afternoon and locked up at the Central Police Station on a telegram sent by W.F. Powell, Chief of Police of the City of Ottawa, Ontario.

A few days ago we ventured the opinion that Rear Admiral SCHLEY would accept orders to command the South Atlantic Station, but also ventured to doubt whether this assignment was intended as a compliment by the Navy Department for his inopportune presence on the Brooklyn when CERVERA'S vessels were destroyed and the commander in chief of the United States fleet -- who claimed the Santiago victory -- was so unfortunate as to be absent.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Only a few years ago Oscar Wilde was a planet amid literary and social stars. Now, so far as the world is concerned, he is extinct. Occasionally wonder is expressed as to how and where he lives. A recent report that he has softening of the brain is not quite accurate.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 23. -- Back of the suit now pending in the United States Court in this city to set aside the recent sale of the Toledo and Ann Arbor Railroad is an intensely dramatic and thrilling story of optimism and nerve.

The Committee on Naval Parade of the Dewey Executive Committee yesterday issued the official programme for the water demonstration which will be the feature of Friday next. In preparing this programme, which also includes the orders to masters of vessels which will participate in the parade, the committee has had the assistance of Capt. Robley D. Evans, who was detailed by the Navy Department for that purpose.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Some English newspapers refer in terms anything but complimentary to the amount of the Dewey Home Fund, which is said here to be $27,000. They seem to think this amount hardly commensurate with the praise lavished on Admiral Dewey's exploit at Manila.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Tuxedo will, from all indications, have this year the gayest and most prosperous season since the Park opened. The Tuxedoites are now all returning from seashore and mountains to occupy their cottages. The clubhouse and the annexes are full and many have been denied rooms, as they have all been taken in advance.

The dredge Hell Gate of the Army Engineers' Department of this port is now stationed over Dimond Reef, in the East River, where a survey is being made, with a view to blasting away this obstruction. After the waters about Dimond Reef are thoroughly sounded, the Hell Gate will move to Coenties Reef, just off Coenties Slip, in the East River.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- The first week of the Yale football season was closed with an hour and a half of hard practice this afternoon. Twenty two of the men were given fifteen minutes of practice in line-up. After a few minutes' rest part of these same twenty-two were put in again for another period of fifteen minutes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Theodore Schaffer of Pittsburg, President of the Amalgamated Iron and Steel Workers, was the first witness before the Industrial Commission to-day. He said that about 70 per cent. of the iron, steel, and tin workers were organized.

CHILDWOLD PARK, Sept. 23. -- After an unusual number of days that were cold and some touches of early frost, the Adirondack season has returned, in this last half of September, to weather of a Springlike softness. Outside the open window the rain drops are falling as straight down as the stems of the slender silver birches.

Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff, who has established himself as the Poo-Bah of Republican politics in Brooklyn, completely dominated the County Convention of that party in Prospect Hall yesterday afternoon. His will was law with the delegates assembled to nominate a ticket for the county offices, and the slate of his choosing went through in a fashion that left no doubt as to his absolute sway over the affairs of the party in the borough.

Deaths of rich men have been frequent in New York recently, and a question that takes on interest is, What does it cost their estates before being turned over to the heirs? What are the various taxes now imposed on the estate, the legal charges for fees of executors, administrators, trustees, or other officials who may have transactions with the conveyance of the estate to the rightful heirs?

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 23. -- A petition was filed in the United States Court Saturday morning, through Attorney Colston, asking that the receivership of the Cincinnati Southern Railroad be lifted. Circuit Judge William H. Taft will hear the petition next Saturday, at which time a decision is expected.

Congratulations upon your attitude respecting the Anglo-Boer negotiations. It is truly a case of Naboth's vineyard, but let us hope that the parallel will not be carried to the end, for the destruction of the British Empire, or even its serious weakening, would be a world calamity. Nevertheless, I hope the Boers will whip the English and do it properly while they are at it.

Robert H.E. Porter, at whose Summer cottage at Point Pleasant, N.J., Robert Adams committed suicide last Wednesday, made a statement yesterday as to how the tragedy occurred. Mr. Porter is the son of Gen. Fitz John Porter, and his wife, whose name has been mentioned conspicuously in connection with the suicide of Adams, is the daughter of the famous cartoonist, Thomas Nest. The statement of Mr. Porter is as follows:

The Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society, through its Secretary, Lawrence Veiller, has taken up the controversy which started on Friday in the Council Chamber, where the Committee on Borough Affairs of the Municipal Council was given a public hearing on the Building Code.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 23. -- Pittsburg and Cleveland played two uninteresting games, Pittsburg taking both with ease. The only features of the games were the good fielding of Ely, Williams, Smith, Lockhead, and Kruger, Attendance, 2,000. Score:
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The cries of a woman attracted the attention of three boys in the village of Falconer, near this city, about 8 o'clock this evening.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- A letter published in this city, dated Gibraltar, Sept. 10, says:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 23. -- The people of Kentucky now fully realize the power of the Goebel election law, under which the State election in November is to be held. The first application of the law was made here last night, when the County Board of Election Commissioners, consisting of two Democrats and a Republican, met to appoint officers of election and registration for this city and county.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The President has suspended the appointment of Henry W. Diederich to be Consul at Bremen and has sent George Murphy, one of the expert clerks in the Consular Bureau here, to take charge of the office, in place of Louis Lange, the retiring Consul.

A new club record for a mixed foursome tournament, was made yesterday on the Morris County golf links at Morristown, N.J. The pair who achieved this distinction and won the event were Miss Elsa Hurlbut and James A. Edwards. They were the only pair of nineteen couples finishing who were rated at scratch, as the event was a handicap, and their victorious score was 96 strokes.

A correspondent of ours, talking about the manners of conductors and gripmen on our street cars, said the other day that a considerable experience in other cities convinced him, or her, that New York was the most unmannerly of all. Curiously enough, that was just what was said a few months ago in one of the magazines.

A further change in the programme for the reception to Admiral Dewey was made yesterday, when the sub-committee of the Reception Committee announced that it had appointed the following as a committee to take charge of the Admiral while he is the city's guest: William C. Whitney, Richard Croker, St. Clair McKelway, Senator Chauncey M. Depew, ex-Gov. Levi P. Morton, William McAdoo, and Warren W. Foster.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 23. -- Newport, despite the departure of many of the cottagers, has not been dull until Wednesday, when the rain fell in torrents. During the week Mrs. Clarence A. Dolan gave a dinner dance prior to her departure to Philadelphia. Very little was recorded in the press of the event, as the press representatives were informed by the doortender at the Dolan cottage that his "Missis never sees newspaper men."

TRENTON, Sept. 23. -- All kinds of politics can be studied in New Jersey at the present time. The assortment runs from factional strife over township constables to a discussion of the position of New Jersey in the National Conventions of both parties.

Travers Island, the Summer home of the New York Athletic Club, was in gala attire yesterday, it being the occasion of the sixty-third games of the club. The attendance was fully 5,000, including club members and their friends. Many ladies graced the occasion and applauded the athletes on to greater effort.
Herman Hyermann, Jr., author of the romantic drama now being presented at the Broadway Theatre under the direction of Jacob Litt, entitled "The Ghetto," has had an interesting career.

The Rev. Dr. Abraham Kuiper, the head of the Dutch Calvanists, has, in reply to a correspondent, written for publication the following interesting letter. Dr. Kuiper is a man of high standing in Holland. He was chosen by the Transvaal delegation which visited London to carry through the Convention as adviser, and is therefore to be heard with advantage on the scope and meaning of that document:

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 23. -- At the annual meeting of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company, held here to-day, former Second Vice President Albert J. Earling of Chicago was elected President of the road, vice Roswell Miller, who was elected Chairman of the Board of Directors. Mr. Miller's retirement from the Presidency was entirely unexpected outside of the inner circles of the company.

KOBE, Japan, Aug. 30. -- The Department of Education when the new treaties came into force issued a series of instructions excluding religious teachings from all schools receiving any recognition from the Government. For the last two or three years there has been very acute trouble between the American Mission Board and the Trustees of a Christian college in Kyoto, called the Doshisha.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 23. -- The Republican State campaign was opened here to-day with one of the largest crowds known in the history of politics in Ohio. The advance guard, which arrived last night, was swelled at an early hour this morning by strangers coming in on early trains, so that when the large delegations arrived about noon the town was already well filled.

It does seem strange that Americans should presume to advise England as to what its duty is toward the Boers. We, presumably, went into a war with Spain because of our sympathy with the down-trodden Cubans, purely from a humanitarian standpoint, and now because England desires to secure the rights that English settlers in the Boerland claim, a number of our people cry shame!

Poor Admiral Dewey has gone down like the Maine upon foot rugs. He is also celebrated, like the Maine, upon bon-bon boxes, and his latest appearance is upon pins and cuff buttons displayed at the first-class jewelers. Upon these, in gold, his head appears as a medalion upon a round coin, and in the same form on the buttons.

Many years ago the maker of musical instruments to his Majesty King George of England fashioned a kettle drum. It chanced to find its way to a regiment of redcoats which crossed the Atlantic. There was a battle one day at Bunker Hill. The drummer of the retreating regiment dropped his instrument in his haste, and it was picked up by American soldiers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- "Palestine will be secured to us and the Zionites will colonize it. The movement is under way, and I believe it will meet with success." So spoke Leon Zolotkoff, who was a delegate to Basel, to-night in the presence of 3,000 Jews of Chicago.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 23. -- Because the telephone girls did not answer her calls quick enough, Mrs. Mary A. Slocum has filed suit in Magistrate Hay's court for $150 damages against the Central Union Telephone Company. She says the operators refused to answer her calls.

Cardinal Patrick F. Moran of the Roman Catholic Church in Australia has been figuring recently in a spirited controversy in the Sydney newspapers with various Protestant missionaries in regard to the Protestant missions in the South Seas, and particularly in Hawaii. As Hawaii is now a part of the United States, this controversy is of interest to American Christians engaged in missionary work.
ALBANY, Sept. 23. -- The civil service rules and regulations to govern the City of Yonkers were approved to-day by the State Commission.

As a British subject permit me to observe that your time might be more profitably employed than in misrepresenting the attitude of Great Britain toward the Transvaal and calling her harsh-sounding names, if your editorial pen were engaged in denouncing the action of your own Government in the Philippines, where the natives are being shot down like dogs simply because they prefer self-government to the Government of the United States.

In your editorial to-day entitled "Latin-American Distrust," you advise President McKinley in sketching out his annual message to Congress not to omit "to provide a paragraph somewhere to counteract the distrust of our intentions that is being cultivated by the anti-imperialist press in those South American republics that have in large part adopted constitutions resembling our own, and have for many years entertained a feeling of fellow-republicanism toward the United States."

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Laverne Wilson, a farmer, living south of this city, was shot through the heart and instantly killed this evening by his brother, Chauncey Wilson. The tragedy took place at the farm of Chauncey Wilson in Laona. The murderer at once gave himself up to Deputy Sheriff Phelps.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23. -- Senator Wellington has forwarded to Gov. Lowndes his reply to the letter received by him requesting him to resign the Chairmanship of the Republican State Central Committee. The letter was sent from Cumberland, and is addressed to Gov. Lowndes at Baltimore. It is as follows:

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 24. -- The seismograph, in operation in the meteorological station here, indicated severe shocks of earthquake yesterday. On the occasion of the recent disturbances at Skaguay the instrument indicated it. Yesterday's was much severer than formerly, and the officials regarded Alaska as the probable scene of another earthquake.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- We are suffering from an acute spasm of military dementia, a disease to which modern empires seem peculiarly liable. The consequence is that financial business of all kinds is suffering from a bad set-back. Whereas during the seven first months of the year new joint stock undertakings were poured on the market every week in scores, now none at all appear of the slightest importance.

Coroner Bausch yesterday issued warrants for the arrest of three collectors employed by a furniture house. He would not give out the names of the men last night, as they had not been arrested, but he said they were charged with asaulting Mrs. Alice Muller, wife of John Muller, a furrier living at 116 University Place.

THE NEW YORK TIMES treats with good natured sarcasm the sturdy effort Philadelphia is now making through its Export Exposition to cultivate international trade at the same time it holds its place as the citadel of protection. But there is no longer pertinency in this jeering. Philadelphia manufacturers have outlived protectionism.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Ernest Melville, a circus rider, for several years with the Barnum Bailey Show, is in jail for stabbing his wife's stepfather with a carving knife. The assault took place at 1 o'clock this afternoon at 141 Lakeside Avenue, the home of both men, and the victim, George Heiffner, is in the Memorial Hospital with three severe wounds, one of them in the back just over the left lung.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- An attempt to hold a pro-Boer, anti-war demonstration in Trafalgar Square, London, this afternoon resulted in failure. Thousands of men assembled, but not to support the speakers. On the contrary, the crowd waved union jacks and sang the national anthem and "Rule, Britannia" like mighty invocations.

NEWPORT, Sept. 24. -- The Vanderbilt private car will go across the continent to meet Alfred G. Vanderbilt at San Francisco when he arrives on the steamer now en route from Yokohama. After he returns here and the will has been probated Mrs. Vanderbilt will close the Breakers. Ever since Mrs. Vanderbilt arrived at her villa in Newport many floral tributes have been left there by her numerous friends among the cottagers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- The Rev. Peter McQueen of Boston arrived here to-day. Dr. McQueen was given a nine months' vacation by his congregation that he might visit the Philippines and inquire into the condition of the people. He arrived in San Francisco from Manila Sept 1. Regarding the conditions in the Philippines he said:

The suggestion thrown out a few days ago by Controller Coler that some decisive change should be made in the cumbersome and elastic law providing for the appointment of Commissioners of Appraisal in condemnation proceedings has evoked an echoing response from numerous taxpayers who have for years grumbled at the excessive charges attendant upon these hearings.

Racing at Morris Park will open for a Fall meeting of fourteen days Oct. 3, and from then on daily, Fridays excepted, the sport will be carried on on the largest race track in the East until Oct. 21, when the meeting ends. The Morris Park meeting really marks the close of the season of high-class racing, for the best horses are usually retired when the meeting closes.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, pastor of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, who returned last week from a long stay in the Adirondacks, occupied his pulpit yesterday morning and preached to a large congregation. The title of his sermon was: "What is salvation? An outlook upon the question, How Saul became Paul."

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Gen. Albert D. Shaw, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, before leaving to-night for Topeka, Kan., where, this week, he will address a reunion of the veterans of that State, said:

The ancient town of Lexington, Mass., is already making preparations for an elaborate celebration it is intended to have April 19, 1900, of the hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the battle there.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 24. -- If anything more were needed to prove conclusively that the Barrow, Wade, Guthrie Co. deal is hopelessly beaten, a circular sent out by the Directors of the Union Cotton Manufacturing Company has furnished it. Mr. Brayton. Treasurer of this corporation, is the recognized leader of the men in the Brayton interest when practical matters in connection with the mills are concerned.
HAVANA, Sept. 24. -- The Epoca, describing the present situation in Cuba, says:

Saturday's bank statement makes it less easy for Stock Exchange speculators to purvey bear "arguments." The much forecasted deficit in surplus reserves does not appear. Money-market conditions generally indicate improvement. Bankers of experience having large opportunities for observations beyond local bounds are not pessimistic; their agreement is that the outlook has become favorable.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 24. -- The most sensational sale of the year was made to-day at the track of the Louisville Fair and Driving Association, when J.C. McCoy of Kirkwood, Del., paid Scott Newman, Jr., the well-known Shelbyville turfman, $10,000 cash for Baralma, an untrained three-year-old gelding by Boreal, 2:15 3/4. The gelding has started but once in a race.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The identity of the young woman who was murdered at Falconer last night, was proved at 2 o'clock this morning by the Rev. P. Martinson, pastor of the Swedish Lutheran Church, who recognized the body as that of Miss Emily Adolphson, a member of his congregation.

MANILA, Sept. 24. -- The United States cruiser Charleston, the monitor Monterey, and the gunboats Concord and Zafiro, with marines and bluejackets from the cruiser Baltimore, left Cavite Sept. 18, and, as already cabled, proceeded to Subig Bay to destroy an insurgent cannon there.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 24. -- This evening at the residence of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Potter Palmer, Miss Julia Grant, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Frederick Dent Grant, was united in marriage to Prince Michel Cantacuzene (Count Speransky) of Russia, the services being in every detail those of the Russian Church.

MANCHESTER, Sept. 24. -- The market last week was firm and hardening, although quiet. In yarns an average business was done, American yarns showing 1/8 and Egyptians 3-16 increase for the week. Some business for India and Japan in bundles was noted. Cloth was dull, but strong. Calcutta was full, but that market bought some dhooties. Bombay, though quiet, bought some bleaching cloths.

" The critics are continually roasting us about our jokes," growled a farce-comedy specialist, who was in town last week. "I wish they would tell us where we can get some new ones and how long we can hang on to them after we get them. A good joke is harder to keep than a silver-mounted umbrella.

It is a pleasure to observe that THE TIMES aims to champion right and justice. The working of the minds that aim to control events in naval circles at Washington have failed to make their impress in the public mind.

NEWPORT, Sept. 24. -- The weekly handicap golf matches at the Newport Golf Club links, which ended Saturday, in two classes for the cups offered by the club, resulted as follows: The winner in Class A was James Stillman, whose score was, gross 86, handicap 4, net 82. The other players were W. Woodward, F.C. Havemeyer, Fred P. Sands, H. Mortimer Brooks, and Robert Rowe.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- A new mercantile agency with a capital stock of $2,000,000, with Erastus Wiman of New York as its chief promoter, will bid for patronage in the near future and will establish its Western office in Chicago, Quarters have been secured in the Woman's Temple, and business will be begun as soon as some of the minor details have been arranged.

A meeting held under the Joint auspices of the Philanthropic Committee of the Religious Society of Friends and the Young Friends' Association, to which the public was invited, was held in the Friends' Meeting House at Fifteenth Street and Rutherfurd Place, last evening, when an address was delivered by Dr. W. Evans Darby of London on "The Hague Conference -- Its Inception, Work, and Results."

With the campaign in Ohio has begun the first serious discussion of the policy of the Administration before the public. It is noteworthy that the only point in which there is any interest shown is the policy in the Philippines.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Sept. 24. -- The official reports of two battles between the Mexicans and Yaquis have just been received here Gen. Luis Torres had declared that the campaign would be suspended until October, but the Yaquis were not consulted on that point.

The clash which took place last week between City Superintendent Maxwell and the School Board of Manhattan and the Bronx over the system of licensing teachers had been anticipated for a long time. To-day Mr. Maxwell is to conduct examinations of teachers for what are known as No. 2 and heads of department licenses.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- The Executive Committee of the Civic Federation of Chicago has authorized its President, Franklin H. Head, to appoint a committee of twenty-five to organize a National civic federation. This committee is to be composed of men representing different sections of the country, and different phases of social, economic, and political questions of the day.

The Spaniard who chances to read the report of Brig. Gen. WILLIAM LUDLOW, U. S.V., commanding the Department of Havana, and Military Governor of the City of Havana, covering the history of the occupation by the United States up to June 30, and a brief supplementary report prepared Sept. 15, ought to be deeply impressed.

DOYLESTOWN, Penn., Sept. 24. -- The annual pilgrimage to the National Farm School, near here, took place to-day. The feature of the pilgrimage was the dedication of five new buildings. Several thousand persons attended the ceremonies. The National Farm School is the only one of its kind in the United States, and although sustained and controlled by Jews from all over the country, it is open to boys of all creeds and nationalities.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24. -- Louisville beat St. Louis and Cleveland in a double-header today. The St. Louis game was interesting from the oRtset, and the bat-ting or both sides was hard and opportune, There were also some sensational plays in the field. The Cleveland contest was dull, and there never was ally doubt about the result.

As the liberal policy of your paper permits of the discussion of various topics, and as one with a grievance has often to express it through the medium of the press, in order to bring said grievance to the notice of the person against whom it is directed, I wish to rebel against the entr'acte music played at some of our leading houses.

THE FRENCH GOVERNMENT SEEKING EVIDENCE AGAINST THE DUC D'ORLEANS. -- The Nationalist press of Paris asserts that the Government has instituted the secret sessions of the Senatorial High Court of Justice in order to gain time to secure evidence tending to show the existence of an agreement between Deroulede and other leaders of the leagues and the Orleanists.

A woman with a shopping bag stopped in front of one of the fancy fruit stores near the Grand Central Station yesterday, and, after tumbling about a basket of peaches and removing the tissue paper from at least a dozen choice Bartlett pears, in order to select one without the slightest sign of rust or overripeness, caught sight of a bunch of red bananas.

In your editorial of the 17th inst. under the caption "It Will Work Both Ways," you take exception to the expressed ideas of Gov. Stone relative to the methods that could be best applied by Congress to rehabilitate our merchant marine. Allow me, as one of the sufferers by its degeneracy, and with a knowledge based upon a seafaring experience of thirty-five years, to answer the queries contained in your article.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Sept. 24. -- Concerning the recent earthquake along the coast of Alaska, the Rev. Sheldon Jackson, educational agent for Alaska, writes as follows from Yakutat under date of Sept. 17:

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 24. -- The steamer Idzumi Maru brings news of terrible conflicts in progress near Canton, China, between the imperial troops and Kwang Tung rebels. In three pitched battles the rebels have defeated Viceroy Tan's soldiers, and hundreds have been killed on both sides The rebels are largely composed of West River pirates, who have succeeded in laying whole districts under tribute.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The Rev. James H. Foster and the woman, Mrs. Andrew Cox, with whom he left Plainfield, N.Y., two weeks ago, thereby causing a sensation, were complained of to the police here to-day by Superintendent Madison of the Union Rescue Mission. They came here a week ago last Wednesday from Brooklyn, and have been preaching in the streets every afternoon and evening since.

My attention has been recently called to the large number of passengers injured, either slightly or fatally, every day, who ride on the "cable railroads" in this city. It has occurred to me that a remedy might be operative that would be conducive to reducing this list of accidents very materially, and which I would suggest.

The Quebec Line steamship Madiana, which arrived yesterday from West Indian ports, brought as passengers Capt. G.W. Heath and wife and seven seamen of the American three-masted schooner Newton of Boston, which was wrecked in a hurricane on Sept. 9 in the Carribean Sea. The Captain and wife and crew were rescued from the waterlogged vessel on Sept. 13 by the British steamship Fontabelle, after four days of thrilling adventure, and landed at St. Thomas.

John McMangin, twenty-six years old, a member of the Stuyvesant Yacht Club, and living in Prospect Avenue, between One Hundred and Sixty-fifth and One Hundred and Sixty-sixth Streets, was drowned yesterday afternoon while sailing a catboat in the East River, off the kills separating Randall's Island from the Bronx, or mainland. McMangin was on his way to the annual regatta of his club.

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 24. -- The cup defender Columbia left here this morning shortly after 9 o'clock for New Rochelle, the home of C. Oliver Iselin. The crew was astir early, preparing for the start, and quite a number of people gathered in the vicinity of the Herreshoffs' to witness the departure of the yacht.

Angered by the revelation of what he considered a confidential conversation with Richard Croker, John C. Sheehan yesterday gave out a statement in which he pronounced the Tammany chief's version of their telephone talk of last Thursday false in many particulars and denounced him as a man who does not keep his word.
Mr. Moss calls the attention of those that have criticised him for not summoning Mr. PLATT to the witness stand to the fact that the inquiry is not closed.

-- What's this from Chicago? That city is envious of New York's success in the abolition of unnecessary street noises and has determined to pass and enforce statutes similar to those through which we have attained to a state of refreshing calm. Well, well, well! It's an old adage that home news comes from afar, and here is proof that the adage is true.

PRETORIA, Sept. 24. -- According to the Volkstein, the Transvaal Government has decided to return to Cecil Rhodes the fine young lion presented to the Transvaal delegates to the Agricultural Union in Cape Town about ten days ago, as it declines to have anything whatever to do with the donor

There is but little change to report in regard to men's wear woolens. The market is comparatively quiet. Cancellations have been comparatively few and revisions not serious. Prices during the week were advanced considerably over those of the openings, and held firmly. The American Woolen Company has advanced clays again, but, as they are sold up, this means nothing except that the company is keeping abreast of the wool market, which is continually advancing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- "Commercial Africa in 1899" is the title of a publication prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics. It describes present commercial conditions in Africa, and incidentally the political divisions as they now exist, and is accompanied by a map showing the boundary lines of the various colonies, protectorates, spheres of influence, and independent States of the great continent whose map has so rapidly changed during the past few years.

James O'Connell, President of the International Machinists, who had been a delegate to the British Trades Congress meeting held in Plymouth, England, spoke yesterday to the Central Federated Union of his experiences and observations at the Congress, and among the working classes in England. He did not have a high opinion of them, and said he was glad he was an American, and lived in the United States.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 24. -- As a result of the maturing of the corn crop, the opening of many new industries that depended upon that condition in Nebraska, and the enormous increase in volume in all lines of business throughout the State, an extraordinary situation prevails in this part of the West.

The Jews of this city who are interested in the Zionist movement gave a popular reception and welcome, at Cooper Union last night, to the returning American delegates to the third Zionist Congress, at Basel, Switzerland. There was a large gathering, which almost filled the hall, and one remarkable feature of the meeting was that, although it was protracted to a very late hour, not a dozen persons left until the last word was said.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 30. -- In spite of the vast difference in their aspect and conditions at the present day, the early history of South Africa and North America closely touches in several important points. Largely intermixed with the Dutch of the Transvaal as well as with the English colonies of South Africa is a race a part of which went to people what were then the British colonies of North America.

NEWPORT, Sept. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks and Mr. and Mrs. J.C. Livermore will end their Newport visit this week and go to New York for the Dewey celebration, after which they will go to Mrs. Brooks's Long Island place for the Fall months.

Patriotism and golf have been well blended for the coming Dewey Day celebrations by the Harbor Hill Golf Club, Staten Island. Unlike most clubs which have abandoned all competitions for those days, the Harbor Hill committee has prepared a most elaborate programme, and the patriotic ring attached to the trophies ought to call forth spirited contests.

Mr. GEORGE FRED WILLIAMS can congratulate himself on the influence attributed to him in the control of his party in his State. Its principles, its policies, its methods, and to a great extent its composition have been radically changed, and the change is openly recognized as due to him.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 24. -- Battery A, Indianapolis Light Artillery, which will participate in the Dewey parade, will go to New York on a special train at an expense of $5,000. It will follow its uniform custom of parading in fatigue service uniforms.

In a recent issue of your paper, a correspondent attempts to draw a parallel between the cases of Capts. Dreyfus and Carter, and the argument he presents, while no doubt logical to his own mind, is hardly substantiated by an analysis of the facts as they really exist. Will you therefore kindly permit me to encroach upon the space of your valued paper to the extent of replying briefly to this champion of Capt. Carter?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Acting Secretary Allen of the navy received a cablegram from Rear Admiral Watson to-day, giving a brief account of the engagement at Subig Bay. It is dated the 24th inst., at Manila, and says:

It is a long time since the streets of this city presented such a very animated appearance as they did yesterday. All New York and his wife, accompanied by their sisters, cousins, and aunts, from out of town, had turned out to witness the preparations for honoring the National hero, Dewey, to judge from the crowds that thronged the principal thoroughfares, and especially those forming the line of route for the parade.

A smoking sou' westerly gale that had been threatening for the past three days kicked up a formidable sea outside the bar at Sandy Hook yesterday, and the Shamrock remained at her mooring in the Horseshoe throughout the day. Storm signals were sent up at the life saving station early in the morning, and Capt. Patterson said that his anemometer registered a trifle more than twenty-five miles an hour.

The nomination of Justice BARRETT for the Supreme Court by both the parties in this city would be so excellent a thing in so many ways that it may be accepted as a public duty, the performance or neglect of which will be a test of the wisdom and essential patriotism of the party leaders.

Satin Slipper and A.N.B., two fair three-year-olds, put up one of the best finishes of the meeting at Gravesend in the Bayshore Stakes yesterday afternoon. Theirs was one of those finishes that amply repay one for a trip to the track. The race was at three-quarters of a mile, and there were six starters. Heliobas and The Pride were the choices of the players, and both were backed for considerable money.

The Boston baseball nine won from the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in a close and brilliant game. Nearly every inning furnished remarkable fielding plays. Stahl made the star play in the eighth inning and, incidentally, saved the day for the Bostons. There were two men on the bases and none out when Gleason stepped to the plate in the eighth inning.

Leopold Weil has sold for Jacob D. Butler to Arthur Gorsch the northwest corner of One Hundred and Fifty-first Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, together with the northeast corner of the same street and St. Nicholas Place, making in all a plot 93 by 92 by 80 by 65, on which the buyer will erect a seven-story apartment house.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- The officials of the Foreign Office this evening gave out the text of the letter the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, sent to the British High Commissioner in South Africa, Sir Alfred Milner, dated Sept. 22. The British reply expresses regret that her Majesty's offer, No. 5, of Sept. 8, had been refused, and says:

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- Upon the occasion today of the funeral of M. Scheurer-Kestner, an ex-Vice President of the French Senate, who died Sept. 20, the day pardon was granted to ex-Capt. Dreyfus, whose steadfast champion Scheurer-Kestner had been from the outset of the revision movement, several speeches were delivered at the Eastern Railroad Station.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Two important dispatches from Gen. Otis at Manila were made public by the War Department today. The first indicates that the insurgents on the Island of Negros are about to recognize the authority of the United States, An election in Negros will be held on the 2d of October. The dispatch follows:

It is a pity that the authors of the new farce or extravaganza called "A Stranger in a Strange Land," produced at the Manhattan Theatre last night, had not acquired a fuller knowledge of the rudiments of the playwright's craft before they put together the comic ideas, ancient and modern, that seemed to them sufficient material for a marketable play.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- With the average of 16.84 knots to her credit, the United States first-class battleship Kearsarge, the latest and greatest addition to the navy, ended her official speed trial this afternoon, a trial successful in every detail. The run over the Cape Ann course came up to the expectations of the Kearsarge's builders, the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, and delighted the official representatives of the Government beyond measure.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 25. -- The Princeton football team will line up for the first time for real football on Wednesday. Langdon Lea, head coach, devoted his time to-day to trying the candidates for the line positions. Duer and McClave, the latter of whom has been put on at end, distinguished themselves to-day.

The movement of the City Club to secure the nomination of candidates for the bench pledged not to contribute to any political party is admirable in its purpose and on lines' that THE TIMES has urged for many years.

HAVANA, Sept. 25. -- The election of delegates to the Municipal Committees has taken place, the voting tables being well attended. In some instances there was an utter lack of order, the crowd taking charge of the tables, and those coming actually snatching the cards from others who were about to vote against the candidate of the former.

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 95. -- A fire in Kaplan's big tenement house, on Second Street, near Mercer, in this city at 3 o'clock this morning caused a panic among the twenty families who occupy it. They escaped in their night clothes, and saved few of their possessions. The building was wrecked. Some of the tenants were almost suffocated by the smoke.

NEWPORT, Sept. 25. -- George Gordon King has sold his villa, known as Edgehill, situated on Harrison and Beacon Hill Road, to Mrs. Herman B. Duryea. This property comprises about twenty-two acres of land, a stone dwelling and stable, and also a stone landing pier in Brenton's Cove, together with a way leading from Harrison Avenue to it between the estates of Henry White and the late William F. Burden.

Rosina and Augustin Neuville, who were partners, as Mme. Augustin Neuville, players and theatrical managers, of 9 East Fourteenth Street, have filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities of $11,442, contracted from 1892 to 1897. They owe $6,048 for printing, $1,562 for borrowed money, and $343 for salaries.

The disposition of Republican newspapers to speak of the outlook in Maryland as doubtful must be encouraging to the Democrats of that State. Analysis of the reasons given for this reluctant Republican admission might justify unfavorable prediction for the Republican cause.
A correspondent for whom we have the highest respect, and whose criticisms we know to be made in good faith, writes to us as follows:

The Municipal Assembly, or, rather, a self-appointed delegation from that body, succeeded yesterday in holding up the Reception Committee of the Dewey Committee, with the result that fourteen members of the local legislature will ride in carriages a short distance behind the guest of honor and ahead of the escorting column.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 25. -- A vestibule train of ten coaches will leave Chicago to-morrow evening over the Lake Shore Road, carrying the Dewey Invitation Committee to New York, where it will invite the Admiral to Chicago for the Fall festival. The train will leave half an hour behind the New York Limited, and will keep up the schedule of the limited all the way.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- President William Bliss of the Boston and Albany to-day denied the statement attributed to the Protective Committee that his name would appear at the head of a ticket nominating a Board of Directors opposed to the lease to the New York Central Railroad. This denial is as follows:

"Veteran's" noble letter and its reply in the editorial, both published in THE TIMES of Sept. 14 regarding the Dewey reception, voice the thoughts of millions -- no doubt of Dewey himself, that the parade without Dyer and Coghlan and Woods and Walker and Wildes, will be a scene of sad disappointment instead of a scene of splendor.

The press dispatches from Paris told us yesterday morning, on the authority of Le Petit Bleu, that Col. JOUAUST, the President of the court-martial at Rennes, voted for the acquittal of Capt. ALFRED DREYFUS.
AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 25. -- Judging from reports reaching here to-day from Oritiz, State of Sonora, Mexico, the Yaqui Indian war is rapidly growing worse instead of abating.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The three Governments interested in Samoa -- Great Britain, Germany, and the United States -- have been considering the claims arising out of the bombardment last Summer, in which the American forces under Admiral Kautz, and the British forces under Capt. Sturdee, participated.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 25. -- Five hundred negroes heard Booker T. Washington, President of the Tuscogee Normal and Industrial School for Negroes, at Tuscogee, Ala., deliver an address here to-night on the "Race Problem in the Light of European Travel."

The article on "The Struggle for Supremacy" in the current number of The Fortnightly Review, from which we made copious extracts on Sunday, is the most elaborate unofficial exposition of the British case we have seen and more elaborate than any official exposition. Indeed, nothing is more remarkable in the official proceedings than the absence of any explanation which shows "a decent respect to the opinions of mankind."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 25. -- The fifth annual meeting of the Louisville Driving and Fair Association began this afternoon, and, notwithstanding the cold rain which began to fall about the time the horses were ready to score for the first heat in the 2:24 trot, the attendance was large. Summaries:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 25. -- The public wedding of Miss Julia Grant, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Frederick Dent Grant and granddaughter of Mrs. U.S. Grant, and Prince Michel Cantacuzene (Count Speransky) of Russia occurred in All Saints' Memorial Chapel this noon.

At the close of yesterday's market quotations were knocked down somewhat. New stories intended to be depressing were in circulation. Adroit manipulation showed. Speculators on the short side were aggressive. Incidentally, money rates were marked up. Charges on call were rushed to 15 per cent., though they staid there but for a moment and fell back to what had been prevailing quotations promptly.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25. -- The game to-day with Louisville was dull and monotonous. Out of thirteen base hits and six bases on balls the visitors managed to score sixteen runs, winning easily. Score:

The Mazet committee resumed its investigation yesterday, instead of to-day, because of the desire of the members to take part in the Dewey celebration. It will meet again to-day, and then adjourn until Monday next. It carried out the programme agreed upon last week, and commenced its inquiry into the political assessment of Judges.

The Robinson Building, an eight-story brick structure at East Broadway, Gouverneur, and Division Streets, occupied by a score of sweatshops, was damaged by fire between midnight and 1 o'clock this morning to the extent of about $20,000.

Denunciations hurled at Senator Platt and Lemuel Ely Quigg by Abraham Gruber, leader of the Twenty-first District, were cheered to the echo at the meeting of the new Republican County Committee in the Murray Hill Lyceum last evening. The committee met for the purpose of organizing, and after applauding Mr. Gruber's attack it re-elected Mr. Quigg President for the fourth time by a vote of 211 to 5.

Raids on six alleged gambling houses were made last night by Anthony Comstock. Since Sept. 14 he has had two of his men going from one gambling house to another securing evidence against the dealers and their assistants. On the evidence thus obtained he got warrants from Magistrate Brann, in the Jefferson Market Court; Magistrate Deuel, in the West Fifty-fourth Street Court, and Magistrate Pool, in the Yorkville Court.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 25. -- Mail dispatches from the Republic of Colombia bring intelligence of the grave political and financial state of affairs there. For some time past the revenue has been falling more and more short of expenditures. This applied to the different so-called "departments," as well as to the national finances. Nowhere has expenditure balanced with revenue.

Is it not about time that the reputable element of this great city arose in its indignation and entered a powerful protest against the further injection of Crokerism into the civic pageant that is being prepared for the welcome of Admiral Dewey?

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 25. -- The man who registered at the United States Hotel in Boston last evening as H.W. Haley of West Concord, N.H., and who was found dead in his room with his throat cut to-day, was Dr. Herman Wadsworth Hayley, instructor of Latin in Wesleyan University, and a member of the Faculty.

Eldridge G. Allen, who had been successively Superintendent of the Ohio River Railroad, the New York and New England Railroad, the Hudson division of the New York Central Railroad, and who for several years was General Superintendent of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, was found dead in bed in his room in the Grand Union Hotel at noon yesterday.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- A head-end collision between a New York Central passenger train and a freight train occurred this morning at 6 o'clock just west of 01. d Flat Bottom Bridge, about a half mile west of the city, and as a result three people are dead, two fatally injured, and four seriously injured.

With only two days remaining before the first of the Dewey celebration holidays, householders and occupants in the fashionable districts up town, and especially those whose residences are on the line of Saturday's parade, find themselves with more work on their hands than they had any idea of.

That the contest in the Protestant Episcopal Church precipitated last Spring over the ordination of the Ray. Dr. Charles A. Briggs is again to be waged fiercely between the High Church and Broad Church factions and prolonged indefinitely was made apparent yesterday afternoon at a meeting held at the home of the Rev. Dr. Edward H. Van Winkle, 25 West Ninth Street, by the adherents of the former faction.

The unexpected arrival of Admiral Dewey threw the various and several committees in charge of the celebration into a state of confusion bordering on hysterics. From the Acting Chairman, President Guggenheimer of the Council, down to "Wiskinskie" Donegan, every one "went up in the air" and remained there throughout the greater part of the day.

The cruiser Olympia with Admiral Dewey and his gallant officers and men is now in this port. She arrived early yesterday morning, two days ahead of the time she was expected and found both the weather and the various committees and other officials charged with the conduct of the celebration unprepared.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Not the slightest surprise was expressed at the Navy Department over the arrival of the Olympia before her scheduled time. One of the officers on duty in the department remarked dryly that Dewey had a habit of surprising people,

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The general feeling, including that of the pro-Boers, as indicated by articles in the afternoon newspapers to-day, is that the published dispatch of the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, to the British High Commissioner in South Africa, Sir Alfred Milner, clears the way for peace if the Boers desire it.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The first intimation of the death of John Sleeper Clarke, the American comedian, who died suddenly at his home, Westbourne House Surbiton-on-Thames, on Monday, received at the Strand Theatre, which he owned, came from his American relatives. This led to the belief that he died in America as he had not been actively connected with the Strand for some time.

TRINIDAD, W.I., Sept. 18. -- Only a few weeks ago it was officially announced from Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, to the outside world, that the "dove of peace had again found a resting place in the Republic of Venezuela," but if it effected a landing at all its rest has been of extremely short duration.

A special committee of the Rapid Transit Railroad Commission appointed to revise the form of contract for the construction of an underground railroad met yesterday in the law office of Commissioner George L. Rives. Besides Mr. Rives, the members of this committee are President Alexander E. Orr, Commissioner John H. Starin and Controller Coler.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Prebyterians from all over the world are arriving here to attend the Pan-Presbyterian Council, which opens its sittings at the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church to-morrow. More than 400 delegates are expected to be in attendance upon this, the seventieth general council.

-- If anything could make the citizens of this country regret their recent manifestations of a new and kinder feeling toward Great Britain it would be the fact that there are Englishmen -- only a few, probably, but a few are too many -- who can misstate and misinterpret facts with the cool insolence shown in the letter from Ottawa which we published Sunday over the most incongruous signature of "Fair Play."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- A dispatch has been received from Manila by the War Department stating that Gen. Snyder attacked the position of the insurgents five miles west of Cebu and destroyed seven forts and quite a number of smooth-bore cannon. The insurgents were utterly routed, and Snyder returned with his force to Cebu.
It was a curious meeting of the Republican County Committee that applauded Mr. GRUBER'S savage attack on Mr. QUIGG and all that he represents and then elected Mr. QUIGG as Chairman by 211 votes to 5.

This town is in a ferment of enthusiasm over the coming of DEWEY. Nothing else is talked about with so much animation. The decorators who are hiding commonplace walls under flags and bunting and pictures of Admiral DEWEY and his exploits work with a zeal equal to that of the sculptors and painters who leave done so much to make New York's Dewey celebration an almost incomparable success.
The following official announcement of the yacht division of the naval parade on Friday has been issued.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Additional subscriptions to the Dewey home fund have been received by Assistant Secretary Vanderlip as follows: ...
Metropolitan Street Railway's earnings on Monday reported to be the largest in the history of the company.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 26. -- The financial projectors of the American Window Glass Company met here to-day and allotted the stock for the new combination. It was decided that all subscribers for stock for $10,000 or less receive the full amount, and all ever that sum are to be shaded 10 per cent. The capitalization of the company is $17,000,000, and the result of the meeting to-day indicates that the stock has been oversubscribed.

HAVANA, Sept. 26. -- "There will not be a general strike," said Gen. Ludlow this evening. "I have sufficient assurances to satisfy me on this point." Civil Governor Rivera says the matter is out of his hands, and entirely within the jurisdiction of the military authorities.

COLUMBUS, Miss., Sept. 26. -- Lowndes County has another shooting affray to add to the long list of crimes that have been committed in the county within the past twelve months. As a result of it one of the best known citizens of the eastern section of the county lies dying, and another prominent man of the same section is in jail awaiting the former's death to stand trial on the charge of murder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Navy Department to-day received from Admiral Watson a cablegram announcing the capture and destruction of the gunboat Urdaneta reported in the press dispatches of yesterday. Another dispatch from the Admiral states that he learns through insurgent sources that her commander, Naval Cadet Welborn C. Wood, was killed in the action.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:

E.H. Sothern will discontinue "The King's Musketeer" at Daly's Theatre probably on Saturday night, Oct. 14. This play will be followed on Monday night by the production of Leo Ditrichstein's first original play, entitled "The Song of the Sword," which received its first trial performance in Providence last Spring under the title of "The Knight of the Garter."

A number of small boys and girls of the east side had a fine time at Mooney's stables, on Twenty-sixth Street, last evening, where Mrs. Myles Standish, President of Our Animal Protective League, gave an interesting talk upon animals, with stereopticon illustrations.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 26. -- Leonard B. Imboden, President of the Planters' Bank, a "wildcat" concern, suppressed by the State officials several months ago, was to-day found guilty in the Criminal Court of forging a draft for $15,000 with which he hoped to get a false credit for his bank. He was sentenced to ten years in the penitentiary.

All roads by land and sea lead to New York this week. And everybody, it is safe to say, is headed that way -- that is, it seems so, though everybody knows scores of persons who say they wouldn't on any account be found in such a crowd, such a mob as is sure to be in every nook and corner, public and private, of New York City.

In the afternoon, sitting in his cabin on the Olympia, Admiral Dewey talked freely of his experiences in the Philippines, although he carefully refrained from expressing definite views at to the course that ought to be pursued in the prosecution of the war, or as to any matter of administrative or political policy. When asked about the Philippine question, he said:

The alleged gamblers arrested in the raids by Anthony Comstock on Monday night were arraigned in the police courts yesterday. In the Jefferson Market Court David Sullivan, James Jones, and Charles Brown, who were arrested at the Adirondack Club, 508 Sixth Avenue, were held for examination by request of Mr. Comstock, who had cases in other courts to look after.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- President Hyde's paper of last night, regarding theological seminaries, has stirred up no little feeling among the delegates to the International Congregational Council. Many have felt the Bowdoin President's speech to have been in the nature of an attack on the seminaries. In consequence, the discussion at the close of this morning's regular programme was devoted to talking over the subject matter of last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The announcement that Archbishop Chapelle of New Orleans has been chosen Apostolic Delegate for the Philippines attracts much attention in official and clerical quarters.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26. -- The friends and relatives of Thomas Janney, Jr., one of the prominent young society men of this city, are very uneasy concerning the young man's safety, and grave apprehensions are felt lest be has met with foul play or has been accidentally drowned.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Attorney General Griggs has written the following reply to a letter recently received from Gov. Pingree of Michigan:
NEWPORT, Sept. 26. -- Mrs. George W. Wales has closed her cottage and has gone to her Winter home, in Boston.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union of the Nineteenth Assembly District met at the Sherman Square Hotel last evening and after a secret discussion of two hours decided to place in nomination Perez M. Stewart for the Assembly against Robert Mazet, and Francis W. Aymar for Alderman. Fifteen members of the committee were present.

Perhaps the regret is sentimental, but it is natural enough to be disappointed instead of enthusiastic about the trial speed of the battleship Kearsarge. She made a record of 17.52 knots on Monday, with wind and tide in her favor, and one of 16.55 under less favorable conditions. Her average speed for the run was 16.84 knots.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 27. -- The announcement that Gov. Roosevelt would be present at the Queens County Fair here to-day and also make an address attracted 12,000 visitors to the inclosure, and he received a hearty welcome.

Scheyer, Pots Co., manufacturers of ladies' cloaks, capes, and suits at 24 and 26 West Fourth Street, made an assignment yesterday to Herman Liebmann. The partners are Moses Scheyer, Theodore Pots, and Edward Stern. The deed was signed by Messrs. Scheyer and Pots only. It was stated in the deed that Mr. Stern had absconded and abandoned the property of the firm.

CALULET, Isle of Luzon, Aug. 16. -- The battle of Hernando, as the attack and capture of the rebel intrenchments north and west of the town will probably be called, has been fought and won, and while our losses were not insignificant, we know that the enemy lost heavily.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 27. -- The musical festival continued with a symphony concert this afternoon. Beethoven's fifth symphony, Goldmark's Sakuntala overture, and Schubert's "Hymn to the Almighty," sung by Ffrangcon Davis, made up the programme.
S. Herbert Wolfe has been appointed examiner of the Minnesota Insurance Department.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The War Office has ordered the whole transport and supply for an army corps to prepare to proceed to the Cape. This is a very important order, and implies the early dispatch of an army corps. The men of twenty-five companies are being medically examined at Aldershot to-day.
BOSTON, Sept. 27. -%'illis of Boston was unsteady to-day, giving eight' bases on balls and making five wild pitches. Boston batted ikcFarland out of the box in two innings. Score:

It would be an act of supreme folly for the Democratic Party to name again William Jennings Bryan for President, for he would be doomed to a more humiliating defeat than he met with before. Call himself whatever he will, he is not a Democrat in the Jeffersonian use of the term. Jefferson advocated a sound financial policy, not favoring the coining of silver in a ratio unequal to gold.

Jockey Spencer, who is under contract to ride for James R. Keene, and who is really one of the best boys in the saddle in the East when he wants to be, was at last brought up with a round turn by the Stewards of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday, when he put up one of the most shameful rides of his career on Mr. Keene's filly Pink Domino.

CALCUTTA, Sept. 27. -- After gathering at the head of the bay, the storm moved north, giving heavy rain in Calcutta, Dinajpur, Rangpur, and Jalpaiguri, and falling with the greatest fury at Darjeeling. Simultaneously another storm gathered at Rangpur and passed westward from Purnea to Monghyr.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The subject of higher criticism, so called, promises to engross much of the attention of the Pan-Presbyterian Alliance, which opened its first session here to-day. It was directly adverted to both in the opening sermon of the Rev. Dr. John De Witt, and subsequently in the formal address of the President of the Council, the Rev. Dr. J. Marshall Lang, of Glasgow, Scotland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Attorney General Griggs to-day gave a hearing to Wayne MacVeagh, counsel in the court-martial case of Capt. O.M. Carter of the army. Mr. MacVeagh asked for a judicial hearing in the case, saying that if the President affirmed the proceedings, he would be guilty of an act of great cruelty and wrong.

NEWPORT, Sept. 27. -- Robert L. Gerry closed his father's cottage, Sea Verge, today and went to New York. Mr. Gerry will entertain a party of Newport friends on the Electra during the Dewey celebration.

At a meeting of the Board of Public Improvements, yesterday, Louis A. Risse, the Chief Topographical Engineer, submitted a plan for a public park, elliptical in form, at the intersection of One Hundred and Tenth Street and Seventh Avenue, and suggested that the present Dewey arch be perpetuated at that point.

The New Yorks and Brooklyns played a postponed game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, the leaders winning out with a timely bast hit by Anderson in the seventh inning. The game, however, was not won on its merits, as the bad work of the umpires deprived the locals of what chance they did have.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 27. -The fo0tball -4eason was opened on rinklin Fteld to-ilay' the TJniverity of Pennsylvania, team defeating the . Franklin and Marshall College eleven of Lancaster, Penn., by a score of 48 to 0, in twenty-minute halves.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Daily Telegraph publishes the following from its special correspondent in Cape Town:
Election of Grant B. Schley a Director of the New York Ontario and Western, succeeding his former partner, the late John G. Moore.

Your Sunday paper quotes the views of Cardinal Moran about Protestantism in Hawaii. The Cardinal is often mistaken in his views. It is a fact that Congregationalism gave the natives much truth and higher ideals. Its first missionaries were often noble men. They made many converts, and among these were Hawaiians of sincere and honest lives.
KEENE, N.H., Sept. 27. -- This city went more or less crazy over Dewey last night, and the clash that resulted between the citizens and the authorities is not ended yet.

Nebraska, according to the last election in that State, was Populist by a plurality of 3,422 in a whole vote of 189,984. In 1897 the fusion of Populists and Democrats carried the State by 13,619 in a whole vote of 194,251. According to the reports of the Department of Agriculture Nebraska's corn crop in 1896 was 298,599,638 bushels, valued at $38,800,000.

The schools of the Long Island Interscholastic Athletic League have opened their doors again and the athletes of these institutions are preparing for active work on the gridiron. It is very early, however, to determine which schools will make the most vigorous bid for the championship of the league.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The yearly meeting of the stockholders of the Illinois Central Railroad was held here to-day. The annual report was submitted and approved. The terms of three Director -- Stuyvesant Fish, E.H. Harriman, and J.J. Astor -- having expired, a vote resulted in their re-election. J.D. Cutting of New York was elected a Director to fill the unexpired term of the late Robert Goelet of New York.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 27. -2'he last o2 the seasov's races of the Norwalk-Westport Driving Association were held at the fair grounds this afternoon. Two races %were run off for purses of $100. The summary follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The special committee appointed to acquaint Admiral Dewey with the plans for his reception in Washington left individually for New York to-night.

-- Violating for once the rule which consigns to the waste basket all anonymous communications, we will acknowledge the receipt and reveal the substance of a letter signed "Work-a-Days." At the top of it is pasted an advertisement announcing that $5 a week will be paid to an elderly man with experience as a bookkeeper and collector and ready to furnish a bond.

HELENA, Mont., Sept. 27. -- Meagre reports have been received in Helena of a bad wreck that occurred on the Great Northern Road about 5 o'clock this morning a short distance west of Glasgow. Five men were killed outright and two others seriously injured. The names of none of the killed or injured, all of whom were employes of the company, can be learned here.

Rockaway defeated Lakewood in a somewhat one-sided game of polo yesterday on the field of the Somerset Country Club, at Bernardsville, N.J. The Rockaway Club was represented by its second team, and won by 11 goals to 1. The teams were equally matched, each having the aggregate handicap of 12 goals. The severe defeat of Lakewood may partially be accounted for on the plea of lack of practice.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27. -- For a time to-day the proposed trip of the Ohio National Guard to New York to participate in the Dewey celebration was abandoned, but, owing to the generosity of Gov. Bushnell and John R. McLean, the trip will now be made.
LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Important light is thrown on the situation by a frank statement to-day by Sir Walter Peace, Agent General for Natal in London, who fought against the Boers in former years.

Gen. Howard Carroll, the Chairman of the Committee on Water Parade, which takes place to-morrow afternoon, yesterday gave out the official list of vessels which will take part in that demonstration, together with the formation of the line. In the line there will be 14 naval vessels of all classes, 5 revenue cutters, 3 army transports, and 1 army hospital ship, representing the Federal Government.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Cornell University this Fall will open with a freshman class surpassing in numbers that of any preceding year. The precise official total will not be obtainable from the register for some days, but the registration is even now much larger than in previous years.
MANILA, Sept. 27. -- Aguinaldo has issued a decree inviting Filipino deserters to return within a month, in which case they will be pardoned.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, who sailed from Yokohama on Sept. 19 homeward bound, is expected to arrive at San Francisco about the middle of next week. He will cross this continent in a private car as rapidly as possible, and very soon after he reaches New York the contents of Cornelius Vanderbilt's will are to be made public.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Ten days ago Mrs. Stanley G. Fowler left her home at Pine Bluff, N.C., with her seven-year-old son. Her husband has been searching for her, and recently succeeded in locating her at Matteawan.

Free and easy manipulation in the money market does not provide as many scarecrows as manipulators planned. There is a fashion of squeezes in call loan rates now -- yesterday a quotation of 20 per cent. being made. On Monday 15 was the top figure, and Tuesday's record was at 17.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27. -- The annual meeting of the Kentucky Distillers' Association was held behind closed doors at the Galt House, and officers for the coming year were elected as follows: President -- John B. Thompson, Harrodsburg; Vice President -- I.W. Bernheim, Louisville; Secretary -- T.M. Gilmore, Louisville. The members of the Executive Committee are E.M. Babbitt, Louisville; John F. Pogue, Maysville; Max Selliger, Louisville; R. Monarch, Owensborough.

We have received a certain number of communications from grieved or disgusted Britons inquiring how we can possibly take such an unfriendly tone as the writers insist that we do about the procedures of the British in the Transvaal. Some of these we have printed. Others we have not the least intention of printing.

I read with a good deal of interest the editorial "French Flats," in to-day's paper and will answer why medium class flats are built so that they are "a disgrace to American civilization." Please consider the following figures:

William A. Brady, who is directly interested in the management of the Manhattan Theatre, with Florence Ziegfeld, Jr., and in various other theatrical enterprises, entered into a contract yesterday with the Robert Blei Syndicate, who are the lessees of the Koster Bial Music Hall, to become the managing director of the latter house and immediately to assume charge of the music hall.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 27. -- Lord Minto Governor General of Canada, accompanied by Lady Minto, will leave for New York on Saturday next, or, at the latest, on Monday. Lady Minto will sail for England Oct. 7, but the Governor General goes to see the international yacht races, to which he has been invited by Sir Thomas Lipton and Sir Roderick Cameron.

HAVANA, Sept. 27. -- In consequence of the proclamation of Gen Ludlow yesterday the backbone of the strike is broken. The men lost their bearings, owing to their inability to hold meetings. Some struck, but others remained uncertain. The military authorities arrested twenty-one leaders and held them in custody, which largely assisted in demoralizing the movement, as there were no alternate leaders ready to issue orders.

J. W. Seligman Co. announced yesterday the engagement at London in open market of 150,000 in gold, which will be shipped on Saturday, so that the tide of gold now setting westward amounts, with Lazard Freres' engagement of $1,000,000, to $1,750,000. The firm declined to talk of the shipment except to class it as an ordinary business transaction by which they profit.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 27. -- Cincinnati to-night is confronted with the possibility of a street railway strike surpassing in magnitude and severity any similar movement known to an American city. All the demands made by the 2,100 employes were summarily rejected by the Board of Directors to-day.

The Diocesan Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church began its first day's session yesterday morning at the Church of the Incarnation in Madison Avenue. Contrary to expectation on the part of a great many, no mention was made of the Briggs controversy, nor was there a debate of any sort on the burning subject of the selection of a Standing Committee for the coming year.
B.M. Strauss Co. have sold for Zimmerman Valente, builders, for about $29,000 each, the two five-story flats 54 and 58 West One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, each 25 by 100.11.

The rush and bustle due to the preparations for to-morrow and Saturday's holidays are nearing the acute stage, and the crowded sidewalks, hotels, and restaurants in the up-town districts made the city rather uncomfortable yesterday for resident New Yorkers. The avenue, looking from the crest of Murray Hill southward and northward resembles a deep new sluiceway, walled on either side by pine boards.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27. -- Amid the enthusiastic plaudits of a big crowd at the fair grounds to-day the little brown gelding Bumps, owned by W.K. Billings of Chicago, trained by C.R. Bently, and driven by W.L. Snow, broke the world's wagon pacing record of 2:04 3/4, held by Joe Patchen. The mile was paced in 2:03 1/4, a second and a half Letter than the record. Summary:
CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- In order to placate the labor organizations Charles Truax formally resigned to-day as President of the Fall Festival Association.

In accordance with an agreement made by the managers of all the print-cloth mills at Fall River, a fixed scale of prices for all goods thirty-three inches in width and under will be maintained up to Jan. 1, 1900. This is an extension of an agreement already made which ended this week. The scale commences at 2 3/4 cents for regular "sixty-four square, twenty-eight-inch" goods, and no lower prices will be quoted.
