The Republican City Committee met last night in the Murray Hill Lyceum and organized by the election of officers and an Executive Committee. The only hitch in the work of organization occurred when it became the turn of the delegations from Kings County to name their members of the Executive Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Figures received at the State Department from the German Bureau of Statistics through Vice Consul General Hanauer, at Frankfort, show that last year Germany imported from the United States more goods and products than from any other country, the total being $208,785,500.

When our egregious Municipal Assembly voted $150,000 to receive and entertain Admiral DEWEY, a cold shiver ran down the spine of every New Yorker who was old enough to remember the time when our old "co-ordinate branch" had the power of appropriating money without the assent of a Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

There is no necessity for inviting anybody to do honor to Admiral DEWEY. Everybody is doing that all over this country, and very unanimously and cordially right here in New York. The pride in him for his work in Manila Bay on May 1, 1898, has increased rather than diminished with the lapse of time.

Your recent editorial article advocating a general support of Judge Barrett at the coming election was most sensible and opportune. At his last election he was the choice of all parties. Can there be any question that his judicial career has justified such expression of public admiration and confidence, or any reason why it should not be renewed?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Census Director Merriam is arranging the questions which shall be asked in the census of 1900. In many respects they differ from those asked in previous years. One of the most curious of the changes is a requirement that agents shall ask, not the age of the person examined, but his age on his last birthday.
LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The Press Association issues the following statement this evening:

I desire to thank "Property Owner" for his letter of the 19th inst. on "Seventh Avenue" and THE TIMES for its publication. Doubtless it was received by your many readers along the avenue like some far-off dream. Certainly no one could realize the actuality of having any one take an interest in this avenue.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Daily Mail says that Mrs. Langtry (Mrs. Hugo Gerald de Bathe) is still writing her reminiscences, which will be published about Christmas.

The Parkville Handicap for three-year-olds, at six furlongs, was the stake feature of a good card at Gravesend yesterday. It furnished an excellent race and a sensational finish. A.N.B. was made favorite, with Satin Slipper a strong second choice and Heliobas also was well played. The field was sent off in the first break to a good start, and Satin Slipper and Heliobas rushed out to make the running.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 28. -- Arrangements have been made by the citizens of Knoxville to give a public reception to Lieut. Valentine Nelson of Admiral Dewey's flagship Olympia about Oct. 9, when he and his wife will be the guest of his mother and other relatives in this city.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- As the Second Battalion of Grenadiers embarked on a transport at Gibraltar, for London, this afternoon, they received a "hurry call," ordering them to proceed to the Cape, for which place they start to-morrow.

In honoring Admiral DEWEY to-day with all forms of public appreciation and approval that have suggested themselves, the City and State of New York, discharging for the Nation a duty that is esteemed a great privilege and honor, does not forget that in acclaiming the famous Admiral it is testifying to its renewed admiration for and confidence in the navy.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 28. -- Amos L. Allen was nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the First Maine District, in convention here to-day. In his speech of acceptance he came out squarely in favor of supporting the President in the prosecution of the war in the Philippines. The nominee was formerly private secretary to Thomas B. Reed.
Increase of $97,178 in Burlington's surplus for August, making an increase of $547,793 since July 1.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 28. -- Gen. Shaw, National Commander in Chief of the G.A.R., in prefacing his address to the veterans at the State reunion to-day spoke of the now famous controversy of the G.A.R. with the Dewey parade managers. He characterized those having the big parade in charge as "narrow minded blunderers, clothed with a little brief authority."
MADRID, Sept. 28. -- The Spanish Cabinet will resign to-morrow as the result of irreconcilable differences between ministers regarding proposals for national defence.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- E.J. Brown, who eloped three weeks ago from Toronto with Mrs. Violet Holden, committed suicide here to-day by shooting himself because he could not bear the woman's remorse. She and her two children are penniless and are being cared for by the police. They arrived early in September and took rooms at the Continental registering as Mr. and Mrs. Holand. They soon moved to the Queen's Hotel.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Capt. Streeter, who for years has held out, on a plot of land formed by dumpings in the lake, against many legal attacks to dispossess him, was to-day, with a number of his followers, indicted by the Grand Jury, charged with conspiracy and conduct calculated to incite riot.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- President Jacob Gould Schurman of Cornell University was accorded an enthusiastic reception by the students and members of the Faculty when he appeared in University Armory to-day to deliver his annual address, which was devoted to the Philippines. An audience of 2,500 was present.

Had the old Florentine painter, Piero di Cosimo, set out to view the decorations of New York at the present time for hints on color, as he used to look at a festa in his own city, it is to be feared that he would have wanted to close his eyes, as it was his habit to stuff his ears. New York is not "as brilliant as a Titian," as some of the newspapers say.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28. -- The home team found Waddell's pitching easy to hit today. Score:

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The Echo to-day says the Greek Government was informed yesterday that the severe shock of earthquake around Smyrna killed 1,000 persons, injured 800, and demolished 2,000 houses and two villages.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 28. -- The inhabitants of Canderave and Poollata, about 150 miles southeast of Arequipa, Peru, have been kept in almost constant alarm since Aug. 15 by seismic disturbances in that district.

The net result of the various meetings and other methods of collection is $210, now on deposit in this city for Mrs. Baker's benefit. I hold, in addition, $88, the sum of donations sent to me. The disagreement of the parties assuming responsibility for bringing the family North, the consequent public distrust, and the final abandonment of the original purpose, have been made known through the columns of the daily press.
CALCUTTA, Sept. 28. -The Methodists vhose stations and schools have suffered from the earthquake are American missionaries.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 28. -- The following is an exact transcript of the letter from President Callaway of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company to the President of the Boston and Albany Railroad Company, defining the position of the Central Company in the matter of the Boston and Albany lease, which was read before the stockholders of the Boston and Albany Company at their meeting here yesterday:

Major Gen. Charles F. Roe, as Chairman of the Committee on Land Parade, yesterday issued a general order in regard to the principal feature of to-morrow's celebration. In this order the names and positions of the organizations participating in the parade are for the first time fully and officially set forth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- In his latest report on conditions in the Far East Consul General Wildman, at Hongkong, says: ...
Active "Lily White" Republicans (the white men's faction of the party) of Louisiana say that they will put a ticket for State officers in the field at the next election.

A picturesque figure abut the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday was Major Gen. J. Warren Keifer of Ohio, who is to command the brigade of Spanish war veterans of Greater New York in the land parade to-morrow. The General, who was Speaker of the Forty-seventh Congress, always wears a silk hat and a swallow-tail coat.

MANILA, Sept. 28. -- Gen. MacArthur entered Porac after half an hour's fighting. The American loss was slight, and the insurgent loss is not known. The enemy fled northward. When the Americans entered the town they found it entirely deserted.

A freight train of the Long Island Railroad ran down and wrecked Open Trolley Car 487 of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company at Foster and Gravesend Avenues, Parkville, yesterday morning. There were twelve persons in the trolley car at the time of the collision. The motorman was John Tammany of 1,414 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, and the conductor was Thomas Burns of 98 Wyckoff Street.

The programme arranged for to-day's part of the Dewey celebration includes the formal welcome to the city of the Admiral by the Mayer at 11 o'clock, the naval parade this afternoon, and the illuminated water pageant on both rivers and the upper bay, and fireworks displays all over the city to-night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Assistant Secretary Spaulding has approved the following rules and regulations for the government and orderly management of all water craft upon the occasion of the coming international yacht races. The rules were submitted by the Regatta Committee of the New York Yacht Club, with the approval of Capt. R.D. Evans, United States Navy, the officer in charge of the patrol fleet:

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- The first formal session of the Twenty-seventh Biennial Conference of the Lutheran General Council was held here to-day, 195 delegates, representing 400,000 communicants in every part of the continent, being present.

In wandering through the old Catholic Cemetery on Main Street, in Baton Rouge, La., some years ago, I happened upon a blackened headstone, which aroused my curiosity. Brushing aside the tangled growth I read the following inscription:

A man was killed, three houses were wrecked, and nearly a dozen others were damaged by an explosion of gas in East Fifty-sixth Street a few minutes before 8 o'clock yesterday morning. Fire followed the explosion, and it was nearly noon before the residents of the disturbed block recovered from the state of panic into which they were thrown by fear of further disasters.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Times applies to President Kruger and the crisis in South Africa a poem by Rudyard Kipling, published in its columns to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- Seymour to-day gave ten bases on balls, and struck out eleven batters. He was unsteady at times, but when he did locate the plate the Philadelphias could not hit him. Prince Ranjitsinhji and several of his English cricketers witnessed the game. Darkness stopped the play at the end of the eighth inning. Attendance, 2,878, Score:

The Joint Committee on Taxation created by the Legislature at its last session to search for and report upon needed amendments to the tax laws of the State met yesterday in this city and, after organizing, adjourned to meet again on Monday, Oct. 9, when the real work of the investigation will be begun.

Among the delegates who met at Chicago to discuss the general problem of trusts none was more fitted for the work than Prof. JOHN BATES CLARK, the political economist of Columbia University. He writes for the current number of The Independent an "account of its results."

A communication appears in your last Sunday's issue over the signature of A.C. Adams, headed "Would Limit Dividends," in which the writer suggests a remedy for one of the alleged evils of trusts. The evil referred to is in "restricting the number of employes, and invariably reducing the scale of wages, so that large dividends can be paid."

Not since the naval parade of 1892 has New York made any such extensive attempt as that of which the results are to be seen to-day to put herself in gala dress. The celebrations are very different. That was an international occasion. This is the celebration of a strictly domestic and National victory, the dawning of a new National self-consciousness.
The Kings County Fire Insurance Company has been admitted to Massachusetts.

It was the opinion of FREDERICK the Great that men of military training made the best public servants in all civil capacities. That opinion has ever since continued to prevail in Prussia, and undoubtedly it is held with great firmness by the present King of Prussia and Emperor of Germany.

The Cup defender Columbia was floated successfully into the big graving dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday morning, and it is of interest to note that it is the first time within the recollection of any of the officials at the yard that a craft other than a warship or Government vessel has been docked there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Secretary Long to-day replied to the application of the citizens of Norfolk and vicinity to have the Olympia sent to Hampton Roads in company with the North Atlantic Squadron, declining to sanction the proposition.

Admiral George Dewey fought another of his great battles yesterday on the flagship Olympia. It was not on the bridge, as in Manila Bay, but on the quarter deck. The man who stood calm and unflinching before the guns of a hostile fleet, surrounded by unknown enemies, faced yesterday a far more formidable bombardment of unknown friends.

When one reads in The Manchester Guardian that "the reported appearance of yellow fever at Key West has had a somewhat depressing effect on the market generally," it gives emphasis to what I wrote you lately on the money value to our Southern States that would be added by stamping out the fever in its garden and nursery -- Cuba.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28. -- Stockholders of the New Haven Road in this city are discussing with great interest the rumor that has been in circulation here this week that a determined attempt was to be made at the next annual meeting of the stockholders, Oct. 18, to stampede the election of stockholders and elect a majority of the new board to favor the interests of the New York Central.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Interest at the first session to-day of the Pan-Presbyterian Alliance was centred in a statistical report presented by the Rev. Dr. G.D. Mathews, General Secretary, and in a paper on "The History of the Work of the Alliance for the First Quarter Century," prepared and read by Secretary Mathews.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28. -- There were immense audiences and all the expected enthusiasm at the Festival Concert to-day. De Pachmann was the central figure this afternoon. He played Chopin's F minor concerto in his former style, with that extraordinary delicacy and a deliberate lack of anything approaching force.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- The fight between the present Board of Directors and the Protective Committee of the Boston and Albany Railroad, on postponing the election of Directors to Nov. 15, when the question of leasing the road to the New York Central is to be acted upon, was compromised to-day.

Let me have a word with the gentleman whose wife cries over "St. Elmo." Respected friend: Pardon the familiarity of this salutation, which only my deed sympathy for your unhappy case can justify. Your wife weeps when she reads "St. Elmo," and again weeps when you criticise that remarkable production of feminine erudition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The State Department has received a dispatch from the United States Consul at Puerto Cabello, Venezuela, under date of the 13th inst., in which he gives a summary of the several encounters between the Government and rebel forces in that country.

Recently in reading the letters of Robert Louis Stevenson, edited by Sidney Colvin, I chanced upon the one written to Will Low, acknowledging the receipt and dedication of the illustrated edition of Keats's "Lamia." It was the one upon the back of which Stevenson wrote the poem "Youth now flees on feathered foot."

Your correspondent, "Robert A. Ferrare," asks advice as to a dictionary. I have no time to enter into the merits of the Standard and the Century Dictionaries, but would call attention to the following from the preface to the latest edition of that excellent work, Chambers's Etymological Dictionary.

A touching appeal has been made to the editor of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW to print the letter that follows here. The author of it would right a great wrong. While this communication is rather prolix, (though not as prolix as when received,) it is conceived in terms so remarkable that it ought not to be withheld from publicity.

There was more life and bustle at Riverside Park and the Claremont Heights at 7 o'clock yesterday morning than is usual at noon on an ordinary day. The placing of the stakeboat St. Mary's off One Hundred and Thirtieth Street made the neighborhood the most interesting of any point of the naval pageant, and, as was expected, the multitudes who turned out to welcome Admiral Dewey home gave it their choice.

In order to reply to "Malta's" question in the last SATURDAY REVIEW, "What books are really funny?" it would be necessary, as suggested, to widen it. If we exclude all short stories, horse play, satire, the "gently humorous" or "books that contain witty remarks that merely tickle the intellectual palate," I fear it will be difficult to make a list.

The programme arranged for to-day contemplates, in the morning, the reception of Admiral Dewey by Mayor Van Wyck at the City Hall, when the presentation of the gold loving cup will take place in the presence of the Municipal Committee and the distinguished guests of the city; the land parade, beginning at 11 o'clock, and the smoker for the sailors of the Olympia at the Waldorf-Astoria in the evening.

The publication this week of Ik Marvel's "American Lands and Letters; Second Series," aside from the great interest of the book, which has already been touched upon in these columns, suggests how many changes Mr. Mitchell must have witnessed, not only in literary circles, but in the country at large, during his long life.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Miss Toulmin-Smith, who knows her Russian through and through, makes an earnest protest against the Russian woman as she is drawn by novelist who are not Russians. This imaginary Russian woman is always beautiful, fascinating, and thoroughly bad. She is invariably a spy, though it is not very clear in what way she exercises her vocation, unless it be in watching other Russian female spies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The Colombian Legation has received an official cablegram from Bogota announcing that Gen. Julio Rengifo, until recently the Colomian representative in Washington, and one of the best-known South American diplomats, has been drowned in the Magdalene River. It is believed that a number of others were drowned at the same time.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The Times, in an editorial on Admiral Dewey's career, says: "Not the least remarkable part of the celebration is the fact that Admiral Dewey has manifestly satisfied all shades of opinion.

The festivities of carnival week, as that which includes the Dewey welcome and the yacht races is termed, and which has brought such countless throngs to New York, have probably occasioned or been the inspiration for art exhibitions and a sale of art objects, furniture, pictures, , at this unprecedentedly early date.

The magnificent metropolis and first maritime city of the country, representing in the highest degree its wealth, culture, industry, and commerce, is obviously the proper and only place in which to give expression to the popular feeling toward Admiral DEWEY. * * * As the popular and naval contribution to the honors due the Admiral of the navy, the New York marine and land celebration is completely National.

The Kingdom of Roumania, one of the Balkan States, which have been well termed by a historian "the moral and political dykes of Southeastern Europe, damming, as they have at times, the flow of Russian aggression from the north, and again of Turkish ambitions from the south," is only generally known to American readers.

All who read or write cannot fail to be interested in your publication of Mr. W.L. Alden's able defense of Hall Caine's alleged plagiarism. Mr. Alden treats the subject so reasonably it ought to be published broadcast pro bono literati.

The police arrangements for the naval parade were successful. Chief of Police Devery was aboard the Patrol, and had under his command twenty-two tugs and steamboats manned by policemen. All the police boats were in charge of either a Captain or a Sergeant, while Acting Deputy Chief William McLaughlin commanded the steamer Julia Safford and Deputy Chief Cortright the tug C.D. Kuper, that were immediately behind the Patrol.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 29. -- The musical festival came to an end this evening with a performance of Berlioz's "Damnation of Faust." In the afternoon Tschaikowsky's fifth symphony was ostensibly the leading number, but Sembrich was the real attraction and she drew a big crowd. Her work was even more satisfactory than on yesterday evening.

It cannot be denied that one who causes a laugh which is free from cynicism and guile is a real benefactor to the world. Life is so full of sober realities and heartfelt responsibilities as to make a smile seem a luxury. The pathos of Barrie's youthful attempt to make Margaret Ogilvy smile through her tears is finding daily unconscious duplications.

Your editorial article on "American Heraldry" displays much humor, perhaps unconsciously. American heraldry is nil. You might as well discourse of American hereditary nobility, or American Divine right of Kings, or any feudal or monarchical institution or custom which was abandoned and discontinued by us in 1776.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Evidently more than one theatrical manager believes the time has come to rehabilitate Oscar Wilde. He has been quietly waiting for this, and has enormous confidence in his own power.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29. -- The wildest panic ever witnessed on the floor of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange occurred to-day shortly after business opened, and caused, in the midst of the intense excitement, the complete suspension of future business, pending the investigation of what at the moment was assumed to be a gigantic conspiracy to swindle the Cotton Exchanges of the country.

I am much obliged for a copy of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW containing some comment on my article in the July Cornhill. You ask for information as to my doings. The article in question gave rise to a good deal of controversy, as Mr. A. Lang and Mr. A.B. Walkley attacked me for my references to Miss Austen. I replied in the August Cornhill, and Mr. Lang continued the discussion in Longman's for September.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The meeting of the British Cabinet, on whose deliberations practically hangs war or peace in South Africa, began at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

There is an interesting bit of theological history behind the series of sermons on St. Paul which the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis began in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last Sunday, and which he is to continue for some Sundays to come. It Is nothing short of a theological right-about-face in the historic pulpit.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- A dispatch to The Times from Pretoria says: "It is generally expected that a state of war will be proclaimed at any moment.
A religious revival, in which all the churches of Brooklyn are expected to take part, has been arranged to take place early next month.
CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 29. -- It can be announced on the highest authority that $13,000,000 in cash has been offered for the Northwestern Elevated Railroad.

In reading over your SATURDAY REVIEW article, "Where American Heraldry Is Weak," with which I agree entirely, permit me to call your attention to an error. You speak of "bar sinister" and the particular meaning of that ornament. According to my authority, which I have beside me, "Practical Heraldry," by Charles Worthy, there is no such term as "bar sinister," except misused. It is bend sinister.

For the purposes of study and of preserving the old chronicles of travel and adventure the modern Hakluyt Society was founded. The name of the society is commemorative of the Rev. Richard Hakluyt, who in 1582 published "Diuers Voyages Touching the Discouerie of America and Islands Adjacent Unto the Same," and later on "Foure Voyages into Florida."

Frank T. Bullen, whose "Cruise of the Cachelot" and "Idylls of the Sea," which have been so successfully handled through D. Appleton Co. in this country, has collected his articles on the recent British naval manoeuvres and will bring them out in book form in London, under the title "The Way They Have in the Navy: Being a Day to Day Record of the Recent Naval Manoeuvres."

Whenever there is a naval pageant in New York Harbor we have fresh reason to congratulate ourselves upon the wisdom and providence of the men who originally devised and urged and finally pushed to execution the scheme of Riverside Park. It has not been by any means the easy and obvious task which it appears now that it is completed.

You will greatly oblige a constant reader of your SATURDAY REVIEW by printing a list of books suitable for a little girl ten years of age -- books instructive and entertaining. She is very fond of reading, and I am desirous of encouraging the good quality. If not possible to print such a list, kindly suggest where one can be found.

When you find in a man's name consisting of eight letters not less than six consonants, if you are an expert in novel reading you have a right to expect a very wicked person. And such is the Count Czvargas of Castle Czvargas. "His face was bronzed like an ancient copper coin; a tangled mass of black hair covered his head and a coarse black beard his face up to his eyes."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- To-day's statement of the condition of the Treasury shows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Railroads in Africa are discussed at considerable length in the monograph entitled "Commercial Africa in 1899,' prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- The International Geographical Congress to-day elected Gen. A.W. Greely, the American arctic explorer, and Mr. Bryant to be honorary Vice Presidents. Mr. Bryant moved to-day that the next congress be held in America. The motion was taken under advisement.

Shortly before Admiral Dewey left Washington for the Asiatic Station, to which he had been appointed, it is stated that a farewell dinner was given to him at which an original poem was read prophesying a successful career.

The great activity of the various "Colonial" and "historical" societies of New York and Pennsylvania and the number and excellence of their publications have so prepared the popular apprehension that the two volumes of Mr. John Fiske's "The Dutch and Quaker Colonies in America" will find more well-informed readers awaiting them than any one of the five pairs which have preceded it during the last ten years.

News of the wreck of the schooner Herald of the Morning, sailing from Hamilton, Bermuda, on Sept. 7, bound for Jacksonville, was brought by the brig Harry Merryday, which arrived in port Thursday night. The Harry Merryday had on board a negro boy named Horace Wellman, the sole survivor of the wreck.

I have read from time to time the many letters to your paper and also the occasional comments by THE TIMES on the lack of attention shown to Admiral Schley, the letter by E.B.W. in yesterday's issue being a sample.

Are all of Henry James's books as hopelessly bad as "The Spoils of Poynton"? By bad, I mean unnatural, impossible, overdrawn as to the characters, and written in a style which is positively irritating. I was inspired with a desire to read some of this author's productions, after hearing and reading constantly for some months of his original and beautiful style of writing.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 29. -- Col. R.S. Huidekoper, late Lieutenant Colonel and Chief Surgeon of the First Army Corps and of the United States troops in Puerto Rico, stirred up a lively discussion by a paper "On the Organization of Army Corps," read before the Association of Military Surgeons to-day.

I have read with great interest the scholarly and interesting criticism of Goethe in your SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 2. The writer shows great good sense, because it is also my opinion in saying that Goethe's prose is not equal to Lessing's. In fact, Lessing has done a great many things far better than any German before or after him.

I read with much interest the instructive review of Dorman B. Eaton's "The Government of Municipalities," from the pen of Charles Mulford Robinson, although I feel that both Mr. Eaton and Mr. Robinson have failed to grasp what the modern municipal home ruler is contending for in connection with the reform of our municipal government.

I have been thought by some people to be wanting in a sense of humor, and it may interest your SATURDAY REVIEW correspondent "Malta" to know what such a person considers "funny." My standard of "funniness" in a book is the amusement it affords me when I read it alone.

Henry George's famous book "Progress and Poverty" has been translated into Chinese -- that is, into the Mandarin form thereof. An American missionary, the Rev. E.T. Williams, is the translator. The book will be printed at Shanghai, probably on the types and presses connected with the North China Herald's establishment.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 29. -- The official inquiry of the Marine Board into the foundering Sept. 25, off Port Morant, on the south coast of Jamaica, of the Atlas Steamship Company's steamer Adula, Capt. McAuley, from Kingston for Baltimore, develops a profund mystery.

With all respectful humility in regard to the contention raised by "E.I.F.,' still we firmly adhere to the wisdom of the position taken in the edition of Sept. 9 respecting "Forest Lovers." The events of this novel are of a bygone age, when prudery and delicacy of thought were little known, and humanity was gloriously vested in its aboriginal purity and strength of conduct.

I would suggest to your correspondent "Malta," who inquires. "What are the really funny books in English and American literature?" that her definition of "funny," that "will make a cultivated man with a good digestion laugh heartily and often," is more often met by books written in all seriousness, and never intended by their authors to be "funny."

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 29. -- Town, city, and probate elections will be held here Monday. In the probate canvass the Republican Convention was dead-locked for several days over a candidate, the delegates from South Norwalk and New Canaan favoring Attorney Joseph Taylor and those from Wilton and Norwalk favoring John Belden Hurlbutt.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Richard F. Stevens, the expert accountant who was appointed some time ago by Justice Collins of the Supreme Court to investigate the alleged shortage in the accounts of Charles Desch, Collector of the Borough of Seabright, filed his report to-day. Accompanying the report is a mass of testimony taken by Mr. Stevens under authority of the court.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- The boom in the London wool market has caused very large shipments of wools brought here from Australia in advance of the next sales, which are to take place in November. It was stated to-day that another purchase of a million pounds has been made during the present week for foreign shipment upon the strength of the London sales.

The best place from which to view the great marine panorama yesterday was from the deck of the Olympia. A brother and the widow of Capt. Gridley, who fought the Olympia in Manila Bay, and Col. Franklin Bartlett, an intimate personal friend of Dewey, were guests-of the Admiral on his flagship, as were several naval officers, one of whom was the engineer when the Olympia led the way past Corregidor Island.

In your able leading editorial article in to-day's issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW, "Where American Heraldry Is Weak," I regret to see mention made of a "bar sinister," a term not infrequently used, as in the present instance, by those who should know that such a thing is a heraldric impossibility.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- The following men were to-day ordered to report at the 'Varsity training table of the University of Fennsylvania football team: Hare, Shover, McC10skey, McCracken, McMah0n, Gardincr. Outland, Stehle, Ruegenberg, Desilver, Hedge, V'oodley, Vrailace, and Kennedy.

Wall Street has never had a holiday in which matters financial have been so generally lost sight of as that of yesterday. Ordinarily international banking houses keep open during hours up to the close of foreign markets; but yesterday Wall Street was wholly shut up.

The first grand and massive fact Mr. Richard P. Rothwell, the editor of The Mineral Industry, shows is this, that "the total value of the mineral production of the United States in 1898 was $709,816,750, against $648,804,899 in 1897." Taking the values of these mineral products for the past six mouths of the present year, the great total of 1898 will be very much exceeded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The story of how Admiral Dewey came to be in Asia so opportunely on the famous 1st of May has never yet been fully told, and may not be for some time to come, but the controversy between the friends of Senator Proctor and Gov. Roosevelt as to which is entitled to the honor sheds some light upon a story often heard here.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Indications this evening lead to the belief that, in view of the Cabinet message, the Boers will probably commit an overt act which will bring on hostilities before the assembling of Parliament. All the latest dispatches from the Transvaal show the liveliest activity on the part of the burghers.

In no previous year has the cause of education in the United States been so enriched by donations and bequests as in 1899. Though more than three months yet remain, the institutions of learning have received $28,720,617, which is $15,634,467 more than they received all last year There have been twenty-four individual donations this year ranging from $100,000 to $15,000,000.

The racing at Gravesend yesterday was remarkable in that two horses, owned by the same man and ridden by the same jockey, fell and were shot on the track. Each horse had injured a leg. The jockey was unhurt in both accidents.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- James B. Forgan, Vice President of the First National Bank, states that an agreement has just been reached by practically all the banks of Chicago, both National and State, to pay 2 per cent. on bank balances from Oct. 1 until further united action of the banks parties to the agreement.
A petition for perpetual copyright, to be submitted to the coming session of Congress, has been prepared by Miss Margaret Lee of Brooklyn.

Will you kindly give me through your column a list of books for a young man twenty-four years of age. I am a stenographer and typewriter and have had a public school education (have been graduated) and several terms at evening high schools. I have read your list addressed to "E.D.F." and trust you will favor me likewise.

The stained-glass window just completed by John La Farge for Sanders Theatre, in Harvard University, will be placed high up on the semicircle above the ranges of seats. Unless one ascends to the gallery back of the highest row, the window must be viewed from a distance. It is therefore important that the subject be simple in order that it may tell its story from afar.

Reading the astonishing letter, purporting to be from a High School graduate of Evanston, Ill., it is puzzling to decide whether it is really the work of a sweet girl graduate of eighteen Summers or of some satirically inclined older person. If this is really the composition of an Illinois High School graduate, the rhetorical Boston infant of the funny columns may have hereafter to hide his diminished head.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Chief of Police Hoy of Prescott, with William Hiscox, a special officer, attempted to raid a band of tramps to-day and a desperate fight ensued.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- Philadelphia was outplayed at every point by New York this afternoon. With the exception of Delehanty none of the locals could do anything with Gettig's pitching. They lost several chances to score by stupid base running. The fielding of Gleason was brilliant. Attendance, 2,052. Score:

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- The list of books about New York is increased by two Boston books, one published this week and one to he issued immediately by Messrs. Richard G. Badger Co. The first, Mr. Howard Pyle's "The Price of Blood," is an Arabian Nights' tale of mysterious strangers, stolen diamonds, jewels of price, robbery, and murder; but it vividly describes the laborious horseplay with which young New York amused itself in 1807.
" The Democrats have more than a fighting chance in Ohio," said John W. Bookwalter, one of that State's most prominent citizens, last night. He is at the Holland House.

" A prefatory conversation" between the author and the ubiquitous Mr. W.T. Stead forms the true preface to Mr. I.S. Bloch's extended volume entitled "The Future of War." Mr. W.T. Stead is an interviewer of distinction, with infinite powers of suction, and so this "prefatory conversation" explains in a measure the author's drift, which is an endeavor to show how war is now impossible.

As the owner of copies of the Standard and Webster Dictionaries, permit me to make comparisons of these works for the benefit of your correspondent, Robert A. Ferrare, who finds Greek printed in Greek characters so much easier to read than when printed in italic type.
The most interesting question raised by the report and resolutions of the Diocesan Convention on the subject of divorce is: What does the Church and what do the pastors mean to do about it?

Because of the welcome to Admiral Dewey the two yachts that will battle for international laurels during this week were visited by comparatively few sightseers yesterday. The crew of the Columbia completed the task of cleaning the underbody of the yacht and spent the greater part of the day painting her topsides.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 30. -- A convention of negro Republicans has been called to meet in Columbia during the State Fair, in the second week in November. The Rev. Junius S. Mobley, one of the most noted negro leaders in the State, and for many years member of the Legislature, is the author of a manifesto to his race, in which the call is embodied, and he represents the sentiment of the old-line negro Republicans.

In one sense the American system of electing Judges may be said to be on trial in the City of New York this year. We say the American system, for, though the system of appointment is in use in the most conspicuous and dignified part of our judiciary -- the Federal -- it is in the United States that the election of Judges has obtained more generally.

The proposed trial to establish a new one-mile straightaway record by E.A. McDuffee will probably be abandoned; that is, so far as riding in this vicinity is concerned. The men who proposed the performance and also had a special motor cycle built have failed to locate a perfectly level straightaway road of sufficient length. It would require a level road of about two miles.

The Art Students' League of New York announces several new features for the coming season. It has decided to merge the antique and life classes into one, and thus give the students the advantage of having both cast and nude models before them, allow the instructor to compare the one with the other, and keep the pupil a longer time under his guidance.

In your paper of Sept. 28 your article headed "Col. Shaw on Pensions" seems to me a strange expression of opinion for a leading New York paper. I am not an old soldier. I lived in a town where "Copperheads" would go out in the streets, swing their hats, and hurrah when an account of a rebel victory reached us.

Wet season or dry, the Federal troops on Luzon Island find it an easy matter to defeat insurgent forces and capture insurgent towns and points of vantage whenever an advance movement is made. The taking of Porac by four regiments under Gens. MacArthur and Wheeler was only a repetition of similar exploits early in the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 30. -- At a meeting to-day of the boilermakers and iron ship builders employed at Cramps' ship yards, it was decided to present demands to the firm for a nine-hour day. A committee was appointed and when they appeared at the company's office they were met by Superintendent Mull of the yard, who, without reading their request, discharged the committee from the employ of the company.

I note with interest that you have made a part of my private letter to you the text of an editorial in THE TIMES of Sept. 26. Please express to the writer my appreciation of the courteous manner of the editorial. I feel that I have placed you in my debt by furnishing you with a text for one of the most persuasive editorials that has appeared in your columns.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Sept. 30. -- The State College football team easily defeated Gettysburg here to-day by the score of 40 to 0 in two thirty-five-minute halves. Dale, Emmeret and Koller played the best for Gettysburg. Burns, Randolph, Scholl, and Hewitt did the best work for State.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 30. -- The international cricket match between Prince Ranjitsinhji's English team and the eleven composed of players picked from the various clubs of this city, which was begun yesterday on the grounds of the Merion Cricket Club, at Haverford a suburb of this city, was resumed to-day. Fine weather prevailed, though it was a little sharp to sit in the open air to watch the play.

We suppose it to be true that all army men are not good administrators. We are not sure that we couldn't, if pressed, cite an instance or two in point. But it is equally and undeniably true that a good many army men have the executive faculty in its highest development, and with it the ability to apply it to new uses under novel conditions.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The Transvaal situation continues to interest Germany, though th's interest has somewhat flagged, owing to the uncertainty of the situation throughout the week. It is learned from a reliable source that there is absolutely no truth in the report that the Emperor has offered to mediate.
PRINCETON, Sept. 30. -- Frederick Smith, who was quarter back of the '96 champion football team at Princeton, in an interview on the chances of this year's eleven, said:

While October is not a festival month among the planets, it is one of the most enjoyable months of the year for studying the stars. The lengthening evenings, the crisp atmosphere, the lingering Summer warmth of the earlier part of the month, invite to the contemplation of the heavens.

It is not without significance, whether the coincidence were accidental or not, that the action of the President confirming the sentence of Capt. CARTER was announced on the day that the army was joining in the tribute of the Nation to Admiral DEWEY. Terrible as is the fate of the faithless officer, his punishment is an illustration of the standard which the United States sets for its soldiers and its sailors.

A few of the readers of Zion's Herald will next year visit the famous Passion Play at Oberammergau; thousands will read with interest descriptions of the same. The American people are pretty generally acquainted with this strange play, which is given every ten years by these quaint Bavarian country folk.

We publish in another column a letter from the Rev. Mr. CHADWICK of Brooklyn, in which he unites with sharp criticism of the policy of the Government in the past in the Philippines a suggestion as to the future. Such utterances are entitled to respect, not merely for their sincerity, which they share with many more extreme utterances, but for their fairness and sense of practical responsibility.
KOBE, Sept. 6. -- No country of its size in the world suffers more year by year from flood and fire than does Japan.

The so-called antique shops in New York, which contain not only antiques, but odds and ends of quaint and curious things picked up here and there all over the world, show by the support given them, while the regular shops are exhibiting richer and more beautiful things than ever before, that the great cry is now for something novel.

MANILA, Sept. 30. -- This has been an eventful day with the northern outposts of the American Army at Angeles. Early this morning the Filipino Peace Commission appeared. The American prisoners followed. Then a commission of three Spaniards, to negotiate for the release of their prisoners, departed up the railroad with a retinue of servants and buffalo carts carrying their baggage.

An automatic electrical signaling device for use on railroad trains to prevent engineers and trainmen from forgetting train orders has been patented by General Superintendent W.H. Stillwell of the Rock Island Railroad. It is without a doubt one of the best signal devices of its kind yet invented, as its main feature consists in being automatic, thus relieving trainmen from any attention to its working parts.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Comment regarding the personnel and material of the British force which is expected to be fighting within a short time in South Africa continues to occupy a large share of public attention. Many criticisms appear, blaming the Government for not permitting the War Office, months ago, to put an adequate defensive force on the probable scene of action.

A probable murder and suicide in the Raines law hotel, known as Reiper's Hotel, at 1,801 Park Avenue, came to light yesterday. A man apparently about thirty-six years old, accompanied by a woman about twenty-four years of age, walked into the hotel at 11 o'clock Friday night and registered as "A.G. Jones and wife, Boston, Mass." They were assigned to Room 8 on the second floor.

In most respects there has never been a better planned or a better managed parade in New York than that which took place yesterday. The start was of a remarkable punctuality, the column was kept moving with very few halts or checks. The parade was over sooner than could reasonably have been expected.

The gold loving cup which the City of New York had been keeping for Admiral Dewey as one of the pleasant mementos of its celebration in his honor was given him yesterday morning by the Mayor on a platform in front of the City Hall, with a large number of well-known people looking on from the stand, and a vastly larger number of everyday people looking on from from a little greater distance.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- Besides Prince Hohenlohe's dinner of Thursday, there was a special performance in honor of the Congress at Urania yesterday, and the city gave a big fete at the Zoological Garden this evening. The place was brilliantly illuminated with 8,500 electric lights. About 1,500 persons sat down to the banquet, which was served at sixty-four tables, each presided over by a member of the Municipal Council.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The Duke of Devonshire, Lord President of the Council, at a public luncheon at the Technical Schools at New Mills, Derbyshire, near Manchester, this afternoon, replying to a toast to his health, referred to the Transvaal situation, saying:

Old age, virility, and the love of sport seldom coexist in a more striking way than in one of whom a friend writes me from Fayette Springs, Penn. The place is perhaps eighty miles from Pittsburg and two miles from the grave of Gen. Braddock, while beyond is the site of Fort Necessity where the American and British forces retreated after Braddock's defeat.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- A local convention of temperance people in this city has called attention to the great increase in intemperance seen upon the streets. The saloons run at all hours of the night in violation of the city ordinances, and it is no uncommon thing for policemen to be seen coming out of these places without the slightest pretense at concealment.

It is peculiarly appropriate that some cold facts about the horse be laid before the public at the present time. These will substantiate the assertion that the horse is an animal of extraordinary little sense -- using the word as synonymous with judgment. He has a remarkably delicate perception, coupled with a very slight power of correlation.

MANILA, P.I., July 27. -- While telegraphic reports of flag raisings in various parts of our Philippine possessions have no doubt been received by you all at home, the details are necessarily wanting, and in the attempt to keep Old Glory flying to the breeze at the Cape Melville lighthouse in South Balabac Island there were some very thrilling incidents.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 27. -- South Carolina citizens will have no objection to the demolition of old Castle Pinckney, situated on a spit of land at the mouth of Cooper River, Charleston Harbor. But the courtesy of Secretary of War Root in a communication on the subject to Gov. McSweeney is generally appreciated.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- The University of Chicago intends to confer the degree of LL. D. on Admiral Dewey when he comes to Chicago.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The majority of the great dailies give a fair amount of space to the Dewey celebration. The Times devotes a leader to him and says: "The people of the United States gave ample evidence yesterday, if, indeed, evidence were needed, of their power to appreciate the services which the gallant sailor has rendered and may render again to the country that is justifiably proud in numbering him among her sons."

I was in your city the week ending Sept. 23. While there I noticed in your paper an article by some one complaining of your street car conductors, and also exposing some ill-bred patrons of the street cars.
QUEBEC, Quebec, Sept. 30. -- Under orders from Capt. Skrimshire all members of the crew of the Scotsman brought up this morning by the Grecian were held under arrest to be searched.

LONDON, Sept 30. -- The coming war is the universal topic here. Nobody apparently even thinks of any other question. That there is to be war seems to be the general conclusion. Even the crusted Tories admit that the Government will fall with the suddenness of a lightning flash if it shows the slightest sign of weakness in its dealings with the Boers.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30. -- The project advanced by a number of members of the Newport Reading Room of a new clubhouse is by no means a dead issue. The Reading Room has among its members some of the richest men in this country. It has been suggested that while a new house is being built the Reading Room members could enjoy the privileges of the Casino club.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30. -- The Williams football team was beaten by Harvard to-day by the score of 29 to 0. Although the Harvard line-up was constantly changed to give as many of the substitutes as possible a chance to play, the team kept well together and played a fast, offensive game. Against the weak Williams ends the Harvard interference was irresistible, enabling Parker and Gierasch to make some brilliant runs around the ends.

" It was 11:30 o'clock when Admiral Sampson boarded the New York, and fifteen minutes later, in full dress, he went over the side into a steam launch and was on his way to the Olympia." -- Newspaper report.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The St. Louis, which sailed to-day from Southampton for New York, has a very large passenger list. Among her passengers are F.S. Witherbee and family of New York, Ernest Wildman of Elmira, and F.W. Whitaker, a large mine owner of Colorado, who lives at Hamilton, Ohio, and is interested in politics.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30. -- Alexander Wustlich, an aged and wealthy German of Stockdale, Penn., was killed, and his wife was probably fatally wounded by burglars last night.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- War now seems certain. Every stage has depended upon President Kruger. If he would not back down when the British demands were less sweepingly expressed he can scarcely do so now, when they are formulated with almost brutal frankness. The negotiations, according to President Kruger's own statements, and judging from all the available information, seem to hape reached an impasse.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Interest in golf seems to increase rather than decrease in Lenox, and the women are now having their innings. On Wednesday they played an eighteen-hole handicap match for a two-handled silver cup, presented by Mr. John Sloane. The cup was won by Miss Charlotte Stillman, a scratch player who made a score of 119.

Wall Street resumes business to-morrow under conditions extraordinary. Holiday interruptions are attended usually by uncertain sequels. But present holidays are holidays so exceptional in varied ways that calculations as to their influence can hardly be adjusted to ordinary standards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The President has approved the sentence imposed by court-martial on Capt. Oberlin M. Carter, Corps of Engineers, United States Army, and a formal order was to-day issued from the War Department directing the execution of the sentence.
LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Sixty-six races have been run since last Saturday. Sloan, with six victories, leads the list of winning jockeys. Cannon rode five winners and Madden four.

KOBE, Japan, Sept. 6. -- In the early hours of Saturday, the 2d of September, the United States transport Morgan City, Capt. Dorris, with 762 officers and men of the army and a crew of 62 on board, ran upon a reef in the Inland Sea and subsequently foundered in deep water, fortunately without the loss of a single life.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 30. -- The fire which started at 1:10 A.M. to-day in the centre of the freight depot of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago, and St. Louis (Big Four) Railroad, destroyed railroad property estimated to have been worth between $500,000 and $1,000,000.

William Cass Baker, Sheriff of Queens County, has purchased the old Union Hall Seminar property, at Jamaica, and will convert it into an opera house. The sale-includes the land in the rear of the building. The recorded price of the property is $7,000.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Nat C. Goodwin and company will sail for New York Oct. 14 on the American Line steamer New York. Mr. Goodwin has not yet fully recovered from the effect of the operation which he recently underwent, but he reappeared to-day at the Duke of York's Theatre. S. Miller Kent, who played Mr. Goodwin's part during the latter's illness, gave satisfaction and received a handsome testimonial from Mr. Goodwin and Charles Frohman.

Preparations are being made on an extensive scale at the Harvard University, Cambridge, for observations to be made during the meteoric shower of November. This will be the second and most important year of the period during which the earth passes three times through or near the Leonid shower, and if the conditions are favorable it is expected that the observations will give results of great value to astronomical science.
" Yer want ter know how to mek okrun soup, Miss May? Well, well, yuse come to de right pusson. But see heah, Miss May, dis yere Norf hain't get no jester."

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Commander in Chief Albert D. Shaw of the Grand Army of the Republic has invited Admiral Dewey to be the guest of honor at the thirty-fourth National Encampment of the organization, which will be held in Chicago in September, 1900, and has telegraphed to Mayor Harrison, now in New York, asking him to urge the Admiral to accept.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Sept. 30. -- The Democratic State campaign was opened here to-day with a great demonstration and speeches by John R. McLean, candidate for Governor, the candidates for other offices on the Democratic State ticket, and others. Platforms were erected on all sides of the Court House, in the public square, for over-flow meetings.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- The University of Pennsylvania football team to-day defeated the Lehigh University eleven on Franklin Field by a score of 20 to 0 in twenty-minute halves. The game was rather slow and uninteresting. Pennsylvania's playing was not up to the standard of the game she put up last Wednesday, the men being slow to get into play.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The prospect of stringency in the money market occupies serious attention in financial circles. There has been an immense drain of gold to South Africa since the crisis. Altogether, from London and Australia about five millions have been drawn, while it is impossible to adequately gauge the future requirements in the same direction.
LONDON, Sept. 30. -- It is understood that Sir Thomas Lipton has been asked to stand for Ashton-Under-Lyne in the Liberal interest at the next election.

The Holly Handicap for two-year-olds and the Oriental Handicap for all ages were the stakes features of the last day of the Gravesend meeting. In the former, Sarmatian was made post favorite at 3 to 1, heavily backed from 6 to 1. He was never a factor, however. Montanic went to the front, but in the stretch Hammock challenged Montanic, and after a hard drive through the last sixteenth won by a neck.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30. -- A deal has been closed by which J.B. Haggin has secured control on a long lease of the famous horses, including Ormonde, owned by W. O'B. MacDonough. This will result in the temporary breaking up of the Menlo Park Stock Farm, on which Mr. MacDonough has spent a quarter of a million dollars.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 30. -- Attorney General Monett to-day filed an application in the Supreme Court for a hearing of all the cases against the Standard Oil Company, Buckeye Pipe Line Company, Solar Refining Company, and the Ohio Oil Company. He is anxious to have the cases disposed of by Jan. 1.

WORCESTER, Sept. 30. -- There is every indication that the forty-second music festival has bean a financial success. The big advance subscription of season tickets was supplemented by a large sale of single tickets during the week. No audience was small, and the concerts and rehearsals at which the highest prices were charged were given to packed houses.

SYDNEY, Aug. 29. -- The unmistakable success of "Secret Service," as produced at Her Majesty's, Sydney, following close on the favor with which the performance of "The Belle of New York" and "A Trip to Chinatown" companies were received, will probably induce Messrs. Williamson and Musgrove to give more attention than hitherto to the works of American dramatists.

A few onlookers who were attracted the other day to the rear of the Upham block, where the hulk of a railroad engine was being lowered into the basement to serve as a portion of the heating apparatus, little suspected that these were the remains of one of the most famous old-time locomotives.

The Cunard Line steamship Campania arrived at her pier shortly after 7 o'clock last night, one day late. Her delay was due to bad weather and to green firemen, the strike in England yet seriously crippling shipping. She encountered strong adverse winds most of the way over, and then fogs compelled her to reduce speed for sixteen hours.
We of the City of New York have good reason to congratulate ourselves, apart from the general success of the plans of the last two days, on two things.

-- The latest copy of Le Journal of Paris to arrive in the city contains a long article by M. Hanotaux, ex-Minister of the French Foreign Office, on the Transvaal question. M. Hanotaux declares that war is absolutely inevitable, for it is a strife of race that is going on, and the clash cannot be staid much longer.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Frank P. Blair, who assisted in the defense of Capt. O.M. Carter was visibly affected as he read the Washington dispatch announcing that President McKinley had approved the finding of the court-martial. He exclaimed: "It is a damnable outrage. It is equal to the Dreyfuf case.

Yesterday's crowds, although they were larger than those of Friday, were, if anything, more easily handled by the city railroad companies. The people came from all directions and went to various points along the route of the parade, so that there was no such concentrated attack on any one place as there was on the Riverside Drive section on Friday.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- A powerful company, composed of Frenchmen, Germans, and Russians, with a capital of more than $50,000,000, has been formed for the purpose of competing with the American pork exporters in Europe, particularly in Germany, England, and Scandinavia.

Will you give place in your columns to some reflections suggested by your admirable and most discriminating editorial of Sept. 30 on the subject of "The Church and Divorce," and allow me to repeat and emphasize some of the points you make and the questions you ask, as well as add thereto some of my own?

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- Politics has given way to militarism during the past ten days, the only subjects of great interest being the prospective meeting of Czar and Kaiser and the probable fight between the Government and the Bund der Landwirthe, or Agricultural Alliance.

In the rapid multiplication of suburban theatres in London, some theatrical prophets see the beginning of a radical change in the methods of management. In opening the new Royal Duchess Theatre at Balham recently, Charles Wyndham, a typical London actor-manager, made a significant speech.

Some cable dispatches set forth that the English are somewhat puzzled to understand the American point of view in respect to the welcome of DEWEY, which seems to them disproportionate to his achievements. On the other hand, Americans will be quite as much at a loss to apprehend the point of view from which it seems to be disproportionate.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Archie Mulle of Nassau, Rensselaer County, N.Y., was arrested in this city to-day by a local officer on a charge of murdering Melville L. Lord, a prosperous farmer of Nassau.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- A dispatch from Cape Town says: "The alarmist reports from Pretcria of the movements of burghers must be received with caution. The strict Boer censorship renders it unlikely that important movements could be telegraphed unless the Transvaal has good reason for it. It is said here that the highly colored reports are either sent to arouse the enthusiasm of the Afrikanders or to produce alarm in the British camps."

Dewey has come and won all hearts as thoroughly, as swiftly, as he won the battle that gave him fame. Had he landed in any other seaport of the United States, the result would have been the same; it is New York's fortune that no other has had the privilege of attesting first the honor in which he is held by the Republic at large.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The papers have devoted much attention this week to Samoa. Curiously enough, a general agitation has been started in nearly all the leading journals, irrespective of party, in favor of Germany's obtaining larger rights in Samoa than those granted either by the convention of 1869 or by the report of the High Commission.

Dewey has come and won all hearts as thoroughly, as swiftly, as he won the battle that gave him fame. Had he landed in any other seaport of the United States, the result would have been the same; it is New York's fortune that no other has had the privilege of attesting first the honor in which he is held by the Republic at large.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The papers have devoted much attention this week to Samoa. Curiously enough, a general agitation has been started in nearly all the leading journals, irrespective of party, in favor of Germany's obtaining larger rights in Samoa than those granted either by the convention of 1869 or by the report of the High Commission.

The sailorman's triumph ended last night in a haze of smoke and vaudeville and general rejoicing at the Waldorf-Astoria. If yesterday was Admiral Dewey's day to own the city, the evening was the time for Jack Tar, and right royally was he entertained. Officially, it was a "smoker," with the city as host, Randolph Guggenheimer as master of ceremonies, and Oscar Hammerstein master of the vaudeville, of which there was a long and entertaining bill.

The course of free lectures under the auspices of the Board of Education will begin to-morrow evening. The first lecture will be delivered at Public School No. 10, One Hundred and Seventeenth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, by Dr. William Bayard Hale, whose subject will be "Sir Walter Scott." This will be the first of a course of five lectures on "Great Novelists."

After eluding the clutches of the law for fifteen years Charles A. Hinckley has been arrested at Princeton, in British Columbia, charged with the stealing of some $97,000 from the West Side Bank of this city. The officers of the bank have spent thousands of dollars in trying to hunt him down, and got their first clue two years ago.
LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Daily News says:

There could be no complaint from the horsemen that the money hung up by the Brooklyn Jockey Club during its meeting, which ended on Saturday last, had not been well distributed. In all, eighty-two horsemen secured some part of it, the sums ranging from $75 to $22,710.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The War Department gave out to-day a statement of exports of merchandise and gold coin at the Port of Havana for the first eight months of American occupation. One of the most striking features of the report is the volume of Products that passes month by month out of the Port of Havana at a time when the agricultural resources of the island are at their minimum.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1. -- The list of the Scotsman's dead remained unchanged at 11 o'clock to-night. The Rev. Dr. Chalmers, the Congregational missionary of Hongkong, who was reported missing last evening, has been located.

NEWARK N.J., Oct. 1. -- A shivering crowd of three thousand persons witnessed the regular Sunday bicycle races on the Vailsburg board track to-day. Six events were on the special Dewey Day card, and a half-mile professional handicap was added to the regular programme. In spite of several well-fought finishes, the sport throughout was tame.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1. -- Among the crew of the steam whaler Mary D. Hume, just arrived here, are eight disappointed gold seekers who went to the arctic region over the Edmonton route. Their names are B.V. Lares, St. Paul; J. Martin, F.T. Thompson, F. Adelman, W.S. Mason, and F. Sisk, all of Chicago; Thomas Tipton, Edmonton, Northwest Territory, and W. McGinn, Cheboygan, Mich.

The machinists expressed a preference for German policemen to those of Irish birth through their mouthpiece, Delegate George H. Warner, at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union. In making a report about a strike in a shop on Morris Heights, Delegate Warner said that the police about the shop were interfering with the union pickets and would not allow them to stand on the side of the street on which the shop was situated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Elaborate preparations have been made to give Admiral Dewey a glorious and mighty welcome when he returns to Washington Monday evening the Nation's hero. His arrival in the city will be signalized by an Admiral's salute of seventeen guns and a pandemonium of noise from all the cannon, bells, and steam whistles in or about the city.

Capt. Frederick Watkins, who was in command of the American Line steamship Paris and on the bridge of that vessel when she ran on the Manacles, arrived here yesterday on the steamship New York. His object in coming here is to fight the decision of the United States Board of Steam Vessel Inspectors, who suspended him for two years on account of the accident.

With the international yacht races commanding so much public attention, it is hardly probable that strong efforts will be made to help the security market toward improvement. Matters of the money market will be likely to run their course and exert such influences as the lesser traders of the Stock Exchange may choose to promote -- and most of them are on the bear side.

New York was still in holiday attire yesterday, and the crowds of sightseers at the principal places of interest were almost as large as those which for three days have made locomotion tedious and uncomfortable on the leading thoroughfares. The Dewey arch, of course, was the main attraction, and the neighborhood of Twenty-third Street and Fifth Avenue presented a lively appearance, in decided contrast to the usual quiet Sunday afternoon scene.

Capt. Oberlin M. Carter was less nervous and much more self-possessed yesterday in his cell in Castle Williams, Governors Island, than he was on Saturday, when he first arrived there. He is incarcerated on the third tier, and the number of his cell is 8. It is one of twelve casemates, whose entrances and doors have been barred.

Although the streets did not indicate it yesterday, there had been a great exodus of Dewey visitors since the passing of the parade on Saturday afternoon. On every street were men and women laden down with the impedimenta of travel, wending their way on foot to the Grand Central Station and the ferries leading to the Jersey City railroad termini.

The general condition of the men's wear market is very good, and the tone is extremely healthy. Confidence has been restored to a great extent in the sections where fears were expressed a week or two ago. There is every element of strength to be found in it to-day and there is every prospect of further advances.

ILOILO, Aug. 8. -- One sees strange pets in these new possessions of ours in the tropics. One that amused us all very much during a recent visit was a baby rhinoceros that was being brought up by hand.

The United States cruiser New Orleans, under command of Capt. Edwin Longnecker, arrived here yesterday afternoon and anchored just south of the Chicago in the North River. She came from Santo Domingo, where she has been for nearly two months awaiting the result of the revolution which occurred there upon the assassination of President Heureaux.

Wilbur Whittaker, a laborer employed in the engineering operations at Fort Schuyler, was drowned off the engineers' pier Saturday afternoon. Whittaker was attempting to reach a skiff in which he was accustomed to row each evening to his home in Whitestone, when he fell between the pier and a sand scow. His body was not recovered until yesterday morning.

Bishop McDonnell of Brooklyn yesterday laid the cornerstone of the new St. Joseph's Trade School, which the Sisters of St. Dominic are building in Farmingdale, Queens. When completed, children from all branches of the institutions in this State under the control of the Dominican Order who desire to learn trades will be instructed by competent and skilled mechanics. It is the first venture of its kind made by this branch of the Sisterhood.

The cruiser Olympia, anchored off One Hundred and Sixth Street, North River, was surrendered to the general public yesterday for the first time since her arrival in port. The decks of the famous vessel were completely overrun throughout the day by a curious and enthusiastic horde of patriotic spectators.
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 1. -- A portion of the Middle West which has become quite noted for a specialty in agriculture is that known as the Kaw Valley potato region, in Eastern Kansas.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1. -- The steam whaler Mary Hume has arrived here after a cruise of six years. She had a very eventful voyage from Bering Sea, being caught in a gale which raged for fourteen hours. Her seams parted, and her joints creaked. The boilers were started out of place, and a pipe broken.

GAFFNEY, S.C., Oct. 1. -- The Trustees of Limestone College have determined to establish as a feature of their institution a department of history, in which, without neglecting other branches of the subject, particular attention will be paid to the history of the Southern States.

A return to the high rate for money which prevailed during the early part of the previous week last week caused further declines in a number of the stocks dealt in on the curb. The unfavorable conditions were somewhat ameliorated later in the week, but the market continued irregular and at the close many of the usually active issues showed net losses for the week.

Rear Admiral Walker, Alfred Noble, Col. Peter C. Hains, and W.H. Burr members of the Isthmian Canal Commission, who went to Paris to study the work of the Panama Canal Company, returned here yesterday on the American liner New York. They were abroad six weeks. They remained a month in Paris, and then visited England and Germany.

John Bleek, twenty-one years old, who gave his address as 262 West Thirty-seventh Street, Manhattan, was arraigned in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday charged by Mrs. Alexander Schell of 737 Carroll Street, that borough, with being implicated in the theft of a manuscript upon which she places the value of $2,000.
LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The special correspondent of The Morning Post at Pietermaritzburg says:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Gov. Roosevelt reached Oyster Bay this morning at 8:50 o'clock from New York, and was at once driven to his home. He looked somewhat tired and worn after his exertions in New York, but was in high spirits.
PARIS, Oct. 1. -- With war between Great Britain and the Transvaal imminent, French opinion as to its justification and probable issue is beginning to express itself.

The Duke of DEVONSHIRE, who is the Lord President of the Council in the Cabinet of Lord SALISBURY, made a frank and even naive statement on Saturday regarding the Transvaal question. He expressed little hope of a pacific outcome, and thus explained the situation:

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 1. -- Col. William J. Bryan has gone to Texas to continue the campaign. He thought at first that he would rest here a day or so, but urgent telegrams caused him to change his mind, and early this morning he left for Dallas. After leaving there he delivers several speeches.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- The new franchise tax law, which will be applied to about 2,500 corporations, went into effect to-day. This city will be the first to profit by it, as its tax lists are made up in November.

So far as we have been able to learn the Democrats of New Jersey who in 1896 manifested their indifference to the peculiar brand of Democracy set forth at Chicago by giving MCKINLEY a totally unexpected and unprecedented Republican majority have not been convinced or converted by the recent capture of the State Democratic organization by the friends of Col. BRYAN.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1. - Ten cars loaded with trotting horses arrived here from Louisville to-day, and scores of horsemen from all parts of the country are coming in to attend the big trotting meeting beginning Tuesday.

Most great political leaders of France seem to have inborn one conspicuous human frailty. Particularly have the military leaders who have risen to high positions of State betrayed this moral weakness. From NAPOLEON to the ill-fated BOULANGER, "the supreme moment" has been ushered in with a vaulting ambition that has completely overshadowed or excluded the highest duty to the State and people to whom the persons in question owed their exalted positions.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 1. -- A message received from Gov. Smith in this city today was to the effect that Dewey Day would be Oct. 12. This was the date fixed by the committee having charge of Vermont's welcome to her honored son, Admiral Dewey, but definite selection of that time rested with the Admiral himself.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Last week was one of great tension and excitement destructive to business. Even the money market was in a condition of suspended animation, and the Bank of England all the week did the cream of the discount business. Until Friday the open market worked at 3 5/8 per cent., taking ninety-day bills at that rate, but quoting 3 3/4 and 4 per cent. to foreign correspondents for bills coming forward.

Though on the surface a jocular, that was really a pathetic, remark which fell from Admiral DEWEY when he arrived in the bay and for the first time appreciated the scale of the preparations that had been made by his fellow-citizens to welcome him. He is reported to have said: "I began this business of being a hero too late in life."

Thousands of people flocked to the Speedway yesterday, and from early morning until long after dusk the sidewalks were crowded with spectators. It was very evident, from the appearance and remarks of the visitors, that the majority of them were strangers in the city and had never seen the famous drive before.

True to its threat, the Staten Island Electric Company shut off the current from all the street lights in Richmond Borough last night. The streets were in darkness, and are likely to remain so until some arrangement is reached between the city and the electric company. The company a few weeks ago sent the formal notice of its intention to Commissioner Kearny.

HAVANA, Oct. 1. -- The street-car conductors and drivers went out on strike, but Mayor Lacoste found substitutes immediately. The companies are reducing the number of working hours, and the strikers can return if they desire. The companies need additional hands, and the substitutes will be kept on.

MANILA, Oct. 1. -- Aguinaldo's third attempt to shift his difficulties into the field of diplomacy is a repetition of the other two with an impossible endeavor to obtain some sort of recognition of his so-called Government.

Mancinelli is composing a new opera. The genial and modest conductor, who arrived on the New York on Saturday, owned the soft impeachment last night -- hesitatingly and blushingly -- when cornered with the direct question thrice repeated. Hitherto he had carefully guarded the secret, even from his friends.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 28. -- Few there are in New York who will not remember a scandal in that city about the middle of the year 1889. At that period there resided at 13 West Forty-second Street John J.T. Plunkett and his wife.

" You're right as a trivet, Admiral," said Capt. Coghlan yesterday when Dewey asked the doughty hero of "Hoch der Kaiser!" how he looked, after the heartbreaking campaign of the week in New York. The judgment of Capt. Coghlan satisfied every one, and "right as a trivet" it was for the remainder of the morning, and hundreds were soon repeating the phrase, although few of them understood its significance.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- Clyde Fitch, the author of "Barbara Frietchie," which was written for Miss Julia Marlowe and which will be the opening attraction when she appears at the Criterion Theatre in this city, attended a rehearsal of the play today. After the rehearsal Mr. Fitch consented to make public for the first time the stage story he has evolved for Miss Marlowe.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- Boston won two games from the New Yorks to-day. In the first game Gettig was batted hard, while Willis kept the hits well scattered. In the third inning of the second game two bases on balls and six hits gave Boston five runs and the game. The second game was called at the end of the sixth inning on account of the cold weather. Scores:
