There is every indication that the season of grand opera to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House by the forces of the Maurice Grau Opera Company, which opens in this city on Dec. 18, will be one of the most brilliant that New York operagoers have ever witnessed, judging from the plans outlined by Mr. Grau yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- This week will probably see another advance in spruce lumber. The dealers and manufacturers are expected to meet and make a new schedule, as they say there is a chance for quite a rise in their commodity under the agreement, which calls for $17 for frames nine inches and under, and $18 for twelve inches and above.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 2. -- It is now estimated that 1,500 persons perished in the earthquakes in Asia Minor, around Aidin. The first shock occurred at 4 in the morning of Sept. 20, and lasted forty seconds. The effects were appalling. Whole villages were completely destroyed. The earthquake was felt as far as Scio, Mitylene, and Smyrna.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Anti-Imperialists' League of Washington has adopted resolutions denouncing the "evident purpose of Great Britain to overthrow the Transvaal Republic and appropriate its territory." The resolutions recite: ...

The New York Presbytery yesterday held its first meeting since the June adjournment in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street. It was the regular semi-annual meeting. The most important communication of the day's proceedings, made officially, was given out by Dr. G.W.F. Birch, the Stated Clerk, who, after the afternoon adjournment, said that the meeting "went off smoothly, and there were no squabbles at all."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- The unique "Little Town Elections" were held in Connecticut to-day, 162 of the 168 towns in the State electing town government officials.

That is an extraordinary, so far as we know an entirely unprecedented, series of precautions which the United States Government has taken in order to insure a fair field and no favor to the Shamrock and the Columbia, The publication of the details of it must have been viewed with apprehension and alarm by all the owners and skippers of tugboats and excursion boats in these waters.

With the thermometer but 8 degrees above the freezing point, energetic women of the Morris County Golf Club started out yesterday morning on their links, near Morristown, N.J., in the qualifying round for the Bushnell silver cup. In this party of cold-weather players were Mrs. W. Fellowes Morgan, Miss Swords, Miss Slade, Miss Howell, and Miss Hurlbut.
The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court resumed its sessions yesterday after the Summer vacation. The ordinary work of the October term will not be taken up until to-day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Only one public reception will be given President McKinley while the latter is in Chicago to attend the Fall Festival. The original intention was to hold two receptions, one under the auspices of the Grand Army of the Republic at Memorial Hall Tuesday afternoon, Oct. 10, and another under the auspices of the Festival Committee at the Auditorium, Wednesday, Oct. 11.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Oct. 2. -- The Postmasters of Kansas and, it is believed, those of all the other States, have been assessed for the Republican campaign fund in Ohio. The assessment is made by letters written by Chairman W.F. Burdell of the Finance Committee of the Ohio Republican State Executive Committee, and dated at Columbus on Sept. 29.

All officers of the navy are instructed in diplomacy while they are acquiring acquaintance with navigation, ordnance, ship and shore drill, electrical and steam power, languages, and discipline. Some of them develop a taste for international law that makes them extremely useful.

It is the general report of all observers that in the crowded festive days of last week the interest and admiration of the thronging people were expressed more uniformly and enthusiastically toward Gov. ROOSEVELT than toward any one else of the distinguished company who were the guests of the city, with the single exception, of course, of Admiral DEWEY.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The prospect of war between Great Britain and the Transvaal was the predominant factor in all the grain and provision markets to-day, and caused sharp advances in some instances. A big foreign demand for American cereals was also a feature. December wheat closed 1 1/4 cents higher and May 1 1/2 1 5/8 cents higher.

There was an engorgement of business in the financial district yesterday. It was due to the holidays from Thursday afternoon, and involved banks, Exchanges, and commercial houses and the Government offices. At the Custom House there was a rush of business that would have swamped the officials and clerks had the transactions pertaining solely to the day been beyond the ordinary.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 2. -- At a meeting of Universalist clergymen this morning in the Universalist public publishing house, the Rev. H.W. Smith of Tufts College expressed his opinion that the Congregational Council "was a dead failure from whatever point of view one may choose to look at it."

ST. JOHNS, N.F., Oct. 2. -- The British steamer Prodano, Capt. Scroggie, twelve days from Baltimore for Leith, with a general cargo, went ashore last night at Peter's River, St. Mary's Bay, during a dense fog, and is a total wreck. The ship struck in an inlet called Wild Cove, striking the rocks bow on.

The collection of taxes for 1899 began yesterday, and at the close of business. Col. David E. Austen, the Receiver of Taxes, estimated that the total amount taken in in his principal and branch offices during the day would aggregate fully $11,090.000.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The Republican Judiciary Convention of the Eighth District was held to-day and resulted in the nomination on the first ballot of the present incumbents -- Daniel J. Kenefick, Truman C. White, and Warren B. Hooker.
NISCH, Servia, Oct. 2. -- A ukase has been issued raising the state of siege established in the Department of Belgrade at the time of the attempted assassination of ex-King Milan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Secretary of War Root is seriously considering action looking to the annulment of the existing contracts with the Atlantic Dredging Company on the charge of conspiracy, of which Capt. Carter, a member of the company, was found guilty. This company has contracts for making improvements on the Savannah River and Cumberland Sound.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- Word has been received here that Fred T. Moore, the defaulting assistant teller of the National Bank of Commerce of this city, has been arrested in Valparaiso, Chile. The cable announcing the arrest came from the United States Consul at Valparaiso. The police say there is no treaty with Chile, and it may be that Moore cannot be brought back to this country Moore is charged with the embezzlement of $53.000.

Your paper of Saturday, Sept. 30, contained a series of statements concerning the affairs of Plymouth Church which indicate that some one, probably pretending to be connected with our church, but not so in fact, has been giving you information in which there is no element of truth.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Gen. Otis cables the following deaths since last report.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- To-day the State Tax Commissioners made public here the brief or opinion prepared for their guidance in enforcing the franchise tax law by their counsel, J. Newton Fiero of Albany, under assignment of Attorney General Davies. It will be noted that the opinion of the special counsel does not advise the adoption of any hard and fast rule applicable to all cases.

Frank R. Sharrott, in connection with W. Wallace Detrick, has sold for the Leopold Kahn Company the seven-story apartment house at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Eighty-seventh Street, known as the Rangeley, 100 by 87.6, for about $275,000. The Rangeley will be under the management of Mr. Detrick.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- A special dispatch from Pretoria says that Gen. Jan Kock will command the Boer forces on the Natal border, Commandant Cronje on the southwestern, and Gen. Schalk Burger on the eastern frontier, while Gen. Malan will be in command at Rustenburg. Altogether there will be nine Generals in command of columns.
HAVANA, Oct. 2. -- The yellow fever report for September shows there were eighteen deaths, eight of the victims being Americans and eight Spaniards. The others were one Frenchman and one German.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 2. -- There were 10,000 people on the grand stand at the fair grounds when the distinguished persons who have come from points outside of the State to attend the Democratic carnival put in an appearance.

It was just ten years ago, with the celebration of the centennial of WASHINGTON'S inauguration, to wit, that the people of this town woke up to the consciousness that they had some talent in the pageant-making way, that they liked it, and that it behooved them to develop it.

While the case of Capt. O. M. CARTER was under consideration by the President and was being discussed by the press, a number of engineers, some of them in charge of improvements in rivers and harbors, contributed to the defense of Capt. CARTER very earnest remonstrances against approval of the verdict of the court-martial that convicted that officer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- A dispatch from Gem Otis was received at the War Department this morning giving an account of his meeting with the insurgent envoys. Gen. Otis said the interview with Aguinaldo's representatives indicated that the leaders were manoeuvring solely with a view to secure recognition of the insurgent Government.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- In anticipation of today's race between the Columbia and Shamrock. The Evening News has erected an immense canvas facing the Thames Embankment, upon which there will be flashed every ten minutes pictures of the course of the race.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 2. -- The Brooklyns won a close game to-day. Both pitchers did good work, but were rather poorly supported. Score:

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Senator John Ford of New York, the framer and introducer of the original Franchise Tax bill, was in the city late this afternoon and consented to be interviewed as to what he thought of Mr. Fiero's opinion. He said:

The Democratic candidate for Governor in Ohio has opened his campaign with a violent attack on the policy of the Administration in the Philippines. He finds that he has exposed himself to a hot fire in the rear or at least on the flank.

Mrs. Thomas P. Ryan of this city has increased her gift of land to the Sisters of the Perpetual Adoration in Washington, D.C. She originally purchased a plot 70 feet front and 145 feet deep on V Street as a site for the new Convent of the Blessed Sacrament. Her second purchase of an adjoining 20 feet of land is designed to afford more room for the proposed structure.

NEWBURG, Oct. 2. -- The finding of the dead body of John Hess, in the Matteawan Creek this afternoon, partially unraveled a mystery which has been puzzling the police of Fishkill Landing and Matteawan and the man's family for several days.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The announced intention of the British Cabinet to meet to-morrow has, apparently, been reconsidered. It is now said that the meeting depends largely on the developments in the Transvaal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Sept. 30 the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,148,905,780, a decrease for the month of $8,400,775. This decrease is accounted for by a corresponding increase in the cash on hand.

United States Circuit Judge Lacombe last night issued a writ of habeas corpus in the case of Capt. Oberlin M. Carter. The writ was granted in Chambers, at a late hour, and on an ex-parte application. It is returnable to-morrow.

The flagship Olympia, anchored off One Hundred and Sixth Street, North River, was the scene of general disappointment yesterday, both to the crew of the vessel and to thousands of would-be visitors. The landsmen were anxious to get aboard, and were unable to do so except in very limited numbers.

Mr. William H. Crane is a patriot as well as an artist. Since he has been a star actor on his own account, he has produced only American plays. No one else in his generation has encouraged that elusive bird, the native dramatist, so bravely, so generously, so steadfastly as Mr. Crane. He must have faltered sometimes, but he has never permitted the public to see him in the act of faltering.
MANILA, Oct. 3. -- The Fourth Infantry Regiment, Major Price commanding, has had a series of encounters with the insurgents about Imus since, Saturday.

OYSTER BAY, Oct. 2. -- Gov. Roosevelt laid the cornerstone of the new Free Library Building here this afternoon. The Governor was in a happy mood, and talked for a short time. It was not a set speech, and was largely devoted to Oyster Bay affairs. The new building stands on Main street on a hill which overlooks the bay.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 2. -- Five men who were held in the county jail here for robbing the Portsmouth car stables about two months ago escaped from that institution at 9:45 o'clock this morning. After a lively chase, in which the entire police force joined, all five men were recaptured and replaced in the jail within two hours from the time of their escape.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- By comparison with the splendid welcome he received in New York, Admiral Dewey's home-coming must have seemed tame to him; but it seemed to move and please him, for though it was not so magnificent, it was the welcome of his old friends and neighbors. It was a homely, heartfelt welcome.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Admiral Dewey has, to use his own pronoun, put "his university" into high good humor.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 3. -- The Common Council of Poughkeepsie adopted a resolution to send an invitation to Gilbert H. Purdy, the gunner of the Olympia, who is reported to have said during the battle of Manila Bay, "To hell with breakfast; let's finish 'em now," to visit Poughkeepsie as the guest of the city.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- The Secretary of State's clerks are finishing up the work of sending registration books to military posts of the Federal Army under opinion of Attorney General Davies and the law of 1898, which provides that residents of this State in the army and navy may vote in the field or aboard ship "while the country is at war."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The Philadelphia Commercial Museum will present to Admiral George Dewey a handsome scroll, inviting him to attend the opening ceremonies of the International Commercial Congress at the National Export Exposition in this city on Oct. 12.

When Mr. QUIGG the other day spoke with enthusiasm about the way in which his party had been deprived of patronage in the National civil service he probably had somewhere up the sleeve of his consciousness a keen appreciation of the contrary effect of the order of the President restoring to the spoilsmen so many thousands of places.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- A unanimous decision was handed down in the Court of Appeals this afternoon in the matter of the appeal of the Equitable Life Assurance Society from an order and judgment obtained by Emil Greeff, the respondent, in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in the second department.

We have been so accustomed to assuming that the yachting supremacy of the world necessarily lay on this side of the ocean that any evidence to the contrary is necessarily repulsive. And yet, why not? There have been, to put it mildly and modestly, a dozen racing yachts built in British waters to one that was built in American waters.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- The Anglo-Venezuelan Boundary Arbitration Commission rendered its verdict to-day, fixing the boundary line between the United States of Venezuela and the colony of British Guiana. Great Britain obtains almost its extreme claim, offset, however, by a cession of a small amount of land near the Orinoco River and in the interior.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- If there has been some lukewarmness of interest in the race for the America's Cup hitherto, London has amply atoned. No event in the annals of sport ever created here such intense and universal excitement as has been displayed over the result of the race between the Shamrock and the Columbia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Following is the description of the sword presented to-day to Admiral Dewey:

Pursuant to the writ of habeas corpus granted on Monday night, Capt. B.K. Roberts, commandant of Governors Island, will produce ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, at 11 o'clock this morning, when the question of the legality of the sentence imposed by the court-martial which tried and convicted him will be argued.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3. -- The sunlight of a perfect October day greeted the opening of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association.

Will you kindly give space at this time to the following short article by a lover of justice, bearing on the grand work of the Legal Aid Society, for doubtless there are many thousands of people visiting the city at this time who have never heard of the work of this society or who have any idea that such a philanthropic agency exists?
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- President McKinley, in honor of Admiral Dewey, gave to-night the largest dinner party in the history of White House social functions. Covers were laid for over eighty persons.

Army Secretary Peyton, of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, who returned yesterday from a stay of six months in the Philippines, declares that the United States has 45,000 ' drunkards, rakes, and gamblers" in in and around Manila, and that religious progress is quite out of the question while American soldiers are there.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Stories of the movements of Boers and British, of the hurried muster and dispatch of troops on both sides, come from many points. A telegram from Ladysmith, Natal, says that the Orange Free State troops have occupied and closed Botha's Pass, on the Free State border, and that Commandant Allriche, Chief of the Free State Artillery, is proceeding in the direction of Kimberley with a considerable force of artillery.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Natal authorities have announced that no more mails will be dispatched to the Transvaal until further notice. Last Friday's mail was sent back from the frontier.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- All this morning's papers have editorial articles on the race for the America's Cup. The Daily Mail says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- It is an unusual thing for a public man, in the presence of an immense multitude of his fellow-citizens, to interrupt with applause a presentation speech made to him by another public man. It is still more surprising when the person who does this is as modest a man as George Dewey.

Mrs. Kate Quinlan, a chambermaid employed in the Hotel Netherland, was yesterday before Magistrate Meade, in the Jefferson Market Court, charged with stealing about $10,000 worth of goods from hotel guests. The woman's thefts are said to have extended over a period of fifteen years. In her room at the hotel the house detective found 500 lace handkerchiefs, 150 diamond and gold collar buttons, scarf pins, cuff buttons, and various pieces of jewelry.

Ex-Gov. PATTISON of Pennsylvania, in a recent conversation with a reporter, said in response to an inquiry about the Philippine situation: "We cannot withdraw. Withdrawal would wound our honor and would invite the invasion of other nations. Whatever be our state now, withdrawal would make our last stage far worse than our first."

We reprinted yesterday an extract from an article in The Plain Dealer of Cleveland sharply criticising the attitude of the Democratic candidate toward the policy of the Government in the Philippines. The same paper follows this by an attack on Mr. MCLEAN of a much more personal character.

Controller Coler yesterday announced his determination not to pay the bills of the Staten Island Electric Company until he is assured by Corporation Counsel Whalen that the contracts existing between the city and that concern are legal He said that while he regretted that the company had turned off the lights in the Borough of Richmond because of the non-payment of the bills, yet he could not be "bluffed" in that way.
NORWAY, Me., Oct. 3. -- The Maine Musical Festival, which opened in the Auditorium last evening, was continued to-night under the leadership of William R. Chapman of New York.

IMUS, Luzon, Oct. 3. -- Gen. Lawton today dispersed the insurgents, driving them to the westward. The purpose of the rebels was to cut the communication maintained between Bacoor and Imus, by means of the road between those places, at a point between Imus and the east bank of the river.

Adelson Slone have bought, through Henry S. Hewson, 1,465 Lexington Avenue, which, together with adjoining property recently purchased, gives the buyers a plot 56 by 95. A seven-story apartment house will be erected on the site.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 3. -- A bomb could not have caused more of a sensation had it dropped in the Dispensary Board of Control meeting to-day than did the report of the special committee of the board appointed a month ago to investigate the management of the institution which is under the direct charge of Commissioner J.B. Douthit.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The Times this morning, referring to the award of the Anglo-Venezuelan Tribunal of Arbitration, says:

It is announced that the Committee on Stock List of the Stock Exchange has ruled that interest on contracts for Wisconsin Central securities, when issued, ceased last night, preparatory to settlement.

A correspondent in last Sunday's edition of your excellent paper, signing himself "A Veteran," under the above caption, among other questions, propounds the following "Are old veterans who have offered life and limb for this Union, who have experienced hard fighting and suffering, to be cast cut among the 'old iron' because we seem a little rusty?"

Society in its gayest mood, with its prettiest show of colors to match the many-tinted leaves on Autumn, and with its most elegantly appointed equipages, has in former years graced the Fall meeting of the Westchester Racing Association, especially the opening day, for at this season of the year racing at Morris Park is seen at its best.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the New York Clearing House Association, James T. Woodward was re-elected President of the association. Edward H. Perkins, Jr., was elected Chairman of the Clearing House Committee to succeed William A. Nash, who could not, under the rules, succeed himself. Secretary Francis L. Hine, Manager William Sherer, and Assistant Manager William J. Gilpin were re-elected.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The following is the dispatch of Gen. Otis received yesterday relative to the visit of the insurgent officers:

SAVANNAH, Oct 3. -- Capt. Cassius E. Gillette, United States Engineer, in charge of the Savannah District, this morning annulled the contract of the Atlanta Contracting Company for building a breakwater in Tybee Roads. This is the only contract the company had in this district. There is one in the Cumberland Sound district with which Capt. Gillette has nothing to do.

There are numbers of good, conservative people who look upon the breaking up of political parties with the utmost consternation. Having been exclusively attached to some special one all their lives, as probably their fathers were before them, they have insensibly imbibed the notion that all honor and virtue and principle are wrapped up in it, and all hopes of their country's welfare are centred in its triumphant success.

I have read your article in your issue of Sept. 25 under the heading "Coler on Condemnation," and having had some experience in such proceedings, I will give you my views. We all agree with the Controller that the burden of the taxpayer should be lessened, and anything that produces that effect will be welcomed.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 3. -- The second and last day of the Democratic carnival in conjunction with the Texas State Fair was the most successful from point of numbers of any political gathering in the history of the State.

Wall Street's market seems to have about reached the point where the only question left is: Have American securities really got value -- does prosperity count, do profits profit? Curious negatives to this inquiry are met. Traders on the Stock Exchange who have for a long time proved their cleverness take the position that it is better to sell than to buy, under current circumstances.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- The news from St. John's, N.F., that the Warren liner Bay State, the finest vessel of the line, had been stranded north of Cape Race, and that only part of her crew had landed, caused consternation among the local underwriters, where the cargo is heavily insured.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- Play in the intercollegiate lawn tennis tournament was commenced to-day on the courts of the New Haven Lawn Tennis Club.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- At to-day's session of the International Geographical Congress and in the presence of a distinguished audience, including many colonial and other Government officials, Poultney Bigelow discussed "Colonial Administration in Different Parts of the World." The paper was received with much applause.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Secretary Root, Secretary Hitchcock, Attorney General Griggs, Senator Hanna, Chairman Boutelle of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, ex-Secretary Bliss and Myron Herrick of Cleveland had an informal talk with the President to-night on the Philippine situation, during which the President in a few words stated his position.

With a percentage of that element known as luck largely in her favor, and in a fluky wind that ranged from twelve knots an hour to a "Paddy's hurricane," Sir Thomas Lipton's aspirant for international yachting laurels managed to hold Columbia in the first of the series of races for the America's cup.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The culmination of Admiral Dewey's triumphal home-coming was reached to-day in the shadow of the dome of the National Capitol. Here he received from the hands of the President the magnificent jeweled sword voted to him by Congress in commemoration of the victory of Manila Bay.

In your issue of the 29th of September, in a letter signed "George Wilson," occurs the following: "Scotland and Ireland once sacrificed their sons in fighting against England; they equally sacrifice them now fighting for her."

John G. Agar of the law firm of Agar, Ely Fulton, who for the last three years has been officially identified with the reform and progressive element in educational matters in this city, yesterday sent his resignation as a member of the School Board of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx to Mayor Van Wyck.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Brooklyn scored an easy victory in the first game to-day, and Washington won the second by good batting. The second game was called on account of darkness. Attendance, 3,000. Scores:

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Sadie Weisman, formerly an inmate of the State Industrial School for Girls, at Trenton, died in the General Hospital here this afternoon about half an hour after an operation, which was performed by Drs. Rogers and Curts in the hope of prolonging her life.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4. -- The Woodburn trotting stock sold well to-day, twenty-eight head averaging nearly $450.

Rear Admiral Schley, amid much enthusiasm, was installed as Commander of the New York State Commandery of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States, at a meeting of that organization at Delmonico's last evening. The Commandery holds four meetings each year. That of last night was the regular October assembly, at which officers are elected for the ensuing year.

HONOLULU, Sept. 24. -- William H. Marshall, editor of a defunct newspaper, has been found guilty of criminal libel, having attacked Chief Justice Judd. Marshall was sentenced to six months at hard labor. He has appealed the case.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- A telegram from Johannesburg says that State Secretary Reitz of the Transvaal informed a correspondent of The Standard and Diggers' News that the proclamation of martial law is being delayed.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 4. -- Replying to a telegram asking for a direct statement from him concerning the report that the Southern Railway system had acquired full control of the Cincinnati Southern, President Samuel Spencer of the Southern telegraphs from New York as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Secretary of War to-day directed Capt. Gillett, in charge of the harbor of Savannah, to advertise for a new project for that work, the contract with the Atlantic Contracting Company, made by Oberlin M. Carter, having been annulled.

The Rainy Day Club discussed rain and short skirts at its first meeting of the season yesterday. Mrs. Florence Jackson Stoddard talked of rain, and gave the club members a bit of rhyme which they are to repeat on rainy days when they cannot appear in their short skirts. It runs:
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The following dispatch from a correspondent who has been at Bloemfontein and Pretoria is telegraphed to The Chronicle:

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 20. -- The court-martial which was in session here for several months trying, in the absence of most of them, the Chiefs of the revolutionary movement which began in February at Bluefields, has proclaimed its decision. Gen. Pablo Reyes and two or three other insurgent officers who escaped from Nicaragua are condemned to suffer the extreme penalty of the law, which is death.

The Columbia and Shamrock will make another attempt to-day to sail over the windward and leeward course to decide the first of the series of races of 1899 for the blue ribbon of the seas. Both boats are tuned up to concert pitch, and their respective owners are confident of victory for their special favorites.

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 4. -- The Brockton Fair opened to-day with the largest attendance in its history, over 13,000 people being present. It was Children's Day, and the morning was given up to children's sports and a Dewey celebration. Five thousand children sang National airs, while waving Old Glory, each of the children being presented with a flag.

John McCullagh, Superintendent of Elections for the Metropolitan Election District, announced yesterday that he had in his possession evidence of violations of law at the primary election on Sept. 19 in the Ninth Assembly District, where John C. Sheehan as leader. Mr. McCullagh stated that he had conferred with the Attorney General with a view to having the Governor appoint a special term of the Supreme Court to investigate the matter.

There was a lively discussion yesterday at the meeting of the School Board for the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx over the pay of special teachers of German in the public schools. There are fifty-five of these teachers, who are paid at the rate of $1.50 for every hour that they teach. The motion was made that the rate be increased to $2 per hour, special teachers of other branches receiving that amount.

In 1745 a resolution was presented in the British Parliament "That for the firmer establishment of his Majesty's throne on the solid basis of his people's affections it should be our speedy care to frame such bills as may effectually secure to his Majesty's subjects the perpetual enjoyment of their undoubted right to be freely and fairly represented in Parliament, frequently chosen, and exempted from undue influence of any kind."

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The award of the Anglo-Venezuelan Boundary Arbitration Commission is referred to by the afternoon papers as eminently satisfactory from the English point of view, but as hardly a proof of the practicability of universal arbitration.

After a brilliant start in the international cricket match with the English team of cricketers, headed by the Indian Prince, K.S. Rinjatinshji, the All New York cricket team, representing the Metropolitan District Cricket League and the New York Cricket Association, gave a disappointing exhibition at the wickets yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- A London news agency publishes the following dispatch from Volksrust, Transvaal, dated Oct. 3:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A split on political lines was narrowly averted in the meeting of the Pan-Presbyterian Alliance to-day. The trouble grew out of a resolution yesterday favoring arbitration as a solution of the difficulty between Great Britain and the Transvaal. Objection to this resolution was raised, on the ground that arbitration was out of place between a sovereign State and one of its dependencies.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 4. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad was held at noon to-day. The forty-eighth annual report of the Board of Directors for the fiscal year ended June 30 was submitted and approved. Besides the election of thirteen Directors, the meeting was called upon to formally decide four important propositions, as follows:

Carter's trial that they were daily doing the same things for which he was partly convicted be likewise investigated, shows a very narrow conception of the subject. If ex-Capt. Carter was a member of the contracting company which did the work of which he was engineer in charge there is not an engineer in good standing who would defend him.

The Republican district leaders in this city have agreed to act in harmony with the other organizations who conferred at the City Club Tuesday night relative to judicial nominations. This action, was taken at a meeting of the leaders yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Republican County Committee, 1 Madison Avenue.

The movement in favor of a permanent Dewey arch is being a trifle retarded by the contest for the America's Cup. Charles H. Nicoll, who has the work of getting together the men behind it, is finding it difficult to locate them in town on cup race days, and was uncertain yesterday just what day the meeting in the Directors' room of the St. Paul Building to form a permanent organization would be held.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- With music, streams of light, and patriotic enthusiasm Chicago's Fall Festival was formally opened this evening in the presence of a vast throng. At 6 o'clock the cords binding the banners lining both sides of the Court of Honor were cut and 25,000 yards of red and white bunting were released.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- From a conversation had this evening with Justice Brewer of the United States Supreme Court regarding the award of the Anglo-Venezuelan Arbitration Tribunal, it appears that the deliberations of the court did not proceed as smoothly and with the spontaneous unanimity which a perusal of the award would lead one to believe.

That is an extremely instructive as well as an extremely interesting article which Dr. ENGELENBURG contributes to the current number of The North American Review, under the title of "A Transvaal View of the South African Question." The Boers in South Africa have shown a curious ineptitude in appealing to the opinion of the civilized world.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 4. -- A Columbian, who is in the Sixteenth Infantry, in writing to a friend here, gives some interesting facts about recent fighting, and the enlisted man's opinion of the native soldiers and the methods now employed in fighting them by Americans in Luzon.

We rather suspect that the idea was that of Capt. EVANS.

The anti-expansionists, who persist in a negative policy in the face of much discouragement, and who have hung on to Admiral DEWEY with affectionate but misplaced tenacity for many months, will have to give him up.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The President to-day directed the immediate dispatch to the Philippines of a number of vessels of the navy, including the cruiser Brooklyn and the gunboats Marietta and Machias. The action is the result of the President's talk to-day with Admiral Dewey.

MANILA, Oct. 4. -- Reconnaissance from Mexico by the Fourth Cavalry toward Santa Ana, northeast of Mexico, and toward Arayat, due north of Santa Ana, developed the fact that the insurgents are in position at both points.

Referring to Mr. Montfort Aubrey's communication in to-day's issue of your paper, and particularly to his remarks about the value of the Missouri Reports, I am put in mind of a remark by Judge Leonard relative to those same reports of judicial decisions in my native State, that "they are not law, but merely Missouri Reports."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Gen. Otis has cabled the War Department the following account of the recent sharp engagements with the insurgents:

Columbia University commenced yesterday morning the one hundred and forty-sixth year of its academic existence with an enrollment of new students which, although not at this early date to be expressed in ultimate figures, nevertheless promises favorable comparison with past years. So far as can be ascertained, the total attendance is over 1,800 students.

There was a good card at Morris Park yesterday, but the attendance was light. Some men on the race track are blessed with remarkably good luck, as was shown on Monday, when Bromley Co. got off with $17,000, the winner's share of the Matron Stakes, because their filly, Indian Fairy, which was considered to have a very poor chance, won.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The momentary disappointment that the first race for the America's Cup should have fallen through has been followed by a feeling of satisfaction that the Shamrock has shown herself a worthy challenger; and hope runs high that she will wipe out a long record of defeat. Among yachtsmen great admiration is expressed for the way in which Capt. Hogarth appears to have handled the yacht.
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- A special dispatch from Newcastle, Natal, dated Wednesday, says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Admiral Dewey made an early start to-day to fill a number of engagements. After breakfast he joined one of his associate officers for a stroll out Connecticut Avenue, and on returning proceeded to the Navy Department, accompanied by Rear Admiral Farquhar, the new commander of the North Atlantic Squadron, and Capt. Lamberton, his chief of staff.

By the score of 6 1/2 to 2 1/4 goals the members of the Staten Island Polo Club won the Somerset Country Club Cups yesterday in the final contest on the Somerset Club's polo field at Bernardsville, N.J. The Morristown team was the one that came out at the small end of the game, and the result presented the unusual condition of the team which allowed handicaps being beaten on even terms.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- The game to-day was a pitchers' battle, in which Garvin kept the Louisvilles' hits well scattered. The Chicagos made their hits in two innings, scoring in each. Score:

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- The International Geographical Congress has referred to its Business Committee invitations from St. Petersburg, Washington, and Budapest with respect to the holding of the next session. The committee will communicate with the authorities at the places named, and will then determine upon a locality.

---- Appreciation of the remarkable success attained Tuesday by the Government boats in protecting the racing yachts from interference should not prevent recognition of the fact that the effectiveness of Capt. EVANS'S little fleet was a mere matter of course, while its use in this particular capacity was a phenomenon almost or quite without precedent.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- A meeting of the War Board to-day discussed and drew up arrangements to insure the safety of the route from Durban to Laing's Nek, so that large bodies of troops may, on disembarkation, be rapidly forwarded up the country to the front without confusion or crowding at the base.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The training ship Essex arrived at Algiers yesterday.

PONCE, Puerto Rico, Sept. 28. -- Planters and merchants are still waiting for relief while the Government and the Relief Committees are pauperizing the laboring classes in their efforts to care for them. The planters are waiting for a market to replace the one they formerly had in Spain. They are waiting for laws that will protect their property and for courts that will deal out justice.

Leopold Weil has sold for Oppenheimer Hamershlag the plot 75 by 125 at the northwest corner of Central park West and Ninety-second Street. This completes the sale of the plot formerly owned by the Woman's Hospital and purchased from that institution by the present sellers last year. The buyer of the corner mentioned is John V. Signell, who wlll erect thereon a seven-story apartment house.

Mrs. Walton Aims and her daughter of 9 East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, who were passengers on the steamship Scotsman, which was wrecked Sept. 22, on Chain Island, arrived at their home yesterday, and gave an account of their experiences. They lost all their clothing, but escaped without injury further than a sprained ankle, sustained by Miss Aims.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- President and Mrs. McKinley and party, including Dr. Rixey, Private Secretary Cortelyou, and the entire Cabinet, left Washington at 9 o'clock to-night for a half month's trip to Chicago and the Northwest. The President arrived a few moments before the time for departure, and, with Mrs. McKinley leaning on his arm, walked briskly down the entire length of the train shed, frequently acknowledging the salutes of a small crowd of spectators.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4. -- Play in the intercollegiate tennis tournament was continued this morning, and both singles and doubles were finished up to the final round. In singles Harvard got both first and second places, and is the favorite for first place in the doubles.

The Board of Estimate yesterday considered the estimates of the Departments of Charities, Fire, and Correction. No decision was announced as to the amounts either of these would receive, the Charities Department estimates going over for a supplemental report. All these requests were considered at an executive session of the board.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Oct. 4. -- The fifteen men reported missing from the Warren Line steamer Bay State, from Liverpool Sept. 25 for Boston, which was wrecked near Cape Race, were rescued by the tug Greyhound this morning. They had been adrift all night in an open boat, their ship having gone to pieces.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 4. -- The Bucknell University football eleven came to this city to-day from Lewisburg, Penn., to play the University of Pennsylvania team, and startled the football world by twice scoring on "Old Penn." The Quakers' score was 47. The kicking of Mathewson, fullback for Bucknell, was the finest seen here in a long time.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- Miss Julia Arthur's production of Emile Bergerat's play, "More than Queen," at the Park Theatre to-night, is regarded by the actress and her friends as her greatest achievement. A large and fashionable audience was much pleased by the fine spectacle which the stage presented and by the representation as a whole.

PALERMO, Sicily, Oct. 4. -- The City of Palermo and the surrounding towns and villages are en fete to-day in celebration of the eightieth birthday of Signor Francesco Crispi, the distinguished Italian statesman and former Premier, who was born at Ribera, Sicily, Oct. 4, 1819.

At the close of yesterday's stock market money rates were down to about 4 per cent. Earlier in the day -- at the opening of business -- the charge was materially higher, quotations of 15 and even 20 per cent. being announced.
NEWPORT, Oct. 4. -- It is reported that L.L. Lorillard has plans drawn for a new villa.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 5. -- Mrs. S.F. Barger entertained at dinner this evening. Thomas Dunn has returned from Boston. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Emmons are visiting in Boston.

Bishop Henry C. Potter is going to the Philippines. This was learned positively last night, although the Bishop himself is reticent as to his plans, and refused to admit anything more than that he was going to Honolulu. He will, however, visit the Philippines as well, and has allotted three or four months for his trip.

Wireless telegraphy is likely to be the subject of litigation. Prof. Amos E. Dolbear of Tufts College declares that he is the discoverer of wireless telegraphy, and he purposes taking steps to prevent Signor Marconi from infringing on his rights. Prof. Dolbear is prepared to show that he holds and controls the United States patent on the whole art of wireless telegraphy and wireless telephony.

No one who has shared the high appreciation by the Administration of the services and advice of Admiral DEWEY will assume for a moment that in advising the President to reinforce the Asiatic Squadron he was controlled by a mere desire to increase our military display in the Philippines.

Juliet M. Hotchkiss has bought from Andrew J. Connick the lot, 25 by 100, on the north side of Twenty-eighth Street, 150 feet east of Fifth Avenue, now occupied by a stable; also, from the Paran Stevens estate, the lot on the north side of Twenty-eighth Street, adjoining the foregoing on the west, 25 by 100.

There is a type of mind that resents any turn in the course of events casting doubt on its own infallibility. A person with this sort of mind is at once unfortunate and disagreeable. In private life he exposes himself to the impatient derision of his companions, and on the public stage he is in danger of being either mischievous or ridiculous.
CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, Oct. 5. -- To-day is "Imp day" in Chillicothe, and it is as great a day for Chillicothe as Dewey Day was for New York City.

Dr. Alexander Ritter von Dorn, editor of The Vienna Weekly Economist, and member of the Vienna Export Association and of various Austrian Chambers of Commerce, has arrived in this city on his way to Philadelphia, where he will attend the International Commercial Congress.

It is not remarkable that the return of Admiral DEWEY to Washington should have revived the rumors that a change is impending in the command in the Philippines. It is added that the President, although he has persistently and upon every suitable occasion proclaimed his confidence in Gen. OTIS, has been impressed by the opinion of President SCHURMAN, as well as by that of the Admiral.

The increasing interest of the German people in American affairs is shown by the action of the Frankfurter Zeitung in opening an office in this city for the collection of news for transmission by cable.

It was the theory of the late Representative GEORGE D. TILLMAN of South Carolina, brother of Senator BEN R. TILLMAN, that negro domination in his State and in the South was less to be feared than a division of the negro vote between the two leading parties and organized effort on the part of each party to obtain the largest share of the votes of the negro population.

HAVANA, Oct. 5. -- The police to-day raided a house in Matanzas suspected to be the headquarters of a gang of counterfeiters. The officers found in the fire a crucible of white metal and two molds, one for coining American fifty-cent pieces and the other for coining American five-dollar pieces. One man waq caught in the building, but the others escaped.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Navy Department was busily engaged to-day in arranging to reinforce the fleet in the Philippines, as suggested yesterday by Admiral Dewey in the course of his conference with the President. In going over the field of available ships, it was found that the plan conceived last evening of sending the Marietta and the Machias with the Brooklyn would have to be modified so as to drop the two gunboats.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Among the few who saw Admiral Dewey to-day were seven marine officers from Washington Barracks, headed by Gen. Heywood, the Commandant, who, attired in full-dress uniforms, marched up to the McLean residence at 5 o'clock this afternoon. They were immediately presented to the Admiral.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 5. -- The British steamship Rhodesia, Capt. Bates, from New Orleans to Hamburg, arrived at Lambert's Point to-day, having on board the complement of the schooner Carrie A. Lane of Bath, Me., who were picked up in the Gulf Stream Tuesday. Those saved are Capt. Frank Scofield, whose wife is with him, and eight men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The District of Columbia Democratic Central Committee met to-night to select a successor to the late Lawrence Gardner as the District member of the Democratic National Committee and adjourned indefinitely without choice, after taking eleven ballots.

It would be a difficult matter to find anywhere better sport than that furnished in these mixed races on the turf, which are common at this season of the year -- those in which the two-year-olds that have developed so rapidly until they are almost as big and strong as the three-year-olds are pitted against older horses.

The House of Refuge, which occupies the southern point of Randall's Island and commands the view of Little Hell Gate, caught fire at 1:25 o'clock this morning and the flames spread very fast. The fire started in the women's laundry. The alarm spread through the institution and the work of getting the inmates out was instantly started.

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- This is the eve of the Republican State convention, and in oldtime fashion the delegates from the distant towns and cities of the Commonwealth poured into the city, filling up the hotels and making the usual gathering places of the politicians miniature hives of hustle and bustle.

The Mazet committee reconvened yesterday morning, after more than a week's rest, in the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation. The committee took up the subject of the small houses in Bronx Borough Parks, and called Park Commissioner August Moebus, who testified that he is in charge of the parks in the Bronx, to explain why the little buildings are not torn down and the parks thrown open to the people.

Although the Englishmen really won a victory, All New York's team of cricketers managed to escape with a technical draw at the eleventh hour yesterday, just when a defeat by an innings stared them in the face. The visitors finished their innings before luncheon and at that time had a clear lead of 181 runs, and this was considered plenty to assure them of the verdict.
Senator WILLIAM E. CHANDLER has outlined a programme for the next session of Congress. Mr. CHANDLER is not always a prophet. He is never dull. He is seldom ill-natured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Industrial Commission resumed its sittings to-day, hearing the members of the Inter-State Commerce Commission on questions affecting railroad transportation, Chairman Knapp being the first to be heard. Replying to questions, Judge Knapp said there was no doubt that at the present time there was more or less discrimination on the part of the railroads in favor of individuals and communities.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 5. -- If present plans mature Gov. Roosevelt of New York will make some speeches in Nebraska this month. The commander of the Rough Riders has agreed to accept the State Central Committee's invitation to make a number of speeches here along the route taken by Bryan in his two week's tour to offset the effect of that gentleman's speeches.

The Society for the Study of Life, an organization of women, held its first meeting of the season yesterday at the Tuxedo. The society, which was founded last year, and of which Mrs. Almon Hensley is President, boasts among its members women physicians, preachers, and teachers. Men are excluded from the ordinary meetings.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- There was a repetition of the scenes of Tuesday night in Fleet Street and along the Thames embankment last evening, and the interest was keenly maintained until the abortive result of the Columbia-Shamrock race was known, when very great disappointment was expressed on all sides, and the crowd, which, owing to the precautions of the police had been more orderly, speedily dispersed.

The second attempt to sail the first of this year's series of races for the America's Cup was made yesterday and, like the first, it ended in a failure for lack of wind. When, fully four miles from the outer mark the competing yachts abandoned the race by mutual agreement. They were at the time on the starboard tack, sailing with their bowsprits even, but the Shamrock about fifty yards to windward.
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- An unconfirmed report says that martial law has been proclaimed in the Transvaal.

The first Fall meeting of the New York Chamber of Commerce was called to order yesterday by Vice President Henry Hentz, President Morris K. Jesup being ill at Lenox. Thirteen new members were elected, among them being Cornelius N. Bliss, Jr., Junius Spencer Morgan, Charles J. Peabody, and Henry Seligman.

What is said to be a case without a precedent in the history of medicine is the saving of a Brooklyn child's life by removing a metal screw from its stomach by means of raw silk, which it was induced to swallow with its food. The operation occurred two weeks ago, but it became generally known only yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- After Rear Admiral Schley was assigned to the command of the South Atlantic Squadron, to a delegation of Marylanders the President declared that he himself was responsible for the appointment, believing it to be an honorable one, and having great respect for Schley's abilities.

The conference on anti-Tammany judiciary candidates, which held its first session on Tuesday evening, met again at the City Club last night and, after a three hours' secret session, adjourned to resume its sittings to-night without having agreed on any portion of the proposed joint ticket.

The Mallory Line steamer Leona, commanded by Capt. Wilder, which cleared from Galveston Sept. 27, and reached her pier in the East River just below Fulton Street at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was badly damaged by a fire in her forward hold, which spread from the main hatch forward to the bow as soon as the hatches were opened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The opinion of Attorney General Griggs in the case of ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter of the army, upon which the President approved the finding of the court-martial, was made public to-day.

The Board of Estimate held two sessions yesterday, at which the estimates of the Departments of Health, Police, and Buildings were considered. At the first session, which was an open one, the heads of these three departments were heard, and at the second, which was an executive session, the requests were gone over item by item and many reductions were ordered.

NEW HAVEN, Conn, Oct. 5. -- The regular annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Tennis Association was held to-day at the close of the tournament. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President -- Raymond D. Little of Princeton; Vice President -- Beals Wright of Harvard; Secretary and Treasurer -- Howard Plummer of Yale.

LONDON, Oct 5. -- The Anchor Line steamer Furnessia, Capt. Baxter, from New York, Sept. 23, arrived at Glasgow this evening having in tow the British steamer Hostia, Capt. Ferguson, from Glasgow, Sept. 24, for Baltimore. The disabled steamer broke her shaft and lost her propeller on Sept. 28 and lay helpless for four days, until she was sighted by the Furnessia.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Oct. 5. -- As President McKinley's special train passed westward to-day the crowds at the stations grew larger and larger. The train carried many distinguished people. All the members of the Cabinet except Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage accompanied the President.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 5. -- Although the Presidential train crossed the Indiana line after dark to-night, and despite the fact that word had been telegraphed ahead to the effect that no stops of any considerable length would be made, large crowds had assembled at Fort Wayne, Peru, Logansport, and Lafayette.

A car on the Smith Street, Brooklyn, line had just crossed Fulton Street about 11:50 o'clock A.M. yesterday when an overhead trolley wire broke and fell to the ground. The end of the wire struck the hat of Dr. Henry Enton of 345 Clinton Street, who was crossing Fulton Street at the same time.

Marcus L. Hennion, son-in-law of the widow of Nicholas Dobbins, whose skeleton was found recently near West Caldwell, N.J., was arrested yesterday in connection with the supposed murder. He identified the skeleton at the morgue in West Caldwell, and was then arrested.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 6. -- The Princeton tigers came to town to-day and played their first game of the season. They had little trouble in vanquishing their opponents, the Maryland Athletic Club, 28 -- 0. At one time it looked as though the Baltimore boys would score. In the first half Wheeler fumbled.

If the strike by the journeymen jewelers which began on Monday is not settled soon the holiday trade will be affected and the price of jewelry will go up. Some leading retailers along Broadway and Fifth Avenue said yesterday that the effect is felt now, and they are apprehensive that their holiday trade -- the greatest of all the twelve months of the year -- may be impaired to the extent of thousands of dollars.

The arrest of two employes of the navy yard in Brooklyn last night brought to light what is believed to be a big conspiracy to rob the United States Government. Besides the two navy yard employes, a junkman who does an extensive business and is well known in Brooklyn was arrested in connection with the thefts.

Mr. Charles E. Homans, in your issue of Sept. 23, this year, believes he finds a "curious blunder" in one of my several translations of Dumas's "Three Musketeers" series -- part called "Twenty Years After" (not "Later.") It is not said that Admiral de Coligny was killed by the Great Duke of Gulse, but that a Coligny and a Gulse fought a duel, being the contemporary heads of those families.

The Mazet Committee presented a varied programme yesterday. It took up the investigation of the kind of gravel that is being used in the parkways in Brooklyn, the building of a bridge across East River in its relation to rapid transit, the letting of contracts without competition by the Dock Department, and the alleged extortion of money from the owners of stands on Dewey Day.
BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- The Republican State Convention to-day nominated the following ticket:

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 6. -- A good part of the population of Peoria, the second city of Illinois, to-day took part in an elaborate demonstration to welcome to their city the President of the United States. The great event of the day was the unveiling of a monument erected by Peoria's citizens as a memorial to the soldiers of the rebellion, living and dead.

Readers are reminded that, with this issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, is published to-day the regular Autumn number of THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, which it is proper to call a newspaper in itself. With this number THE SATURDAY REVIEW completes its third year, having grown from a modest eight-page supplement to the dimensions seen to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Gen. O'Beirne of New York, whom the Transvaal Government has appointed its representative in this country, arrived here from New York to-night, and has an appointment with Acting Secretary of State Hill at 11 o'clock tomorrow, when the matter of his recognition by this Government as the South African Republic's accredited Diplomatic Commissioner will be taken up.

Much as our Republican friends may regret the fact, it has been forced upon them that Vice President HOBART, although showing improvement of health with rest and the exercise of the greatest care, will scarcely be able to face again the ordeal of a Presidential campaign.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Albion W. Tourgee, the American Consul at Bordeaux, has sent the following communication to the State Department:

We look upon the submission to arbitration of the Venezuela boundary dispute as a victory for us in which the immediate parties to the contention and the rest of the civilized world ought to be glad to participate. According to the decision at Paris, a line has been drawn between the extremes of the two contentions.

While the Board of Estimate was considering the estimates of the Board of Public Improvements yesterday morning, Mayor Van Wyck seized, or rather made, the opportunity to announce that he was weary of his job, and that he would be glad when his term expired. President Holahan was explaining the amounts needed by his board when the Mayor exclaimed, "I know one public official who will be glad when his salary as Mayor ceases."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- A suggestion was made to-day of the possibility that a diplomatic officer of the United States might have to be employed to collect a lawyer's fee for an ex-President of the United States. The situation, it was admitted, would be unprecedented if it presented itself, but is not thought likely that it will.

In its November number, which ushers in Mr. John Morley's "Oliver Cromwell," The Century Magazine will make a notable departure. The illustrations of Mr. Morley's work and for the text of Ernest Seton-Thompson's "The Biography of a Grizzly," will be done in color. Not-only this, but the reading matter and some of the pictures of these and other articles and stories will be arranged in a manner we believe, so far unique in magazine publication.

On all sides we realize the existence of men who will find it impossible to fraternize with either of the two great parties next year. From every State come complaints against both. The dissidents are men of character and ability. Will the dissatisfaction crystalize into opposition to be felt at the polls?

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Superintendent Wennas of the Pencoyd Iron Works of this city and the seven skilled ironworkers who accompanied him to Egypt to erect the bridge over Atbara River, in the Soudan, were given a royal welcome when they reached the Pencoyd Works to-day. They are looked upon as heroes by their thousands of fellow-workmen and the whole force turned out to greet them.
I think that the disappointment of Mr. Henry A. Newberry would be exceedingly bitter if his letter in eulogy of Mr. F. Anstey did not call forth a few plaints of contradiction and reproof.
LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Kegan Paul will shortly publish his "Memories of the Past," which will include his own life and glimpses of the lives of others, such as Tennyson, Huxley, and Tyndall.

THE NEW YORK TIMES marvels that the country should regard that city as being out of touch and harmony with it. The explanation is simple. New York is not an American city. Its very name is foreign. It has foreign ways, foreign ideas, foreign tastes, foreign ambitions. It is filled by foreigners, ruled by foreigners, disgraced by foreigners.

" Little Journeys," Elbert Hubbard's charming volumes of chat about famous homes of people known and loved of men and women, books, and fames, are hereafter to be printed by the Roycrofters at Ye East Aurora Shop, and issued there-from, as well as the Putnams'.

I want to register a protest. I read THE SATURDAY REVIEW every week and immensely enjoy the fare spread before me. I read all the letters that are sent to you, Mr. Editor -- that is, those that you make public -- and yet I am tired. In the name of heaven, does anybody in this broad land read books on sociology, psychology, morphology, pedagogy, art, science, religion, politics, philosophy?

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Addressing a peace meeting at Carnarvon this evening, John Morley asked the country to realize the predicament to which it had been brought by unhappy diplomacy and the bedlamite counsels of the war press and the war party.
LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Tod Sloan met with an accident to-day at Kempton Park, one result of which was the defeat of Democrat, the American favorite for the Derby, by a head.

The Council Committee on Law gave a hearing yesterday on the proposed ordinance requiring speculators in theatre tickets to stand at least 100 feet from the entrances to places of amusement while plying their vocation. The ordinance was drafted at the request of several theatre owners, who were represented at the hearing by Abraham H. Kaffenburgh of the firm of Howe Hummel.

MANILA, Oct. 6. -- The United States transport Siam, which left San Francisco Aug. 19 with more than 300 valuable mules, the coming of which had been anxiously awaited, as mules are in great demand for continuing the campaign, arrived this morning and reported that all but sixteen of the animals had been lost in two severe typhoons under peculiarly distressing conditions.

The Supreme Court of Michigan says that the law does not give a right of action for damages to feelings merely. It "does not prevent offenses against good taste. It does not discriminate between persons who are sensitive and those who are not," and therefore leaves the sensitive to suffer. The court marvels at the impertinence which does not respect the feelings of others, but is unable to do anything to check that impertinence.
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The Daily News this morning asserts that an army corps will be mobilized to-day.

The differences of opinion that have caused the delay in the conference at the City Club, from which much was expected, appear to have arisen from a confusion as to the purpose of the movement. That purpose, as originally announced and as generally understood by the public, was to secure the nomination and election of judicial candidates pledged to not give any contribution for party uses.

I do not understand how there can be in a city like Oakland, Cal., where there is so much culture and general intelligence, a man whose opinions of authors' works are so harsh and biased. I have often wondered why Californians cared so little about Mark Twain's writings. I have been told more than once that his earlier books were only read by a small intellectual circle in San Francisco.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 6. -- The City of Boston will present to Admiral Dewey when he comes here, on the 14th, a gold watch costing $1,000.

-- On the day of the Dewey parade people to the number of several millions gave vocal expression to the emotions created in their minds by the sight of the Seventh Regiment. Since then a much smaller, but still very large, number of people have written more or less wisely on the question whether the cheers or the hisses which the regiment received were its just deserts.

A Wall Street expert estimate yesterday of the outgoing and incoming of money since last week says that the loss to the banks on balance to the interior through the express movement is on a larger scale than at any time this season. Taking the known movements of money, so far as may be obtained, the estimate places the net loss in cash to the banks at $3,913,790.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Marcus Hennion, who war arrested yesterday on suspicion of being the murderer of his step-father-in-law, Nicholas W. Dobbins, whose body was found buried under a pile of stones at West Caldwell last Monday, is still confined in the county jail here. The prisoner's wife, with her brother, Freeholder Judson Van Ness, called at the jail this morning to see her husband, but Warden Underhill referred her to Prosecutor Riker.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 6. -- The finals in the woman's four days' tournament on the Lenox golf links for the silver trophy given by David W. Bishop, Sr., were played this morning by Miss Cornelia Barnes and Miss Charlotte Stillman. Miss Barnes won by two up and one to play. Rain fell from the time they commenced until they had finished the eighteen holes, and the players were thoroughly drenched when the match was over.

Mr. Moss is undoubtedly a zealous and well-meaning counsel, and it is to the interest of everybody concerned, even to that of the City Government, so far as that is well-meaning, that his zeal should be according to knowledge. Frankly, we are obliged to say that the investigation he yesterday undertook of the building and operation of the stands for the Dewey parade was not of this kind.

Our people all have pride in our vast extent of territory, in our marvelous and varied resources, in our National history, our prowess in arms, our gallantry at sea. And so far so well. But how when it comes to the question of our literature? Are we as loyal here -- as discerning? I think not.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 6. -- Edgar C. Felton, President of the Pennsylvania Steel Company, which owns and operates the Maryland Steel Company, with a party of officials of the company to-day inspected the works at Sparrow's Point. In an interview, Mr. Felton said:

The steamship Picqua, Capt. Brown, arrived in Quarantine at 12:15 o'clock this morning with her cargo on fire. At 6:30 P.M. yesterday smoke was discovered coming from the after hold, and everything was battened down in order to smother it.

At a regular meeting of the Building Trades Section of the Central Labor Union of Brooklyn, held last Thursday evening, William Walton, the Democratic candidate for the office of Sheriff in Kings County, was indorsed.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 6. -- At an early hour this morning some one drove up to the home of T.W. Bates, cashier of the Merchants and Mechanics' Bank, in a hack and delivered a note signed by the Chief of Police, Wiley Williams, asking Mr. Bates to come to the bank at once, as the Chief had discovered a plot to rob the institution.

GREENPORT, L.I., Oct. 6. -- The Holland submarine torpedo boat made a trial run to-day over the measured course which is to be used in the Government trials in Little Peconic Bay. The little craft left her moorings in a heavy rainstorm with head winds and against a tide that caused the sea to run high.

QUINCY, Ill., Oct. 6. -- This was a day of days in the late history of Quincy. Early this morning, amid the booming of cannon and the playing of bands, President McKinley alighted from his car at the grounds of the Soldiers' Home, and later, from the stand in the square at the Court House, he, with five members of his Cabinet, addressed thousands of the people of Quincy and its surroundings.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Oct. 6. -- The State College football team, with substitutes and trainers, left here this morning for West Point, where they will struggle with the cadets to-morrow for football supremacy. The team is in very good condition, and as this is the first big game of the season State's supporters will watch the outcome with special interest, in order to get some idea of the full strength of the team.

" Kid" Lavigne of Saginaw, Mich., and George McFaddin of this city, put up a fight at the Broadway Athletic Club last night which for savagery and punishment has not been equalled in a number of years. In the nineteenth round Lavigne was knocked out, but he succumbed only after he had been punched into state of complete exhaustion and was unable to keep his hands up to protect his jaw.
HAVANA, Oct. 6. -- The Mayor of Havana, Senor Perfecto Lacoste, has issued an order directing that no Spanish flag shall be displayed in the City of Havana, except at the Spanish Consulate.

For the third time the committees from the Republican organization, the Citizens' Union, the City Club, and the Chamber of Commerce met last night at the City Club, 19 West Thirty-fourth Street, to see if an agreement could not be reached upon anti-Tammany candidates.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Through the efforts of a Chicagoan, Herbert B. Gehr, a company has been formed which proposes to build the first steam railroad on the Island of Hawaii.

This book, which is the work of Wilbur L. Cross, assistant professor of English at Yale, traces the rise of English fiction from the Motte Darthur to Stevenson, and is particularly full and interesting in its account of the earlier novels and their authors, indicating all Continental sources and other tributaries which have contributed to their development.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 6. -- Valuable zinc lands have been discovered in Kentucky less than 100 miles from Cincinnati, and near a railroad system. Within a few days a company of local capitalists will begin working a mine there. John J. Sullivan is President of the company, which is known as the Queen City Mining and Manufacturing Company.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Gov. Roosevelt did not receive a very warm reception here to-day. He came to Elmira at 9:30 o'clock this morning as the guest of honor at a memorial celebration in honor of the late Frederick Douglass. Republican politicians attempted to use his visit as a political deal to swing in line the colored voters for a Fall Assembly contest.

An edition de luxe is being prepared by the Croscup Sterling Company of the "Diary of Samuel Pepys," which will make its appearance as soon as the final volume of the popular edition of the "Diary," edited by H.B. Wheatly, shall have been issued. The new edition, which will be artistically illustrated, is limited to a few hundred copies.

Judge BROWN is very severe upon the arrangement by which HORGAN and SLATTERY have endeavored, as he more than intimates, to cheat their creditors. But nobody who has followed the proceedings which have culminated in his decision will be likely to say that he is too severe.

Stock market irregularity continues, transactions remaining relatively small. Still Wall Street talks chiefly of money market conditions and of prospects encouraging or discouraging as to the early future. Among the more active traders disagreement continues as to whether stringency is over or is to be increased.

Among readers of verse to-day, who reads Peter Pindar? But then who reads Spenser? Probably not ten men living have read through the "Faerie Queen." Who reads the "Anatomy of Melancholy"? And yet but for those two great books, how many books are alive to-day which would never have existed? Peter, too has helped to make other books which the world keeps alive, but he himself is on the top shelf of neglect.
CANTON, Ill., Oct. 6. -- Col. William Jennings Bryan sat directly behind President McKinley this afternoon while the President delivered a brief address to the citizens of this town.

Edwin G. Russell, General Superintendent of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, before the end of the month will change his headquarters from Scranton, Penn., to the Lackawanna Building, in Exchange Place, this city. It has been decided by Lackawanna's management to change the route of the line from the Bergen tunnel to the Hoboken station, so as to shorten it.

We have spoken of books as friends, as corresponding in sentiment to relatives, to relatives-in-law, to mere acquaintances. In each case, having personified the volumes in the library, there is found a suggestion for Autumn evening reverie in thought of their communal character. For individuals do hot dwell together and be still in isolation.

There is no mistaking the confidence that the publishers feel this year in regard to most remarkable transactions in books. Some say that it bids fair to surpass anything since 1891. Others say that it will be absolutely unprecedented. Even the more conservative and less demonstrative, however vaguely they may talk, show by their lists of books that they are disposed to tempt fate, personified in the reading public, to their utmost capacity.

Your mood is solemn. You have been reading the "Book of the Dead," speculating on the dynasties, trying to solve the mysteries of the oldest Egypt, and here comes Mr. Frederic Courtland Penfield with his "Present Day in Egypt," and then away goes contemplative antiquarian gropings, for with a stroke of his pen, 5000 B.C. is crowded out by A.D. 1899.

With the promise of a glorious breeze from the north and the prospect of a lively, jumping sea, the third attempt to sail a leeward and windward race of the series of 1899 for the America's Cup bids fair to be completed by nightfall to-day. One of the two fliers will then certainly have one leg of the cup.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- To-day's developments in the trial of the persons charged with gambling at the Club der Harmlosen indicate that the Special Commissioner who was intrusted to work up the prosecution was wholly unfit for the task. He allowed the worst offenders to escape.

THE TIMES is in general so accurate in its statements that I was very much surprised to read on Saturday last, in the editorial headed "The Church and Divorce," the following remarkable assertion: "Both [the Church and the State laws] admit divorce for the offense of adultery and for willful desertion, and contemplate as free from blame the remarriage of the innocent party to such a divorce."

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, speaking at Maidstone to-day at a luncheon specially arranged to give the leader of the opposition in the House of Commons an opportunity of expressing the view of official Liberalism regarding the Transvaal cirsis, said that neither side had shut the door upon further negotiations.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The great question exciting British yachting circles just now is whether or not Sir Thomas Lipton, in the event of the Shamrock winning the America's Cup, ought not to be elected a member of that exclusive body the Royal Yacht Squadron of which the Prince of Wales is Commodore and the Marquis of Ormonde Vice Commodore.

Conventions of both parties, to nominate candidates for the Assembly, will be held in the thirty-five districts of New York County next Monday night. The near approach of the nominating period has caused slate-making to go on at a rapid rate for the past few days, and in most of these districts the men who are to be named already are picked out.
The sales in London for this year of Illuminated MSS. and other MSS. was exceedingly large, and brought high prices. Among the leading MSS. these may be cited:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Admiral Dewey will accept a house in Washington, already constructed, instead of having one built for his occupation.

New church projects fill the air. They are put forth by almost all religious bodies and have to do with church extension or strengthening during the Winter. The same Presbyterian leaders who planned the Northfield pilgrimage are now planning uplift work at home. The leaders in the effort are the Rev. Drs. Wilton Merle Smith, Henry Van Dyke, John Balcom Shaw, J. Wilbur Chapman, George S. Webster, D.J. McMillin, and W.D. Buchanan.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Harriet Overheiser and Leander Crall to Abraham Ruth and I.M. Berinstein the plot of six lots on the north side of One Hundredth Street, 120 feet west of Park Avenue, 150 by 109.9.

Frances E. Milne, a woman printer, and who, with her printing office, runs the N.Y.B. Supply Company, at 12 Chambers Street, has brought a suit in the Supreme Court to compel Andrew Beiser, the President, and Thomas J. McManus, the Treasurer, of the Union Musical String and Gut Manufacturing Company, to allow the plaintiff as a stockholder to examine the books of the corporation and to compel them to render an accounting.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- Beginning Nov. 1, another advance in rates on grain and grain products will become effective. Representatives of the transcontinental lines decided yesterday to raise the rate from Chicago to the Atlantic seaboard on export corn from 14 to 20 cents per 100 pounds and from 18 to 22 cents on domestic corn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- The inauguration of President Hadley of Yale University on the 18th inst. will bring together a notable gathering of university and college Presidents. Nearly all the institutions of learning in the country will be represented by their Presidents.
