NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 7. -- The North Atlantic Squadron arrived at Hampton Roads at 8 o'clock this morning, Rear Admiral Sampson commanding. The six ships spent the night off Cape Henry, awaiting the New Orleans, which, owing to the heavy weather, was unable to keep her place in line. The little dispatch yacht Scorpion, however, held her own.

IOLO, Island of Sulu, Aug. 10. -- The Sultana Dowager, as we might call the mother of the reigning Sultan of the Sulu Archipelago, has shown an unexpected practical side of her character lately by actually making with her own hands a copy of the royal standard of Sulu.

The rowing season in the Harlem River closed yesterday with the annual regatta of the Harlem Rowing Club. Seven well-contested events were rowed over a half-mile course. The start was off One Hundred and Fortieth Street, and the finish off the boathouse at One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The Brooklyns scored an easy victory over the New Yorks at Washington Park yesterday afternoon, and, as the Bostons met defeat at the hands of the Philadelphias, the Brooklyns cannot be beaten for the championship.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Oct 7. -- A compact made between two slaves fifty years ago was faithfully executed here to-day, when the Rev. James Rosamond of the Methodist Church preached the funeral sermon of the Rev. Gabriel Poole, known as "Father" Poole, of the Baptist Church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Admiral Dewey has chosen J.W. Crawford as his official secretary. Mr. Crawford is an employe in the office of the Judge Advocate General of the Navy. He will hold the rank of Lieutenant in the navy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Yale defeated Bates College this afternoon by the Score of 28 to 0 in a well-played game of football. Twenty-two of the points were rolled up in the first half of twenty minutes. In this half the play was marked by the excellent running of the Yale backs, McBride, Sharpe, and Adams.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 7. -- Thirty-five hundred men gathered around the tables in the great banquet hall of the Auditorium to-night at the annual banquet of the Marquette Club. This banquet is a star event, and, although coming at the same time as the Fall festival, is not distinctively a part of it.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- While Erie train No. 9 was coming into Tuxedo Station this morning Mrs. George L. Rives, who was waiting with many others to board the train to attend the Goshen Horse Show, was struck by the engine and knocked down.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 7. -- Consul Marshal Halstead of Birmingham has reported to the State Department as a strange and unusual occurrence that an attack has been made upon a trust in England. "Once in a while," he explains, "a voice is raised in England against a British trust, but generally any protest is in low tones, and trusts are accepted as a necessary modern condition."
BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Gen. Benjamin Harrison and Mrs. Harrison, who arrived in Berlin last evening from Paris, viewed the sights of the town to-day, accompanied by United States Ambassador White.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- Public attention has been engrossed this week in following the proceedings of the International Geographical Congress. There was considerable comment among the delegates to the congress, as well as on the part of the public, during the sittings regarding the relatively unimportant share taken by the United States.

Capt. C.A.Q. Norton, now a merchant of Harford, Conn., who in the civil war lost his right arm at Fort Fisher at the head of a squadron of the First Maine Cavalry, figured conspicuously as a fearless citizen in upholding yesterday the rights of about 800 passengers on the steamboat Georgeanna.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- A new element of danger in the Transvaal situation has arisen in the exasperation caused throughout the British colonies in South Africa by the stories of brutal treatment of refugees by Boers. The accounts of outrages upon women and children are having their effect, and are being accepted, in many quarters hitherto incredulous, as confirming the anticipations of the savagery that would mark the progress of the war.

The production of "Die Meistersinger" in English by the Castle Square Opera Company suggests some pertinent comments on the fortunes of English opera in general. There is always a demand in the air for opera in the tongue of the people. Perhaps it is not a wholly genuine demand, but one which grows out of the knowledge on the part of a few persons that other nations have their opera in their own language.

The positive statement by Mayor Van Wyck at the meeting of the Board of Estimate on Wednesday that no increases of salaries for 1900 would be allowed is causing much uneasiness among the officers and clerks of the Board of Education, whose salaries are increased in the annual budget, which has just been adopted for the coming year.

Three or four years ago in a musical purletta called "Miss Manhattan," presented at Wallack's in the off season, Mr. Reuben Fax, in the person of Father Knickerbocker, was compelled by the author to break the current of irresponsible frivolity by putting into words his vision of the majestic greatness of the city which in the fullness of time would occupy the domain of his inheritance.
The Rev. Arthur N. Thompson, pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church, Jersey City, is preparing a series of sermons based on the question: "Why do not men go to Church?"

The Manhattan policemen have not yet entirely recovered, since the Dewey days, from the tender, conciliatory tones they used in addressing children and strangers, and which the number of the latter in the city brought out. If a New York woman happens to be up around the arch, loses her bearings for a second, and questions the officer, he immediately adopts this protecting I'll-tell-you-all-about-it manner.

A decision was handed down yesterday by Judge Thomas, in the United States Circuit Court, Brooklyn, which it is believed will end the dispute between the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and the brewers throughout the country, with reference to the rebate on beer stamps purchased on July 24, 1897.

Since Admiral Dewey's arrival, there has been much speculating, both by politicians and ordinary citizens, as to the probability of his being the next President. And this speculation seems to me not to be altogether without foundation. The Admiral accepted the invitation to visit Philadelphia and Chicago; no doubt, in each of these places an ovation equal to, if not greater than, that of New York will be given him.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The mystery surrounding the murder of Nicholas W. Dobbins of West Caldwell, whose skeleton was found buried under a heap of stones on Monday last, is as far from solution as ever. The Prosecutor's detectives are still at work on the case, but as far as can be learned have found nothing of importance to fasten the crime on Marcus L. Hennion, the murdered man's stepson-in-law, who is under arrest.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 7. -- The Naval Cadets played their first game of football this afternoon and held Princeton down to five points. Both teams did much more kicking than formerly, but several of the home team were injured in the rushes. The touch-down made by Edwards for Princeton was the result of a fumble by the Navy and was made near the end of the first half.

That the "Dewey Arch," properly developed, in accordance with the judgment of the architects and sculptors who designed it for the purpose it has so splendidly served, would form a noble and fitting monument to the American Navy is generally conceded. Not a dissentient voice has been heard on that proposition.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The Deutscherverband has arranged to hold monster meetings in the principal German cities to protest against war in the Transvaal. It has sent greetings to Queen Wilhelmina, "as the highest representative of that brother nation now so cruelly tried."

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7. -- Newport has been decidedly dull during the week, as the cottagers who are staying late went on to New York for the yacht races and quite a few staid over from the Dewey celebration and enjoyed the splendid weather in automobiling, golfing, and other out-of-door amusements.
BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- Senator Hoar returned from Europe to-day. He will go directly to the convention of Unitarians at Washington.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Navy Department has received the following cablegram from Capt. Hemphill of the Detroit:

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 7. -- The trouble between Miss Mary King, daughter of John A. King, and Frederick Wittmeyer, over the location of a roadhouse in this village has come to an end. Miss King has won a signal victory after a long struggle.
BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The trial of the Club der Harmlosen has stirred fashionable and sporting circles to the very depths.

International golf championship honors will remain in the United States for another year. The home players proved their superiority over their Canadian brethren yesterday on the links of the Morris County Golf Club, at Morristown, N.J., by the score of 93 holes to 0.

In the editorial in to-day's TIMES under the head of "Street Decorations," you severely criticise the absence of decorations on the private houses generally along Fifth Avenue. Your criticism is a very just one, but I think you are too lenient when you allow the imputation to be drawn from your article that the owners of the many fortified mansions along that avenue were absent during the Dewey celebration.
MANILA, Oct. 7. -- Aguinaldo, in a proclamation announcing the release of American prisoners and authorizing Filipino soldiers in the northern provinces to return to their homes, says:

Men in Washington and in the District of Columbia, that is married men, appear to be entitled to interest themselves in to effort to be made in the next Congress to secure approval of a codification of laws for the District that has been prepared by Judge Cox, one of the ablest and hitherto most respected members of the legal profession.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- A bright English boy who is visiting this country made up his mind that he would not leave America without shaking hands with Admiral Dewey.

About 200 National Guardsmen tried to qualify as marksmen and sharpshooters at the Creedmoor ranges yesterday. Weather conditions were fair. Seventy-seven aspirants succeeded in qualifying as marksmen and fifty-three as sharpshooters. Brig. Gen. McCoskry Butt was a visitor at the ranges and qualified in the sharpshooters' class.

"Music" seems to state his case clearly enough. The subject calls for little comment. In some of the theatres the entr'acte music is very depressing. In Wallack's, on Mr. Crane's opening night, a man was permitted to pound on that instrument of torture called a xylophone. When he finished there was much applause. Mr. Mansfield's attempt to have good music at the Garrick Theatre met with no public response.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 7. -- Brown tied Pennsylvania this afternoon, 6 to 6, in one, of the greatest football contests ever played in Providence. Brown scored her only touchdown after five minutes of play. It was Pennsylvania's ball on her twenty-five-yard line. The ball was passed to Outland for play, but he fumbled, and Cuddy picked it up and easily scored a touchdown. Richardson kicked the goal.

As Admiral DEWEY rode in triumph past St. PATRICK'S Cathedral, on Fifth Avenue, there hung high above him between the noble spires the banner of his country, and its ample and splendid folds vibrated to the notes of "America" rung out by the great chimes, while in the streets below thousands on thousands of faithful followers of the Roman Catholic Church shook the air with their cheers.

GALESBURG, Ill., Oct. 7. -- On the campus of historic Knox College, where, forty-one years ago, Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas met in one of a memorable series of debates to determine which should occupy a seat in the United States Senate, President McKinley and Postmaster General Charles Emorv Smith this morning delivered stirring addresses commemorative of the contest between those two great leaders of former days.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- The German Treasury Minister, Baron Thielmann, yesterday expressed his regret to me that the period of time from the announcement to the opening of the American Commercial Congress had been too short to accomplish much on Germany's part, and also that many of the German manufacturers were possessed of the idea that the congress would do them harm instead of good.

The Executive Committee of Tammany Hall last night appointed a sub-committee to confer with "all organizations desirous of a conference" on judicial nominations. This is Tammany's answer to the effort of the City Club and the Republican County Committee to form an anti-Tammany alliance.

Louis G. H. Murphy, an insurance agent, with offices at 20 East Forty-second Street, fell into the sub-cellar of the new Pabst Building on the north side of Forty-second Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, last evening and was killed.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 7. -- Nearly all the cottagers who went down to the Dewey celebration have returned. Not one of the country places has yet been closed, and the cottagers will have one of the liveliest Octobers in the history of Lenox, with boat races, golf, coaching parties, afternoon teas, tableaus, dances, and other entertainments.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7. -- Mrs. Madison Taylor, sister of J. Coleman Drayton; Miss Edith Taylor of Philadelphia, and Miss Braman are the guests of Dwight Braman, who returned from New York to-day.
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- "Man and His Makers," by Wilson Barrett and Louis N. Parker, was presented at the Lyceum Theatre this evening, in the presence of a fashionable audience.

It was a woman who had the honor of making the big silk Admiral's flag which waved over the White House in Washington at the time of the presentation of the sword by the President to Admiral Dewey, and she will always feel that she gets a little glory from the work in addition to the pleasure of doing it, for her initials were printed upon one end of it.

At a meeting of the Hoboken Quartet Club, held last night in Hoboken, Vice President Arthur Freund, Treasurer Herman Ruhl, and Financial Secretary F.W. Stammerber tendered their resignations. When asked to give their reasons for resigning, they refused to make any statement.

The informal opening of the Winter quarters of the Nassau Boat Club, at 160 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, was celebrated last evening. Many of the older members of the club were present, and the many prizes won during the season, which has been a most successful one for the club, were on exhibition.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- An old tar has been discovered at Portsmouth who says he was one of the crew of the America when she won the cup. His name is A.J. Williams. He rather scoffs at modern yachting. According to his story he joined the America at New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The real football work of the season has begun, and every effort will be made toward developing every man who eagerly aspires to a position on Nassau's eleven. The first weeding out of the candidates on Wednesday resulted in relegating some players to the freshman squad or relieving them from daily practice.

The atmospheric condition last Sunday were not exactly suited to cycling. Those who ventured out in the country had a strong wind to contend against. There were several century runs engaged in, but nothing in the way of order could be maintained in the various divisions. The less experienced riders dropped out before half the distance had been covered, becoming exhausted from riding against the wind.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7. -- Harvard won an easy victory from Wesleyan to-day with an eleven composed largely of substitutes. It was expected Wesleyan would have made a much better fight than she did. Indeed, Harvard's score was due more to the splendid individual playing of the half backs than to any superiority in team work.

Charles H. Treat, United States Collector of Internal Revenue in the Second District of this city, went to Chicago yesterday to attend an important conference of the principal Internal Revenue Collectors throughout the country. One purpose of this conference is to secure uniformity in the enforcement of the law.

Members of the Rapid Transit Railroad Commission do not expect that there will be any trouble in obtaining bids from responsible persons for the construction of the underground railroad. During the framing of the form of contract application was made to the board by several persons for information regarding the method of putting in bids, terms,
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to --
At Quincy, Ill., on Friday, the President said:

The third attempt to sail the opening race of the series for the America's Cup was made yesterday, and again there was a failure for want of wind. All kinds of experts came like young Lochinvar out of the West and prophesied gales, squalls, hurricanes, and divers winds of high and low degree for yesterday, but alas! the only things which really blew hard were the experts themselves.

Four Justices of the Supreme Court appeared before the Mazet committee yesterday and gave their views on the propriety of campaign contributions by judicial candidates and the need of reforms in the referee system. William J. O'Brien, representative of the Granite Cutters' Union, testified to the existence of serious defects in the stonework of the new Tombs Prison, and the committee, after a two hours' session, adjourned until Tuesday morning next.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- A delegation of Atlanta citizens called on Admiral Dewey to-day and invited him to become the guest of that city. The Admiral promised that he would go to Atlanta at some time not later than Nov. 1, the date to be arranged later.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- The City Council has again under consideration the rather formidable task of lowering the tunnels in order to allow sufficient draught in the river for the heavy traffic. The City Engineer has completed the plans, and he finds that the Van Buren Street tunnel will have to be lowered eight feet and eleven inches at the centre.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7. -- October will be spent in Baltimore in marrying and giving in marriage, and November will bravely follow its example. In fact, in the memory of the oldest inhabitant such a season for matrimony never before existed.

Freeman Strait was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday by Special Officers Brooks, Taylor, and Bivins of the Internal Revenue Service for selling restored stamps. Fifty stamps of the one-dollar denomination were offered as evidence against the accused man. Strait was held in $2,500 bail for examination to-morrow.

Under the pressure of the Pacific Coast States and some of their neighbors in the Far West, the Congress in May, 1882, passed an act "to execute certain treaty stipulations relating to Chinese." The reasons given in the prolonged debate were apparently those ascertained by the people of the States requesting the legislation.
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- A royal proclamation summoning Parliament to meet on Oct. 17 and authorizing the calling out of the reserves was signed this morning.

Friends and relatives of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt have been expecting since last Friday morning advices that he had reached San Francisco. He took passage from Yokohama Sept. 19 on the steamship City of Peking, which was due to arrive at San Francisco last Friday or Saturday. The fact that no word has been received from young Vanderbilt, however, has occasioned no anxiety.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- It required two long trains to carry the passengers for the Lucania from Euston Station to Liverpool to-day. Among them were Marcus Stone, R.A., and family; James Richmond, Philip Lehman and family, Charles Menzesheimer, W.L. Brown and family of Chicago, and W. A. Gaylord of the Chicago Board of Trade.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The question of Sir Thomas Lipton's eligibility for membership in the Royal Yacht Squadron is assuming large proportions. That exclusive body has blackballed many men who are not quite so immersed in trade as Sir Thomas. Among these Mr. Ashbury and the Duke of Hamilton have already been mentioned.

For the purpose of instructing bank officers and clerks in the work of equipping and conducting a banker's credit department, the American Bankers' Association has arranged to set up a model credit department in a room adjoining its office in the Commercial Cable Building, 20 Broad Street, this city.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Most important news comes from the Transvaal to-night, which, if true, probably indicates that the South African Republic is about to yield, or, in any case, that the Boers have abandoned all idea of invading Natal.

The conference at the City Club is composed of delegates from the club, from the Citizens' Union, from the Bar Association, from the Independent Labor Party, and from the Republican Party. It is announced that an agreement will be reached on a judiciary ticket which will not include the name of Justice BARRETT.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Great Britain is not likely to make a formal declaration of war against what she considers a dependent nation, the process being a mere issue of orders to the military forces to restore the state of sovereignty which she alleges originally existed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- A remarkable activity in the emerald market that seized the populace of Bogota, Colombia, is described by United States Minister Hart in his report dated July 21. He says:

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Charles Frohman will give the first English production of Hall Caine's play, "The Christian," next Monday evening at Liverpool. His adoption of American methods in launching the play in the provinces for a week's trial before producing it in London puzzles many English managers, but the Liverpool booking already justifies the step, despite the counter-attractions of Sir Henry Irving's farewell week.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- At 9:45 this morning the report of the Ramapo Water Company of Brooklyn for the year ended Oct. 31, 1898, was filed with State Controller Morgan in accordance with the requirements of Chapter 908, Laws of 1896, Section 186.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- Representatives of fifty manufacturing firms of fleece-lined underwear perfected an organization for the purpose of establishing and maintaining prices of underwear consistent with the recent advance in wool, cotton, yarns,

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Extraordinary scenes of excitement at Waterloo Station are of daily occurrence. Generally when troops for South Africa arrive from Aldershot or other camps and are marched from point to point, they are preceded by bands, sometimes three of them. The troops are followed by immense crowds, who cheer the silent soldiers madly.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- A Green Book issued yesterday, contains President Kruger's reply to Mr. Chamberlain's dispatch referring to the petition of the Outlanders to the Queen. The Transvaal objects to Great Britain's interference in its internal affairs, and explains that, if the Outlanders had first addressed the Transvaal, instead of the British Government, their complaints would have been immediately heeded.

WEST POINT, Oct. 7. -- West Point played her second football game of the season on the plain this afternoon with Pennsylvania State College in two fifteen-minute halves. The game was rather a disappointing one, resulting in a defeat of 6 to 0, Pennsylvania State scoring in the first half. The visiting team developed unexpected strength and beat West Point in every point of the game.

The reception in London of "The Moonlight Blossom," Chester Bailey Fernald's Japanese play, which Forbes Robertson and Mrs. Patrick Campbell have produced at the Prince of Wales's Theatre, seems to be much like that accorded here to Mr. Daly's beautiful production of a translation of Judith Gautier's "Queen of Smiles." As a play, the thing scarcely counts.
Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday remanded Alice Shand, for whom a writ of habeas corpus was secured Friday, to the custody of her parents, Thomas and Mary Shand.

The programme at Morris Park yesterday was one of the best that any racing association this year has presented. It included, besides the Champion Steeplechase, the Hunter Handicap for three-year-old fillies over the Withers mile, the rich Nursery Handicap for two-year-olds down the Eclipse course, an overnight handicap, a maiden race, and a selling race.

Acting Secretary Nicoll of the committee formed for the purpose of taking steps to perpetuate the Dewey arch said yesterday that the committee is being flooded with letters offering sympathy and practical help. "In fact," said Mr. Nicoll, "we are receiving letters from citizens in all walks of life.

NORYALK, Conn., Oct. 7. -- There is an interesting clash between the State Law and Order League and the Police Department of the City of Danbury, as a result of the state of affairs at the Danbury Fair this week.
I have read with much interest the two very timely letters addressed to you in behalf of better music in the theatres that appeared in your columns of last week.
CINCINNATI, Ohio. Oct. 7. -- Feeling between the University of Cincinnati on the one hand and the Hebrew Union College on the other is at high tension.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The fifth annual exhibition of the Horse Show Association of Orange County was held at the Goshen Driving Park to-day, and notwithstanding the counter attraction of the yacht races, was a success from every point of view. The -cather was superb, the entries were numerous and of high class, the attendance was very large, and the management of the meeting left nothing to be desired.

Wall Street still talks chiefly of the market for money. Forty per cent. rates were reached early during the week. From 10 to 12 per cent. has been the ruling quotation. At times there has even been nervousness shown upon the part of interests heretofore insisting that hurtful stringency need not be apprehended.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 7. -- An order in Council has been passed making some important changes in regard to placer mining in the Yukon. Under existing regulations it is necessary that $200 worth of work be done on each claim every year. This has been changed, and a fee of $200 will be accepted in lieu of the work.

The market apparently is at last feeling its renewed strength. Yesterday, after a hesitating opening, the quotation list took on a firm tone, and neither the fact that London proved a seller rather than a buyer, nor yet that the bank statement showed that the surplus reserves had dwindled perilously near to the zero mark, could prejudice the quotations to any appreciable extent.

Complaints of delays in the reconstruction and electrical installation of the Third Avenue Railroad Company's system have been heard for some time from stockholders, as well as from property owners along the lines of the excavations. Holders of stock in the different branches of the Third Avenue system have remonstrated with the officers of the company for allowing the contractor to be so slow.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 7. -- Tiring of the assertions made from the stump by Senator Goebel, the Democratic candidate for Governor, John G. Carlisle comes out today in a hot statement, made over his signature. The statement was especially inspired by the following remarks of Goebel recently at Versailles:

THE RUSSO-SERVIAN SITUATION. -- The recent announcement of the Vienna press cabled to this country, that diplomatic relations between Russia and Servia had been severed, recalls the definite commands of the former against the execution of the sentences announced against the alleged conspirators and would-be assassins of ex-King Milan.

WARREN, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- A street car on the Trumbull line, containing twenty-three people, was struck by the Cleveland and Pittsburg train on the Pittsburg and Western Railroad at Niles to-night and badly wrecked. Bert S Ward of De Forest was killed and Joseph Allen, Strickland Holton, Ella McBride, Mrs. Samuel Cartwright, and the two-year-old daughter of Charles Lintz of Niles were badly injured.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Sunday was not a day of rest for President McKinley. Besides receiving many callers, committees, and delegations, he attended three religious services, two in the Auditorium and the third in Quinn Chapel, where he spoke a few words of greeting to the enthusiastic colored congregation there assembled.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Every department of the Government to-day is as busy as though actual hostilities had begun. The announcement of the mobilization of the army reserves and the summoning of Parliament set every wheel of the Government machinery in motion. An hour after the Gazette appeared executive orders were being dispatched from the War Office to every section of the kingdom.

The nominations made by the County Convention of the Independent Labor Party last week, gave rise to a bitter dispute in the Central Federated Union yesterday. Although they were finally indorsed by a fair majority of the delegates, a previous test vote on the subject tended to show that the nominations have not given entire satisfaction.

BLOEMFONTEIN, Orange Free State, Oct. 8. -- The correspondence between President Steyn and Sir Alfred Milner, British High Commissioner in South Africa and Governor of Cape Colony, has been published. In a communication dated Sept. 26 President Steyn pointed out that the tone of the British dispatches was altered and that the imperial Government had departed from the original basis of negotiations with the Transvaal.

CANTON, Ill., Oct. 8. -- It was learned that Col. William J. Bryan was paid $600 for making his speech here Friday, and a member of the local Committee of Arrangements says that the Nebraska orator stipulated expressly that the money should be paid over before he began the address.

DUBLIN, Oct. 8. -- Daniel Tallon, the Lord Mayor, to-day marched at the head of a procession which this year replaced the usual demonstration at the grave of Charles Stewart Parnell in Glasnevin Cemetery, and subsequently laid the foundation stone of the Parnell Statue at the head of Sackville Street.

Early in the last session of the Fifty-fifth Congress the President sent to the Senate a long list of naval officers whose advancement for conspicuous service to their country in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans had been recommended by the Secretary of the Navy.

NOVELETA, Island of Luzon, Oct. 8. -Gen. Schwan's column, consisting of the Thirteenth Infantry, a battalion of the Fourteenth, two troops of cavalry, Capt. Reilly's battery of the Fifth Artillery, and Lowe's scouts, advanced from Bacoor this morning and occupied Cavite Viejo and Noveleta.

An anti-expansion league has been organized in this city under the name of "The American League." Its purpose is to oppose the expansion and "imperial" spirit in the United States, which is supposed to be growing as a result of the easy triumphs of the war with Spain. The first meeting of the organization was held early in September, and a platform of principles was adopted.

Transactions on the curb during the past week were in very limited amount. Now and then some stock became more than usually active, and on one or two days the total of transactions was fairly large, but as a whole the curb was lifeless. High rates for money continued, and the inevitable result of high money, at least as far as the curb is concerned, is a dull market.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 8. -- The culmination of the trouble existing between the State Law and Order League and the Danbury police force resulted late last evening in the arrest of S.P. Thrasher of New Haven, Secretary of the league, who was locked up at the Danbury Police Station on a charge of assault.

Walter Wellman, the arctic explorer, who recently returned from a journey of exploration in Franz Josef Land, arrived in this city yesterday on the steamship Umbria. He was accompanied from England by his wife. After luncheon, Mr. and Mrs. Wellman took a train for Washington, where they reside.

Looking hale and hearty after five months of rest and recreation abroad, United States Senator James K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, reached this city yesterday on the Cunard Line steamship Umbria. Willis J. Abbot and James Oliver, Sergeant at Arms of the committee, met him at the pier.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. "This year's corn crop will be one of the largest in our history," said Secretary of Agriculture James Wilson, who is in Chicago with the Presidential party, in an interview to-day. "The total yield, it is estimated, will be between twenty-three and twenty-five hundred millions of bushels.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- When Sir Wilfrid Laurier, Premier of the Dominion of Canada, stooped to kiss two little girls who were presenting a bunch of red roses to him on the stage of Studebaker Hall to-day, he won his way at once to the hearts of more than 2,000 people, who were gathered there to bid him welcome in the name of the French Canadians of Chicago.

Dr. James L. Guy, a dentist, of Corona, Queens Borough, and Miss Eliza McPherson, also of Corona, were married about midnight on Friday night by the Rev. J. Harmon Potter or Flushing. The ceremony was performed at the house of the minister, who was aroused from bed by the couple. The marriage is said to have been opposed by the bride's mother, so Dr. Guy and Miss McPherson took the matter into their own hands.

In the discovery of the leg of a woman on Saturday morning and the trunk of the body in the North River at about midnight of the same day the police are convinced that they have a murder mystery to solve quite as baffling at the outset as that of William Guldensuppe. The two crimes, in fact, bear a close analogy to each other.

Notwithstanding the interest that will be shown this week in the women's golf championship at Philadelphia, there will be considerable activity on local links. The postponed tournament of the Nassau Country Club, due to the yacht races last week, will be held on the club's new links at Glen Cove.
As evidence of the development of manufacturing interests, the following from the current number of Paper is both interesting and significant:

MANCHESTER, Oct. 8. -- During the last week the volume of business in yarns and cloth was small, with firmly maintained quotations. Light cloths for bleaching, printing, and finishing were still doing the best. The small total of trade was spread over innumerable small orders. The monthly trade returns are very favorable.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 8. -- The first tornado ever known in this State devastated a tract of land from 300 to 600 yards wide and 50 miles long Thursday afternoon. The damage done extends, from Orting, 30 miles east of Tacoma, to Mossy Rock and Osborne, in Lewis County. No fatalities have been reported, but orchards and fences were destroyed.

The Christian and Missionary Alliance for its closing week held a series of meetings yesterday at the Gospel Tabernacle and Carnegie Hall. The Rev. D.W. Le Lacheur preached at the 10 o'clock service in Carnegie Hall to a large audience. Mr. Le Lacheur devoted his time principally to a talk on the power of faith and prayer, and the great need of evangelization work among different peoples.
MADRID, Oct. 8. -- It is announced here that the Filipino Government has given full powers to Agoncillo to treat for the release of the Spanish prisoners now held by the insurgents.

All the more important Judges of our courts have now been before the Mazet committee and stated their experience and their views as to the payment of political contributions by candidates for the bench. There is a good deal of difference among them. It is worth while to examine their attitude with reference to the manner that public opinion is likely to develop on this question.

Yesterday morning we grouped together a few sentences from the speeches of the President and his Cabinet officers in Quincy, Ill., to show that it is "plain enough" what policy the Administration has finally adopted in the Philippines and the manner in which it intends to carry it out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Admiral Dewey to-day attended divine services at St. John's Episcopal Church, where the Episcopal special ceremony of prayer and thanksgiving for the crown of victory for our arms and for the safe return from sea was conducted by the Rev. Dr. Mackay-Smith, the rector.

G. Wolf Newman, the driver of a coal wagon, who lives at 958 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, was badly hurt by a trolley car of the Putnam Avenue line early yesterday morning at Howard Avenue and Halsey Street. His horse was killed, and another man's, John Johnson, who was also driving a wagon, and who got mixed up in the smash-up, was also slightly bruised.

Shut in a dark cellar with a wolf was the exciting predicament in which Park Keeper Schiffer found himself on Saturday. He has not yet recovered from the emotion it caused him. Park Keeper Schiffer was a very scared man. The wolf was the animal that escaped from the new Zoological Garden in Bronx Park on Oct. 3, and caused so much excitement in the Bronx.

The threatening weather of yesterday kept many Sunday drivers away from the Speedway, but it had no effect on the regulars, who were out in force with their fast steppers. The roadbed was in excellent condition, and the absence of the crowd gave the pacers and trotters an excellent chance to try their speed, which they did, and the result was many lively brushes between horses with and without records.

Michael Angelo, twenty-eight years old, an Italian speculator, was shot and killed yesterday afternoon by Michael Cangoes, a fellow-countryman, at Johnson Avenue and Humboldt Street, Brooklyn. The shooting followed a quarrel over some money the murderer owed his victim. The murder was committed in the presence of many passers-by.

While the rain was coming down in torrents last night a policeman saw three men drive a wagon up to the big grand stand at Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street, which was built for the Dewey parades. They proceeded with all possible speed to pile into their vehicle as much of the lumber as it would contain.

You have editorially characterized my statement in The Chicago Chronicle that the punishment of Capt. O.M. Carter, under the sentence of court-martial, was a "damnable outrage," and my comparison of his trial with that of Dreyfus, as "preposterous and absurd," as "useless and infamous."

M. Raffaelli, who, because he has painted so many Parisian street scenes, has come to be known as "the painter of Paris," arrived on the French line steamer La Champagne yesterday. He has come to this country to act as a member of the jury of awards at the annual exhibition at the Carnegie Art Gallery, Pittsburg.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed arrived in Washington to-night. He declined to discuss politics, saying he was here only to remove some of his private belongings.

CAPT. DREYFUS'S GRATITUDE TO THE LATE M. SCHEURER-KESTNER. -- The latest Paris papers to arrive in the city give a great deal of space to the late Senator Scheurer-Kestner, as a man, and to the ceremonies that attended his funeral. The body, after lying in state for a few days at the residence of the late statesman and champion of Dreyfus, was taken to Thaun, in Alsace.

In our Financial Supplement this morning our London correspondent explains at some length the difficulties likely to arise from an excessive demand for gold within the next few months, difficulties that will be aggravated by the cutting off of the supply from South Africa and the necessity of large shipments to that quarter to meet military expenditure.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- At a meeting to-day of the Western members of the new American Association of Baseball Clubs representing Chicago, St. Louis, Milwaukee, and Detroit, President H.D. Quinn was ordered to call a meeting for the complete organization of the new association at New York on Thursday, Oct. 26.

A strange story of love and revenge was revealed yesterday through the murder of Anton Schavalli, who was shot and killed while walking with his wife on Elm Street, Astoria, by Carmello Giancintras, who is now in prison calmly prepared to bear the consequences of his crime. Schavalli is the third of four brothers to be shot by the prisoner.

NEWPORT, Oct. 8. -- Lispenard Stewart, one of the guests at a dinner given last evening by Mrs. A. Lanfear Norrie, went from his cottage to Mrs. Norrie's on his bicycle, and left it on the lawn. After dinner Mr. Stewart went to mount his wheel, but found it had been stolen. The police are looking for the valuable bicycle, which Mr. Stewart had had made expressly for himself.

A service in memory of Cornelius Vanderbilt was held yesterday afternoon in the Railroad Men's Building, 361 Madison Avenue, under the auspices of the Railroad Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. The hall was filled with men, although the special invitations had been limited to the seating capacity.

Saturday's bank statement will be used by bear speculators this week. Wall Street generally was surprised by the decrease shown in the exhibit of Clearing House figures, few bankers anticipating a material decrease in surplus reserves. Yet the stock market on Saturday refused utterly to go down because of the disappointing showings; in fact, a pronounced rally was their Stock Exchange sequel.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- Chief Justice Melville W. Fuller and Associate Justice David J. Brewer of the United States Supreme Court, who were members of the Anglo-Venezuelan Boundary Arbitration Tribunal, will sail from Liverpool for New York Oct. 11 by the White Star Line steamer Majestic.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 9. -- Ex-State Senator CJ. Bronston of this city, who has been a warm supporter and friend of J.C.S. Blackburn, bolted Goebel this afternoon. He had just read the correspondence between Goebel and ex-Secretary Carlisle, which showed Goebel was trying to make Carlisle a Presidential possibility, while he was pretending to work for Blackburn. In a published statement issued this evening, and addressed to Blackburn, Bronston says in part:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- No charges have been made to the Treasury Department against the officers of the Georgeanna, on which the gambling riot occurred. The local United States Steamboat Inspectors in New York have full power to act in the case, though the owners of the vessel may appeal from their decision.
HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- When the Governor appointed a new Board of Managers of the Hudson Reformatory a few months ago one of their first acts was the abolition of all corporal punishment.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- "The Girl in the Barracks," a new musical farce from the German, with Louis Mann and Clara Lipman as "stars," was produced at the Academy of Music to-night, under the direction of Rich Harris. Mr. Mann as a Parisian chocolate maker and roue and Miss Lipman as a vivacious chanteuse, are both well suited.

ROME, Sept. 25. -- The burst of indignation on the part of the Italian press which followed the first tidings of the recent lynching at Tallulah has to some degree subsided but by no means died out, and the papers are still full of angry and severe criticisms against the existence of the barbarous custom in certain parts of the United States and the apparent toleration of it by the authorities.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- Interest in the celebrated revenue stamp counterfeiting conspiracy unearthed about six months ago by the United States Secret Service, and which resulted in the arrest of eight men, one a Government employe and two formerly in the service of the United States, was revived to-day when the defendants were placed on trial before Judge McPherson, in the United States District Court.

ALAMEDA, Cal., Oct. 9. -- At midnight last night Chief of Police Conrade shot and killed one of three burglars who were attempting to rob a jewelry store. When the men were discovered they began shooting at the officers, one of whom received a bullet in the hand.

The conference of the anti-Tammany organizations called by the City Club, which met for the fourth time last night, has agreed upon a judicial ticket and a nominee for Sheriff. At the meeting, which was held at the City Clubhouse last night, there were present representative committees from the Republican County Convention, the Citizens' Union, the Reform Club, and the City Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Capt. C.H. Rockwell, at present Captain of the Norfolk Navy Yard, was to-day ordered to command the Chicago, which will be Admiral Schley's flagship on the South Atlantic Station. The detail was made at Capt. Rockwell's request.

Somerset scored a polo triumph over Staten Island yesterday, and thereby deadened the memory of the defeat which the latter administered to the New Jersey men at Bernardsville two weeks ago. The game was played on the field of the Staten Island Polo Club at West Brighton, and the victors won by the score of 7 3/4 goals to 1 3/4.

During the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday it was developed that the City of New York came into possession of a lot of neglected, broken-down buildings in Brooklyn through consolidation. This showing was made when Commissioner Kearny of the Department of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies was explaining the estimates for his department, and the figures presented were such as to cause Mayor Van Wyck much mental disturbance.

Admiral DEWEY has put at ease everybody who has been in any way connected with the attempt to provide for him, in Washington, a house to be presented as a popular and substantial acknowledgment of the esteem in which he is held as an officer and a gentleman.

Mr. J.C. Monaghan, United States Consul at Chemnitz, in response to a large number of invitations from commercial bodies in the United States, arrived in New York yesterday on the Kaiser Friedrich. Consul Monaghan has received an extended leave of absence from the Department of State in order to hold a series of lectures and practical talks on our export trade and on trade schools in Germany.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Oct. 9. -- The Brokerhoff brothers of this place to-day closed negotiations with a large syndicate of Williamsport lumbermen and Philadelphia capitalists by which the latter bought the timber on 13,000 acres of land in Braxton County, West Virginia. The tract is in the midst of the recently discovered coal and oil section of that State.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 9. -- Twelve employes of the New York State Fish Commission are locating themselves at various points around Lake Superior this week. They have come to gather a score of millions of fish eggs, mostly those of the lake trout, which are to be shipped to New York hatcheries and later planted in the waters of that State.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 9. -- The suit for $10,000 damages for the alienation of his wife's affections brought by Frederick W. Hargraves, a prominent business man of Westfield, formerly of this city, against Wesley R. Brokaw, a piano dealer of West Front Street, this city, was tried in the Union County Court to-day.

With the adoption of their new creed of expansion, the present leaders of the Republican Party, and specifically the Executive, seem to have abandoned a cardinal principle of the political and economic faith which inspired them in some of the fiercest and most stubbornly waged political contests of the past, and on which at least one of their most signal victories -- the election of Benjamin Harrison -- was won.

----- If one could know whether few or many residents of Memphis, Tenn., believe the statements about this city which we republished from The Commercial-Appeal on Saturday, one could more easily decide whether to laugh at the absurdity of the attack or to grieve over the injustice, the ignorance, and the ingratitude which the attack displayed.

HANOVER, Oct. 9. -- The tenth annual Socialist Conference since the repeal of the Socialist laws opened this morning in the Ballhof, which is tastefully decorated with laurel wreaths, red banners, and the escutcheons of various German cities. In the centre, grouped amid ferns and flowers around an allegorical figure of Liberty, are busts of Ferdinand Lassalle, the originator of the Social-Democratic movement in Germany; Karl Marx, the chief of international Socialism, and Engels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Gen. Otis has informed the War Department that he abolished the censorship over press dispatches on Sept. 9. He still requires that copies of the telegrams sent shall be furnished to headquarters. The office of censor has been abolished.

There are some encouraging features in the South African situation. The chief of them is, of course, that the expected collision has not yet taken place. The longer a conflict can be delayed, the better is the chance that it may not take place at all. It is clear that President KRUEGER and Gen. JOUBERT have their Boers under very good control.

If the hopes of every beauty lover in the city are realized, and the movement for the perpetuation of the Dewey arch is successful, may I enter a plea for the adoption of the present site, or, at least, the use of Madison Square or Union Square instead of the upper Park region for the purpose intended?

Capt. Alphonse Sterckx of the steamer Georgeanna of Philadelphia, upon which passengers were insulted and robbed by alleged gamblers last Saturday during the yacht races, was yesterday arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields, and the hearing of his case was fixed for Thursday afternoon next at 2 o'clock. He was released under $750 bail, furnished by Samuel I. Ferguson, a lawyer.

In an article upon the yachts Columbia and Shamrock by "An Old Shipowner," in your issue of this morning, he says; "The British yachtsmen have entirely abandoned their style of build and adopted our own, (the Shamrock being a close copy of the Defender,)" He closes by saying: "The winner in either case will be an American model." I beg leave to differ.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The United States Supreme Court convened to-day for the regular October term, but adjourned without transacting any business.

A year ago to-day THE TIMES reduced its price to one cent for its daily issue, in the hope that it would increase its circulation and its business, its influence and its profits. It was a confident hope based on careful study of the conditions, but the measure of success was necessarily a matter of some doubt.

A performance of one of Shakespeare's least familiar plays, "The Winter's Tale," drew an audience that crowded the capacious Grand Opera House last evening. To say that it was followed with understanding and sympathy, such as the German playgoers give to performances of classical drama, from beginning to end, would be to say too much.

PARIS, Sept. 29. -- Everybody is awaiting with real curiosity the next development of the Dreyfus case. From the side of the army, no new step will be taken. What will the Government do? What will the President do? What will Dreyfus do?

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The Duke of Devonshire, Lord President of the Council of Ministers, speaking at Sheffield to-day, said that the deductions made from his recent speech at Manchester regarding the Transvaal situation had warned him that a member of the Government could not be too careful.
Two occurrences of the past week have exasperated the plain citizen who has a pride in this noble city and appreciation of the work of its public servants:

That must be a very welcome announcement to everybody concerned that after Thursday there will be an attempt at a yacht race every week day unless one of the competitors objects, after the conclusion of a race or an attempt to race, to making another attempt the next day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The Washingtons won the first game to-day by outplaying the Baltimores. The second game went to the visitors, who hit McFarland's pitching hard. Errors by the Washingtons also assisted them materially.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The vastness of Great Britain's military preparations -- seemingly out of all proportions to the work in hand in South Africa -- was not fully realized by the public until the War Office announced that 25,000 reserves had already been summoned to rejoin the colors.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 9. -- In reply to a telegraphic inquiry as to the report that he was very ill and probably would have to give up his campaign work, William J. Bryan replied as follows from Webster, Iowa, where he is stopping with Frederick White, the Democratic candidate for Governor of that State.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- President S.R. Callaway of the New York Central Railroad and Frank Barry, Secretary of the National Millers' Association, were before the Industrial Commission to-day.

Maximilian Morgenthau has sold, through A. Rothmiller, to Peter Muller, the plot running through from One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street to One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, beginning 178 feet east of Seventh Avenue and fronting 260 feet on either street. The buyer will erect on the lots at once twenty five-story flats, each 26 by 80 by 100.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Through their official representatives the three great countries of North America were introduced to one another here to-day, the reception occurring early in the forenoon. The Mexican delegation, headed by Vice President Mariscal, and the Canadian, under the leadership of Premier Laurier, were received by President McKinley in the Auditorium Annex.

The latest murder mystery with which the police have to grapple seems little nearer solution early this morning than it has been at any time since the finding of the thigh portion of a woman's body in front of 160 West Seventeenth Street on Saturday morning, and the portion of the torso at the foot of Thirteenth Street late that night.
NEWPORT, Oct. 9. -- Mrs. Duncan Elliot has gone to New London for a short visit.

Yesterday, with its chill east winds and mist, was taken advantage of by the many women still lingering in town with the hope of seeing at least one cup race, for shopping, and the arranging for putting their city houses in order, and so, despite the bad weather, there were many familiar feminine faces to be seen on the avenue, and especially at the fashionable restaurants at the luncheon and dinner hours.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- The most spectacular outdoor feature of the Fall Festival, the Parade of all Nations, took place to-night, and was viewed by thousands, the streets in the down-town districts being literally a solid mass of humanity.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 9. -- The latest news by steamer from Central America is that the rate of exchange has since Sept. 20 dropped from 800 to 500 in Guatemala, and that business conditions are vastly improved as a result of the excellent prospect of an advantageous sale of the Guatemala Northern Railroad by the Government within the next thirty days.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Daily News this morning publishes the report of an interview with Mr. Bertram Mitford, the South African novelist, who spent twenty-five years among the Cape Dutch, in which Mr. Mitford predicts that victory will only be attained by the British after a long, bloody, and costly war. He says:
Buyers of yearlings in training as well as brood mares and stallions, the property of R.H. Walden Sons and A.H. D.H. Morris, were in lively bidding humor at Morris Park yesterday.

Time was when an arctic expedition was a real hardship, when men were earnestly bent on doing something for the glory of their country and for the cause of science, but that day seems to have gone past. Compared with what the men of McClure and Franklin's day suffered, the Pearys and others have been enjoying a Summer picnic, with champagne and cigars all along the line.

To-day is commonly known in the vicinity of the Metropolitan Opera House as "moving day," as it is the day when the entire Maurice Grau Opera Company leaves this city to make a tour of some of the principal cities of the country.
The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa, late rector of the Church of St. John the Evangelist, made public yesterday his resignation from the Protestant Episcopal priesthood.

Abodel Kahuli, a Syrian immigrant, twenty-four years old, was yesterday discovered suffering with smallpox, in a small room in the tenement house 27 and 29 Washington Street. A policeman of the Church Street Station was informed by some one of the man's plight, and he called an ambulance from Hudson Street Hospital.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Daily Mail reports a conversation with two prominent delegates from Portugal to the Geographical Congress, both of whom declare that Portugal is bound by a secret, but formal, offensive and defensive alliance with England, not to interfere in any way with Transvaal affairs, and that therefore she will remain neutral.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Ministers in this city are being made the victims of a sad-faced woman in black with a new confidence game. This woman picks out some clergyman noted for his gentle and guileless nature and visits him. She tells him a story about the sad case of a destitute woman who has just passed away.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The six hundredth performance of "The Belle of New York" at the Shaftesbury Theatre this evening by George W. Lederer's Casino company was made resplendent with new costumes and embellishments. It was witnessed by a large and enthusiastic audience. New duets had been written for Edna May and W.P. Carleton, and for Frank Lawton and Ella Snyder, and new solos for Edward J. Connelly and George Fortescue.

Justice Bischoff, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday refused the application of George G. Renville for a peremptory writ of mandamus requiring the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company or the Western Union Telegraph Company to connect the ticker in his office with its telegraph wires, and furnish him with quotations of transactions upon the New York Stock Exchange.

The joint committee of the Legislature on the revision of the tax laws held its first business session since organization in the roms of the City Court, General Term, yesterday. All the members were present except Assemblyman Palmer of Schoharie.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- One of the interesting features of President McKinley's visit to Chicago transpired to-day, when he laid the cornerstone of the new Federal Building.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- This was Chicago's and President McKinley's busy day. There was a cornerstone to lay, a banquet to be eaten, likewise a luncheon and two parades to take care of, foreign representatives to be greeted, and two and a half million people to face.

Tammany conventions held in the thirty-five districts of New York County last night for the nomination of candidates for the Assembly developed few surprises. The prearranged "slate" went through without a hitch in every district except the Twentieth, where the convention was adjourned to to-morrow night to give time to agree on a successor to Assemblyman Collins, who has been made a Deputy Assistant District Attorney.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Transvaal ultimatum, which is signed by the Secretary of State, consists of four demands and contains a time limit of forty-eight hours. The following paragraph immediately precedes the four demands:

A most important and interesting event will be the International Commercial Congress to be held to-morrow in Philadelphia, in connection with the National Export Exposition recently opened "for the advancement of American manufactures and the extension of export trade." The exposition, liberally encouraged by the National Congress, already has justified much of the expectation of its promoters.

The Bar Association, at its monthly meeting last night, placed itself on record as favoring the renomination of Justice George C. Barrett by adopting resolutions urging all political organizations to place him upon their tickets. Over 300 members of the association were in attendance at the meeting, and the sentiment in favor of the resolutions was so general as to be practically unanimous.

MORGANTOWN, West Va., Oct. 10. -- Chadwick Day was celebrated by 25,000 people to-day. The special train with naval officers arrived at 6 o'clock, and a salute in honor of Admiral Sampson was fired by the university cadets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip has decided to anticipate the interest for the entire fiscal year, the period ending with July 1, 1900. The interest due Nov. 1 will be paid in full without discount, but if holders of bonds wish to take advantage of the offer to anticipate interest due at subsequent dates, a discount at the rate of two-tenths of 1 per cent. a month will be exacted.
HAVANA, Oct. 10. -- A list of thirty people was handed to the Mayor of Guanajay, with a request from the inhabitants that he expel them.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The reports from all the military centres show that the mobilization orders are received with the greatest enthusiasm, now that President Kruger has crossed the Rubicon and taken the irrevocable step of issuing an ultimatum.
Permit me to second the eloquent appeal of Mr. George Tyler in your issue of to-day under the above heading.

The conference of the anti-Tammany forces, which was called by the City Club, received a set-back, if not a fatal blow, last night. After several conferences and the final adoption of a report Monday night as to a judicial ticket and a nominee for Sheriff, to which all the conferrees were pledged, the City Club itself last night refused to accept the ticket in its entirety, and insisted on the renomination of Justice Barrett.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Supreme Court Justice Bernard has granted an order that the assessed value of the real property owned by the City of New York in the town of Somers be reduced from $166,588.29 to $143,078.68.

Interest in the proposed new hotel for women has taken a decided advance within the past few weeks, and it now leeks as if as if the construction of the hotel will be begun in January. The amount of the capital stock is to be $400;000, and it will be necessars to have three-fourths of it subscribed before the company may be incorporated. The total subscription to date amounts to some thing over $150,000.

It is to be regretted that the remarks which appeared in your column "Topics of the Times" a few days ago concerning the replacing of the portrait of Gen. Robert E. Lee on the wall of the graduation hall at West Point should have been the occasion of any further "unpleasantness" between North and South.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- About 300 delegates, representing the business interests of New York State, assembled here to-day to discuss methods of increasing the commerce of the State, and especially the Port of New York.

The new building code, which was passed by the Board of Aldermen last month, received the approval of the Council yesterday, after it had been reported favorably by the Committee on Affairs of Boroughs. Hardly had the Council been called to order when Mr. Goodwin (Tam.) moved that the code, as reported by the commission which drafted it, be placed on its final passage.

Louis James acted Macbeth at the Grand Opera House last evening in presence of an audience that nearly filled the theatre, and occupied all the seats except a few of the most expensive ones. The tragedy was put on the stage much as it used to be in the era of Forrest and Booth. A few ill-looking supernumeraries represented the army of Scotland.
Directors of the Rock Island to start from Chicago to-morrow for their annual tour of inspection of the road.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The naval account of the attack on Novaleta, which differs materially from the account given by Gen. Otis, is contained in the following cablegram received at the Navy Department to-day from Admiral Watson:

The Council yesterday gave an exhibition of wrangling seldom equaled and never surpassed in that contentious body. Several times the lie was passed in a thin disguise and in one instance the contradiction reached such a stage that blows were narrowly averted, and the presence of the Sergeant at Arms became necessary.

In this morning's TIMES I notice a communication from "An Old Shipowner," which is very misleading. He says, apropos of Columbia and Shamrock: "The British yachtsmen have entirely abandoned their style of build and have adopted our own, (the Shamrock being a close copy of the Defender.")
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The English character was never better exemplified than it is in London to-night, when Great Britain is face to face with war.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The South African Republic has sent an ultimatum to Great Britain, demanding that the points in dispute be referred to arbitration, that all troops on the border be instantly withdrawn, that reinforcements sent to South Africa since June 1 be removed, and that no further troops be landed. An answer is demanded by 5 P.M. on Wednesday, Oct. 11.

Isaac L. Rice has bought frown W.W. T.M. Hall, through L.J. Phillips Co., the plot at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-ninth Street, measuring 116 feet on the Drive and having a depth of 148 feet and a street frontage of 100.6 feet. In part payment for this plot Mr. Rice gives the dwelling at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-eighth Street, 75 by 100.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10. -- In a street duel in front of Newspaper Row, on Camp Street, to-day Dominick C. O'Malley, proprietor of The Evening Item, and C. Harrison Parker, Chairman of the Democratic State Campaign Committee, and editor of The Delta, the anti-lottery organ, were seriously if not fatally wounded.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10. -- A week from to-morrow, on Oct. 18, the annual meeting of the stockholders of the New Haven Road will be held and the incoming Board of Directors for the year 1899-1900 elected. It is generally understood that at that meeting there will be no contest of any sort, and that the old Board of Directors will be re-elected.

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 10. -- Both Eddie McDuffee and Ben Munroe, the later from Memphis, Tenn., broke world's records at the track here to-day, McDuffie lowering the time for from one to five miles and Munroe for from five miles to twenty-three miles, inclusive. McDuffee rode his first two miles in less than three minutes and his last mile in 1:21.

Permit me to express my hearty approbation of the attitude of THE TIMES in reference to the renomination of Justice Barrett. That there should be any opposition to giving to this brilliant and upright Judge the reward to which his long and faithful services entitle him is a matter of surprise to all who desire an honest judiciary and hope for the severance of our courts from the sphere of politics.

MANILA, Sept. 4. -- The army in Luzon has lost more men during the past fortnight by drowning than by bullets. All the little streams which in dry weather were mere creeks have become swift, wide rivers with unexpected and treacherous currents and eddies.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- At 11:30 o'clock tonight President McKinley and the members of his Cabinet left Chicago for Evansville, Ind., where he will attend the National reunion of the Blue and Gray.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- President McKinley had scarcely finished breakfast this morning, when the first of the many of the delegations seeking attention reached the Auditorium. The delegation was made up principally of members of the Bricklayers and Stone Masons' Union, which some weeks ago made the President an honorary member of their organization.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -- The Metropolitan Opera House company, under the direction of Mr. Maurice Grau, opened the grand opera season in America at the Hyperion Theatre, in this city, to-night.

The site for the Dewey arch at Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Tenth Street is probably the best yet proposed. Fifth Avenue already has one arch, and is inferior in width and grades to Seventh Avenue. Mr. Risse's idea of a park at this point as a setting for the arch is a good one, though why it should be elliptical is hardly obvious to any one who knows the locality.
A San Francisco fund for the erection in that city of a monument to cemmemorate Admiral Dewey's victory at Manila has reached $36,000 and over and is still being added to.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Late this afternoon the Colonial Office gave out the text of the following telegram, transmitted by Sir Alfred Milner, British High Commissioner in South Africa, to the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, and received at 6:45 A.M. to-day:

Kate Shaughnessy, the seven-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Shaughnessy of 105 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, is recovering at the home of her parents from an encounter with a huge house rat, which almost resulted in her death.

The chief incident of interest in Wall Street yesterday was the announcement of the offer of the Government to pay in advance the interest due Nov. 1 without deduction, and to prepay all interest due July 1 next year, subject to a discount of 2 4-10 per cent. per annum.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 10. -- For the second time since 1890 the training station has an epidemic of typhoid fever. To-day Medical Inspector Siegfried, when called upon to verify the report, said that eleven cases of typhoid fever had developed within the past few days among the apprentices.

That is very startling news that the Boers, instead of waiting for a British ultimatum, have served upon Great Britain one of their own, and one of the most peremptory kind. And yet nobody ought to be surprised at what is simply an obvious military precaution, if war is really inevitable.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- A dispatch from Pretoria, dated Monday evening, says:
MANILA, Oct. 10. -- Gen. Schwan's column entered San Francisco de Malabon without opposition this morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- In sharp contrast to the miserable exhibition of yesterday was the clean, snappy game put up by the 'Varsity against the "scrub" team on Osborn Field to-day. Two touch-downs were scored, and it looked to the side-line spectators as though more points might have been made had the same backs been used throughout the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- The annual women's championship golf competition began to-day on the links of the Philadelphia Country Club at Bala, a suburb of this city, under the auspices of the United States Golf Association.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Julia Marlowe's new play, by Clyde Fitch, entitled "Barbara Frietchie," was produced for the first time to-night at the South Broad Street Theatre.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- It cannot be doubted that Great Britain will flatly reject President Kruger's demands and that at 3:15 o'clock this afternoon, English time, an actual state of war will exist.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., October 10. -- Assemblyman Edmund J. Pickett of Saranac was unanimously renominated at the Clinton County Democratic Convention here today.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10. -- The game between the Baltimore and Washington teams to-day was called on account of darkness after six innings had been played and the score a tie. Nops lost the game for Baltimore by his unsteady pitching in the third inning. Umpire Latham put La Chance and Smith of Baltimore and McGill of Washington out of the game for "kicking." Score:

ST. PAUL, Oct. 10. -- Interest in the opening day's proceedings of the Congress of the Protestant Episcopal Church centred in a debae to-night on the question, "Does National expansion involve imperialism?" Bishop Henry C. Potter opened the discussion. In the course of his address he said:

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The body of a young woman was found in a lonely place on Pawtucket Street, near the Merrimac River, here, at 2 o'clock this morning. It was evident that the woman had been strangled.
Tammany Hall held its County Convention in the wigwam in Fourteenth Street last night and placed the following ticket in nomination:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- President Samuel Spencer of the Southern Railway system was the only witness before the Industrial Commission to-day.

The funeral yesterday of Rosie Wunsch, the four-year-old twin daughter of Ludwig Wunsch, a pocketbook maker, of 397 Melrose Street, Williamsburg, was preceded by interference on the part of Coroner Delap of Williamsburg. He was informed that a death certificate setting forth that the child had died of tetanus had been rejected by the Health Department.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11. -- The first public utterance of Judge William R. Day, who was President of the American Peace Commission, concerning the deliberations of the Commissioners at Paris, is contained in a letter written to ex-Congressman D.K. Watson of this city, and was read by him at a Republican meeting on the east side tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- A flood of oratory on the Transvaal situation burst out to-night, A.J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury; Henry Herbert Asquith, former Home Secretary, and others speaking in various parts of the country. Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who was to have delivered an address on the subject, is suffering from an attack of bronchitis, and consequently was unable to speak.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 11. -- Admiral Dewey arrived here from Shelburne on a special train at 5:25 o'clock this evening.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- It is rumored that Conyingham Greene, the British Diplomatic Agent at Pretoria, has been assassinated there. The report, however, is unconfirmed, and is discredited at the Colonial Office.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Montague White, Consul General of the South African Republic in London, closed the Consulate this afternoon and immediately left for the Continent. Before leaving he said:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The Tigers defeated Lafayette to-day in a game of football by the score of 12 to 0. In the first half, Wheeler kicked off for Princeton. Fumbles were frequent, and the ball changed sides very often. On Lafayette's forty-yard line, Levick circled the left end for twenty-five yards, and Kafer made a touch-down after nine and a half minutes play.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 11. -- Within ten days the greatest sales of print cloths and gray goods have been made in this market that have ever been known in the history of the trade. The total is in excess of 2,000,000 pieces, but even this large amount fails to represent the extraordinary state of the trade, both in the goods controlled by the selling committee and those made on wide looms.

BRIGHAM YOUNG ROBERTS, who was in 1898 elected a Representative in Congress from Utah by a plurality of 5,665 votes, who has been certified to the Clerk of the Fifty-fifth Congress by the Governor of his State, and who has been drawing his salary, at the rate of $5,000 a year, since March 3, appears to be in some danger of temporary, and perhaps permanent, exclusion from the House of Representatives.

The Republican County Convention, in adjourned session at the Murray Hill Lyceum last night, nominated the ticket suggested by the anti-Tammany conference held at the City Club, with George C. Barrett substituted for George C. Holt as a candidate for the Supreme Court. This makes the Republican ticket consist of three Democrats, two Labor men, and two Republicans, as follows:

There was a remarkable scene at yesterday's meeting of the Central Board of Education. City Superintendent William H. Maxwell presented his first annual report, and the board by a nearly unanimous vote declined to permit its publication until the Committee on School System had an opportunity to answer the sharp criticisms which Superintendent Maxwell's report makes upon the local committee system of Brooklyn.

Under the pressure of the alarm for the safety of our coasts at the beginning of the war with Spain, rapid headway was made in developing the scheme of coast defenses adopted while Mr. ENDICOTT was Secretary of War. Guns that had been completed but which had not been mounted, for an altogether inscrutable reason, were hurried to the emplacements that had been provided but not occupied.

Corporation Counsel Whalen yesterday approved, as to form, the proposed contract for the construction of the rapid transit road, and forwarded it to Alexander E. Orr, the President of the Rapid Transit Commission. With the approved contract Mr. Whalen also sent a letter, outlining his views, and again suggesting the modifications which he proposed in his letter to the commission about a fortnight ago.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 11. -- President McKinley and his Cabinet came from Chicago this morning to attend the National reunion of the Blue and the Gray. A heavy rain was falling, but despite this, 10,000 veterans and visitors thronged about the railroad station, and the "vets" in gray vied with those in blue in tendering a tremendous ovation when the Presidential party arrived.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 11. -- At midnight the complete official returns from thirteen of the fifteen wards in the city indicate that Mayor Taggart, Democrat, is re-elected by 530 majority, and the City Clerk, Police Justice, and Councilmen at Large, all Democrats, by about 300. There is but little talk now of a contest by the Republicans.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- In the face of the fact that committees worked until a late hour last night, the State Commerce Convention opened its session at 9 o'clock this morning.

Rumors that the Mazet investigation would be suspended at the end of the present week circulated yesterday, and because of the public conviction that high officials of the Republican Party want it stopped, obtained ready acceptance. They were promptly denied, however, by Chairman Mazet, who said the committee would sit with "possibly occasional interruptions to allow the members to take part in the campaign," right up to the election.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 11. -- At the first session of the annual reunion of the Army of the Potomac here to-day Judge Martin T. McMahon read the following poem, entitled "Ode to the Republic, (Morituri te Salutant,)":
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Lord Rosebery, the former Premier and Liberal leader, has finally declared his position relative to the South African question. In a letter under to-day's date he says:

There was not a brilliant programme promised at Morris Park yesterday, but a larger crowd than has been present for some time was out to see the races. In three of the races the finishes were so close that the spectators had to guess which of the contenders had won until, the number of the winner was hoisted on the jockey board. This was the case in the races won by Lambent, Toluca, and Raffaelo.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Preparations are being made at Southampton for the departure on Saturday of Gen. Sir Redvers Buller, and a great demonstration is anticipated. The Duke of Connaught, the Duke of York, Lord Lansdowne, Gen. Lord Wolseley, and Gen. Sir Evelyn Wood are expected to accompany him to Southampton from London.

Charles Murphy of the Calumet Club was yesterday held by Magistrate Meade in the Jefferson Market Court in $500 bonds to stand trial for disorderly conduct and assaulting an officer. Murphy gave his name as William Henry and his address as 108 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, but he is said to be the same Charles Murphy who claimed that Policeman Carmody assaulted him some time ago.
