NEWPORT, Oct. 11. -- Paymaster Cowie of the Training Station is entertaining S.P. Read, formerly United States Consul at Tien-Tsin, China.

Admiral Lord Charles Beresford of the British Navy visited the financial district yesterday and called at the office of J. Seligman, the Broad Street bankers. News of his presence in Wall Street reached the Stock Exchange, and preparations were made to give him a reception on the floor of the Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- The Pennsylvania special bearing the Presidential party arrived in Chicago this evening from Evansville, Ind., and was at once delivered to the tracks of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road. St. Paul will be reached at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning. The day and evening will be spent at Minneapolis and St. Paul, and at midnight the departure will be made for Duluth.

GREENPORT, L.I., Oct. 11. -- The crew of the Holland submarine boat had a narrow escape from death by asphyxiation this morning. The Holland had been out for a short trial run in the bay and had come into the pier at New Suffolk. Nothing unusual was noticed by those on the dock until some little time had elapsed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- A communication from Minister Straus, at Constantinople, to the State Department, deals with the unfortunate condition of the immigrant Jews, many of whom appear to be paupers. He incloses a letter from Consul Merrill of Jerusalem, saying:

It is likely to be some time before a satisfactory plan for perpetuating the Dewey arch is formulated and a much longer time before it is executed. There are to be considered the question of site, the question of scale, and the question of modifications of detail. The architect and all the sculptors will without doubt demand an opportunity to revise their work before it is put into durable marble or granite and bronze.

Richard Croker achieved a triumph last night in the meeting of the Democratic State Committee, and is to-day the recognized leader of the Democratic Party in the State of New York. The test as to the actual leader of the party was in the seating of the committeeman from the Forty-fourth District, Monroe County, and it was a trial of strength between Mr. Croker and David B. Hill.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- The colors of Miss Beatrix Hoyt of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Southampton, L.I., were lowered to-day by Mrs. Caleb F. Fox of the Huntingdon Valley Cricket Club, Rydal, Penn., in the first round of the Women's Golf Championship Tournament, now being held on the links of the Philadelphia Country Club at Bala, near this city.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 11. -- The general topic at to-night's session of the Protestant Episcopal Church Conference was "The Bearing of the Newspaper on Intellectual and Moral Life."

It is far more the City Club than it is Judge BARRETT which is to be congratulated upon the "indorsement" by the former of the latter. It was an indorsement that was much more needed by the indorser than by the indorsee. The most valuable approval to any Judge seeking re-election is the approval of the bar.

Staten Island society turned out in good numbers yesterday to witness the battle on the polo field of the Staten Island Polo Club between Lakewood and Rockaway, which proved the best polo contest seen on the island this year. The Rockaway men beat Lakewood for the second time. The score was 9 goals to 5 3/4.

FORT MONROE, Va., Oct. 11. -- The complimentary ball given to-night at the Chamberlin by the Business Men's Associations of Norfolk, Newport News, Richmond, Old Point, and Hampton in honor of the officers of the North Atlantic Squadron, eclipsed all events in the social annals of this noted resort.

The annual meeting of the Charity Organization Society was held yesterday afternoon in the United Charities Building. Samuel M. Jackson presided. Only a few members of the society were present, and the meeting was held behind closed doors.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Further particulars regarding the correspondence between President Steyn of the Orange Free State and Sir Alfred Milner, Governor of Cape Colony and British High Commissioner in South Africa, cabled from Bloemfontein, show that Sir Alfred Milner on Oct. 7 stated that the Imperial Government was reconsidering the situation in view of the grave fact that both the republics were on a war footing. In another dispatch he says:

The dismembered body which has furnished a problem for the police is not, in their opinion, likely to be identified under present conditions. Police authorities announced last night that unless the head is found they will take no stock in identifications, but that the solution of the mystery must be obtained from outside clues.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11. -- Harvard easily defeated Amherst to-day, rolling up 41 points to nothing in fifteen-minute halves. Amherst was outplayed in every point of the game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Woman's National Industrial League to-night took the initial steps to raise a fund with which to purchase a home in Washington for Admiral Schley. An Executive Committee, with Mrs. Charlotte Smith as its head, was appointed to push the movement, and the Citizens' National Bank of Washington was designated as the institution to which subscribers should send their subscriptions. Resolutions were adopted as follows:

The Carnegie Hall mass meeting last night to express sympathy for the Boers in their struggle for independence was a notable one. The body of the hall was packed, as were the galleries. The box circle fas well occupied, and a few boxes were taken in the tier above. There were few women, however, among the main audience.

A reception was tendered to Senator Orville H. Platt last night by the Union League Club of Brooklyn. There was a large attendance of members and friends, and in response to an invitation Senator Platt made an address on "The Expansion Question."

The Eagle calls attention to an article on the page next to this one to-day, on the desirability of still further increasing the subscriptions for the Dewey home fund. The reasons for that are timely and sound.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.-- The University of Virginia eleven to-day surprised themselves possibly more than they did the three thousand spectators by scoring a touchdown on the University of Pennsylvania half a minute before time was called, the final score being University of Pennsylvania 33, University of Virginia, 6.

This morning the yachting enthusiasts will wend their way for the fifth time to the piers from which the club steamboats, the steam yachts, and the very few excursion steamboats which still advertise that they will attend the cup races, will start for what has now become a monotonous trip to the lightship.

SAN FRANCISCO DE MALABON, Oct. 11. -- Gen. Schwan's column, in approaching this town, marched through a country so muddy that the mules all collapsed. He occupied the town without fighting, the insurgents retreating under cover of the creek beds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- There was trouble last night at the third meeting of the Democratic Central Committee of the District of Columbia called to select a successor to the late Lawrence Gardner. Two persons were chosen, James L. Norris by the regular meeting and William Holmead by a bolting faction.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 11. -- Some people are determined that Admiral Dewey's home shall be complete in every respect. One of them wrote to the committee to-day offering a canary bird and a cage to make home pleasant for the Admiral. The writer is a bird dealer in Philadelphia. The letter will be turned over to the Admiral.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11. -- The Twentieth Kansas Regiment and the 400 discharged soldiers who arrived here last night on the transport Tartar were landed today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- The following cablegram was received to-night by The Chicago Tribune from President Kruger of the Transvaal Republic. The cablegram was sent in answer to a message from The Tribune, requesting a statement of the position of the Transvaal in the present crisis. In the cablegram which follows small words have been filled in in order to make smoother reading:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- There was trouble last night at the third meeting of the Democratic Central Committee of the District of Columbia called to select a successor to the late Lawrence Gardner. Two persons were chosen, James L. Norris by the regular meeting and William Holmead by a bolting faction.

A queer and complicated east side romance, in which Minnie Haberman, a lovelorn damsel whose age is declared to be "considerably over thirty," and Max Goodman, who is alleged to be many years her junior, figure as the heroine and hero, will have its denouement in the City Court next week, when Miss Haberman's claim for $2,800 for breach of promise will be heard.

I am one of those who are anxious to contribute toward the perpetuation of the Dewey arch, bat I protest against beginning a scheme which shall result in failure. There have been many. Remember the Charter Day affair. Twenty-five thousand dollars to $30,000 were collected.

ROSELLE, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Robert Murray of this place and a gang of workmen employed by the Westfield and Elizabeth Street Railroad, or by the contractor constructing the line of the company through this village, had an encounter to-day. Water had gathered in the excavation for the road on First Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The federation of the Australian colonies is an accomplished fact, according to Consul General John P. Bray, at Melbourne. A communication from him, received at the State Department, and made public to-day, was written before Queensland voted on the Constitution, but he said that it had been adopted by large majorities in Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia, and Tasmania.
NORTHFIELD, Vt., Oct. 12. -- Admiral Dewey arrived here to-night. At sunrise he will receive an Admiral's salute from guns manned by cadets of Norwich University.

The weather was admirable for racing yesterday, for the atmosphere was as balmy as it was last June. Only one thing there was to mar the pleasure of the patrons of the Morris Park track, and that was the heavy fog that almost shut the horses out of range of vision late in the afternoon.

Interest in the doings of the Democratic State Committee, which on Wednesday night gave Richard Croker the advantage over ex-Senator David B. Hill by refusing to seat the latter's candidate from the Forty-fourth (Rochester) District, was revived yesterday by a statement made by Frank Campbell, the Chairman of the committee, and a close friend of Senator Hill, in which Mr. Campbell said that Mr. Croker had obtained control of the committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 12. -- The International Commercial Congress was formally opened to-day in the large auditorium of the main building at the National Export Exposition. Fully 3,000 people assembled in the spacious hall and added their enthusiastic applause to the welcome extended to the delegates, while the Marine Band did its share in enlivening the greeting to the foreign representatives.

Mr. Iselin says, in your issue of to-day, that one of the matters which has impressed him this year, in comparison with other years, "is the lax support which is being given the American boat," and he evidently feels this a grievance. And so it would be were the defender sailed by an American skipper.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- A special to The Times-Herald from San Francisco, says: "I see no reason why the Americans should not be sole masters of the Philippines by March next year."

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- When the Cabinet meets at noon to-day it is evident the Boer advance will be in full swing. Judging from present appearances, the Boers are preparing for a simultaneous invasion at five separate points -- Laing's Nek, Kimberley, Vryburg, Mafeking, and Lobatsi.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 12 -- At this evening's session of the Congress of the Protestant Episcopal Church the general topic was "Lessons of the Ritual Contest in the Church of England." The Rev. John H. Elliott of Washington read the first paper. He said in part:

The mystery surrounding the killing of the young woman portions of whose body have been found almost daily since last Saturday was as deep as ever yesterday, and there was even an absence of clues such as had been cropping up from time to time only to be run down and result in disappointment.

The Independent Labor Party held a mass meeting last evening to ratify the nominations made by its County Convention last week, but with the exception of William J. O'Brien, the candidate for Sheriff, and James Seabury, for City Judge, the ticket ratified last night was entirely different from that put up by the County Convention. It had been doctored so as to agree with the Republican and fusion county tickets.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Sir Louis Henry Davies, Canadian Minister of Marine and Fisheries, declares that he has given Canada's consent to a temporary arrangement of the Alaskan dispute. This has practically settled the whole matter for the time being, as the main features of the arrangement were originally suggested by the United States.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12. -- The Yale coaches this afternoon paid almost exclusive attention to developing Yale's defense in anticipation of a hard game with Dartmouth next Saturday. It was the last day of practice before the game, as the eleven with a host of substitutes leaves for Boston to-morrow afternoon.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 12. -- A dispatch to the Handelsblad from Batavia, capital of the Netherlands Indies, Java, says that a violent earthquake has visited the south side of the Island of Ceram, completely destroying the town of Amhei and killing, it is estimated, some four thousand people, as well as injuring about five hundred others.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 12. -- Joseph Burns, twenty-one months old, died to-day of burns received several days ago, and Mrs. Julia Brannan and Katie Brady are held charged with causing his death. The mother of the little fellow left him in the care of the women while she did an errand in the neighborhood of her home. When she returned the lower part of his body was horribly burned.

The period of registration for the November election, which is also the period of enrollment for next year's primaries, begins to-day. There will be four days in which legally qualified voters may register and enroll -- two this week, to-day and tomorrow, and two next week, Friday, Oct. 20, and Saturday, Oct. 21.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The Record to-morrow will say: "Senator Hanna intends to issue a call for a meeting of the Republican National Committee in Washington early in December. It is believed the committee will select the city in which to hold the National Convention.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Oct. 12. -- The friends and supporters of the State College football team are very much worried over the outcome of the game which is to be played here to-morrow against the strong Washington and Jefferson team. While the State College team has made a remarkably good showing so far this season, it is at present in a rather crippled condition from its game with West Point on Saturday last.

While Francis Christy of 176 Monroe Street was driving a truck through Oliver Street yesterday afternoon he was attracted by a shrill cry of "Hello! Ma Baby!" and after vainly endeavoring to locate the place from which the hail came, discovered a parrot perched on the curbstone. The truck-man took the parrot's salutation as a friendly overture and stopped his horse and endeavored to catch the bird.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The Putnam County Convention was held at Carmel this afternoon, and resulted in the nomination of Commodore W.N. Everett for member of Assembly. Both ex-Speaker Hamilton Fish and ex-Assemblyman Addis claim it as a victory.

Selig Bardin, manufacturer of clothing, shirts, and overalls, with salesroom at 343 Broadway and factory at 126 Greene Street, is wanted by his creditors. He is reported to have obtained a large quantity of goods on credit, and the goods cannot be found.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12. -- In his speech here to-day President McKinley defended the purchase of the Philippine Islands, comparing it with the acquisition of other territory by the United States, which had been at first strenuously opposed, but afterward proved to be good policy. He also spoke of the future of the islands, saying he felt assured that Congress would provide a Government which would bring blessings to them, with material prosperity.

We do not think that Mr. BRYAN feels very much stronger, either in the party or before the people, for the complimentary terms in which Mr. CROKER, through the State Committee, has spoken of him. It is, of course, pleasant to be called "the natural and approved leader of the Democratic Party in the Nation," and to be assured of the "loyalty and love" of the simple and faithful souls over whom Mr. CROKER presides.
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Baron Farrer died suddenly this morning.

I am a constant reader of your newspaper. I prefer it to all other daily newspapers printed in this city. I remember very well the time when its scholarly founder, the late Henry J. Raymond, withdrew from the editorial sanctum of The New York Tribune and began the publication of THE TIMES. Mr. Raymond was an accomplished writer, an eloquent orator, and one of the most popular lecturers and public speakers of his day.

The Board of Estimate met yesterday and finished consideration of the estimates of the city departments originally scheduled, with the exception of those for the charitable institutions and some other minor matters postponed until next week.

The Mazet investigation began to show a decided disposition to halt yesterday. Counsel Frank Moss is understood to have demanded time in which to get his material in shape for a final fusillade. Chairman Mazet and Assemblymen Fallows and Costello are anxious to get out to work in their contests for re-election, and the leaders of the Republican organization are convinced that the committee's vote-getting properties, if it ever had any, have been lost.

The holdings of Woodbury G. Langdon, at the southeast corner of Broadway and Spring Street, running through to Crosby Street, have been bought by Charles F. Ayer for about $510,000. The plot, which is now occupied by old buildings known as 524 and 526 Broadway, 82 and 84 Spring Street, and 68, 70, and 72 Crosby Street, measures 51.2 feet on Broadway, 70.7 feet on Crosby Street, and 200 feet on Spring Street.

The huge British Empire and the diminutive South African Republic are arraigned together before the bar of the public opinion of the world. Whichever of them is responsible, or the more responsible, for the war that is now begun, has a heavy burden to bear. As to the republic, its very existence is at stake.

In a few days the United States Civil Service Commission will begin examinations throughout the country to find young men who are capable of filling the position of Assistant Examiner in the United States Patent Office, at an entrance salary or $1,200 a year and the prospect of promotion and increase to $2,500.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12. -- An interesting election dispute is going on in the town of Hamden. By an illegality in ballots, the Republicans of the town had to relinquish a victory to the Democrats. Now the Republicans claim that the ballots were intentionally made illegal by a leader of their party because his plans were defeated in a caucus held a week before the election. An investigation will be made into the affair.

The Brooklyns and Baltimores gave a good exhibition of baseball at Washington Park, Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the champions winning by a score of 5 to 1. It was one of the quickest played games of the season, being completed in one hour and twenty-two minutes.
NEWPORT, Oct. 12. -- James J. Van Alen is passing a visit here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The only feature of the first game to-day was Freeman's twenty-seventh home run. The bases were occupied at the time. In the second the visitors outbatted the Washingtons. Scores:...

SALT LAKE, Utah. Oct. 12. -- At the annual meeting of the Oregon Short Line stockholders the following Directors were elected: Oliver Ames, Francis S. Bangs, Horace G. Burt, Samuel Carr, Thomas Jefferson Coolidge, W.D. Cornish, W.E. Glinn, George J Gould, E.E. Harriman, Thomas R. Jones. Otto H. Kahn, G. M. Lane. James Loeb, Oliver W. Mink, and Winslow S. Pierce.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The mystery of the identity of the man who tried to rob Charles H. Patten's bank, in Palatine, Sept. 21, and who was mortally wounded in the attempt, was, it is thought, cleared up to-day by one who believes himself a brother of the dead man and by C.A. Partridge of Waukegan, Adjutant General of the Illinois Department of the Grand Army of the Republic.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- News that the Carnegie Steel Company has contracted with the American Shipbuilding Company to construct five steel steamers of the eight-thousand-ton class was a disagreeable shock to vessel owners to-day.

It must have given Mr. CHARLES H. KNOX, President of the Civil Service Commission of the city, a curious sensation when, as Chairman of the Tammany County Convention, he announced the unanimous vote of the convention for the following declaration:

The fog which has hung over this coast had its third day yesterday and the cup racers and those who have been trying to see them race were not the only sufferers. All vessels entering and leaving port were more or less delayed, while there was the customary interruption of harbor traffic, ferryboat service, and trouble for Sound and Hudson River boats.

The State Board of Railroad Commissioners will hear the complaint of the Taxpayers' Alliance of the Borough of the Bronx against the Manhattan Railway Company at the Fifth Avenue Hotel at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning. The Taxpayers' Alliance, which is composed of about thirty taxpayers' associations, has been fighting the company ever since it bought the system of the Suburban Rapid Transit Company, about eight years ago.

I should have been glad to address you upon subjects which concern your social welfare; but there has appeared before us now the spirit of war [Hear! Hear!] -- that spirit which is the real enemy of social reforms and of public economy. We are told that we are to go to war with a country which was thus described by the present Colonial Secretary, Mr. Chamberlain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The following official statement was issued by the State Department to-day:

-- "Magnanimity" and "forgetfulness," according to the correspondent whose eloquent and earnest letter we published Wednesday, are words that betray want of tact if used by a Northern writer in discussing the relations between the once hostile but now thoroughly united sections of the country, and if so employed, they justify expressions of resentment from The Charleston News and Courier, or any other "fearless" Southern paper.

Anthony Odenweller, seventy-eight years of age, died at Whitestone yesterday. He was born in Frankfort, Germany, and came to this country at the outbreak of the civil war. He enlisted at once and served with Company I, Sixty-second New York Volunteers, from June, 1861, until 1863, when he was wounded and discharged from the service.

Raskill Stewart was found lying on the floor of her apartments in the basement of 262 West Forty-first Street, yesterday afternoon, and died in Bellevue Hospital a few hours later, without regaining consciousness. The woman lived with George W. Johnson, her common-law husband, who is known as the "whistling coon."

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 12. -- Admiral Dewey was to-day the recipient of the honors bestowed upon him by the people of Vermont. When the Mayor and City Council sent to Dewey a message of congratulation for his victory, he replied that if the people of his native city, Montpelier, were pleased with what he had done he was fully repaid.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 12. -- President McKinley spent over twelve hours in the Twin Cities to-day, leaving this city a little before midnight for Duluth and West Superior, where he will make a short visit early in the morning, thence proceeding direct to Fargo, N.D., to pay his respects to the Dakota volunteers who have just returned from the Philippines.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- The Westchester County Republicans held their county convention to-day for the purpose of nominating candidates for County Treasurer and Town Coroners.
In reply to your editorial question of today, "What Do They Propose to Do About It?" I would say that the American League has not yet had any meeting, but will have one shortly.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Official confirmation of the announcement that the Orange Free State burghers have entered Natal by way of Van Reenen's Pass is at hand. It leaves no further room for doubt that acts of war have already been committed and that the campaign has begun.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 12. -- A good golf match was played to-day in the second round for the women's championship of the United States on the links of the Philadelphia Country Club, at Bala, near here.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- The Canadian Grand Trunk Railway Company at its half-yearly meeting to-day approved the agreement with the Canadian Minister of Railways for the extension of the Intercolonial Railway from Chaudiere Junction, Province of Quebec, to Montreal and the termini there.
MANILA, Oct. 12. -- Gen. Schwan's expedition having accomplished its object, the troops are all returning to their former positions, abandoning the towns taken.
Central Freight Association lines to further advance grain rates on Nov. 1, making the highest tariff in five years.

The annual meeting and election of The Lambs was held Thursday night in the clubhouse, 70 West Thirty-sixth Street, but it was long after midnight before the result was known. The regular ticket was elected by an overwhelming vote, notwithstanding a contest was anticipated between the non-professional and the professional members, it being generally understood that the actors were dissatisfied with the non-professionals.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Oct. 13. -- The worst storm of the season prevailed here this afternoon. Several houses in the suburbs were wrecked.

In The Cornhill a lady, who signs herself "L.F.," the wife of an English officer of rank, presents some highly interesting reminiscences of Macaulay, Rogers, and Tennyson. Of Macaulay the lady writes.

BRAINERD, Minn., Oct. 13. -- President McKinley's train passed through this city at 3:30 this afternoon. A large crowd had assembled at the station, with school children to the number of several hundred in the front ranks. President McKinley and Secretaries Wilson and Hitchcock spoke briefly. The President said, in part:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13. -- In his speech at Hartford, Ky., Senator Goebel, Democratic candidate for Governor, made reply to the recently published letter of John G. Carlisle concerning Mr. Goebel's attitude toward him as a candidate for President in 1896. The Senator said in part:

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- If to-day's reports are correct, fighting has now begun in earnest on both the Natal and the western frontier. The first vague reports have been received of what may prove to be an important engagement between the British forces under Gen. White and the Boer troops. The destruction of an armored train en route to Mafeking with two cannon is confirmed by official dispatches.

PARIS, Oct. 13. -- A great sensation has been caused here by the murder of an Englishman named Derrick by French detectives at Dieppe. Derrick was so shockingly injured that an unusual surgical operation had to be performed upon him, with the result that gangrene intervened and he died.

The next event of interest and importance in the American art world, and which really opens the season in the United States, will be the opening of the annual exhibition at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburg. The first meeting of the jury on this exhibition was held in the Carnegie galleries on Thursday morning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Weather Bureau instruments showed the temperature to be 81 degrees above zero to-day. This is remarkably warm weather for mid-October, but it breaks no records. Southerly winds for three days have caused it. To-night it is said there will be a change, and to-morrow overcoats and heavy wraps will be in order.

FARGO, N.D., Oct. 13. -- Over 10,000 persons greeted President McKinley and his party when they arrived here to-night at 7:35 o'clock. Entering carriages, the party was driven to a reviewing stand through lines of the First North Dakota Volunteers, who recently returned from the Philippines.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- dispatch from Paris says that a representative of the Intransigeant, M. Rochefort's paper, asserts that, while seeing a friend off on the Orient Express last evening, he observed Col. Schneider. formerly Military Attache of the Austro-Hungarian Embassy in Paris, being carried to the train, accompanied by physicians and with blood flowing from a wound in his side.
That general activity in trade and business of all kinds continues is evident from the reports of the commercial agencies.

There was a persistent rumor in local dramatic circles yesterday to the effect that the executors of the will of Augustin Daly have been presented with a number of unlooked-for bills against Mr. Daly's estate, and that the charitable institutions mentioned in the will would not receive much on the final settlement.
AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 13. -- Information reaching here to-night from Ortiz, State of Sonora, Mexico, contains the following information with reference to the Yaqui Indian war:

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- "The philosophy of such movements as the operations of England in South Africa, of the events being enacted in the Philippines, and that have been witnessed in Cuba and Puerto Rico is that it is the destiny of civilization to creep in and help those peoples whose conditions are needful of improvement."

Nothing more righteously just was ever penned than Superintendent Maxwell's condemnation of the local committee system of appointing teachers in Brooklyn. If there is an evil peculiar to the management of our public schools in this city that may fittingly be characterized as the bane of the system, this is the one. My last promotion as a teacher in the Brooklyn schools was to a position for which there were other candidates.

She was a nice little girl who prepared her mind for Sunday by reading every word in THE SATURDAY REVIEW, and she accepted as gospel the letters in reply to your editorial article on "Department Store Books" -- letters describing the erudition of the gentlemen and ladies who dispense books in department shops -- and she took the invitations to "browse" at the counters in perfect good faith.

WADENA, Minn., Oct. 13. -- A large and enthusiastic crowd greeted President McKinley late this afternoon. The President, although no stop had been arranged, answered repeated demands for a speech. He said:

Contrary to general expectations, practically little opposition to Controller Coler's plan for reforming the present system of municipal aid to private charities was manifested by the representatives of charitable institutions who appeared before the Board of Estimate yesterday to urge their claims for appropriations for next year. The Controller's plan was so radical that it was generally believed that the institutions affected would make strong objections.
LONDON, Oct. 13. -- "Gillian the Dreamer," by Neil Munro, has been published by Messrs. Isbister. The author receives more praise than the work, which is generally criticised as exasperating.

Mr. DEPEW, in his oration yesterday at the Norwich University, caught and expressed the feeling of the occasion with his usual tact. A man who has done great things for his country and who has been welcomed and acclaimed by millions of his countrymen, does not feel himself so well repaid as by the approval of his own neighbors and friends.

HANOVER, Oct. 13. -- At to-day's session of the Socialist Congress Herr Bebel's resolution of Oct. 10, declaring that the party should remain what it is, namely a class party, of which the historical aim is to acquire political supremacy, and declaring that there is no reason why it should alter its programme, tactics, or name, was adopted by 218 votes again 22.

Under the caption of "Henry George in Chinese" you begin by speaking of his "famous book 'Progress and Poverty.'" Permit me to say that what I consider one of the most remarkable things connected with this famous book is the fact that, though written in beautifully clear language, it is yet so often utterly misunderstood by those who do not hesitate to speak or to write in criticism of it.

The breezy exchange of compliments between Mazet's counsel and a pair of his witnesses on Tuesday was decidedly refreshing and entertaining in more ways than one. The behavior of the witnesses seems to have been quite appropriate for the occasion, and in point of respectability fully up to the level of the manner and method of their inquisitor.

My compliments to Mr. Newberry; he certainly has the courage of his prejudices. A man who can dismiss a genius like Meredith with a lofty wave of the hand and exalt such a lightweight as Anstey to the extent of three solid columns of type and cocksureness recalls Whistler and his "I am not arguing with you, I am telling you."

HASTINGS, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- An accident in the National Conduit and Cable Works shortly after 7 o'clock this morning, started a fire which did $150,000 damage. One of the workmen dropped a big knife, which cut through a lead pipe that supplied gasoline to one of the lead presses. An explosion followed, and soon this building, which was of frame and about 100 feet square, was in flames.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 13. -- Surgeon Spear of the New York, while pitching ball at Old Point to-day, snapped a bone in his right arm. The shock was so great that he became unconscious.

The block bounded by Fifth and Madison Avenues, Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, has been sold by the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum. The purchaser is a client of the firm of Richard M. Montgomery Co., and the price is understood to have been $2,500,000.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 13. -- As the guest of the City of Boston, welcomed to the old Bay State, and accompanied here by the Governor of the Granite State, Admiral Dewey to-night is one day nearer the end of his triumphal journey through New England.

I have enjoyed a great pleasure recently in reading "Richard Carvel" for the first time. It is certainly one of the finest studies in American Colonial history that has yet been achieved by any of our novelists. Mr. Churchill has evidently made a most careful and exhaustive research of all material that could throw light upon the life of that day, and his historical accuracy is very remarkable.

As yet none of your readers has called attention to the curious resemblance between "The Man With the Hoe" and two passages in "Sartor Resartus." In the chapter on "Helotage" he writes: "Two men I honor and no third. First the toilworn Craftsman that with earth-made Implement laboriously conquers the earth and makes her man's.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 13. -- Ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed presided to-day at the second session of the International Commercial Congress. The congress held its meeting in the convention hall of the main building of the National Export Exposition. Mr. Reed was enthusiastically greeted, and appeared to be in splendid health.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- "The Choir Invisible," dramatized by Frances Hastings from James Lane Allen's novel of that name, was produced for the first time to-night by the Henry Jewett Dramatic Company at the Lafayette Square Opera House.

SEVIERVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 13. -- At attempt by three masked men to rob the Sevierville bank to-day resulted in a fight that ended disastrously for all of them. William Derrick was killed, William Thurmer fatally wounded, and Cal Derrick slightly wounded.

STATE COLLEGE, Penn., Oct. 13. -- The game of football here this afternoon between the elevens of Washington and Jefferson College and State College ended in a general row in which the players of both teams took part.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Oct. 13. -- President McKinley and party stopped here this forenoon for a short time. Over 15,000 persons, including 7,000 school children, received the party at the City Hall. A committee of children presented the President and party with a neatly printed souvenir, purchased with penny contributions by the school children. Caroline Kennedy, a six-year-old girl, presented the souvenir.

" Kid" McPartland of this city got a decision on points over Owen Zeigler of Philadelphia by Referee "Johnny" White at the Broadway Athletic Club last night in a twenty-five-round bout at 138 pounds. A more unsatisfactory decision to the spectators, however, was never given at the club. When McPartland was declared the "winner on points," the crowd hooted and yelled, for the worst they expected for Zeigler was a draw.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 13. -- The four men who have accepted positions as Trustees of the State Industrial School for Girls met at the school to-day. They are Howell C. Stull and John D. Rue of Trenton, who were selected by the Governor some time ago; William H. McCullough, a lumber merchant of Swedesborough, and A.D. Carnagy of Trenton.

We have it on the authority of the genial humorist and man of letters himself that Mark Twain was not serious when, in an unguarded (possibly) moment, he announced that he intended to write his autobiography to be published a century hence. Possibly his gentle egotism allowed him for the moment to wonder as to how his extraordinary statement would be received. He found out.

HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The rebellious inmates of the House of Refuge for Women, in this city, became hysterical again last evening and broke to fragments all the window glass that had just been reset after their riot of last Sunday.

As a reader and admirer of THE SATURDAY REVIEW I am disappointed to find in your issue of Sept. 30 so careless a notice of the Chinese translation of Henry George's "Progress and Poverty." You say that such a work would seem a superfluity in a country which has had a continuous application of the George ideal for centuries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Major Gen. Wesley Merritt, commanding the Department of the East, in his annual report to the War Department, says:

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- At Brighton this evening a public meeting was held under the auspices of the South African Association in support of the Government. The meeting hall was crowded, over 3,000 persons being present in consequence of the report that Rudyard Kipling would speak. The audience, before the addresses were begun, sang patriotic songs.

It seems to be not uncommonly believed even to-day that Henry Hudson was the discoverer of the river that bears his name. But the student of history gets accustomed to finding that the beginnings of things were earlier than had been supposed. So many famous discoveries have turned out to be rediscoveries that we become cautious about asserting that any event on achievement was the first of its kind.

The present volume is the second series of Max Muller's recollections of his friends, acquaintances, and correspondents. The first was devoted to his friends, musical, royal, literary, and even beggarly. He now turns to his Indian friends and correspondents, for, as he says, he has had many friends who were personally unknown to him.

Dr. Weir Mitchell has written a new story called "The Autobiography of a Quack, the opening chapters of which will appear in the November Century. In constructing this work Dr. Mitchell is said to have made use of his knowledge of the under side of his profession in a way that gives an unusually attractive psychological study.

The address of the President at Minneapolis was the most careful and elaborate he has yet made in defense of his policy. From some phrases in it that are rot in the line of his usual manner of thought and expression it may be inferred that it is the fruit of Cabinet consultation, and, like the famous Farewell Address of WASHINGTON, embodies the best thought of the President's advisers.

-- As might have been -- and was -- anticipated, The London Standard's transmutation of "lads" into "ladies" in a dispatch from its New York correspondent, has started the other English papers to making comments, sometimes condescendingly kind and sometimes frankly contemptuous, on the peculiarities of Americans and American manners.
LONDON, Oct. 13. -- The War Office has received the following dispatch from the General commanding the Cape forces:

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 13. -- A noisy welcome was given the Presidential party on its arrival in this city to-day on its way to Fargo, N.D. Hundreds of tugboats and grain steamers were anchored under the bridge across the St. Louis River, and as the special train passed overhead the screaming sirens beneath the bridge joined in a hair-raising chorus.

The Mazet Investigating Committee has taken a recess until a week before election. When the committee adjourned yesterday Chairman Mazet announced that it would meet again on Tuesday, Oct. 31, and added:

Senator JAMES K. JONES, the Chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, has reached Washington in robust health and buoyant spirits. Having been abroad for several months seeking health and inspiration at points remote from the scene of his arduous political labors in 1896, but not out of reach of postal facilities, he returns to communicate to the country his belief that the Democratic situation is very encouraging and satisfactory.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- Mrs. Caleb F. Fox of the Huntingdon Valley Country Club of Rydal, Penn., and Miss Ruth Underhill of the Nassau Golf Club of Glen Cove, L.I., won their matches in the semi-final round for the women's championship of the United States to-day on the links of the Philadelphia Country Club. These players will to-morrow play off the final round for the championship.

The warm, pleasant weather of yesterday afternoon attracted an unusually large number of horsemen to the Speedway, and as a consequence there were a number of exciting brushes between well-known owners of fast horses. Among the early arrivals was Calypso, 2:10 1/2, driven by James Ahearn, who was beaten Thursday afternoon, but was in much better form yesterday.

The fog had another inning yesterday and there was in consequence a repetition of the delays and interruptions to shipping and harbor traffic, with a few collisions and goings ashore. No serious injury was reported, and no one was hurt, though the first rumor that spread of one collision gave it a sensational color which investigation proved to be unwarranted.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13. -- The Yale football squad, numbering about thirty men, left with the coachers for Auburndale, Mass., this afternoon late. At Newton to-morrow Yale meets Dartmouth in the first out-of-town game that the Yale eleven has played this season. Sharp, Adams, Gordon, Brown, and Auchincloss are not to be allowed to play with the possible exception of Sharpe, though that is hardly probable.
M. L. Hess have sold to Boehm Coon the four-story buildings 91 and 92 Mercer Street, the former 25 by 125, for Dr. Henry C. Eno, and the latter, 25 by 100, for Ellen Griffen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The State Department was to-day notified of the withdrawal from Pretoria of Conyngham Greene, the British diplomatic agent to the South African Republic, and the existence of a state of war between Great Britain and that republic. Mr. Macrum, the American Consul at Pretoria, has accordingly been instructed to undertake the care of the British interests in that section during the war.
Registration for the November election began yesterday, and will continue throughout to-day, the places of registry being open from 7 A.M. to 10 P.M.

Senor Ignacio Mariscal, Vice President and Minister of Foreign Affairs for the Republic of Mexico, is at the Waldorf-Astoria with a party of friends, and will probably be sight-seeing in this vicinity for the next three weeks.

It will be hard to deal with Mr. E.I. Fraser's case without some knowledge of his mental equipment. He seems to reveal himself only in the following sentence: "One would have to shut himself up in some place without windows, far removed from noise or distraction of any kind, in order to concentrate his thoughts sufficiently on the story to understand it."

We are all agreed that October, at least in our latitude, and at its best, is the most delightful month of the American year. It is the one month in which, for days and sometimes weeks together, it is equally delightful to be in doors and out of doors, in the sun and in the shade, engaging in active exercise or loafing and inviting one's soul, as the late WALT WHITMAN used to put it.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 13. -- A representative of the Carnegie-Oliver mining interests, in commenting to-day upon the announcement that Rockefeller had secured all the ore-carrying vessels, and that rates on ore would be considerably advanced next season said:

It seems somewhat of a pity that your columns should be given over to people who are so narrow-minded and prejudiced as "New Englander" apparently is. The remarks he makes in regard to Englishmen coming to this country merely with the object of making money, and that at heart they have no use for Americans, are too far removed from the truth to be worthy of notice.

I once discussed the subject of Americanisms with an English gentleman, a native of Southern Staffordshire, who has spent some fifteen years in this country, with visits home; and I think his close observations are entitled to notice. It would seem from his testimony that many Americanisms are already adopted or are being adopted in England.

Monotonous baffling calms and dank, disagreeable fog prevailed again yesterday in the vicinity of Sandy Hook, and once more Columbia and Shamrock, the rival yachts that for two weeks have been held in leash awaiting the favoring breath of the god of the winds, were compelled to lie idly at their moorings in the Horseshoe, rising and falling on the smooth surface of the lazy sea.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- At the evening session of the Indian Conference the Rev. Dr. William H. Ward, Chairman of the Business Committee, presented on behalf of the committee the following platform:

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- After twenty-eight years of search, Harry Walters, a bank burglar, who escaped from the State prison here, will be brought back to-morrow to continue the term interrupted by his escape. Walters was convicted of a bank burglary in Poughkeepsie, and in October, 1869, he was sentenced to five years in the prison here. He served one year and ten months.

Congregational leaders in this and other cities are alarmed about denominational affairs. The immediate cause is the recent showing made by the American Board meeting at Providence. Everybody supposed that an effort would be made to raise the debt, almost $100,000, and that D. Willis James of this city, who is Vice President, would be advanced to first place.

STAPLES, Minn., Oct. 13. -- Friendly greetings were extended by a large crowd to the Presidential special on the Northern Pacific, which passed through here this afternoon en route to Fargo. President McKinley, in responding to demands for a speech, said, in part:

The statement attributed to me in some reports of my speech in Carnegie Hall, concerning the political status of Catholics in England, is so palpably absurd that until it had been made the subject of comment I never suposed anybody could be misled by it, or would consider it other than the result of a stenographic error.

ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- Superintendent of Insurance Payn in an interview to-night said: "The Independent Order of B'rith Abraham was incorporated under the insurance laws several years ago. Recently the Grand Lodge of the United Order of B'rith Abraham attempted to reincorporate under the insurance law.

Feeling strongly as we do that "now comes on the sweet of the year" and that a golden October day is much rarer than the highly lauded day in June, it is with surprise that we find the Autumn with so few to sing her praises. Nearly all writers seem to agree with Bryant's The melancholy days have come, the saddest of the year.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 13. -- The managers of Mayor Jones's non-partisan campaign today started a large number of bicycle riders out over the State to carry the documents to rural districts. The entire State will be covered in this way, and the Jones people will distribute 1,000,000 documents by election time. Nearly all the bicycle riders are speakers as well, and they will conduct meetings wherever possible.

The recent revival of interest in Thackeray's writings and personality by the delightful reminiscent notes of his daughter attached to the volumes of the latest edition of the novelist's work bring to mind his visits to this country. Of these episodes in his life some charming glimpses are to be had in a thin volume ' privately printed" in the year 1864 entitled "Hand Immemor."

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- The Northwestern limited train leaving Chicago at 10:30 P.M. to-night was held up not far from De Kalb, Ill., and robbed. The train is due at De Kalb at 12:20 and the hold-up occurred three miles from Maple Parke, Ill. It is not known whether the robbers secured any great amount of booty.

According to estimates made in Washington by officers of the Treasury, the receipts from customs for the current fiscal year, based upon expectations created by the returns for the months of July, August, and September, and the present and prospective business conditions, will exceed those of the best year in the history of the country.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 13. -- The Dewey train ran from Northfield to Boston on special schedule, all freights along the line being side-tracked in consequence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The impression is gaining ground here that if the Ohio election turns out in a way disadvantageous to the President there will be an effort to make Admiral Dewey the Republican candidate for President.

THE NEW YORK TIMES, which is not a poster paper like several of its contemporaries, did issue an attractive supplement with its Sunday issue which contained a few good illustrations and a moderate amount of interesting reading matter. A short time ago it discontinued this supplement, taking the ground that a newspaper which gives all the news has all it can reasonably hope to do successfully in presenting the news.

In your London letter of a fortnight ago Mr. Alden speaks of some notice he had seen of an automatic typewriter, on which he remarks: "The automatic typewriter will probably compose stories as well as print them."

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Oct. 13. -- The feature of the Southern Industrial Convention to-day was an address on the Nicaragua Canal and its relation to the industrial progress of the South by Senator Morgan of Alabama.
NEWPORT, Oct. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Andrews will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary at their Summer home, Sunset Lawn, on Monday next.
Mr. Crockett must dictate to as many simultaneous amanuenses as Julius Caesar -- stenographers withal, which presumably Caesar's scribes were not.

For example, there is Chaucer, whose charming "Wayside Inn" is a most suitable stopping place for any of your readers on a literary pilgrimage.

For example, there is Chaucer, whose charming "Wayside Inn" is a most suitable stopping place for any of your readers on a literary pilgrimage.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Advices received here note the presence of the Boers at Maribogo, forty miles south of Mafeking, which seems to indicate that they are endeavoring to get Col. Baden-Powell between two fires.

The closing game of the season at Washington Park yesterday between the Brooklyns and Baltimores ended, in a row, the Baltimores forfeiting the game. After the forfeiture a postponed game was played. This was won by the Brooklyns by a score of 8 to 3, giving the champions a record of 101 games won for the season.

LAKE PRESTON, S.D., Oct. 14. -- President McKinley's special train was transferred from the Chicago and Northwestern Railway to the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul line here at 4:15 o'clock, and proceeded to Sioux Falls, one and a half hours' late. Several hundred persons gathered at the station and cheered vociferously. President McKinley said:

Mrs. Phoebe A. Cranston, the wife of James H. Cranston, who was until a few years ago the owner of the old New York Hotel, has made application to the Supreme Court to have her husband punished for contempt of court for not paying alimony due her under a decree of separation which she secured from Justice Dugro in the Superior Court on June 27, 1894.

The football game between Princeton and Columbia Universities at Manhattan Field yesterday resulted in a victory for Princeton by a score of 11 to 0. Bright sunshine and Summer temperature attended the much-looked-forward-to game, and these conditions, though very trying to the heavily-padded players, were delightful enough to the spectators, who turned out in hosts.

As a resident of the Riverside district in this city, I venture to ask whether the Third Avenue Railroad Company cannot be compelled to complete and operate its line upon Forty-second Street and the Boulevard, or whether, under our system of municipal government, corporations of that character are absolutely free to do as they like?

LONDON, Oct 14. -- The capture of the armored train on the western border of the Transvaal is the beginning of a few anticipated reverses at the outset of the campaign. The Boer plan is now unfolding itself. It seems to be to strike simultaneously at different points, with a view to obtaining a strong strategic position in Natal before the arrival of the British army corps.

Mr. Clyde Fitch's new romantic play called "Barbara Frietchie" was produced in Philadelphia last week, with Julia Marlowe in the title role, and all the indications are that it will have a long life. To the controversy as to the actual personage whose name was immortalized by Whittier and is used as a title for this piece, Mr. Fitch herewith adds his contribution:

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 14. -- A meeting of Group 6 of the New York State Bankers' Association was held at Larchmont Manor yesterday, and was continued to-day. The meeting was held at the house of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Charles F. Innegall, President of the group, presided, and about 100 members were present.

Rees P. Francis, a Hoboken livery stable keeper, entered the barroom of the Palace Hotel, in Newark Street, on Friday night. He was accompanied by a big dog, half mastiff, half St. Bernard. After taking a drink Francis sat down and fell asleep. His dog lay down at his feet and kept guard over him. Whenever any one went too near the dog showed his teeth with a vicious growl.

Ex-Mayor Frank A Magowan of Trenton was in the West Side Police Court yesterday on a charge of unlawfully withholding $15,000 worth of stock. He was summoned to court by Stephen H. Sprague, a note broker, of Jersey City.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14. -- Six State tickets will be printed on the Australian ballot in Ohio for the election of November -- Republican, Democratic, Prohibition, Union Reform, Socialist Labor, and Jones. Three of these will be voted for by the average number of faddists.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14. -- White the entire programme for the inauguration of President Arthur Twining Hadley of Yale has not yet been completed in every detail, the plans for the occasion are so far advanced that the ceremonies are practically arranged.

Capt. Alphonso Sterckx of the steamer Georgeanna, on which passengers were insulted and robbed by alleged gamblers on Saturday last, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields for examination yesterday morning.

REDFIELD, S.D., Oct. 14. -- President McKinley and party reached this city at 12:50 o'clock this afternoon on the Chicago and Northwestern Railway. A speakers' stand had been erected near the station, and on three sides of it there were jammed people anxious to hear the Chief Executive. President McKinley spoke at some length, and the telling points of his address were greeted with wild applause.

No merely public-spirited society has so rapidly won its way into public favor as "Scapa." The mystery of its title, being interpreted, means the Society for Checking the Abuses of Public Advertising. It should get rid of the name at once. Scapa is too fanciful and too purely non-descriptive.

Calm judgment will scarcely approve of this as the time at which to pass upon the wisdom or expediency of selecting Admiral Dewey as a Presidential candidate. Public opinion is removed as far as possible from a normal state of placidity. It is wildly enthusiastic and in an almost irresponsible stage of hero worship.

Two men whose wives have eloped called at the Morgue yesterday and looked at the mangled remains there of the woman whose identity is still a mystery. They were Carl A. Scheach, a cider manufacturer, who lives at Flushing Avenue and Garrison Street, Long Island City, and Otto H. Krause, proprietor of the Franklin House, in Hackensack.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 14. -- Attached to the train due here at 5:40 this evening from Boston was the private car of President Clark of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, having on board Alfred G. Vanderbilt, second son of the late Cornelius Vanderbilt, who has been speeding here by steamer and special train from Kobe, Japan, through Yokohama and San Francisco.

The American liner St. Paul which arrived here yesterday morning, brought among its passengers several persons who are prominent in theatrical affairs in this country, and who have been abroad for the purpose of securing new attractions for the American stage this season. Prominent among those who arrived were Joseph Humphreys, who is the general stage manager for all of Charles Frohman's productions in this country and abroad.
BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- A high German official, whose utterances may be taken as absolutely conclusive, said to-day:

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The war would have lessened interest in the yacht races in any circumstances, but the long list of failures has almost driven the races out of the public mind. They are recalled at times by suggestions in the press that the Americans are such eminent judges of a good thing that they want to keep Sir Thomas Lipton as long as possible.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14. -- The talent signalized the closing day of the Lexington Fall meeting by putting favorites through in all three races. The track was in good condition, although a little lumpy near the rail, and the weather was perfect.

LIEUT. COL. GEORGES PICQUART REHABILITATED. -- It will be recalled that Lieut. Col. Georges Picquart was dismissed from the French Army on the charge of endeavoring to put "an innocent man" in the place of Capt. Dreyfus. The specific document charges were the communication of State documents to his lawyer and the forging of the petit bleu.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 14. -- Miss Ruth Underhill defeated Mrs. Caleb Fox two up and one to play in the final game of the women's golf contest at Bala to-day, and won the championship of the United States. Score: Miss Underhill -- Out 52, in 49; Mrs. Fox -- out 55, in 48.

Delegations from the Taxpayers' Alliance of the Borough of the Bronx and from the North Side Board of Trade appeared before the State Railroad Commissioners, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday, to press a complaint against the Manhattan Railway Company regarding the failure of that corporation to extend its lines in the Borough of the Bronx.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 14. -- The following is a copy of the cablegram received from Joseph Chamberlain by Lord Seymour, who was administrator, in regard to the sending of a Canadian contingent to the Transvaal:

MARATHON, Texas, Oct. 14. -- Prof. Robert T. Hill of the United States Geological Survey and his corps of assistants have established their camp here and started in on their work of making an official survey of the comparatively unknown region along the Rio Grande border immediately south of here, known as the Great Bloody Bend of Texas.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- A hundred years ago Alexander von Humboldt, who gave its modern impulse to geography, used to develop his ideas and plans at the tea table and fireside of a royal friend and protector in Berlin. To-day an audience of 1,500 listens to Humboldt's successors in the new Prussian Parliament house.

With the sale of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum's block practically assured, and a variety of other good-sized deals involving almost every class of property, there has been something worthy of being called a market during the last week, and there has been encouragement accordingly among brokers, operators, and all those who deal in and gossip about realty.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- The administration building of the Loomis Sanitarium, a short distance outside of this place, was destroyed by fire to-day. The fire was caused by the explosion of an alcohol lamp in the western end of the building. The loss is placed at $100,000; insurance, $50,000.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 14. -- For the first time in the history of intercollegiate football, a strong Eastern eleven was to-day decisively defeated by a Western team. Cornell University and the University of Chicago elevens met on Marshall Field to-day, Chicago winning by a score of 17 to 6. The result was a surprise even to Chicago's strongest adherents, though it was believed Chicago would hold Cornell down to a low score.

The mortality among birds must be quite high in localities where their numbers are so great that they are crowded in the nesting season or in their roosting places. In the days when the wild pigeons were found in this country by the millions, thousands of them were killed every year by accident and diseases peculiar to all crowded conditions of living creatures.

Once more the Columbia and Shamrock were yesterday towed out to the Sandy Hook Lightship, ready to battle for the "blue ribbon of the sea," but the breeze failed to put in an appearance, although the London fog that reminded Sir Thomas of his fatherland had disappeared to a great extent.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 14. -- Kawakami Otojiro, called in English Otto Kawakami, Japan's leading actor, and Mme. Yacco, the Sarah Bernhardt of the Japanese stage, are guests at the Grand Pacific Hotel. They head a Japanese dramatic company that is on its way to Paris from Tokio.

The reopening of the series of Sunday evening concerts at the Metropolitan Opera House was attended by the unfailing evidences of public lack of interest in art and overabundance of it in the personality of the artists. The soloists were applauded to the echo and there was absolutely no discrimination in the distribution of the applause, except that the reception of Signor Campanari, when he came upon the stage, was of an unusually warm nature.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- It is announced to-day that the robbers who held up Northwestern Railroad Train No. 9 shortly before midnight of Saturday escaped with $25,000 in cash alone and possibly a larger amount in jewels.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 14. -- Nebraska may turn a political summersault next month and land in the Republican column, but it would be hazardous to make that prediction for a certainty. Republican leaders are, however, more confident than they have been at any time in the past eight years.

James H. Eckels, ex-Controller of the Currency, had a narrow escape from a most serious if not a fatal injury on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. He was run over by an express wagon at the Twenty-eighth Street crossing, on the west side of the avenue, one wheel of the vehicle passing completely over his body.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Navy Department has substituted the Ranger for the Badger as one of the reinforcing fleet for the Philippines. The Badger was found to require repairs so extensive as to make it impossible for her to get off for a long time. The Ranger is just out of the navy yard and is in excellent condition.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 14. -- Beginning next Monday morning William Jennings Bryan begins a three days' tour through Kentucky, ostensibly in the interest of the State Democratic ticket, headed by Senator William Goebel.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 14. -- The University of Pennsylvania football eleven was defeated this afternoon by the Carlisle Indian team by a score of 16 to 5 on Franklin Field in twenty-five-minute halves. The Indians won because they played the better football. There was no fluke or chance about it, but it was a clean-cut victory.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Many of the cottagers who went to New York from here to witness the cup races became tired of waiting for a contest and have returned to their country places here. Mr. John E. Alexandre came back early in the week, Mr. William D. Sloane returned on Wednesday, and Mr. Charles Lanier on Friday.

The Kaltenborn concerts at St. Nicholas Garden, in Columbus Avenue, are drawing to their close. While they have been going on, and that has been since early in July, they have been engaged in confounding all the predictions that had been drawn from the experience of the last decade, or decade and a half.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 14. -- Plan 20 has been selected by the committee of experts appointed by the Nassau County Supervisors to consider forty-one plans and report the best one for a new County Court House. The Supervisors received the report yesterday, but did not make any decision in the matter.

During the progress of the Saturday night shopping in lower Seventh Avenue last night, while the avenue was crowded with men and women and carts filled with produce were lined along the street, two shots were heard at Twenty-seventh Street, which the police believe were fired in a duel between two men in the open street. They arrested two men, both of whom had revolvers.
PRETORIA, Oct. 13. -- The trial of Mr. Robertson, the Englishman charged with enlisting recruits for the Imperial Light Horse, has begun at Johannesburg.

HARBOR BEACH, Mich., Oct. 14. -- The steamer W.P. Ketcham ran down the little schooner Typo in Lake Huron to-day. The Typo was instantly sunk and four of the crew were drowned. Their names follow: Harry Ledford, mate of the Typo; Daniel Carr, seaman; John Campbell, seaman, and Mrs. Adams, cook.

Apropcs of the recent dinner at Berlin, in the course of which the Kaiser is reported to have questioned ex-President Harrison concerning the battle hymn of the United States, it would be interesting to know the reply of the latter. Can we lay claim to such a thing as a National battle hymn?
LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Sir Henry Irving, Miss Ellen Terry, and their company of forty sail to-morrow on the Atlantic transport liner Marquette, which carries them for the reasonable amount of 9 a head.
MADISON, S.D., Oct. 14. -- Several thousand farmers and inhabitants gathered here to greet President McKinley. The President said:

It does not seem possible, and she was a stranger in New York, too. She had just come from Canada, she said. She was going shopping on a Fifth Avenue 'bus. Every stranger in New York now is supposed to have been here over the Dewey celebrations or to be anxious to see what is left to be seen of the honors New York prepared for the Admiral.
LONDON, Oct. 14. -- There is war in the air. The brazen tones of military bands only cease to give place to the wild cheering of immense crowds which follow the soldiers going to the front.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The visit of Gen. and Mrs. Benjamin Harrison has created an excellent impression, the newspapers commenting pleasantly and in a tone of hearty hospitality. The Lokal Anzeiger says:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Supreme Court Justice Marean to-day vacated the injunction which had been granted restraining the New York, Westchester and Connecticut Traction Company from laying its tracks in the town of East Chester.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The retirement on Monday next of Gen. Shafter at San Francisco will not affect that officer's rank in the volunteer army nor cause any change in his present command.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14. -- How the Consolidated Railroad saved at least $1,000,000 during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1899, is causing much comment in the small circle of railroad managers where the fact is known.

The Executive Committee, otherwise known as the Campaign Committee, of the Democratic State Committee, established yesterday its permanent headquarters in the Hoffman House. The rooms selected for the purpose are the same as those used by the committee in 1897. The campaign will be opened at once, under the familiar leadership of Elliot Danforth. Mr. Danforth moved into the Hoffman House yesterday, and he will reside there during the campaign of this year and next.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 14. -- From present indications, after a careful review of the political situation in Maryland, everything points to the return of the State to the Democratic column in November. The campaign is now fairly on, and is being waged hotly. The Democrats held their first big mass meeting on Thursday night, when the candidates for State offices and other orators discussed the issues before the people.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 14. -- Yale defeated Dartmouth 12 to 0 on the Newton Athletic Association grounds, at Newton Centre, this afternoon in one of the best preliminary games of the season. While Dartmouth failed to score, the Granite State eleven forced Yale to fight for every point, and played a game which surprised even their own backers.

We have several times had occasion to observe that the enthusiasm that has been displayed for the perpetuation of the Dewey arch, though it ought to be and doubtless is immensely gratifying to the artists concerned in the production of the arch, and though it was very creditable to the enthusiasts, was perhaps not altogether "according to knowledge."

Sydney Grundy's adaptation of "The Black Tulip," by the elder Dumas, will soon be produced at the Haymarket Theatre, London, and the old story of the origin of the work has been set going again. Flotow, the composer, insisted that the father of the present young Queen of the Netherlands suggested the plot to Dumas.

Notwithstanding the encroachments on the dime museum business by the concert halls, cheap vaudeville shows, and other similar enterprises which have been established in New York in ever increasing numbers within recent years, the dime museum is fat from being driven from the amusement field.

CAPE TOWN, Sept. 20. -- Louis de Rougemont is at present sojourning in Cape Town, whither he has come under the doctor's orders. He is suffering from an affection of the throat, brought on by continuous lecturing, which caused the loss of his voice. The name of the vessel by which he traveled has not been learned, but he denied his identity to the other passengers on board.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 14. -- A number of the cottagers have returned from New York, having gone down for the Dewey celebration and the attempted cup races. Newport is in all her Autumn glory, and the perfect air is being taken advantage of by the late stayers. Golf, automobiling, and a dinner now and then, with plenty of driving, are the principal amusements of the cottagers.

The vast and tumultuously affectionate throng that on Thursday greeted the President and the members of his Cabinet in the Minneapolis Auditorium, and which cheered without critical reservation the speeches of the President, Gov. LIND, and Attorney General GRIGGS, was not an audience so carried away with its enthusiasm as to have lost control of its judgment.

Nearly 300 National Guardsmen tried for the destinction of marksman and sharpshooter at the ninth supplementary rifle practice on the Creedmoor ranges yesterday. Weather conditions were of the best, bosh the light and a steady "6 o'clock" breeze favoring the riflemen. Fifty aspirants succeeded in entering the sharpshooters' class, and 107 qualified as marksmen.

John G. Wight, President of the Schoolmasters' Association, made an attack at the monthly meeting of the association yesterday on the "Science of Pedagogy" which considerably surprised his hearers. The meeting was held in the Brearly School, 17 West Forty-fourth Street, and the large classroom was crowded.

It is a great pity that the intelligent men of the Island of Luzon, in the Philippines, should be unable or unwilling to comprehend the serviceable and kindly disposition of the American people toward the inhabitants of those islands and the political necessities of the relation in which the sequence of events, which neither they nor we are responsible for, has respectively placed us.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 14. -- In the second match play round for the championship of the Englewood Golf Club to-day, four men and two women survived for the semi-finals and finals, respectively, as follow:

There was a perceptible falling off in the number of registrations in all the boroughs, and practically in all the Assembly districts and wards in the city, yesterday. As compared with last year, the totals were smaller, but this may be accounted for by the fact that at last year's election a Governor and Congressmen were voted for, in addition to Justices of the Supreme Court.

He was a very ordinary appearing chap, and as he labored unsteadily up the stoop of the Fulton Street Police Station, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning and pushed his way through his own breath to the desk the Sergeant glanced at him with habitual indifference.
BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- The day's events for Admiral Dewey ended with a reception and banquet at the Algonquin Club this evening.

HELENA, Mon., Oct. 14. -- Some few months ago Mollie Weinsheimer, a wealthy resident of this place, began an action against Thomas Eddingfield, her former husband, to have certain conveyances, transferring valuable property in this city, set aside. She claimed that she had signed the papers while under the influence of drugs and liquors, administered by Eddingfield, for the alleged fraudulent purpose of securing her property without due recompense.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- The football match between the Orange and Dreadnaught teams at Orange Oval to-day was an easy thing for the locals, the Mott Haven boys never having a chance to win. The total score was 33 to 0, Orange making five touch-downs and kicking three goals.

HURON, S.D., Oct. 14. -- At 2:30 o'clock this afternoon the Presidential train halted for a few minutes in this city. In the square surrounding the station a large crowd had gathered. The President was vociferously cheered as he emerged from the car for a minute talk.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- All Europe is watching Great Britain at this crucial moment in her military affairs. Foreign statesmen and military experts regard the result of the war with the Boers as a foregone conclusion. What they scan with such anxious interest is Britain's tremendous preparations for the contest.

The resolutions adopted by the mass meeting in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, Oct. 11, asking the Government of the United States to use its good offices to prevent bloodshed in the Transvaal, have been forwarded to the President by George W. Van Siclen.

The St. Paul, which arrived yesterday morning from Southampton and Cherbourg, brought Lieut. D. Vassilieff of the Russian Imperial Navy, and fifty-three seamen for the new Russian cruiser Vargiak, now being constructed at the Cramp Shipyard, Philadelphia. Mrs. Charles Barr, wife of the sailing master of the cup defender Columbia, was also a passenger on the St. Paul.
City Superintendent Maxwell advocates amendment of the law with regard to the compulsory school age. In his opinion the time has arrived when this amendment should be made.

The lady barber is no new thing, but she is new in the sense of modern development. Some of us, whose memories can go back a good few years, can remember a little barber's shop, somewhere off Holborn, where, if the good man were not in, his buxom wife would herself operate upon the customers with razor and shaving brush.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- Four thousand people witnessed an exciting football game here this afternoon between the Military Academy team and that of Harvard. The West Pointers put up a fine defensive game from start to finish. They made good offensive work at times, but Harvard was so strong that much distance was well-nigh impossible.

ABERDEEN, S.D., Oct. 14. -- At 8 o'clock this morning President McKinley's special arrived in this city. A fair run was made after leaving Wahpeton, N.D., and the train, which had been running two hours behind schedule, arrived here on time. At the station a large crowd gathered to see the first President of the United States who has visited the Dakotas since Statehood.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 14. -- Fall hunting is now the chief amusement of the kennel clubs, and five meets a week is the usual allowance. Mrs. Ross Whistler is as devoted to the sport as ever, and both she and Mrs. Edward A. Jackson are at all the Elkridge Club meets. They do not, however, appear as often at the Green Spring Valley Hunt Club: the Charles Street Avenue kennels are more convenient.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 14. -- The International Commercial Congress, which opened yesterday in the auditorium of the National Export Exposition, with nearly 1,000 delegates, representing nearly every country in the world, to-day settled down to the real purpose of the gathering, the interchange of views on the general subject of trade and commerce.

We have received from a gentleman unusually well informed as to financial matters -- we may add that he is not a banker -- the following table, which has been prepared with care, showing the rise in value of the share of stock of thirteen of the trust companies in this city since 1895:
