PARIS, Oct. 6. -- We now know that, if the French Government had been willing, Col. von Schwartzkoppen would have been authorized by the German military authorities to give evidence in Dreyfus's favor at Rennes. We know also what he would have said. He would have denounced Esterhazy as the traitor, and proved the complicity between that arch-scoundrel and Col. Henry.

The musical critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who has frequently something suggestive to say upon other themes than music and the opera, speaks most feelingly in last Sunday's issue on the enunciation of the singers of the opera given at the American Theatre, and adds: "Just where our singers are to learn to enunciate is what the present writer cannot tell.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Gen. Sir Redvers Buller, who will have the chief command in South Africa, accompanied by his staff, left Waterloo Station, London, this afternoon for Southampton, to go on board the Dunottar Castle.

The absence of competition in the theatrical field last week, so far as new productions were concerned, may not have benefited the strolling players at the Grand Opera House much in a pecuniary way; but the performances of Shakespeare and Sheridan attracted a larger share of attention from the theatrical habitues and reviewers than they may have counted upon.

VRYBURG, Oct. 13. -- The driver of the armored train destroyed by the Boers at Kraaipan escaped to the veldt, and has turned up at Maribogo, from which place he telephones that all the persons on the train except himself were taken prisoners.

The Very Rev. Charles William Stubbs, D.D., Dean of Ely Cathedral, in England, was a passenger on the Lucania, which arrived yesterday, Dr. Stubbs, when seen at the Everett House, said: "I have come to America primarily to find out how much better you do church work than we in England, and incidentally to deliver a few addresses.

SYDNEY, Sept. 13. -- The downfall of Mr. Reid, the New South Wales Premier, has been one of the political surprises of the year. His defeat had nothing to do with his general policy, but was the result of an unauthorized payment of 350, admittedly without corrupt motives, to a member of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly to recoup expenses incurred in the preparation of an elaborate report on old age pensions.

WAHPETON, N.D., Oct. 14. -- President McKinley's special stopped here last night. A large crowd greeted the Chief Executive, who, in spite of the late hour, left his car and briefly addressed a large assemblage. Secretaries Gage, Hitchcock, and Wilson and Attorney General Griggs followed the President in brief remarks. The President said:
Out in Odd Fellows' Cemetery stands the largest, the best, the most original, and most beautiful columbarium in the whole world.

Five persons are known to have lost their lives by the burning early yesterday morning of the steamboat Nutmeg State off Sands Point, while bound up the Sound from Bridgeport to New York. Several persons were injured and two persons are missing. It is feared that the list of fatalities may be swelled before the full extent of the catastrophe has been measured by further investigation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Navy Department has made public a report from Commander Taussig of the Bennington, with appended reports of subordinate officers, concerning an engagement at Malabon on March 4 last. The purpose of the department in making public the report appears to be solely to make known the gallant conduct of the sailors engaged, and particularly that of Assistant Engineer Winship.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 15. -- In the First Baptist Church this evening a petition to Congressman E.J. Hill was circulated requesting that he do all in his power to prevent the seating of Congressman-elect Roberts of Utah, and further to endeavor to have enacted a Constitutional amendment regulating plural marriage.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Clear skies and warm weather brought nearly 3,000 persons to the Vailsburg bicycle track this afternoon. The event of the day was the twenty-five-mile open race, in which the pick of Eastern long-distance amateurs had been entered. Again J.P. Jacobson of New Haven, the fifty-mile amateur champion, demonstrated his ability by winning in the record-breaking time of 1:03:45, the previous track record, for twenty-five miles being 1:04:51.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Two trolley cars on the Totowa line of the Paterson City Railway Company were in collision between West Side Park and Lincoln Bridge this afternoon. Several persons were injured serevely, and all of those on the two cars suffered from shock and from slight cuts resulting from broken glass falling upon them. Those most severely injured are:

Seven weeks hence the Fifty-sixth Congress will be in session and ready to receive the annual message of the President offering his views as to "the state of the Nation," together with his recommendations of "such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient."

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 15. -- The steam propeller Pottsville, owned by the James McWilliams Towing and Transportation Company of New York was wrecked and burned off Norwalk Islands, near the mouth of the harbor late Saturday night, and proved a total loss. Capt. Ryan and crew of nine men escaped unharmed, but lost all of their effects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Edwin B. Hay, counsel for W.F. Sylvester, owner of the steamer Abbey, which was seized as a filibuster carrying arms and ammunition to the Filipino insurgents, to-day made the following statement in defense of Dr. Edward Bedloe, United States Consul at Canton, China, against whom charges were made in connection with the grant of an American registry to the Abbey:

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- Senator Hanna, who, with Senators Foraker and Frye of Maine and Congressman Littlefield, was here Saturday in his private car, said: "I believe that the President will recommend the establishment of a Department of Commerce in his next annual message." This statement was made to W.G. Davis of Sidney, Ohio, who discussed National matters with Senator Hanna at some length.

The action of the Citizens' Union and of the Independent Labor Party makes it certain that the election of Justice BARRETT, which was, of course, assured, will be entirely unanimous. This result has been brought about after so brief a contest and with so much apparent ease that its significance may not be appreciated by the general public.

There is still a small amount of business coming to hand for Fall goods in the men's wear department, but aside from the lateness of the season and the lateness there-from, it is unimportant. Deliveries of Fall and first Spring orders are taking up the attention of the woolen district. The delivery of sample pieces has been considerably delayed, and the clothiers are clamoring for their goods, All worsted goods are in a bad situation.
LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The Daily Mail's Cape Town correspondent, telegraphing Sunday evening, says: ...

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 15. -- Advices from Potare, ten miles from Caracas, say the people have risen against President Andrade and a crisis is imminent here. The commander of the Government forces has betrayed the President and will allow the revolutionary army to march upon Caracas without a battle.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 15. -- Sir Charles Tupper in a letter to Sir Wilfrid Laurier yesterday said: "The announcement is made to-day that the Government of Canada has consented to send a Canadian contingent to the Transvaal on the condition that a large share of the expense and pay of the men is to be borne by the mother country.

The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Jersey City, continued last evening his series of discourses on "Marriage Bells." His subject was "How to Choose a Good Wife." He said, in part:
CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- The season closed here to-day with a double-header. Garvin pitched a great game against St. Louis, and with three fast double plays back of him, made it a shut-out.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oat. 15. -- The Hackensack Classis of the Christian Reformed Church will meet at Nanuet on Tuesday next, and an interesting time is expected. John Y. Dater, editor of The Ramsay's Journal, who was expelled from the church at that place because he took a picture with his camera on a Sunday, will appeal.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Congressman William D. Daly of Hoboken, who is regarded as Col. Bryan's most ardent supporter in New Jersey, and has been mentioned as a Vice Presidential possibility on the Democratic National ticket next year, had an important conference with James E. Martine, one of the leaders of the Union County Democracy, last Thursday.

Under this title The Hartford Courant takes Secretary LONG to task for referring to the currency question as "a thing of the past." "That was a bad break, Mr. Secretary," says The Courant; "it should not be repeated."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- In his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, Chief Constructor Hichborn lays special stress upon the importance of continuing the work of improving the plants at the various navy yards, inviting particular attention to those at Boston and League Island. A plant is also recommended at Algiers, La., as without it the new dock will be worthless when completed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 15. -- This morning the private car of the Vanderbilt family, which brought Alfred G. Vanderbilt home Saturday evening, was provisioned and sent to Wickford Junction. This evening Harry Payne Whitney, Alfred G. Vanderbilt, and Reginald Vanderbilt drove to the boat and started for Wickford, whence a train conveyed them to the junction.

HEMPSTSEAD, L.I., Oct. 15. -- The Rev. Eugene Zwinger, pastor of the German Lutheran Church here, retained possession of the church to-day, despite the efforts of the old Board of Trustees, whose position was sustained yesterday by a decision of the Nassau County Court, against the new board, composed of his friends.

There must be some mistake in the announcement made by the usually alert and always entertaining correspondent of The Mail and Express in Washington concerning a remarkable political enterprise contemplated by the wife of the Democratic candidate for Governor of Ohio.

Mr. BRYAN can now claim, on the certificate of the Democratic State Committee of New York, that he is the "natural and approved leader of the party in the Nation." But he must have a realizing sense that he is so only because the party can find no other. He represents the ideas of 1896, which were distinctively his own ideas.

VRYBURG, Cape Colony, Oct. 15. -- A hospital train that started for Maribogo, fifty miles northeast of here, has just returned, after an adventurous journey. It had reached a curve on a culvert 700 yards south of Maribogo, and had just slackened speed, when it was observed that rails ahead had been upturned.

Sixty years ago the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Haskins preached his first sermon as pastor of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, Bedford Avenue and South Fifth Street, Brooklyn. Without any interval and with few absences from the services of the church, he has held the same place ever since, accomplishing a record that is almost unparalleled, both in point of time and in the perpetual unanimity between people and pastor.

Having been taught effectively that raids upon the security market, as a whole, do not frighten investors or dislodge stocks, the bear contingent devotes itself to onslaughts ripen specialties. In a few quarters success has attended the demoralization efforts -- enough success to make it certain that the same tactics will be continued.

HONOLULU, Oct. 8. -- The transport Centennial arrived from San Francisco on the 5th. She brought 300 horses, 60 of them hanging in slings and ready to die from simple exhaustion. Two of them died after reaching port.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Despite their earlier intention to take a faster ship. Sir Henry Irving and Miss Ellen Terry, with their full company, sailed for the United States this morning on the Atlantic Transport Line steamer Marquette, which is due to arrive in New York Oct. 25 or 26.

The police and detectives detailed to work on the case of the murdered woman, parts of whose body have been found in different sections of the city, apparently made no headway yesterday toward a solution of the mystery. Their work at present seems to be confined to searching for missing women, who continue to be reported daily.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Our markets moved much as anticipated last week. In money ease increased daily, until call loans were down to 3 per cent. and sometimes less. Loans for a week are now barely 3 1/4 to 3 1/2 per cent., and this cheapness will probably continue for another eight or ten days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Adelbert W. Cox, for several years prior to Oct. 1 a member of the Washington police force, and Etta Williams, a young woman with whom he lived, were arrested yesterday morning by Detectives Miller and Peck, charged with the larceny of $100 from James A. Stewart, fifty-five years of age, and for a long time a clerk in the General Land Office.
DURBAN, Oct. 15. -- The following official statement has been published:

Prosecutions by wholesale are promised by State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh as a result of the use of his new "challenge affidavits" during the present registration period. The State Superintendent was at his office all day yesterday going over with Deputy Superintendent Van Duser and a corps of clerks the results of the work of the preceding two days.

All that was left yesterday of the big Sound steamer Nutmeg State, which caught fire on her way up the Sound from Bridgeport early Saturday morning, during which five persons are known to have lost their lives, was a blackened hulk lying a few hundred yards from shore at the mouth of East Creek, off Old Hen Point, near Port Washington, Long Island.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The following table shows the current annual expenditures of the maritime nations of Europe and Japan, so far as they have been ascertained, in behalf of their respective merchant navies. The latest available official reports and reports of steamship companies and mail contracts, copies of which are on file in the bureau, have been used.

The Rev. Dr. J.F. Carson, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, who at a recent meeting of the Brooklyn Presbytery startled that body and caused a great deal of talk in local church circles by asserting that one-half the population of Brooklyn was not reached by the churches, followed up his statement yesterday with a sermon on the subject.
" The Place of the Pulpit in Modern Life and Thought" formed the subject of a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

Harm is done when a paper of the standing of THE TIMES prints and with scare-head lines such an article as that upon the American Board in this morning's issue. A very little inquiry would have convinced you that it is essentially incorrect from start to finish.

There was a brief but exciting discussion at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union over an attempt to allow a Tammany politician to deliver an address, and then pass a resolution of confidence in him. The Tammanyites in the meeting were unfortunately in the minority, and were badly defeated, but some of them said they would yet catch the Central Federated Union napping.

The crews of Columbia and Shamrock spent another day of comparative idleness in the snug anchorage inside Sandy Hook, and beyond overhauling some of the standing rigging and stretching the sails on Columbia the day was without incident. Sir Thomas entertained the usual number of guests on board the Erin yesterday, and the Irish Knight made strenuous efforts to appear merry and satisfied with the weather.

A fortnight ago we had occasion to speak of the French Minister of War, General le Marquis DE GALLIFFET, and to emphasize the remarkable work that he was doing in restoring tranquility to a disrupted country and rehabilitating her in the eyes of the world.
CAPE TOWN, Oct. 15. -- President Steyn of the Orange Free State and President Kruge of the Transvaal maintain direct telephonic connection.

The report that the Rev. Dr. Burstell is to be installed as pastor of the Church of the Epiphany, while not denied, is said to be premature. Archbishop Corrigan, in reply to a question concerning the report, yesterday said:

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 16. -- The little oyster sloop Dream, a mass of flames, drifted into Rock Creek yesterday forenoon. The dismembered portions of a white man's body, supposed to have been Capt. Oliver Caulk, her owner, were found after the fire had been extinguished.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- This was Australia day at the International Commercial Congress. Before the discussions of the regular programme J.P. Allen of Toronto spoken on water transportation between Canada and the United States, complaining that while Canadian waterways are open to American ships, Canada could not ship even a barge to New York without breaking bulk and reshipment at the border.

PADUCAH, Ky., Oct. 16. -- The largest crowd of the day was met at Mayfield. Mr. Bryan and Mr. Goebel were the speakers, the former delivering the most elaborate speech o the morning, thus far. Mounted upon an elevated platform he said he did not know in which direction to talk.

Jefferson M. Levy answered all inquiries yesterday relative to his reported connection with the purchase of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum Block by saying that he was non-committal. Ex-Mayor Smith Ely said that several weeks ago Mr. Levy had spoken to him about entering a syndicate for the purchase of the property and that he had acquiesced.
MOUNT HOREB, Wis., Oct. 16. -- A great crowd greeted the President here this afternoon. He spoke ten minutes, and was enthusiastically applauded. He said:
CINCINNATI, Oct. 16. -- In a rear corner of Squire Bloom's court stands a trunk, the property of Israel Barris, and containing his wedding outfit.
ASHTABULA, Ohio, Oct. 16. -- One of the most enthusiastic meetings of the Ohio Republican campaign was held to-day at Ashtabula, special trains bringing crowds from outlying towns in all directions.

After some general conversation with regard to the controversy, as possibly indicating a schism between the army and the navy with regard to the Cuban campaign, Rear Admiral Sampson took up the case in point as follows:
With a distracted mother urging them to their best efforts with the offer of a reward of $10,000, five Brooklyn doctors labored in vain yesterday to save her child from death by strangulation.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 16. -- Coach King, with his string of Wisconsin football players, left Madison this morning, for the East to do battle with Yale next Saturday. The men are all in good condition at present, and every means will be taken to keep them so. Water will be taken along for them to drink.

Many prominent Southerners are visiting this city at present, and they are discussing freely the situation in the South and West as foreshadowing the probable issues of the approaching Presidential campaign, as well as the part that William Jennings Bryan is expected by his adherents to play in that contest.

DODGEVILLE, Wis., Oct. 16. -- When the special train bearing President McKinley and his party arrived here this afternoon the farmers were out in full force to greet the Chief Executive. The President was greatly pleased with his reception. He said:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The Industrial Commission to-day heard the testimony of President M.E. Ingalls of the Big Four and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Companies on the transportation subject.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- It is probable that the anti-imperialist conference, which will begin a two-day session in Chicago this morning, will set forth its position in the form of a memorial to Congress.

There was more excitement manifested at the Morris Park race track yesterday when the announcement was made on the jockey board that Columbia had won the yacht race than there was at any other time during the day. Between the races, which were rather tame affairs, the bulletin board under the grandstand, where telegrams giving the story of the progress of the race were posted, was surrounded by a large crowd.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 16. -- Mrs. Edward S. Willing entertained at dinner this evening in honor of her daughter, Miss Susan Willing, whose engagement to Frank C. Lawrance of New York was formally announced. The wedding will occur Nov. 2.

PHILDELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- There was some improvement in the market to-day, although it did not extend to any marked advances in prices. Fractional gains were made by nearly all of the active leaders, including Asphalt, Union Traction, Pennsylvania Railroad, and the iron and steel issues. The latter were benefited by the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share (6 per cent.) on New Haven Iron and Steel.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 16. -- The revenue cutter Corwin, which arrived this morning, brings news that great suffering has commenced at Cape Nome, owing to a deficiency in the supply of food, clothing, and fuel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The War Department has received the following dispatches from Gen. Merriam regarding a possible outbreak at the San Carlos Agency, Arizona. The first reads: "Denver, Oct. 15. -- Commanding officer, San Carlos, reports that Friday night about twelve of command made attack on four peaceful Indians, beating them severely.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, who was summoned home from Japan for a family conference preparatory to the filing for probate of the will of his father, Cornelius Vanderbilt, reached this city from Newport early yesterday morning, and spent about three hours at the Grand Central Station in conference with his uncle, W.K. Vanderbilt, and with counsel.

The opening series of games in the American National bowling tournament were rolled at the Germania alleys last night. The weather was almost too warm for bowling, but this did not deter a large crowd from visiting the alleys. The Fidelia, Orchard, and Glendale Clubs competed in the first series.

GALENA, Ill., Oct. 16. -- President McKinley's special train arrived here at 1 o'clock this afternoon. A large crowd assembled at the station within sight of the Grant Monument. After a short speech by the President, Secretaries Gage and Long made a few remarks. The President said:

Plans have been quietly maturing for some weeks past looking to the consolidation of all the paper manufactories of the country grouped in those now independent mills which manufacture wood pulp board, paper pulp board, and straw board. All told, some one hundred or more mills are interested in the projected consolidation scheme, and the amount of capital involved is about $50,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The Colonial Office issued this evening the correspondence between Mr. Chamberlain and Sir Alfred Milner, British High Commissioner in South Africa, respecting the Transvaal controversy, from Sept. 8 to Oct. 12. The salient points of the principal dispatches, however, have already been published.

BARDWELL, Ky., Oct. 16. -- The Bryan party left Cairo, Ill., this morning at 7 o'clock for a tour through Kentucky and Ohio. Among those on the train were Mr. and Mrs. William Jennings Bryan, National Committeeman Woodson of Kentucky, William Goebel, Democratic candidate for Governor; Capt. Joseph Blackburn, brother of Senator Blackburn; G.G. Coulter, candidate for Auditor, and others known to the Kentucky Democracy, and an array of newspaper correspondents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Acting for the Attorney General of Louisiana, Edgar H. Farrar to-day entered a motion in the United States Supreme Court for leave to file an injunction bill on behalf of Louisiana against the State of Texas prohibiting the freight embargo feature of the New Orleans yellow fever quarantine.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Oct. 16. -- Mrs. Jane Lindsay, who is trying to break the bicycle record of 700 consecutive miles, made not long ago by Miss Jane Yatman over the triangular course here, finished her fifth hundred at 2:02 P.M. to-day, and began to plod away on the sixth hundred.

MANILA, Oct. 16. -- Mail advices from Iloilo state that there is great tension between the Visayans and Tagalos growing out of the Tagalos holding Araneta, a leader of the Visayans, a prisoner since the threatened Visayan revolt against Tagalo domination a month ago. The Visayans are incensed to the point of rebellion.
MADRID, Oct. 16. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 71.00. Gold was quoted at 26.87.

John Kane, Chief of Police of Undercliff Borough, shot and seriously wounded William F. Murray of that place yesterday morning. Two bullets took effect. One bullet went very near to the heart, but it is not thought that it will prove fatal.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16. -- The Yale football squad was given a stiff and sharp but short practice this afternoon. There was no cessation of work for any of the players, except those whose bruises were of such a nature that it would be dangerous for them to play.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16. -- The annual election of the stockholders of the Cincinnati, New Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway took place this afternoon in the general offices of the company in the Odd Fellows' Temple. The following Directors were elected to serve for the ensuing year: M.E. Ingalls, Lawrence Maxwell, Jr., Francis Lynde Stetson, Samuel Spencer, H.F. Shoemaker, Eugene Zimmerman, and M.D. Woodford.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Partly owing to the diminished interest after so many abortive attempts and partly to disappointment over the results of to-day's race for the America's Cup, London's demonstrations were rather tame.

MILWAUKEE, Oct 16. -- The special train bearing President McKinley and party arrived in this city from the trip through Iowa and part of Wisconsin over the Chicago and Northwestern early this evening.
Second withdrawal by Controller Coler of the offer to sell bonds of the city amounting to $9,087,107, and new offer to be made, under which $2,377,107 of these bonds will be sold on Oct. 26.

A new, startling, and highly interesting chapter has been contributed to the history of our war with Spain. Capt. FRENCH E. CHADWICK, who commanded the armored cruiser New York under Rear Admiral SAMPSON, and who was recently honored at Morgantown, West Va., by the gift of a jeweled sword from the proud fellow-citizens of his native town, unconsciously provoked the startling revelation.

I have waited patiently for three weeks to see some intimation in your paper or elsewhere that the surface railway companies offer any inducement by advertisement in their cars for the public to make complaint of the rudeness of their employes. There is no notice (as in the elevated railroad cars) that employes are expected to be civil, to give information to passengers, and to gives their name and number if asked for.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The Queen's speech at the opening of Parliament to-morrow will declare that Parliament has been summoned at an unusual date for a specific purpose, and that this course has been rendered necessary by two circumstances:

When the Mazet committee meets again the last of this month one of the subjects to be taken up will be the amount of fees received by referees. Mr. Moss is already in receipt of several statements of this nature, returned in response to the application of the committee, and said yesterday that, although they were coming in slowly, he expected to have considerable material for the future sessions.

BENTON, Ky., Oct. 16. -- Mr. Bryan was cordially greeted at Benton by a very large crowd at noon. He was introduced as the "Great Democrat" of the day and took occasion to say in reply that all Democrats were great who lived up to their responsibilities. The defeat of 1896 merely made the party more determined to win.
ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- By order of Gov. Roosevelt, Thomas Hutson, County Treasurer of Chautauqua County, is to be removed from office for misusing county funds.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 16. -- The Pittsburg Coal Company, the $64,000,000 combination of the railroad coal interests of the Pittsburg district, will get in working order at the office of the Union Trust Company to-morrow by the election of the following stated officers: F.M. Osborne, President; J.C. Dysart, Secretary, or Vice President; U.A. Andrews, Treasurer; C.W. Baine, Secretary of one of the departments.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 16. -- The President arose at dawn to-day and started on his trip through Iowa and Wisconsin to Milwaukee. At every stop he was greeted by great crowds. His first speech was made at 6:20 o'clock in the morning at Cedar Falls, where he said:

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 16. -- Nearly 10,000 persons were massed in front of the State Capitol here this afternoon to hear President McKinley speak. He was cheered enthusiastically from the start. The special train arrived at 4 o'clock, and all the members of the party were driven to the Capitol, a mile from the station. A detachment of militia acted as an escort.
PEKING, Oct. 16. -- Yano Fumio, Japanese Minister to China, has been recalled. He will be succeeded by Mr. Nishii, former Japanese Minister to Russia.
FORT MONROE, Oct. 16. -- The cruiser Brooklyn left Hampton Roads at 4:45 o'clock this afternoon, bound for Manila, through the Suez Canal.

A plan for the merging into the New York Public Library of all the free libraries which are now mainly supported by the city, was developed at yesterday's session of the Board of Estimate. The plan was suggested by Controller Coler, who has given the subject much thought, and it has received not only the support of the other members of the board, but also of many representatives of the libraries concerned.

It has been said that the most malignant and bitter feelings that take possession of weak humanity are those sometimes engendered by opposing factions in church organizations. This may not be wholly true, but certain it is that people sometimes do the most disgusting and intemperate acts in the name of God and Christianity that are possible for reasonably well-intentioned beings to perform.

Mr. CECIL RHODES appears to have made a tactical mistake in establishing himself at Kimberley. It is true that for him to take up his residence there on the eve of a conflict between the Boers and the British was to give proof of his own confidence in the defensibleness of the place, which he is said to have pronounced "as safe as Piccadilly."

WEST PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 16. -- Not since the University of Pennsylvania has been an important factor in intercollegiate football has any man save George Woodruff had anything to do except in an advisory capacity with coaching the team.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16. -- Senator James K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee; Vice Chairman Stone, J.G. Johnson of Kansas, Chairman of the Executive Committee, and S.B. Cook, Chairman of the National Ways and Means Committee, met at the Planters' Hotel to-day and conferred on the political situation.
President J.H. Jenkins of the Bridgeport Steamboat Company returned yesterday from Sands Point, where he had been inspecting the wreck of the burned steamboat Nutmeg State.
The Automobile Club of America met last night in the State apartments at the Waldorf-Astoria. A constitution and by-laws were adopted and permanent officers were announced.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16. -- To-morrow morning there will be buried from St. Xavier's Church, at solemn requiem high mass, the remains of Miss Mary Laughlin, aged eighteen, of 519 Torrence Road. Miss Laughlin died from blood poisoning and with terrible agony.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 16. -- Ottmar Mergenthaler, the inventor of the linotype, the machine which has revolutionized printing offices all over the world, is seriously ill at his home, 159 West Lanvale Street, this city.
LONDON, Oct. 16. -- A somewhat revised edition of Hall Caine's "The Christian" was produced at the Duke of York's Theatre this evening before a distinguished and interested audience.

IPSWICH, Wis., Oct. 16. -- President McKinley spoke to a large crowd here this afternoon from a stand near the railway station, J.W. Babcock, who represents this district in Congress, boarded the train and accompanied the Presidential party to Milwaukee. President McKinley said:

The will of Henry Chauncey, Jr., who died at Lenox, Mass., on Sept. 27, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The value of the estate, according to the petition, is unknown. It is said to be very large, however. Mr. Chauncey inherited one-third of the estate left by his mother, who died in 1895.

Tammany's campaign against Assemblyman Robert Mazet in the Nineteenth District was opened last night with an open-air meeting at Amsterdam Avenue and Sixtieth Street, where between 600 and 700 people cheered to the echo a series of violent denunciations of the Chairman of the legislative investigating committee and the committee itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Since the recent work on the Dismal Swamp Canal, the Navy Department has been asked to detail a vessel to make the trip through the canal to the sounds on the south. The Talbot, one of the smaller torpedo boats, has been detailed for this duty and has sailed from Norfolk for that purpose.
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The war news is still in the region of surmise. There are rumors that the Boers have been repulsed at Mafeking and are attacking Vryburg.

-- Certain features of the recent Mayoralty election in Chattanooga might seem to furnish the editorial mind with a topic better suited for private and silent consideration than for printed comment, but little excuse as these features give for journalistic pride and exultation, their interest is beyond question, and interesting things are not so plenty that one of them can be ignored just because its tendency is to overthrow a pleasant theory or two.

The mystery surrounding the murder of the woman, portions of whose body have been found in this city and surrounding waters, was not cleared up yesterday, although the detectives claim to be working on what looks like the most promising clue so far developed. This relates to Mrs. Kate Feeley, who disappeared on Friday, Oct. 6, the day before the first portion of the body, now in the Morgue, was found.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 16. -- Gen. William R. Shafter, who has held the positions of Brigadier General in the regular army and Major General in the volunteer army, will go on the retired list of the regular army to-day. This is Gen. Shafter's sixty-fourth birthday, and he retires by operation of the law which fixes the age limit of officers of the regular army.

The public school teachers of Brooklyn, numbering more than 3,500 men and women, have received not one penny of their salaries since June last. Although the schools of that borough have been open since the first week of September, one delay after another has interfered with the payment of the money due them.

Israel Zangwill's play "Children of the Ghetto," which was acted for the first time in New York at the Herald Square Theatre last night, was found to justify the expectations of its worth which an experienced playgoer might have derived from the accounts of its performances in other cities.

The Merchants' Association is still continuing to receive replies to the circular letter which it sent out last week to all the signers of the petitions of 1883 and 1895, which are attached to the present petition now before the Board of Public Improvements, asking the signers of those old petitions if they intended when they signed them that their names should be used for what is now generally known as the Ramapo scheme.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Oct. 17. -- The State College football team, with substitutes, trainers, and a large body of students, left for Princeton this morning. The team is in excellent condition, and most of the players have recovered from the injuries received in the Washington-Jefferson game.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- At the first day's racing of the Gatwick October meeting to-day, J. Reiff won the Willow Nursery on the Squabble colt. Clun was second. "Tod" Sloan finished third with Bathing Woman. Fourteen horses ran. The betting was 100 to 8 against the Squabble colt.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 17. -- The Yale football eleven, 'Varsity and college, practiced this afternoon behind closed gates for an hour. This was unexpected, and the large company of students that went out to the field was taken by surprise. It appears in the light of this secret practice that Yale anticipates a hard game on Saturday, and is working up a lot of trick plays for defensive work.

That the beautiful arch erected to commemorate Admiral Dewey's victory shall be reproduced in more enduring form is to be accepted as a matter of course. Discussion will therefore be limited to the proper site for it.
ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- Gov. Roosevelt tonight issued the formal order removing Thomas Hutson from the office of Treasurer of Chautauqua County. After reviewing the case, the Governor says:
My attention has been called to a long communication in your issue of Oct. 2, entitled "The Key West Fever Fight," and signed "M.H.S.," presumably a representative of the Marine Hospital Service.

The statement is made by a Republican newspaper that at the recent Republican primary elections in New York County only 15 per cent. of the voters of that party participated in the choice of delegates who afterward nominated the candidates to be voted for at the approaching election.

The Irish tongue was spoken the greater part of last evening at the Twenty-first annual Feis Ceoil Agus Seanachas (Festival of Music and Talk) of the Gaelic Society. The entertainment was held at the Lenox Lyceum, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, and was presided over by ex-Justice Joseph F. Daly.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Parliament opened to-day in extraordinary session to consider the South African situation. The Lords and Commoners assembled in the House of Lords to hear the speech from the throne, after which the House of Lords took a recess until 4 o'clock in the afternoon. Upon reassembling, the Liberal leader, Lord Kimberley pledged the support of the opposition to necessary measures, but attacked the course of the Government.

If any doubt existed in the minds of racing men as to the superiority of Perry Belmont's colt Ethelbert over Raffaello, who defeated him over the Withers mile course last Thursday, it was cleared away yesterday, when the pair met again in the Dixiana Stakes. Ethelbert carried a pound more than he did on the previous occasion, while Raffaello carried 115 pounds, the same weight he had up last Thursday.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- At Marlborough House, London, great disappointment was expressed at the accident to the Shamrock this morning, the news of which was conveyed to the Prince of Wales just as he was preparing to leave town.
A.D. Juilliard, representing Mary C. Dodge, has sold to Boehm Boehm the two four-story dwellings 37 and 39 East Twenty-first Street, 50 by 98.9, for about $100,000.
PROVIDENCE, Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Dr. William Herbert Perry Faunce of New York was inaugurated to-day as President of Brown University. In the course of his inaugural address Dr. Faunce said:

I desire to thank you very sincerely for the editorial "The Boer and the British," appearing in to-day's (Sunday) TIMES. You have said many hard things about us on the Transvaal question, but in a just and strictly impartial manner.
JACKSON, Mich., Oct. 17. -- The President's first stop after leaving Chicago on his journey East was made at Three Oaks.
EDINBURGH, Oct. 17. -The Scotsman, referring to yesterday's race for the America's Cup. says:

The second of the races for the America's Cup was won yesterday by the Columbia owing to an accident to Shamrock. The course was over an equilateral triangle of ten miles to each side, and it was so set that the first leg was to windward. The two yachts made a beautiful start and went off on a long port tack soon after going over the line.

Rockaway won the West Brighton Polo Cups yesterday in the final contest on the Staten Island Polo Club's field, defeating the team of the Somerset Country Club of Bernardsville, N.J. It was a well played match, and marked by the most exciting finish of the entire series of games at the Staten Island Club.
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- A special dispatch from Cape Town says that 300 Boers and 18 British have been killed in a battle at Mafeking.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Notwithstanding the fact that President McKinley did not retire until 4 o'clock this morning, when he returned from the banquet given by the Milwaukee Merchants and Manufacturers' Association, he was up bright and early, and at 9:30 o'clock the party was driven out to the National Soldiers' Home, in the extreme western portion of Milwaukee.

John C. Sheehan has a suit on his hands as a result of the fight for the leadership in the Ninth Assembly District, which he won at the primaries last month, and his enemies in the district do not purpose to let him enjoy his victory without a struggle. One of his strongest opponents after Goodwin, beaten at the polls, now has recourse to the law, and has sued him for $10,000 for slander.

A silver service made by Tiffany Co. and consisting of two candelabra, a centre piece, a waiter, and a tea set of five articles was yesterday presented to George W. Ely on his retirement from the office of Secretary of the Stock Exchange. After the closing of the Exchange, President Rudolph Keppler, with Capt. Ely and Vice President R.H. Thomas, went to the rostrum.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- Charles G. Dawes, Controller of the Currency, delivered an address this evening at the annual meeting of the Merchants' Club of this city on "Trusts and Trade Combinations." He took the ground that the trusts are a proper subject of regulation by the Federal Government, and not by State Legislatures.

The late Captain Bunsby, who was a philosopher rather than a mariner, and Col. W.J. BRYAN, who is a philosopher rather than a military man or a politician, would have discovered a mutual likeness if the lamented Bunsby could have been spared to meet with and listen to Col. BRYAN as the latter spoke at Bardwell, Ky., on Monday morning.

The Board of Estimate yesterday took up the estimates of the Board of Education, and for nearly two hours President Little and his colleagues were kept busy replying to questions fired at them by the Mayor, the Controller, and President Guggenheimer, all of whom seemed to take great pleasure in inquiring into the great increases demanded for the support of the schools next year.

There will be more interest and excitement in the Nineteenth Assembly District this year than in any contest elsewhere in the city. There Mr. MAZET has been nominated by the Republicans and Mr. STEWART by the Citizens' Union, and Tammany has indorsed the latter. The Republicans stake nearly all their prestige in the city on the re-election of the Chairman of the investigating committee, and the Democrats are naturally as eager to defeat him.

That was a misfortune for much more than the immediate sufferer which the Shamrock underwent yesterday within twenty minutes or so after the start. All experts are agreed that it is a misfortune that might have happened to anybody, that might have happened to her rival. Your big jibtopsail is well known to be a sparbreaker of the most formidable kind.

CAPE TOWN, Oct. 17. -- The Boers seized the telephone at Modder River last evening and attempted to speak with Kimberley, hoping to learn the disposition of the British forces there. The manoeuvre was discovered and frustrated.
Deputy Chief Benjamin A. Gicquel of the Fire Department has been on the sick list for a week as the result of a large carbuncle on his left hand.

The interest in the Far East which this country has felt since May 1, 1898, and the tempting field for building up an export trade which China affords, have led to the acquisition by American merchants of a site and building for a large American warehouse at Shanghai, China. This warehouse is to be used for exhibiting samples of American manufactures, and is to be maintained by the National Association of Manufacturers.
PRINCETON, Oct. 17. -- If the sophomore class can get possession of a picture taken of the freshmen class to-day the latter will be disgraced forever. No effort will be spared to obtain a copy.

STANFORD, Ky., Oct. 17. -- The second-day of William J. Bryan's Kentucky campaigning trip was spent in the central part of the State under unfavorable weather conditions. The start was made from Louisville this morning at 6 o'clock. A heavy rainstorm prevailed and continued throughout the day.

-- Balancing as carefully as possible the rather contradictory accounts of the happenings on board the Nutmeg State, one gets the impression that the crew, as a whole, behaved neither very well nor very ill, but still stronger is the impression that its several members did about as they chose and that no adequate provision had been made for meeting an emergency unusual, indeed, but far from unprecedented or safely negligible.

The meeting held on Monday showed that the project for the "perpetuation," as it is rather inaccurately called, of the Dewey arch, has fallen among practical men, who know how such an undertaking should be gone about, and are preparing to go about it in the right way. We have already pointed out the futility of appealing, in the first instance, to "popular subscription."

The Rev. Andrew Fleming, who has been minister in charge of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, since April, 1898, during the absence of the rector, the Rev. Dr. James B. Nies, in the Holy Land, has resigned. There have been slight dissensions in the church for some time, dating back to the removal of Choirmaster William H. Pilcher, with whom Mr. Fleming had a disagreement.

A charge of total lack of originality, preferred against the sculptors of America by Robert B. Roosevelt, provoked sharp answers from several well-known artists of this city yesterday. Mr. Roosevelt is a member of a committee of the Holland Society charged with the duty of selecting a design for a monument to the Dutch founders of New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The opposition of the anti-expansionists to the subjugation of the Filipinos took tangible form to-day in the meeting of about 160 delegates from different parts of the country to launch a crusade against the policy of the Administration in the Philippines.
As of interest to other readers as well as myself, will you briefly state in your columns what the present law is as to the detention of persons suspected of causing the death of another?

Immediately after the Windsor Hotel fire Mr. Brady stated that he knew the building was a firetrap, and that he knew of many other equally dangerous buildings, but that the present building laws did not give him power to make these houses reasonably safe. Thereupon three different lawyers were hurrying to Albany to have some romantic and wonderful legislation enacted to remedy the defects in the law.

The Democratic nominees for county and judicial offices were officially notified of their nomination at the Democratic Club last night. The ceremony, which was very simple, although it attracted to the clubhouse a large gathering of the members, began at about 9 o'clock. Chairman Michael C. Murphy of the Notification Committee acted as master of ceremonies.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The Neueste Nachrichten declares that the Colonial Council has adopted a resolution declaring it compatible with German colonial interests to abandon Samoa in return for sufficient indemnification.
LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The Daily News, commenting upon the agitation of the German press regarding a settlement in Samoa, says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The State Department has been informed by cable that telegraphic communicator with the Transvaal has been completely interrupted. The department is thus cut off from communication with United States Consul Macrum at Pretoria.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18. -- Arthur Twining Hadley, LL.D., was to-day inaugurated thirteenth President of Yale University to succeed Timothy Dwight. The ceremony took place this afternoon in Battell Chapel, the college church, in the presence of hundreds of distinguished men and women, prominent in higher educational affairs in all sections of the country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18. -- Three thousand Yale undergraduates and recent graduates united to-night in a demonstration in honor of the inauguration of President Hadley. The hit of the procession was the train of cars of the "Hadley Transportation Company." It consisted of a locomotive and three ears, each of the latter 16 feet long and 7 feet high, lighted from within with lanterns.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- William C. Whitney of New York is reported to have purchased the Stony Ford Stock Farm, eight miles from this city.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Emmons J. Swift, State Excise Inspector, of Forestville, was nominated for Treasurer of Chautauqua County this morning, to succeed Thomas Hutson of Mayville, who was removed from office by Gov. Roosevelt. The Governor may appoint Swift to serve out Hutson's unexpired term.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 18. -- The Essex County Republican Convention was held to-night in Music Hall, Richard C. Jenkins of Newark presided.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. l8. -- President McKinley and party reached this city at 8:45 o'clock this morning. The train was sidetracked near Oberlin, Ohio, at 2 o'clock this morning and remained there until 8 o'clock.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- At the second day of the Gatwick October meeting, to-day, Stage Villain, ridden by "Skeets" Martin, won the Gatwick Mid-Weight Handicap. Winsome Charteris was second, and Ameer third. "Tod" Sloan rode Jiffy II., but was unplaced in a field of thirteen. The betting was 10 to 1 against Stage Villain and 3 to 1 against Jiffy II.

That "first-class burgher" and robustipus Boer, the Hon. ROBERT B. ROOSEVELT, is extremely disgusted with the sculptors, upon the ground that they are persons of no ideas. Now, most people who have had dealings as clients with sculptors find fault with them on the ground that their ideas are too numerous and too expensive in execution for a committee which is never unlimited.

Sir Thomas Lipton's cup hunter, Shamrock, was remeasured at Erie Basin yesterday morning with the result that in future she will be compelled to allow Columbia sixteen and twenty-hundredths seconds over the thirty-mile course. The new figures give a water-line length of 88.98 feet, an increase of 1.29 feet over her former measurement.

MANILA, Oct. 18. -- The Consuls in Manila have received from Tarlac, where it is believed that Aguinaldo remains, a book containing the correspondences between him and the American commanders and Consuls in which, as he contended in his recent appeal for recognition, the Filipinos find the basis for their assertion that the American Government recognized their sovereignty and promised them independence.

The manner in which death came to the woman, portions of whose body have rested in the Morgue for the past ten days, remains as much of a mystery as ever. The police, however, yesterday discovered a new and promising clue.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Prominent men, who either in official or mercantile life have been actively engaged in the trade between China and the United States, England, and other countries, to-day discussed that trade as it is, and as it should be, before the International Commercial Congress.

Joseph Fischer, a blind man living in Jane Street, West Hoboken, yesterday filed papers in chancery asking that his sister Catherine and his brother Henry be compelled to surrender property valued at $20,000 to him and a younger sister named Clara. He claims that at the death of their parents he and Clara, who is also blind, were sent out to beg.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Oct. 18. -- Mrs. Jane Lindsay, after 91 hours and 48 minutes of almost continuous pedaling, completed her self-imposed task of riding 800 miles on a bicycle over the country roads in this vicinity. The limit of time she had set for herself was 96 hours.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- The Princetons to-day defeated the Pennsylvania State College eleven by the score of 12 to 0. Halves of fifteen and ten minutes were played and the game was fast and exciting throughout. The Princeton players out-pointed their opponents in nearly every play. One touchdown was made in each half. The line-up follows:

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. l8. -- The Textile Council, made up of delegates from all the labor unions of textile workers in this city, will meet Friday night and take steps to secure an advance in the wage scale.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 18. -- Twenty thousand people greeted William J. Bryan and the candidates on the Democratic State ticket at Churchill Downs this afternoon, the occasion being the first demonstration by local Democrats in the State campaign now in progress. The crowd was filled with enthusiasm and satiated with barbecued meat and burgoo.

Controller Bird S. Coler was the guest last evening of the National Civic Club, at 144 Montague Street, Brooklyn. He made an address upon several topics of interest in connection with municipal affairs.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The Cape Town correspondent of The Daily Mail says: "Dispatches from Beira, dated Saturday, state that the Boers advancing northward were repulsed at Lobatsi station. This doubtless means that Col. Plumer's force, advancing to the relief of Mafeking, had encountered the Boers."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- A movement is on foot among a number of fashionable people, including several recognized society leaders, to give their large entertainments this Winter, such as teas, musicales, luncheons, dinners, and receptions on Sunday.

The inevitable began to suggest itself in yesterday's security market. Outsiders began to buy. Some professional speculators on the short side began to buy. Insiders for some time past have been buying. The result was a rally extending through the entire list; hardly a single notable decline was recorded, while many advances were substantial.

Opposition to the application of the Rapid Transit Board for a reduction of the amount of the contractor's bond of $14,000,000 has already manifested itself. The Justices of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court are petitioned to reduce the amount of this bond on the affidavits of President Orr and of Controller Coler.

In his last message to Congress President MCKINLEY asked for authority to "correspond with the Governments of the principal maritime powers, with a view of incorporating into the permanent law of nations the principle of the exemption of all private property at sea, not contraband of war, from capture or destruction by belligerent powers."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- The University of Pennsylvania football team was again scored on to-day, this time by the Wesleyan College eleven. Pennsylvania, however, won the game by a score of 17 to 6. Wesleyan's touch-down was made on a seventy-three-yard run by Wilcox, on a double pass, and was one of the longest sprints made on Franklin Field this year.
LONDON, Oct. 18. -- All messages to and from South Africa are subjected to scrutiny at Aden.

CHICAGO, Oct 18. -- The Anti-Imperial Conference closed to-day. Before adjourning a declaration of principles was promulgated. It denounces the "policy of imperialism" as hostile to liberty, as unconstitutional, and as tending toward militarism. The policy of the present National Administration is condemned and the immediate cessation of the Philippine war demanded.

It is not to be supposed that any American citizen is entirely satisfied with the position which we occupy, before the world and before ourselves, with reference to the Philippine Islands. If we were entirely at ease in our own minds we could bear with entire equanimity the observations of the Gentiles. But we are not.

Experience derived from the attempt to make old theory meet actual condition has not been without good result in the army, and in the Subsistence Department, which was found to be lamentably unable to meet war conditions, and which does not easily meet peace conditions, lessons have been learned that would have been of great value if Gen. EAGAN could have had the benefit of them earlier.

A special meeting of the Central Board of Education was held yesterday afternoon for the express purpose of considering the withholding of the Brooklyn teachers' pay for September, owing to alleged illegalities discovered by City Superintendent Maxwell and Auditor Cook in the manner in which the pay rolls were presented.

The nominees on what is known as the county fusion ticket were notified yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Lawyers' Club, 120 Broadway, of their nomination by the Republican county convention. All the nominees were present except Justice Barrett, who had been notified at his home the day before, and Judge James A. Blanchard, who was kept away by a sudden attack of illness.

With an agreement reached between the United States and Great Britain for a temporary and convenient boundary between American and British possessions in the far Northwest, the Alaskan boundary controversy is fortunately taken out of the hands of the Joint High Commission that separated in Washington because of the inability of the American and Canadian Commissioners to adjust that difficult question.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Secretary Hay had a conference to-day with Mr. Tower, the Charge of the British Embassy here, relative to the Alaskan modus vivendi. The Secretary had already given consideration to the last proposition of the British Government and was prepared to submit the answer from the United States, which in this case takes the form of another proposition.
The bookmakers at Morris Park were an angry lot yesterday as they left the track with badly flattened bank rolls, caused by the winning of five favorites.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- At the annual meeting of the American Missionary Association at this place to-day the Rev. Dr. W.H. Ward made a report on the school system of Puerto Rico and on the religious conditions prevailing there. He said, in part:

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- The Minister of the Colonies, M. Decrais, has received an official dispatch announcing that Capt. Voulet and Capt. Chanoine, of the outlawed French expedition in the Soudan, whose members recently massacred most of the members of the expedition, under Lieut.-Col. Klobb, sent to arrest those officers on charges of cruelty and insubordination, have been shot by their own men.

Ever since England (not as the result of any deep moral conviction on the part of either rulers or people as to the iniquity of slavery, but really through the temporary zeal of the first Reformed Parliament being skillfully taken advantage of by Buxton and his confreres,) paid 20,000,000 to secure the abolition of slavery in her dependencies, she has been accorded the premier place among the nations, as the great civilizing and Christianizing power.

The City Club met last night to receive the report of the second Committee on Conference that replaced the first committee, which had reported adversely on the renomination of Justice George C. Barrett. There was present a bare quorum of the club, and in fact the meeting was delayed until a sufficient number of the members could be got together to make the action taken official.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 18. -- President McKinley's special train arrived here at 5 o'clock this evening, and the Chief Executive delivered the last speech of his tour. The train was backed upon a side track, and the President and his Cabinet went on foot to a platform near by. Apparently everybody in town had crowded into the two streets facing the platform, and it was with great difficulty that the President could make himself heard.
The first open session of the National Carriage and Harness Dealers' Association was held at the Grand Central Palace yesterday.

-- Whenever the Sampson-Schley controversy shows signs of quieting down, the most vivacious of our neighbors takes pains to stir it all up again, and to ask for another decision from a public that made up its mind on the subject for good and all over a year ago. To do this gives our neighbor a lot of satisfaction, and most people view the operation with entire composure and full appreciation of its futility.
There was little evidence at the Sub-Treasury yesterday of a demand for the anticipated interest offered by the Government to relieve the money market. Only $18,000 was paid out on coupons.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Frederick D. Williamson was put through an examination in court to-day to ascertain what he knew about history, arithmetic, spelling, grammar, and bookkeeping. The cause was a suit brought by his father against C.E. McChesney for breach of contract.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 18. -- The police have organized to secure an advance in wages from $2.50 a day to $3 a day. If their propositions are not considered they will strike. The men have appointed committees to attend a general meeting of representatives from all the districts. A delegation will call on Director Brown with the following demands:

The Bank Clerks' Bowling League held a meeting at Reid's alleys, 200 Church Street, last evening, and arranged for the annual tournament that will begin at Reid's alleys next Monday. The following is the schedule of the first round of games:

To trim one's sail to catch the passing gale, seems as necessary in writing a letter to a public paper as in sailing a yacht. The writer, however, whether attacking one of Lord Salisbury's manifestos -- his notable Cardiff emanation, to wit -- or in attacking Archdeacon Denison's ritualism, face to face with him on the public platform, uses very little japan, electro plate, or varnish.

NILES, Ohio, Oct. 18. -- In this town President McKinley first saw the light of day. Thousands of his boyhood friends gathered at the railway station this afternoon to cheer him on his journey back to Washington.
HAMBURG, Oct. 18. -- The new German warship was launched here to-day in the presence of Emperor William. She was christened "Kaiser Karl der Grosse" by Dr. von Monckeberg, Burgomaster of Hamburg.

The third sale of the real estate holdings of the late Amos R. Eno, held by order of the executors in the Trinity Building Salesroom yesterday, realized $2,316,250. A crowd large enough to fill one end of the room in front of Auctioneer Meyer's stand was on hand, but to all appearances there was less interest than on either of the two previous offerings by the estate.

MANILA, Oct. 18. -- Ten former Spanish soldiers who were captured by the Filipinos and for a time acted as officers and members of a Filipino artillery regiment situated in the vicinity of Santa Rosa, in the Laguna de Bay district, determined to surrender the artillery to the Americans. The plot was discovered by the Filipinos, who killed seven of the conspirators, the other three making their escape to Manila.

The report that the Rev. Dr. Watson of Birkenhead, England, has refused to allow his name to be considered for the pulpit of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church seems to be unfounded. Mr. William Grivin, who is an elder of the church and a member of the Pulpit Committee, was seen yesterday and asked relative to the matter. He said:

MANILA, Oct. 18. -- Gen. Otis has received messages purporting to come from the insurgent General, Pio del Pilar, offering to sell his army out and to deliver Aguinaldo into the hands of the Americans. Although he is not satisfied that this offer is authentic, it is not intrinsically improbable. The policy of Gen. Otis is firmly set against buying any surrenders.
ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Gov. Roosevelt this afternoon addressed the New York State Assembly of Mothers and gave them some good advice. He said:

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- The Boston police, who have been informed of the suspicions that the woman murdered and dissected in New York was Camille Dupont of this city, say that the meagre description can be applied to the woman in question.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Walter S. Guibord, General Agent of the Washington Life Insurance Company, forty-five years old, and a brother of Mayor Guibord of Plattsburg, was found dead in his apartments to-day. Death was due to asphyxiation. A stop-cock of a gas burner was found turned partly on.

WARREN, Ohio, Oct. l8. -- Citizens of Trumbull County turned out in force this afternoon to welcome the Presidential party. Carriages carried the President and his Cabinet to a speakers' stand in front of the Court House, on three sides of which were massed thousands of spectators. In the front ranks were public school children. President McKinley was continuously cheered. He said:

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Frederick Prunier, aged thirty-five, was arrested to-night by Under Sheriff James A. Darragh of Dutchess County on a requisition from the Governor of Vermont. Prunier's home is in Burlington, Vt., where he has a wife and children. Some time ago his wife secured a divorce from him and was awarded $25 a week alimony. Prunier is now eighteen months behind on the alimony.

National colors, enthusiasm, and patriotic music were prevalent in the Catholic Club last night on the occasion of a banquet in honor of the Rev. W.H.I. Reaney, chaplain of the United States flagship Olympia. Many persons present had known Father Reaney when he was stationed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, prior to his assignment to the Asiatic Squadron.
LONDON, Oct 18. -- In the House of Commons to-day, the First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader, the Right Hon. Arthur J. Balfour, brought in the following message from the Queen:

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- In the House of Commons to-day, after the presentation of a message from the Queen signifying her intention of calling out further reserves, a motion by Mr. Balfour, appropriating the entire special session for Government business, was carried by 279 votes against 48.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Secretary of War has instructed the Quartermaster General to forward from San Francisco any Christmas boxes which may be delivered there prior to Nov. 20 for officers and soldiers in the Philippines. Such boxes should be consigned to Major O.F. Long, General Superintendent, Army Transport Service, San Francisco, Cal.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- Until May 1, 1900, the Carnegie-Oliver interests will have absolute control of the entire output of all the steamship yards of the American Shipbuilding Company. Contracts have been closed wherein the company agrees to build for the Carnegie interests alone, and two more big vessels were ordered today.
LONDON, Oct 20. -- The Ladysmith correspondent of The Daily Telegraph, under date of Oct. 19, says:

HAVANA, Oct. 19 -- Gen. Ludlow, Military Governor of Havana, has written to Gen. Brooke, regarding the appointment of many criminals and men under police surveillance as census enumerators in Havana. Gen. Ludlow said to-day, in an interview, that many of the men appointed had unsavory records, the list including perjurers, swindlers, blackmailers, and men leading immoral lives.

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- Mrs. Stephani, the mother of Alphonse J. Stephani, who is serving a life sentence in Sing Sing Prison for the murder of ex-Judge Clinton J. Reynolds in New York in 1891, made application to Gov. Roosevelt for her son's pardon, which application the Governor refused.

It is useless to refer to the social features attendant upon the cup races. There have been but few this week, and there were not many yachts down the Bay yesterday. Society yesterday was for a great measure at Baltusrol, where it was a delightful Indian Summer day, and absolutely perfect for golf.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- Senator Hanna, in a speech before the Fifth District Republican Club to-night, defined his position regarding the trusts. On this subject he said:
TROY, N.Y., Oct 19. -- At this afternoon's session of the New York Presbyterian Synod Bishop Potter's lead on the divorce question was followed by the adoption of the following resolution:

The communication in your esteemed journal of yesterday signed "Sufferer No. 2" is right to the point as far as barking dogs are concerned; I mean the worthless, homely, measly brand that make it impossible for people to sleep, owing to their almost incessant yelping at night. This is really the most aggravating and intolerable nuisance prevalent in New York City to-day.

GREENVILLE, Ohio, Oct 19. -- Mr. Bryan's first speech to-day was delivered here in the Court House Square early this morning. He spoke to a large crowd, which was not lacking in enthusiasm. He was introduced to his audience by John R. McLean, the Democratic candidate for Governor, as "the unchallenged leader of the Democratic masses."

Thomas F. Seymour, an English actor and stage manager of The Dairy Farm Company, known to the American stage as Thomas Stratton, was a defendant in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning on the complaint of Miss Ina Cloughan, an actress with whom he had been in partnership.

VAN WERT, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- Mr. Bryan arrived at 7 o'clock. The visiting party was escorted in carriages to the Court House through streets thronged with a cheering mass of humanity. Mr. Bryan in his address said:

THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day urges its Brooklyn readers to vote for ex-Judge Hiram R. Steele, the Republican candidate for District Attorney. It remarks that it approves of his appointment by Gov. Roosevelt "for the express and avowed purpose of securing the most thorough prosecution of certain Republicans who had been accused of corruption in various forms."

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- A provincial paper is authority for the statement that if the Shamrock fails to win the America's Cup, Mr. Lever, a millionaire soap manufacturer, intends to issue a challenge for a series of races in 1900.

Leopold Weil has sold for Edward Oppenheimer and Hirsh Brothers to E. Bloch the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, a plot 100.11 by 100, on which the buyer will erect a seven-story apartment house.
Henry G. Hilton, through his counsel, A. H. Hummel, filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court a notice of the contest of the will of his father, Henry Hilton.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 19. -The officials of the Colorado Midland Railway Company have discovered a case of ticket counterfeiting which promises to prove one of the most extensive ever discovered in this country. The ticket counterfeited is what is known as a skeleton round trip form. The ticket is so made that with the coupon attached it can be made out to any point in the country and return.

Your excellent protest in to-day's paper against the uncharitable accusations of Carl Schurz and Burritt Smith in their intemperate assaults on the President for his assumed Philippine policy reminds me of a document signed by those two gentlemen in 1898, in which, if I rightly interpret its meaning, (and I drew the substance of it,) they advised the President to do exactly what he has done.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 19. -- The managers of the Democratic State Committee claim to derive much satisfaction from tile showing made by the anti-imperialists' convention, which closed last night. They assert the anti-imperialism issue will gather round the Democratic standard all the gold Democrats led by men like Bourke Cockran, J. Sterling Morton, and Carl Schurz, who deserted the party in 1896 and besides, attract many Republican votes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- The following have been elected officers of the Intercollegiate Tennis Association: President -- R.D. Little, Princeton; Vice President -- Beale Wright, Harvard, and Secretary and Treasurer -- Howard A. Plummer, Yale.

The official announcement will almost beyond doubt be rnade in a short time that Pullman's Palace Car Company and the Wagner Palace Car Company have effected an agreement of consolidation. THE-NEW YORK TIMES is able to make this assertion on statements made yesterday by interests close enough to the Wagner Company to have the utterances considered authoritative that the deal has been actually agreed upon, even to details, and that it is a merger.

ORANGE RIVER, Oct. 18. -- The Boers suffered a reverse on Sunday at Spruitfontein, ten miles south of Kimberley. An armored train went out to bring in a train reported to have been captured by the Boers near the Spruitfontein siding. A party of Boers who were encamped near by lowered the railway signal and displayed a white flag, apparently with the idea of inducing the driver to proceed.

J. Will- ] iams of the' Transvaal out of $'-00.

Visiting America by invitation to explain the scope and object of the Parnell Monument movement, the Right Hon. Daniel Tallon, Lord Mayor of Dublin, and John E. Redmond, M.P., the Parnellite leader in the British House of Commons, were passengers on the White Star liner Majestic, which was docked yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The Cape Town correspondent of The Daily Mail, telegraphing at 10 o'clock Thursday night, says:
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The Pietermaritzburg correspondent of The Daily Mail, in a dispatch dated Thursday, says:

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- The Bryan party closed the first day of the Ohio tour in this city to-night before a large and interested audience in the Opera House. A street parade preceded the meeting. Ex-Congressman W.D. Hill presided. John J. Lentz, who was speaking when the Bryan party entered, gave way to John R. McLean, the candidate for Governor, who briefly addressed the meeting in introducing Mr. Bryan.

BOSTON, Oct. 19. -- The local police are looking for a fashionably dressed woman, who, it was at first believed, committed suicide last night by jumping from the East Boston ferryboat Revere, and who, while not revealing her identity, left a letter saying that, in case her body was found, Bishop Potter of New York would see that it was buried.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Gen. Otis to-day reported to the War Department the following casualties:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 19. -- In passing upon the case of George F. Harding and others against the American Glucose Company, in which the plaintiffs alleged that a giant pool had been formed to regulate unlawfully the price of glucose, the Supreme Court to-day held that the company was a trust and that its charter was a violation of the State law.

The accident by which Mr. ECKELS was injured the other day is an accident which every New Yorker whose occasion requires him to be much about the streets narrowly escapes almost every day of his life. Probably there is no city in which reckless driving, in the sense not so much of furious driving as of careless driving, is so common as in New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Up to the close of the State Department this afternoon nothing had been heard from London respecting the Alaskan modus vivendi.

The most entertaining game of last night's series of the Columbia tournament was the second, between the Orientals and Puritans. The result was not definitely known until the last ball was rolled, the Orientals winning by 10 pins.
LONDON, Oct. 19. -- At the first day's racing of the Sandown Park Autumn Meeting to-day a Selling Nursery Handicap was won by Disdainful. J. Reiff rode Westmoreland and finished second.
MANILA, Sept. 7. -- The questions whether or not there are opportunities for American young men in the Philippines and the advisability of going to seek them may be answered by both "Yes and no!"

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 19 -- The Peggy Stewart Chapter of the Daughters of the Revolution of Annapolis celebrated to-day the burning of the Peggy Stewart here on Oct. 19, 1774. The Annapolis public schools took part in the exercises.

ISLE DE LUZON, Sept. 7. -- The soldier's life in the Philippines must be of exciting interest to those far away, when we read of his brave deeds and hardships as seen on the field of action. After the din and excitement of the day's battle, the simplicity and regularity with which towns are occupied after the capture is absorbing in itself.

Apropos to the discussion about Brooklyn schools I would like to ask: Are married women lawfully eligible to the positions of school teachers in this borough? I know of two who teach, and one is so fortunate as to be able to retain her position, though at times unable to teach owing to approaching and actual maternity.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 19. -- Henry Ball, the son of a noted New York physician, fell from his horse while hunting with the Meadowbrook hounds to-day. The fifth fence proved a Waterloo for the young man and his mount was badly cut up. Mr. Ball sustained several contusions, but no bones were broken.

After the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Pulpit Committee has heard the Rev. Dr. N. Audley Ross, and permitted the congregation of that church to do so next Sunday morning and afternoon, it is said that body will take a vote on the question of recommending a pastor and will then call a congregational meeting.

Plans for perpetuating the Dewey arch are progressing rapidly, two interesting developments having been disclosed yesterday. Henry M. Flagler has reversed his decision not to serve on the Executive Committee appointed by Col. William C. Church, Chairman of the Citizens' Committee, and it is probable that a woman's committee will be formed.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 19. -- The fifth annual convention of the Pennsylvania Bankers' continue two days. The feature of the first session was the presence of Ellis H. Roberts, Treasurer of the United States, who, after routine matters had been Treasury and the Currency."

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- The recently published statistics of the insane in the public asylums of the City of London suggest to persons familiar with the statistics of the insane in New York and surrounding States that there is reason for congratulation that no such condition of affairs exists in American institutions as is made so painfully prominent in the report of the London County Council.

This is the story of fizzle No. 8: Shamrock and Columbia attempted to race again yesterday, and the contest was once more called off when the lightship was five miles away. It was exasperating. There are people who will not hesitate to say that it was maddening.

Activity somewhat slackened on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Until just before the close quotations were strong; then, however, concerted action began against values and many recessions followed. Something over 400,000 shares were traded in and a number of issues went each beyond the 20,000 mark.
Michael Clancy, whose hoarse cry has so often startled the spectators in the grand stand at the metropolitan race tracks, has at last found himself in a tight place.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 19. -- Nebraska's political situation becomes more animated hourly, and it begins to look as if next week the State will be the centre of the greatest political disturbance in its history. At that time W.J. Bryan will be touring the State in a special train, making five-minute speeches from the rear, while Gov. Roosevelt will be doing as much for the opposition.
