The State Commerce Commission held a session yesterday afternoon at the Produce Exchange and examined a number of witnesses regarding lighterage and differentials in connection with the commerce of this port.

The anti-Tammany fusion county ticket was ratified last night by a meeting held at Durland's Riding Academy, under the auspices of the Republican County Committee. Nearly 10,000 persons, it was estimated, were gathered in and about the hall, and in the volume and vigor of their enthusiasm there were no signs that this is an "off year" politically.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Floor and galleries were densely crowded to-day in the House of Commons in anticipation of a speech by the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, on the Government's policy in South Africa. United States Ambassador Choate and Henry White, Secretary of the United States Embassy, were in the Chamber during Mr. Chamberlain's speech.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- The annual reunions of the Second New York Cavalry, known as Harris's Light Cavalry, and the Eleventh New York Cavalry, known as Scott's Nine Hundred, were held here last night and to-day. Last night there was a smoker and camp fire given by Delancy Cole Camp, No. 78, S.O.V.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -The International Commercial Congress devoted its time to-day to a discussion of various means of encouraging trade witch Japan. Everett Fraser, Consul General to Korea, presided, and brief addresses were made by Minister Komura and Imperial Consul Uchida of Japan.
CELINA, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- William J. Bryan received a cordial reception here when he was introduced by John R. McLean as the man who would be nominated in 1900. Mr. Bryan said in part:

Paul Meurice, in his preface to the Hugo Memoirs, states that the volume has a double character -- historical and intimate; that the book is neither a continuous biography nor a record of events in logical order, but rather the haphazard setting down of striking incidents and occurrences in Victor Hugo's long life:
The arch of triumph prepared by the National Sculpture Society in hot haste, to meet the request of the committee having the reception of Admiral Dewey in charge, was a happy inspiration.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- The following statement was issued to-day by the Pullman's Palace Car Company:

The publication of Mr. Lewis Melville's life of Thackeray brings up the old question of the man's cynicism, which, possibly excusable years ago in Thackeray's own lifetime, in the light of our present knowledge would seem to be entirely unwarrantable. Thackeray's nature seems best expressed in the little vignette of the tired jester on the yellow paper covers of the first edition of his own "Ballads."

ROCKLAND LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- A mysterious and terrific explosion occurred at the works of the Rockland Lake Trap Rock Company while the regular noon blast was being set off, which killed four men almost instantly and fatally wounded four more.

Mr. Steevens, an observing and brilliant newspaper correspondent, favorably known as the author of "With Kitchener to Khartoum" and "The Land of the Dollar" has given his impressions of the recent court-martial in Rennes, together with a valuable appendix which contains the translations of many documents drawn from the official literature of the cause celebre.

BLOOMFIELD, Iowa, Oct. 20. -- Senator Allison, in a public address here this afternoon, declared that it was not the intention of the Republican Party to retire the greenbacks. He said the currency of this country was the best on the face of the globe.

Will the ever friendly, unbiased, and independent TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW permit a long howl to at last escape from the poor "cur dog" yclept "Department Book Store?" The "thoroughbreds" have pulled his ears, trod on his tall, and stoned him galore, but with his traditional good nature he has quietly continued to gnaw his own bone in his own corner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The annual report of the Chief of Engineers of the Army, Brig. Gen. John M. Wilson, made public to-day submits estimates for river and harbor works, already authorized by Congress, but not provided for by continuing contracts, amounting to $26,906,821. In addition he asks for $15,582,626 to carry on works already contracted for.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Oct. 20. -- William J. Bryan closed his day of speechmaking at this place to-night, after having discussed the income tax, silver, and the Philippines in several counties which gave him a majority in 1896.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 20. -- The crisis is virtually over Gen. Andrade, the President, accepted the conditions proposed by the insurgent commander, Gen. Cipriano Castro, among them being one that he will go abroad, the Presidency to devolve upon the Vice President.

Your editorial article of Oct. 14, "Autumn with the Poets," has strongly and strangely affected me. Out of your love for October, did you write it, or did I? How did you happen to use quotations from unknown poets, that long habit and use have made my exclusive property? Where did you find those exquisite lines -- are they "in an old Blackwood's"? -- that I thought no one knew but me.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Admiral Dewey's visit to the Columbia Theatre last night to see Francis Wilson as "Cyrano de Bergerac" is the talk of the town. This is the song which Mr. Wilson sang and which made such a hit:
Can you find for me some humorous verses that were written about Kipling, in which is this line: "When the Rudyards cease from Kipling?"

The Third Avenue cable, between the cable house, at Third Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street and the end of the route at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, will terminate its career about 3:30 o'clock to-morrow morning. The traffic on that stretch of road will be stopped for six or seven hours, and when it starts again, sub-trolley cars will have taken the place of the cable cars.

May a reader venture to plead the editor's cause with the irate correspondent who protests against the attention given to fiction, desiring to know if there be nobody in the country interested in biography, history, travels, and various sciences more or less abstruse?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The applications so far received at the Treasury for interest on bonds deposited by National banks to secure circulation and public deposits, under the Secretary's recent offer to anticipate interest due up to July 1, 1900, amount to $372,144 from which the Government received a rebate of $5,349.
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Messrs. Longman Co. have just published "The Map of Life Conduct and Character," by William Lecky.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 20. -- Miss Blanche Walsh, who lost her voice last night in the second act of "Gismonda," in which she was playing the title role at Nixon Zimmerman's Academy of Music, was much improved to-night, and successfully rendered "La Tosca."

Accompanying the report of the gross earnings of the Norfolk and Western for the second week of October, showing an Increase of $71,290 over last year, is a statement of the earnings of the road since July 1. This shows a total increase of $220,000 over the corresponding period last year.

ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- State Excise Commissioner Lyman has prepared a table showing by comparison the difference between the operation of the old excise law during its last year of service and of the new liquor tax law during the year ending April 30, 1899, the statistics being tabulated for each county.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- In the House of Commons to-day the First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader, Arthur J. Balfour, moved an address of thanks to her Majesty for the royal message calling out the militia.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Bishop Wigger goes to Europe next month, and it was thought possible he had been summoned to Rome. One of the leading priests of the diocese said to-day this was not the case. The Bishop, he said needed a rest, and he would seek it abroad. Father L.C.M. Carroll of Hoboken will accompany the Bishop. They will visit Rome and probably see the Pope.

It is somewhat surprising to find that such an assiduous "working journalist" as Mr. Horace White has been long indulging in the avocation of translating an ancient history of Rome, made up chiefly of an account of its many wars, out of a Greek original, but Mr. White has performed a valuable service to the scholarship of the day in presenting the little-known writings of Appian of Alexandria in an attractive English dress.

Your newspaper worthily begins the celebration of its SATURDAY REVIEW anniversary on the very first page. The account of "David Harum" in England claims the smiles of your readers; yea, even unto Oakland, where they lie in wait for the jester to slay him. Next comes that compendious, tempting, and serviceable list, which we have not yet read.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The dispatches received from South Africa leave no doubt that the Boers failed in their endeavor to execute a combined attack, and that the British have achieved a brilliant victory, but at the cost of a heavy list of killed and wounded.
Secretary W.F. Bernard of the National Convention of Mutual Life Underwriters has resigned to become Agency Superintendent of the Safety Fund Life Insurance Society of Syracuse.

Israel Zangwill, the author and playwright, who came to this country for the purpose of staging the dramatization of his book, "Children of the Ghetto," will take his departure for England on the Cunard liner Lucania to-day.
MADRID, Oct. 20. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 61.35. Gold was quoted at 25.82.
DURBAN, Oct. 20. -- It is officially announced that the Boers retired from Hatting Spruit this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- College men participated in the proceedings of the Commercial Congress to-day. "Commercial Education" was the general subject, and it was treated in admirable fashion by the speakers. Seth Low, President of Columbia University, presided, and Charles Eliot, Harvard's President, made one of the most interesting addresses of the day, saying in part:

In to-day's issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW a correspondent complains that he is satiated with novels, and inquires if any one ever reads a list of "ologies" that evidently delight his particular soul. Yes, some of us doubtless do read them, but the novel -- I mean the healthy story, that book that mirrors human nature -- appeals more strongly to the reading public.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- A Glencoe Camp correspondent, telegraphing yesterday, says:

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday directed the suspension for two years of Eliazer S. Mashbir, a lawyer. The charge was "deceit and malpractice in swearing to and submitting for taxation a false and fraudulent bill of costs, and in subsequently making and submitting two other false and fraudulent affidavits in connection with the same matter, after his attention had been called to the false statements contained in the said bill of costs."

The poles are not more widely sundered than are the two types pf historical novels: the one for the writing of which the author has "read up" the other written because the author's mind has reached the saturation point. The one is a manufacture, the other a precipitation. In the one we are introduced into the valley of dry bones; in the other they have been clothed with flesh and breathe and move before us.

I wish to express my gratitude to THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 30 for the list of historical novels and other books to be read with contemporary English history. I had already read to a young friend Strickland's "Stories from History" and some of Shakespeare's plays in connection with English history, and THE SATURDAY REVIEW list is just what I needed.
Gutwillig Brothers have resold the southwest corner of Hudson and Vestry Streets, a plot 33 by 100, to William C. Dewey, who will erect thereon a seven-story warehouse.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The London press, commenting on the defeat of the Shamrock, is almost a unit in saying the better boat won. The Daily News says:

The editorial article in your Issue of Sept. 23, "Where American Heraldry is Weak" and the comments upon it by readers of THE SATURDAY REVIEW, printed in your issue of Sept. 30, are interesting. As the editorial reads it would appear that you take the position that American heraldry is exclusively English in its origin.

Two churches two blocks distant from each other packed so full last night that many would-be worshippers were unable to gain admittance testified to the interest that is being aroused in the great revival movement in Brooklyn, begun on Wednesday last.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- The silver service for Admiral Dewey, which the Chicago Committee on Presentation has under consideration, and the selection of which is subject to approval by the General Municipal Committee on the Admiral's entertainment, is of French gray finish. Laurel and the acanthus, the former symbolic of victory, and the latter beloved by the Greeks, are the prevailing decorations.

George Milne, 894 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn: 'I have for sale or exchange the colored Herald, and also of The World, from the beginning of the issue of such supplements to within a few weeks, or, in all, over five years. They are fresh and clean, and have never been handled.'

" Signors of the Night," a new volume of short stories by Max Pemberton, will shortly be published by Dodd, Mead Co. The sub-title of the book is "The Story of Fra. Giovanni, the Soldier Monk of Venice, and of Others in the Silent City."

A Great Dane dog terrorized the passengers on a Grand Street ferryboat last evening while the boat was making a trip from New York to Williamsburg, and was finally killed by three policemen, who fired thirteen shots into the animal's body.

It is said that only the most magnanimous natures can receive gracefully favors that it is unable to return in kind. For months the burden of obligation has been increasing, until to-day I venture to send a note of thanks and to express appreciation of the never-falling excellence of the intellectual feast your SATURDAY REVIEW spreads for the delectation of your many readers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Herman Vogel of Bound Brook shot his wife and her mother on Albany Street this morning and then turned the revolver upon himself, putting an end to his life. The women will both recover.

The recent unveiling of the bust of Edgar Allan Poe at the University of Virginia has awakened many memories of the poet and his contemporaries. With the exception of Emerson and Whitman our country has as yet produced no poet with so distinctive and unique a personality as the author of "The Raven," "The Belles," "Ullalume," and "The Haunted Palace."

William M. Chase and the other American memoers of this year's jury of the annual exhibition at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburg have returned, having completed their work. The announcement of the prizes, award will be made on the eve of the opening of the exhibition on Nov. 1. Mr. Chase is of the opinion that the awards will give general satisfaction, and enthusiastic as to the merits of this years display.

The very interesting article "Where American Heraldry Is Weak" in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 23 and the correspondence it has elicited prompt me to ask information concerning the use of the "bar sinister."' Is not the bar when impressed from right to left indicative of irregularity in lineage or of some stain upon the escutcheon?

Manhattan, the Bronx, and Brooklyn pastors, with Presbyterian, Congregational, and Baptist pastors leading, are working together in the attempt to awaken religious interest in this city and decrease the number of non-churchgoers. A retreat for Presbyterian ministers will take place at Riverdale on Nov. 6, 7, and 8, and union meetings will be held in Presbyterian churches in different parts of the city, to begin about Nov. 15.

Every Saturday I manage to spare the time to read your charming paper, and all the discussions which arise interest me very much. A letter which attracted my particular attention was the one received from a member of the high school at Evanston, Ill. The writer claimed, I believe, that your list of books prepared for girls of eighteen was composed of works which most well-educated girls of that age have read and appreciated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Mr. Tower, the British Charge here, called at the State Department to-day and handed to Secretary Hay a note formally accepting for his Government the proposition for the temporary adjustment of the Alaskan boundary line proposed by Secretary Hay in his note of yesterday.

William Eugene Dougherty, who for many years was a labor reporter on evening newspapers, died suddenly yesterday afternoon in the hallway of 33 Park Row. He was taken ill in the street soon after 4 o'clock and was carried into the hallway, while a messenger hurried to the Astor House for a physician. An ambulance was summoned from, Hudson Street Hospital, but before Surgeon McWhorter arrived with it, Mr. Dougherty was dead.

We need not wonder at the zeal with which the Briton pursues the America's Cup. It is the only aquatic trophy which is not already in his possession. When GEORGE STEERS built the America and an enterprising "syndicate," as we should say now, took her into British waters to "hunt mugs," we were already, or still, a maritime nation to be reckoned with.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20. -- The Yale football Squad went through a long season of practice under the direction of ten Coachers this afternoon in the final try-out for the game with Wisconsin to-morrow.

LONDON, Oct, 20. -- At to-day's racing at Sandown Park the Temple Handicap was won by Filassier. "Skeets" Martin finished second on Suppliant. Remember Me was third, "Tod" Sloan rode Myakka, but was unplaced. Escurial, ridden by Martin, won the Park Selling Plate. The betting was 7 to 2 against Escurial.

The article on "Autumn With the Poets" in last week's issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW revived in memory some verses I had memorized, but since have forgotten. They are said to have been written on the window shade of a summer boarding house on Long Island. The last two stanzas containing allusions to Huxley and Darwin I cannot recall, but they much resemble Bryant in flow and sentiment.
The third day of the registration period showed an appreciable falling off in the number of persons registered in New York County, while the contrary was true in Kings County.

Two weeks from next Tuesday elections will be held in eleven States, in Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Nebraska, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Virginia. They will be for State officers, judicial officers, members of one or both branches of the Legislature.

Mr. Cyrus Coolridge, in your REVIEW of Sept. 23, quotes from Charles Burr Todd's "Life of Barlow" a misleading, statement, namely, that Paine's "qualification to be a member of the [French] Convention required an oath of fidelity to that country." No oath of any kind was taken; no affirmation or declaration or form was required for membership in an assembly whose function was to frame a Constitution where none existed.
On Dec. 7, 1898, the President sent to the Senate the following nominations, "for eminent and conspicuous conduct in battle ": Commodore...

Sterling exchange rates yielded yesterday, coincident with cable dispatches announcing that the Bank of England had reduced its bid price for coin. This intelligence came to Wall Street as something of a surprise, for in speculative Circles there has been much insistence that New York would have to come to the front, perforce, to help out British money exigencies because of Boer war apprehensions and drafts.
LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The War Office has received the following official dispatch from Ladysmith, filed at 3:30 this afternoon:
GLENCOE CAMP, Oct. 20. -- Afternoon. -- In a battle to-day the Boers met a reverse which may possibly, for a time at any rate, check all aggressive action.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Mafeking correspondent of The Daily Mail, writing on Oct. 14, says:

In spite of the fact that Albert Crosby spends his Summers in a luxurious home on Cape Cod, Mass., and the rest of the year in New York hotels and in travel abroad, his creditors are unable to collect two judgments against him which amount to $28,155.41. The judgments are in favor of the estate of George M. Jeroloman of Indiana.

The Right Hon. Daniel Tallon, Lord Mayor of Dublin, and John E. Redmond, M.P., escorted by Councilman Stewart ,M. Brice, paid a visit to Mayor Van Wyck yesterday afternoon. The party which accompanied the Lord Mayor included William Temple Emmet, Justice Wauhope Lynn, Michael Kennedy, P.J. Cody, William McLaughlin, David J. Naughton, H.G. Bannon, Justice James A. O'Gorman, Edward Flaherty, John E, Fitzgerald, W.H. Walker and William J. O'Brien.
The content thickens; on, ye brave, Who rush to glory or the grave.
LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The War Office announces that in the fighting yesterday between Glencoe and Dundee, in Natal, 31 non-commissioned officers and men were killed and 151 wounded.

The registration books for the coming election were closed at 10 o'clock last night. Throughout the entire city the falling off in the number of names added to the lists was general, and this fact, taken in conjunction with the comparatively small registration of the previous three days of the period, tended to make the total for the four days considerably smaller than it was for the years 1896, 1897, and 1898.

Not more than 150 National Guardsmen braved the foretaste of Winter at supplementary rifle practice on the Creedmoor range yesterday. A strong "fish-tail" wind, sweeping up the ranges all day long, added to the disadvantages of the benumbed riflemen, and only two out of the seventy-five or more aspirants succeeded in qualifying in the difficult expert class.

-- A young American woman on her way home from service in the hospitals in and near Manila was interviewed while at Colombo by a representative of The Ceylon Standard, and as a result that paper prints about as interesting an article on military conditions in the Philippines as we have seen anywhere.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 21. -- For several years past the students of Wesleyan University have been careless about the conditions under which the tuition scholarships, amounting to over $14,000, have been awarded. One of them is that the applicant shall be a total abstainer from all intoxicating liquors, but this has been passed over as not meaning anything by some of the students.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- The annual meeting of the Pullman Car Company Directors this week calls attention to the fact that Several local commercial organizations contemplate a memorial to Congress recommending that the jurisdiction of the Inter-State Commerce Commission be extended so as to cover sleeping-car companies as well as the railways.

Brooklyn won the final game of the exhibition series with Philadelphia yesterday. Score: Philadelphia -- 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 1, 3 -- 5 -- 10 -- 2; Brooklyn -- 0, 1, 3, 4, 0, 2. . . -- 10 -- 16 -- 2. Earned runs -- Brooklyn, 6. Three-base hits -- Pratt, Kelly, Jennings. Two-base hits -- Lajoie, Jennings, Yeager, Casey. First base on errors -- Philadelphia, 2.
In the resolutions adopted by the "American League" at Chicago last week were the following portentous sentences:

ST, LOUIS, Oct. 21. -- Jefferson Barracks, the United States army post just south of this city, is the National mule headquarters for the army. Since the beginning of the war with Spain more than 2,500 mules, mostly native Missourians, have been mobilized there and trained for pack service.

The Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling League began its annual tournament at Reid's alleys, 200 Church Street, yesterday. Six games were rolled, Colgate Co. and Dodge . Olcott each winning two games. The tournament will be continued every Saturday afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Minister Davis of the Canadian Cabinet arrived here a few days ago and had a conference with Lord Salisbury and another with Ambassador Choate. He had been called here to give information about the Alaskan boundary.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Oct. 21. -- Col. William Jennings Bryan to-night closed the most remarkable week in his career of campaigning. He was scheduled for six speeches daily, the first three days of the week in Kentucky and for the same number the last three days, in Ohio. He has been continuously on a special train since last Monday morning, and has made many more than the thirty-six speeches on the schedule.

ANDERSON, S.C., Oct. 21. -- Conditions much like slavery have been brought about among the negroes in this State by the fine-alternative system of punishing minor crimes, and the Grand Jury of this (Anderson) County, in its presentment, just made, directs attention to them.

May I be allowed the courtesy of your columns to express my regret that a journal so justly valued as an authority on the drama as THE NEW YORK TIMES should have been deceived into discrediting, even by inference, the originality of my new play on the subject of Marie Antoinette, now being presented by Mme. Modjeska.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- War talk reigns supreme everywhere in England. London is teeming with people notable socially, but what cares London for society when troops are piling into transports and when everybody, from her Majesty down, is saying "Good-bye," "God bless you," and "Good luck to you"? The newsboys are fairly reveling in their "'Orrible Slaughters," and the ordinarily pacific stock brokers talk incessantly of strategic and military tactics.

Would it be an audacious suggestion that the National motto of the United States, instead of "E Pluribus Unum," should be "Steady by Jerks"? The latter might not describe so well the principle by which we like to think that we are guided, but it would certainly fit the National habit, especially in dealing with public affairs.

FLUSHING, Oct. 21. -- The Flushing High School team, which seeks admission to the Long Island Interscholastic League, played a game of football this afternoon at Murray Hill with the academic team from St. Francis Xavier's College.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- London gave the Guards a grand farewell to-day on their departure for Southampton, where they embarked for the Cape. Three battalions, the First Scots, the Second Coldstreams, and the Third Grenadiers, left. The Scots entrained at Waterloo Station, South London at 7 o'clock this morning.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- Baron Speck von Sternberg, the German member of the Samoan Commission, has recovered from his illness, due to the climate of Apia, though he is still weak. He lunched with the Emperor on Tuesday. Baron von Eckardstein of the London Embassy was also present. His Majesty thoroughly informed himself on the state of the Samoan question.

Evangelist Dwight L. Moody, at a special service of prayer held yesterday afternoon in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, announced his belief that the whole country is on the eve of a great religious awakening. This was Mr. Moody's second service in the union revival series which the Brooklyn pastors have inaugurated.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Major Baden-Powell, brother of Col. Baden-Powell, the British commander at Mafeking, has caused a revival of the discussion regarding flying machines by drawing attention to the importance of the one now being constructed in Germany by Count von Zeppleins. He describes it as resembling the slender skeleton of a huge battleship made of aluminium, containing a large number of balloons.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Hamilton College this afternoon at Genesee Park defeated New York University by a score of 35 to 0. New York did not have possession of the ball for five minutes of the game. Their bad showing was due to the meeting with Columbia on Wednesday, which left the team weakened and unable to either withstand the rush of Hamilton or advance the ball.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Autumn at Tuxedo Park is the most beautiful season of the year. The delightful weather of the past week has increased the number of guests at the club and cottages. The club and annexes have been filled during the week, and the rooms have all been engaged for the Autumn ball, which takes place at the club, Oct. 27.

WEST POINT, Oct. 21. -- The West point Cadet football team met their third defeat of the season here this afternoon, Princetons defeating them by a score of 23 to 0. The game began at 3:15, Princeton winning the toss. A very strong wind was blowing straight down the field and Princeton took the north end.

One of the mild estimates of political anti-expansionists is that the United States Government's Philippine policy is full of dreadful threats for this country financially. The United States cannot proceed to increase National territory without risks unprecedented, they insist; and even commercial and financial embarrassments are excitedly forecast.

Dear! dear! and here is Mrs. Jennie June Croly, original member and ex-President of Sorosis, sharer of that mother of women's club's early persecutions, founder and President of the New York Woman's Press Club, writer and compiler of the history of woman's clubs in America, going to England to join the Astors and Bradley Martins. If all her wealth and erudition goes abroad whatever is New York going to do.

F. Tennyson Neely, publisher of 114 Fifth Avenue, yesterday filed a petition in bankruptcy in the Clerk's office of the United States District Court. The liabilities are placed at $359,531.76. Of this amount, $1,136.50 is due to twenty-one employes for wages in sums ranging from $4 to $300.

BRISTOL, R.I., Oct. 21. -- Enthusiasm over the victory of Columbia over Shamrock took definite shape to-night in a celebration in which a procession and brass band, four large bonfires, a brilliant pyrotechnical display, red fire, and many fine private expressions of patriotism figured prominently. The paraders visited the homes of J.B. and Nat Herreshoff and gave them rounds of cheers.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Marquis of Dufferin and Ava, Commodore of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club, replying to a request for an expression of opinion regarding the contest for the America's Cup, telegraphed to-day:

"I'll take that bag myself," said a guest to a hallboy at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, as the latter extended a hand for his satchel. "Just been touched for $3,500," continued the speaker, who was none other than Gen. Julian S. Carr of Durham, N.C.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21. -- The engagement of Miss Laura Jenkins and Mr. Raal Paar has seemingly moved the pen of the sensational news gatherer, and many surprising items have been given to the public regarding it. Among other things, it is pleasantly stated that Miss Jenkins is nine years older than her fiance, but access to the family Bible proves that the nine years dwindle down to two or, possibly, three.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 21. -- Since last Sunday several things have occurred that may or may not have a direct effect upon the fortunes of one or the other of the two contesting parties for supremacy.

The German theatre managers of the city are varied, as are managers of the other theatres, by budding geniuses who are willing to favor them with their services. Some of the geniuses have already budded and blossomed and are willing to act for acting's sake, but there are not many of either class who have the chance.

Constant Coquelin, who will make a tour of this country in 1900-1, in company with Sarah Bernhardt, has a great number of new plays. Among them are "Le Grand Juge." by Emile Moreau, in which he will impersonate the infamous Jeffries: "Jean Bart." by Haraucourt, a dramatization of "Les Miserables," in which he will act Jean Valjean; "Falstaff," by Paul Delair, and Vacquerie's "Tragaldabas."

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The English may describe themselves as reticent and in a manner coldblooded; they laughed at the enthusiasm of the Americans when the latter declared war against Spain. They called it a tinpot war, and hoped that America would win because Continental Europe hoped she would not, for Continental Europe and Great Britain are always on different sides.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 21. -- Two weeks before the Pennsylvania game finds Harvard men sanguine of victory over both their big football rivals, Pennsylvania and Yale. The past week has witnessed great improvement in the eleven. The men play with a great deal more snap and vigor, there is less off-side playing, and considerably less fumbling.

Golf activity still continues with unabated zeal, and there is likely to be little diminution in the play on the links before the close of Thanksgiving week. The completion of the women's championship a week ago marked the end of those big events held under the auspices of the United States Golf Association, but another championship of equal interest to a large circle will be the feature of the coming week.
BUFFALO, Oct. 21. -- The total registration in this city is 63,660, a decrease of 354 compared with last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- President John K. Cowen of the Baltimore and Ohio Railway was before the Industrial Commission to-day. In the course of his testimony he expressed himself as opposed to State laws restricting the running of railway trains on Sunday. "I don't think Sunday laws amount to anything or benefit anybody," he said.
LONDON, Oct. 22. -- At 2 o'clock this (Sunday) morning the War Office posted the following from Gen. Sir Archibald Hunter.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21. -- Yale defeated Wisconsin this afternoon by a score of 6 to 0, but the Yale men required nearly all of the fifty minutes of play to score the single touch-down and goal which constituted her victory over the young men from the West.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- A dispatch from Austin, Texas, says that P.O. Saunders, a prominent American capitalist living in the City of Mexico, is expected here in a day or two to consult with ex-Gov. Hogg regarding the immediate inauguration of work on the Inter-Continental Railway, which is better known as the Pan-American Road.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The German press is just as unanimously anti-British in the Transvaal war as it was anti-American in the war between the United States and Spain. Even the Liberal papers, although politically and commercially they have all along sought and found an ideal in Great Britain, now strongly disapprove her procedure in varied but never complimentary utterances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Eugene Easton of Kansas City, Mo., a newspaper man, has been captured by the Boer forces in South Africa, and the State Department is now in negotiation with the Transvaal authorities looking to his release. Word of his capture came this afternoon from Easton's father, the Rev. Dr. J.A. Easton of Tippecanoe City, Ohio, who telegraphed Assistant Secretary of the Interior Davis as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Commemoration exercises of the one hundred and fifty-third anniversary of the founding of Princeton University were held in Alexander Hall to-day. The Faculty and Trustees had assembled in the Chancellor Greene Library and then formed a procession and marched to Alexander Hall, headed by President Patton and Mr. Whitelaw Reid.

Of course Sir THOMAS LIPTON will not sail any more races on this side of the water with the Shamrock. Hence the pardonable curiosity of yachting experts to know Whether Mr. FIFE has attained his purpose of producing a boat that would beat the Defender will not be gratified.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 21. -- The suicide of Herman Vogel of Bound Brook, who killed himself in this city yesterday, after trying to murder his wife and her mother, has resulted in another woman coming forward and claiming his property. The new claimant is Mrs. Jane Vogpohl of Port Chester, N.Y. Both women claim the body and have determined to fight for possession of it.

The co-operative arrangements recently made between the League of American Wheelmen and the Cyclist Touring Club of England are about to be supplemented by a similar agreement between the League of American Wheelmen and the Deutscher Radfahrer Bund, the national cycling organization of Germany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The President has appointed Frank M. Foote Receiver of the Land Office at Evanston, Wyoming. Mr. Foote was Major of the First Wyoming Battalion in the Philippine campaign.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Oct. 19. -- Mount Lebanon Baptist Church of this (Greenville) county is threatened with a split over the Sloan-Watson shooting affair.

When Intrusive went past the judges an easy winner in the sixth race at Morris Park yesterday afternoon, the racing of 1899 on the metropolitan tracks was practically at an end. What racing there will be in the vicinity for the balance of the season, which ends on Election Day, will be at Aqueduct, and although the contests there are usually interesting, there will be very few fixtures with big purses.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Judge and Mrs. Gray of New York have arrived at Curtis's Hotel. The only house closed this week was that of Mr. Harold Godwin, who with his family has returned to New York. Mr. and Mrs. Morris K. Jesup are now at Belvoir Terrace and will remain here until November. The report which in some way got abroad that Mr. Jesup was ill is unfounded.

LINCOLN, Neb. 21. -- The Fusionists have made William Jennings Bryan the issue in the Nebraska campaign. That issue the Republicans have met on the stump, and other issues have taken a secondary position.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21. -- As the campaign for votes nears its close, there are increasing signs of a disposition on the part of the wavering to line up with the parties with which they have heretofore affiliated. This is obviously due to the usual attempts of the party whips, who appeal in the most natural way for the votes that have been counted on in the ante-election poll books.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Lafayette's team to-day scored six points on the University of Pennsylvania team and prevented the Pennsylvanians from getting any nearer than nine yards to the Lafayette goal line. Lafayette's six points were made within fifteen seconds after the game had started.

Controller COLER has made virtually the same suggestion about the private libraries, or, rather, the libraries under private direction and yet receiving support from the municipality, that he made about charities in a similar situation. His report on the latter subject was received with sympathy and concurrence on the part of everybody who was in a condition to judge and who had no "adverse interest."

The real name of Signor Foil, the basso, whose death in London was announced yesterday, was Allan James Foley. He was born in Cahir, Tipperary, Ireland, but came to the United States with his parents when a child. The family settled in Hartford, Conn., the elder Foley gaining his livelihood as a laborer.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to:

It is generally conceded that the future of the Filipinos must be determined by the will of the people of the United States. Rightfully or wrongfully, the close of the war with Spain left the Government of the United States in possession of the capital city of the chief island, and entitled to all the rights of sovereignty transferred by the treaty with the defeated nation.

Rarely has Wall Street had a week of more interest than that just closed. Much endeavor has been used to induce apprehension and coerce liquidation. Adroit manipulators have been engaged in the scarecrow business. Yet small results have followed all their industry. Final quotations show for the week few declines, many advances.

The janitor of the Cooper Union Building, at the junction of Third and Fourth Avenues, and between Seventh and Eighth Streets, has thought for years that he had been left out in the readjustment of the election districts in this city, and has been feeling that he had been forsaken and deserted by both parties, and that his rights as a free citizen possessed of the franchise were in serious jeopardy.

The American liner New York, which reached this port late yesterday afternoon, brought back to this country a number of representatives of the theatrical and musical profession who have been abroad since the close of last season.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- Bruno von Kayser, a Government official; Herr von Kroecher, son of Gen. von Kroecher, commander of an army corps and an intimate adviser of Emperor William, and Paul von Schachtmeyer, three of the defendants in the trial which began in this city Oct. 3 of persons charged with gambling at the Club der Harmlosen, have been acquitted.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- The trial of members of the Harmless Club has been a judicial fiasco. Herr von Manteuffel, the Criminal Commissary, who "worked up" the case, has been severely criticised by the newspapers, and would be dismissed from his post were not his superiors aware that in placing the "Harmless" players in cells at Moabit he acted on the wishes of the Emperor himself.

"People are going to see, or they are seeing, a change in the style of dancing," says M.S. Frothingham, who is an authority on the subject. "Everything now points to a more stately method than we have been having, less romping, and more graceful dancing. The dancing teachers have been working for this for some time, but it is not altogether owing to their work that the change has come.

PARIS, Oct. 13. -- Paris has determined that bullfights shall not be introduced within the precincts of the Ville Lumiere. The cable account which appeared last week in THE NEW YORK TIMES showed that failure, absolute and complete, had attended the first effort of the aficionados to introduce this essentially southern sport into the north of France.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- The Royal Canadian Yacht Club has decided to challenge the Chicago Yacht Club for the Canada Cup, which was won by the Chicago yacht Genesee last August at Toronto.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- Emperor William's trip to Hamburg Wednesday showed how popular he is there. During his drive in the evening through the illuminated streets he was enthusiastically greeted by enormous crowds of people. His speech at the dinner is regarded as being one of his finest and most powerful efforts, and the impression it made can hardly be overestimated.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 21. -- The Peavey Grain Company has erected in Minneapolis some high circular tanks of concrete, which are to be tested within a few days, and on the results of these tests hinges the question of the erection in this city of a mammoth elevator of a style of construction entirely novel to this country, though in use in a small way along the lower Danube.

Judge Hascall, in the City Court, yesterday heard testimony in supplementary proceedings concerning the financial condition of Mrs. Carolyn A. Rogers. The examination was conducted by counsel for the creditors, J.P. McHugh Co.

NEW LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The fast steam yacht Kanawha, owned by John P. Duncan of New York, has arrived here from the cup races and will lay up for the Winter. Her owner and Captain are well satisfied with the speedy boat's performance in beating the flier of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, the Monmouth, as well as the queen of the Sound, the Richard Peck.

The English morning coat which is worn so much abroad is gradually making its appearance here. The English gentleman wears this coat to business in the forenoon just as we wear a short "sack" or a Cambridge suit, but New Yorkers find it a convenient dress for morning occasions when something more dressy than the ordinary street attire is desirable.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 21. -- Gov. Asa S. Bushnell was in the city all day and night, but he did not attend the big Republican meeting in Music Hall. Perhaps the chief reason was that he was not invited. Chairman Hinnica was asked if the Governor would attend the meeting.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Canadian High-Commissioner, Lord Strathcona and Mount Royal, is a candidate for the Lord Rector-ship of the University of Aberdeen, vacated by the Marquis of Huntly. Candidacy in his case is tantamount to an election.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The earliest dispatches regarding yesterday's battle conveyed the impression that the whole affair was over in a couple of hours, the British artillery silencing the Boer guns and infantry and then simply charging right over the hill. According to the latest advices, however, the battle lasted eight hours, and nearly seven hours elapsed before the last Boer gun was put out of action.

An unusual tribute was paid Mrs. G.H. Gilbert last night on the stage of the Lyceum Theatre, when a silver service was presented to her in the name of forty-nine of her friends and admirers "in front of the footlights."

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Harry Elkes tried to lower the New Jersey State records to-day at the Vailsburg bicycle track for one, two, three, four, and five miles, but failed. Elkes had a bad fall at Berkeley Oval Thursday, which probably accounts for his poor time.

Sir Thomas Lipton spent yesterday on board his steam yacht Erin. During the greater portion of the morning he was busy with his secretaries, but in the afternoon he took a rest. He saw few visitors, although hundreds of small boats floated around the big yacht. Some of the most venturesome went up to the gangway, and sent cards on board.

Electric cars will be running on the Third Avenue surface line this morning from Sixty-fifth Street to Harlem Bridge. The last cable car on this section finished its journey at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, but contrary to expectations, passenger service had not been resumed at 3 o'clock this morning. It was said, however, that the line would be ready in an hour.

The Presidents of two of the large universities spoke before the Export Congress in Philadelphia the other day on what sort of education the colleges could give that would fit young men for commerce. President ELIOT of Harvard went into a discussion of the subject with his usual clearness and force, and President Low of Columbia, while not speaking so definitely, advocated the general idea of a higher commercial education.

There was another lively discussion in the Central Federated Union yesterday between the Tammany men on one side and the Independent Labor Party men and their Republican allies on the other. The allies are in the majority and have repeatedly downed the Tammanyites, and yesterday some of them tried to stifle the Tammanyites by moving the suspension of political discussion during the remainder of the campaign.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 22. -Beginning Tuesday morning W. J. Bryan will start on more elaborate county-by county and town-to-town canvass than he ever before has made in Nebraska, not excepting the year he ran for President.

William Altone, forty-two years old, of 2,484 Second Avenue, was struck and instantly killed by a northbound electric car on the Second Avenue line at 7 o'clock last evening. The accident occurred between One Hundred and Twenty-seventh and One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Streets. So tightly was the body wedged under the car that the trucks had to be lifted off the track before it could be removed.

W.A. JOHNSON, Middletown, Conn. -- James Bryce, M.P., in his "Impressions of South Africa," thus defines the difference between the London Convention of 1884 and other conventions entered into by the Transvaal and the British Government since 1881:

The residents of West Eighty-ninth Street, on the block between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, are still talking about the remarkable rescue of a boy from a position of extreme peril last Friday afternoon. As the incident was not reported to the police, it escaped mention in the newspapers of the following day.

The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Briggs occupied the pulpit of the Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street, last evening and preached his first sermon since his ordination as a clergyman of the Protestant Episcopal Church. The church was filled, and among the congregation were many of Dr. Briggs's personal friends.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Henry Haefield, who played football on the High School team and resides at Cornwall, is in the hospital here suffering from concussion of the brain as the result of injuries received while playing yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -The second British victory, that at Elandslaagte, in which the British losses, though heavy, were not out of proportion to its importance, may be regarded as having completely demoralized the well-laid, but ineffectively executed, plans of the Boers. In the opinion of military critics, it will tend to bring the war to a speedy conclusion.

The five-story iron-front building at 390 Broadway, and its contents, the property of several firms, were destroyed by fire this morning. The fire was discovered in the basement of the building at 12:30 A.M. An alarm was turned in, and a second, third, and fourth alarm followed.

An attempt (made by your Anglo-Catholic correspondent in to-day's issue) to answer my letter of the 16th inst. I regret to say is a failure. If Anglo-Catholic will tell us whether the Church of England is a compromise of Rome, or whether Rome is but a mere compromise of the Church of England, he will assist me to obtain what I am seeking -- knowledge.

Will you allow me a few lines in answer to the letter entitled "England's Duplicity,'' written by Benjamin Macmahon, in to-day's TIMES? The writer attacks not only England's policy, but all who believe that her victories, or the victories of our own country, have been secured through the guiding hand of God, who shapes the destiny of nations.

A QUARREL ARISING BETWEEN GREAT BRITAIN AND BELGIUM. -- The intention of Lord Kitchener to move some Anglo-Egyptian troops westward into the Bahr-el-Ghazal country has been forestalled by the authorities of the Congo Free State taking possession of their abandoned posts in that portion of the Nile Basin.

Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee professes absolute confidence in the outlook for his party in the coming election. He gave out the following statement last night, after reviewing reports from the various County Committees throughout the State:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- President Nick Young to-day gave out the following official averages of players of the National Baseball League who took part in fifteen or more games in the past season:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- From a New England visitor to this city, a gentleman greatly interested in and well informed about the course of events in Turkey prior to and since Minister Straus succeeded Minister Angel, some information, concerning which the State Department manifests a reluctance to talk, is obtained concerning American interests in the Ottoman Empire.

Arthur Eames of 140 Lexington Avenue, Jersey City, was passing through Communipaw Avenue, near the Hackensack River, yesterday, when he saw a vacant house a short distance from the road. The door stood open, and he walked over to examine the place. After inspecting the outside, he entered, and in the first room on the ground floor stumbled over the body of a man.

At the beginning of the war with Spain our coast defenses were such only in name. There was a plan, some emplacements, some guns. The plan was adopted during the first Administration of President CLEVELAND, the Engineer Department constructed some of the emplacements called for, and the Ordnance Department turned out many modern guns of large calibre and high power.

Crowds so great that it was impossible to accommodate hundreds who wanted to hear him flocked to the Central Presbyterian Church in the morning and to the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in the evening yesterday to see and listen to Evangelist Dwight L. Moody, who is continuing the revival services inaugurated in Brooklyn last Wednesday by the Rev. Dr. G. Campbell Morgan of London.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- Last week ended with us in a cheerful mood. The crushing defeat of the Boers inspires a hope that the war may soon be over, and the disposition to buy stocks is consequently much stimulated. So far, however, the public buys only in fits and starts, and I see no indication of reviving interest in your securities.

While administering medicine to her patient yesterday afternoon Mrs. J.M. Kennedy, twenty-five years old, a trained nurse attached to the staff of St. Mark's Hospital, 177 Second Avenue, was attacked by heart disease, and fell across the bed dead. The tragic incident is fraught with grave results to the patient, Mrs. Herman Stielberg, and the shock so affected her that her life is now despaired of.
Baltimore City has an Ancient and Honorable Mechanical Company. It celebrated a few nights ago by a festival and banquet the one hundred and thirty-sixth anniversary of its organization.

ATCHISON, Kan., Oct. 22. -- Two robbers last night shot and killed one man and wounded another in a store at Doniphan, which they later robbed, and to-day ambushed and killed a policeman and wounded another man, both members of a posse pursuing them. To-night the robbers are surrounded six miles north of Atchison, and an attempt to arrest them will be made at daylight.

LADYSMITH, Oct. 22. -- Realizing that the first attack on Glencoe was part of a general combined attack by three columns, and that the situation was still serious so long as the Boers held the railway at Elandslaagte, severing communication between Ladysmith and Dundee, Gen. White on Friday resolved to give battle with a view of recapturing Elandslaagte.

Wall Street's professional traders are no longer on one side, and the result of this may be a broader market than recently has ruled. The fact that a long list of evil prophecies have failed of consummation may also have effect. Certainly there is improvement in the situation in a variety of ways. Money market conditions notably are better. Public sentiment no longer reflects anything like nervousness.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, pastor of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, preached yesterday morning on "The Drama of Man's Soul: a Study of Life's Epochs and Teachers." He used the life of Jacob to illustrate his theme.
The chief interest in the election in this city attaches to the candidacy of ex-Justice DALY for the Supreme Court.

The interesting address delivered at Princeton University by Mr. WHITELAW REID on Saturday, on the occasion of the commemoration of the one hundred and fifty-third anniversary of the founding of the university, is impressive as coming from a source regarded as not entirely in sympathy with the Administration at Washington.

OGDEN, Utah, Oct. 22. -- Through information imparted by one Donald, Sheriff Layne of Ogden has captured a man said to be one of the persons concerned in the hold-up of the Union Pacific train at Wilcox, Wyo., June 2, when a large amount of money was taken from the express company's safe. The prisoner is James C. Lyle, and he was taken at Rigby, Idaho, Thursday night.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 22. -- The British Government has placed an immense order for ammunition with the Union Metallic Cartridge Company of this city for use in the war in South Africa. It is unofficially declared that part of the order is for 5,000,000 shot shell, with as many more ball cartridges.

I have read with considerable interest the editorial in your paper of this day's issue under the heading "Mr. Schurz's Policy." The suggestion that the Filipinos be given "freedom and independence" seems to me to conflict with the true relationship which the island territory bears to the United States.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 22. -- The Lombardi Italian Grand Opera Company has disbanded here, after a trip through the West, because of poor business.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- During a thick fog the British steamer Laristan, from Marseilles for Rotterdam, was sunk in collision to-day off the Goodwin Sands by the British steamer Crimea. The damage to the Crimea is unknown. There were no fatalities.

Dr. Felix Adler delivered an address before the Society for Ethical Culture yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall on "Conflicting Views as to the Influence of the Late Robert G. Ingersoll." The speaker said in part:
LONDON, Oct. 22. -A correspondent at Glencoe Camp, telegraphing on Oct. 20, and describing the fighting that followed the first engagement in the Boer attack upon the British position that day, says:

OMAHA, Oct. 22. -- A cable dispatch was received here to-day announcing the death in the Philippines on Saturday of Lieut. Col. Guy Howard, son of Gen. O.O. Howard. The cablegram, dated Saturday, was received by Judge J.M. Woolworth, father-in-law of Col. Howard, and read as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- It is stated that notwithstanding the high price steel rails are now bringing, the Pennsylvania Railroad Company intends to lay in a large quantity, and it has now contracted for 100,000 tons.

The Brooklyn police last evening sent out a general alarm for the arrest of "a cross-eyed boy, bare-headed, and wearing a fiery red sweater and blue overalls." The boy thus described is Charles Paretta, eleven years old, of Fountain and New Lots Avenues, Brooklyn. Charles is a fugitive as the result of playing Gen. Funston to his eight-year-old sister Rose's Aguinaldo.

" How to Treat Your Wife" was the subject of the fifth discourse on "Marriage Bells," delivered by the Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Jersey City, last evening. He said in part:

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 22. -- A dispatch from Stillwater, Minn., says: "J.C. McBride, a convict at the State Prison, received in December last, to serve three years and five months for an assault, has made a remarkable confession, showing him to be, it the confession is true, a high-handed murderer.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- The remains of Col. John B. Yates, a distinguished officer of the civil war and an engineer of high standing, who died at Amesburg, Ontario, Wednesday, were interred here to-day. Col. Yates was born Oct. 18, 1833, his father being the Rev. John Austin Yates, D.D. He began life as an axeman in the engineers' corps of the Utica and Schenectady Railroad.

Three alarms were sent out for a fire which was discovered shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the six-story brick building 104 and 106 East Thirty-second Street, occupied as a factory by Herts Brothers, architectural woodworkers.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 23. -- The famous stallion Star Pointer has been taken off the track by his owner, W.J. White. The great pacer's leg will never again be in condition for racing.
DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 23. -- A dispatch from El Paso says:

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- The men who died as the result of the explosion at Rockland Lake last week were buried to-night at Haverstraw. While the cortege was on its way to the cemetery the team attached to the rear hearse became frightened and ran away, and the hearse was upset and smashed to pieces. The horses finally broke loose from the hearse. The driver was badly hurt.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 23. -- The new musical extravaganza called "Chris and the Wonderful Lamp," founded on the popular short story with that title, was produced at the Hyperion Theatre in this city to-night, and was well received by a crowded house. Glen Macdonough wrote the book, while the music, much of which is very taking, was composed by John Philip Sousa.

The veterans of the Seventh Regiment, officially known as the Veterans of the Seventh Regiment, N.G. N.Y., held their annual election in Sherry's last evening. Over three hundred of the men who have been identified with the regiment, many of them having performed service in the civil war, were present. It was the thirty-ninth election in the history of the organization.

What is believed by the police to have been one of the most extensively planned schemes for wire tapping ever attempted in this city was broken up by Capt. Schmittberger and Detective Walsh of the West Twentieth Street Station yesterday, when they descended on the fourth flat in the house at 230 West Twenty-fourth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23. -- Only five of the Yale 'Varsity football eleven who played in the game against Wisconsin last Saturday were sent into the practice this afternoon. They were Cunha, whose work at centre is open to considerable criticism, particularly his passing of the ball, which is responsible for much of the fumbling by the backs; Sweppe at end, Hale at tackle.

Now that the great parade is well over, can we not turn our civic pride and patriotic fervor to good account by rescuing, our via triumphalis from the sordid condition into which it has relapsed since our guest has gone? It is difficult for the average mortal to keep up an everyday patriotism; a stirring event arouses an ebullition of enthusiasm which quickly subsides when the transient stimulus is withdrawn.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 23. -- The Lombardi Italian Grand Opera Company, which stranded here Saturday, was reorganized here to-day, with Collamarini, prima donna, as its financial backer, and the company will complete its tour of Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska and the South.
LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, made a statement in the House of Commons to-day on the question of the expenditure entailed by the Transvaal war.
Only one favorite out of six managed to get home at Aqueduct yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Late this afternoon it was announced that a sensational burglary had taken place yesterday at the Savoy Hotel, London, where the room of Mrs. Stockwell of New York, widow of a New York jeweler, was entered and robbed, it is understood, of jewelry valued at 10,000 and banknotes and other negotiable currency to the amount of 5,000.

" My new yacht will be a ninety-footer, the same as Shamrock," said Sir Thomas Lipton yesterday afternoon in his rooms at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, "and further, I would like to say that the races for the America's Cup will be sailed off Sandy Hook and not off any other place. There have been some rumors afloat that they would be sailed off Newport, and still others that Marblehead would be the port.

We observe that a good many of the boys who were named Grover Cleveland in 1882 and 1884 are coming into the colleges and high schools now. All of them may feel that they will never have cause to be ashamed of their name. We do not hear much of Grover Cleveland these times, but he is yet a growing man.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The following cablegram confirming the report of the death of Capt. Guy Howard was received at the War Department from Gen. Otis to-day:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Col. R.W. Huntingdon, of the United States Marine Corps, has been retired, to take effect Jan. 10 next. He entered the service June 5, 1861, and was promoted to the rank of Colonel Aug. 10, 1898.

WASECA, Minn., Oct. 23. -- The Rev. P.M. McCabe, a well-known Roman Catholic clergyman, is dead of Bright's disease at St. Mary's, a small mission near Waseca. His death recalls an exploit of international interest in which he was a conspicuous actor. It was Father McCabe who was instrumental in liberating the political prisoner John Boyle O'Reilly, who afterward became the noted American poet.
LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Interesting and graphic accounts are supplied by other war correspondents of the battle of Elandslaagte, from which the following are extracts. The Daily Telegraph says:

The Board of Directors of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad yesterday authorized an increase of the capital stock of the road of $15,000,000, which will make the total capitalization of the Central $115,000,000. The additional capital is to be used in the acquirement of equipment. All of the Directors were present at the meeting. Another important act was the election of William Rockefeller as a member of the Executive Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The British victories in Natal, following each other in quick succession, though accompanied by heavy losses on the side of the victors, bear striking testimony to the valor of the vanquished Boers. They appear to have fallen victims to the very plan on which they counted to drive the British into the sea.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23. -- Chairman Dick of the Republican State Committee has received a copy of a letter written by Gov. Steunenberg of Idaho, under date of Oct. 10, to Secretary of War Root, in which the Governor assumes for the State full responsibility for all that has been done in Shoshone County in connection with the Coeur d'Alene mining troubles.

The headquarters of the Republican County Committee were opened for the campaign at 1 Madison Avenue, yesterday, with President Lemuel E. Quigg, Secretary George R. Manchester, and Sergeant at Arms Bodine in charge. Mr. Quigg celebrated the opening by giving out a statement predicting that "if the Republicans and independents who have registered come out and vote, with the aid of the Independent Labor Party they can carry the county."
On Sunday, in an address before the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn, on the occasion of its forty-sixth anniversary, Controller COLER made the following curious statement:

MANILA, Oct. 23. -- The insurgents around Calamba and Angeles have bothered the Americans lately with their repeated attacks, which, like most of the Filipino attacks, consisted of shooting a lot of ammunition into their opponents' camp from long range.

The work of changing the cable system of the Third Avenue Road to electricity has given the company more vexatious delays than its officials bargained for. Incidentally the east side traveling public had its share of trials and tribulations during yesterday and Sunday and only a few who rode on the company's electrical cars on cable transfers seemed to appreciate the mechanical difficulties presented in such a big work and took everything good-naturedly.

Dr. Henry Granger Hanchett, Director of the Adelphi School of Musical Art, gave the first of his Autumn series of analytical pianoforte recitals yesterday afternoon in the assembly hall of Adelphi College, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, in co-operation with Adelphi College.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 23. -- Andrew Carnegie has offered to present $50,000 to the City of Duluth to erect a building for a free public library, conditioned upon a satisfactory site being provided by the city.

The engagements thus far between the Boers and the British have singularly failed to confirm the indications of the war of 1881. The fight at Majuba Hill, although in the technical language of war only an "affair," was a brilliant victory for the Boers. Not only in the actual fighting, but in the planning it showed them to be clearly superior to the invaders.

EDEN MUSEE. -- The attractions last night were unusually good. The concert by the Neopolitan Orchestra was well received, and new moving pictures were shown every hour. In addition there were new wax groups exhibited.
LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The Daily Mail publishes the following description of the battle of Elandslaagte from its special war correspondent, G.W. Steevens, filed at Ladysmith:

The contest that the Board of Education of the Borough of Brooklyn is making in the matter of Dr. MAXWELL'S criticism of the committee system is of more than local importance. It really involves two very broad questions. One is the question of expert authority in matters of education. The other is that of the separation from political and personal influence of a very essential department of the public service.

BOSTON, Oct. 23. -- Jack Gill, though only a Newfoundland dog, performed a feat of valor this morning which wins him the everlasting love of his owner. With the flames crackling around him and handicapped by suffocating smoke, Jack saved his mistress and his playmate, the little boy, from being burned to death in their home on Bourne Street, Jamaica Plain.

It is sincerely to be regretted that some of our most earnest, gifted, and respected anti-imperialist fellow-citizens are disposed to play with straws. Assuming that the President's assertions of his inability to yield the Philippine Islands to the Tagals are an official declaration that he regards those islands, secured to our authority by the treaty of peace with Spain, as now and always to be ours, they charge that the President is "breaking faith."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- Under the management of Charles Frohman there was presented at the Star Theatre this evening a drama introducing to the stage for the first time Dr. A. Conan Doyle's famous character of Sherlock Holmes, dramatized by William Gillette.
" I am in the city on purely personal business," remarked Urey Woodson of Owens-borough, Democratic National Committeeman from Kentucky, at the Hoffman House yesterday.

-----While in Chicago last week, Mr. EDWARD ATKINSON went through an experience little less painful than that to which he was recently subjected by a monster in human form in want of $100. It was the morning after the great anti-expansion meeting, and the eminent Aguinaldian was seated in the breakfast room of his hotel, strengthening himself for further contests with accomplished facts and the progress of events.

Col. Baden-Powell, who has occasioned so much surprise by moving from Mafeking toward the Transvaal, is an officer who has had a varied experience of South Africa, where he is well known, and is feared by the Boers more probably than any other officer in the British Army. Like Mr. Cecil Rhodes, he is a son of the rectory, and is still in the full vigor of manhood.

BOSTON, Oct. 23. -- The biennial convention of the Universalist Church was opened here to-day. Charles L. Hutchinson of Chicago presided, and the preliminary devotional service was conducted by the Rev. Joseph Crocker Snow of Haverhill.

During the stay of the Olympia in the Mediterranean it was the pleasure of a couple of St. Louis girls to be in Rome. In their party was also a pretty Ohio girl, and the three young Americans were quite the rage with the Dewey men who came to the Holy City. Quite as popular with them was the kind priest of the Olympia.

A noteworthy and memorable new play is "Barbara Frietchie," by Clyde Fitch, which was produced at the Criterion Theatre last night, with Julia Marlowe in the title role. It tells, simply and tenderly, yet with much dramatic ingenuity, a love story with a tragic ending, which does not depress the spectator's mind by its sadness, but leaves him elated by its exhibition of heroism and devotion.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- An amended list of the British casualties at the battle of Elandslaagte places the number of officers killed at 6 and wounded at 30, and the number of non-commissioned officers and men killed at 37 and wounded at 175, the total number of casualties being 248. Ten men are missing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Archbishop Chapelle of New Orleans, Apostolic Delegate to Cuba, Puerto Rico, and the Philippines, to-day gave out the following statement:

The chartering by Great Britain of a a large number of vessels that were ordinarily engaged in the foreign carrying trade of the United States, as a result of the critical situation in the Transvaal, has caused such a marked advance in freight rates that it cannot fail to impress American shippers with the inadequacy of our merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The use of savings banks by children in France is interestingly treated in one of the State Department's publications, a report from Consul John C. Covert at Lyons. They are steady depositors, and in the case of the little girls the practice is encouraged for a peculiarly French reason.
The Premier Bowling Club gave a splendid exhibition in the Harlem League, at the Palace Alleys, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, last night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- In the Harvard football practice to-day the 'Varsity eleven were scored against for the first time this season. On the old guards-back formation the second eleven gained steadily through the line of the first, which was weakened by the absence of Burden, Boal, and Burnett. Only at times were the forwards of the first eleven able to break through the formation of the play.

The will of the late ex-Justice Charles P. Daly was made public yesterday by being filed for probate in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court at Riverhead, L.I. Mr. Daly died at his Summer home near Sag Harbor recently without a surviving blood relative. Henry R. Hoyt and Alexander T. Mason, his partners in the law firm of Daly, Hoyt Mason, were named as his executors.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 28. -- William P. Lord, ex-Governor of Oregon, has been appointed Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the Argentine Republic. He was appointed as Minister to Persia on April 18, 1899, but declined.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 23. -- Gov. Steunenberg of Idaho had another conference to-day with Secretary Root respecting the maintenance of Federal custody of the miners who are now held as prisoners in Idaho by the troops. The War Department is anxious to escape the responsibility for the further care of these prisoners.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- Edwin Van Dusen Paul, who was delegated to represent President Kruger at the International Commercial Congress, will not take further part in the proceedings. He left the city for Chicago, whence he goes to transact other business for the Transvaal Government. Mr. Paul intended to read a paper before the congress, but the state of affairs in South Africa called him to other duties.

A cylinder filled with molten lead exploded in the Nichols Chemical Works in Laurel Hill, Queens Borough, yesterday morning, and two men were seriously injured. One of them will probably die, and the other will be fearfully disfigured and will lose the sight of one of his eyes. The injured men are George Clarke, twenty-five years of age, of Clifton Avenue, Laurel Hill, and John McMullen, twenty-six years old, of Elizabeth, N.J.
HAVANA, Oct. 23. -- A largely attended meeting was held to-day to celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of the inauguration of the movement for independence.

The United States has just adopted for use in the army and navy a gun capable of greater rapidity of fire than any gun of the same calibre and class in existence. The new weapon is a 6-pounder, and by that is meant that it fires a shell weighing six pounds, though the cartridge complete weighs about fourteen pounds. The extraordinary

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- Attorney General Davies to-night, upon the report submitted to him by his deputy, Mr. Coyne, recommended to the Governor that he call an extraordinary term of the Supreme Court to convene a special Grand Jury to investigate the alleged frauds committed at the primary elections of the Democratic Party in the Ninth Assembly District in New York City, and also other alleged registration frauds.

Richard Croker appeared at the Wigwam yesterday morning about 10:30 o'clock, and immediately took charge of the local campaign. He seated himself behind the big carved desk in the little half-private room leading off from the big assembly room where the leaders gather, and at once plunged into the business of running a campaign.

There is a bad political mix up in the Thirty-first Assembly District, and at the present time there are two enrolled Republicans nominated by the regular Republican organization of the district for the Assembly and Board of Aldermen, running against two enrolled Republicans nominated by the Citizens' Union for the same offices.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 23. -- Sylvester Conklin, who was arrested here a week ago on suspicion of being responsible for the death of William Strong on Saturday, Oct. 14, was examined this afternoon, and was committed for the Grand Jury. Strong was employed as a laborer by Charles Limon, a farmer of this place.
LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The correspondent of The Daily Mail at Durban, Natal, says:

Anson R. Flower has returned from a tour of inspection of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway, which he made in company with President Cable and other officers and Directors of the road. The party traveled 5,200 miles, 3,400 of which were on the Rock Island system, in the two weeks of their trip, and passed through fourteen different States.

The Caledonian Insurance Company of Edinburgh has bought, through John N. Golding, from P. Harmony's Nephews Co. the old five-story buildings 50 and 52 Pine Street, adjoining the northeast corner of William Street. On this plot, which is 40.2 feet front and measures 97.1 feet and 101.10 feet on its easterly and westerly lines, respectively, the purchasing company will erect immediately a twelve or fifteen story office building.

The President's secretary, Mr. JOHN ADDISON PORTER, we learn from the Washington correspondent of The Evening Post, is very greatly troubled in finding a way to exclude from the White House those Washington visitors who desire to see the parlors of the Executive Mansion, and who are not satisfied to be permitted to look only at the East Room.

Superintendent of Elections McCullagh yesterday in the Essex Market Police Court arraigned Charles Moon, said to be a special officer m McGurk's dance hall on the Bowery, and charged him with inducing a stranger to register in Mr. Mazet's district. The stranger is Harry Gardiner, seventeen years of age, who arrived here last Friday from Boston.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 24. -- After a voyage of twenty-eight days from Cape Nome, during which two men died from starvation and others were half crazed from want of food and water, the schooner Hera arrived in port to-day with nearly 200 passengers on board. News of the wretched plight of the Hera's passengers was brought here on Sunday night by the steamer Lakme.
The New York State Medical Association began its sixteenth annual meeting yesterday morning at the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street. The meeting is to last three days.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 24. -- The National convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union passed a series of resolutions to-day, some of them after hours of discussion. The longest debates were over two resolutions, one censuring Attorney General Griggs and ex-Secretary of War Alger for their action on the Anti-Canteen law, and the other denouncing the war in the Philippines.

MANILA, Oct. 24. -- Iloilo is stirred by the expectation of important fighting. Gen. Pulion began "unrolling the bloody scroll," as he promised his followers in a recent speech, by firing volleys at the American outposts nightly. Since Sunday reinforcements have been arriving from the north. This activity is designed to divert the Bisayans from their dissatisfaction against the Tagalogs.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The Daily Telegraph has the following from De Aar, Cape Colony, dated Monday evening:
With largely increased membership and a programme that promises a season of profitable discussion, the Woman's Society for Political Study has resumed its meetings after the Summer interim.

In 1893, owing to the increase in the number of accidents to railway employes in consequence of the use of hand-couplers and the failure of railway corporations to apply automatic brakes to their cars, the Congress pased an act, which became law on March 2 of that year -- a year in which 7,346 persons were killed and 40,393 injured by railway accidents in the United States.
