PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 24. -- Crazed by being denied the hand of the girl he loved, on account of objections to his nationality by her parents, Juan Garcia, a Cuban, shot and killed Bessie Mahoney, aged twenty years, and then committed suicide.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- James A. Herne's new play, "Sag Harbor," which was performed for the first time to-night at the Park Theatre, is, like "Shore Acres," a story of human affection, and was well received here to-night.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The Premier, the Marquis of Salisbury, was present this evening at a private dinner given to Gen. Benjamin Harrison and Mrs. Harrison by United States Ambassador Choate and Mrs. Choate.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -Arthur J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader in the House of Commons, writing to the Conservative candidate for Parliament in Bow, makes it perfectly clear that tile Government asks the support of the electorate at the present juncture on patriotic grounds.

ALBANY, Oct. 24. -- Gov. Roosevelt will designate Justice William E. Werner of Rochester, of the Seventh Judicial District, to hold the extraordinary term of the Supreme Court to empanel a special Grand Jury to consider the alleged election primary and registration frauds in the metropolitan districts, especially in the Ninth Assembly District.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 24. -- Although the weather conditions were decidedly unfavorable for good football practice to-day, the Yale football eleven was given a hard day's work. Capt. McBride and his advisers gave their attention to the working of the backs, believing that the time is now ripe to develop these positions on the team.

P.H. Flynn, who some time ago got the contract for supplying Jersey City with water, yesterday notified Mayor Hoos and the Street and Water Board that he had selected a site for the dam and reservoir. They will be situated on the Banta property, lying on the Rockaway River, near Boonton. The reservoir will have a capacity of 50,000,000 gallons daily, which may be increased to 70,000,000 gallons when necessary.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- It is now possible to give authoritatively Canada's final proposition for a permanent settlement of the Alaska dispute. It is very different from her former demands, and was delivered to the United States Ambassador, Joseph H. Choate, by the Canadian Minister of Marine and Fisheries, Sir Louis Henry Davies, late on the night before the latter sailed. It was dispatched to-day to Washington by the officials of the United states Embassy.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 24. -- Advices from La Paz, capital of Bolivia, announce the election, by a vote of 55 out of 57 in the Chamber of Deputies, of Gen. Pando, the revolutionary or Federalist candidate for the Presidency of Bolivia.

That is a curious announcement that Senator PLATT has abandoned the contest for the New York Legislature, the defense of the Ramapo job, and other important functions which belong to him in his capacity either as Senator or as Boss, if these functions be distinguishable, in order to go over to Washington and try to upset the decision arrived at in respect to the new New York Custom House.
CAPE TOWN, Oct. 24. -- The following advices have been received here from Maseru, Basutoland, dated Oct. 23:

Sir Thomas Lipton was the guest yesterday afternoon of the Transportation Club at a luncheon given in his honor at the club rooms, on the top floor of the Manhattan Hotel Building. The occasion brought together many notable representatives of the country's carrying interests, and was provocative of a great outpouring of international good-fellowship and spontaneous demonstrations of good-will for the owner of the Shamrock.

APIA, Samoan Islands, Oct. 15, via Auckland. -- Ostensibly to collect the poll tax imposed by the provisional Government, thirty Mataafa chiefs came into Apia. Two of their number were assaulted by a relative of Tamasese for a breach of etiquette while passing the latter's house.

Evidences multiply that financiers, engineers, and contractors are taking a deep interest in the awarding of the contract for the underground rapid transit railroad, for which bids are to be invited as soon as the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court passes upon the question of reducing the amount of the contractor's bond from $14,000,000 to $5,000,000.

We were speaking yesterday of the necessity which the Boers of the Transvaal had found themselves under of excepting their field artillery from the rule of confiding their defense to an amateur and citizen soldiery. It seemed that their efforts had not been very successful and that it was in artillery that they were most distinctly inferior to the regular troops opposed to them.

CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 24. -- The Indian football team's coach, "Pop" Warner, returned yesterday from Cambridge, where he had been absorbing information on Harvard's work. He seems to think that Harvard's offensive play is not up to standard, and his hopes for a victory are strengthened.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- The early morning rain failed to dampen the spirits of the National Beagle Club members, and they gathered at the farm of W.C. Whitney at 7 o'clock to resume the trials of Class A.

Richard Croker thinks that the Mazet committee is a good thing for the Democrats. As campaign material, he regards it as the best vote-producing argument that Tammany can possibly make use of. He said yesterday that the Republicans had an idea that the investigation would result in bringing upon Tammany such public odium that the people would rise up, as in the case of the Tweed ring, and cast it out of office.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Unless the management of the trolley lines in this city, which recently passed into the control of the Shanley syndicate, recedes from its position or the motormen and conductors decide to modify their demands, there is every probability of a strike. The present plan of the men is to quit work to-morrow unless their demands are granted.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- At the opening of the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day a Trial Plate was won by Tovaros, ridden by L. Reiff. Sloan finished second with Tarolinta, and Lambrequin was third among nine starters.

The acrid dispute now raging between Messrs. CROKER and QUIGG as to the means by which the former raises money for campaign expenses is not likely to lead to any definite information for the public on that interesting question. No one doubts that poolrooms and other unlawful places exist in this city or that they could be suppressed largely if not wholly by the police, and the inference is strong that they buy exemption.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24. -- With only two more weeks left until election the Kentucky campaign is getting warm. Sensations, plots, and counter plots are sprung every day. This morning Judge John T. Hodge of Newport resigned as a member of the Democratic State Campaign Committee. The trouble grew out of the John G. Carlisle correspondence, in which Carlisle attacked Goebel's silver record.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- A disastrous fire visited the stock farm of Gideon Daly in Holmdel, a few miles from this place, early to-day. Flames broke out in the brood mare stable, and before they were discovered had gained such headway that the building was doomed.

Thomas J. McManus, the Republican and Citizens' Union candidate for Assembly in the Fifteenth Assembly District, was arrested last night by Deputy Sheriff Walgering on an order signed by Justice Scott of the Supreme Court in an action brought against him by Mrs. Frances E. Milne, who runs a printing house at 12 Chambers Street.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 24. -- It is practically settled that Wellington will play at left half back and Henry at left end on the University of Chicago football team, which will meet Pennsylvania Saturday on Marshall Field. To-day, in the first signal practice of the week for the Pennsylvania game, the two players were in those positions, and Capt. Kennedy at quarterback, the remainder of the team being the same as in recent games.
The Parnell Monument Committee of New York appeals for support and aid them in carrying out the objects for which they came into existence. Those objects are:

Capt. Joseph Solomon, who has been reelected commander of Company H. Eighth Regiment, said yesterday there are other reasons for Col. Jarvis's disapproval of his election than the Captain's alleged defection at the beginning of the Spanish war. Capt. Solomon has in his possession a certificate from Dr. A.A. Richardson showing that at the time of the regiment's departure he was sick and physically unable to go.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- One of the President's callers to-day was the Rev. Robert McKinnon, known as "the soldier priest," the Chaplain of the First California. He had a long interview with Mr. McKinley, to whom he gave his views of the situation.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 24. -- Gen. Cipriano Castro, the insurgent commander, has assumed control of the Government and has formed the following Cabinet:
Samuel Goldstieker has sold for John L. Jordan to George F. Cain the lot on the north side of One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, 273 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue 23 by 93.11.

With the end of the racing season so near at hand, H.T. Griffin, who has in other years been the terror of owners who enter horses too cheaply in selling races, begins to feel the need of buying a few good selling platers at low prices to race in the West this Winter.

PADUCAH, Ky., Oct. 24. -- In a Court Street saloon, shortly before 11 o'clock last night, Murray Gilbert, a well-known band leader and musician, fatally shot Mrs. Jane Hall and then blew out his own brains.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The Bering Sea claims against Russia originated in the seizure by the Russia authorities off the coast of Siberia of three American sealing vessels, and the damages claimed aggregate about $150,000. The vessels were the James Hamilton Lewis, the Cape Horn Pigeon, and the C.H. White. In each case the largest item of the claim is on account of the sufferings of the American officers and crews while under arrest.

Ex-Mayor William L. Strong paid what he was pleased to term his "annual visit" to the Nineteenth Assembly District last night, for the purpose of making a speech at the mass meeting which was held in the house of the West Side Republican Club at Eighty-third Street and Broadway in the interest of Assemblyman Mazet and the other district candidates.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 24. -- Two railroad systems -- the Southern and the Seaboard Air Line -- are giving exhibitions of railroad building in the vicinity of Columbia that have never been equaled in the South. The Seaboard is building from Cheraw to Columbia, eighty miles, and from Columbia to Cacey's, three miles, but these three miles are all trestling, and include a 500-foot steel bridge over the Congaree River.

A dispatch from Gen. White to the Secretary of State for War clears up the situation in Northern Natal. There is now no doubt that Gen. Yule has abandoned the Glencoe camp and is making all speed to Ladysmith, to connect with the forces directly under Gen. White.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24. -- The approach of the big games was denoted this afternoon, when the gates of Soldiers' Field were closed and the 'Varsity football squad held secret practice. This means that the coaches look upon next Saturday's game with the Carlisle Indians as one to be reckoned for just as carefully as one of the championship contests.

Citizens of Brooklyn and presumably some from Manhattan who went to the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last evening to hear the debate between Lieut. Gov. Woodruff and ex-Corporation Counsel of Brooklyn John F. Clarke, got more entertainment out of it than has ever before been furnished by anything in politics in the memory of the oldest politician of that borough.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The Parliamentary Secretary of the War Office George Wyndham in the House of Commons to-day announced that Field Marshal Lord Wolseley, the Commander in Chief of the forces, sums up the situation in Natal to-day as follows:

The Columbia University football representatives put in a good day of practice on the grounds opposite the library yesterday under the supervision of Coaches Sanford and Ely. The men are impressed with the importance of their game against Yale at Manhattan Field next Saturday, and there is probably not a more confident lot of football players in training than these Columbia representatives.

Teams representing the Sub-Treasury, National Park Bank, and Mechanics and Traders' Bank competed in the opening series of the Bank Clerks' Bowling League at Reid's alleys, 200 Church Street, last night.

Another call to arms against Tammany was sounded yesterday when the Citizens' Union issued its address to the registered voters of the County of New York in favor of the Fusion ticket. The address appeals for "cordial, united, and active support, without distinction of party, of the union ticket, which has been put in nomination by the Citizens' Union and by the Republican County Convention, and which is recommended by the City Club."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- The University of Pennsylvania football team leaves Philadelphia for Chicago to-morrow at noon to meet the University of Chicago team on Saturday. The Pennsylvania men, with a record far from satisfactory for the season, are still hopeful of defeating the Western players, who ran up a score of over 50 points against Oberlin, and who have been preparing for this game since April.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The 'Varsity was put through forty minutes of hard practice to-day. This was not in preparation for the Lehigh game to-morrow, but because Capt. Chamberlain of the brown and white telegraphed this morning to Capt. Edwards the request that the time of halves be cut to the limit to-morrow.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24. -- Gov. Roosevelt of New York, who is to make a series of speeches in Maryland within the next forty-eight hours, arrived here to-night, and was met by United States Senator McComas, District Attorney John C. Rose, Attorney General George R. Gaither, and Chairman Thomas J. Shryock of the Republican State Committee.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The following dispatch from Gen. Sir George Stewart White to the Marquis of Lansdowne, Secretary of State for War, received last evening at 11 o'clock, was posted at the War Office soon after midnight:

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Cornell's 'Varsity football team braced up in an astonishing fashion this afternoon for the first time this season. The improvement that was expected to take place after the defeat at Chicago was not apparent in Saturday's game against Lehigh. The result was a feeling of decided discouragement among the football men as well as in the university at large.

The Woman's Municipal League, at 361 East Thirty-fourth Street, listened yesterday to the fifth in a course of six Normal lessons its members have been taking with the idea of fitting themselves to give instruction to classes of women in settlements and various philanthropic and religious associations.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Russia has at last agreed to submit to arbitration the United States claims resulting from the seizure of sealers in the Bering Sea, which have been pending for about eight years. A protocol between the two Governments has been drawn up, and the final formalities are expected to be concluded next month.

The customary meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall which precedes immediately all elections in this city was held yesterday afternoon at the headquarters, in East Fourteenth Street. Judge McMahon presided, and all the Assembly districts were represented except the Twelfth and Thirteenth.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The President to-day issued the following Thanksgiving proclamation:

The Rev. Dr. L.W. Batten, the newly appointed rector of St. Mark's Church, spoke at the Church Club of New York last evening on "The Holy Scriptures" from the point of view of those who believe in the "higher criticism." He dwelt particularly upon the subject of inspiration, making a vigorous argument for a modification of the old idea that the Bible is infallible and the foundation of the Protestant faith.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- At a meeting of stockholders of the Massachusetts Central Railroad to-day, at which 18,675 shares were represented, the old Board of Directors was re-elected, with the exception of President Samuel H. Aldrich and W.T. Sweet, who declined to serve. Their places in the Directorate are to be filled later.

These companies hitherto have not been managed for the advantage of the public in the matter of rates. They have steadily refused to cut them down. The only competition between them was in making contracts with particular railroad companies. This inured to the advantage of the companies, but not to the advantage of the public.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- With unconscious humor a Cape Town correspondent telegraphed yesterday:
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Michael Davitt, Irish Nationalist, member for South Mayo, announced in the House of Commons to-day that he would resign to-morrow as a protest against the Boer war.

Millard F. Jones, once atorney for and a Director in the North River Bank, which failed in 1890, who was taken to Bellevue Hospital on Tuesday and placed in the insane pavilion, was yesterday declared insane by the examining physicians. He will be taken to the Manhattan State Hospital for the Insane to-morrow.
LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Grant Allen, the author, who had been in ill-health for some time past, is dead.

GREAT FALLS, Montana, Oct. 25. -- Many interesting instances of the sufferings and heroism of sheep herders and their dogs during the recent blizzard on the ranges are coming to light. Some of them show a devotion to duty on the part of the men who died in the storm that is worthy of the best traditions.

Miss Clara Butt, an English contralto, who is very popular in her own country, made her first appearance in America last night at Mendelssohn Hall. Her entertainment was in the form of a song recital diversified by piano and violoncello playing. Her assistants were Miss Lotta Mills, pianist, and Mr. Leo Stern, 'cellist.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The sport to-day at the trials of the National Beagle Club was of the finest. Game was plentiful, and the weather, although murky, held the scent much better than yesterday. The scene of the contests was again on the W.C. Whitney place. To-night the club members are guests of James L. Kernochan.

Frank L. Henry, a banker and member of the New York Stock Exchange, died suddenly last night of apoplexy at the Racquet Club. 27 West Forty-third Street, shortly after 8 o'clock. Mr. Henry had entered the clubhouse a few minutes before and went to the third floor to take a bath. He had hardly entered the room before he was seized with violent pains and fell to the floor.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Application was made to Judge Barnard at Special Term this morning by Francis A. Barry and fifty-eight other students at St. Joseph's Catholic Seminary, at Yonkers, for a writ of mandamus to compel the Inspectors of Election in the First District of the Seventh Ward of the City of Yonkers to place their names on the registry list.

CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 25. -- Excellent weather has materially aided the Indian team in the last few days' practice. The work was taken up briskly, although the whole team was not present, Scholder, injured at Pennsylvania, and Wheelock, with a lame kicking leg, were necessarily out.

Controller Coler yesterday prepared a statement showing how much the sanitary protection of the Croton watershed had cost the city since the passage of the Webster act in 1893. The statement is a striking illustration of the enormous expense of acquiring lands for city purposes under the existing system.

Military circles are stirred by a report that Brig. Gen. McCoskry Butt, commander of the First Brigade, is at variance with Major Gen. Charles F. Roe, commanding the National Guard forces of the State, and that charges against Gen. Roe, accusing him of violating the Military Code, will be formally sent to the Governor by Gen. Butt.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25. -- A decision was rendered to-day by the First Federal Court approving the accounts of J.A. Robertson of Monterey during his incumbency of the receivership of the Monterey and Mexican Gulf Railroad. This vindicates the record of Receiver Robertson and affirms the claims of many American creditors of that corporation now under the management of the Belgian bondholders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Consul General Richard Guenther, writing to the State Department from Frankfort, says that the last few years have formed an era of trusts there. While Germany did not take the lead in making trusts, she is following other countries with increasing eagerness. In 1898 trusts were formed in iron wire, woolen goods, iron goods, wall paper, cast iron, asphalt, indigo,

FREDERICK, Md., Oct. 25. -- Gov. Roosevelt reached here to-night after making a dozen speeches and traveling nearly 250 miles through the State since daybreak this morning. He was met at the station by more than a thousand cheering people, and escorted to the City Opera House by an immense torchlight procession through streets which were lined with shouting thousands and ablaze with red fire.

The Staten Island Electric Company last night, without warning, shut off all the street lights in Richmond Borough, and for the second time within a month the whole borough was plunged in darkness. General Manager Swinarton of the company had no explanation to make except to say he had received orders from the Board of Directors of the company to take the action.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 25. -- The Altgeld and Harrison factions of the Democratic Party in Cook County will be united if the Fall elections in other States indicate that the Democrats will have a good fighting chance in Illinois. Ex-Gov. Altgeld has declared that he does not wish to be a delegate to the National Convention, this being a big stumbling block in the way of reconciliation.

De Witt C. Knox, sixty-three years old, for many years an employe of the Brewster Carriage Company, at Forty-eighth Street and Broadway, committed suicide early yesterday morning in his apartments in the Marion, at 415 West Forty-eighth Street, by taking carbolic acid and laudanum. It is believed that loneliness and grief, caused by the realization that he had departed from his usual custom of abstemiousness, impelled the man to the act.

The second day of the annual meeting of the New York State Medical Association opened yesterday morning in the hall of the Academy of Medicine, in West Forty-third Street. A paper which excited great interest among the physicians present was that on "Morphinism Among Physicians," by Dr. T.D. Crothers of Hartford, Conn. He said in part:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Preparations for the sessions of the Philippine Commission were begun this morning. The anteroom used by the Diplomatic Corps will be reserved for them, and suitable furniture has been placed there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The fielding records of players who took part in twenty or more championship baseball games have been compiled by President N.E. Young. The percentages of the players follow:
The practice that Coach Stanford put the Columbia University football squad through yesterday consisted of straight football, and the 'Varsity squad showed up strong.

May I be allowed to caution any persons intending just now to visit the Central Park greenhouses in consequence of several letters seen in the papers leading readers to infer that those greenhouses are at present awaiting visitors? One writer is even astonished that more persons do not avail themselves of the privilege of seeing the beautiful tropical plants and trees they may contain.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- The Chicago University eleven began practice for the Pennsylvania game this afternoon, although there are still two days for work before the contest. Marshall Field was deserted all afternoon, with the exception of a lone punter and one or two men not fast enough for even the scrubs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Archbishop Chapelle is ready to start for the Philippines, and will probably go by the transport Sherman, leaving San Francisco Nov. 10. With Father McKinnon, the "soldier priest," who is to accompany him, he visited the State and War Departments to-day and had interviews with Secretaries Hay and Root.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The latest dispatch from Kimberley gives details of the arrangements made by the British commander, Col. Kekewiche, for the defense of the town. The meat consumption is limited to a pound daily, a fire brigade has been formed, and its members are prohibited from joining in the defense of the place, as their services are likely to be otherwise required.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The War Office returns show that the total British casualties since the beginning of hostilities reach 597, 18 officers having been killed and 55 wounded, and 76 men killed and 435 wounded. There are 13 unaccounted for.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- At the Newmarket-Houghton meeting to-day Tod Sloan won the Newmarket Second Welter Handicap with My Lady's Maid. Sea Fog, ridden by Martin, was second, and Nil Desperandum was third. The betting was 10 to 1 against My Lady's Maid and 6 to 1 against Sea Fog.

The campaign in the Nineteenth Assembly District, where Robert Mazet stands for the Assembly against Perez M. Stewart, the candidate of the Citizens Union and of Tammany Hall, is just now at fever heat. The Stewart men are the more confident, although they are none the less wary on that account.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Twenty-four million dollars is to be demanded through the courts from corporations in Cook County for violations of the Illinois statutes. State's Attorney Deneen will make the demand in a few days by filing 3,000 suits, the largest batch ever seen at one time in the offices of the court clerks of the county.

Harvard won the team championship of the Intercollegiate Golf Association yesterday on the Garden City links, beating Princeton, after a splendidly fought contest, by 8 points, or 21 holes to 2. The contest was twice as long as in previous years, 36 holes being played, instead of 18, for the final round.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 25. -- The members of the Freshman class of Franklin and Marshall College have been notified that the entire class will be suspended if they do not pay the bill for expenses incurred in repairing damage done by them during a recent skylarking, in which they painted a building with legends deriding the sophomores.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The 'Varsity team continued its good work of yesterday in the practice this afternoon. Five touch-downs were made against the scrubs in less than an hour, while the latter, with the ball in their possession, made but two gains; one of five yards through the line and the other on a pull from Coach Haughton.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The extent of the British naval preparations revealed by today's information causes a strong revival of the rumors of serious foreign complications. It is now said that Rear Admiral Lord Charles Beresford will command the Mediterranean Squadron, and details of the activity at the dockyards and naval stations are coming in hot and fast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- It is reported here that a list of Government employes whose wives also are employed in the departments is being compiled, and that when completed one or other of the family must resign.

That is rather a gloomy dispatch to an esteemed contemporary which sets forth that Mr. CHOATE, our Ambassador in London, has taken so literally some well-meaning instructions from the State Department, which enjoined upon him not to express his opinions upon public affairs, except through the safe medium of the British Foreign Office.

Yachtsmen at the New York Yacht Club house yesterday knew little about the rumor that Mr. A.D. Clarke was to issue a challenge for the America's Cup. As a matter of fact, Mr. Clarke has been dead for more than a year.

M.E. Hewitt Co. have sold for the Halter Investment Company the four-story flat, 523 West One Hundred and Forty-first Street; also, for H.D. Stringer. the four-story flat, 508 West One Hundred and Forty-second Street; also, for a client, 144 East Fifty-third Street, a three-story brownstone-front dwelling on a lot 17 by 100.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Seventeen points represent the sum total that the Princeton eleven was able to roll up against the third-rate Lehigh eleven to-day.

A paper prepared by President John E. Searles of the American Cotton Company was read yesterday at the Cotton Growers' Convention at Atlanta, Ga. The writer dwelt at length on the waste and loss which the cotton grower now has to face before marketing his product, and advocated the "roundlap" bale as the most economical.
Surely I shall voice the wish of thousands when I wish the League of American Wheelmen success in its new effort to suppress the street-sprinkling nuisance.

VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 25. -- Intelligence is brought by the Rinsa Maru that the typhoon through which the Empress and Senator passed proved even more disastrous on land than on sea. In Tokio and Yokohama hundreds of houses were wrecked, but few persons were killed. A train near Fuhushima encountered a gale of such fury when crossing the Hokogowa that it was blown into the river.

I was not surprised to read your editorial in to-day's issue entitled "English Calm," for unless the cables greatly exaggerate, no such wildly enthusiastic scenes have been witnessed in English cities since the return of the victorious troops from the Crimea, some forty-three years ago, as are now being recorded.

A most interesting correspondence was recently opened by the sending of a letter signed by nine Presidents of South Carolina cotton manufactories to Senators TILLMAN and MCLAURIN and each of the seven Representatives of the State in the House of Representatives.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- The achievements of American railroads and their relation to commercial, industrial, and agricultural interests were set forth in an address to-day before the Internation Commercial Congress by Gorge H. Daniels, General Passenger Agent of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad and President of the American Association of Passenger Agents.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 25. -- The University of Pennsylvania football team left Philadelphia at noon to-day for Chicago and were given the most enthusiastic send-off ever accorded a Pennsylvania team. The students, nearly 2,000 in number, marched from the campus, headed by the student band, and awaited the arrival of the team at the railroad station.

It is quite evident that neither the Boers nor the British regard the British successes thus far had in Natal or in Cape Colony as decisive or even as very indicative of the final result. When we were at war with the Spaniards, the very first engagement of the war showed that there was nothing to be apprehended from the Spaniard at sea.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25. -- The 'Varsity practice was secret again to-day, and spectators will probably be kept off the field until the game with Pennsylvania, with the exception that the student body will be given an opportunity to see what their team is doing.

A meeting to further the organization of a woman's auxiliary to the Interdenominational Guild for the Aid of Crippled Children of the Poor was held yesterday afternoon at the residence of Dr. Egbert Guernsey. Addresses were made by several persons interested in the movement, and it was decided to hold an organization meeting at the Guild's School for Crippled Children, 234 West Sixty-third Street, Tuesday afternoon, Oct. 31. Among those present yesterday were:

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 25. -- The Georgia Legislature met in regular session to-day. After organization had been perfected the message of Gov. Candler was read. The Chief Executive took the position that there should be the strictest economy in the administration of the school fund of the State, and pointed out the importance of restricting the work of the public schools to the elementary branches.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25. -- The coaches of the Yale football eleven expect a hard battle with Columbia next Saturday, and are making every possible effort to get the team in shape for the contest. The idea is to have the team line up materially the same as it did in the game with Wisconsin. Slight injuries received by two of the best men included in last Saturday's line-up may prevent this being done.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 25. -- The American Manufacturer in its issue to-morrow will say:

If JONES of Toledo, the "Golden Rule" independent candidate for Governor of the Buckeye State, were out of the race and out of the way the supporters of NASH, Republican, and MCLEAN, Democrat, would be much calmer, better able to enjoy the simplified contest, and much more capable of indulging in predictions.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- C.H. Matthiessen, President of the Glucose Sugar Refining Company, this evening made the following statement regarding the recent Supreme Court decision:

It is wonderful to see how history sometimes repeats itself. The battle of King's Mountain, fought during our Revolutionary War, and the battle of Majuba Hill, which, occurring some eighteen years ago, has been brought back into prominence by the present South African war, are remarkably alike in their details.

The expressions of Controller Coler, reported in THE TIMES of this date in reference to public reform, strike, in my opinion, the true note. In his address to the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn, he is reported to have said: "This reform movement * * * is an evil, for it spreads abroad and makes public the vice and crime, so that the children even become familiar with them."

When Warrenton beat Box at a mile and a sixteenth, after a long, hard drive through the stretch, at Aqueduct on Tuesday, he was thought by many to have returned to his old form. But that opinion was dissipated yesterday, when, in the fourth race, at a mile and an eighth, Wait Not beat him.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 25. -- The Democratic Convention was held to-night in Orange Music Hall to select nominees for State Senator, Sheriff, Surrogate, and eleven Assemblymen.

Brooklyn's school troubles keep on accumulating. At the meeting of the Central Board of Education yesterday it was announced by President Robertson of the Brooklyn Board that 4,500 pupils in that borough were without teachers. Every effort, he added, had been made to secure from City Superintendent Maxwell's eligible list the ninety-one additional teachers absolutely needed, but without success.

President Samuel R. Callaway, in discussing yesterday the uses to which the proceeds of the new issue of $15,000,000 of New York Central and Hudson River Railroad stock would be put, disposed of several rumors and misstatements and made it clear that the money would be applied solely to rolling stock equipment.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The War Office last evening made public the following dispatch sent by Gen. White from Ladysmith at 3:50 that afternoon:

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- The trial of Hugh Henry Hammond, who shot John T. Shayne, the wealthy furrier, last March, while the latter was dining with Mr. Hammond's divorced wife at the Auditorium Annex, was begun to-day before Judge Hutchinson.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 25. -- The demand for laborers throughout all sections of the West continues to be greatly in excess of the supply, in spite of the fact that the Winter season is coming on. The supply of men for transportation west of Omaha has fallen off more than half since the Summer, although a considerable number its collected and forwarded every day.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 25. -- The first account of the Equitable Trust Company, receiver of the Keen-Sutterle Company, which failed in January, 1896, was filed to-day in the Common Pleas Court, and the Auditor declared a dividend of less than 2 per cent. on the claims, amounting to over $1,000,000.

There is something more than admiration for a military hero in the general desire that Dewey shall be the next President of the United States. The brilliancy of his naval exploit has much to do with this, but there are many people not carried away by its dazzling quality who still hold that Dewey is the man of the present era for that office.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 26. -- A general meeting of the stockholders of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad Company will be held at the office of the company in Raleigh, N.C., on Wednesday, Nov. 29, for the purpose of considering the change of its corporate title from that of "The Raleigh and Gaston Railroad Company" to "Sea-any other name that may be selected and board Aid Line Railroad Company" or agreed upon.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26. -- Perhaps the largest political gathering that Baltimore has seen in years assembled in and about Music Hall to-night to hear Gov. Roosevelt of New York who to-day closed a tour of the western counties of the State.
The games in the Harlem League last night furnished an excellent exhibition of bowling for a large crowd at the Harlem Palace alleys.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- A dinner in honor of Rear Admiral Entwistle, whose home is in this city, was given to-night at the Hamilton Club by the citizens of Paterson. Entwistle was Dewey's Fleet Engineer at the battle of Manila. Dewey was expected, but did not come. Instead, he sent a letter of regrets which was read by Capt. John H. Hopper, the toastmaster.
Some of the best bowling of the season was done in the American National Tournament at the Germania alleys last night, five cores of over 900 being rolled.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Details of the fighting at Rietfontein are coming in slowly. A special dispatch from Ladysmith, dated Oct. 24, filed after the fight, says:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The fifth annual session of the State Federation of Women's Clubs was opened at the Brighton to-day by an address of welcome delivered by Mrs. Allen B. Endicott on behalf of the Woman's Research Club of this city. Mrs. Emily E. Williamson of Elizabeth, the State President, made the response.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Lady Randolph Churchill presided yesterday at a meeting of American women in London, organized to raise funds to equip a hospital ship for South African waters.

In the Nineteenth Assembly District, where the political fight is raging hotter than in any other part of the city, the temporary withdrawal of the Tammany fighting forces last night to attend the ratification meeting on Fourteenth Street left the district practically in the hands of the Republican forces, who took the field and waged vigorous war all over the district.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Ex-Mayor Charles A. Schieren of Brooklyn to-day addressed the delegates to the International Commercial Congress on the value of our export trade if continuously pushed. He said in part:

Several changes are being made in the old publishing house of Harper Brothers, as a result of Doubleday McClure's connection with the firm. Harper's Round Table has been dropped, but its editor Albert Lee has been transferred temporarily to one of the McClure publications. Mrs. Margaret E. Sangster, editor of The Bazar, has been transferred to another post and her place has been taken by J.H. Sears.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 26. -- A scramble between the supporters of Gen. Patrick A. Collins and John R. Murphy, candidates for Mayor of Boston, to obtain places of advantage for filing nomination papers at the Democratic City Committee's headquarters here to-day, developed into a hot battle between the factions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- In official and diplomatic quarters attention is being directed to the question of a Pacific cable linking this country with the Philippines and points beyond, and it is understood that this Government and those foreign Governments which would be affected by the cable are now actively considering the subject.

That the Columbia is going abroad in search of the many yachting trophies that will be hung up next Spring in the Mediterranean and the British circuit has been definitely decided. Capt. Barr will command Columbia during her cruise in quest of cups on the other side, and after her return will again report for duty on Commodore Postley's schooner Colonia for the Summer.

Charles Hitchcock, Jr., one of Yale's new golfing recruits, and the winner last Summer of the Point Judith Country Club Cup at Narragansett, led the field of collegiate contestants yesterday in the preliminary round for the intercollegiate golf championship.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 26. -- Flag Lieut. Thomas M. Brumby of the Olympia was to-day presented with a sword in recognition of his services at Manila. At an early hour the Reception Committee called on Lieut. Brumby at the Aragon Hotel.

The postal authorities at Washington have for many years insisted that their reports of the postal transactions of the country were true indicators of a condition of dullness or activity in business. From quarter to quarter of each year they have insisted, upon what to them appeared to be safe grounds, that the expansion or shrinkage of postal business was related intimately with all other business, and that no theory can put them down.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A committee appointed at the recent National Bankers' Convention, headed by F.W. Hayes of Detroit, is here to obtain, if possible, a reversal of the opinion rendered by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, holding that express companies selling domestic and foreign exchange are not compelled to pay the $50 annual war tax exacted of bankers dealing in such paper.

PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The jury summoned by Acting Coroner Allen to investigate the death of Mary Lagger and her child Rose, resulting from the burning of the steamboat Nutmeg State on Oct. 15, brought in a verdict tonight that the woman and child came to their death by drowning.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The Times publishes a letter from Rear Admiral Hubert Campion summarizing a story received from his nephew, now at Fort Churchill, Hudson Bay, which says that some Esquimaux traders up north some time ago shot two white men supposed to belong to the Andree expedition.
Miss Helen M. Gould has received a message asking her to organize a woman's committee to assist in raising funds for perpetuating the Dewey arch, but has as yet seat no reply.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Gen. Sir George Stewart White, according to a dispatch from Cape Town to The Daily Mail, will attack the Orange Free State forces in Natal as soon as Gen. Yule's men have rested. Strong British reinforcements are being sent up from the Cape.

Miss Helen Miller Gould has given $6,000 to the League for Social Service, to be used in the crusade against Mormonism. As a medium through which to use her money most effectively in aiding in the expulsion from Congress of Brigham H. Roberts, Miss Gould chooses the league because its definite object is the social and industrial advancement of the country.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The Chronicle will say to-morrow:

It is curious that the frantic efforts made by a majority of the French officers who appeared at Rennes to give what they called "evidence" and were permitted by the other officers on the bench to give as evidence, to affirm the guilt of DREYFUS and the sacredness of the "chose mal jugee," should have reacted so quickly upon themselves and the army which they have converted into a huge trades union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- G. Edmonston, a resident of Washington, several weeks ago wrote to the District Commissioners announcing that he had serious thoughts of purchasing a motor vehicle, but before doing so wished to ascertain if the authorities had any objection, and if the automobile would be considered in any way injurious to the well-being of Washington he was perfectly willing to forego his intentions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- War Department officials refuse to make public any of the provisions of the arrangement made by Gen. Bates with the Sultan of Sulu, the southernmost group of the Philippines, but state that its main features have been touched upon in the cabled press reports from Manila.

Under the will of Cornelius Vanderbilt, as made public last night, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt is made the heir of the bulk of his father's fortune, estimated at $70,000,000. Young Cornelius Vanderbilt is cut off with a direct gift of $500,000 and the income from a trust fund of $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A sharp controversy is being waged in this city over the question of public school methods. The issue is practically the same as in New York and most of the other large cities of the land, namely, the supersession of the old way of teaching the "three r's" by the "advanced" method, based on object lessons.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 26. -- The Marine Review to-morrow will say:

In a small store on West Eighth Street -- the number is 1,332 -- where he sells apples, pears, candy, and tobacco, can be found every day a man who was an important factor in the Harrison-Van Buren Presidential campaign of nearly sixty years ago. His name is H.J. Ogden, and notwithstanding his eighty years, his mind is as clear regarding that memorable event as if it had been only a year ago.

Judging from the work done in practice by the Columbia University football squad yesterday, the local collegians must be considered a factor in their game with Yale at Manhattan Field to-morrow afternoon.

Bids for $2,877,107.32 of 3 1/2 per cent. bonds of the City of New York were opened by the Sinking Fund Commission yesterday. These bonds are a part of the issue of $9,000,000 which was to have been sold on Oct. 18, but which was withdrawn on account of the prevalent tightness of the money market.
The Pulpit Committee of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church took definite action in the matter of a successor to the late Rev. Dr. John Hall at a meeting held on Wednesday night.

John Rice, nineteen years of age, of 75 Market Street, Manhattan, was arrested last night in Greenpoint, charged with kidnapping the two-year-old child of Mrs. Kate Simpson of 305 Oakland Street, Greenpoint.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The death of Gen. William Penn Symons, the British commander at Glencoe, who was shot in the stomach in the battle with the Boers there Oct. 20, was officially announced in the House of Commons to-day.

The second day of the Empire City Trotting Club's Autumn meeting furnished two exciting incidents. In the first heat of the first race there were eight starters, Woodford C. selling favorite at 12, with the field at 20. They were sent away to a very poor start, with Rifle and King Chimes in the lead and on even terms. These two raced like a team to the three-quarter pole.

In its issue of to-day The Engineering News publishes a picture and details of construction of a new locomotive for the Illinois Central Railroad, which is the largest ever constructed, and capable of drawing over any grade of the road for which it was built solid trains carrying 2,000 tons of paying freight, without counting the weight of the cars.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26. -- This is not football weather in Cambridge. The heat was almost oppressive to-day, and the 'Varsity was therefore allowed two short halves for line-up work, with preliminary practice in passing, punting, and falling on the ball. In spite of the heat, however, the play was fast and steady, and the second, although in good form, failed to make any gains worth speaking of.
"I look for certainly three years of undimmed prosperity, not only for the Granger roads, but for all freight carriers."

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The trials of the National Beagle Club to-day were again held on the W.C. Whitney place, but to-morrow the scene will be shifted back to the A.D. Lewis farm, at East Meadow.
Permit me to call your attention to the importance of the Constitutional amendment affecting the bonded indebtedness of cities, to be voted on at the approaching election.

Sir Henry Irving, Miss Ellen Terry, and almost the entire company of the English actor's organization arrived in this city yesterday morning. When the Atlantic Transport liner Marquette unloaded her passengers at the wharf they were undoubtedly the most notable gathering of stage celebrities that have reached these shores in some time.

Smith McNell's, the old down-town restaurant and hotel, will change hands shortly for the first time in its long career. It is one of the last of the old-time hotels to remain in the lower end of Manhattan, and has been a favorite lunching place for two generations of New Yorkers. The name of the prospective owner cannot yet be learned, but it is said to be a well-known hotel man of this city.

Whatever Lord SALISBURY has to say, from the height of his official position and the depth of his personal experience, about any question of "planetary polities" is sure to be worth the attention of serious readers. And so we make no apology for reprinting in full what he said at the beginning of the present session in the House of Lords upon the Transvaal question.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- The State Land Board at its meeting to-day granted the application of John J. Albright of Buffalo for a grant of fifty acres of land under water at Stony Point, just west of Buffalo, which territory abuts the site on which Buffalo's big steel plant is to be erected at a cost of $20,000,000.

Tammany Hall and its environs were the points toward which thousands of Democrats from all parts of the two boroughs on Manhattan Island swarmed last night to set their seal of approval on the ticket named at the recent County Convention and to pledge their support to the nominees on election day.

BUFFALO, Oct. 26. -- The Rev. Dr. Francis Lobdell died suddenly in Trinity Church rectory this morning as a result, it is believed, of laudanum taken for insomnia. He came to Trinity from St. Andrew's Church, New York City, twelve years ago. He was very prominent in church work, and had a large circle of friends.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The report that Lieut. Commander J.C. Colwell, the United States Naval Attache here, will soon be recalled is received with astonishment in London, where, owing to his exertions at the time of the Spanish war, he was probably better known than any former attache.

Sir Thomas Lipton, Secretary of War Elihu Root, and Capt. Robley D. Evans, United States Navy, were elected honorary members of the New York Yacht Club at their fifth general meeting in the Madison Avenue clubhouse last night. The gathering was a thoroughly representative one, and the various complimentary resolutions were received with the utmost enthusiasm.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The Tigers' last practice before the Cornell game was rather disappointing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The annual report of Commissioner Hermann of the General Land Office, made public to-day, shows a grand total of 929,308,088 acres of unappropriated and unreserved public land in the United States. The disposals of public lands during the fiscal year show an increase of 728,516 acres as compared with the aggregate of the previous year.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 26. -- Dollars rained for three minutes in the sale ring of the horse show to-day. The money was for Mrs. Kate Wilder Cross, widow of Charles S. Cross, founder of the Sunny Slope stock farm and one of the most noted breeders in the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The Navy Department has made public the report of Rear Admiral Charles O'Neill, Chief of Ordnance. It shows that no satisfactory bids have yet been received at the price of $400 a ton specified for the 24,000 tons of armor plate for the seven new war vessels authorized by Congress last year.

The New York Athletic Club "five" made their first appearance in the National League Tournament at Starr's alleys last night and were beaten in two games by the Americas of Newark and the Kings County team. Score:

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- In preparation for the Princeton game Cornell has as yet not done any work behind closed gates, and, as only light practice will be indulged in to-morrow, no secret playing is likely to take place.

Gen. Plet Joubert (Sliem Piet) is perhaps the second most prominent figure among the Boers. Long-headed, shrewd, cold, and calculating, he is also by no means a typical Boer. He has paid two or three visits to England, and perhaps is one of the three or four in the inner Government circles in Pretoria who realizes what war with England would mean.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 21. -- The Alaska Territorial Convention, which has been in session for more than a week, has adjourned. The most important work accomplished was the adoption of a memorial to Congress and the selection of John G. Price of Skaguay as a representative to go to Washington in the interest of the people in Alaska.

The New York State Medical Association brought its annual meeting to a close yesterday. Besides the reading of many papers, the annual election of officers was held, and several reports were made and committees appointed.
The New York Board of Fire Underwriters has issued a set of rules governing the installation and use of kerosene vapor lamps.
SCHENECTADY, Oct. 26. -- Col. William Fox, who is engaged in the work of compiling the records of all the regiments participating in the civil war, was here to-day.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The War Office to-day received the following telegrams from Gen. White.

BOSTON, Oct. 26. -- Leo Dietrichstein is surprised at A.C. Gunter's claim that his play, "The Song of the Sword," is taken from a novel entitled "The Gift of Bonaparte," written by 'Robert Shortz. Mr. Dietrichstein, who is at the Boston Museum, said to-day: "I never heard of Mr. Shortz or his book, 'The Gift of Bonaparte.'
The Gotham, Welcome, and Bleecker Clubs broke even in the series rolled in the Arlington National Tournament, at 19 St. Mark's Place, last night. Scores:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A committee representing the Woman's National Industrial and Patriotic League and the Washington Industrial League called upon Rear Admiral Schley to-night and informed him that the league had decided and was ready to undertake the task of procuring by popular subscription a home for him here at the National capital.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- The practice of the Yale Varsity football eleven today was probably the shortest on record. The candidates were given less than half an hour of work. The sun poured down on the field, and the warm weather seemed to take the vim out of the men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The resolutions adopted at a mass meeting held in Carnegie Hall, New York, Oct. 11, urging the President to offer the friendly services of the United States in mediation between Great Britain and the Transvaal and Orange Free State Republics, were presented to the President this afternoon by a delegation from New York, headed by Tunis G. Bergen, President of the Holland Society.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The Democratic County Convention, which was held at Orange last night, made a funny mistake. In nominating the eleven candidates for Assembly the convention followed the district plan, and when the representatives from an imaginary district agreed upon a man the rest of the delegates voted for him.

At Aqueduct yesterday four heavily played favorites in the first four races went down in defeat, and until Bangor scored a victory for the talent by winning the fifth race, it looked as if the bookmakers were going to have a field day.

President MCKINLEY may well regard his Secretary of the Treasury with mingled feelings. He certainly finds in him a sympathetic supporter of his general policy, and the Secretary's record in the purely fiscal branch of his work is highly creditable, and greatly strengthens the Administration.
Brig. Gen. Guy V. Henry of the United States Army is seriously ill at his home, 139 Madison Avenue.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The University of Pennsylvania football players arrived in Chicago this morning for Saturday's University of Chicago game.

CARLISLE, Penn., Oct. 26. -- The Indian football team departed for their fight with Harvard shortly after noon with roars of enthusiasm from the school's students singing in their ears. The men will stop at Auburnville, a short distance out from Cambridge, and intend to spend the whole day Friday in secret practice. Overtraining will be studiously avoided, and the day will be devoted to finishing off several new tricks lately devised by Coach Warner.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26. -- While the Missionary Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church was to-day considering a resolution to make a rule requiring stated contributions to the missionary fund, the Rev. W. McKnight of Elmira, N.Y., commented on the advantage the English Church has over the American Church, because of its connection with the Government, and intimated that he would like to see the union of the Church and State in this country.

PLATTSBURG, Oct. 26. -- The total registration of Clinton County is 13,531, an increase of 507 over last year. This is the largest registration in the history of the county. Each party claims to see an advantage in it. The increase in the Republican towns of Au Sable, Blackbrook, Chazy, Ellenburgh, and Mooers is 350, and the only Democratic towns that show increases are Altona, Beekmantown, and Saranac, where the gain is only 150.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- Several delayed dispatches from Pretoria arrived here this morning via Lorenzo Marques. Among them are the following:
We trust that all our readers will give heed to the letter of Controller COLER in another column.

Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt has bought, through Leopold Weil, from William B. Franke the Monticello apartment house, at the northeast corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, a seven-story structure on a plot 100.2 by 125. The price is reported at $420,000. Mr. Hewitt has in recent years been a large investor in apartment house properties along the west side and north of Central Park.

Charles Reade's great novel "Peg Woffington" will shortly be brought out in an elaborate edition by the Doubleday McClure Company. There will be seventy illustrations by Hugh Thomson, also initial letters and a cover design by the same artist. Mr. Austin Dobson has written a characteristically happy introduction to the work. It will be recalled that Mr. Thomson recently illustrated an edition of Jane Austen.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- The annual Autumn ball took place here to-night in the circuit ballroom, which was beautifully decorated with Autumn leaves, palms, and evergreens. Two orchestras played on each side of the room alternately. At 9:30 o'clock the cottagers with their guests began to assemble at the clubhouse.

William F. Ellis was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday by Detectives Price and Hoffman of the Central Office, charged with obtaining $45,000 from the First National Bank of Washington, Penn., by means of forged notes. Ellis gave his address as Boston, and the detectives say that he is well-known in society in Washington, Philadelphia, and Baltimore.

Cornelius Vanderbilt made it plain in a statement which he gave out last evening that he did not think he had received anything more than was justly due him as the result of the action of his brother Alfred in transferring to him about $6,000,000 of their father's estate.

Your editorial article of week before last on "Autumn with the Poets" was the something that all unconsciously we were awaiting. You voiced a feeling that was but waiting for a voice. 'Twas like a breeze escaped from the usual paths, and made many "thoughts" begin "to rustle" beside Thoreau's, bringing down such a shower of beautiful Autumn thoughts, which, like the leaves, only needed the releasing touch.

The novel that Mrs. Humphry Ward has been at work on for over a year is now completed. It will make its first appearance in Harper's Magazine, beginning with the January number. Although dealing freely with contemporary thought as swayed by the political and religious questions, the main theme is purely a love story the evolution of which rests quite as much on human passion as on human faith.

A posthumous work by the author of "Natural Law in the Spir itual World" is in preparation by Dodd, Mead Co. It will be called "The New Evangelism." Henry Drummond in his "Natural Law in the Spiritual World" made use of his great scientific knowledge to prove by analogy the phenomena of spiritual existence, and everybody will recall with what profound respect mingled with enthusiasm his work was received by churchmen throughout the world.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 27. -- Superintendent W.F. Davis has resigned from the Newport Golf Club and will sever his connection with the club on Nov. 1, after having served since the club was organized. Mr. Davis will go to the Washington Golf Club for the Winter, and for next year he has made no definite plans, as he has received a number of offers from the leading golf clubs of the country.

May Irwin began her annual engagement at the Bijou Theatre last night amid a tumult of welcoming applause. She retains her vogue, and has lost none of the skill and personal force that established it. Her new three-act farce is called "Sister Mary," (the title, by the way, of a drama by Clement Scott, in which Julia Arthur acted at the American Theatre some years ago,) and Glen Macdonough built it to order for her.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27. -- Mrs. P.W. Patton, wife of Capt. Patton, whose vessel, the American ship George B. Stetson, was burned at sea off the coast of Formosa two months ago, has arrived here, and tells a graphic story of the destruction of the vessel. She was the only woman aboard.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Christian Engle, father of Miss Marie Engle, the opera singer, died at Engleside, Mich., Wednesday, at the age of seventy-five. He was for many years a resident of Chicago, acting as private secretary to A.A. Munger for part of the time. He was born in France, and came to America in 1831.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The Berlin cablegram to-night, intimating that the German delegates to the Commercial Congress in this city have complained to the Congress that United States Consuls in Germany "exact illegally high fees" doubtless refers to the report of the German-Austrian-American Commission which has been presented to the Congress, and which awaits action by that body before being made public.

Efforts are being made to induce the Railroad Committees of the Board of Aldermen and the Municipal Council to meet and take action in the matter of the franchise to enable the Long Island Railroad to build the proposed tunnel under the East River to the Flatbush Avenue Station in Brooklyn.

The letter of "E.S.F.," in your SATURDAY REVIEW of the 21st inst., referring to the article "Autumn with the Poets," entitled "Poe and Sarah Helen Whitman," recalled the eccentric figure of Mrs. Whitman as she stood at the gate of her residence in 1858, after listening to the poem, then just delivered in Manning Hall as the poet of his class by John Hay.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27. -- The eve of the Indian game finds almost as much excitement in Cambridge as is usually witnessed on the night before a championship match, and it is not to be wondered at, for to-morrow's game promises to be one of the hardest fights that a Crimson football team has ever had.

Edwin Markham has returned from California, bringing his family with him. They will reside hereafter in the Borough of Brooklyn, where the poet has taken up a residence. The Harpers-McClure syndicate probably decided that move.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 27. -- One of the oldest banking houses west of the Alleghanies, that of David A. Sayre Co., made an assignment to the Safety Vault and Trust Company here to-day. The liabilities and assets are unknown.
LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Florence Marryat, the well-known author, known in private life as Mrs. Francis Lean, died in London this morning.

The last Congress, in demanding that the three new battleships authorized by it to he added to the navy should not only exceed in displacement any of those previously authorized and completed or begun, but should have the highest practicable speed, undoubtedly reflected the educated opinion of the Navy Department, an opinion strengthened by recent experience.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- The trials of the National Beagle Club to-day were long-drawn-out, owing to the scarcity of game on the A.D. Lewis and other near-by farms hunted over. The game on W.C. Whitney's place had been plentiful all the week, but the ground is so heavily covered with bushes that it was thought the pack events could be tried to better advantage in the more open country.

In its current issue Paper mentions the rumor of a monster news paper manufacturing concern, "which, so far as mill equipment is concerned, will overtop all others." A company is said to be organized which is to enter the news paper producing field, and which will build a twenty-machine plant on a water power which is never failing.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Rain or shine, on a slippery gridiron, Chicago and Pennsylvania will line up to-morrow afternoon. This will be the first game ever played on a Western field by one of the "Big Four" universities of the East.

From time to time you have had so much to say in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW about first editions that I have become interested to the extent of buying several books, thinking they were such; but, in the absence of specific knowledge, I begin to have doubts.
The reports of the commercial agencies bear striking testimony to the continued presence of good times and the wideness of their extent.

ALBANY, Oct. 27. -- The suit brought by Joseph Campbell and others, as executors to William Campbell, to recover $1,489,500 from the New York Life Insurance Company, was to-day decided by the Court of Appeals in favor of the insurance company. The judgment of the lower court, dismissing the complaint, is affirmed, with costs.

On looking over THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Oct. 21, I read eagerly the letters written by some of your readers on "Autumn with the Poets," hoping to find some mention of Thomson's poem on the "Seasons," particularly Autumn, but was disappointed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The coming year will be marked by the greatest trade activity the steel and iron interests of the country have ever known, according to the predictions of executive officials in this industry. Every mill in the United States, so is the forecast, will run throughout the year, furnishing steady employment to many thousands of men.

"No," said the librarian, "we haven't a copy of 'David Harum,' and we don't expect to get one. There isn't money enough on hand to buy all the solid literature we ought to have for the library, to say nothing of novels."

Competitors for the prizes of $500, $200, and $100 offered by "Responsibility" and guaranteed by The Sun are reminded that the time for the submission of manuscripts expired on Oct. 15, a week ago yesterday.

Unless Starter Pettingill gets his fields off in better time the officials of the Queens County Jockey Club will be compelled some evening to declare off the last event, in order to get the racing over within the required sunset limit. Yesterday when the day's sport ended it was dangerously close to sundown.

I have been interested in your recent SATURDAY REVIEW editorial article and letters on "Autumn with the Poets," and venture to send a word from South Carolina. On arriving in Aiken I was surprised to find that after the long Summer months of dry and unusual heat, the Autumn coloring was most exquisite and varied.

In part payment for the Monticello apartment house, at the northeast corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt gave the Hotel Cecil property, at the southeast corner of One Hundred and Eighteenth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The latter, which is a five-story structure on a plot 118 by 124 by 100 by 61, figured in the trade at about $200,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The books of Recorder Simon to-day bear the record of a first mortgage to secure $10,000,000 6 per cent. sinking fund twenty-year gold bonds given by the American Hide and Leather Company, a corporation of New York, by George A. Hill, President, and Robert S. Greer, Secretary, to the Colonial Trust Company of New York as trustee.

Senator MASON has the right idea of his course in regard to the policy of his party. He proposes at the earliest practicable moment to appeal to the people of Illinois, if his party and he shall sharply differ.

"All the world loves a lover," says Emerson. The interest of the world is more than doubled when there are two lovers "and these two are truly one. Witness the delight, the cordial welcome that has greeted the published letters of Robert Browning and Elizabeth Barrett, a work that stands by itself, unique, without precedent and likely to remain long without a parallel.
The letter from Mr. Henry A. Newberry, which you entitle "Anstey His Idol." at least throws a good deal of light upon some things not accessible in the books of facts -- encyclopedias of anecdote,

In THE SATURDAY REVIEW for Oct. 21, under the title "Autumn with the Poets," a poem by Sarah Helen Whitman is given as entire. I have a copy, taken verbatim from the original, which appeared quite forty years ago. There are two words which I find changed in the printed copy, and changed in both cases for the worse.

At the Broadway Athletic Club last night Referee "Johnny" White's decision making a draw of the twenty-five-round bout between Matty Matthews of this city and Eddie Connolly of St. Johns, New Brunswick, was decidedly unpopular.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Agnes, Forty-third Street, near Lexington Avenue, which was damaged by fire last December to the extent of about $50,000, and has been rebuilt and improved, will be formally blessed to-morrow. At 11 o'clock Archbishop Corrigan will sing high pontifical mass, and Bishop McFaul of Trenton will preach the sermon.

Brig. Gen. Guy Vernor Henry, United States Army, who until recently was Military Governor of the Island of Puerto Rico, died at 3:50 o'clock yesterday morning at his home, 139 Madison Avenue. Pneumonia, which developed from a cold contracted nine days ago, was the cause of his death.
Mr. MAZET has appeared before the voters of his district to present his claims to re-election. We do not think that he hag made a strong case.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Lord Rosebery in a speech said yesterday that in his opinion the Transvaal was not a very complicated question, but merely the effort of a community to "put back the clock." Referring to Majuba Hill, Lord Rosebery said Mr. Gladstone's action was determined by the belief that the power of Great Britain was so great that she could afford to do things other nations could not afford to do without risk.

The debate on the address in reply to the Queen's speech, with which the session of Parliament opened, was both entertaining and instructive. Perhaps, upon the whole, it was more entertaining than instructive, but it did not lack for instructiveness. We have already given in full the remarks of Lord SALISBURY in the House of Lords, because these constitute the most authoritative statement of the "case" of the British Government.
The police of the West Twentieth Street Station believe that they have stopped a large swindling scheme by which several men have been victimized.

It appears, therefore, that Robespierre was born on May 6, 1758. Atrecht, in the Departement Pas de Calais, was at that time a prosperous town situated in the midst of a flourishing agricultural district. A tradition exists that the family of Robespierre had emigrated from Ireland after the battle of the Boyne, and that their name was formerly Robertspeare.

The editorial article in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW entitled "Autumn with the Poets" contained many remarks in accordance with my own thoughts on the subject in question. I have noticed a dearth of Autumn poetry, and it almost "passeth understanding" why so many poets should revel in Spring and sing its praises, while Autumn is scarcely noticed.

PALMYRA, Oct. 27. -- Elaborate preparations were made for the welcome to-day of Rear Admiral William T. Sampson to his birthplace in this village. Banners swung across the streets, in every window the Admiral's picture was displayed, and the people of Palmyra had fully 20.000 visitors to honor the man who but fifty years ago trudged around the streets of this village sawing wood for a living.

I desire to second the motion made by Agnes E. Blanchard in your SATURDAY REVIEW of Oct. 21, under the heading of "A Book to Stand by Elia's Side." The suggestion is such an excellent one that I hope you will adept it and thus preserve for book lovers many of the good things which THE SATURDAY REVIEW puts before us.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- A special dispatch from Cape Town to-day gives details of the defeat of 700 Boers by the British north of Kimberley, in which the enemy was completely routed with heavy loss, the British loss being three men killed and twenty-one men, including two officers, wounded. The Boer losses are described as very heavy.

I want to add my voice to the chorus of praise of that charming editorial article on "Autumn with the Poets." I enjoy THE SATURDAY REVIEW more and more, and find it a most helpful guidance in the purchase of books. The amount I can use for this purpose is limited, and I have to be careful to put it "where it will do the most good."

Allow me to add my little say to the enthusiasm over the Autumn days. Shortly before your editorial article on "Autumn with the Poets" appeared, we had been talking of the sadness that poets had thrown over the Autumn season, and we thought that it was for these reasons:

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27. -- A man dressed in a blue suit, about forty-five years of age, who was provided with a pair of overalls, tape line, and measures, robbed the nurses of the Memorial Hospital yesterday afternoon. He had been gone several hours before the robbery was discovered.

Mr. Editor, you are a canny man. When you want four columns of selected poems on Autumn what do you do? Do you set the chubby office boy to thumbing over Dana's "Household Book of Poetry" for timely verses? Do you whirl round in your office chair, and, reaching up for Bartlett's "Familiar Quotations," extract therefrom enough seasonable copy for your purpose?

I desire to submit to a jury of your bookmaking readers a question concerning the use of the apostrophe in dialect typography. Maybe the matter is not one of great importance in itself, but uniformity of style is one of the traditions and indeed, necessities of the printing house. I had some trouble lately in adjusting the differences between the intelligent linotypist and myself and between him and his fellows in their apostrophe practice.

Adolph Peabody, a jeweler, is practically under parole to the local Treasury officials to appear on Monday before Collector Bid-well and give full information as to a quantity of diamonds appraised at $15,000, nearly all of which he brought to the Custom House on a hint from a Treasury agent that his best interests would be served in so doing.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27. -- The senior class of Yale University elected its Commencement officers this evening as follows:

One of Mr. Perry's characters is a man in search of adjectives by which to describe life. The first he finds that seems to him suitable is droll -- life is droll; then after an experience of common, wretched, every-day tragedy, he tries pitiful -- life is pitiful. Finally the heroism of a little gutter boy in saving a dog inspires the adjective divine, and there is life -- droll, pitiful, and divine.

All the campaign managers are greatly interested just now in reports of the shifting of voters from certain districts in this city, in which there is a plethora of one kind of electors, to certain other districts in which electors of the same political faith are too few to place victory within the range of probability.

ITHACA, Oct. 27. -- Contrary to expectations, the 'Varsity eleven went into secret practice this afternoon. At the close of the under-class track meet all the 'Varsity football men were ordered off the grounds, so that little could be learned of the work. Starbuck and Young spent some time in catching and kicking punts.

The Nineteenth Assembly District, in which Tammany Hall is concentrating all its energies toward defeating Robert Mazet for the Assembly, was the scene last evening of an intense political battle. The whole district was ablaze with torchlights and illuminated transparencies, and there were drums and fifes in active operation sufficient to lead an army corps.

Neither in your charming editorial article on "Autumn With the Poets," nor in the interesting letters called forth by the same, do I see any reference to the beauties of October in this Southland -- October, when Nature pulls herself together again after the long fever of Summer, and we have a Spring without the enervation, an awakening to life without the steam of rain-soaked ground and the fervent heat of the growing sun.
DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 27. -- The Rev. G.E. Morrison was hanged to-day at Vernon, Texas, for wife murder. He protested his innocence to the last.

It probably amounts to the same thing, but the quotation from Johnson in your article in this week's SATURDAY REVIEW, in "New and Notable Fiction," is not verbally accurate. You make Johnson say:
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 27. -- A number of prominent German citizens recently addressed an invitation to Carl Schurz to deliver an address in Cincinnati. The following reply was received to-day:

While I do not agree with your correspondent Henry A. Newberry's estimate of the humor of Stockton, Twain, and others, I am tempted to indorse his opinion of F. Anstey. The stories selected by Mr. Newberry, however, are not the funniest that Anstey has written. The humorous subtleties of "Tourmalin's Time Cheques," its romping fun and genuinely mirthful incidents entitle it to a high place among humorous books.
Let me add a word or so to the few lines I interjected on the Dutchess affair.

Hamerton's "Intellectual Life," "done into a book by the Roycrofters and finished this third day of October, 1899," has just come to us in a sumptuously printed volume which, with its double-columned page, is strongly suggestive of William Morris, and the work of the Kelmscott Press. Indeed, there are many suggestions of Morris and his influence in much of the Roycroft work.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The third reading of the Appropriation bill in the House of Commons to-day gave the opportunity for further attacks on the Government's war policy. Gavin Brown Clark, (Radical,) formerly Consul General of the Transvaal, accused the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, of publishing an emasculated version of the Boer Franchise bill passed by the Volksraad.
The experts that watched the work in practice of the Columbia University football squad yesterday say Yale will meet her strongest opponents of the season at Manhattan Field this afternoon.

Returning to America after many years of dull European Autumns, I was so struck by the color-smitten glory of our October woods and fields that I cried out: "Where are our nature poets and where are our great colorists?"
