Considered in strict military sense as an affaire de metier, there were three officers in the Southern service, Thomas Jonathan Jackson, Joseph Eccleston Johnston, and Nathan Bedford Forrest, who were soldiers with a genius for war. The first two, Jackson and Johnston, had the inestimable advantage which only education gives.

What of the condition of the man who has written some 160 lines entitled "Man, Whence and Where?" John P. Morris of Providence, R.I., the author, is a bricklayer, and he writes that he "never had the advantage of school education. But I love books," and he adds: "As you would say if you saw my collection, and I also love to write my thoughts, and I seem best able to do so in verse."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 27. -- "Shall America Enforce and Maintain Sovereignty Over the Philippines?" was the question discussed to-night before the Outlook Club in Montclair Club Hall. The Rev. Lyman Abbott, D.D., of New York, spoke in the affirmative and the Rev. A.A. Berle, D.D., pastor of the Brighton Congregational Church, Boston, in the negative. Dr. Abbott said, in part:

Is an automobile victoria-phaeton a pleasure carriage within the meaning of the Central Park rules? Winslow E. Buzby argues that it is. The Park Commissioners are in doubt about it. Police Captain England of the Arsenal Station declares emphatically that it is not. To clear up any possible doubt upon the subject Mr. Buzby had himself arrested yesterday afternoon.

A surprise in the shape of $35,000 has come to John A. Schaefer, a bartender at 8 Barclay Street. He received the news of his sudden fortune Wednesday, when a letter came to him from the law firm of Klos Vanderhoeven of Berlin, stating that his uncle, Hermann Schaefer had died in that city on Sept. 29 last, and left a will making him his sole heir.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Belated dispatches from Tuli Fort partially elucidate the situation on the Rhodesian border. It appears that Col. Plumer ascertained that all the Zoutpansberg Boers, numbering 700 men, mustered under Pier Joubert, at the Brack River, and proceeded to Limpopo River, where they arrived Oct. 16, accompanied by a number of armed Shangaan and Zoutpansberg Kafirs, whom they had compelled to take up arms.

It is surely a remarkable fact that the "Father of Realism," Honore de Balzac, half a century after his death, is having three, more or less complete, editions of his entire works presented in translation before the English-speaking world. In England Prof. George Saintsbury is editing an edition, which is considered one of the most elaborate efforts of bookmaking of the day.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The Parliamentary bye-election for the Bow and Bromley Division of Tower Hamlets, London, held today to replace Lionel R. Holland, Conservative, was fought on the Government's Transvaal policy, and resulted in a big victory for the Government, the Conservative candidate, William Guthrie, being elected by 4,328 votes, against 2,123 votes cast for his Liberal and Radical opponent, Harold Spender.

In your SATURDAY REVIEW of to-day you give unconsciously a tremendous impetus to the waning Baconian malady. You and Mrs. B.W. Hunt in her beautiful poem on Autumn, Page 708, have done it. For who can gainsay that by your caption, "Did You Write It, or Did I?" you prove that a doubt of the Shakespearean authorship exists?

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- At the Hurst Park October meeting to-day Sweet Balsam won the Stewards' Nursery Handicap, with Sloan up. Beatrice Maude and Adele were second and third, respectively. Fifteen horses ran. The betting was 7 to 1 against Sweet Balsam.

Dr. John D. McGill, President of the Jersey City Police Board, was summoned to Baltimore, Md., on Friday night by his brother, Chancellor Alexander T. McGill, who is a patient at Johns Hopkins Hospital under the care of Prof. Ossler. Dr. McGill said the Chancellor had improved somewhat since he went to Baltimore, but is still a sick man.

Morris Phillips, whose sincerity and sympathy with earnest artistic effort are not to be disputed, writes as follows in his paper, The Home Journal, of the dramatization of "The Children of the Ghetto":

The campaign in the Nineteenth Assembly District was continued yesterday with no let-up on either side. There were three meetings last evening -- one held by the Republicans, at Sixty-third Street and Columbus Avenue, and the others by the Democrats and Citizens' Union, a Sixty-fifth Street and Broadway and Sixty-ninth Street and West End Avenue.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 30. -- The mail service between New South Wales, New Zealand, and San Francisco has recently come under the review of the New Zealand Parliament, that colony being a co-contributor with New South Wales to the subsidiary which is paid annually to the service which has now been running to and from San Francisco for over twenty years.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Late to-day it was learned from an absolutely reliable source that Prince Hohenlohe had agreed to the following new naval programme, and that the Government, the Emperor consenting, will present the programme to the Reichstag between 1901 and 1903:
LONDON, Oct. 28. -- All our thoughts this week have been absorbed by the war in South Africa.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to --

A very considerable number of earnest men and women in this country have been devoting themselves, apparently with increasing activity, to the presentation of such a remonstrance against the seating of BRIGHAM H. ROBERTS of Utah as a Representative in Congress, as will prevail upon the membership of the House of Representatives to refuse to permit him to be sworn in.

Some speculation is indulged in by those who are considering the possible effect of the war in South Africa upon the gold supply and the consequent diminution of gold money. The interest in this problem does not appear to have become intense in the Exchanges, and the report of the Director of the Mint for 1898 justifies the tranquillity in quarters that might be expected to be sensitive if there were any occasion for alarm.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 28. -- Nebraska is today the battlefield of political giants. Never before in the history of the State has Democracy made such heroic efforts to win a campaign or retain its prestige with the voters. The silver-tongued orators of the Democratic cause are engaged in the battle in desperate earnestness.

Charges of collusion between physicians attached to free clinics and some of the opthalmic hospitals and certain opticians, whereby the physicians obtain a commission from the sale of glasses to poor patients have been made by Louis L. Ferguson, President of the Optical Society.
The American theatrical "invasion" of England still seems to be a burning topic in London. "W.J.L." writes entertainingly of the historical aspect of the matter in The Stage:

Columbia Oval, as Manhattan Field is to be formally christened in the near future, was yesterday afternoon the scene of one of the most disastrous defeats Yale has ever experienced in her athletic career. It was also the scene of the most notable victory in the recent athletic history of Columbia.

-- We notice with regret that our Gallic neighbor, The Courrier des Etats-Unis, is endeavoring to identify itself with the more inestimable section of the Parisian press by echoing the rabid denunciations of the soldier statesman who is now doing so much to persuade the world that there is still a saving element in the French Army strong enough to raise that organization from the slough of disgrace into which it has fallen.
The following address was delivered on Friday evening before the International Commercial Congress at Philadelphia by Ulysses D. Eddy of this city:

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- The fight for 25,000f. between Charlemont, the French champion, and "Jerry" Driscoll, former champion of the British Navy, this afternoon, resulted in a victory for the former. There was a great crowd present, and the fighting was very hot for six rounds.

The Fusion anti-Tammany ticket was ratified last night by a meeting held at Cooper Union under the auspices of the Citizens' Union. The speakers represented the Citizens' Union, the City Club, the Republican County Committee, and the Independent Labor Party, and the audience, judging from its manifestations, was fairly distributed among these elements, with a preponderance on the labor side.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 28. -- For the first time in the history of Newport a woman has been nominated for the position of School Committee member, and this honor has fallen to the lot of Mrs. Victor Sorchan, one of the leading cottagers of the city, and one who has done so much for the public schools here.

Mr. Karl Ondricek is the new second violin of the Kneisel Quartet, taking the place of Mr. Otto Roth, retired. After his first appearance with the quartet last week, Mr. W.F. Apthorp wrote the following illuminative criticism for The Boston Transcript:

ROME, Oct. 13. -- European papers and scientific magazines are occupying themselves pretty generally at the present moment with criticisms concerning the great ship canal which is destined to connect the Baltic with the Black Sea, work on which was begun last year by the Russian Government, and is being pushed forward with the greatest zeal, and at the same time with a quietness amounting almost to secrecy.

The constellations in the November evening sky are those of the fourth quarter of the heavens west of the meridian and those of the first quarter east of it. The arbitrary lines which divide the sky into four equal lune-shaped areas are those passing through the equinoctial and solstitial points, or the points occupied by the sun about March 20, June 20, Sept. 22, and Dec. 21.

La Lorrame, the steamship now building for the French Line, is rapidly drawing near completion, and will make her first trip to this port probably during March next. The new vessel is the first of two sister ships which are building at St. Nazaire designed to meet the provisions in point of speed and other naval reserve requirements of the French Government under a subsidy act.

This is the season of the year when with the pleasure of shopping for handsome gowns comes the pleasure of selecting the dressings for the house, and chief among them the carpets. The carpet season has changed with other things in New York life. Where at one time Spring was the season for such work, it is not now until Fall.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28. -- The list of students at Yale this year, which is just published, offers several interesting opportunities for study, both in the relative changes in the attendance of the men and in their geographical distribution.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 28. -- Biela's Comet has been seen here with the naked eye.

A plan for the Manhattan approach to the new East River Bridge, which includes the opening of a new 110-foot street from the triangle south of Cooper Union to the corner of Norfolk and Delancey Streets, will be submitted to the Board of Public Improvements at its next meeting.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Samoa continues to exercise the press, which indulged this week in the wildest surmises. On the authority of the Foreign Office and United States Ambassador White, it can be said that the present situation is that the negotiations between Berlin and Washington some time ago reached a satisfactory agreement, and those between Berlin and London are progressing satisfactorily.

ALBANY, Oct. 28. -State Engineer A. Bond is paying great attention to the matter of construction of good roads, and has just issued a bulletin calling attention to the necessity of great care after the roads are constructed. He says;
HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The windup of the National Beagle Club's trials today was held on the W.C. Whitney place. The game was exceedingly plentiful.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28. -- In one of the hardest fought and most exciting football games ever played on Soldiers' Field, Harvard defeated the Carlisle Indians this afternoon by the score of 22 to 10. It was a battle royal, with careful and scientific football pitted against indomitable courage and physical prowess combined with the cleverest drop kicking in the world, and science came out the victor.

We recently quoted in THE TIMES an article from The Engineering News commenting on recent construction of large locomotives, in which the writer expressed the opinion that in the present conditions freight in bulk over low-grade roads could be carried at a lower rate than on any inland waterway, canal, or river in the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Maryland campaign is coming to a close, and the predictions of those people who expected the treatment of Rear Admiral Schley to be made an issue have not been verified. This is due to Admiral Schley himself. The idea of being mixed up in party politics is distasteful to a man who, like Dewey, is simply a plain, blunt sailor, with no liking for politics or politicians.

Wall Street has been waiting all the week for a bad bank statement. It was, indeed, a fashionable forecast that surplus reserves would be wiped out in the Clearing House exhibit due yesterday. Not merely the professional pessimists have been counting on such a depressing showing, but even interests having abiding confidence in the intrinsic healthfulness of the business situation were apprehensive.

You were kind enough to republish on the 13th inst. an article which I sent you apropos of the Barbara Frietchie controversy, and which appeared soon after Whittier's death in The Frederick (Md.) Examiner, having been written by Mrs. Shriver Tompkins, now Mrs. Rives of 905 Cathedral Street, Baltimore, who was a friend of Whittier, and also knew Barbara Frietchie personally.

James Peoncea. an Italian employed in the Street Cleaning Department and living at 36 Baxter Street, was before ,Magistrate Meade. in the Jefferson ,Market Police Court yesterday, charged by hls wife Julia vlth abandonment and non-support. After a recital of marital woes by the wife, Peontea said that instead of being the offender he was the offended.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 28. -- Gov. Roosevelt has come and gone, and the practical results of his visit are being figured out. The Republicans claim that his words of encouragement had the effect of solidifying the party vote, besides bringing recruits to the ranks from the independents. The Democrats say that their cause has not suffered by the presence in Maryland of New York's Executive.

President Clinton L. Rossiter of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company yesterday announced additional prospective changes in the operation of the company's system. One of the most important of these will a through five-cent fare from Manhattan to Coney Island on the elevated roads. The present fare is 10 cents.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Oct. 28. -- State College won her fourth game here to-day by defeating Dickinson by the score of 15 to 0. The game was hotly contested from beginning to end, and was marked with numerous brilliant plays. The visitors could not withstand State's line bucking, and it was only by the superb kicking of Han that they were able to hold State down as they did.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- It is not often that the Government enters into competition with the comic papers, but The Daily Bulletin of the Post Office Department to-day is full of humor. Yesterday The Bulletin announced the creation of a Post Office in the Indian Territory named Story, "Special from Beefsteak."
Cornelius Vanderbilt talked yesterday as a railroad man in the offices of the Superintendent of Motive Power and Rolling Stock at the Grand Central Station.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The teams of the Universities of Chicago and Pennsylvania played football for two hours and a half this afternoon on a sawdust arena to the intense delight of some 5,000 on the wet and soggy stands, and about 100 others who shrieked from adjacent roofs and telegraph poles.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The Tribune to-day prints a summary of the situation in the Philippine Islands from its special correspondent there. The letter, which is dated Manila, Sept. 14, says:

The three men and the young woman arrested on Friday by the West Twentieth Street Station police on charges of swindling, were arraigned in the Jefferson darket Court yesterday, where they met other complainants, who wished to put in claims of having been swindled out of thousands of dollars.

SYDNEY, Sept. 27. -- Bequests of books and pictures to the Australian people are comparatively rare, for although the colonists are great readers, the number of book and picture collectors is limited, good paintings in a Sydney auction room bringing as many shillings as they would dollars in New York. In Melbourne prices are somewhat better.

" Talk about being beautiful," said the woman, "if it is for the sake of gaining a husband, not of course in the mercenary, must-have-a-husband-to-support-me or the don't-want-to-be-an-old-maid sense, but in the way every girl looks forward to some Prince Charming who is to be the only man in the world to her some time, there doesn't seem to be much of a question of beauty in it.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28. -- The marriage on Wednesday of Miss Ella Johnson Keer and Mr. Randolph Hicks was quite a pretty one. The bride is the daughter of the late Charles G. Keer and the niece of Mrs. Thomas Morris. Her little cousin, Mary Camilla McKim, was one of the flower girls.

Is not the communication, "Another City Nuisance," in your issue of Oct. 26, an assault upon a practice rendered necessary by conditions concerning which the communication is wholly silent? City mud would, of course, be non-existent but for the preexistence of city dust, which, as every one knows, consists mainly of finely divided earthy particles from our macadamized thoroughfares.

Your good-humored and slightly contemptous editorial of this morning on "Golden Rule" Jones might leave the reader under the impression that the platform on which Mayor Jones stands in his candidacy for the Governorship of Ohio is nothing more politically practical than the Golden Rule. This impression would be a mistake.

GERMANY'S REAL ATTITUDE TOWARD SAMOA. -- About ten days ago the German press, with singular unanimity, declared that the Imperial Government desired to do away with the tri-dominium in regard to Samoa, which had been maintained by herself, Great Britain, and the United States. It was plainly put that Germany desired a partition of the islands, she retaining absolute control over Upolu, for which compensation would be rendered to the other powers interested.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 28. -- With little more than a week left before the voting begins, the result of the election in Kentucky is uncertain now as it was two months ago. Both sides claim it by about 40,000 majority, but it is extremely doubtful if the winner has more than 10,000 votes to spare.
At Aqueduct yesterday the third race came near being fatal to some of the jockeys, and it did result in the death of one of the horses.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The transfer of "El Capitan" to the Comedy Theatre will have additional interest in the fact that De Wolf Hopper will have the opportunity to display his comedy talents. For this purpose W.H. Post, whose travesties are well known at the Lambs' gambols, has prepared a travesty on "The Degenerates," in which Marion Giroux will take a Langtry part and Hopper the leading male role.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 28. -- Miss Frances L. Wood has resigned her position as teacher in the North Street District School on account of the gossip which arose among the residents of that neighborhood when it became known that she rode a man's bicycle and wore divided skirts. The parents of the children feared lest the example of the teacher in this garb should have a bad influence.

As all the elevens of the "big four" were scored against yesterday, and two of them -- Yale and Princeton -- were beaten, no football team now has a clean record. Harvard still leads in the total number of points scored as against its opponents, but Yale and Princeton, though beaten, have had fewer points scored against them.

There was much that was suggestive in the interview reported a day or two ago with Col. FROST, of one of the new regiments, a Captain in the army, who has taken part in all the campaigning in Luzon. According to this officer, the chief disadvantage which our troops have to contend with is the superior mobility of the Filipinos.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The appellate Division of the Supreme Court has reversed Surrogate Theodore H. Silkman of Westchester County, who confirmed the report of Frank L. Young, the appraiser of the estate of Joseph Thorne of this village. Mr. Thorne was the inventor of the typesetting machine which bears his name, and of sewing and other machines.
LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The lull in the news from Ladysmith, Natal, which was beginning to be regarded as ominous, has at length been broken by a Cape Town dispatch, under this morning's date, saying:
The second series of games in the Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling League tournament were rolled at Reid's alleys, 200 Church Street, yesterday afternoon.

After an absence of eight months, spent in a careful investigation of industrial conditions in Great Britain and Continental Europe, Robert P. Porter was a passenger on the American Line steamer St. Louis, which arrived yesterday. When seen at his home, 36 East Sixty-fifth Street, Mr. Porter said:

Col. Albert L. Mills, Superintendent of the West Point Military Academy, whose bravery at San Juan brought an almost mortal wound, saw a great deal of the roughest kind of Indian campaigning in the Northwest. Col. Mills found time the other day when seen at West Point to recount some of the incidents in his Indian experience.

In a bower of crimson, russet, and golden leaves the handiwork of that peerless artist Nature, interspersed with brilliant yellow chrysanthemums and "Old Glory" ingeniously intertwined with the Union Jack of Old England, the members of the Lotos Club entertained Sir Henry Irving at a banquet at their clubhouse last night.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Cornell defeated Princeton in a decisive manner this afternoon by the score of 5 to 0. The score was made by George Young, the little quarter back, who took the ball and kicked clean goal from the field. In the latter part of the second half Cornell had the pigskin on Princeton's twenty-yard line.

Golfers who are interested in watching the progress of their favorite sport in America found material for many interesting comparisons in the intercollegiate tournament at Garden City, which finished yesterday. The team championship went, as many had predicted, to Harvard, and although Princeton was the runner-up, her team did not make so fine a showings as the first day's contests seemed to indicate.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 28. -- The Transcript says users of hemp are confronted now with a possible famine in their material, which nothing but the reversal of the order closing the Philippine ports can avert. As things now stand, there is not enough material in the country or on shipboard to supply the demand up to the time when a shipment, if made to-day from Manila, would arrive at our mills.

An unusual amount of interest has already been developed in the Horse Show of 1899, which is scheduled for Nov. 13-18. Even at this early date the rooms of the association on East Twenty-third Street are crowded daily with horsemen and other admirers of the aristocrats of equine society.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28. -- Dr. Frank H. Chase, a tutor in English in the academic department at Yale, was arrested last night for trespass on the property of George Ebel, a resident of Edgewood Avenue. Dr. Chase has been acting queerly of late, because of overstudy, it is said, and has not been entirely responsible for his actions.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- At the Apawamis Club house, Rye, N.Y., last night, was held an informal dance in the nature of a housewarming.

The present City of New York derives its water supply from a number of sources. Manhattan Island and part of the Bronx Borough are supplied from the Croton River through thirty-three miles of masonry aqueducts, capable of conveying 400,000,000 gallons a day, and delivering the water to the Bronx Borough at 131.5 feet above tide level, and to Manhattan Island at 119 feet above tide.

SYDNEY, Sept. 27. -- Taking it for granted that federation will soon be an accomplished fact, the Federal tariff is already being energetically discussed, and everything points to the probability of its being framed on a protectionist basis, although there is a strong party in favor of moderate duties only.

Reports from Albany that J. Newton Fiero, counsel for the State Tax Commission, had found difficulties in the new franchise tax law as a result of the omission of the word "across," have been interpreted in some quarters as indicating the invalidation of the hole act. That there is danger of this was denied yesterday by Senator John Ford, author of the law.

The recent occurrence of the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Chopin has filled the columns of the musical and unmusical papers with discussions of his genius or talent. The question is whether he was really or not a great composer or just a person of diseased mind who used the piano to work off his humors on an impressionable world.

Threatening weather yesterday morning made attendance at supplementary rifle practice on the Creedmoor ranges somewhat lighter than is usual for the last Saturday of the season. Nearly 300 National Guardsmen were on hand, however, and weather conditions were exceptionally favorable after the skies had cleared.

-- It is learned from a Portuguese source of information that Portugal has actually committed herself to a definite policy in regard to Delagoa Bay by signing a secret treaty with Great Britain, in which Germany, as far as commercial privileges are concerned, is also a participant. This treaty, it is asserted, will go into operation Nov. 1, unless the Government in Lisbon requests postponement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Major Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, in an interview to-day, said: "Cuba, on the whole, is doing well; the condition of the island is improving. The Cubans are tractable and quiet, and the revolution has given them self-respect and self-reliance. They have come out of their fight hopeful and confident, and the people of the island are to-day eager to make the most of their opportunities

The Executive Committee of Tammany Hall gave out last night its address to the voters of this county. This document has been in course of preparation for some days, and it is supposed to have been drafted by Dr. W.J. O'Sullivan of the Committee on Resolutions. The statement follows in part:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- An understanding has been reached by which it is expected that negotiations will be opened soon at Madrid for a new treaty between the United States and Spain. This will be the last step toward completely restoring friendly relations between the two countries.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29. -- The Yale football eleven arrived in this city early this evening from New York. The players, from Capt. McBride through the list to the furthest substitute, were quiet and reserved, offering no explanations and seeking no sympathy for the defeat by Columbia. They all seemed to realize that the biggest shake-up in a Yale football squad that has taken place will be on the schedule for this week.

Two men last night waylaid Edward B. Clint, thirty years old, of Hilton, N.Y., in Twenty-ninth Street, near First Avenue, and after giving him a severe beating relieved him of his gold watch and $12 in cash. They made their escape.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 29. -- Reports of the severe rainstorm that has swept the country arrive from various points and confirm the fear that extensive damage has been done. The Rio Cobre inundated Spanish Town, doing considerable harm, particularly to the power plant of the electric railway.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Capt. Shepherd Hudson of the barkentine Jennie Sweeney has reached his home here in a badly battered condition as the result of an injury on board his vessel. The Jennie Sweeney is well known to boatmen and usually plies between Southern ports and New York and Philadelphia.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29. -- When the steamship Sardinian, with the Canadian contingent for the Transvaal on board, sails from Quebec on Tuesday morning, she will carry from their native shores considerably less than 100 French-Canadians. The total strength of the contingent is 1,000 men, but though the French-Canadian population is fully three or four times as large as the British, the latter has had to furnish over 900 of the volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A long official statement reviewing the legal phases of the political assessment question, and holding that the soliciting of campaign funds by letter comes clearly within the remedial provisions of the civil service law, was made public by the Civil Service Commission to- night.

HAVANA, Oct. 29. -- Gen. Wilson says there is no section of Cuba, laboring under the same disadvantages, which is more rapidly recovering from the effects of the war than Manicaragua Valley, which is twenty miles from the railroad and accessible only by almost impassable thoroughfares, yet is so enterprising and so rapidly being reconstructed that in two years, in his opinion, its tobacco output will surpass that of any previous year.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Arthur T. Ball, better known in the pugilistic world as "Jack" Ball, was found dead to-night in an opium resort conducted by Chinese at 22 Fair Street, this city. Ball, with three companions, went to the place at 2 o'clock this morning. He smoked and then fell asleep. His companions left, and when they returned for him this evening they found him in the same position.

John McCullagh, Superintendent of the Bureau of Elections, gave out yesterday a statement in reference to the reports of the colonization of voters in certain Assembly districts of this city. The document goes into detail with regard to the Eighth District, and makes use of that district as an example of what the Superintendent thinks has been done in a number of others.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Ease in our market increased last week, and I am not sure that we have seen the lowest depth in rates. In his somewhat oracular speech at the Fishmongers' dinner the Governor of the Bank of England said he did not think that South Africa would take more than 6,000,000 in gold altogether, and more than half that had already gone.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- That the memory of Charles Stewart Parnell lives in the hearts of the Irish people of Boston was unquestionably proved to-night, when Boston's largest theatre was crowded to its utmost to welcome the Hon. Daniel Tallon, Lord Mayor of Dublin, and John Redmond, M.P., who are touring the country in behalf of the Parnell monument fund.

-- All enlightened sentiment -- all, that is, founded on appreciation of the present as it is, and of the future as it must be -- will take the form of commendation and encouragement for Mr. WINSLOW E. BUZBY in the campaign which he, a volunteer representative of the Automobile Club, has opened against the Park Board.

The article from The London Chronicle, reproduced in THE TIMES of Oct. 27, sharply criticising Dr. Lyman Abbott's address before the Congregational Council at Boston, recalls a curious parallel to his treatment by hasty critics. Dr. Dale, a man of equal note in England, fared precisely the same for what he said at the Congregational Council in London in 1891.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 29. -- W.J. Bryan rested quietly at 'Stanton to-day, where he, made his last speech yesterday. The rest was much needed, as the hard work of campaigning has told heavily on him. He will make only seven, speeches to-morrow, be ginning at Holdredge, the other points to be visited being Axtell, Mindel, Kenesaw, Juniata, Hastings, and Kearney.

There was another political tussle between the contending elements in the Central Federated Union yesterday, and this time the attack was begun by the anti-Tammany element, which demanded the expulsion of the delegates of the Druggists' League, on the charge that it was not a bona-fide organization, and existed only on paper.

Late advices from up the State indicate that the proposed knit underwear trust, with a capital of $35,000,000, has fallen through. Col. George W. Kavanaugh, one of the largest manufacturers in the Cohoes district, was at the Hotel Imperial yesterday, and said:

PRINCETON, Oct. 29. -- Bruised and battered from yesterday's game with Cornell, the Princeton football eleven arrived here this morning shortly after 2 o'clock. They were driven at once to the 'Varsity Club House. The defeat by Cornell was a severe blow to the Tigers, and as a result of the game there will be a great shake-up in the team.

In his recent candid letter declining to speak in Ohio on "Imperialism," even in a non-partisan manner, Mr. SCHURZ makes some interesting predictions. He is of the opinion that "if the Filipinos are not granted their independence, then imperialism will be made the main issue in the Presidential election next year, crowding all other issues into the background."

At the close of last week's trading in the market for outside securities there seemed more ground than for some weeks for the hope that marked improvement in that market is at hand. It is true that the market did not show a uniformly upward tendency, but enough strength was shown and advances were numerous enough to give rise to a fairly general feeling of confidence in the immediate future of the market.
DURBAN, Oct. 28. -- The following official account of the capture of the squadron of the Eighteenth Hussars by the Boers is given by Capt. Hardy:
Will you kindly give space to another communication relative to this controversy from one who is as ill-informed about its merits as are most of those who have already written you?

It is a matter of very great surprise to me that no general protest has been made against the changing of position of our street signs. I can safely say that five-sixths of the people with whom I come in contact are strenuously opposed to the wholly uncalled for and absurd innovation in question.

Sixteen-year-old James Dugan of 1,187 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, is causing the police of that borough no end of mental distress and much bodily weariness. In the opinion of the tired and disgusted bluecoats James is the tallest liar since the days of Ananias.

Senator HANNA may discover ground for disquietude of mind in the report sent back from Columbus by a very conservative campaign correspondent of The Philadelphia Ledger who telegraphs from Columbus. This observer says that HANNA'S speech at Cleveland has annoyed the Republican managers and has been converted to campaign use by the Democrats.

In your issue of Oct. 23 "Water Witch" seems more bewitched than bewitching in his argument. From what I have gathered as to the purpose and spirit of the Dewey arch, the general idea seems to be that it shall serve as a memorial of the navy as a whole, including officers and men, with ample sculptured representations of its brilliant deeds, for the people, the masses, to see, admire, and be inspired by.

With her sails bent and most of her stores on board, the yacht Shamrock lies in Erle Basin, ready to sail for the Clyde to-morrow. To-day she will be towed down to Tompkinsville, preparatory to starting on the voyage. Capt. Archie Hogarth will be in command, with Capt. Hamilton as navigator and Capt. Wringe as chief officer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Bureau of Naval Intelligence has made public a very interesting document published in the official organ of the Minister of War at Madrid and containing the sentence of the Supreme Council in the proceedings instituted because of the capitulation of Santiago in the Summer of 1898.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- C.B. Orvis, an oil operator from the Pennsylvania oil region, was arrested on a Wabash train, at Twenty-seventh Street, by detectives of the Central Station at noon to-day, and is being held for alleged forgeries at Washington, Penn., by which over $30,000 is said to have been realized.

Gen. C.H.T. Collis, who was taken ill at the dinner given to Sir Henry Irving at the Lotos Club Saturday night, was much improved yesterday, and is now, according to a statement made by his physician, Dr, W. P. Northrup, last night, entirely out of danger. The following bulletin was issued at the club at 8:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon by his son, Lloyd Collis:
CAPE TOWN, Oct. 29. -- The following official data are made public regarding the fighting near Dundee on Oct. 19:

One of the most brilliant and important incidents of the sea fight at Santiago on July 3, 1898, was the pursuit and destruction, by the little unprotected auxiliary gunboat Gloucester, a hastily converted yacht, of the dreaded Spanish torpedo-boat destroyers Pluton and Furor.

An appeal for diplomatic intervention of the highest respectability to stop the fratricidal duel in South Africa and submit all matters in dispute to arbitration should now be considered by the belligerents. The condescension, good-will, and disinterestedness of the interpellant will be indubitably admitted by both parties. One such a persona grata to each combatant ought to be sure of a hearing.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 29. -- W.H. Greer, United States Deputy Revenue Officer, was shot Friday by Bill Hunnicutt, a noted moonshiner, and died yesterday near Elk Park: N.C. Deputy Sheriff Witt Phillips was fatally shot by Hunnicutt yesterday when an attempt at arrest was made. Hunnicutt has killed five men.

Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee arrived from Newburg at the Fifth Avenue Hotel at a little after 8 o'clock last evening. It was said that Senator Platt had telegraphed him to come to headquarters. When Mr. Odell left on Saturday he said that he would not return until to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The funeral train bearing the body of Gen. Henry arrived here from New York at 6:10 o'clock to-night. With a platoon of light artillerymen as escort, the body was taken to St. John's Episcopal Church, where it will lie in state under a guard of honor furnished by the Guy. V. Henry Post of the Loyal Legion until the funeral to-morrow.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- It is asserted in quarters usually reliable that Emperor William is the sole moving spirit in the new naval programme. The present agitation was undertaken without first consulting the Bundesrath, and really against the wishes of that body.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Mrs. George Ehret, wife of the New York brewer, died at the Beechwood Hotel last night from a hemorrhage. She had been an invalid for some time, and by the advice of her physician came to Summit. She appeared to be improving until last night, when the hemorrhage occurred, and then death followed quickly.

The Rev. Father William D. McKinnon, who went to the Philippines as Chaplain of the First California Volunteers, delivered an illustrated lecture last evening at Columbus Hall on "Facts About the Philippines." During his work in the army the priest was twice wounded. After the capture of Manila he was appointed Superintendent of the Schools and Cemeteries of Manila.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- According to the latest reports from Cape Town, Gen. Joubert has joined hands with the Free State forces, and there has been some outpost fighting. President Kruger has arrived at Glencoe.

When Col. WARING undertook the work of the Street Cleaning Department, prompt and ample provision was made for the collection and removal of the ashes from business buildings, and notice was given that the department preferred that this work be left entirely to its employes, by whom it was done in the most satisfactory manner.

As a reader of your paper I am surprised at the statement in your otherwise well-considered leading article in your issue of this morning headed "The Boer Artillery," that the volunteer batteries of the civil war "on the Union side never approached the regular batteries in efficiency." It seems a pity to one who served in that army that the impressions of the present day should be so erroneous.
CAPE TOWN, Oct. 29. -- The following dispatch, dated Oct. 23, has been received from Mafeking:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- The Russian cruiser Variag, which is designed to be the fastest armored vessel of her class ever constructed by the Cramp, shipbuilding firm, will be launched on Tuesday, with unusual display. Prominent Russian naval attaches, and Government officials are expected at the christening.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Trainer McMasters is very happy to-day, for all of the men who played in the game against the Indians yesterday were up bright and early this morning and appeared at the training table for breakfast. With the exception of a little stiffness and a few slight black and blue marks, these men are all in as good condition as before yesterday's hard-fought battle.

Dr. Felix Adler addressed the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall, yesterday morning, on "The Lessons of the Dreyfus Case." He began his discourse with a recital of the circumstances attending the second conviction of Dreyfus. "The burst of indignant protest which circled round the world was a very real thing," he said.

The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the First Congregational Church, Jersey City, last night delivered his sixth discourse, on "Marriage Bells." It was entitled "How to Treat Your Husband." Mr. Scudder said in part:

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Four Justices of the Peace and a jury of twelve men were required to try a dog case at Schraalenburgh to-day. It was a suit brought by Edwin H. Morris of Englewood to recover damages from Constable Henry L. Haring for the loss of a dog. The animal in question was "Nero," a prize-winning St. Bernard.

About ten days ago Arthur La Due, on trial before Recorder Goff, charged with the larceny of a watch, told the jury that he was on the Iowa and had participated in the battle of Santiago. They acquitted him.

FALL RIVER, Oct. 30. -- The mill operatives of Fall River, through their representatives in the Textile Council, have asked for an increase of 10 per cent. in their wages, to take effect Monday, Nov. 13. The manufacturers, through their committee, replied to-day that they had no power to grant the increase asked, but would refer the request back to their association for instructions.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- The University of Pennsylvania football squad arrived home to-day from Chicago, where the 'Varsity eleven played a tie game with the Chicago University team on Saturday, and was royally received by the student body. A thousand undergraduates, headed by the university band, escorted the red and blue warriors from the railroad station to the training house, near the university grounds.
William Waldorf Astor has sold to Franklin Pettit a plot of eight lots on the north side of One Hundred and Eighth Street, 100 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The Record to-morrow will say:

The very interesting exposition of "The Water Supply Situation in New York," by Mr. J.J.R. CROES, which we printed on Sunday, is in effect an indictment of the present administration of the Croton Water Bureau and therefore of the present administration of the Department of Public Works.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Secretary Long to-day said that he did not contemplate making any change in Admiral Schley's orders. So far, these are nothing more than a direction to take command of the South Atlantic Station The date will be definitely fixed when it is known exactly how soon the Chicago will be ready for sea.

Twenty mechanics' liens aggregating $21,628 were filed -- yesterday against Peyser Bookstaver, builder, on houses 153 to 157 East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, southwest corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-eighth Street, and on Brook, Avenue, near Wendover Street, and near One Hundred and Seventy-first Street.

LADYSMITH, Oct. 30 -- 6 P.M. -- An advance was made by the British at dawn, with the object of shelling the Boers from the position where yesterday they had mounted a number of guns. On reaching the spot, however it was found that they had evacuated the position.
PATERSON, N.J. -- Oct. 31. -- Vice President Garret A. Hobart, who has been ill ever since the close of the last Congress, is now very weak.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Admiral Dewey to-day took possession of his new home. The last of the furniture was arranged in the new house to-day, and the Admiral's trunks were brought up from the apartments he has been occupying at the Everett.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- In to-day's practice the Princeton eleven played with a fierceness and desperation that reminded lone of last year's Yale game, but for the 'Varsity it was in vain. The college eleven not only outplayed them, but did not allow them even a score.

The Board of Governors of the Automobile Club of America met at the Waldorf-Astoria last night to complete arrangements for the run next Saturday, and incidentally to discuss the arrest in Central Park of Winslow E. Buzby and Whitney Lyon.

Among the arrivals on the Bovic of the White Star Line yesterday was C.E. Metcalf, in charge of Bettie R., the trotting mare that was sent abroad a few years ago and, under the assumed name Andria, nearly cleared out a lot of French speculators before the French authorities detected the cheat.

While leaning over a cooking stove in her apartments at 409 Hadson Street yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Harriet Bennett was severely burned about the face and body through her clothes catching fire. She was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital. It is believed that she inhaled the flames. Her condition is very serious.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Though it was assamed until a short time ago that the Republicans would nominate the "old ticket" next year, the uneasiness over the health of Vice President Hobart has obliged the Republican leaders to canvass for a second choice, in case the Vice President should be unable to accept a renomination.

Our correspondent who complains by asking the question "Why THE TIMES upholds SCHLEY and belittles SAMPSON" of a partiality exhibited by this paper for SCHLEY manifestly is affected by a partiality for SAMPSON which prevents him from seeing the simple point that THE TIMES has always insisted upon, that SCHLEY was engaged in the battle of Santiago.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 30. -- The Dispatch tomorrow will say:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Admiral Dewey announced to some of his more intimate friends to-night the fact of his engagement to Mrs. W.B. Hazen of this city.

CORNING, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- A peculiar capture of a burglar was made by the Corning police about 5 o'clock this morning. During the night a burglar broke into the rooms of George Jones, a colored bootblack living in a store building, and stole certificates of deposit amounting to $4,300, which the bootblack had saved by years of shines.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The Vossische Zeitung says it understands that Great Britain has offered Germany the Gilbert Islands and the British portion of the Solomon Islands in return for a renunciation of Germany's claims in Samoa.

TRENTON, Oct. 30. -- Friends of some of the teachers in the Girls' Industrial School, which has been under fire for some time, owing to the methods of treating the girls in the institution adopted by the matron, Mrs. Myrtle B. Eyler, now complain that the teachers who appeared before the Governor and recited the facts are being forced out of the school by a series of petty persecutions.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- That the heavy guns of the Boers, from which so much was expected, should be silenced so speedily, as indicated in the dispatches from Ladysmith, is a matter of great surprise; but the subsequent advance of the Burgher force on the British left flank shows the attackers were in no way dismayed thereby, and were still full of the same self-confidence and daring they have already exhibited on various occasions.

Plans which have been quietly maturing for several months have at last been completed, and as a result there has been formed an immense new paper company, which, though its factories will be located in Canada, purposes nevertheless to enter the American field and actively to compete with the International Paper Company, which now controls the majority of the news paper mills of the United States.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30. -- Yale's defeat at the hands of Columbia on last Saturday has aroused the advisers and coachers, and to-day immediate steps were taken to strengthen the team. All this week the 'Varsity squad will have at least half an hour daily of secret practice. Another half hour's work each day will be given over to open work, such as has been in progress during the season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Admiral Dewey is receiving credit here for another manifestation of sound judgment and appreciation of the proprieties. On Saturday night, at the Metropolitan Club, as has been reported, a dinner of twenty-two covers, given just before Dewey, then Commodore, sailed for the Asiatic station, nearly two years ago, was repeated with twenty of the original twenty-two present.

Frederick Goller and his wife of Bridgeport about ten days ago visited Dr. George W. Jacoby of 663 Madison Avenue to be examiners as to their sanity, and now, as a result of the examination, they are confined in the Connecticut State Asylum for the Insane at Middletown, while their four children have been sent to the County Home.
Only one favorite of the six in yesterday's races at Aqueduct managed to squeeze home a winner, with the result that the crowd went home dissatisfied.
The Corinthians scored a double victory in the Columbia League last night, winning both games easily.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- In accordance with custom, the railway mail service, by order of the Postmaster General, to-day reissued a general order of Oct. 18, 1894, directing Division Superintendents to give such instructions to chief clerks and other employes "as will enable those who desire to vote at the approaching election to do so, irrespective of party affiliations."

The principle of municipal ownership of gas and electric lighting plants, street railways, and other "public utilities" must stand or fall by the answer which human experience given to these two foundation questions:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- The statement of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company for the month of September, 1899, compared with the same period in 1898, shows:

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 30. -- Surrogate Theodore H. Silkman of Westchester County, to-day signed an order that a citation be issued to Nathaniel B. Valentine, the sole executor of the estate of George B. Valentine, requiring him to appear to-morrow to show cause why he should not be removed. This action was taken on the petition of Harriet A. Burtis, Charles E. Burtis, and William L. Burtis, children and grandchildren of the testator.

D. Edgar Anthony, a lawyer, who was found guilty last week of grand larceny in the second degree for appropriating the sum of $223.66 belonging to Miss Laura H. Johnson of 148 Montague Street, Brooklyn, was yesterday sentenced to five years' imprisonment in Sing Sing Prison, at hard labor, by Judge Aspinall in the Kings County Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- The International Commercial Congress, which has been in session here since Oct. 12, to-day entered upon the final week of its work. The congress will close on Wednesday. Today's session was devoted first to papers on European trade.

Will THE TIMES kindly inform an old-time reader why it upholds Schley and belittles Sampson? Another question I wish to ask is, What did Schley do? I have read all the articles in the magazines, including the important ones by "The Captains," and for the life of me I can't see where Schley comes in for any credit.

In the Nineteenth Assembly District, where Tammany Hall, in supporting Perez M. Stewart for Assemblyman, is putting forth herculean efforts to defeat Robert Mazet, the fight waxes warmer as Election Day draws near. Every one of the candidates on both tickets was circulating through the district last night, fighting tooth and nail for the slightest advantage.

PARIS, Oct. 30. -- The ultimate failure of the case before the High Court of the Senate in which Deroulede and a number of Nationalists and Royalists are implicated on the charge of plotting the restoration of the monarchy was said from the very first to be likely, and to-day's proceedings continue to justify the prediction.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 30. -- The British officials here, fearing that the Chinese reformer, Kang-Yu-Wei, is on board the steamer Empress of India, from Vancouver, have sent the torpedo boat destroyers Fame and Whiting to Woo-Sung, a maritime town at the mouth of the Woo-Sung River, ten miles north of Shanghai, to prevent the Chinese from searching the vessel.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 30. -- The annual calculation of the number of victims lost from the fishing fleet of this port was made to-day, and it was learned that sixty lives have been added to the great total that has accumulated during the past few years, that fifteen widows and twenty-six children have been bereaved, and that shipping property valued at nearly $80,000 has been swallowed up by the sea.

A great deal of speculation is being indulged in just now by the leaders of both parties in Brooklyn as to the probable result of Assembly elections in Kings County. Gains are being predicted by the leaders of either organization, but the situation generally appears to favor the claims of the Democrats.

Will you permit an old-timer, who rode astride a tree-body twenty miles, with five barrels of hard cider swung below, to the building of a log cabin in the 1840 campaign of "Tippecanoe and Tyler, too," in Niagara County, N.Y., to supplement Mr. Ogden's very interesting interview in yesterday's TIMES by refreshing his memory as to the last verse of the famous song?

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Yesterday's engagement at Ladysmith, which, despite the rather heavy losses, must be regarded rather as an extended reconnaissance or skirmish than a battle, seems to make little change in the actual position. It is disappointing to the British public, as again revealing tactical skill of an unexpectedly high order on the side of the Boers.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30. -- Robert B. Jennings, Secretary and Treasurer of the Broadway cable line, was robbed of $1,043 in cash and $48,750 in checks while standing on the rear platform of a Broadway car at Broadway and Washington Avenue, at noon to-day. The police attempted to suppress the facts, and as a consequence the news was not generally known until three or four hours later in the day.

The double-decked ferry-boat Chicago of the Pennsylvania Railroad Cortlandt Street line was run down and sunk near her New York slip in the North River by the steamship the City of Augusta, of the Savannah Line, at 12:35 this morning.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- The drowning of the Cornell Student, Edward Fairfax Berkley. Jr., has resulted in several editorials in the local newspapers, in which the Kappa Alpha Fraternity is severely censured. One paper says:

Money on call loaned on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday a high as 40 per cent. This was just at the close of business with belated borrowers bidding against one another. Transactions in some volume were at a 25 per cent. call rate. The bulk of the day's business was at an average figure of from 8 to 10 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- "The politicians are using Helen Gould's money to awaken sentimental twaddle against Congressman-elect Roberts of Utah," said Mrs. Corinne Brown of the Woodlawn Woman's Club and Chairman of the National Industrial Committee of the General Federation of Woman's Clubs, to-day.
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- An official dispatch from Gen. White, which was dated at Ladysmith at 4:30 P.M. to-day, reads:

MANILA, Oct. 30. -- Three companies of Col. Bell's regiment have had two encounters with the insurgents near Labam and scattered them. The insurgents left four officers and eight men dead on the field, and the Americans captured three prisoners and several guns. On the American side one man was killed and two officers and six men were wounded.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- The fact that Haughton of Harvard turned a third-rate eleven into championship form in ten days of coaching is just beginning to sift through the bewildered brains of the Ithacans, as it has perhaps already sifted through those of the Princetonians.

We alluded the other day to the unqualified statement of the President of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad, Mr. CALLAWAY, that he expected the present state of prosperity in business to last at least three years. The evidence of his confidence and that of the other managers of the great property of which he is the head is found in the investment of $15,000,000 in rolling stock.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30. -- The Harvard football eleven resumed practice on Soldiers' Field to-day. The hard game of Saturday had apparently had no other effect than to put more dash and spirit into the play, and every man who played in the Carlisle game was in the line for practice to-day except Dady.

In the death of JOHN CODMAN ROPES of Boston the country incurs the loss of the one man who could hae given to it, and had undertaken to give to it, a complete military history of the civil war, worthy to rank in accuracy, skill, and authority with the best work of its kind. Happily the task assumed by Mr. ROPES was nearing completion.

The case of young Edward Fairfax Berkley of Cornell University, who was drowned at Geneva on Friday last, is one of the saddest on record, and calls forth an indignant protest against the brutal methods so prevalent at many of the leading colleges in this country. Fairfax, as he was known to his friends, was a bright, handsome fellow, universally popular, an only son, and idolized by his parents.

MANILA Oct. 30. -- The Spanish commission which entered the insurgent lines a month ago with money to relieve the wants of several thousand military and civil Spanish prisoners returned to Angeles to-day. The Commissioners report that they spent most of the time in Tarlac and the vicinity, where there are some 200 sick Spaniards in the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The Philippine Commission held its first meeting at the quarters selected for it in the Arlington to-day. Prof. Schurman, for whose arrival the other members have been waiting, reached Washington this morning and made an early call at the State Department, after which he went to the commission's rooms, where Admiral Dewey and Col. Denby were waiting.

Zip, son of the dog Fly, who inherited his father's histrionic gifts and entertained the public nightly for the last seventeen years, died on Thursday night. Zip asserted his predilection for the footlights in his puppyhood. At the age of five months he made his first appearance with "the Mannings," in Cleveland, Ohio, and has never missed a night since.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 30. -- Orlando Tefft, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, has issued the following proclamation to voters:

The application for the reduction of the amount of the bond to be required from the contractor for the proposed rapid-transit road was argued yesterday before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Presiding Justice Van Brunt and Justices Barrett. Patterson and Ingraham heard the argument and reserved decision.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The heavy rainstorm in which the Yale 'Varsity football squad practiced this afternoon had anything but a depressing effect upon the players' work. Although the field was in a condition specially conducive to accidents, and the rain made the ball hard to handle, the practice was quite encouraging.

Mr. Crane produced another new play at Wallack's Theatre last evening. The value of "A Rich Man's Son," which is a version of a German sentimental farce made for Mr. Crane by Michael Morton, lies almost wholly in the suitability of its principal role to the style and personal humor of Mr. Crane.

The following note from Gen. GUY V. HENRY was written a few weeks before his death. It should have been promptly published, but was accidentally laid aside and its printing deferred. It is so full of the wise and humane spirit of the noble officer whose loss is so nearly irreparable that it may be regarded now almost as a voice from the grave.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- An ominous curtain has again descended upon affairs in Natal. No dispatch, except the official telegrams of General Sir George Stewart White, has thus far been permitted to mention the disaster; and no telegram from Ladysmith has been received in London since the advices from the British commander.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 31. -- Bryan is still touring the State, making speeches from the rear of a Pullman car. He spoke at Kearney to-night. His health has been affected by the two weeks of hard campaigning, but he is still able to fill his dates. Altgeld made two speeches at Omaha to-night.

The sinking of the Pennsylvania ferryboat Chicago by the Savannah Line steamship City of Augusta off the foot of Cortlandt Street, North River, early yesterday morning was not productive of as great loss of life as the conditions under which the disaster occurred warranted. So far as has been ascertained only one man is dead and three are missing.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 31. -- The first-class battleship Kentucky went out on her builders' trial trip this morning at 8 o'clock. The sea was heavy and the wind high. These conditions prevailed all day, preventing any attempt at record running.

The United States and Russia will settle, by an arbitration already agreed to, a question that involves either the reaffirmation of the three-mile limit of marine jurisdiction long generally accepted in international law, in which case Russia must lose, or the acceptance of a new rule, suggested by Russia, in which case the United States will lose.

There is in force in this city (on paper only, however,) an ordinance prohibiting the leaving of unattended horses in the streets, and requiring that the police arrest such offenders, yet I venture to say that no one ever knew of a policeman to make an arrest for such a violation, for reasons best known to themselves, it being much more comfortable and entertaining to pass the time in colloquial activity at street corners.

It is surprising that talk about Continental interference between England and the Boers should in any quarter receive serious attention. It is particularly surprising to see in a well-informed American newspaper a reference to "the question of Continental mediation" as likely to be revived by the Boer victory.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- At to-day's session of the Commercial Congress resolutions were adopted in substance as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- The coaches to-day took advantage of the soggy field to stay indoors and hold a little secret conference with the men. It was learned from good authority that to-day witnessed a new departure, and established an era of good feeling between the coaches, the Captain, and the men.
Announcement by the Baltimore and Ohio that it will have sixty-two new compound consolidated freight locomotives by Jan. 1.

The responsibility for the collision by which a ferryboat on the North River has been wrecked and at least one life lost does not clearly appear from the statements of the survivors. Each Captain is concerned to make out the best case he can for himself. Even if a clear view of the responsibility could be had from among these conflicting statements, it would be improper to state it in advance of the official investigation.
LONDON, Oct. 31. -- It is learned that the War Office has ordered a second army corps to be in readiness to be called out.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 31. -- If Judge William Neville be elected to Congress by the Fusionists in the Sixth Nebraska District there is every probability that his right to the seat will be contested. His name will appear on many of the ballots in the Sixth District as the candidate of the Populists, Democrats, and Free Silver Republicans. He was nominated by the Populists and Free Silver Republicans, but not by the Democrats.
Bleiman Co. have sold for J. Diescher and Elizabeth Sweet to Adelson Slone the two three-story buildings 386 and 338 East Eighteenth Street, 40 by 92.
LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Baron Hylton died this morning.

This is All Saints' Day, and the faithful, particularly those of the Roman Catholic and Anglican communions, which more especially observe the day, will gather in their churches for memorial services for the saints departed, while the cemeteries will be visited also by thousands who on this day make their annual pilgrimage to the graves of departed relatives and friends.

Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy was a witness yesterday afternoon before the Mazet investigating committee, which had resumed its sessions in the morning after an interval of some weeks. There was a large crowd present all day in the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation, but the interest seemed to centre around the testimony to be given by Gen. Tracy.

On the eighth page of your issue of this date is an item of news headed, "The Bronx County Plan -- Charles M. Kaeppel, Its Father, Denies that There Is Any Politics in It," and it is with the view of correcting the impression that Mr. Kaeppel is the father of the plan to create the County of the Bronx that I write this letter.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The North American will to-morrow say:

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The Mayor, in accordance with the order of the City Council, will appoint a committee of 100 citizens, who will take up the question of cutting off the limit of the bonded indebtedness and giving to Chicago a new and up-to-date Constitution. The committee, it is said, will be both representative and non-partisan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Richard Mansfield announced to-day that he would open his New York season, which is to begin shortly, with a revival of "Yorick's Love," a romantic drama, which has not been played since Lawrence Barrett used it. The play is from the Spanish of Calderon, and, like all the secular dramas of that writer, is remarkable for perfect construction and ingenious situations.

The charges against District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner, which have been prepared by individual members of the Municipal Government Committee of the City Club were made public yesterday. Edward L. Heydecker took the charges to Albany night before last, but could not place them in the Governor's hands until yesterday morning.

Magistrate Olmsted, in the Yorkville Court, yesterday afternoon, decided that Winslow E. Buzby had not been guilty of disorderly conduct in attempting to run his automobile in the driveways of Central Park.

-- Spain must be so sure by this time of the friendliness and good-will with which she is now regarded by almost everybody in the United States that even her peculiarly delicate sensibilities with regard to anything like ridicule will not be painfully stirred at the smiles with which the average American will hear the news that the Spanish fleet has been ordered to concentrate at Cadiz.

PARIS, Oct. 31. -- (Copyright, 1899, by The New York Times.) -- News of the British disaster in Natal has caused great excitement here, and the general feeling is one of jubilation. The French, with their quick habit of jumping to conclusions, think that the capitulation of the British Army at Ladysmith is merely a matter of a few hours and that the war is practically at an end.

PONCE, Puerto Rico, Oct. 25. -- While commerce and commercial enterprises of every kind are waiting for the United States to give to Puerto Rico a market in place of the one taken from her more than a year ago nature seems to be trying to show how much she can do for the island, and it is surprising to note the changes that have been wrought in the past two months.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- At the Lewes Autumn meeting to-day the Lewes Nursery Handicap was won by Ardeer. Tathwell Lassie finished second and Beatrice Maude, ridden by J. Reiff, was third. Twelve horses ran.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The production of Clyde Fitch's new play, "Sapho," by Miss Olga Nethersole, at Powers's Theatre, tonight was a decided success. The playhouse was crowded to the doors by an enthusiastic audience, which gave the actress half a dozen curtain calls after every act. The opening performance was postponed from Monday evening to give the company an opportunity for a dress rehearsal, and the result was a smooth and well-balanced performance.

The charges against District Attorney GARDINER are in their general character extremely serious, and his effort to treat them with scornful indifference is more characteristic than prudent or dignified. They are presented by reputable citizens, who have made a long and careful investigation before avowing their ability to prove them.
Four scores of more than 900 were rolled in the Harlem League at the Palace Alleys, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, last night.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 31. -- An important decision was handed down to-day by Judge White of the County Court against labor unions. The case was one which caused a great deal of comment in labor circles all over the country. C. Flaccus, a glass manufacturer of Tarentum, Penn., brought suit against the officers of the American Flint Glass Workers' Union to prevent them from inducing the apprentices of the plaintiff to join the union.

A horse left standing in the shafts of a delivery wagon took fright from some unknown cause early yesterday afternoon, and in the course of a run of only a few hundred feet sent an elderly woman to almost instant death. She was in the act of crossing Sixth Avenue on the south side of West Thirty-ninth Street when struck, and was holding an umbrella over her head.

Some of the users of commutation tickets along the line of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad are complaining about a new system to be put into effect on the road. For about two years the road has been selling the tickets on what is known as the sliding scale. A person residing at Orange, for instance, would pay $5.95 for a ticket good for sixty trips to or from New York the first month.

The Brooklyn school teachers yesterday delivered their ultimatum in the matter of their held-up salaries for September. They will get every dollar they believe to be due them, they declare, as they will fight for it in the courts.
LONDON, Oct. 31. -- A special dispatch from Ladysmith says the Boers suffered severely during the engagement, some persons estimating their loss at 900 to 1,000 killed and wounded.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The new Russian cruiser Variag was launched to-day at Cramps' shipyards with impressive ceremonies. The religious ceremonies formed a spectacular feature. In addition to passing a gilded cross before the huge hull in benediction the Rev. Mr. Hatovitsky sprinkled the vessel with holy water.

The article in your valued paper of this morning, headed "Dead Letter Lessons," seems to me, and to several friends who, like myself, have frequently suffered from the inefficient postal service of this great city, to cast unjust blame on the much-abused public, in an attempt to laud the negligent officials.

I notice an article in The Montreal Gazette, copied from your paper, referring to the loss of the Nutmeg State, and the behavior of her crew, and also reference is made to the steamship Scotsman and her crew, and, as far as I can understand, the behavior of one crew was similar to the other.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- The thirty days provided in the franchise tax law to file reports with the State Board of Tax Commissioners expires at midnight. The commission sent out about 1,200 blanks, and it was stated at the department to-day that responses from the corporations have been general.
The first annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Society of New York was held last evening in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 200 members and guests were present.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- Gov. Roosevelt, while taking breakfast at the Executive Mansion this morning, received a copy of the charges preferred against District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner of New York County by members of the City Club. They were presented by Edward L. Heydecker. The Governor hastily scanned them, and then turned them over to Attorney General Davies and Secretary Youngs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- In view of the discussion of the military agreement between Gen. Bates and the Sultan of Sulu, the views of President Schurman of the Philippine Commission on this subject are interesting.

A meeting to organize a woman's auxiliary to the Interdenominational Guild for the Aid of Crippled Children of the Poor was held yesterday at 234 West Sixty-third Street. Loring Brace, Secretary of the Children's Aid Society, made an address of welcome. The Rev. Dr. Hegeman of Christ Church, Riverdale, and Miss May Darrach, the two originators of the movement, and Mrs. Fiske, the actress, also made addresses.

It is no wonder that the brilliant little engagements of last week, creditable as they were to the British arms, should have failed to satisfy British aspirations. For they were engagements incurred in the task of enabling a British force to concentrate in the presence of an outnumbering enemy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The train bearing President McKinley and party, and the guests invited to participate in the demonstration at Richmond incident to the launching of the torpedo boat Shubrick arrived at the Pennsylvania Station on time. Throughout the day the President expressed anxiety as to the condition of Vice President Hobart, and was kept informed constantly by telegraph of the changes which took place in his illness.

HAVANA, Oct. 31. -- Gen. Maximo Gomez said to-day that he had a very large quantity of manuscript treating of the warfare in Cuba from 1868 to the present time. Tiffs he regards as his greatest treasure. Of late he has been going carefully through his diaries and papers, collecting all data bearing upon the subject, with the view of writing a history of the revolution, as he has known it internally and externally.
It was decided at a meeting of the officers of the Seventy-first Regiment last night that a committee be appointed to nominate a candidate for Colonel in place of Francis V. Greene, resigned.

The steady downpour of rain last night failed to dampen the ardor of the political campaign that is being waged in the Nineteenth Assembly District. The evening had been chosen for extraordinary oratorical efforts at the three separate political camps on the battlefield. Each Assembly candidate spoke at a mass meeting, and the Tammanyites gathered in force at their district headquarters at Sixty-fifth Street and Broadway, and whooped things up in lively fashion for Stewart.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- There was a continuous stream of callers at the War Office until a late hour, everybody anxiously inquiring regarding yesterday's casualties, but the War Office declared that nothing had been received since Sir George White's dispatch communicating the news of the capture of the Royal Irish Fusiliers and the Gloucestershire Regiment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- It is reported that John A. Spoor, President of the Chicago Junction Railway and Union Stock Yards Company, will become General Manager of the Pullman Company after the consolidation of the Pullman-Wagner interests. The Vanderbilts are largely interested in the Stock Yards Company, and Mr. Spoor is known as their representative in the company.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 31. -- The 'Varsity practiced to-day in a pouring rain and on a field that was wet and soggy. In spite of these conditions, however, the play was brisk and worked by much less fumbling than yesterday. There was no change in the line-up except that Daly took his old place at quarter back in the first half, and Hallowell was at left end during the first half.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- At 2:30 this morning fire started in the kitchen of the State prison. An alarm was sounded by three blasts from the big prison whistle. Fire companies from Peekskill, Tarrytown, and this village were sent to fight the flames.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Whatever the final outcome of the present serious illness of Vie President Hobart, he will not again resume his duties as an officer of the United States. He will not return to Washington, and will not again take any part in public life. The formal announcement of his retirement was made this afternoon, and has the sanction of the entire Hobart family.
Favorites and outsiders divided the programme in the rain at Aqueduct yesterday.

Official authority gave yesterday uncompromising denial to a story that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was, at a meeting in this city, to turn over its independent parlor and sleeping car service to the Pullman's Palace Car Company, which has taken in the Wagner Palace Car Company.

To a large number of persons in this broad land the "popularity" of the Spanish war loan of 1898, by which it was subscribed by a large number of small lenders instead of being subscribed by a syndicate, large or small, was extremely gratifying. The idea that the money needed by the Government should be contributed by the greatest possible number of subscribers, in the smallest permissible amounts, unquestionably appealed to the sentimental.

Further reports on the fighting at Ladysmith Monday show that it was a great disaster to the British forces, which lost, according to competent judges, no less than 2,000 men taken prisoners by the Boers, in addition to the killed and wounded.
A jury in Chicago has given a verdict of $21,000 against a trolley company to a boy who had both legs cut off by a car, which ran over him. The company has asked for a new trial.

A wee specimen of humanity, one of prematurely born twins, after having supposedly made his entree into the world lifeless, and passing three hours in a nailed-up and paper-enveloped macaroni box in a temperature of 25 degrees in a refrigerator at the Morgue, was discovered to be alive and survived the terrible ordeal for ten hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Bids were opened at the Navy Department to-day for the construction of six sheathed and coppered cruisers authorized by the last Naval Appropriation bill. These vessels will be of about 3,200 tons' displacement, a little larger than the Raleigh and Cincinnati class.

The indications are that the Automobile Club of America will speedily have a membership of 500, and that it will continually grow. Up to date 160 applications have been presented, and of these thirty were received in one mail yesterday by Capt. Homer W. Hedge, the Secretary of the organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The climate and crop bulletin for October, issued to-day by the Weather Bureau, says:
William J. O'Brien, nominee for Sheriff on the fusion ticket, gave out yesterday an answer to Tammany Hall's address to the labor classes. Mr. O'Brien says:
