It was WILKES himself who said to GEORGE III. of one of his stanchest supporters, "Ah, Sir, he was a Wilkesite, which I never was." But WILKES was a cynic. WILLIAM McKINLEY is no cynic. He is an eminently sincere and straightforward man, direct and simple in thought and speech.

MANILA, Nov. 1. -- An escaped Spanish prisoner from the insurgent lines north of Manila has arrived at Angeles. He confirms the report that the insurgents are running short of Mauser ammunition and are unable to refill cartridges of this class. He says, however, that they are well supplied with Remington ammunition, which they manufacture for themselves.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- "Dr." John Alexander Dowie, the alleged healer, was rescued from his Oak Park Church at 2:35 o'clock this morning by a Sergeant and twenty policemen from the West Lake Street Station. He had been a prisoner in the building since 7:30 o'clock last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 1. -- The Pennsylvania football team arrived here to-night to remain until the morning of the Harvard game. The men are feeling particularly well to-night, and the practice this afternoon was the best of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- A recapitulation of the casualties in actions and deaths in the regular and volunteer armies beginning May 1, 1898, and ending June 30, 1899, contained in the annual report of the Adjutant General of the Army, shows a grand total of 10,076 men. The casualty list alone aggregates 3,454, of whom 35 officers and 458 enlisted men were killed and 197 officers and 2,764 enlisted men wounded.
LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Lord George Hamilton, Secretary of State for India, speaking at Ealing this evening regarding the situation in South Africa, said:

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The War Office has made a welcome concession to the public desire for news. Hereafter every Post Office will be open Sunday morning and will post copies of all telegrams received by the War Office up to 1 A.M. Sunday.
M.L. Alexander has been appointed Cincinnati agent of the Aetna Insurance Company of Hartford.

There is no denial to the charge that on the day that the Ottawa soldiers were leaving for the Transvaal and the city was en fete in honor of the event, the Hon. J. Israel Tarte gave orders that the British flag was not to be raised over the Parliament buildings. We think that in the absence of any denial of this serious charge we are at liberty to assume that it is true.

Early in the Summer there appeared to be a redundancy of currency hereabouts. At all events, there was an unusual plenitude of money in the market. As a consequence, the reserves of the banks were piled up and they naturally expanded their loans, while their deposits were increased beyond all precedent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- When questioned to-day about the various rumors with respect to the proposed changes in the plan of organization of the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad Company and its terminal properties, William F. Haity, the Chairman of the Philadelphia Reorganization Committee, said:

Another day of racing through a track fetlock-deep in mud did not seem to bother about 2,000 of the regular followers at Aqueduct yesterday. The best played horses, though by no means the favorites, in every case won five of the six races, and the other was taken by Royal Sterling, a 15 to 1 shot.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- Attorney General Davies has notified the Governor that the charges preferred against Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney of New York County, are of sufficient gravity to warrant a service under the public officers' law, of a copy on the accused, and to request an answer.

The postal clerks in the Federal Building are considerably exercised over the fact that they have received circulars inviting them to contribute to the Republican campaign fund. According to the statement of Postmaster Van Cott, these men are absolutely safe from political influence, and such influence does not affect their chances of promotion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Mrs. J. Rush Branch was found dead last night in her apartments with a bullet in her heart. It is believed the body had lain in the flat for more than a week. Finger prints and bloodstains were found on the wall beside the body, and a revolver with one chamber empty lying on a bed in Mrs. Branch's room.

I wish to express through your columns my obligations to Mr. Everett P. Wheeler for his letter in your issue of the 30th inst. Mr. Wheeler's party affiliations on National questions, as well as his personal reputation, give especial value to his suggestion on the Assembly contest in the Nineteenth District.

MANILA, Nov. 1. -- Gen. Hughes, commanding in the Bisayan District, has sent in an encouraging report. He says the Island of Negros is now more peaceful and orderly than for twenty years. The planters are pursuing their business undisturbed by the bands of brigands who had long levied tribute on them.

It is unfortunate that Senator PLATT should have been moved to bestir himself to upset the decision in respect to the design for the new Custom House. Because it seems that there is really something to be said, on architectural grounds, in favor of the position which the Senator and Boss has been moved to take, while nobody believes that, upon such grounds, he would be moved to say it.

Now that Gen. TRACY has frankly explained his connection with the Ramapo Company his best friends must admit that the Mazet committee did him a substantial service in giving him the opportunity to make a public explanation. For his own reputation, which emerges untainted from the atmosphere of scandal and corruption which invests that concern, he had need to define his relations to it.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 1. -- The treasure ship Roanoke, which reported here to-day, sixteen days from St. Michaels and eleven days from Cape Nome, brings the first story of the death of several New Yorkers, members of the Alaska Prospecting Company. The dead are:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1. -- Rain again interfered with the practice of the Yale football squad to-day, but the work was in no way of an inferior quality. The half hour of secret practice behind closed gates inaugurated yesterday preceded the practice game, and in this, besides team work being drilled into the men, each player was given an overhauling.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The members of the Phillippine Commission, Admiral Dewey, Profs. Schurman and Worcester, and Col. Denby, will make a preliminary report to the President before the end of this week, and it is understood the report will be immediately given to the public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The annual report of the Adjutant General of the army, Brig. Gen. Corbin, to the Secretary of War, was made public to-day. Aside from the strictly technical recital of the details of a busy year in military life, the report gives much information of an interesting general character, and submits numerous recommendations for the betterment of the service.

The report of a majority of the Committee on High Schools of the Manhattan School Board, in striking from the supply list of text books, recommended by the Board of Borough Superintendents, seven books published by Henry Holt and Company, was approved by the School Board at its meeting yesterday afternoon after a heated controversy.
Ruland Whiting have sold for Mrs. Rolande Noeggerath the six-story fire-proof building, 15 Walker Street.

The remarks we had occasion to make the other day about reckless driving have been very tragically enforced. Some years ago, on the occaion of a fatal accident in consequence of intrusting a horse to a boy, an ordinance was passed prohibiting the employment of any boy of tender years as the driver of a delivery wagon.

Brooklyn Rapid Transit activity was the feature of yesterday's Stock Exchange transactions, over a third of the day's total business being in that one stock. The price rose between four and five points. Two reasons there were to account for the record. One was buying by insiders and the other was buying for the account of speculators who have recently made extraordinary commitments on the short side.

An audience which filled nearly every seat in Cooper Union gathered last night at a mass meeting held under the auspices of the Republican Club. Senator Depew was to have presided, but he sent word yesterday morning that he would be detained in Washington. W.M.K. Olcott presided in his stead, and on the stage were many members of the club and quite a number of women.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Reports to Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service indicate that the yellow fever epidemic which has prevailed at Key West for the past six weeks has about run its course. Only one or two new cases a day are now reported, and the messages say that a good breeze has been blowing for the past two weeks, which, it is believed, has had a beneficial influence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The negotiations for the partition of the Samoan Islands are proceeding rapidly and officials here would not be surprised if a final agreement were reached in the near future. The discussion which is going on in London with the cooperation of the authorities here and in Berlin has brought out certain essential features on which all three powers, Great Britain, Germany, and the United States, appear to be agreed.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- Attorney General Davies to-day authorized William R. Hearst of New York City, a stockholder in the Ramapo Water Company, to commence an action in the Supreme Court in the name of the people of the State to annul the charter of and dissolve that corporation. Two applications were made by Mr. Hearst, the first by him as a citizen, and the second by him as a stockholder in the company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The War Department to-day made public the report of Brig. Gen. Leonard Wood, commanding the Department of Santiago, Cuba, which is in addition to what has already been made public from this officer. Gen. Wood gives an interesting account of the sanitary reforms put in force, and the good effect in reducing the extent of yellow fever, small pox, and other diseases.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The breakdown of the Delagoa Bay cable route, combined with the monopolization of the available telegraph lines by the Government and British staff officers, is responsible for the fact that nothing further has reached the public from South Africa. The Government has received dispatches rectifying the casualty lists. These will be published to-day.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1. -- A thousand Harvard students tramped through the mud and slush to Soldiers' Field this afternoon to see the football eleven practice. It was the last opportunity the undergraduates will have to see the men line up before the Pennsylvania game. To-morrow practice will again be secret, as it has been for the past two weeks.

Divers had yesterday explored nearly every part of the wreck of the Pennsylvania ferryboat Chicago, which was run down and sunk Tuesday near her Cortlandt Street slip by the City of Augusta. No human bodies were found, but four persons who, it has been ascertained almost positively, were on the ferryboat are still missing.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- The Republican rally held here to-night in the City Hall, at which Mark Hanna was the star attraction, at one time came near ending in a row. The hall was packed to suffocation, and people pushed and scrambled to obtain entrance.
Justice Fursman, sitting in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, yesterday, named Nov. 14 as the date for the beginning of the trial of Roland B. Molineux.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- The Princeton custom of standing loyally by a team which has suffered defeat was never better exemplified than at present.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 1. -- An Omaha sporting man has posted an offer agreeing to give 10 per cent. on all bets secured for him on election. He is offering to place even bets on Holcomb, the fusion candidate for Supreme Court Judge against Reese, the Republican candidate.

The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company's new system of transfers between its surface and elevated lines, which was introduced yesterday morning, failed to work as satisfactorily as was expected by the company. There was confusion at all of the transfer stations, and the diverting of suburban traffic from the surface lines to the elevated roads resulted in overcrowding the trains on the latter lines and the bridge cars and in frequent delays.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The victors of the Cornell-Princeton game gathered in uniform on Percy Field this afternoon for the first work since that contest. Owing to heavy rains which have continued since Monday, a scrub team was not called out, and the 'Varsity men were put through lively signal practice. They acted more like frisky colts than a set of men who were being put in motion after an exhausting battle.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 1. -- Archbishop Ireland, when shown a telegram saying Gen. Funston would probably begin action against him for criminal libel, did not appear to be worried. After reading the dispatch he said:

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 1. -- The Indians, realizing the poor showing they made at Cambridge, plunged into hard work yesterday, when they were lined up against the second team in a driving rain and were put through a thorough limbering up. This work was continued to-day during foul weather.

The following communication, which is signed by Robert W. Gibson, Israels Harder, Bruce Price, Cady, Berg See, George Martin Huss, Francis H. Kimball, James B. Baker, Trowbridge Livingston, and Clinton Russell, who entered the competition to furnish the plans for the new Custom House, and which was sent to President McKinley last Saturday, was made public last night:
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1. -- The United States transport City of Puebla arrived to-day, twenty-seven days from Manila, bearing sick and discharged soldiers. Seven enlisted men died en route.

It seems to us to be rather late to be offering to Chairman QUIGG information which, if proved to be true, would enable him to predict with greater fluency and comprehensiveness, but upon the theory that "better late than never" is not altogether inapplicable to politics, the intimation yesterday given out by The Evening Sun may prove to be of service to Mr. PLATT'S young man.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 1. -- Advices from Morehead City, N.C., say: "The three-masted schooner Charles S. Davis, Somers Point, N.J., from Savannah for Philadelphia, lumber laden, is ashore at Bogue Inlet, twenty-five miles west of Morehead City. The vessel and cargo are a total wreck.

Standing on the starboard wing of the bridge of the American liner St. Louis, and waving his yachting cap in farewell to his friends, Sir Thomas Lipton sailed away yesterday morning over a rolling sea that rendered it unadvisable for his beloved yacht Shamrock to leave port.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Three men are dead and three other persons are missing as the result of the collapse of a six-story building at 139 and 141 West Lake Street this evening. About $200,000 damage was done.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- There will be no State officer voted for on Tuesday next, and but one Congressman. The latter vacancy is in the Thirty-fourth District, and is caused by the designation of Warren B. Hooker, Supreme Court Justice, by the Governor, and his nomination for the office by the Republicans.

The body of Frederick Hardy, Jr., a young art student, the son of a wealthy phosphate mine owner of Mount Pleasant, Tenn., was found floating in Raritan Bay, near Keys-port, N.J., by a fisherman on Wednesday.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 2. -- The Court of Appeals by unanimous decision of the Judges, refused to advance the case of the Brown Democrats who sought to compel precinct election boards to allow anti-Goebel Democratic Inspectors at the polls. The court adjourned till Nov. 8.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 2. -- The greatest difficulty met in developing the Indian team each year is the acquisition of signals and their practical application to the game. A large part of this afternoon's practice was devoted to this work. Each individual was given a thorough going over, and better results were gained than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The bids for the six new cruisers opened at the Navy Department yesterday have been turned over to the Board of Construction, which will pass upon their merits before the bids are awarded. This will take perhaps two weeks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Levi R. Dory, a capitalist, seeks relief in bankruptcy from liabilities amounting to $5,000,000. He is the President of the Northern Fuel Company and the Lehigh Coal and Coke Company. He is also a stockholder in several other mercantile establishments. He scheduled assets of $400,000. The total indebtedness is the largest in any petition since the Bankruptcy act went into effect.

The letter of Capt. MAHAN and the statement of Mr. CLARKE as to the candidacy of Mr. MAZET and that of Mr. STEWART in the Nineteenth Assembly District put the case for the Republican candidate as strongly as it can be put. But the element of weakness in the two statements is that one important fact is either omitted or misrepresented.

Francis Parkman Freeman died suddenly at his home, Lakewood, N.J., yesterday of heart failure. He was seventy-two years old, and was born in Boston. In 1873 he opened a brokerage office in Exchange Place, New York, and handled much of Commodore Vanderbilt's interest during a number of years.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 2. -- Returning warriors never received a warmer welcome home than that accorded to-day to the soldiers of Kansas's famous fighting Twentieth on its arrival from San Francisco. Gen. Frederick Funston came in for the lion's share of attention shown to the officers, and the "Little Hero of Manila" was literally taken off his feet by his admirers in their eagerness to display their regard for him.

At a meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday it was decided to issue an appeal to voters to support at the approaching election the proposed Constitutional amendment providing for the separation of the indebtedness of the counties embraced in the City of New York from the city debt.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2. -- The Bulletin to-day published direct advices, the first that have been received here for months, from the Island of Guam. The advices arrived here on the China, and will be forwarded to Washington as part of a report prepared by the officers of the United States steamer Brutus.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Both the Mutual and Equitable Life Insurance Companies of New York have notified the Government that they have given up the intention to apply for readmittance to do business in Prussia

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve decreased 929,000, circulation increased 574,000, bullion decreased 355,107, other securities decreased 660,000, other deposits decreased 1,337,000, public deposits decreased 252,000, notes reserve decreased 843,000, and Government securities unchanged.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 2. -- The first concert for the present season by the Pittsburg Orchestra was given in Carnegie Music Hall this evening before an immense and enthusiastic audience. The occasion marked the first appearance of Mme. Schumann-Heink since her return from Europe. The concert was a triumph, both for the soloist and for Victor Herbert, who has begun his second year as conductor of the Pittsburg Orchestra.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The Marquis of Lansdowne, Secretary of State for War, was the chief speaker at the Cutlers' feast in Sheffield this evening, the function being attended by the usual distinguished assemblage.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- The Department of Taxes of the City of New York has completed its valuation of real and personal property in New York City for 1899, and certified it to the State Tax Commission. Upon these valuations the State tax levy for 1900 will be made. The figures demonstrate that New York City has increased its real estate valuation by over $100,000,000, and its personal has been slightly reduced.

Messrs. HOLT Co., the publishers of The Educational Review, of which Dr. BUTLER is the editor, having printed what was regarded as a, libel by the President of the Board of Education, he succeeded in getting them indicted by the Grand Jury. The indictment was quashed after the publishers and the editor had been put to pretty heavy and, as the result proved, entirely unjustifiable expense.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Gen. Sir George Stewart White has cabled the War Office that in the engagement at Farquhar's farm, near Ladysmith, on Oct. 30, when Lieut. Col. Carleton's column was compelled to surrender, six officers were killed and nine wounded. Among the non-commissioned officers and men the casualties were 54 in killed and 231 in wounded.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- A cutting cold wind blew across the Yale field this afternoon and dried up the mud caused from two days of heavy rain. It was typical football weather, and the bracing air made the players unusually vigorous. After a half hour's secret practice the 'Varsity lined up against the scrubs for halves of twenty minutes each.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange approached the million-share mark yesterday, almost double recent average daily totals. With the activity there was strength. Almost the entire list made gains, only two or three declines of as much as a whole point taking place, while many more than a score of similar advances were recorded.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 2. -- Bryan sustained no injuries in the carriage accident last night, and to-day delivered six speeches, beginning at Alliance at noon and ending the work of the day at Chadron this evening. To-morrow he will make twenty speeches, and on Saturday he will increase the number to two dozen, concluding the State campaign in a gigantic rally at Lincoln Saturday night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- The Harvard football team left Cambridge this afternoon for Philadelphia, where they will battle with the University of Pennsylvania on Saturday afternoon for the 1899 championship honors. They carried with them the firm confidence of every undergraduate, and the general opinion among the student body at Cambridge is that the Harvard eleven will win, but not without the hardest kind of a struggle.

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court has granted an injunction order, returnable to-day, to determine the relative rights of the Directors and Liquidation Committee of the Franklin National Bank. The bank closed its doors and went into liquidation Aug. 1. It is admitted that there is some impairment of the capital stock of $200,000.

LONDON Nov. 2. -- At to-day's racing of the Lingfield Park November meeting the Sunnyside Selling Handicap was won by May Bruce, with J. Reiff in the saddle. Doria was second and Merely was third. Nine horses ran, and the betting was 5 to 1 against the winner.

We do not see any reason why the postal clerks in this city should be exercised over the receipt of begging circulars from the Finance Committee of the Republican County Committee asking that contributions to be used to defeat Tammany Hall in the coming election shall be sent to JOHN SABINE SMITH, Treasurer, at 30 Broad Street, New York.

The members of the Automobile Club of America are so enthusiastic over the great success of their undertaking that they are discussing the advisability of a big dinner next month to celebrate the formation of the organization.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Cornell adopted this afternoon the tactics that have been pursued by Harvard and Columbia in making the 'Varsity eleven work against an enlarged scrub line. The result was entirely satisfactory from the 'Varsity standpoint. With the scrubs reinforced by five extra men behind their defense, the big team moved across the field against them like clock work.

GENEVA, Nov. 2. -- Word has been received here to the effect that E.F. Berkeley, father of the young Cornell student who was drowned near here last week while being put through the preliminary initiation of the Kappa Alpha fraternity, will not push the matter any further. He has stated, however, that he will make a thorough investigation, but that he will not let the findings of it influence him in the least.

CHATHAM, England, Nov. 2. -- The launching of the British first-class battleship Venerable here to-day was accompanied by scenes of unusual enthusiasm. The christening was performed by Mrs. Joseph Chamberlain, formerly Miss Endicott of Washington, who was accompanied by her husband, the British Secretary of State for the Colonies.

In the racing at Aqueduct yesterday five of the six races resulted in head-and-head finishes. The fourth race, a handicap for all ages, at a mile and a sixteenth, brought into the field only four starters, but they were of fair class. Trillo, who has probably won more money at the Aqueduct meeting than any other horse there, was made the favorite, and was faithful to the trust reposed in him.
PRINCETON. N.J., Nov. 2. -- There were very few of the "regulars" who did not get into the practice game to-day against the college eleven.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The War Office has received a dispatch from the Governor of Natal, Sir Walter Francis Hely-Hutchinson, announcing that communication with Ladysmith has been interrupted since 2:30 P.M. Thursday.

NEWPORT, Nov. 2. -- The wedding of Miss Susan Willing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Willing, to Francis C. Lawrence, Jr., of New York, was celebrated in Trinity Church this afternoon in the presence of relatives and immediate friends. Prior to the ceremony the St. Cecilia Quartet sang several selections.

The Mazet committee is to sit to-day to hear evidence volunteered by Richard Croker, who suddenly injected himself into the proceedings of the committee at its session yesterday in the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation. It had been decided that when the session of yesterday came to a close the committee would adjourn until Nov. 21, as a number of the members desired to give their attention to election matters.

The attention of the People's Committee on the Amsterdam Avenue matter of last year, and of all the people interested therein, is invited to the operations of the Third Avenue Railroad Company, which is now indicating its intention of installing the last two of the four lines of track in Amsterdam Avenue south of Manhattan Street.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 2. -- Edward D. Shultz of New York, well known as a theatrical manager, committed suicide at the Victoria Hotel, this city, some time this morning, but the body was not discovered until late in the day. A bullet wound from a revolver caused his death. Shultz came here Tuesday.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 2. -- At a meeting of the Southern Cotton Spinners' Association in this city to-day, between fifty and sixty mills being represented, resolutions were unanimously adopted urging upon the President of the United States and on the Senators and Representatives in Congress the preservation of the integrity of the Chinese Empire, and the maintenance of an open-door policy in China with the commerce of all nations.

The Mazet committee has done Senator PLATT a grave injustice by adjourning without giving him an opportunity to go on the witness stand. We have no doubt that the example of Gen. TRACY inspired the Senator with a burning desire to unpack his heart before MAZET. The impression that Gen. TRACY made was unquestionably that of a candid witness.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The rest for which the University of Pennsylvania football team came to the seashore has not been realized, as Coach Woodruff put the men through hard signal practice both morning and afternoon at the Inlet Baseball Park.
John N. Golding has sold for William H. McCord to a client the five-story American-basement dwelling 223 West Seventieth Street, 15 by 100.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- A unique performance took place to-night in the Columbia Theatre. After the curtain fell on the last act of "His Excellency the Governor" it was rung up again on a dress rehearsal of an entirely new farce by Guy F. Steely, entitled "Hunting for Hawkins," the novelty of the performance being the fact that it was given as a trial production.

The members of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday tendered a reception to Senor Ignacio M. Mariscal, Vice President and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Mexico, and other prominent Mexicans now in the city. Charles Stewart Smith, Chairman of the Executive Committee, introduced the visitors, and said in part:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- In accordance with the understanding reached at the conference at the White House yesterday, the Philippine Commission to-day submitted to the President the preliminary report which it had promised to prepare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A part of Secretary Root's plan for the government of the American colonies, or dependencies, contemplates the building up of an insular bureau, which shall practically be a department by itself. He has offered to Robert P. Porter the headship of this bureau, but Mr. Porter has not been able to accept it for business reasons.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- The Political Action Committee of the Tippecanoe Club, a strong Republican organization, decided yesterday to recommend the expulsion of United States Senator Mason from its membership. The action was taken on account of Senator Mason's opposition to the policy of the National Administration in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Assistant Secretary Taylor recently sent telegrams to a number of leading architects of the country, asking for an expression of their views on the pending question of the selection of an architect for the New York Custom House building.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 2. -- The Government of Costa Rica has definitely refused to surrender Rutherford, the man charged with the murder of the American citizen, Archer unless the British Government guarantees not to inflict capital punishment, to which the Government cannot accede, thus closing the case so far as Jamaica is concerned.

The Thirtieth Assembly District had a large meeting last night in and around the Old Homestsead, at Ninetieth Street and Third Avenue, when a large amount of enthusiasm for the Tammany Hall ticket of the county and district was stirred up. The grounds of the place were brilliantly illuminated, and there was a display of fireworks which, with the oratory, served to bring out a great crowd.

While your special contributor's conclusions on the effect of the stoppage of gold supplies from the Transvaal may prove to have been correct, the grounds for this optimism are certainly not above questioning.

SAGINAW, Mich., Nov. 2. -- A meeting of the stockholders of the Flint and Pere Marquette Railroad called for to-day to transfer the road to the newly formed Pere Marquette Railway Company, preliminary to consolidation with the Denver,Rio Grande and Western and the C. and W.M. Roads, was postponed to Dec. 6.

A mass meeting was held in the Clermont Avenue Rink, in Brooklyn, last night to ratify the Democratic ticket in Kings County. The rink was plentifully decorated with American flags. The enthusiasm of the crowd was especially manifested in ovations to Edward M. Shepard and Controller Coler.

Campaigning in the Nineteenth Assembly District was carried on vigorously last night. Robert Mazet addressed two open-air meetings held under the auspices of the Nineteenth Assembly District Republican Club, at Sixty-eighth Street and West End Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Other speakers at the Eighty-eighth Street meeting were M.J. Nerney, L.H. Porter, and Julius Seymour, and at the Sixty-eighth Street meeting, M. J. Harrington, N. Grogan, David N. Holmes, and C.S. Dana.

The fiancee of the man who now holds the foremost place in the hearts of his countrymen is in the city buying her trousseau. She is Mildred B. Hazen, widow of Gen. William B. Hazen, and is soon to wed Admiral George Dewey.

Methodist feeling throughout the country is intensely alive over the Epworth League's affairs. A special meeting of the Board of Control of that body has been called in Cincinnati for Nov. 22. This is most unusual, because, under the law, the board may have a stipulated number of meetings only during the quadrennium between General Conferences.

Our neighbor The Sun has been doing a public service of considerable magnitude in calling attention to a huge omission on the part of the municipal administration. That omission is the omission of any precaution to find out how the new bridges will look.

The world owes a considerable debt to M. Eugene Muntz, the learned and faithful French student of art and of the history of art. He has given to us, after years of minute study, the extent and obscurity and complexity of which it is not easy to exaggerate, or even to appreciate, a work on Leonardo that will probably be accepted as final in all essential regards.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- Paris and Berlin continue to supply statements of British reverses, the latest being that Mafeking has fallen.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3. -- The practice of the 'Varsity eleven to-day was short and light. It consisted mainly in rehearsing the signals and going through the formations to be tried against West Point to-morrow and was entirely secret. Yale has two men on the crippled list. Thomas, at end, and Stillman, the left tackle.

OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 3. -- Peter De Graff, a wealthy oyster skipper of West Sayville, was accidentally and fatally shot here today by his friend and companion, William Rudolph. The wounded man was taken to his home at West Sayville, where Drs. Merritt and Krichbaum attended him. He sank gradually, and died at 1:10 o'clock this afternoon.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Football practice was continued this afternoon in a pouring rain. The incessant drizzle of the past few days has put Percy Field in such slippery and soft condition as to make it almost impossible to gauge the merits and mistakes of the teams with any degree of accuracy or to tell what would happen in any given play were the field dry.

-- Even in well-doing, it is wise to show a reasonable moderation and to pay at least a little attention to the laws of proportion. In the minds of a few critics of current events there is now an impression that our treatment of Sir THOMAS LIPTON has been faulty in both these respects and that it illustrates all too clearly the American tendency to "run things into the ground."

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 3. -- The police of this city place little credence in the stories of assault narrated from time to time by Polly McGrail, the woman who has attained notoriety by working in the Hand Silk Mills during the strike of the operatives there. She claims to have been sandbagged one evening recently, but the police have been able to find nothing to confirm the statement.
Sunk in the mire of practical living have I been for long -- too long, in fact, a prisoner mid the perplexities that are like an entail upon the proprietary interests of family life.

Steady rain that drove everybody off the streets compelled the restriction of political oratory within doors in the Nineteenth Assembly District last night. Four indoor rallies were held, one only of which was in the interest of Mr. Mazet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The proposition for a National university at Washington under Government auspices was negatived to-day by the committee of the National Educational Association, which has been in session here the past two days. The committee has a suggestion contemplating a plan in which the persons who have had exceptional educational opportunities may secure the advantages afforded by the institutions at Washington.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Consul Liefeld writes from Freiburg, Sept. 23, 1899:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 3. -- Because of the decision of the local Election Commission to refuse to allow Inspectors for the bolting Democrats at the polls the Brown men will institute mandamus proceedings in the courts, though they can expect little assistance from this source, as the complexion of the judiciary in this city is decidedly Democratic.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The Times, in an editorial on the report of the Philippine Commission, says:
In his letter to Lord Salisbury, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Mr. Frederic Harrison quoted, the following hexameter: Bella geri placuit, nullos habitura triumphos?

DURBAN, Natal, Oct. 27. -- The Natal Mercury relates an incident of the battle at Elandslaagte. The fire of the British guns was getting too hot for the Boers. Eight Boers suddenly ran forward out of cover, and coolly opened fire on the Imperial Light Horse, evidently for the purpose of drawing the British fire while their companions changed their position. Seven of the eight men were instantly killed. -- Press dispatch.

In the new volume (the ninth) of "The National Cyclopedia of American Biography" (James T. White Co.) appears a sketch of Col. Charles Baxter, one of the heroes of the Mexican war, of whom, we believe, no former cyclopedia, and no history, have made any mention. Col. Baxter's name at one time was one of the most familiar in New York.

What might be termed the second wind of the first Autumn storm struck the city yesterday. In the early morning hours any one not sophisticated in weather manners might have thought that a crisp Autumn day was in prospect. When later the northeast wind made the sky gray and the atmosphere cold with a suggestion of early snow, he may have been caught going out without an umbrella.

The new plan for the reorganization of the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad Company will be officially announced on or about the 14th inst. under the auspices of the Philadelphia committee, of which William F. Harrity is Chairman. The plan was perfected yesterday, and copies of it go to Europe to-day.

A. Blackwood, the writer of an able review of Hamerton's "Intellectual Life," published in your SATURDAY REVIEW a few weeks ago, says that Hamerton's "treatment of his subject as related to woman and marriage is an interesting study." The writer of this letter found it not only interesting, but surprising.
Are the Republicans about to "knife" the constitutional amendment permitting the City of New York to borrow much-needed money for public works?
In a cover of unusual beauty and appropriateness, and with illustrations worthy of the text, Mr. Crawford's "Via Crucis" emerges from its serial state and is given to an eagerly awaiting public.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- A special dispatch from Washington asserts that the American State Department recently asked France, Germany, and Russia to give written assurances regarding the preservation of the "open door" in China, being dissatisfied with mere oral assurances, and rejecting a proposal that the United States should seize a port and establish a sphere of influence in China.

The action of the Metropolitan District Cricket League in discussing the absence of Prince Ranjitsinhji from the game in New York, and the accusation that his team acted in a manner scarcely courteous to their hosts while here, have caused surprise in England.

Mr. Low the other evening, at a fusion meeting, broached the idea of requiring a public statement of all political expenditures and of the sources from which they are derived, though he said that he had no clear opinion as to how it would work.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- The rumors about the change in the Columbia Theatre are at last settled. The theatre will not be turned into an office building. Kobi Castle, proprietors of the vaudeville circuit are to take the house and use it for vaudeville under the old name. Al Hayman and Will J. Davis, the present proprietors, are to have a new house.

One of the mystifying things in literature is the extraordinary and altogether unmerited popularity of Victor Hugo's unearthly romance, "Les Miserables." Popularity, did I say? That's not the word for it. The feeling of millions of my compatriots toward that book partakes more of the force and fervor of a religious creed, to question which were sacrilege.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3. -- A very hard, cold rain fell incessantly here all day, but the coaches brought the team out of the cage, where they had been having preliminary practice, and put them through a hard fifteen-minute half. Unless Brown had the benefit of this rainy day's practice, Princeton is likely to give her a drubbing to-morrow, for the field is sure to be soft and wet and the ball soaked.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- A special to The Times-Herald from Indianapolis says: "A number of Chicago men and several representatives of other cities have been here since Wednesday in consultation with reference to forming an anti-trust baking powder company, and it is announced that the details have been completed and that on of the largest baking powder plants in the country will be established in Chicago.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 3. -- Assistant Secretary of War Meiklejohn, who has been stumping the State for ten days in the interest of Republican success, made the following statement to-day:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The difficulties attending the administration of justice in Cuba and Puerto Rico are pointedly brought out in reports to the Judge Advocate General of the Army, Gen. Lieber, whose annual report was made public to-day. Major Dudley, at Havana, states in the course of a report:

Nothing akin to "Egotistography" is to be found in John Sartain's reminiscences of his most useful life, which closed in October, 1897. Of his own work, the helping hand and the wise guidance he gave to American art, he wrote in so modest a manner that one almost wishes he had more particularly emphasized them.
LORENZO MARQUES. Nov. 2. -- Three additional cases of the plague have been reported at Burghersdorp.

Of all the campaigns conducted by the famous soldiers of history, the one which Napoleon undertook when he invaded Russia in May, 1812, is undoubtedly the most interesting. It marked the beginning of the end of a marvelous career. Having subjugated the principal nations of Continental Europe he did not hesitate to take possession of any territory which appealed to his fancy.

At Aqueduct yesterday, Peter Reilly, a member of the Metropolitan Turf Association, was informed by John Cavanagh, who has charge of the betting ring, that his presence in the ring was not desired. The objection was made because of the finding of the Stewards in the case of Ceylon, whose race of a few days ago they investigated.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 3. -- Vice President Hobart, after a short sinking spell which yielded readily to treatment during the early morning hours, grew stonger after daylight and spent a most comfortable day.

The article printed in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW last week on Poe and Mrs. Whitman gives particular interest to the following poem written by Mrs. Whitman after the death of Poe. It appeared in her volume called "Hours of Life and Other Poems," long since out of print and scarce. In order to secure a copy of the poems for THE SATURDAY REVIEW, a request was sent to Providence, Mrs. Whitman's former home.

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 3. -- H.F. Cochems, Harvard's strongest student, to-day made a new college record for the shot put, casting the sixteen-pound iron ball forty-two feet one-half inch. Cochems is a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and is now a student of the Harvard Law School. The record was made on Holmes Field.

James J. Jeffries of Los Angeles, Cal., who wrested the heavyweight championship of the world from "Bob" Fitzsimmons of Australia at the Coney Island Athletic Club on June 9, successfully defended his title last night in a twenty-five-round bout for the championship of the world with "Tom" Sharkey of Ireland.

The most curious aspect of the British situation in South Africa is the amount of credible news that leaks out, past a British censorship and over cables of which every one is in British possession. The explanation probably is, in part, that suggested by the London dispatches, that foreign Governments retain their privilege of sending cipher messages, and that under cover of this privilege they send war news which "transpires."

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The list of casualties among the non-commissioned officers and men at Farquhar's Farm shows the Gloucesters lost 30 killed and 53 wounded, the Fusillers 10 killed and 41 wounded, and the Tenth Mountain Battery 2 wounded before they surrendered. The captured, who are given under the head of missing, are divided as follows: Gloucesters, 19 officers and 330 men; Tenth Mountain Battery, 5 officers and 84 men; Fusillers, not yet reported.

Mr. J.M. Barrie has at length completed the sequel to his "Sentimental Tommy." It is to be called "Tommy and Grizel," and its opening chapters will appear in the January Scribner. Grizel has become a woman and Tommy is celebrated even as the story opens. The action takes place in London, and the most dramatic or artistic scenes will be set off with illustrations by Bernard Patridge.

The inclosed poems came to my notice some time since, and they seem to strike the Autumn harp which THE SATURDAY REVIEW has been recently playing upon to the exquisite delight of its readers with still further charm and rhythm. I cannot tell who wrote these lines.

Weather permitting, the first run of the Automobile Club of America will take place to-day. In the event of a storm the tour will be postponed for one week, starting from the same point and going over the same territory.

James Quigley, who was arrested several days ago at 182 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street by Deputy Superintendent of Elections Masterson, on the charge of illegal registration, was examined yesterday in the West Side Police Court. Quigley had registered in the Nineteenth Election District of the Nineteenth Assembly District, giving his residence as 208 Amsterdam Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The controversy over the selection of an architect for the New York Custom House was finally settled to-day by the approval by the Secretary of the Treasury of the report of the commission appointed to examine the plans of the competitors. The commission recommended the appointment of Mr. Cass Gilbert of New York, and the approval of that report makes Mr. Gilbert the architect of the New York Custom House.

One of the fiercest fires with which the department has had to cope in some time occurred yesterday afternoon in the six-story brick building at 94, 96, and 98 Mott Street. The building and its contents were totally destroyed and there is also every evidence that three men lost their lives in the fire while a number were more or less injured, one fatally.

Richard Croker, at a meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon, took occasion to urge the adoption by the voters of the amendment to the Constitution providing for the separation of city and county debts, and also made a reply for the organization to the charges against District Attorney Gardiner.

My attention has been so frequently called to an interview with Mr. Quigg reported in your columns last week, in which he calls attention to the association of my name with Mr. Stewart's candidacy in the Nineteenth Assembly District, that it is only just to myself to give the reasons why I shall vote for Mr. Stewart, although he will receive the vote of Tammany Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- In a report to the State Department Consul McCook, at Dawson, under date of Sept. 14 last, says that the gold shipments for the season aggregated $9,247,745. Prices of living, he says, have been slowly declining. Typhoid was decreasing, and the death rate had fallen.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 3. -- While 200 men were listening to reports of the Jeffries-Sharkey fight on the second floor of the Great Western Hotel, the floor suddenly collapsed, and they were precipitated in a heap to the first floor. A dozen were more or less hurt, none seriously.

Professional Wall Street devoted energy yesterday in speculations as to what might be the showing of to-day's bank statement. Many gruesome predictions were current, though no bank authority of consequence was quoted as taking any other than favorable views of money market prospects.

The first of the large exhibitions of the year -- that of the New York Water Color Club -- will open to the public to-morrow afternoon in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, in West Fifty-seventh Street. A private view will be given to-day from 10 to 6 o'clock and the usual reception will be held this evening.

In response to numerous inquiries, we regret to announce that Mr. E.L. Godkin has severed his active connection with The Evening Post. It was his intention to do so in any case on the 1st of January next, but the step has been hastened by impaired health. He will continue to be an occasional editorial contributor.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Workmen of the New York, Westchester and Connecticut Traction Company worked all night removing the tracks of the Union Railway, the rival trolley company, from the White Plains Road in the town of Eastchester, outside the village of Bronxville. The task was finished this morning.

"Autumn with the Poets," in your charming paper, THE SATURDAY REVIEW, cast its magic spell over me, and I inclose the little "Autumn Slumber Song" which it inspires. THE SATURDAY REVIEW is certainly the star of literary papers, and must shed its cheering rays to light the way for many who are seeking "the beautiful," as it does for one of the least of its readers.

Your inspiring editorial article in THE SATURDAY REVIEW on "Autumn with the Poets" and the letters it has called forth I have read with delight. Yet to one like myself, who is fond of reading Mother Nature's poems in the original, it seems as if the tone of sadness that characterizes so much that poets have written of the Autumn is not without a raison d'etre.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- President Isaac G. Lombard of the American National Bank to-day announced the committee of bankers which will formulate a National law for uniform check collection charges, in accordance with the action authorized by the Cleveland Conference in September.

There is no longer any doubt as to a conspicuous revival in Irish literature. During the last month or two the work of several new Irish writers has been noted in these columns, and some new editions have been announced of old novels. The most recent addition to the list new fiction is "Some Experiences of an Irish R.M.," by E.E. Somerville and Martin Ross, with illustrations by the former.
Mr. Nathan Bijur has sent the following reply to Mr. William J. Schieffelin, who argued in favor of the election of Perez M. Stewart as Assemblyman from the Nineteenth District:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The War Department has received the following cablegram:

LORD CURZON PLANS TO COMBAT THE GREAT FAMINE IN INDIA. -- It is now believed at the Indian Office in London that a terrible famine is imminent in British India over an area that will exceed the stricken territory of three years ago. The area that appears to be seriously affected comprises 100,000 square miles of British territory, and 250,000 square miles of native States containing in all a population of over 30,000,000.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 4. -- The annual tournament for the championship of the Wee Burn Golf Club was commenced to-day at Noroton. There were numerous entries, and the playing as a rule was good. Among the men the first eight qualified for the championship, and the next eight for the Consolation Cup.

With the advent of Winter and the prospect of the first fall of snow, the trap shooting season at live birds begins. Under the crisp air and the strong breezes that usually prevail during the season that Jack Frost is in evidence, the pigeons, poor victims of the expert gunners, fly faster than in the warmer months.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The Naval and Military Record sums up the situation in South Africa as follows:

The building of underground trolleys and miles of asphalt streets has developed an industry that enjoys many unique features. Sand and gravel have suddenly assumed a commercial value never before attached to either, and the man who could be fortunate enough to own a sandbank on Manhattan Island would realize a fortune little short of that derived from a gold mine.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Harvard won a decisive football victory over the University of Pennsylvania on Franklin Field this afternoon by the score of 16 to 0. Splendid defensive work, timely end runs and steady line bucking made up for frequent fumbling and enabled Harvard to win by a good margin against a team that fought for every inch of ground and gave up the fight very reluctantly when the timekeeper declared the game over

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- Eduard Bernstein has every reason to be satisfied with the result of the Socialist Congress in Hanover. Instead of turning him out of the party his opponents thoroughly debated the questions raised in his book, and finally the Congress, by 216 votes against 21, adopted a resolution which, while indorsing the previous tactics and principles of the party pro forma recognized the justice of many of Bernstein's criticisms.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- President McKinley to-day issued the following order:

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence, who were married here on Thursday, will spend a short time in New York and Philadelphia, and then will start for Europe and during the Winter join Col. and Mrs. Astor on the Nile. The wedding brought to Newport a few of the cottagers, who remained over a day or two and filled Hill Top and the Muenchinger-King cottages to their utmost capacity.

Henry made in 1831 a short quantity circuit, producing a sound signal; the articles composing this are also in the National Museum. BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 4. -- All indications point to the election of John Walter Smith, Democratic candidate for Governor, and his associates on the State ticket next Tuesday. The campaign practically ended to-night, when both the Republicans and the Democrats held large mass meetings in this city.

Ex-Senator FRANK D. PAVEY, in an article in The North American Review for November, satisfies his own mind and attempts to convince his readers that we shall be unable without a Constitutional amendment to keep an open door in the Philippines. We think he is in error and that the development of our policy will show him to be in error.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- The news of the British reverses and losses has been received in Germany with less demonstrations of joy than might have been expected from previous expressions The mistakes and shortcomings of the British preparations are pointed out with much vigor by the press strategists and military writers, but the other newspapers comment on the week's events fairly.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Cottagers have been enjoying an early season of Indian Summer here, and gay parties are everywhere playing golf, riding and driving and gathering chestnuts.

President Callaway of the New York Central is so much pleased with the developments that have attended the reform of exclusively using anthracite on locomotives of his road entering New York, that it is said he contemplates the adoption of a furnace which will use anthracite, and, it is believed, overcome the economical objections always urged in favor of the use of bituminous for traffic.

ROBERTS from Congress support their demands will make it plain to every member of the Fifty-sixth Congress that it cannot be justified by the test of his eligibility under the Constitution of the United States.

While things are going on favorably there is a natural disposition to "let well enough atone," and there is an equally natural fear that if Congress begins to meddle it will go too far or will go wrong.

Mme. Adelina Patti has been giving some excellent advice to a would-be debutante on the operatic stage "Do not make too free use of warm clothing, but harden yourself against changes of temperature. Thanks to infinite and minute precautions I have preserved my voice, but I have always been careful not to weaken myself by excessive fear of heat or cold.

Tuxedo defeated Morris County at golf yesterday in a closely contested team match. The game was played on the Morris County links, at Morristown, N.J., and the visitors won by 1 point, scoring 7 points to 6.
A deficit in Clearing House bank reserves -- this was the Wall Street sensation of yesterday.

Hinduism is not a single religion, but a huge encyclopedia of distinct and independent worships; it is not a unity either of thought or custom, but an immense multiplicity of sects and their observances. It may be described as the amalgam of all the religious ideas and usages of all the Indian peoples through all their past.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Commissioner Wilson of the Internal Revenue Bureau has decided that when banks loan money without taking promissory notes, and specified collaterals are pledged as security for a certain and definite sum of money as evidenced by memoranda and entries on bank loan books, , a tax accrues as a pledge. The question came up on a case in Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Not even in the early days of its construction has there been more activity than there is at present on the Drainage Canal. Next month is the time set long since for its completion, and it was not until a few months ago that the Trustees began to realize that unless the work was pushed more rapidly it would not be finished in time.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- Mark Hambourg, the young Russian pianist, who achieved such success in Europe and Australia in the last few years, made his first appearance in America at the concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra to-night and won marked recognition by an audience that crowded Music Hall.

After Columbia defeated Yale so decisively at football last Saturday, a few dissatisfied collegians tried to cause trouble between the two universities, which have always enjoyed friendly relations, by circulating rumors to the effect that Columbia's victory was secured through unsports-manlike methods, alleging that the head coach, G. Foster Sanford, and Morris Ely, former Yale players revealed Yale secrets.
Sir: After something more than twelve years of absence, I return to New York to make it once more my home, and find many surprising changes.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 4. -- The schooner Clara, bound from Rockland, Me., to New York, with a cargo of lime, went ashore here at an early hour this morning. After striking her cargo caught fire and burned fiercely all day and until late to-night. Her crew, consisting of six men, were in no danger, and they managed to save a good part of the rigging and sails of the boat.

"Whatever you do," wrote STEVENSON to a young American of sixteen, "read something else besides novels and newspapers; the first are good enough when they are good; the second, at their best, are worth nothing. Read great books of literature and history; try to understand the Roman Empire and the Middle Ages," and thus, reasoned this idolater of "literature," "you will know a little more about to-day, and may be a good President."
Three favorites and as many outsiders crossed the line winners at Aqueduct yesterday, and Jockeys O'Connor and Jenkins had each two winning mounts to their credit.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- The local market was characterized by a fairly sharp break in Diamond Match. The stock has been very quiet for some time, with the price holding well around 130. This morning, however, on a very moderate selling prospect, there was a decline to 127 1/2, and the close was at that figure.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman, the new rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, preached his first sermon yesterday, taking the pulpit in succession to the Rev. Dr. Gustav Gottheil.

The General Chemical Company did the best wor, k: in the games decided in the Wholesale Drug qrade Association tournament: at Reid's alleys, 200 Church Street, , yesterday afternoon. This is the first sea- son that the company has entered a team, :and it, bids fair to carry off first Drlze. Scores:

I cannot understand how Mr. Schurz can call our position in the Philippines imperialism. We certainly did not enter upon the war with Spain with any thought of imperialism or annexation, our sole motive being to reduce Spain to subjection, and we did it. In accomplishing our object we realized the saying that "war never ends where it begins," and by our superior naval power we came into possession of Manila.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- For the past year, under instructions from the President, the State Department has been quietly negotiating for the consummation of American interests in China. The officials of the State Department flatly refuse to make any statement relative to the measure of success that has attended their efforts, though it is admitted that the subject so far is still open, although the prospects of ultimate success are regarded as highly encouraging.

While being taken to Bellevue Hospital last night an unknown woman, who was insane, attempted to jump from a Hudson Street Hospital ambulance at Fourteenth Street and Second Avenue. In her efforts to escape the woman stabbed with a long hatpin Policeman Dunbar and Dr. Sherrill, the former in the hand and the latter in the cheek and chin.

The art of cutting a quill by adept "quill-drivers" was dying when I first began schooling. Steel pens had been known for some time, but were not in general use. The goose quill pen died a hard death as a commonly used writing tool. My first schoolmaster was a first-rate hand at cutting a quill, and he could use it with wonderful effects in flourishes.

The question is often asked, particularly by those who can recall the customs and experiences of twenty-five years ago, "Why do so many persons nowadays wear glasses?" The answer is easy: "The increase in the number of spectacles worn is not to be regarded as an evidence of modern degeneration of the eyes, but rather that a long-felt necessity has been met."

James J. Jeffries, who defended his title of heavyweight champion of the world at the Coney Island Athletic Club Friday night against Thomas Sharkey, and incidentally earned about $30.000, left for Philadelphia yesterday afternoon to keep an engagement to box Joseph Goddard.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 4. -- Mr. Chauncey M. Depew has been in Lenox for a few days as the guest of Mr. John Sloane. He comes up to Wyndhurst nearly every year. Mr. John Sloane accompanied Mr. Depew from New York in his private car. While here Mr. Depew received many attentions from the cottagers.

"In every child there lies a wonderful deep," says Schumann, and so there does, but few people realize how capable the child mind occasionally is of grasping theories and problems, which, being considered to be too abstruse for its comprehension, are discussed with more or less freedom in the presence of children by their elders.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Although outwardly calm, the suppressed anxiety of the country over this South African war is intense. Last Monday night, when the news reached the War Office of the disaster to the brigade at Ladysmith, a perfect panic seized the military clubs of the West End, and all sorts of further disasters were predicted.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Caleb L. Crockett, forty-four years old, of 47 Spring Street, this city, was arrested at the Pace Hotel to-night by Internal Revenue Agent Thompson of New York. The man was taken to Police Headquarters, where Agent Thompson charged him with erasing cancel marks from revenue stamps.

The Queen, that is, in spite of the thousand temptations which must have arisen during sixty-two years of sovereignty, has never shown fussiness, irritability, overanxiety, or any other form of distraction and want of mental balance.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- The Republicans wound up their municipal campaign to-night by a general ratification meeting in the Alhambra, addressed by the Republican candidate for Mayor, ex-Attorney General Theodore E. Hancock, Senator Horace White, Congressman M.E. Driscoll, Ceylon H. Lewis, and Walter W. Magee.

Elections will be held in twelve States on Tuesday, New York, New Jersey, and Virginia electing only members of the State legislative body. Governors will be chosen in Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, and Mississippi, while the other States choose only minor State officers, and in some cases members of the Legislature.

Election Day, as has been the case for the past three years, will be prolific in golf matches on all the links in the metropolitan district. Nor will New York be the only locality to feel this golf activity, for the devotees of the sport in Boston and Philadelphia will be busy, and news from the West is that there will be plenty of fun at the clubs around Chicago and other localities.

The hottest campaign yet fought in the Nineteenth Assembly District came to a practical close last night with oratory, fireworks, the sending out of appeals to voters by the opposing candidates, and in charges and counter-charges. To-day and to-morrow will be spent in closing up the odds and ends of the campaign and making final preparations for the work of Tuesday.

The wealth of the clans consisted not in silver and gold, but in flocks and herds. Some of the latter were bred in districts from which they had been forcibly "lifted," but their possessors would point to the consideration that their late owners probably held four-footed property of which they also had, by similar means, forcibly deprived their original owners.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 4. -- Colombian advices dated Oct. 31 and private direct advices contradict the story received over censored cables of the destruction of the Colombian insurgent fleet, which now resolves itself into the capture of a few small boats, conveying 200 insurgents, of whom 20 were killed. The others escaped ashore.

A large room has been set apart for library purposes in the office assigned to City Superintendent Maxwell and his staff in the new building of the Board of Education. Dr. Maxwell has asked that a suitable sum be appropriated for the purpose of providing in this room a central educational library for the use of his board of examiners and such members of the supervising and teaching force as may desire to consult it.

We had stopped the night before at the small village of Jepiroh, beautifully situated on high ground, and chiefly remarkable for the numbers of small green and red parrots that swarmed in the guinea corn fields all round it.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- A large body of undergraduates was out this afternoon to see the last home practice before the Columbia game. In spite of the absence of Coach Haughton and Capt. Starbuck, who were in Philadelphia to get ideas from the Harvard-Pennsylvania game the practice was very lively, and the men were put through a hard afternoon's work.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4. -- A dispatch from Nashville, Tenn., says that Judge W.J. Wood of Florence, Ala., has received a letter from Gen. Joseph Wheeler, who states that he will resume his seat in Congress when that body meets. Gen. Wheeler does not say when he will return from the Philippines.

To-day in the Thirty-first District the Republican organization has just issued a circular in support of Mr. Slater, its candidate for the Assembly. Under the head of "Witnesses to His Record," after quoting Gov. Roosevelt and others, I am surprised to read the following: "Mr. Edward L. Heydecker, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union of this district: 'The record of Assemblyman Slater certainly commends itself to all voters.

The instant that any one is admitted to membership on any other grounds than ability the decline of the society has begun. Regular attendance can be secured only by arousing the enthusiasm of the members.

The evolution of dress is very interesting. It is a far deeper subject and involves much more than the casual observer would imagine. In years gone by the making of costumes, as we all know, was largely controlled by an uneducated class of people, who, although they strove to produce effects, were without the finesse and delicacy of idea that breeding and association with the people who wear the clothes can alone give.

With regard to the future colonization of this outlying portion of the empire of the Czar, there is no doubt that an unmistakable gain will be derived, for the growth of the population in Siberia, where an area of 13,400,000 square miles is inhabited by only 7,100,000 souls, and where the extraordinary wealth in minerals, woods, and arable land still awaits exploitation, will certainly proceed with greater strides than heretofore.

DEER ISLAND, Me., Nov. 4. -- The men who sailed the victorious yacht Columbia had their formal welcome home at the hands of the Deer Islanders to-night. The procession was abandoned owing to a storm, but the men were given a reception, during which each member of the Columbia's crew was presented with a medal, the gift of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- The State campaign in Massachusetts, which practically closed to-night, has been more than ordinarily dull, even for an off year, the Republicans being confident of victory and the Democrats only hopeful of making a better showing than last Fall.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- The Carlisle Indians this afternoon at Genesee Park easily defeated Hamilton College by a score of 32 to 0. The game was decided within the first five minutes of play, for in that time the redmen rushed the oval over the line for a touch-down, and thus demoralized Hamilton to a certain extent.

ATLANTA, Nov. 4. -- Rear Admiral W.S. Schley was welcomed to Atlanta to-day. The early hour of the arrival of the train prevented a large crowd from being present at the station, but the reception was, nevertheless, warm. In the party besides the Admiral were Mrs. Schley, Miss Letterman, Gen. Felix Agnus, and Mr. Louis Garthe of Baltimore.

In your issue of Oct. 28, the article entitled "Hilton Will Fight Bitter," you report that Mr. Dos Passos made the following remark: "This eminent jurist, Judge Hilton, attached a seal to his will, an entirely unnecessary act, and a thing which the veriest tyro in the legal profession would not have been guilty of."

The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs opens its annual convention at Rochester on Nov. 8, to continue three days. One of the "distinguished" women to be present will be Queen Lavinia H. Van W. Dempsey of the Holland Dames, who, with the Mrs. May Banks Stacey, is a delegate from that organization.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- The Emperor's naval projects have formed the main subject of press discussion this week. The Government now admits that the revised plan really means doubling the navy, as compared with what it would be under the plan of 1897, and that 25,000 additional men will be needed for the new fleet.

Republicans of the Twentieth Assembly District did not march past the Tammany district headquarters in East Thirty-second Street last evening. As originally planned, the parade was to pass through Thirty-second Street, but on Thursday Capt. F. Norton Goddard, the Republican leader in the district, received a note from Chief Devery requesting him to call at the Bureau of Information.

Several changes were made yesterday in the figures submitted to Richard Croker by the Tammany leaders in the various Assembly districts at Friday's meeting of the Executive Committee. Mr. Croker declined to make any of the estimates public, saying that they had only been made for the purpose of seeing how close the leaders could come to guessing the results in their districts.
The initial run of the Automobile Club of America yesterday was a pronounced success.

The recent assignment of Dr. William L. Felter as Principal of the new Commercial High School in Brooklyn Borough calls attention to the fact that there is no such school in Manhattan. City Superintendent Maxwell is now making every effort to supply this deficiency.

My critic, under the head of "A Worse City Nuisance," jumps to the conclusion, rather hastily, that any one who objects to mud and slime on the streets is "willing to live in and breathe a dust-laden atmosphere."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4. -- Eighteen persons narrowly escaped death on a Fourth Avenue car this evening by being run into by a Louisville and Nashville passenger train. The street car was literally smashed to splinters, but no one was killed. The motorman saw the locomotive bearing down on him, but stuck to his post, throwing the electric current on full force.

Already we have the beginnir, gs of a new method of utilizing natural energy which will prove enormously more effective than coal ever has been, and will be practically inexhaustible, to whatever extent industry may expand.'

The leaders of the New Jersey Democrats are attacking the Republican Party by sending circulars into the doubtful counties of Gloucester, Salem, Somerset, Monmouth, and Cumberland, calling attention to the Stokes Education bill, known as Senate bill 197, which was laid over from the last Legislature, and which they claim would, if passed, be subversive of the rights and powers of the people.

Agnes Sorma sticks to her published plan of giving a series of performances in Paris during the Exposition next year. But there is likely to be another German dramatic troupe in Paris at the same time.

A performance of Leopold Lewis's English version of "Le Juif Polonais," called "The Bells," so closely associated with the fame of Henry Irving, was followed last night With rapt attention by an audience which crowded the Knickerbocker Theatre and expressed its admiration of the actor's art in a tumult of applause.

The recent war with Spain has awakened the people of the United States to a realization that this Nation is not altogether exempt from the dread possibilities of foreign war. Uneasiness and even fright was felt by the inhabitants of all our sea coasts. A very large emergency fund was appropriated.

Will you permit me to correct an amusing error in the letter of Mr. Jesse W. Reno in THE SUNDAY TIMES of the 29th inst., headed "The Real Barbara Frietchie"? He speaks there of a "Mrs. Rives of 905 Cathedral Street, Baltimore," as "formerly a Mrs. Shriver Tompkins." Now "there is no such person" as Mrs. Rives, and, to the best of my knowledge, never was such.

Mayor SAMUEL M. JONES of Toledo informs our neighbor The World that his State Committee estimates the vote in Ohio to-morrow in this way: JONES, nonpartisan, 335,000; NASH, Republican, 300,000; McLEAN, Democrat, 265,000.

I have for years been a constant reader of your esteemed paper, and not often have I felt so dissatisfied with anything in it as with your attitude as regards the South African war now going on. One day you seem to favor the Boers, and then again you side with the British. So far as I can see, there are no good reasons for this ever-repeated "about face." No one can serve two masters.

A brief telegraphic dispatch on Saturday announced the arrival at St. Thomas of ex-President IGNACIO ANDRADE of Venezuela, on his way to Puerto Rico. Mr. ANDRADE was compelled to yield the Presidency of Venezuela to Gen. CIPRIANO CASTRO, who was assisted in a successful revolt against ANDRADE by Gen. HERNANDEZ, who has since revolted against CASTRO.
Beaming with happiness and looking, as she said she felt, "outrageously healthy." Mme. Lillian Nordica arrived from Europe yesterday on the overdue St. Paul.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5. -- The most significant development in the Ohio campaign since yesterday is the prediction made by e-Gov. Charles Foster, who has been speaking throughout the State for the Republican ticket. He estimates the total vote of the State at 975,000, of which Nash, Republican, will get not less than 465,000, McLean, Democrat, not more than 410,000, and Jones, Non-partisan, and all others will divide the remainder.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 5. -- The report that W.H. McCrokie and H.P. Headly have been trying to purchase the old Kentucky Association track from its St. Louis owners is denied by The Thoroughbred Record, published in this city. The track has grown up in weeds on account of the gates having been nailed up all Summer.
Rabbi Samuel Schulman, at Temple Beth-El, spoke yesterday morning on "Zangwill's Children of the Ghetto, an Incomplete Picture of Jews and Judaism." He said in part:
The following letter was yesterday sent to Chairman Mazet by Frank Moss of counsel to the Legislative Investigating Committee:

It is with no uncertain voice that President HADLEY of Yale speaks in the November number of Scribner's on the "Formation and Control of Trusts." And there is no one at present that could speak with more authority. Of all the American writers on subjects of an economic character, there is none who has a cooler judgment or wider information or a greater power of clear and comprehensive generalization.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5. -- The time for action has almost come. The campaign in Kentucky is over, and with the exception of a last rally in this city to-morrow around the standards of the party leaders, there will be no more work for the various tickets in the field.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- Chairman Reeder of the Republican State Committee said to-night that he has now received reports from every county in the State conveying conservative estimates of the vote of Tuesday next. He declined to make public any of these county estimates, but said his estimate, based on these returns, is that the Republican State ticket will have a plurality of at least 175,000 votes.

Fannie Eskilla a young woman who was found by Patrolman Tighe of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Police Station trying to break in her skull with a paving stone at the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-second Street, on Saturday night, jumped through a plate-glass window at the J. Hood Wright Memorial Hospital yesterday morning, and landed on the walk below, which, luckily, was only one story from the window.

LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 5. -- Arthur Henry, twenty-one years old, son of S.P. Henry, a pominent Democratic politician who has been Speaker of the House in the Legislature for many years, and Sidney Debarge, his chum, are in jail charged with murder, the former as principal and the latter as accessory.

The Speedway was the scene of some rare sport yesterday morning, when there was a gathering of horseflesh that would have delighted the most exacting horseman. About every speedy horse in and about the city was out for a jog, and the result was a series of lively brushes, several of which were among the best seen on the Speedway this Fall.

Capt. Anthony J. Griffin and Company F of the Sixty-ninth Regiment have a grievance against Col. Edward Duffy, commander of the regiment, and Brig. Gen. George Moore Smith is likely to have a hand in the matter. The trouble is the result of the parade in honor of the late Gen. Guy V. Henry on Sunday, Oct. 29.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Standard says:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 5. -- Great excitement exists to-day in Kenton County, the home of William Goebel, candidate of the Democratic Party for Governor, over the circulation of a report of a plan for wholesale fraud at the elections on Tuesday. According to this report, several thousand rings bearing rubber stamps have been distributed.
