Patrick Divver presided last night at the final Democratic rally of the campaign in the Second Assembly District, and his hosts of followers filled the old Thalia Theatre from the orchestra to the gallery of the gods. The audience was a yelling and enthusiastic multitude from the Bowery and the streets adjacent.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- The boys who attempted to stampede the other boys at the Reform School at Jamesburg on Sept. 12 were sentenced yesterday for the assault upon the guards which followed the attempt. The effort to stampede the whole school was not a success, and only those who planned the affair took part in it.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The War Office issued the following at 11:40 P.M. yesterday:

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 5. -- The present week will without doubt be the hardest of the season for the Yale football squad, as the coachers plan to give the men a week of pounding such as they will not experience during the two remaining weeks after the game of next Saturday with the Pennsylvania State College eleven. The weeks immediately preceding the Harvard and the Princeton games will be much easier for the players.

Simon Clauer, thirty-four years old, was arraigned in Morrisania Court yesterday on suspicion of having thrown his wife, Anne, two years his junior, from a window of their flat on the fourth floor of the tenement 822 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street shortly after midnight. Clauer was held by Magistrate Cornell without bail pending the action of the Coroner.

The twentieth annual meeting of the Directors of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society was held yesterday. Samuel D. Levy, President of the Board of Trustees, read his annual report, which included the report of the Treasurer for the fiscal year just ended. The income from bequests and membership fees was $102,911.19, and the disbursements $102,725.52.

The second annual Ladies' Day of the Strollers' Club will be observed Friday afternoon with a reception in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The membership of the club, which was modeled after the famous Tavern and St. Botolph Clubs of Boston, is made up largely of clubmen who are amateur patrons of the stage.

All the employes in the distributing department of the General Post Office were called out yesterday to relieve an unusual congestion in both the local and outgoing mails, the men who receive Sunday as a holiday being compelled to forego their usual day of rest. The first Sunday of the month is always a busy day at the Post Office. Nothing like the volume of mail handled yesterday has been received for many months.

MANILA, Nov. 5. -- This evening a fleet of transports and gunboats left Manila for the most important expedition of the Autumn campaign. Its destination is supposed to be Dagupan or some other northern port.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Otto Maya turned the tables on "Archie" MacEachern to-day at the last meet at the Vailsburg bicycle track by defeating him in the international team pursuit race. MacEachern's partner was "Bobby ' Thompson, and Fred Sims rode with Maya. Both MacEachern and Thompson are from Canada.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A vigorous plea for rural free delivery is made in the annual report of First Assistant Postmaster General Perry S. Heath, made public tonight.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 5. -- Vice President Hobart remains to-night in about the same condition he has been in for the last three or four days. There was no change to-day either for better or worse. Dr. Newton said he had not issued a bulletin to-day because there was nothing to say.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Adjt. Gen. H.C. Corbin arrived in this city to-day. Tomorrow he will go to his old home, Batavia, to vote, and will return immediately to Washington. He remarked briefly on the Philippine situation that he fully expected to see the end of the insurrection by February. He said the military authorities there have orders to end the uprising without further parleying.

-- According to The London Chronicle, "the British Empire is face to face with a repulse comparable only to the surrender of BURGOYNE to the embattled farmers of our American colonies." The analogy is indeed an appreciably close one, but will not Gen. WHITE and his friends find it extremely hard to endure?

It is not often that an ocean steamship is rammed at sea and practically disabled by a sailing vessel, but this is what happened on Saturday evening to the Savannah Line steamship Tallahassee, which put back into port for repairs, arriving at her dock at midnight, six hours after sailing on her regular trip to Savannah.

Admiral Dewey came to the city yesterday afternoon on the train from Washington which arrived in Jersey City at 2:45 o'clock. He was accompanied only by his Chinese valet. The Admiral wore a high hat, a black overcoat, and black clothes. There was no demonstration in the railroad station when he alighted. His arrival at that hour was unexpected, and very few, if any, of the persons in the station recognized him.

Mr. Croker issued last night from the Democratic Club a statement attacking the Republican Party in general and "Platt's law firm" in particular for alleged opposition to the rapid transit plan and failure to help pass the amendment to the Constitution providing for the separation of the county and city debts. His statement follows:

The Central Federated Union practically came out yesterday as a supporter of the Fusion ticket, although it was not supposed to support either of the old parties. It had organized the Independent Labor Party and started it afloat with directions to nominate genuine, independent labor men, and not to affiliate with either of the existing dominant parties.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Daily Mail publishes the following dispatch from Burghersdorp, dated Nov. 2:

A correspondent ("J.L.B.") in last Friday's TIMES questioned the grounds of the optimistic view taken by the present writer of the effect of the "hold-up" of the Transvaal gold supply by the war in South Africa. He thinks that its coincidence with expanding trade must reduce current resources and intensify the pressure on banking reserves, and that this may be a serious matter.

GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- The sad drowning accident in which Edward Fairfax Berkeley of St. Louis, a Cornell student, met his death while undergoing the preliminary initiation of the Kappa Alpha Fraternity, will probably be presented to the Grand Jury. District Attorney Moran of Seneca County, in which county the accident occurred, is the authority for the above statement.

Register Isaac Fromme, who has been conducting the campaign of Perez M. Stewart for the Assembly, yesterday made good his threat to give out the names of men who, he charged, had been directing the colonization of voters in the Nineteenth District in the interest of the Republican ticket.

At the Presbyterian Ministers' Association meeting, which was held yesterday in the Presbyterian Building, the Rev. Dr. David G. Wylie read a paper entitled "The Services of the Roman Catholic Church to American Civilization," which aroused discussion. Dr. Wylie bestowed high praise upon the Roman Catholic Church for many things.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6. -- Gov. Bradley, in his capacity as Commander in Chief of the State National Guard, is the central figure in the political situation to-night. The Governor believes the situation to be so serious that he will not go to his home at Lancaster, only about a hundred miles from Louisville, to cast his vote to-morrow.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The Rev. Acton T. Civill, pastor of the Methodist Church here, is believed to have become suddenly insane. He created a sensation in the church yesterday, and nobody could account for his actions until the theory of insanity was suggested.

If all the world loves a lover, how much greater is the affection inspired in the public by a lover who is at the same time a National hero? This question was naturally suggested by the interest that Admiral Dewey stirred up when he showed his face yesterday outside of the Cambridge Hotel, at Thirty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, where he is now staying.

Not until the Bureau of Navigation thought of it did it occur to anybody to attempt to add to the glory of any other officer or officers of the navy by minimizing the glory of the victory of Admiral DEWEY at Manila.

In this morning's issue you answer the questions of your correspondent "Morris Henry" by telling him that in case of the death of Vice President Hobart Senator William P. Frye, as President pro tem. of the Senate, would become the President of the Senate, and if the President of the United States should also die the Secretary of State would become acting President.

An unidentified young woman bicyclist, well dressed in a pretty wheeling costume, was run over and instantly killed at the intersection of Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue early last evening by an express wagon belonging to the Long Island Express Company. The accident occurred at 8 o'clock, and at the time when Fifth Avenue is crowded with vehicles and wheelmen and wheelwomen.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 6. -- A local paper says this city is soon to be the centre of the automobile industry of the United States. A man from Iowa has invented a machine weighing not more than seventy-five pounds which can be attached to any vehicle now drawn by a horse and is capable of reaching a speed of fifty miles an hour.
Prof. J.K. Rees told about falling stars and the meteoric display expected next week in an illustrated lecture last night before the New York Academy of Sciences, at 12 West Thirty-first Street.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Although the exact terms of the agreement are still carefully guarded, it can be said with some degree of certainty that the Samoan question is practically settled, and that the finalities will take place within a few days, unless some most unexpected hitch occurs.
CAPE CHARLES, Va., Nov. 6. -- An unknown man jumped or fell from the steamer Old Point Comfort as she was making her landing here last night and was drowned.

GREENPORT, L. I., Nov. 6. -- The trial of the submarine boat Holland under the supervision of the Board of Inspection and Survey of the United States Navy took place in Peconic Bay to-day. The members of the board, led by Rear Admiral Rogers, congratulated the inventor, John P. Holland, at the conclusion of the trial.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6. -- A meeting of the Regents of the Confederate Museum was held here to-day, and the shaft of the iron-clad Virginia (the Merrimac) was presented to the Confederate Museum. The presentation addresses were made by Col. Aston Ramsey of Baltimore and Virginius Newton of this city.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6. -- Arrangements have been perfected for a combination of the lime manufacturing concerns in the South. The new company will be known as the Consolidated Lime Company. It will go into operation on Jan. 1, 1900, and will have a capital of about $2,500,000.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6. -- Cleveland capitalists, including M.J. Mandelbaum Co., F.D. Pomeroy, D.N. Kimberly, and A.E. Akins, are back of a project to build the longest trolley line in the world in the Miami Valley. They have already obtained control of the electric railroads connecting Cincinnati, Hamilton, and Dayton, and are operating them as one system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Auditor for the Post Office Department in his annual report shows that during the last year the number of Post Offices in the United States increased from 72,976 to 74,384; the number of domestic money orders issued increased from 27,798,078, representing $401,113,717, to 29,007,870, representing $442,483,354, a net increase in number of 1,209,792, and in volume of $41,369,636.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- Those in the list of the line-up of the Yale 'Varsity eleven that played against West Point on Saturday were given light work to-day, but the other candidates were subjected to hard practice. After the usual secret play the 'Varsity and scrub elevens lined up to halves of twenty minutes each.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- Prof. M.M. Marble, the head of the scientific department of the Hillhouse High School, and well known for several inventions in the line of applied physics, has just finished work on a new system of wireless telegraphy, and has already tried his invention with marked success.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The 'Varsity men are still resting, because it is part of the management's plan to go easy and not bring the men to the top notch prematurely.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 6. -- The properties of the Elyton Company were sold at noon to-day to W.H. Halls of New York, representing the Reorganizing Committee, for $1,040,000. The sale was under a decree of the Chancery Court on the cross bill of the Maryland Trust Company filed in the case of Semmes and others against the Elyton Company.
While the South African war is going on it may be of interest to recollect what Frederick the Great thought of the English when they made war on the American colonists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The War Department has received the following cablegram:

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 6. -- Amos L. Allen, Republican candidate for Congress in the First Maine District, was elected to-day by a majority of more than 4,600 votes over Luther F. McKinney, the Democratic candidate. With the town of Dayton, in York County, to hear from, Mr. Allen's majority is over 4,657. Dayton will doubtless reduce this, but not enough to bring it below 4,600.
At Aqueduct yesterday, Buffoon was the first of the four favorites that won. This was in a seven furlong dash for three-year-olds and upward.

Richard Croker, in talking of the prospects of to-day's election, at Tammany Hall yesterday, made a direct charge of treason against ex-Senator Hill, who, he said, was working against the Democratic ticket. Although he did not mention Mr. Hill by name, Mr. Croker's allusion to the ex-Senator was so pointed that the latter's friends at once divined who was meant, and they lost no time in resenting the charge.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- At the first day of the Lincoln Autumn meeting, to-day, the Chaplain Nursery Stakes were won by Innel!an. Friar Buck finished second and Downbam, ridden by "Ted" Sloan, was third. Fourteen horses ran.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., .Nov. 6. -- Eighteen acres of land here, including valuable water rights, were transferred to-day to the American Investment Company by Mrs. Richard C. Shreve. The company will replace the present mill dam with a substantial stone dam capable of impounding a big head of water, which will overflow the meadows in all directions.

A number of boys on Sunday evening were annoying a girl in front of the residence of Major Rudolph Fitzpatrick, a veteran, at 82 Edgecombe Avenue. Major Fitzpatrick opened his window and commanded the boys to desist. The boys answered in such a profane manner that the ire of the Major was aroused, and he put on his hat and rushed to the street.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6. -- To-morrow will be election day in New Orleans and a legal holiday. It will be the first city election held in November, the new Constitution having separated State and municipal elections. There are two tickets in the field, one headed by Mayor Flower and supported by the Citizens' League and the Jackson Democratic Association, the other headed by Paul Capdevielle and supported by the regular Democratic organization.
A runaway horse ran madly through the principal streets of the shopping district between 6 and 7 o'clock last evening, creating great excitement and injuring two persons.

Any intelligent banker, any Secretary of the Treasury that we have had for the last fifty years, could devise a system of automatic restraints upon the issue of circulating notes by banks that, while allowing an increase commensurate with the legitimate demands of business, would effectually prevent speculative overissues by reckless bankers. Every currency plan worthy of attention contains such checks.

The Cornell-Columbia football game, to be decided at Manhattan Field this afternoon, is looked upon as one of the most important games of the year, particularly to Columbia. A victory for the local university over Cornell will place Columbia on an equal footing with the "Big Four" ahead of Yale and Princeton.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 6. -- A dispatch from Maseru, Basutoland, dated Friday evening, says that since Magistrate Lagden's warning that their interference with the Basutos would cause an uprising, the Boers have been letting the Basutos cross the river into Basutoland. The natives, however, continued to complain that they were being robbed of their savings by the authorities. There is no disguising from the natives that the British suffered a reverse at Ladysmith.

Justice Scott, in the Supreme Court, yesterday held, in the case of John Parris, a motorman charged with the death of Capt. Rhoads of the Seventh Regiment, that running a car fifteen miles or over in the streets of New York is criminal negligence.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Daily Mail says it is practically certain that the Empress and the two youngest children will accompany Emperor William in his Majesty's forthcoming visit to England.
MANILA, Nov. 6. -- Magalang, the town taken yesterday by two columns of Gen. MacArthur's division, under Col. Smith and Major O'Brien, is a strong town, situated midway between Angeles and Arayat.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 6. -- On the links of the Wee Burn Golf Club this afternoon the tournament for the club championship was continued. Those to meet in the finals to-morrow are George Hecker and W.B. Wheeler, and Miss Genevieve Hecker and Miss Gladys Robinson. These matches will be at 36 holes, and will doubtless prove of great interest.

PIETERMARITZBURG, Natal, Nov. 4. -- The General commanding the line of communication with Maritzburg has arrived with his staff at Estcourt. Telegraphic communication north of Estcourt is entirely stopped.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 6. -- The most important brown ore deal ever negotiated in the South has just been consummated in Florence, Ala., by A.A. Berger and N.C. Elting, President and Secretary and Treasurer respectively of the West Point Mining Company.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 6. -- There are six candidates for Governor to be voted for in Ohio to-morrow. Three of them claim their election is sure. The Jones vote will reduce the vote of all others, including that of the Prohibitionists, the Union Reform, and the Social-Labor tickets, and the result depends very materially on where most of the Jones vote will come from.

Yesterday's business at private contract was what might have been expected of a day between Sunday and election day. Reports were current of the sale of a large piece of vacant property on the west side, between One Hundred and Tenth and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Streets, but inquiry from the owners' representatives revealed only pending negotiations, which, however, are in a fair way to have a successful termination.

The case of the alleged theft of a watch belonging to Charles H Willcox of Westport, Conn., a Director of the Willcox Gibbs Sewing Machine Company, which was brought into court on Sunday by the arraignment of William Fagan, a waiter, who had aroused Mr. Willcox's suspicions, proved yesterday, when Fagan was discharged, to be one of more than ordinary interest.
PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The Vice President is slightly weaker at midnight tonight.

I have addressed you on one or two occasions anent the new arrangement -- or let me say the stupid arrangement -- of street signs, which, as you may remember, stirred up quite a commotion at the time of its inauguration, and you printed several communications from your readers on that subject.

Efforts on the Stock Exchange yesterday to use Saturday's bank statement as a demoralizing influence accomplished little. Quotations did at the outset of the day yield somewhat, but it was not long before very clear evidence showed that owners of securities were in nowise nervous. Nothing like liquidation appeared anywhere. And before the day was over most of the early recessions disappeared, and in almost the entire list some notable advances showed.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Gen. Lord Wolseley, the Commander in Chief, who was the guest of the Authors' Club last evening, said that the short-service system in the British Army had at last been acknowledged as the right one, even by its most strenuous opponents.

Sherlock Holmes's triumph on the stage will equal if not fairly surpass his triumph in the circulating libraries. The new charm Dr. Doyle lent to his detective yarns was the charm of humor. The typical detective of fiction had always seemed to lack the very sense of humor. Vidocq, Monsieur Lecocq, and Hawkshaw are always as solemn as owls.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- There is nothing to indicate that to-morrow's election in Massachusetts will prove to be anything but the customary Republican victory. Not since 1892 have the Democrats carried the State, and to-night the election of W. Murray Crane, the present Lieutenant Governor and the Republican candidate for Governor, is conceded beyond the possibility of a doubt.

MANILA, Nov. 6. -- At Bacolot, in the Island of Negros, the first autonomous government of the Filipinos was established to-day. Gen. Smith, Governor of the Island of Negros, administered the oath of office to the Judge of the Supreme Court, who in turn swore in the Governor, three Judges, twelve Councilmen, the Auditor, and the Secretary of the Interior.

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- Nemesis in the form of a condemnation to three years' imprisonment for swindling has at last overtaken the notorious Esterhazy. It was to escape this charge that he fled to England some sixteen months ago disguised as a horse trainer and bitterly lamenting his ignorance of the use of the bicycle, it being the best and cheapest means, so he said, of dodging detectives.

Among the passengers sailing on the Lahn this morning will be a party of German delegates to the Commercial Congress at Philadelphia. Since the close of the congress they have been in Chicago and other cities in the West, inspecting industrial establishments and gathering information that may be of benefit to German merchants.

Some lively correspondence passed yesterday between State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh and the Police Department in regard to the assistance that the former's deputies are to expect from the police and from any private citizens on whom they may call to help them arrest men who have illegally registered and may try to vote.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Dr. Vosburg Rekow and Edmund Wirth, the former a Director of the Imperial Central Bureau of Commercial Treaties of Germany, and the latter a large manufacturer and President of the Chamber of Commerce in Seraw, Brandenburg, have just concluded an inspection of the Chicago packing houses.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7. -- By the combined efforts of the Republicans and anti-Goebelites, Attorney General W.S. Taylor, Republican, has been elected Governor of Kentucky by a majority variously estimated from 7,000 to 15,000 over Goebel, Democrat.
RYE, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- First and second rounds for the President's Cup match play at the Apawamis Club to-day resulted as follows:

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The Rev. Acton C. Civill of the Methodist Church of this village, who startled his congregation on Sunday by announcing he would not conduct the service or administer the communion because he was morally unfit, became violent to-day.

MANILA, Nov. 7. -- Gen. Wheaton's orders were to land at or near San Fabian, a fishing village twenty miles northeast of Dagupan. The insurgent force there only numbered about 300 men, intrenched, whereas at Dagupan there are some thousands of insurgents and five miles of strong trenches. The Mounts River is blockaded.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Ex-President Cleveland had all kinds of trouble today in connection with the election. He made his first mistake when he started out to cast his ballot. His coachman was directed to drive to the polling place in Odd Fellows' Hall, on Witherspoon Street. The carriage arrived there, and the President with some trouble entered the polling place.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- J.C. Monaghan, Consul at Chemnitz, has sent a report on the resources of Russia as follows:

There can be little doubt that Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN is just now undergoing a painful process of disillusion. The last proverb upon which that active and pushful statesman models his own behavior is that which assures us that all things come to him who waits. His incapability of waiting has been the most conspicuous trait developed and illustrated by his career.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 7. -- Scattering returns received from representative sections of the State indicate a very light vote in the Mississippi election. The entire Democratic State ticket is elected by a majority conservatively estimated at 30,000. The official count will not vary greatly from these figures. The Populist vote shows a decided falling off, which probably will amount to 30 per cent. Not over 65,000 votes were polled.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7. -- At the meeting of the stockholders of the Middletown, Meriden and Waterbury Railroad Company, held in Meriden to-day, there was an upheaval of the Directorate, five of the old New England owners and Directors being supplanted by five Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Road.

The dreadful ignorance of the intelligent voter is proverbial. He approaches the ballot box filled with big resolves and small information. As a citizen he is proud of his good intentions, as a voter he is ashamed of his bad preparation. Between the tickets of the two great parties he can usually choose with certainty, for the newspapers, which have their uses, after all, have made him acquainted with the names of the leading nominees.
LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The following is the text of a dispatch from Gen. Buller, from Cape Town, dated Nov. 7, 12:55 P.M.:
That is a rather confusing estimate of the strength of the Boers now operating in the "triangle of Natal" which comes to us from London. The estimate is:
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Once more the Tigers are making every effort to get into shape to meet the Indians.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7. -- The Yale football squad had to-day one of the hardest sessions of practice that has yet taken place at the field. The programme for the day's work began in the morning, when the 'Varsity squad rehearsed the signals over and over again, and mapped out several new formations.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The returns at midnight indicate that the Republicans have carried the State by about 20,000 plurality, although there was no direct vote on a State ticket. The Republicans will control both houses of the Legislature by good working majorities, and will have an increased representation in the House of Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Assistant Secretary Hill, for the United States; Mr. Tower, for Great Britain, and Mr. Mumm von Schwarzenstein, on the part of Germany, to-day, at the State Department, signed a convention providing for the adjustment by arbitration of claims of inhabitants of Samoa for damages resulting from the naval and military operations there last Spring.

The American Chess Magazine has entered upon its third year, and despite the fact, well recognized by chess players, that it is the equal of any similar publication in the world, it is still an experiment. Its management, which has changed several times, is still making a hard fight for the kind of recognition that will support it.

BUFFALO, Nov. 7. -- The Republicans have made almost a clean sweep, electing Philip Gerst City Treasurer, H.F. Emerson Superintendent of Education, Thomas Murphy Police Justice, Otto W. Volger Municipal Court Justice, A.H. Rochford Justice of the Peace, and Albert H. Meyer and Nicholas J. Merk Assessors by majorities ranging from 2,000 to 9,000.

In the elections of yesterday the Democrats appear to have been successful in wresting Maryland from the Republicans, while they have failed to capture the State of Ohio, the State in which, next to Nebraska, their greatest efforts to were put forth. Nebraska appears to have increased its Fusion vote over that of 1898, but has not matched the great vote of 1896, although the whole vote of this year was very large.
Mr. MAZET has lost his seat in the Assembly because he was unable or unwilling to seize the opportunity that was offered to him to do a great public service.

If the friends of WILLIAM J. BRYAN are not wholly deprived of sight and sense they must perceive that the State elections held yesterday terminate his political career. The voters did not indorse him or his principles. They sustained the Administration and its policies, which he has attacked.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Nov. 7. -- A railway franchise, including a right of way 100 feet wide along the Bay of San Diego, has been granted by the Common Council to U.S. Grant, George W. Marson, George H. Ballou, and M.A. Luce.

-- An example that might well be followed by other patriotic Americans has been set by Major Gen. WILLIAM BUEL FRANKLIN of Hartford in the presentation by him to the Congressional Library of one of the finest copies extant of Capt. JOHN SMITH'S "General Historie of Virginia, New England, and the Summer-Isles."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 7. -- Returns from Ohio come in slowly. Judge Nash's election is claimed by 30,000 by the Republican managers. In Cleveland Jones ran like wildfire and will probably have a majority over both opponents, Nash having a good plurality over McLean, however. Apparently the Republican State ticket is safely elected.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 7. -- President McKinley cast his ballot just as the noon hour struck. He was scheduled to reach the city at 10:15, but his train was an hoar and twenty minutes late. With him came Mrs. McKinley, Assistant Secretary Cortelyou, and Dr. Rixey.

HARTFORD CITY, Ind., Nov. 7. -- Details of the organization of the American Window Glass Company, capitalized at $17,000,000, controlling 85 per cent. of the window glass capacity of the United States, and which will succeed the American Glass Company, are made known by H.B. Smith of this city, who attended the meeting at Pittsburg, at which permanent officers were elected.

BAYSIDE, L.I., Nov. 7. -- Election day furnished the members of the Oakland Golf Club with a variety of attractions, the most important of which was the first and semi-final rounds for the club championship and the consolation event. In the morning a hunt in which prominent society folk participated was concluded on the Oakland links.

ESTCOURT, Natal, Nov. 5. -- It is now possible to furnish official details of Friday's fighting around Ladysmith. The Boer artillery fire was accurate and well sustained, but ineffective. The British cavalry was constantly out, the investment not being close enough to prevent this. Cavalry and artillery under Col. Brocklehurst about noon drove the enemy from all their positions with great slaughter.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 7. -- The Indian football team was deprived of a much-needed rest after their rounds from the Hamilton by being plunged yesterday afternoon into the midst of most severe practice. In pursuance of this coures of action Coach Warner was animated by a strong desire to retrieve the Harvard disaster by a thoroughly administered defeat of Princeton.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Evidently more detailed reports of Gen. White's doings at Ladysmith must be received before the public will be able to form a clear idea of what has happened. Reports from various sources show that another important reconnaissance or engagement occurred on Saturday to the south of Ladysmith, and a Cape Town newspaper reports that 2,000 Boers were captured there.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Estimates from all of the counties in the State indicate Barnett's (Rep.) plurality over Creasy (Dem.) to be 125,483. In some counties the estimates were necessarily based on meagre information, and complete returns may change the figures here given.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- Shortly after the polls closed this evening fifty intoxicated negroes ran amuck on Centre Market Space. They fired pistols and threw stones about promiscuously, one of the bullets entering the abdomen of Oscar Dietz, a twelve-year-old boy.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 7. -- The fifth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs opened a four days' meeting in the Eureka Clubhouse this morning. The federation was called to order by Mrs. William Tod Helmuth, the President. The invocation was pronounced by Mrs. John Talbot Gracey.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- The J.G. Brill Car Company of this city is now engaged in building a large number of double-deck trolley cars for the General Traction Company of Paris, which will operate street tramways from the centre of the city to the exposition grounds in 1900. Owing to the size and weight of the cars they will be mounted upon heavy double trucks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7. -- The regular 'Varsity players continued resting to-day, taking no football exercise whatever. They were rubbed down carefully by trainer McGaston, who stated afterward that every man who played on Saturday was in good condition. The team will begin regular practice to-morrow.

Returns from all the districts in the State show the election of a Republican Assembly, the figures at 3 A.M. showing a total of 91 Republicans elected to 59 Democrats, giving the Republicans an apparent majority of 32.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The Orange Athletic Club eleven beat that of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club of New York this morning by a score of 11 to 10.
LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The Standard's correspondent at Luxembourg, gives further details of the Boer plan of campaign, which was drawn up, he asserts, by "a General of European reputation."

A huge bonfire illumined Morningside Heights a week ago last Saturday night in honor of Columbia's victory over Yale. Yesterday, as the shades of night descended upon the city, Morningside Heights were enveloped in gloom.

WHEATLEY HILLS, L.I., Nov. 7. -- The annual Autumn meeting of the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Association, given this afternoon on the large country seat of William C. Whitney, at Wheatley Hills, was replete with sport.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 7. -- The thoroughbred brood mares sold by Col. S.D. Bruce to Andrew Albright, Jr., of Red Bank, N.J., were shipped to-day by G.D. Wilson. With them were shipped the stallion Tristan and ten brood mares belonging to L.O. Appleby of New York. Tristan has been leased by Mr. Albright, and Mr. Appleby is sending his brood mares to his New Jersey farm to breed them to imp. King Thistle.

OMAHA, Nov. 7. -- Chairman Tefft of the Republican State Committee concedes the election of Holcomb, Fusion candidate for Supreme Judge, by 8,000 to 10,000. Chairman Edminston for the Fusionists claims the State by 15,000.

Tammany Hall last night at the Wigwam, in Fourteenth Street, celebrated in royal manner the Democratic victory in the city. Incidentally, through its speakers, it gave further impetus to the boom for W.J. Bryan for President in 1900; urged the wisdom of a united and harmonious Democracy, and listened to speeches from Lord Mayor Tallon of Dublin and John E. Redmond, M.P., who were unexpectedly present.
The election in this city has resulted in an overwhelming victory for the Democracy.
Racing in the State of New York for the season of 1899 ended yesterday.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The cards were announced to-day at the Essex County Country Club in the tournament for the cup championship. C.W. O'Connor was the winner in the first round from Howard A. Colby; C.F. Watson beat Clifford A. Gould, L. St. Clair Colby beat George M. Gill, Sidney M. Colgate beat Thomas T. Reid. In the second round C.W. O'Connor beat C.F. Watson, Sidney M. Colgate beat L. St. Clair Colby.
" Well, after all, it's a little better than the Mayoralty campaign."

We cannot suppose that the result of the election in this county yesterday was very much of a surprise to fairly well informed observers. The only element in it that at any time could have been regarded as uncertain was the strength that the Independent Labor Party would be able to lend to the Fusion ticket.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- It is rumored among Chicago Democrats that the Iroquois and Monticello Clubs will soon be merged in one organization, and the silver issue thus be buried in favor of some more desirable platform, probably anti-imperialism. The Monticello Club was organized about two years ago, its first members being silverites who left the Iroquois Club because of its strong stand for sound money.

American securities were exceptionally active in London's market yesterday, and the list was almost uniformly strong. Atchison and Baltimore and Ohio issues and Southern Pacific were conspicuous. The two former gained about a point apiece, while in Southern Pacific there was a rise to what was equivalent to 42 5/8 here.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 7. -- Returns so far received make the election of the entire Democratic ticket in this county practically certain. The Democratic managers claim a plurality over the Republicans of from 4,000 to 5,000. The proposition to issue bonds of the City of Denver for the construction of a municipal water plant is carried by a majority of 2,000 in a vote of a little over 5,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Russian Ambassador, Count Cassini, who is just back from a long visit to Europe, was seen at the Russian Embassy to-day, and talked in a most entertaining manner on international questions which have engaged public attention recently.
MADRID, Nov. 7. -- Spanish 4s closed to-day at 71.60. Gold was quoted at 25.47.
FLORENCE, Ala., Nov. 7. -- Gen. Wheeler in a letter to W.J. Wood of Florence, stating his views on the Philippine question, says:

Regarding a rumor that Government engineers, who have recently been taking measurements on the Brooklyn Bridge, had discovered a sag of eight inches, an engineer officer of the army said yesterday: "The only significance of the measurements taken is that the Government desired its own measurement for use in the coast pilot publication.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- To the eyes of military experts the darkest page of the war is now being written. But even that is illuminated with bright passages, such as Gen. White's victorious sorties. If he can keep the British flag flying over Ladysmith until he is relieved the campaign will turn a fresh page, and, with the advance of Sir Redvers Buller's force, the British public is promised more cheerful reading.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 8. -- Word has reached here from Ducktown, Tenn., in Monroe County, that serious trouble is brewing there between the miners and operators of the Ducktown Sulphur, Copper, and Iron Company. Six hundred miners are on strike, and the company has arranged to put men in their places to-day.
ESTCOURT, Natal, Nov. 5. -- Brig.-Gen. Wolfe-Murray has received important dispatches from Ladysmith, by a runner, but their contents have not yet been divulged.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 8. -- The Italian bark Salvatore, Capt. Saccrino, arrived here at dark from Trapani, Italy, bound for this port with 700 tons of salt. She had on board Capt. A.T. Dyer and the shipwrecked crew of seven men of the schooner William E. Downes of New Haven, bound from Savannah to that port with 500,000 feet of hard pine.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 8. -- The Republicans have carried Iowa by about 60,000 plurality, electing Leslie M. Shaw Governor over Fred E. White, the Fusion nominee. A light vote was polled in nearly all parts of the State, except where hot local fights were in progress. Chairman Huffman of the Democratic State Committee concedes the election of Shaw by 50,000, and Chairman Weaver of the Republican State Committee claims by 60,000.

As the result of negotiations which have been under way for some time the Rubber Goods Manufacturing Company yesterday acquired .% controlling interest in the stocks of the Hartford Rubber %'orks Ccmpany, the Peoria Rubber and {anufacturing Company, and the India.napolis Rubber Company, as well as the rubber manufacturing plant of the Indiana Bicycle Company.

Revised returns on Tuesday's election, based upon reports made to the police and through them to the Bureau of Elections, make no material change in the results as announced in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. In the contest for Alderman in the Twenty-first Assembly District, however, Armitage Matthews, the Republican candidate, was elected over E.S. Potter, (Dem:,) according to the completed returns, by a majority of-429 votes.

Maclay Davies have sold for William Schneider the block front on the west side of Park Avenue, between One Hundred and Thirtieth and One Hundred and Thirty-first Streets, 199.10 by 90. The buyer, whose name is withheld, will erect on the site a six-story fireproof building for light manufacturing.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8. -- Semi-official results indicate that Judge Nash's plurality will exceed that of Gov. Bushnell's two years ago by 27,770, giving him the splendid total of 55,939. The plurality has hovered around 60,000 all day. To the figures above must be added about 10,000 from Cuyahoga and 20,000 from Lucas Counties.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 8. -- Good grounds and admirable weather were conducive to effective practice of the Carlisle Indians today. George Conner, the new assistant coach, has taken charge of dummy tackling and is relieving Coach Warner considerably in looking after the team's discipline. Warner himself is attending closely to the new plays he intends springing on Princeton, as well as looking after the "subs" in a general way.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Without being enthusiastic, the morning papers generally regard the Samoan agreement with satisfaction. The Times in the course of an article ridiculing the idea that the imperial meeting at Potsdam is in any way antagonistic to British policy in South Africa, says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day began the hearing in the case of the Merchants' Association of New York, brought in the name of William Crawford against the Adams Express Company, to test whether the express companies or the shippers should pay the war revenue tax charged upon packages sent by express.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 8. -- There is still some doubt as to the result of the vote for Suffolk County Treasurer. According to the returns received to-night. John Sherry, (Rep..) appears to have been elected, with a plurality of 23. Livingston Smith (Rep.) defeated Rowland Mills (Dem.) for District Attorney by 85 votes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8. -- A good-sized audience saw the initial performance of "Make Way for the Ladies," presented under the direction of Charles Frohman in the Hyperion Theatre in this city last night.

DURBAN, Nov. 5. -- Other information confirms the statement of native eye witnesses respecting the severity of the fighting on both Friday and Saturday at Ladysmith. The natives assert that the Boers were so cut up that they howled for mercy on the field and covered their bodies. Ladysmith is crowded with Boer prisoners and wounded, the latter presenting horrible evidence of the swordsmanship of the cavalry.

Yesterday's meeting of the Board of Public improvements was enlivened somewhat by the service of the members present with a temporary writ of injunction issued during the day by Justice Wilmot F. Smith, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. It was obtained by Edward M. Grout, President of Brooklyn Borough, and member of the board, to restrain that body and the Commissioner of Water Supply from entering into a contract with the Ramapo Water Company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8. -- After three days of rest, the regular 'Varsity players put on their football clothes to-day, and had twenty-five minutes of signal practice, followed by a short game with the second eleven.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 8. -- The election returns so far make sure the election of Silas A. Holcomb, Fusion candidate, as Judge for the Supreme Court. The reports are coming in rather slowly, few counties having submitted the exact results as yet. There is little doubt that Holcomb's majority will be at least 12,000. This is the minimum figure as given out at the Republican State Headquarters.

" Mysterious Billy" Smith of this city was given the decision in a twenty-round bout over Charles McKeever of Philadelphia at the Broadway Athletic Club last night. The men are in the welterweight class. The fight last night was at catch weights, Smith's weight being given at 145 pounds and McKeever's at 144 pounds.

Some of our newspaper neighbors in Canada are manifesting a disposition plaintively to criticise the Ottawa Government. They accuse it of favor toward the United States, calculated, perhaps, to weaken the representatives of the Dominion Government in the attempt they may soon renew to bring about a fair adjustment of differences by a reciprocity treaty.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 8. -- The Rev. Benjamin S. Everett, sixty years of age, was married at noon to-day to Miss Carrie Mount, twenty-five years old, at the home of Mrs. Albert Paxton, near Jamesburg. The ceremony was performed by Mr. Everett's three sons -- Frank, William, and Benjamin, Jr. -- all preachers, and all of whom, like their father, had married school teachers.

In your editorial of last Friday, "Cushion Carroms," much is said that is well considered and true, but as a lover of the game, having attended two of the three evenings of the recent match, and as one of those desiring more frequent public meetings between Messrs. Schaefer and Slosson, I wish to call attention to one more fact in accounting for the small attendance at the Assembly Hall.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- The Rev. Dr. William Hart Dexter, President of the New York Naval Academy of Nyack, has disappeared, and his wife and family believe he has met with some bad accident or with foul play.
CAPE TOWN, Nov. 5. -- The following is an official description from Pretoria of the battle of Nicholson's Nek:

WASHINTON, Nov. 8. -- The State Department has not yet been advised of the agreement between Great Britain and Germany respecting the Samoan group. It is gathered, however, that if the outline of the arrangement set out in the cable advices is accurate, there will be no disposition to withhold our approval, provided certain minor conditions are included.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The Daily News, commenting upon the American elections, says it believes Mr. Bryan has no chance for the Presidency, and that Mr. McKinley has every reason to hope for a second term.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 8. -- W. Murray Crane, Governor-elect of Massachusetts, was given an ovation in his home in Dalton to-night, when over 10,000 persons were present, coming from all parts of Western Massachusetts, including a delegation of his political friends from Boston. It was the largest affair of a political nature that ever took place in Western Massachusetts.

-- Lord ROSEBERY, in the course of a speech delivered the other day at Bath, declared that the Transvaal question was far from complicated. The war, he said, was the natural and inevitable result of a determined effort on the part of the Boers "to put back the hands of the clock," and then the speaker proceeded to draw a parallel of direct and contemporaneous interest to Americans.

Among the many interesting features which elections in this vicinity have developed the spectacle of a man chosen to fill a fat office and then declaring his intention to reject a part of the remuneration attaching thereto has seldom been afforded. Kings County now presents such a phenomenon, however, in the person of ex-Congressman James R. Howe, the successful Republican candidate for Register, who has beaten John M. Gray, the Democratic nominee, by 168 votes.

Our thoughtful readers, who have been following the political developments of the late campaign, must have been impressed by the strong affinity between two candidates in the sort of appeal they made to the voters. One of them is, or has been, the Mayor of no mean city, less than ever mean in electing him.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 12. -- A bill was presented in the Brazilian Chambers to-day relative to removing the capital from Rio de Janeiro to Bello Horizonte, the actual capital of the State of Minas Geraes.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra gave the first concert of its thirteenth season in the City of New York yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The entertainments of this body have in late years assumed the character of fashionable functions, so that there is always a large audience. Possibly it is not a thoroughly representative musical audience, but it is a very good one, and it supports an enterprise that ought to be supported.

BOSTON, Nov. 8. -- The vote of Massachusetts for Governor complete is as follows: Crane, (Rep.,) 168, 876; Paine, (Dem.,) 103,814; Republican plurality, 65,052. The vote of 1898 was: Wolcott, (Rep.,) 191,146; Bruce, (Dem.,) 107,960. The last town to forward returns was Gosnold, in the Elizabeth Islands. The town gave Crane 27 and Paine 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The mysterious London dispatch printed to-day in which it was said that a British newspaper had received a cablegram from Washington in regard to Anglo-American relations in China of such a nature that they had decided not to give it out at this time is being widely discussed.

The Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers yesterday handed clown a decision, through Judge Somerville, in which it is held that Cuba, so far as tariff duties are concerned, is still a foreign country

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- It was officially announced this morning that an agreement, subject to the approval of the United States, had been arrived at between Great Britain and Germany by virtue of which the Samoa act is repealed and the Islands of Upolu, Savaii, and the small adjacent islands fall to Germany as free property, and the Island of Tutuila and its subsidiary islands go to the United States.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Princeton beat the North Carolina team this afternoon on Osborne Field by 30 to 0.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 8. -- The morning session of the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs was devoted to the reading of papers on various subjects. Among the topics discussed by the speakers were "Literature," "Women's Patriotic Societies in America," "Genealogical Societies," and "The Work of the Vacation Schools."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- The Democrats carried but four counties in the State yesterday, Hudson, Hunterdon, Sussex, and Warren. As a result the Republicans gaired seven Assemblymen and held their own in the Senate. The Republican majority on joint ballot was increased from twenty-one to thirty-five.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 8. -- In this city yesterday the total vote cast was 152,333. The registration was 218,354. The contest on the State ticket was over the office of State Treasurer, and Col. James E. Barnett (Rep.) had 69,543 plurality over his Democratic opponent, William T. Creasy, the vote resulting: Barnett 110,078; Creasy, 40,535; Caldwell, (Proh.,) 1,530; Watkins, (Peop.,) 200.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- An effort to organize the Western Union Telegraph Company, the Postal Telegraph Company, and all the independent telephone systems in the United States in a trust, with the stupendous capital of $350,000,000, has brought about a fight which is growing warmer and more exciting every day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8. -- Frederick Gregory, late private in the Thirteenth Minnesota Regiment and interpreter in the police court at Manila, says the looting of churches in the Philippines was done by the Filipinos themselves and by Chinamen.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8. -- The Republican Campaign Committee claims Taylor's election by from 9,500 to 10,000. The count in Pulaski gives Taylor 1,600 majority. Belated returns from Clay and Leslie gave him 2,000 more. Chairman Long states that returns had been received from all but five counties in the State, and that the figures 9,500 would not be far from the correct result.

Traders who bought stocks at the beginning of the week on anticipations of inspiriting election news were free sellers at the opening of yesterday's market. On this account security market values generally showed less buoyancy than Wall Street had counted upon, for election returns were well up to what had been forecast.

The country is going forward. BRYAN has gone backward. In a campaign that resounded with his speeches he has not caught the ear or won the confidence of the American people. They have turned away from him. They reject his views, they will have nothing to do with his platform.

If, as it is claimed, Perez M. Stewart, the Assemblyman-elect from the Nineteenth Assembly District, where he decisively beat Robert Mazet on Tuesday, has suddenly become one of the shining lights in the local political firmament, he is as yet undazzled by his own effulgence. One of Mr. Stewart's most prominent characteristics, as vouched for by his friends and exhibited by him in the heated campaign that has just come to an end, is modesty.

Senator CAFFERY of Louisiana has kindly furnished to the public through the correspondent of The Evening Post a statement of his views as to the course to be pursued by the anti-imperialists, of whom he is a convinced and prominent leader.

During the past few years articles have been published in some of the secular papers, written by Summer residents, tourists, and newspaper correspondents from the New England States, which have given the impression that Protestantism in New England was losing its influence, that churches were going to decay, and that a condition of heathenism existed in many country regions.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 8. -- To the music of the university band and the cheers of 1,500 yelling students the Michigan football team left for the East to-night to try conclusions on the gridiron with Pennsylvania. The men were in high spirits and prime condition physically. The Michigan party will arrive at Bellevue Villa tomorrow night.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 8. -- The United Daughters of the Confederacy assembled in their sixth annual convention at the Jefferson Hotel roof garden here this morning. Mrs. Kate Cabell Currie, the President, called the body to order. Mrs. Norman V. Randolph welcomed the Daughters and Mrs. E.C. Miner, on behalf of Mrs. Joseph Bryan, President of the Ladies' Memorial Literary Society, who could not be present, also read a welcoming address. Mrs. Currie responded.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Lady Randolph Churchill made to-day the following statement to American friends with regard to the project of American women in England of fitting out a hospital ship for use in South African w-ters:

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 8. -- The effort of the Democrats to elect Miss Addie Hicks School Commissioner of Nassau County failed. In her own neighborhood she polled a heavy vote, but in all other portions of the county the threats that were made before she was nominated seem to have been carried out to a slight extent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- No one in Washington was more interested in the Ohio election than Pension Commissioner H. Clay Evans. He was one of the Ohio issues. The Democrats made every effort to enlist the soldier vote against Nash, claiming that McLean's election would compel the President to move Evans out of the Pension Bureau.

It is a dullard or a dreamer who fails to observe the signs of the times in international events now transpiring. The expressions "expansion" or "anti-expansion" are misnomers so far as describing the American situation is concerned. A giant battle for supremacy is being waged between races and forms of government which would become most ferocious but for the readiness of the more civilized to protect themselves and possibly act as peacemakers between others.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- No event in yesterday's election is fraught with more local political significance than the Mayoralty contest here. It means the effacement to a considerable extent of ex-United States Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., as a political factor in this section, and the advancement of the political fortunes of ex-Gov. Frank S. Black, who worked hard to secure Conway's election.

At the meeting of the Trustees of the New York Public Library, held yesterday afternoon in the Astor Library Building, a letter was read from J. Pierpont Morgan announcing that he had presented to the library the Ford collection of books, manuscripts, and letters. The letter reads in part as follows:
POTSDAM, Nov. 8. -- The Czar and Czarina arrived here at 11 o'clock this morning, and were welcomed by the German Emperor and Empress at Wildpark Station.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8. -- Returns from the close counties in Maryland continue to come in slowly, but enough is now known to assure to the Democrats the control of both branches of the General Assembly. They have carried the lower House by such a decisive majority as to make it almost unanimous, but in order to control the Senate it was necessary that they should elect ten Senators.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 8. -- In the secret practice to-day the coaches of the Yale 'Varsity eleven gave the candidates a long session of hard work. The coaches spent the afternoon in criticising the squad, and their voices were heard all over the field. There was a slight improvement in the team work as a result, but perfection is not yet reached.

Among the minor morals of the election is one chronic moral which is of chronic importance and which we have frequently had occasion to draw. That is the moral that when a Boss has once established himself, by hook or by crook, there is no way of getting rid of him except by beating him, which means beating the party which he pretends to represent, at the polls.
The New York Fire Insurance Exchange will meet to-day.
" A large paper and pulp mill is to be built at the Flume, in the White Mountains."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 9. -- Five medical experts made an examination to-day of Moses Fowler Chase, the young heir to a large estate, whose mental condition has been the subject of contention between his father, Frederick Chase, of Lafayette, Ind., and his uncle, Charles Duhme of this city. The examination was strictly private, being made not by order of court, but by agreement of counsel.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 9. -- In the Superior Court this afternoon Lewis Warner, who wrecked the Hampshire County National Bank and the Hampshire Savings Bank by embezzling $500,000, was sentenced to a term in State prison of not more than twelve nor less than nine years, first day solitary confinement.

Apparently the question of the sufficiency of the Samoan settlement, by which Germany retains control of two of the principal islands and the United States of the third, is a question for British statesmanship exclusively. Great Britain is the only loser by such a transaction, the only power entitled to demand compensations elsewhere for what she gives up.

Money-market conditions grow somewhat more agreeable, but Stock Exchange sentiment did not yesterday reflect such improvement. Throughout most of the day quotations were distinctly weak. Again Leather Trust common stock disported sensationally. Its record, though, was not quite so bad as on the day before, for while the decline of Wednesday was 12 points, yesterday's was only 11.

Patrick O'Keefe, the policeman who was shot on Sept. 3 by Michael Farelli, a saloon keeper, and whose eyes had to be removed as a result of his injuries, was carried into the Harlem Court in the arms of one of his comrades yesterday and tenderly placed in the witness chair to testify to the shooting.

Benjamin A. Gicquel, Deputy Chief of the Fire Department, died yesterday morning at his home, 247 Wrest Forty-eighth Street. He reported sick about three weeks ago, but at that time his illness was not regarded as serious. Later a carbuncle on his left hand, resulting from an old injury, rendered necessary an operation.

The opinion that we expressed during the campaign that the issue in the Nineteenth Assembly District was the principle of the Citizens' Union, and that that issue was more clearly presented there than in any other quarter, is confirmed by the modest and manly utterances of Mr. STEWART since election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Spanish Minister, Duke d'Arcos, was among the callers at the State Department to-day. It is understood that the negotiations for the new treaty of friendship, commerce, and navigation have opened at Madrid, and while not directly participating, the authorities here are exchanging views on the various features of the treaty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Simon W. Hanauer, Vice Consul General at Frankfort, reports to the State Department that the "German papers discuss and copiously comment on the late news that the firm of Bruhm's Soeline of Gera, one of the largest textile-manufacturing concerns in Germany, is now about to establish a factory and branch house in the United States.

Rumors continue of the sale of Caven Point, Jersey City, by the Standard Oil Company to the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, notwithstanding official denials. Color has been given to the report by the fact that the removal of one of the largest tanks on Caven Point to the Standard Oil Company's plant at Constable Hook, Bayonne, was begun on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The urgent necessity of adequate coaling stations for our warships is dwelt upon by Rear Admiral Bradford, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Equipment, in his report to the Secretary of the Navy. He relates the difficulties encountered during the war with Spain in securing coal, transporting it, and getting it aboard the ships.

ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- The Prussian Insurance Company, which under a legislative act was forbidden to do business in this State because of Germany's prohibitive laws against American companies, has filed with Superintendent Payn a new application to do business on the ground that Germany's prohibition has been removed.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- City Electrician Ellicott submitted a report to Mayor Harrison to-day showing the decrease in the cost of electric lights for the last four years.

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- The morning papers have long accounts of an interview with Dr. Leyds, the special representative in Europe of the Transvaal Government, who argues that the Transvaal has everything to gain by remaining independent, and that her mining laws are the most liberal in the world, and prevent capitalists from obtaining monopolies.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- The University of Michigan football team arrived here at 7:30 o'clock to-night. There are twenty-four men in the party, including F.W. Henninger, coach, and Keene Fitzpatrick, trainer.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Complete figures from every county in the State, nearly all of them unofficial footings of the official returns, show that the plurality of Barnett, Republican candidate for State Treasurer over Creasy (Dem.) is 106,217.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 9. -- The Indians took their last secret practice this evening preparatory to Saturday's Princeton game, with the team in reasonably fair condition. They were handicapped by the absence of Redwater, the giant guard, and Artie Miller, late half back. The latter has experienced a transposition to the right end, which is thought by Warner to be a very desirable change, Miller having been slated for an end in September.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9. -- The practice at the Yale field to-day was extremely light in comparison to what it has been for the past few days. The trainers have notified the coaches that there are symptoms of overtraining and lighter work was suggested. The hard work of Tuesday and Wednesday has asserted itself in a few lame ankles and many bruises, but none is considered very serious.

Republican district leaders who favored the placing of a straight ticket in the field and opposed the idea of a fusion with other anti-Tammany forces have seized upon the result of the election as a club with which to attack Lemuel E. Quigg, the President of the County Committee, and there was considerable talk yesterday to the effect that Mr. Quigg should be forced to resign his place at the head of the organization.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Lord Salisbury, the British Premier, was the principal speaker at the Lord Mayor's banquet at Guildhall to-night. Near the close of his address, which dealt chiefly with affairs in South Africa, he announced that England would not accept interference in her trouble with the Transvaal Republic, and that she would settle it in her own way.

The case of Roland B. Molineux, accused of the murder of Katherine J. Adams, was on the calendar of Part II., General Sessions, yesterday morning, having been placed there by the District Attorney for the purpose of getting a definite date set for the trial. The argument in the matter resulted in Recorder Goff administering a sharp rebuke to the District Attorney.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- A woman's medal play handicap held at the Apawamis Club, Rye, to-day, resulted as follows:

PITTSBURG, Nov. 9. -- G.H. Raymond of Buffalo in a speech recently stated that lake cities would dethrone Pittsburg as a steel centre. Andrew Carnegie answers T.J. Keenan of this city on the subject as follows:

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9. -- This was another great Confederate day in Richmond, the occasion being the unveiling in Hollywood Cemetery, under the auspices of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, now in convention here, of the memorials in Hollywood to President Jefferson Davis and Miss Winnie Davis.

A traveler setting out from Portland, Me., might traverse the entire continent to Portland, Oregon, without putting his foot upon the soil of any Democratic State or Territory, save that in passing from Iowa to Kansas he would be obliged to cross the southwestern corner of the State of Nebraska -- BRYAN'S State -- which has just been carried by Populist and Democratic candidates representing his principles.

My attention has been called to an article in your issue of the 6th inst., signed by F.R. Sturgis, relating to the Mount Sinai Hospital, and to certain remarks alleged to have been made by me before Commissioner Smith of the State Board of Charities, when responding to an invitation extended by him for the purpose of expressing my views on the subject of the incorporation of the proposed Emanu-El Hospital.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 9. -- Judge Curtis of the Court of Common Pleas has just rendered a decision in the case of Horatio C. Chapman against the Connecticut Commercial Traveler's' Mutual Accident Association for Chapman to receive $69.74 and costs. Chapman is a commercial traveler, and was insured in the association.

There would have been a sense of relief in the money market at the suspension of the order of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue for collecting a tax upon pledges for the security of call loans -- pending the Attorney General's examination of the legal question -- if it had been conceivable that such an order would be executed.

MACON, Ga., Nov. 9. -- Congressman Bartlett and Senator Bacon received to-day a petition, signed by about 100 negroes asking them to use their best efforts to secure the passage of a law whereby the negroes might be deported to Africa. They say that conditions under which they live are not satisfactory.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The British steamer Alps. Capt. Kirkby, which went ashore in Kingston Harbor, Jamaica, en route from Haiti for New York was floated to-day. She is uninjured, and will sail to-morrow.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 9. -- The price of steel bars was advanced in Pittsburg to-day from $2.50 per 100 pounds to $2.75 for prompt delivery. This means an increase of $5 per ton. Even at these figures it is almost impossible to obtain steel bars for use any time prior to the first of the coming year. For delivery in the second quarter of 1900 a price of $2.30 per 100 pounds is asked.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 9. -- The Democrats in view of the feeling on the race question, which so largely dominated the election, will have a bill passed by the new Legislature for the submission to the people of a constitutional amendment providing for educational and property qualification in the exercise of franchise.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- The Common Council passed a resolution, offered by Councilman Collins of the Thirteenth Ward, this evening, protesting against the erection on Boston common of a memorial to the British soldiers who fell in the battle of Bunker Hill, and calling upon the Mayor to rescind his approval of such a memorial.

TOCCOA, Ca., Nov. 9. -- A head-on collision occurred on the Southern Railway here to-night, both freight trains. Train No. 43, south-bound, ran into Extra No. 385, north-bound. Conductor Faysoux of the south-bound train was considerably bruised. Flagman Homer Gary was cut on the back of the head; Flagman Hughes's back was wrenched, a negro fireman was cut on back of the head.

Your editorial of to-day hits the nail on the head regarding the New York National Guard. With few exceptions most of the regiments in the State militia saw service during the past year in garrison, camp, and battlefield. The weak points of its company, field, and staff officers were prominently exposed; those, however, who passed safely through the ordeal without tarnishing their reputations as officers were practically made in a military sense.

ORANGE N.J., Nov. 9. -- The horse show under the auspices of the Riding and Driving Club of Orange opened this evening. It will be continued to-morrow evening and Saturday afternoon and evening. There are forty-seven classes in which prizes will be given and there are 250 entries. All the boxes have been sold, and to-night the house was well filled.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 9. -- The proceedings in the Supreme Court hearing of the Welcome disbarment case opened to-day. John B. Welcome, a Butte attorney, who Was Senator Clark's manager during the recent legislative session, is the defendant, while ex-Senator Whiteside, who made the noted $30,000 bribery charges against Clark, is the petitioner seeking the disbarment of Welcome on the ground that his connection herewith was unprofessional.

The combination of independent companies to fight the Western Union and the Postal Telegraph Companies, which are said to be endeavoring to organize a trust, has taken definite shape by the incorporation at Trenton, N.J., last evening of the Telephone, Telegraph, and Cable Company of America. The company is capitalized at $30,000,000.

The market at private contract yesterday developed little that was interesting, in not-able contrast to that of Wednesday, when several good-sized deals, involving various classes of property, were reported. Brokers, however, say that considerable business is in negotiation, and there is no reason to suppose that the lull is more than temporary.

HAVANA, Nov. 9. -- The local papers are again exercised about the price of meat. Last month, they say, 35,000 head of cattle were imported, but there is no reduction in price. Many of the poor, they point out, cannot buy meat at all, owing to the high figures, as a good deal of the meat is sold at 40 cents a pound, whereas all could be sold at 15 cents a pound.

DETROIT, Nov. 9. -- George A. Kruger, of Chicago, a nephew of President Kruger, of the Transvaal Republic, and Miss Berta Buck, of Chicago, were married at Sandwich, Ont., to-day. The groom's age was recorded as twenty-seven and the bride's as twenty-one.
Most of the trust companies affected by the rules recommended by the Clearing House Committee appear to accept them as proper, within the province of the Clearing House, and directed to a good end.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9. -- To-day's practice for the 'Varsity took the form of a short game of ten and twelve minute halves with the freshmen. The freshmen scored in 30 seconds, but after that the 'Varsity was on its mettle, and, in addition to holding their opponents, scored five touchdowns.

BERLIN, Nov. 9. -- The Colonial Council at a meeting to-day heartily approved the Samoan agreement. Prince von Wied declared that thanks were due, firstly, to the Emperor, and called for three cheers for his Majesty. A telegram was dispatched to the Emperor expressing the Council's gratification at the ending of the Samoan dispute "to the imperishable glory of the Emperor and the honor of Germany."

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- The first sitting of the Senate High Court for the judgment of prisoners in the alleged Royalist plot, which has so far had any interest for the public, took place this afternoon. The Senate Chamber was crammed with distinguished spectators, among them Gyp, in her now historic coal-scuttle bonnet; the "Dame Blanche," dressed, however, in black; Mlle.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 9. -- To-night, at the Music Hall, Manager Augustus Pitou produced "The Gunner's Mate," a drama by Hugh J. Gallagher, formerly of the United States Navy and W.J. McKiernan. It is not a war play, although several of the scenes are laid on board the United States cruiser New York.

Philip J. Ernst, eighty-four years of age, and his wife, Louisa, eighty-five years of age, were found in their apartments, on the first floor of the four-story tenement at 341 Sixth Street, at 12:30 yesterday afternoon, overcome by gas. The woman was dead when an ambulance surgeon arrived, and the man was taken to Bellevue Hospital unconscious.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- Michigan Central Train No. 310, from Toledo to Detroit, was ditched by the spreading of rails between Alexis and Vienna, Mich., about 8 o'clock to-night.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Chicago will, with little doubt, have a stock show this winter which will far surpass any previous gathering of breeders ever held in this country.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Vice Chancellor Pitney this afternoon listened to the evidence in the divorce suit brought by Mrs. Estelle G. Allen of Ocean Grove against her husband, the Rev. William A. Allen, now of Colorado Springs, on the ground of cruelty and desertion. The couple were married Oct. 7, 1884.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 9. -- A confusion of claims and counter-claims, to quiet which the official count or perhaps a contest before the Legislature will be necessary, is all that is left of Tuesday's election. Above it all vehement cries of fraud, committed or contemplated, are heard. Each side claims the election of its ticket and presents figures to back up the claim.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Admiral George Dewey and Mrs. Mildred M. Hazen were married quietly at the rectory of St. Paul's Catholic Church, shortly before 10 o'clock this morning. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James F. Mackin, pastor of the church, assisted by the Rev. Joseph H. Foley, assistant pastor, and the Rev. Sidney Hurlbut.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 9. -During a heavy fog to-day a rearend collision occurred on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad on the high bridge over the Brandywine River, in this city. A south-bound freight train parted by reason of a broken coupling, and the rear portion of the train stopped on the bridge.
Statement by an official of the Chicago and Northwestern that he does not consider it likely that there will be an increase in the dividend rate, as much money is being put into betterments.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9. -- The New Haven Union this afternoon says that late yesterday counsel for Robert H. Waters filed the reasons for appeal from the probating of the will of the late Prof. Othniel C. Marsh of Yale University in the Superior Court. The document filed by counsel for Mr. Waters is startling in the nature of its allegations.

A number of residents and property holders in South Brooklyn have formed all association to fight the so-called improved transfer plan of President Clinton L. Rossiter of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Railroad Company. Capt. George B. Lockhart, a shipping and commission merchant, is its President, and Willis Van Valkenburgh of 438 Seventh Street Secretary.

A correspondent of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, speaking, he says, from knowledge acquired in the course of twenty years' service in India as an army Chaplain -- which is not, perhaps, the very best possible training for a military critic -- asserts that it was a "grievous mistake" to give Gen. Sir GEORGE WHITE an important command in South Africa, and that the disaster which has followed might easily have been prophesied.

Your articles of Oct. 31 and to-day on reckless driving in the streets and the practice of leaving horses standing unguarded, and calling attention to the case of the poor woman who was killed by the runaway on Sixth Avenue, lead me to make a suggestion which, if carried out, would, it seems to me, have a practical bearing on the subject.

The West End Women's Republican Association held a social meeting yesterday afternoon at the West End Republican Club house, 2,307 Broadway. Mrs. Cornelia S. Robinson, President of the association, occupied the chair and introduced the guest of honor, Mrs. Donald McLean, Regent of New York City Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution.

Yesterday was another red letter day for the golfers and lovers of outdoor sports who are now scattered through the suburbs, while a large country wedding, always a most popular entertainment when the weather is as fine as it was yesterday, enabled the younger element in society to meet and still more pleasantly mark the day.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The Lord Mayor's Show, which marked the induction of Mr. A.J. Newton into office, was honored today by exceptionally brilliant weather. But antiquated floats failed to satisfy the London crowds, who poured out in enormous numbers to vent their martial enthusiasm.

Is the Dewey arch too beautiful to be enjoyed by the multitude every day? Is it desirable that fewer eyes should turn upon it, that it should be a rare and not a familiar vision? Are the names of our sculptors, now on every tongue, suffering from too much notoriety? What are the sufficient reasons why, in a permanent form, this arch should be placed elsewhere?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The first task to which the President will address himself now that the election is over, is the establishment of civil government in Cuba and Puerto Rico. He is displaying considerable impatience to have this work, which has been hanging fire so long, pushed through as soon as possible.

The mystery surrounding the disappearance of the Rev. William Hart Dexter, Principal of the New York Naval Academy, at Nyack, deepens as the investigation concerning his whereabouts goes on, and there is now strong evidence to prove that he was probably assaulted and robbed at least, if not murdered, after he left the steamer C.H. Northam, on which he had secured a berth on Thursday night of last week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- "A Danish syndicate has been formed for the purpose of supplying our country with American coal," was the assertion made to-night by W.G. Pedersen, a newspaper man, whose home is in Copenhagen. In addition to owning a newspaper, Mr. Pedersen is the representative of a large marble mining syndicate in his native county, and arrived in Chicago to-day in the interest of his marble company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The War Department definitely located Aguinaldo to-day as on his way to the town of Boambang, about seventy-five miles northeast of Tarlac.

The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company is severely criticised by the readers of your valuable paper for the change which it inaugurated Nov. 1.
