The idea of transferring from the surface to the elevated and vice versa is a good one, and it will work satisfactorily if the new conditions which arise are carefully studied, with a view of correcting the faults.

At a meeting of the Session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church last evening it was voted to inform Hermann Warszawiak of his restoration to Church membership, as embodied in a set of resolutions passed last Friday night, through a committee, instead of reading the resolutions from the pulpit.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 9. -- When Mrs. William Tod Helmuth called the third day's session of the fifth annual meeting of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs to order this morning, election day announcements were made. Mrs. Helmuth, elected President last year, holds over until next year, as do the other officers, with the exception of the four members of the Executive Committee, whose terms expire this year.

PLATTSBURG, Nov. 9. -- The political fight in Clinton County for the Assembly between Assemblyman Edmund J. Pickett, Democrat, who was supported by the Democratic Party and the Weaver faction of the Republican Party, and Charles E. Johnson, the Republican candidate, which resulted in victory for the regular Republicans, was the bitterest and most stub bornly contested fight in the history of Clinton County.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The scanty and conflicting news from the seat of war and the fact that Gen. White has not yet said a word about the alleged fighting around Ladysmith are again producing a feeling of gloom. It may be that Gen. White has sent news and that Gen. Buller has thought best to keep it to himself.
I submit for your inspection the following medley of book titles, which, perhaps, may interest some of your SATURDAY REVIEW readers:

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Prank A. Vanderlip, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who arrived in Chicago to-day for a week's visit with his family, says that the Treasury Department has no intention of buying $100,000,000 of bonds for the relief of the money stringency felt by stock speculators in New York, and that there has been no organized demand upon the department for such form of assistance.

Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay has become involved in a contest with the residents of Roslyn, L.I., where she is building a Summer home. For almost a quarter of a century a highway has extended through the property recently purchased by her, which was used in going to and from Roslyn Bay. Mrs. Mackay did not like the idea of this travel over her property, and made arrangements to close up the road.

The war in Cuba and the Philippines has quickened the memory of the American people, and they are becoming moved to pay homage to deeds of heroism performed long years ago. An example of this is found in a movement to erect a monument on the battlefield of the Arrickaree, where in 1868 Gen. George A. Forsythe and a band of fifty-four scouts fought the most memorable fight recorded in the annals of Indian warfare.

Otto P.T. Grantz is counted the richest man in the Black Hills. He is rated as the first millionaire in this little mining country, and no one disputes his claim. For thirty-seven years Otto Grantz has been following a prospector's life, first in California, then Oregon, Nevada, Utah, and for twenty-three years in the Black Hills, with varying luck.
NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- While no tidings have been received of missing Dr. Dexter, the clergyman who disappeared from this place, the case has excited increased interest.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- The number of children's books this season is something almost appalling, and the number of authors represented on three, four, five, and even a larger number of lists suggests that the work of writing them is undertaken with a light heart, although the most prolific authors do not seem to repeat themselves, but give something new to each publisher and each set of readers.
The most important event in football to-day will be the meeting between Princeton University and the Carlisle Indians at Manhattan Field.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 10. -- Gens. Frederick Funston and Wilder Metcalf, Col. Little, and the staff of the Twentieth Kansas Regiment were brought into the city to-day by special train as guests of the Knife and Fork Club. They were met at the station by a large crowd and escorted to Convention Hall, where a public reception was given.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10. -- After hearing arguments for a modification of his order of sale for the Clover Leaf Railway system Judge Taft announced to-night that he would make an additional entry to-morrow.
" Sillaga's" objections to the sprinkling cart in your issues of Oct. 26 and Nov. 5 do not seem to fit with the following facts:

Our American nicknames used to annoy and disgust Richard Grant White, and particularly did he dislike to hear the great monarch of the Hudson River called "Butter Hill." The peak in question was called "Buttel Hill" in a very ancient map, and as "Buttel" is the German for bailiff or jailer, one who commands or guards, one sees the origin of the probable misnomer.

Your correspondent Annie Pomfret Proudman finds fault with Hamerton's reflection that women uninfluenced by masculine influence are not intellectually "superior at fifty to what they were at twenty-five."

The first day of admiral and Mrs. Dewey's honeymoon was spent very quietly yesterday, and mostly in their suite of rooms adjoining the private apartments of Proprietor Boldt of the Waldorf-Astoria. Only once did they issue from their retreat together, and that was for a short drive before luncheon. They are not registered at the hotel, and the guests only learned of their presence through the morning newspapers.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- A public movement has been started in this city to prevail upon the Rev. Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock to decline the call to the Brick Presbyterian Church of New York City. Prominent people of all the Protestant denominations as well as Presbyterians are interested in keeping him in Baltimore, as he is one of the most popular preachers in the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The November report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture will give 25.2 bushels as the average yield per acre of corn, according to the preliminary returns of the department's correspondents. The preliminary estimate last year was 24.8 bushels, that of 1897, 23.7 bushels, and the mean of the preliminary estimates of the last ten years 24 bushels.

If a French audience disapprove of an actor or a play they make a continuance of the performance impossible by a "demonstration." Very seldom they show their resentment through quiet disdain or sheer indifference. Occasionally they do so, however. They are showing it now in regard to the trial of the conspirators that has just begun before the Senate sitting as a High Court of Justice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The War Department has received the following:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- To-morrow afternoon Harvard will line up against Dartmouth, on Soldiers' Field, for the last game before the contest with Yale next Saturday. There will be several substitutes in the line-up, Ristine, A.R. Sargent, C. Sargent, and Fincke taking the places, respectively, of Campbell, Boal, Burnett, and Daly.

" The Memoirs and Correspondence of Lord Playfair," written and edited by Sir Weymss Reid, will shortly be brought out by Harper Brothers. The memoirs are based upon an unfinished autobiography which Lord Playfair left behind him, and their Value will be enhanced by a large number of important letters from such men as Sir Robert Peel, Mr. Gladstone, and Mr. Chamberlain, which will appear therein for the first time.

It was the original intention of The Century Company to present only three extracts from Capt. Joshua Slocum's "Sailing Alone Around the World," in as many numbers of the magazine. The installments already presented have excited so much interest and irritated so much comment, however, that the story of the Captain's adventures in port and on the high seas will be continued through the February number, when it will make its appearance in book form.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- The story printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday relative to the Adirondack Railway losing its action to compel the officers of the State to condemn a strip of land through the forest preserve recalls the hurried midnight session of the old Forest Commission to get the grant to this railroad company through before the present Cnstitutin went into effect.

There is no doubt that "the times that try men's souls" exhibit the British soul to particular advantage. In spite of the immense experience of Lord SALISBURY, an experience which Mr. HARRISON said, the other day, that no living statesman could pretend to rival, even though Mr. HARRISON might have excepted Signor CRISPI, there has been nothing like the occasion which confronted him at the Lord Mayor's banquet on Thursday.

The mystery surrounding the disappearance of the Rev. William Hart Dexter, Principal of the New York Naval Academy, at Nyack, deepens, in spite of the efforts of eight of Capt. McClusky's detectives to gather clues that would lead to the solution of the matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Rear Admiral Winfield Scott Schley to-night received the orders which made him a Knight Templar and a Knight of Malta. The degrees were conferred upon Admiral Schley by the officers of Columbia Commandery, No. 2, District of Columbia, in the presence of a large and distinguished assemblage of Knights Templars of this jurisdiction and of the jurisdictions of many States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Industrial Commission spent considerable time to-day considering a statement which George Rice of Ohio had submitted at the request of the commission, forecasting what he expected to say on the stand. This statement, it is said, was severe in its reflection upon railroads, the Standard Oil Company, the Inter-State Commerce Commission, and also upon other Government officials.

On Nov. 20 the extraordinary condition will be presented of three Grand Juries sitting at once in New York County for the investigation of crimes or alleged crimes. No such extreme measure was ever resorted to heretofore. Indeed, a like condition was legally impossible under the old Constitution of the State.

The dissatisfaction of the residents of Bay Ridge over the double-fare system established by the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company to points beyond Sixty-fifth Street on the surface lines is increasing daily. A movement is already on foot to hold a mass meeting with the idea of bringing about, if possible, not only an abolition of the extra fare, but to obtain better time and better connections at transfer points.

Readers of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, who had the privilege of perusing the series of sketches of American contemporaneous life and culture that appeared in the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES under the signature of William Archer, will doubtless be glad to hear that these articles, together with others on the same general theme, are soon to be brought out in book form by Charles Scribner's Sons.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Department yesterday handed down an opinion granting the motion of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners for the reduction of the bond to be given by the contractor for the construction of the underground tunnel from $14,000,000 to $5,000,000.

Mr. Howells has told us how our civilization impresses a traveler from Altruria, and Mr. Whiteing tells us how the Altrurians impress a traveler from civilization. Not that Altruria is the name of his island, which is the old story of Pitcairn redivivus, but Altrurian well expresses the attitude of the simple islanders, and explains why it was exceedingly difficult to describe to them our highly complex and competitive modern life.

HARTFORD CITY, Ind., Nov. 10. -- Fire to-day destroyed the Briscoe Block, entailing a loss of $50,000. The building was occupied by Lieber Campbell, hardware; John Woods. groceries; J.L. Hoover, furniture; the Kentucky Liquor Company. C. E. Larrick, liquor dealer; the Western Union Telegraph Company, and the Central Union Telephone Company.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 10. -- A special train of mules from the Kansas City stock yards started for New Orleans to-day, bound for the Trasvaal. This is the second trainload of mules purchased in this market by the English Government. To-day's order is a "hurry" one and the train will try to make a record run.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. - -Admiral Hichborn, Chief Constructor of the Navy, has caused to be prepared a statement of the work on naval vessels now building, from which it appears that the battleship Kearsarge, at Newport News, is advanced toward completion 97 per cent.; the Kentucky, at the same place, 95 per cent., and the Illinois 71 per cent.

I read with great pleasure the letter written in the last SATURDAY REVIEW by Annie Pomfret Proudman, and the question which it raises is not only an interesting one, but also opens a large field for discussion.

Edward McLaughlin of Philadelphia won from Thomas Gallagher of Chicago in the 1,000 point cushion carrom match for a purse of $250, which was terminated at Maurice Daly's Academy last night after five consecutive nights of play.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The October monthly statement of domestic exports, issued by the Bureau of Statistics, shows as follows:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 10. -- With the marriage in this city next Monday of James Gilmer, a prominent business man of Kansas City, and Mrs. K.A. Ferron of St. Louis, there will end a story that rivals the tale of "Enoch Arden."
I notice the suggestion of S.B.H. in your last issue that the second line of Mrs. Whitman's "A Still Day in Autumn" should read:

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 10. -- The practice to-day was light and did not show the improvement that marked the work of the eleven throughout the early part of the week. It was not as full of snap and dash and fumbling was frequent. The warm weather seemed to make the men dull and stupid.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The University of Michigan football eleven will meet the University of Pennsylvania football team on Franklin Field to-morrow. So little is known of Michigan's playing strength that the Pennsylvanians are somewhat apprehensive as to the outcome of the game. Reports have been received that the Westerners are playing a strong game, and the Eastern team has done considerable hard practicing during the past week.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- A description of the scenes at the Revolutionary Convention which Michelet has left us would give a fair idea of what happened in the Senate this afternoon on the arrival of about 100 additional witnesses who came to answer to their names. Pandemonium is not the word for it.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Complete silence has again fallen upon affairs in South Africa. The British public must perforce be content with the brief, stereotyped report which the censor allows to filter through from Cape Town. That this condition of things is no longer due to pressure of work or defective cables has been amply proved.

After reading the very able and interesting article on "Conversation as a Lost Art," in a recent number of your SATURDAY REVIEW, the question came to my mind as to what constitutes the art of conversation. That it seems a lost one, I agree fully with your contributor. When it is resolved back to first causes, intelligence is, of course, a presupposed and obvious factor, a primal one, as it is in everything of importance.

In his reply to what he styles my "vivacious attack" on the pronouncing vocabulary attached to his brief introduction to the latest Portland edition of FitzGerald's "Ruba'iyat," Mr. Nathan Haskell Dole confesses to two of the "mistakes" and to several of the "inconsistencies" to which I called attention.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day received the charges preferred by Brig. Gen. McCoskry Butt of the Fifth Brigade, New York City, against his superior, Major Gen Roe, commanding the State National Guard. The Governor refused to make known the text of the charges, saying that he would first secure an opinion from the Attorney General.
Is it possible that it is three years since you began THE SATURDAY REVIEW? It seems only a Summer.

In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Oct. 28, in a paragraph headed "Two Other Stanzas," "S.B.H." suggests two corrections in Mrs. Whitman's poem, "A Still Day in Autumn," as printed in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Oct. 21. These are "gloom" for "light" in the first stanza, and "paling" for "palmy" in the sixth.

Mr. BRYAN is not without honor in AGUINALDO'S country. At Tarlac the other day, while that town was still the capital of the insurgent chieftain, they held a celebration in honor of the American anti-imperialists. There was a procession, with religious services and some speeches by insurgent officers, including one from AGUINALDO himself.

A new and complete edition of the works of the late Robert G. Ingersoll, to be known as the Dresden Edition, is in press at C.P. Farrell's. The issue will include twelve volumes, handsomely illustrated with photogravures, etchings, and half-tones. Additional and hitherto unpublished material will be found in the volumes, including Mr. Ingersoll's first lecture entitled "Progress," written and delivered in 1860, and his lecture on Robert Burns.

The season is slowly opening. The first art sale was held on Thursday evening at the Fifth Avenue Auction Rooms, where a number of pictures, chiefly by members of the Barbizon and modern French schools, were disposed of at fair prices.
HELENA, Mont., Nov. 10. -- Among the witnesses before the Supreme Court in the Welcome disbarment case to-day was Chaplain E.H. Warren of the House, who in reply to a question said:
Will the editor (who presides at all sorts of literary "scraps" in this excellent column) allow room for an iconoclast to throw his little stone at a popular idol of fiction?

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 10. -- As the result of an investigation five men, all residents of Washington, D.C., arrested on Tuesday, were to-day held in bail for court on the charge of repeating, impersonating election officers and making fraudulent returns. The defendants are John F. Sheehan, R.M. Drinkert, William Cook, Harry McCabe, and George Kirkland. All but one are said to be in Government employ.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- In an address Prof. Richard G. Moulton, the pioneer of University Extension in the United States, made the following interesting remarks concerning the aims and purposes of the movement:
At the United Service Institution, Lieut. Col. C.M. Douglas, V.C., M.D., (Hon. Brigade Surgeon,) read a paper on "The Recruit from a Depot Medical Officer's Point of View."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Fourth Assistant Postmaster General John L. Bristow in his annual report to-day announces that during the past fiscal year 14,604 Postmasters were appointed, 13,523 being fourth-class Postmasters and the remainder Presidential. Concerning the policy of removals, the report says:

In a suggestive bit which recently appeared in THE SATURDAY REVIEW Julia Hartwell says: "It is an undisputed fact that conversation has become a lost art. The proofs that this is the case, and the causes of it, are matters of real interest. That the younger people of our day should not be required to know anything of this very fine art is a deplorable fact, and one which excites no comment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- From out of the West friends of Congressman David A. De Armond are coming to Chicago Nov. 20 to engage in their first skirmish in the fight to land the Missourian in the position of leader of the Democratic minority in the House of Representatives. From the South friends of James D. Richardson of Tennessee will come to voice the claims of their candidate for the coveted position.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Great interest is felt in the War Department over Aguinaldo's sudden change of base northeastward from Tarlac to Bayombong, about 75 miles northeast. There are numerous spellings of the latter place, but the form given is the one most generally adhered to on the maps in possession of the War Department.

" The Strange Story of a Strange People" -- would not that be an appropriate description of "Children of the Ghetto"? Mr. Zangwill surely has won for himself a place among the true realists of the time, and, I do not know whether the comparison is original, but could he not be named the "Jewish Dickens"?

A number of correspondents have asked for help to enable them to obtain the completion of a poem, a line or verse of which they recall from the past as contained "in the school readers we used." And in this month's Book Buyer some one sends a selection from "The Lone Indian" which seemed as familiar to me as Mary's lamb.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Nov. 10. -- The astronomers of the Yerkes Observatory are already on the lookout for meteors, although none of the leonides is expected before Sunday morning. The twenty-four-inch reflecting telescope, which has just been completed in the instrument shop of the observatory, has been set up temporarily on the roof of the building.

A few weeks since, being thereunto impelled by the very favorable notices in THE TIMES and other journals, I read Mr. Winston Churchill's now famous novel, "Richard Carvel," and while in the vein concluded to add "Hugh Wynne, Free Quaker," to my "have read" stock. I read "Carvel with unqualified pleasure and "Wynne" with wonder.
The Empires and Belvideres divided honors in the Columbia League last night.

EDINBURGH, Nov. 10. -- Joseph Hodges Choate, the United States Ambassador, who was the chief guest at the annual banquet of the Walter Scott Club this evening, met with an enthusiastic reception. Sir Herbert Maxwell, who presided, made a cordial reference to "the friendship that seals England and America."

" The New Pacific," the subject which occupies Mr. Robert Howe Bancroft's attention, had necessarily to be treated in an extended manner. History does not depend on a single incident. The annexation of the Philippine Islands was brought about by circumstances, not happening in 1898, but dating from long centuries before. The blowing up of the Maine was only as the the fuse which fired the train.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The Horse Show of the Orange Riding and Driving Club, which opened last night at East Orange, was continued to-night. Lord Mayor Tallon of Dublin occupied a box in a conspicuous location, decorated with green flags and palms. He was the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Nevins.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Judged simply by its length Mr. Bolton King's "History of the Unity of Italy" is a more important work than the much smaller volume recently published by Mr. Stillman, but most men who are familiar with the phases of the long struggle that resulted in the foundation of the Italian kingdom will give an unhesitating preference to Mr. Stillman's book.
Reading the other day, we were much surprised to find the following assertion made by a man whose name is far from being unknown in the world of letters:

Fire Chief Croker yesterday detailed men to take part in the funeral of Deputy Chief Benjamin A. Gicquel, which will take place from St. Francis Xavier's Church this morning. The escort will consist of a fire brigade of two battalions, four companies in each battalion, ten men in a company. Deputy Chief of Department William Duane will command the brigade.

It has frequently been said that Mark Twain objects to giving his autograph in response to requests for it. One enterprising young collector, however, used a unique means toward the attainment of her end. She inclosed to him the following extract from "Pudd'nhead Wilson":

Although born of English parents, the juvenile colonial or Transvaaler mixes much, and of necessity, with Dutch children and Dutch-speaking native servants. Hence, as he grows up, a certain number of quasi-Dutch phrases become a part and parcel of his vocabulary, and require some study on the part of the newly arrived Briton in order to understand their true significance.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 10. -- The fourth and last day's session of the Federation of Women's Clubs was convened this morning, with Mrs. Helmuth, the President, in the chair. The wide subject of philanthropy was the first to come before the convention for discussion. "Aesthetics in Civics" was then taken up.
Everybody knows that the gallant British officer is the best loved creature in the philosophy of West End London life.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- While the Cornell football team this afternoon merely indulged in signal practice, there were several changes made in the substitute team which may mean that Otis, heretofore substitute left half back, is to be displaced by a man who has held the position of substitute in some other position.

MANILA, Nov. 10. -- It has been raining hard throughout the week, handicapping Gens. Lawton and MacArthur. The transportation is the chief difficulty. In the advance Gen. Lawton depended on the river to get his supplies. The San Isidro River is fed by mountain streams, and is alternately too shallow for navigation or too swift.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 10. -- The official count of the ballots cast on Tuesday was begun to-day throughout the State. In this city a large crowd gathered at the Court House. Representatives of all the parties were admitted by the Commissioners and the examination of the ballots proceeded in an orderly manner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The President has appointed ex-Gov. Joseph W. Fifer of Illinois a member of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, vice W.J. Calhoun, resigned.

A few Sundays ago THE NEW YORK TIMES published a short article headed "Dust Laid by Oil." It was stated therein that on several railroads the obnoxious dust nuisance had been abated by the use of a preparation of crude oil.
May I, as a Rough Rider, call your attention to certain inaccuracies in Tom Hall's "The Fun and Fighting of the Rough Riders," and say a word about the author?

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The commission which is investigating the prison system of the State held its final session here to-day, and then went to New York City. It will next take up Auburn Prison.

Prof. McGiffert of Union Seminary, unless he chooses to surprise the Presbytery next Monday, will not bring peace to New York Presbyterianism by taking himself out of it. At any rate, the final meeting of the Presbytery committee developed nothing new, and the committee will take its stand on the General Assembly's four-fold doctrinal deliverance and venture to recommend that the case be referred back to the General Assembly for more definite instructions.

There is an incredible vitality in the project of an underground rapid transit road for the City of New York. It has died a dozen deaths. The Legislature has killed it many times, the Court of Appeals once, the Appellate Division once, Tammany more than once, and its own managers and special custodians not a few times.

DETROIT, Nov. 10. -- The Michigan Central Railroad Company win offer a reward of $2,500 for the capture and conviction of the persons who caused the wreck on that line near La Salle, Mich., last night. General Superintendent L'Hommedieu made that statement this morning. He said:

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- The Delaware Valley and Kingston Railway Company, with a capital of $2,500,000, was incorporated here to-day. It will be operated by electricity and will be about eighty-one miles in length, with termini at Kingston, Ulster County, and a point in Sullivan County on the boundary line between New York and Pennsylvania, opposite the Borough of Lackawaxen, Pike County, Penn.

You hit the nail on the head to-day in the matter of the amendments to the Constitution. For one, I had never seen or heard of the amendments till the ballot was put in my hands. Can it be possible that an honest and intelligent vote of the citizens was desired, when no effort was made to give a clear idea of what the changes really mean?

Being very much interested in a letter from "St. Elmo," published under date of Sept. 23, I venture to tell Mrs. "St. Elmo" of my sympathy with her, because of a similar experience, though not at all unpleasant, and you, Mr. Editor, deserve thanks for the delicate manner in which you have answered "St. Elmo's" appeal.

A corner plot on Fifth Avenue, north of Seventy-second Street. has been sold for about $300,000. Whitehouse Porter, the brokers, admit that such a deal has been made, but decline to give any further particulars in regard to the location of the property or the names of the interested parties.

In the issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, supplement to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 30, on Page 650, appears an article entitled "Perpetual Copyright." The last paragraph of said article is almost a complete perversion of the facts stated in the petition as prepared for Congress, and is a complete misstatement of the law in reference to retroactive or retrospective enactments.

Your correspondent, "W. Matches," represents a large number of your appreciative bookmaking readers, who have daily difficulties with the apostrophe, not only in dialect typography, but also in other important connections. There is probably no mark in the printer's case so often misused and abused.

A valuable art book is about to be published through Messrs. Cassell Co. It is to be entitled "The National Gallery," and, as its title implies, will contain reproductions of the most distinctive works in the great British collection. The work is being edited by Sir Edward J. Poynter, Director of the National Gallery, who will write the introduction and present such critical notes as will prove of great value to dealers and amateurs.

Some of our younger readers who may have indulged a belief that the popular books of the day are to remain permanent additions to English literature may like to read the following list of novels which were popular favorites half a century or more ago. The list appears in Literature as furnished by Archibald Sparke. How many of our young readers ever heard of these books:

Every one interested in education will be well repaid, it is believed, for visiting the vacation schools' exhibit to be held next week in the old Public School No. 1, at 30 Vandewater Street. There will be displayed picked specimens of all kinds of work done by the children of the ten vacation schools, from the sandhouses built by babbling six-year-olds to the ornate bunches of paper roses cut by the larger girls.

The time allotted by the Park Department as the period in which the Manhattan Railway Company must take its elevated structure out of Battery Park will expire next Friday. President Clausen's order to the company to remove the structure in six months' time was served on Feb. 17, and shortly before the six months were up the company got a three months' extension.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Three of the striking employes of Cramps' shipyard and Business Agent. John J. Keegan of the International Association of Machinists and Frederick Counselman, Treasurer of the machinists' organization, to-day were arrested and held in $2,000 bail each, charged with inciting to riot.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 11. -- F.C. Berendes, cashier of the Bank of Boulder, was the first witness in the Wellcome disbarment proceedings this morning. He was asked to detail any dealings he may have had with Senator Warner of Jefferson County at the time of the Legislative Assembly. He replied that in November, 1898, or just before the Legislature met, he had loaned Mr. Warner $500.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11. -- The Western Turf Association has announced three stakes to be run at the Spring meetings of 1900, 1901, and 1902. The Western Stakes, to be run in i900, for two year-olds, at five furlongs, and the Western Foal Stakes, to be run in 1901, are to have $2,000 added money.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Although there are more than 200 varieties of fish in Puerto Rican waters, there are practically no fishing industries there, and the Puerto Ricans import fish in large quantities from the United States, Canada, and other places. According to an officer of the Fish Commission, the whole trouble is due to a lack of enterprise.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The third Horse Show of the Orange Riding and Driving Club came to a successful close to-night with a fine exhibition of horses in several harness and saddle classes. There was a larger attendance than at any previous time during the three days of the exhibition.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- Bishop Curtis, who represents Cardinal Gibbons in the latter's absence from the archdiocese, to-day explained the manner of the granting of the dispensation for the marriage of Admiral Dewey and Mrs. Hazen. Father MacKin came to Baltimore several days before the wedding and applied to Bishop Curtis for permission to perform the marriage ceremony between Mrs. Hazen and the Admiral.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- A general reduction of the force of the department of construction and repair at the League Island Navy Yard has been made. Of the 380 employes 102 have been discharged, and it is believed that more will follow. The discharged men include shipwrights, ship-fitters, painters, shipsmiths, joiners, plumbers, boat-builders, and laborers.

Never shall I forget my first experience of Heckingham Workhouse. Having been elected a guardian, I attended the board in due course, and, as is too often my fortune, at the very first meeting fell into controversy. At that date all children in the house, including infants, were fed upon skimmed milk.

In these days of National, State, and municipal excitement it is well to know that there is one thing upon which every one in this city is agreed. The Brooklyn Christmas Tree must provide its big round of universal joy upon that day for the neglected and destitute children of Brooklyn. This is a plea that touches every heart and interferes with nobody's prejudices.

We know from the narrative of Bernal Diaz and the journals of the Coronado expedition that the turquoise was in general use for personal adornment, and that it was most highly prized, and was an object of trade or commerce between the various tribes. It was also reported as in use at Cibola for the adornment of the portals of chiefs' houses by inlaying.
LONDON, Nov. 11. -- The War Office has received from Gen. Buller the following dispatch:

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- The long-expected agreement on the Samoan question and the visit of the Czar to Emperor William at Potsdam were two events which brought joy to the hearts of the Germans, for they were both construed as favorable to the empire and Government, and the press did everything to assure the Czar a hearty welcome.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- Warwick J. Price of the Mutual Life Insurance Company was well known here, where he was graduated from Yale in the class of 94. He was a society man at Yale and a high stand scholar. He was interested in literary matters, and was Chairman of the Yale Courant during his senior year. He wrote extensively for magazines and the press while in Yale.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- The Yale Varsity eleven smashed right and left into the defense of the Pennsylvania State College team here to-day, and ran up 30 points in the first half before Pennsylvania knew where it stood. In the second half the visitors woke up and held Yale down to 12 points, making the final score, Yale, 42; Pennsylvania State College, 0.

The Central Board of Education has come to the aid of a deserving teacher, Miss C. Cecilia Carey, who after thirty-six years' continuous service in the public schools of this borough, has been compelled by ill-health to resign. Miss Carey was appointed a teacher in June, 1857, and taught until February, 1893, when she resigned as teacher in Public School No. 56, in West Eighteenth Street.

That is a very interesting suggestion which comes from London that the real "compensation" for England's acquiescence in an agreement which shuts her out from any share in the "control, disposition, or government" of the Samoan archipelago is to be looked for in China. It is true that Germany is far away the most important power in Samoa as concerns the capital and enterprise invested in Samoan industries.

An evil which ought to engage the attention of Messrs. PLATT, CROKER, ROOSEVELT, and other reformers has made its appearance in clubdom and may spread to the clubless ranks of the city unless arrested now. Hitherto the vices of club men most reprobated by the pure and the good consisted of drink and the use of dice, gambling with cards or the fly and sugar, backbiting, and unreasonable interference with the House Committee.
South Bend, Ind., would like to have the Prohibition National Convention next Summer, and Milwaukee is willing it should have that. What Milwaukee wants is the Democratic.
OMAHA, Nov. 11. -- A special to The Bee from Denison, Iowa, says:

The successful professional poacher is a fellow of keen observation. He has a complete comprehension of animated nature, of woodcraft, and of how changes in the weather affect the customs of his quarry. Discarding the gun, which has the disadvantage, unless it be an air one, of betraying his presence, he chiefly relies on nets and his dog.

VIENNA, Oct. 24. -- The ladies' tailors in Vienna state that Viennese fashions have obtained a great victory -- an unhoped-for one -- and the greater as the vanquished are the all-prevailing Parisian fashions. Astonishing revelations were made at the last committee meeting of the Vienna Fashion Club, the other day.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 1. -- Love laughs at locksmiths and trade maintains an equally derisive attitude toward conventions; not, of course, that international treaties do not make smooth the paths of international commerce, but it is none the less a fact that trade does not wait on treaties any more than treaties can create trade.

Lord Mayor Tallon and the Hon. John E. Redmond, M.P., left New York yesterday for Albany, where they will be the guests of the city. To-morrow night the visitors will be the guests of Gov. Roosevelt at an official dinner. Before leaving, Lord Mayor Tallon gave out facts and figures on the present condition of the peasantry in Ireland. He said in part:

Advices from Sofia by way of Paris are that the Vienna Bank Syndicate has refused to make any concessions to the Bulgarian Government in regard to a further loan. This, it is said, unless the Government decides to break its agreement with the syndicate, in which event it is not unlikely that Austria would intervene, practically leaves Bulgaria bankrupt.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- There is a great scarcity of the famous Chesapeake Bay diamond back terrapin. This luxury promises to be more expensive this season than ever. The receipts and shipments for the opening weeks are not up to the average. Prices range about as follows: Five inches, $15 to $18 a dozen; six-inch, $36 to $45; seven-inch, $60 to $75.

Warwick J. Price, Superintendent of the Insurance Department of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, and John A. Meade of 683 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, a dealer in revenue stamps at 23 Liberty Street, were arrested yesterday and taken by a Central Office detective to Police Headquarters.

Their mendicity is passive rather than active. Unlike the Mendicant Friars, they never ask, but they know much will be given them. They know, too -- strange fact in a strange country -- that the university is open to all, irrespective of means or position. Thus the university becomes the poor Russian's golden opportunity, for here, as elsewhere, there are many posts for which graduates alone are eligible.

When the curtain is brought down on the last performance at the Knickerbocker Theatre of Sir Henry Irving and his London Lyceum Company next Saturday night they will have fulfilled one of the most remarkable engagements ever attempted in this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- United States Minister Loomis has advised the State Department of the impending bombardment of Gen. Parade's forces in Puerto Cabello by the forces of Gen. Castro. The Minister has evidently looked to the department for instructions, and these are to go forward at once.
Being interrogated by a reporter as to the probable battle cry of the Democrats in the Presidential contest next year, Mr. RICHARD CROKER made this answer:

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Europe is now agog with rumors of diplomatic activity and alliances that may be effected. As a result, the relations of the European powers seem to be rapidly assuming a new phase. This doubtless is greatly due to the fact that in nearly all the recent international negotiations the United States has been a factor.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- Sir William C. Van Horne, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway, is in Chicago.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 11. -- The death of Ponto, an intelligent St. Bernard dog of famous pedigree belonging to Frank P. Marsh of New York, which occurred in March, resulted to-day in the arraignment in the Greenwich Borough Court of his caretaker, Jesse Terverey, on a charge of willful neglect of the dog.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- In the fiercest game played on Franklin Field this year the University of Pennsylvania football team this afternoon defeated the University of Michigan eleven by the close score of 11 to 10. The game was a royal battle from start to finish, and was marked by both brilliant and poor playing by both teams.

Powder for the hair seems to have died out about the end of the last century when the scarcity of flour combined with Pitt's tax on powder in 1795 caused a complete change in the appearance of both sexes, though individuals here and there in fashionable circles had for some years left it off, the ladies partly from artistic influences and admiration of the portraits with natural hair and simple dress.

ROME, Oct. 24. -- It has been announced that on account of the encouraging successes attending the recent excavations in the Roman Forum, the Hon. Baccelli, Minister of Public Instruction, has finally appointed a committee to report upon the best means of carrying on the excavations on a larger and more important scale.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- The theory of suicide in the case of missing Rev. Mr. Dexter, as intimated by Capt. McClusky, is rejected by the clergyman's family and all who were intimately acquainted with him in Nyack.

An old business block owned by the Hammersley estate, at William and John Streets, was destroyed by fire last night. The blaze started at 8 o'clock, when the entire block was dark and vacated. The damage is estimated at $40,000. An old chophouse, formerly owned by James A. Farrish, who was succeeded by Charles A. Hickey, was destroyed, and the tailoring establishment of Reubenstone Son was damaged by water.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., Oct. 28. -- With characteristic cordiality the Captain or the sardine boat ushers aboard his craft the stranger who wants to study the details of so interesting an industry as sardine fishing and canning, which is extensively carried on along the California coast.

In certain districts of the city, especially in the cheaper neighborhoods, little shops like those of London are appearing with a rapidity suggestive of a great industry in the near future. These shops partake of the character of the "beaneries" and coffee-and-cake places so long a feature of Park Row and the Bowery.
SARATOGA, Nov. 11. -- The official vote of this county on the Constitutional amendments was as follows:
As the year 1900 approaches, one cannot help but give considerable thought to imperialism, which will be the significant feature in the platforms of the two leading political parties.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Nov. 11. -- At the morning service in the Elmwood Presbyterian Church to-morrow the resignation of the pastor, the Rev. Samuel J. McClenaghan, will be read to the congregation and offered for a vote. While his parishioners are thus acting upon his resignation, the Rev. Mr. McClenaghan is on his way to Cuba and hoped-for forgetfulness of unpleasant remembrances connected with the pastorate he is leaving.

The broad sunny Prado is as gay as a parterre of moving flowers. The central avenue, which is wider, I think, than that of the Champs Elysees, is roped off and no one allowed in it except maskers and two single rows of moving carriages, admirably controlled by the police. Now the Spanish policeman is not merely useful -- he is beau tiful.

URBANA, Iowa, Nov. 11. -- Clarence Burrell, son of Banker J.C. Burrell, was instantly killed to-day by an explosion of dynamite, which wrecked the bank building and partially destroyed the Monitor general store.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 11. -- William J. Bryan this evening gave to the press an extended statement summing up the results of the elections in different States. In Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, where the Democrats reaffirmed the Chicago platform, he finds that they have made gains, while in New York and New Jersey the Republican vote shows a falling off. Maryland, he declares, is now surely Democratic.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 11. -- The pie counter having descended by inheritance to a new joint stock association of Republicans, the self-constituted Directors have begun, without advertisement, to invoice the goods and figure on new help all around, from scullion to steward. It is the general plan of those who helped win the victory to weed out these who didn't.

MOUND CITY, Ill., Nov. 11. -- Since June 21 last, when Michael Tobin murdered Major Thomas A. Fitzpatrick of this city, the whereabouts of the murderer remained a mystery until this afternoon, when his skeleton was found under a tree in the woods, two miles northeast of here.
"Every mother and father in this city, or anywhere else, is interested in child study and wants to know what is being done to further the development of that science."

A week ago Wall Street sentiment seemed largely dependent upon what would come to pass on election day; and election day results were in the Wall Street view satisfactory. Yet throughout all the week nervousness has ruled on the Stock Exchange and quotations generally have declined.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11. -- In the final round in the tournament of the New Haven Golf Club, played yesterday, T.L. Cheney, Yale, 1900, defeated E.C. Cox, Yale, 1900, 6 up, 4 to play. This victory gives Cheney the championship of the State, Yale University, and the New Haven Golf Club.

One thousand years ago almost, on the night of Oct. 12, 1902, King Ibrahim-BenAhmed passed out of this world, and as he lay a-dying a strange thing happened, for throughout that night "a multitude of falling stars scattered themselves across the sky like rain."

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11. -- About thirty inmates of the New Jersey Home for Disabled Soldiers at Kearny held a meeting at Roach's Hall, here, this morning and passed resolutions censuring the Board of Managers of the home for its action in expelling Benjamin Morehouse for alleged in subordination.

No officer of the National Guard, active or veteran, can view the present contest for the Colonelcy of the Seventy-first Regiment without asking whether the old-time esprit de corps of that famous command is to be sacrificed for the alleged interests of the regiment.

Overshadowing all other branches of industry in this city, both in wealth and magnitude of operations, the Chicago live stock market not only takes precedence over all similar markets in the world, but annually receives and slaughters more cattle, hogs, and sheep than the five other principal live stock markets of this country combined.

The engagement of Sir Henry Irving, which will end with this week, has been even more profitable than it was expected to be. One must go to tolerably dim and remote history for a precedent in this town for the rush for tickets. Perhaps the demand was as great and the waiting line at the box office was as long when Irving first acted here at the Star Theatre sixteen years ago.

Benjamin A. Gicquel, Deputy Chief of the Fire Department, who died on Thursday, was laid to rest in Calvary Cemetery yesterday after imposing funeral services art St. Francis Xavier's Church. Two battalions of firemen, in full uniform, with a crepe band on their left arm, marched before the hearse from the late home of the deceased, 247 West Forty-eighth Street, to the church, and, after the service, from the church to the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- The last infantry battalions under orders for South Africa left England to-day, and the last of the Hussars also sailed, leaving the Household Regiment the only cavalry still to be dispatched. Last, but not by any means least, the First Battery of the howitzer artillery has started. Great things are expected of the howitzer battery, of which there are only three in the British Army.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- It is officially announced that the troopships Hawarden Castle, Yorkshire. Lismore Castle, and Aurania have arrived at Cape Town with 5,676 troops. The first two steamers immediately proceeded to Durban. It is supposed the Aurania's troops will be landed at Cape Town.

The Executive Committee of the committee of 175 citizens who met last week to protest against the two-fare system and other methods adopted by the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system to which Brooklyn residents object, held a meeting last evening in Parshall Hall, Fifty-third Street and Third Avenue.

When Mr. GAGE was about to leave Chicago to become Secretary of the Treasury, a friend who had been for many years at the head of an important bureau in the Treasury, and who suspected that Mr. GAGE contemplated reforms in the department he was about to accept, gave him advice. "Wash your hands of any such notion; when you get to Washington you will find there a government by clerks."

What shall we say of him who fights not simply for pelf, but for worldly honor, that he may be esteemed and valued as such a valiant man, and so on? My answer is: Greed of honor and greed of gold are both greed and one as wrong as the other; whoever fights in such a vicious spirit will gain hell.
Frederick Anstey is said to yearn for some of the honors and emoluments of dramatic authorship. He is dramatizing his story called "The Man from Blankley's," which appeared as a serial in Punch.

Wall Street forecasts of the weekly bank statement named over $4,000,000 as likely to be the decrease shown in Clearing House surplus reserves. But the official figures as finally announced during the last hour of business on the Stock Exchange showed a shrinkage of $2,450,000. This brings the "surplus reserve" deficit up to $2,788,950.
ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 11. -- Everything was gay at the Essex County Country Club this evening, for the golf team had met the crack team from the Philadelphia Cricket Club and the Quakers had succumbed.

MANILA, Sept. 30. -- The gunboat Manila has recently returned here, after a most interesting and eventful cruise among the islands forming the southwestern group of the Philippines, where she has performed most arduous and efficient service. An account of the spirited encounter with the outlaw tribe which attempted to interfere with the management of the Cape Melville Light has already been sent to the United States.

If the New York Central officials lack the courage and vigor to grapple with the "tip" nuisance, that "vilest of imported vices," as you rightly term it, the persistent campaigning by your influential journal might at least arouse a goodly portion of your readers to make a bold resistance to that species of blackmail.

In no year in the past decade have there been on the Metropolitan racing circuit so many owners of horses fortunate enough to capture a fair share of the prize money as in the season which closed on election day at Acueduct.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- It is learned that one of the most remarkable innovations in warfare will shortly be tested in South Africa. Lieut. Foulkes, a young officer of the Royal Engineers, sailed for Cape Town Oct. 11 to put photographs to uses hitherto considered impracticable, which, if successful, will revolutionize the methods of military reconnaissance.

BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- The Reichstag meets Nov. 14, and it is probable that the session will be most lively. There are three very important measures about which great diversity of opinion exists. They are the Anti-Strike bill, the Naval bill and the renewal of the commercial treaties. The first is not likely to pass unless the Government accepts radical changes.

The author of the "Curiosities of Literature'' throws doubt upon the story that Lord Arlington and Lord Ossory, who were said to have a small package of tea from Holland in 1666, were the first introducers. Disraeli states that he has heard of a collector who was in possession of Oliver Cromwell's teapot.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 11. -- E.H. Beers of Bethel, Conn., traveling salesman, was arrested here last night by Sheriff F.H. Judd of Danbury. Beers registered at the Metropolitan Hotel with a woman as E.H. Beers and wife, New York, ten days ago. He is said to have deserted a wife and three children in Bethel.

ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- A.B. Donaldson, Secretary and Treasurer of the Erie Canal Electric Traction Company, was here to-day in company with the company's engineer inspecting the canal lock at Cohoes. Mr. Donaldson was asked as to the future plans of his company, and when the proposed new equipment would be in operation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- On a wet field, with compact offensive play and against a team not yet recovered from the Columbia game, Lafayette this afternoon defeated Cornell at Percy Field by a score of 6 to 5. Both scores were made in the first half, Cornell winning her's after she had lost the ball on downs on Lafayette's five-yard line by blocking a punt and falling on the ball back of the line.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 8. -- The movements of the Boers north of Cape Colony appear to be half-hearted. Aliwal North is entirely at their mercy. It is probable that they will shortly occupy Bethulie, one of the points of railway entrance into the Free State. They have occupied Burghersdorp, where the lines diverge, but Bethulie and Aliwal North are still unoccupied.

ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- Supreme Court Justice James A. Betts, at a Special Term held at Kingston to-day granted an order permitting William R. Hearst of New York City to begin an action dissolving the corporate existence of the Ramapo Water Company. Ex-Senator David B. Hill, with the consent of Attorney General Davies, and acting for Mr. Hearst, presented the facts to Justice Betts.
The Columbia University track team held its annual cross-country run of five miles for the university championship cup at Morris Park yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- In a furious game of twenty-five and twenty-minute halves Columbia defeated Wrest Point by a score of 16 to 0 on the Parade Ground to-day. West Point played a good game, but was unable to prevent Weeks, Morley, and Larendon from forcing her line and circling her ends for telling gains.
HAVANA, Nov. 11. -- Second Lieut. Edward Carpenter of the Second Artillery has been appointed aide on the staff of Brig. Gen. Ludlow.

"Confusion worse confounded" seems to attend the efforts of the city officials to straighten out the tangle into which the charter has gotten the question of the public school teachers' salaries. Richmond Borough is now loudly protesting because it has been placed, through no fault of its own, it says, in the embarrassing position of withholding its teachers' salaries for part of October and for all of November and December.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 11. -- Chairman Young (Democrat) wires that he has discovered gross frauds affecting the whole vote in several mountain counties and precincts in other counties, and on these it is supposed a contest will be made before the State Board, if the final returns from counties should show Goebel not elected.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- The locking out of 300 sheet metal workers by their employers to-day is thought to be the beginning of very serious labor troubles. Builders, contractors, and manufacturers on one side, and workingmen on the other have been drawing away from each other all year, and during the last few months the relations have been stretched to the parting point.

WHEN the Constitution was under discussion prior to its ratification by the States, one of the arguments brought against the Government it would establish was that, owing to the Presidential power of appointment, a "change of the Chief Magistrate" would occasion "a violent or general revolution in the officers of the Government."

With the approach of Winter the hardy dwellers in the Borough of the Bronx, having unpacked and shaken the moth balls out of great coats, fur caps, buffalo skin gloves, neckerchiefs, ear pads, shawls, and other paraphernalia necessary to maintain life during the cold season while getting about their business under the present transit facilities in that district, are beginning to utter their annual complaint against the treatment accorded them by the Union Railway Company.

The Democratic Party from its birth until the advent of Bryan was the party of sound money. Under his leadership it has been put in the attitude of declaring that a fifty-cent dollar would be a good enough tender for the payment of 100 cents worth of indebtedness or for the purchase of 100 cents worth of labor, and it has suffered defeat in consequence.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 11. -- Three masked robbers blew open the safe at the D.A.V. and P. Railway ticket office last night, but secured only about $20. The bandits then went to a house on East Spring Street and on entering presented revolvers and proceeded to relieve the inmates of what valuables they had, reported as amounting to $1,000 worth of jewels and $500 in cash.

BAYSIDE, L.I., Nov. 11. -- Walter J. Travis won the championship of the Oakland Golf Club on the links here this afternoon. He played in the finals against Dr. W.S. Brown and won by 3 up and 2 to play. Travis has been champion of the Oakland Club since its organization, but he never before had so close a contest.

SYDNEY, Oct. 11. -- Even the gloomy aspect of affairs in the Transvaal has not had the effect of diverting colonial attention from the work of federation. Queensland has given an affirmative vote, with a substantial majority, but Western Australia is still hesitating, Sir John Forrest, the Colonial Premier, being unwilling to press forward, although the great body of Westralians are ready to vote in favor of union.

If there were 6,000 people in the grand stands at Manhattan Field yesterday to see the football game between Princeton and the Carlisle Indians, as was claimed by the management, there was certainly double that number who saw Princeton trounce the Indians, 12 to 0, from the free stands on the viaduct and Speedway, which bound the grounds on the south and west sides.

The investigation into the charges against Commander Delehanty, United States Navy, as Governor of Sailors' Snug Harbor, was continued yesterday in the Administration Building at the Harbor, S.I., before the special committee of the Board of Trustees, composed of Recorder Goff, the Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield, and Capt. Austin Jayne, Lewis L. Delafield, counsel to the board, examined the witnesses.

VIENNA, Oct. 24. -- Sarah Bernhardt was acting Hamlet in Vienna last week, and failed thoroughly, as in London and Brussels. According to the programme, she was to play Hamlet four times, but after the reception she met with at the first performance she had to give up appearing in the part again here. Nevertheless she made a lot of money; the loser was only the public.

PARIS, Oct. 27. -- French hostility to England finds ample opportunity for expressing itself in connection with the Boer war. Although most of the war news necessarily comes through British sources, the French papers exercise their ingenuity in twisting the information received so as to exhibit it in the most unfavorable light to the British.

Here's an ideal menage, according to the nice and pretty theories that so many people like to talk about and which they so seldom put into practice. It is an establishment to delight the heart of the most conservative and old-fashioned housekeeper of olden time. The family which has this ideal establishment is one of the numerous ones, good, bad, and indifferent, residing in the Greater New York.

CAPE TOWN, Oct. 10. -- The extraordinary seizure by the Transvaal Government of gold valued at about 500,000 belonging to the mining companies has more the appearance of an incident in the romance of an Anthony Hope than the act of the Government of a civilized State at the end of the nineteenth century, and is about the last thing with which the simple and God-fearing Boers would be credited by the outside world.

WINCHESTER, Ky., Nov. 11. -- After several days' suppression, the facts about the wholesale intimidation practice in Judge Redwine's county, Breathitt, came to light to-day. A man who is a high official came here and told the story. He said it would be as much as his life is worth if it became known that he gave out the information.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Three important dispatches from Gen. Otis were received at the War Department to-day, showing the hardships and difficulties encountered by our troops in their advance, and giving a captured insurgent dispatch showing the line of argument put forward to sustain the insurrection.

In another column Mr. THEODORE GILMAN discusses the defects of our rigid currency, which, like the poor, we have always with us. His letter has the merit of clearness, and his opinions are based on study and on practical experience and observation. We commend it to the attention of our readers.

My own feeling is that the South will gradually reach the point where it will see the wisdom and the justice of enacting an educational or property qualification, or both, for voting, that shall be made to apply honestly to both races. The industrial development of the negro in connection with education and Christian character will help to hasten this end.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 11. -- It is now an open secret that the links of the golf club are decidedly wet, too wet, in fact. The selection of the golf club grounds was faulty and there can be no improvement unless something like $25,000 is expended for the draining of the grounds. This amount the golf club does not feel like expending on some one else's property.

The committee to reorganize the San Francisco symphony concerts consists of Prof. William Carey Jones of the University of California, Chairman; H.B. Pasmore, Robert Tolmie, J.N. Odell, W.A. Sabin, and Mmes. J.N. Odell, A.F. Morrison, J.N. Goewey, James Tucker, C.O. Richardson, and J.J. Price, Mrs. Phebe Hearst, in accordance with her usual desire to aid beneficial movements, has kindly given the sum of $2,000 for the purpose of commencing the concerts.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11. -- While at work in the casting room of the Newark Steel Works to-night eight men and a boy were seriously burned. Three of them may die. The accident was caused by the bursting of a mold into which a mass of hot steel was being poured.
D. Van Wart has been appointed general agent of the New Amsterdam Casualty Company of New York at Milwaukee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- George Rice of Marietta, Ohio, who described himself as "a moderate producer of oil," was before the Industrial Commission to-day. In his formal statement before the commission, Mr. Rice accused the railroad companies generally with conspiring in connection with the Standard Oil Company to drive independent refineries out of the field of activity.

The Campaign Committee of the Citizens' Union of the Nineteenth Assembly District gave a dinner last night at the Sherman Square Hotel in honor of the union's candidates for Assemblyman and Alderman, Perez M. Stewart and Francis W. Aymar. The gathering was practically a celebration of Mr. Stewart's election by the men who had helped to bring it about, and the only regret expressed was that Mr. Aymar's candidacy had not been successful.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- A dispatch from Mumbles, Wales, says that the Norwegian bark Duisburg, Capt. Olsen, from Parrsborough, N.S., Sept. 5, for that part, has gone ashore at Oxwich Point, in the Bristol Channel, and is expected to become a total wreck. Her masts are gone. The crew were all saved.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- It is understood that the President will avail himself of the opportunity offered by the existence of the vacancies in the regular army caused by the death of Gen. Henry and the retirement of Gen. Shafter to promote and retire with the rank of Brigadier General in the regular army several of the few remaining Colonels of the regular establishment who rendered conspicuous service in the civil war.
NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 11. -- Rutgers College was defeated by New York University this afternoon in a stubbornly contested football game by a score of 6 to 5.

A committee of the New York State Prison Association, which is making an examination of the penal institutions under State control, has, after holding a number of sessions at Sing Sing, decided that that institution is not fit for habitation. It will therefore recommend in its report that the prison be reconstructed or another prison be built at another point.

Ex-Judge John M. Hall of New Haven, Conn., Vice President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, was yesterday elected to the Presidency to succeed Charles Peter Clark, who tendered his resignation some time ago on the advice of his physician. This choice sets at rest many unfounded rumors, emanating mainly from the Nutmeg State.

When the first bull was let into the ring, a powerful, strong-looking beast, he made straight for the horses and caught and lifted on his horns a gray horse, whose shriek of agony and terror remained for many a long day in my ears. I heard the thud of its body against the boards, for the mangling of the horse took place immediately under the place where I was sitting.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- Tired of a continual state of stringency in local financial matters, this city has begun to take steps by which posterity will be made to assume a part of the responsibilities for the advantages which will accrue to it by reason of public improvements of a large nature which are now needed and which are necessary for the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Tutuila, the Samoan island which falls to the United States in the recent arrangement completed between Germany and England, subject to ratification by the United States Government, becomes an extremely valuable addition to the possessions of the United States in the Pacific.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 12. -- Assemblyman Robert Mazet, who was married Saturday at Bolton, N.Y., to the daughter of Commodore John W. Moore, United States Navy, retired, arrived in the city this morning, and was interviewed as to his plans for continuing the investigation of metropolitan affairs.
I have seen so many letters in THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the inefficient postal service in this city that I take the liberty, as a postal clerk, to add a few words.

An unsually large congregation gathered in the Brick Presbyterian Church, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday morning to hear what many believed would be the farewell sermon of the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke. So many persons came to the church that the seating capacity of the building was overtaxed long before the sermon was begun, and probably as many were turned away as got inside.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- A dispatch from Omaha, Neb., says:

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12. -- The Princeton football team returned home to-day, happy after the victory over the Carlisle Indians at Manhattan Field Saturday. The coaches are not satisfied with some of the features of yesterday's work, but say, however, that the players put up a game to be proud of. Princeton's big centre said today that the defensive play of the Tigers was something wonderful, but that the offensive tactics were poor.

Is there nobody among Mr. BRYAN'S advisers with candor enough to point out to him frankly his present situation and prospects, and with courage enough to request that he declare explicitly upon what grounds he justifies his continuing claim to the party leadership and the Presidential candidacy?

Harry Apfel of the St. George Athletic Club may lose his life as the result of a prizefight in which he was a principal on Saturday night at the Pelican Athletic Club, Third Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

An audience which included many professional people and a number of persons who have won distinction in one line or another assembled last evening in the studio of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Stedman, 53 East Fifty-sixth Street, to hear a reading of Charles Henry Meltzer's translation of the German poet, Hauptmann's "The Sunken Bell."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12. -- The few returns received to-day have made no material change in the lead of Taylor over Goebel for Governor. At his headquarters Gen. Taylor said to-night that the annals of history could be searched and in no instance would they reveal a parallel to the infamy, force, and fraud that go to make up the record of Goebel's campaign in the State of Kentucky. He further said:...

Stephen Beyer, a tailor thirty-six years old, of 145 McKibbin Street, Brooklyn, tried four ways to end his life yesterday afternoon, and finding that death did not come quick enough, finally gave up the task and began to shout for help. When the would-be-suicide's relatives with whom he boarded reached his bedroom they found Beyer in a semi-conscious condition on the bed.

The ferryhouse of the Staten Island Ferry, at St. George, and the overhead structure on which the cars of the Staten Island Electric Company run into the ferryhouse were badly damaged by fire last evening. The trolley employes claim the fire started in a small building owned by the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company, at the rear of the ferryhouse, and beneath the railroad structure.
MANILA, Nov. 13. -- Major Bell's regiment and a small force of cavalry entered Tarlac last night without opposition.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 12. -- Mrs. Herman Vogel of Port Chester has been appointed by the courts in Bound Brook, N.J., and in Greenwich administratrix of the estate of her husband, who killed himself at New Brunswick last month. Before committing suicide, Mr. Vogel, who was proprietor of the Old Homestead Hotel at Bound Brook, shot his supposed wife, a woman by the name of Caldwell.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- This morning's news from the seat of war in South Africa continues fairly satisfactory. The official cables are not very detailed with regard to the Belmont incident, which, except for the loss of Col. Keith-Falconer, was not a very serious affair.

I noticed in this morning's TIMES letters from Hornellsville and Newburg, in which the writers state that not being able to vote intelligently on proposed constitutional amendments at the late election, they did not vote at all. The reason they could not vote intelligently was stated to be because the Inspectors or watchers were not able to give the purpose and effect of the respective amendments.

The contracts under which sections of the Borough of Queens are being lighted expire within a year, and the Deputy Commissioner of the borough has started work on a reorganization of the whole system. The plan he is adopting looks toward a much more general distribution of the street lights at less expense to the taxpayers.

That is a very interesting attempt which seems to be making to convert Mr. LEMUEL E. QUIGG into a JONAH and to visit upon him the responsibility for the defeat of Assemblyman MAZET in particular. The attempt seems to have originated with that stanch old upholder of Republican principles, and practices, The New York Sun, and was therefore assumed, not unnaturally, to have an inspired and official character.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 12. -- A remarkable case that is interesting the physicians here is that of Hannah Reardon, a domestic employed by Mrs. J.M. Nather, on Madison Street, who is a human needle cushion. Several weeks ago she complained of a sore finger and went to Dr. Swithin Chandler. An examination showed a needle in the finger, which the surgeon extracted, then another and another until four were discovered.

The School Board of Queens Borough is so seriously embarrassed because it has no funds to pay its teachers for November or December that it may follow the proposed plan of the Richmond Borough School Board to close all of its schools, and let the State Superintendent of Public Instruction reopen them as he would be required to do by law at this city's expense.

Cannot those extremists among the foes of what they call "criminal aggression" in the Philippines take hope and indulge in a better opinion of the Administration and its purposes by considering such evidences of good policy as are to be found in the reports about our work for Cuba and the Cubans?

PUERTO CABELLO, Venezuela Nov. 12. -- Gen. Paredes, a former commander in the army of ex-President Andrade, who had refused the demand made upon him by Gen. Cipriano Castro and the de facto authorities to surrender the town, even when this was re-enforced by the request of the British, American, French, German, and Dutch commanders, surrendered this morning at 10 o'clock, after a terrible battle.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12. -- The fifth annual meeting of the National Municipal League will be held here Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of this week. The most important business of the coming meeting is the discussion of the "Municipal Programme," which aims to present a form of government under which municipalities will be least subject to corruption and offer most advantages for substantial growth.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 12. -- To-morrow afternoon the Harvard eleven will begin its last period of training for the Yale game which is to be played in Cambridge next Saturday afternoon. The crimson has a clean record of victories so far, and only one team, the Carlisle Indians, has been able to score against the Cambridge players.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 12. -- Herr Leyds, brother of Dr. Leyds, and himself an agent of the Transvaal Government, died of apoplexy yesterday while on a visit to his brother.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- The Executive Committee named at the recent Trust Conference in this city to make arrangements for another convention met at the Sherman House Saturday, and decided that the conference should be held in January in Chicago.

There is a possibility that Miss Julia Arthur may have to face a suit for damages as a result of her action on Wednesday night, at the Broadway Theatre, when she caused the curtain to be rung down on her play "More Than Queen," until two couples who were occupying a box and who had annoyed her by their conversation and actions, had left the theatre.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 12. -- Miss Carrie Hubbell of Stratford ras been selected by Committeeman William J. Mead as teacher in the North Street School to succeed Miss Frances Wood of Meriden, and now everything is going along nicely in the school.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Hurry orders have been received by the builders of the Japanese battleship now in process of construction at Clyde Bank to complete the vessel as speedily as possible. The new ship, which will be one of the largest afloat, is to be finished by Jan. 1, 1900. It is believed that these instructions are the result of the increasing tension between Japan and Russia.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Nov. 12. -- A murder at sea on the schooner J.B. Van Dusen was made known to-day by the receipt of a message from the vessel's mate to the owners' agent in this city. It stated that Capt. Baisley had been stabbed by a sailor named Maxwell, had afterward fallen overboard, and had died in the ship's boat, which had put off to rescue him.

-- Political oratory ought to be easy work out in Nebraska. Perhaps the attainment of a certain degree of success in that line is not particularly difficult anywhere, but, judging from the chances which Mr. BRYAN deems it safe to take while addressing the voters of his own State, glib volubility and a good memory for resonant phrases are there sufficient foundation for a claim to eloquent statesmanship.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12. -- Col. C.W.F. Dick, Chairman of the Republican State Committee and Secretary of the National Committee, will go to Washington the latter part of next week or the week following to shape up the business of the National Committee, in readiness for the meeting which Chairman Hanna will call for the middle of December. At that meeting the time and place of holding the next National Convention will be determined.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 12. -- Capt. McCarthy of the British steamer Trunkby, which arrived here to-day from Santa Cruz, Teneriffe, brings a story of a tragedy that occurred a few days before his arrival there from England.

While some parts of the textile markets are quiet now, there is the same underlying strength which has characterized them for the past six months. In fact, they are probably in a firmer position than ever, as far as woolens, worsteds, dress goods, cotton goods, and knit goods are concerned. They are all strongly backed by the conditions in the markets for raw material, which shows not only great firmness, but strong advances.
CAPE TOWN, Nov. 11. -- The following dispatch, undated, has been received from Kimberley, by dispatch rider, via Hopetown:

There is one disturbing factor in the money market of this country which is variable in its effect, but continual and irresistible in its operation. Complaints against it are of long standing, but they have taken the form of suppressed grumbling because they are generally regarded as useless, not to say hopeless.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Whether Chinese exclusion should be applied to the Philippines is among the subjects engaging the attention of the Philippine Commission. Considerable evidence bearing on the matter has been collected, and besides presenting this testimony with the full report, it is expected that a recommendation will be made which may have considerable influence in shaping the course of this Government and the action of Congress.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- Now for Yale. That was the spirit of the 'Varsity practice to-day, and as a result there was plenty of dash and determination in the work. The principal object of the coaches from now on will be to get team play, and correct such faults as fumbling, off-side play, and holding.

The Executive Committee of the Committee of Citizens of Brooklyn to take action against the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Railroad Company for its adoption of double fares and its new system of transfers has made much progress since the meeting last Saturday night.

TIFFIN, Ohio, Nov. 13. -- A magazine used by the Bradford nitroglycerine factory to store the explosive, situated two and a half miles east of Gibsonburg, exploded this afternoon. The shock was heard at towns within a radius of forty miles, and the effects of the explosion in the immediate neighborhood were terrific.

MANILA, Nov. 13. -- When Col. Bell left Capas, ten miles from Tarlac, at 1 o'clock yesterday, he intended merely to reconnoitre. He had with him the Thirty-sixth Infantry, Slavens's scouts, Troop E of the Fourth Cavalry, a battalion of the Twenty-second Regiment, and Gatling guns.
