-- Gen. FUNSTON does not seem to have been disquieted either by the denials or by the denunciations which his accusations against the friars in the Philippines have elicited, and he is now quoted by a correspondent of Harper's Weekly as saying that "if our Government would confiscate the property of the Dominicans and expel them from the islands the insurrection would fall to pieces."

That was a pathetic letter from a postal clerk which we printed yesterday. Moreover, the writer was entirely in the right. The postal clerks are overworked and still the service is unsatisfactory. The local delivery is especially unsatisfactory in comparison not only with the great cities of Europe, but even with what has been done here in the past.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- To Capt. John L. Steelman of the schooner Samuel L. Beachman belongs the credit of saving from a raft in mid-ocean Mate Loud and Seaman John Robinson, the sole survivors of the Philadelphia schooner William M. Bud. The vessel was wrecked off the South Carolina coast on the night of Oct, 30.

Militarism is the great National peril that now fills the minds of Mr. BRYAN and his allies with horror and alarm. Expansion, as the Bryanites have discovered, has no terrors for Americans. They like it. The anti-imperialism outery they refused to take seriously. To the antitrust crusade they paid no attention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- It is ascertained at the Treasury that it is not considered at all probable that Secretary Gage will take any steps in the direction of the purchase of outstanding bonds, with the view of releasing money now held in the Treasury, as he prefers to await the assembling of Congress and the pleasure of that body in dealing with the finances.
PETERSON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Vice President Hobart spent a good night last night, resting comfortably, and was bright and strong this morning. He sat up most of to-day and took three good meals.

At the regular quarterly meeting of the Executive Committee of the Marine Society, held yesterday afternoon, the attitude of Capt. George L. Norton in the investigation by the Board of Trustees of the Sailors' Snug Harbor, of charges against Commander Daniel Delehanty, United States Navy, as Governor of that institution, was fully sustained in resolutions.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 13. -- The tangle growing out of last week's election grows worse with each day. This was the third day of the official count, but the work of the County Boards of Canvassers disclosed little information to clear the situation. Chairman Long of the Republican Campaign Committee to-day repeated his claim of a plurality of 3,111 for Taylor, based on official returns from 110 counties and unofficial returns from the remaining 9.

There are two facts that are only lightly touched on by those who are crying out for the Treasury to come to the "relief of the money market." One is the actual condition of the Treasury; the other is the real source and nature of the demand for "relief."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13. -- Yale's coaches took advantage of the cold, bracing air to-day and gave the squad a hard and long afternoon's work. The secret practice was half an hour longer than usual. A large crowd shivered on the outside, waiting to get in the inclosed field and see the work.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13. -- Thomas G. Hayes, who was recently elected Mayor of Baltimore, caused consternation among the Democratic office seekers and politicians to-day by making this announcement:

Mr. CROKER'S entry into the domain of "up-the-State" politics can hardly afford him any special satisfaction. His influence over and his prestige with the Democracy of Greater New York are apparently as great as ever, but Tuesday's elections are ample evidence of the resentment that has been aroused by his assumption of State dictatorship.

Ex-Assemblyman Solomon D. Rosenthal said late last night that he would appear before the County Canvassers to-day and demand a certificate of his election as Recorder to succeed John W. Goff. Mr. Rosenthal claims that he received six votes, all that were cast for the office, and that, therefore, his election was unanimous.
MANILA, Nov. 13. -- Gen. Young is supposed to have reached San Nicolas, about thirty miles east of Dagupan, but his wagons are far behind.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- A special dispatch from Shanghai says the differences between Russia and Japan have been accentuated by Japan's refusal to grant Russia a foothold on the sea front of Massampo Harbor, Korea.
The Knickerbocker Council team gave a poor exhibition in the Royal Arcanum League at the Tennis Club alleys last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 13. -- New Yorkers in force took possession of the National Export Exposition to-day. A special train carrying a large number of leading citizens of the metropolis arrived at 11:30 o'clock. The party was composed of prominent business men, politicians, and others who came by special invitation of the Merchants' Association of New York.

The appeal sent out to the teachers in the public schools of the Boroughs of Queens and Richmond by Superintendent MAXWELL will probably have the desired effect. It is practically a pledge, so far as the Superintendent can give a pledge, that the City of New York will ultimately pay the teachers for their services.

Two golf champions took part yesterday in the open tournament for women suddenly announced by the Ardsley Club, near Dobbs Ferry, last week. They were Miss Ruth Underhill, the present holder of that title, and Mrs. Charles S. Brown of the Shinnecock Golf Club.

Major Putnam Bradlee Strong, son of ex-Mayor Strong, spoke to the Plaza Republican Club last night on expansion, as viewed in the light of his experience as a soldier in the Philippines. He was introduced by President James Yereance.

PARIS, Nov. 3. -- The descriptions freely telegraphed to the English press of the joy shown by the French over the British defeats in Natal are greatly exaggerated and end to produce a false impression. It cannot be denied that the French as a whole thoroughly dislike the English, and believe the latter to be their mortal enemies.

I have read with much interest and admiration the timely, just, and sensible editorials in THE NEW YORK TIMES, showing that the results of the recent State elections discredit William J. Bryan as a leader, and advising him to abandon his claims upon the next Democratic Presidential nomination.

B.C. F.T. Barry have sold to Collins Collins for about $100,000 the four-story dwelling at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street, 25 by 90. The building will be remodeled for offices and apartments.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13. -- Nearly forty students of Kentucky University have typhoid fever, and it has become necessary for the Faculty to take decided steps toward checking it. The students have been sent to the Good Samaritan Hospital, but since there is no more room at that institution, it has become necessary to care for them at their boarding houses.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- Following the scheme introduced after the Brown game the practice to-day consisted mostly of play between the scrubs and a team composed of 'Varsity substitutes, while the regulars who played through the game with the Indians were given a rest. This is not necessitated by the physical condition of the team, for it has never this Fall come out of a game in such good shape.

FLAGSTAFF, Arizona, Nov. 13. -- One white man and five Navajo Indians killed and two whites and one Navajo wounded was the result of an attempt of a Deputy Sheriff to arrest a Navajo yesterday, ten miles south of Walnut Station. news of which has just reached here.
ST. PAUL, Nov. 13. -- President Hill denies the story that he is interested in a proposition to establish a steamship and rail line from London to Hongkong.
MANILA, Nov. 14. -- The United States cruiser Charleston, which had been patrolling the northern coast of Luzon, was wrecked on a reef off the northwest coast on Tuesday, Nov. 7.
Discussing Manhattan affairs, a Director of the company said yesterday:

The case of the People against Roland B. Molineux, indicted for the murder of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams by means of poison on Dec. 25, 1898, will be called for trial this morning before Recorder Golf in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- According to a dispatch from De Aar, the Boers at Kimberley have got the exact range of the mines and are constantly throwing shells at the dynamite huts. Several of the latter have been blown up, and the damage done to the mines already amounts to many thousands of pounds.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners met for the first time in their new offices on the fourth floor of 320 Broadway yesterday afternoon and took the final steps necessary to authorize the advertising for bids from contractors to build the underground road. The meeting was brief and harmonious, and the Board will have no further important work to do before opening the sealed bids which may have been sent in on Jan. 15, 1900.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Forty-three years of continuous service with the Bank of Montreal were terminated to-day by William Munro, manager of the Chicago branch of that institution. Mr. Munro took advantage of the privilege accorded by the Bank of Montreal to its employes of retiring on a pension after a certain number of years of service.

NEW ROCHELLE, Nov. 13. -- Mayor Dillon of this city, with a gang of 200 workmen, this afternoon began tearing up the rails of the Union Railway's horse car line on Centre Avenue. This action was taken after the company had failed for five days to take action in response to a notice relative to paving the street between its tracks and on either side.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Manager Porter of the Cornell football team this afternoon announced that, at the request of Oberlin College, the game with Cornell had been canceled. The reason assigned by Oberlin was that her team has practically gone to pieces. Cornell readily agreed to Oberlin's offer of cancellation, for her own team is far from being in fine shape.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 13. -- Mrs. Leslie Carter's illness has developed into a case of quinsy. It started with an aggravated attack of tonsilitis. Painful ulcers have formed in her throat and her physician wanted to perform an operation to relieve her, but she preferred to let the ailment take its course. Dr. Wissinger gives assurance that there is nothing alarming in her condition.

What is regarded by the officials of the Manhattan Railway Company as another move in the campaign of the Tammany administration against that corporation was made yesterday, when Fire Chief Croker "sounded an alarm" against the introduction of the third-rail electric system on the elevated railroad lines in this borough.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- One of the most curious results of the annexation of Puerto Rico will be an alteration in the shape of the island as it is known to the world.
Over 1,000,000 bushels of grain carried into Newport News, Va., by the Chesapeake and Ohio last week, of which 900,000 bushels were exported.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The following dispatch from Gen. Otis was received at the War Department to-day:
The National Assurance Company of Ireland has applied for admission to West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Guam, the United States naval station in the Ladrones, gives promise of being a profitable postal station. Capt. Leery, the Governor of the island, has just sent to the Post Office Department a requisition for about $11,000 worth of stamps, which he considers not much more than sufficient to meet the immediate demand for Guam stamps.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- In the special Berlin letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES printed on Aug. 6 there appeared the following:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A claim for bounty for Admiral Dewey and his men, growing out of the battle of Manila Bay, has been filed with the Court of Claims by their attorneys. Herbert Micou and Charles and William B. King. The decision of the court will be more than usually interesting, for it will be an adjudication of the question whether or not Dewey's force was superior to that of Montojo.

Admiral Dewey was in excellent humor yesterday. The people had heeded the requests published in the newspapers not to make him a museum curiosity, and he expressed his gratitude to the members of the press for their kindly offices.

DURBAN, Nov. 9. -- It is understood that message was received here to-day from Gen. White, at Ladysmith, by pigeon, containing birthday congratulations for the Prince of Wales, and was forwarded to London.

LORENZO MARQUEZ, Delagoa Bay, Nov. 9. -- Father Matthew, who has arrived here from Pretoria, says with reference to the surrender of the Irish Fusiliers and the Gloucestershire troops at Nicholson's Nek, that after the mules stampeded, the force got hard pressed by the enemy.

OAMAHA, Nov. 13. -- The Commissioners of Douglas County ordered a correction to-day in the county records of a year ago, expunging there from the words "Stephen C. Boyle, Pauper, buried at county expense."
HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 13. -- A heavy snow and rain storm, accompanied by gales of wind and causing loss of life and damage to shipping, prevails in the maritime provinces and Newfoundland

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13. -- A private letter received by Edward A.T. Gallagher of this city says that American sentiment in Guatemala against United States Minister W. Godfrey Hunter, is very bitter, because of reprisals that are said to have followed the sending to Washington of a petition against his methods.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13. -- Sportsmen from various parts of the country are here to attend the annual meeting of the National Fox Hunters Association at Estill Springs, beginning Wednesday. Representative dogs from the principal kennels of the United States will be here. Dr. Sturgill, the President, arrives to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The task of supplying the navy with Krag-Jorgensen rifles, in place of the Lee rifles that have been in use in the navy for some time, has begun, the Ordnance Bureau of the War Department having issued 1,000 Krag-Jorgensen rifles, and 5,000 rounds of ammunition to be served to the battleships Kentucky and Kearsarge at the New York Navy Yard.

Speculators who yesterday counted upon security market demoralization counted unwarrantably. Instead of weakness there was strength. Instead of a money market panic there was actual ease in funds. In every way and to a far extending degree Wall Street had an inspiriting day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- In giving his testimony before the Industrial Commission to-day Mr. John W. Gates, Managing Director of the American Steel and Wire Company, gave an interesting account of his effort to effect a consolidation of all the wire producing countries, including all the European nations.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 14. -- At the annual meeting of stockholders of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad Company, the following Directors were elected:

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 14. -- Major Russell B. Harrison, Inspector General of the department under Gen. Leonard Wood in the Province of Santiago de Cuba, has arrived in Omaha on sick leave, and will remain here with his wife till he has thoroughly recovered from a severe attack of yellow fever contracted in Cuba.

We do not suppose that the advice Mr. BRYAN is receiving as to his duty to relieve his party of the burden of his discredited ambition produces much effect on his mind. His conviction that he is the natural and by far the strongest candidate for the Presidency next year cannot be dissipated by argument or evidence, because it was not constructed on evidence and was not sustained by reason.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- A cable dispatch received from Gen. Otis at the War Department to-day announces that Major John A. Logan, Thirty-third Volunteer Infantry, had been killed while leading his battalion in the fight near San Jacinto.

Yesterday afternoon's attendance at the Horse Show more nearly approached that of former years than did that of Monday, in spite of the forbidding appearance of the weather with its promise of the snow that came when the class for park drags was being passed upon. Box holders were very largely in evidence, except in the corner where the "Hempstead set" have their quarters.

The citizens of Corona, who since the adoption of the new schedule of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company have made numerous complaints of bad and unfair service, vented their feelings last evening in a mass meeting held in Firemen's Hall. Despite the storm about 200 were present.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 14. -- There is no longer any doubt of Taylor's election in Kentucky if the votes are properly counted, for the figures of all the Louisville papers, including The Courier Journal, now show a plurality for Taylor. But that paper does not concede his election. Official and uncontested votes from 114 counties show a plurality of 2,919 for Goebel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- Physicians in charge of Mrs. Leslie Carter, who has been confined to her hotel in this city since last Friday with an ulcerated sore throat that threatens to develop into tonsilitis. have decided upon an operation as the only method of permanent relief. An operation would have been performed several days ago had not Mrs. Carter strongly objected.

HAVANA, Nov. 14. -- The bark New Venice, from Key West, which was captured off Puerto Padre under conditions that excited suspicion, was found to have several hundred pounds of dynamite on board. It is supposed that she intended to poach fish in Cuban waters.

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 14. -- The Harvard practice this afternoon was another step in the gradual recovery of the team from its slump of the past week, but it was only a slight step. The fumbling was bad as usual, and the kicking was weak. The ends played a particularly poor game. Ellis is causing trouble in the interference mainly because he is headstrong and does not take kindly to coaching.

Roland Burnham Molineux was placed on trial for his life yesterday in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions before Recorder Goff charged with having caused the death of Katherine J. Adams by poison on Dec. 28 past. There have been many notable murder trials in New York County in late years, but even the most celebrated of these have failed to arouse the general interest manifested in the trial of young Molineux.

HELENA, Mont., Nov. 14. -- When the Supreme Court resumed consideration of the Wellcome disbarment case this morning, the Chief Justice announced the court's decision as to the admissibility of certain testimony introduced by the plaintiff to which the defense objected on the ground that, while it showed alleged corruption on the part of Senator Clark's agents, the transactions were not conducted by the defendant, Wellcome, but by other Clark leaders.

The officers of the Mutual Life Insurance Company are confronted by a curious problem, of some responsibility, in dealing with the case of WARWICK JAMES PRICE, who has admitted his theft from the company of several thousand dollars' worth of revenue stamps.
Decrease of nearly 15,000 tons in eastbound shipments of dead freight from Chicago last week as compared with the previous week.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 14. -- The Indians took their first practice this afternoon after the Princeton game. The players feel very blue over their defeat, particularly over their inability to score, giving as a prime reason for incapacity the paucity of reliable substitutes. For the first time in the history of the eleven, the players, almost without an exception, returned home badly bruised up.

The first of the three matinee concerts which are on the schedule of the Kneisel Quartet of Boston was given yesterday afternoon in Mendelssohn Hall. The audience was not as large as those which are the rule at the evening entertainments of this organization, but that is not a matter for wonder. Chamber music is the least personal of all forms of music.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 14. -- Gov. Johnston this afternoon makes formal announcement of his candidacy for succession to the seat of United States Senator John T. Morgan, Gov. Johnston has been known to be an aspirant for Morgan's place for some time, but has heretofore declined to state his plans explicitly.

At a meeting of the Trustees of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association held yesterday in the United Charities Building the General Agent reported at considerable length upon the preparatory work for the coming collection in the churches, synagogues, trades, and exchanges. The work is well advanced, and the hope is entertained that the collection, which was over $70,000 last year, will, under the impulse of prosperity, reach a total of $100,000 this year.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14. -- The committee representing the Brick Presbyterian Church, New York City, and the Rev. Dr. George Alexander, representing the Presbytery of New York, came to Baltimore to-day and held a conference to-night in Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church with the Session of that church in reference to the call recntly extended to the Rev. Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock by the Brick Church.

HAVANA, Nov. 14. -- At a mass meeting of the Republican Party at Cienfuegos yesterday Dr. Vieta said the war had ceased because God had touched the hearts of a great people and inclined them to aid the Cubans in their distress. He then added:

%VASHINGTON. Nov. 14. -- Surgeon General Sternberg's annual report gives a comprehensive view of the health of the troops, in the field and at home, the casualties and losses in battle and in hospital, 'the care extended to the sick and wounded, and other interesting information relating to the physical welfare of the army.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- In his annual report, made public at the War Department to-day, Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles, commanding the army, says:

Under the caption of "The Tipping Habit" a correspondent in to-day's issue writes: "However strongly intrenched, I believe, at least in this part of the world, there is enough manhood left to boldly face and uproot this vilest of imported vices."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 14. -- Four zinc-lined trunks, such as are used by traveling men to carry samples, each containing a corpse, were taken from the baggage room at Union Station to-day, and Frank Thompson, who says he is city undertaker of Memphis, Tenn., is under arrest. Charges against Thompson are being formulated.

The announcement that Japan has refused the request of Russia for "a foothold" on the sea front of Massampo Harbor, in Korea, may not have the significance which is attached to it in the dispatches. But it is in itself probable enough, and it is as easy to underrate as to overrate its importance.
In your issue of Sunday last a certain party wrote a vehement protest against the tipping habit existing in public resorts, naming it the "vilest of imported vices."

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- The oil excitement which started a few weeks ago in the vicinity of Jefferson, Ashtabula County, and a short time previous to that date at Chardon, Lake County, is spreading rapidly throughout a great part of Northeastern Ohio. To-day it is reported from Geneva, a town of 3,000 inhabitants in the western end of this county, that several wells are to be opened there at once.

PARIS, Nov. 14. -- There was a large and animated attendance at the opening of the Chamber of Deputies to-day. The President, M. Deschanel, read numerous requests from members for permission to interpellate the Government. The Premier, M. Waldeck-Rousseau, asked that all interpellations respecting the Government's general policy be discussed together.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Admiral Watson cables to the Navy Department the following official report of the wreck of the cruiser Charleston:

The modified plan for the reorganization of the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad Company, as arranged at the request of a number of stockholders by a committee known as the New York committee, the Chairman of which is Ernst Thalmann, has been made public. The modified plan takes the place of the plan declared operative last August.

ESTILL SPRINGS, Ky., Nov. 14. -- Everything is in readiness for the meeting of the National Fox Hunters' Association, which begins here to-morrow. Rain to-night threatens to delay the start, but the dampness will be all the better for the sport if it is not raining. It is said there are plenty of foxes.
The United States Senate Committee on Manufactures, which is investigating the adulteration of beer, ale, and porter, held another session yesterday at the Hotel Imperial.
The Riverdales' score of 925 in the third game against the Hamiltons was the feature of last night's series in the Columbia League. Scores:

Dr. Buckley in his debate yesterday voiced a spirit which has been working for a number of years among certain of those who are called leaders in the Methodist ministry, and who have given color and form to Methodist legislation. If Dr. Buckley and his assistants who distrust the laymen of the church will look about just here they may find some explanation for the decaying interest of laymen in church matters.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The work outlined for the 'Varsity during the coming two weeks will be hard, thorough, and comprehensive.

MANILA, Nov. 14. -- Further details regarding the grounding of the United States cruiser Charleston show that she struck and uncharted coral reef ten miles east of Kaniguan Island. Her stern was almost submerged and the bow almost out of water. A heavy sea was on, and the cruiser began rolling violently. The watertight doors were Quickly closed, but were stove in under the engine compartment, the largest of the ship.

SANTO DOMINGO CITY, Nov. 4. -- The new Government of President Jimenes and Vice President Vasquez will be inaugurated Wednesday, Nov. 15. It had previously been announced that the inauguration would take place Dec. 1, but it is officially stated here that the date has been changed.

SAN FR.c_iqcIsco, Nov. 14. -- Additional particulars of the terrible trip of the transport Siam, from this port to Manila, have been received here. The Siam left here on. Aug. 19 with 400 horses for the army in the Philippines. All went well between here and Honolulu, where a stop of ten days gave the horse an opportunity to recover from the voyage.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14. -- There are said to be no less than twelve plays planned by the Yale coaches for the game with Harvard. The work to-day was no heavier than yesterday, but was much faster. Stillman and Brown, who are getting down pretty close to the limit of fineness of training, are being given light work, neither participating in to-day's public practice.

MANILA, Nov. 14. -- The Thirty-third Infantry, in one of the sharpest two hours' engagements of the war, with an equal force of insurgents, five miles from San Fabian. Saturday, lost one officer (Major John A. Logan) and six men killed and had one officer and twelve men wounded.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- An arrangement has been made by which the form of the lease of the Boston and Albany Railroad to the New York Central Railroad has been made satisfactory to the Protective Committee, and an addition of $1,500,000 has been made to the cash about to be paid by the New York Central Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Copies of the annual report of Gen. Otis have been received at the War Department, but the report will not be made public until it has received the consideration of the President and Secretary of War.

After eighteen months of waiting, Secretary Long of the Navy has written a surreptitious letter to the President attacking Admiral Schley and his friends and asserting that the latter are the ones responsible for the controversy and that their attacks are uncalled for, as the department has not persecuted the Admiral, but treated him better than he deserved.
Admiral and Mrs. Dewey left New York for Washington yesterday afternoon.

Dr. Louis L. Seaman, late Surgeon Major First Regiment United States Volunteer Engineers, has just returned from the Philippines and was seen at his home yesterday with regard to conditions there. Dr. Seaman went to Manila on his own initiative, in order to further investigate the effect of the army ration on the health of soldiers in the tropics.

The Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company of America, the newly incorporated concern which represents the interests of William C. Whitney, W.L. Elkins, P.A.B. Widener, and their associates, and which was organized to rival the Bell concern, is now negotiating for the absorption of the Knickerbocker Telephone and Telegraph Company and the People's Telephone Corporation, both of this city.

Rumors long rife of a coming legal battle over the strange will of Henry B. Plant, railroad, steamship, and hotel magnate, crystallized yesterday in the definite announcement that Seward, Guthrie Steele had been retained to guard the interests of Mrs. Margaret Plant, the widow of the millionaire, who is said to be dissatisfied with the provisions of the will.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The Princeton 'Varsity put in fifty-five minutes of the hardest practice of the season to-day behind closed doors.

Something like the Horse Show crushes of the past was on hand at Madison Square Garden last night, for nearly all of the boxes and arena seats were occupied. The promenade was crowded, and there was for those who walked back and forth there the best showing of gowns that has been made during the week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Dean C. Worcester, member of the Philippine Commission, spoke at Central Music Hall to-night upon "The Philippine Question." The address, which was delivered under the auspices of the Hamilton Club, a local Republican organization, was received with every manifestation of approval.

ALBANY, Nov. 15. -- The Joint Committee of the Legislature on Taxation has been in session in this city for several days past. The members have carefully looked into the taxation of corporations, and, in speaking of the matter to-day, Senator Stranahan said that the committee had divided up the work into sub-committees, and would submit to the next Legislature very important amendments to the taxation laws.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Judge George M. Thomas, Solicitor of Internal Revenue, has just returned from Kentucky. He said to-day, speaking of the election controversy: "Knox County, which gave Taylor 1,300 majority, is liable to be thrown out because the name of John H. Wilson appeared on some ballots as a candidate for Circuit Judge when there was probably no vacancy in that office.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 15. -- Startling and sensational disclosures came out of the investigation of the Plankinton Bank assigneeship before Court Commissioner Schreiber to-day by the filing of three orders, made by Judge Johnson on April 8 last, authorizing the settlement of claims aggregating $990,483 for the sum of $5,942 in cash and a note for the same amount to run eight months.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15. -- Definite plans are now under consideration for the sale of the city's holdings in the Western Maryland Railroad Company to a syndicate of New York capitalists. Details of the sale and of the city's transfer of its holdings of about 4,000 shares of the railroad company's stocks are being arranged.

The Commercial Cable Company has decided to lay a new cable. To obtain the necessary funds the Directors have voted to increase the capital stock of the corporation from $10,000,000 to $15,000,000. A special meeting of the stockholders has been called for Dec. 4 at the main office, 253 Broadway, to ratify the action of the Directors.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The total reinforcements that have arrived in South Africa since Friday are 19,000 men, chiefly infantry, nearly 13,000 horses and mules, three batteries of field artillery, and a number of quick-firing Maxim guns.

Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT, it is announced, favors several amendments to the charter of this city to correct evils in its working which, in his judgment, call for remedies. He will accordingly use his great influence with the Legislature to secure the enactment of amending bills at the coming session.

The Board of Health yesterday began its inquiry into the complaints it has received against the Manhattan Elevated Railway. Capt. Chadwick, whose complaint it was supposed would be taken up, was not present, nor was the alleged had ventilation of the Manhattan's cars touched upon.

ALBANY, Nov. 15. -- The Appellate Division handed down a decision to-day in a case involving the constitutionality of the civil service law, the meaning of which is that Civil Service Boards are not required to take the man highest on a civil service list. They may choose one of three highest.

NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., Nov. 15. -- To-night Senator-elect M.L. Hayward is dying. The physicians agree that death is inevitable, although the sick man may survive several days. He has sustained a rupture of a lobe of the brain, and as this is the third paralytic stroke in three months, the case is hopeless.

The latest advices from Kentucky denote that GOEBEL and his conspirators have in effect abandoned their original idea of stealing the State. The evidence that the people have voted against them is too clear. It is not true that a man can be induced to risk his life in order to bring about the triumph of a cause which he does not believe to be just.
The trial of Roland B. Molineux, charged with the murder in December last of Katherine J. Adams, made little progress yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 15. -- The entire Southern cotton belt is at present suffering from a severe drought. For the last four months there has not been at any one time enough rain to wet the earth. For the last thirty days men and animals alike have been casting up their eyes to heaven in mute appeal for water.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- W.L. Chambers, Chief Justice of Samoa, said to-day of the Samoan settlement:

The meeting of the National Academy of Sciences, which began Tuesday in Havemeyer Hall, Columbia, came to a close yesterday. A business session was held at 11 o'clock, and was enlivened by the presence of President Seth Low of Columbia University, who called to the attention of the Academy the matter of deciding who was to get the next Barnard Medal.
ALBANY, Nov. 15. -- Bishop Doane in his address to the diocesan convention to-day dwelt at length upon the divorce question. Speaking of divorce, he said in part:

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from its correspondent at Mafeking gives a vivid description of the recent fighting there. The correspondent says: "After the failure to rush the town, Gen. Cronje had recourse to the tactics employed during the siege of Potchefstroom in 1881, making an advance to the town by a succession of trenches in echelon.

Two more games were played yesterday in the intercity and interclub amateur billiard tournament at Slosson's Academy. J. Byron Stark, a scratch man, won the evening game from F.A. Keeney, to whom he conceded 20 points.

" The Merchant of Venice" was presented at the Knickerbocker Theatre last evening with every detail of scene and dress in accordance with the long established manner of the London Lyceum and a distribution of most of the roles, insuring an intelligent and well ordered interpretation of the poet's fancy.

The Committee of Citizens from the Committee of One Hundred and Seventy-five of Brooklyn called upon President Rossiter of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company yesterday to set forth their grievances against the present trolley arrangements.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The Rev. Frederick C. Mooney, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Rahway, and Mrs. Alice Whitney were married this afternoon at the home of the bride on Church Street. The bridegroom is thirty-four years old and the bride fifty-two.

Members of the Dewey Arch Committee of the National Sculpture Society received a hearty acknowledgment of the value of their public services in offering their time and labor without compensation for the erection of the mighty triumphal structure when they were entertained at a banquet given in their honor by the Reform Club last night.

It was Aug. 7, I believe, that the Independent Labor Party was born, and it was Nov. 7 it died, a three months' infant, after careful nursing, an apparently healthy infant; it was nursed to death by some political villain. Who it is is a question. John Swinton says that Platt was responsible for its conception, but who is responsible for its death?

The annual election of Directors of the Third Avenue Railroad Company was held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the company, 1,119 Third Avenue. A large majority of the stock was represented. There was no opposition to the ticket proposed, which consisted of the same names as last year, except that George A. Heyl took the place of the late William H. Webb, who died two weeks ago.

President Guggenheimer of the Council was called upon several days ago by a friend, Edmund Eckert, of 22 West Ninety-fifth Street, who asked him to use his good offices to obtain Mayor Van Wyck's consent to perform the marriage ceremony between Mr. Eckert and Miss Emilie Marie Gietl.

MATTHEW STANLEY QUAY was appointed by the Governor of Pennsylvania to be a Senator of the United States, after the Legislature of his State had failed to elect him and had adjourned, and expects to be seated by the votes of a majority of the Senate.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 15. -- The Goebel Democrats evidently are determined to obtain a plurality without the necessity of a contest if it is possible. In Louisville the recount is not half completed, but Goebel is gaining steadily. In one precinct alone today fifty-two more votes were added to his credit.

Policeman Henry Ward of the Bedford Avenue Station, Williamsburg, considered the oldest and wealthiest member of the force, died yesterday in the Eastern District Hospital from apoplexy. He was stricken on Tuesday night while on duty at Havemeyer and South Fourth Streets.

Emil L. Boas, local manager of the Hamburg-American Line, said that he had received no further advices than were contained in the foregoing cable. Regarding the report that 150 persons had been landed at Dover, he said that as the Patria carried on this trip 44 cabin and 78 steerage passengers, and her crew numbered 65 all told, it was evident that 28 of her crew had also landed, leaving 37 men aboard.

The idea of laying the dust of the streets by means of oil is not original at this time, but it has certain advantages to commend it. First of all, it would be effectual, and doubtless the suggestion would receive the unqualified approval of the stockholders of the Standard Oil Company. The greatest benefits, however, seem to me to lie in another direction.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. Nov. 15. -- The fifth annual meeting of the National Municipal League and the seventh National conference for good city government opened in this city to-day. Over 200 delegates are present, the gathering being a most representative one, composed as it is of city officials and municipal authorities from all over the country.

That is an extraordinary sequel of the Dreyfus trial which is now going on in France, and which seems to furnish the most important moral of that wonderful investigation. Not many years ago a very leading newspaper of New York was able to allude to France, without exciting any dissent, as the nation which had maintained "the leadership of Europe" without dispute for several centuries.

Your correspondent "Moore" pleads so eloquently in favor of placing the Dewey Arch permanently where the temporary structure now stands that I gladly add to his plea another reason in favor of this site.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 15. -- The Yale 'Varsity football team went through its practice to-day on a field of slush. The snow last night and the rain this morning put the field in bad shape. The weather was trying to the men, and the trainers worked hard to keep them from catching cold. The squad appeared in a new set of blankets, and between work were kept muffled up and moving by Trainer Robinson.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15. -- Three thousand undergraduates marched to Soldiers' Field this afternoon, led by the college band, to cheer the Harvard eleven for the last time before the Yale game. It had been announced that the practice would be open to-day for the last time, so the students took the opportunity to get a line on the play.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 15. -- J.J. Fry, general manager of the Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, to-day announced that he had tendered his resignation.

The following figures are taken from a statement made by James O'Connell, President of the International Association of Machinists, in reference to the discussion of the comparative conditions of workmen in the shipbuilding industries of Great Britain and the United States.

City Superintendent of Schools Maxwell issued the following reply yesterday to a recent statement by Controller Coler that the salaries of all the employes in the Superintendent's bureau had been raised:

The withheld salaries of the public school teachers of Manhattan and the Bronx led yesterday to one of the liveliest meetings which the School Board for these boroughs has held in a long time. The only absent members were Commissioners Farrell, Harrison, Moriarty, and A. Stern.
LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The Hamburg-American steamer Patria, Capt. Frohlich, which left New York Nov. 4 for Hamburg and passed the Lizard yesterday, is on fire near Dover.

-- Several of the Southern papers have been moved by an appeal which recently appeared in The Americus (Ga.) Times-Recorder to tell again the story of the Alabama and to ask why SCHLEY and BRUMBY are feted, while JOHN MCINTOSH KELL, First Lieutenant under Admiral SEMMES, is living in Atlanta almost forgotten.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 15. -- The Rev. Dr. Maltbie Davenport Babcock, pastor of Brown Memorial Church, has decided to accept the call from the Brick Presbyterian Church of New York in succession to Dr. Henry Van Dyke, and to-night handed his resignation to the Board of Trustees of Brown Memorial Immediately after the usual Wednesday night prayer meeting, a meeting of the deacons and Elders of the church was called and assembled in the chapel.
MANILA, Nov. 15, -- Gen. Hughes Nov, 12 occupied Tagbanan and Guimbal, on the southern coast, and also Cordova, in the interior. The enemy did not oppose his advance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The result in the hurdle race was the surprise of the day at Bennings, McFonso, a "rank outsider," with odds of 100 to 1, landing first money by a length in front of Julius Caesar, the favorite, who defeated the Lost Chord for a place by six lengths. Summaries:

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 15. -- A number of Americans here secured employment on the British transports which have sailed from this port with mules for South Africa. These men were employed by the steamship agents, and not by the officers of the British Government stationed here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The War Department has received the following cablegram:

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Anton Pollak and Josef Virag, inventors of the rapid sending and receiving automatic devices which promise a revolution in telegraphy, have arrived in Chicago from Budapest, Hungary, to make demonstrations of their invention. This series of experiments will be the first made in the United States of this system of telegraphy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- A postal deficiency of $6,610,777 for the fiscal year just closed, almost a 27 per cent. decrease from last year's deficiency, is shown in the annual report of Third Assistant Postmaster General E.C. Madden. The total receipts from all sources were over $95,000,000. Over 4,700,00 stamps in all have been supplied to the Philippines, 4,080,000 to Puerto Rico, 18,420,000 to Cuba, and 45,000 to Guam during the fiscal year.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 15. -- For the purpose of prevention of the intimidation of witnesses, the Supreme Court this afternoon ordered all newspapers to cease discussing the Wellcome disbarment case in any manner. The Clark and Daly Democratic papers, as well as some of the Republican organs, have carried the matter in a very high-handed personal manner, the court declared, and it must cease until after the decision is rendered.

The financial question has already been postponed many times. If it shall be deemed "good politics" to sidetrack it again, we may be very sure that there will be no currency reform legislation at the approaching session.

The Merchants' Association, which has been investigating the water situation in this city and incidentally the Ramapo contract, on Tuesday sent this letter to Commissioner Dalton of the Department of Water Supply:

BRISTOL, Nov. 15. -- The visit of Queen Victoria here to-day to open the Convalescent Home of Clifton was made the occasion for a great display of patriotism. The town was lavishly decorated, and her Majesty passed between six miles of Venetian masts, imperial standards, heraldic designs, and garlands of flowers.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 15. -- With the exception of Capt. Hare and McCracken the Pennsylvania 'Varsity football players put up a miserable game against the scrubs to-day on Franklin Field. The scrub eleven was strengthened, and before time was called for the end of the practice the second eleven made two touch-downs.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for Maria Bonnett to a client the lot on the north side of One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 100 feet west of Fifth Avenue, to-gether with an abutting lot on the south side of One Hundred and Eighteenth Street.

LONDON, Nov 15. -- Advices from Cape Town, bearing date of Nov. 10, say a dispatch received there from Pretoria, under date of Thursday Nov. 9, claims the reports received there from Ladysmith announce that heavy cannonading started at daybreak, and that some of the Boer forces were within 1,500 yards of the British when the cannonading ceased and rifle fire commenced.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 15. -- John Sabine Smith, the well-known New York lawyer and politician, and Miss Alice Clara Sawyer of Randolph were married at 1 o'clock this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church at Randolph by the Rev. Dr. Homer White.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The plaintiff in the case of John Maxwell against Nat Goodwin scored a point in the United States Circuit Court to-day when Judge Kohlsaat denied the motion of the defendant's attorney to suppress parts of a deposition of Henry Guy Carleton, the author of "Ambition," which is charged to be a plagiarized edition of the plaintiff's play, "Congress."
The bowling team of the Equitable Life Assurance Society entertained the members of the Life Insurance League at Starr's Alleys last night.

Argument has just been completed on a case in the United States Circuit Court at Boston which is the beginning of a legal fight between Bell telephone interests and their rivals in this country, that, it is said, may drag through years and spread to every State in the Union. It is a fight involving indirectly all independent companies.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- "The Boston Funmakers," a vaudeville company, started to give a performance last night at Yates Hall, South River. Two hundred and fifty persons, at 50 cents a head, were present when the curtain was rung up. After a few variety turns James Wilson, billed as the "king of black-face comedians," gave a song and dance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The Federal authorities to-day took cognizance of the reports which had been made concerning the alleged fraudulent business of the Board of Trade firm of McLain Brothers Co. and arrested Charles R. and Albert O. McLain, members of the firm. The charge was using the United States mails to carry on a scheme to defraud.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15. -- David Sinton, the richest man in Cincinnati, gave a $100,000 endowment to the University of Cincinnati to-day. The university board met in special session at 11 o'clock and accepted the gift. There were no conditions except that the money was to be used in the academic department of the institution.

Less than half a million shares were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the market lagging all day long until just before the close of business, when some activity developed attended by suggestions of much underlying strength. Net changes for the day were largely upon the side of advances, no railroad stock traded in to the extent of 200 shares declining as much as a whole point.

LOUISVILLE, Ky.. Nov. 16. -- The Democrats are now lying low and awaiting the session of the State Board of Election Commissioners, when, by reason of a Democratic majority on that board, they expect to have sufficient contested votes thrown out to give the certificates of election not only to Goebel, but to the entire Democratic ticket as well.

Justice Mattice, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, handed down a decision in the case of Dr. Francis M. Banta, who was appointed medical officer to the Fire Department of the old City of New York on Nov. 30, 1895, after passing a competitive civil service examination, and who was removed by Fire Commissioner Scannell on Sept. 22, 1898.

ESTCOURT, Nov. 16. -- An armored train, engaged in reconnoitring the Boer position, was derailed yesterday by a force of the enemy who were in ambush, and it is estimated the British loss was 100 to 150 in killed, wounded, and missing. Among the latter are Capt. Haldane and Lieut. Winston Churchill, son of Lady Randolph Churchill. Both, it is believed, are prisoners.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16. -- At Osborn Field to-day, after a long bout at preliminary practice, the 'Varsity lined up against the strongest college eleven that could be put in the field. All the 'Varsity players were in their places with the exception of Pell and Booth, who are resting.
SOUTHAMPTON, Nov. 16. -- The rescued passengers of the Hamburg-American liner Patria arrived here this afternoon from Dover.

PASSAIC, N.J., Nov. 16. -- A dozen passengers riding on a trolley car of the Jersey City, Passaic and Paterson line dropped with the car a distance of ten feet from the trestle over Weasel Brook, a mile from this city, this afternoon. All were injured with the exception of a boy. The car was traveling at the rate of fifteen or twenty miles an hour.

An informal talk on the transformation of Havana under the American flag and Cuba under the wardenship of the United States was given yesterday afternoon, in the gallery of the Chamber of Commerce, by Brig. Gen. William Ludlow, United States Volunteers, Governor of Havana.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Nov. 16. -- The tragedy on the American schooner J.B. Van Dusen, which occurred on the high seas in the Bay of Fundy last Saturday night, will result, like other recent famous murder cases, in the trial of the murderer at an American port.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners announces that absolutely no information as to the value which it proposes to fix on a franchise will be made public until the corporation holding the franchise is informed of the amount. Then it will be made a matter of public information.
Collins Collins have sold for James K. Atkinson to an investor the four-story brownstone front dwelling 557 Fifth Avenue, 25 by 100. It is reported that the buyer is C.C. Goodwin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- William H. Griffith, tin-plate maker of Washington, Penn., was before the Industrial Commission to-day. He told the commission that his company, which has since disposed of its plant, cleared 20 per cent. in profit last year, when the price of tin was $2.60 per box, the lowest ever known for plate.

"The Patriotic Spy; or, On Neutral Ground," the "magnificent scenic production.'' as the play bills have it, of the "thrilling" story of the Revolution, written by Lavinia I., Queen of the Holland Dames, otherwise Miss Lavinia H. Van Westervelt Dempsey, has got as near this city -- its eventual destination -- as Hoboken.

After nearly two days and a half of constant questioning of talesmen, the first juror in the Molineux case was found yesterday in the person of Mathias L.B. Martin, a retired broker of 28 West Ninety-sixth Street. Late in the afternoon a second juror was accepted. He is William G. Post, a retired confectioner of 110 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Treasury Department announced at the hour of closing this evening that offers had been made to the various Sub-Treasuries for the sale of bonds in compliance with Secretary Gage's offer, as follows: New York, $2,894,200; Baltimore, $19,000; Cincinnati, $28,760, a total of $2,941,900.

As the result of the compromise between the school officials and the law and finance officers of the city, the teachers of Brooklyn will receive their October salaries on the May basis, either to-day or to-morrow. This announcement was made by Auditor H.M. Cook of the Board of Education yesterday.

J. Henry Harper, Vice President of Harper Brothers, announced last evening that at a meeting of the directors of the publishing company, held yesterday afternoon, George B.M. Harvey, editor and proprietor of The North American Review, was elected President and Managing Director of Harper Brothers. He added that Mr. Harvey had purchased from the shareholders a large interest in the company.

-- An explanation for the banishment of photographers, or of cameras, which amounts to the same thing, from the new Zoological Garden has been given by Director W.T. HORNADAY. "The general use of cameras in the park," he says, "would utterly destroy a valuable privilege which the city has granted the society, to be utilized as the same privilege is in other zoological gardens."

Eminent authorities on railroad law agree that the far-reaching importance of the recent decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in favor of the merchants of Chattanooga, Tenn., upon their claim that they were discriminated against by the railroads, is such that an appeal to the Supreme Court of the United States is a foregone conclusion.

Ex-Mayor P.J. Gleason of Long Island City appeared yesterday before Magistrate Connorton of Flushing and complained against Dr. W.H. Nammack of Far Rockaway, alleging that on Nov. 8 the physician punched him in the chest while he was in Miller's Hotel, in Long Island City, and also used abusive language to him.

Fully 2,000 citizens of large lung power, all with a grievance against the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, gathered in Prospect Hall, in Prospect Avenue, near Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, last night, gave voice to their troubles, and showed their dislike for President Rossiter by hissing whenever his name was mentioned.
LEIPSIC, Nov. 16. -- Herr Moritz Busch, biographer of Prince Bismarck, died here to-day.

I have read your editorial article of to-day, entitled, "Getting Rid of BRYAN." I presume you desire the Democratic Party, in getting rid of BRYAN, to get rid also of the issues with which his name is associated, the issues, namely, of free silver, anti-imperialism, and trust regulation. The abandonment of these issues seems to me to involve the approval of the general policy, both foreign and domestic, of the present National Administration.

Golf honors were divided yesterday on the Ardsley Club links, near Dobbs Ferry, by the Baltusrol and Cincinnati Golf Clubs. The chief trophy, the Ardsley Cup, was won by Mrs. H.B. Ashmore of the former club at Short Hills, N.J., while the Hudson or Consolation Cup fell to the possession of Miss Lucy Herron.

FRANKFORT, KF., Nov. 16. -- Secretary of State Finley has received official returns from fifty counties and is tabulating them for the State Election Board. Candidates for minor State officers on both tickets fear that the returns may show the head of one ticket elected with candidates on the other ticket faring likewise.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 16. -- John Miller, son of William A. Miller, a wealthy wholesale liquor dealer of Park Square, Boston, is named as defendant in a suit for $20,000 damages for alleged defamation of character, which has been begun by George E. Rose of Bayonne, who until recently was a prefect and seminarian at Seton Hall College.

The seventh general meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers which began in the library of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers yesterday morning, was the magnet that attracted more than 100 experts in the art of marine construction engineering from all parts of the country.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- The long-contested Silesian inheritance of the late Duke Louis of Sagan-Valencay has just been granted, by imperial letters, in fief to the French Due de Talleyrand-Perigord, who swore allegiance to Germany before he received the award of the revenues of the duchy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The steamer Conesota of the Anchor Line sank at the mouth of the harbor early this morning, after a race for life.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Times publishes the following dispatch from Pietermaritzburg, dated Wednesday, Nov. 15:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Representative Chester I. Long of Kansas, who defeated Jerry Simpson for Congress last Fall, is here and settled for the Winter. Representative Long says that Kansas is as much interested in the campaign against Representative Roberts of Utah as the State of New York, and he has received a number of petitions and protests regarding the case.

The New York State Association of Railway Surgeons held their ninth annual meeting yesterday at the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street. The morning session was devoted to discussion of the special topic, "Physical Fitness of Railway Employes," papers being read by representatives of the various departments of railway organization.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The Chamber of Deputies was thronged with an excited crowd to-day on the resumption of the debate on the interpellations of the Government. Abbe Hippolyte Gayraud, Republican, made a bitter attack on Freemasonry, and Col. Guerin, Republican, defended the attitude of Gen de Negrier.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The inaugural performance of "David Garrick" at Wyndham's Theatre, Charles Wyndham's new house, at the corner of Cranbourne Street and Charing Cross Road, this evening, furnished ample testimony that his old friends will follow this favorite actor wherever he chooses to lead. Fashionable, enthusiastic, and patriotic admirers packed the house, the entire receipts being devoted to the Aldershot branch of the British Soldiers' Wives and Families' Association.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 16. -- The sessions of the National Municipal League continued today. The discussion, in which Controller Coler of New York took part, was on the new programme prepared by the special committee.

The case against the Louisville and Nashville and a number of other railroads and common carriers, decided in Cincinnati on Monday last, is important, not so much for the novelty of the principle involved as for the fact that the principle was so plainly stated and was accepted by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals so unqualifiedly.

ESTCOURT, Natal, Nov. 16. -- A missionary, a native, but a reliable man, who arrived here yesterday from Ladysmith, reports that a big fight took place there on Friday, Nov. 10. He says the volunteers went out in the early morning and drew the enemy from their positions on to a fiat, where the regular troops, under Sir George White, outmanoeuvred them by outflanking the Boers, administering a crushing defeat and inflicting great loss.
CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 16. -- This evening's practice has seen enough important charges in the make-up of the Indian team to almost revolutionize its standing before the other teams in the country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Gen. Garcia, who has returned to Washington, from Cuba, publicly criticises the appointments which have been made by Gen. Brooke. He says:
An important meeting was held in Wall Street yesterday, at which there was discussion of important projects which have in view benefits for the Union Pacific Railway.

The announcement of the offer of the Secretary of the Treasury to buy $25,000,000 of 5 per cent. bonds of 1904 and 4 per cent. bonds of 1907 took Wall Street thoroughly by surprise yesterday. New York bankers seemed quite as much astonished as were speculators. On the Stock Exchange, under the influence of the announcement, there was new activity, the volume of transactions being 50 per cent. beyond recent daily averages.

The Board of Trustees of the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute of Hampton, Va., which is devoted to the education and industrial training of negroes and Indians, has issued a circular appealing for gifts sufficient to increase the endowment fund of the institution by $1,000,000.

Congressman B.B. Odell, Jr., Chairman of the State Republican Committee, went to Albany yesterday morning and spent the greater part of the day in conference with Gov. Roosevelt. When he returned to the city last night Mr. Odell declared that his conference was on general lines and that he had not talked over possible police legislation or charter amendments with the Governor.
BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- There was a rather brilliant display of Leonids here between 2 and 5 o'clock this morning.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- According to the Pietermaritzburg correspondent of the London Outlook rumors are current in the Natal Capital that the Boers contemplate a retreat. It is needless, however, to attach importance to such reports, which are spread in all probability with a view of luring Gen. White, if possible, to abandon his defensive attitude.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- The Trust Company of New York to-day filed its articles of incor poration with the State Banking Department. Its business is to be transacted in the section bounded by Broadway, Pearl, and Pine Streets, and Exchange Place, in Manhattan Borough.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16. -- The practice at the Yale held to-day was disappointing to the large crowd of undergraduates that gathered to see the final work of the eleven before the Harvard game. There was no line-up whatever, and there was simply the uninteresting work in punt catching and ball practice.

Arthur Townsend, 280, met William Arnold, a limit man, in the afternoon game in the intercity and interclub billiard tournament yesterday. Townsend won in the fifty-fifth inning after playing a very irregular game.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16. -- Yesterday morning at 2 o'clock Sam Wright, a burly negro who shipped at Philadelphia as cook on the steamship Lindsfarne, attacked the twelve-year-old daughter of Mr. Gassenberger, a well-known politician of West Wego, a suburb of New Orleans.

CHESTER, Penn., Nov. 16. -- Darby can boast of a heroine, one whose brave conduct in fighting a burglar prevented the house of a sick friend from being robbed. Her name is Miss Helen Louderback, aged eighteen years, daughter of Prof. Louderback of Chester. She was nursing a sick friend, Miss Alice Pierson, who has been ill for months, and has been living with her in her Chester home for more than two months.
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The Times's Durban correspondent, under date of Nov. 12, says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The report of the Board of Inspection and Survey on the official test of the submarine boat Holland in Peconic Bay, Nov. 6, has been given out by the Secretary of the Navy. The tests were made to ascertain whether the boat was able to come up to the requirements for a submarine boat for the navy.

MANILA, Nov. 16. -- Reports have been received here from Gen. Young dated Humingam yesterday. Humingam is about thirty miles east of San Fabian, and Gen. Young is supposed to have advanced considerably further toward San Fabian.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 16. -- M. de Martens, professor of international law at the University of St. Petersburg, and who was a member of the Russian delegation to the Peace Conference at The Hague, has published a letter in The Official Messenger, in which he expresses his regret that the horrors of war should have appeared within two months after The Hague conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Charles G. Dawes, Controller of the Currency, has just made public the results of the investigation which he has made into the number of loans and deposit accounts, rates of interest, and resources of the combined banks of the United States in the years 1889, 1894, and 1899.
DOVER, Nov. 16. -- L Duplace, one of the four passengers of the Patria who remained here, died from shock this evening.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 10. -- A dispatch from Pretoria, dated Thursday, Nov. 9, says the natives are quiet. They have been called upon to plow the farms of the absent burghers, and are responding willingly. A proclamation has been issued by the Government, dealing with the appointment of officials of the general military administration, with the object of protecting life and property in the territories now occupied by the Transvaal forces.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17. -- James Kitchen, representing the New York syndicate that has made a proposition to Baltimore City to secure the controlling interest in the Western Maryland Railroad, is expected here to-morrow with the papers in the agreement.

Your appreciative article, with sketch reprinted from the "National Cyclopedia of American Biography," calling timely attention to the career of Lieut. Col. Charles Baxter, and the failure of the city even to erect the promised monument over his grave in Greenwood Cemetery, very appropriately headed "Benefits Forgot," in your issue of Nov. 4, was read by me with much interest and pleasure.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 17. -- Dwight L. Moody, who has been preaching here to thousands nightly in Convention Hall, is broken in health, and is suffering from an affliction of the heart. His engagement here was cut short, and to-night he is en route for his home, at Northfield, Mass., in the care of Dr. Schauffter of this city and C.M. Vining, teller of the Union National Bank.
The work of securing a jury to try Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Katherine J. Adams in December last proceeded yesterday in Part IV. of General Sessions, before Recorder Goff.

Readers of Mr. H. Rider Haggard's "Jess" and other tales of his concerning South Africa will perhaps be glad to learn that this writer has just produced a serious book on his familiar theme which events render paricularly valuable. This is nothing less than "A History of South Africa," which is in press for early publication by the New Amsterdam Book Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17. -- The Examiner says that Collis P. Huntington is today in full control of three-fourths of the property of the Southern Pacific Company and its allied corporation, the Pacific Improvement Company. With the help of the banking syndicate headed by the Speyers of New York and London he has bought out the Crocker and Stanford interests, each amounting to about one-fourth of the stock.

In the preparation of books and illustrated periodicals during half a century, the house of Harper Brothers has reproduced from time to time not only the best work of modern artists, but many of the most celebrated paintings of the Old Masters. Among the dust-covered plates in the firm's storeroom have been put away many superb reproductions of Rembrandt, Van Dyke, Hals, Murillo, Velasquez, Rubens, and modern painters too numerous to mention.

Controller Bird S. Coler, in an address delivered before the People's Institute at Cooper Union last night, on "The Financial Effects of Consolidation," advanced the proposition that great public improvements of a permanent character which are self-supporting, such as docks and rapid transit, should be exempt, as is the water supply, from having the cost considered in connection with the Constitutional debt limit.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 17. -- Assistant Coach George Conners to-day had charge of the Indians' practice, which consisted chiefly of dummy tackling and falling on the ball. The team lined up for about fifteen minutes against the scrubs, who in numerous hard attacks on the line failed to make an impression.

Your correspondent, "Cynic," thinks that womankind can do nothing in the intellectual world "uninfluenced by man." He fails to define, however, what man can do uninfluenced by woman. Has he ever discovered a woman uninfluenced by man or a man uninfluenced by woman? The fact that either is unmarried goes for little; influence is not confined to the married state.

Mr. BRYAN announces his intention to spend the entire Winter in going up and down in the land seeking how he may, like a modern Carnot, "organize victory" for whatever principles he may finally conclude to adopt in the campaign of next year. We trust that he will not regard it as presumptuous to suggest that he will succeed better the sooner he gets some definite idea of what those principles are to be.
Will "Cynic" kindly answer some questions for a woman who cheerfully concedes that man is the intellectual superior of woman?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Bureau of Immigration is preparing plans for a more rigid examination of intending immigrants. Officials of the bureau have been investigating the way in which immigrants are examined by medical officers abroad, and the researches have led to the belief that in many cases the examination is a farce.

ft. Byron Stark and Frank A. Keeney were the winners in the inter-city and inter-club handicap tournament at Slosson's Billiard _,kcademy yesterday. Each man played good billiards, Keeney naking an average of 9 1-31 ill the afternoon game, the best he has ever done in tournament work. In the evening Stark did even better, making an average of 10 10-29.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The following censored dispatch from Pretoria gives details of the engagement referred to in the dispatch from Pretoria of Nov. 15, sent out today...
" The Minister's Ward" is the title of a novel that will shortly appear from the press of D. Appleton Co. It is by a new and unknown writer, written something in the style of Miss Montresor's books.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Admiralty announced this evening the arrival at Cape Town of the troopships Malta, City of Vienna, City of Cambridge, and the Arcana, the latter with a battalion of the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, (the Princess Louise's regiment,) bringing the reinforcements up to 23,500, of which 7,200 have already disembarked at Durban, with 18 field guns, a number of machine guns, engineers and hospital troops, as well as 700 mules.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- Pennsylvania had no trouble in defeating the Pennsylvania State College team on Franklin Field to-day, the score being: Pennsylvania, 47; State College, 0. The Red and Blue eleven played a strong and fast game. The players made few mistakes, and there was little fumbling.

The most striking feature of the accounts of their expenditures by the various candidates is that in every case nearly all the money accounted for is put down as given to the party committee. Now, as a matter of cold fact, this is no accounting at all. It amounts to no more in disclosing what the money went for than Dora Copperfield's bookkeeping.

Our editor, possessing an early edition of Richardson's "Clarissa Harlow" as a foundation for his lettered "castle in Spain" -- foundations of these delightful castles are always on the "top" -- reminds me of the pleasure I once took in reading "Clarissa," and perhaps as much in reading contemporary opinions of the author. Disraeli, the elder, says foreign critics were more just to Richardson than his own countrymen.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 17. -- The proposition to-day from Goebel's lawyers to throw out the entire vote of Jefferson County, which includes Louisville, was not wholly unlooked for by the Republican leaders here.

William R. George's institution at Freeville, N.Y., known as the George Junior Republic, was the subject of a full discussion at the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the annual meeting of the George Junior Republic Association. Charles S. Fairchild, ex-Secretary of the Treasury, presided at the meeting, and a short talk was made by the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17. -- Prof. Charles Eliot Norton of Harvard University to-day confirmed a report that Mrs. Elizabeth Cary Agassiz, President of Radcliffe College, had resigned. He gave out the following statement:

The wholesale fireworks establishment of the Thomas Lloyd Fireworks Company, at 15 Park Place, was wrecked by a fire of unknown origin, which broke out in the third story of the building at 2:40 o'clock this morning.
In your review of my work printed on Nov. 11 in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW there are the following queries and statements:

The immediate success of "Young April," stimulated no doubt by a delightful remembrance of "The Pride of Jennice," has naturally made the reading public somewhat eager to learn more about Mr. Egerton Castle. Recently this author wrote to the Frederick A. Stokes Company: "Among a writer's literary family is there not one nearer his heart than all the rest -- his dream-child? * * * This book is my dream-child."

Mr. Arthur F. Cosby's letter published on Nov. 11 criticising Tom Hall's publication, "Fun and Fighting of the Rough Riders," is of double interest to those who either knew the said Tom Hall or indulged in the fun (?) and fighting mentioned.

Edwin Markham is a native of the great Emerald State, Oregon. After her husband's death the mother settled in California, and young Markham, a lad of tender years, became a cowboy of the high Sierras. But he was a new sort of cowboy, a cowboy of books.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The bonds offered to the Government to-day at the several Sub-Treasuries under Secretary Gage's offer of last Tuesday amounted to $2,341,350, as follows: New York, $1,859,150; Philadelphia, $478,000; Cincinnati, $4,000; Baltimore, $20,000; Boston, $197,505.

So conscientiously have all records of Nathaniel Hawthorne been searched for publication, and so divergent have been the critical opinions of the man, that the young student of literature stands somewhat appalled before the mass which he must read and digest if he would form an accurate and impartial opinion of the author of "The Scarlet Letter."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Navy Department to-day gave out a circumstantial account of the conspicuous gallantry of Ensign W.R. Gherardi during the recent terrific cyclone which swept across Puerto Rico. It was forwarded by Capt. Snow, commanding the United States naval station at San Juan, who inclosed letters of Lieut. Col. Carr of the Fifth Cavalry and others concerning the daring of the exploit.

In December, 1875, Baron Christian Thomsen and his wife, Florentine Thomsen, by proceedings in the Court of Common Pleas, under the law of 1873, adopted a child named Sylvia, four and one-half years old. Mr. and Mrs. Thomsen had at this time two children -- a son, Hugo A., born in 1850, and a daughter, Betita, who was born in 1854.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 17. -- The Goebel leaders to-day challenged the entire vote of the City of Louisville, which gave Taylor a plurality of 2,537 on the face of the returns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Active negotiations are proceeding to secure from Brazil such tariff concessions as will extend the market for American wheat and American flour in that country. It is understood that a proposition to this effect has heretofore been submitted to the authorities at Rio de Janeiro, and they have sought to accede to the desires of the authorities here.

The Republicans, as has been intimated, purpose utilizing their large majority in the incoming Legislature in curtailing the powers of Tammany Hall. Senator Thomas C. Platt admitted as much at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night, and incidentally the Senator expressed the opinion that Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff would make a good running mate with William McKinley on the Presidential ticket next year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Secret practice was again the order of the day, but information as to the quality of the work is current to-night. Owing to the fact of the hard game with Washington and Jefferson to-morrow, the line-up against the scrub was of short duration, only one fifteen-minute half being played.

NEWTON, N.C., Nov. 17. -- The twenty-first annual meeting of the Eastern Field Trial Club is now in progress at this place. A good number of the members of the club and visitors are now on the ground, and many more are expected as the trials progress.

A cablegram from Bishop Potter, dated Yokohama, has been received, announcing his arrival in Japan after a pleasant voyage and stay in Honolulu of a day and a half. He is accompanied by the Rev. Percy S. Grant of the Church of the Ascension of this city, and they are on their way to the Philippines, but may go also to India before their return.

The war vessel was again the feature of the majority of the papers that were read during the second and last day's sessions of the annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers. The gathering assembled in the library of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, at 12 West Thirty-first Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- This is the night before the great annual football struggle between Harvard and Yale Universities. Everywhere may be seen the sympathizers of the Blue and the Crimson, and arguments on the relative merits of the teams are heard in the streets, the cars, and hotel corridors. The city is filled with Yale and Harvard undergraduates and alumni, eager to argue and just as eager to bet.

As you seem to be willing to hear from the Philistines, (as per an editorial, "Philistinism Gone Almost Mad,") I put in my oar. Briefly, I have no use for the profession of letters. What a profession it is, to be sure! In every other, wealth is the measure of success. In letters, you must be poor in order to be respectable.

About a thousand members of the City Teachers' Association of Manhattan met yesterday afternoon in the Normal College in response to a call by William L. Ettinger, the President of the body, to discuss the question of the teachers' salaries and act upon it. The spirit manifested at the meeting was an aggressive one.

I have read with much interest the "Cynic's," as well as Isaac Hyman's, letter in last SATURDAY'S REVIEW'. I quite agree with every word the former has said, and I think facts of everyday occurrence bear out his views. Here is a case in point: A short time ago the Government of a certain country appointed a commission to inquire into alleged educational abuses.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- Prior to his departure for Boston this morning Gov. Roosevelt conferred with Adjutant General Andrews on National Guard topics. The most important matter under discussion was the necessity of procuring greater improvement in both field and range rifle practice on the part of organizations of the Guard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Major Gen. Lawton in his report to the War Department of the expedition which was undertaken last April to Santa Cruz, in the Province of La Laguna, Luzon, pays high tribute to some of his officers. He says:

" Young April" starts off with such a fine clatter! The fat and sleek prebend, the Rev. Thomas Smiley, is tutor to Edward Warrender, and Smiley looks toward preferment, for has not her Grace, Edward's pious aunt, put into the reverend gentleman's hands for his guidance, worldly and spiritual, the future of her nephew, who is to be Duke of Richmond?

President George C.
