Clausen of the Park Board yesterday clearly defined the position of the department in the matter of the removal of the elevated railway structure from Battery Park by the announcement that the question was going to be settled immediately and once for all. Further evasion of the issue on the part of the railway company, he said, would not be tolerated.
Indefinite postponement of the suit of the minority stockholders of the old Memphis and Charleston Railroad Company to prevent the sale of that property to the Southern Railroad.

Father Brady has recently translated from the French of Mgr. Bougaud, Bishop of Laval, a new life of St. Vincent de Paul. A larger and more detailed history of this saint was written by one of his contemporaries, the Bishop of Rodez, and there are also in existence "St. Vincent's Letters," 2,500 in number, a selection made from the 30,000 which existed at the time of the latter's death, in 1660.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 17. -- To-day's Supreme Court sitting was devoted to rebuttal testimony by the prosecution relative to State Senator W.A. Clark of Madison County, whose character was so vigorously attacked by the defense yesterday. Clark is the one witness on whose veracity, it is believed, depends John B. Wellcome's disbarment, as he is, with the exception of Whiteside, the only man who claims to have received money from Wellcome.
ESTCOURT, Natal, Nov. 16. -- A correspondent who has just visited the Sanatorium Hospital says all the armored-train wounded are doing well.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Lewis Lucas Troy, Superintendent of the United States Railway Mail Service in Chicago, died at 8:10 o'clock to-night at his home in this city of neuralgia of the heart. He had been in ill-health for nearly a year, but attended to his work until a week ago. His death had been expected for twenty-four hours before he breathed his last.

There is on file in the records of the Police Department in this city a letter dated twenty-eight years ago, signed by George Andrew, recommending James K. Price for a place on the police force. In 1871 Mr. Andrew was foreman in the iron foundry of Cobanks Theall, and young Price was a workman there.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Carrying out a plot he had apparently planned with deliberation, Cornelius Corcoran to-day shot four of his children, killing two of them, and then ended his own life. The tragedy occurred at his home, 5,401 Dearborn Street. The dead are Cornelius Corcoran, forty-nine years old; Margaret Corcoran, five years old, died at Mercy Hospital; John Corcoran, seven years old, died at the same hospital.

All told, exactly $2,082,832.98 was disbursed at the Sub-Treasury yesterday in payments for bonds proffered in response to the offer of purchase made by the Secreary of the Treasury. Of this total $1,859,150 represented principal, the additional amount being interest and premium, and of this principal $738,150 was for the fours and $1,121,000 for the fives.

Col. Lawrence Kip died at 9:30 o'clock last evening at his residence, 452 Fifth Avenue. He had been seriously ill for nearly three weeks from stomach trouble, and had been gradually sinking. He was, however, conscious up to the last.

In this day's editorial article you say: "We are quite sure that most of our readers will agree with the old saying that the style is the man, and that the manner is of much more importance than the matter of the book." Now I am not of that majority, and would like to know what your readers do think upon the vexed question.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for the estate of William Rankin to Henry Oppenheimer the plot on the north side of Eighty-fourth Street, 100 feet west of West End Avenue, 100 by 102.2.

Some weeks ago you kindly published a letter in reference to Robinson Crusoe's goats. Can you stand another one regarding Crusoe's cave? In reading the interesting voyage of the Spray, (current Century, Page 143,) we read: "Having feasted on nothing sweeter than a visit to the very cave of Robinson Crusoe on the Island of Juan Fernandez,"

About half of the attendants and keepers in the institutions on Randall's Island were in a state bordering on mental and physical exhaustion yesterday, as a result of a remarkable exciting coon hunt which took place in the early hours of the morning. Not until the quarry was bagged, after several hours of tremendous effort and excitement, was it definitely known that it was a coon hunt.

Last day of the Horse Show. A blessed relief is the reflection this morning, even of those who are most interested, and have been the most devoted in their attendance. Yesterday at the Garden was a repetition of Thursday, with the same crowds and the same general atmosphere that has for the past few years prevailed in the same place on the closing days of the show.

One week from to-day, (on Nov. 25,) THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW will be issued as a twenty-four page number. Its special feature will be a series of articles outlining the plans made by the editors of the magazines for the coming year. Heretofore it has been the custom, with newspapers and literary-publications, to print scattered items of this sort from time to time.
ORANGE RIVER, Cape Colony, Nov. 12. -- Gen. Lord Methuen, Commander of the First Division, has arrived here with his staff from Cape Town.

JOPLIN, Mo., Nov. 17. -- Robbers blew open the safe of the Bank of Carl Junction, ten miles north of here, after midnight, and secured between $3,000 and $4,000 in cash. The robbers numbered four and were well armed. A crowd of men pursued them a short distance out of town, but soon returned without having gotten near enough to exchange shots.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17. -- Enthusiasm more spirited than ever before, attended the departure of the Yale football team for the hostile grounds of the Crimson to-day. The 'Varsity contingent left the campus at 2:20 o'clock this afternoon for Boston. Over 1,000 undergraduates crowded about the players and cheered and cheered.

The first public rehearsal of the fifty-eighth season of the Philharmonic Society of the City of New York took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The surroundings were of the customary gladsome nature. The audience was a large one, and there was a manifest determination to accept the proceedings of the afternoon in the spirit in which they were offered.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18. -- The official vote for Governor in Hamilton County is as follows: George K. Nash, (Rep.,) 35,740; John R. McLean, (Dem.,) 36,805; Seth H. Ellis, (Union Reform,) 377; George M. Hammell, (Proh.,) 138; Robert Bandlow. (Soc.,) 244; Samuel M. Jones, (Ind.,) 12,503; McLean's plurality, 1,065.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Criticism of the Intelligence Department of the War Office continues to appear in publications of all kinds. Even the conservative Times makes it the object of scathing denunciations, saying: "We hope the War Office, having learned by experience what might have been learned from cheaper sources, will not omit to provide our troops with artillery, heavier and of longer range than our excellent field guns."

Six teams will compete in the Amateur Hockey League this season. Last year the New York Athletic Club, St. Nicholas Skating Club, Hockey Club of New York, Montclair Athletic Club, and Brooklyn Skating Club were the competitors. The Crescent Athletic Club has been taken in and will play its home games at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn.

CAPE TOWN, Oct. 18. -- There have been further raids on the banks at Johannesburg by the Government. In view of the results of similar visits, great were the consternation and excitement at the Standard Bank when three vehicles drew up outside, and under the direction of Lieut. Oosthuizen, acting on behalf of the Transvaal Government, a number of ingots of gold and silver were transferred from the bank premises to the vehicles.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Advices from Maseru, Basutoland, dated Wednesday, Nov. 8, say that Chief Joel, terrorized by false Boer assertions that the British have been beaten in every engagement and are being driven out of South Africa, is preparing to join the Boers, believing theirs the winning side. The Boers are said to have supplied him with guns, which they have accompanied with specious promises.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company has decided to give its old patrons the benefits they claim due them on the old sliding scale commutation rates. Under the sliding scale the price of a monthly ticket was reduced with each succeeding month for one year. The sliding scale was abolished Nov. 1 and "the standard" commutation rate, which establishes a uniform price for the commutation tickets each month established.

They were sitting, a small party of miners from the Klondike, in the Hoffman corridor, spinning yarns of lucky "finds," big nuggets, experiences, and all such things that miners delight in telling about when they drop in on the effete East. In the group were prospective "tenderfeet" to the gold region, and mayhap it was this that prompted E.D. Michler, recently of Cape Nome district, to weave a "tenderfoot" yarn.

Dr. L.L. Seaman has made some severe strictures upon the food supplied to our army in the Philippines. The subject is deserving of most careful consideration. If it is true that our army is suffering from improper food to anything like the extent represented by Dr. Seaman, the persons responsible for it should be made to feel the power of public indignation.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The movement to increase the navy has not lost its vigor. The agitation started by the Emperor is being skillfully managed. Capt. von Heeringen of the Marine Ministry, who has done most of the literary work connected with the movement, has, by the Emperor's order, published a pamphlet arguing powerfully in favor of the necessity of a large navy.
The State of New York will send to the exposition a forestry exhibit of thirty-four specimens of wood, all native to the State.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 18. -- The first test case under the Connecticut legislation provision that an independent telephone company must show convenience and necessity will be heard by Judge Thayer of the Superior Court of New London County in this city on Monday, Nov. 20. The New London Automatic Telephone Company is the petitioner, and the Southern New England Telephone Company will oppose.

Once on a time your shoe was nothing without the buckle. Indeed, it was a case of the "tail wagging the dog," for the buckle was the attraction and the shoe but the accompaniment. Be it observed that at first, however it was not the size, but the costliness of the buckle which was conspicuous.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 18. -- Notwithstanding the attraction of the Horse Show in New York this week, matters continued in the even tenor of their way here among the beautiful pines. The big Lakewood Hotel has been besieged all week by cottagers and guests from other hotels to inspect the new and beautiful interior decorations and rich furnishings.
Do the recent elections show that the Democratic Party, led by Mr. Bryan, cannot win in 1900?
I would be much obliged if the man who writes the articles on the "Well-Dressed Man" in THE SUNDAY TIMES would answer two or three questions:

The Presbyterian Church has gone through the throes of one ecclesiastical struggle to find itself on the eve of another, which may prove still more bitter in character and more lamentable in results. It is generally admitted that the Briggs controversy has dealt a blow at the prestige and influence of Presbyterianism from which it is not likely to recover in this generation.

The public school controversy, now raging in the four boroughs of this city, is apparently to be taken up and carried on at Albany this Winter. The other day State Senator Elsberg announced that he intended re-introducing his bill, authorizing the Mayor to appoint directly the members of the Central Board and enlarging the present powers of the City Superintendent.

Apropos of the superstitions of the Hohenzollerns -- superstitions, by the way, found in all ancient royal families, including our own -- the rulers of that house possess a talisman brought into it by a good spirit said to guard its destinies. This is the curious "black stone," to which is attached the following quaint tradition:

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 18. -- A desperate fight occurred last night at the home of a white man named Johnson, who lives in this county, fifteen miles from here. Seven men were engaged in it, and four of them were seriously wounded, two perhaps fatally.
Several interesting contests were played yesterday on the Ardsley Club links for the two November cups, which are now attracting the attention of a large number of members.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- An interesting volume on the lessons of the late war from the Spanish point of view has just been translated by the Bureau of Naval Intelligence. It is entitled "Blockaces and Coast Defenses," by Severo Gomez Nunez, Captain of artillery. He bases nearly all his conclusions as to coast defenses oil long extracts from several articles written since the war by Capt. Mahan of our navy.

DENVER, Nov. 18. -- A special to The Republican from Glenwood Springs, Col., says that Game Warden Johnson and his posse have had a fight with the Indians, who have invaded the State from Utah, for the purpose of hunting, and that one Indian was killed. The details are not known.

LONDON: Nov. 18. -- The latest news from the seat of war in South Africa is, from one point of view, favorable to the British, showing that Kimberley is able to hold its own easily against the Boer bombardment, and that Estcourt is also in a position to beat back an attack by the Boer force now facing it.

So far as the fashion of the day is concerned, so large a meet of women of the world and taste at any set season as was that at the Horse Show must have its influence upon the modes. There are always improvements and changes in the advance of fashion as in all else, but the principal ideas as seen in this November show will remain throughout the Winter.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- Before the Senate, sitting as a High Court, to-day, M. Deroulede was examined in the conspiracy cases. He began by affirming his love for the republic. "But," he explained, "a plebicitary republic." He then attacked President Loubet, but was checked by M. Fallieres, President of the Senate, who refused to listen to his tirade, and demanded that he withdraw his allegations.

Champion Day drew an unusually large crowd to the Madison Square Garden for the closing day of the Horse Show. From a horsey standpoint it was the day of the whole show, for it brought to the final test the prize winners in the several contests for the much-coveted tri-colored ribbon that denotes championship honors.
BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The imperial yacht Hohenzollern, with the Emperor and Empress of Germany and two of their sons on board, sailed from Kiel for England at 9 o'clock this morning.

DUNKIRK, France, Nov. 18. -- Two German steamers have taken the Patria, which caught fire off Dover, England, Wednesday, and which was abandoned in flames in tow fifteen miles northeast of Grabelines, France.

Col. Ethan Allen of this city, who, during the existence of the Cuban League, was its President and most active agent, and who in such capacity labored for nearly thirty-five years for American intervention in behalf of the Cuban patriots, is now one of the supporters of the present foreign policy of the Administration.

A day or two ago The Evening Post printed in full the record of the attempts of the Merchants' Association to get information from the Commissioner of Water Supply and from the President of the Board of Public Improvements upon the legal and engineering aspects of the project of making a contract with the Ramapo Water Company to supply additional water for the Borough of Manhattan.

The position which the piano virtuoso is content to occupy in the musical world is one most compromising. It is thoroughly known among professional musicians, and it ought to be among music lovers, and is to some extent. But many persons still think that there is a certain high musical honor among pianists, and the players themselves have so succeeded in blunting their artistic consciences that they think their conduct perfectly virtuous.
HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Rawlins L. Cottenet and C. Albert Stevens were thrown to-day while following the hounds over the Meadow Brook Hunt Club course and severely injured.
BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The comment on the South African war news this week is more cautious, but not more friendly to the British. A military writer in the Kreuz-Zeitung, reviewing the situation, says:

Local Democratic leaders and officials have about come to the conclusion that the coming session of the Legislature is to be largely devoted to charter amendments consequent upon the recent Tammany victory at the polls and the revelations made before the Mazet Committee, and they have decided, in a measure, to combat the Republicans by proposing amendments of their own.
The following statement was given out at the Woman's Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church yesterday by Mrs. Darwin R. James:

Much has been said about the great mortality among the British officers in the South African war, and some gentleman, with a turn for figures, has ciphered out that after a certain number of engagements, all the British officers being dead or disabled, the army will be composed exclusively of privates.
LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The Matin of Paris announces that France will have two more submarine boats ready before next October.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Mrs. James Brown Potter's tea chantant at Claridge's Hotel today, for the benefit of the American hospital ship Maine, was a great success. The exquisitely decorated rooms were thronged with the exclusive set of fashionable people in brilliant attire, including the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Cambridge, Princess Christian of Schleswig-Holstein, Princess Aribert of Anhault, and Princess Victoria of Schleswig-Holstein.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- The Cornell football team entered the Lafayette game a week ago with two of her best men missing on account of illness, while several that did play should have been in bed. Pierson, the centre, and Caldwell, right guard, were both sent to the infirmary at the close of that game.

The certificate of incorporation of the Single Tube Automobile and Bicycle Tire Company was filed at Trenton yesterday. The company is organized with a capital of $1,000,000. It is understood that it will acquire from the Tillinghast Tire Association the so-called Tillinghast patent and the rights under it.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 18. -- A hunting license for probably the youngest lad ever permitted to hunt under State regulations in this part of the country has been issued to Mark Atkinson of Hibbing, this county. He is nine years old, but the small game whose hunting does not require a State license has now no attraction for him.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The military fervor which has seized hold of the nation shows no sign of abatement. This is scarcely to be wondered at, when it is realized how many households of all degrees throughout the United Kingdom are affected by the war.

_dmltting the unpleasant features of the tipping vice, one of the correspondents in your Wednesday issue claims that it is an outgrowth of our unrighteous industrial conditions, which force large numbers to depend on gratuities in lieu of wages.

May I be allowed to say a word or so concerning the automobiles in the Park? I note in your issue of the 14th, where Mr. Clausen states that the "high class" horses object to the auto, whereas the ordinary street horse pays no attention to it. I drove an automobile in Newport for many weeks during the past Summer, and my experience was exactly the reverse of the above statement.

Interest in amateur billiards was awakened during the past two weeks. At Schaefer's Academy a tournament of Class B men, governed by the Amateur Athletic Union, has been in progress two weeks, and at Slosson's the seceders from the Amateur Athletic Union, who play under the rules of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, held forth last week.

In a letter published three years ago I maintained that our municipal transit was defective patchwork, made up of conflicting and competing private companies, which should be consolidated and connected.

The occasion of the publication yesterday of the earnings of Missouri Pacific for the second week in November led Russell Sage to speak in glowing terms of the property. "I have always had faith in the railroad." he said, "and now with its greatly increased earnings, my faith is growing stronger and stronger.

If illegal salaries have Been paid to the teachers of this borough, as the Corporation Counsel implies, is not the Controller of the city responsible? Perhaps money enough could be collected from Mr. Coler (in return for sums unwarrantably drawn from the Municipal Treasury) to keep the schools of bankrupt Richmond open until January brings relief.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- Judge McPherson of the United States District Court, before whom Ellery P. Ingham, ex-United States District Attorney, and Harvey K. Newitt, his law partner and former assistant, were tried and convicted of the charges of conspiracy and bribing a Secret Service operative, to-day rendered a decision refusing to grant a new trial to the defendants.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 18. -- Before the large and at times wildly enthusiastic crowd the Eastman College eleven to-day won a well-earned victory over the team of the College of the City of New York. Because of off-side playing the Eastman team did not score in the first half, while the City College men worked the home line for good gains, after trying in vain to skirt Eastman's ends.

District Attorney Gardiner yesterday sent to Gov. Roosevelt by messenger his answer to the charges preferred against him by members of the City Club. In the charges filed with the Governor, there were 2,000 specifications, and these the District Attorney answered in detail. After the answer had been received by the Governor, the District Attorney made public the contents, which covered eighty type-written pages.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 18. -- In order to obtain the certificate of election it will be necessary for Goebel to overcome a plurality of 4,223 for Taylor. Goebel has contested a total of 5,386 votes, and if successful in every instance he could then claim a plurality of 1,163 votes. Every county has now been officially reported save Jefferson, of which Louisville is the seat.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The officers of the National Butchers' Guild will consider next Friday the advisability of calling a congress of European butchers to devise steps against the increasing competition of American meat. The guild has distributed in the last two months millions of posters and pamphlets on this subject.

Wash day in a great city does not always fall on Monday, but custom is yet strong enough to cause an increased demand on the water supply of several million gallons on that day in a city like New York. In former days before the new water supply was in operation, wash day was looked forward to apprehensively by the Water Commissioners during seasons of unusual dryness.

ROME, Nov. 4. -- The programme of works to he given at the world-famous Opera House of La Scala, at Milan, during the coming Winter of 1899-1900, was published here on Wednesday last. To the large number of Wagner lovers in this country the season promises to be one of unusual interest, as the great German master's music-drama "Siegfried" is to be given in this theatre for the first time in Italy.

Souvenir copies of the Thanksgiving proclamation of Gov. George W. Atkinson of West Virginia have been received in this city. The copies are printed, bound in illustrated paper covers, and tied with narrow ribbon. The proclamation reads:

An unusually large number of recent plays by German dramatists of repute has been accounted unsuccessful by the theatre managers. This has led to the initiation of a new scheme which may have good artistic results and certainly will be interesting in its development. A certain number of new plays will be produced anonymously each season, and if one makes a hit its author's name will be announced after the tenth performance.

'l'he marketwomen of Paris became the terrible Vestals, the drunken Bacchantes of the new god Ltber. It is they who foment ever uprising, small or large; it is they' who the men into their wake; it is they who set the national militia in motion; it is ,2hey who place themselves between the loyal guard and the pseudo-patriotic hordes; it is they who lead the attack on the parti of order and paralyze their defense.

Forty-six members of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club competed in the first handicap match of the season at the armory last night, in which five prizes were offered. Several good scores were made. First place was won by Private D. Brandreth of Company I. Veteran A. Stein, besides taking third place in the handicap match, broke the regiment's record in the rapid-fire test during a successful attempt to qualify as an expert.

Relatively little interest was manifested yesterday in the football contest between Columbia and Dartmouth, which ended in an anticipated victory for the local team, the score being 22 to 0. The attention of football enthusiasts generally was monopolized by the duel between Yale and Harvard, and the contest at Manhattan Field attracted barely 1,000 spectators.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- After the game the Yale team returned to Hotel Vendome for dinner. Not a man showed serious injuries and no bruises to speak of, although they admitted that the contest was the hardest of the year. The players were very happy, and in their talk they expressed their satisfaction with the game.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 18. -- The second game of the new triangular league resulted in an easy victory for Wesleyan to-day by a score of 40 to 0. The Amherst team suffered chiefly from its light weight, but showed considerable pluck in the face of big odds and an overwhelming defeat. Wesleyan did the greater part of her scoring in the first half, piling up 30 points before its expiration.

URBANA, Ohio, Nov. 18. -- A mob of masked men broke into the jail at West Liberty this morning about 1 o'clock and took out "Nell" Jackson, the white widow of the notorious colored man Grant Jackson, who was killed at West Liberty a few years ago; Edward Jackson, father-in-law of the woman, and "Dave" Rickman, a colored man of Bellefontaine.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 18. -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and her family will remain at The Breakers until the weather becomes very cold. They will then go to New York for a time, and afterward to Europe for the remainder of the Winter. A drive about the Summer colony district shows a small army of laborers and mechanics at work digging foundations for new cottages or making improvements and enlargements to others.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Ex-Congressman W.D. Bynum of Indiana has been appointed a member of the Board of General Appraisers at New York, vice Wilkinson, resigned.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The preparations to receive the Emperor of Germany have been completed. The Duke of Connaught will greet his Majesty at Portsmouth, instead of the Prince of Wales, as originally intended. Six battleships, four cruisers, and eight torpedo-boat destroyers, under Admiral Seymour, will assembly at Spithead to meet the imperial yacht Hohenzollern and the new battleship Kaiser Friedrich III.

The Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute is now in its nineteenth year or work. It is no longer an experiment, but has proved to the country its value in helping to uplift the millions of negroes and to bring about harmonious relations between them and the white people of the South.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18. -- Yale won a virtual victory over Harvard on Soldiers' Field this afternoon by playing the Crimson a tie game of nothing to nothing. That was the opinion of all the Yale experts. It was the opinion of the impartial observer, and the Harvard undergraduate, with his hopes shattered, is willing to acknowledge the game a defeat.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 18. -- "The next party wanting an option on my interests in the steel and other businesses connected with it will have to pay an enhanced price," said Andrew Carnegie to-day. Mr. Carnegie will leave for New York to-morrow, and, following custom, gave out an interview prior to his departure from Pittsburg.

Abraham Farley, a guard on the Sixth Avenue elevated railroad, shot himself through the head last evening, dying instantly. Farley killed himself in Morningside Park near One Hundred and Nineteenth Street. He had quit work two weeks ago.

The balls b-ere made of scarlet or purple leather, and filled with flour or feathers, grass, wool.- fig seeds, or sand. They were small, and the object of covering them with such a bright color was that they might flash and look bright in the sun, nd De easily seen when they were thrown.

In your editorial of Saturday, on a recent speech of Lord Salisbury, this occurs: "But the main source of comfort that Lord Salisbury finds * * * is the sympathy of Germany and the United States, Perhaps it would be more accurate to say in the support of the Government of Germany and of the people of the United States."

May Irwin said something surprising the other day. It was up at the Bijou Theatre, in a cozy litle inner office, on one of those briskly cool days last week when an open fire looked and felt comfortable, and there was one in the office.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 11. -- The Collector General's review of the report of the colony's trade during the financial year just closed has recently been published. It shows that for a number of years the United States exports to the British West Indies in general, and to Jamaica in particular, have exhibited a steady increase proportionate to the detriment of the English monopoly that previously existed.

We pointed out the other day that Mr. CHAMBERLAIN was very unlikely to get any political capital out of the war in South Africa, whoever else obtained any. As Colonial Secretary he would necessarily have been conspicuous, but he has taken no pains at all to preserve the pretense of consulting his colleagues on the preliminary negotiations; he has, on the contrary, taken pains to make it appear that he was doing it all alone.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Two dispatches were received at the War Department from Gen. Otis, giving the details of the advance of Lawton and MacArthur. The first dispatch follows:

Sir Henry Irving and Miss Ellen Terry completed what is by a considerable margin the most successful engagement in their joint career before another great audience at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night, and to-day the famous players and their company will leave for Boston, where "Robespierre" is to be presented to-morrow night.

It is an excellent thing, from every point of view, that the Horse Show should this year have reverted, without question, to the original purpose of its creation. For several seasons it became what was first called a "beauty show" and then a "society show," and this was very bad.

NYACK, Nov. 18. -- Dr. William Hart Dexter, who has been missing from Nyack since Nov. 2, arrived at home this evening. His wife and daughter Katherine left here this morning for North Wales, Penn., to meet him, but he did not know of their going.
MADRID, Nov. 18. -- The Spanish cruiser Emperador Carlos V. has been ordered to Barcelona, where she will be used as a prison for the instigators of the opposition to the payment of taxes.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- The visit of the Czar to Potsdam serves to emphasize the fact that the Franco-Russian alliance does not preclude the most friendly relations between Germany and Russia, and also to make clear that, in the event of concerted action by France and Russia against Great Britain, the attitude of Germany is of preponderating importance.

It appears from the accouts coming from Manila that one of the difficulties of speedily ending the war is that the captured natives hide their arms in the brush, come in, many claiming to be "amigos," are turned loose, and go back to fight. It is suggested that all prisoners taken shall have their ears bored before being released.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- In accordance with General Order No. 16, recently issued from National Guard Headquarters, which provides that service in which organizations have borne a meritorious part may be engraved upon silver rings, fastened on the lances of the colors, another order was issued to-day designating those organizations that are entitled to carry one or more rings.

The first annual meet of the Intercollegiate Cross Country Association was held at Morris Park yesterday. The race, which was run over the regular steeplechase course, was for six and a quarter miles. Although the course was in rather poor condition on account of a drizzling rain, yet the time -- 34:05 2-5 -- made by Cregan of Princeton -- establishes a record for this track.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 17. -- Election day is nearly two weeks gone by, and yet every adult person in this State appears to be too deeply engrossed in discussing the contest for Governor to talk patiently, continuously, and with interest on any other topic. Not only here at the capital, for many reasons the focusing point for all conflicting reports, but at Louisville and other cities, the Goebel and Taylor partisans monopolize general attention.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 18. -- Probably the most sensational civil case ever tried in Montana came to a close this morning in the Supreme Court when the prosecution in the Wellcome disbarment case announced that it had no more rebuttal testimony to offer. The defense made a similar announcement, and both agreed to submit the case without oral argument.

Though the League of American Wheelmen will have been in existence twenty years next May, it is practically a young organization, owing to the fact that cycling is still in its early years, and many changes will have to be made in the plan of the organization before the officials will consider it nearly perfect.

THOSE engaged in working up a public sentiment against the Representative from Utah demand of the House of Representatives either that he be not allowed to take his seat, to which it is admitted that he was legally elected, or, after being admitted, that he be expelled. That the House can do either of these two things is extremely doubtful.

In this age of close competition the question of utility is always uppermost. "Try all things and hold fast that which is good" is old and sound advice; but the good in modern parlance has come to mean the good for something, the useful, that which contributes to the attainment of an end. The contests in life are so strenuous that he who would win must lay aside every impediment.

Wall Street is a syndicate of sentiment. When Wall Street is hopeful and confident and cheery market prices go up, and when Wall Street frets and fumes and watches for scarecrows quotations go down -- sentiment far beyond intrinsic value having effective influence. Exceptional illustration of this has been in view this week.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 18. -- On the links of the Weeburn Golf Club this afternoon the semi-finals and final rounds for the Vice President's cup were played. The cup is presented by Charles Stewart Smith. In the semi-finals W.L. Baldwin, handicap 3, beat W.B. Wheeler, handicap 2, by 5 up and 4 to play.

-- Although, as stated the other day, we can see no reason why a person who manipulates his or her own machine should not be allowed to typewrite the greater part, if not the whole, of his or her private correspondence, we share the general prejudice against putting communications even nominally personal into the form of printed circulars.

The "dry diggings" of the Kimberley district, in South Africa. afford the unique. locality in Which the diamond has thus far been found in its original home, and all our kn*owledge of the genesis of the mineral has been derived from study of this locality. The mines are located in "pans," in which is found the "blue ground" now recognized as the disintegrated matrix of the diamond.

A few days ago the report was printed that efforts would be made by railway officials to put a stop to the exactions of parlor and sleeping car porters. Although the report proved unfounded, it has led to quite a widespread discussion over the propriety of giving tips to waiters and others for personal services rendered.
Two cases of what is believed to be bubonic plague reached this port yesterday on the Lamport Holt steamer J.W. Taylor, coffee laden, from Santos, Brazil.

Wall Street is a syndicate of sentiment. When Wall Street is hopeful and confident and cheery market prices go up, and when Wall Street frets and fumes and watches for scarecrows quotations go down -- sentiment far beyond intrinsic value having effective influence. Exceptional illustration of this has been in view this week.
Two cases of what is believed to be bubonic plague reached this port yesterday on the Lamport Holt steamer J.W. Taylor, coffee laden, from Santos, Brazil.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Belated dispatches from Cape Town give Gen. Buller's reply to the application of Col. Schiel, the German officer captured at Elandslaagte, for a parole, in accordance with the alleged promise of Gen. White. Gen. Buller expresses regret that it is inconvenient to Col. Schiel, but declines to admit there is any breach of etiquette.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18. -- Mrs. Evangeline O'Neill of Chicago was arrested this afternoon at the Windsor Hotel on a charge of fraud involving the possession of diamonds, other precious stones, and jewelry valued at $50,000. It is charged that Mrs. O'Neill obtained possession of these valuables through legal proceeding of some kind and that she took the first train for Canada.

Two Canal Street business houses, less than a block apart, were entered by burglars yesterday afternoon and property valued at considerably over $2,000 was stolen. As a result of the two burglaries five men are locked up at the Leonard Street Police Station.

Prof. Vida D. Scudder of Wellesley College spoke before the League for Political Education yesterday morning on "The Modern Novel as a Social Document." The lecture room of the league's building, 23 West Forty-fourth Street, was crowded with members and their guests.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Chicago contractors and builders made an open declaration of war last night on the trades unions, charging them with causing the present apathy in building operations in the city and crippling municipal growth. An ultimatum, setting forth the employers' view of the situation, and stating the terms on which labor must meet capital after Jan. 1, 1900, was drawn up and presented to the Building Trades Council.
E.K. Warren, President of the village of Three Oaks, Mich., has telegraphed the following from that place:
Congratulations may be extended this morning on the anniversaries of their weddings to:

There has been organized recently in the Borough of the Bronx a corporation known as the Bronx Realty Company. As set forth in the company's charter its object is the purchase and improvement of real estate and the operating of the property so acquired for the profit of the company. Another branch of its business will be the purchase of unimproved property at forced sales and the resale of it, with loans, to responsible builders.

HAVANA, Nov. 18. -- A meeting of the delegates of the Cuban National League and the National Party was held last night and a stormy debate took place, which was described by some members present as at times almost chaotic. During the debate personalities were indulged in by various prominent persons taking part in the discussion.

Some surprise is expressed from day to day that the rate of foreign exchange is maintained so high as to prevent or delay the movement of gold from Europe to this market, but those who are directly engaged in exchange dealings find nothing mysterious about this, considering the conditions prevailing. These conditions are unusual, but in no way abnormal.

Albert Miller, a laborer, thirty-one years old, was arrested at 10 o'clock last night in a saloon at 1 Forsyth Street by Joseph Reitman, one of Superintendent McCullagh's deputies. Miller, who, the deputy alleges, is William Bennett, is charged with illegal registration in the First Election District of the Eighth Assembly District and a warrant was issued for his arrest prior to election day.

It was a graceful thing of the Woman's Art Club the other night when opening their little private show of pictures in the gallery of the new National Arts Club to select Miss Cecilia Beaux of Philadelphia as the guest of honor for their reception. That lady has just received the gold medal and money prize from an international jury at Pittsburg.

Promptly at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a blue flag bearing two white stars shot upward on the mainmast of the United States cruiser Chicago as she lay at anchor off Tompkinsville, S.I. A second later a salute of seventeen guns thundered forth, announcing that Rear Admiral Winfield Scott Schley had assumed formal command of the South Atlantic Station.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- The death in the almshouse of Dr. Isabel Mitchell of this city has disclosed a remarkable story. Brought to that institution a delirious sufferer from the garret of a house in which she was practically friendless and alone, she died without relatives at hand, and with a secret formula locked in her breast for which she had refused the sum of $50,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- The Yale freshmen in the game with the Princeton freshmen, at the Yale Field, this afternoon showed up stronger than was generally expected they would. The final score was: Princeton, 19; Yale, 6. The game was one characterized by great aggressive work by both sides, but poor defensive play.

Florence Crosby, residing at the Parker House, on West Thirty-ninth Street, was last night refused permission to remain in the Broadway Theatre, where Julia Arthur is playing "More Than Queen." She was accompanied by a Mr. Hughes, who had tickets for a box and when she left the house he went with her.

What can be the object of all this fuss about the salaries of the teachers? Who is going to make any political or other capital out of holding up these salaries? If any public official or officials are looking to advance his or their popularity by posing as watch dogs of the public treasury by curtailing the salaries of public school teachers they are likely to be disappointed.
In the course of a little "tiff" with the City Superintendent of Schools the other day Controller COLER, with a reference to Dr. MAXWELL that was neither good-tempered nor pertinent, said:

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- The Tribune says: "It is probable that the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy will build an extension to Ogden, Utah, and make connection there with the Southern Pacific. The proposed extension is not to be from Denver west, but is to run from Alliance, Neb., to Hartville, where there are large and valuable iron deposits, and thence due west fifty miles north of Cheyenne, Wyoming, to Ogden.
LORENZO MARQUES, Nov. 18. -- The following dispatch has been received here from Pretoria, dated Nov. 16:

SIOUX FALLS, South Dakota, Nov. 19. -Six men were killed and four seriously, if not fatally, injured in an accident this evening on the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railroad at Humboldt, twenty miles west of Sioux Falls.

PRETORIA, Nov. 18 -- (By way of Lorenzo Marques, Nov. 19.) -- At noon to-day fifty-six British prisoners, including men of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers and several blue-jackets, arrived here. There were large crowds at the railway station, but no demonstration was made.

The Pulpit Committee of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, by a majority vote, decided last evening to recommend to the Session, for approval by the congregation, the Rev. G. Campbell Morgan, pastor of the New Court Congregational Church of London, as successor to the late Rev. Dr. John Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The annual report of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, William A. Jones, besides reviewing the progress of affairs in all branches of the service, urges more schools, more systematic methods, study of individual traits, and consideration of subsequent environment in outlining studies in the Indian schools. The entire educational system of the Indian Office, he says, is predicated upon the final abolishment of the anomalous Indian reservation system.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The Hamburg-American liner Patria, Capt. Frolich, which caught fire in the English Channel last Wednesday, while on her way from New York, for Hamburg, and which was finally abandoned Thursday noon, when all attempts to tow her to some port had failed, now lies between Walmar and the South Foreland, on the Kentish coast.

LORD KITCHENER OPENS THE NILE VALLEY FOR TOURISTS. -- Lord Kitchener's expected decisive battle with the Khalifa did not occur. Lord Kitchener appeared in battle array a Jebel Gedir, but the bird had flown. His Lordship has now returned to Cairo. Squadrons of cavalry and of the camel corps will continue to cover the territory extending 100 miles south of Khartoum.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- S.I. Morris will tomorrow file a suit for $30,000 against the Illinois Steel Company for services in securing the passage of the Calumet and Blue Island ordinance in 1895. He claims that he spent $20,000 of his own money in "entertaining" Aldermen, and that his services were worth $10,000 more.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Navigation Commissioner Chamberlain's annual report discloses more satisfactory conditions than have existed in any former year in the bureau's history. The total documented tonnage on June 30, 1899, comprised 22,728 vessels, of 4,864,238 gross tons, the largest since 1865.

Influenced by the easier conditions of money, the outside market during the past week was active and strong. As money market stringency and the fear of the conditions that might arise in that market were the chief impediments to curb market improvement, so, when easier rates prevailed and the outlook for the immediate future became better, stocks in the outside market almost immediately reflected the change.

The church world of Brooklyn learned with surprise and regret yesterday that the Rev. Dr. Richard Salter Storrs had brought to an end his pastorate of fifty-three years in the Congregational Church of the Pilgrims. The resignation of Dr. Storrs as pastor was read at the close of the services yesterday morning.
DURBAN, Natal, Nov. 18. -- The Times of Natal publishes the following, dated Wednesday, Nov. 15, from its special correspondent at Ladysmith:

The school teachers of Queens Borough have learned with concern that on account of certain action by the Queens Borough School Board they may have no claim against the city for salaries during the months of November or December.

All sorts of delays transpired in the work of changing the motive power of the lower section of the Third Avenue surface railroad from cable to electricity yesterday, and early this morning, after one of his many trips of inspection along the line, Superintendent J.H. Robertson said that the change, which it was publicly announced would be effected in the course of a few hours, could not possibly be completed before some time to-day.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 19. -- Advices just received here show that on Thursday, Nov. 16, a combined force of Free State and Transvaal burghers occupied Colesburg, Cape Colony, without opposition by the residents and proclaimed the district to be Free State territory.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Chicago engineers are designing the earthquake-proof steel palace for the Crown Prince of Japan, which is to mark the advent of American steel construction in the Mikado's land, and the imperial Government has appropriated $3,000,000 for its erection. Foundations are being laid with a view to rearing the framework in February.
LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The Shamrock, which left New York Nov. 2, arrived in the Clyde at midnight.

A new turn was given the discussion in the closing canvass for the Colonelcy of the Seventy-first Regiment yesterday, when it was learned that the papers in the case of four newly elected officers who are avowed partisans of Major C.H. Smith had failed to reach the brigade examining board, with the result that they will not receive their commissions from Albany in time to vote at the election of a Colonel to-night.

A thrilling attempt to rescue Michael Conlon, the engineer of the buildings 94, 96, and 98 Mort Street, which were recently destroyed by fire, was revealed yesterday in a report made to Fire Chief Croker by Chief of Battalion Callaghan. Chief Croker has recommended that the two firemen mentioned in the report be placed on the roll of merit for their heroism.

Lemuel E. Quigg, President of the Republican County Committee, issued yesterday a formal statement in regard to the result of the recent election and the lesson to be drawn from it. Mr. Quigg's statement is virtually a reply to the criticisms of his conduct of the campaign which have been made by Republican district leaders and Republican newspapers within the last two weeks.
CUXHAVEN, Nov. 19. -- Capt. Frolich of the Patria, in the course of an interview today, made the following statement:

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Last week was much quieter in the credit market than had been anticipated. For reasons explained in my last letter everybody feared large applications at the Bank of England on Wednesday, and not one took place. On Tuesday a few loans were taken, but from fright, not necessity.
LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Lady White, wife of Sir George Stewart White. British commander at Ladysmith, was received in audience by the Queen at Windsor Castle this afternoon.

The delegate of the Pipe Calkers and Tappers' Union complained yesterday to the Central Federated Union that a gas company at Mount Vernon had brought over a large number of non-union men from Philadelphia, and was employing them in the places of good union workingmen of that town.
The Merchants' Association has had in hand for some time a general plan for the betterment of the postal facilities of this city and of its sister cities throughout the United States.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott spoke last evening before the People's Institute at Cooper Union on "Christ's Laws of Life." It was the first of a series of five addresses that he will deliver upon the subject.

Last Thursday the French Chamber of Deputies by a vote of 340 to 215 gave an inspiring approval of the work thus far performed by the Waldeck-Rousseau Ministry. It is a stable majority, as far as concerns the defense of the republic. Respect for law, for order, for reform, and a determination to protect republican institutions brought it together.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 19. -- Sylvia Heyward, the seven-year-old daughter of Bernard Heyward, an embalmer, died this afternoon from the effects of a peculiar accident. The little girl attended St. Ludwig's Catholic School, at Eighth and Walnut Streets. Last Wednesday, when recess time was announced, the child, in her anxiety to reach the playgrounds, ran out of the room with a slate pencil in her hand.
MANILA, Nov. 19. -- The following dispatches have been received here from correspondents accompanying the American advance northward:

BLOCK ISLAND, Nov. 19. -- The quaintest and most original community on the American coast is Block Island. It is a miniature world, in which the customs and habits of 150 years ago still prevail. Every head of a household on the island is both a fisherman and a farmer. By both occupations he manages to eke out a fair living.

HAVANA, Nov. 19. -- Since the Cuban League and the National Party joined forces there has been but little harmony at the meetings of the delegates. Matters have gone from bad to worse, and the proceedings have become more and more disorderly. Gen. Collazo is not alone in his refusal to co-operate further in the joint deliberations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- The members of the football team are apparently none the worse for their difficult struggle with Washington and Jefferson yesterday. Every player is practically in as good condition as when he entered the game, and will begin this week's practice with lots of snap and dash as a final preparation for the game with Yale on Saturday.
The New York Council now has a clear lead in the Royal Arcanum League. The Alco Club holds the same position in the Arlington National tournament.

A number of the old friends and parishioners of the Rev. Sylvester Malone, pastor of Sts. Peter and Paul's Church, Brooklyn, desirous of giving him the opportunity to witness the completion of the last of his many works for the welfare of the people in the Williamsburg section, will give an entertainment on Thursday evening in the Henry McCaddin Memorial Building, Berry Street, in aid of the Father Sylvester Malone Free Library.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 19. -- William Goebel's only hope of reaching the Gubernatorial chair of Kentucky now rests with the Democratic Legislature. Even it will be unable to save him unless the State Board of Election Commissioners, which will meet on Nov. 27 to canvass the returns, perpetrates some action which, in view of the official count, can be little less than a bold and outright theft.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 19. -- The British steamer Atrato, from Barranquilla Tuesday and Colon Friday, reports a widespread revolutionary movement in Colombia and a grave outlook. Her cargo she landed with difficulty, and she was unable to secure an outward cargo owing to the suspension of inland transportation.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 19. -- Grace Evangeline O'Neill is still at the Windsor Hotel with her little girl, Jean, and with them is Henry J. O'Neill, the Chicago broker, known as the "Barley King."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The current number of the Weekly Health Reports, issued by the Marine Hospital Service, contains brief information concerning the bubonic plague at Santos, Brazil, from which port the steamship Taylor, having cases of the disease aboard, arrived in New York yesterday.

ROSLYN, L.I., Nov. 19. -- The sensational statements in some of the New York papers this morning which affirmed that Rawlins L. Cottenet was probably fatally and C. Albert Stevens very badly injured while riding to hounds with the Meadow Brook Hunt yesterday caused considerable astonishment among the members of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club, and brought many anxious inquiries from friends of the Cottenet and Stevens families.
LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The War Office posted the following telegram from Gen. Sir Redvers Buller to the Marquis of Lansdowne:

Anton Krumenacker, a farmer, who lived with his wife and eight children at Foster's Meadows, L.I., died at St. Catharine's Hospital, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning after surviving for nearly twenty-four hours injuries that would have killed most men instantly. The farmer set out for the city on Saturday morning with a load of produce.

The Forty-first Volunteer Infantry, which was recruited from the country at large, and which has been preparing for service at Camp Meade, Penn., reached the city early yesterday morning, and immediately went aboard the transport Logan, which will leave port this afternoon, bound for the Philippines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19. -- The Harvard eleven broke training very quietly last night, and with none of the usual celebration. The election of a Captain was postponed for about three weeks, in order to give the men a chance to talk the matter over.

The wave of sympathetic appreciation that swept over the more respectable organs of French public opinion when Sir GEORGE WHITE'S dispatch announcing his defeat at Ladysmith was made known has been noted. It was a personal, an intimate appreciation, that might have been expected from a people to whom the traditions of BAYARD have always been dear. It was the expression of deep-felt emotion, sincere but transitory, unstudied and spontaneous.

President Alfred Walter of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company said last evening that the purchase of the New York Lighterage and Transportation Company by the railroad company was an accomplished fact.

NORFOLK. Va., Nov. 20. -- According to reports ten ships are ashore in the Straits of Magellan. The steamship Kurdistan, Capt. Littlehale, reported six, and the Heedless, Capt. Milton, reported four. Each vessel came through the straits bound here for coal, and had an extremely rough voyage.

What promises to be the greatest sale of trotting and pacing stock ever held, was inaugurated by the Fasig-Tipton Company at Madison Square Garden yesterday morning. The sale will continue nine days, and daring this time will be offered more than 800 trotters and pacers, a large number of them being the most fashionably bred and fastest in the country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- The Democratic National Executive Committee, with National Chairman J.K. Jones in the chair, spent most of to-day in a room in the Sherman House discussing matters pertaining to organization, ways and means, and the administrative affairs of the organization. The committee will meet again to-morrow and it is expected will get through with the business on hand before night.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 20. -- The Democratic State Campaign Committee concedes that Taylor has a plurality on the face of the returns, but bases a hope of the election of the Democratic ticket on throwing out the vote of Louisville on account of interference of Gov. Bradley's soldiers, and Johnson and Knox Counties, where tissue ballots were used.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- David Belasco announced to the public to-day that Mrs. Leslie Carter will remain in Columbus another two weeks, as a result of her severe illness from tonsilitis. Mrs. Carter hopes to be able to appear in St. Louis Dec. 4, but intermediate dates have been canceled. Mrs. Carter has made a request for a return date to this city, as Columbus has been kind to her in her illness.
LONDON, Nov. 20. -- At the Marquis of Lansdowne's suggestion, the Queen has decided that her Christmas present to the troops in South Africa is to take the form of a tin of chocolate for each man.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- Judge George K. Nash, Republican, was elected Governor of Ohio on Nov. 7 by a plurality of 49,023. Of the total vote, Judge Nash received 417,199, John R. McLean, Democrat, 368,176, and Samuel M. Jones, non-partisan, 106,721.

Le Temps takes an exceedingly pessimistic view of the French Government's attempt to set up the tri-color in the French Soudan, so-called. Among the vociferations of the Paris press at the time of Commandant MARCHAND'S exploration achievement, Le Temps was the only paper over there which seemed to see in the affair no great cause for national enthusiasm.

Gov. Roosevelt will resume to-morrow morning his series of conferences with Senator Platt concerning the affairs of the State. These conferences were very frequent during the last session of the Legislature, and especially during that part of it in which measures affecting this city were under discussion. They were practically discontinued after the adjournment of the Legislature, and the Governor and Senator met infrequently during the Summer and early Autumn.

Mr. and Mrs. Kendal, who were received with genuine cordiality at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night, both have exceptionally suitable and effective roles in the play new to this town, which they used as the medium of their reappearance and will keep in their bill throughout their engagement.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- After an absence of thirty years James Edwards, whose home is now in Denver, returned to this city and discovered that his wife had been divorced from him and married to another man. Thirty-five years ago Edwards married Miss Belle Hickman of this city, whose parents were wealthy. Edwards was in poor circumstances, and his wife's mother opposed the marriage.

It is plain enough that the dispatches which pass the British censorship do not accurately represent the condition of the South African campaign. These dispatches have been representing the point of chief military interest as Ladysmith, where Gen. WHITE is beleaguered. Now we are suddenly apprised that a British Brigadier is making his way by forced marches to the relief of Kimberley.

Never before were so many promoters actively at work in this city as at present. Them are to be found in all the leading hotels, and all of them interviewed in the past week expressed the opinion that they are being seriously hampered by the tightening of the money market, yet trusts are forming that will require enormous sums to finance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20. -- The entire Yale 'Varsity squad was on the practice field this afternoon without as much as a bruise or any lameness, for the first time since the struggle with Harvard. The practice was extremely light, and lasted only a few minutes. It consisted entirely of signal work to get the men limbered up for heavier work during the next few days.

It is not at all surprising that the politicians are stirred up by the possibility that the employes in the counties of larger size are to be subjected to the civil service rules. The county offices have long been the stronghold of the spoils system, and until last Winter it was found impossible to get them included under the principle laid down by the Constitution.

Yesterday's evening papers relate that the counsel for the prosecution and the defense in the case of MOLINEUX agree that "they see no reason why the work of getting the jury should not be finished this week."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- One of the first matters of business laid before Secretary Long to-day was the sailing orders to be given to Rear Admiral Schley.

MANILA, Nov. 20. -- There has been a revival of insurgent activity south of Manila, particularly in Cavite Province. At Imus yesterday the Filipinos fired a smooth-bore cannon, but this was soon silenced by the American artillery.
Alfred Seton, Jr., has sold for Mandelbaum Lewine to G.E. Coleman the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 44 West Thirty-eighth Street, 20 by 98.9.

A handsome T-cart belonging to C. W. Schultz, drawn by a ligh-stepping black horse, in charge of Philip Reilly, a groom, of 1t7 West Eighty-ninth Street. was proceeding rapidly north on the East Drive in Central Park about 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the horse took fright opposite the Casino, seized the bit in his teeth, and began to run.
The Brokerage Committee of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange will meet to-day.

The report and opinion of the Inter-State Commerce Commission has just been published in the case of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway Company, involving practically the same principles as the Chattanooga case recently decided by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at Cincinnati.

The second week of the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the alleged murder on Dec. 28 last of Katherine J. Adams opened auspiciously yesterday in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions before Recorder Goff by the selection of three more jurors who are to determine the question of the guilt or innocence of the accused.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 20. -- Oscar G. Fleming, the Princess Anne County Magistrate who last Thursday shot and killed young Clarence L. Snyder, while the latter, accompanied by a friend, was returning to this city from a hunt, this morning killed one of a party who attempted to lynch him.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 20. -- The German steamer Olinda, Capt. Hansen, from Matanzas, Cuba, to New York, with a general cargo, put into Hampton Roads this morning signalling the Cape Henry station "On fire; send help."

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals to-day rendered an opinion in the case of the Howard Savings Institution of Newark against the City of Newark. The saving's bank had appealed from an assessment which included the United States securities held by the institution.

Manager Edwin Knowles of the Fifth Avenue Theatre denies a report that James A. Herne's new play, "Sag Harbor," is to be presented at his theatre. It is not likely that Mrs. Fiske's season in this city with "Becky Sharp" will be interrupted until the week beginning Dec. 18, which will probably mark the last week of her engagement.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Reports of railroad companies operating steam surface, elevated, and street surface roads, made to the State Railroad Commissioners for the quarter ended Sept. 30, show big gains in earnings over the corresponding quarter in 1898.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The following bond purchases to-day under the recent offer of the Secretary of the Treasury, are reported: St. Louis, $10,200; Baltimore, $4,100; Philadelphia, $116,000; Boston, $19,750; Cincinnati, $58,700.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The plan of operations on both sides is slowly unfolding itself. Glen. Joubert is evidently moving south to prevent, if possible, the junction of the British relieving force with the forces at Estcourt and Ladysmith; while, on the Orange River border, the Boers are believed to be concentrating at Donkerpoort to oppose Gen. Buller's advance.

Something happened to the motor on Eighth Avenue Electric Car No. 1,709 as it was nearing Eighty-fourth Street last night, and there was a pyrotechnic display that gave the passengers a mild scare. The car was stopped and the passengers made haste to get out.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- Cornell began work this afternoon for her final game of the season, which will be played with the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia on Thanksgiving Day. Coach Haughton was again in charge of the team, having returned from Cambridge this morning. He found the men quite recovered from any injuries which they were suffering.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- While the Czar was at Potsdam recently, the general lines of a prospective commercial treaty between Germany and Russia were reached. Emperor William, the Czar, Dr. von Miquel, and M. de Witte discussed the whole situation, including the financial crisis in Russia.

Servatius and Estabrook played off the tie for first place in the Class B amateur billiard tournament at Schaefer's Academy last night, and the former won. The game was interesting and very exciting. The prize a silver cup, will be presented to the winner on Dec. 5. The score:
WINDSOR, England, Nov. 20. -- Following the programme mapped out for the visit of Emperor William of Germany to Queen Victoria, the imperial party is now at the castle.
ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- It is stated on excellent authority here that all of the Constitutional amendments voted upon by the people at the last election have been adopted.

Capt. Waters and the cook of the steamship J.W. Taylor, who were sent to the Swinburne Island Hospital Saturday suffering from what was believed to be bubonic plague, were reported yesterday to be doing well. Drs. L'Hommedieu and Fitzpatrick returned from the island late yesterday afternoon after examining the patients, and Dr. L'Hommedieu then made the following statement:
Mr. R.M. Olyphant, President of the Delaware and Hudson Company, takes a decidedly optimistic view of the general business situation and outlook. He says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Three cable dispatches were received at the War Department to-day from Gen. Otis. They are all dated to-day but received at different times. The first, received at 2:15 A.M., says:

Major William G. Bates was elected Colonel of the Seventy-first Regiment at the election held at the armory last night. The choice of the candidate was unanimous, every one of the twenty-four commissioned officers of the regiment being present and voting.

There is one consideration with reference to the apparently plausible notion that we can adopt the same policy toward the Philippines that we have set forth in regard to Cuba which would be fatal to it if there were no other objection.
LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Lady Salisbury, wife of the Premier, who had been in ill-health for a long time past, suffering a second stroke of paralysis in July last, died this afternoon at Hatfield House.

The new trouble in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, caused by the recent action of the majority of the Session in reinstating Herman Warszawiak to membership, final action in the case being by appeal and complaint transferred to the Presbytery, was complicated yesterday when the matter came up for adjudication in the adjourned meeting of that body from the preceding Monday.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 20. -- The carriage spring and axle manufacturers are preparing to consolidate, and an application will be made shortly for a New Jersey charter.

The Extraordinary Term of the Supreme Court ordered by Gov. Roosevelt convened yesterday in the County Court House, Justice William E. Werner of Rochester presiding. The Grand Jury was sworn in, Louis A. Lehmaier being designated by the Court to act as foreman. After the jurors had been sworn, Justice Werner addressed them in part as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The latest development in the make-up of the team which is to meet Yale on Saturday is that the Seminole, Craig, who came out only a week ago in order to make the tackle positions stronger by a good substitute, and who yesterday was put in at guard in place of Mills, who was injured, is blossoming like the rose under the tutelage of Holt.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 21. -- The Southern Railway has in a neat way extricated itself from the dilemma in which it was placed last Spring when the Seaboard acquired the south-bound division of the Florida Central and Peninsular, which the Southern had been using for its Florida connections. Its lease expires Jan. 1, but the Southern has found a parallel outlet from Columbia to Savannah.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The Rev. Dr. S.E. Wishard, Superintendent of the Home Mission work for the Presbyterian Synod in Utah, one of the two Protestant ministers who attended the lecture of the Mormon Elder Edward H. Snow in Brooklyn last night, and openly challenged the truth of some of the latter's statements concerning polygamy, delivered a lecture on "The Mormon Menace" to-night in the First Presbyterian Church here.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 21. -- Charles E. Stewart, the aged prisoner who is accused of swindling at Woonsocket, was taken back to Rhode Island to-night in charge of three big detectives. The officers were afraid of habeas corpus proceedings, but no fight was made against extradition. The parting interview between Stewart and his wife was most pathetic. She is left here penniless and without friends.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- The sentiment of the members of the Democratic National Executive Committee is unanimous that the Democratic National Convention next year should indorse the Chicago platform in its entirety and that anti-trust and anti-imperialistic planks should also be adopted. None was willing to express an opinion as to the paramount issue in the campaign.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Committee of One Hundred and Seventy-five, of South Brooklyn, will hold a meeting at 201 Montague Street, Brooklyn, to-morrow evening to further its campaign against the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company. Delegates from many organizations will be present to formulate plans for more concerted action against the company.

Col. Alpheus E. Clarke died on Monday at his home, 63 Grand Street, Jersey City, of heart disease. His body yesterday was conveyed for burial to Uniontown, Penn., where he had a sister and other relatives living. He was fifty-seven years old. Col. Clarke came into rather conspicuous notice about three years ago through an episode which had its beginning when he was a young Lieutenant stationed at Fort Hamilton.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 21. -- United States Senator Sewell, who was a warm personal friend of Mr. Hobart, was deeply affected upon receiving information of the Vice President's death. "Mr. Hobart had the capacity for almost any business or any profession,'' Senator Sewell said, "and was about the best-equipped all-around man we had in the State.

* * * The United States hereby disclaim any purpose or intention to exercise sovereignty, jurisdiction, or control over said island, except for the pacification thereof, and declare that when that shall have been accomplished they will withdraw and leave the island and its government to its own people.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Circuit Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick, who was a college companion of Mr. Hobart in New Brunswick, said to-day: "Our Vice President was taken away from us at a time when, with his vigorous mind, and immense energy, he was in a position to be of incalculable service to his country.

Gov. Roosevelt decided yesterday that he will appoint a Commissioner at once to take testimony in the matter of the charges preferred against District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner by the members of the Municipal Government Committee of the City Club. This decision was reached after a long conference with the Attorney General and the members of the committee, and after the entire charges had been examined by the Attorney General.

The talk of a Democratic triumvirate in Brooklyn was revived yesterday, when it became known that James Shevlin and Senator Michael J. Coffey had been in conference the day before, and that Mr. Shevlin, accompanied by Senator P.H. McCarren, afterward paid a visit to Richard Croker in Manhattan.

As one of your subscribers and daily readers, I desire to call earnest attention to a most important and valuable subject. In your columns of to-day, Tuesday, Nov. 21, you publish an article headed "Tonsils and Infection -- Physician Advises Their Removal as Preventive of Disease."

The negotiations which the Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company of America have been for the last few weeks carrying on in an effort to bring together the independent, or anti-Bell, concerns of the country have not come to an end, as far as this city is concerned, in spite of previous announcements to the contrary.

WINDSOR, England, Nov. 21. -- The State banquet in honor of the Emperor and Empress of Germany, which was held to-night in St. George's Hall, was an unusually brilliant affair. At either end of the table was arranged a specially constructed sideboard, on which was piled up the gold plate to the height of fifteen feet.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 21. -- The trouble which has been brewing for some time between the people of Rio Grande City and the negro troops of the Ninth Cavalry at Fort Ringgold came to a climax last night, when a pitched battle took place between the negro garrison and several hundred armed men from the town.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The stockholders of the Union Traction Company have voted to increase the number of Directors from seven to eleven. The object of this is to secure a larger Chicago representation on the board. The new Directors will be chosen at an adjourned meeting, to be held on Dec. 13.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21. -- The former Baltimore and Liverpool liner Queensmore, now known as the Manchester Enterprise, has foundered at sea. All hands have been saved. The news of the disaster reached Baltimore to-day from Cape Henry, when the Donaldson Line steamer Lakonia passed in from Antwerp.

The resignation by Dr. RICHARD S. STORRS of the pastorate of the Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn is not a matter of merely local importance. At least it affords an opportunity of recognizing the great service that the venerable preacher has in his time rendered to the whole country, and which we may all hope that he will be spared to continue.

TRENTON, Nov. 21. -- There was a large attendance of the Republican members of the next Legislature at P.e State House to-day. The .organization of the House was discussed, and it is almost settled that enjamin F. Jones of Essex will be Speaker, and Asselnblyman Vakelee of Bergen liepublican leader.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Numerous railroads have petitioned the inter..State Com. merce Commission for a further extension of time in whichto equip their cars with automatic coupiers ana train brakes. The commission have fixed Dec. 6 next as the date when the petitioners will be heard, and invite all parties interested to appear at that time or file statements for or against such extension.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Aaron Wolfsohn surprised his uncle, S. Blumenthal, a wholesale liquor dealer, by calling on him while en route for the East. His appearance at the Blumenthal residence was unexpected to the last degree, and his reception was as much a surprise to him as it was to his uncle and aunt.

Yesterday was again devoted to the country by the men and women of leisure, who, in the continued beautiful mild Autumn weather, golfed and rode to hounds all day and gathered at evening around big wood fires in country clubs and houses to tell of the day's pleasures and to plan for those of the morrow.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- Before the Court of Appeals to-day arguments were made by former Attorney General Theodore E. Hancock and former United States Senator David B. Hill in the case of the State ex rel. the State Board of Charities against the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

William F. Miller, manager of the Franklin Syndicate, was arrested yesterday by Deputy Sheriff O'Donnell of Kings County on an order of arrest granted by Justice Bookstaver in a civil suit for $50,000 damages for slander brought by E.L. Blake of 20 Broad Street, the editor of a financial paper. Miller has been doing business at 144 Floyd Street, Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 21. -- Six months ago a stranger committed suicide in this city. While the body was at the morgue it was identified as that of Aaron Wolfsohn of St. Louis. The local agent of the New York Life Insurance Company reported that Aaron Wolfsohn had taken out a ten-thousand-dollar life insurance policy some time before his death.

In answer to the letter of "A.M.," Nov. 1, and also to "W.H.R.," of Nov. 7, about the "Local Postal Service," kindly allow me, through your valuable paper, to express my appreciation of the highly efficient service maintained at the New York Post Office.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 21. -- Henry Veazey of Cincinnati, a traveling salesman for the whisky firm of Frank Tullidge Co., is in New York, consulting with his lawyers about a suit for a very large sum of money, said to be $1,000,000. The defendants are Henry Allen Co. of New York, stock brokers.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 21. -- The much discussed Fowler-Chase case was compromised to-day and the insanity proceedings in the Circuit Court were dropped. The motion to dismiss was objected to by the defense, and the cause was submitted to the Court, who heard briefly the evidence of local physicians and decided the defendant to be of sound mind, the prosecution offering no objections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- A subject whieh is much discussed just now is the probable effect of Admiral Dewey's transfer of his house upon the home fund for Admiral Schley. The general opinion is that it will injure the fund, at least-as far as Washington is concerned. The attitude of the public in the matter of the ._dmiral's home has changed vastly.
