Probably the largest progressive euchre party ever held in Brooklyn was given last night at the Knapp mansion, Bedford Avenue and Ross Street, Williamsburg, under the auspices of the Ladies' Aid Society, attached to St. Catharine's Hospital, for the benefit of sick poor in the institution. More than $1,000 was realized. There were 400 tables, and so great was the crush that many were unable to gain admission.

-- Terrible as undoubtedly is the disease, two cases of which are believed to have been brought, to this port by the steamer J.W. Taylor, there is no excuse whatever for even the beginning of a panic, and little for anxiety. The bubonic plague is slowly making its way around the world, but the severity of its ravages is proportioned to the sanitary condition of the cities it enters.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Garret A. Hobart, Vice President of the United States, died this morning. Warning that his long, brave fight with death had been in vain, and that his end was nigh, came yesterday afternoon in the shape of a sharp attack of angina pectoris. He rallied from this for a brief space, but his vitality was exhausted.

TAUNTON, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Joseph F. McMahon was shot and probably fatally wounded while asleep at his home here early this morning. John Gallagher, McMahon's brother-in-law, did the shooting and escaped before the police arrived at the house.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The Lafayette Memorial Commission announces to-day that the United States Mint at Philadelphia will soon begin striking the Lafayette dollar authorized by Congress in aid of the monument. The coin, a legal tender, will bear upon its face in bas relief a double medallion of the heads of Washington and Lafayette, and upon its reverse a miniature reproduction of the equestrian statue of Lafayette, to be used on the monument.

A rumor that the old buildings 36 to 42 Broadway, running through to New Street, had been sold to a syndicate of Chicago capitalists, was denied last evening by the owner of those properties, Woodbury G. Langdon. The property has been on the market for some time, but Mr. Langdon says that, so far as he knows, it is not at present involved in any negotiations that could be called active.
CAPE TOWN, Nov. 21. -- The Midland News says that Messrs. Vanderwalt and Gober, members of the Cape Assembly, have joined the Boer forces at Colesburg.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Vice president Hobart's funeral on Saturday will be attended by the President and his Cabinet, the Supreme Court, the Senate in a body, and a large committee from the House of Representatives, besides many other high dignitaries of the Government, who will journey to Paterson to pay their last tribute of respect to the memory of the Vice President.

The Third Avenue Railroad Company early yesterday morning practically completed its change of equipment from cable to electricity by getting its electric trolley cars through from Fort Lee to Chambers Street, and throughout the day passengers were transported at a rate a little less than the required schedule time of the cable system. The cars ran throughout the bus}hess hours of the day 6n a one-and-a-half-minute schedule.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 21. -- The work of the Indian team this evening was devoted mainly to the much-needed signal practice and a first trial of some intricate tricks designed by Coach Warner for Oberlin University's confusion. The playing was very snappy, every man being energetic, as the authorities have lately given an intimation that no man's position is assured solely on grounds of reputation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- For the second day this week Yale's practice was very light, and consisted only of signal drill and catching punts for the 'Varsity. The practice was all open to the public, and it is Capt. McBride's intention to have it so during the rest of the week. The first half hour was devoted to signal work.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The Rev. Father Michael Curren, assistant pastor of the Gloucester City Roman Catholic Church, is under bonds to answer an assault charge made against him by the Rev. Father Peter J. Connolly, pastor of the church. The bail was taken late last night in this city by Justice Schmidt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Church to-day placed itself on record against the seating of Representative-elect Brigham H. Roberts of Utah in the next Congress. The matter came up when the appropriation for mission work in Utah was under discussion. Bishop Warren presented the following resolution:

The attention of Superintendent Blair of the Outdoor Poor Department was called yesterday to a white woman with two pretty mulatto girls, who has been visiting the Morgue and acting strangely for several days. An Inspector found out that the woman was the wife of James G. Spaulding, a colored porter, supposed to be employed on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The latest direct news from Ladysmith, dated Nov. 16 and Nov. 17, strangely conflicts with the reiterated reports of "tremendous battles and great British victories," Wednesday and Thursday. Neither of the above referred to messages, though dispatched on the days following the dates of the alleged fights, mention any great engagements or Boer defeats.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- George Goodwin Dewey, Admiral Dewey's only son, is now the owner of the residence presented to the Admiral by the American people.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Regrets were expressed on all sides to-day when the news of the death of Vice President Hobart reaced here. Attorney General Gray made a formal announcement of the death to the Court of Errors and Appeal, which is in session here. Mr. Gray said that Mr. Hobart was a distinguished Jerseyman and a member of the bar of the State.

PHILADELUHIA, Nov. 21. -- All the members of the University of Pennsylvania football team were out on Franklin Field to-day and started the practice for the Cornell game, which will be played here on Thanksgiving Day.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 21. -- The Republicans of Kansas are talking about presenting a medal to Mrs. Ellen F. Keleher of Graham County. Mrs. Keleher, who is the Register of Deeds of that county, was first elected in 1897 and re-elected this month.

MARLBOROUGH, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Florence Beatrice Pigott, once a member of the Metropolitan Opera Company's ballet, New York, died here yesterday at the home of her aunt, Mrs. John Odell. Consumption was the cause of her death.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- Ex-Policeman Hannigan of the New York City police force, who, while on duty on Thanksgiving Day, 1897, shot and painfully wounded a boy named Charles L. McNally, who was running away from him, will have to serve his sentence of two years in State Prison, meted out to him in the trial court.

The Chamber of Commerce, some 350 strong, met in Delmonico's main banquet hall last night for its one hundred and thirty-first annual banquet. Music, good cheer, and good oratory characterized the occasion this year, as they have characterized it from time immemorial. The presence of well-known merchants, bankers, scholars, divines, and public men was as much a feature as ever, and the dinner was a thorough and a harmonious success.

Ferdinand Poggenburg retained his lead in the inter-city and inter-club handicap amateur billiard tournament at Slosson's Academy by defeating Frank A. Keeney last night in an interesting game. The men played an even game for twenty innings, when a series of good runs by Poggenburg gave him a decided advantage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Secretary of State Hay said to-day of Mr. Hobart's death: "Mr. Hobart was a man of such a peculiarly amiable and delightful character that the loss is felt distinctly as a personal one by every member of the Government who had come in contact with him.
AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 21. -- This afternoon Gov. Sayers sent the following telegram to the Secretary of War at Washington:

MANILA, Nov. 21. -- The United States gunboat Helena arrived at Kamaguin during the night of Nov. 12. The watchers of the wrecked cruiser Charleston saw her lights and thought there was a fire upon a near-by island, whereupon they began to take steps to help those endangered. But, as the searchlights of the Helena communicated her presence, the village where the men of the Charleston were located rang with their cheers.

EASTPORT, L.I., Nov. 21. -- Mrs. Delia Nichols, a divorced woman, who lives in the Mills House, a mile outside of this village, has complained to the authorities that on Saturday night she was the victim of a "whitecap" outrage. It is asserted by others that the affair was only a prank of a party of young men.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 21. -- The Kentucky Democrats are in a despondent mood. The refusal of the Jefferson County Commissioners to do Goebel's bidding has greatly disconcerted them. They generally share in the popular belief that their candidate will not fill the Gubernatorial chair.

The Board of Public Improvements, by a unanimous vote, decided yesterday to defer all action on the proposed contract with the Ramapo Water Company for three months, in order to allow the Merchants' Association to make a thorough investigation of the city's water supply and the advisability of increasing it, either by municipal ownership or by contract with a private corporation.

NAPOLEON, Ohio, Nov. 22. -- Frederick Klinder and his son Henry, farmers near here, were arrested at noon to-day charged with the murder of Mrs. Frederick Klinder in 1894. At the time the woman's body was found in the garden near her home with her throat cut, and a knife wound near her heart. Suicide was alleged.

A wealthy Danish noblewoman, who spends much of her time in doing missionary work and in relieving the poor, arrived in this city in her yacht on Tuesday. She is Adeline, Countess Schimmelmann, and Countess of Lindenborg, and her other titles on her card designate her as "Extraordinary Lady of the Convent of Valloe and Lady of Honor to H.I.M., the late Empress Augusta of Germany."

NASHVILLE, Tenn. Nov. 22. -- Gen. Joe Wheeler has written a letter from Santa Rita, Island of Luzon. Philippine Islands, to a friend in Huntsville, Ala., in which he gives a history of the islands, and his opinion on whether or not they should be retained by the United States. He is emp hatically in favor of this policy and in his letter gives his reasons as follows:

MANILA, Nov. 23. -- News from the pursuit of Aguinaldo is not expected for a day or two. Yesterday a report reached Gen. Lawton, by courier from Gen. Young, that people knowing the country think that Aguinaldo's destination is Ilocos.

During the last two days a large real estate deal has been put through on Staten Island. A tract of land containing in all about 450 acres has been sold by Daniel T. Cornell of Stapleton to Charles G. Dickerson, representing a syndicate. The land was formerly the property of the Mersereaus, Moores, Coles, Simonsons, and others.

In the almost universal condemnation of Admiral Dewey's action regarding his transfer of the house given him by the people of America, would it not be well for us all to stop, for a moment, to look "at the other side"?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The deed transferring the Dewey home from Admiral and Mrs. Dewey to the Admiral's son George was recorded in the office of the Recorder of Deeds to-day. A life interest in the property is reserved by Admiral Dewey and his wife in the following provision:

In your issue of Nov. 15 I wrote that the tipping habit originates from intelligent, noble-minded and characteristic people. To substantiate my assertion I wish to show your readers a few comparisons. There is yet one Solomon to be found who can in any manner demonstrate that this "vice" is an imported affair.

WINDSOR, England, Nov. 22. -- Emperor William of Germany to-day inspected a Corporal and two troopers of the Life Guards, in khaki field service uniform, in the quadrangle of Windsor Castle. His Majesty expressed great satisfaction with the serviceability of the uniform.

The demand for the free use of cameras in the Zoological Park comes to the Zoological Society in the nature of a surprise. The fact that the Zoological Park has been singled out and made the object of a demand for privileges which are not granted in any similar institution on earth, so far as I am aware, either in a zoological garden, museum, or art gallery, is, to say the least, unexpected.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The following are the pitchers' records as given out by President Young of the National League to-day. The names are in alphabetical order and not in the order of standing:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The treatment to which Admiral Dewey is being subjected in the city where he has made his home is almost incredible to people who have seen him greeted as a hero and loaded with adulation. From the reports that come in from other cities, it would appear that the hostile sentiment is not nearly so strong elsewhere as it is here.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 21. -- Two Kentuckians, each representing a great body of citizens of the Blue Grass State, are making such a strife to win the office of Governor of this Commonwealth that they have concentrated public attention upon the State to a degree that it has seldom before enjoyed since it became a member of the Union.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The morning papers generally commend the sentiments expressed by Whitelaw Reid Tuesday evening at the banquet of the New York Chamber of Commerce, upon "The Existing Friendly Relations Between the United States and Great Britain."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 22. -- The City Council of Elizabeth was in session last night until 2 o'clock this morning in an attempt to pass the trolley ordinance of the Westfield and Elizabeth Company, which has constructed its line all the way from Plainfield, and desires an entrance into Elizabeth at the city line on Jersey Avenue.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- Various officials of the British Admiralty have been interviewed regarding The London Daily Chronicle's bad-beef assertions, and they say they have not received a single complaint as to the quality of food furnished on the transports.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 22. -- Three men were to-day arrested by Secret Service operatives charged with attempting to influence the jury in the conspiracy and bribery cases against former United States District Attorney Ellery P. Ingham and his law partner, Harvey K. Newitt. Their names are Thomas O'Dea, Harry J. Fairbanks, and George W. Peifer, all of this city.

The nature of the rumored State Constabulary bill is sufficiently understood to permit its being described as a measure to legislate the political control of New York City into the hands of the party dominant at Albany.

The Central Board of Education, at its meeting yesterday afternoon, renewed the fight against the publication of City Superintendent Maxwell's first annual report, because of its severe criticisms of the local committee system of Brooklyn Borough. After a heated discussion it was decided not to publish it.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 22. -- The Willingham bill providing for prohibition in Georgia was passed by the lower house of the General Assembly to-day. The vote stood: Yeas, 93, nays, 65. The measure received a majority of five votes more than the two-thirds necessary.
LONDON, Nov. 22. -- A special dispatch from Vienna reiterates the report, which was denied last week, that the Russians had occupied Herat.

It is evident that the display of bad taste in the Dewey homestead matter has not been on the part of Admiral Dewey, who has gone even further than the occasion required to insure the retention of the homestead in the Dewey family, but on the part of those who, forgetting the requirements of common courtesy, have presumed to exercise a right of censorship over his personal and domestic affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- News comes from Manila that Father McKinnon, late of the California Volunteers, who was appointed an army Chaplain and sent out again to Manila with Archbishop Chapelle to assist in pacifying the natives and accustoming them to American methods, went there also by direction of the Pope in an important clerical capacity.

-- Such a display of mingled amiability and wisdom as the President of the Park Board has made in the matter of admitting automobiles to Central Park is worthy of commendation none the less hearty because something of astonishment must be expressed in connection with it. Mr. CLAUSEN'S first position was utterly wrong, and he defended it for a while by arguments that had no relation with logic or fact.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22. -- Search for the remains of victims supposed to have been buried on the premises of Mrs. Bamberger, now under arrest, charged with numerous murders, at 919 Chouteau Avenue, was continued to-day. While digging in the stable this afternoon the laborers discovered a place where the earth had been turned up recently.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Admiral Dewey talked freely regarding the transfer of his house with a Sun reporter whom he received at his residence to-night. He expressed the keenest regret, indignation, sorrow, and resentment at the manner in which the information that he had deeded his home to his wife has been received.

Many contracting firms and syndicates will compete for the privilege of building the rapid transit tunnel, which, it is realized, is likely to be a very profitable undertaking. William Barclay Parsons said yesterday that a large number of plans and contracts had been asked for by persons who announced their intention to bid, and he added that the outlook for active competition and low prices was very encouraging.
The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, as the result of negotiations with the Union Ferry Company of New York and Brooklyn, issued yesterday the following notice:

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- Although it is evident that the situation in Natal is again becoming sufficiently alarming, nothing can be officially ascertained to allay public anxiety or the curiosity felt regarding the disposition of the reinforcements recently landed at Durban. The War Office dispatches are confined to a mere recital of a few casualties at Mooi River, which confirm the reports of skirmishes there, but give no details as to how the engagements happened.

Excellent prices and a brisk demand for high-class animals continue at the Madison Square Garden sale of trotters and pacers. The morning and afternoon yesterday were taken up in completing the sale of the consignment of C.W. Williams, Galesburg, Ill. There were seventy-five head, principally young animals, the get of Allerton.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Gen. Otis to-day cabled the War Department as follows:

It is lucky that the American people are not acutely sensitive to the criticisms of foreigners. If they were mindful of the opinions of what Justice STANLEY MATTHEWS called "abroad," many of them would crimson with shame and humiliation at the spectacle offered to the eyes and the mirth of the world by our present and our recent attitude toward Admiral DEWEY.

There is to be the liveliest kind of a coal war. That was practically decided yesterday at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria of the Anthracite Coal Operators' Association. Sixty-eight representatives of independent operators in the Lackawanna, Lehigh, Schuylkill, and Wyoming regions of Pennsylvania attended. The combined capital represented approximates $125,000,000.

Some little nervousness continues to show in the call money market, Stock Exchange rates rising yesterday to 8 per cent. at one time, although insignificant transactions took place above 6 per cent., many more contracts being made at the minimum of 4 per cent. than at the earlier 8 per cent. figure.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- The funeral services for Vice President Hobart, whose body still lies at his home, Carroll Hall, are to have the public character which the high office the dead man held would make it natural to expect. The desire of the widow to have as little display as possible is as strong as ever, but it has been thought best to make some concession to public feeling in the matter.

Cap. William R. Abercrombie of the United States Second Infantry, who for two years has been in Alaska in charge of an expedition surveying an all-American route from tidewater to the gold fields, and who recently returned to Seattle, arrived here yesterday on a visit to his father-in-law, Col. Kimball, the New York Depot Quartermaster. Capt. Abercrombie, in talking of his work in Alaska, said:

Although M. DEROULEDE was sentenced on Saturday to three years' imprisonment by the Senatorial High Court of France, this fact has nothing to do with the indictment which brought him before the court. It was simply a side issue, made possible by an idiosyncrasy of French jurisprudence, which suffers an obnoxious defendant to be summarily dealt with while his trial is going on.

There is no doubt that several fraudulent advertisements appear daily in several New York papers. That this cannot easily be prevented is clear, but something should, as far as possible, be done to stop the nefarious traffic.

Dr. M.B. Feeney, Chief Sanitary Inspector of Manhattan, gave out a statement yesterday in which he said that the Health Board Inspector's reports on the condition of every station of the Manhattan Elevated Road will be made next Wednesday. He also said that the Manhattan is at present more active than ever before in making repairs.

I have read with interest the letter of Mr. Theodore Gilman in your issue of the 12th inst. I have also read with interest your editorial reply, from which I gather that you invite intelligent discussion of the broad question, "The remedy for the evils and defects of our rigid currency." I shall confine my remarks to this subject.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Evaristo Montalvo and Francisco Figueras, Commissioners appointed by the Planters and Farmers' Association of Cuba, together with W.O. McDowell, President of the Cuban-American League, accompanied by Senor Quesada, the Cuban Commissioner, called upon the President to-day and laid before him a petition adopted by the Farmers and Planters' Association.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 22. -- Four hundred and fifty "redskins" at the Sac and Fox Indian reservation in Tama County are ready to start on the warpath with rifle and tomahawk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The diplomatic body in Washington is not to be formally invited to attend the funeral of Vice President Hobart on Saturday, a study of the precedents in such cases being against the invitations. They will receive each a simple note announcing the demise of Mr. Hobart.

The Metropolitan, John Hancock, and Germania Companies, the competitors in last night's series of games in the Life Insurance League at Starr's alleys, furnished some good sport. The first game between the John Hancock and Germania teams, was rather one-sided. The steady bowling of the John Hancock representatives enabled them to win easily by 84 pins.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 22. -- The trouble between the Rev. Father Connolly, pastor of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, and his curate, Father Curren, which resulted in the arrest of the latter on Monday evening upon a charge of assault, broke out afresh again this morning. The trouble started over the divergent views of the priests over the proposal to end the vice in Gloucester City by annexing the town to Camden.
DURBAN, Nov. 22. -- Owing to the proximity of the Boers to Pietermaritzburg, it has been necessary to alter the defenses of Durban.
ALBANY, Nov. 22. -- The State Civil Service Commission to-day gave a hearing upon the subject of the White civil service law relative to its application to county offices.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22. -- A new method of disposing of stolen horses came to light to-day through the arrest of Frank McCullough, a one-legged negro, twenty-two years old, of 159 Steuben Street, Jersey City. Albert Braxton of Morristown on Friday last drove to this city to attend a horse sale.

William F. Miller, manager of the Franklin Syndicate at 144 Floyd Street, Brooklyn, who was arrested Tuesday in connection with a civil suit for $50,000 damages for slander brought by E.L. Blake, the editor of a financial paper, has been compelled to remove his accounts from the Hide and Leather National Bank and the Broadway Bank of Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Important amendments to the inter-State commerce law were approved at a conference to-day of representatives of over thirty National and industrial and manufacturing associations, merchants and shippers. The proposed amendments to the statutes were prepared by Frank Barry of Milwaukee, Wis., Secretary of the Millers' National Association.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22. -- In a drizzling rain the Yale 'Varsity eleven had its first real practice of the week. At 2:15 the squad trotted out upon the field, where the 'Varsity and scrub were lined up for signal practice. The plays and forming of interference were gone through with slowly and carefully at first, but gradually increasing in speed.

EAST STROUDSBURG, Penn., Nov. 22. -- The residents of Stauffers, this county, turned out almost in a body last night to search for Reuben Harps, a missing hunter from Wilkesbarre. After searching for hours, they found the hunter unconscious, mangled and bleeding from lacerations of the body. Beside the hunter was the dead body of a black bear of immense size.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- There has apparently been no communication with Estcourt, Natal, since noon Tuesday, and the Boers now control the railroad thence to the Mooi River. Consequently, it is said, momentous developments may be expected at any time.

I wish to protest against the fickleness of many of my countrymen. During eighteen months we lauded Admiral Dewey to the sky -- put him equal to Nelson, who fought more large and really desperate battles than any other Admiral in history. None criticised Dewey's having taken Aguinaldo to the Philippines, which I have thought an error of judgment, nor anything else.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- As a result of hazing at the Lawrenceville school one of the students now lies dead from injuries received. Martin V. Bergen, the victim, together with a number of other freshmen students at Lawrenceville, were being subjected to the usual hazing methods on last Friday night by some higher classmen, in the course of which some one cruelly jumped on Bergen's stomach with his knees, rendering him unconscious.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Secretary Long will recommend to Congress a programme for new naval construction which will be in accordance with the policy that has been pursued for the past three years. He will ask for three armored cruisers of about 13,000 tons displacement, three protected cruisers of about 8,000 tons, and a dozen gunboats of 900 tons, making eighteen ships in all.

J.N. Kalley Son in conjunctions with Holdridge Ward have sold for W. E. Dennis to an investor the five-story stonefront building 30 Warren Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Church Street, 244 by 100.

Mr. Leo Schulz, a violoncello player, who was formerly a member of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, but who is now a resident of this city, gave the first of a series of chamber music recitals at the Carnegie Lyceum yesterday morning. A peculiarity of these entertainments will be the changing of the performers of the instrumental works at each concert, only Mr. Schulz remaining constant factor in the series.

John Hays Hammond, the American who became noted during the Jameson raid in the Transvaal, and who holds responsible positions in connection with mining enterprises in various parts of the world, arrived here on the White Star Line steamship Teutonic with his family yesterday. He went to the Waldorf-Astoria. In speaking of South Africa, Mr. Hammond said:

" The Principles of a Banking Currency" is the heading given to an article written by Mr. Charles A. Conant, and published, September last, in pamphlet form by the Sound Money Committee of the Reform Club of your city.

Fifty citizens, representing almost every section of Kings and Queens Counties affected by the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system, met last evening at 201 Montague Street, Brooklyn, to prepare for to-morrow's hearing before the State Railroad Commission upon the protests against the recent changes inaugurated by President Rossiter.

At this time, when a few malicious critics have set themselves up to pass judgment upon the private and personal actions of an American gentlemen, it seems that a word of encouragement and sympathy in this matter, that has so unfortunately disturbed the peace of mind of our National hero, should take the form of a personal communication.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The board of bureau chiefs, under whose recommendation the Secretary of the Navy has drawn his plans for the new naval construction which will be recommended to Congress, has outlined in a very general way the features of the eighteen vessels included in that programme.

CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, Nov. 23. -- Miss May Campbell Quinn, the only child of James Cecil Quinn, a millionaire banker, and Lloyd Lowndes, Jr., a son of Gov. Lowndes of Maryland, were married in the First Presbyterian Church of this city at noon to-day. The wedding was a notable event in society circles.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Two treaties for the final partition of the Samoan Islands have been drawn, and one of them has already been signed.
The Quackenbush estate has sold to a builder the plot at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, 100.11 by 120.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23. -- Before sailing for Manila to-day Gen. Frederick Funston took occasion to make definite denial of recent stories regarding himself, Col. Wilder S. lIetcalf, and Major Bishop, in which Lieut. Callahan, a former officer of the Twentieth Kansas, and-others of that regiment are credited with charging these ofricers with many sins of commission and omission, including the charges against ietcalf and Bishop of shooting, defenseless Filipino prisoners.

In reference to the criticisms of the public about the transfer of the Dewey home by the Admiral, first to his wife and subsequently to his son, permit me to say that such acts on the part of the public are certainly unwarrantable and unjustifiable.

NEW ROCHELLE, Nov. 23. -- Peter Reinstein, proprietor of the Larchmont Hotel, in Larchmont, was found insensible behind the bar this morning by his wife. When he revived he told of his experience at midnight with a thief.

- turning point in the local illuminating gas situation was reached yesterday, when the Directors of the New 2rnsterdam Gas Company, through Frank S. Hastings, the representative in the hoard of the E. C. Benedict and Kern Incandescent Light Company interests, announced that the company would, dating from next Friday, change their rate to customers from 50 cents to the legaI rate, $1.10, per thousand feet.

" THAT wielder of words who for any reason cannot have access to The Century Dictionary and Cyclopedia and Atlas, and who has not yet been tantalized by an opportunity of examining it during an hour or two, is the most-to-be-pitied literary woman or man I know. For the inspection would have convinced him that whatever he could possibly want to know about any English word, is in these volumes.
