ATLANTIC, CITY, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Ground was broken here to-day by the contractor, Allen B. Rorke of Philadelphia, for the big new hotel that is to be built on the site of the Pennsylvania Railroad Excursion House. The property, which was recently purchased by the Atlantic City and Chelsea Improvement Company, Covers fourteen acres, with an ocean frontage of 1,400 feet.
LIVERPOOL, Nov. 23. -- Thomas Henry Ismay, the founder and Chairman of the Board of Directors of the White Star Line Steamship Company, died suddenly this evening.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- "From every section of the country," Admiral Dewey said to-day, "have telegrams and letters come to me showing the good-will and kindness of the American people. It is impossible for me to acknowledge each one of these communications, individually, but I assure you that I am deeply grateful to their senders and appreciate their consideration.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The fact that fresh portions of Natal are being overrun daily by the Boers is producing exasperation in that colony and intense humiliation in Great Britain, where the idea of a possible extensive violation of British soil was so contemptuously dismissed in the early stages of the war.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve, increased, 130,000; circulation, decreased, 117,090; bullion, increased, 12,382; other securities, decreased, 181,000; other deposits, decreased. 802,000; public deposits, decreased. 761,000; notes reserve, increased, 138,000; Government securities, decreased 1,500,000; The proportion of the Bank of England's reserve to liability is 43.19 per cent.
MANILA, Nov. 23. -- Col. Carpenter, operating north of Iloilo Nov. 18, advanced to Santa Barbara, straight north from Jaro, taking trench after trench, the enemy fighting and retreating.

Of course it is not only to the last degree discourteous, but small and narrow, to criticise Admiral Dewey openly for what he may have done with his own property, and odiously vulgar to heap abuse upon him on that account. Far wiser as well as nobler would it have been to let the whole matter pass in dignified silence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Senator James K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, returned to Washington to-day from his trip to Chicago, where he went to attend a conference of the Executive Committee.

A south-bound Broadway cable car was passing Canal Street at 2:50 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when a tremendous explosion took place just a few feet behind it in the trench where some laborers in the employ of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company were at work.

Ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed continued his cross-examination of William J. Logan, in Part IV., Special Term of the Supreme Court, yesterday afternoon, in the action instituted by the latter against Henry Rogers, E.C. Benedict, Grant B. Schley, William Rockefeller, and others, to compel an accounting of profits in the consolidation of the Brooklyn gas companies.

WINDSOR, Nov. 23. -- Emperor William, the Prince of Wales the Duke of Connaught, and Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein shot in the great park this morning, near Cumberland Lodge, where they lunched.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The extraordinary interest this city is taking in the funeral of Vice President Hobart was apparent to-day at a meeting of the Citizens' General Committee of Arrangements. The men who came together at this meeting are making preparations to look out for all the visitors, with the exception of the President's immediate party, and they will see to it that this party is met by carriages at the railroad station.

The unanimous vote of the Board of Public Improvements to defer action on the proposed contract with the Ramapo Water Company for three months is a most gratifying evidence of the power of public opinion. It is also a particular tribute to the public spirit and the efficiency of the Merchants' Association.

Marie Timpany, a Brooklyn girl, who received several packages of poisoned candy and cologne last February and March, is now being tormented by threatening letters. The girl is eighteen years old and lives at Fourth Avenue and Ninety-third Street. Eugene V. Brewster, a lawyer to whom the letters were given, has sent them to Post Office Inspector Maginnis, who has forwarded them to Washington.
MUNCIE, Ind., Nov. 23. -- Congressman George W. Gromer of the Eighth District said to-day.

Your article in THE TIMES of Nov. 20, entitled "Faith in Bryan," was read with interest, but it is impossible for me to see where the Republican Party can hope for any consolation in the recent State elections. Although they try to make the people believe they were perfectly satisfied with the results, it is plain to be seen, through the many utterances of their leaders, that such is not the case.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 23. -- Col. Honey, counsel for Mrs. Goddard, made public to-day the fact that a settlement in the Ledyard will contest had been effected.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Three members of the New York State Commerce Commission have been in conference with prominent local grain and provision dealers in Chicago. The discussion involved the recent increase of business by Southern routes. There will be some investigations as to the effort being made by local firms to hold the business of the North and the West. The commission goes from here to Minneapolis and later to Duluth.

BOSTON, Nov. 23. -- The Dominion liner Turcoman, which arrived here to-day from Liverpool, brought seven men, comprising the shipwrecked crew of the British brigantine Cleddu Belle, who were rescued from their sinking vessel on Nov. 15, about 300 miles from the Irish coast.

President Holahan of the Board of Public Improvements said yesterday that the Ramapo water scheme was not dead. "I believe," he said, "that the Merchants' Association will report in favor of it, if the city cannot build its own water works. The city needs water. There is no question about it. Can the city build additional water works?

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 23. -- The case in which the Indiana Supreme Court made its famous anti-trust decision was finally disposed of to-day. The case was entitled The State in relation of Frank H. Snyder, Prosecuting Attorney, vs. The Portland Natural Gas and Oil Company. A decision of the Circuit Court in favor of the company was revered last June, and to-day a petition for rehearing was overruled.
The characteristic trait of the American public to blow hot and cold with one breath was never better illustrated than in the case of Admiral Dewey.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Investigation shows that the facts in the Cameroon scandal, made public by the Tageblatt on Nov. 18, when that paper said that an apparently corrupt deal had taken place, by which the Chief of the Colonial Department gave away 80,000 square kilometers of Cameroon soil, estimated to be worth about 40,000,000 marks, to various high personages, far exceed the Tageblatt's story in sensational features.

Financiers are asking who is back of the scheme by which William F. Miller alleges that he is enabled to pay dividends of 520 per cent. per annum on money confided to him by the public. What becomes of the money is another question that they are asking themselves and each other. That sums aggregating a vast amount have been pouring into the coffers of the Franklin Syndicate is now known.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Postmaster General Charles Emery Smith, in a general order to-day, formally declared all mail matter passing between the United States and Puerto Rico, the Philippine archipelago, and Guam or between these island possessions od, the United States subject to the United States domestic classification, conditions, and rates of postage.

Dr. Frederick A. Cook of Brooklyn, the surgeon and anthropologist of the Belgian Antarctic expedition recently returned from a fifteen months' sojourn in the Antarctic Ocean, delivered his first lecture on his travels at Association Hall, Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, last night. Every seat in the hall had been sold a week before, and standing room was at a premium last night.
A friend of mine in New York favors me occasionally with your paper. In your issue of Oct. 19 a letter occurs entitled "England's Duplicity."

Public School No. 5, Academy Street, near Grand, in Long Island City, which City Superintendent Maxwell reported to the Board of Education at its meeting on Wednesday as filled to suffocation, is one of the oldest school buildings in the borough. Borough Superintendent Stevens of Queens said yesterday that the school was built long before the civil war; under a special act of the Legislature, in School District No. 3 in the Township of Newtown.

BOSTON, Nov. 23. -- The stock market as a whole was practically a repetition of recent previous days. The trading dragged badly; changes, as a rule, were of little importance and features were few in number. Westinghouse Electric was pushed into the front rank of speculative favorites, and for a time on good buying, which lifted it to 44 3/4, it attracted considerable attention.

Isaac L. Rice, until recently president of the Electric Vehicle Company, talked yesterday of the newly incorporated $10,000,000 Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company of America, of which he is an incorporator.
LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The Secretary of War has received the following dispatch through Gen. Forestier-Walker from Gen. Methuen, dated Belmont, Nov. 23:

The City Club last night took up the suppression by members of the Board of Education of the report of Dr. Maxwell, City Superintendent of Schools. It appointed a committee of three, consisting of Oswald G. Villard, John P. Faure, and James W. Pryor, to investigate the subject, and, if necessary, to attempt to secure for the suppressed report full publicity.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Because fifteen non-union men employed at the Northwestern elevated power house were not discharged yesterday when Business Agent Buchanan of the structural iron workers made the demand that they should be, a strike all along the line is in force to-day. All of the structural iron workers and all union men employed in other trades were ordered not to return to work unless the non-union men were discharged.

ATHENS, Ala., Nov. 23. -- In a debate at Elkmont last night between Senator John T. Morgan and Gov. Johnston, the latter began to read an alleged Washington interview with Senator Morgan, in which the Senator said that Bryan's leadership was not necessary to the success of the party. Senator Morgan said:

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 23. -- The first of three briefs to be filed in the Wellcome disbarment case, that of the Attorney General, was submitted to the Supreme Court to-day. He reviews the case in a somewhat lengthy manner, elaborating upon the sensational evidence against Senator Clark's campaign manager.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- Franklin Field was almost a sea of mud to-day as the result of heavy rain, but this did not deter the University of Pennsylvania football eleven from putting in an afternoon of hard practice. All the 'Varsity players were out, and the showing made by the men was gratifying to Coach Woodruff.

An experience of my own may suggest a solution and end of the contemptible fuss that has been raised over the gift of a house to Admiral Dewey. It might also help to unmask the real authors of the noisome controversy which tends to bring our people into ridicule and contempt abroad.

Trading in yesterday's market for outside securities was not much more active than on the previous day, but prices were firmer and a number of stocks ended the day with net gains of importance. Prominent issues either remained at Wednesday's closing figures or advanced, and very few net losses resulted from the day's transactions.

Vice Chancellor Pitney, at Jersey City, yesterday, heard testimony in the habeas corpus proceedings brought by Mrs. Emily Schultze to obtain possession of her three children, now in the custody of Frederick Schultze, from whom Mrs. Schultze recently obtained a divorce on statutory grounds. Mrs. Schultze alleged that the children are now in the care of Miss Jennie Meyers, who was named as co-respondent in the divorce suit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Upon the recommendation of the Secretary of the Treasury, the President has directed the following-named officers of the Marine Hospital service to serve in the offices of the United States Consuls at the ports named.
Controller Charles Gates Dawes is being talked of in Illinois as a compromise candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of the State.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23. -- The Yale University Corporation held its regular Fall meeting in this city to-day. Practically the full membership was in attendance. Most of the three hours' session was occupied with the consideration of the preliminary plans for the new memorial hall and the consideration of the recently submitted plan for the consolidation of the athletic interests of the university.

" Masters, remember that I am an ass; though it be not written down, yet forget not that I am an ass." Since SHAKESPEARE created the immortal Dogberry with an itching to be known and recorded in his true and inalienable character, there has been nothing approaching the exasperating asininity of the majority of the Central Board of Education in its treatment of Superintendent MAXWELL.

A Trifle over two years ago one of our Commodores left the capital to take charge of a modest little scludron then engaged in looking after the interests of Uncle Sam in very distant quarter of the globe.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Nov. 23. -- The second section of Baltimore and Ohio passenger train No. 9, west-bound, known as the oyster train, crashed into the first section in South Cumberland early this morning and was wrecked.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- The Westchester County Electric Railway Company to-day filed a notification in the County Clerk's office that it purposes to extend its roads or to construct branches or extensions as follows:

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- One hundred and twenty girls employed by the Union Horse Nail Company, at West Twenty-second Street and Ashland Avenue, went on strike to-day to secure a 10 per cent. advance in wages for eighty men who were working in the factory with them for less pay than the girls were earning

In the many letters which appear in this morning's paper condemning the contemptible meanness which is surging up in waves of cruel criticism around "our hero," there is too much stress laid on it as American meanness. Our Dewey is not the first who has experienced the fickleness of the populace; he has read history, he has read Shakespeare.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- Trading in the stock market to-day was rnore spirited than for a long time past. Interest centred principally in the specialties, and wherever any good demand existed prices promptly advanced. In most cases the tnovement was limited to small fractions, but Marsden rose 1%, to 14; Pennsylvania Steel 5, to S0; United Gas 1, to 1031/.2, and Philadelphia Electric l, to 7.

That New York City will have a new Post Office and other improvements in the facilities for handling mails is now practically certain, according to Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott. Mr. Van Cott returned yesterday morning from Washington, where he conferred with Postmaster General Smith and First Assistant Postmaster General Heath on the subject, with the result of arousing the interest of both of them in formulating plans for the proposed improvements.

The Postmaster's report of his visit to Washington, printed yesterday, is reassuring, so far as it goes. That is to say, Mr. VAN COTT seems to have found all the officials of the department ready and anxious to meet his views as regards the provision of suitable facilities for the New York Post Office, to enable it to transact its great and growing business.

That New York City will have a new Post Office and other improvements in the facilities for handling mails is now practically certain, according to Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott. Mr. Van Cott returned yesterday morning from Washington, where he conferred with Postmaster General Smith and First Assistant Postmaster General Heath on the subject, with the result of arousing the interest of both of them in formulating plans for the proposed improvements.

The Postmaster's report of his visit to Washington, printed yesterday, is reassuring, so far as it goes. That is to say, Mr. VAN COTT seems to have found all the officials of the department ready and anxious to meet his views as regards the provision of suitable facilities for the New York Post Office, to enable it to transact its great and growing business.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 23. -- The Indians practiced in the gymnasium to-night on account of the inclemency of the weather. All of the regular team were present in their places, and displayed much acuteness in running the signals. Several end plays were practiced, and were found to work with much rapidity. The guard plays also worked successfully.

Frank Craig, the "Harlem Coffee Cooler," who returned from England recently with the reputation of having beaten almost every good man in his class there, put up the worst exhibition in his pugilistic career in a twenty-round bout with "Tommy" West at the Broadway Athletic Club last night.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24. -- It became known here to-day that Ross B. Farrington of 268 Broad Street, this city, the operatic singer who was found dead in a Pullman coach at Washington, D.C., this week, was married three years ago to Miss Mamie Wallace of Bloomfield. Mrs. Farrington, who now keeps a boarding house in Bloomfield, last saw her husband seven months ago in Philadelphia.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 24. -- The testimony of several witnesses was taken to-day before United States Commissioner George E. Johnson for use in the trial of the case of Mrs. Malvina Prunier of this city against Mrs. Lillian Campbell, sometimes known as Mrs. Lillian Ash of Fishkill, N.Y. The suit is brought for the alienation of the affections of Mrs. Prunier's husband, and is for $50,000.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The great artistic event of the next few weeks will be the general exhibition of Alfred Stevens's works which, by a gracious consent of the Government, will be held at the Ecole des Beaux Arts. Alfred Stevens, though a Belgian by birth, has lived all his artistic life in Paris, and is as much identified with French art as Alma Tadema with that of England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Mr. Macrum, the United States Consul at Pretoria, has been instructed by cable to impress upon President Kruger that in the view of this Government the usages of all civilized nations sanction the ministration of a neutral representative in the interest of the citizens and captives of one of the parties to a war, and he must further insist upon performing the sacred duties imposed by all considerations of humanity.

Brentano's have just received from Paris "Histoire du Chateau de Versailles: l'Architecture, la Decoratton, les Oeuvres d'Art, les Pares, et les Jardins le Grand et le Petit Trianon," by Pierre de Nolhat, Director of the National Museum at Versailles, being the most significant work ever published regarding this famous palace, to be completed in sixteen numbers, each containing thirty-two pages, fifteen plates in addition to those included in the text.
" We have too much money in the Far West," was the statement made at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday by Jacob Furth, President of the Puget Sound National Bank of Seattle, Washington.

The origin of the various stories as to Gov. ROOSEVELT'S negotiations with Senator PLATT with reference to the Constabulary bill and the renomination of PAYN to the Insurance Department is doubtful, except that they cannot be authorized by the Governor.

Another juror was found yesterday to try Roland B. Molineux on the charge of murdering Katherine J. Adams, and the second week of the trial has come to an end with only seven jurors in the box. At the opening of the week there were five jurors in the box. Four were chosen during the week and two excused who had already been sworn.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 24. -- Representatives of the Textile Council and a special committee of the Mill Manufacturers' Association entered into an agreement at to-day's wage conference which will, when finally adopted by operatives and employers, result in a definite settlement of the present wage agitation, and ultimately, when a sliding scale is agreed to, will make wage disputes in this city a thing of the past.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 24. -- A movement is on foot between the local lodges of the Knights and Ladies of Honor to secede from the National organization. There are 900 members in Cincinnati.

An injunction was granted yesterday by Justice Bookstaver on the application of The Sun Printing and Publishing Association, pending its suit against John H. Delaney and others, restraining the defendants, who are officers of various labor organizations connected with the printing trade, from interfering with the property rights or business of the plaintiff.

The repm-t comes from London that George Frederick W'atts. whom -- if such talent as his were not so rare -- one would call first a public-spirited citizen and then , painter, has in his mind a plan for the erection of a cloistered court around the ' churchyard of St. Botolph. Aldersgate, and then the utilization of .thfs as a Valhalla for obscure heroes and heroines.

The sixth annual dinner of the Edinburgh Sir Walter Scott Club took place two weeks ago in the Royal Hotel. Princes Street, Edinburgh. The gathering, which numbered over 200, is described as one of the most brilliant and representative which has yet been held under the club's auspices. Mr. Choate, on rising to propose the toast of "Literature," was greeted with very cordial applause, the audience upstanding as a mark of respect and honor.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24. -- Through the efforts of J. Kennedy Tod, the New York banker, who resides in Sound Beach, that village is to have a golf club which for ease of access promises to be a rival to the famous Fairfield County Golf Club. Mr. Tod's place is called Innis Arden, and that name is to be applied to the new club.

The Stevenson letters, like all good autobiography, give us a perfect picture of the man -- far stronger, more lifelike, and interesting than anything a biographer could hope to write. We are usually thankful when a favorite author sets down his own life for us; but the fact that he is writing for present or future publication can usually be read between the lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Representative William Sulzer, who arrived in town to-day, said that his friends thought his chances of election to the Democratic leadership of the House were very good. Incidentally, Mr. Sulzer mentioned that New York and New Jersey would be "doubtful States" in the next Presidential campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Pennsylvania played her last practice game of the season with the scrub on Franklin Field today, and from now until Thanksgiving Day, when the team will meet Cornell, the practice will be of the lightest kind, consisting of signal and formation drill, catching, punting, and running.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Congressman Brigham H. Roberts of Utah to-day declared that he was sure of retaining his seat, and that the amnesty proclamations of ex-Presidents Harrison and Cleveland covered his case. After outlining his side of the case in much the same language as that employed in his article in last Sunday's TIMES, Mr. Roberts said:

William B. Hornblower continued yesterday the redirect examination in Part IV., Special Term, of the Supreme Court, of his client, W.J. Logan, who is suing for an account of the profits alleged to have resulted from consolidation of the Brooklyn gas companies. The courtroom, as at the previous sessions, was filled with spectators, among whom were many lawyers, attracted by the report that E.C. Benedict would take the witness stand during the day.

XaTASI-IINGTON, Nov. 24. -- tWuller details of the sharp engagement between Carpenter's command and the insurgents in IloiIo reached the War Department to-day in the following dispatch from Gen. Otis, dated at Manila to-day: "

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 24. -- Minneapolis mills during the present season have broken all records in the amount of lumber sawed. For the past seven months every mill in the city has been working almost continually, with the result that their total product will be slightly in excess of 600,000,000 feet. Shipments for the present year up to last Tuesday were 453,285,000 feet, or about 65,000,000 in excess of any full year previously.

When it was announced that Capt. RICHARD P. LEARY, United States Navy, had been appointed Governor of Guam, those American citizens who were familiar with the record of the officer in question said to themselves, and haply to other people, in the language of Private Terence Mulvaney, "there will be proceedin's."

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Delcasse, made some references to the foreign policy of France. During the discussion of the foreign estimates Count Montaigu, Conservative, asked for explanations as to the incident of a British cruiser stopping and boarding a French steamer, the Cordoba, in Delagoa Bay.
HAVANA, Nov. 24. -- Governor General Brooke, in the course of a report just issued, says:

The propriety of having a lithographed certificate of service presented to each member of the Board of Aldermen was the cause of a long discussion in that body yesterday, and some merriment at the expense of Alderman Kenney, (Dem., Kings,) who fathered the scheme.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24. -- Everything is in readiness for the game with Princeton tomorrow. Yards of blue streamers are floating from the buildings of the city and the hotels are full of football guests. Most of them are old "grads," and this afternoon, rank and file, they went to the Yale Field to see Eli's sturdy warriors go through their final practice.

Vigor was of a sudden disclosed in yesterday's stock market. There was activity as well as exceptional strength. A number of stocks that have been lagging recently jumped into prominence. Commission house buying was conspicuous, there being yet further exhibition of the fact that the outside public is alertly waiting for even slight encouragement to get again into Wall Street.

The death of Thomas Henry Ismay deserves more than a passing notice. In the extraordinary development of the commercial marine of Great Britain during the last quarter of a century he had been one of the leaders. What Spofford Tileston and Grinnell Minturn were in New York before the war, the firm of Ismay, Imrie Co. has been in Liverpool, and he was its head.
May I touch Mr. Newberry's shield lightly and say gently a word of his criticism of Hugo's "Les Miserables" without having him couch his lance in return?

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 24. -- The Board of Health, it is believed, has the diphtheria cases pretty will in hand to-night. There is said to be no danger at present of the disease becoming epidemic, although two new cases were reported to-day. The sickness is confined to the poorer localities, where the sanitary conditions are by no means favorable.

This ill wind that stirred up such a dust about Admiral DEWEY was but a passing gust, a bit of a squall that sped on and left the sunshine all the brighter behind it, but why should it not blow some good to the Naval Arch, the Dewey Arch?

BOSTON, Nov. 24. -- S. George Davis was arrested here to-day, charged with being implicated in the plot recently unearthed at Winthrop, Mass., by which Eastern Canada was flooded with counterfeit money. Davis says he is a brother of William Davis, alias W.H. Williams, who is under arrest for the same affair at Guthrie, Oklahoma.

Your recent editorial article on the various editions of Lamb in connection with your notice of the new one of Macmillan's was of interest to the lovers of the author of "Old Familiar Faces," but I think there is one edition of his works not alluded to by you which is worthy of mention. I refer to that published in Boston in 1862 with the imprint of William Veazie.
School Commissioner George Livingston last night made a statement in regard to the recent action of the School Board in reference to City Superintendent Maxwell's report.
VALPARAISO, Nov. 24. -- The coalition Cabinet, headed by Senor Rafael Sotomayor, which was formed on Sept. 3 last, has resigned.

I am amazed that such an effusion as "England's Love for America," which appeared in your issue of yesterday, could, by any possibility, emanate from a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Surely a person of even ordinary intelligence who has perused your able editorials on Great Britain and the Transvaal must be sufficiently conversant with the subject to discuss it understandingly.

Will you allow me, a constant reader and your warm friend and admirer, to enter a protest against anonymous letters? They have long been barred out of polite society and in recent days have been used in literature, as a rule, for the purpose of doing under a pen name what the writer imagines would smirch his own name did he openly sign it.
The Height divorce case, in which Mary L. Haight, a deaf-mute, is seeking a divorce from Henry L. Haight, also a deaf-mute, was continued yesterday before Justice Giegerich in the Supreme Court.

Lord Roberts presided at a Council meeting of the Army Temperance Association. The Chairman, in moving the adoption of the report, expressed satisfaction with its contents, and observed that during the manoeuvres in Ireland the association made admirable arrangements for giving the men ample opportunity of getting non-alcoholic drinks.

The crack Metropolitan team did some good bowling in the National League at Starr's Alleys last night. In the second game the team won almost as it pleased from the Riverdales, who rolled in poor form. The "Mets" furnished the only 900 score of the evening in the third game, in which the Rosevilles were beaten by more than 100 points. Rosevilles showed up splendidly in the first game, winning from the Riverdales. Scores:

Harry Shelaner, twenty-six years old, a private of Battery N, Seventh United States Artillery, stationed at Willets Point, was removed from the Woman's Christian Temperance Union Training School and Settlement, 463 West Thirty-second Street, to Roosevelt Hospital yesterday afternoon for treatment. Shelaner is believed to be insane.

A brace of artistically illustrated boys' books for the holidays are "Drake and His Yeomen," by James Barnes, and "Soldier Rigdale," by Beulah Marie Dix, both being published by the Macmillan Company. The frontispiece of the first is in color, and is a striking reproduction of an oil painting of one of the old-time warships.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 24. -- The Court of Appeals will render a decision to-morrow in the Nelson County contested election case, in which 1,198 votes, erroneously certified for W.P., instead of W.S. Taylor, are involved.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- The work of the Cornell team to-day was the most important of the week for the Ithacans. To encourage the 'Varsity players for the game with the University of Pennsylvania, about 800 students came down to the practice this afternoon, and cheered the players and coaches individually and collectively as the work progressed.

Col. Higginson's new volume, "Contemporaries" has almost the air of a collection of obituary eulogies, but in reality many of the papers composing it are reminiscent, having been written long after the death of their subject, and all have been somewhat revised excepting that describing a visit to John Brown's household in 1859, conscientiously left unchanged.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- Ex-United States District Attorney Ellery H. Ingham and his law partner and former assistant, Harvey K. Newitt, were to-day sentenced by Judge McPherson, in the United States District Court, to imprisonment in the Eastern Penitentiary for two years and six months and to pay a fine of $1 and the costs of the prosecution.

If George Eberhardt of 998 Avenue D had not studied the rules on "first aid to the injured" he would probably not be alive to-day. As he is at present, he is minus his right leg, but he is in the Flower Hospital on a fair road to recovery, after a very narrow escape from death.

ELKTON, Md., Nov. 24. -- The body of Silas White, who killed his sweetheart, Rhoda Jackson, last night, was found in a clump of bushes near the scene of the murder, this morning, by a party of men who were searching for the murderer.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- A member of the Cramp strikers' Executive Committee stated to-day that the plans had been laid looking to a general strike at the Cramp shipyards on Monday next. The committeeman in question further stated that sufficient assurances had been received from non-union workmen in the several departments to insure the success of the movement.
Episcopal affairs in Hawaii were explained yesterday by a gentleman recently arrived from there.

In "Nature and the Poets," John Burroughs, in criticising Bryant's poem on the fringed gentian, says: "The fringed gentian belongs to September, and when the severer frosts keep away it runs over into October." Although I freely admit that Bryant's poem has placed the gentian later in the season than it should be, I also think that Burroughs has conveyed the idea that the flower is peculiar to September.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Burglars last night or early this morning entered the house of John Coates here, and after gagging and binding him, robbed him of several thousand dollars in money and as much more in negotiable securities.

In the list of stories and novels touching American history that THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW gave some weeks ago was the singular omission of the Macmillan "Stories from American History." Because of this omission I am going to take the liberty of calling your attention to what these stories are, and what general view is back of them.

BOSTON, Nov. 24. -- Against tide, wind, and heavy head seas for at least half her course, the new battleship Kentucky made a record of 16.877 knots an hour to-day on her official speed trial over the Government course, from Cape Ann to Boone Island, and by her work showed that she is a little faster than her sister ship, the Kearsarge, which recently was sent over the same course.

William F. Miller, manager of the Franklin Syndicate, and Cecil Leslie, who has acted as Miller's press agent, were indicted yesterday by the Kings County Grand Jury on a charge of conspiracy, and bench warrants for their arrest were issued by County Judge Hurd and placed in the hands of Capt. Reynolds of the Brooklyn Detective Bureau.

Two correspondents of THE SATURDAY REVIEW have lately remarked upon the forgotten fame of Col. Charles E. Baxter, a gallant New York officer who was killed in the battle of Chapultepec during the Mexican war.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 24. -- The Indians indulged in their last practice this evening, preparatory to to-morrow's game with Oberlin. With the exception of Schoulder and Hudson, all of the players are in fair condition and were in their places during the line-up. Schoulder, though he again donned his suit this afternoon, was not permitted to take part in the scrimmages.

On that awful February night in Havana Harbor when the Maine was blown up, carrying the great majority of her gallant crew to the bottom in her shattered wreck, William Anthony, a marine on duty near Capt. Sigsbee's cabin, gained renown second only to that which came to his commander as a result of the tragedy.

Mr. Paul Leicester Ford has been much amused by the attempts of some of the critics of his historical romance, "Janice Meredith," to find in his characters actual historical personages, besides those named, and then to show that there is no record of the dialogue that Mr. Ford puts into their mouths ever having taken place.

About five years ago Alfred Ollivant, a young officer in the English Army, had the misfortune to be injured by his horse so severely that for nearly two years he was unable to leave his bed. During his boyhood he had spent some time among the shepherd dogs with their flocks in the English hill country, and learned to love the dogs, as every one does who knows their characters.

The interest manifested through the columns in your SATURDAY REVIEW in discussing words like "proven prompts me to invite attention to other errors of speech that are current, notwithstanding persistent attack.

Republican leaders are beginning to hold the usual conferences and caucuses in this city for the purpose of mapping out the work of the next Legislature. The first of these conferences was, naturally, that held on Wednesday by Senator Platt, Gov. Roosevelt, and Chairman Odell of the State Committee.

The gas war is still on. It was never off. The rivals of the New Amsterdam Gas Company did not yesterday follow its lead and raise the price of gas to the legal limit, $1.10 a thousand, so that if New Amsterdam displayed a flag of truce it was fired upon.

The order of the Postmaster General concerning the rates between the United States and their new acquisitions is one of the things which forcibly illustrate the necessity of having the status of those acquisitions fixed by Congressional action and not left to be regulated by the taste and fancy of the head of a department.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Certificates of merit for service during the Spanish-American war have been awarded by the War Department to the following men:

It dates back to Aristotle that in a play the story is the essential thing, and the corresponding proposition -- that in a story the play is the main point -- has been more or less in favor of late years. In Mr. Hope's stories, in those at least that follow the "Dolly Dialogues," we have had the play continually in sight.

Three young Hoosiers who have come into prominence of late are Booth Tarkington, author of "The Gentleman from Indiana"; George Ade, author of "Artie," "Doc Horne," and "Fables in Slang," and John T. McCutcheon, the artist and war correspondent, who has done work in the Philippines.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- "I shall not attempt to manage another grand opera season in Chicago unless I am guaranteed my price or have very good reason to believe that the attitude of Chicago people toward this form of amusement has materially changed."

PRETORIA, Nov. 24. -- Through the courtesy of the Transvaal authorities, a visit was paid to Lieut. Winston Churchill to-day at the Model School, where he is confined with the captured British officers. Beyond a slight bullet wound in the right hand, he seemed well and looked hearty, although naturally chafing under enforced idleness. In the course of the interview Mr. Churchill said:

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Marvin Hughitt, President of the Northwestern system, recently has assured representatives of Sioux City that the company of which he is the official head stands ready to expend $1,000,000 in improving the line in the Iowa town and to extend the road's branch from Moville, Ia., to Sioux City and to Centerville, South Dakota.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Now that the Dewey incident is closed, there is naturally a good deal of speculation as to the origin and cause of the sudden storm of wrath which came up, apparently from a clear sky, and began to beat on the Admiral's head within an hour after the first report of the transfer was known.
Samuel Goldsticker has sold for the estate of Bernard Earle to Janpole Werner the plot at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Eleventh Street, 50.11 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- A split has occurred in the organization of the Spanish War Veterans, and a rival body was formed to-day, to be known as the Spanish-American War Veterans. Last week the original organization held a protracted meeting in this city and perfected its constitution and by-laws, and at that time there were rumors of an impending split, but nothing was made public officially about it.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 21. -- The parading and rioting of the wives and other women relatives of the striking miners at Nanticoke were resumed here this morning, and before long resulted in the arrest of one of their number for throwing pepper in the eyes of one of the deputies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 24. -- The War Department has requested that twelve more Army Secretaries of the Young Men's Christian Association be sent with the troops to Manila. On Monday last W. Frank Gloeckner sailed on the transport Hancock and will be connected with the Forty-fourth United States Volunteer Infantry.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- A dispatch from Durban says that The Natal Advertiser confirms the report of fighting near Willow Grange. That paper says:

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 24. -- The New York State Commerce Commission held an all-day conference here to-day with leading grain and flour shippers in an endeavor to get at the reasons for the decadence of commerce through the Port of New York.

SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., Nov. 24. -- From occurrences of the past two days it is evident that the proposed Delaware Valley and Kingston Railroad, which the independent anthracite coal operators of Lackawanna, Wyoming, Lehigh, and Schuylkill Counties planned to run along the abandoned Delaware and Hudson towpath will meet with the combined opposition of the Erie and the Delaware and Western Railroad Companies, born in the courts and elsewhere.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24. -- The Epworth League disturbance over the official conduct of its Secretary, the Rev. Dr. Edwin A. Schell, was suddenly terminated to-day by his own act in tendering his resignation to the Board of Control. This was done after the board, with but one dissenting vote, and adopted the report of a committee in these words:

WOODSTOCK, Nov. 24. -- Emperor William arrived here at 12:45 o'clock P.M., accompanied by the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Connaught. The occasion was made a public holiday. In the display of bunting, American and German flags predominated. A hundred Oxford undergraduates on bicycles helped to enliven the village.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Gen. Otis's dispatch summarizing the situation and announcing the practical breaking up of the insurgents, gave much pleasure to the War Department officials. In his dispatch Gen. Otis says that the insurgent Government can no longer claim to exist, its troops and officials are scattered, and Aguinaldo in hiding.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Definite steps were taken to-day at a meeting of committees from each of the ten United States live stock breeding associations included in the proposed new association of live stock breeders, commission men, and stock yards officials, for the holding of an international fat stock and breeders' exposition in Chicago next Fall and in subsequent years.

The final match in the team club contests at the Nassau Country Club, Glen Cove, was played yesterday and resulted in two close finishes. Eight teams had originally started at match play for two trophies. Team No. 7 won the victory in the first event, beating Team No. 1 by 7 holes to 4. Each member of the winning team received a special prize.

Of late I have met with frequent utterances on the part of those who are opposed to what is called imperialism to the effect that the assertion of American supremacy over the Philippines is in contravention of the principle upon which our Government is founded, viz., that "Governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- To-day's races at Bennings resulted as follows:

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- It is often difficult to gauge the trend of public opinion, especially excited public opinion, but amid the din of contending factions there are some indications that the party of moderation is becoming stronger in this country in regard to South Africa.
CAIRO, Nov. 25. -- Lord Cromer, the British Minister here, has received the following dispatch from Gen. Kitchener:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 25. -- Princeton has finally done it, and done it well. Of course, they always want to defeat Yale whenever they meet at football. Their ambition has not always been gratified. Whenever it has been there has always grown a, terrible longing to "do 'em again." Fate had not been kind to the boys from Old Nassau in this desire up to yesterday.

W. V. S. Theme, President of the Delaware Valley and Kingston Railway, a new coal road to be .built from Laekawaxen, Penn., to Iingston, lT. Y., along the old Delaware and lIudson Canal, yesterday made the following statement with reference to his road:

KENOSHA, Wis., Nov. 25. -- The formal transfer of the plant of the Charles H. Sieg Manufacturing Company, at this point, to the American Bicycle Company, commonly known as the bicycle trust, was made to-day. All departments were at once shut down. The price paid for the plant is said to be $246,000.

The infant mortality in Oporto is very high, the mean rate for children under one year in the period 1893-7 being 226.3 per 1,000 born, against 158.8 in London, 147.7 in Glasgow, 187.4 in Manchester, and 118.9 in Paris.
Gov. Stone of Pennsylvania is of the opinion, and expresses it frankly and openly, that every husband should deed to his wife the homestead, she being queen of the home and entitled to it.

Commissioner Ira L. Bamberger of the Brooklyn School Board said yesterday that the fight of the public school teachers of that borough for their salaries under the July schedule adopted by the School Board would come up in the Supreme Court, Special Term, Brooklyn, on Tuesday morning next.

The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church has been calling or making overtures to another British minister to succeed the late JOHN HALL. Even the singular and interesting Mr. WARSZAWIAK, who denies a great many plausible propositions, does not deny that. It is true that he darkly intimates that his own "pull," in evangelical circles on the other side, is great enough to prevent the acceptance of the call.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The reply of the Empress to the Berlin Municipal Council's birthday congratulations is still much discussed not only in Berlin but throughout Germany. It appears that the letter was written at the dictation of the Emperor. The points raised by the letter are old and refer to the question of the city's Church patronage and contributions to Church funds.

The fact that Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" was played during the past week at the American Theatre to audiences of extreme size leads to the natural conclusion that this work is become the classic of the musically unprogressive. This seems a hazardous statement, yet it may be shown without undue effort to enjoy a substantial and definite basis.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 25. -- The Bee to-morrow will say:
SUNBURY, Penn., Nov. 25. -- The Dickinson-Susquehanna football game here to-day ended in a fight, and the umpire awarded the game to Dickinson.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Nov. 25. -- Report comes from Okmulgee that the "full-blood" faction in the Creek Nation will oppose the seating of Gen. S. Porter, recently elected principal chief, when it is attempted to install him in office on Monday next. The "full-bloods" are said to have held an election and named Chitto Harjo for the office, and it is said he will be supported at Okmulgee by 300 "full-bloods."

The Blooming Grove Park Association of Pike County, Pennsylvania, closes the season for 1899, the twenty-eighth of its history, in a few days. The year, while not a red-letter one, has been of average prosperity, and the prestige of the club as a resort for recreation and lovers of angling and upland shooting has been maintained.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25. -- In the annual football game between Brown and Dartmouth here to-day, Brown was the victor by a score of 16 to 5. Dartmouth showed unexpected strength, and time and again held for downs. Richardson was forced to punt often. For the first ten minutes of play Brown was outplayed, fumbling badly.

Autumn has come again, and with it comes, as usual, the annual influx into the city of the crowds of people who have been spending the Summer among the mountains or by the sea or in Europe. Let us hope that they bring back with them not only renovated health and faculties, but also a few useful impressions that may be put to practical use at home.

MANCHESTER, Ky., Nov. 23. -- "Go to Clay County? Well, not just now; or, at all events, if you do, go quietly, on some business pretext, and if convenient go provided with an introduction to some man not identified with any of the factions recently engaged in the feuds that have made the county notorious."

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 25. -- The Court of Appeals to-day clinched Taylor's right to 1,197 Nelson County votes. The court, all the Judges concurring, refused to dissolve the injunction as asked by Goebel's attorneys.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- A false impression has been created in the United States, as well as in Europe, by the publication of a statement that there is discontent and dismay among Russian owners of trotters who have imported American horses for the purpose of improving the Russian breed, which every one knows can not compare with the American trotter.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 25. -- At the newsboys' dinner which Mrs. F.W. Vanderbilt is to give on Thursday afternoon next in Masonic Hall there will be about 300 of the little fellows. An orchestra has been engaged for the event, and the popular songs of the day will be rendered, so that the boys will be enabled to sing the choruses.

Sir Horace Walpole's description of the maiden Queen, drawn from her portraits and from contemporary accounts, is not a very attractive one. "A pale Roman nose, a head of hair loaded with crowns and powdered with diamonds, a vast ruff, a vaster farthingale, and a bushel of pearls are," he says, "the features by which everybody knows at a glance the pictures of Queen Elizabeth."

President Gawtry of the Consolidated Gas Company said yesterday that he had nothing to add to his statement of the position of his company in the gas war than was published yesterday, and that he did not expect that there would be another meeting of the Directors of the company before the next regular one, a month hence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Relative to the statement attributed to Count Mouravieff, the Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs, that the propriety of remodeling the trade treaty of 1832 between the United States and Russia was now under consideration, it is learned that about two months ago this movement was initiated by the Russian Embassy here.

Business of fair volume has continued throughout the week, but it has shown little change from the desultory character of the dealings of the last two months, and no features have been developed, either in the matter of individual transactions or in general market conditions. Better inquiry for investment properties, particularly in the lower part of the city, and slightly increased activity in low-priced flats and tenements are, however, encouraging phases of the present situation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25. -- Football enthusiasm received a partial revival here to-day when the Harvard freshmen defeated their youthful Yale rivals by the large score of 54 to 0. The game, although very one-sided, was filled with sensational plays and incidents, so that it proved very interesting to the large crowd of spectators who came out to see the last football game of the season in Cambridge.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The number of families thrown into mourning by the war is already having an appreciable effect on the attendance at the West End theatres. The managers feel that war plays are too realistic to be popular for some time to come.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, among its many titles to respect and its varied and anomalous attributes, has won for itself an undisputed authority in the matter of after-dinner speakers. It will not do to say that the speaking at its banquets is always good, but it never fails of being the best that at the given time it is practicable to secure.

In recent times much reliance has been placed upon dogs for arctic traveling. Yet nothing has been done with them to be compared with what men have achieved without dogs. Indeed, only one journey of considerable length has ever been performed in the arctic regions with dogs -- that by Mr. Peary across the inland ice of Greealand.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Two important promotions were announced to-day by President Marvin Hughitt of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad. John M. Whitman, present General Manager, is appointed to the position of Fourth Vice President, a newly-created office. William A. Gardner, Assistant General Superintendent, is appointed to the position left vacant by Mr. Whitman.

With a jack tar swinging the hand lead from the starboard forechains and reporting the depth of water every 200 feet, the cruiser Chicago, flagship of the South Atlantic Squadron, flying the broad pennant of Rear Admiral Winfleld Scott Schley, started for her station from the Tompkinsville anchorage shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

There were a number of developments in the Molineux case yesterday. Two detectives, who have been connected with the District Attorney's office in gathering evidence against Molineux, brought to Mr. Osborne's Office on Friday Charles D. Allen, a young chemist of Brooklyn, who is a friend of Molineux, and formerly worked in the same shop with the prisoner in Newark, N.J.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- A dispatch from Christiansand says that the missing lifeboat of the steamer Coquet, abandoned as before reported, has drifted into Hvaernvaerhiteren. On board the boat were eleven life belts and some provisions. There is a chance that the crew were taken off by some vessel.

Mr. L.S. Carlin has evidently made up his mind that "we are the people." Let us hope that he is an American born, and not one who has broken his vows to his native land to act as a sycophant to the country of his adoption. This sentence is great: "We can quickly improvise a navy that would (or will) sweep every European war vessel from the sea and bombard every seacoast town of Europe."

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- As a result of the United States' request to the powers for assurances regarding the maintenance of the "open door" in China, it can now be said that negotiations have been entered into looking to a more permanent and important international agreement than yet mooted.

THE question about which you ask me to give a brief abstract of my opinions and of the utterances that I have made in regard to it is very often spoken of, it seems to me, "wrong end first." It really is not, so far as I am concerned, marriage and divorce, but it is divorce and remarriage.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25.-- Coincident with the alleged retirement of two commission firms under pressure from the Bureau of Information because of so-called illegal methods of business, the Board of Trade has set about reforming its trading rules. The Directors assert that this reform has been contemplated for some time and that it has nothing to do with and was not the result of the prosecution of the firms in question.

The Boers are affording us a magnificent object lesson on the value of volunteers in defensive warfare. They are strictly volunteers. That is to say, they are not trained at all in barracks; and though when in the field they are under strict laws, their discipline consists really in their readiness to obey.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- The Union League Club, organized thirty-six years ago in support of the cause of the Union in the civil war, and since then a stanch supporter of all Republican administrations, was the scene of a brilliant gathering to-night, the occasion being the observance of Founders' Day.

When thick watches with removable cases were carried, it was the custom for watch- makers, whenever they cleaned a watch, to place in the bottom of the loose case an engraved label with their names and addresses, on which they would write the date of the repair. Frequently these labels were elaborately engraved; sometimes they contained maxims or verses around the outside.

ST. THOMAS, D.W.I., Nov. 25. -- The finances of the Island of Trinidad prevent the ratification of a convention with the United States and petitions have been sent to Mr. Joseph Chamberlain to negotiate arrangements on a basis suitable to the colony's position.

MANILA, Nov. 25. -- The movement against the insurgents in the Island of Panay has resulted in driving them to the mountains, twenty miles inward. The troops engaged were two battalions of the Nineteenth Regiment, a battalion of the Twenty-sixth Regiment, the Eighteenth Regiment, Gordon's Mounted Scouts, and Bridgman's Battery of the Sixth Artillery.

BRIDGEWATER, Mass., Nov. 25. -- The Jo'hn Howard InduStrial Home for Discharged Criminals, which v;as opened Oct. 19, was burned during the niht. All the inmates escaped. The loss is $5,000. The home grew out of a mission w'hieh several years ago was established in Boston for the dssistance of those who had been in prison and upon their release found difficulty in o,btaining work. It probably will be rebuilt.

MANILA, Nov. 25. -- The news which the steamship Brutus brings from Dagupan dispels all doubts that the so-called Filipino Republic is crumbling like a house of cards. Aguinaldo is deserted or being abandoned by the politicians, and the army which a fortnight ago was intrenched at Tarlac and exercised a de facto government over nine-tenths of the people of Luzon, is fugitive in the mountains, with small hopes of re-establishing the machine.

It has always been a reproach to European countries that mendicancy was acknowledged tacitly to be one of the Old World institutions. On the Continent of Europe, particularly in Spain and Italy, the beggars had, and probably do still, constitute themselves a nuisance, while Great Britain and Ireland were not in the least degree behind in their possession of the "army of rags and tatters."

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- Although expected, the burial of the Anti-Strike bill came more swiftly than anticipated by either the Government or the Reichstag. The collapse was due to the conviction of the Centrists that their amendments would not be accepted by the Government.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The hysterical outbreak which has ensued since "Tommy Alkins" and his officer became a full-fledged society craze has already been the subject of satirical articles in the better class of British publications, and now all signs point to a reaction from that unreasoning enthusiasm which is responsible for so many undignified antics.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 25. -- Excitement continues to run high in Lenox over the prospect of the invasion of the trolley in this quiet and exclusive resort. The Aldermen of the City of Pittsfield have granted the franchise to the Lenox line, asked for by the Pittsfield Electric Street Railway Company. This fact makes the Lenox people doubly determined to use every effort possibl to prevent the electric road entering this town.

Though I am not by calling a foolkiller or a reformer, I take the liberty of answering a letter which appeared in yesterday's TIMES. The writer of this epistle has much to say about the "cruel and causeless war" which England is waging against the Transvaal. Let that pass. What astonishes me in Mr. Carlin's letter are these statements: "As a Nation, we are under no obligation to England.

While the game of golf is sufficiently filled with troublesome points to exasperate the good nature of the humblest follower of the sport, it is particularly hard at this time, when the golfer is trying to extract as much comfort as possible out of his last season's play, to be told that the price of golf balls is likely to go up.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25. -- Gen. Nelson A. Miles arrived here last night from New Orleans. When asked what he thought would be the probable result of the British and Boer war in the Transvaal he did not hesitate to say that England would eventually win, but he emphasized the fact that the victory would be bought with great sacrifice of lives and property.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The movement in favor of German cables is growing. Besides a direct cable to New York, now under way, the Government proposes soon to lay one to the German colonies in Africa, via the Azores, with a terminus at Swakopmund. Thence the line will cross to German East Africa, touching at Togo, Cameroons.

Permit an old reader to congratulate you upon the altogether admirable editorial in Saturday's TIMES upon the Sampson-Schley controversy, so called. It is admirable both in tone and in matter, and, to one having no aim other than fairness and justice, is about conclusive. Both Schley and Sampson have their individual merits and also merits in common.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Mme. Patti reappeared at Albert Hall on Nov. 22, but the event passed practically unnoticed. She will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of her first appearance before the public at a charity concert, in 1909, in New York City.

The hearing of grievances against the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company before the State Railroad Commissioners set for yesterday morning at the Borough Hall was adjourned out of respect for the late Vice President Hobart until next Saturday at 10 o'clock.

PRINCETON, Nov. 25. -- There was great rejoicing in Princeton to-night over the football team's victory at New Haven. When news of the result was received bells rang, cannon crackers were heard, and there were cheers everywhere. Soon there were cries of "everybody get wood," and on every side eager students and townspeople alike began to cart wood to the historic cannon at the rear of Old North for a bonfire to greet the victors.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 4. -- "Yes, we have 5 o'clock teas in Dawson," replied Mrs. W. Sampson of Klondike City smilingly, in answer to a question as to society life in the far north.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The position in Natal remains full of perplexities, which the censorship has increased. Although a division and a half have now reached Durban. that place is practically powerless until supplied with cavalry and artillery, and until these arrive the situation will undoubtedly remain grave.
PARIS, Nov. 25. -- The Senate, sitting as a High Court, heard witnesses to-day in reference to the Royalist arrangements for an uprising in February last.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Oct. 27. -- Throughout the whole of the British colonies in these latitudes the people have gone wild with excitement over the declaration of war between Great Britain and the little Transvaal Republic. There is no limit to their enthusiasm, and the whole of these democratic communities have become suddenly infected with imperialism of the most pronounced type.

Augustus Thomas, the dramatist, had neither desire nor intention of becoming the owner of a gold mine three months ago. His plays were good enough "pay dirt" for him. He knows all about plays, but doesn't pretend to know much about gold mines. He will probably know more about mines a year or two hence.

The Sons of the Revolution celebrated the one hundred and sixteenth anniversary of the evacuation of New York by the British at Delmonico's last night. There was an exhibition of the original pictures -- paintings and drawings -- from which Senator Lodge's story of the Revolution was illustrated, and a lecture by G. Grosvenor Dawe on "George Washington from the Standpoint of an Englishman," illustrated with stereopticon views.

A piece of furniture that is going into one New York home and that promises to be convenient as well as useful is a small case for books to go on top of an old-fashioned desk. This desk is handsome, made of mahogany, inlaid, and of the ordinary style, with a top that lets down for writing.

BISMARCK, N. D., Nov. 25. -- The State Supreme Court, in its decision just handed down in Graham vs. Graham, strikes another hard blow at the divorce industry. It holds that residence in the State must be bona fide and characterized by the intention to stay to give the litigant the benefit of the State law.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25. -- Mayor Hayes, backed up by the reformers in City Councils, is retrenching and introducing reforms in every department of the City Government. Councils have passed the ordinance placing the Fire Department on the merit system basis. For years under previous Democratic administrations this department was a refuge for political workers.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 25. -- The football season closed this afternoon with a game with Williams College, which resulted in favor of Wesleyan, 11 to 5, and this victory carries with it the championship in the triangular league.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 25. -- Alarming reports come from the lower Gulf coast of Texas, where a severe storm has been raging. The storm was most severe in the vicinity of Rockport. A number of small vessels have been lost and hundreds of head of cattle are drowned. Many houses have been destroyed, and it is feared some lives were lost.

Why sneer at the tailors? The craft has given to the world more than one famous soldier. What of John Hawkweed, who gave up his needle and thimble for a sword and a shield? His life was indeed, a marvelous one. Knighted by Edward III. on the field of battle, he received the praise of the chivalric Black Prince on the bloody but glorious day at Poitiers.

Winter comes apace, and with it that old befuddling question. I think "The Man Behind the Gun" should make way for his notable confrere. It is now "The Man Behind the Paper" who has the stage. Dear reader, you know who he is. If you are of the gender feminine and have hung to a strap -- listen what I say -- "if" you have -- then you know him. Oh, yes, you know him.

William F. Miller, manager of the exposed Franklin Syndicate, in Brooklyn, is still missing. The police are also looking for his press agent and boomer in chief, Cecil Leslie, who was jointly indicted with Miller, but with the same poor success that attended their efforts in catching the accused men on Friday after the news of the indictments became public.

THE meeting last week at Columbus, Ohio, of the National Municipal League brought together a .highly respectable company of men, many of whom have given years of patient and unrequited labor to the task of improving the government of our cities. Most of them had made long journeys and incurred considerable expense to attend this meeting, and there was small compensation for their outlay in the attention given by the local public to their proceedings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Adjutant General has received the following cable from Gen. Otis:

" No, it is not the people who demand a certain style of furniture," says a woman who knows from A to Z the work of carving, inlaying, painting, and designing in a big up-town furniture house, "it is the furniture which creates the demand. You will almost never find people who ask for a piece of furniture which they have not seen or seen something that is very similar before.

Only three more weeks remain before the grand opera season in this city will, open at the Metropolitan Opera House under the direction of Maurice Grau, the date finally decided upon being Monday evening, Dec. 18. The intervening time will be devoted to filling the engagement in Chicago, one week of which yet remains, while the other two weeks will be spent in Boston.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- State Superintendent of Public Instruction Charles R. Skinner has just completed the school statistics of the State, which will form a part of his annual report, to be submitted to the Legislature in January next. They show that the total expenditures in the State for educational purposes during the school year 1899 were $28,052,999, a decrease of $422,881 compared with the preceding year.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Public funeral services for Garret Augustus Hobart, Vice President of the United States, were held this afternoon in the Church of the Redeemer, at Broadway and Ellison Street, in this city. They were preceded by a short service at Carroll Hall for the family, the President and his Cabinet.

The tercentenary of Oliver Cromwell was celebrated at London on the 14th of November by the unveiling of a statue of the Protector, modeled by Hamo Thornycroft, representing him with a sword in one hand, a Bible in the other, and a lion at his feet. In the evening there was a meeting in the Queen's Hall, in Langham Place, presided over by Lord Welby of the London County Council, and addressed by Lord Rosebery.

Considering that it is nearly half a century since CARLYLE published his "Life, Letters, and Speeches of Oliver Cromwell," it is remarkable that there should just now be such an active rehabilitation of the Great Protector. CARLYLE never did a more useful and inspiring work in the way of authorship than, in this instance, he did in the humbler way of editing, and that is saying a great deal.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Special Policeman Thomas O'Neil, who has been for years employed as a watchman by a number of business houses in the lower part of the city, was shot early this morning by a stranger who had been acting suspiciously in Lexington Street. The officer received three bullets in his body, and is probably fatally injured.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The comment on the South African war generally is tinctured with ill-will for Great Britain. The Deutschc-Zeitung assumes the success of the Boers and advises President Kruger to insist, as the terms of peace, on the cession of Delagoa Bay to the Transvaal, which, it adds, will "lead to a new and better German policy in South Africa."

The exposure and flight of William F. Miller, the Franklin Syndicate manager, have brought to light and admittedly interfered with the plans of another syndicate, which also promises fabulous profits to depositors. The scene of operations of this new syndicate is Greenpoint, and though its office was opened less than three weeks ago the manager said yesterday that its receipts thus far had been in the neighborhood of $10,000.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 7. -- Universal public interest in the war in the Transvaal excites comment among those not Russian by birth, because the ordinary Russian takes little interest in things not directly related to his own country. This is particularly true of the masses. Yet just now aristocracy and peasant alike are interested intensely in the war between the Briton and the Boer.

Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, listened to an application for alimony and counsel fees in a suit for separation instituted by Grace Barringer Bush against her husband, Benjamin Franklin Bush, a comedian, now playing an engagement at Tony Pastor's Theatre. The woman alleges cruel treatment, which, she further declares, culminated in his driving her out of their home at Elmhurst.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25. -- Alexander Brown Sons, bankers of this city, have about completed negotiations for a consolidation of the United Telephone and Telegraph Company, which was recently incorporated by Baltimore capitalists under the laws of New Jersey, and the Federal Telephone and Telegraph Company, which also has a New Jersey charter.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- It would he difficult to imagine anything more ridiculous than the scenes which take place in the Senate during the sessions of the High Court. If it were not for the fact that all parties play an equally ridiculous role in the colossal farce, the fate of the republic would be sealed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The tenth biennial report of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of Illinois, just published, contains an interesting chapter devoted to a study of the results of private and municipal ownership in the operation of electric light and power plants and water works in the cities and towns of that State.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The students and townspeople are still in a happy vein and smiling mood over Princeton's victory at New Haven yesterday. The football championship for 1899 was the principal topic of conversation to-day. A great pile of barrels and boxes is ready for the bonfire which will illuminate the campus to-morrow night.
Republican leaders have begun to look over the National field for the purpose of finding a man to become the running mate of President McKinley next year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Senator R.F. Pettigrew of South Dakota and ex-Congressman Charles A. Towne of Minnesota, members of the National Executive Committee of the Silver Republican Party, are in Chicago. A conference of the Executive Committee of the party will be held here Tuesday, at which plans for the coming Presidential campaign will be discussed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Secretary of the Navy Long to-day received a cablegram from Admiral Watson informing him that the entire Province of Zamboanga, Island of Mindanao, had surrendered unconditionally to Commander Very of the Castine. The surrender was made on the 18th instant. Admiral Watson's dispatch follows:

ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- Gov. Roosevelt, accompanied by Frederick W. Holls of Yonkers, arrived here from New York at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. The Governor had nothing to say for publication, except that Mr. Holls would be his guest over night, to discuss with him the important question of the unification of the State educational system.

The growth in popularity of the Speedway was evidenced yesterday by the immense crowd which gathered there to witness the regular Sunday morning meet of road drivers and their fast steppers. The weather was perfect, the footing firm without being dusty, and for two hours there was not a dull moment. Race followed race in quick succession, and each winner as he wheeled his rig about under the arch of Washington Bridge received enthusiastic applause.
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- A special dispatch from Estcourt, dated Thursday, Nov. 26, and describing the engagement at Willow Grange, says:

Nearly all lines of textiles are advancing. This is particularly true of cotton goods, and every branch of cotton goods shows higher prices from the raw cotton to the finished cloth. Woolens and worsteds for men's wear are in an exceptionally strong position, and the chances that the saying which is frequently heard in the trade that "The mills will never weave again at the prices of the past" is perhaps true.

After a siege of two years by the united Christian armies of Aragon and Castile, Granada fell, and the power of the Moors in Spain was extirpated by FERDINAND and ISABELLA. The annihilation of the dervish power in the Nile Valley is just as significant. One was a victory of the Christian Church over the religion of the sword.

In commenting on a dispatch in THE TIMES from Philadelphia, reporting a sale of pig iron at $25 per ton for immediate delivery. The Financial Chronicle calls attention to some interesting comparative figures of prices. It says:

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 26. -- To-day was the first "dry" Sunday experienced in this city for three years, as a result of the Sunday closing movement instituted by the clergymen of the city, about thirty of whom signed a petition to Mayor Mack urging him to enforce the State law and city ordinance concerning the observance of the day.

A brief outline of the famine conditions now prevailing in the western part of India, upon which the Viceroy, Lord Curzon, has made an exhaustive official report, was published yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES. A more complete summary of the situation has now been obtained from the Rev. J.E. Abbott of 700 Park Avenue, who has received a copy of the statement prepared by Lord Curzon.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 26. -- The staid old college town of Ada is reveling in a sensation that promises trouble. For some time past a disciple of Dowie, the Chicago man, has been preaching in Ada, and has made a number of converts. This follower of Chicago's faith healer, among other remarkable doctrines, contends that no medicine should be used, but that all cures should be effected through faith alone.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The defunct Franklin Syndicate had a number of members in Perth Amboy. Fully twenty of the boatmen who call Perth Amboy home lost large and small amounts. One man lost $400.

PASSAIC, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The plant of the Passaic Beef Company on the Erie Railroad, near the station here, was destroyed by fire this afternoon. The fire was one of the worst that this city has ever seen. The building was largely devoted to cold storage, and the firemen were driven back time and again by ammonia fumes which escaped from the tanks and pipes.

There was an explosion of gas last night in front of 545 and 547 West Fifty-seventh Street that destroyed at thirty-foot section of the sidewalk and curb and gave three children in particular and the neighborhood in general a scare from which they will not recover for several days. That the children escaped unhurt under the circumstances was considered remarkable by those who witnessed the accident.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 26. -- The heirs of Mrs. Nancy E. Taylor of Thornport, Ohio, have sued Dr. J.F. Baldwin for $100,000 damages, charging that he caused the death of Mrs. Taylor, who died from blood poisoning at the Protestant Hospital after an operation had been performed by him.

It is not at all surprising that the Chinese Minister should be indignant at the report that a treaty is under negotiation between the powers of the world for the delimitation of "spheres of influence" in the Celestial Empire and the enforcement of the "open door." He is at least logical from his point of view in saying that such a treaty would closely resemble an agreement between robbers.

It is more than four months since the Municipal Assembly received the application of the company formed to build the tunnel under the East River to connect with the Long Island Railroad and form a line of true rapid transit through the thickly settled section of Brooklyn and out to the suburban region on Long Island.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Dr. von Holleben, German Ambassador to the United States, to-day in the presence of 2,000 Germans, presented a flag sent by Emperor William to the United German Soldiers' Societies in Chicago. In delivering the gift Dr. von Holleben said:
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 26. -- Yesterday at Lebanon, Kan., a sign writer decorated E.D. Heyde's big grain elevator with these Bible texts:

Neither William F. Miller, the proprietor, nor Cecil Leslie, the press agent, of the Franklin Syndicate delivered himself up to the Brooklyn police yesterday, and the present whereabouts of the two men remains as much a mystery as ever.

I see that the Bishop of Albany in the State of New York has been good enough to grace the cause of the English in the Transvaal war with his full approval. There be those of the evil minded that may be moved to sneer at the idea of a leader of the Church approving any war, but the worthy Bishop has thoughtfully provided an antidote for any such carping criticism.

The first for the eighth season of the chamber music matinees at the Aschenbroedel was given yesterday afternoon. It proved to be one of the pleasantest and most interesting of the entertainments for which the music lovers who have been privileged to hear them are so much indebted to Mr. Sam Franko.
