The new United National Association of Post Office Clerks, that claims to have amalgamated the National Association and the United Association of Post Office Clerks, appears to have failed at its inception, or has again split, and over a rule made by the new association to exclude Superintendents and Assistants from active membership.

Somewhat to the surprise of most observers of the market, last week proved a not very active and an irregular one. From the conditions prevailing at the close of the previous week, it seemed likely that trading in the outside market would continue active and that prices would show general strength.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The Republican Caucus Committee appointed at the last session of Congress to prepare a general financial measure for report to the coming Congress is preparing to complete the duty assigned it. To-night seven of the members of the committee gathered at prospective Speaker Henderson's rooms, at the Normandie Hotel, and informally considered the bill prepared by the committee in Atlantic City during the past Summer.
LONDON, Nov. 26. -- This afternoon the War Office posted the following dispatch, dated Cape Town, 12:20 P.M., to-day, from Gen. Forestier-Walker:

The physicians who are attending ex-Mayor Frederick A. Schroeder of Brooklyn, who is seriously ill at the Hotel Margaret, issued the following bulletin as to the patient's condition late yesterday afternoon:

BROCKTON, Mass., Nov. 26. -- As a guest of the city Rear Admiral W.T. Sampson spoke here to-night before a mass meeting held under the management of the Young Men's Christian Association. President Reed of the Young Men's Christian Association presided, and in introducing Admiral Sampson said that if the Santiago battle had been lost it would have been Admiral Sampson's defeat, and therefore the victory belonged to him.
BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- The Deutsche Zeitung publishes a letter purporting to come from Gen. Joubert and dated Ladysmith Oct. 27, in which the writer says:

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- Our market worked itself up to the apprehension point last week. Short loans continued easy at from 3 to 4 per cent., but various causes were instrumental in producing the dread of an immediate advance in the Bank of England rate, the drop in your exchange with London taking the lead.

HAVANA, Nov. 26. -- From every part of the island communications are received by the local papers protesting against a civil Governor General. Almost without exception every paper published in Spanish has objected. The majority condemn the project utterly. The minority think that any change to be made should be by way of reducing the number of American troops in the island.
The Rev. Dr. L.W. Batten, rector of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, took as his subject for his sermon yesterday morning. "Marriage and Divorce." Dr. Batten said in part:

In this morning's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES there is published an interview with the Rev. Dr. Nevin, who is quoted as having "traveled considerably in South Africa," and one of my recent lectures on the Transvaal situation being referred to, I am described as one "who had participated in the Jameson raid," while lower down Dr. Nevin remarks upon "the opinions of a man who formed part of a raiding party," (meaning myself.)

This week's security market finds opportunities much improved, thanks to the inspiriting exhibit presented in the weekly bank statement. That showing, with the re-establishment of surplus reserves of several millions, was far more favorable than Wall Street had counted upon; and further inspiration comes from indications that the West is already beginning to remit large sums of crop money here.

John Levy, whose home is on Flushing Avenue, in the Astoria section of Queens, was held yesterday by Magistrate Smith upon a charge of grand larceny. It is alleged that he stole a phonograph from the saloon of Otto Roesch, at 3 Woolsey Avenue, in the same section of the city.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- A fresh interruption in the East African cable service at this interesting moment has caused a cessation of war news. As yet the War Office has not received Lord Methuen's detailed list of casualties, nor is any information at hand regarding the whereabouts of the Ninth Lancers, who were sent in pursuit of the Boers from Gras Pan.
The annual report of Charles G. Dawes, Controller of the Currency, for the year ended Oct. 31, 1899, has been prepared for transmission to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Contracts for the six new 3,500-ton cruisers were awarded to-day at the Navy Department in accordance with the recommendations of the Board of Construction, one to each of the following firms: William R. Trigg of Richmond, Lewis Nixon of Elizabethport, N.J.; the Bath Iron Works of Bath, Me.; the Union Iron Works of San Francisco; the Fore River Engine Company of Braintree, Mass., and Neafie Levy of Philadelphia.

FISHKILL LANDING, Nov. 27. -- An exceedingly interesting and unique historical collection of paintings has recently been presented to the Cullom Memorial at West Point by P. Kemble Paulding of Cold Spring.

It is particularly difficult to get at the real opinion of Cuba from the utterances of the Cuban press. The peaceable and industrious part of the Cuban population has in view the real prosperity of the island. And those who make up this class are the best judges of the measures which that prosperity requires.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Gen. Otis reports to the War Department that the officer killed in action at Iloilo on the 22d inst. was Charles M. Smith, a Second Lieutenant in the Eighteenth Infantry. Following is the full list of casualties reported by Gen. Otis under date of yesterday:

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- Football as a Thanksgiving Day attraction was decried at the Congregational ministers' meeting to-day as a flagrant desecration of an institution conceived in the spirit of religion. A strong resolution, condemning the practice of playing on that day, was introduced by the Rev. David Beaton of the Lincoln Park Church.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Reports to the Immigration Bureau show that during the last month aliens have been deported from the United States as follows: Public charges, 301; diseased, 24; insane, 5; contract laborers, 30; returned within one year after landing, 3; total, 363.

In to-day's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Howard C. Hillegas makes a rather caustic reply to John-Hays Hammond and challenges his assertion that every American in the Transvaal is in sympathy with the British unless modified with the clause, "every American employed by British mine owners."

MANILA, Nov. 27 -- The insurgents have evacuated Mangataren, Province of Pangasinan, leaving seven American and ninety-four Spanish prisoners, who escaped in the turmoil of the Filipino retreat. The Americans are P.J. Green and George H. Powers of the battleship Oregon, Thomas Edwards and Charles Bird of the Sixteenth Infantry, Henry W. James of the Twelfth Infantry, John Desmond of the Signal Corps, and F.E. Huber of Lowe's Scouts.
BUFFALO, Nov. 27. -- Mr. Ainsley Wilcox said this afternoon:

It was in the form of a Washington dispatch that The New York Sun, in its issue of Nov. 11, published Secretary LONG'S letter to the President anent the Sampson-Schley controversy. The introductory statement here quoted preceded the text of the letter:

A matter of the greatest National importance has for some time past occupied the attention of writers of magazine articles -- the Arbitration Convention drawn up at the Hague conference. This convention is already signed by several of the powers, and will soon be submitted for the approval of the Senate of the United States.

A friend who was in the Union Station in St. Louis a short time ago narrates an incident that attracted his attention, which may be of interest to the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES. A gentleman attired in the garb of a hunter, carrying a gun, entered the station one morning and looked all about him, apparently for the purpose of seeing whether or not he was noticed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 27. -- The statements of the Republican and Democratic State Campaign Committees were filed at the Office of the County Clerk this afternoon as required by law. The Republican committee expended, according to its report, $91,123.97. The largest outlay was in the conduct of the literary bureau which furnished every daily and weekly Republican newspaper in the State with plate service and cartoons during the campaign.

Wall Street sentiment improves materially. The Clearing House statement of Saturday has exerted tonic influence. Commission house business was more in evidence yesterday than for some time past, and from such sources available information is to the effect that the outside public is showing an almost aggressive disposition to resume security market activity.

Mayer S. Auerbach has bought from the various owners the old buildings 40 to 44 West Fourth Street, on a plot 60 by 56.6. The property will probably be resold in the near future to a builder for improvement with an eight or ten story business building.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- The Evening Bulletin to-day publishes the following:

The letter from a special contributor in re Bank and Trust Companies, published in your edition of last Tuesday, was both well-written and well-thought out. But to my mind there is a fundamental mistake in it. Your contributor bases his arguments on the presumption that these trust companies will always have at their head men whose business sagacity will induce them to keep at command an adequate reserve.

The trial of the Miller conveyer for coaling vessels at sea, which has been carried on for a week past outside Sandy Hook by the battleship Massachusetts, and the collier Marcellus, was completed yesterday, and was pronounced by the Maritime Board to be a complete success. The tests showed that over twenty tons an hour could be passed by the overhead system from collier to warship.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 27. -- There are now twenty-four cases of diphtheria in this place. These victims of the disease have been all stricken since the first of the month.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- The Directors of the East Chester Electric Company, desiring to extend its business and powers, to-day filed in the Westchester County Clerk's office a certificate to that effect.

ITHACA, Nov. 27. -- Cornell's football team has taken its last hard practice before leaving for Philadelphia, where it will play the University of Pennsylvania on Thanksgiving Day. All of the men reported at the field this afternoon and took part in a short, snappy line-up against the second team.

Company H of the Eighth Regiment, whose selection of Joseph Solomon as Captain was recently disapproved by Col. James H. Jarvis and Brig. Gen. George Moore Smith of the Fifth Brigade, is likely to get into more trouble. It was learned yesterday that Solomon had failed to pass the Brigade Examining Board, and it is the rule in the National Guard that an officer-elect cannot receive his commission without the approval of that body.

When the consolidation of the various cities now composing the City of New York was undertaken, one of the greatest obstacles to the scheme was the obstinate attachment of Brooklyn to its independence in the matter of schools, and one of the "valuable considerations" offered that community for consenting to be merged in the Greater New York was the practical retention of this independence.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, the discussion of the foreign policy of the Government was resumed. The Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Delcasse, protested against the attacks of the Opposition which, he said, did not recoil even before the risk of embroiling France in external difficulties.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 27. -- Bert Repine of Nashville, Tenn., won the forty-eight hour bicycle race that began in Convention Hall on Tuesday afternoon of last week, and in winning the race established a new record for forty-eight hours. The distance covered -- 961 1/8 miles -- is 87 1-6 miles better than the previous record for a similar contest.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 27. -- It is reported that the Latonia race track will revert to its original owners Jan. 1 next.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 27. -- Thirty-five Mormon Elders engaged in proselyting in the Southern States concluded their annual conference in this city to-day. They were in session yesterday, but the day was devoted to religious exercises. Elder Ben E. Rich, President of Missions in the Southern States and Ohio, was the spokesman of the party, and preached the principal sermon.

NEWARK, Nov. 27. -- Horace E. Fanshawe, a Newark financier, makes the alluring promise to people who have sums from $100 to $1,000 to invest in his care to reap profits for them to the amount of 3 per cent. a week. He asserts that his business is strictly legitimate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Nashville has arrived at Aden, the Potomac at Portsmouth, the Texas at Hampton Roads, and the Nezinscot at Norfolk, where she has been placed out of commission.

The Merchants' Association of New York, through its President, William F. King, issued a general circular yesterday to 12,000 business men asking for subscriptions to aid its work of investigating the proposed Ramapo water contract.

HAVANA, Nov. 27. -- Nothing is known at headquarters in this division or in Gen. Lee's to justify the report, published in the United States and cabled back here, that a thousand armed Cuban insurgents have taken to the woods in the Province of Pinar del Rio, and that a general uprising against the Americans has been planned for Thanksgiving Day.

The work of discharging the coffee from the bubonic plague steamship J.W. Taylor onto lighters was continued yesterday at Quarantine. A number of dead rats have been found in the hold, showing that the fumigation, intended to kill them as well as the germs of the plague, should there happen to be any of the latter in the cargo, had been successful.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 27. -- Judge Hook of the United States Circuit Court this afternoon handed down a lengthy opinion knocking out the Court of Visitation. This is the court established by the last Legislature to regulate railroads and telegraph companies. The Court decided the law is in the nature of confiscation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The General Currency bill, prepared by the Republican caucus committee appointed by the last Congress has received its final revision at the hands of the members and will be given to the press to-morrow afternoon for publication Wednesday after a copy has been mailed to each Republican Representative in Congress.

Yesterday's dispatches mark the beginning of "serious operations" in South Africa. The temporary advantage gained by the Boers through their prompt declaration of war has now been neutralized. Rather it has been exhausted. It cannot be said that the Boers have worked it so well as might have been expected.

The Assembly Investigating Committee resumed its hearings yesterday morning in the room of Part XI. of the Supreme Court, with Chairman Mazet and Messrs. Hoffman, Costello, Wilson, and Fallows present. Among the early arrivals was the Rev. Thomas R. Slicer, who came with the sole purpose of keeping an ear open for the testimony of Asa Bird Gardiner, who was expected to be the principal witness of the day.

In the series of games decided in the Harlem League at the Palace Alleys last night, the Empire Club team established a new world's competition record for the American ten-frame game on regulation alleys. The team scored 1,103 pins, in the third game against the Corinthians, supplanting the record of 1,083 pins held by the New York Club of the Inter-State League.

William F. Miller, the head of the collapsed Franklin Syndicate, of 144 Floyd Street, Brooklyn, through whose agency thousands of men and women were made victims of their own greed and credulity, has not yet been captured by the police. Neither has Cecil Leslie, his press agent and right-hand man.

James Kirchner, a canalboat Captain, proved himself to be of the material of which brave men are made, when he plunged into the East River yesterday afternoon and rescued Mrs. John Irving, who had thrown herself into the stream with her seventeen-months-old girl baby in her arms at the foot of Seventy-sixth Street.
LOi'DO. iX,'ov. 27.The -Var Of/ice has received the following dispatch from Gem Bulter, dated Pietermaritzburg, Natal, Sund a.;.. 1N-or.."26' i

The question which has arisen between the banks and the trust companies is somewhat complicated in its relation to each class of institutions, and it is not easy to state the case so as to avoid the appearance of bias. Last week I presented what may be regarded as the trust company view of the subject, and it is only fair to give equal prominence to the bank view.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27. -- Henry C. Payne, the Wisconsin member, will present at the meeting of the National Republican Committee in Washington, Dec. 12, a resolution recommending a change in the basis of representation in future Republican National Conventions. The resolution follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- " I think the rebellion will be thoroughly crushed out before Christmas," said Secretary Root, commenting on Gen. Otis's dispatches regarding the flight of Aguinaldo.

More than twenty charges of passing worthless checks are hanging over the head of Egon M. Reiner, who was arrested at the Belvedere Hotel yesterday by Detective Sergeant Stransky. The specific charge was the cashing of two checks for $40 each at Charles Baerute's saloon, at 88 First Avenue.

"The Manoeuvres" of Jane," a whimsical comedy by Henry Arthur Jones, was presented at Daly's Theatre last evening to begin the Winter season of Mr. Daniel Frohman's stock company. The performance was well received by the customary large audience never lacking nowadays, on an important theatrical premiere, and the night was one of personal triumph for Miss Mannering, who once more revealed her uncommon ability as an actress of comedy.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 27. -- The Rev. Dr. John Schoenhoft, whose name has been forwarded to Rome as a suitable candidate for the Bishopric of Fort Wayne Diocese, is pastor of St. Lawrence Church, Price Hill. He was born in Cincinnati fifty years ago, and was educated in this city and abroad. He was ordained in Rome in 1873.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 27. -- The game on Saturday with Oberlin University did not deter Coach Warner from putting the Indians through hard practice to-night. Last week was consumed almost entirely in perfecting team work. The time which will intervene before the Columbia game will be utilized in learning new plays.
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Lord Ardilaun has purchased the Muckross estate, which includes the Lakes of Killarney, for 60,000.

After having been confined in the Manhattan State Asylum for the Insane, at Ward's Island, for fourteen years, William B. Redfield will walk out of it to-day a free man. Redfield owes his freedom to the zeal of Miss Mary W. Board, the sweetheart of his boyhood days. The order for his release reached Dr. Bryant, who has charge of the male department of the asylum, yesterday afternoon.

Col. Carlos Garcia, son of the late Gen. Calixto Garcia, is staying for a few days in the city, having recently come on from Washington, where he is one of the Cuban delegation looking after Cuban interests at the capital. Col. Garcia was the author of the proposed scheme of civil government for Cuba.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Arthur J. Balfour, the Government leader in the House of Commons, addressing the National Conservative conference at Dewsbury to-day, repelled the charge that the Government's motive in the war in South Africa was the acquisition of the gold fields.

Official New York was well represented yesterday morning at the pier of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company, in Hoboken, when the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse swung into the stream, having on board Richard Croker, leader of Tammany Hall. His loyal followers crowded the pier to say good-bye to their chief and wish him a pleasant voyage and a safe return.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in the Second Department, yesterday handed down an opinion reversing the decision of Justice Maddox restraining Commissioner Kearny of the Department of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies from entering into contracts with gas and electric companies for the lighting of streets and public buildings.

At the close of the session in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, where Roland B. Molineux is on trial for the murder by poison of Katherine J. Adams in December last, there were ten jurors in the box who are to try the issues which shall determine the guilt or innocence of the prisoner.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 28. -- The State Supreme Court has denied the petition of Paul Corcoran for a writ of habeas corpus. Corcoran was convicted of murder in the second degree and sentenced to seventeen years' imprisonment for murder committed by a mob of which he was a member, and which destroyed the Bunker Hill Mill on April 19.
Extraordinary accomplishments were completed yesterday in Eastern trunk line railway affairs. Changes are brought about in three important railroad systems.

It has taken the Republican leaders a great while to reach the conclusion that something should be done to establish more firmly the basis of our currency, and to agree as to what that something is. Certain prepossessions, amounting almost to obsessions, in their minds, have been, in the words of the unhappy CHARLES, an unconscionable time dying.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The attempt to burn the Village of Three Bridges last night having failed, the incendiaries renewed the attempts to-night, and came even nearer to succeeding than they did last night. Charles Wood's big hay press was set on fire and destroyed. Both of last night's fires were on the outskirts of the village, but to-night the incendiaries selected a building in the more thickly settled part.

ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- Gov. Roosevelt's committee which is to recommend a plan for the unification of the educational system of the State, to-day adopted the tentative plan, which educators here believe will be finally adopted. This contemplates the absorption of the work of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction by the State Board of Regents.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- It is officially reported that the statement that the United States has rejected the agreement between Great Britain and Germany regarding Samoa and has submitted a new draft of an agreement is misleading. It is asserted here that the exact status of the Samoa question is as follows:

The Mazet committee resumed its inquiry into the affairs of the District Attorney's office yesterday, with special reference to the dismissal of defendants in murder cases where Assistant District Attorney McIntyre appeared for the State and his son, Glanvil G. McIntyre, and John Palmieri for the defense.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The Northwestern Elevated Railway Company has asked for a fourth extension of the time set for its completion. This is because of delays caused by labor troubles. Mayor Harrison intimated to-day that he would adhere to the policy of compensation to the city for privileges received in dealing with the company's latest petition.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 28. -- Congressman George H. White, the only negro member of the National House of Representatives, will present a bill in the House next month providing that the Federal courts shall have jurisdiction in cases where persons who have participated in lynching are to be tried.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 28. -- The Indians indulged in their last practice this evening preparatory to the game with Columbia on Thursday. The men were put through rigid signal practice, dummy tackling, and falling on the ball; in fact, they run through all the tactics which will be used by them in the Columbia game.

WASHINGTON, Nov 28. -- The President has directed that a Congressional medal of honor be presented to Col. J. Franklin Bell, Thirty-sixth United States Volunteer Infantry, for most distinguished gallantry in action Sept. 9, 1899, near Porac, Luzon, P.I.

The difficulties under which the publishing house of Harper Brothers has, according to rumor, been laboring for many months resulted yesterday in the entire business passing from the hands of the Harpers into the control of the State Trust Company, acting as trustee for J.P. Morgan Co., holders of $3,500,000 in mortgage bonds.

-- It has often been charged against Americans that they feel an appreciation differing but minutely from admiration for successful shrewdness, and do not, as of course all other peoples invariably do, insist that the shrewdness be displayed and the success be attained only in ways thoroughly approved by orthodox moralists and economists.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The action of Lord Pauncefote and other British Ambassadors in notifying the powers that a state of war has existed since Oct. 11 between Great Britain and the South African republics has prompted inquiries by the various London embassies regarding the nature of the hostilities.

It was on the 11th of October that the Boer declaration of war, anticipating the declaration which Mr. CHAMBERLAIN intended to issue as soon as his preparations for war were completed, was delivered in London. Within twenty-four hours the Boers had occupied British territory and a "state of war" was not only a fact, but the most evident and flagrant of contemporary facts.

The Engineering News is convinced that the underground rapid-transit road will pay. This independent professional opinion is encouraging. The project appears to have passed unscathed all the perils that laid low its predecessors. The contract is now awaiting bidders. That is the last stage but one.

To-morrow's Thanksgiving holiday will be extended by many important Wall Street men over until Monday, and this fact seems to have had the effect of restricting stock market activity, which otherwise might have been fairly counted upon. Yesterday's total transactions nearly reached 600,000 shares, however; and while the list fluctuated irregularly, there were some developments of more than ordinary consequence.

HAVANA, Nov. 28. -- Although there has been a great deal of exaggeration with reference to risings in different parts of the island, there is no doubt that, despite the tranquillity of the country, some apprehension exists lest within the next few months some trouble should occur, in the event that the United States Congress does not give definite assurances respecting the future of Cuba.

Yesterday was absolutely a day in which Cupid played a very important part. There were many weddings, and the receptions which followed these constituted the chief entertainments. The tea for the coming out of Miss Harriet Delafield was possibly the one affair of a purely social character. This morning the trains will be crowded with the holiday seekers who are to be guests at the various house parties to be given over Thanksgiving.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Senator Rawlins of Utah, for the present the sole representative of that State in the Senate, furnishes the following statement with reference to the charges against his State on account of the election of Mr. Roberts:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Noble E. Dawson, a clerk in the War Department, who has been confidential clerk to Gen. Miles, was dismissed to-day because of his style of letter writing. Dawson has been in the War Department for many years, but never gave any indication that he was troubled with humor until President McKinley went West.

ROME, Nov. 28. -- Dr. Bacelli, Minister of the Treasury, presented his financial statement in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. He said the budgets of 1898-9 closed with a surplus of over 15,000,000 lire, owing almost entirely to the increased revenue, exceeding the estimates by 42,000,000 lire.

Through the arrest of Louis A. Gourdain and the closing of the "Imperial National Bank" yesterday the police nipped in the bud a plausible endless-chain scheme, which offered inducements greater, if anything, than those held cut by the Franklin Syndicate and similar concerns, whose operations have recently been brought to light.

With the forty-seventh annual report of the Children's Aid Society, made public at the meeting held yesterday, public attention is called to a subject of perpetual interest. Few can fail to be aroused by the story of thousands of infants and half-grown children raised from the lowest pits of vice and transferred from the curse of poverty into an existence leading to useful citizenship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Commissioner George W. Wilson of the Internal Revenue Bureau, in his report to the Secretary of the Treasury on the operations of his office for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1899, shows that the receipts from all sources aggregated $273,484,573, an increase over the preceding year of $102,617,000, and an increase of $3,484,573 over the estimate of the Commissioner made one year ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28. -- Transport officials at this port are at a loss to explain the alleged unseaworthy condition of the transport Manauense, whose arrival at Manila was reported to-day. A number of the officials were seen to-day, and in every instance it was stated that the Manauense was in first-class condition when she left this port on Oct. 26.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- It seems clear that Lord Methuen is continuing to advance rapidly, and that, finding the railway much damaged, he left it behind him. When telegraphic communication is resumed it is quite possible that news may come of four simultaneous battles -- at Modder River, Arundel, Stormberg, and Colenso.

ALBANY, Nov. 28. -- The Independent Telephone Company of New York City, with a capital stock of $100,000, which may be increased to $20,000,000, filed articles of incorporation to-day with the Secretary of State.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The financial bill prepared by the Republican caucus committee which met at Atlantic City last Spring was to-day made public by the committee. Its text follows:

A fire, which caused the death of an elderly couple and probably fatal injuries to a young man and was attended by many exciting incidents, occurred yesterday afternoon in a four-story brick building at 104 East Houston Street, near the Bowery. The dead are William Helmbold, sixty years old, and his wife, Matilda, sixty-five, who were burned.

MANILA, Nov. 28. -- The transport Manauense, with Lieut. Col. Webb C. Hayes and three companies of the Thirty-first Infantry on board, has arrived here. She narrowly escaped disaster. The officers and soldiers were for twelve days bailing with buckets. The steamer was unseaworthy, undermanned, and short of provisions. Her engines broke down and she rolled three days in a typhoon.

In the current number of The Independent Senor F. AGONCILLO, writing from Paris, publishes "A Letter to the President and the American People." It is not very clear what the Filipino agent wants. His letter is largely devoted to asserting that the Americans and not the Filipinos provoked the beginning of hostilities last Summer and are responsible for the war that has since been raging.
LIVERPOOL, Nov. 28. -- The failure of Bryson, Cooper Co., a small firm of cotton brokers, is announced.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The doors of the home office of the Investors' Trust, 1221 Arch Street, doing business exclusively with patrons outside the city, and promising large profits on investments, were closed to-day. Efforts to find Lipman Keene, the President; Charles L. Work, Secretary, and Miss M. C. Carson, cashier, were unavailing.

PORT VICTORIA, Nov. 28. -- The Emperor and Empress of Germany arrived here from Sandringham at 1:36 o'clock. The Duke of York escorted the Empress on board the Hohenzollern, followed by the Emperor and his suite. The crew of the imperial yacht manned ship and saluted the royal standard as it was hoisted at the main.

At the funeral of Michael Treacy, a contractor of 239 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, which was held in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph yesterday, a hat and a new overcoat belonging to Henry P. Davis, the undertaker's assistant, and containing the Board of Health papers and the cemetery lot papers, were taken during the service.

Henry W. Purdy and George H. Wyatt, composing the firm of Purdy Wyatt, proprietors of the Hotel Metropole, at Broadway and Forty-second Street, made an assignment yesterday to Joseph H. Bailey without preference. They have managed the hotel since May 1 last. The building belongs to the Coe estate.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28. -- A street duel on Wylie Avenue to-day between Policeman C.M. Forbes and Wilson Yancy (colored) resulted in the officer being wounded four times, from the effects of which he will probably die.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The report of Rear Admiral Endicott, Chief of the Bureau of Naval Yards and Docks, submits estimates for improvements amounting to $14,756,439. The recommendations are made with a view to so improving the various stations that the entire navy, including the portion in reserve, may be put into immediate service and kept there continuously.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Caleb Baldwin, Newark's "Grand Old Man," celebrated his one hundredth birthday to-day at his home, 43 Orchard Street, and received the congratulations of nearly forty relatives and a host of friends, among them a delegation from the Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, who presented to him a gold badge of the society.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Informal discussion by members of the Executive Committee of the National Silver Republican Committee and Chairmen of the State Committees, at the meeting held here to-day, developed, as the consensus of purpose, adherence to the Bryan Democracy, "if the right men are nominated." There was no dissent from the opinion that, as the Presidential candidate, William J. Bryan would be "the right man."

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- The Cornell football team indulged in the first secret practice of the season to-day, it being also the last practice of the year at Percy Field. Both the Varsity men and the substitutes reported this afternoon and were given signal and other light work. Much attention was paid to defense.

President George J. Gould of the Manhattan Railway Company said yesterday, after the Executive Committee meeting, that a contract had been awarded to the Westinghouse Electric Company for the heavy generating machinery for the new power house and apparatus for sub-stations which, with the contracts already given for engines, boilers, , practically completes the material required for the stationary installation of the electrical equipment of the system.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 29. -- Horses in training sold well here to-day. Anna Bain brought the top price, $5,300, while the noted Kriss Kringle brought only $2,700. The racing stables of William McGuigan, John W. Schorr Son, Baker Gentry, and others were sold. There were also a lot of stallions, brood mares, and yearlings in the offerings, most of which sold cheaply.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 29. -- Orders were issued to-day instructing the agent of the Fall River Iron Works Cotton Mills in this city to post notices of a 10 per cent. advance in wages, to take effect Monday, Dec. 4. The announcement caused great surprise, as the other cotton mills here have offered their employes only a 5 per cent. increase.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Chicago bankers generally like the draft of the financial bill prepared by the Republican caucus. They say it will establish in law what has been in existence in fact since 1873 -- a gold-standard currency. Ex-Controller Eckels says: "It at least fixes in law the standard of value in this country to be the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The Right Hon. Daniel Tallon, Lord Mayor of Dublin, accompanied by his private secretary, Mr. Kennedy, arrived in Washington to-day. To-night, by appointment, the Mayor and his secretary, accompanied by Dominick Murphy of this city and Commissioner Powderly of the immigration Bureau, visited the White House and spent a half hour in conversation with the President.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Enthusiastic scenes marked the departure to-day of the first detachments of the composite battalion of the Household Cavalry going to South Africa. Surging masses thronged Windsor, cheering and singing, and similar scenes were witnessed in London, in spite of the dense fog.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- In response to an appeal made by the striking workmen of Cramps' shipyards, seventy-five reamers, drillers, and riveters to-day laid down their tools and joined the ranks of the strikers for a nine-hour day. The strikers assert that not more than twenty reamers are now at work in the yard.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Addressing a meeting of 7,000 people in Leicester this evening Joseph Chamberlain devoted the greater part of a long speech to a justification of the Government's policy in South Africa and to a refutation of the arguments of the Earl of Kimberley. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman and others.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 6. -- President Zelaya, Nov. 2, caused the arrest of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Nicaragua, Pereira, at the episcopal residence at Leon, and had him brought, under surveillance, to Managua.
LONDON, Nov. 29. -- A special dispatch from Windsor says that Gen. Methuen's dispatch to the Queen after the battle of Modder River says:

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 29. -- After a trial lasting two nights, William Kemp, for fifty years a member of the Stamford Methodist Episcopal Church, was expelled from that church last night. This was the culmination of friction dating back several years. Other members are about to be tried, and it is probable that they also will be expelled.

FLUSHING, Nov. 29. -- The imperial German yacht Hohenzollern, having on board the Emperor and Empress of Germany and their suite, arrived here to-day from Sheerness. Their .Majesties were received at the landing stage by the Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs, Dr. de Beaufort, and the German Minister and other notables.

The Brooklyn Borough police have relaxed none of their efforts to capture William F. Miller, the manager of the Franklin Syndicate, and his associate, Cecil Leslie, who disappeared last Friday when the 520 per cent. a year concern went to smash. Deputy Chief Mackellar, who still has charge of the case, said yesterday that there was nothing new for publication.
Russell Sage has sold the lot at the northwest corner of Central Park West and Sixty-seventh Street, 25 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The annual report of the General Superintendent of the Life-Saving Service states that at the close of the year the establishment embraced 265 stations, 193 being on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, 56 on the Great Lakes, 15 on the Pacific, and one at the Falls of the Ohio, Louisville, Ky.

The chief interest in football to-day centres in the game between Columbia University and the Carlisle Indians at Manhattan Field. It will be the first time in several years that a game of so much importance has been decided in this city on Thanksgiving Day, and as both teams are considered among the strongest in the country, there is expected to turn out a typical holiday football assemblage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- J.P.V. Gridley, a son of the late Capt. Charles V. Gridley, who commanded Admiral Dewey's flagship at the battle of Manila, was to-day designated for appointment as a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps by President McKinley.

There is no doubt, apparently, that Gen. Lord METHUEN has gained an advantage in the fight at the Modder River, which seems to have been the most important and extensive engagement that has thus far been fought in South Africa. That he himself thinks so there can be no doubt at all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The annual report of Secretary Wilson summarizes the work done by the Agricultural Department during the past year. He comments particularly on the successful extension of the Weather Bureau Service around the Caribbean Sea, giving timely storm warnings to the vessels of the navy and merchant marine.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 29. -- The Buffalo Express, east-bound, while waiting outside the station on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad at the Van Winkle Street crossing to-night was run into by a swiftly-moving accommodation train bound from Phillipsburg, N.J., to Hoboken.

ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn has granted the application of the Aachen and Munich Fire Insurance Company and the Prussian National Insurance Company for permission to transact business in the State of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 29. -- The office of the Investors' Trust, a concern in this city which many believe to be affiliated with the Miller Franklin Syndicate or Brooklyn, remained closed to-day, and none of the officials could be found. No charges have been preferred against the members of the company by investors or by the postal authorities.

The trolley has now been long enough introduced on the Third Avenue Railroad to be a fair subject for candid criticism, and does not deserve to have any additional allowances made for it on the score of inexperience and experimentality. Of course, the first thought of every humane patron of the line is to present his congratulations to the Third Avenue car horse on being extinct.
The games in the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum tournament between the Welcome, Brooklyn, and Iolanthe Councils, scheduled for last night, were postponed until Saturday night.

-- In another column we republish a neighbor's summary of, and comments on, a report just issued by Admiral CERVERA on the cruise that ended with the destruction of his fleet. The fact that the Admiral was allowed thus frankly to reveal the secrets of that hopeless, tragical, and infinitely heroic voyage is perhaps more remarkable than any of its incidents, and they, surely, are remarkable enough.

The story of the revolution of the Eastern railway situation by the Morgan-Vanderbilt deals, by which a syndicate acquires for the Pennsylvania control of the Baltimore and Ohio and W.K. Vanderbilt takes the controlling interest of J. Pierpont Morgan in the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis and the Chesapeake and Ohio system was yesterday the engrossing topic of the railroad and financial worlds.

Amid a great hullabaloo of felicitation William Young's dramatization of Gen. Lew Wallace's renowned and admired work of fiction called "Ben Hur" was produced at The Broadway Theatre last night. The play is divided into six acts, and these are re-divided into a dozen or more tableaus, in which the background of Oriental splendor is happily simulated by the scene painters.

The counsel retained by the New York City Teachers' Association to sue the city for the withheld salaries of teachers in Manhattan and the Bronx Boroughs is Lewis L. Delafield. Dr. William L. Ettinger, Principal of Public School No. 1, in Henry Street, and President of the Teachers' Association, said yesterday:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The following cablegram has been received at the Navy Department from Admiral Watson:

The Mazet committee held but one session yesterday, with Controller Coler as the principal witness. When the hearing opened, Mr. Moss took up for a brief space the question of appointment of Street Opening Commissioners. City Chamberlain Keenan followed, and in answer to a question from Mr. Moss as to whether there is any reason why his office should not be merged into that of the Controller, said:

WEST POINT, Nov. 29. -- The football season for the West Point team will close on Saturday, Dec. 2, at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, when as guests of the University of Pennsylvania the team will line up against the navy team for the first time since 1893. The team will be entertained by the University of Pennsylvania.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 29. -- Louis A. Gourdain, arrested in New York for running a scheme similar, as alleged, to that of the Franklin Syndicate, is well known in this city. Several years ago he served a sentence of ninety days in the county jail here, having been convicted in the Federal Court of fraudulent use of the mails in promoting a lottery scheme.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- Col. James Kilbourne, President of the Kilbourne-Jacobs Manufacturing Company, to-day made public a letter purporting to be from J.K. Turner, manager of the Manufacturers' Information Bureau of Cleveland, Ohio, offering to furnish a complete report of the secret sessions of the convention of the American Federation of Labor, to be held in Detroit Dec. 11.

If the Republican caucus bill shall be enacted into law the gold standard will be established in this country, and there will be no doubt about it. The title of the measure declares that it is "a bill to define and fix the standard of value," and the first section fulfills the promise of the title:
BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- His Majesty's Hohenzollern drama, "The Iron Tooth," will have its first performance in Berlin on the eve of his birthday.

PRETORIA, Nov. 27. -- Gen. Dutort reports that the British made a sortie from Kimberley early Saturday morning and fired on the Boers with artillery and infantry in the darkness. The British sortied where the Bloemhof Boer force was stationed. On the Boer side there were 300 men. Gen. Dutort, who was nine miles off, hastened to the assistance of the Bloemhof contingent with a hundred men.
MANILA, Nov. 29. -- A dispatch from Namacpacan, Province of Union, dated Sunday, Nov. 26, says:
HAVANA, Nov. 29. -- La Lucha, in an editorial on the present situation in Cuba, says:

BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- Ambassador White, who is taking a short vacation in Italy, sent the following dispatch this evening in reply to an inquiry regarding the report that he intended to resign on account of advanced age:

After seventeen days of continual examination of talesmen, during which time 504 men were on the witness stand to answer as to their qualifications for impartially trying the case of Roland B. Molineux, accused of murder in the first degree for having caused the death on Dec. 28 last of Katherine J. Adams by poison, the jury was finally completed yesterday, and with the fourth week of the trial the taking of testimony will begin.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Residents of this place were much interested last night when it became known that Miss Marie Leonard, eldest daughter of John Leonard, a millionaire iron manufacturer, was secretly married in New York to-day to Vosburg Horton, a New York wholesale woolen goods dealer, by the Rev. Father Van Rensselaer of St. Francis Xavier's College, on Sixteenth Street, New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- It is feared by members of the Lippincott Company that the plates of the famous Variorum Edition of Shakespeare, the work of Horace Howard Furness of this city, may have been destroyed They were stored in a vault along with other valuables.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -To-morrow Pennsylvania and Cornell will play their annual Thanksgiving football game on Franklin Field. Both teams have had a good, long rest, and are in almost perfect physical condition for the contest. Cotnell is confident of winning out, while the Pennsylvanians expect to defeat the Ithace[ team by a good score.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- As the result of a conference to-day between Secretary Root and Gen. Leonard Wood, the Fifteenth Infantry and one troop each from the cavalry regiments now in Cuba will be ordered to return to the United States.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The War Office officials to-day reiterate that they have received absolutely nothing to indicate the slightest likelihood of Ladysmith surrendering, while, on the other hand, they expect the place will be relieved shortly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- The Silver Republicans, in conference here Tuesday and Wednesday, planned, it is announced, to ally themselves with and to make use of the "anti-imperialism" agitation, especially in Eastern States, where the silver issue does not attract. Co-operation with Edward Atkinson's following will be sought.
MANILA, Dec. 1 -- 12:50 A.M. -- "As an American officer and gentleman, I protest against being shot with my hands tied."

It was a proud day for the turkey yesterday, the noble fowl which long since attained the dignity of a National institution and to whom the honor of homage has been paid by even so fastidious an epicure as Brillat-Savarin. But it was far otherwise with three of the proudest birds of the air who pose in luxurious captivity in the Central Park "Zoo."

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 30. -- Reports received at the capital this evening indicate that Senator-elect M.L. Hayward has but a few hours to live. He will probably die before morning. Politicians have been busy in Nebraska for some time figuring out the successor to be appointed. There have been thus far four names mentioned prominently for the position -- ex-Senator W.V. Allen, W.J. Bryan, Gilbert A. Hitchcock, and Gov. Poynter.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The annual Thanksgiving banquet of the American Society in London was attended by 275 guests, and was marked by enthusiastic demonstrations of friendship for England in the war against the Boers. A striking speech by Ambassador Choate along that, line, and the presence of the uniformed nurses and doctors of the American hospital ship Maine were the features of the occasion.

When the management of the American Pet Dog Club's annual show, now in progress at the Metropolitan Opera House, decided to keep the show open on Thanksgiving Day there were many in the club who predicted that whatever might be the fate of the show on the other days of the exhibition, it would on the holiday get only a frosty reception from the members of the social world.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Pennsylvania ran the Cornell men off their feet on Franklin Field this afternoon, defeating the Ithaca football team by the score of 20 to 0. That the red and blue would score a victory over the carnelian and white was confidently expected by the Pennsylvania followers, but that they would be defeated by so decisive a score was almost beyond the wildest hopes of the Pennsylvanians.

The house of Herman Buek, a retired merchant, living at 1,019 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, was robbed late on Wednesday night. The thieves took a quantity of old silver, linen, clothing, and the material for a Thanksgiving dinner stored in the cupboard. Such of the material as was cooked was eaten at once, and this was washed down with a gallon of choice wine, set aside for the family feast.
HAVANA, Nov. 30. -- To-day's races were a great success. They were witnessed by a large crowd, in which all Havana society was represented. There were nine events, with entries averaging seven.

I say Amen! to THE TIMES'S able editorial in the issue of yesterday on the subject of the East River tunnel. No one who is at all familiar with the subject but agrees that there is necessity for connecting, not two cities, but two great parts of one city by tunnel, and when this can be accomplished through the medium of a strong corporation and without calling on the taxpayers the case is exceptional.

In a decision of the Court of Appeals, rendered on Nov. 21, the trustees of Union College were declared the beneficiaries under the will of Thomas Armstrong of Plattsburg. The value of the estate approximates $200,000.

KIMBERLEY, Nov. 24. -- There were a few rifle shots early to-day from the direction of Wright's farm, but this is regarded as merely one of the numerous Boer tricks to draw our men out by inducing us to believe that the relieving forces are drawing near. This afternoon the Boers blew up two large culverts near the rifle butts on the railway line toward Spytfontein.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Nov. 30. -- The deer season, which closed to-day in Monroe and Pike Counties, has given great sport to New York hunters. The most remarkable thing in connection with the season which has just closed is that not a single accident has occurred. In Pike County alone it is estimated that nearly 200 deer have been killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 30. -- It was learned to-day that, with few exceptions, the valuable electrotype plates stored in vaults in the J.B. Lippincott Company's building were not damaged by the fire which yesterday destroyed that publishing house.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 30. -- Nicholas Putz, a laborer, shot Mary Wielgosznska, who resisted his attentions, and then turned the weapon upon himself, to-night. The girl was shot through the neck and will recover. Putz shot himself in each breast and cannot live until morning.

Pet dogs of high degree have been having their day at the Metropolitan Opera House, and now household pets of another kind have put forward a claim to public attention at Lyric Hall. These are 500 canaries, assembled to compete in form and grace and voice at the instance of the Greater New York Ornithological Society of Canaries and Cage Birds, whose second annual exhibition opened yesterday.

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Miss Helen M. Gould to-day entertained a large number of the poor persons of Irvington and vicinity at Woodycrest, the home where she regularly cares for many poor children from the city. Prior to the gathering of the poor whose dinner Miss Gould supervised herself the twelve children from the hospitals in New York, who are staying at the place at present, were entertained.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- Emma R. Samaine, a housekeeper, and John Barnard, her employer, were seriously wounded with an axe, which, the police claim, was wielded by Charles G. West, the janitor of the Barnard Block, in the Roxbury district, this morning. Mr. Barnard, who is seventy-nine years old, will probably die.
BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Among the officials who are arriving to see the Emperor is Dr. von Mumm von Schwartzenstein, who, since his arrival from Washington, has been at his home in Baden.

The State of Georgia has a right to congratulate itself and to be thanked by the country for the disposition that it has made of a bill practically intended to disfranchise the ignorant blacks while leaving the ignorant among the whites with all their rights or privileges unimpaired. The striking thing about this result is that it was largely due to an appeal from the intelligent blacks sustained by the whites of the same class.

The body of the late Rev. Father John C. Drumgoole, founder of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin at Great Jones Street, this city, and at Mount Loretto, S.I., was removed yesterday afternoon from the grave in the cemetery at Mount Loretto, where it had rested for eleven years, and was placed in a vault in the memorial chapel recently erected at that place.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The game between the elevens of the Orange Athletic Club and the Newark Field Club at the Orange Oval to-day was, as had been anticipated, a very exciting contest. Fully 3,000 persons were present. It was a stubborn battle, in which brilliant plays were shown at times, while there was also some fumbling.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 30. -- On the links of the Wee Burn Golf Club to-day competitions were played for special prizes. There was a large field of entries. There were three classes, prizes being awarded in each. The results were:

BAYSIDE, L.I., Nov. 30. -- The members of the Oakland Golf Club held a holiday handicap on the links to-day. The handsome silver trophy offered by the Handicap Committee was won by W.G. Barnwell, whose gross score was an even 100. This score was excelled by that of Dr. W.S. Brown, who made the rounds in 54 and 44, respectively, and returned the next best net card.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- "Oliver Goldsmith," the new comedy by Augustus Thomas, produced by Stuart Robson, was well received at the Empire Theatre this afternoon and evening. The theatre was packed at both representations, and Mr. Robson had to respond to several curtain calls. The audiences applauded the climax of the second act enthusiastically, and the situations in the last act also evoked much applause.

Columbia's football players wound up their first season yesterday afternoon in heart-breaking fashion on Manhattan Field. They met the Indian eleven from the Carlisle School, and were played to a standstill, the score against them at the finish being 45 to 0.

The conservative sentiment of the country in all sections receives the currency plan of the Republican House caucus committee with hearty approval and expressions of profound encouragement. It is not merely that the declaration of the gold standard is so clear and explicit, but the admirably simple means for maintaining that standard are seen to be adequate and permanent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The Quartermaster General has received a detailed report by telegraph from Lieut. Col. O.F. Long, in charge of the transport service at San Francisco, on the transport Manauense, which recently arrived at Manila after undergoing frightful hardships in a Pacific typhoon.

Such measures for the common control of great transportation lines as have taken place recently and are now going forward will undoubtedly attract the attention not merely of the professional and political anti-trust agitators, but of many disinterested students of the evolution of modern business who fear the encroachments of concentrated capital.

MANILA, Dec. 1. -- 12:50 A.M. -- Gen. MacArthur is now in Bayambang (or Bayamban) preparing to sweep the country on both sides of the Manila-Dagupan Railroad. Gen. Wheaton is at San Fabian and Gen. Lawton is at Tayug.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 30. -- William J. Bryan's attention having been called to a report from Washington that it was hinted there that he was inclined to favor the nomination of Sulzer for Speaker by the Democratic Congressional contingent, expressed himself as follows in the matter:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- "Love will find the way" should be the motto of the Capp and McElroy families, who are convinced of the truth of the adage by the marriage of Seth Bunker Capp and Miss Katherina McElroy in Trinity Church, New York, yesterday. Both Mr. Capp and his wife are residents of this city. Mrs. Capp is a granddaughter of Matthias Baldwin, the founder of the locomotive works. .She has an annual income.

ROTTERDAM, Nov. 30. -- The Holland-America Line steamer Statendam, Capt. Bonjer, from New York Nov. 19, via Boulogne Nov. 29, for this port, is aground at Maasluis, ten miles below here, and must lighten to float.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 30. -- While William J. Bryan and other politicians were making rear-end train speeches at Elgin, near this city, a boom was started for ex-Gov. James Hogg of Texas for second place on the National Democratic ticket, and Mr. Bryan warmly applauded the proposition.

ROME, Nov. 30. -- Thanksgiving Day was celebrated by the American colony in Rome with the usual enthusiasm. There was a lavish display of Stars and Stripes at the Embassy, the Consulate, and the residences of Americans throughout the city. King Humbert received Ambassador Draper in private audience.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 30. -- Commander Booth-Tucker, head of the Salvation Army, will arrive her to-morrow en route from New York to New Orleans. The purpose of his visit to the South at this time is to inaugurate Salvation Army work among the negroes. Regular corps of negroes will be organized at once in the principal cities of the South.

Thanksgiving was yesterday celebrated in this city in happy, orderly, and comfortable fashion. The weather, delightfully fine for this season of the year, was no small factor in the general result. There were abundant evidences of prosperity and good times in the garb and bearing of wage-earners. Contentment appeared to reign everywhere. There was lavish incentive to be thankful. None need have gone hungry.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 30. -- The Seventh District Congressional Convention, which was expected to sound the ante-election keynote for the Goebel Democracy as well as to nominate a candidate to succeed Evan Settle, deceased, convened to-day, but owing to a tie-up in the Committee on Resolutions it accomplished nothing this afternoon.

Thousands of persons flocked to the Zoological Gardens. in the Bronx, yesterday. Long before the various houses were opened the crowd had swelled to large proportions, and when the doors were thrown open, at 10 o'clock, the combined efforts of half a dozen policemen and as many more attendants were required to handle it.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 30. -- Alabama fittingly rejoices on this Thanksgiving Day at its emancipation from thralldom as a purveyor of raw materials to other districts. To-day, by the entrance on the manufacture of steel by another industrial giant, the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, at Ensley, a suburb of Birmingham, the State opens a new chapter in its history.

The Knickerbocker Athletic Club held a very successful carnival of athletic sports and games yesterday afternoon and evening at the Madison Square Garden. The attendance was not all that the management could have desired, but the conflict of the opening hour with the Thanksgiving dinner time undoubtedly kept many at home.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The number of those who lost their lives in last night's collision on the Boonton branch of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, just west of the road's depot at Barclay Street, this city, has not been swelled to-day, although at least one other death was feared.

H. Walter Webb, who three years ago through ill-health retired from his active duties as a Vice President of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company and as a Director or officer of two-score corporations, was late in the Summer reported as in extremis from phthisis. To-day Mr. Webb's friends rejoice.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- The University of Chicago finished her triumphant series to-day by defeating Brown by a score of 17 to 0. Only twice in the game did Brown menace the Maroon goal, and each time Chicago braced with fine spirit and saved her goal from the rushes of the Rhode Islanders. From centre to end the Maroons outpointed Brown, and gave an exhibition of consistent defense which she has seldom surpassed.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- It has been long since a public speech has been delivered that has excited so much comment as Mr. Chamberlain's yesterday. Every provincial paper, important or unimportant, has a leading editorial this morning discussing it.

Lakewood extended its most welcome hand to its invading army of golfers yesterday, and notwithstanding the frowning battlements of Jasper Lynch's new castle-like house, which is one of the new things of Lakewood this season, the men who find enjoyment and pleasure on the links were royally received. From early morning until late at night the scene around the comfortable Lakewood Golf Club House was one of animation and enthusiasm.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- The celebration of Thanksgiving Day at the Kaiserhof this evening was one of the largest and most successful in the history of the American colony in Berlin. Nearly 300 persons were present, most of them being young men and women students.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- The police authorities to-day telegraphed to Secretary of State Hay at Washington asking if extradition papers for Michael J. Sampson had been honored by the British Government. The message was sent upon the receipt of a cablegram from the Inspector of Police of Tipperary.
LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The Times publishes the following dispatch from Frere, Natal, dated Monday, Nov. 27:

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 30. -- This afternoon 400 boys were given a Thanksgiving dinner in Masonic Hall by Mrs. F.W. Vanderbilt, who was simply having her custom of former years carried out. Long before the doors opened the boys lined the street and a squad of police aided the little fellows to keep in line.

I have heard some comment among Democrats in this city on the letter signed "F.G.R.," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 14, urging the formation in this city of an anti-Bryan, anti-Tammany Democratic association. I cordially indorse the suggestion. Col. Bryan will doubtless be nominated again for the Presidency and again defeated. Tammany having, through its leader, Richard Croker, supported this unwise nomination, will have to bear responsibility for the result.

Rumors that George W. Lederer had resigned the management of the New York Theatre were verified last night. Previously it had been said that Mr. Lederer's retirement was caused by some disagreement with Sire Brothers, owners of the theatre; but the manager denied this.

The search for William F. Miller, the Franklin Syndicate manager, of Brooklyn, and his associate, Cecil Leslie, has not been productive of any important results, so far as could be learned yesterday from the Brooklyn police. The borough Police Headquarters staff seemed to be in a state of intense uneasiness on account of the criticisms of the Grand Jury of Kings County.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- There was a narrow escape from a serious accident at Bunns crossing of the New York and Greenwood Lake Division of the Erie Railroad early to-day. Five men were in a wagon driving from Newark for a day's shooting at Midvale. It was not yet daylight when they reached the crossing, which is a dangerous one.

A perfect day and good birds helped to make the Thanksgiving Day shoot of the Carteret Gun Club at Garden City, L.I., a success. While the chief event of the day was the handicap for the Maryland Cup, presented by Mr. Isaac E. Emerson, the most remarkable shooting was in the doubles. In the latter event the bettors who wagered even money that both birds would not be killed were heavy losers.

The Rev. Dr. MADISON C. PETERS, at Bloomingdale Reformed Church. -- Some people and parties are like a man riding backward on a wagon -- they never see anything until it is passed. The National fogyism, which shudders at the retention of the Philippnes, is opposed to every step in the Nation's progress, and has just seen the wisdom of the step after opposing it.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, in a speech at a luncheon at Leicester to-day, said that ever since the great split in the Liberal Party he had found himself a mark for slanders and misrepresentations of the "baser sort of politicians." But, he added, he had found compensation in the generous appreciation of the majority of his countrymen.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1. -- Private advices received here yesterday tell of a dangerous political disturbance now fermenting in the South American Republic of Ecuador. For some weeks past trouble has been brewing between the Church and State, and recently the situation has become so acute that it is now dangerous for foreigners to venture out of the large towns.

MANILA, Dec. 1 . -- The steamer Salvador, from Zamboanga, Island of Mindanao, which has arrived here brings details of the occupation of the town by Commander Very of the United States gunboat Castine.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The Right Hon. James Lowther, addressing the Gimcrack Club this evening at York, in response to a toast to "The Jockey Club," said that the year now closing had witnessed a remarkable success for the transatlantic system of riding, but he regarded the results as a triumph of the system rather than a triumph of individual jockeys.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- This morning there were filed in the Secretary of State's office at Albany and in the County Clerk's office here articles of agreement of the Rochester Optical Camera Company, to have a capital of $3,500,000. It starts off with a capital of $2,000,000, which will all be subscribed by Rochester financiers.

Walter J. Travis, after enjoying the honors of a gold medal victory in the qualifying match of the Lakewood Golf Club's tournament, found out what it is to be defeated yesterday in the match play contests for the chief cup. It was like a bombshell in the camp of his friends, for Travis and Douglas had been picked by many to meet in the final round.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 1. -- The scheme to appoint at once a Civil Governor and establish a civil government for Cuba is dead. Although the Administration was fully determined upon it a short time ago, and the names of candidates for the Civil Governorship were being canvassed, the scheme has been killed and buried, and is past the possibility of resurrection.
Archibald Watt has sold to William H. Hail the plot at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-second Street, being 100 feet on the avenue and 350 feet on the street.

Two additional volumes in the series of books descriptive of the new possessions of our country have lately appeared from the press of Harper Brothers. Both are from the pens of special correspondents of that firm, and a large portion of the material contained in each volume has already appeared in the columns of the Harper publications.

The investigation of the circumstances attending the wreck on Wednesday night; at Paterson, N.J., on the Boonton Branch of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, is proceeding somewhat slowly, as it involves considerable work. The inquest over the body of Mrs. May B. Roe is to be held next Tuesday, in all probability, at the County Court House at Paterson.

VIENNA, Dec. 1. -- Replying to the addresses of the Presidents of the Hungarian and Austrian Delegations to-day, Emperor Francis Joseph referred with emotion to the "innumerable manifestations of devotion to himself and the imperial house" in which the peoples of the Monarchy had united with himself in deep sorrow at the death of the Empress.

At a charity sale in Rochester last week, a book turned up of a rarity and local interest that gave to the "find" a dramatic character. And, though this is not altogether unusual, the quality fails, generally at least to arouse as much popular curiosity as has this.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Mr. Kipling's poem, "The Absent-Minded Beggar," has made a sensation. It is nightly recited by Mrs. Beerbohm Tree, and it has been copied in nearly all the papers, except The Daily Chronicle, which, as the organ of the Little Englanders, has a very low opinion of all patriotic poetry.

After a long conference with Republican State leaders, Senator Thomas C. Platt announced last night that no definite result had been reached, and that in all probability it would be another week before any legislative programme would be adopted. "Nothing has been settled," said the Senator. "Things are still in the air. I hope that the atmosphere will have cleared before I return next week."

In a very charming paper on "Tennyson and the Old Annuals," which appeared in Literature the other day, Mr. Frederick Lees discourses so charmingly on the subject that it seems rather a pity he should have made several inaccurate statements.

An exhibition of the works of Maximilien Luce has just closed at the Durand-Ruel Galleries in Paris. Luce is a painter, who has come into vogue in France, and who has reached his chief success in his paintings of Parisian street and river scenes and of the country around the French capital.

TRENTON, Dec. 1. -- The thirteenth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland began here to-day in the auditorium of the State Schools. More than 500 delegates were present.

Alluding to your note on the new volume of Mr. Sydney George Fisher, "The True William Penn," considerable light was thrown by this able writer on the character of the founder of the Penn colony in his work entitled, "Men, Women, and Manners of Colonial Times." The title of this work (two volumes) hardly does it justice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Gen. Otis's advices to the War Department to-day show that the advance into the interior is being vigorously pushed and the American troops continue to drive back and disperse the scattered bands encountered. He states that Capt. Warwick, Eighteenth Infantry, was killed in an engagement at Passi, Iloilo Province, on the 26th inst. Gen. Otis's dispatch is as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1. -- Attorney General Edward C. Crow began proceedings in the St. Louis Court of Appeals to-day to have the National Lead Company excluded from the privilege of doing business in Missouri on the ground that it is a trust.

Masterpiece, an Irish terrier, whose tawny rough coat and bristling whiskers would possess no attraction for people who are not "up on dogs," was the star yesterday at the Pet Dog Show, the last session of which was held at the Metropolitan Opera House. He was adjudged the best dog exhibited and to mark his superiority, a two-hundred-and-fifty-dollar gold and diamond medal was presented to his owner. M. Bruckheimer, of this city.

ik*ehemiah and Malachi were fellow-laborers. They were very kindred sp.rits. Nehemiah was the last of the secular Governors appointed over God's people of whom the ScripTures give us any account, lNIaachi was the last of that long series of prophets by whom "God at sundry times, and in divers manners, spoke in time past unto the fathers."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- At a conference of about twenty-five prominent House Republicans, held at the Capitol to-night, it was decided that the eligibility of Representative-elect Roberts of Utah to occupy a seat in the House of Representatives should be investigated and determined, and that pending the decision he should not be permitted to take the oath of office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The office of Auditor for the Navy Department is being deluged with inquiries concerning the progress of claims for extra pay, prize money, , to such an extent that it actually interferes with business. The inquiries relate to claims arising out of the Spanish war.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 1. -- Justus Morris died to-day at his home in Linden. He was born in Lower Rahway in 1821. He first worked on a farm, then made money as a painter, and later was a successful real estate speculator here. He owned some of the best business property in the city. He served on the Board of Chosen Freeholders, and was defeated for Mayor on an independent ticket.
HONESDALE, Penn., Dec. 1. -- Two young sons of Adolph Bea of Haley were hunting in Pike County, when one, Charles, aged fifteen years, was accidentally shot. He lived about twelve hours.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- The subject of free text books for the public schools has been brought before the members of the Board of Education by the resolution introduced by a Trustee, calling for the compilation and publication of the books under the charge of the board. Trustees to-day discussed the plan from this point of view.

The loveliest example, in some respects, of the library of Jean Grolier, the first collector who devoted any attention to the coverings of his books, was recently sold in this city at a high figure, and has become a part of a private collection, another being thus added to the large number of Groliers now in the United States in public and private libraries.
Mr. Howard S. Ruddy, who is the literary editor of The Rochester Herald, has just issued a volume for which all lovers of bookish verse should be duly grateful.

A peremptory writ of mandamus was served upon Controller Coler yesterday requiring him to pay immediately the claim of $700,000 held against the city by O'Brien Clark for extra work done on the new aqueduct. The matter has been in the courts in various phases for several years, and Controller Coler has resisted the payment of the claim ever since he went into office. Mr. Coler said:

The only new feature in the gas situation yesterday was the going into effect of the rate of $1.10 fixed by the New Amsterdam Gas Company at the last meeting of its Directors. "The 'new rate went into effect to-day," said F.S. Hastings, a Director of the company, "and no change is possible without another meeting of the Directors. So far as I know, the new rate will be kept up."

Under the blended colors of the United States and Great Britain 450 members of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York dined last night at Delmonico's, in honor of the one hundred and forty-third anniversary of the foundation of their society. Andrew Carnegie, President of the society, acted as toastmaster.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 1. -- Wilhelmina Eisley, thirty years of age, a servant employed in the family of William White, a wealthy farmer of Yardville, a suburb of this city, was murdered last night by Edgar Williams, it is alleged, a colored man employed on the farm. He is missing.

That the books of William Dean Howells have not as yet any especial attraction for the collector of American first editions was proved by a recent New York book sale, when an almost complete collection of his writings was offered, nearly everything from the "Poems of Two Friends," 1860, to "Stories of Ohio," 1897, being included.

ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- For open corruption of the electorate and general violation of the franchise laws it is likely that a score of prominent Republican and Democratic politicians here may be indicted by the Grand Jury when it sits next week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The first annual report of the Secretary of War, Elihu Root, covers the operations of the department since Nov. 29, 1898, and, beginning with the wiping out of the volunteer army as a result of the signing of the peace protocol by the United States and Spain, covers the increase of the army for operations in the Philippines up to date.

Ex-Chief Justice William L. Chambers of Samoa was one of the speakers at a dinner of the Chi Phi Fraternity at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, and warmly advocated a policy of American colonial expansion. Lloyd McKim Garrison presided.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 1. -- The following memorial addressed to the Democratic members of the United States Senate by the Democratic State Executive Committee of Pennsylvania is made public to-night. It gives in detail the reasons why M.S. Quay should not be permitted to take his seat in the Senate.

I notice in your yesterday's paper a complaint about the non-originality of the Dewey arch. This defect having struck me also, I beg to offer two original propositions and think you will bear me out that the effect suggested would be both novel and striking.

A conflict is coming, so it is said, over the owhershtp of real estate in the Clty of Manila. About three-fourths of all of it within the old and walled city is in the hands of the Roman 'Catholic friars of the various orders. There is not, it is said, any intention to contest the claims of these orders on religious grounds, or any thought of aquiring the property for Protestant uses.

"Mrs. Leicester's School" -- Charles and Mary Lamb's delightful book for children, appears, in one of Dent's dainty editions, with charming old-fashioned illustrations in color by Winifred Green, the artist who illustrated the reprint of "Poetry for Children," published last year.

It was rather a coincidence that Mr. CHOATE at the Thanksgiving Day gathering of Americans in London and Mr. CHAMBERLAIN at a luncheon in Leicester should on the same day have been moved to celebrate "the understanding." And yet it was almost inevitable, given the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- All the interest in the Speakership is centered in the contest among the Democrats. Not all the mem bers of the minority side have arrived, and as for the majority it begins to look as if it would be short many votes of the caucus to-morrow night.
