Would your astronomical correspondent who so delightfully forecasts the monthly sidereal condition of the heavens, or some other expert observer, kindly explain a phenomenon which the writer has observed in connection with the constellation Orion the last three nights, viz., 25th, 26th, and 27th?
FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- Reports have been received here that Charles Lashier, aged thirteen years, is now incarcerated in the Fonda jail on the charge of attempted train wrecking.

BOSTON, Nov. 26. -- The heroine of the Rev. Frank Samuel Child's "An Unknown Patriot" performed her work for her country "without ceasing to be quiet and womanly.'' The omission of "without" in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Nov. 18 rather impaired the description of her character, which is really very beautiful.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 1. -- During a fog yesterday the schooner Clara, from Cape May, N.J., for Philadelphia, with a cargo of sand, while at anchor in the Delaware River, near Chester, Penn., was run down by the Philadelphia and Baltimore steamer Ericsson.

The residents of Pocantico Hills are excited over the probability of the erection in their neighborhood of a casino and hotel by Joseph Oussani, proprietor of the Cairo Cafe and Smoking Parlor at 34 West Twenty-ninth Street. It is likely that a concerted effort will be made to prevent him from carrying out his plans.
LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Lord Rosebery, speaking at Edinburgh this evening, deprecated Mr. Chamberlain's reference to France in his speech at Leicester, and said:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 1. -- At noon today the men of the navy who will battle on the gridiron to-morrow at Philadelphia went forth to meet the champions of the army. They were Naval Cadets Adams, Belknap, Halligan, Fremont, Nichols, Wortman, (Capt.,) Williams, Rogers, Berrien, Long, Weaver, Read, Osterhaus, Cannon, Fowler, Wade, Freyer, Homing, Manley, Land, Dodd, Bruff, Spilman, (Manager,) and Berry.

Drs. Samuel Alexander, L.B. Bangs, and F.W. Jackson, attached to the visiting staff of Bellevue Hospital, were worried yesterday afternoon by the temporary loss of their overcoats and hats. The three physicians were at a meeting of the Medical Board of the hospital. After the more important matters had been disposed of, Dr. Jackson left the board room hurriedly, seizing an overcoat and hat from a table near him.

I should like to have you throw light on a difficulty raised by one of the new books. We are accustomed to look upon Abraham Lincoln as one of the most creditable products of American civilization. Hundreds of men admire him who have little respect for practical politicians of the day, like President McKinley.

It is my good fortune to count among my personal friends a large number of leading members and prominent officers of the Grand Army of the Republic. They are men who have won laurels on the field, and upon their return to civil life regarded a pension certificate as a "badge of honor."

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 1. -- An unknown white masked man robbed a Southern Express Company car near Branchville, S.C., on the Southern Railway, to-night. The train had just left the station when Messengers Ramsey and Rhodes were covered with two revolvers held in the hands of the robber.
FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- The transactions leading up to the killing of McMahon are said to be substantially as follows:
Will you kindly permit me to correct the false impression given to your readers in your issue of the 27th inst. by the Rev. Dr. Batten in his sermon on "Marriage and Divorce"?

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- The Thanksgiving message sent ,.o President -McKinley by Erring XVlns!ow. Secretary of the Anti-Imperialist LtJague, was intended as a personal message by the send*-r. In an interview Mr. N-lnslow said that ttte expression was in no way connected with tile league. Continuing, he said:

CINCINNATI, Dec. 1. -- The paper trade is in a serious condition, according to Albert Diem, one of the largest manufacturers in Cincinnati or the West. Mr. Diem says that within a fortnight the trust will raise prices from 20 to 25 per cent. This condition is due not so much to a desire to make profits as to an actual scarcity of the commodity.

Mrs. Mary J. Wernberg, forty-seven years old, wife of Jere A. Wernberg, a lawyer of Brooklyn, was found dead in her apartments, at 80 Lafayette Avenue, that borough, yesterday morning. She was discovered lying on a bed in an inside room. The room was filled with gas, which was escaping from a jet which had been partly turned on.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 1. -- After a legal battle in the United States courts covering a period of two years. Joseph Wilkins of Washington, D.C., and Howard Butler of this city were to-day sent to prison to serve sentences imposed upon them for having violated the law regarding the sale of oleomargarine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Word comes from the Philippine that the two companies of Macabebe scouts under Capt. Batson are doing so well that it has been decided to organize a full battalion of those natives. The additional two companies will be very useful in the present campaign, in tracking the fleeing remnants of Aguinaldo's disorganized army.

PARIS, Dec., 1. -- Some of the newspapers attach considerable importance to the utterances of Joseph Chamberlain at Leicester yesterday, and consider that they show that Emperor William's visit to England was partly political. The majority, however, characterize certain of Mr. Chamberlain's declarations as empty threats, and regard the suggestion of an alliance between Great Britain, the United States, and Germany as simply eccentric.

-- LAFCADIO HEARN is now an out-and-out Japanese in everything except birth, for not only does he dress and live in all respects like a son of the Sunrise Land, but he has guaranteed the permanency of his separation from the Occident by taking whatever may be the Japanese equivalent of naturalization papers and obtaining all the privileges of a subject of the Mikado by assuming all the duties and obligations of one.
Indeed, I must protest upon your permitting your columns to be used to criticise Prof. Brander Matthews! He is a professor in Columbia University, and it is nothing less than lese majeste!

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- The News says today: "A two-hundred-million-dollar trust is in contemplation. There is every prospect that the American Sugar Refining Company, the Glucose Refining Company, and all of the so-called independent sugar refineries will be consolidated.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Most of the big industrial concerns now making their headquarters in Chicago are threatening to remove their places and offices to New York after the first of the year. The officers of the discontented concerns assign as a motive for the removal that the State Legislature and the Illinois courts are openly hostile to aggregations of capital and corporate enterprise.

The Orientals and Belvideres furnished an exciting finish in the third game in the Harlem League at the Palace Alleys last night. The Belvideres had the game in hand until Hill got a "split," the pins being too far apart to make the spare. This loss of 10 pins, the value of a spare, gave the victory to the Orientals by two pins.

It is announced that the ceremonies attending the unveiling of the two memorial tablets to be placed in the chapel at West Point by the Daughters of the Revolution of the State of New York in honor of Revolutionary patriots and heroes of the Spanish-American war will take place on Tuesday afternoon, Dec. 5, at 3 o'clock.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- A special dispatch received here to-day from Frere, dated Tuesday, Nov. 28, says that while attempting to blow up a 500-foot bridge over the river at Colenso, the Boers were driven back by British artillery and mounted infantry.

Henry Darius McCord and William Mangan McCord, who under the style of Henry D. McCord Son did business as grain and feed merchants and Produce Exchange brokers at 92 and 94 Broad Street, and were rated at from $75,000 to $125,000, made an assignment yesterday. The assignment is without preferences, and the assignee is John P. Truesdell, President of the John P. Truesdell Company, grain merchants.

All the books of the Franklin Syndicate were yesterday brought to Police Headquarters from the Vernon Avenue Police Station, in Brooklyn, in order to facilitate the investigation which the Police Commissioners and Chief Devery are making with a view to finding out how many of the members of the force, if any, were involved in the enterprise, and more especially to learn how it happened that Miller was permitted to escape so easily.

In your SATURDAY REVIEW of Nov. 11 is a letter signed "Iconoclast," in which the writer attempts to find fault with Mr. Brander Matthews's style and also endeavors to take to task certain editors for continuing to present to their readers stories from that author's pen.

Busk Jevons, agents of the steamship J.W. Taylor, which arrived with cases of bubonic plague on board, from Santos, Brazil, and is with her cargo under the strictest quarantine, made application yesterday to enter the vessel in the Marine Division of the Custom House. Collector Bid-well conferred with Col. Dudley F. Phelps, Chief of the Law Division, and Harrison W. Gourley, Controller, and decided not to grant the request of the agents.

I have become so accustomed to looking to the Saturday issue of THE TIMES for accurate and up-to-date news from the world of books that I am surprised to find in your article of last week on "The Three Edi tions of Balzac" remarks that must mislead those not acquainted with the facts.

I take note of funny little discussion in progress over the possibility of Edwin Markham's having read a short and good poem by Miss Cora E. Chase upon "The Man with the Hoe," and then conveyed the idea to himself.

Here is a passage from a letter written by Patrick Bronte in 1855 to Mrs. Sarah Newsome, who had been a nurse in the Bronte household. The full text of the letter and other important matter will be incorporated in the new edition of Marion Harland's "Charlotte Bronte" in the Literary Heartstones series that G.P. Putnam's Sons are publishing.

Of all the articles in last week's issue of your splendid SATURDAY REVIEW, the one that pleased me most and that tickled the very cockles of my heart was that on Frederick Saunders. I have long been an admirer of that delightful medley "Salad for the Solitary and the Social." Indeed, "Salad for the Solitary" was one of the first books that I placed in the little collection that I call my library.

Your correspondent "Similia Similibus" of Saturday last, in comparing "Richard Carvel" with "Hugh Wynne," and merely claiming one to be the "prototype" of the other, only partially reaches the core of the matter, and, instead of hitting the nail on the head, merely strikes a tack.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 1. -- The will of Garret A. Hobart, late Vice President of the United States, was probated and made public to-day. By it $1,000,000 is given to the widow, she receiving that sum outright, besides being made the residuary legatee. The will gives $70,000 to relatives and friends, and $5,000 is given to each of the local institutions of a charitable character.

A new industrial empire is in process of creation in the South. Its foundations and its organic institutions are the mills and factories projected, under way, or already completed that are transforming that part of the Union from a producer of raw material into a producer of manufactured goods.

Looking at some of the Autumn books the other day it occurred to us that illustrated volumes might be roughly divided into three classes: Books with illustrations that really illustrate, those adorned with pretty pictures, either bearing no special relation to the text itself or absolutely misinterpreting it; and a third class containing pictures which seem to have absolutely no excuse for being -- possessing claims neither to beauty nor to suggestiveness.

Many of your readers will probably find the same interest I derived from a reading of Julia A. Shwartz's "Vassar Studies." This book throws quite a new light on the college girl, and describes her character, tastes, and habits, as well as the different types of the steadily increasing class of womankind in a very interesting way.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1. -- Col. John Walter Smith of Snow Hill will be inaugurated Governor on the second Monday in January, 1900, and the Democrats will then resume control in Maryland after four years of Republican rule following thirty years of Democratic sway. The Democratic Legislature will meet on Jan. 2.

Notwithstanding the ephemeral character of many volumes in the great flood of books which has been descending upon us from the publishers since the cessation of hostilities with Spain and the revival of business prosperity, the year which is drawing to a close has been exceptionally rich in its contributions to one department of literature, and that a most delightful one -- the autobiographies, letters, and reminiscences.
Lieut. Henry Canill, who was a member of the staff of Gen. Gomez of the Cuban Army, has entered the Law School of Boston University, intending to take the three years' course.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 15. -- The news of the partial defeat of the English troops in South Africa was received with great enthusiasm in St. Petersburg. Many voices have already been heard of an immediate action by Russia in favor of the Boers. But, as I have before pointed out in the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES, let the friends of the Boers have no illusions on that subject.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2. -- Mail advices from Manila give the following extract from the Filipino proclamation, notable for its references to W.J. Bryan, Rizal, and Aguinaldo, the substance of which was cabled and published some weeks ago. The proclamation was published at Tarlac in La Independencia, the official organ of Aguinaldo, Oct. 28. As translated from the Spanish the preface reads:

The eclipse of the sun that took place yesterday was the last of its kind for the year, and was not visible to us in this part of the world. Neither was any portion of our new dominion included. The other principal event in which December's sun plays a part is his arrival at his furthest point south which occurs on the 21st, on which day astronomical Winter begins.

The consistency of the Citizens' Committee is very much like that of our immaculate police force, which permits a criminal to slip through its fingers and then justifies the act by trying to place the responsibility elsewhere.

The most dramatic incident in the theatrical version of "Ben-Hur" is the return of missing Judah, after an absence of eight years, to the ken of his father's slave, Simonides, at Antioch. Simonides, intrusted with the management of the vast commercial interests of the house of Hur, has become as rich as Caesar since the family's seeming obliteration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Mr. Powell, Minister to Haiti and Santo Domingo, has been instructed to proceed to Santo Domingo to urge upon the Jimenes Government the payment of the overdue installment in the arbitration award to the McKay estate on account of the absorption by the Government of a bridge concession.

It is the general opinion of those best informed that the public schools, especially in the larger cities, are gradually being abandoned by the children of those who can afford to send their children to private schools. It is not easy to fix the extent of this change, but that it is going on will not seriously be denied.

VIENNA, Nov. 21. -- The Austrian Parliament is again working, but now the neutral and non-political Cabinet of Count Clary, which started it working, is shaky. The Conservative majority, of which the Czechs form a part, naturally desire a Cabinet of their own, although no such Cabinet could as yet keep its ground.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The South African war progresses slowly. Gen. Methuen is described in a weekly paper as being a bright spot in the Boer campaign. He has won great popular favor by his victories on the march to Kimberley. No one, it is said, knows the topography between the Orange River and Kimberley better than he does.

The first reflection which the report of the Secretary of War is calculated to induce in reflective minds is, how good it is, in troublous and difficult times, to have a Man at the head of an important public service. This is the difference between Secretary ROOT and his predecessor. Mr. ALGER, poor man, had made, for all we know, as many or more dollars than his successor.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2. -- The twin-screw passenger steamer Chester W. Chopin, built by the Maryland Steel Company for the New Haven Steamboat Company, on her trial trip in Annapolis Roads to-day developed a speed of 20 1/2 statute miles an hour, which was a surprise to the builders, as well as to the officials of the steamboat company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Democrats of the House of Representatives, at their caucus held this afternoon, selected Representative James D. Richardson of Tennessee as their candidate for Speaker after a spirited contest, which lasted through six ballots. This carries with it the Democratic leadership on the floor.

EUREKA, Cal., Dec. 2. -- The steamer Weeott lies a total wreck on the south jetty of Humboldt Bay, having struck the rocks there, and of the twenty-four person on board all are safe but two. One passenger, Mrs. Carmichael, a resident of Ferndale, this county, and Gus Nelson, a seaman of the steamer, lost their lives. Mrs. Carmichael was the first person the life saving crew tried to rescue.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- The army whipped the navy on Franklin Field this afternoon in a hard-fought football battle by the score of 17 to 5. The result of the contest was somewhat of a surprise not only because the West Point cadets were victorious, but because they won by such a wide margin.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The meagre official dispatch giving a list of the British casualties at Modder River and announcing the bare fact that Lord Methuen is still there awaiting reinforcements is only supplemented by a brief special message from Cape Town to-night stating that the Boers destroyed the bridge over the Modder River before the battle and are now concentrating at Spytfontein.

The expected clash yesterday between Senator Michael J. Coffey and Ashley W. Cole, President of the State Railroad Commission, because of aspersions cast upon that body by the Senator three weeks ago, did not come to pass at the hearing in the Brooklyn Rapid Transit troubles, at the Borough Hall, in Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- Judge Braley of the Superior Court has appointed Thomas W-eston receiver of the New England Mutual Accident -- ssoeiatlon. The association entered into an agreement with the General Accident Assurance Corporation, Limited, of Perth, Scotland, last April, whereby all the association's policies were assumed by the Scotch corporation.

The Police Inspector said: "About ten years ago I was watching some workmen pulling down a row of old riverside houses that had had a desperately bad reputation time out of mind, and I can recollect what a start it gave me when they showed me that nearly every house had a great trapdoor through which anything could be dropped into the race of the tide below.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to the following:

No reasonable man will say that The Times is unfriendly to the Democratic Party because it tells that party the truth. It is not Democracy that business men are afraid of, for true Democracy so far from being a menace to the country, is a great conservator of our institutions. It is that which holds Republicans in check and guarantees popular government. But Bryanism and free silver and Populism are a terror to business men.

Richard Mansfield, who has been playing at the Garden Theatre in "Cyrano de Bergerac," was unable to finish his performance last night owing to an attack of nervousness, and the curtain was rung down in the first scene of the last act. Mr. Mansfield, who was immediately taken to his residence, 316 Riverside Drive, it was said by A.M. Palmer, his manager, is not in a serious condition.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 2. -- Silas Derby, who for forty years has driven a stage almost daily from Greenwich station to Banksville, a distance of sixteen miles, to-day made his last trip, and will now retire to his home in Banksville to spend the remainder of his days. He is seventy-seven years of age, and was a shoemaker before he became a stage driver.

The four-story brownstone building at 137 East Fifty-ninth Street, owned by Bloomingdale Brothers, was badly damaged by fire last evening. It was shortly after 6 o'clock, when the streets in the vicinity were crowded with workers going to their homes, that flames were discovered in the second floor of the structure, occupied by Jacob Wohlfield, dealer in furs.

Whenever a war is on rumors of other wars are sure to follow. The conflict in South Africa has already produced a goodly crop of surmises as to foreign intervention, European coalitions, Russian designs on the Persian Gulf. French preparations for avenging Fashoda, and so on. None of these gossipy prophecies are likely to turn out correct.

Will you kindly allow me to appeal through your columns to the Irish readers of your paper, on behalf of the special fund which has been inaugurated by my husband, Sir John Arnott, in The Irish Times, and which is now being distributed by Lord Roberts and a committee for the widows and orphans of the men of the Irish regiments who have fallen nobly in South Africa in defense of our common empire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The caucus of the Republican members of the House to-night was a cut-and-dried affair. The selection of a candidate for Speaker by the party in power is usually an animated affair, but months ago all the other candidates who entered the field after the retirement of Speaker Reed abandoned the contest, laving Gen. David B. Henderson of Iowa the unopposed candidate.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- After a fortnight of preliminary skirmishing, the Reichstag, during the coming week, will begin serious work, starting with the first reading of the budget, which always leads to serious and heated debates, the important part of which will be the advance fight for and against the new naval bill.

Shall it be golf on Sunday or not on Sunday has been the question that has given Staten Island golfers more to talk about and think about recently than any other local event of the year. This Sunday question was forced upon the attention of the Richmond County fraternity through the offer by Col. J.R. Branch of a gold medal that should represent the championship of the island.

Joseph McNally, a lineman in the employ of the Western Union Telegraph Company, twenty-nine years old, of 2,084 Honeywell Avenue, had a narrow escape from death yesterday afternoon. Several wires on a thirty-foot wooden pole opposite 25 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street had become broken, and McNally was assigned to repair them.

The first of Mr. Frank Damrosch's series of young people's concerts was given yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The audience was not one of extraordinary size, but there was close attention to the music and to the explanatory remarks which prefaced the performance of each orchestral number. The plan pursued this season is the same as that of last Winter.

A certain English Consul in Morocco, traveling to the Court, stopped at a little town. Rivers had risen, tribes had cut the road, our Lord the Sultan with his camp was on a journey and had eaten up the food upon the usual road, or some one or another of the incidents of flood or field which render travel in Morocco interesting had happened.

The latest official returns show the strength of the three brigades of National Guard in New York City to be in the aggregate 8,271 officers and men. In numerical strength the Second Brigade, commanded by Gen. James McLeer, leads with 3,085; the Fifth Brigade, Gen. George Moore Smith, follows closely with 3,078, and the First Brigade, Gen. McCoskry Butt, stands third with 2,108 officers and men.

" The Canary," the new play by Constance Fletcher, (George Fleming,) produced in London at the Prince of Wales's Theatre, seems to be a comic treatment of the subject of Ibsen's "A Doll's House." As the "canary," a frivolous, later-day Frou-Frou, Mrs. Patrick Campbell wears some brilliant yellow gowns and acts, they say, with unexpected vivacity and humor.

THERE is no port in the Far East more centrally situated for commercial exchange than Manila, and no individual country better situated for the carrying on of foreign trade exchange up and down the transpacific coast line. The more one studies the map and conditions of trade, the more is he convinced of the truth of these statements.

The action of the Federated Women's Clubs of the State of New York, at their recent convention in Rochester, touching Brigham H. Roberts of Utah being allowed to retain his seat in Congress, has attracted wide attention and requires further notice and consideration. The true explanation of this action must surely be found not in any sympathy on the part of Miss Susan B. Anthony or of the Women's Clubs with Mormonism.

In those who look for an improved real estate market, patience would seem to be a most necessary attribute. As the season advances each week shows a slight increase in the volume of business, as well as a somewhat wider scope in the character of dealings, but the transition is so gradual that the improvement from week to week is often questionable.

Not so many years ago the gathering of samphire for purposes of pickling was a regular occupation on various parts of the coast. This trade is a very ancient, one, and is alluded to by Shakespeare in "King Lear":

LENOX, Mass., Dec. 2. -- William C. Whitney is so much interested in his place on October Mountain that he has been up frequently during the Autumn, and while his house is closed, he has so many people living on his large estate that he can have it opened on very short notice. He greatly enjoys this most secluded spot.

VIENNA, Nov. 21. -- The mild Autumn weather has been so prolonged here that although in deference to the calendar we write of Winter toilets, they have in fact scarcely been called into requisition. Though these charming Autumns are very welcome to the general public, to the business houses they prove a misfortune, as no one will invest in expensive furs or elaborate fur-trimmed outdoor garments merely for ornament.

Steamers la0en with coffee from the port of Santos, that is infected with the bubonic plague, are arriving one after another, and President l{urphy of the Health Board said yesterday that about ten ships from that port will be here, and expressed his determination not to allow any coffee from them to be landed in the city, at least until all danger of infection shall have passed.

A house-to-house religious canvass by district visitors of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, has caused the Rev. Dr. Robert Rogers, the rector of the neighboring Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd, at McDonougn Street and Stuyvesant Avenue, to protest in the columns of his parish paper.

The lighter or off-colored fish are said to be found at all times, but their proportionate numbers may vary more or less at different seasons. Thus, for instance, on the Fraser River the white-meated fish are reported generally to form only a small percentage of the Spring catch, though their number may increase toward the end of the Spring run.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Dec. 2. -- Charles Hoehlein, an engineer on the Long Island Railroad, while running the passenger train which left this place at 11:27 this morning, was knocked from his engine by the breaking of a driving rod, and had a narrow escape from death. The accident occurred between Woodside and Long Island City.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The Empress has descended into the political arena. In accordance with a loyal tradition, the two branches of the Berlin municipality -- the Magistrates and Councilors -- sent her an address of congratulation on her forty-first birthday. To the Magistrates she returned thanks in a letter which excites surprise by a passage declaring that of recent years religious development and peace had been hindered instead of being promoted.

The Board of Education has transmitted to Mayor Van Wyck its report for the fiscal year 1899. The school year reported on is the first during the whole of which the Department of Education under the Greater New York charter has existed. While, therefore, it is the second annual report of the board under the new charter, it is the first annual report for a complete school year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The treaty for the partition of the Samoan Islands was signed at the State Department at 3:20 o'clock this afternoon.

J.A.R. Elliott, the Kansas City expert wing shot, defeated Aaron T. Doty of Paterson, N.J., in the 100-bird match for the Republic Cup, a trophy representing the championship of America, and $100 a side. The match was decided yesterday afternoon at the traps of the Lyndhurst Gun Club, and the score at the finish stood, ninety-one kills for Elliott and eighty-one for his younger opponent.

ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 2;-. -- E.. Arden Noblett of Llewellyn Park was arrested to-day by Policeman AicDonald of West Orange on a charge of being a fugitive from justice. His wife, who owns the house in the park, furnished bail for hfm in tlie sum of $3,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 2. -- The crowning triumph of the National Export Exposition, which closed its portals to-night, comes with the unofficial statement, which will be confirmed officially in a day or two, that after paying all expenses the exposition has actually cleared $100,000.

Madison Square Garden was packed to the doors last evening at the opening of the indoor bicycle season under the auspices of the American Cycle Racing Association. It is seldom that so many champions of international fame are assembled on the same track.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Herman Cohn, alias Grossman, alias Valentine, and numerous other names, was arrested to-night by Chicago detectives as he was trying to escape from the Sherman House. In Cohn's valise were blank checks on many banks, letterheads of various clothing firms, a check perforator, lists of firms, and letters addressed to himself and purporting to be from B. Selig Co., manufacturers of boys' clothing at Philadelphia.

We seated ourselves round it on cushions, and each took possession of the flat piece of scone which supplied the place of a plate during the meal, those articles not being considered a necessary luxury. In the centre of the table stood a large bowl full of white soup, from which everybody ate, taking as many spoonfuls as they chose from the common tureen with the long-handled wooden ladles provided for each guest.

Probably the majority of people suppose that the observatories obtain the correct time from the sun. When the average man wishes to give his watch the highest praise he says, "It regulates the sun," not being aware that a watch which would keep with the sun around the year would have to be nearly as bad as Cap'n Cuttle's.

The crown of Russia is at present presumably the richest in diamonds. Besides several valuable collections in the imperial Treasury, there are three crowns entirely composed of these stones. That of Ivan Alexiowitch contains 881, that of Peter the Great 847, and that of Catharine II. 2,526. One of its most remarkable diamonds is the "Orloff," now set in the top of the imperial sceptre, and on this account is sometimes called the "Sceptre" diamond.

John Wesley contested the three kingdoms in the cause of Christ during a campaign which lasted forty years. He did it for the most part on horseback. He paid more turnpikes than any man who ever bestrode a beast. Eight thousand miles was his annual record for many a long year, during each of which he seldom preached less frequently than 5,000 times.

The local Board of Improvements of the Borough of the Bronx will give a hearing at the Municipal Building, One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street and Third Avenue on Thursday in regard to a public park in connection with an approach to the Willis Avenue bridge from the Southern Boulevard.

Nov. 2, 1809. Late at night, in rain and in darkness, the Seventy-third Battery, R.F. A., left Dorchester Barracks for the war in South Africa, marching on foot to the railway station, where their guns were already entrained.

PARIS, Dec. 2. -- In the Senate High Court to-day M. Guerin asked for an adjournment of the proceedings to permit the selection of new counsel. The Public Prosecutor objected, and M. Guerin argued, amid a fearful din from the prisoners, among whom M. Andre Buffet, Vice President of the Young Royalist League and representative of the Duke of Orleans's Political Bureau, was distinguishable as especially violent.

HAVANA, Dec. 2. -- Civil Governor Emilio Nunez had a conference to-day with Secretary of State Capote, in the course of which he announced that he had officially instructed all the Mayors in the Havana Province to refrain from joining in the protests against the establishment of a civil government, which are being made at the veteran centres, as the Mayors and superior authorities cannot, under existing laws, take part in politics.

Should this bill pass substantially in its present form the "endless chain" will be broken, for legal tenders redeemed in gold cannot be paid out for current expenses and then be used to draw out more gold. The establishment by law of a redemption fund which can be used for no other purpose will prevent any such drafts on that fund as were made during 1893 and subsequent years because of revenue deficits.

There is likely to be some good sport on the Speedway this morning if the weather is at all favorable and the roadbed is in good condition. Several well-known Speedway drivers have new horses and they are anxious to brush them with such horses as Cobwebs, 2:12, owned by Nathan Straus; Jack. 2:121/.z, owned by Dr. Gill, and other well-known Speedway favorites in order to test their peed.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Lucien O. Appleby is preparing to go into thoroughbred horse breeding on an even more extensive scale than ever at his farm here. Thirty head of brood mares have already been added to the score or more of turf matrons already here, the new arrivals coming from several Kentucky stock farms, where Mr. Appleby has had them during the past year.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 2. -- The steamer Warrimoo arrived here to-day from Sydney, bringing Australian advices to Nov. 7. On account of the drought during the past year, the pastoral farming, dairying, and mining industries have been in a state of stagnation, with the result that large numbers of men were thrown out of employment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2. -- One of the largest dry docks in the United States is to be constructed at Hunter's Point, in this harbor. It will be built over a natural rock basin, and will cost about $750,000. The dock is to be 750 feet long, 80 feet wide at the bottom, and 120 feet wide at the top. It will have twenty-eight feet of water over the sills at low tide.

In the Autumn of 1832 malibran was at Rome, and went one afternoon to the Villa Pamphili with Horace Vernet, then Director of the French Academy at Rome, his wife and beautiful daughter, Louise Vernet, and Legouve. The great singer had been mute for several days, such periods of silence in her art being not unusual with her.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Edward Williams, a colored man, narrowly escaped lynching to-night at the hands of a big crowd of angry citizens at Hamilton Square, a small place just outside of this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Republican members of the Senate probably will hold a caucus next Tuesday afternoon to make provision for the reorganization of the committees. There are many vacancies on committees caused by the retirement of Senators. These will be filled, and in cases in which the Republicans are in the minority on committees steps will be taken so to change the membership as to give them control.

To those of our citizens, and especially property owners who have deferred action in the matter of tree planting on our city streets, it may be said that planting may still be done under favorable conditions, as young trees can now be handled and shipped from the nurseries, , in even greater safety than in the early part of the season.

Charles E. Anchisi, sixty-five years old, a veteran of the civil wars of Italy and the United States and a court interpreter in the Harlem Police Court, died at his home, 104 West One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, last night. He had been a sufferer from heart disease, and had a stroke of paralysis Thanksgiving Day.

Daniel Tallon, Lord Mayor of Dublin, and John E. Redmond, the Irish member of Parliament, sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard Line steamship Campania. With them sailed Thomas Kennedy, the Lord Mayor's secretary. They took back with them over $30,000 in American money, which will be used in saving Parnell's house and in erecting a monument to him in Dublin.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- The Tribune to-morrow will say:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Republican members of the Senate Committee on Finance met in the room of that committee to-day in accordance with the call of the Chairman, Senator Aldrich, to consider a currency bill to be presented at the approaching session of Congress. There were present Senators Aldrich, Allison, Platt of Connecticut, Wolcott, and Burrows, Mr. Platt of New York being the only absentee.

The Supreme Court, in its opinion in the case of William H. French against the town of Waterbury, gives expression to its views regarding professional ethics, which will be of interest to every lawyer as well as to many laymen. The opinion is by Judge Hamersley and the rest of the Judges concur.

With a party of friends a Mrs. Rouch of 142 West Eighty-sixth Street dined yesterday evening in a cafe at 105 West Twenty-fifth Street, sitting at a table near the front of the building. After finishing the meal Mrs. Rouch and party left the cafe, and a woman giving the name of Mrs. Florence Raymond of 36 West Sixty-fourth Street, came in and sat down at the table just vacated by the Rouch party.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2. -- The November Grand Jury before being discharged to-day made three presentations, one of which severely censured the Pennsylvania Railroad because of circumstances attending the killing of a woman by an express train at the New York Avenue crossing of the railroad. The woman, the presentment set forth, attempted to drive across the tracks, and after she was upon them the gates were closed.

A horse attached to a runabout, driven by a negro named Lewis Jones of 222 West Sixty-third Street, took fright at Sixty-sixth Street and Broadway yesterday afternoon and ran away. The horse broke a trace and threw Jones to the pavement, and then dashed down Broadway to Sixty-fourth Street.

A FRENCH PROTEST AGAINST ANGLOPHOBIA. -- M. Urbain Gohier, whose book attacking the French Army, "L'Armee Contre la Nation," caused him to be prosecuted by the French Government, has now entered the lists against his fellow-journalists, who are attacking Great Britain. His first article, published in L'Aurore, has not only excited much comment on the Continent, but it has been widely copied in England. Writes M. Gohier:

The Thames was the silent highway of London. One bridge only spanned it, and that bridge led into Southwark. Two thousand wherries, plied by 3,000 watermen, were in constant employment for the purpose of transit, for the bridge resembled a continuous street, having houses on both sides, and it was so narrow that carts could scarcely pass one another upon it.

From the reign of William Rufus to that of Henry VII. fashion appears to have played the most remarkable freaks with shoes and boots -- all the more remarkable because played in a practical very much out-of-door and athletic-recreations age with articles of dress which were necessities for use, not mere accessories capable of any amount of grotesque absurdity.

For the last two or three years guns and ammunition have been imported through Delagoa Bay (that convenient harbor where so little is known) in such quantities that the whole of Afrikanderdom might be said to be armed with guns from this source. Here was an open menace to England and to England's power.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- Lieut. Gov. Wodruff, it is reported, will emulate the example set by Gov. Roosevelt and take boxing and wrestling lessons. He is negotiating, it is said, with the Western fighter Karl Johnson, otherwise known as the "Terrible Swede," who is now in this city. Johnson also is to start a boxing and wrestling class on Jan. 1 for the benfit of the legislators during their three months' stay in Albany.

HEMSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 2. -- E. Willard Roby, a lawyer and well-known polo player and clubman, was badly injured while following the hounds over the Meadow Brook Hunt Club course to-day. Just before reaching the check Mr. Roby's horse fell, pinning its rider down.

MANCHESTER, Ky., Dec. 1. -- Clay County knows that it has a bad name. The visitor finds that knowledge affecting its people who have never participated in the brutal assassinations that have characterized its two feuds of recent date. Decent and law-abiding men, some of them fairly educated, a few well educated, and others quite destitute of education, deplore it and denounce it altogether.

Wordsworth was "literary," but Wordsworth would not have risen early and walked far to get a new poem by Scott or Byron. No, he could wait for these with resignation; he was not in a hurry. But he rose early and walked long miles to get the newspaper during the Peninsular war. The majority of mankind is like Wordsworth in this respect.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The fire reported yesterday on board the British steamer Comeric, Capt. Kennedy, from Galveston, at Havre, catching while discharging cargo, is now under control and no further danger is apprehended.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 2. -- With a large force of men, horses, and implements Contractor Maccolini is pushing ahead the work on the new polo grounds for the Westchester Polo Club, on Bateman's Avenue, near the Newport Golf Club, and when the work is completed it will be the finest polo field in this country.

HELENA, Mont., Dec. 2. -- A petition will be presented to the United States Senate next Monday protesting against W.A. Clark of Butte being permitted to occupy a seat in that body, on the ground that his election was brought about by means of bribery and corruption. The petition has been in circulation throughout the State for two weeks.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 2. -- As the result of a runaway to-day Mrs. E.J. Cook, sister of R.T. Wilson of New York and aunt of young Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, was severely, perhaps fatally, injured. The physicians say she has a fractured skull. Her arm is also broken, and it is thought she received internal injuries. She had not at a late hour to-night regained consciousness since the accident.

There are more things that incapacitate for service than people often think. Now snoring is apparently a harmless occupation, which is not generally supposed to do anything more serious than give people who are in the vicinity of the open-mouthed sleeper the opportunity to exercise patience and a few other worthy virtues.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- There is an interesting discussion at the present time between the judiciary and the bar of New Jersey over the proposition to have the Justices and Judges of the New Jersey courts wear black gowns. The lawyers are much divided on the question, but the Judges are almost a unit in their opposition, so that the gowning of the judiciary of New Jersey is not likely to happen at once.
B.E. Greene says of the Manhattan Railway Company in The Electrical Review's current number:

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- A special to the Chicago Record from San Francisco says: That a large number of he vessels on their way to coast ports, now long overdue, are suffering from lack of food and are damaged by the series of gales that have been blowing at sea for some time past is evident from stories brought here to-day by the steamer Robert Adamson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Many Democrats who were not directly interested in the contest for the leadership of the minority in the House are greatly pleased to-night with the victory of Representative James D. Richardson over his several competitors in the Democratic caucus.

John Insley Blair, "Plain John I.," as the people about his home in Blairstown, N.J., were wont to call him, died yesterday morning at the age of ninety-seven years. The end came in the town which bears his name and in the house in which he lived nearly all his life. He was one of the richest men in the world, and he made all of his vast fortune, estimated at nearly $70,000,000, himself.

Your issue of Sunday quoted from an address of Prof. Chubb in which he spoke of a lessened ability among our people in speaking their own language. It is not at all improbable that he is correct in his views. The causes are plain to be seen -- floods of new books, shoals of magazines and newspapers, the influx of foreigners, and the hurry of modern life.

An assault on a man by a woman with an umbrella and a subsequent fight between the man and the woman's escort in a Broadway cable car last night caused a panic among the women passengers and great excitement among the men. The three combatants were taken to the West Thirtieth Street Station House finally, one of them being locked up.
MR. Washington Gladden, in his article on "Reform in City Government," published in THE TIMES of last Sunday, writes:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The State Department will take no cognizance of the party recruited by Gustav Theilkuhl for the alleged purpose of going to South Africa, as the department officials say the British authorities have not called attention to the movement, and it is not looked upon as serious.

Three results may be confidently looked for from the change from steam to electricity as the motive power of the elevated railroads. The first, and the one in which the public is chiefly interested, will be increased carrying capacity, conducing to the comfort and convenience of the passengers.

The exhibition and sale of the library of Francisque Sarcey, the famous dramatic critic, attracted great crowds in Paris. Rowland Strong says that Sarcey probably established a record in the matter of presentation copies, of which he received an extraordinary number in the course of his long career.

It seems to me that your architectural editor, in his praiseworthy attempt to arouse public opinion to the necessity of better aesthetic qualities in the new bridges proposed to be built by the City of New York, has cast a very unjust slur upon the body of civil engineers of which I am a member, and for whom I ask to be heard.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dee. 2. -- The officla[ closing quotations for mining stocks to-day and yestex day were as follows:

Pigeon roosts, flower gardens, and even kennels and rabbit hutches, on the roofs of the towering buildings about town are now so common as to fail to be matters of novelty to those familiar with the queer phases of city life. But there is one small animal farm that has attracted the attention of hundreds during this Summer and Fall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Surgeon Gen. Sternberg has prepared two bills for introduction immediately upon the assembling of Congress, intended to correct an injustice worked to volunteer and Acting Assistant Surgeons in the army, through a construction of law made by the Controller.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 2. -- Henry S. Hyde of this city, Vice President of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, was interviewed this evening concerning the report that, because of the transferral of American Bell assets to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Bell Company's offices of this State will be removed to New York.

The average patron of the trolley car in New York does not realize the tremendous energy required to move him and his fellow-passengers throughout the city during one given moment of the day. He knows that the electrical power which propels the car on which he happens to be riding comes from somewhere somehow, and he never gives the matter a thought except to kick -frequently -- when there is a break in that supply.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Buffalo Pan-American Exposition managers appear to be seeking to convince the Post Office Department that it would be a good thing to issue a set of special postage stamps to direct attention to the coming show in 1901. The idea is to have a set of nine distinctive stamps, after the style generally of the Columbian Exposition and the Omaha Exposition stamps.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The South African war is still our one preoccupation. Foreign politics, imperial visits, confabulations of statesmen and politicians may be said to interest the public only in relation to this great struggle now darkening South Africa.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- The first of the monster Erie engines arrived from Marion, Ohio, and it was found that its smokestack was three inches too high to allow it to pass through the subway under the Western Indiana tracks at Sixteenth Street. It went back to have the stack cut down.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- The Directors of the American Bell Telephone Company have voted to turn over the assets of the company to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. This is the first step in the removal of the company from Massachusetts to New York.

Findlay Douglas, ex-champion of the United States, won the Lakewood Cup yesterday in the final match for the chief trophy on the Lakewood Golf Club links. He met in the deciding round F.P. Kimball, whose game last week clearly marked him as the strongest Lakewood Club golfer, and the latter was defeated by 6 up and 5 to play.

The musical interest of the past week was large, but the chief pleasure to the connoisseurs was afforded by the piano recital of Mr. Arthur Whiting. This was one of those entertainments to which the serious lover of music can sit and listen with unalloyed delight. To say that is to say that it was something far out of the common order.

Brooklyn Lodge No. 22, B.P.O. Elks, held its annual memorial services at Plymouth Church yesterday afternoon. The services were in memory of forty members, including Hasson H. Wheeler, Harry Kennedy, John M. Ward, Alonzo B. Pettit, Charles H. Byrne, Walter L. Sinn, Henry C. Saffen, David L. Foutz, William H. Leaycraft, Aaron J. Wechsler, David F. Roche, and Harry Gilbert.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 3. -After several :'ears of effort on tile part of the Rikeri-Iine trolIey syndicate in obtaining franchises and building its line, the electric railway between Plainfield and the Elizabeth City line was formally opened last night, and is now in active operation.
In your issue of to-day I find a letter with the caption "Republicans and Polygamy," signed "D." In that letter appears the following paragraphs:

BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- The advance of the Bank of England's rate dominates the attention of the Berlin money market. At first it was supposed that this would not have an immediate effect here, the British balances having been much reduced of late, but since London exchange has already shown a rising tendency the market reckons with the possibility that the Reichsbank will soon raise its rate to 7 per cent.

-- So we are not to have the regenerator of Santiago as Surgeon General, after all. Well, the disappointment can easily be endured. That Gen. WOOD would have made an admirable successor to Gen. STERNBERG is practically certain, and there is no doubt that a man as competent as he to vivify and energize the army Medical Department will be hard to find.

A movement for the raising of funds for a proposed memorial orphan asylum for Cuban children, which shall bear the name of Mrs. Thurston, wife of Senator John M. Thurston, who died shortly after a visit she made to Cuba, was started last night in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church under the auspices of the Thurston Memorial Association.

An informal caucus or conference of some score of prominent Republican members of the House has made arrangements for the disposition of the case of the Mormon member from Utah. When his name is called from the roll on which the Clerk is required to place it, because of the entire regularity of his credentials, objection will be made to his taking the oath of office and the rights and privileges of a member.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- We have got our 6 per cent. bank rate, and the question now is, What is it going to do for us? To some extent the advance was a surprise, for no further adverse movement in foreign exchanges had taken place and the market was to all appearance suffering merely from end of the month Stock Exchange settlement and bankers' balance sheet squeezes.

The published reports of recent concentrations of railroad interests have been followed by the usual denials. These disclaimers have not removed from the public mind the very distinct impression that new relations of amity and alliance have been established between important trunk lines.

The arrangement announced in Boston on Saturday by which the American Bell Telephone Company transfers its assets to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will make New York instead of Boston the centre of the vast Bell telephone system. The purpose, so far as can be learned, is to bring about a more complete centralization of control and a closer connection between the long-distance and local lines operated under rights obtained from the Bell Company.

HAVANA, Dec. 3. -- The Havana Commercial Company is placing armed guards on its plantations in the Province of Pinar del Rio, and will apply to Governor General Brooke for an infantry contingent. Mr. Merrylees, the manager, says:

PRINCETON, Dec. 3. -- President Patton of Princeton University this evening in the pulpit congratulated the members of the football team and based his sermon on the moral lessons to be drawn from their success.

There was great bustle and excitement about the Governors Island-Ferry landing at the Barge Office yesterday afternoon. Word had come across from Governors Island that Admiral and Mrs. Dewey were calling upon Gen and Mrs. Merritt on the island. The crew of the Governors Island ferryboat excitedly communicated to the gatekeepers on this side that the distinguished couple were due to return to the city on the 3 o'clock trip.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 3. -- W.J. Bryan, who is here with ex-Gov. Hogg on an outing, spoke to-day at some length on next year's campaign. Mr. Bryan states that the Democrats will make great gains next year among large classes of people.

The recommendations of the Secretary of War with reference to the future government of Puerto Rico undoubtedly contain the general principles that he would wish to apply, in due time, to the Philippines. These are fairly simple, and it is to be remarked that they have received the cordial approval even of some of the journals that have been the most ardent opponents of the policy of the Administration.

A general amnesty bill will shortly be introduced in the French Chamber which will return to their former place those men who, for their advocacy of the cause of Capt. DREYFUS, became the victims of a military conspiracy. It will be a Government measure. A political expedient the Moderate Republican press will doubtless call it.

It would be unscientific to talk in that way about oxen or honey bees or oysters. Even man has individuality, and women are full of it. Sweeping generalizations may be permitted to the ethnologist, who has to deal with whole races of men: or to the anthropologist, whose subject is all men through all the ages.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 3. -- Information reaching here to-day from Ortiz. State of Sonora, Mexico, stages that Marshal Terhune, an expert mining engineer, who has been in the mines in the Yaqui country for some months past, has arrived at Ortiz. He announces that since Nov. 18 the Yaqui Indians and the Mexican military forces have had several severe engagements, attended with loss of life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Considerable diversity of opinion exists among the Democratic members of the House of Representatives as to the best policy to be followed by the party to-morrow when the Republicans object to the administering of the oath of office to Representative Roberts, the Mormon member-elect from Utah. The Democrats have not yet conferred on the matter, but some understanding may be arrived at to-morrow morning before the House meets.

Three persons were injured in a double runaway accident in Central Park yesterday noon, one of them, and the worst sufferer, being Mounted Policeman Mark J. Glynn, who, with a companion, was engaged in a thrilling effort to bring a frightened horse to a standstill. A score of narrow escapes occurred along the driveways while the exciting events were in progress, and the wonder is only that the casualties were so few.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hilllis, in his sermon in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening, conceded that Christian Science, faith and mind cure were half truths. He cautioned the members of his congregation, however, not to fail to call in a physician should any member of their families fall ill.

The action of the Republican caucus in refusing to consider a change in the rules taking power from the Speaker and the Committee on Rules makes it certain that the autocratic and arbitrary methods now in vogue will not be modified for at least two years. And though they are arbitrary and autocratic, it is by no means certain that they could be changed to advantage.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman preached yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El on "The Presentation of Religion on the Stage." He began by saying that there was no doubt that the theatre had its origin in the church, and that the drama sprang from religious ceremonies. The early priests resembled actors rather than devotees of religion.

Capt. McClusky and his detectives are investigating another clue in the mysterious case of the unknown young woman parts of whose dismembered body were found in this city in October. The investigation was started as a result of a report made to Police Headquarters by Patrolman William D. Mott of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 3. -- The King of Tonga, whose realm is 10,000 miles away, is expected to arrive in Chicago thas week from Australia for an X-ray operation. This is the information derived from a letter received by W.C. Fuchs, the X-ray photographer, from Dr. Donald McLennan, royal physician to King George III.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Serious news comes from the northern sections of Cape Colony. The whole border district between Colesberg and Burghersdorp has declared for the Boers. In Venterstad alone more than 2,000 have joined the rebellion. The farmers have formed a commandeering committee and talk confidently of a triumphant march on Cape Town.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa, who in September last resigned the rectorship of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist, was yesterday afternoon received into the Roman Catholic Church. The ceremony took place in the chapel of the Academy of the Sacred Heart in West Seventeenth Street.

It was like a Summer morning on the Speedway yesterday, and for several hours the crowd of spectators was the largest ever seen there. They stood two and three deep against the railing on the west side of the roadway, while on the east side they were strung out for a mile along the stretch. On the roadway were some of the best road horses in the country, dashing back and forth in brushes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The annual report of Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith was made public to-night. Its chief feature is a plea for Congressional action to stop the abuse of second-class mail privileges, which he says results in an annual waste of upward of $20,000,000. The Postmaster General says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The crusade in this city against the seating of Brigham H. Roberts, as a Representative from Utah culminated in a largely attended mass meeting in the First Congregational Church this afternoon. As many prominent clergymen of Washington as were in a position to be present occupied seats on the platform or in the audience.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The War Office publishes the following dispatch from Cape Town, dated yesterday:

Henry Fournier, the French automobilist, was arrested in Madison Avenue, at Thirty-sixth Street last night, for violation of the speed ordinance. Accompanied by Arthur A. Zimmerman, the ex-bicycle champion, and the latter's father, Fournier started out for an automobile spin.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Mr. Chamberlain's Leicester speech continues to form the subject of extended comment here and abroad. The New York correspondent of The Daily News declares that the speech has "greatly increased the popular dislike of the Colonial Secretary in the United States," and that, instead of being an aid Mr. Chamberlain is "an almost insuperable obstacle to an Anglo-American alliance."

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 3. -- At noon tomorrow the State Board of Election Commissioners of Kentucky will meet to canvass the returns from the last State election and to decide whether Goebel or Taylor is entitled to the certificate of election as Governor. There is not much probability that the matter will be settled to-morrow, and it may be Wednesday or later before a certificate is issued.
GRAND OPERA HOUSE. -- James O'Neill appeared last evening before the usual large audience of regular patrons in his last season's play, "The Musketeers."

DENVER, Dec. 4. -- A rear-end collision occurred between two passenger trains on the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad this morning, in which seven persons were killed outright and several others were severely injured. The accident happened at English Switch, about six miles east of Salida, at 6 A.M.
The promotion of W.J. BRYAN'S nomination or acquiescence in it by New York Democrats is not only bad morals, but blind and suicidal as politics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Promptly at 12 o'clock noon Mr. Frye of Maine, President pro tem, called the Senate to order. The blind Chaplain, the Rev. Dr. Milburn, pronounced the invocation, making a beautiful and touching reference to the death of Vice President Hobart.

" Father Bill" Daly, the turfman, appeared in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday to answer to a complaint of ill-treatment made by James Hathersall, one of his jockeys. The boy, who is sixteen years old, was apprenticed to Daly in 1898 by his father, Matthew Hathersall, of 452 West Twenty-ninth Street, Manhattan, for five years.
Edward F. Sharp has been appointed sole Chicago agent of the Franklin Fire Insurance Company of Philadelphia.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Carlton Sheppard, eighteen years old, was arraigned before Justice Schat to-day on a charge of grand larceny made by his mother, Mrs. Kate Sheppard, of 527 South Seventh Avenue, this place. He was remanded until to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The election of Speaker Henderson and his induction into office, the appointment of the usual committees to wait upon the President, and the seat-drawing contest with the usual amusing features went off without a hitch. The only other feature out of the ordinary was the adoption of the Reed rules for the present Congress.

The work ordered by Henry C. Frick of Pittsburg from M. Theobald Chartran, the French portrait painter, is on its way to this country on the Normannia, and will be exhibited at Knoedler's Gallery, Fifth Avenue, early next month. It is the artist's intention to send it afterward to the Paris Exposition.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 4. -- The Municipal Art Society of Baltimore, which was formed for the purpose of furthering plans which might be of value in beautifying the city, has determined to invite artists and architects from all parts of the country, and delegates from kindred societies in Boston, Philadelphia, and Cincinnati, to attend a conference in this city.

ALBANY, Dec. 4. -- Gov. Roosevelt states that he will not recommend, and there probably will be no change in the provisions of the franchise tax law, so far as affects the application of that law, made at the coming session of the Legislature.

It was announced in Jersey City yesterday that Miss Agnes Robinson, the daughter of Gilbert Robinson of 13 Lewis Street, a veteran circus manager, had married France Reed, a circus performer, and had gone westward with her husband. The marriage took place against the wishes of the bride's parents.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- In a telegram received here to-night at the local offices of the Mooney Boland Detective Agency, the capture of William F. Miller, accused of having been connected with the Franklin Syndicate swindle in New York, was announced as having been effected at Montreal by the agency's operatives, who have been in pursuit of the fugitive since his disap pearance ten days ago.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Errors have been discovered in the accounts of Louis E. Goldsmith, assistant cashier of the National Bank of Port Jervis, and it is said the shortage may reach $20,000 or possibly $25,000. The accounts have been thoroughly investigated by Bank Examiner W.H. Bryan, who has been at work upon the books since Nov. 14.

An audience that filled every seat and overflowed into the aisles gathered last evening in the Concert Hall at Madison Square Garden at a meeting in aid of the Tuskegee Industrial Institute, at Tuskegee, Ala. Ex-President Grover Cleveland was to have presided, but was unable to come, and sent a letter instead, which was read.

Although the seating capacity of Madison Square Garden was at no time heavily taxed by the spectators who witnessed the six-day international bicycle race in progress there under the auspices of the American Cycle Racing Association yesterday, enough interest was shown to make it a safe prediction that before the week is out the event will have proved to be one of the most popular sporting events of the Winter season.

George L. Rives, acting on behalf of the Directors of Harper Brothers, yesterday made application to Justice Gildersleeve for the dissolution of that corporation. Notice of his intended action had been served, as provided by statute, on the Attorney General, but Deputy Attorney General Francis, who represented the Attorney General, said there was no opposition to the application.

The torpedo boat destroyer Barley will be launched from the works of the Gas Engine and Power Company and Charles L. Seabury Co. to-day at noon, at Morris Heights. The invited guests will be conveyed to the Mount Morris works on a special train over the New York Central Railroad, leaving the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street station at 11 o'clock.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- J.J. Van Alen, the American millionaire, has had an unsuccessful experience, it seems, in attempting to render aid to the British wounded in South Africa. He first offered the War Office an ambulance fully equipped, to the extent of 10,000, to be officered and manned by the English army, on condition that he be allowed to accompany it to the front.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The text of the Currency bill prepared by the Republican members of the Senate Finance Committee is as follows:

ALBANY, Dec. 4. -- The question as to how many Supreme Court Justices are necessary is now being debated by the members of the Court of Appeals and the Governor. The Court of Appeals Justices do not want to take any more of the Supreme Court Justices than is absolutely necessary, and do not desire any more than can be worked advantageously.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Julian Ralph, describing in The Daily Mail this morning the battle at Modder River, says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The memorial presented in the Senate to-day by Mr. Carter (Rep., Mon.,) is from some of the members of the Montana Legislature, and against the "validity of the pretended election of William A. Clark" to the Senate. The memorial recites that Mr. Clark "did secure and procure votes in this legislative assembly by the payment therefor, and by the promise of payment therefor, of large sums of money."

Comic operas, as they are called in spite of the obvious fact that few of them are comic and fewer are operas, have to be made in these days to fit the peculiarities of comedians and companies. It can hardly be possible that either the librettist or the composer sits down with a free hand to write what he thinks will please the public.

As long as the Indian Summer weather lasts people will be loath to leave the country and come to town. Although church parade on Sunday was quite brilliant, and for an hour Fifth Avenue looked itself again, still there were many absentees and a number of houses are yet closed. The Ogden Mills have been in and out of town for the past month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Among the men whom the United States is sending into wild and dangerous regions on its errands are fourteen who will receive very little recognition, and will never be known as heroes, and yet they are taking their lives into their hands in the service of their country as truly as the soldiers in the Philippines. They are the census enumerators in Northern Alaska.

Anxiety is felt by officials in charge of Brooklyn's water supply because of the unusually low level of water in the main storAge reservoir of the system at Rockville Centre, L. I. Ordinarily at this season there have been from twenty to twenty-three feet of water in this reservoir. The depth of water in the big basin at present is only four feet, eleven inches.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The American doctors and nurses who are going to South Africa on the American hospital ship Maine visited Windsor Castle this afternoon under the guidance of Major Cabell. A landau and an omnibus from the royal stables took the party from the station. They were received by Lord Pelham-Clinton, Master of the Queen's Household.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 4. -- Prosecutor English and County Detective Keron were informed of a peculiar story late this afternoon, too late to take any steps toward investigation before morning.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 29. -- Local interest in Puerto Rico is just now centred on the elections. The two parties, the Republicans and Federals, are striving for supremacy. The fight is an even one, and it will be a case of the best winning. The result will go a great way toward determining how soon Puerto Rico will be given civil government. Elections are to be held in sixty-nine towns.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 4. -- Fifty-one countries were canvassed by the Kentucky State Board of Election Commissioners to-day out of a total of 119 in the State. Of these 51 countries, 5 were passed over to be considered immediately upon conclusion of the work of the Canvassing Board. The counties passed over are Christian, Fleming, Green, Harlan, and Harrison.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Dec. 4. -- A most remarkable snowstorm struck Northeastern Ohio to-day, the first of the season. At 5 o'clock A.M. the air was filled with large flakes, and by noon, by actual measurement, there was a nineteen-inch depth on a level. This evening it is a little less than three feet deep on a level, and in places four feet.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Discussing the decision of the Supreme Court in the Iron Pipe Trust case, Edward O. Brown said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day transmitted to the House of Representatives estimates of appropriations required for the service of the fiscal year ending June 30, 1901. The aggregate of the appropriations estimated for is $631,081,994, an increase over the estimates for the present fiscal year of $38,033,616, and an increase over the appropriations for the present fiscal year of $34,235,024.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Eager throngs crowded to the Capitol to-day to witness the opening of the Fifty-sixth Congress. Aside from the usual interest which attaches to the assembling of the Nation's lawmakers, there seemed to be a general desire to see the new Speaker sworn in, while many were drawn to the scene by the promise of a unique spectacle in the Roberts case.
BOSTON, Dec 4. -- Local financial circles are still discussing with much interest the pending Bell Long Distance Telephone consolidation, and opinions regarding the proposition differ widely.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Mafeking is safe. A dispatch from Cape Town says:

The trial of Roland Burnham Molineux fcr the murder by poison of Katherine J. Adams on Dec. 28, 1998, began in earnest yesterday in the Court of General Sessions before Recorder Golf and a jury that it had taken three weeks to choose. The theatre of the trial is the largest of the four rooms of the Court of General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day the Addyston Pipe case was decided. This case involved the constitutionality of the combination of pipe manufacturers to manufacture pipe, which, it was charged, was a trust. The decision which was handed down by Justice Peckham was in opposition to the trust. The opinion of the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit was affirmed.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 4. -- Ernest Talmage of this city was shot twice and seriously injured by highwaymen last evening shortly after 8 o'clock in a clump of woods on the old Boston-New York Turnpike Road, as he was on his way home. One bullet penetrated the body near the heart, and the other lodged in the muscles of the left arm.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 4. -- Athletics at Harvard for the fourteen months ending Sept. 1, 1899, necessitated the expenditure of nearly $64,000. Of this sum the management was enabled to devote more than $13,000 to betterments and permanent improvements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Brigham H. Roberts, the Mormon, Representative-elect from Utah, was not allowed to-day to take the oath of office prescribed for members of the House. The programme outlined by the Republican House leaders in their conference Friday night was carried out, so far as it related to the proceedings of the opening day of the session.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4. -- E.J. Baldwin, better known by his sobriquet of "Lucky," this evening signed a contract to sell the Baldwin Hotel site, at Powell and Market Streets, which has remained covered with unsightly ruins for thirteen months.

CLINTON, Mass., Dec. 4. -- A fire started in the cellar of the Clinton Theatre building this afternoon, and before the apparatus could be put into use the whole lower portion of the structure was in flames. From it the flames spread to adjoining property on every side, so that within two hours the theatre building was leveled and one and a half acres of property left a mass of smoking embers.

We congratulate the Executive Committee of the Indianapolis Monetary Convention on the approach of a great success in their work. With the passage in anything like completeness of the financial bill prepared by the House Caucus Committee, Mr. H.H. HANNA and his associates will have a right to feel that they are rewarded for the faithful, intelligent, and unselfish labors that they have crowded into the last three years.
CHICAGO Dec. 4. -- The Tribune to-morrow will say:

John N. Golding has sold for the New York Realty Company the lot at the southwest corner of Broadway and Sixty-ninth Street, 29 by 100, purchased at the last sale of the End estate properties; also, in conjunction with Samuel Goldsticker, for Mrs. Elizabeth Clark to the New York Realty Company the lot, 20.6 by 100, on the north side of Fifty-eighth Street, 200 feet west of Eighth Avenue.

One of the boldest highway robberies of recent years in the vicinity of this city was perpetrated in Yonkers shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The victim is George H. Huber, the museum owner and roadhouse keeper, who is now lamenting the loss of a gold watch and nearly $250 in cash, and who is nursing a severely injured leg as a result of his mishap.

The Haight divorce case, in which Mary L. Haight is seeking a divorce from Henry J. Haight, was continued yesterday before Justice Giegerich. The sun shone into the court windows in the afternoon and bothered the deaf-mute witnesses and the expert interpreter in the sign language. The shades had to be pulled down and the gas lit.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- The Reichstag to-day discussed the Government's Currency bill providing for an increase of silver coins until the amount reaches the proportion of 14 marks per head of the population. Dr. von Thielman, Secretary of the Treasury, said the increase was imperative, adding that thaler pieces would at the same time be withdrawn from circulation.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- An exposition of Japanese dramatic art was given at the Tremont Theatre yesterday afternoon by Otto Kawakami, Sada Yacco, and a company of dramatic students from Tokio. Two plays were given -- a farce, called "Zingoro," (a story of a statuemaker, which proved to be a Japanese version of "Pygmalion and Galatea,") and "The Geisha and the Knight," a three-act tragedy, by Mr. Kawakami.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- All the morning papers have editorials upon President McKinley's message to Congress. The Daily Telegraph says:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- The Call prints the following:

The expressions of the President referring to the currency are on the whole extremely satisfactory. It is to be assumed that they are in harmony with the views of the Secretary of the Treasury, which will be submitted to-day, and they are in entire harmony with the bill of the House caucus committee. The prospect of legislation in accordance with these views is, therefore, bright.

When the news was spread about the city between noon and 1 o'clock yesterday that the Hotel Marlborough was on fire, the thoughts of everybody who heard it reverted to the Windsor catastrophe. A throng of people speedily gathered in the vicinity of the hotel, and in response to two alarms eight fire engines and two hook and ladder trucks were rushed to the scene, with Deputy Chief Purroy in command.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Sir Henry Tate, formerly head of the firm of Henry Tate Sons, sugar refiners, and donor of the Tate Collection and Picture Gallery, Westminster, is dead.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The Common Council met this evening and organized by electing Alderman M.J. Walsh to succeed himself as Chairman. There was a big crowd present to hear the annual message of Mayor Sutherland, who began his second term in office to-day. Mr. Sutherland has shown indications of a socialistic leaning, and during the campaign this was used against him.

There was a larger attendance at Madison Square Garden on the second day of the six-day international bicycle race under the auspices of the American Cycle Racing Association than on Monday. There were few vacant seats last night outside of the reserved front rows, and before midnight these, too, were well filled.

The Queens School Board, at a meeting in Flushing yesterday, denounced Mayor Van Wyck. Commissioner Patrick J. White of Long Island City took exception to the Mayor's charge that the members of the board had rendered themselves criminally liable on the ground that they had exceeded their appropriation.
