Mayor Van Wyck and Controller Coler had a lively tilt at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday over a suggestion made by the Controller to delay action in issuing bonds for the two proposed bridges over the East River until the question of the advisability of constructing tunnels in lieu of bridges could be thoroughly investigated and discussed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Attorney General Griggs, in his annual report to Congress, reviews the work of the Department of Justice during the year, and then says that application is occasionally made to the department to have legal proceedings brought in the name of the United States against corporations or combinations of companies that are alleged to be engaged in forming or maintaining monopolies or agreements in restraint of trade or competition.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 5. -- The League of Domestic Products was organized in Omaha to-day with these officers: Henry T. Oxnard, New York City, President; Julius Stroh, Detroit, Treasurer; R.H. Allen, Nebraska, Secretary. In addition the organization will have a Vice President in every State in the Union. The ostensible purpose of the league is to oppose the annexation of the new possessions.

Anent your recent illuminating editorials on bridge designing "as she is" practiced from an editorial chair, and, with the aid of a kodak, taking in the scope of European as well as American practice, may I ask if you have not neglected to consider the Hogarthian lines of beauty of the Forth Bridge, near the braw toon o' Edinburgh?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The House to-day, by a vote of 302 to 30, referred the question of the eligibility of Brigham H. Roberts, the Mormon Congressman-elect from Utah, to a committee of nine members, to be appointed by the Speaker. This action was consequent on the adoption of the following resolution offered by Mr. Tayler of Ohio Monday:

At a meeting of active and retired Acting Assistant Surgeons of the United States Army, held in the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday for the purpose of formulating a plan to obtain from the Government certain privileges and payments claimed to be due them, a permanent organization was formed under the title of The Association of the Acting Assistant Surgeons of the United States Army in the Spanish War.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 5. -- Ex-Senator Allen, now a District Judge, can name the successor of Senator Monroe L. Hayward, who died at his home in Nebraska City, this morning. This is the sentiment of the Fusionists in Nebraska to-day, and there is no doubt that Gov. Poynter will regard their wishes.

Several hundred members of the Tammany Hall organization in the Eighth Assembly District who attended the regular monthly meeting of the organization last evening at Grand and Ludlow Streets received a surprise when their leader, Councilman Martin Engel, announced that he had resigned as a member of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall.

The prosecution in the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Katherine G. Adams, now being heard before Recorder Goff and a jury in the Court of General Sessions, sprung its first surprise on the defense yesterday, and in so doing it proved the enmity of the defendant for A.A. Harpster, at one time an employe of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club and later a collector for the Ballantine Brewery, in Newark.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The rush of bills in the House of Representatives yesterday was the greatest in the memory of House officials, the total being 861 bills, public and private, and thirty resolutions.
In a fit of insanity yesterday morning Mrs. Anna Glennan of 402 Douglass Street, Brooklyn, killed her five-year-old daughter, May, with a carving knife.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Gen. Otis has informed the War Department of the death of Major Samuel T. Armstrong, Surgeon of the Thirty-second Infantry, which occurred yesterday at Manila. The cause of death is given as leukemia.

The President turns the Philippine problem over to Congress very much as President CLEVELAND turned the Hawaiian tangle over to that body after its opposition to his policy of strict justice at Honolulu had created a situation with which it was beyond the power of the Executive to deal satisfactorily.
N. Brigham Hall has sold for Mrs. Julia C. Blagden the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 32 East Twenty-second Street, between Broadway and Fourth Avenue, 26.3 by 98.9

At the threshold of your deliberations you are called to mourn with your countrymen the death of Vice President Hobart, who passed from this life on the morning of Nov. 21 last. His great soul now rests in eternal peace. His private life was pure and elevated, while his public career was ever distinguished by large capacity, stainless integrity, and exalted motives.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- A charter election was held here to-day, and for the first time in the history of the city it was fought out on party lines. The city is always Republican, but usually there has been a citizens' ticket in opposition to the Republican ticket, and both tickets have contained the names of men of both parties.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- An anti- polygamy meeting was held in the Tarrytown Music Hall to-night. The speakers were Dr. C.R. Greegan, Mrs. Darwin R. James, and Dr. D.J. McMillan. Resolutions were adopted condemning polygamy and favoring the expulsion of Mr. Roberts from Congress.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Lewis E. Goldsmith, the defaulting assistant cashier of the National Bank of Port Jervis, made an attempt to leave here to-day after shaving off his mustache. He was removed from the train by a special officer and taken to his home. A special examiner from the Treasury Department at Washington is now endeavoring to ascertain the exact amount of the defalcation.

Cornelius J. Mahoney, a private detective of 296 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, was run over last night by a trolley car at Ninth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, that borough, and seriously injured. He was removed to Seney Hospital, and it was found necessary to amputate his right leg at the knee. After the operation he rallied a little, but his condition is critical.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A week from next Thursday, according to the plan of the Republican framers of the House Financial bill, it is the purpose to take up and dispose of the Currency bill prepared by the committee that was at work during the interval between the Fifty-fifth and the Fifty-sixth Congresses, and it is confidently expected that the bill will be passed.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5. -- For the first time since Canada became a confederation the principal political issue between the parties will this year not be on the question of tariff. Indeed, the chief question on which the Liberal and Conservative politicians seem to be divided just now is the rather curious one whether the tariff is a matter on which they differ at all.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The funeral of John Insley Blair was held here this afternoon and all kinds of business were suspended while it was in progress. Many business places were closed throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Three caucuses were held in the Senate end of the Capitol to-day. They were under the auspices respectively of the Republican, the Democratic, and the Independent Senators, the last named including the Silver Republicans and the Populists. Each meeting discussed reorganization of the committees and referred details to special committees.

Mrs. Louisa Loomis, wife of Charles H. Loomis of 61 West One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of heart disease, in the rooms of the Cavendish Whist Club, 53 East Fifty-sixth Street. Dr. Mary B. Jewett, who has an office in the building, was summoned, but was unable to do anything.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 5. -- The State Board of Election Commissioners, sitting as a canvassing board, finished its work at 4 o'clock this afternoon and to-morrow at 11 o'clock the members will sit in the State Senate chamber as a contesting board to hear arguments in the cases of eleven contested counties.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- According to the latest accounts of the battle of Modder River, the Boer fire was the hottest on record, and will revolutionize existing theories. It was effective up to 1,600 yards; but the casualties among the prone troops were trifling. It was found impossible to bring the British ammunition reserves to the firing line. Many Boers wearing Red Cross badges were actually employed in serving out ammunition.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The sortie from Kimberley on Nov. 25 appears to have been much more serious than had been supposed. Details are now arriving of a reconnoissance in force by mounted troops under Major Scott-Turner, at dawn, in the direction of a ridge near Carter's Farm, where the Boers were strongly intrenched. Finding the Boer pickets asleep.

HAVANA, Dec. 6. -- President McKinley's message to Congress has been received by Cubans of all classes with much satisfaction. Even the leaders of the Extreme Party admit this, and the announcement that there will be no American Civil Governor has cleared away most of the clouds that had been hanging over the Cuban political situation.

BAYBLON, L.I., Dec. 6. -- James W. Eaton, private secretary of Seth Low, who is Superintendent of the Episcopal Sunday School here, left this place with a party of friends yesterday morning in Mr. Eaton's naphtha launch Clip, for a trip to sea. The boat's machinery broke down when it was several miles off the coast.

Dr. S. Schechter, who is recognized as one of the greatest European scholars in Jewish science, has accepted the call extended to him some time ago to assume the Presidency of the Jewish Theological Seminary in this city, in succession to the Rev. Dr. Sabato Morais, who died about two years ago.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa, whose reception into the Roman Catholic Church took place last Sunday, has written an article which is to be published in Catholic papers in which he explains his reasons for the step he has taken. Following is an abstract of the article:

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- The German Government and press almost unanimously welcome President McKinley's message to Congress. Even the Agrarian papers, always opposed to things American, grudgingly admit that the message is fair and honest. The drift of private comment is virtually the same.

The City Club met last night at the clubhouse, No. 19 West Thirty-fourth Street. The report of the Council, covering the work done since last Spring, was presented and, after some discussion, was adopted. After telling the result of the efforts of the Committee on Legislation last Winter, the report says:

RACINE, Wis., Dec. 6. -- The Rev. David Cheney of the First Baptist Church, and his wife were shot by a burglar to-day at their home on Lake Avenue. Mrs. Cheney was shot in the breast. The ball glanced downward, and is believed to have lodged in her left lung. Mr. Cheney was shot in the abdomen, and in the centre of the breast. Both are in a critical condition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage in his report for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1899, shows the revenues of the Government from all sources (by warrants) to have been $610,982,004.35; the expenditures for the same period, $700,093,564.02, showing a deficit of $99,111,559.67.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Since the death of Senator Hayward of Nebraska there has been a revival of the talk about William J. Bryan's possible appointment to this place. It is pointed out that Mr. Bryan has broken all his engagements without apparent reason, and gone into retreat, so that he could not be accused of influencing Gov. Poynter if the latter should appoint him.

THE Civil SERVICE LAW. -- James C. Strahan, who had been one of the Deputy Tax Commissioners in the former City of New York since 1876, was at the time of the consolidation under the Greater New York charter receiving a salary of $2,700 a year, and his position was in the classified service.

WASHINGTON Dec. 6. -- Gen. Otis to-day cabled the War Department that he has had no word of Gen. Young for a week. This is taken to indicate that Gen. Young is continuing his hot pursuit of Aguinaldo and probably is in a country where he regards it as unsafe to use couriers. Gen. Otis's dispatch, which follows, also gives an official account of Lieut. Col. Parker's engagement at Vigan:

SUMMIT, N.J., Dec. 6. -- The strike of the weavers at the Summit Silk Mills, which has been in progress for nine weeks, developed a lively row this morning between the strikers and twenty-five non-union men brought here by the company to take their places. The police while protecting the new men had to draw their revolvers and fire into the air.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The President to-day nominated Brig. Gen. Leonard Wood, United States Volunteers, to be a Major General of Volunteers. He also nominated Col. Edgar R. Kellogg of the Sixth United States Infantry, Col. Gilbert S. Carpenter of the Eighteenth United States Infantry, Col. William A. Kobbe of the Thirty-fifth United States Volunteers, and Col. J. Franklin Bell of the Thirty-sixth United States Volunteers to be Brigadier General of Volunteers.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- The open split in the Democratic Party in this city, which has resulted in bitter recrimination being hurled back and forth between the two sides, has suddenly change the aspect of the present municipal campaign from one of lethargy to the warmest and most sensational that has taken place in Boston for many years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The reciprocity treaties negotiated during the Congressional recess were transmitted to the Senate to-day and in the executive session were ordered printed and referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.

Ignate Tracer, twenty year old, is a shirt operator, living on the lower east side, and so is Jennie Ehrlich. Accompanied by some of the young woman's friends they went yesterday to the Essex Market Police Court and asked Magistrate Meade to marry them. He refused, and they went to the office of a lawyer, where Alderman Minsky prepared to perform the ceremony.

It has been assumed in certain quarters, and was so assumed by Mr. Roberts in his letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES a week or two ago, that the Constitution defines the qualifications of members of Congress, and that Congress has no right to exclude any one who possesses these qualifications. I think a careful reading of the Constitution will show that this assumption is not well founded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Nearly 800 bills and joint resolutions were introduced in the Senate to-day. Many of them related to local and personal interests, and many were old bills coming over from the last session. The most important were the following:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Representatives of 100 railroads and of various labor organizations appeared before the Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day to attend the hearing of the application made recently by a number of transportation lines asking for an extension till March 2, 1903, of the time in which to equip their cars and engines with safety appliances.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 6. -- The State Board of Election Commissioners heard arguments to-day in the contested election cases. In behalf of Taylor, the Republican candidate for Governor, it was argued that the board had no right to go behind the returns received from the county election officers; the attorneys for Goebel, the Democratic candidate, opposed this proposition.

Would the Supreme Court declare unconstitutional an act of Congress establishing a civil Government and a system of laws in Puerto Rico and the Philippines, but treating them, not as integral parts of the Union, but as dependent possessions? The determination of the political status of those islands is one of the most important questions of National policy now before the people.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The Southern Pacific and Santa Fe Railroads have agreed to call a meeting of passenger officials of all trans-continental lines to consider the California rate war. It will be held in Chicago as soon after Dec. 15 as possible.

Chairman Ashley W. Cole and Commissioner F.M. Baker of the State Railroad Commission, with Charles E. Barnes, electrical expert of the commission, yesterday made a tour of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system with a view of seeing for themselves what facilities were afforded for transportation from Brooklyn to Manhattan and between different points in the first-mentioned borough.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The Internal Revenue Collectors of the United States are organizing a movement to have a new department of the Government established and a new Cabinet position created. A meeting will be held in January to form an association with this end in view.

EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, Dec. 6. -- Letters received from Charles F. Macrum, United States Consul at Pretoria, who has resigned his position, by friends in this city, his home, are of interest in view of the recent dispatches from Washington regarding his experience in the Transvaal as representative during the war of the interests of the subjects of Great Britain in the South African Republic.

BAYARD TAYLOR said of Kaiser WILHELM I. that he had only a moderate respect for Constitutional forms and the will of the people. The present German Emperor faithfully continues and upholds the Hohenzollern traditions. The Divine right of Kings has seldom been more frankly proclaimed than in the Kaiser's contribution to a portrait and autograph album published at Leipsic:

Interest in the six-day international bicycle race at Madison Square Garden continued unabated all day yesterday. The crowd of the night before had dwindled to a few hundred men and boys and an occasional woman when daylight broke yesterday morning, but they were not left alone long after that in possession of the Garden.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- Three years ago Robert Earl disappeared from his home in Rochester and no trace could be found of him. Last September a man was found dead in an icehouse in Rochester and Mrs. Earl identified the body as that of her husband. The body was buried and a small amount of insurance placed on Earl's life was collected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- It is evident to friends of ex-Senator M.S. Quay that the canvasses reported of the division of the Senate, on the question of Quay's admission on the appointment of Gov. Stone, have been published without careful ascertainment of the standing of the applicant with the Senate.

Inch by inch and step by step Bartow S. Weeks is fighting the testimony which the prosecution, through Assistant District Attorney Osborne, is seeking to have introduced in the trial of Roland B. Molineux, charged with the murder by poison of Katherine J. Adams on Dec. 28 last.

The State Civil Service Board is now taking cognizance of a case which it thinks demands action on its part, though this opinion is disputed. It is that of the man who keeps the cottage at Mount McGregor, N.Y., where Gen. U.S. Grant died, and who has hitherto pursued his peaceful way untrammeled by thoughts of competitive examinations and eligible lists.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- The steamer Lampasas arrived at the wharf of the Eastern Railroad in East Boston this morning with a hole fully 15 by 5 feet in her starboard bow. It was caused by a collision last night with the Pollock Rip Lightship. A large piece of canvas was stretched over the bow of the steamer to prevent the water gaining access to the forward compartment.

The Board of Public Improvements went on record yesterday in favor of investigation of the subject of intercommunication among the various boroughs by means of tunnels by the adoption of two resolutions requesting the Board of Estimate to appropriate money to defray the cost of such investigations.

There was a spirited debate at the meeting of the School Board for Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday afternoon over the question whether or not the board had the right to compel Borough Superintendent Jasper to make a written report of his reasons for reporting against the renewal of Miss Caroline M. Banks's license to teach in the public schools of this city.
PARIS, Dec. 6. -- The Temps says it finds "want of decision" in President McKinley's message to Congress, "which must be disconcerting for the country, which needs an unequivocal, firm statement."

The St. Nicholas Society held its sixty-fifth annual dinner last evening at Delmonico's with the customary quaint ceremonies. The banquet hall was decorated with orange streamers, and the arms of the society, with four great American flags, decked the wall in the rear of the dais, which, like the doors of the room, was guarded by coal black negroes in picturesque Knickerbocker costume of orange and black.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Nashville arrived at Colombo, Island of Ceylon, yesterday on her way to Manila.

Important addresses by Bishop William C. Doane of Albany, Bishop Walters of Jersey City, the Rev. W.I. Wishart of Allegheny, Penn.; Anthony Comstock, and others, were delivered at the second day's session of the National Reform Convention at the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday, which, with an intermission for luncheon, lasted from 9 o'clock A.M. to 5 P.M.

Ignace Paderewski arrived here yesterday on the White Star liner Oceanic, and will be heard for the first time since his last visit three years ago at the Carnegie Music Hall on Dec. 12. The pianist was accompanied on the voyage by his wife, who, shortly after her arrival, left for Boston, where she will remain with some friends until her husband's entire tour in this country is completed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Republican members of the House of Representatives gave their unanimous approval to-day to the House Financial bill recently introduced, and recommended its immediate consideration and passage. This was accomplished at the caucus held in the hall of the House during the forenoon by the adoption of the following resolution:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- William Harherson, aged sixty-seven years, formerly a well-to-do contractor of this city, met death in a peculiar manner to-day. While walking to his home he became benumbed with cold and fell down a railroad embankment into a small stream which was frozen over.

As nothing relative to our picturesque District Attorney fails of public interest, especially at the present time, I am venturing to trust that you may find room for the following in your esteemed columns, particularly as (in your issue of Dec. 3, 1895.) you printed a letter from me on the same general quest.

The members of the Rainy Day Club yesterday listened to a talk by H.K. Bush-Brown, the sculptor. He astonished them somewhat by the knowledge he displayed of the niceties of feminine apparel. He eulogized the bonnet and anathematized the gown of the day. He recommended the destruction of the fashion plate and the encouragement of simplicity and good taste in home and attire.

MAYSVILLE, Ky., Dec. 6. -- Richard Coleman, colored, the confessed murderer of Mrs. James Lashbrook, wife of his employer, expiated his crime in daylight to-day by burning at the stake after suffering torture and fright beyond description, at the hands of a mob of thousands of citizens.

Dr. N.A. Sawyier of 242 West One Hundred and Fourth Street sent a letter to the Park Board yesterday proposing a system of signals in the Park that-will do away with much of the uncertainty regarding runaways. He suggests that at the reservoirs there be stationed alarm bells which will ring under certain conditions, and that they be electrically equipped and connected with various stations along the different roads.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- Common Council to-day voted unanimously to support the movement to bring the Republican National Convention to this city next year, and appointed a joint committee of twenty members to co-operate with outside organizations in the work. It is expected that councils will appropriate $10,000 or $15,000 toward the fund of $100,000 which is being raised.

The natural action to have been taken by the Board of Estimate on the statement of the Controller, and on the engineering reports adduced by him in support of it, would have been the appointment of a commission as impartial as was compatible with competency to go into the whole matter.

New moves are to be made in the New York gas war. When, a fortnight ago, official announcement was made of an advance by the New Amsterdam Company from 50 cents to $1.10 per thousand, there was a hasty conclusion, not only upon the part of investors and speculators in Wall Street, but by householders throughout the city, that the gas war was over.
Henry C. Fleager, twenty-one years old, while at work on the Brooklyn side of the new East River bridge yesterday afternoon, fell 100 feet, and escaped with a few contusions of the body.

A large audience attended the fourth session of the annual convention of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers yesterday in their library in West Thirty-first Street. Six hundred and thirty members were in their seats when Herman Poole mounted the platform and began to read a paper on the use of gasoline gas for boiler heating.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Before the House met to-day, the Republican and Democratic leaders attempted to perfect an agreement for the consideration of the Currency bill, but negotiations failed.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- Since the return of the German delegates to the Philadelphia Exposition deep interest has been manifested here in the plans for founding a commercial museum in Berlin upon the Philadelphia model. The Bureau for the preparation of Commercial Treaties, which is a private organization of manufacturers, held a meeting to-day and decided to draw up a plan for presentation to the Government, expecting to get a large appropriation.

A case has recently been decided in the Supreme Court in a way which establishes the principle that it is unlawful to serve oxalic acid as a complementary beverage with a drink of whisky. Patrick Flannagan obtained judgment for $100 damages in a suit against Mrs. Mary Sullivan, who owns a place of refreshment at 831 Western Boulevard, because he got a drink of that sort there.

READING, Penn., Dec. 7. -- Fire in the extensive hosiery mill of the Nolde Hoist Company to-day destroyed the plant, and caused the death of one person, besides injuring fifty-seven other employes of the company. A badly burned corpse was recovered from the ruins this afternoon. It was probably that of Louise Clay, forty-eight years old. Of the fifty-seven persons who were injured, thirty -- all women and girls -- are seriously hurt.

NEWBURG, Dec. 7. -- Frank Timoney, one of the best-known brick manufacturers along the Hudson, was seriously injured this morning on the tracks of the New York Central Railroad near Timoneyville. Michael Doyle of Newburg, employed at the Timoney brick yards, who was standing a few feet from Timoney, was instantly killed.

The series in the Bank Clerks' League at Reid's Alleys last night was productive of a new record for the tournament. In the third game Miles of the Mechanics and Traders' Bank rolled a score of 248, the best score made in the tournament this year. He made his score on eight strikes and two spares. Miles made an average of 216 1/2 for two games. The scores of the three games decided follow:

President Morris K. Jesup called the December meeting of the New York Chamber of Commerce to order yesterday. The meeting was of more than ordinary importance several measures of vital interest to New York being considered, among them the revision of the Greater New York charter and municipal ownership of water-front property.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Government has received through one of its agents an account dated the latter part of November, of the inception and growth of the present revolutionary movement in Colombia. The revolution, according to this statement, is an attempt on the part of the Liberals to oust the Conservatives, who have been in power for many years.

There was but a three hours' session of the Molineux trial yesterday. Mr. Edgar, one of the jurors, desired to attend a funeral, and Recorder Goff had put down the trial for 1 o'clock in the afternoon. At that hour it was announced that the Recorder was detained at a board meeting, and the trial was further put off until 2 o'clock.

The Constitutional functions of the Vice President are to preside over the Senate and to be handy by in case anything happens to the President. To these the late Vice President HOBART added the exercise of police powers of high utility. He took charge of cases of political vagrancy in the Senate and House.

When the North German Lloyd steamship Trave was docked at Hoboken yesterday, Isaac Waldheim was on the pier to meet his wife, Dora, who was returning from Germany, where she had gone six months ago. Mr. Waldheim was accompanied by his wife's parents. Each carried a bouquet for Mrs. Waldheim When the passengers trooped off, Mrs. Waldheim's mother expressed a fear that her daughter had not come.

The Ways and Means Committee of the Citizens' Committee appointed by the Board of Trade and Transportation to secure either or both of the National political conventions of 1900 for New York held a meeting yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the board, and devised plans for the raising of funds, Lewis Nixon, presided.

Damage to the amount of $75,000 was the result of a serious fire which started on the second floor of the five-story brownstone mercantile building, 577 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, and blazed fiercely for a short time. Rumors that all the tenants had not escaped were current after the firemen had put it out, but there is no evidence to prove that any one was injured.
Commissioner Scofield of the Connecticut Insurance Department has authorized the Ocean Accident and Guarantee Corporation of London to transact a general casualty and accident business in that State.

MANILA, Dec. 7. -- The expectation of catching Aguinaldo in the north has been practically abandoned, and the probability now is that he will turn southward, if he is not already there, with his destination Cavite Province, his home, where the insurrection began and where it still has its greatest strength.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 7. -- The decision of the State Board of Election Commissioners covering the Gubernatorial contest will be handed down on Saturday morning. The general expectation is that certificates of election will be given to William S. Taylor, the Republican candidate for Governor, and to the Republican candidates for the other offices on the State ticket. The vote will probably be two for the Republican and one for the Democratic State ticket.

Lap after lap and mile after mile the seven teams and Pastaire, Aronson, and Walthour, the individual riders in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden, are rolling up, and by this morning the effect of the long ride is beginning to tell on even the veterans. They went on like so many automatons all day yesterday, and Miller and Waller still held their lead.
The murder by burning of the negro COLEMAN at Maysville, Ky., is an outrage so terrible and so shameful that it can only be explained as an outbreak of popular delirium.

The annual tug-of-war between the sophomore and freshman classes of Columbia College was held yesterday afternoon in the field opposite the college. It was attended by exciting incidents that were not on the programme.

The position of Secretary GAGE at the present time is somewhat peculiar and very interesting From the moment he took office he has been a consistent and eager advocate of legislation to establish beyond all question the gold standard and to maintain it with perfect steadfastness. On this vital subject he has been in advance of his chief, the President, and of the leaders of the majority in Congress.

-- When Mr. CHARLES MACRUM, late United States Consul at Pretoria, gets out into the open again he will have a lot of explaining to do, and as things look now he will have considerable difficulty in convincing the State Department officials and the general public that he has acted like a good American citizen.

At Daly's Academy, where the Intercity and Interclub handicap amateur billiard tournament is in progress, and at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, where the A.A.U. tournament is being played for the championship of Class B, there was a large attendance yesterday and last night. In both places it was "ladies' day."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The special committee of the House appointed to investigate the charges against Mr. Roberts, the Mormon Representative from Utah, held its first meeting to-day behind closed doors. The meeting was called for the purpose of determining the method of procedure in the case.

The convention of the National Reform Association, which has been in session at the Broadway Tabernacle, closed yesterday. A resolution condemning "Seven-Day Journalism" was unanimously adopted. It formed one of a series of resolutions denouncing alleged evils and grew out of a discussion of that particular topic, the chief feature of the day. The resolution is as follows:

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 7. -- Nine students of the School of Theology, Boston University, have just transferred their allegiance to Drew Seminary, Madison, N.J., owing to what they term the "rabid rationalism" which is taught in the institution here. Hinckly G. Mitchell is the instructor against whose teachings they protested.

The sudden collapse of the Mazet investigation has been explained in various ways by the members of the committee and Frank Moss, its counsel. In some quarters these explanations have been regarded as proof that the closing days of the inquiry were marked by strife between the Republican members of the committee and Mr. Moss, and that the subject upon which they disagreed was the question of calling United States Senator Platt as a witness.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Ferdinand W. Peck has declined re-election as President of the National Business League. His duties as Commissioner General to the Paris Exposition will make his presence in Paris necessary during the coming year, and he has notified the Directors of the league that he will not be a candidate for another term.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Lo-Feng-Luh, the Chinese Minister, who presided this evening at the monthly dinner of the Article Club, at which Rear Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, many other members of Parliament, and the Servian, Chilean, and Uruguayan Ministers were present, responded to the toast "The Development of British Trade in China."

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 7. -- The handsome residence on the property of Camiele Weidenfeld a New York broker, was destroyed to-night by a fire which, it is believed was due to incendiary origin. The house was on what was known as the Edwin S. Cowles estate. It was purchased last Spring by Mr. Weidenfeld for $40,000, and was being entirely refitted and improved.

G. Reis, a tenor and member of what is known on the vaudeville stage as the Verdi Trio, while engaged yesterday afternoon on the roof of the New York Theatre in demonstrating his ability as a singer in anticipation of obtaining a position in the forthcoming production of the new extravaganza, "Broadway to Tokio," to be produced early in January at the New York Theatre, burst a blood vessel.

I could not help but be amused when I examined the church at Paranaque. The reports sent out had spoken of the total demolition of it by the bombardment of the fleet. But, nevertheless, it is standing there peacefully, used as barracks by the soldiers.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- A dispatch, dated Pietermaritzburg, Dec. 5, says that Gen Buller and his staff have started for the front.

Pain's Fireworks Company, which maintained branches in Chicago and Boston, in addition to its headquarters at 12 Park Place, this city, made an assignment yesterday in Brooklyn to Bertram Gardner, a lawyer of 32 Nassau Street. The following statement in regard to the matter was given out:

Mr. David Bispham, the popular baritone, gave a song recital yesterday afternoon at Mendelssohn Hall, with the assistance of Mr. Walter Damrosch, who presided at the piano. It is hardly necessary to say that the audience was one of large size. It would be remarkable, indeed, if two such favorites as Mr. Bispham and Mr. Damrosch could appear before a local audience of small number.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- The stockholders of the Union Broom Supply Company held a secret meeting here to-day and decided to make the price on broom corn $200 a ton. This is the first time the company has given a quotation on the supply held by it, and it is said by stockholders that this price will advance materially within another month.

Judgment for $750 against the Wagner Palace Car Company was obtained by Marcus Braun on Wednesday as the result of a mistake made by one of the company's conductors in allotting a berth already sold to Braun to a woman passenger. Through the error Braun was compelled to sit in a day coach all night on a trip from Cleveland to New York.

Positive announcement was made last night by Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee that the proposed state Constabulary bill would not be introduced in the Legislature at the coming session. Mr. Odell returned late Wednesday night from Washington, where he had a long talk with Senator Platt, and last night the former made the following official statement:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 7. -- Word reaches here from Crenshaw County that the fifteen-year-old son of Widow Rhodes shot and killed William Jones and mortally wounded John Pruitt while they were attempting to force an entrance into his mother's home.

SHANGHAI, China, Nov. 9. -- There is a radical change in the balance of power at Peking. It was the expectation in the East that Russia would seize the opportunity afforded by the British-Boer war to bring unusual pressure to bear on the effete Peking regime.

The reception, by official and unofficial Germany, of the cordial language of the President's message in respect to that power, must be as gratifying to Americans as the language itself has been to Germans. If there were no other reason for cordiality than that supplied by the large number of excellent citizens of German birth in this country, that would be quite sufficient.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Mrs. L. Schurtzenberg, a National delegate from the Red Cross Society to the Philippines, and a personal friend of President McKinley, is lying at the home of Mrs. S.S. Wise, 401 Thirty-third Street, under a physician's care, with her face bruised and swollen and her arms and body black and blue as the result of a struggle with a burglar last night.

Wall Street yesterday was fairly bombarded with depressing tales. Gold shipments were freely forecast, incidental to predictions that to-day's weekly bank statement will make an exceptionally bad showing, it being represented that losses by the banks through payments to the Treasury and remittances West have reached figures big enough to do grave damage to surplus reserves.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Speculation is active as to the disposition of his vast estate by John I. Blair, who recently died at Blairstown. The will cannot be probated before Dec. 12, and it need not be probated for several weeks or even months.

The first edition of Mrs. Frances Hogdson Burnett's "The De Willoughby Claim" was oversold before the day of publication and the book is now rapidly passing to its third edition at Charles Scribner's Sons. Few writers have achieved, as has Mrs. Burnett, repeated successes in different fields of fiction.

Oyez! Oyez! I, the undersigned, being of sound mind and free will, do hereby beg to protest. It is certainly time, I fancy, to voice the demurrer against the extraordinary lengths to which the present-day novelist goes in the invention of plots, which, in the face of them, are obviously and purely and simply a sop to the "something new" loving spirit of the age.

Dr. William A. Lockwood, who at one time was well known as a physician, committed suicide yesterday morning at his lodgings, at 21 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, by taking carbolic acid. William Gemmitt, who is employed in the house, found the doctor sitting in a chair at the foot of his bed. His eyes were open, and he appeared to be deep in thought.
Your issue of the 25th inst. contains the following startling communication signed "Laudator Temporis Acti."

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- According to a special dispatch from Pretoria, Gen. Joubert recently proposed an exchange of prisoners, especially Lady Sarah Wilson for a Boer lady, taken prisoner at Mafeking. Lady Wilson is an aunt of Winston Churchill, and the wife of Capt. G.C. Wilson of the Royal Horse Guards.

There is no department of the admirable SATURDAY REVIEW that affords more entertainment -- of a certain kind -- than that devoted to "Letters to the Editor," when its readers are favored by a contributor with an olio of peppery terms for presuming to like some strong and favorably established work of a recognized master, the self-appointed arbiter warming to his subject with plentiful dashes of verbal tabasco sauce.

PORT COLBORNE, Ont., Dec. 8. -- It is believed here to-night that the Canadian steamer Niagara has foundered on Lake Erie and that all hands were lost. The crew probably comprised sixteen persons all told. Of these Capt. Henry McGlory, master of the lost steamer, is the only one known here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Representative Lentz of Ohio to-day introduced a joint resolution, reciting the charges growing out of the presence of United States troops under Brig. Gen. Merriam at the centres of mining troubles in Idaho, and asking for an investigation by a special committee of nine members, to be appointed by the Speaker.

The second public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall was an entertainment which had more than the usual number of attractive features. There was a further opportunity to study the peculiarities of that interesting young bundle of nerves, Mark Hambourg, and that in itself was not a feature to be overlooked.

The Executive Committee of the American Woolen Company decided, at at meeting in Boston yesterday, to increase the wages of all the employes of the company 10 per cent. The rise is to go into effect on Jan. 1. It will affect over 20,000 employes, and it is estimated that the number of persons who will derive advantage from the increase is about 100,000.

How easily our delusions, cherished it may be for years, can be dispelled when a master mind reveals the fact to us that we have yielded a blind obedience to error and shown an unqualified willingness to "exhaust the vocabulary of praise" upon "solemn rubbish" which, in our mental weakness, we have magnified into literary excellence!

I like the flavor of your articles on old books. There is something in the subject that makes the articles always attractive, whether they touch upon the binding, the paper, the printing, or the illustrations -- the physical and decorative features of such books. Still more interesting are they when they touch upon the authors and the literary contents of them.

It cannot be said that the reception of the President's message in England, so far as we can judge from the English press, is exactly unsatisfactory. But there does seem to be some disappointment that the President took more pains to express our National good feeling toward Germany than toward England, to which neither any Englishman nor any American doubts that we owe much more.

With feelings of regret and surprise I read in your last SATURDAY REVIEW a blast from the bulge of Mr. Newberry, the Oakland sage, calling all to witness that Victor Hugo was nothing more than a dilettante chiseler on the palace of letters; that Victor Hugo was a bumptious ass, and that Victor Hugo should be treated as any pretender, and ruthlessly crushed under foot by the true devotees at the shrine of art.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The committee which is to inquire into the status of Mr. Roberts of Utah held a protracted session behind closed doors to-day. During the early hours of the meeting Mr. Roberts was present, accompanied by his secretary, and made a statement as to his general wishes in connection with the inquiry.

A suit for $100,000 damages, claimed by Joseph Palmerston Gill-Martin. a landscape painter, for the alleged alienation of his former wife's affections by Patrick McInerney, a dry goods merchant of Brooklyn, which was begun before Justice Fitzgerald, in the Supreme Court, several days ago, was closed yesterday, with the exception of the summing up by the counsel on both sides, which will take place Monday.

For the first time in the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder by poison of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams Barrow S. Weeks, as counsel for the defendant, made an admission yesterday. He conceded that Molineux had at one time used blue tinted paper bearing the crest of three intertwined crescents and had written to a patent medicine firm for a remedy.

Such a rush and crush to obtain seats in any auditorium probably was never before known in New York as was seen yesterday, both afternoon and evening, at Carnegie Lyceum. Not only were every seat and every available space for standing room fully occupied both afternoon and evening by the great audiences which greeted Dr. Wilson, but thousands upon thousands of people anxious to obtain admission were turned away.

It is rumored in London literary circles that St. George Mivart, the distinguished Lecturer on Zoology at St. Mary's Hospital Medical School, and Professor at the University of Louvain, has a novel in preparation, which will see light some time in the Spring. St. George Mivart is probably the most liberal Roman Catholic writer in England, so liberal, in fact, that he has often been called to account by the prelates of the Church.

The arraignment of Victor Hugo before the bar of opinion is timely. Timely, because it shows which way the course is still setting. The law that no mechanism is stronger than its weakest part may well apply to the mechanism of society. Genius always treads a century or two in advance of the average thinker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Senator Lodge called at the State Department to-day to talk with Secretary Hay about his Galapagos Islands resolution. As to the basis of his resolution of inquiry, he said that all the information he had as to the reported attempt of the English Government to secure the islands was derived from newspaper sources.

Frank L. Smith, for more than a year Secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association at San Juan, and just returned from there, said yesterday, in speaking upon Puerto Rican conditions, that the Protestant missionary bodies are making a mistake in their methods of entering that island.

I have read with interest and pleasure the address of our distinguished Ambassador to Great Britain delivered at the sixth annual dinner of the Edinburgh Sir Walter Scott Club, and published in your SATURDAY REVIEW of the 25th inst. I am a friend to the Ambassador, and an admirer of his great gifts as all orator and statesman.

The dispatch given out yesterday by the British War Office shows the real danger of the operations in which the British forces are engaged on the Cape Colony side of the Orange Free State. It explains and justifies the tone of anxiety and apprehension which the British press has been taking, even after engagements that upon the face of them were British victories.

Complying with the request of one of your correspondents, who is an enthusiastic admirer of Zangwill's masterpiece, I take the liberty of using your valued columns as means of responding to what appears to me an excellent review to that wonderfully natural pen picture of Jewish life in the Ghetto.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Gen. Otis to-day cabled the War Department in regard to the uprising in Negros as follows:

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- A man dragged himself into St. Joseph's Hospital here this afternoon and asked to be admitted. He gave his name as Bartholomew Moriarity and said he was sixty-five years of age and a resident of Dobbs Ferry, a hod carrier. He said he had fallen from a scaffold and had broken his neck.
New phases appear in Sugar Trust affairs -- and they are not unlikely to develop into what even in Wall Street may be regarded as sensational.

The rapidly approaching Christmas season, with its gifts to be selected for so many varying tastes, brings with it the difficulty of deciding upon what articles will give the most pleasure to their recipients. This is, of course, a matter for personal consideration and decision; the chief qualification being that the gifts selected shall in some way express the individuality of the giver and also of the friends to whom they are to be presented.

FRANKFORT Ky., Dec. 8. -- The State Board of Election Commissioners of Kentucky to-day decided to issue certificates of election to William S. Taylor and the other candidates on the Republican ticket. The decision is a very long one, but the essential parts are as follows;

The hobby forms that appeal to various enthusiasts are many. With one it is postage stamps, with another coins. Book plates, ivory carvings, fans, pipes, old bricks, glass bottles, (sometimes broken,) and a long and expanding line of other objects are shrines before which a devoted homage is willingly paid by those carried captive by the particular objects or series of objects that, in individual cases, rise and become transcendent.

At their dividend meeting yesterday the Directors of the Standard Gas Company, acting in agreement with the views of Russell Sage, chief owner of the company's securities, omitted the declaration of the usual dividend. This was in accordance with the forecast by Mr. Sage, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 8. -- The latest returns to The Star from yesterday's Legislative election in the Province of Manitoba show the election of twenty-four Conservatives and fourteen Liberals, with two districts in doubt. The Liberal party under Thomas Greenway has been in power for many years and yesterday's result is a surprising turnover.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 8. -- The receivers of the Massachusetts Benefit Life Association announce that they have received from the Mexican Government $3,500 out of the $20,000 in Mexican currency deposited to protect the association's policy holders. The $20,000 represented about $9,400 in American coin.

A letter appeared in last week's issue of THE REVIEW, headed "Children of the Ghetto," from Irene Carter, who asks: "Is there any feeling but honor in our hearts for the old man, (Reb Shemuel,) who by his decision obeyed his law, his God, even though it tore out his own and even his daughter's heart?"

The America Club of Newark scored a double victory in the National League at Starr's Tournament Hall last night, defeating two of the best clubs in New York. The Empires were the first to fall before the Jerseymen in the first game, and in the third game the Phoenix team was beaten. The Empire and Phoenix teams furnished the best sport of the night.
The art season now grows livelier and more interesting every week, and the past seven days have brought a number of interesting incidents and events.

The ending of the Mazet Committee throws light on its beginning. It has plainly fallen to pieces. Why this has come about is revealed by what its counsel, Mr. Moss, refuses to say. He insisted on calling Mr. PLATT, and his committee saw no way to prevent him but to adjourn sine die.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 8. -- Lilian Marion Knott, well known on the operatic stage, having been understudy for Camile Darville in "Madeleine, or the Magic Kiss," and having with the Corinne and Duff Opera Companies, is in the workhouse here charged with petit larceny.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Representative Hitt (Rep., Ill.) to-day introduced a bill to provide a Territorial form of government for Hawaii. It is similar to the measure reported to the House last year, providing a Territorial Governor appointed by the President and a Legislature of two houses.

When the members of the seven teams and the three individual riders in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden realized at midnight last night that they were entering upon the last day of their trial of speed and endurance, they settled own to the work before them with a grim determination to grind out as many miles as possible before 10 o'clock this evening, when their long ride will come to an end.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8. -- In the cases of Sol Stein and W.F. Hogaman, bookmakers, charged with violating the breeders' law, Judge Clark of the Court of Criminal Correction to-day ruled that the State failed to make a case by not proving that the bets were registered in a real book, with leaves and binding.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- At a special meeting of the Board of Directors of the Chicago Theological Seminary last night, Prof. George Holly Gilbert of Iowa, Professor of New Testament Literature and Interpretation, was criticised because of the doctrines contained in his books, "The Revelation of Jesus" and "Students' Life of Christ."

Of all the journals, magazines, and papers that come to my home I find THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW by far the most interesting, and most instructive, and I think it is only right to say so to you. That of last Saturday I have found especially interesting. I wonder who wrote that advertisement for Doubleday McClure about their book.

The week ends, as did its predecessor last Saturday, with a number of coming-out receptions, which will keep the members of the gay world busily employed all the afternoon and into the evening. There will also be two dances this evening -- the first De Coverley at Sherry's and the first of Mrs. Philip Sands's dancing class at Delmonico's. Cotillions will be danced at both these affairs.

While reading lately a book on military tactics, to oblige a friend, I was impressed by the many illustrations of its principles to be found in this Letter Box. In more senses than one our editor ably conducts THE SATURDAY REVIEW, and whatever his tastes he doesn't always sit beside the Lamb.

"Child Life in Colonial Days" touches upon a most fascinating phase of American history. A number of books have been written about the lives and customs of the people of that period, especial attention having been given to a comparison of their lives with ours and of the primitive household utensils with our modern conveniences. But of the child life of Colonial days it has been left to Mrs. Earle to give this beautiful account.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 8. -- The drop of the curtain to-morrow night at the Lyceum Theatre will signalize the permanent retirement from the stage of John W. Albaugh, Sr., the veteran actor-manager.

There is always so much discussion going on as to the evil tendency of the vast amount of commonplace books and magazines which are said to make up the larger portion of each season's output that one not well acquainted with English and American literature would think them both in a deplorable condition.
Very generous and optimistic editor: Hail the new American humorist! Newberry! He out-Ansteys Anstey; he is side-splitting.

Justice Gildersleeve, in the Supreme Court, yesterday handed down two decisions denying the applications to continue the temporary injunctions which have been restraining the Board of Public Improvements from passing upon the contract with the Ramapo Water Company.

My esteemed critic in your SATURDAY REVIEW of Nov. 18 clearly misunderstands my purpose in rehearsing the experiences of a voyage around the world. Many things in this age must necessarily go untouched. It is true that in my own poor narrative I had quite overlooked the hole in the ground on the Island of Tobago.
"A.B.S." New York City: "Will you kindly inform me who is the Water Poet mentioned in the preface of Charles Major's 'When Knighthood Was in Flower'?"

Leopold Weil has sold for the Franke estate to a client, for cash, the three five-story apartment houses at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 45, 40, and 40 feet front, respectively, by 100.11.

I have no doubt that many of your readers besides myself have been scornfully amused by Mr. Newberry's strange diatribe in your last SATURDAY REVIEW against what he calls "Victor Hugo's unearthly romance, Les Miserables.'" Without commenting upon your correspondent's private views further than to remark, as did the old Irish woman to the stranger who refused to buy of her lace.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 8 -- Gov. Bradley to-night gave out his first public utterance on the burning of the negro, Dick Coleman, at Maysville. This came in reply to an interview by Judge James P. Tarvin of Covington, criticising the State authorities and holding them responsible for the Maysvile mob.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The House today adopted a special order for the consideration of the Currency bill, beginning next Monday. By the terms of the order the general debate will continue until Friday. On Saturday amendments may be offered under the five-minute rule, and on the following Monday the vote will be taken.

Hoboken's Health Board, several months ago, adopted an ordinance imposing a fine varying from $10 to $25 upon any person who expectorated upon the floor of a trolley car, ferryboat, or any other public conveyance or public building. The law was frequently violated, but no arrests were ever made.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8. -The races at Tanfaran to-day resulted as follows:

MANILA, Dec. 8. -- There was considerable relief in Manila when the news was received to-day that Gen. Young's small force had arrived safely at Vigan, Province of South Ilocos, Dec. 6. Anxiety had been felt for Gen. Young and the garrison at Vigan since it was known that Gen. Tino had a large, aggressive body of insurgents operating in the vicinity.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The latest advices from Frere camp show that the bombardment of Ladysmith was continued Thursday, Dec. 7. A pneumatic dynamite gun on Umbulwana Hill commenced the work.

You make mention of books reaching large circulations, and promise an issue on Dec. 9 giving a list of 100 books best adapted for purchases in the holiday season. The memorial edition of Timrod's poems was published at the end of April last -- 4,000 copies. In seven months 3,000 copies have been sold, which for a volume of poetry is thought to be and is a phenomenal sale.

The question whether the municipal court of the City of New York, in any of the municipal districts of the greater city, since the consolidation, has jurisdiction of a defendant residing in any portion of the greater cty, has finally been unequivocally decided in the affirmative by the Appellate Division of the First Department.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 8. -- Gov. Poynter has been called from the Capitol to Albion by the illness of his father and this has caused a slight break in the fight for the appointment of a Senator to succeed Hayward. The friends of both former Senator William V. Allen and G.M. Hitchcock, publisher of The Omaha World-Herald, are busy organizing their forces, however.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 8. -- John J. Jackson, a wealthy manufacturing jeweler, whose place of business was at 91 Mechanic Street, and who lived at 521 Summer Avenue, died suddenly this afternoon at his factory. Death was apparently due to heart disease, but the events preceding it caused the police to question several persons.

Your correspondent of Nov. 11 does not understand the uses of a writer like Prof. Brander Matthews. He complains in a simple-minded way because the latter's stories have no plots or ideas or things like that that the editors overrate them and the reader is disappointed in them. At the same time he admits that their style is all that one could wish.

All persons of independent habit of thought will agree with Mr. Newberry that "Les Miserables" is a vastly overrated work and utterly unworthy of the vogue it has attained. Not to have read "Les Miserables," however, is "to argue yourself unknown,'' and thus it is that many people heroically wade through the dismalities of this literary slough, emerging physically exhausted and mentally debilitated.

In reading these stories it is difficult to think of Mr. Zangwill as the author of "The Bachelors' Club" and of his other humorous productions. It is difficult even to think of him as the author of "The King of the Schnorrers," so completely has the sense of tragedy taken possession of him. But there is really no great change in his manner of looking at life.

It occurs to us that Mr. Bryan has put himself into all sorts of an embarrassing position by a recent act. He has saved up $60,000 from the profits of his books and lectures, and this he has invested in United States 4 per cent. bonds, placed in his wife's name. Now, there are two or three inconsistent phases of this transaction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- An answer to Brigham H. Roberts's address to the American people was issued to-day by a delegation representing the Gentile element in Utah, who are here to oppose Mr. Roberts. The answer is as follows:

New utterances from a master mind now forever silent are among the most welcome of literary revelations, and come none too often. The messages they bear may have been long ago written; but no matter what history has ensued or what perspectives have changed, they seem, when the broken bond of privacy suddenly brings them to us, alive and palpitating, and they thrill us in the old enchanting way.

Henry L. Mossler, a middle-aged well-to-do liquor dealer, is ill at his home, 311 West One Hundred and Twelfth Street, as a result of an encounter with a footpad, who, he says, attacked him at Broadway and Warren Street in the shadow of the scaffolding surrounding a new building shortly before 11 o'clock on Thanksgiving Night as he was returning from Brooklyn to his home.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- The Times-Herald to-morrow will say:

The sudden adjournment on Wednesday of the Mazet investigating committee continued to cause considerable talk yesterday, but the members of the committee and Mr. Moss had little to say in regard to the trouble between them. It is evident that the differences, especially between Mr. Mazet and Mr. Fallows on one side and Mr. Moss on the other, are more than superficial.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Gen. Forestier-Walker has sent the following dispatch, dated at 9 o'clock last (Friday) evening, to the War Office from Cape Town. It explains the report received earlier in the day that the Boers had blown up a railroad culvert at Gras Pan and had cut the telegraph wires in the rear of Gen. Methuen:

ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- An effort will be made at the coming session of the Legislature to have the corporation law amended so as to compel certain corporations leasing and virtually operating railroads to make a full report to the State Railroad Commission. The matter has been informally discussed by members of the Board of Railroad Commissioners, and promises to come up before a regular meeting of the board in the near future.

The qualifying preliminary rounds in the Class B amateur billiard tournament at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club were finished yesterday. In the afternoon Threshie defeated Tobias, and in the evening Hendrick disposed of Miller. This leaves the two Boston men, Cutler and Threshie, Hevner of Philadelphia, Kellogg of Chicago, and Smith of St. Louis to play in the finals, which will be started to-morrow. None of the New York players succeeded in qualifying.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- A week of gnawing anxiety has drawn to its close without bringing relief in the shape of decisive war news. We are getting heartily sick of the daily hash of victories, Boer bayonetings, treacheries, surprises, lootings, and so forth, and the mind of the public is centred on two coming events, the relief of Ladysmith and Kimberley.

The typewriter is probably one of the greatest of recent benefits to humanity. It is used now almost entirely for correspondence in business houses, large and small, by professional men in professional documents, and for their own personal use, and it is being introduced into editorial rooms for the benefit of both the writers and the compositors.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- Five men in the employ of Bellow Merrit, contractors, were badly injured this afternoon while at work on the old Boston Post Road. The men were blasting and had set five sticks of dynamite.

There are few persons who visit the race track regularly all season who find themselves winners when the season comes to a close, and fewer, even among the big plungers, who ever win as much as $100,000, but that is the sum the "Sporting Duchess," Mrs. Amelia Westphal of 414 Pearl Street, is credited with having won this season, and on Wednesday she will open a new hotel at the above address.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Albert Gardner, seventeen years old, son of Congressman John J. Gardner of this district, met a tragic death to-day in Egg Harbor City.

STAMFORD. Dec. 9. -- Owing to the efforts of Mrs. J. Kennedy Tod. Edwin Einney, and other prominent Summer residents of Sound Beach. that suburb is soon to have a school house which will be a credit to the place. A few weeks ago Mrs. Tod offered to present the sum of $1.200 for the establishment of a kindergarten in conjunction with the school.

Traders were active on the bear side in yesterday's market for outside securities. Liquidation also continued and added to the recessions brought about by bear attacks. Transactions were in fairly large amount and distributed over a number of issues, but the day's business was less active than on Friday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- The Rev. Dr. George T. Purvis, Professor of the New Testament Exegesis in the Theological Seminary and the university's preacher, has received a call to the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York. A committee of eight representing the Fifth Avenue Church called upon Dr. Purvis this afternoon and extended an invitation to him to become pastor of the New York church.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- It is generally but reluctantly admitted now that there is widespread disloyalty among the Cape Dutch. It appears that the British forward movement is retarded more by the political conditions prevailing in the territory through which the lines of communications pass than by the Boers, who hang like bulldogs on the advanced flanks.

Representatives of the Taxpayers' Association of the Bronx appeared before the State Railroad Commission at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday to register a further protest against the Manhattan Railroad Company in neglecting, as alleged, to make its long-promised extensions in the outlying territory.

Delegates from University Settlements Clothing Makers' Union and the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor held a conference yesterday afternoon in the guild room of St. Stephen's Church at 122 West Sixty-ninth Street, and announced as their conclusion that the factory inspection laws were inoperative, and that the State Factory Inspector, appointed by Gov. Roosevelt, and his assistants and deputies were not doing their duty.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec 9. -- Six miles of railroad in Bayfield County were completed on the morning of Dec. 14, six hours too late to entitle its promoters, among whom is ex-Senator D.M. Sabin of Minnesota, to $30,000 in bonds that had been voted by the people.

Such a rush and crush to obtain seats in any auditorium probably was never before known in New York as was seen last Friday, both afternoon and evening, at Carnegie Lyceum. Not only were every seat and every available space for standing room fully occupied both afternoon and evening by the great audiences which greeted Dr. Wilson, but thousands upon thousands of people anxious to obtain admission were turned away.

BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- The members of the Board of Management of the Stock Exchange to-day voted unanimously to so amend the by-laws of the board that "club trading," so called, on the floor of the Exchange, shall be prohibited. The penalties for the violation of this rule are in the hands of the Governing Committee.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 9. -- The Republican candidates have received their certificates of election and Taylor will be inaugurated Governor next Tuesday without resistance or protest.

Thomas Lynch, an ex-convict, attempted to kill Katie Hanrahan, his accuser, yesterday morning, in the presence of Magistrate Pool and the other officers of the Centre Street Police Court. Lynch lives at 535 Canal Street, and was released only last Monday from the penitentiary, where he had served a month's sentence for annoying Miss Hanrahan.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- Next Monday will be a great day in the Reichstag. The budget debate will open, and Count von Buelow will make a full presentation of the present status of Germany's foreign policy. He will dwell particularly on Samoa and the Transvaal, and will frankly acknowledge the high value he attaches to the fully established cordial understanding between Germany, the United States, and Great Britain.

The seventieth and seventy-first performances of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in this city are announced for next Wednesday afternoon, Dec. 13, at 2:30, and the following Thursday evening, at 8 o'clock, at Carnegie Hall. These two performances are notable from the fact that both the Soloists and the composer of one of the solo numbers are from the ranks of the orchestra itself.

The statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday that developments impending in the Sugar Trust situation might create a Wall Street sensation was amply verified by the course of yesterday's security market. After opening around 145, Sugar Trust stock fell steadily, until at the end of the two hours of business it was selling at 139 1/2, with brokers offering the stock at a still lower price after the close.

The Cercle Francais de l'Universite Harvard is preparing for its usual active season. Its annual French play is to be produced this month, and the members have arranged for a course of lectures in the Spring by Henri de Regnier, the poet. This will be the third course of lectures by prominent French literary men under the auspices of the cercle.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 9. -- A surprise has been sprung on the Democracy of Arkansas by The Arkansas Gazette declaring for expansion. This paper has for many years been the organ of the party and has always exercised great influence in its councils. In a leading editorial entitled "For Expansion," it says:
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The War Office tonight issued the following dispatch from Gen. Buller, dated Frere Camp, Dec. 9, afternoon:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Col. J.C. Boyd, Assistant Attorney General, gave a hearing to-day to John A. Garver and others, representing a committee of the American Bankers' Association, and John J. McCook, representing the Wells-Fargo Express Company, and Charles Steele of the Adams Express Company, on the question of the taxability of express companies as brokers under the War Revenue act.
Wall Street is listening to the echoes of President McKinley's observations on trusts. They do not sound like whispers.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9. -- His Majesty Rex has conferred upon Admiral George Dewey and his wife a patent of nobility, making them Duke and Duchess of Manila, and has invited them to participate in the splendors of his carnival celebration next February. The invitation and the patent of nobility sent through Lord Bathurst, Lord High Chamberlain, were beautifully engraved on parchment and handsomely framed.

A writer in The Musical Standard of London devoted recently considerable space to a review of an article in this place. The article was one in which the present writer declared himself unable to find among the musical activities of our time anything to show that there was in existence a composer worthy to take rank with the great masters who had passed away.

With the opening of the Paris Exposition yet six months distant applications for transportation from this country in the direction of the French capital during the next Summer and Fall are pouring into the steamship offices in an ever-increasing stream. The local officers of every trans-Atlantic steamship line whose boats touch at English or French ports have for nearly a month past been booking accommodations on outward bound steamers as far ahead as next July.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 9. -- Judge Tarvin of Covington has written a long, sarcastic reply to the interview with Gov. Bradley published in to-day's newspapers. The following extracts give its spirit:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The reciprocity treaties negotiated between the United States and France and between the United States and Great Britain during the past Summer, the terms of which have been carefully guarded, have at last been printed. They were transmitted to the Senate on Tuesday, and will be taken up for consideration by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations at the first meeting of that committee, which will probably be held next Wednesday.

In your issue of Dec. 2, in a communication about the Roman Church and divorce, William F. McGinnis asks: "Is it not passing strange that Rome preferred to offend the monarch [Henry VIII.] and lose a kingdom rather than make one of those convenient 'loopholes'?" [That is, a Papal dispensation which would, in effect, divorce Catherine from Henry.]

There appeared in the papers yesterday very short notices of my father, Mr. James Moir's, life, some of which have been quite incorrect, and it has seemed to me that when a landmark, such as he, was removed from the city life, it might be a kindness to write the real facts of his life.

The decision of the State Board of Election Commissioners in Kentucky to give a certificate of election to Mr. TAYLOR, the Republican candidate for Governor, is a right decision reached in circumstances of difficulty and trial. It is due to the courage and rectitude of Judge PRYOR, a Democrat, who voted with the Republican member of the board to make the needed majority.

ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- The Committee on Legislation of the Associated Academic Principals of the State of New York in session here to-day discussed the tentative educational unification bill. The committee is of the opinion that only such changes as are indispensable to the one purpose of unification should be made, and the whole system should be carefully guarded against any possible influence of partisan politics.

About Roberts. Mighty interesting, isn't it? I see that many of the women are forninst him, and that probably settles his hash, right or wrong; for though the men are natural polygamists, regardless of latitude, nation, race, or creed, yet they have in common one weakness that makes them each obedient in the end to one woman and converts them into practical monogamists.

In our columns the other day a retired officer of the Royal Engineers disputed the conclusions which Capt. ZALINSKI had already announced to our renders concerning the importance of completing our seacoast defenses and of manning them with artillerists instructed in the use of the delicate machinery of modern high-power guns.

COLUMBUS. Ohio, Dec. 9. -- The Union Reform Party will nominate by direct vote a Presidential ticket in 1900 on the established platform of the party, which consists of a single plank advocating the initiative and referendum method for all legislation, both State and National. This decision was reached to-day by the National Executive Committee of the parry at a conference in this city with the Ohio State Executive Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The story that some of the friends of Rear Admiral Schley have been to the President to urge him to settle the Sampson-Schley controversy by making Sampson and Schley Vice Admirals, in that order, appears to meet with greater favor among the friends of Rear Admiral Sampson than it does with those of Rear Admiral Schley.

Louis F. Haffen, President of the Borough of the Bronx, yesterday sent a reply to Frank Moss, counsel of the Mazet investigating committee, in answer to a letter of Nov. 21. In this letter Mr. Moss asked for the expression of views on the question of the retention of the borough system in Greater New York and cognate subjects. Mr. Haffen, in his reply, says in part:

The prosecution in the Molineux case was jubilant yesterday over the arrest of Mamie Melando, the young woman, who, besides being forewoman in the prussian blue department of Hermann Co.'s place in Newark where Molineux was employed as Superintendent, also kept the accused man's apartments in the factory in order.

OMAHA, Dec. 9. -- The organization of the League of Domestic Products in Omaha this week by some of the largest industrial and agricultural interests of the republic, for the avowed purpose of opposing annexation of the Colonial possessions of the republic, has created a sensation in a commercial way. The President of the league is Henry T. Oxnard of New York City.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- In preparation for the expected influx of automobiles, which is scheduled to take place at the first of the year, Mayor Harrison has ordered the enforcement of the ordinance which requires the licensing of all the operators after an examination by a board. The board was organized this week, and consists of Superintendent Ellicott of the Electrical Bureau as Chairman, Health Commissioner Reynolds, and City Engineer Ericson.

It must be plain to all that it is for the Republican organization of the Empire State seriously to consider whether the Hon. THOMAS C. PLATT is longer desirable as its authoritative leader. It is not necessary to give in detail the why and the wherefore of this particular duty; it is manifest without specifications.

The New Yorker who visits the Grand Central Station after the work of reconstruction now going on there has been completed might easily imagine himself in Boston or Philadelphia or some other wideawake and advancing city. The good things come to us late in Manhattan, but when we get them they are altogether "up to date."

Louie Freear has revived the old sketch called "Nan, the Good-for-Nothing," in her tour of English cities. She ought to be able to do something with the title role. Comparatively recent efforts to put new life into Nan in this country have failed dismally. But only a few years ago the piece was in the repertory of every stock company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The consideration of the case of Mr. Roberts of Utah was resumed at 10 o'clock this morning by the House Investigating Committee, Mr. Roberts being present to plead, to certain specific interrogatories which had been framed. The early proceedings were behind closed doors.

READERS of THE NEW YORK TIMES cannot have forgotten the slow and infelicitous passage this Fall of the new Building Code through the Municipal Assembly. No other act of that newly established legislative body has been attended by anything like as much publicity and criticism, yet, as we all know, the ordinance was passed, and on Dec. 23 it will take effect.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 9. -- W.D. Smith, a white barber, was taken from here to Atlanta to-day to avoid lynching. The offense which so aroused the community against Smith was the throwing by him of acid in the face of Mrs. S.M. Hillard, his landlady, and blinding her.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- Raymond D. Starbuck was to-day re-eIeeted Captain of the Cornell football team.
