Sts. rbuck will graduate next year from the College of Civil ngineering, and will then have played on ornell's 'Varsity team for four yeats. His regular position has been at full-back. He entered Cornell from Glens Falls, N. Y. He is twenty-two years old and is a popular man in his class.

Christianity is indeed the religion of peace. Above the portals of the Church of Christ, the Christmas greeting of the angels, "Peace on earth and good-will to men," glows as an inscription. This is theory. The practice of the Church is quite different. She scarcely ever prevented war and frequently pressed the sword into the hands of the faithful.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Mr. Chamberlain shows no signs of repentance or desire to recant his Leicester speech. When questioned in this connection he replied: "I have nothing to add to what I have already said."

In your issue of yesterday a letter headed "The Way We Speak English" and signed "Andover" suggests two questions: First, What is the proper way to speak English? and second, Why should Americans speak English and not American?

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Col. Herbert Eaton of the Grenadier Guards, who has been promoted to Major General, is the husband of Elizabeth, a daughter of the late F.O. French of New York. Gen. Eaton's mother is also an American. He had seen no active service, and commanded the Grenadier Guards when they were sent in disgrace to Bermuda.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A poetical tribute has been paid to President McKinley by ex-Congressman William Robert Moore of Tennessee, who, under the appellation of the "Statesman of Blue Hog Bottom," was favorably mentioned by some humorous persons for Mr McKinley's running mate in 1896. The poem is entitled "Political Polliwogs," and is "respectfully dedicated to William McKinley, that is, and is to be, President of the United States."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The December dinner of the Gridiron Club was held to-night at the Arlington Hotel, where about 130 guests were entertained in characteristic manner by the forty correspondents who compose the organization. Gen. H.V. Boynton presided. He took part in a burlesque election, in which members of the club impersonated well-known statesmen and politicians, and participated in a Kentucky-Philadelphia election on plans of the most exaggerated type.

SYDNEY, Nov. 8. -- The war spirit in Australia displays no indications of abating; on the contrary, the critical state of affairs in South Africa occasioned a great increase in the number of applicants for military enrolment, followed by a demand for the dispatch of a second contingent, several thousand strong, to the seat of war.

With the close of the open tournament at Lakewood the local golf season has practically come to an end. At Lakewood, however, the game has bounded into the liveliest activity. Thanksgiving is looked upon as the real opening time of golf in that popular resort, and the success of the club's latest tournament indicates that the coming months will show fully as much interest in golf as was the case last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Putting private Democratic opinion and public Democratic utterance together, it is becoming very plain here that the silver question has lost some of its hold upon that party. One of the most pronounced and outspoken advocates of free silver coinage a few years ago was Representative Sibley of Pennsylvania.

We have already had occasion to call attention to the action of some newspapers, with reference to a capital case now on trial, as being not only plainly uncivilized and outrageous, but also apparently unlawful. We refer to the open and public expression of opinion upon the merits of a case on trial before a jury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The House Republicans, who are determined to push the Currency bill to passage notwithstanding the remonstrance of the opposition, assume that the Democratic objections to the bill are in part perfunctory, and that they would be urged on other grounds than those made if time were granted to enable the Democrats to examine the question in the light of the provisions of the House bill.

Notwithstanding the activity of the stock market yesterday, call money rates showed no disposition toward any serious advance, the highest figure being 6 per cent., while as low as 3 per cent. was at one time recorded.

The influence of the coming Christmastide begins to be felt, and with only a fortnight from to-morrow until the festival, that large element in New York social life which spends Christmas in the country, or comes to town only a day or so before the feast, finds the time all too short for the necessary shopping and preparations.

Articles have appeared recently in the public press criticising the army ration, denouncing its unsuitability for troops in a tropical climate, and urging a radical change in its character. These articles are based on the elementary propositions that, while fatty foods are good where a high development of animal heat is required, they are harmful in a climate where there is no call on the system for a large heat production.

The amount of money spent on apparently minor details of business is a surprise to outsiders, and they have no idea of the attention given them. In one of the big uptown stores where they make a specialty of decorations for special occasions it cost between $12,000 and $15,000 for those of Christmas last year.

No action was taken by the Health Board in the case of the coffee from the plague-infected port of Santos at the public hearing yesterday. President Murphy said he would notify to-morrow the owners of the vessels having cargoes of coffee, but no cases of plague, what disposition would be made of their cases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The long struggle to overcome the defects of the old-fashioned chimneys of the Capitol and make them conform to the customs of the end of the century has at last been made partially successful. These chimneys, which number nearly a hundred, were built when open grate fires were the usual means of heating.

George F. Tasche, fifty years old, a Custom House broker doing business at 65 Broadway, dropped dead on his way to business yesterday morning. Mr. Tasche, who resided at 444 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street, had been suffering from heart trouble for several months and had been confined to his bed on several occasions.

The Corinthians are still in the lead in the National bowling tournament and in the National League tournament share the lead with the Metropolitans. The Empires retain their lead in the Harlem League, as do the Alcos in the Arlington National tournament. The following tables show the standing of the clubs in the various tournament:

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 9. -- Isaac Wardwell and his twin sister, Mrs. W.C. Hoyt, are celebrating the eighty-fourth anniversary of their birth at Mrs. Hoyt's residence this afternoon. They will be eighty four years old to-morrow. They are of the sixth generation of the family who have lived in Stamford.

New York City's charter is to be amended, but not in the manner first suggested by the leaders of the Republican State organization. This decision was reached yesterday morning at the conference held between Gov. Roosevelt, Senator T.C. Platt, and Chairman Odell at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- Money will be a useless commodity in Philadelphia on Sundays hereafter, if all the forces arrayed in favor of the old blue laws succeed in their crusade. Not a store will be open; not a newsboy visible. In short, the only opening for the coin of the citizens will be the church contribution boxes and the street cars, which will be permitted to run by law.

The notable Russian psychologist, M. de Manaceine, has recently published a most interesting and instructive book on the dreams of the deaf and dumb, the abnormally formed people, cripples, and infants. He has noticed that in the case of the deaf and dumb, if deafness occurs before they are five years old, they forget what they have learned of spoken words; those words never being remembered in their dreams.

ANTWERP, Dec. 9. -- The North German Lloyd steamer Koenigin Lulse, bolind for Australia, which grounded yesterday on Walswoords Bank, in the lower Scheldt, and which was thought to be in a critical condition, has been floated and has proceeded on her voyage.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Articles of incorporation were filed to-day with the Secretary of State of the Seashore and Delaware River Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company. The company is part of a system to be established by the Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company of America, and is capitalized at $100,000.

Mrs. Percy Widdrington of London, well known in England as a lecturer on social topics, spoke to members of the League for Political Education yesterday on "The Ethics of Shopping." The duty of the consumer, said Mrs. Widdrington, is two-fold, -- first in regard to the production and second, to the distribution of goods.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 9. -- The team of Harvard debaters has been working hard in preparation for the debate with Princeton, to be held in Sanders Theatre, Cambridge, Dec. 15. The question, of which Harvard supports the affirmative, is: "Resolved, That the English claims in the present controversy with the South African Republic are justifiable."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- John Wanamaker testified to-day before the Industrial Commission on the subject of department stores. He declared that these stores were beneficial to society, having a substantial economic and moral basis for their existence.

Brooklyn is the danger point in the water supply of the city. That is very evident to any one who has followed the Ramapo water scheme -- especially those who have studied in detail the annual report for 1898 of the Commissioner of Water Supply. The papers are now telling us that the supply in the Ridgewood reservoir is about four feet, when it should be four or five times as much.

Sidney Lee has been scolding Englishmen for permitting copies of the Shakespeare Folios to leave the right little, tight little island. Good copies of all four of the Folios, including an unusually well-preserved one of the 1623 edition, are in the library of the late Augustin Daly, which is soon to be put under the hammer.

" I see THE TIMES has been publishing some letters lately from people who have been finding fault with our local mail service," remarked, the man who lives in a flat, and who, like most flat-dwellers moves occasionally as new and better flats renting within his means multiply. I am suffering from a too perfect mail service. I moved in October from one up-town west-side flat to another.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The War Department has received the following from Gen. Otis:

At the Metropolitan Opera House the second of Mr. Wolfsohn's concerts will be given to-night with a combination of artists and a programme equally as interesting as the one of last Sunday. Schumann-Heink, Campanari, Vladimir de Pachmann, and Walter Damrosch and his efficient orchestra of seventy-five all in one evening.

A comparatively recent development of the public school system in Brooklyn is what is known as the Parents' League. It is composed of the fathers and mothers of school children whose homes are in the Bedford district of that borough and who attend Public School No. 3. The league was organized in May last, and already has a membership of several hundred.

Mary Sanders, five years old, of 344 East Sixty-fifth Street, is lying perhaps fatally burned on a cot in Flower Hospital, as the result of playing "Ring Around a Rosie," the "Rosie" in the case being a bonfire. While playing in a vacant lot at 410 East Sixty-fifth Street yesterday afternoon she approached too near the flames, and in an instant her woolen dress was afire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- An explosion took place to-day in Shaft 7 of the Carbon Hill Mines, at Carbonado, forty miles east of Tacoma. About sixty miners lost their lives. The cause of the disaster is unknown, but it is supposed the miners working between the 300 and 600 foot levels broke into the old mine workings, which were filled with gas.

The question is once more being raised in this country of the desirability of a uniform musical pitch. Some years ago the Philharmonic Society in London decided to lower the pitch of its orchestra to that universal on the Continent; and, although, there was some confusion at first, the wisdom of that movement is now acknowledged.

The organization of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railway Company, which was changed last month by the retirement of President Charles P. Clark to the Directorate and the election of ex-Judge John M. Hall to the Presidency, was yesterday advanced in the line of permanency by the election as Vice President of William F. Merrill, Vice President of the Erie Railroad.

MIDDLESBOROUGH, Ky., Nov. 25. -- Middlesborough, a "city" in style of designation and in architectural and street and other municipal improvements, is but the husk of a vast, expensive, and collapsed boom, a city of magnificent pretentions, in which 3,000 or 4,000 people live in the expectation that the "boom" may be patched up and started anew where it went to pieces several years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Fifty-sixth Congress is in motion at the usual opening pace, with interest manifested principally in two questions, and with a prodigious rush of old and new bills. Speaker Henderson will soon complete the organization of the House by the appointment of committees to work under the Reed rules as adopted promptly on the opening day.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- The Kinzie Rowan Home for Aged and Infirm Women is closed to-day because Mr. Rowan, who gave the home to the Methodists of the State, was apparently unwilling to have the institution conducted by young women.

The announcement that ex-Judge William G. Ewing of Chicago would deliver a lecture on Christian Science yesterday was sufficient to fill the Metropolitan Opera House, where the lecture was delivered, with an appreciative audience. An organ recital was given prior to the introduction of the lecturer. Ex-Judge Ewing, who was introduced by Carol Norton, said, in part:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service, in view of the officially reported prevalence of plague in Santos, Brazil, and Oporto, Portugal, and the local conditions at those ports, has issued regulations to prevent its introduction into the United States, which regulations are to remain in force until thirty days after the official announcement of the cessation of the plague in these cities.

One more section of the electric car lines of the Third Avenue Railroad system was opened for traffic at five minutes to 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. This is the stretch from Fort Lee Ferry to Seventy-first Street and Broadway. The first car sent over the road experimentally made the trip at 3 o'clock in the morning.

The trouble between William A. Brady, who resigned as managing director of Koster Bial's last Friday night, and the Robert Blei syndicate, represented by Simon Dessau, was amicably settled last night by an arrangement which takes "Around New York in Eighty Minutes" out of the hands of the syndicate. After a conference Mr. Brady announced he had bought the play with all its costumes and accessories.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Dec. 10. -- In an interview yesterday with reference to the case of Brigham H. Roberts, ex-Judge C.C. Goodwin of The Salt Lake Tribune said:

The dispatch printed yesterday that a committee from the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church had called upon Prof. G.T. Purves of Princeton University to ask him if he would consider a call to the vacant pastorship was confirmed after the services yesterday morning by H. Edwards Rowland, Chairman of the Pulpit Supply Committee of the church, in the following written statement:
CARBONADO, Washington, Dec. 10. -- Stunned by the suddenness of last night's mine horror, the people here seem too dazed for any expression of grief of a demonstrative nature.

MANILA, Dec. 10. -- Col. Julio del Rio, who is among the released Spaniards that have just arrived here, gives an interesting version of the famous Irene incident in Subig Bay in July of last year. He was formerly in command of the Spanish troops in the Olongapo District. His narrative is corroborated by Senor Rafael Rosello, a wealthy Spanish merchant, who also fell into the hands of the insurgents.

ALTOONA, Penn., Dec. 10. -- Unless the Standard Steel Company of Lewistown, Penn., can get a consignment of coal within the next few days, the entire works, employing 2,500 men, will be forced to shut down because of the scarcity of fuel.

Edward R. Hamilton, known by his associates as "Punch" Hamilton, a colored man, twenty-five years old, was shot and instantly killed at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the barroom at the rear of the Owl Hotel, at 43 Borden Avenue, Long Island City, by Ferdinand Baer, the proprietor of the place. Self-defense is alleged by Baer and several witnesses of the shooting.

George Koch, who conducted a water cure establishment at 226 East Eighty-third Street, and who died Saturday night in the Presbyterian Hospital from the effects of poison, denounced his wife as his murderess. The woman was arrested yesterday at Pleasantville on the Harlem Railroad. Her neighbors and the police, however, believe that Koch did not tell the truth when he accused the woman, whose life he had already ruined.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 10. -- The office of the Pacific Express Company in this city was robbed last night of several thousand dollars. When Agent O.C. Brownlee entered the office this morning he found the safe open and the money gone.

At the Church of the Eternal Hope, in West Eighty-first Street, yesterday morning, the Rev. Dr. W.S. Crowe preached on the subject, "Why We Abandoned Our Creed," his sermon being a defense of the recent action of the Universalist Church in abolishing its historic creed, adopted at Winchester, N.H., in 1803, and substituting for it a platform containing a declaration of five Universalist principles.

So far as the public now know it, the policy of the Governor as to the charter and the government of the City of New York seems to entitle that gentleman to the respect and gratitude of this community. It is not, in some regards, an ideal policy, but, considering the actual situation, which is far from ideal, it has certain great merits.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- It is hardly too much to regard Gen. Gatacre's repulse near Stormberg as the most serious defeat British arms have yet sustained in the whole campaign. Already the official advices show that 2 men were killed, 9 officers and 17 men were wounded, and 9 officers and 596 men are missing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The probability that Dr. George T. Purves will accept a call to the Fifth Avenue Church was the chief topic of conversation here to-day. The students and members of the Faculty in both the seminary and university are in favor of his remaining here, and several letters have already been sent to Dr. Purves urging him to stay.

The Secretary of State, in transmitting his estimates to the Treasury Department, lays particular stress on "the necessity of keeping a vigilant and efficient watch over the growing interests of American trade and enterprise in the Far East." He recommends the appropriation of $1,000 each to pay the salaries of ten student interpreters, being young men of American citizenship between the ages of eighteen and twenty-four, attached to the legation at Peking.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- William J. Connors of Buffalo has been in consultation here with some of the largest grain shippers of Chicago regarding the scheme of an all-water route for grain to the seaboard, with Montreal as the seaboard terminal of the route. A Chicago architect is now working on plans for three elevators, with an aggregate capacity of 9,000,000 bushels, to be erected in Montreal.

Last week's advance of the Bank of England's rate of discount has had little effect here. Our bankers who deal largely in international exchange have not regarded it as a matter of serious significance. It is unusual, but the circumstances are unusual, and the move was not made at a time of financial uneasiness, but of general confidence, notwithstanding the vexatious war which Great Britain has on her hands.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The Pretoria reports of renewed fighting at Modder River originated from the fact that the British with a team of thirty-two oxen hauled a naval gun to the top of a high ridge north of Modder River Town, whence they fired lyddite shells on the Boer position at a range of 6,700 yards, where the enemy was apparently constructing an emplacement for a forty-pounder.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Nervousness and anxiety increase in our money market because it begins to see how difficult it is for any other market to supply its necessities in the matter of gold. Exchanges have responded in the usual manner to our 6 per cent. bank rate, but as they move in our favor steps are taken by the markets threatened to prevent loss of bullion.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

Wherever Wall Street men met yesterday there was much speculation as to what would or might develop in to-day's stock market. The shake-up at the close of last week has prepared most observers to expect some further disturbance of values, and even they who are confidently bullish -- relying on the phenomenal business activity showing in every quarter -- will be little surprised if to-day's opening discloses more weakness.

PARIS, Dec. 10. -- Some fifty meters of the Place d l'Etoile fell last night into the Metropolitan Railway tunnel. Ten trees were carried down, and two persons buried in the debris, although quickly rescued.

EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, Dec. 10. -- Friends in this city of Charles E. Macrum, until recently United States Consul at Pretoria, who is returning to this country with important information for the State Department which he was unwilling to risk cabling, believe that his most recent letters furnish a clew to his mysterious mission.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 10. -- The fight for the Senatorship left vacant by the death of Senator Hayward grows hotter every hour. That either Senator William V. Allen or G.M. Hitchcock, editor of The Omaha World-Herald, will be the successful competitor is now generally acceded, as the candidacy of W.H. Thompson of Grand Island was announced too late to be of any moment. Senator Allen says he is in the fight to stay.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Two hotels and several other buildings were destroyed by fire here early this morning. Two persons were burned to death and their bodies were found at daylight in the ruins of the building, where they had been asleep.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- George E. Roberts, the Director of the Mint, in his annual report, says:

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- The Election Committee of the Century Road Club met at the Great Northern Hotel to-day and elected the following officers: President -- E.J. Porter, New York; First Vice President -- H.W. Knights, Melrose, Mass.; Second Vice President -- Jules Denegre, St. Paul, Minn., Secretary -- C.M. Fairchild, Chicago, Ill.: Treasurer -- W.G. Niemeyer, Joliet, Ill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The House will devote the week entirely to the financial debate on the Currency bill. Under the terms of the special order adopted on Friday, the general debate will open to-morrow immediately after the reading of the journal, and continue daily from noon until 5 o'clock Friday. On Saturday the bill will be read paragraph by paragraph for amendment, under the five-minute rule.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The War Office publishes the following dispatch from Gen. Forestier-Walker at Cape Town:
Net changes of 1 point or more in the more active stocks were:

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- The money market situation continues to be the chief concern of the German business world. London exchange continued to rise all last week. Gold exports are now possible, and therefore an increase in the bank rate is considered virtually certain. The officials of the Reichsbank were in consultation yesterday on the subject, and there was a general sentiment in favor of an advance to 7 per cent.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 10. -- A dispatch from Durango, Mexico, says that the Supreme Court of the State of Durango has rendered a decision as to the ownership of the Vacas, San Marcos and Bismarck Mines in that State by which the original American owners again come into possession of these properties, valued at not less than $20,000,000.

The Industrial Commission on Saturday heard Mr. JOHN WANAMAKER on the general subject of department stores. Incidentally he dropped a hint as to the operation of the protective tariff and its probable future which is extremely significant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- If Gen. Leonard Wood is made Military Governor of Cuba, he will probably have under him few, if any, of the general of officers who are now stationed in the island. There is so much jealousy among the various officers there that it would be impossible to make one of them Military Governor without giving offense to others.

An evidence of the way in which our officers are doing their work in Puerto Rico and winning the victories of peace is given in the following letter to The San Juan News. Col. HOFF is the chief medical officer of the United States Army in the island and Chairman of the Relief Committee charged with distributing food to the sufferers from the hurricane of August last:

ORANGE RIVER, Dec. 9. -- Half the men of the Canadian contingent have gone forward. Like the Australian contingent, they have been put to stiff work since their arrival, and have been building sidings, erecting platforms, and rendering the usual routine service. They are in excellent condition and very zealous.

BOSTON, Dec. 10. -- The fire losses during November in the United States and Canada show an increase of more than $1,590,000 over the corresponding period last year, and an increase of more than $16,500,000 on the year's business.

MOLTENO, Cape Colony, Dec. 10. -- Gen. Gatacre's movement may be termed a reconnoissance in force. Its obect was to ascertain the strength of the position of the Boers, who were strongly intrenchel along the Stormberg Range. He left Putter's Kraal shortly after noon yesterday, with a fighting force slightly over 4,000 men.

Road drivers and their fast steppers were out in force yesterday, and for a couple of hours in the morning there was some lively racing on the Speedway. The roadbed was in unusually fine condition, and the absence of a crowd of visitors in heavy rigs made speeding safe, and the brushes fast and exciting.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Jacob Takakjian, a silk weaver, was almost beaten to death to-day by four strikers from the Summit Silk Mill, at Summit, because he went there to work. The strikers came to Paterson in search of him, knowing that he would spend the day here with his family.

The significance of the attacks of a certain section of the French press upon the British Government and the indecent lampooning of the Queen has been ill-comprehended in this country. When Mr. CHAMBERLAIN attempted to rebuke French manners, Englishmen as well as Americans rightly thought that by so doing he had lowered the dignity of the high office which he held.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Jacob Takakjian, a silk weaver, was almost beaten to death to-day by four strikers from the Summit Silk Mill, at Summit, because he went there to work. The strikers came to Paterson in search of him, knowing that he would spend the day here with his family.

The significance of the attacks of a certain section of the French press upon the British Government and the indecent lampooning of the Queen has been ill-comprehended in this country. When Mr. CHAMBERLAIN attempted to rebuke French manners, Englishmen as well as Americans rightly thought that by so doing he had lowered the dignity of the high office which he held.

Hudson County politicians have been greatly excited for a week or more over reports that when the Grand Jury should be discharged it would present indictments against many officials. These rumors were verified yesterday when indictments were presented against the entire Board of Freeholders and also against a majority of the Hoboken Common Council and Mayor Fagan.

The Strollers last evening gave the first performance of "The Lady from Chicago," described as a "musical comedy," the book by Edward Fales Coward, Louis Fitzgerald, Jr., J. Cheever Goodwin, Rupert Hughes, Robert C. Sands, and James Barnes, and the lyrics by Richard Henry Warren, Henry K. Hadley, William F. Peters, and Melville Ellis, to a large and distinctively fashionable audience.

-- Complaint is made by one of our readers because hyphenated proper names occasionally appear in our columns. "This," says the critic, "is snobbery of the most contemptible sort." What is -- the hyphenation of names by the owners thereof, or our tacit admission that said owners have a right to call themselves whatever they choose?
Roger M. Sherman read a paper on "The Law and Science of Capital Punishment by Electricity" before the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at its annual meeting in the Academy of Medicine last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Gen. Otis cables to the War Department the following casualties:

The case of Peter J. Kiernan, the employing tile layer who is suing the Tile, Grate and Mantel Association of New York for $25,000 damages for having, as he alleges, ruined his business by prohibiting its members from selling him tiles, came up yesterday morning before Justice Andrews, in Part IV. of the Supreme Court.
MANILA, Dec. 11. -- Dispatches dated Concepcion, Dec. 2, from a correspondent with the detachment pursuing Aguinaldo have just reached Manila by messenger.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Gov. Murphy and twenty-nine of the leading citizens of Arizona are coming to Washington to aid in the passage of a bill admitting that Territory as a State of the Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Senate, in executive session to-day, removed the injunction of secrecy from the commercial treaties negotiated between the United States and other countries last Summer, and which with one exception, were sent out in Washington dispatches Saturday night. The exception was the treaty with the Argentine Republic.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 11. -- William B. Guild, the Newark lawyer referred to by Mamie Melando in her testimony in the Molineux case to-day, is one of the leading lawyers of this city and is a member of the Board of Police Commissioners. When seen this afternoon he said:

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- After a preliminary contest in some respects unique in the city's history the campaign for the political control of Boston closed to-night with both sides apparently confident of victory to-morrow. The Democrats, despite the defection of one of their leaders, claim the city for Gen. Collins by 7,500, while the Republicans are not so extravagant, placing the probable lead of their nominee for Mayor, Thomas N. Hart, at 5,000.

The most remarkable thing about the currency debate that began in the House yesterday is that it does not create a ripple of excitement in the public mind not even in Wall Street, where minds are always keenly plotting for excuses for excitement. The debate will develop no new views, and the resulting action is already determined by the unanimous vote of the Republican caucus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The preliminary Skirmishing for the contest for the honor of entertaining the next Republican National Convention was begun to-day, when the advance guard of the Philadelphia delegation, which is to work in behalf of that city, arrived at the National capital and took quarters at the Arlington Hotel, where the National Committee will meet next Friday.

Wall Street endurance was called upon to stand some severe tests yesterday. At times the market was excited enough to cause anxiety in many circles. At the opening of the Stock Exchange such confusion ruled as to make nervous people apprehensive even of panic developments. Stocks were traded in on a tremendous scale and at material recessions.

Gustav H. Schwab, manager of the North German Lloyd Steamship Line, yesterday announced the following traffic arrangements made by his company for the coming year: The usual regular weekly service on Tuesdays and the Thursday service, consisting of large twin screw passenger steamers, will be continued. To accommodate the exposition traffic the company will start steamers from here on Saturdays in June, July, August, and September.

Assemblyman Doughty will, it is said, introduce, by request, a bill at the coming session of the Legislature to have the old lines of the former Town of Hempstead restored. This would mean that Far Rockaway, Edgemere, Arverne, and Rockaway Beach would be taken out of the city and added to Nassau.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- It now appears as though John Brennan, whose body was found lying alongside the New York Central Railroad tracks at Fishkill on Saturday morning, was murdered, and not struck by a train. Brennan was sixty years of age and an old resident of Fishkill.

The most interesting event in the recent history of the Democratic Party is the determination of several of the New York Democrats in the House to vote for the Republican currency measure. It is practically the first open breaking away from Bryanism of Democrats who are actively and professionally engaged in politics and the public service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Col. Bingham, Superintendent of Public Buildings and Grounds, and who in that capacity directs the official receptions at the White House, is nearly ready to announce the number and dates of the receptions and dinners to be given by the President and Mrs. McKinley at the Executive Mansion.

It is not a good showing for the British Army, it is not a good showing for modern civilization in consequence, which has just been made by, or more properly of, Gen. GATACRE. That officer thought to make a brilliant stroke by surprising an intrenched camp of Boers, and he has succeeded in making only what the French call a "stroke missed."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Representative Payne (Rep., N.Y.), prospective Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, to-day introduced a bill extending the privilege of shipping goods in bond across the country, without reference to the destination of the goods. At present this free bonding privilege is restricted to goods going to the adjacent territory of Canada or Mexico.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Baron Penzance, James Plaisted Wilde, is dead.
HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- The teachers of Havana have presented a petition to Gen. Brooke, in the course of which they say:

The Knickerbocker Athletic Club had out its best team in the National League at Starr's tournament hall last night, and were victorious in two games. The Knickerbockers won the first game of the night rather easily from the Lotus team. The second game between the Lotus and Riverdale bowlers was close throughout.

In view of the possible nomination of William J. Bryan by the Democratic Party in 1900 as their candidate for the Presidency, the writer, long a Democrat, begs to give his views. His first vote was cast in 1860 for Abraham Lincoln. From that time onward he voted the Democratic ticket at each Presidential election down to 1896.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Postmaster Van Cott of New York City was in conference here to-day with the postal officials and with Senator Platt in regard to the proposed new Post Office building in New York.
The Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society has offered four prizes to architects for plans for improved city tenements.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- The controversy between the Brewery Workers' International Union, with the Brewery Workers' Unions Nos. 29 and 14 of Boston, and the Narragansett Brewing Company of Providence, which has involved the trade unions of New York and New England for upward of four years, was settled to-day, on terms satisfactory to the union brewers, by John J. McCarthy, General Organizer of the international union.

Dr. Dudley of the house staff of the Harlem Hospital appeared at the monthly meeting of the Harlem Board of Commerce last night and before a large and interested audience made a strong appeal for a new hospital and denounced the conditions prevailing in the present institution.

Several of the Sandy Hook pilots were receiving the congratulations of their friends yesterday on a narrow escape from disaster. They had come near being hit by an eight-inch dummy shell fired from the ordnance proving grounds at Sandy Hook on Saturday. The story did not come out until yesterday morning, when the pilot boat James Gordon Bennett of the New Jersey Pilots' Association came up from the Hook to undergo repairs.

LINGAYAN BAY, P.I., Nov. 7. -- The possibilities of a thoroughly successful combination of manoeuvres between army and havy were again proved to-day, when the two branches of the service met before the trenches of the insurgents at the head of Lingayan Gulf and worked harmoniously and effectually to a finish in such a way as to reflect great credit upon themselves.

MANILA, Dec. 11. -- The advance guard of Gen. Grant's command, under Major Spence, arrived at Olangapo, Subig Bay, during the night of Saturday, Dec. 9, which place was occupied with little resistance, the enemy fleeing.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- In the Reichstag today Prince Hohenlohe, the Imperial Chancellor, announced, that the Federal Government had come to the conclusion that the present navy was insufficient for the country's needs, and that estimates for doubling the present number of warships would be submitted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day affirmed the opinion of the Court of Claims in the case of the claim of the Los Abra Silver Mining Company against the Republic of Mexico, holding that claim to be fraudulent and unfounded. The claim was for nearly $4,000, 000.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 11. -- William McCormick, who was found dead in his room in Manhattan this morning, was a brother of Judge Thomas F. McCormick, who committed suicide because of financial troubles.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- It is said that, possibly, the proposed Harvard-Yale-Oxford-Cambridge Easter return athletic meeting in the United States will not be brought off, in which case the Oxford-Cambridge team will have to go to America in July, unless the Harvard-Yale team accept the suggestion that they visit England again and then go to Paris.

Mr. BRYAN ought to make known to the country his attitude toward the isthmian canal project, especially to the people of the South, to whom the building of the canal is a matter of vital importance for the development of their industries and trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- In the House to-day the Currency bill was discussed at length by representatives of both parties. The debate was opened by Mr. Overstreet, (Rep., Ind.,) who will have charge of the measure on the floor. Speeches were also made by Mr. Maddox, (Dem., Ga.,) Mr. McClellan, (Dem., N.Y.,) Mr. De Armond, (Dem., Mo.,) and Mr. Dolliver, (Rep., Iowa.)

ALBANY, Dec. 11. -- Gov. Roosevelt said to-day that he was in receipt of Corporation Counsel Whalen's letter requesting him not to sign any patent issued by the State Land Board to the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company for a grant of sixteen and one-half acres of land under water in Astoria, Queens County, and that he would give it his most careful consideration and deal justice out equally to all.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The announced intention of Mr. Mason, (Rep., Ill.,) to address the Senate to-day on his resolution expressing the sympathy of the Senate with the South African republics in their war with Great Britain, and extending to them the hopes of the Senate for the success of their arms, drew a large audience to the Senate galleries.

A collection of pictures numbering some 360 and all, with the exception of an Inness, by foreign brushes, now on exhibition at the American Art Galleries will be sold there at auction this evening, to-morrow, (Wednesday,) and Thursday at 8 o'clock each evening. The paintings are owned by Willem F. Lamorimiere, and make up unmistakably what is known as a dealer's collection.

Not for some time has the stock market been so perilously near to a panic as it was yesterday for the first two hours after the opening. Stocks pressed on the market by the wholesale, and excited groups of brokers, gathered around the trading posts on the Exchange in much larger numbers than usual, were kept busy executing their orders.

DETROIT, Dec. 11. -- The nineteenth annual convention of the American Federation of Labor opened to-day. In the absence of President Gompers, who on account of his recent bicycle accident is detained in Washington, James Duncan, Second Vice President, presided.
Heilner Wolf have sold the old four-story building, 28 West Twenty-sixth Street, 25 by 98.9, to a builder, who will erect on the lot an eight-story fireproof bachelor apartment house.

Announcement was made in Wall Street yesterday that the cigar factory of Kerbs, Wertheim Schiffer, at 1,018 Second Avenue, this city, had been bought by the American Tobacco Company, for a price approximating $1,500,000. It has been an open secret for several months that the American Tobacco Company contemplated adding the manufacture of cigars to its other industries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Senator Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) has introduced a joint resolution to prohibit combinations between corporations to control inter-State commerce and transportation. The resolution is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Cockrell (Dem., Mo.) directed the attention of the Pension Committee to a bill introduced by request by Mr. Pettus (Dem., Ale.) providing for the payment of a pension to freedmen.

Gov. Tyler of Virginia says in his message to the Legislature: "The injury and evil arising from the assertion and publication of the charge of buying votes and controlling elections in the State by the use of money and corporate influence is growing to an alarming extent. Especially is this the case in regard to county and municipal elections.

LONDON Dec. 11. -- The Royal Societies Club gave a banquet this evening to Lord Chief Justice Russell and Sir Richard Henn Collins, Lord Justice of Appeal, who were Great Britain's representatives in the arbitration of the Anglo-Venezuelan boundary dispute. The company, which included all the chief members of the English bench, was large and very distinguished.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The dramatic version of Henry Sienckiewicz's "Quo Vadis" received its initial production at McVicker's Theatre this evening, Monday night was originally set for the performance, but the elaborateness of the staging demanded further rehearsal, and the play was postponed until to-night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Senator Cullom to-day introduced in the Senate a comprehensive bill for the amendment of the law creating the Inter-State Commerce Commission. The bill is in most respects similar to the Cullom bill of the last Congress for the same purpose, but it has been changed in several minor particulars. The main features of the proposed measure are as follows:
" CAPE TOWN, Dec. 11. -- Gatacre reports as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Great interest was manifested in the House to-day in the speech of Representative Driggs, (Dem., N.Y.,) who was the first member of his party to speak in advocacy of the Republican currency bill. He announced that he had pledged himself before election to support the gold standard and proposed to redeem that pledge.

LIMA, Ohio, Dec. 12. -- A verdict for $18,000 was returned against N.L. Michael and Gus Kalb, Vice President and Cashier of the American National Bank, to-day, by the jury in the suit brought by the Board of Directors.

MANILA, Dec. 12. -- Col. Smith, with a detachment of the Seventeenth Infantry, surrounded and captured in a village near Malasqui a party of guerrillas, who had made their headquarters there. The party included the band which assassinated seven officials at Malasqui for friendliness to the Americans.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- At a special meeting to-day of the stockholders of the Chicago Union Traction Company four new Directors were elected as follows: William Dickinson and John V. Clark, Chicago; Walter F. Johnston and Henry H. Hollins, New York. The office of Third Vice President was also created and ex-General Counsel Walter H. Wilson was elected to the position.

A largely attended meeting of the Trustees of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association was held yesterday afternoon in the United Charities Building. Mrs. Edmund L. Baylies, President of the Woman's Auxiliary of the association, reported upon the preparatory work for subscriptions to the Woman's Fund. For the last two years the proceeds of a concert at the Waldorf-Astoria, netting each season about $2,000, have helped to increase this fund.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- The Morning Post says: "We have high authority for stating that there is considerable doubt whether or not the negotiations regarding the Anglo-American railway between Han-Kow and Canton will be carried to a successful issue. The view in official circles is that the matter will stand over.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The fight of the cities has begun for the Republican Convention in 1900. Lemuel E. Quigg and Michael J. Dady are here looking over the ground in the interest of New York, and Philadelphia has already opened headquarters, and her delegates are hard at work. A delegation from St. Louis is expected shortly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Representative Joseph C. Sibley of Pennsylvania, about whose alleged change of view on the money question there has been much inquiry during the last week, has given a statement of his opinions, in which he not only acknowledges that he was mistaken in his notions about the intimate relation between free silver and prosperity, but comes out frankly and cordially in favor of expansion.

The prosecution, through Assistant District Attorney Osborne, practically admitted yesterday that it would endeavor to prove the crime of murder in the first degree against Roland B. Molineux on the strength of expert testimony relating to handwriting. Most of the testimony so far introduced has been on this basis.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Julia Arthur, who is filling a week's engagement here at the Newark Theatre in "More Than Queen," will retire from the stage, it is understood, at the end of this season. Whether her retirement will be permanent or temporary is uncertain. The probability is that it will be temporary and necessitated by the state of the actress's health.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 12. -- A number of the prominent hat manufacturers of this place, which is the largest hat-producing city in the East, have just completed stocktaking, and, although the season was one of the busiest in the past twenty years, no money was made by those engaged in the domestic trade.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- In the Senate today Mr. Pettigrew (S. D.) offered the following resolution: ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Roberts investigating committee resumed its session at 10 o'clock to-day, but, contrary to expectation, the early proceedings were behind closed doors. This, it was explained, was to permit the committee to receive and discuss reports on procedure, form of subpoena, During this time Mr. Roberts and quite a gathering of Mormons and Gentiles stood outside the committee door awaiting admission.

But this is a great war upon which we have entered. It is not a small task that this country has, not for the first time in its glorious history, undertaken. We are told that the Transvaal is a weak power. Weakness in war depends upon many considerations. It is not merely a question of numbers or of wealth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Some of the Democrats of the House are repeating a criticism said to have been made to-day by one of their leaders that the Republicans threw away a trick by not taking the Currency bill into a committee composed in part of Democrats, and thus lodging upon the opposition minority the task of reporting a minority bill.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 12. -- Judge Lurton, in the United States court to-day, began the hearing of the case of Calvin Cone against the United States Express Company. Frank Platt of New York is conducting the defense, and Senator T.C. Platt is expected as a witness on behalf of the company tomorrow.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 12. -- At Sac City, Iowa, this afternoon W.D. Sansom, an eccentric young farmer, entered the First National Bank, and, holding a revolver in the face of the assistant cashier, demanded and received the pile of paper money lying near the cashier's window, amounting to nearly $400.

Shipping Commissioner Dickey yesterday received from Commissioner of Navigation E.T. Chamberlain at Washington, copies of a report of the United States District Attorney of the Maryland District on a recent verdict in the matter of shipping seamen.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 12. -- The Supreme Court to-day handed down a decision dismissing the ouster suits brought by the Attorney General against the following insurance companies on the grounds that they had combined to fix rates:
Details in regard to the sale of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum property will be found in another column.

Count VON BUELOW'S exposition of the appropriation for the German Navy was a pattern in its kind. Neither Lord SALISBURY nor any other "old Parliamentary hand" could have done it any better. It was entirely free from anything of menace. On the contrary, it was an announcement of good relations all around.

The latest attempt of the Protection organ to prove that the tariff is the source of all good and perfect gifts is a peculiar one. We have before us a card sent out by The American Protective Tariff League to the officers of all the churches in the country who can be reached.

James M. Croft, who was a Lieutenant and Battalion Adjutant of the First Montana Volunteers in the early fighting in the Philippines, is making a visit to friends in the East. The matter of the army ration being under discussion, Lieut. Croft said that the experience of the men of his regiment had been to verify the fact that in quality and quantity the army ration is satisfactory in every way.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Beda Voigt of 294 Fairmount Avenue has received word that his son, Gustave K. Voigt, a mining engineer, died at Monterey, Mexico, yesterday from injuries received by a fall Dec. 6.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- At the conclusion of morning business in the Senate to-day, the resolution offered yesterday by Mr. Pettigrew, (Silver, S.D.,) reciting certain things alleged to have been done by Gen. Merriam in connection with the trouble in the Coeur d'Alene mining district, and directing the Secretary of War to transmit to the Senate all orders and information in his possession bearing upon the subject, was laid before the Senate.

Gen. Edward Ferrero, for many years prior to last May the lessee of the Lenox Lyceum, and one of the most interesting characters of New York, died at 4 o'clock on Monday afternoon at his residence, 111 West Seventy-eighth Street, of a complication of diseases. Gen. Ferrero had been in poor health for several months, and had retired altogether from active business life.

The differences between the Committee of the Trustees of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum and the syndicate which has been negotiating for the purchase of the asylum block, at Fifth Avenue, Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, have, it is believed, been satisfactorily adjusted and the final contracts for the sale of the property will probably be signed within a day or two.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 12. -- The road and fence war which has interested the hamlet of Echo for two years has broken out afresh. The Brookhaven Highway Commissioners, in an effort to straighten the main road in front of Ansel Smith's property, at Echo, two years ago laid the new lines of the road, but Mr. Smith claimed the highway encroached upon his property to nearly one-half the width of the road.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Three lives were lost as the result of a freight train wreck which piled the cars of three freight trains in a heap and blocked the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad for several hours near Schalk's Station early this morning. The trains involved were running on different tracks.

Much of the war news from South Africa that has come by the way of Continental Europe has been colored by charges against the British soldier tending to show that he had suddenly become regardless of the rules of civilized warfare. We were told that Boers were massacred after surrendering at Elandslaagte, and that the survivors suffered unspeakable indignities while being conveyed as prisoners of war to the naval station near Cape Town.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Senator John W. Daniel of Virginia, who has been a Democrat "since 1800," according to his own playful statement before the Virginia Democratic Association, at its banquet given here last night justified some of the reports that have been heard about him as to the necessity for a restatement of Democratic policy in 1900 without abandoning any of the vital principles that have been held by the party since its formation.
Samuel Layton of Plainfield, N.J., died at Christ Hospital, Jersey City, Monday night. He was visiting Jersey City friends, and on Thursday last was prostrated by pneumonia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- When the Currency bill comes to a vote in the House of Representatives it is expected that the Democrats of the New York delegation will give it a vote of at least 10. Before the discussion began a few strong sound-money men began to work to assure a vote creditable to the delegation and the constituencies they represent.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, yesterday passed upon the "single standard" of morality as a matter of law in the suit brought by Richard F. Abbe against his brother, Max F. Abbe, to recover $10,000 damages for alleged libel. This libel consisted of statements contained in a letter written by the defendant and sent by him to another man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- At the instance of the Secretary of the Navy, Senator Hale (Rep., Me.,) to-day introduced a bill providing for the classification of vessels of the navy into four classes, torpedo boats excepted. The bill provides that vessels of more than 5,000 tons' displacement shall be first class, and provides tor a gradation downward.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- A gang of alleged boy burglars was arrested last evening in lavishly furnished apartments in a barn in the rear of 4,341 Wentworth Avenue. Five boys compose the gang, and their ages range from eleven to seventeen years.

The "campaign of education" of the Canal Committee of the New York Produce Exchange was begun last evening by a meeting in the manager's room of the Exchange of the committee and representatives of commercial organizations of the city, together with members of the State Canal Commission.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- Manager Grau's season of Italian opera, now in its second and last week in Boston, has been, as he himself puts it, satisfactory both from the artistic and financial point of view. Saleza's illness from bronchitis has caused the only change from an announced bill, and the season has progressed smoothly notwithstanding.

The National Society of New England Women met at Delmonico's yesterday afternoon for their annual luncheon. Although the weather was anything but propitious for out-of-town members, there was a very good attendance, some 200 women, including guests, being present. Among the features of the decorations were masses of holly on each table and a large Christmas tree in the centre of the room.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- The event of the day has been Dr. Lieber's criticism in the Reichstag of Emperor William's speech at Hamburg. The spectacle of this cautious leader of the most important group in the Reichstag -- the section that will decide the fate of the Naval bill -- thus severely blaming the Kaiser, is almost without parallel in German Parliamentary history.

New York has now the finest collection of objects illustrating the ancient civilization of Mexico and Central America in the world. A private view was given yesterday of the Mexican Hall of the Museum of Natural History, and those who were invited were more than astonished at the results of work that has been going on, unknown to the general public, for several years.
LONDON, Dec. 13. -- The War Office publishes the following dispatch from Gen. Buller:

A morning of wind and rain, which made walking impossible and even driving disagreeable, and an afternoon of enervating warmth was the story of yesterday's climatic conditions, which must be told in brief, as upon the state of the thermometer and the elements society doings in this transition period of the year largely depend.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Executive Committee of the National League of Republican Clubs met here to-day for the purpose of deciding upon a city for holding the next convention of the league. The chair was occupied by President George Stone of San Francisco, and the roll call showed forty-four members present, the largest number on record at such a meeting.

Everybody connected with the Mazet committee refuses to talk about the letter in which Frank Moss, counsel to the committee, is said to have demanded the calling of Senator T.C. Platt as a witness. Mr. Moss was requested yesterday afternoon to make public the letter which he admits he sent to the Republican members of the committee. He refused to do so, and said:
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 12. -- A Washington dispatch to The Leader says:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Vice Chancellor Emery this afternoon heard testimony in a suit brought by Mrs. Jennie Ryan against her husband, John J. Ryan, for maintenance and support. The Ryans were married in March, 1886. On July 9, 1898, Mrs. Ryan alleges, she was forced, because of cruel treatment, to leave her husband.

ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- Gov. Roosevelt announced to-day that he was considering the names of Francis Hendricks of Syracuse, ex-Attorney General T.E. Hancock, also of Syracuse, and Hubert Cillis of New York City of the Germania Life Insurance Company, as candidates to succeed Louis F. Payn, State Superintendent of Insurance, whose term expires in February.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 12. -- The disaster that overtook the Island of Ceram on the second of last month resulted in a great loss of life and property.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The names of forty-three defendants in bucket-shop cases were called off by the Clerk in Judge Waterman's courtroom this morning. Many of the defendants failed to put in an appearance and their bonds were declared forfeited. Others appeared personally and entered pleas of guilty, while a few were ready to stand trial.

James Halcrow, night clerk in the Waverley Hotel, a cheap lodging house at 352 Eighth Avenue, was murdered there at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning by Martin Sweeney, who occasionally stopped at the house. Halcrow was shot three times in the breast, and died before the arrival of an ambulance from Roosevelt Hospital.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The principal feature of to-day's session of the Reichstag was Dr. von Miquel's defense against the implied charge of the Centrist leader, Dr. Lieber, that he was the "irresponsible adviser who has prejudiced the Emperor against the Reichstag and the people." This he hotly repudiated, declaring that he found it difficult to reply to such an insinuation with Parliamentary courtesy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The following is the text of the agreement made between Gen. Bates and the Sultan of Jolo, known as the Jolo treaty, which has been sent to the Senate by the President:

That is an extraordinary report which the Commissioner of Water Supply has made to the Mayor upon the operations of his department. The most obvious comment upon it is that the "Ramapo job" is not yet dead, that the Commissioner of Water Supply is one of the jobbers, and that he assumes the Mayor to be another.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The announcement of the wedding of John W. Oliver, editor of The Yonkers Statesman, which is to take place to-morrow evening at his home, Rose cottage, was a surprise to his friends, who thought that, as he is eighty-four years of age, he was out of the matrimonial field.
MANILA, Dec. 13. -- The following dispatch, dated Cervantes, Dec. 5, has just been received from a correspondent with Major March's batallion:

Both branches of the Municipal Assembly have passed the resolution adopted by the Board of Public Improvements last week asking the Board of Estimate to appropriate $50,000 for the purpose of ascertaining the practicability and the cost of a tunnel from the foot of Manhattan Island to the foot of Hamilton Avenue, in the Borough of Brooklyn, following the line of the existing Hamilton Ferry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Senator Depew and Lieut. Gov. Woodruff will deliver the principal speeches for New York before the Republican National Committee on Friday, when there will be a hearing for the different cities which want to secure the National Convention. New York is now represented here by a number of advocates, but the main body of the committee will not be here until to-morrow.

Four games were decided in the Life Insurance League at Starr's tournament hall last night. The winners were the Fidelity and Casualty Company, Prudential, Equitable, and Metropolitan teams. A feature of the series was a spare on Pins 8 and 10 by Haubner of the Equitable team in the third game. Scores:

The little troubles that have caused much pain and some alarm in the region of Wall Street during the last few days need impair no man's confidence in the greatness of his country and the stability of its institutions.
ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- The State Land Board at its meeting this afternoon received a letter from Gov. Roosevelt on the Astoria Gas Company's grant, which was read and placed on file. It is as follows:

There has been a deal of talk about the weather lately and its behavior. Of course the weather is always a popular subject, ranking a close second to the friendly salutation, "Howd'y." But the widespread belief that there is something radically wrong with the seasons has given the subject an unusual boom of late.

At the meeting yesterday of the Board of Trade and Transportation a resolution offered by the Committee on City Affairs, which urged on Congress the necessity for a new New York Post Office, increased appropriations for an adequately increased force of employes, and the need of a more complete system to expedite the delivery of foreign mail was adopted.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Each important battle seems to bring a worse reverse for the British, and the papers this morning sorrowfully admit that Lord Methuen's check at Magersfontein is the most serious event the war has yet produced. The Morning Post says:

The public school in Adelina Place, North Bergen, Hudson County, N.J., was entered by burglars a week ago and a wagon load of furniture carried away. The police thought the burglars might return, and two officers were stationed in the school.

Serious as was the break in stocks on Monday last, it was insignificant as compared with the violent decline in prices yesterday all through the Stock Exchange list. For a time during the afternoon, and particularly toward the close, conditions were panicky, and the closing of the market alone stayed the enormous volume of liquidation and further declines.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 13. -- The residents of this section do not know whether to praise or condemn George H. Townsend. There have been many robberies recently, and meetings have been held to consider means of ending them.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- The Board of Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company at a meeting to-day authorized an allotment of stock at par for 10 per cent. of the holdings of the stockholders as they stand registered on Tuesday, Dec. 26. Payment is to be made in full between Jan. 14 and 20, 1900, at which latter date the privilege will cease.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- By direction of the President Major Gen. Leonard Wood, United States Volunteers, was to-day assigned to the command of the Division of Cuba, relieving Major Gen. John R. Brooke, United States Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The Republican Senators will hold a caucus to-morrow to receive the report of their committee appointed at the last caucus to make new committee assignments. The committee also will report the creation of four new committees, and that they have made an arrangement with the Democratic committee for increased Republican representation upon the thirteen principal committees.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Bucknall Brothers of London, managers of the American-African Line, have written to the morning papers setting forth the fact with respect to the cargo of the British steamer Mashona, Capt. Johnstone, which left New York Nov. 3, via St. Vincent Nov. 16, for Algoa Bay, laden with flour for the Transvaal, and which was captured by the British gunboat Partridge.

Col. Julius Walker Adams, one of the first engineers who conceived the idea of building the New York and Brooklyn Bridge, died at his home, 155 Congress Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. He was eighty-seven years old and was born in Boston, Mass. Col. Adams was a cousin of President John Quincy Adams.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The Senate today confirmed the following nominations: ...

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Gen. Lord Methuen has met with a disastrous defeat in an attack upon the Boer positions at Magersfontein, four miles north of the Modder River. It is estimated here that Lord Methuen's forces amounted to 11,000 men, and perhaps to more. No reliable estimate of his losses has yet been received. They are believed to have been at least 450.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Secretary Long has taken the first step toward carrying out his project for the consolidation of the naval bureaus under one head, and has prepared a bill to be introduced immediately in Congress for that purpose.

William J. Kinsley, the chief handwriting expert for the prosecution in the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Katherine J. Adams, was on the witness stand during the greater part of yesterday's session, telling the jury the points of similarity between the admitted handwriting of the defendant, the Barnet and Cornish requests for medicinal remedies, and the address on the poison package received by Cornish.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 13. -- It is reported here that the American Steel and Wire Company has made a contract to furnish an enormous quantity of wire and nails for export. It seems that German iron and steel manufacturers will be far short in their requirements; that they have sought in vain to fill orders in England and America for pig iron.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Edward Leland of the firm of Leland Ware, which in its line did the biggest private-wire business in the country, was expelled from the Chicago Stock Exchange to-day on the general charge of indulging in methods detrimental to the interests and contrary to the rules of the institution of which he had been a member only a year.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- The opening performance of "The Mystical Miss" at the Comedy Theatre this evening was kindly received by the audience and the critics, although Mr. Sousa's catchy airs were liked better than Mr. Klein's libretto. Mr. Hopper, Miss Nella Bergen, and Howard Blake made much merry nonsense.

The Grand Jury for the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New York was sworn in yesterday. Judge Thomas, who is to preside over the sessions of the court, called the attention of the jury to a statement made some time ago by Superintendent of Municipal Elections John McCullagh, in which the Superintendent said: ...

MANILA, Dec. 13. -- Gen. Tirona, commanding the Filipinos in the Province of Cagayan, surrendered the entire province at Aparri on Dec. 11 to Capt. McCalla of the United States cruiser Newark. Capt. McCalla appointed him Civil Governor of the province, subject to the approval of Gen. Otis.

State Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn had a long talk yesterday with Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee. After he left Mr. Odell he talked freely concerning Gov. Roosevelt's reported intention to appoint a new man in his place in February next, when Mr. Payn's term will have expired.

There have been two serious defeats of the British in South Africa reported this week. But the trapping of Gen. GATACRE'S reconnoitring column was a small matter compared with the checking of Gen. METHUEN'S advance. The previous fight at the Modder may fairly be called a drawn battle. But this fight, by the testimony of the British commander, is a defeat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The currency debate in the House lasted from 11 o'clock this morning until 10:30 tonight, with a recess of three hours for dinner. The pressure for time to speak continues, as most of the members desire to make contributions to the literature of the occasion. Much of it however, seems to be for home consumption.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Gen. Otis had some stirring news to report to-day from Manila, his advices going to show that the insurgents are, as he predicted a few days ago, at the end of their resources from a military point of view, and are melting away before the rapid advance of the American troops at all points. His cablegrams were as follows: ...

The Dry Goods Trade Auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, Mr. Louis Stix, Treasurer, reports the following subscriptions up to date. The indications are that it will be the largest collection in the history of the Dry Goods Auxiliary:

Christmas shopping, from all appearances, is the most popular amusement in society just now, and the shopping district proper, which extends from Union Square to Thirty-fourth Street, is daily crowded with carriages, while those known at all in or to the fashionable world can be met on Fifth Avenue, Broadway, Twenty-third Street, and even Sixth Avenue in the late morning and early afternoon.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 13. -- The Montreal bankers unanimously deny the published statement that Canadian gold has been withdrawn from New York to be shipped to England. The managers say they can do much better in New York than in London.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13. -- John Skelton Williams, President of the Seaboard Air Line system, Baltimore Steam Packet Company. Georgia and Alabama Railway. Florida Central and Peninsular Railroad, and other properties that will be included in the new Seaboard Air Line Railway Company was in Baltimore to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -- A dispatch from Seattle, Washington, says: "Capt. J.B. Coghlan, who was commander of the United States cruiser Raleigh at Manila, is now commandant of the Port Orchard naval station. When seen to-day in reference to the allegations made at Manila by Col. Julio Del Rio, a Spanish officer, and Senor Rafael Rosello, a merchant, Capt. Coghlan said:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 13. -- The Plain Dealer to-morrow will say: A party of twenty-five young Irish-Americans hax, e left this city to join the Boers in their fight against Great Britain. At-New York these young men, who are mostly veterans of the Spanish-American war, will Join about 500 other Irishmen, and the entire party will sail from New York on Saturday for Paris.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -The battleship Iowa and tile cruiser Philadelphia, sailed to-day for the south coast. The cruiser Albemar]e will meet them at Magdalena I3ay and there will be a month of target practice.
" CAPE TOWN, Tuesday, Dec. 12. -- Methuen wires that Gen. Wauchope was killed in action yesterday."

Representative SIBLEY possesses intelligence of a high order and courage to match it. The two together make him a consistent statesman. They enable him to discard the outworn beliefs he held three years ago, which events and later knowledge have shown to be unsound. He says frankly that he has discarded them, that he was mistaken. He avows present convictions born of new knowledge and of the world's experience.

ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- The police here knew P.E. King, the burglar shot by a night watchman at Deep River, Conn., as a suspicious character. He was believed to be one of those who robbed a brewery in Amsterdam last Fall. At one time he was a brakeman on the Boston and Albany Railroad and stopped at the Eastern Hotel in this city.

The dissensions in the Sugar Trust become more positive. Not content with writing a letter last week declaring that his name must not be used for re-election to the Board of Directors of the American Sugar Refining Company, F.O. Matthiessen -- the more clearly, it is said, to emphasize his position yesterday wrote a formal letter of resignation as a Director of the company.

The Health Board yesterday reached a decision in the cases of the vessels from the plague-infected Port of Santos, and later made the decision public. The three vessels now in quarantine, none of which had cases of the plague on board, are to be permitted to dock and to land their coffee. The other vessel, the J.W. Taylor, the only one which had any cases of the plague aboard, sailed for Queenstown on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Elaborate preparations have been made for the celebration to-morrow of the hundredth anniversary of the death of George Washington. Many visitors from a distance, especially among the Masonic fraternity, have arrived in the city to participate in the ceremonies. Four separate and distinct events have been planned for this locality.

The National Baseball League magnates continued in session yesterday afternoon and last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. It is believed that the Board of Directors will recommend that the Brooklyn-Baltimore syndicate be fined $1,500 for taking Shortstop Wrigley away from the New York team. The board spent several hours yesterday considering the matter.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13. -- Gov. Poynter has appointed ex-Senator Allen to fill the Senatorial vacancy caused by the death of Mr. Hayward.

The second concert of the afternoon series of the Boston Symphony Orchestra took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The audience was not what one is accustomed to see at the entertainments of this organization. It was by no means as large as a concert of this kind deserves, and the only inference was that the business of Christmas shopping was too strong an opposition to the delicate art of music.

YONKERS, Dec. 14. -- John W. Oliver, one of the oldest and most popular citizens of this city, and editor and publisher of the Yonkers Daily Statesman, married Mrs. Maria Du Bois of Kingston, N.Y., at half-past 8 o'clock to-night at his home, Rose Cottage, 192 Warburton Avenue. Mr. Oliver is in his eighty-fifth year.

Two deeds that caused much speculation were filed in the Hudson County Register's office at Jersey City yesterday. They show that the Standard Oil Company has conveyed to the New Jersey Storage Company its oil yards, buildings, and apparatus at Bayonne. At the same time the National Docks and Storage Company conveys to the New Jersey Storage Company its docks and property at Black Tom Island, near Cavan Point.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- A decision which is regarded as of great importance was rendered to-day by Vice Chancellor Reed. It accompanies an order allowing an injunction against members of the Glass Bottle Blowers' Association of the United States and Canada.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- In the Reichstag, today, in the continuation of the debate on the budget estimates, Eugene Richter, the Radical leader, commenting on the Emperor's Hamburg speech, defended the House from the reproach of persistently refusing to increase the navy.

Mayor Van Wyck took occasion at the meeting of the Armory Board yesterday to emphasize his dislike for Controller Coler's East River tunnel plan and to announce that all the city's money would be spent in such ways as would prevent the construction of tunnels.

Controller Coler was the principal guest and speaker at the first dinner of the City Club for the season of 1899-1900, at 19 West Thirty-fourth Street, last night, when the announced subject was "The Municipal Ownership of the Water Supply of the City of New York."

A Representative in Congress ought to stand up for his State as well as for his country and his party. There is some present need of reminding the New York members of the House of Representatives that this is one of their duties.

The British steamship Manica, twenty days out from Shields, England, recently reported by the steamship Albano as being disabled at sea, reached this port yesterday. That she came in under her own steam, saving her owners salvage claims, was due to the clever work of her chief engineer -- Mr. Gooding -- who, while the vessel was laboring in troubled seas, successfully repaired a broken shaft.

ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- The commission to unify the educational system of the State met to-day. Regent St. Clair McKelway, on behalf of the Regents of the university, presented a statement and a provisional draft of amendments prepared by a special committee of the Board of Regents. The statement says in part:

ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- John T. O'Brien, representing Corporation Counsel John Whalen of New York City, came to Albany to-day and served papers on Gov. Roosevelt, Secretary of State McDonough, Attorney General Davies, Controller Morgan, and other members of the State Land Board to restrain and enjoin the Commissioners from granting the application of the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company for a grant of sixteen and one-half acres of land under water at Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Pettigrew's resolution asking for information as to whether the flag of the Philippine Republic had ever been saluted by the American forces in the Philippines came up in the regular order.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Speaking at a Unionist meeting in Hackney, London, this evening. Rear Admiral Lord Charles Beresford said that he long ago told the Secretary of State for War, Lord Lansdowne, that the Government was not sending enough troops to the Transvaal.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Prosecutor Emery is far from being satisfied with the verdict rendered by the Coroner's jury in the recent Lackawanna disaster. The jury held George W. Cappell, the conductor, and William Snedeker, the rear flagman, of the express responsible, and last night Coroner Yates issued warrants for their arrest.

Imposing ceremonial marked the service in commemoration of the death of Washington, held under the auspices of the General Society of the Cincinnati and the New York State Society of the Sons of the Revolution in St. Paul's Chapel yesterday. While the service was in progress a salute of 100 guns, fired at one minute intervals, thundered from Castle William.

It is not surprising that the recent reverses of the British arms should have stimulated the British press to call for large and immediate reinforcements. These reverses, by the way, have been entirely confined to the Cape Colony side and the southern border of the Orange Free State.
