It was the general remark of shrewd and experienced observers yesterday that Wall Street was full of bargains, and, though the net result of the violent fluctuations of prices on the Exchange was to leave the level about the same as at the closing on the previous day, the remark remained true.

After having been on the stand intermittently for five days under the direct examination of Assistant District Attorney Osborne, William J. Kinsley, the chief handwriting expert for the prosecution in the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder by poison of Katherine J. Adams, was turned over yesterday to Mr. Weeks for cross-examination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Representative Overstreet of Indiana, in charge of the financial bill now under consideration in the House of Representatives, said to-day that the informal canvasses thus far made showed that the bill would pass on the final vote next Monday by a majority of about 36, in case the full strength of both sides was present.

ROME, Dec. 14. -- At the consistory held to-day the Pope formally announced the appointment of a number of Bishops. One of them was that of Mgr. Fergo McEvay to the Bishopric of London, Ontario, which post he has been occupying since August last.

The equanimity with which the Bank of France has held its customary course during the increasing financial stress in London, due to the South African war, and its capacity to come to the rescue with supplies of the much-needed gold, when the stress threatens to become too severe, is calculated to attract special attention to that institution just now.

The Assembly ball of last night, the story of which will be found in another column, was the chief topic of anticipatory interest wherever people prominent in the gay world of New York met yesterday, and the preparations for the ball had their effect upon the teas, receptions, and other incidents of the day.

One of the most active members of the Harvard Club had just returned from a visit to his Alma Mater, and as he was an oarsman of note in his student days, and active in securing money from the New York alumni for the building of the new boathouse on the Charles River, his talk naturally drifted to college rowing.

The Union College Alumni Association of this city held its twelfth annual reunion at the Hotel Savoy last evening. About 115 persons attended. A business meeting, at which Dr. Daniel M. Stimson, President of the association, was re-elected for another year, was followed by a dinner, at which he acted as toastmaster.

KENSICO, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- A sensation was caused in Armonk to-day when it became known that an attempt had been made to poison the family of Robert Cox. He is proprietor of a boarding house in Armonk and operates the stage route from Armonk.

Prof. John B. Clark of Columbia University said last night, at the Cooper Institute, that the most effective means for controlling trusts were publicity regarding their affairs and the compulsion of uniformity in their prices. The occasion was a discussion of the "Pros and Cons of Trusts," held under the auspices of the Fellow-Citizenship Association of the East Side House Settlement.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- "There is one feature of the war in the Transvaal that is not generally considered," said Gen. Thomas M. Anderson last night, "and that is that the English are violating the military usage by fighting with three armies of invasion." He continued:

Martin Niles Wilcoxson, whose wife is suing him for a separation on the ground of cruelty, was put on the stand before Justice Russell, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, and told his side of the case. Mrs. Wilcoxson frequently showed by her whispered protests to her lawyer that she disagreed with the testimony of the defendant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The debate on the Currency bill in the House to-day was tame and prosaic. The attendance both in the galleries and on the floor was light, and none of the speeches made attracted especial attention. Mr. Sibley, (Dem., Penn.,) who has publicly announced his change of views on the money question, and who, it was thought, might vote for the bill, stated that he would vote against it.

The Sub-Treasury team lost a chance to win two games in the Bank Clerks' League at Reid's alleys last night through Jenkins missing an easy spare. The team won the first game easily from the Hamilton Bank bowlers. The Chemical National Bank five disposed of the Hamiltons as easily in the second game.

STONINGTON, Conn., Dec. 14. -- A note addressed to "Mrs. T. Doremus, Upper Montclair, N.J.," and signed by "T. Doremus," in which the writer said he was about to end his life by throwing himself overboard, was found attached to a white Fedora hat in a stateroom of the steamer State of Maine on her arrival here this morning.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Sir Charles Warren, who arrived at Cape Town yesterday, will possibly join Lord Methuen and take command of the combined forces. The newspapers are calling upon the Government to employ the Cunarders as well as the White Star steamers as transports, seeing the urgent necessity for getting more men to the Cape as speedily as possible.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The Globe says: ...

The only remaining doubt as to the programme of the Republican managers for 1900 is now dispelled by the selection of Secretary ROOT as the candidate for Vice President. To this the assent of Mr. ROOT is believed to have been secured, and the plan will be carried out unless circumstances that cannot be foreseen shall interfere.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- Locked up at Police Headquarters in the City Hall is a white woman, charged with burning the body of a new-born infant in the cellar furnace of a boarding house.

BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- At a meeting to-day of the Boston Clearing House Association, representing the National banks of this city, it was voted to issue $3,500,000 in special Clearing House certificates to enable the Globe National Bank to tide over the difficulties in its finances, which have existed for some time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- At the War Department it is learned that an order has been sent to Manila directing the military officers there to adopt a course that will render unsafe to the Filipinos the continuation of cruel acts upon friendly natives who have disregarded the instructions of the insurgent leaders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- In the fight for the Republican National Convention New York's prospects are not bright, unless conditions suddenly change.

Washington L. Galbraith was found guilty last evening of "obvious fraud" by the Board of Directors of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange and was expelled from membership. The technical charge against him involved specifications of conduct prejudicial to the welfare and repute of the Exchange, and the fundamental offense was sending out circulars of the Franklin Syndicate character after the officers of the Exchange had prohibited such practices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Secretary Gage announced to-day that he would anticipate the interest due Jan. 1, 1900, on United States registered and coupon 4 per cent. bonds of 1907 without rebate. Checks to the number of 26,563 will be mailed to-morrow to holders of the registered bonds, and interest on the coupons will be paid on presentation of the same.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The Great Council of the United States of the Improved Order of Red Men held exercises in Convention Hall this evening to commemorate the centenary of the death of George Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Advance sheets of the report of James W. Ragsdale, United States Consul at Tientsin, on the agricultural products of North China, have been issued by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce. The report considers both the products and agricultural methods of the two principal northern provinces, Pechili and Shantung, which are taken as typical of the northern part of the empire.

A contest over the will of the Rev. John M. Kiely, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration, who died on August 9 last, was begun in Surrogate Abbott's court, Brooklyn, yesterday. The ground of the contest is that Father Kiely was insane when he executed his will on Sept. 15, 1898.

HAVANA, Dec. 14. -- Governor General Brooke is indignant at the reports cabled from Washington which represent him as having protested against the order of the President relieving him of the Military Governorship of Cuba. He says:

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 14. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Santa Fe was held in this city at noon to-day. A meeting of the Board of Directors was held immediately following it. At the stockholders' meeting the acquisition by purchase or lease of a number of branch railroad companies was approved.
BERNE, Dec. 14. -- The Federal Assembly has elected Walther Hauser to be President for 1900.

MODDER RIVER, Dec. 13. -- Ambulances started early yesterday morning, under a flag of truce, to collect the wounded and bury the dead who fell at Magersfontein. Brig. Gen. Wauchope, who led the Highland Brigade, was found dead near the trenches, shot in the chest and thigh. A few wounded were found near the trenches.

Last evening took place the first Assembly ball of the season in the large ballroom of the Astoria. For several years, since the Patriarchs passed into history, the Assembly has been looked upon as the veritable opening of the social year. The Horse Show is only a prelude, and after that event is over society returns to the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Two joint resolutions were introduced in the House of Representatives to-day by Representative Williams of Mississippi, which are the result of consultation among a number of Democratic leaders in the House and are understood to be expressive of their general position on the Philippine question. The principal resolution is as follows:

There is one gratifying circumstance about the interview with which the malodorous "LOU" PAYN has favored our esteemed contemporary The Sun. That is the entirely conclusive showing it makes that "LOU" is in pain. We pointed out, a good many days ago, that it was quite a moral impossibility that the Governor should renominate "LOU."

Driven by his desire to peer into the mystery of future life, Maurice Strauss, twenty years ago a well-known actor, and lately an enthusiastic Spiritualist, is supposed to have ended his life by plunging into the Sound from the Fall River steamer Puritan, which arrived at New York Thursday morning.

Controller Coler scored a noteworthy victory in the Board of Aldermen yesterday, when the members of that body, actuated largely by a statement furnished by him, refused to concur in the action of the Board of Estimate in appropriating $1,000,000 for the proposed Blackwell's Island bridge, and recommitted the bridge resolution to the Committee on Bridges and Tunnels for investigation.

Will you permit a reader to call your attention to a noteworthy new book -- a first utterance? The note rings strong, withal at times strident, In Mrs. Josephine Bontecou Steffens's novel, "Letitia Berkeley, A. M." But it is a woman's tone, and as such is often full and low and warm -- a real contralto, to pursue the simile in its characteristic impressiveness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The Republican National Convention will be held at Philadelphia on Tuesday, June 19, next. The place and date were decided upon by the National Republican Committee to-day after a friendly contest for the honor of entertaining the convention between the city selected, Chicago, St. Louis, and New York.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 15. -- Adam Crist to-night shot his wife fatally, killed his eight-year-old son, seriously wounded a second, aged five years, and then shot and killed himself. Jealousy is the only motive assigned for the crime.

The rising of "the Sun of Righteousness" which Malachi saw four hundred years before it began to illume the earth Isaiah saw more than three hundred years before Malachi was born. But many hundred years before Isaiah was born Abraham saw it as clearly as he. It was the blessed promise of a coming Saviour.
ROME, Dec. 15. -- The text of the Pope's allocution at yesterday's Consistory is published to-day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- It is not often nowadays that an old-established railroad, traversing a thickly populated and well-developed country, can, in a few weeks, create forty-one new towns, with prospects of good business from each. Yet this is what the Northwestern Company has just accomplished.
Replying to your correspondent who asks the meaning of Coleridge's great poem, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner," the following is submitted:

For William Reno, who was arraigned before Judge Newburger in part IV, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday next Christmas will be the first Christmas spent out of jail in twenty-two years. He owes this privilege to the eloquence of his pleadings and the clemency of Justice Newburger, who suspended a sentence for grand larceny and let him go on his own recognizance.

Gold exports started yesterday. But instead of showing any disturbance over the development the security market actually advanced. About $2,000,000 constituted the first shipment, various banking houses joining in the engagements. The warrant for the movement was found in foreign advances in the price of every form of gold, whether in bullion or coinage; and incidental bearing appeared in sharp advances in money market rates abroad.

Policeman Brennan of the Oak Street Station and some of the employes in the General Post Office found a carrier pigeon yesterday that they were willing to bet had as great a hypersense as the collie dog Leo that always knew when his master boarded a train fourteen miles away from home.

" The Charming Renee, by Arabella Keneaby, author of "Dr. Janet of Harley St.," and "Men Are Such Gentlemen," is being prepared for publication by Harper Brothers. It is a. romance, very much in the style of "Jane Eyre." A new volume by Cutcliffe Hyne, "The Lost Continent," is also in active preparation by the same house.

Dull blue, the faded blue of the royal regiments of France, with the English leopards romping on a field sown with the Bourbon lily, makes the livery of this holiday edition of a story that needs no embellishment and has a catastroph6 as sad and splendid as ever dawned upon the imagination of a Greek dramatist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- This was the closing day of the general debate on the Financial bill in the House of Representatives. To-morrow all speeches will be made under the five-minute rule. During the early hours to-day there was less than a score of Republican members on the floor and the Democratic representation was thin and scattered. Jones (Dem., Va.,) opened the debate in opposition to the bill.

An important collection of bindings is now being exhibited by Meyer Brothers Co. of this city. In point of variety of items, in number of master artisans represented, in exquisiteness of decoration, in gilt work, in inlaid leather, and in emblematic designs the exhibition will particularly appeal to collectors.
Holdridge Ward and J.N. Kalley Son have sold for a client the six-story business building 198 and 200 Canal Street, 50 by 100.

The present volume appears in response to earnest solicitations made by certain members of the House of Bishops in the Autumn of 1894 that Bishop Whipple would give to the public a history of his great life work, most of it being spent among the Indians of our Northwest. Probably of all the laborers in the Indian missions none has been more untiring, more earnest, or more successful than our author, the Indians' true friend.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Herbert Putnam, the Librarian of Congress, hopes to be able at an early day to install in the Capitol a reference library, made up of selected volumes now in the new library building. This was contemplated in the last Appropriation bill. There is now no reference library at the Capitol, and books can be obtained from the Congressional Library only after a delay of from twenty to thirty minutes.

In recalling the death of George Washington, which has been forcibly brought to memory in view of the centenary of that event on Dec. 14, it seems almost as though one's attention were carried back into ancient history, so rapid has been the material growth of our country since 1799. How swift has been the advance in all those things that pertain to the higher civilization.

EDMUND CLARENCE STEDMAN says of "In Chimney Corners," Mr. Seumas MacManus's book: "Not the least doubt as to the prerogative of your Donegal boy, Seumas MacManus. We are on 'the old sod' at once, whether reading his folk-lore and country sketches, or -- having him read them for us."

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- The biography of Dr. Benson, late Archbishop of Canterbury, just published, reveals an interesting letter which the Prince of Wales wrote to him after the Tranbycroft scandal. It is as follows:
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- It is announced that Gen. Hector Macdonald has been ordered to leave India immediately, to succeed the late Gen. Wauchope in command of the Highland Brigade.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- "Under Two Flags in Cuba" was the title by which Capt. George Clarke Musgrave intended to publish book early in the Spring of 1898, but, being arrested as a spy and sent to Spain, the circulation of both the manuscript and the photographs by which it was to be illustrated was limited to Gen. Blanco and those members of his staff who were able to read English.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Quartermaster General Ludington is rapidly reducing the expense for transports, and thus the daily expenditure by the Government of a large sum of money. All the troops intended for use in the Philippines excepting one regiment have been forwarded. When the last regiment was started the War Department was paying for forty transports at the rate of from $500 to $1,000 a day.

In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of to-day's date appear two letters referring to my epistle on the "Children of the Ghetto," to which I should like to reply. The writer of one letter most emphatically condemns Reb Shemuel for his action, losing sight, it seems, of the fact that it was the "law" he was upholding, and to a Hebrew the law is infallible -- " is God," as he tells David Brandon.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The news of Gen. Buller's reverse was received so late that morning newspaper comment to-day is confined to perfunctory expressions of extreme regret and disappointment and of the necessity of calmness and redoubled efforts to retrieve the position. This latest check is regarded as the most serious event in Great Britain's military history since the Indian mutiny.

Attorneys for the United Verde Copper Company and for United States Senator William A. Clark and the other Directors appeared before Justice Gildersleeve, in the Supreme Court, yesterday in opposition to the continuance of a temporary injunction restraining the sale of the mining properties of the company on Dec. 19.

The Imperial Club appeared with only four men in the National League at Starr's Tournament Hall last night and were beaten in two games. The four men rolled good scores, however, particularly in the third game, against the Doolittles of Jersey City. The latter had out their full team, but did not have an easy time of it, the Imperials with four men rolling but fifty-two pins less than their opponents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- In the House to-day the serenity of the currency debate was unexpectedly interrupted by a personal clash between Mr. Berry and Mr. Wheeler, both Democrats, of Kentucky. Mr. Wheeler secured recognition to question statements made by Mr. Berry yesterday as to corruption in the recent Kentucky campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- A few nights ago Jim Johnson and Hesy Brown, two colored nimrods of Fairfax County, Va., were out hunting 'possum with one of the best coon dogs in the county, General Grant. The dog struck a fox's trail, and the men followed it all night. At daybreak they came up with the dog standing guard over a big hollow stump.

The artists written of are all men who have achieved a high reputation, and the examples of their art chosen for reproduction are those commonly accepted as in their most characteristic manner.

Last week we gave as the special feature of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW a list, with short reviews, of 100 books adapted to purchases during the Holiday season. It was a list restricted to books actually published during the year 1899. While a few were books of older date than 1899 as to first publication, they had been brought out in new editions this year usually with illustrations.

Christian Hitt, thirty-three years old, of 40 Mallory Avenue, Jersey City, is lying in a critical condition at the City Hospital from poisoning by sulphate of chromium. Henry Bolzer of 112 Morris Street is in the City Prison without bail, charged with administering the poison with intent to kill.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15. -- There was general satisfaction expressed on all sides when it became known here this afternoon that Philadelphia had been selected as the place for holding the Republican National Convention next year. The citizens worked hard for the honor, and intend to work all the harder from now on to properly take care of the host of Republicans that will be here.

The baseball magnates who comprise the National League and American Association of Baseball Clubs have at last straightened out the trouble between the New York and Brooklyn Clubs over the latter signing Shortstop Wrigley after the latter signed a New York contract.

One feels a bond of sympathy with the reviewer of Mrs. Frances Hodgson Burnett's recent story as regards the title of that bit of fiction. "In Connection with the De Willoughby Claim" is certainly formidable, and it is with some trepidation that we attack a book bearing so fearful a name.

It is probable that the Governor's commission will be able to recommend a simple plan for bringing the educational system of the State under one supervision and management. The differences that at one time threatened to arise between the Regents and the Department of Public Instruction are now in a fair way to be averted altogether, as it is understood that the plan under discussion is acceptable to both parties.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 15. -- Edward R. Bacon, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railway Company and a member of the Board of Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, was in Baltimore to-day. Mr. Bacon went to the Baltimore and Ohio Central building, where he was closeted with President Cowen and Chairman of the Board Salomon the greater part of the day.

A report was circulated yesterday to the effect that the contracting firm of O'Brien Sheehan, of which John C. Sheehan is a member, had decided not to bid for the contract to construct the rapid transit tunnel. When the matter was brought to Mr. Sheehan's attention, however, he denied that any decision in the matter had been reached.

There is a unity, coherence, and granitic solidity of fatuousness about the composition that stamp it as the work of one mind -- undoubtedly the mind of Mr. WILLIAMS himself.

This accounts, he thinks, for the pleasure with which we read books about English life and English landscape.

The eighteen silent centuries that that enshrouded the lost life and mystery of Pompeii have at length been made to speak in no uncertain voice. It is almost as though the city had come to live again in all its throbbing existence and color and light -- an illusion made possible through the genius of a German savant, Dr. August Mau.

A contributor to The Author of London tells a harrowing tale of how, on the very morning that an appreciative review of a certain book appeared in The Times, he discovered the writer of the said book frying a red herring for his breakfast. This leads the contributor to ask pathetically. "Can a man live by authorship?" The reply seems easy.

The first large picture auction sale of the season at the American Art Galleries, a display of portraits by A.A. Anderson at the Avery Galleries, and the first of the season's monthly art displays at the Union League and Lotos Clubs, made up the sum total of the week's art events in New York.

Miss Cary has written a fit companion to her admirable book on Tennyson published last year, and the publishers have made it a joy to the eye, in its binding, paper, type, and illustrations.

The early history of bookselling is very interesting reading, both as showing how a business which began in a very humble way -- printer, publisher, and bookseller being united in one man -- has reached its present position; but even more so as indicating the difference in birth and breeding between the booksellers of the past and our present publishers.

Though recent book sales held by Bangs Co. have contained many items of unusual interest, few books of extreme importance have been offered. The collection of J.C. Clegg, sold Dec. 5-7, contained, however, a copy of the first edition (London, 1822,) of De Quincey's "Confessions of an English Opium Eater" in the original boards.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Senator Hanna has leased the Cameron residence on Lafayette Square, formerly occupied by Vice President Hobart.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- To-day the practical completion of the Senate committees for the fifty-sixth Congress was announced officially by Senator Aldrich of Rhode Island. He presented to the Senate an order fixing the committees, and it was adopted without dissent. A few vacancies in the minority representation are yet to be filled.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The War Office has received a dispatch announcing that Gen. Buller yesterday met with a serious reverse, losing eleven guns.

William J. Kinsley, the chief expert in handwriting for the prosecution in the case of Roland B. Molineux, charged with having murdered Mrs. Katherine J. Adams by poison in December last, and on whose testimony the State bases its main hope for the conviction of the prisoner, spent a trying day on the witness stand yesterday under cross-examination by Bartow S. Weeks, the senior counsel for the defense.
Major General Leonard Wood, who has been appointed Military Governor of Cuba, was at the Cambridge Hotel yesterday. To a TIMES reporter he said:

Two citizens well-known in Wall Street will call upon Park Commissioner Clausen this morning to demand of him an explanation why they cannot continue to operate automobiles in the Park upon the strength of permits issued a few days ago by Mr. Clausen himself.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 15. -- Fine golf was witnessed in the open tournament of the Atlantic City Country Club to-day on the links at Northfield. The weather was again delightful, except that a very strong and chilly wind blew across the course, which made heavy wraps desirable.

On coats and gowns a new touch is an applique of fur on lace in big leaf, or ample flower that partially hides the lace. When this treatment is applied, the pattern should be selected with an idea to boldness of design. Sealskin, beaver, and baby lamb lend themselves admirably to this purpose, and the deep ecru or coffee color laces make a charming contrast.

No city in the country is more capable of entertaining the delegates and visitors to the National Republican Convention than Philadelphia. No city ever handled au encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, which always involves a vast concourse of people, more competently than this city.

The English family name of Buller has acquired a special interest by the reflected renown of the Gen. Sir Redvers Buller, now commanding the British army in the Transvaal. There is an American branch of the family which retains many of the dominant traits of character that have given place and power to their relatives in England, and these American Bullers are entirely worthy of their respectable origin.

Mr. Thomas G. Shearman in your Sunday issue asks some questions which he evidently thinks can be answered in but one way, and when so answered completely dispose of the whole Boer question. He asks what would we Americans do under certain conditions. Has it never occurred to him that it is far more important to know what we Americans should do than what we would do?

HAVANA, Dec. 8. -- The word "transport" does not suggest much luxury in the way of ocean travel; on the contrary, one is rather more apt to picture a large flat boat on the lighter plan, with accommodations for none but soldiers, and even those accommodations very scant; their only resting place the hard floor of the deck, with blanket and knapsack for mattress and pillow.

There seems to be some animated discussion in progress among high authorities in insurance circles upon the subject of agents' rebating. Little has been heard from the agents' standpoint, presumably because the ordinary life insurance agent would not be supposed to have any opinions worth considering

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The grave situation confronting Great Britain in South Africa almost obliterates the effect of the speech of the German Minister of Foreign Affairs, Count von Buelow, in the Reichstag, Monday last, though scarcely any announcement of recent years hats had so much bearing on the future of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Representative Sulzer (Dem., N.Y.,) to-day introduced a joint resolution in the House declaring that a state of war exists in South Africa, and according belligerent rights to the Transvaal Government.

Ex-Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason filed a petition in bankruptcy in the United States Court in Brooklyn yesterday. The total amount of his liabilities is given as $226,894.14, while his assets are $8,938.32. Among the liabilities are the following:

Representatives from the various Boards of Education in Hudson County, N.J., met yesterday afternoon in Public School No. 4, Park Avenue and Sixth Street, Hoboken, to consider Senate Bill No. 197, which codifies and revises the school laws of the State and which, it is alleged, both infringes upon the dignity and powers of every Board of Education in the State and is hostile to the best interests of the schools and all the teachers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 16. -- The open golf tournament of the Country Club of Atlantic City was concluded to-day on the Northfield links with Some very interesting playing. The programme consisted of the final rounds for all four cups, and an eighteen-hole handicap and a foursome for members of the same clubs.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- With Government aid, including financial assistance, the projected Commercial Museum may now be regarded as secured for Germany. Consul General Mason regards this as the most important matter in relation to the commercial intercourse of the United States and Germany that has happened for years.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day approved of the increase of stock of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company from $100,000,000 to $115,000,000, the increase to be used for equipment purposes.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- As legislators drop into town, ostensibly to pick out quarters for the Winter, and in reality to ascertain the situation, little information is gleaned as to the coming session of the Legislature. Speaker Nixon of the Assembly was here early in the week to attend State board meetings. He held conferences with Assemblymen Allds and Kelsey and the Governor.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- Chairman Clark of the Police Board lectured the Captains to-day on the sale of cigars on Sunday. He pointed out the law on the matter, which makes such sales illegal. This applies to all large hotels as well as restaurants and tobacco stores, although druggists can sell the cigars as "drugs."

TO THE LADIES of the Rainy Day Club: When I had the honor of addressing you, I supposed it to be just a friendly talk, so it was something of a surprise to find reporters there and extracts from my address in the papers. Their garbled accounts distorted the meaning of my words, which were not intended in a malicious spirit of ridicule, as has been made to appear.

Wall Street has passed through a week of extraordinary incidents. On some days almost panic conditions have ruled; and in the list of net changes for the week only an insignificant number show advances; practically the entire stock list declined; and, virtually, the same statement describes the course of the bond market as well.

It is like evening Cripple Creek claims by the Colorado Springs people or possessing Denver suburban acres in a real estate boom.

The Orphan Asylum deal, it is true, is very much of a special transaction, but having dragged along in various stages of incompletion over a period of two months, it cannot be classed with the business of the last week.

An interesting play must have a subject that can be understood by everybody, sentiment that touches the common heart, "situations" growling out of misunderstandings and equivocations. One character or set of characters must have something to conceal from the others, or at least from one other.

In twenty-five years the number of students in the undergraduate courses of colleges and scientific schools has increased from 573 in each 1,000,000 of population to 1,193. In the eighty-seven colleges for men, for women, and for both men and women in the Middle States and Maryland there were in 1897-8 nearly 17,000 undergraduate students.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- For the third time this week Parisians met hoarse-voiced news venders running along the boulevards to-day shouting "Crushing defeat of the English,'' "Great victory for the Boers," and displaying the front sheets of their papers bearing big headlines -- " The English Routed,"

The set rules and unbreakable laws upon men's dress make the slight diversion that is allowed in bathrobes, room jackets, , ah the more interesting. This season the bath robes are prettier than ever. There is a chocolate shade of eiderdown, reversible with blue, that is particularly good. The edges are bound with brown satin ribbon.

Dr. Webber won the cut-glass decanter that was offered as a prize in the sixth sweepstake event of the Brooklyn Gun Club in the shoot at Union Course, yesterday. The other important winner of the day was Van Allen, who captured the Francotte gun in the fifty-bird race, after a tie with Woods, and also made a strong bid for the free entrance to the Grand American Handicap.

Recent correspondence with my uncle, Franklin Reno of Chicago, who was on the staff of my father, Gen. Reno, during the civil war, has developed some faces apropos of Barbara Frietchie's Union flag which may interest the readers of THE TIMES.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 16. -- After making two unsuccessful attempts to burn schoolhouses in Savannah, some one succeeded at an early hour this morning in destroying the greater portion of the Chatham Academy, the largest school building in the city. A portion of the building was gutted by the flames, and the entire structure drenched by water.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The members of the Republican National Committee were received by President McKinley to-day at the White House. There was no speechmaking, the members of the committee simply passing through the room and shaking hands with the President. After the reception the members of the committee returned to the Arlington Hotel, and assembled in session.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The West India docks were gay this afternoon with about 6,000 prominent people present, including a number of royalties. The occasion of this gathering of celebrities and others was the presentation of the Queen's flag to the American hospital ship Maine. The Duke of Connaught, surrounded by the ladies of the committee, on the poop deck, presented the flag to Lady Randolph Churchill.

The leading editorial on your issue of the 7th inst., headed "The Coming Question," is timely, full of thought, and may well be commended to the attention of thoughtful readers throughout the country. The last sentence therein is full of suggestion, and affords a text for the consideration of the wisest and best legislative and judicial talent of the land.

Spending the closing days of their long lives in Stroudsburg are Mrs. Catherine B. Bowden and Mrs. Lucinda J. Valentine, who, with their sister, Mrs. Phoebe Gainsford of Matamoras, Pike County, Pa., have the great distinction of being the only three sisters living who are daughters of a Revolutionary soldier.

HAS GREAT BRITAIN ACKNOWLEDGED THE SOVEREIGNTY OF THE SOUTH AFRICAN REPUBLICS? -- European diplomatic circles have been thrown into a flutter of excitement by the statement published in the Russian Official Messenger saying that the British Charge d'Affaires in St. Petersburg had officially informed the Russian Government that Great Britain "is in a state of war with the South African Republics."

Polygamy has been becoming extinct in Utah as rapidly as death could remove those involved in it. It is not unreasonable to expect that within a comparatively brief span of years polygamy will become as rare there as it is in New York. And then the real Mormon problem will be as far from solution as ever, unless in the meantime it be solved by the Mormon people themselves.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The news of the defeat of Gen. Buller at Tugela River caused a momentary panic on the Stock Exchange here to-day, where there was intense excitement in all departments. Immediately after the opening jobbers started realizing, and all prices opened from one to six points below the closing prices of yesterday, Consols being down 1 1/4.

Dr. Wilson, the great aurist, gave another of his regular free illustrated lectures last Thursday evening to an interesting and much interested audience at the New York headquarters of the National Association of Physicians and Surgeons, 240 Fifth Avenue.

The return of Mr. Paderewski may be set down as of no small benefit to musical art. The playing of many pianos is weariness to the flesh and of the making of virtuosos there is no end. But behind the virtuoso lies the great art of playing on the piano and the beneficent task of interpreting the music of the masters.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- While Gen. Buller's reverse was an unexpected blow to the public that had pinned its faith to him, it would appear that the original plan of campaign, if adhered to, would have given better results, for the besieged towns have shown themselves quite capable of holding out.

Mr. Thomas G. Shearman in to-day's TIMES puts sundry questions to all sympathizers with the Transvaal and Orange State farmers, and I beg opportunity through the same medium to essay an answer, but only by putting the same questions to Mr. Shearman with a few trifling changes in the terms of them.

Consul Lebert at Ghent calls the State Department's attention to the contemplated sale of the Snock Musical Museum in that city. The collection, which was commenced in 1854, is said to be one of the finest and most important in Europe, containing about 1,145 instruments of 225 kinds, including 40 pianos, dating from the sixteenth century, in addition to the library of many thousand volumes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Frequent discoveries that large amounts of money are due the city under different franchises has spurred Mayor Harrison to a decision that a franchise bookkeeper must be employed by the city, either in the Controller's or Public Works office. A recommendation to this effect will be included in the next appropriation bill when it goes to the City Council.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16. -- William Betsch of 625 South Eighteenth Street and his wife were arraigned on a charge of larceny in the Fourth Precinct Police Court last night. The charge was preferred by the father of Mrs. Betsch, who accused the couple of stealing $153 worth of jewelry from his home. Betsch is twenty years old and his wife three years younger.

BOSTON, Dec. 16, -- Frank O. and Fred F. Squire and their attorneys, with Herman W. Chaplin, the assignee, were busy today upon the affairs of the Squire pork packing concern, the assignment of which was announced yesterday. Very little new information could be gleaned to-day as to the situation.

"Paolo and Francesca," the poetical drama by Stephen Phillips, quotations from which have already appeared in this column, has been published in London. The author has presented the story of the tragedy of the house of Malatesta in its simplest form, without the accessories which various commentators of the sixteenth century have added to the story as told by Dante.

The heroism of Miss Florence Zerega is the cause of her lying dangerously ill in the Waldorf-Astoria, suffering from three fractured ribs, a fractured collarbone, a broken ankle and toe, and severe contusions of the body.

Our London correspondent gives evidence which is cumulative of that which has reached us from other sources of what he calls the "passion of rage, disappointment, and, I might almost say, fear," which has swept over England.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The final arrangements were being made to-day for the vote on the Financial bill in the House on Monday. Mr. Tawney, the Republican "whip" said about 170 out of the 186 Republican members would be present, and those absent would be paired for the bill. It is estimated also that about 150 Democratic would be present.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Gen Buller reports to the War Office that his losses in yesterday's engagement were:

Four alleged burglars were bagged in an early morning hunt by the Brooklyn police yesterday. The prisoners described themselves as Thomas Shanly, forty-five years old, of 79 Bond Street; John Garahy, thirty-one years old, of the same address; Edward McCarthy of 228 Willoughby Street, and Owen Reilly, known as "Mud" Reilly, of 224 Bridge Street.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 16. -- In view of many conflicting stories now published as to wars that are scheduled to come off between iron ore and steelmaking interests, especially since the resignation of H.C. Frick from the Carnegie Steel Company, a few facts may be interesting.

Mr. William T. Evans, Chairman of the Art Committee of the Lotos Club, has arranged for the club's first monthly art exhibition of this season a display of thirty-one landscapes by American artists. These will be on view in the club gallery to-day and to-morrow to members of the club and their men guests, while ladies holding tickets of invitation will be admitted on Monday and Tuesday afternoons.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Dec. 16. -- Thomas A. McWhinney, Postmaster at this place, has preferred charges before Justice Jay against Joseph H. Wheelock and his daughter, Maisie Wheelock, for using offensive and abusive language and interfering with the Postmaster in the discharge of his duties. The Wheelocks reside at Inwood, but have a box in the Lawrence Post Office.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 26. -- To get out of Eastern Kentucky and into the heart of Eastern Tennessee is a matter requiring little expenditure of time. It is but a passing from one side of a ridge of mountains to the other. From Middlesborough, in Bell County, Kentucky, to Knoxville, in Knox County, Tennessee, is but a railroad ride of about two hours.

MANILA, Dec. 16. -- Major Peyton C. March of the Thirty-third Infantry has abandoned his pursuit of Aguinaldo, and has reached Bagnen, in the heart of the Grand Cordilleram, where the range is 10,000 feet high, and food is scarce and travel almost impossible.
NORTH BRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16. -- The Riverdale Woolen Company will advance wages 10 per cent. Jan. 1. About 300 hands are employed and the works are running overtime.
Of Wall Street and business conditions, past and present, and of the outlook for the future, Mr. W.E. Connor says:

Clouds marred the commencement of the eclipse of the moon last night, and for a time it looked as though it would be invisible during the period of greatest interest, but they gradually dissolved as the eclipse progressed, and in doing so lent some beautiful effects to the spectacle. When at its height the eclipse was seen in this city under perfect conditions, as far as the atmosphere was concerned.

"Nome City is the best piece in the world to work for gold," said Arthur Vogt yesterday to several old friends among whom he had distributed a few gold nuggets, and then he added: "I am going back there next April."

Willis L. Moore, Chief of the United States Weather Bureau, has drafted a bill which is now before Congress, and which, if it becomes a law, will tend, he believes, to establish a discipline and efficiency in the personnel of his bureau second to that in no other portion of the Government service.

It is no small record for a war correspondent to pass through seven distinct campaigns of warfare, but when, in addition to this, such a man achieves, meanwhile, numerous specific triumphs as a news-getter and deliverer, then indeed is he entitled to fame. It is such a record and such achievements that have made Archibald Forbes, who is now critically ill in London, perhaps the most notable war correspondent now living.
There is one good work in this city that is entitled to especial consideration at this time, peculiarly consecrated to the happiness of children. It is the Children's Aid Society.

The two victories that the bowlers representing Merck Co. scored in the Wholesale Drug Trade Association tournament yesterday, at Reid's alleys, gave them second place. Dodge Olcott's team also improved its position by winning two games, while the National Lead Company team, by losing two games, dropped from second to fifth place.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- The old volunteer firemen of this place had the laugh on the new paid firemen early this morning, when one of the latter, seeing a quantity of smoke coming out of one of the towers of St. Mary's Church, turned in an alarm. The church was built some years ago, and the architect, in order to hide a big chimney, disguised it by building a tower around it.

Without any desire to have my name added to the list of cranks, kickers, and complainers who are always finding fault with things in general and on general principles, I beg to call your attention to what appears to me an outrage and a total disregard of the rights and comfort of its passengers on behalf of the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 16. -- The position of affairs at Ladysmith continues to excite much anxiety, while the progress of the campaign on the western borders of Cape Colony is being regarded with great interest. Sir George White's little garrison at Ladysmith continues to be invested by the great bulk of the Boer forces.
"It is not against the rules of modern warfare to shoot horses, but it is against all the rules of honorable warfare to calumniate and belle a brave enemy."

SHELBURNE FALLS, Mass., Dec. 16. -- Henry Winterhelder was arrested here today charged with manslaughter, in causing the death of his wife, Lucy, Dec. 5, which followed that of an infant born Nov. 30. The babe lived only a few hours. It is alleged that the death of both mother and child were due to the cruelties of the husband.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 16. -- The series of reverses culminating in the repulse of Gen. Buller at Tugela River, has had a disquieting effect on the soldiers in this garrison. Officers here freely predict that England will call out every available man, and it is thought that Halifax may be left without a regular garrison.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to --

Some ten or fifteen years ago I read an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES advocating the adoption of an ordinance, or law, to compel builders of tall structures in narrow streets to erect these buildings some distance back from the line of the old houses, so that gradually these streets would be widened and become light and broad thoroughfares and not mere gloomy canons, reached by very little light and sunshine.

Charles Threshie, champion of the Boston Athletic Club, won first prize and the championship of Class B in the amateur billiard tournament held under the auspices of the Amateur Athletic Union, by defeating J. De Mun Smith of St. Louis last night in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.

The annual dinner of the First Panel Sheriff's Jury, at the Hotel Savoy last night, was one of the most elaborate and jovial affairs of the kind held so far this season. The banquet of 250 covers was spread in the ballroom, which had been profusely decorated with palms. The table decorations were pink and crimson roses, and the dais, in addition, was decked with broad crimson ribbons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The assembling of the Republican National Committee, the celebration of the anniversary of the death of Washington, the proceedings before The special House committee to get rid of Representative B.H. Roberts, and the announcement of the make-up of the Senate committees have been the events of the week here, which incidentally brought out Senator Depew in two speeches not made in the Senate.

"Al" Copeland, who had charge of the training of the Yale track and field athletic teams last Spring has been officially notified that the Yale Athletic Club has secured a new trainer. At the same time it is learned that "Mike" Murphy will resume his duties as trainer at Yale at the expiration of his contract with the University of Pennsylvania, next June.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 16. -- Prosperity, long absent, has returned to the shipyards of Maine, and there is rejoicing all along the shore. For some years past the new tonnage figures have been so small as to be scarcely worth publishing, but now the showing is encouraging, and the prospect is bright.

Those sad men who make mental pathology the subject of life study have given some attention to the phenomenon of imitative or suggested action among men in crowds, where an idea possessing a few minds spreads throughout the mass until it possesses all minds, quite independent of any conscious exercise of the reasoning faculty.

The police of the West Twentieth Street Station have in their custody a man for whom they have been looking for several months. He described himself last evening when arrested as George Grant, fifty years old, but refused to give his address claiming that his wife was sick and that he did not want her to know that he had been arrested.

Christmas shopping has set in earlier than ever this year, say the merchants, and a stroll about the shopping districts will readily verify the truth of their assertions. Shops have been overrun during the past week, and the strain of the unusual work has already begun to tell on the clerks who have to cater to the wants of the traders and sightseers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- A dispatch from Toledo says the Ann Arbor Railroad will put wireless telegraphy to practical test by introducing it in connection with the car ferry business across Lake Michigan. The contract with the Marconi people has been closed, and the system will be introduced at once.
Every one must serve his time at every trade Save censure; critics alone are ready-made.

PARIS, Dec. 1. -- The great sensation today is the news conveyed in Mr. Chamberlain's speech of an Anglo-German alliance. It is not too much to say that this has shattered the fondest dreams of ninety-nine French politicians out of a hundred, and that henceforward the scheme of a Russo-French and German alliance directed against Great Britain must be abandoned, probably for all time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- This city, which ever since the World's Fair has been the meeting place of conventions of the liberal religions, saw another gathering of that kind this week in Sinai Temple. Dr. Thomas of the People's Church, presided, and by his side sat Rabbi Hirsch, Dr. Joseph Stolz, the Rev. Jenkin Lloyd Jones, the Rev. Galusha Anderson, and many others.

Dennis O'Brien of 384 Eighth Avenue, Manhattan, early yesterday morning smashed a plate glass window valued at $100 in Otto Oetinger's drug store at 61 South Eighth Street, Brooklyn, in order that he should be arrested. He is twenty-nine years old, and has been out of work for several months.

It seems to me that a striking feature of the polities of the day (I am speaking more particularly of local as distinguished from National polities) is the absence of co-operation between the practical and the theoretical politicians -- between those who practice without theorizing and those who theorize without practicing.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Dec. 16. -Stephen D. Brundage, a young man in the last stages of consumption, pleaded guilty to-day to the charge of highway robbery in Judge Rogers's court, and was held to await the action of the Grand Jury. The prisoner stole to provide food for himself and family.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- As a result of the failure of the John P. Squire Company, pork packers of Cambridge, for $3,000,000, which was announced late yesterday afternoon, the Broadway National Bank of this city, in which the Squires were largerly interested, did not open its doors to-day, and a notice at the entrance announced that the affairs of the bank were in the hands of the Controller of the Currency.

Continental bicycle racing stock experienced an awful slump last night at Madison Square Garden, when in the presence of 2,000 persons three foreign champions went down before the superior prowess of American bicycle cracks.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- It is still the war with us, and nothing but the war. Three defeats in one week have fairly upset our equanimity, and the population of London is becoming excited to a degree that has rarely been witnessed.

ROME, Nov. 28. -- The management of the Costanzi Theatre here has already published the programme for the second series of opera to be given at the well-known theatre during January and February. The series is to be opened with the premiere of Maestro Puccini's anxiously awaited "La Tosca," fixed for Jan. 4.

You have published a letter from Thomas G. Shearman asking Boer sympathizers to answer certain questions. Permit me the pleasure of answering them. I will put my answers in the same shape that he has used for his questions but my answers shall contain the facts without concealment or perversion so far as I know them and with a fairness which seems to me to be somewhat wanting in some of his.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. William H. Veeder, attorney for Swift Co. of Chicago, is authority for the statement that the firm will not buy the plant of J.P. Squire Co., the bankrupt pork packers of Boston. Mr. Veeder says the firm never contemplated such a deal.

Undoubtedly there is something very gallant and chivalric, and thus attractive, about the character of the German Emperor. The resemblance which has been found by psychological inquirers between him and the present Governor of New York is more than merely fanciful. We can fancy "Governor WILHELM" doing most of the things that Governor ROOSEVELT has been doing and "Kaiser TEDDY" doing most of the things that Kaiser WILHELM has been doing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. William H. Veeder, attorney for Swift Co. of Chicago, is authority for the statement that the firm will not buy the plant of J.P. Squire Co., the bankrupt pork packers of Boston. Mr. Veeder says the firm never contemplated such a deal.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- At the centennial celebration by the citizens of Albany of the birth of Prof. Joseph Henry, LL. D., held here to-night under the auspices of the Albany Institute and the Albany Historical and Art Society, President Verplanck Colvin of the institute read a letter from President McKinley, attesting the good work done by Prof. Henry in developing magnetic telegraphy.

As a sort of offset to the proposed Cape to Cairo railway project of the English, the French people are now agitating for a trans-Saharan line, which shall enable them to reach the hinterland of their possessions in Southwestern Africa, and the rich Lake Tchad region.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Nicholas Davis of Kentucky, a member of Troop B, Third Cavalry, stationed at Fort Myer, Va., who had been drinking heavily, armed with a Krag-Jorgensen rifle and several hundred rounds of ammunition, barricaded himself in an upper room of the company quarters yesterday.

The writer, by request of the representatives of thousands of "loyal Irish" scattered over America, would ask you to give space in your columns for a brief reply to a letter which recently appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "An Appeal to Irish Hearts," over the signature of Caroline Arnott, 68 Merrion Square, Dublin, Ireland.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16. -- Mayor Hayes, in the six weeks he has been in office, has shown the politicians, the other city officers, business men, and the officials of properties in which the city is interested that he is the whole administration and that he proposes to run the city according to his own ideas.

Justice Werner, presiding in the Extraordinary Term of the Supreme Court, called by Gov. Roosevelt to try election cases, adjourned all the trials of men who have been indicted for violation of the election laws yesterday for the purpose of hearing the summing up of the case of Logan against the Brooklyn Gas syndicate, the evidence in which was heard by him before the election trials began.

For reasons that may be partly political the Bank of France does not thus far seem disposed to come to the rescue of the Bank of England in its time of financial need by offering to loan from its own abundant supply of gold to that institution. At the time of the Baring failure, in 1890, it showed a more accommodating spirit and sent 3,000,000 to London to relieve the stress.
BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- The German press and people are jubilant over the news from South Africa, and everywhere in the streets people stop each other and offer congratulations.

"Why does New York City keep a flock of sheep in Central Park?" is a by no means unusual query that one who frequents the Park may hear, particularly if he is addicted to the habit of sitting on the benches near the South Meadow, where the sheep most frequently feed, or if he takes a ride about the drives in the carryals.

Bishop Chatard, speaking of his long absence from home, (he left here on the third day of April, and returned on Dec. 9.) talks interestingly of his sojourn at various points on the Atlantic coast, in this country, and of his tour in Europe. "From this country," said the Bishop. "I went to London, where I stayed a few days and saw a number of friends.

From a real estate point of view the past year has been a remarkable one in the Borough of the Bronx. Building operations show an increase of one-third over those of 1898, and values have taken fabulous jumps. Single lots have been sold for $20,000, a figure that a couple of years ago would have been considered a ridiculous valuation even by the most audacious boomer.

The second piano recital by the famous Polish pianist, Mr. I.J. Paderewski, took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The audience was considerably larger than that which attended the first recital by the same artist, on Tuesday last. The assembly represented in money about $6,500, which is about $1,000 more than the amount of the receipts at the first recital.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 16. -- The American Federation of Labor this afternoon registered emphatic disapproval of Government subsidies to American ship owners, and later declared almost unanimously against the principle and practice of subsidy legislation. Federal officeholders and others who had been lobbying to obtain an indorsement of the Frye Subsidy bill suffered a decided defeat.

August Belmont, it was announced at the offices of the Citizens' Committee to Perpetuate the Dewey Arch yesterday, has promised $5,000 to the fund. Many large subscriptions were received in the course of the week just ended, amounting in all to nearly $30,000.

From a real estate point of view the past year has been a remarkable one in the Borough of the Bronx. Building operations show an increase of one-third over those of 1898, and values have taken fabulous jumps. Single lots have been sold for $20,000, a figure that a couple of years ago would have been considered a ridiculous valuation even by the most audacious boomer.

The second piano recital by the famous Polish pianist, Mr. I.J. Paderewski, took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The audience was considerably larger than that which attended the first recital by the same artist, on Tuesday last. The assembly represented in money about $6,500, which is about $1,000 more than the amount of the receipts at the first recital.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 16. -- The American Federation of Labor this afternoon registered emphatic disapproval of Government subsidies to American ship owners, and later declared almost unanimously against the principle and practice of subsidy legislation. Federal officeholders and others who had been lobbying to obtain an indorsement of the Frye Subsidy bill suffered a decided defeat.
BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- The Post will say to-morrow:

A stranger in town who might have wandered into 300 Mulberry Street just after dark last night would never have believed he was in the famous Police Headquarters of the metropolis. The few men in uniform and their listless manner were more in keeping with some small station.

An unusually large congregation gathered in the Second Collegiate Reformed Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and Lenox Avenue, yesterday morning. Many persons not members of the church were present, attracted by the publication of articles regarding the expected resignation of the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William Justin Harsha.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- M. Routkowsky, the agent of the Ministry of Finances of Russia, in Washington, in a communication which has received the approval of the Russian Ambassador, complains of the attempts which he says were made in Europe recently to create in this country the impression that the relations between the Governments of Japan and Russia were strained.

DUBLIN, Dec. 17. -- The announcement that a pro-Boer meeting would be convened to-day as a protest against the proposal of Trinity College to confer a degree upon Joseph Chamberlain led to exciting scenes. A large force of police was called out, and the troops were held in readiness.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 17. -- In an interview to-day John Skelton Williams, President of the Seaboard Air Line, gave a resume of the opposition of Thomas F. Ryan to the consolidation into the Greater Seaboard Company of the various Southern railways. Among other things, Mr. Williams said:

As a result of the cutting down by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment of the allowance made by the city to the New York Free Circulating Library, a notice was conspicuously posted yesterday in all of the eleven branches throughout the city of the library that they would be closed on Sundays.

The security market has reached the point where it is sensitive enough to respond to good news almost as quickly as to bad. Liquidation has been thoroughgoing. Weak accounts have been slaughtered by wholesale. People with thin margins are not being permitted to carry lines of stocks.
Let no American imagine for an instant that this Nation or the cause of civilization will be the gainer by the disasters to the British forces in South Africa.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 17. -- Three persons were burned here late this afternoon by the explosion of gases in a cellar. The injured are Mrs. William Chamberlain of East Third Street, her daughter Lottie, fifteen years of age, and Joseph Stevens, a man employed by Mr. Chamberlain.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- The police of this city to-day began the enforcement of the law forbidding any dealer to sell goods on a Sunday. The Christian Endeavor Societies have been stirring up trouble here for some time and have caused the saloon keepers much trouble.

The Rev. Dr. George T. Purves, Professor of New Testament Literature and Greek Exegesis in Princeton Theological Seminary and pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Princeton, will be the new pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church of this city, to succeed the late Rev. Dr. John Hall.
The retirement of Adjt. Gen. ANDREW'S is a cause for sincere regret to all who have an interest in the militia service of the State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The two events of importance in the House this week before the adjournment for the holiday recess on Wednesday will be the vote on the Currency bill to-morrow immediately after the reading of the Journal and the announcement of the committees on Tuesday.

Col. Elias Gonzalez Esteves, the newly appointed Venezuelan Consul General at New York, arrived on the Red D line steamer Philadelphia yesterday. He received his appointment from Cipriano Castro, Provisional President of Venezuela. Col. Gonzalez is a brother-in-law of the Venezuelan Minister of the Exterior, Gen. Andueza Palacio, and has previously held several minor positions under the new Government.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- The Rev. Dr. Purves, whose proposed departure from this place to accept the pastorate of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church has aroused general opposition here, spoke at the chapel exercises this morning, but made no reference to the question of his call to New York.

Senator T.C. Platt, leader of the Republican State organization, had a long talk yesterday morning with S Frederick Nixon of Chautauqua, who will again be Speaker of the Assembly, and B.B. Odell, Jr., Chairman of the Republican State Committee, who represents Mr. Platt while the latter is in Washington.
WILLETS POINT, L.I., Dec. 17. -- Through an order of the War Department Jack, the old army mule, known to every visitor at the army post here for some years, was executed yesterday.

While it was in his official capacity that Randolph Guggenheimer, President of the Municipal Council, appeared at the meeting of the Household Economic Association to make an address a few days ago, he takes something more than a superficial interest in such matters, for he has made cooking a sort of hobby.

PONCE, Puerto Rico, Dec. 11. -- Now that Congress is in session Puerto Rico feels more than ever the high cable rates she is compelled to pay. The newspapers are able to furnish only meagre cablegrams, and many persons strongly advocate an appropriation from some source by which the Government for a few thousand dollars a year would supply free to the newspapers several thousand words of general news each day.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- The Chronicle to- morrow will say:

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 17. -- Forger James H. Morton, alias Rogers, alias Hall, en route from Boston to Sioux City with his wife and Sheriff Davenport of Woodbury County, jumped from an Illinois Central train west of Dubuque last night and is a fugitive.

PHOENIX, Arizona, Dec. 17. -- A performance by the "Three Musketeers" Company at the Patton Grand here late last night came to an abrupt ending. The Opera House was packed when some unexpected shooting in the fourth act caused a stampede.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Chicagoans here are still busy explaining why they did not get the Republican Convention. The Chicago delegation came here expecting that the convention would be thrown at their heads, and they have not yet recovered from the shock they received when it went to Philadelphia. The French cry, "We are betrayed," has been raised, and Chicago is looking for a victim.

The friends of Mr. BRYAN submit to the American people a Philippine policy which deserve a candid examination. Mr. BRYAN might be wrong about silver, but right about the Philippines. In large transactions the safe way is to hear both sides, to consider the matter as a whole and try to determine which is the wiser way.

The presence of an unusual factor in the defense of Natal has aroused much important discussion among British naval officers and strategists at home. The unusual factor is the navy -- the introduction of naval officers, seamen, and naval armaments in warfare carried on several hundred miles inland.

Adjt. Gen. Avery D. Andrews has sent in his resignation to Gov. Roosevelt, giving as his reason that he is too much occupied with business to attend to military affairs. Among his intimate friends it is known that he wished to take this step some time ago, but remained in office to assist in the re-establishment of the National Guard after the Spanish war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Lieut. Thomas M. Brumby, Flag Lieutenant to Admiral Dewey during the Manila campaign, who has bean ill with typhoid fever for several weeks, died at Garfield Hospital shortly after 6 o'clock this evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Lieut. Thomas M. Brumby, Flag Lieutenant to Admiral Dewey during the Manila campaign, who has bean ill with typhoid fever for several weeks, died at Garfield Hospital shortly after 6 o'clock this evening.

An end has apparently been put to the discord among English Catholics in their attitude toward Cardinal Gibbons, who has been asked by Cardinal Vaughan to deliver the sermon at the dedication next year of the new cathedral at Westminster, by the Baltimore prelate's explanatory letter published in the last issue of The London Tablet.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 17. -- Edmund Morris, General Inspector of the Ontario Bank, and widely known in banking circles, died suddenly of heart failure this afternoon. His son is an officer in Gen. Buller's army in South Africa, and Mr. Morris was attacked shortly after reading the latest war bulletins posted at the newspaper offices.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 17. -- Hongkong mail advices state another Franco-Chinese war is imminent over the delimitation of French "leased" territory at Kuang Chou Bay, on the Tonkin border. This dispute is of several months' standing, the French having demanded thrice the amount of territory which China is willing to concede under France's original demand for an open port there under French domination.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Soon before midnight the following notice was posted at the War Office:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- After becoming engaged to one girl, falling in love with another, renouncing his first attachment, and attempting to commit suicide as the easiest way to solve the snarl in which cupid had involved his affections, the Rev. George Alien of Milton has essayed another venture in the direction of matrimony.

Fire started in some sudden manner at 12:40 o'clock this morning in the big factory building 655 and 657 First Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets. The flames spread with such rapidity that the firemen, fearing the destruction of many of the tenements which crowd upon the factory on all sides, hurriedly sent out additional alarms.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Lieut. the Hon. F.H.S. Roberts, son of Baron Roberts of Kandahar and Waterford, who was wounded in the engagement at Tugela River, is dead. Such was his display of gallantry on Friday in an attempt to rescue the guns that he was recommended for the Victoria Cross.

Liquidation that brought such large declines the week before last was continued during the week just ended, and resulted in further considerable net losses. Declines of 1 point or more were recorded in a number of the more active stocks, while in some cases the week's recession in price amounted to 3, and, in a few cases, to even 5, points.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 17. -- Senator Horace White said to-night that he proposed to principally devote his attention, during the coming session of the State Legislature, to the passage of an educational measure in conformity with the report of the commission in the matter of unification of the educational departments of the State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- There is some disquietude among the friends of Matthew Stanley Quay to-night in consequence of the persistency of the report that Gov. Stone, who appointed him to be Senator, is to convene the Legislature of Pennsylvania in extra session to endeavor to elect a Senator.

The conditions that enable the United States markets to send gold to England in the present crisis were very clearly set forth in our financial columns yesterday by our special contributor "A.K.F." Practically the process is one of lending for the sake of the higher return that the needs of England justify.

The police of the Eldridge Street Station would like to find a certain second-hand clothing dealer in Eldridge Street, who once thought he knew something about horses. After being "done" in a horse trade the man wandered into the police station Saturday night, and, with much emotion, asked to have some one come and kill his purchase, as it was not fit to live.

The big sidewheel steamer Plymouth of the Fall River Line, one of the largest vessels of her type in the world, went ashore on a reef on the north side of Riker's Island at 8:30 o'clock last night. She had about 600 passengers aboard at the time A hole about five feet in diameter was stove in the boat wel forward and she made water rapidly.

ROME, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- The Coroner's inquest in the case of Mrs. M.M. Davis, who died under Christian Science treatment, was continued this evening. Dr. W.B. Reid, who made the autopsy, said he examined for strychnine or arsenic, but found none in the stomach. There was a strong alcoholic odor present.

The contest over the will of Christine Ehminne, which was tried before Surrogate Arnold, was decided by Surrogate Varnum yesterday adversely to the proponents. The will offered for probate was claimed to have been made by Mrs. Ehminne on the 24th of April, 1896. She was a German woman, seventy years old, comparatively ignorant, and without known relatives.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18. -- Henry C. Payne of Wisconsin, speaking to-night of the Vice Presidency, said:

The sloop Ida Belle Lowndes, owned by Capt. Thomas Madge of Greenwich, Conn., will leave to-day for Cuba with her owner and a crew of two men. The sail will be both for pleasure and business, including a cruise for some weeks off the south coast of the island.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18. -- It was officially announced to-night that the plan of pensioning aged employes by the Pennsylvania Railroad will be put into effect next January. There will be 950 employes retired and pensioned on that date. Thereafter all officers and employes not yet seventy years of age will be retired and pensioned on the first day of the month following their attainment of that age.

P.A.B. Widener's gift to Philadelphia of an industrial home for crippled children is to be duplicated in a measure by an industrial school for girls, to be presented to the city by James M. Munyon. The institution will be built on the rolling land between the Old Lancaster Road and George's Hill, Fairmount Park, near the "Towers," Mr. Munyon's home.

It was said yesterday that Stephen H. Olin, a well-known lawyer, stood the best chance of being appointed to succeed Avery D. Andrews as Adjutant General of the New York National Guard. Mr. Olin is now Assistant Adjutant General at division headquarters in this city. He is the son of the Rev. Dr. Stephen Olin, who was one of the leading educators of his generation in the United States.

Martin D. Knapp of 2,961 Seventh Avenue, on the night of Dec. 10, while riding in an electric car, had a valuable diamond horseshoe pin stolen by men who were standing near him on the platform of the car, at One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue. He did not report the loss to the police, but put an advertisement in a newspaper.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- "If Great Britain is ultimately successful in South Africa, the powers of the world will unite to resist her advance. A coalition will be formed against British domination, and when this war of the nations comes, which side will the United States take? We must take one side or the other.

The press of the Continental countries and the street crowds of their capitals openly rejoice at the reverses England has suffered in South Africa. Their sympathies are not with her. They pray for the triumph of the Boers. They want to see England humbled and her great influence in European politics diminished.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Mr. Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) called up his resolution (to prohibit combinations between corporations to control inter-State commerce and transportation and addressed the Senate upon it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- What the Senate may accomplish in the way of legislation for the Philippines during the present session is problematical, but that the question will be thoroughly discussed is indicated by the number of resolutions bearing upon it being introduced.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Consols were flat today because a large new issue is said to be in contemplation by the Government to pay the extraordinary expenses of the South African war, for which sufficient provision was not made in the estimates. Something of the kind is probable, but the tale is not confirmed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- After the passage to-day by the House of the Financial bill, the Silver Republican leaders in the city held a meeting and adopted an address setting forth their views as to its effect. The address is as follows:
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Bernard Quaritch, the famous art dealer and vendor of rare books, died yesterday in his eighty-second year. He had a world-wide reputation among bibliophiles.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Gen. Lord Roberts and his staff will sail for South Africa on the Dunottar Castle Saturday.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 18. -- "One-half of the reserve funds of Cincinnati banks have been loaned in the New York markets," said a Director in three banks to-day, "and at 7 and 8 per cent interest. This shows the city's prosperous condition. Money here ranges from 4 to 6 per cent."

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 18. -- By a majority of from 2,800 to 3,200, June Gayle (Silver Democrat) was elected to-day to Congress from the Seventh District, to succeed the late Evan Settle. The election passed off without incident in the eight counties composing the district, and the vote fell about 33 per cent. short of the usual totals. In no county was any particular interest taken in the election.

The excitement, amounting for the time to panic, on the Stock Exchange yesterday was due primarily to the collapse of a new trust company which broke under the burden of speculative securities that it had not succeeded in unloading. The collapse came at a moment when speculation on the Exchange had for some little time been difficult and precarious, and when the minds of the habitus were strained and nervous.

The sixth week of the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder a year ago of Katherine J. Adams by poison opened yesterday before Recorder Goff, in the Court of General Sessions, with William J. Kinsley, the chief handwriting expert of the prosecution, on the stand under cross-examination by Bartow S. Weeks, the senior counsel for the defense.

Doubtless it will not be very long before Bishop POTTER expands and develops, for the benefit of his countrymen, the observations which he has permitted to be summarized for The Herald. There could be no more competent observer, and none whose remarks upon the political and social and commercial problems which confront us there could be more illuminating.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Currency bill was passed to-day by the House by a vote of 190 to 150. It had the support of every Republican in the House and of eleven Democrats -- Messrs. Clayton, Driggs, Fitzgerald, Levy, Ruppert Scudder. Underhill and Wilson of New York; Mr. McAleer of Pennsylvania, Denny of Maryland, and Mr. Thayer of Massachusets.
