WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Speaker Henderson to-day announced the committees of the House of Representatives. It proved to have very few surprises, as the Speaker preserved the time-honored custom of following precedent as to old members, leaving them in their old Chairmanships and places, and gradually advancing them as vacancies occur.

-- After negotiations extending over some two years, the Massachusetts State Society United States Daughters of 1812 has secured the probably effectual assistance of Secretary LONG in obtaining from Congress permission to rebuild the old frigate Constitution, now tied up in the Charlestown Navy Yard.

Every housewife in Brooklyn might have envied Mrs. Paul Fritzmeyer the possession of Mary Coffey as a servant yesterday. Mary Coffey is declared to be a model in the discharge of her duties, and yesterday morning she proved that she is also able to fill the role of protector of her employer's home in the absence of the man of the house.

HAVANA, Dec. 18. -- This morning a gang of fourteen gravediggers, superintended by Chaplain Chidwick and Dr. Macour, began the exhumation in Colon Cemetery of the remains of the victims of the Maine. After clearing away the tops of the mounds from a majority of the graves, the men set to work at 7 o'clock to open up the first three, which contained twenty coffins.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Edgar F. Bailey of 11 Watson Avenue, a member of the firm of Bailey Alling, Newark lumber dealers, was shot by a burglar in the early hours of this morning, when he surprised the burglar in his dining room, where the man was gathering up sliver plate and other articles of value.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 18. -- The Supreme Court declared invalid the act to license commission merchants. The cases were appealed from the Criminal Court of Cook County, where judgments were obtained against Edward C. Reichwald, William G. Reichwald, and Charles W. Losser, indicted for receiving and soliciting certain prints without securing a license.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18. -- The Charles A. Vogeler Company, druggists, consisting of Christian Devries and his wife, formerly Mrs. Minnie A. Vogeler, have made a general assignment for the benefit of their creditors. Henry S. Dulaney, who has been for many years the general manager of the concern, is the assignee.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Throughout the country volunteers are responding with the utmost alacrity to the official notices. Lord Lonsdale says he believes the Government will only accept from twenty to fifty men from each yeomanry regiment. It is asserted that many officers of the volunteer regiments are offering to go as troopers, if not accepted as officers.

Much the worst panic that Wall Street has seen since the memorable crash of 1893, commonly known as the "Cordage Smash," came upon the Street yesterday, and when the day was over market values had declined millions upon millions of dollars, men who but a few hours before had counted their money by the thousands were ruined, and gloom was everywhere.

The Methodist preachers' meeting at 150 Fifth Avenue yesterday adoputed vigorous resolutions against prizefighting. The subject was discussed some weeks ago, and yesterday the resolutions submitted by a special committee were adopted unanimously without debate. The committee was composed of the Rev. Drs. William H. Lawrence, John Rhey Thompson, and J.W. Campbell.

A fire at which one person was seriously hurt, four persons slightly injured, and several heroic rescues were made by police and firemen, occurred in Hoboken early yesterday morning. The burned building was 118 Jefferson Street, a double four-story brick tenement house, occupied by seven families, aggregating thirty-five persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Among the members of the House from some of the States there is mourning over the committees as appointed, in consequence of the losses suffered in Chairmen and in places. A comparison of the appointments with those for the Fifty-fifth Congress ought not to be made without explanation, as the explanation accounts for the differences of which complaint is made.

The heaviest fog that has visited New York and vicinity thus far this Winter hung over the landscape yesterday like a great yellowish blanket. It acted as a serious deterrent to rapid or any other kind of transit. Under its all-pervading and depressing influence every living thing was made more or less anxious and unhappy, except a few London tourists, and even their comfort was marred somewhat by envy and homesickness.

The Rev. Arthur Ritchie, rector of the Church of St. Ignatius, West Fortieth Street, was seized with a sudden attack of illness while preaching in his church on Sunday evening, and was obliged to discontinue his sermon.

A change in the organization of the Doubleday McClure Company, which is in effect a dissolution of partnership between Messrs. Doubleday McClure, will take place early in January. It is understood, however, that Mr. McClure, although retiring as an active partner, may still retain a small interest in the stock of the company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Navy Department has concluded that it has not the means of converting into a receiving ship the captured Spanish cruiser Reina Cristina. Therefore the vessel will be allowed to remain at Norfolk, for the present at least.

WILLETS POINT, L.I., Dec. 19. -- Many surveyors from Brooklyn and others interested in the study of topography have visited the Government post at this place the last few days to inspect the new orograph, which is now being put in readiness by the Engineer Corps of the United States Army, for use in Cuba.

The lodgers in Sidney G. Poole's residence at 109 East Twenty-sixth Street breathed a sigh of relief yesterday when it became known that Justice Giegerich of the Supreme Court had handed down a decision granting a perpetual injunction forbidding Mrs. Poole to collect any more rents from the lodgers, the court deciding thereby that Mr. Poole is the master of the house.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19. -- The transport City of Rio de Janeiro has arrived from Manila with several officers on leave and a number of sick and discharged soldiers. Patrick Fleary, Thirty-fifth Infantry, died on the outward voyage, and the following soldiers, invalided home, died on the way from Manila:

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 19. -- The Echo fence war is settled, Ansel Smith, who for two years has defied the Commissioners of Highways, having removed the fence he placed in the highway because he claimed the land belonged to him. A week ago the Commissioners of Highways removed the fence by force, but when they departed the posts were replaced.

There is a pretty political kettle of fish in Rensselaer County, the home of ex-Gov. Frank S. Black. Senator Thomas C. Platt, according to people in that part of the State, is accountable for the trouble.

APIA, Samoa, Dec. 13, (via Auckland, N.Z., Dec. 19.) -- The German flag was hoisted over the Court House to-day as an official notification of the annexation of the islands, by agreement, to Germany. The German Consul, on board the Cormoran, was interviewed by the Samoan chiefs. He replied that the Samoans could have their own King and chiefs. They then informed the Consul that Mataafa would be selected.

Yesterday was not a cheerful day for the members of the gay world, who were obliged perforce, now that they are in harness, to go from one house to another all the afternoon and evening in the heavy rain so as to make an appearance at the receptions, dinners, dances, and musicales which made up the sum total of the day's doings.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Shaves are a necessity, according to Recorder George B. Senoir, who this morning handed down his decision in reference to the Barbers' Union and its Sunday closing movement. The Judge dismissed every complaint lodged by the union against those barbers who refused to close on Sundays in face of the fact that they were threatened with arrest.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 19. -- A movement has been started in this city by the Order of the Sons of St. George to raise a fund for the widows and orphans of the British soldiers killed in the Transvaal, and is meeting with a promising response from the various lodges throughout the country. In Camden and Philadelphia contributions amounting to over $500 have been made, with several lodges yet to be heard from.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- In the House to-day Mr. Payne, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, presented the resolution for the distribution of the President's message to the various committees having jurisdiction.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Special reports regarding the fighting at Tugela River are still filtering through, but all the newspapers complain that these are severely censored, and it is still impossible to get an accurate idea of the battle. From the latest accounts, however, it appears that Gen. Buller was in personal command.

Gen. Horatio C. King addressed the members of the National Civic Club of Brooklyn last evening on "Patriotism vs. Partisanship." His speech, which as in the nature of an answer to addresses made by Foward M. Shepard and others before the club, was a caustic review of the Chicago platform, and of the attitude of those who espouse the cause of the Filipinos.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Spanish Government has undertaken to continue the payments which it was pledged to make under the treaty of 1834, and the State Department has been notified that the Government at Madrid has drawn two drafts for the payment of the interest due on what are known as the "perpetual rentes of 1834."

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Attorney General Davies to-day made his decision in the case of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association, in which he says he is powerless to take action against the corporation unless facts stated in the report of the Superintendent of Insurance warrant such action. In forwarding the decision to Mr. Payn, Mr. Davies says:
HAVANA, Dec. 19. -- Gen. Brooke will issue to-morrow the following proclamation:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 19. -- Ex-Controller J.H. Eckels is here to-day in attendance upon the annual banquet of the Kansas City Commercial Clulb, which he addressed to-night on the subject, "Banking and Currency." Concerning the flurry in Wall Street he said:

The saving of time which will result from the statute enacted in 1896 which provides for the appointment of a special Jury Commissioner for the weeding out of undesirable talesmen was strikingly shown yesterday afternoon in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. A jury is being selected there to try William Neufeld, who is accused of having murdered Mrs. Annie Kronman on August 7.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- First Assistant Postmaster General Heath said to-day that his much-talked-of order against the retention of Post Office employes who marry was a necessary step in the public interest, though it had been spoken of as if it were an attack upon married women. The impossibility of retaining clerks who marry each other, Mr. Heath said, was due to the peculiar unreasonableness of brides and bridegrooms.

Wall Street had a comparatively quiet and easy day yesterday. After the storm of Monday came the calm, and with that calm a better and more reasoning spirit. Prices, which on the day previous had gone tumbling down, became more stable, and grew steadier with each passing hour, with the result that when the day was closed many of the stocks had scored substantial gains and a generally better feeling was manifest everywhere.

The Kneisel Quartet is always sure of a hearty welcome when it comes to town in these days, and therefore it was to be expected that its concert a Mendelssohn Hall last night would be attended by a large audience. The programme introduced to this public two novelties, a terzetto for two violins and viola, by Antonin Dvorak, and a piano quartet by Richard Strauss.

The heavy fog of Monday night was particularly severe on the fireboat service of the Fire Department. During the middle of the night and early morning several alarms were received for river front fires. The fireboats Zophar Mills and R.A. Van Wyck, which lay in the North River, found that it was impossible for them to leave their berths.

MANILA, Nov. 21. -- Belated mail reports have reached Manila of an expedition on the Island of Cebu last month by a small force of American soldiers of the Sixth Infantry, which was repulsed by insurgents mainly through the desertion of native allies upon whom the Americans depended. Two of the Americans were killed and two wounded, and in the force of native police accompanying them one was killed and four wounded.

LOSS OF PREMIUM OF TRUST INVESTMENT. -- The late Jesse Hoyt directed his executors to invest $1,250,000 for the use and benefit of his daughter, Mary Irene Hoyt, and to apply the income "to her use, for and during her natural life, in the most bounteous and liberal manner as to expenditure, and so as to promote her convenience and comfort and gratify her reasonable desires."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 19. -- The passengers on the Missouri Pacific's Omaha and Nebraska City passenger train, which left here at 9:15 o'clock to-night were robbed by two masked men, who boarded the train in Kansas City, Kan.

Although the Committee on Bridges and Tunnels of the Board of Aldermen had decided to report favorably on Mayor Van Wyck's plan for two new bridges over the East River, Alfred R. Conkling, representing a number of heavy taxpayers in this borough, succeeded yesterday in convincing the board that the subject was important enough to make another hearing necessary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- For expediency the Payne plan of reapportioning delegates to the Republican National Convention was not voted on at the recent meeting of the committee, but there are indications that the project to restrict representation in Congress will be taken up with the view of limiting the strength of a State's representation to the actual number of voters reported as participating in Congressional elections.

MERIDEN, Conn., Dec. 19. -- The Aeolian Company of this city has practically completed its plans for the concentration of its newly acquired properties at Garwood, N.J., on the line of the New Jersey Central. The Aeolian Company has absorbed the Votey Company of Detroit, Mich., and the Vocalion Company of Worcester, Mass., thus securing entire control of the self-playing musical instruments as well as of the perforated sheet music industries in the country.

MANILA, Dec. 19. -- Major Gen. Henry W. Lawton has been shot and killed. The bullet that ended his life struck him in the breast as he was standing before his troops at San Mateo. His heart was pierced by the ball and death was almost instantaneous.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 19. -- From a trustworthy source it was learned to-day that two companies of Montana volunteers who came back from Manila on the transport Zealandia brought with them $150,000 in gold and Mexican silver.

Three points stand out in the various views expressed as to the disturbance in Wall Street on Monday. These are: The relation of the Government to the local money market and the degree to which the Treasury can and ought to come to the relief of the market: the speculation in "industrials," with its effect on general business; the relation of the currency system to business.

But for himself Mr. RUSSELL A. ALGER would be regarded by his countrymen with a relief not readily to be distinguished from admiration. When anything occurs to bring him to their minds their amiable impulse is to say: "Oh, what does it matter? He did get out, didn't he? Let the man alone."

No, the money question is not quite dead, but the symptoms of its impending dissolution are so numerous and alarming that public interest in it has narrowed down to the revelations of the autopsy and the ceremonies of the funeral. It is true that the Republican Party will make the next campaign "an open fight for gold monometallism."

Burglaries, highwaymen, and other types of robbers are having a merry time of it in Brooklyn these days. Within the past week numerous unusually bold robberies, including burglaries and hold-ups, have taken place in the borough, and in nearly every case the thieves have escaped arrest.

All the real estate, rights, and franchises of the South Brooklyn Railroad and Terminal Company were yesterday sold to Samuel C. Herriman, representing W. Bayard Cutting, for the upset price of $150,000. The sale was in a suit in foreclosure brought by Jonathan K. Gapin, as trustee for certain promissory notes amounting to $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- It is apparent that some dissatisfaction is felt by the members of the Foreign Affairs Committee in the House and the Foreign Relations Committee in the Senate over the creation of the Insular Committee in the House and three new committees in the Senate to take care of the affairs of our new possessions.
The Central, Boulevard, and Friendship Clubs each won and lost a game in the Harlem League at the Palace alleys last night. The Centrals and Friendships each rolled scores of over 900. Scores:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Senator Cullom's bill to improve the White House has aroused considerable interest here and has had the effect of reviving the periodical discussion as to whether the building is suitable for the President and whether better quarters should not be devised. It has been suggested that a building for the President's own use should be erected on the White House ground.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Senator Lodge has introduced a bill providing for the erection of a five-hundred-thousand-dollar National memorial arch in this city. A man named John Kortz Carey has been sending out appeals for popular subscriptions for the same purpose, saying that $500,000 is to be appropriated by Congress, if it passes Lodge's bill, and $500,000 raised by popular subscription.

There is much common sense and real statesmanship in the recent utterances of President SCHURMAN as to the future of the Philippines. Whether that future is to be reasonably peaceful and prosperous is the problem for us to solve, and its solution is the test of the right or wrong of our whole policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- William D. Bynum, formerly of Indiana, and recently appointed a member of the Board of General Appraisers at New York, to-day denied that he had ever stated that he had joined the Republican Party. He asserted that when on the stump favoring sound money he had always said that he did not agree with the Republicans except on the financial question.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The Earl of Tankerville is dead.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19. -- Judge Phelps, in the City Circuit Court late this afternoon, appointed Harry A. Parr receiver for the Columbia Iron Works and Dry Dock Company. Mr. Parr gave bonds for $100,000. The receiver was appointed by consent. The Columbia Works built several vessels for the navy.

COLUMBUS, Dec. 19. -- The Supereme Court to-day, in a test suit brought by the Auditor of State against the Auditor of Franklin County, decided that telephone instruments must be placed upon the tax duplicates of the various counties at a valuation based upon their earning capacity. Only the wires, poles, and other tangible property have heretofore been taxed.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Dec. 19. -- This was the second day of the Fingerhut murder trial, in which Mrs. Fingerhut is charged with killing Paul Roehricht of New York, who owned the farm upon which the Fingerhut family live. The State closed its case and the counsel for the woman made his opening address.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A number of witnesses from Utah appeared to-day before the committee of the House which is investigating the case of Mr. Roberts of Utah. They included Mrs. Dr. Luella Miles, a practicing physician of Salt Lake City; Mrs. McDougall, Mr. E.L. McDaniel, and S.E. Wishard, all of Salt Lake City.

Controller Coler yesterday prepared for Corporation Counsel Whalen a statement showing the amount of money paid by New York County to the State for school purposes, and the amount received by the county from the State as its share of the free school fund in the last thirty years. The amounts for each year are shown.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19. -- Christian Devries and Mrs. Minnie A. Devries, his wife, filed a joint deed of trust this morning, conveying all their property, real and personal, to Henry S. Dulaney, trustee, to be by him converted into cash and used in the liquidation of the debts of the Vogeler Company, of which Mr. Devries is President.

The trial of Robert W. Fielding, indicted for alleged conniving in his official capacity as Deputy Commissioner of City Works of the former City of Brooklyn at the audit and allowance of alleged fraudulent bills brought against the city, was begun yesterday before Justice Wilmot M. Smith, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. When the court adjourned six jurors had been obtained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Financial bill passed by the House yesterday was received from the House, and at the suggestion of Mr. Aldrich, (Rep., R.I.,) Chairman of the Finance Committee, it was referred to that committee.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Robert Mazet, Chairman of the Mazet investigation committee, called on Gov. Roosevelt to-day and submitted an outline of the recommendations that the committee will embody in its report to the Legislature. Mr. Mazet declined to state what they were.
Seven persons met death in two tenement house fires which occurred in the city early yesterday morning. Several more persons were burned and otherwise injured.

The Union Club, at a meeting held last evening at the clubhouse, Twenty-first Street and Fifth Avenue, adopted a recommendation of the Governing Committee that the club should purchase a new site at Fifty-first Street and Fifth Avenue, and subsequently prepared the way for this purchase by passing the following resolution:

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Dec. 20. -- Mrs. Fingerhut, who is charged with killing Paul Roehricht, went on the stand to-day in her own defense. She identified the battering ram which Mr. Roehricht and his party used in breaking down the door of her home, and described the shooting. She said she did not mean to shoot Mr. Roehricht, but merely to scare him away, as she thought he was going to kill her.

All this tremendous Christmas buying and incidental Christmas traffic is bringing thoughts of home, of happier days, perhaps, to a lot of people who have become flotsam and jetsam in the maelstrom of city life. It was unconsciously indicated by a conductor on one of the Broadway cars last evening.

President James J. Hill of the Great Northern has been in the city during the past few days, and the Street sees in his visit much of consequence in the way of pending railroad developments. While here President Hill has been in conference with a number of leading railroad officials, but what has been done at these meetings only those in the inner circles know.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 20. -- William Wright Heard was nominated for Governor to-night by the Democratic State Convention at Baton Rouge. He is a Silver Democrat with Populistic tendencies, and received the nomination through the aid of Gov. Foster, who is the present incumbent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Chairman Barton of the River and Harbor Committee authorized the following statement to-day:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The President sent the following cablegram to Gen. Otis:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Gen. Lawton died a poor man, although but few beyond his circle of immediate friends knew of the small pecuniary return that had come to him from his life work in behalf of his country. Therefore some of these friends have thought proper now to come to the aid of his family, as is shown by the following statement, addressed to the American people, issued to-day:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The marrla.e of WIiss lfargaret Cox to Laurence Yincent Benet, vhich took place to-day at 1 o'clock at St. Paul's Church, was largely attended. The Rev. Dr. Alfred Harding, the rector, officiated. The bride's only attendant was , her sister, AIiss Sally S. Cox, and tile hest man was Edward Pierce Casey of New %'ork, formerly of this city.

The closing of the free libraries on Sunday, which began this week, has drawn forth an ultimatum from Controller Coler and Corporation Counsel Whalen, who yesterday declared that if the managers of the libraries persist in their determination, the city would intervene by cutting off the appropriations altogether.
QUEENSTOWN, Dec. 21. -- Considerable anxiety is felt regarding the White Star steamer Oceanic, Capt. Cameron, which left New York Dec. 18. She is thirty hours overdue.

LACONIA, N.H., Dec. 20. -- The charges brought by ex-Gov. C.A. Busiel and Senator W.E. Chandler against Senator J.H. Gallinger, alleging violation of the civil service laws, will be taken before the Grand Jury next week. The case now is in the hands of United States District Attorney Hamblett.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The Senate today confirmed the following nominations:

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- A bill submitting the Franco-American reciprocity treaty to the approval of the French Parliament was introduced to-day in the Chamber of Deputies. The Government, in an elaborate preamble, makes a point of setting forth the "kindly disposition of the American Government which has enabled the negotiations to be brought to a successful conclusion," and expatiates upon the great stimulus the treaty will give to commerce between the two countries.
SCHENECTADY, Dec. 20. -- In an interview to-day regarding the trip to Paris next year of the Princeton track team, Capt. John F. Cracken, who is spending the holidays in this city, said:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 20. -- The composition of the second Canadian contingent to join the British forces in South Africa is no longer a matter of speculation. When the Minister of Militia left the Privy Council room, where the Cabinet had been sitting, this afternoon, he said:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- There is one man in the city to-day who would probably want to fight if any one should wish him a Merry Christmas. He sits around with a heavy heart hating the "joyous Christmastide." His name is Sherman, and he owned the six trained goats heralded the world over as Sherman's Caprine Paradox.

On Dec. 10 you published a few questions which I addressed to the advocates of the Boers. Several gentlemen have written to you, saying that they wanted permission to answer these questions; but not one of them has answered them. Instead of doing so, they ask questions of a different kind themselves, or else indulge in mere declamation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the treaty negotiated by the powers at The Hague last July for the pacific settlement of disputes between nations and the declaration to prohibit for five years the launching of explosives from balloons. The Senate immediately removed the injunction of secrecy.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Gen. Lord Roberts, who is to have full command of the British troops in South Africa, accompanied by Lady Roberts and their two daughters, arrived in London this morning, having traveled from Dublin with Mr. Chamberlain. Their departure from Dublin was marked by cheering crowds, but the General made a quiet entry into London.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 20. -- Further testimony was heard to-day by Receiver Edward S. Campbell of the wrecked Middlesex County Bank of Perth Amboy in the hearing granted several claimants who contend that they are preferred creditors, inasmuch as the bank received their deposits when the Directors knew, or should have known, that the bank was insolvent.

Eugene V. Brewster and his fellow-leaders of the Chicago Platform Democracy of Brooklyn last night cut loose from bimetallism and came out for a paper currency only. This action was taken at a meeting at the home of Mr. Brewster of the Executive Committee of the Democratic National Ways and Means Committee for Kings County.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 20. -- Job Cleveland, a cousin of ex-President Grover Cleveland, was initiated into the mysteries of the war tax in the office of Internal Revenue Collctor Harkins to-day. The old man is a manufacturer of wine, and leads a secluded life in Buncombe County.

ALBANY, Dec. 20. -- The Legislature at its coming session will undoubtedly be called upon to pass legislation to give New York City power to establish and maintain a crematory for the disposal of garbage and ashes.

Doubtless the British public is looking for a scapegoat. Such a quest is mere human nature. Also it is one of the wholesome checks upon the degeneration of democracy into demagogy. It is the business of a responsible statesman to know more than the people he represents about the dangers of the courses which they desire.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The following call for the next Republican National Convention was issued to-night:
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- President J.G. Schurman of Cornell and the head of the Philippine Commission, to-day spoke feelingly of the death of Major Gen. Lawton. He said:

Something over a year ago you honored me with space on your financial page in printing a letter, which you headed "Idiosyncrasies of the Street." At that time I was the veriest lamb in the fold -- indeed, had practically been through my first shearing only and made no pretense to "knowing it all."
MANILA, Dec. 20. -- Major Gen. Lawton's body was brought from San Mateo to Manila this afternoon, his staff and a squadron of cavalry acting as escort. It was found necessary to bridge the river.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- Apropos of the many reports in circulation as to the Governor's choice to succeed Adjt. Gen. Andrews, the Governor, besides the name of Capt. Landon of Company I, Seventh Regiment, which has been prominently mentioned in connection with the office, has about twenty names under consideration.

It is very generally understood, we suppose, that there are only two ways of getting money out of the United States Treasury. One is to pay it out as authorized in the appropriations of Congress. The other is to buy or redeem bonds with it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Mr. Hawley, (Rep.,Conn.,) Chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, drew a sharp speech from Mr. Pettigrew (Silver, S.D.,) in the Senate to-day by a motion to reconsider a resolution previously introduced by Mr. Pettigrew and passed directing the Secretary of War to forward to the Senate the full report of the commission appointed by the President to investigate the conduct of the Spanish war.

Ferdinand Poggenburg of the Liederkranz won the Slosson-Daly Emblem last night at Slosson's Billiard Academy by defeating Frank A. Keeney of the Crescent Athletic Club in the final half of their six-hundred-point match. When the game adjourned on Tuesday night at Daly's Academy the score was 300 to 198 in Poggenburg's favor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. - Mr. Hoar (Rep., Mass.,) introduced a resolution in the Senate to-day declaring how the people of the island possessions of the United States should be governed. The resolution is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The President has granted a full pardon to James H. Bacon, who was convicted in 1896 and sentenced to imprisonment for seven years in the Utah Penitentiary for making a false report to the Controller of the Currency of the condition of the National Bank of Salt Lake, Utah, of which he was President.

The congregation of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by a rising vote and harmoniously decided last night to call the Rev. Dr. George T. Purves, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Princeton, to succeed the late Dr. John Hall. The report of the committee to which was allotted the task of choosing Dr. Hall's successor gave testimony of the searching tests as to orthodoxy applied in the case of all candidates favorably considered.

To create a ten-thousand-dollar office and then put it absolutely outside of politics is an undertaking beyond the powers of any save the most resolute and celestial-minded of men. Some reformers tried it at Albany last week and their adamantine virtue became as soft as beeswax before that cruel temptation.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- John Gardiner, aged sixty, residing on the western outskirts of this city, to-night shot his wife, aged twenty-nine, in the right breast and left arm. He then retired to his house. Where he awaited the coming of the officers at a window. On catching sight of the brass buttons of the policemen he raised the revolver to his head and sent a bullet crashing through his brain, death being instantaneous.

HAVANA, Dec. 20. -- The welcome given Gen. Wood, the new Governor General of Cuba, this morning on entering Havana, was, according to all the old residents, without parallel in the history of the island. The elaborate display of bunting in the harbor and the multitude of boats and bands showed that the hastily formed Reception Committee had done excellent work.

A suit for $50,000 damages brought by Hugh Gibben against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for injuries alleged to have been received in 1894 by being thrown from a Second Avenue horse car, was given to the jury yesterday in the Supreme Court.

Yesterday was not one of many social diversions. There were two weddings in town, several receptions, and dinners, but the principal event was the opera in the evening, at which appeared in the parterre many new faces. To-day's programme is fuller and much more varied. A number of well-known people will go to Lakewood to the private theatricals to be given there by Mrs. George Gould at Georgian Court.

At its final meeting for 1899, held yesterday afternoon, the School Board for Manhattan and the Bronx Boroughs determined to unite with the other school boards of the city in fighting objectionable legislation at Albany, and decided, owing to want of sufficient funds, to abandon with the new year its schedule of May 17 equalizing salaries, and to go back to the salaries in force previous to the adoption of that schedule.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 20. -- The remains of Lieut. T.M. Brumby, Admiral Dewey's flag officer, were laid to rest to-day in the soil of his native State. The funeral was under the direction of the military, and the service of the Episcopal Church was conducted by Bishop C.K. Nelson.

Of course, it is greatly to be wished on many accounts that a higher grade of intelligence, not to speak of integrity, could be obtained for the Municipal Assembly. Since that is out of the question the dictates of experience point to the solution revived by the Controller last year, that the Municipal Legislature be abolished.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- Troublous conditions in the financial circles are apparently ended. The mischief that has been done, however, is still very manifest in present market values. Nowhere has the storm done more serious injury than in the copper shares. In view of the fact that the copper shares and their unhealthy inflation were indirectly, at least the cause of the trouble, it is not at all surprising that this should be the case.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- The University of Pennsylvania's free Museum of Science and Art, one of the late Dr. William Pepper's cherished hopes, was formally opened to-day in the presence of several thousands of interested people. Immediately following the presentation to the Board of Trustees of the Museum.

"Oyster Jim," who figures in the Rogues' Gallery under that alias, and the name of Patrick Stewart, and is a confidence man, the police say, of great ability, whose special line is that of a professional mourner, was held for trial in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday on a charge of larceny. He attended a funeral at the home of Robert Trunkle, at 459 West Twenty-sixth Street, on Tuesday, to which he was not invited.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 20. -- To-night before the Lexington Chess Club the champion, H.N. Pillsbury of Wheeling, West Va., played a blindfolded exhibition game carrying twelve boards at one time. The noted player Showalter of Georgetown was present. Pillsbury plays in a tournament in Louisville, Thursday, Fridays, and Saturdays.
LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Nothing has been heard from Lord Methuen since Sunday, and it is feared that his communications have been cut. If this be so, his position is dangerous.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Some interesting experiments in the photography of live fishes have been made by Capt. R.W. Shufeldt, the results of whose work have just been published by the Fish Commission, Heretofore success in or even attempts at this sort of photography have been rare, as compared with the photography of other living forms, and few such photographs have been published.

-- That bodies nominally representative are more than occasionally composed of persons quite lacking in both ability and inclination to express any except their own private and inconsequential opinions is a phenomenon lamentably familiar to us all. It is still an interesting one, however, and sometimes the examples of misrepresentation are amusing enough or irritating enough to deserve special attention.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- To-night at the Collingwood Opera House. Fannie Rice gave the first performance of her new play. "A Wonderful Woman." The name of the author is a guarded secret.

ABERDEEN, S.D., Dec. 20. -- W.F.T. Bushnell is in receipt of a letter from his sister, Dr. Katherine Bushnell, who is at present in India doing missionary work. She is in one of the plague-stricken districts, on the verge of the famine district, and says that the sufferings of the natives are already terrible, although the famine has just begun.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- In the Senate, sitting as a High Court of Justice, to-day, counsel urged that the charges against M. Marcel-Habert be joined to the present proceedings, but the Prosecutor General declared this would be illegal. M. Deroulede, who, though ill, was present, virulently denounced the Senators and law officers for being "subservient to the Government's orders."
ELMIRA, Dec. 20. -- Justice Mattice to-day granted a non-suit in the Robinson-Mutual Life damage case.

The Executive Committee of the Dewey Arch Committee met in Parlor B at the Hotel Savoy last evening. There were about sixteen members present, and William C. Church presided. The members present said that the building of a permanent arch was now assured.

ALBANY, Dec. 20. -- Assemblyman Fallows of New York, as Chairman of the special committee appointed by the Legislature to investigate the workings of the Surrogate's Court in New York County, called on Gov. Roosevelt this morning and submitted the committee's report, together with the recommendations that will be made.
John T. Williams said yesterday afternoon that the report that he had sold his ten-story building, at the southwest corner of Broadway and White Street, 50 by 100, was without foundation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- Col. M.S. Quay, leader of the Republican organization of Pennsylvania and claimant to a seat in the United States Senate under the credentials issued by Gov. Stone, dropped quietly into town from Washington this morning.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 20. -- The Rev. Dr. W.J. Robinson, pastor of the First United Presbyterian Church of Allegheny and Moderator of the United Presbyterian General Assembly which met at Philadelphia last May, died to-day at Battle Creek, Mich., where he went three months ago.

A dispatch from Rome makes the startling assertion that the Negus of Abyssinia is preparing to strike Great Britain a blow in the Soudan. A dispatch from London informs us that the news has caused much uneasiness there. All this might have been expected. It is even to be wondered at that the announcement is so tardy in its arrival.

TULI, Monday, Dec. 11, via Lorenzo Marques, Dec. 16. -- Col. Plumer, with a strong reconnoitring party of horsemen, has returned here after a week's expedition into Transvaal territory. He reached a point fifty miles from Pietersburg, in the South African Republic, but found no Boers, the country being seemingly empty of men.

War a outrance on stray dogs in Central Park has been declared by the Park Board, and is being waged relentlessly with shotguns in the hands of the keepers of the menagerie, two of whom, Head Keeper Peter Shannon and Keeper Snyder, are dead shots, as many an ownerless or prodigal bow-wow has found to his cost during the past few weeks.

The following extracts from letters sent by our soldiers in South Africa to friends at home afford vivid glimpses of the war. A letter from a wounded Lance Corporal of the King's Royal Rifles to his mother, just come to hand, gives a description of the storming of Glencoe:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 21. -- Playing lost nearly $100,000 in the recent crash in the stock market Capt. Louis Schneeberger, cashier of the Baltimore Post Office, prominent in politics, and treasurer of the Young Republican Club, yesterday committed suicide by shooting himself in the head. Post Office Inspector Waffle says that Capt. Schneeberger's accounts as cashier are correct and his books balance to date.
PITTSBURG, Dec. 21. -- Senator M.A. Hanna, arrived here this morning, leaving the city for Cleveland to-night. The Senator said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Chief Naval Constructor Rear Admiral Hichborn has just received two large packages from the Boston Navy Yard. One is a section of a berth from an officer's stateroom on the Olympia. It is about a foot and a half long by about a foot wide. The front and varnished side is pierced with small holes, resembling shot holes.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The Daily Mail says: "We understand that news has arrived from Gen. White to the effect that Ladysmith is well supplied with food and ammunition and can hold out much longer than has been estimated. The troops are described as in good spirits and anxious to fight."

Ex-United States Senator Washburn of Minnesota was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. Speaking of the proposed plan to have Congress name a commission to improve American commercial relations in the Far East, particularly in China, he said:

Is not the action of the House of Representatives in assuming the burden of proof in the Roberts case an error? Mr. Roberts refuses to admit or deny, anything, but stands on what he calls his Constitutional rights, and leaves the committee to prove their case, as if they were conducting a criminal prosecution, and the committee submits to his dictation and undertakes to do so. Is this right?

Berry Trenholm have sold the Scotia apartment house at the southeast corner of St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Twentieth Street, known as 200 to 206 St. Nicholas Avenue, for Dr. E.L. McComb Bristol to Dewitt Judson for about $130,000; also, the Treupel place, on the old White Plains Road, Mamaroneck, for a client, to Dr. E.L. McComb Bristol for about $40,000.

The simplest announcement in the daily papers that Dr. Wilson, the world's greatest aurist, is to lecture and give free treatment to the deaf is sufficient to fill to overflowing the largest auditorium in this or any other country, but when the quarters where the lecture is to be given are more circumscribed there is almost a life and death struggle among those who desire to gain admission.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The house party given by Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould for the throwing open of the new casino, Bachelors' Hall, on their handsome country place here, which bears the name of Georgian Court, brought about a hundred fashionable people from New York and Philadelphia to this town to-day.

The Justices of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, have announced the assignment of Supreme Court Justices for the Trial and Special Terms for the year 1900. Justice David McAdam, of the Supreme Court, when seen at his home last night, said regarding the assignments of Justices:

ALBANY, Dec. 21. -- Deputy Superintendent of Public Instruction Ainsworth to-day was shown Controller Coler's figures with reference to the amount of money paid into the State Treasury by New York County for school purposes, and his implied claim that because the amount paid in largely exceeded the amount drawn out by New York, she has the right to be exempt from State regulation.

There is in the General Post Office an old employee who has the reputation of being able to decipher almost any address that is passed over as illegible by the other clerks, and his busy season has just arrived. Since Monday he has been daily in receipt of small stacks of mail, and in almost every case the address has been deciphered to read "Santa Claus," "Mr. Santa Claus," or "Kris Kringle."

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The sharp attacks made of late upon imperial and Prussian Ministers seem to be bringing about a change in political customs, as the Ministers are replying through the newspapers to their assailants. Only a few days ago Dr. von Miquel answered, over his own signature, the charge that he was the Prussian Minister responsible for the dismissal of the Landrathe, who had voted against the Canal bill.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 21. -- Many Senators and Representatives called upon the President to-day to pay their respects and extend their Christmas greetings before leaving for their homes to spend the holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Mr. Tracewell, the Controller of the Treasury, has passed upon the claim of Swift Co. of Chicago for the price of 300,000 pounds of fresh beef, which, according to contract, was shipped from Newport News, Va., on Aug. 5, 1898, for use of the army in Puerto Rico, and was on Sept. 7 condemned at Montauk Point, N.Y., and thrown overboard.

This being Forefathers' Day, the exchange editor has noticed that many of the New England papery are republishing as a particularly appropriate bit of verse for the time the poem of Mrs. Hemans which begins:

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 21. -- The address to the Democracy of the State, indorsing the contest instituted by Goebel and other candidates of the defeated Democratic ticket, and giving the reasons therefore was issued to-night. It is signed by ex-Senator Blackburn. Chairman of the State Campaign Committee. Chairman Young of the State Central and Legislative Committees and all of the members of those committees.

BUFFALO, Dec. 21. -- Clark Howell of Atlanta, who with several friends from that city arrived here last evening as the guest of the Independent Club, to-day, in charge of a committee of the club and representatives of the Pan-American Exposition Company, visited the site of the exhibition and inspected the service building, which has just been completed, and the other work in progress.

NATICK, Mass., Dec. 21. -- Lewis Perry, a Spanish war veteran, was shot and killed this afternoon by Miss Lizzie Morse, at her home in West Natick. Four shots were fired, two of them taking effect, one in the heart. Miss Morse was shortly afterward placed under arrest. She claims that the circumstance justified her in shooting Perry.

It is immensely to the credit of the organs of British opinion that they do not attempt to disguise from themselves or from anybody else the awful seriousness of the British situation in South Africa. The London Times has as much responsibility for that situation as any public man, and far more than any other public newspaper, because it has had the weight of an authority to which no other newspaper can pretend.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 21. -- W.J. Dent, the ex-convict who is under arrest at Tucson, Arizona, awaiting extradition to answer to the charge here of securing the release from the penitentiary of George Isaacs, is a nephew of United States District Judge John Jackson of West Virginia, and a cousin of the late Gen. Stonewall Jackson.

John F. Tyrrell, the expert in handwriting, gave testimony all day yesterday in the trial of Roland B. Molineux. He was under direct examination all the morning by Mr. Osborne, and in the afternoon Mr. Weeks tried to shake whatever impression the witness had made on the jury by a searching cross-examination.
William Neufeld, who is charged with the murder of Mrs. Annie Kronman of 266 West Thirty-fifth Street, went on trial before Justice Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday.

The New England Society of Brooklyn held its twentieth annual dinner at the Pouch Gallery on Clinton Avenue last evening. The occasion commemorated the landing of the Pilgrims at Plymouth Rock -- this year bringing the two hundred and seventy-ninth anniversary of that event -- and their descendants gathered to recount the adventures of the hardy band and extol the principles that they represented. About 150 were present, fully half that number being women.

The Belvideres carried off the honors in the Harlem League last night, defeating the Morningside and Central teams. In the second game the Belvideres did excellent work, three members of the team rolling scores of over 260. Scores:

The extraordinary vitality displayed by Walter Duryea, who has been for the last five months in Roosevelt Hospital, is causing renewed astonishment to the many physicians and surgeons who are watching his case. Mr. Duryea, who is a son of a well-known manufacturer, broke his neck last Summer at Glen Cove while diving into shallow water. On being taken to Roosevelt Hospital he underwent an operation which was widely discussed by medical men.

The underlying motive of the silver movement is the desire to get something for nothing. The Brooklyn Bryan Democrats now frankly acknowledge that they would prefer dollars of paper that cost nothing at all to dollars of silver that cost 52 cents apiece. It is reported that this move is in obedience to the suggestion of Mr. BRYAN.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 21. -- Edward Tibbits, known to the authorities as H.C. Foster, and also as "Boston" Tibbits, and who, the Brooklyn detectives say, is a clever swindler and old-time bunko man, was arrested at Ravenview Hotel, Stratford, last night by Deputy Sheriff Stagg of Stratford, at the request of Brooklyn detectives.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The Rev. Dr. George T. Purves, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, has the formal call from the members of the Fifth Avenue Church, New York, to become their pastor.

There was a stormy ten minutes' session of the Republican County Committee at Murray Hill Lyceum last night, caused by the refusal of the Platt men to permit Abraham Gruber, the anti-Platt leader in the Twenty-first Assembly District, to introduce an amendment to the by-laws concerning the designation of Inspectors and Clerks of Election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- James Duane Taylor, one of the officers of the Wagner Palace Car Company, and a son-in-law of the founder of the company, committed suicide to-day soon after noon at the Grafton Hotel, in this city, by cutting his throat with a razor. Mr. Taylor was in ill-health, and the fatal act was committed apparently on the impulse of the moment.

The Musical Art Society gave the first concert of its seventh season at Carnegie Hall last night. The entertainments of this organization have a strong social backing which makes their pecuniary success a matter beyond doubt. Their artistic character has long been an established fact, and one goes to these concerts with the expectation that he will there hear music to which he can listen with more than ordinary satisfaction.

HAVANA, Dec. 21. -- Major Gen. Wood formally took charge of the Governor General's offices at 9 o'clock this morning. His first act was to accept the resignation of the members of the Advisory Cabinet of Gen. Brooke. These officials, after considering the question overnight, had decided to insist upon retiring.

HAVANA, Dec. 21. -- The removal of the dead of the Maine was not accompanied by any ceremonies over the bodies. Newly coffined, they were placed in the mortuary chapel of the cemetery until all was completed. At 10 o'clock last night twenty wagons formed a mournful procession, carrying 151 coffins to the Machina Wharf, passing through unfrequented streets.

PORT AU PRINCE, Dec. 8. -- The German warship Nixe entered this port yesterday, coming from Puerto Plata, in the neighboring republic of Santo Domingo. The Nixe, which has a crew of 350 sailors and marines, mounts seventeen guns, and is commanded by Capt. von Basse, saluted the Haitian flag.

Christopher Fine, who died on Wednesday at his residence, 230 West Twenty-first Street, in his seventy-fourth year, was one of the last survivors of a famous school of lawyers in this city. He was a typical advocate, relying for success largely upon a fervid style of oratory, which was very effective with juries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A hearing was begun to-day by the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the matter of changes in freight classification and advances in freight rates by carriers using the official classification.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The following general order announcing to the army the death of Gen. Lawton, was issued from the War Department to-day:

FARMINGTON, Conn., Dec. 21. -- Two locomotives and eleven cars were totally wrecked in a head-on collision between two freight trains on the Northampton Division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company near here this morning. The debris caught fire and eleven cars were destroyed.
According to The Sun -- a very good authority on such things -- Mr. MCKINLEY is regarded by his friends in Congress as having struck "a blow at the Republican policy of protection."

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- A $400,000 attachment against Edward A. Clark and William H. Coolidge has been filed by Dupee Sargent, State Street bankers and brokers. The writ relates especially to property held by the firms of Hayden, Stone Co. and Frederick H. Prince Co., bankers, and owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Clark, wife of Edward A. Clark.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Senator Foraker published some time ago a long article concerning the origin and adoption of the "gold plank" at the Republican National Convention of 1896, in which he maintained that the pank was prepared by the Committee on Resolutions, of which he was Chairman, after much discussion and out of diverse materials.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The Duke of Marlborough, who is a Lieutenant in the Oxfordshire Yeomanry, and who has volunteered for service in South Africa, will take with him, if his offer is accepted, 150 men and horses. He will personally furnish the equipment for these men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin, at the head of the committee charged with the collection of funds for the benefit of the family of the late Gen. Lawton, is in receipt of expressions of sympathy and of willingness to co-operate from all quarters of the country. Some of these are accompanied by contributions of money, and altogether there is promise of a generous response to the committee's appeal issued yesterday.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 21. -- Upon application this morning of attorneys for Thomas F. Ryan of New York, a temporary restraining order was issued by United States District Judge Thomas R. Purnell to prevent any action of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad stockholders looking toward the consolidation here to-day of the various lines of the Seaboard Air Line system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- "It is generally a careful and calm analysis of the situation," said Secretary Gage to-day, referring to the leading editorial article in this morning's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES on "Relief from the Treasury." "It is the business man's view and is helpful in not adding excitement to the situation.

The new addition to the Forty-seventh Regiment armory at Marcy Avenue and Lynch Street, Brooklyn, was formally opened last night with a review, followed by a reception. Several thousand persons were in attendance, and the great drill hall was elaborately decorated with flags and bunting. With the addition, the armory occupies an entire block and makes the drill hall one of the largest in America.

-- In a letter recently sent to an American friend HENRY M. STANLEY not only ascribes the British reverses in South Africa to the almost criminal lack of foresight of the Government, but expresses strong apprehension that after the costly victory has been won its fruits will not be gathered.

The fine weather of yesterday was hailed with delight by the Christmas shoppers, who, with the festival now so near at hand, find the time all too short for their purchases. The Avenue was less crowded than usual on a fine early Winter day for the reason that society itself had gone shopping and could be found on Sixth Avenue, Broadway, and the east and west side shopping streets.

After being out only fifteen minutes the jury in the case of Robert Fielding, ex-Deputy Commissioner of Public Works in Brooklyn, charged while in office with auditing fraudulent bills, returned a verdict yesterday afternoon of not guilty.

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- Congressman Charles A. Boutelle of Maine, Chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs, who is stopping at Young's Hotel in this city, was taken ill there this afternoon and was carried to his room unconscious. Everything is being done for his comfort.
The National Assurance Company of Ireland has signed the agreement of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Senator James K. Jones, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, looked into party affairs at headquarters in the Unity Building today. He assured everybody that the prospects for Democratic success next year are brighter than they were in 1896. He said only W.J. Bryan would he mentioned as candidate for President in the convention.

The large seven-story apartment house in course of construction on the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-seventh Street was gutted by fire at noon yesterday. Work that had occupied six months in the doing was undone by the flames in an hour, and it will be necessary to level the building to the third floor, at least.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Controller Dawes this evening appointed Special Examiner Daniel G. Wing temporary receiver of the Globe National Bank of Boston, Mass. In connection with his action the Controller said:

Senator HOAR has snatched up the torch that lately fell from the hand of JONES of Toledo and is bearing it on far up the heights. But how vastly is the field of illumination enlarged! JONES concerned himself almost altogether with cities, franchises, and wage-earners. Senator HOAR'S benignant counsels of perfection embrace the universal brotherhood of man with all its woes and passions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The following statement is made by the official German authorities here:

If there is one thing more than another that a member of the Democratic Club cares to guard from his fellow-clubmen, it is what is going on in his mind, for no matter what he may think, no matter how disappointed he may feel at not having an office, he wears a happy smile and outwardly shows no traces of despondency.

The first two volumes of the British Empire Series have appeared, bearing the titles "India Ceylon, Straits Settlements, "British North Borneo, Hongkong," and "British Africa." They include a series of articles, most of which were originally given as lecturesin the Sunday afternoon course at South Place Institute, London, from 1895 to 1898.

In an attractive volume, save for its exceedingly ugly cover, which might in itself almost prejudice possible readers against the book, comes a story told in letters, in the most poetical and beautiful prose imaginable -- a book which, once read, will be taken up again and again for the beauty of its language and imagery.

It has often been said that unconscious humor is the best, and the following anecdote seems to prove the truth of the saying: The other evening at dinner a little lady who had been seriously reading Mr. Frank Stockton's collection of strange and wonderful tales contained in "A Story Teller's Pack," gravely announced that she had been reading Mr. Stockton's "A Pack of Lies."

Continuing liquidation yesterday played further havoc with stock market quotations. Sugar Trust was knocked clown to a new low price, and even standard shares of the highest class suffered severely. The market was not in an upset because of any new bad business developments, for in a very large majority incidents disclosed during the day were satisfactory and ought to have been helpful.

The period chosen by Mr. Harris Dickson for his romance, "The Black Wolf's Breed," was when Louis XIV, was King of France. The hero, Placide de Mouret, is a young French gentleman brought up in Louisiana. There are plots in the French colony to subvert the Government and give the country over to the Spaniard.

Just one year ago to-day some person dropped into the General Post Office in this city a package addressed to Harry Cornish at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. The package contained a bottle of bromo-seltzer mixed with cyanide of mercury, the bottle being inclosed in a silver holder.

President Thomas L. James of the Lincoln National Bank was notified yesterday that Secretary Gage had designated it as a depository of public moneys especially to receive deposits only on account of "Transfer of Funds" under Section 5,153 United States Revised Statutes. The designation is temporary, and the security $250,000 in United States bonds, which have been deposited with the Assistant United States Treasurer.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- A gradual veering of public opinion in Germany regarding the war in South Africa is becoming apparent. The change is led by the inspired section of the press. To-day several articles appear pointing in the new direction.

We have come to be such readers that Santa Claus must surely have added a publishing house to his old-time workshop, and the stocking that will not hold a moderate-sized book is likely to lose some of its share of presents. There is an appropriateness in gifts of books or pictures at Christmas time that is the growing custom's excuse and explanation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- It is probable that as soon as Congress reassembles a resolution will be passed by the House to concur with the Senate in the division between the two houses of the space in the Capitol Building vacated by the Library of Congress.

The discussion that has arisen over the resemblance between the literary style and the plot of "Richard Carvel" and "Hugh Wynne" naturally brings to mention other resemblances of the kind in fiction. In the case at point no doubt remains that the two authors wrote without knowledge of the lines each was following.

Among the many interesting letters called out by your editorial article on "Autumn with the Poets," the beautiful and suggestive quotations from Thoreau led me to take up a certain little soft leather copy of essays, bearing his name, and to try to learn anew how "in every life there might be time to be wise, opportunity to tend the growth of the spirit."

Do you and others in the east know where books are loved? Where the author steps out from his ambush of printed pages and walks with you hand in hand, a flesh and blood friend and comrade through thick and thin?

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- Another day of unrest in Boston's financial circles went by without incidents of a startling nature. The receivership for the Globe National Bank took nearly every banker and broker by surprise, and before business in the money market began, forebodings were dire. But prophesying and fears were not realized, for the situation to-night was considered as good if not slightly better than at any time for a fortnight.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 22. -- The annual Forefathers' Day dinner of the Orange New England Society was held this evening in Upper Music Hall. The hall was tastefully decorated, the National colors and Christmas greens predominating. About 300 sat down to the tables. President C.J. Kidder presided and acted toastmaster.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22. -- The creditors of the John P. Squire Co. corporation, at a meeting to-day, voted to continue the business of the firm under an assignee subject to the assistance and approval of a committee of three representing the creditors.
As to Mr. Churchill's story "Richard Carrel;" in my judgment this book is very much overpraised. As an American novel it ranks high, but what is its position as a world novel?

The Youth's Companion Calendar for 1900, which will be presented to all new subscribers to the periodical, is worthy of notice. It is made of three heavy half-tone plaques, attached so that when opened they may rest upright. The oval centrepiece, in dainty colors and inclosed in a border of embossed gold and flowers, represents "A Dream of Summer," and is supported on each side by an admirably executed figure piece in delicate tints.

The ninety-fourth annual banquet of the New England Society in the City of New York, held in the grand ball room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night, was declared by many old members of the society to be the most elaborate in their recollection. It was remarkable, too, as being made the occasion of a pro-British demonstration on the part of the majority of the 528 members and guests at table.

HAVANA, Dec. 22. -- Sixty-five persons were present at the farewell banquet tendered to Gen. Brooke to-day at the Paris Restaurant. Gen. Mario Menocal presided, and Ernest Lee Conant acted as toastmaster. Senor Llorente, in proposing the health of Gen. Brooke, said:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22. -- Recent moves in the negotiations concerning the intended sale by Baltimore of the Western Maryland Railroad indicate that the acquisition of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal and the Western Maryland Railroad is Part of the big deal between the Pennsylvania and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.

That there are different ways of looking at things was evidenced at the Grand Hotel yesterday, where a couple of army officers were having a late breakfast. "I see Brown has been transferred to the -- th Infantry," remarked one of them, as he looked up from his morning paper.

The phrase "Dutch courage" has been popularly used to reflect upon the bravery of the Hollander. Strange that this should be as we view him in the light of history! At the opening of the present war together with other disparaging epithets, this was thrown up at the Boers of the Transvaal. That mode of warfare, however, has now ceased, and, whether victorious or defeated, the Dutchman will hereafter never be regarded as cowardly.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 22. -- An afternoon paper to-day cabled Mrs. Lawton, Manila:
We are losing enough Assembly districts now to make dishonest performances like this bring the flush of shame to the face of every Republican.

Mr. Ripley Hitchcock, in the current number of The Independent, presents a brief but careful essay on "In the Ninth Year of International Copyright." After introducing his subject by describing the trying condition of affairs that prevailed before the passage of the act and the many ill-omened prognostications that accompanied its early working, Mr. Hitchcock demonstrates how the International Copyright law has benefited both American publishers and authors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The Committee on Organization and Literature appointed immediately after the meeting of the Republican National Committee, has begun correspondence at once, and already reports the receipt of letters from different parts of the country setting forth the temper and condition of the party. The reports are said to be uniformly satisfactory.

If there is left in THE REVIEW space and patience for something additional apropos of "David Harum," it would gratify the subscriber to go on record with those who do not comprehend the continually advertised popularity and phenomenal sale of the book.
Mr. Thomas Ryan, whose name is intimately connected with the musical history of Boston, has given us a charming volume of reminiscences. In his preface he says:

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 22. -- The charter of the Union Central Railroad has been approved by the Attorney General for filing with the Secretary of State. This road is capitalized for $600,000. It will be constructed from Houston, Texas, to a point on the Red River near Paris, Texas, and will have spurs to Waco and to Palestine, Texas. The entire mileage will be 560.

QUINCY, Ill., Dec. 22. -- Francis Parochial School, situated at Seventeenth and Vine Streets, this city, was the scene of a terrible disaster at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The school has between 500 and 600 pupils and a number of them had been drilled for a Christmas entertainment by Sister Theotama.

Petitions in bankruptcy were filed yesterday against the Upper New York City Water Company of Greenberg, Westchester County, and the New York City District Water Supply Company of Glen Park by three creditors in each case. They allege that the companies are insolvent and have committed acts of bankruptcy by transferring to certain creditors property in order to prefer them and by permitting creditors to obtain a preference by legal proceedings.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles to-day, in expressing his opinion regarding the South African war, said to a reporter:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22. -- The Murphy Iron Works of this city has just demonstrated the fact that steel and iron ships can be built here. Up to a short time ago no local firm had the boldness to attempt such a departure, and when the Murphy people secured a contract from the Texas and Pacific Railroad to rebuild the big steel transfer boat Gouldsboro on new lines, considerable comment was excited.

Ex-Alderman Charles J. Smith, better known as "Silver Dollar" Smith, died yesterday morning at his home, 64 Essex Street. He had consumption, diabetes, and several other ailments. Mr. Smith became seriously ill a week ago Wednesday, when he had to go to bed. To the last he appeared to have great vitality.

Mrs. Ida Schirbs, said to be one hundred years old, died at midnight Thursday in the apartments of her son-in-law, Abraham Molenik, on the first floor of 411 Grand Street. Mrs. Schirbs came to this country six years ago from Buhisdok, in the Province of Grogoa, Russia.

Strong opposition it is reported has developed within the Republican State organization to the proposed plan of the Unification Commission, of placing the public school system of the State under one head, which is favored by Gov. Roosevelt. The Governor is reported to be greatly interested in the idea, and wants to see it realized at the coming session of the Legislature.

Having been a reader of THE SATURDAY REVIEW for two years, this is my first outbreak, so I hope for pardon. The reason I write is because I am glad to see that some readers of THE SATURDAY REVIEW are not prostrate before the literary idols of the present generation. Any mediocre writer nowadays can win the bay of literary renown by means of a partial reviewer and unscrupulous publishers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Representative McClellan, who has a companion in Congress with whom he is almost as intimate as he formerly was with Ermentrout of Pennsylvania, may lose him. His friend is Representative Stallings of Alabama, who aspires to be Governor of his State, and who may get the nomination if Gen. Shelley does not run off with it.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Adelbert S. Hay, the new United States Consul at Pretoria, formally received at the United States Embassy to-day a number of wives and other relatives of British officers who came to make special requests regarding the prisoners at the Transvaal capital.

We believe it was Sir CHARLES BERESFORD who, since the present war began, found and proclaimed a similarity between Great Britain and the United States in that they were the only two great nations which did not resort to conscription, but relied upon volunteers for their defense.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22. -- Results at Oakland:

Although to-morrow will in reality be Christmas Eve, the world in general looks upon to-day, since to-morrow will be Sunday, when no purchases can be made, as the eve of the festival. There will be a hurrying and a skurrying all day long and well into the evening on the part of the always large army of belated Christmas shoppers to complete their purchases and put the final touches to the Christmas arrangements.

The second hearing held by the Aldermanic Committee on Bridges and Tunnels on the resolution authorizing the construction of the two proposed bridges over the East River yesterday came near ending in a row, and it was only through the coolness of the Chairman. Alderman Schneider, that a scene of great disorder was averted.
In reading Sir Walter Scott a good and interesting course is to take the novels in chronological order, that is, the oldest in date to begin with.

William L. Wixson, forty-three years old, of 200 West Ninety-ninth Street, and his wife's grandfather, Edward F. Johnson, eighty-eight years old, of 115 West Ninety-sixth Street, were knocked down and dragged several feet by south-bound Amsterdam Avenue electric car No. 1,582, at Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, last night.

The presentation of folk-lore is not usually an achievement in literature, but it is always in some sort a contribution to history. The more at variance is this embodiment of wild and savage imagination with our more commonplace trend of mind, the more of strange interest it offers to our contemplation. In the last book, "In Chimney Corners," by the young Irish schoolmaster.

Dumahaut of the Harlem Wheelmen bowled in excellent form in the Harlem League series at the Harlem Palace last night. His score of 248, on eight strikes and two spares, in the third game, brought victory to his team. He made an average of 215 for two games. The Harlem Wheelmen easily defeated the Corinthians, and the latter won from the Grove Hills, which lost two games. Scores:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The committee engaged in raising a fund for the relief of the widow and four young children of Major Gen. Henry W. Lawton is gratified with the generous, response to its appeal, and now suggests through the press that all those feeling able and so disposed make a Christmas offering to promote the work in hand.

ROME, Dec. 22. -- A terrible disaster took place this afternoon at Amalfi, the popular tourist resort on the Gulf of Salerno. About 2 o'clock an enormous rock, upon which stood the Cappuccini Hotel, slid bodily into the sea with a deafening roar, and without a moment's warning, carrying with it the hotel, the old Capuchin Monastery below, the Hotel Santa Calerina, and several villas.

You have given us in THE REVIEW many such admirable reviews of new books, and some such really valuable ones, that it was with a distinct feeling of pleasure that I saw in TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW that you had a notice of Mr. Quiller-Couch's beautiful story. "The Ship of Stars." It was with a feeling not unlike indignation that I laid the paper down after reading the notice.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 22. -- At this date Winter has not arrived in Maine, and the ground is as bare as in August, while the rivers are entirely free from ice. This is pleasing to the ice dealers here, for they argue that if Maine's Winter is to be short, that of New York must be still shorter, so that there can be but little ice in the Hudson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Secretary Long has addressed letters to Senator Hale and Representative Boutelle, who look after naval legislation in the Senate and House, relative to the plan of refitting the historic old craft Constitution as a naval training ship. The Massachusetts State Society of the Daughters of 1812 propose to pay for the refitting through popular subscriptions, and Secretary Long refers to this as a worthy purpose, inspired by patriotic impulse.

A man whom all the book world knew as Quaritch, so that the name had almost become an institution, died in London last Sunday. THE NEW YORK TIMES has already printed an outline of his career, but some fuller details will interest readers of THE SATURDAY REVIEW. Born in Worbis, Prussia, April 23, 1819, the son of a military officer, Bernard Quaritch became fatherless and practically friendless in his ninth year.

The volume which the President of the Johns Hopkins University devotes to James Dwight Dana is full of human and scientific interest. The canvas had to be a broad one, for how otherwise could we understand the man, who was scientific explorer, mineralogist, geologist, zoologist, writer, editor, and teacher? Consider only that Dana worked on almost unceasingly for sixty years.

VIENNA, Dec. 22.-- The fourth round of the Kolisch memorial tournament, which was played in this city to-day, resulted as follows: Alapin and Brody and Zinkl and Schlechter drew, Albin beat Prock, Wolf beat Popiel, and Schwarz beat Marco. The Korte-Maroczy game was adjourned in a position favorable to Maroczy.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- At a meeting of the Regents of the State University the Special Committee on Educational Unification reported the recommendations which were sent to the State Commission, the details of which were made public at the time. The findings of the commission were also recited and a strong plea was made that a larger measure of discretion be left to the Regents.

When it was announced some little time ago that these reminiscences were about to appear, the general feeling was that they would be found unusually interesting. As is well known, portions of the volume came out in The Atlantic for the current year, and were found to be as had been expected, very charming, and they are even more so now, on the appearance of the completed work.

In all the interesting discussions of the Rubaiyat that have brightened the pages of our TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW I have seen no mention of a variant, a tangential output, by Mr. John Kenworthy of England, as published by the Society of the Rose. Mr. Kenworthy calls his quatrains, which have the repetend and break of rhyme we know so lovingly, "The Western Rubaiyat."

That the operatic public does not look with favor on changes of the programme at the Metropolitan Opera House was pretty thoroughly demonstrated last night. "Tannhauser" was originally announced for the evening, but owing to the troubles of the company in struggling with the weather while "on the road" the drama of Wagner could not be given.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Dec. 22. -- With the words "God is calling me," Dwight L. Moody, the Evangelist, died at his home here at noon to-day. His passing was as gentle as could be wished for. His family were gathered at his bedside, and the dying man's last moments were spent in comforting them.

Watson R. Sperry, at one time editor of The Evening Post of this city, and afterward editor and owner of The Wilmington (Del.) News, but who has long been living in Dresden, writes from Dresden to a recent number of The Wilmington News:

The lessons of the last quarter have covered somewhat less than a century of time. They have all directed our attention to the relation of God's people to Himself, and to the obligations growing out of that relationship. They were His restored people. Our studies, therefore, have had nothing to do with His relation to the heathen or with their relation to Him, and but very little to do with His own people in Babylon.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 22. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railway, which has been repeatedly postponed while waiting for the final reports of the receiver, was held to-day.
