An examination of the Christmas numbers of our leading magazines seems to show that something of the Christmas feeling is fast departing. The December issues generally have more or less claim to being special numbers, insomuch as they all have attractive covers, and many of them illustrations in colors.

MANILA, Dec. 22. -- The newspaper Democracia, the organ of a coterie of Filipinos, including the Supreme Court Judges, favoring American control in the Philippines, tonight announces that it has been decided to suspend publication. The paper was started at the suggestion and under the patronage of the Philippine Advisory Commission, headed by Prof. J.G. Schurman.

The article, "A Public Print Collection," in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of THE NEW YORK TIMES states that "there is no public print collection in New York City -- none nearer than Boston." May I beg to remind you that the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia owns the largest and in many respects the finest collection of prints in this country?
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Benjamin Francis Conn Costelloe, M.A., the Chairman of the Local Government Committee of the London County Council, is dead.

-- People who make, or try to make, a living by pleasing other people vastly increase the difficulty of their task if they present their claim for approbation while the objects of their efforts are in a state of justifiable irritation against them. This is a truth which the managers of theatres have especial reason to ponder, and doubtless they do give it a good deal of attention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The hearing before the Inter-State Commerce Commission called on account of complaints made by shippers against the proposed new classification of freight by railroads operating under the "official classification" was resumed to-day.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The Daily Telegraph has a special from Chieveley, dated Dec. 16, which tells how Lieut. Roberts, son of Lord Roberts, fell at Tugela River. It says:

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- It is a pity that there cannot be a law requiring every man who wishes to write a book to pass an examination in Herbert Spencer's "Essay on Style" before receiving permission to publish. The number of young authors who have been wrecked on the rock of style must be enormous.

To seek fame in one direction and find it unexpectedly, and very often accidentally, in quite another, has been the fate of many gifted men. The Rev. Charles Lutwidge Dodgson, grave, dignified, and scholarly Oxford don, devoted to mathematics and logic throughout his long life, could never reconcile himself to accept the renown which came to "Lewis Carroll" as the author of those ingenious and delightful whimsicalities in "Alice in Wonderland."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Senator Cullom of Illinois is a man of generous impulse, prone to be too willing to oblige anybody who comes to him on behalf of "comrades" of the war of the rebellion. He introduced a bill at the very beginning of the session proposing to give an honorable discharge to all soldiers who had served sixty days and who were borne on the records as deserters.

Horace S. Ely Co. have sold for the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company and another, Trustees, the four-story building 79 Fifth Avenue, east side, 100 feet north of Fifteenth Street, 34 by 129. It is understood that the purchaser will improve the property.

A few years later than the "shrinking schoolgirl" period I took up "Les Miserables" after a brief convalescence. No one had "pushed me into the arms of that Moloch of dreariness," nor did the reading of it "entail such a strain on my endurance as to leave me wan and enfeebled for six months afterward." Had some kind fate suggested one-tenth of the grandeur contained therein I would have read it sooner.

W.J. BRYAN does not perceive the remarkable change that has come over the South. The men of the Southern States used to be absorbed in politics. They are now occupied with business. The real leaders there are not the politicians, but the creative men of the new industrial era.

A great wave of liquidation swept over the stock market yesterday, knocking away the calculations of all those persons in Wall Street who believed that the bottom had at last been reached, and for a time depressing prices so appreciably that in not a few instances the quotations were several points under the figures of Monday when panic prevailed.

Ex-Gov. Thomas M. Waller of Connecticut, well known as interested in trolley railways, and as a practicing attorney at 15 Wall Street, is charged, by Joseph W. Pullar, with having conspired with Alfred R. Page and others to defraud him out of his rights in an inheritance worth almost $100,000, about half of which is in personal property, and the rest improved realty in Chicago.
As we have before stated (many a time and oft) correspondents of THE SATURDAY REVIEW who use this column will oblige the editor if they will send, in all cases, their full names and addresses.

The walk from Cambridge to Concord by way of Lexington is a delightful one, and to the person interested in the early struggle for liberty, doubly so. The journey can be made in a day by one accustomed to walking, but too much time must not be spent on the many by-paths of historic interest.

There are few things a man knows less about than his own self, and few things which, for ignorance of, there is less excuse made for him. But the knowing never so intimately and the expressing quite honestly are two different things. Here we have not a memoir, but an autobiography, what, par excellence, concerns the man; and there is no task so hard. Most men could as easily describe the seventh heaven.

When Bernard Quaritch died in London on Sunday, Dec. 17, there passed from the bibliographical world probably the most remarkable man that ever entered it. Coming into the world of rare books a mere errand boy, he left it the prince of book sellers, having revolutionized the trade, which he made a profession, and having encouraged the gathering of books to an astonishing degree.

The discussion of the power of the Secretary of the Treasury to come to the relief of the money market in certain contingencies and of the effective way to do so if the contingency should require is not at the present moment a discussion of what can be called a burning question. Happily the situation now does not demand any action further than has been taken by the Secretary and the Associated Banks.

The week in the art world of New York has not been one of any particular incident or excitement. There have been no new exhibitions, with the exception of some fifty paintings and drawings by Julius Rolshoven at the American Art Galleries, and of a number of paintings and pastels by the Boston art writer and painter, Philip L. Hale, at the Durand-Ruel Galleries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Attention has been directed by a Kentucky Republican to certain provision of the Kentucky election law, made by Goebel, who contests Taylor's right to be Governor. These may explain any apparent hesitation on the part of the Goebelites to try the experiment of a contest before the Legislature.

Christmas this year will be very extensively observed by the churches of various denominations. This unusual observance of Christmas obtains among Presbyterians in particular. Services will he held in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Central Church, West Fifty-seventh Street; West End Church, Old First Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street; Madison Avenue Church, and Fourth Avenue Church.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- Secretary Melvil Dewey to-day tendered his resignation to the State Board of Regents of the University. His action was taken after a speech by State Superintendent Skinner, in which the latter said that neither the Regents nor their officers were willing to make any concessions of dignities or powers.

It has been a pleasure to note the long view of the South African war taken in THE TIMES of Sunday and Monday. We all lament the apparent lack of tact and patience of Mr. Chamberlain, but he is possessed of more information as to what has been going on behind the scenes than his critics.

Prof. William A. Keener, Dean of Columbia Law School, appeared as complainant in the Harlem Police Court yesterday against Frederick J. Park, nineteen years of age, of 213 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, the assistant librarian of the school, and charged him with stealing a law book valued at $2.50.

The Committee on Tariff Reform of the Reform Club has issued a circular calllig attention to the resolution opposing a subsidized American merchant marine passed by the National Grange at its recent session at Springfield, Ohio, and reciting the reasons why the committee opposes tile Shipping Subsody bill now before Congress.

Louis Barnett of 124 Forsyth Street caught a man last night prowling about in the house in which he lives, and in spite of a revolver thrust in his face by the burglar, held on to him and yelled for help, the result being that the thief was lodged in jail. The man gave his name as Henry Rice, a carpenter, twenty-one years old, of 53 Lewis Street.

In your issue of Dec. 20 you publish Mr. Shearman's twenty-six articles against the Boers, but with all the legal ability of the writer he makes out a poor case. His twenty-six articles furnish no justification for the shocking war between two Christian nations, who instead of fighting should at this Christmas season be rejoicing in the advent of the Prince of Peace.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to --

In your issue of yesterday I noticed another effusion signed by Thomas G. Shearman, a person hitherto unknown, but evidently a new star in the world of writers of humorous fiction. It seems to me that you ought to have a special heading made for his department, and label it "Laugh and Grow Fat."

"Yes," said the little man up town who makes theatrical "Props" and incidentally any number of "props" for other things. "there is nothing like papier mache. It is being used more and more all the time now and there are more and more things for which it can be used. It is the strongest material known for its weight.

There will be unveiled for the morning service in the Church of the Holy Trinity, at Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, to-day a new window, designed and executed by Francis Lathrop, the well-known decorative artist, and which has been placed in the church by Mr. Leander H. Crall in memory of his wife.

As an American of English, Scotch, and Irish descent, whose forefathers fought the British at Eutaw Springs, at King's Mountain, at Yorktown, and at New Orleans, I wish to thank you for your able leading editorial of this date. I can agree with you that the time has not yet come when the British nation shall cease its work of developing and civilizing the waste places of the earth.

BOSTON, Dec. 23. -- Trading was fairly well distributed during the two hours of business to-day, but as it was still almost wholly on a cash basis, the transactions did not reach large proportions. The Copper shares, as a class, showed slight gains. Montana touched 260, a lift of 5 points over Friday's closing, but just at the end it fell back to 258.

The unnual glorification of opera singers began at the Metropolitan Opera House last Monday night. The musical world has now come to a standstill, and the mystic power, personality, reigns where sometimes sat the goddess of beauty. But potent as is the charm of personality, it cannot account for the whole of the popularity of opera as a form of public entertainment.

Once each year, on its last night, the thousands of Hungarians of this city reproduce a small corner of their fatherland in one of the larger assembly halls, and, amid scenes which bring back thoughts of their former homes, give themselves up to the pleasures, games, and pursuits of the rollicking, care-free peasant of the land for which they fought and bled.

I beg you to call public attention to the great utilitarian value of the triumphal arch and colonnade now spanning Fifth Avenue, opposite Twenty-fourth Street, and reaching from Twenty-third to Twenty-fifth Street.

WILLETS POINT, L.I., Dec. 23. -- The wives and children of the members of Companies A and B, United States Engineers, who are living at the army post here, will spend a merry Christmas while their husbands and fathers are fighting in Manila. The outlook for Christmas was not bright until Major John C. Knight, the post commander, suggested an entertainment tonight for their benefit.

The humor of a comic song is at best so ephemeral in its allusiveness that strict comparison between the laughter-breeding ditties of bygone times and those of to-day is out of the question. "Hot Codlins" and "Tippitywitchet" appear childish enough now in all conscience, but probably not more so than will jingles of the "Tarara-. boom-de-ay" order to our own great-grandchildren.

For some unknown reason, when men attack the system of woman's gowning, past or present, fashionable or rational, they always hammer on the same aged nailhead and pathetically inquire why women will not dress in a sensible, or, as our esteemed friend H.K. Bush-Brown puts it, in a rational manner.

In commenting on the mischievous policy of Charles Townshend, who, as Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Ministry of George III., framed the famous laws of 1768 for the regulation of commerce in the American Colonies, among which was the provision for the imposition of a duty on tea that subsequently acquired so grave an import in the quarrel between the King and his American subjects, Prof. Fiske has written:
Withers Mills have been appointed metropolitan agents of the Norwalk Fire Insurance Company.

The ground is hidden beneath a mass of Jungle grass, sword grass, and fern, all bowed under a weight of moisture, and this forest is dreary, damp, and cold. It is hilly country, and you hear the notes of the different birds echoing and deceiving you. They are all high, piping sounds, save now and then when a thud-thud like a thunder bolt seems to strike the earth.

The simplest announcement in the daily Papers that Dr. Wilson, the world's greatest aurist, is to lecture and give free treatment to the deaf is sufficient to fill to overflowing the largest auditorium in this or any other country, but when the quarters where the lecture is to be given are more circumscribed there is almost a life and death struggle among those who desire to gain admission.

THE simultaneous appearance of late years of a number of circumstances unfavorable to horses has caused certain persons, who take time by the forelock and easily echo vague notions that are fashionable for the moment, to foretell the extinction of these animals.

That is a fearful arraignment of the Boers in Mr. Thomas G. Shearman's letter addressed to you, published in this morning's TIMES. Its bill of particulars is so lengthy and so specific that it impresses one with the conviction it must be correct. And yet, like many a similar effort, in its very force (apparent) lies its weakness.

The nauseating and fulsome flattery of this country by the press of Great Britain and, to a great extent, by its Government, a flattery which daily increases as its situation becomes more and more critical, remind us strongly of the homely saying that "words are words and facts are facts." When and where did that Government ever pursue a truly liberal and generous policy without a selfish aim?

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 23. -- The traveler whose destination is Birmingham, whether he be one of the large and eager and confident throng of commercial men visiting a greedy market or a newspaper man willing to observe and note the evidences of general activity in business, will do well to write or telegraph ahead if he desires to be provided on his arrival with a room in a hotel.

Bishop Wigger, the Roman Catholic prelate of New Jersey, who this year is to conduct the Christmas ceremonies and grand high mass in the Church of the Nativity, in Bethlehem, will, on his arrival in Palestine, find himself in a land whose physical features and inhabitants differ greatly from the country of his birth, and in a climate that will make him imagine that Winter has been omitted in this year's seasons.

A car of the Madison Avenue line, bound south at 7 o'clock last night, crashed into a Spring Street horse car as it crossed the Bowery into Delancey Street, and three persons were injured, the windows of the horse car broken, and many persons panic stricken.

I have read the remarks of Mr. Thomas G. Shearman in recent issues of your paper and also the replies thereto with great interest -- and some profit. But there is one point I am puzzled over, and that not a little Mr. Shearman lays great stress upon the so-called "invitation" extended by Kruger in 1884. When Kruger was merely a Commissioner in England endeavoring to perfect a treaty with Great Britain.

All owners who wished to avail themselves of the privileges of the old building code had to file their plans before midnight on Friday, and the result was that during that day new building operations involving an outlay of $10,593,400 were placed on record. This is the largest amount represented by a single day's business in the history of the Building Department.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 23. -- The harm which has been done to legitimate investors by the circulation of false and malicious reports respecting the condition of different financial institutions during the past week can hardly be estimated. The names of the most substantial institutions and individuals in Baltimore were bandied about without regard to the injury that might result.

Miss Edith Howard, richly dressed and about twenty-five years of age, was arrested between midnight and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, at Broadway and Forty-second Street, for alleged disorderly conduct. She was discharged in court. She called at the West Thirtieth Street Station last night with a man who gave his name as A.R. Ferguson.

In your issue of the 21st inst. one T. G. Shearman, in twenty-three cantos, as it were, gives his opinion of the Republic of the Transvaal in such form that if the illiterate, ignorant rigmarole did not bespeak the writer's status, moral and mental, one would be led to think the Dutch race (our own respected founders) should never have supplanted the hottentot Kings of Southern Africa.

Controller Coler has not yet broached the subject of the extension of the rapid transit system to Brooklyn and Queens to Alexander E. Orr, the President of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, but he will do so early next week. Mr. Orr was out of the city yesterday.

Leslie W. Bradley, a Western Union telegraph operator at 195 Broadway, was run over by a hansom in front of the building yesterday and perhaps fatally injured. Bradley is forty-five years old, unmarried, and lived in apartments at 14 Irving Place.

From the veranda some clematis hangs down in beautiful festoons, and in early Autumn it is a mass of bloom. But, alas for the scent of it! Yet it is the favorite rendezvous for all the butterflies, flies, and moths of the place. All day and half the night they besiege it. In their eagerness to reach the evil-smelling flowers they pass over jessamine and roses, heliotrope and lavender, musk and mignonette.

Several hundred persons were bitterly disappointed yesterday afternoon when they entered the Metropolitan Opera House to see the notices posted up to the effect that Mlle. Emma Calve was unable to sing the part of Marguerite, in which she was billed to appear, in "Faust," and that her place would be taken by Miss Susanne Adams.

The fact that the Consolidated, Standard, and New Amsterdam Gas Companies made identical bids for the lighting of streets and public buildings has led city officials to surmise that a combination of the companies has been effected.

I write you as a reader of your editorial utterances on the Boer war to let you know that they do not find an echo in my mind, no matter how I may try to reason the matter. The fact that the Boer Government will secure positively and retain their independence need not injure England any more than our securing our independence injured her growth and prosperity in legitimate lines.

M. LOCKROY, FRENCH EX-MINISTER OF MARINE, ON THE RESULTS OF THE WAR. -- M. Lockroy, who has twice held the Portfolio of Marine in French Cabinets, sees in the war in South Africa a lesson which he places before his Government and his compatriots in a statement made through the press of France.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- The Governors of the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club have announced that the office of Secretary and Treasurer of the club has been accepted by Eustace H. Miles, M.A., of King's College, England, holder of the gold prize, winner of the open competition in the amateur racquet championship of England, and late lecturer of Cambridge University.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Christmas is here, and right royally is Gen. M. C., Wentworth, the new manager of the Lakewood Hotel, celebrating it with a grand Christmas dance to-night in the pretty ballroom of the hotel, to which he invited all the cottage set. The result is a great success, for a throng is present, the number of arrivals at the hotel to-day being over two hundred.

Chief Devery has made up his mind to change the patrol system of the police part of Central Park, so that the men now doing duty in the Park may perform patrol duty the same as in other precincts. Under the system now in vogue in the Park the men are on duty eight hours and have sixteen hours off.

SIMLA, India, Nov. 23. -- The Viceroy left this city for a tour in the plains something like a month ago, while his members of council, heads of departments, and other officials of high degree, both civil and military, have also followed suit. Lord Curzon's first real tour in India has perforce been of a somewhat melancholy character.
An American woman desires, through the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES, (her daily paper) to give expression to her sympathy with the cause of the oppressed Boers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- The University of Pennsylvania announced a few weeks ago a gift of $250,000 for a new Laboratory of Physics. The Provost of the university announced to-day as a Christmas gift another subscription of $250,000. Of this sum $200,000 has been contributed without any restriction as to its use by the Trustees.

It is astounding that a partisan committee of professing Christians of Stamford, of which the Chairman professed to be a servant of Christ, with two Doctors of Divinity as prosecutors and managers, could be found to render the verdict they did against William Kemp, who had been a member of the Methodist Church for many years.
ROME, Dec. 10. -- The thoughts of people in many lands are turning toward Rome and the opening of the Holy Door, which marks the beginning of the year of jubilee.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 23. -- The seminary for female ministers which the Rev. A.M. Harvuot of the Central Christian Church of this city succeeded in having favorably considered by the jubilee convention of the Church Missionary Societies held here last October, and which it was thought would be located in Cincinnati, will probably be established in Chicago.

HAVANA, Dec. 17. -- Beyond doubt the most beautiful of Havana's suburbs is Vedado, situated on the coast about three miles from the city proper, and reached by "dummy" line or by coach. Another line, an electric one, has been spoken of to run from the city along the coast to the Playa of Marianao, a fashionable Summer resort eight miles out of town.

The regular company of the Empire Theatre will take possession of its own stage to-morrow night, when a new whimsical comedy in four acts entitled "My Lady's Lord," written by Henry V. Esmond, a young dramatist of whom much is expected, will be acted. This play has been given by Mr. Frohman's actors in other cities lately, and its first performance here may be expected to be uncommonly smooth.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23. -- Subjects of Great Britain living in Kansas City have contributed $1,022 to the fund for the relief of the families of British soldiers fighting in South Africa. The contribution was remitted to-day to the Lord Mayor of London.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The immigration officers of the Treasury Department have found a virtual state of slavery in Avon, Livingston County, N.Y. An Italian colony of 270 persons exists there, headed by Salvatore De Loatis, who is their padrone and appropriates their wages. He hires out the Italians to farmers and fruit growers.
As a result of causes too mysterious for the mind of man to comprehend, fashion claimed the terns for her own.

Roland Burnham Molineux will spend Christmas in jail for the first time in his life, yet from information obtainable from the best sources, his father, his counsel, and Warden Hagan of the Tombs, the young clubman who has been on trial six weeks for the murder of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams nearly a year ago is in the best possible spirits under the circumstances.

Have you room for anything more concerning the tripartite relation of England, America, and the Transvaal; if so, will you publish this letter and my reply? My position was admirably expressed and sustained in your editorial on the same subject, but I have suffered so much misconstruction and have received so many reproaches that I would like to set myself right.

"Just how the so-called joint committee of the National Guard Association can represent the National Guard of the United States, is what is puzzling a good many of us," said a prominent officer of the Guard in referring to the bill to be introduced in Congress prepared under the direction of the above organization, which makes the militia a reserve of the regular army.

Mr. Labouchere indulged in some rather disrespectful remarks about leader writers in Truth a couple of years ago. "Article writing is, to a great extent, trick writing," he wrote. "To 'catch on' they must dogmatize in pointed commonplace. Some persons possess this trick, which is rather an acquired than a natural gift.
CAIRO, Dec. 23. -- Gen. Wingate has succeeded Gen. Kitchener as Sirdar and Governor General of the Soudan.
Joseph Block, twenty-seven years old, of 2,230 Fifth Avenue, a well-dressed man, walked into Bellevue Hospital last night and asked to be examined. He said he feared he was not in his right mind.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 23. -- Charles H. Cole, formerly President of the Globe National Bank of Boston, is under Federal surveillance at a hotel in this city. Mr. Cole is charged, in a complaint mailed today by the Boston authorities, with the embezzlement of $900,000.

The substantial grievance of banks in this State, so far as they are in competition with trust companies, lies in the difference in the taxation of the two classes of institutions. There are trust companies, mostly those recently organized, which encroach upon the banking field by inviting general mercantile deposits and dealing in commercial paper, but many believe that this will rectify itself.
The editorial in your issue of the 19th inst. entitled "England's Friends and England's Enemies" is so admirable and well timed that I wish it could be read by every intelligent American in our land.

Public golf in New York City has demonstrated its success far more than the most sanguine expected last Spring, when it was decided to increase the playing facilities of the Van Cortlandt links from nine to eighteen holes. This unlooked-for success and the increasing number of players will undoubtedly lead to the laying out of another public course before another season's golf begins.

THE newspaper reports of the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States promulgated on Dec. 4, 1899, in the case of Bolles vs. Outing, did not indicate the grave import of the rulings announced in the case. The matter is very much more serious than appears on the surface, and the decision only serves to emphasize the hopelessly chaotic condition in which our copyright law at present exists.

Fish was in great demand at Rome, and incredible sums might be made by fish ponds or wasted on them. The humble fish pond of the people, supplied with rain water and replenished by fish taken out of rivers or lakes, brought in large returns. The aristocratic fish pond, furnished by Neptune and constructed with elaborate art. was more apt to empty pockets than to fill them.

I have read with the keenest pleasure the letters of Mr. Bleecker Miller and Mr. Shearman. I think the former's suggestions most valuable and such as should be promptly carried out in their entirety. Certainly the Boer press agency work is the finest thing of its kind ever done internationally.

ANSONIA, Conn., Dec. 23. -- George Blakeman of this city, the oldest man in Connecticut, being in his one hundred and first year, ascribes his longevity to his total abstinence from medicine of any description. In spite of his years, he is well and active. Every pleasant day he walks half a mile to the Post Office, and on Sundays he is a regular attendant at the First Congregational Church.

It is most improbable, next to impossible, that a non-Italian Cardinal should be elected. Not only is the majority in the Conclave composed of Italians born, the totals being thirty-five to twenty-six, but there are grave reasons, almost overwhelming reasons, why no one who is not of that nation should be elected.

Noticing that at a meeting of the National Sculpture Society this week it was proposed by Mr. J. Scott Hartley to erect a water gate at the foot of West Seventy-second Street leading to Riverside Drive, according to a design submitted by that gentleman, which comprised terraced walks from the river up to the drive, embellished with statues of Hudson and Stuyvesant, and other ornamental features, I would like to ask a few questions.

Wall Street approaches a forlorn Christmas. A year of buoyant activity, of confidence begotten of evidences indisputable that great good times have come to the country, is offset, unsettled, and made to look insignificant by disturbance extraordinary from whatsoever standpoint it may be viewed.

I have been a reader of your paper for about twenty years, and have read it with a good deal of satisfaction, and no doubt considerable profit, and still read it, and expect to do so, but there comes over me a sense of great weariness when I read your editorials of recent date regarding our relations with Great Britain in connection with the South African war.

Justice Fitzsimons of the City Court on Friday scored Cornelius Vanderbilt for neglect to answer in any way a summons for jury duty last April or to respond to notifications to appear since that time. The summons was given to a court officer on April 7, and he, instead of serving it in person, sent it to Mr. Vanderbilt in the mail.
In reading your editorial of the 18th inst. on "The Deplorable Reverses of the British" I am forced to believe that you are as pro-English as your namesake of London.

The alleged outbreak of bubonic plague in Paraguay is the subject of a report to the State Department by Albert W. Swalm, United States Consul at Montevideo. "Business in Paraguay is paralyzed by the prevalence of what is supposed to be the bubonic plague," says Consul Ruffin, writing from Asuncion, the capital of Paraguay, in a note appended to Mr. Swalm's report.
I wish to congratulate you on the manner in which you are treating the South Africa situation in your editorial department.

Permit me to thank you for your recent editorials on the British defeats and Transvaal question in general. They will indeed commend themselves to all lovers of justice. England's isolated position is due to the moral support she afforded this country during the Spanish war.

A dapper little man in dark clothes with a rakish Fedora hat was one of the first to step down the gang plank when the St. Paul was warped into her berth at the American Line pier yesterday. He was A. Henry Savage Landor, author, traveler, and lecturer, whose experiences in Thibet have been of a hair-raising character.

The exhibits of the American Museum of Natural History will soon be enriched by a fine collection of turquois objects obtained from the ancient ruins of New Mexico. The collection was brought in a few weeks ago, and contains many objects which are unique and of great scientific value, aside from their intrinsic worth.
It is something phenomenal to read in the daily press the strictures upon England, her Government, and her people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Prof. Dean C. Worcester, a member of the Philippine Commission, who was very near to Gen. Lawton, made the following statement to-day of the last conversation he had with the General before his return to this country:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Assistant Postmaster General Heath's recent order against the employment of married women in the Postal Service has called attention to the employment of husbands and wives, and also of people who are related by birth, in the various executive departments. Before the era of civil service reform the departments were honeycombed with families.

I shall never forget the pride with which a farm steward last year took me up to a pigstye and said: "The great actor, Sir 'Enry Irving, went right inside that there pigstye, Sir, last Sunday, and examined every one of them there pigs, Sir, and thought so 'ighly of 'em, Sir, that he did me the honor of asking me to go to his theatre and take my family.

It has been quite amusing to me to read the several letters of Mr. Thomas G. Shearman, which have appeared in your columns lately. He seems to see only the worst character of a few Boer politicians, such as we find wherever we may go.
Unto the cradle of the Wondrous Child Heaven brought its star, and man his gold and myrrh;

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 22. -- Particulars of further engagements between the British and Boer forces in Natal state that two companies of British mounted troops engaged about 300 of the enemy about eight miles from Estcourt. The Boers occupied a strong position, but were driven back with great loss.

If one considers the vast numbers of letters and articles with which the press of this country is flooded touching the South African question, and the perverted ingenuity of the majority of the writers thereby revealed, one is tempted to imagine that there is at work in our midst a Memphis-tophelian spirit which is playing sad tricks with the public mind in making the worse appear the better argument.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A bill is now pending in Congress for the relief of Hattie A. Phillips, the widow of John Phillips. Two Congresses have failed to pass on similar bills, but it is believed that the revival of patriotic enthusiasm brought about by the war will ensure the passage of this one, especially as there is a desire to honor heroes.

It seems almost a mockery to transcribe, on the eve of this Christmas, the words which ushered in the birth of CHRIST. The Nativity was hailed as the beginning of the fulfillment of the prophecy that the nations "should not learn war any more." As a matter of fact, so large a part of the population was never, in nominally Christian countries, actively engaged in "learning war" as is so engaged now.

What is the flag of the Transvaal Republic? if the present war keeps on as it is now going, it will soon be in the list of the flags of nations. Poor old John Bull. He is brave with the bravery of the lion by which he is type. But he is still laboring , after a hundred years or more , under the same old disability of the times of the American Revolution.

At the Metropolitan Opera House the usual Sunday night concert will take place this evening. The soloists will be Mme. Suzanne Adams, Mme. Schumann-Heink, and M. Planson. The programme of opera for the week is as follows: Monday, "Il Barbiere di Siviglia," Mme. Sembrich, Signor Campanari, M.E de Reszke, and M. Salignac.

BOSTON, Dec. 23. -- News of the detention of Charles H. Cole, formerly President of the Globe National Bank of this city, at Los Angeles, Cal., reached here this afternoon, after an unusual effort on the part of the United States authorities to keep secret the fact that any action had been taken to bring about the arrest of the man.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Dec. 23. -- The people of South Carolina have been divided of late in their interest into three factions, and the newspapers have been assigning space in equal proportions to the dispensary row, the trouble Senator Tillman had with two editors and a North Carolina hotelkeeper, and the battle in this city between the Howard clan and the dispensary authorities.

BROWNSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 23. -- Thirty men are entombed in the Braznell Mine, four miles from here as the result of an explosion of gas which occurred this morning. At 10 o'clock to-night Mine Inspector James Blick said: "There is scarcely any hope that any man in the pit is now alive."

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Dreary indeed is this Christmastide in England. The London streets are thronged with crowds as usual, and all the shops are displaying their accustomed wares, but there is no mirth, and business is not active. From the West End, especially, complaints come that the overturn will be poor, because nobody has any money to waste or any heart to spend.

Please accept my hearty thanks for your excellent editorial. "England's Enemies and England's Friends." It is a pity that your correspondents who criticise you will not read history aright, and appeal to reason rather than to prejudice. Can any one deny the justice, cold truth, and common sense of your remarks:

Gov. Roosevelt received yesterday the views of many persons who are interested in measures which will engage the attention of the Legislature at the session which will begin next month. The Governor acted as host at a breakfast at the home of his sister, Mrs. Douglas Robinson, 422 Madison Avenue.

ALBANY, Dec. 23. -- The charter of the New York Preparatory School of New York City has been suspended by the State Board of Regents. The charter has also been revoked of a branch of that institution situated in Brooklyn. Asa O. Gallup is the founder and Principal of these institutions. Mr. Gallup is married to a niece of Dr. Dewey, who has resigned from the Secretaryship of the Board of Regents.

ROME, Dec. 23. -- It now appears that the disaster at Amalfi, on the Gulf of Salerno, yesterday afternoon, caused by the rock on which stood the Capuccini Hotel sliding bodily into the sea, was not so fatal as at first supposed. Only ten persons were killed.

Talbot J. Taylor, the Stock Exchange member of Talbot J. Taylor Co., and who is James R. Keene's son-in-law, was yesterday served with a subpoena to appear before the Grand Jury next Wednesday. The summons was served by a clerk employed by Sheehan Collin of counsel for the Brooklyn Rapid T ansit Company.

The student of the human race has just now an opportunity to observe the results of a courtly and a mere civic education. Emperor William and the German nation have given sufficient proofs of character to deny the supposition that either of them has changed within the last twenty years their likes and dislikes, their purposes and their ideas regarding International comity and obligation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Lawton home fund is growing with most gratifying rapidity. The indications are now such as to encourage the committee which has undertaken to collect the fund in the hope that if the contributions continue at the present rate they will be able to carry out the idea of making the fund a Christmas present to Gen. Lawton's family. The total reported this morning was $7,449.55.

Permit me to express through the medium of your letter column my admiration for your timely editorial in this morning's issue entitled "The British Defeats." It is quite characteristic of THE TIMES fearlessly to express an independent opinion, when too many journals and their readers are ready to pose as critics of Britain, and to cavil at England's policy in this her hour of need.

TRENTON N.J., Dec. 23. -- Ellen Clementine Howarth, the poetess who wrote the "Wind Harp" and other pieces, died here to-night, in her seventy-third year. Mrs. Howarth had not written much for years and lived in humble circumstances in this city. On her last birthday, May 21, she was visited by Mrs. Grover Cleveland and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Watson Gilder.

The origin of the outbreak in Oporto has naturally been the subject of much discussion, but it remains purely a matter of speculation. Introduction has not been traced. At first it was hastily put down to an infected cargo brought in a ship from India, but on investigation the story melts away.

Probably there is no man now living in the United States, unless very eminent in public station, whose death would affect the minds and the hearts of so great a multitude on both sides of the ocean as have felt the death of Mr. MOODY.

ROME, Dec. 1. -- An event of unusual interest in the Italian musical world has been the representation at Milan of Hector Berlioz's little-know opera or "lyric poem." "The Taking of Troy." Following close upon the recent performances of "The Trojans" in its entirety at Paris, the work has created much interest and comment in this country.

The steamer Trinidad, that came in yesterday from Bermuda, brought along Capt. Alberthsen and eleven men of the crew of the Norwegian bark Autocrat, which was wrecked in a gale near Bermuda. Seaman Frank Gell said that the bark left Brunswick, Ga., on Nov. 24, with a load of heavy timber for King's Lynn.

There lies beside me as I write a sketch which has been widely circulated as the advertisement of an encyclopedia. It represents a young woman and a young man with a large folio volume on a desk between them. The youth is in football costume, the girl wears the cap and gown of the student. She is poring over the book, while his gaze is fixed admiringly on her.

We observe that a good deal of the sympathy which the Boers of South Africa find in this country comes from the fact that Great Britain calls herself an empire and that the burghers of South Africa call their States' "republics." Really, that was the only ground upon which Senator MASON based his resolution of sympathy with the Boers and of denunciation of the British.
SOUTHAMPTON, Dec. 23. -- Lord Roberts, in the course of an interview had with him before sailing to-night for South Africa, said:

I wish to commend your recent editorial utterances with regard to the war in South Africa and the attitude of the United States toward Great Britain during the continuance of that struggle. The United States, with abundant reason, has had her grievances against England in the past; but England has made noble atonement.

The holiday crowds surging past the always busy corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, in one continuous kaleidoscopic, cosmopolitan parade, were startled just after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon by the sudden advent of death. Above the tramp of hurrying feet, the clanging of loaded cable cars a buzz of shoppers' chatter, and the hoarse cries of street vendors, they heard three pistol shots discharged rapidly.

Several prominent trap shooters are at work on the preliminary arrangements for a big trap shooting carnaval that will be inferior in importance only to the Grand American Handicap and the Annual Amateur Championship of America. The plan is to hold a tournament for the championship of Greater New York the competition to be open to all shooters within a radius of fifty miles of this city.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 23. -- A new Indian monument has recently been erected in the cemetery at Stockbridge, Mass., where many Indians connected with the old Congregational Church and with town affairs, are buried. This is the inscription upon it: "In memory of good Capt. Konkapot, Peter Pau-Quau-nau-peet, and many of the Housatonic Indians, 1734-1900."
There is at the present moment at the Natural History Museum a model of the skull of an eagle so gigantic that the imagination can scarcely fit It into the life of this planet at all.

THE Rev. Dr. Smith of St. Paul has recently made some extraordinary statements in regard to woman's status in economics. He contended -- if the newspapers reported him correctly -- that the feminine wage earner is one of the evils of modern civilization, and he suggested that "the world would be better off if all the women were turned out of their jobs to-morrow."

The production at a meeting of the Sculpture Society of various more or less comprehensive schemes for the embellishment of the city is not a novelty among artistic bodies. Similar schemes were brought forward, a year or two ago, at a meeting of the Architectural League, and very interesting schemes some of them were.

The charges of collusion and fraud as attorneys which were preferred against Fulton McMahon and E.L. Heydecker by Ignatius Weltner, a lawyer of this city, were yesterday formally retracted by E.A. Alexander, counsel for Mr. Weltner at a continuance of the hearing before Magistrate Mayo in the Jefferson Market Police Court.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Dec. 23. -- Yielding to pressure brought to bear by friends, the family of D.L. Moody to-day decided to defer the funeral of Mr. Moody until Tuesday afternoon. Some of the details were arranged during the forenoon, and it was made known later that the family had consented that public services should be held in the Congregational Church at 2:30 o'clock.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23. -- An important railroad deal which has been pending for some time was concluded yesterday at the Carrollton Hotel, when the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company purchased for cash the Monongahela River Railroad. Possession of the new property will pass in April next.

The coloring power which can be derived from coal tar is quite astonishing. From one ton of good cannel coal are obtained by distillation about twelve gallons of coal tar. From this tar are produced one pound of benzine, one pound toluene, one and a half pounds of phenol or carbolic acid, six pounds of naphthalene, half a pound of anthracene, and a small quantity of xylene.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 23. -- Terence V. Powderly, Commissioner of Immigration, was in Pittsburg to-day, and held a consultation with Immigrant Inspector Robert D. Lawton of this district on business connected with the department.
Money on call was 3 4 per cent., closing at 4 per cent.

I am very sorry that I did not see Mr. Shearman's questions on the Boer war, in your issue of Dec. 10; if I had I would have endeavored to have answered them. I will now try to answer some of his very authoritative statements, although he admits that they are taken "chapter and verse" from two anti-Boer writers:

On the Welsh border it used to be considered that the surest precaution against witchcraft was to wear the left stocking wrong-side out. This leads us to another kind of superstition connected with the harmless, necessary hose -their value, when properly worn or arranged, as charms or as protections against sickness or pain.

In reading your editorial of this morning, (Dec. 19.) entitled "England's Enemies and England's Friend's." I was astonished to find any paper in this "land of the free and home of the brave" advocating sentiments so contrary to all our traditions and the principles upon which our country was founded.

Sales in greater variety, many of them involving good-sized amounts, have contributed to the market's steady improvement during the week and strengthened the belief that there is an active Spring season ahead. The purchase of the southwest corner of Broadway and White Street, a ten-story building, by James B. Haggin, brings the city's main thoroughfare to the front again and in a most gratifying way.

We print in the following columns a portion of the letters that have been received in this office dealing with the struggle that is now going on in South Africa. These letters are written from persons who move in many and widely diversified walks of life, and they give expression to almost every phase of the general question involved.

The Saracens charged on and repeatedly defeated the mail-clad legions of Europe, and this when the latter were of the two the more animated by religious fervor. Hyder Ali's horsemen were as good troops as any in the world. Even in our own time the French feared Arabs when commanded by Ab-del-Kadir, and the best Italian troops were defeated by Menelek.

New York, bent upon shopping, went down town yesterday morning empty-handed. It returned at intervals during the day and evening full-laden with more varieties of things than a generation ago were dreamed of for the good cheer of the Christmastide, conscious, indeed, that another pleasant duty was done, albeit at the expense of an empty purse.

I am of the Americans who feel grateful to England for sympathy and good wishes during our late war with Spain, and I do not care whether her attitude was prompted by love for "her cousins" or by pure self-interest. But I cannot agree with the position you take in the editorial about the deplorable reverses of the British.

Lamb, like his own child-angel, was "to know weakness and reliance and the shadow of human imbecility." He went with a lame gait. He used to get drunk somewhat too frequently. Let the fact be stated in all Its deformity -- he was too fond of gin-and-water. He once gave a lady the welcome assurance that he never got drunk twice in the same house.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Tax authorities and others here express great indignation at the manner in which the State Board of Equalization has permitted the railways and many of the rich corporations to escape from the tax lists. It is asserted that the loss to Cook County by reason of this alleged dereliction will amount to over $2,500.000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- There was plenty of wit and humor in the debate on the Currency Bill.

Mr. Shearman, in to-day's TIMES, sets us Americans thinking anew about the South African war. He quotes freely from Fitzpatrick, Britain's partisan, but to the Boers' facts scarcely more than refers. It does him credit to suppose that, like an upright Judge, he has lent an impartial ear to both pleas. Where lie his sympathies, to begin with, is as plain as day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A cablegram from Gen. Otis was received at the War Department to-day giving the first news for some time of the detachments under Cols. Hare and Howze, who are pursuing Aguinaldo. Gen. Otis's advices indicate that they are close up on the insurgent leader, and state that four of the American prisoners have been retaken, though Lieut. Gillmore is still in the hands of the enemy. Gen. Otis's dispatch follows:
Municipal Baltimore is ending the century by the beginning of a reform which embodies a practical test of many of the theories of modern political economy.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Your readers cannot be surprised at the turn events took in the week just ended. I have always said that the pinch would become severe at the end of the year, and I much fear that the new year will bring but temporary relief.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis paid a tribute to the memory of Dwight L. Moody in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Tile subject of Dr. Hillis's sermon was: "The Last of the Great Group; a Study of Mr. Moody's Life, Career, and Message."

ILOILO, Island of Panay, Philippines, Nov. 13. -- This Island of Panay, sister island to Negros and another of the Visayan group, has for months past been in insurgent hands To-day the American forces are taking the aggressive for the first time and are moving out to cover and hold more territory.

At the annual meeting of the Trustees of the Henry McCaddin Memorial Institute, in Berry Street, Brooklyn, the new parish house, connected with Father Sylvester Malone's Church, held yesterday afternoon in the institute, the resigination of Sylvester L. Malone, a nephew of Father Malone, who has managed the building since its opening, was accepted.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Col. Samuel R. Johnstone died from paralysis at his home, 82 East Park Street, East Orange, to-day. He was born in Fairfax County, Va., in 1833. He was a civil engineer and a descendant of George Johnstone, who is said to have written the resolution introduced by Patrick Henry which led to his "liberty or death" speech.

Theodore S. Thorsen, a Swede living on Jersey Street, New Brighton, is in the S.R. Smith Infirmary there, apparently recovering from an attack of typhoid fever which until last week was considered likely to cause his death. He is twenty-eight years old, and was to have been married to-day to Miss Mary Nilson of Tyson Street, New Brighton.

BACOLOT, Island of Nefiros, Nov. 7. -- The mountains of Negros run down its centre and length, and between the foothills of this range and the sea there is a belt of lowlands averaging in width from five to twenty miles. On these lowlands are the farms and plantations producing the island's yearly crop of sugar, all of which is sent to Iloilo, on the Island of Panay, for shipment.

There was a rather unusual mix-up in the weather conditions yesterday which rendered it exceedingly difficult for the weather man to keep his bearings. A taste of each of the seasons was experienced during the twenty-four hours, but Old Winter got the mastery finally and showed up good and strong at the end.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Dec. 24. -- The catboat Lizzie of Somers Point has been missing since last Friday morning. The boat left here on Friday with Capt. John Townsend, Capt. Stimson, and M.C. Boice on board.

" Don't tread on the alligator," is a sign that might be appropriately displayed in the central one of the three big plant houses at Central Park just back of the Magown's Pass Tavern on the East Drive. There are three of the alligators at large in that house, which is devoted to palms and semi-tropical plants.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 24. -- The Jacksonian Club will open the Bryan Presidential campaign here Jan. 8. There will be present at the banquet W.J. Bryan, Gov. Hogg of Texas, Congressman E.W. Carmack of Tennessee, David Overmeyer of Kansas, Carter Harrison of Chicago, John P. Altgeld of Illinois, Champ Clark and Mr. Stone of Missouri, ex-Congressman Charles A. Towne, Coin Harvey, Senator William V. Allen, Henry Watterson of Kentucky, and other prominent Democratic leaders.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 24. -- Shelburne House, the home of Dr. and Mrs. W.S. Webb, was the scene of a pleasant event on Saturday evening when eighteen well-known railroad officials, in behalf of the 4,000 employes of the Wagner Palace Car Company, presented to Dr. Webb, who is President of the corporation, a magnificent loving cup.

Speculators on both sides of the market "evened up" their contracts in so far as they could toward the end of last week, neither bull nor bear deeming it prudent to have large one-sided commitments over a holiday extending from Saturday noon to Tuesday morning -- with so many market-making events possible of development.

In his third annual message, sent to Congress on Dec. 3, 1867, President ANDREW JOHNSON pointed out with a good show of reason the need of an advanced naval outpost between our Atlantic Coast and Europe. "With the possession of such a station by the United States," he declared, "neither we nor any other American nation need longer apprehend injury or offense from any transatlantic enemy.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- National Bank Examiner D.G. Wing, who was last week appointed temporary receiver of the Globe National Bank, gave out a statement to-night in which he says that in the course of his regular examination of the bank's affairs Sept. 9, he found $600,000 of Globe Bank checks outstanding, which did not appear upon the books.

Frank Moss and Francis E. Laimbeer have presented their report as counsel to the Mazet investigating committee. It is in the form of a printed pamphlet of 101 pages, and is addressed to Chairman Robert Mazet.
" Justice to the Christian and the Jew" was the subject of a lecture delivered yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Silverman in Temple Emanu-El, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 24. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company is completing negotiations for the purchase of the Wheeler Steamboat Line, the acquisition of which will give it almost absolute control of the traffic by water and rail of the Maryland and Delaware peninsula. It will operate a fleet of fifteen or twenty steamers between this city and points on the Eastern Shore of the Chesapeake Bay.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- The advance in the Reichsbank rate to 7 per cent. had a great effect upon the security of the market. Values declined only moderately. There was nothing in the nature of a panic, as occurred in New York and London. Notwithstanding the fact that the advance in London exchange continued, reaching yesterday 4 pfennigs above the gold point, gold exports have hitherto been but moderate.

Four alarms were sent in at an early hour yesterday morning for a fire which nearly gutted the six-story brick building 134 and 136 William Street, and also damaged the adjoining structures, Nos. 132 and 138. After an hour of hard fighting the firemen succeeded in getting control of the flames, after they had caused losses aggregating $85,000.

Three members of the 1899 football teams of Yale and Princeton addressed a meeting of men at the West Side Young Men's Christian Association, 318 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon. They were Howard Richards, left half back of the Yale team: H.R. Reiter, right half back of the Princeton team, and S.G. Craig, guard of the Princeton eleven.

DENVER, Dec. 24. -- Judge A.W. Rucker has returned from St. Louis, where he conferred with a number of leading silver men of the country concerning the proposed silver brick suit, which is to be carried into the Supreme Court of the United States. The Judge says no final plan has been adopted, as it is necessary to consult with others before the movement is put under way.

Mr. DORMAN B. EATON was a man of unusual ability and of a very high standard of conduct in the public and private relations of life. He had made for himself an honorable place in the profession of law when in the prime of life he was stricken down by the hand of an intending assassin, whose blow disabled him from active work for several years.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 24. -- The horror of the Braznell Mine disaster, near Brownsville, grows in intensity with every hour. The number of the dead is now estimated at forty, and may pass that figure. At the same time there is a strong presumption that the laws regulating mining were carelessly and probably criminally disregarded.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 24. - Apropos of the reports put in circulation at the time of the death of Major John A. Logan, killed in action in the Philippines, the following letter received to-day by L.S. Leiberman from his son, Dr. B. Albert Leiberman, Major and surgeon of the Thirty-third United States Infantry, (Major Logan's regiment,) effectually disproves the statement that Major Logan was shot by his own men:
BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- On New Year's Day direct telephonic communication will be opened between Berlin and aris.

The Suydam Homestead at Bushwick and Johnson Avenues, Brooklyn, which is over 200 years old, and the oldest of the few Dutch houses now left in the Williamsburg section, will be razed to the ground in a few days. The site has been purchased for church purposes, and when the old structure is demolished, excavations will be begun for the erection of a German church.

Cornelius Vanderbilt made a statement yesterday concerning his failure to appear for jury duty, which was the basis of remarks made in the City Court on Friday by Justice Fitzsimons. Mr. Vanderbilt said:

In his very able speech before the New England Society of Orange Secretary GAGE gave another proof of the advantage it is to the country to have in the Treasury Department a banker who adds to an intimate knowledge of the practical side of his business a careful and intelligent study of its underlying principles and of the relation to it of the functions of Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24. -- Mrs. Thomas Kaerston, a victim of New York thugs, arrived here yesterday on an overland train with her mind and health shattered and the possibility that her reason will never be fully restored.

CAPE HENRY, Va., Dec. 24. -- The British steamer Ariosto, Capt. Baines, bound from Galveston to Hamburg, was wrecked at 4 o'clock this morning, six miles south of Hatteras, N.C., and twenty-one of the crew were drowned. Capt. Baines and eight of the crew were saved by the heroic efforts of the Ocracoke life-saving crew, under Capt. James Howard.

The Christmas decorations were all in place yesterday in Trinity Church. Great bunches of greenery were massed about the pillars, and branches of fir trees decorated the windows, the whole interior presenting a beautiful appearance. There was only a small attendance at the morning service.

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- The theatrical season is now in full swing, and the new pieces absorb the Parisian mind more than anything else, except perhaps the Anglo-Boer war. There are no direct references to Dreyfus on the stage, but Dreyfus preoccupies us all the same. At the Odeon the management is distinctly anti-Dreyfusard.
The letter from Gen. LAWTON read by ex-Minister BARRETT at the New England dinner on Friday evening was of such significance and importance that we reproduce it here in full:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The children at the homes of the Asiatic diplomats will have just as merry a Christmas to-morrow as any Christian boy in America. The Asiatics have adopted the Santa Claus feature of Christmas with great enthusiasm, and that is about the only feature of the sacred holiday that interests the children.

ROME, Dec. 24. -- The Pope solemnly inaugurated the holy year by performing the impressive ceremony of opening the Holy Door of St. Peter's Cathedral at 11 o'clock this morning. The ceremony was performed in the vestibule, which was handsomely decorated, in the presence of the Papal officers, the members of the Diplomatic Corps, leading representatives of the Roman nobility, and a number of invited guests.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The following is Gen. Otis's weekly death report:

There still lingers in the minds of the uninformed and prejudiced so much vague but mischievous animosity toward capitalists, and especially toward bankers, that the following plain statement of fact from the columns of The Financial Chronicle regarding the action of the bankers in the panic of last week on the Stock Exchange is peculiarly timely:
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The War Office has received a cablegram from Gen. Forestieralker, dated at Cape Town yesterday, saying: "Have no further news of the general situation."

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 24. -- The second payments to the tenth annual renewal of the Kentucky Futurity are the biggest in its history. Twenty-nine States are represented and 843 colts and fillies are kept in the event. There are 226 stallons represented, of which 23 have records of 2:10 or better; 153 of the mares have records, and 174 of them are producers.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- A dispatch from Chieveley, dated Tuesday, Dec. 19, says:

Will you allow a workingman to congratulate you on your publication of so many varied and interesting opinions on the South African war in last Sunday's TIMES? It was evident that the majority of them was written by intelligent and unbiased men, and I can assure you that I enjoyed a treat in reading them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25. -- To-day the East and the West lined up on the gridiron, the opposing teams being Carlisle of Pennsylvania and the University of California. Six thousand people witnessed the game. The Berkeley rooters were out in force, but the Indians were not lacking sympathizers.

The Commission on Codification and Revision of the New Jersey School Laws has issued a letter asking for suggestions as to the proposed law known as Senate Bill No. 197. I earnestly beg citizens, parents, taxpayers, Boards of Education, Principals, and teachers to refrain from indorsing this measure until it has been thoroughly discussed in the press, on the public platform, and on the floor of the Legislature.

News from Rome regarding the Christian Brothers, who have protested against the action of their superiors in France, who ordered them to cease teaching the classics in their colleges in this country, has been received in this city. The authorities in Rome are expected to decide against the Brothers.

From the social standpoint New York had yesterday one of the quietest and least eventful Christmases for many years past. The first touch of Winter was rather appropriate, but came too suddenly after the recent warm weather to be entirely agreeable, and the gray skies of the afternoon made the day's close rather dreary.

Since the illness of the Rev. Sylvester Malone, the rector of the Church of Sts. Peter and Paul, in Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn, trouble as alleged has been brewing between the relatives of the dying priest and some of the authorities of the Roman Catholic Church in the Diocese of Brooklyn. A crisis is now reported to be at hand.

The tobacco and pipes with which the soldier at the front is being presented by the people he leaves behind him form the most acceptable and valuable gift he can have. The comforts of tobacco are never more appreciated than on the battlefield.

BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 25. -- Jesse Muncy has been missing since Friday night, and every effort to find him has proved to be of no avail. It is generally believed now that he was murdered and robbed and his body disposed of. No other solution of his total disappearance from the range of country which has been scoured during the past two days can be arrived at.

ALBANY, Dec. 25. -- In their Christmas sermons to-day Bishop Doane. Episcopal, and Bishop Burke, Roman Catholic, touched upon the war in South Africa. Bishop Doane said that righteousness would bring about peace, and added:

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- John Gillies, an operative connected with a private detective agency, is at the County Hospital, probably fatally hurt. According to the story he tells he was hurled from the Twelfth Street Viaduct by two men yesterday and nearly ground to death under the wheels of an incoming train on the Grand Trunk Railway.

The Sumatra, which leaves the Royal Albert Docks to-morrow for the Cape, may be taken by way of illustration, though, as she is conveying not more than about 1,200 men, her supplies represent what those concerned regard as rather a "small" order. To persons unacquainted with these things, however, the quantities will appear formidable enough, especially as the supplies in question refer exclusively to what will be required at sea.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 25. -- The Salvation Army fed many of the poor of the city today. In the morning clothing, together with baskets each containing the materials for a Christmas dinner for five persons, were distributed among needy families from the Y.M.C.A. Building. At 11:30 o'clock 2,500 other poor people, many of them street boys, were given a Christmas dinner in the Grays' armory.

The one thing that nineteen-year-old Harry Haffner of 826 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, desired particularly as a Christmas gift was a writing desk. His mother, conscious of his wish, planned to surprise him with the desk on Christmas morning. The result of that lovingly planned surprise was that the husband and father of the family lay dead last night and Harry, the son, was locked up in the Grand Avenue Police Station, charged with killing him.

The brave policemen who sometimes risk their lives to stop runaway horses have a new and dangerous rival, but this rivalry is only for a share in the perils. As the police force is now constituted, the rival stands no show of promotion. Indeed, he is not eligible to membership, so of course he can never be Chief. He is a wooden Indian.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- Miss Helen Gould gave her usual Christmas dinner today to the little inmates of Woody Crest, which she founded several years ago. This home for little unfortunates is always generously remembered by Miss Gould, and in addition to the dinner each child received a present.
Your editorial in THE TIMES of Friday, the 22d instant, on "The Golden Rule at Washington," suggests a few thoughts on the law of human progress.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Dec. 25. -- The most severe shock of earthquake experienced in this city in fourteen years occurred at 4:25 A.M. to-day. It was accompanied by a loud rumbling noise. The higher buildings in the city were severely shaken, but no serious damage was done. A high wave struck the ocean front soon after the shock, but no damage was done to shipping. A slighter shock followed the first a few seconds later.

I note what your financial column in today's issue says about the obligations of the Stock Exchange regarding industrial securities. If the Exchange does not heed the advice, their business from the public will inevitably shrink, and it will become almost exclusively a business of "insiders" and "professionals" -- "dog eat dog," so to speak.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 25. -- Announcement was made to-day of the retirement of A.N. Stillwell from the presidency of the Guardian Trust Company. This corporation, which was formerly known as the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Trust Company, had its headquarters in Kansas until a few months ago, when the name was changed, the capital increased from $1,250,000 to $2,500,000, and the general offices removed to Chicago.

PRETORIA, Dec. 17. -- Over 509 British prisoners, captured at the battle of Stormberg, have arrived here. They have been taken to Waterfall, to join the other prisoners. An official account of the Boer casualties at the battle of Tugela River says thirty men were killed or wounded.
In an article in The Globe, various mispronunciations are dwelt upon; but it seems to be assumed that they cannot be explained.

Organization Republicans were much interested yesterday in the report made public by Frank Moss, counsel to the Mazet Investigating Committee, in which he presented his case to the committee. There was considerable discussion as to the probability of the committee accepting Mr. Moss's report, and the opinion was freely expressed that the committee would prepare a report of its own to submit to the Legislature.

HAVANA, Dec. 25. -- All the stores in Havana closed at 10 o'clock this morning, and the rest of the day was devoted to conviviality. Only two newspapers appeared with the usual editions. Bands played on the Prado. Americans generally visited friends, most of those having families here giving dinners and inviting others of their acquaintance.

The Christmas Day services at St. Patrick's Cathedral are always beautiful and elaborate, and this year they were, if anything, more elaborate and beautiful than usual. It is difficult to imagine that church music could ever be richer or be produced with greater care as to details than in the solemn pontifical mass at 11 o'clock.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 25. -- James Martin and George Oram ate Christmas dinner together to-day. They had done so before, but until a few days ago it looked as if Martin would eat his Christmas dinner in the State prison at Trenton. He had been sent to that place to serve a term of four years for shooting Oram.
HAVANA, Dec. 25. -- Gov. Gen. Wood says he intends to order work at once upon the highways, which are greatly in need of repair. This will also serve to give employment to a large number of men.

SING SING, Dec. 25. -- The prisoners in [ .ing Sing Prison had a Christmas celebral tion to-day in the Protestant chapel in the form of a minstrel performance. Those who took Dart had been rehearsing for a month or more, and among them were several who had walked the boards of the variety stage before they came to grief and a cell in prison.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- Joseph Tussei, seventy-one years of age, of 31 Stevens Avenue. Mount Vernon, was found in a dying condition at the foot of a stairway in John Aparando's Hotel at 4 o'clock to-day. He was taken to the Mount Vernon Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The War Department made public to-day a statement showing the progress made in relief work in the Island of Puerto Rico between Sept. 25 and Nov. 30, 1899. The population of the island is estimated at 918,,926. The average daily indigent was 221,087 persons; average weekly sick, 17,372, and the average weekly deaths, 632 persons.

The city relinquished most of its customary occupations yesterday to celebrate, with a prodigious amount of turkey and cranberry sauce, the annual feast of Christmas. In countless windows of houses and shops in all parts of the metropolis hung the circular green wreaths, tied often with bright ribbons, that announced the coming once again of the season of peace and good cheer.

Rumors were plentiful last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House regarding an important engagement which it was said Maurice Grau would consummate this morning with the representative of a prominent prima donna.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The contest between Senator Foraker and H. H. Kohlsaat for the honor of the authorship of the gold plank in 1896 is complicated by the appearance of ex-Secretary Alger as a candidate. Mr. Alger, however, divides the credit with Senator Foraker. In a letter to The Washington Post the ex-Secretary says:

A recent decision by the Court of Appeals in the case of the Skaneateles Water Works Company against the village of Skaneateles seems to have some bearing on the Ramapo water contest in this city. According to counsel opposed to the Ramapo contract the relation is remote, but according to counsel for the Ramapo people the Court of Appeals decision sustains the position they have taken.
DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 25. -- Dallas has not known so many bloody affrays in a single day in many years as have been recorded to-day.

You have given your readers and correspondents fair notice that you are not responsible for any opinions expressed by the letters in your columns. On our part we take THE TIMES because, aside of its advocacy of wholesale murder inaugurated by a weak Executive, it is a clean paper, which our wives and children may not blush to read.

Gen. Hector Macdonald, who is to go out to take the place in the staff vacated by Col. Wauchope's lamented death, must be known by name to every reader of the newspapers. His name in the army is "Fighting Mac." Where all are fighters, what a meaning that fact has! He was, after Lord Kitchener himself, the hero of Omdurman.

BERLIN Dec. 25. -- Emperor William celebrated Christmas in the usual manner at New Palace, Potsdam. At 3 o'clock he attended a "bescheerung" given for the First Regiment of the Guards. At 4 he dined with the imperial family, after which there was a "bescheerung" for the members of the imperial family and the Court entourage.

EMILE ZOLA'S account of the forces that shape public opinion on the Continent is not flattering to the intelligence of the French, German, and Russians. M. ZOLA himself, while he is no imperialist, is friendly to Great Britain, as he has good reason to be; but French opinion is on the side of the Boers. He gives the reasons:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The case of Nicholas Davis of Troop B, Third Cavalry, having been reported to Gen. Merritt, commanding the Department of the East at New York, he has authorized the committal of the man to the Government Hospital for the Insane near this city.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 14. -- The citizens of British Guiana, in the enjoyment of a franchise of practically republican character, which was originally secured to the colony by treaty of capitulation, and has since then been liberally modified or extended to meet changing conditions, are indignant at a recent misrepresentation about their Constitution to which currency has been given in the United States.

BOSTON, Dec. 25. -- The splendid new Masonic Temple erected on the site of the old building burned some time ago is to be dedicated with appropriate ceremonies next Wednesday. The day is the feast of St. John the Evangelist, the patron saint of Freemasons throughout the world.

The eight chess representatives from Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton began their eighth annual tournament yesterday afternoon at the Columbia Grammar School, at 2 o'clock, at which time Edward A. Caswell, the manager of this intercollegiate event, formally opened the proceedings with a speech of welcome.

Co-operation among New York bankers of importance is likely to show early security market consequence -- or, at least, may much influence the course of the local money market. Nothing at all sensational is impending or contemplated, as some curious Wall Street efforts try to suggest; but energetic, straightforward businesslike plans are under way to relieve pressure in quarters where damage has been inflicted or threatened.

Honors were pretty evenly divided in the Christmas Day shoot of the Carteret Gun Club, which was held on its well-appointed. grounds at Garden City. Two cup events were scheduled, the first, the December Cup, was won by H.G. Browne, with a score of nine kills out of his selection, and R. Stuart captured the Christmas Day Cup with eight kills, which, with the allowance accorded with his handicap rise, made a clean score.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- Baron Ludlow of Heywood, former Recorder of Exeter and subsequently Judge of the Court of Appeal, died to-day in his seventy-third year.

There wasn't another man along the Bowery yesterday so much talked about as Senator Timothy D. Sullivan. There never is at this time of year, when the Senator gives his annual Christmas dinner to the lodging house population, which turns out en masse and surges about the doors of the Metamora Club.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 25. -- The Salvation Army fed 3,500 poor at a dinner to-day, and also distributed 1,500 baskets of provisions, which together are equivalent to giving a dinner to 8,000 poor people.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Clyde H. Wallace, a clerk in the United States Sub-Treasury in this city, was arrested to-day on the charge of having stolen $5,000 in gold from the office. The young man is said to have made a full confession to the secret service officials.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- Gov. Roosevelt has signed the letters patent granting to the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company three grants of land aggregating 16.31 acres at Astoria. The Governor signed the letters patent just as soon as he was informed by Attorney General Davies that the proceedings in the Supreme Court instituted by Corporation Counsel Whalen of New York City had been discontinued on stipulation by the complainant.
Speaking yesterday of the fining of Cornelius Vanderbilt $100 for contempt of court in not responding to a jury summons last January, Judge Fitzsimons of the City Court said:

The differences between John C. Calhoun of this city and Patrick Calhoun of Cleveland, Ohio, the grandsons of John C. Calhoun of South Carolina, over the proper division of the profits and losses of several enterprises in which they were jointly interested, have led to a suit brought against Patrick Calhoun by his brother in the New York Supreme Court for the recovery of $115,383.43.
