WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Mr. Roberts, the Director of the Mints, was asked to-day whether the present monetary stringency in his opinion signified an actual scarcity of money to meet the present requirements of trade. He said:

Not only has individual opinion in France been made a subject for universal applause or contempt through the cause celebre which has agitated that country for the last two years, but the problems which have grown out of the question of justice to the individual have forced the political parties of the republic to dissolve and to reorganize themselves within definite and conspicuous lines.

The Social Reform Club attacked the question of bridges versus tunnels at its headquarters, 45 University Place, last night. Alfred R. Conkling, the principal speaker, appeared for "the defendant, tunnels,'' as he expressed it, and found that no one rose to oppose his view. He read the report of W. Barclay Parsons, Chief Engineer of the Rapid Transit Commission, on the question at issue, which report is included in a pamphlet issued by Controller Coler.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- The Public Prosecutor this afternoon began his closing speech before the Senate High Court in the conspiracy cases. He reviewed the evidence, which, he said, showed the conspiracy was more dangerous "than when the Comte de Paris so forgot the traditions of his family as to join hands with Gen. Boulanger."

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- As a result of the telegrams sent to Los Angeles, Cal., stating that Aaron Wolfsohn, on the finding of whose supposed body the New York Life Insurance Company paid the Public Administrator of his estate $10,000, was alive in this city, Attorney Edward O'Bryan of the company received several messages to-day asking for a confirmation.

Thomas F. Ryan, the complainant in the litigation now going forward in Virginia and North Carolina to prevent the consolidation of the Seaboard Air Line with two roads owned by the Williams syndicate, known as the Georgia and Alabama and the Florida Central and Peninsular, sent yesterday the following telegram setting forth the reasons of his opposition to John Skelton Williams:

It is evident that the Mazet committee and especial5' its Chairman is vexed at tile report of Mr. Moss, and everything possible is being done to belittle it. In this tlle committee has the sympathy and coSperation of Mr. PLATT, who ostentatiously declares that he has not read the report, ar, d that no action will be based on it.
The theory of the majority leaders that they will have a short session of the Legislature this year is very unlikely to be carried out.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- William R. Hill came to this city in 1888 to work with J.J.R. Croes of New York City, who was investigating the best source of water supply for Syracuse. He was principal assistant on that work, after which he returned to Brooklyn and had charge of the erection of the superstructure of the Fifth Avenue elevated railroad.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Under to-day's date Gen. Otis at Manila reports some details of engagements with the insurgents following the death of Gen. Lawton. His dispatch follows:

One of the Third Avenue Railroad Company's new electric cars took fire yesterday afternoon. The occupants, about thirty in number, were thrown into a state of panic. They made a wild rush for the door, breaking seats and windows in their eagerness to escape. Two women fainted, one of whom, Mrs. Annie Reinhardt, of 2,251 Third Avenue, it is alleged, received a severe electric shock.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 26. -- The lumber plant of the Perkins Manufacturing Company and the Georgia Iron Works, owned by the Perkins Manufacturing Company, were completely destroyed by fire, the origin of which is unknown. The total loss was about $175,000, divided as follows: Lumber plant, including machinery and finished lumber stored in yards, $125,000; Georgia Iron Works, mill and machinery, $50,000.

The Eagle is gratified to announce the established improvement in health of the Rev. Dr. Storrs. His arrival at the point from which recovery of strength can be declared was more gradual than was expected when he resigned the pastorate of the Church of the Pilgrims; but the resignation itself, in shutting him out from the sense of official responsibility, became a factor in the restoration of his strength, which is steadily being effected.

WASHINTON, Dec. 26. -- The negotiations which have been in progress for some time between China and Mexico for a general treaty of trade, navigation, and immigration have been brought to a successful conclusion here, and the formal signing of the document was completed at the Mexican Embassy, Senor Aspiroz, the Mexican Ambassador, signing for his country, and Minister Wu Ting Fang for China.

MANILA, Dec. 26. -- Col. J. Franklin Bell of the Thirty-sixth Infantry encountered 150 Filipinos Thursday near Alaminos, Province of Zambales, and killed, wounded, or captured 28 of them. Our troops also obtained possession of a number of rifles and a quantity of ammunition. One American was wounded.

The selection of Col. EDWARD M. HOFFMAN as the successor of Gen. ANDREWS in the office of Adjutant General is on the same high level as the other appointments made by the Governor in connection with the military service of the State. Col. HOFFMAN has been in close sympathy with the change in the military administration by which the staff organization was introduced and has had an important part in connection with it.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 26. -- C.H. Canby Co., a private wire Board of Trade grain house, to-day refused to accept 170,000 bushels of wheat on account of the firm of Barrett, Farnum Co. The grain was tendered through Jackson Brothers. The offer presumably was made to liquidate a purchase of December wheat made on 'Change by C.H. Canby Co., prior to the failure of Barrett, Farnum Co.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 26. -- James K. Hackett and company produced to-night at Ford's Opera House before a large audience the four-act play "The Pride of Jennico," this being its first performance on any stage. The play is a dramatization of the novel of the same name, and is the work of Abby Sage Richardson and Grace L. Furniss, authors of "Americans at Home" and "A Colonial Girl."

The North Side Board of Trade held its annual election of officers last evening at its rooms, One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street and Alexander Avenue. About sixty members were present. The Nominating Committee, composed of ex-Judge Ernest Hall, Henry A. Gumbleton, Col. Joseph A. Goulden, and Frederick A. Saward, presented the following ticket which was unanimously elected, there being but one ticket in the field:

SAN JACINTO, Cal., Dec. 26. -- The earthquake of yesterday left this little city scene of desolation to-day. People are beginning to recover from the terror inspired by the shock which centred here and destroyed every brick building in the town, and some definite estimates of the damage wrought can now be made.

The Executive Committee of the Kings County Democratic General Committee met and organized last night. Bridge Commissioner John L. Shea was re-elected Chairman. The other officers elected are Frank E. O'Reilly, Secretary, and Michael H. Keeley, clerk.

It is not wonderful that Gen. GATACRE'S order should already have been likened to the procedures of Gen. WEYLER in Cuba and the Dutch farmers whom it affects be described as "reconcentrados." In one way the comparison is most unjust to the British commander. The Spanish General "concentrated" the natives of Cuba to prevent them from acting against him or from giving information to his enemies.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 26. -- The Siegel-Hillman Dry Goods Company, which operated a large department store here, to-day filed a deed of trust to secure all its creditors. The liabilities of the firm are placed at about $225,000, and its assets at about the same amount. Thomas H. McKittrick of the Hargadine-McKittrick Dry Goods Company, one of the heaviest creditors, was named as trustee.

It is net surprising to learn that a difference of opinion exists between Gen. MILES and Gen. CORBIN upon a question relating to the efficiency of the army. Such differences between the General commanding the army and the Generals commanding bureaus of the War Department have been frequent and have become painfully public within the last two years.

Charlton T. Lewis, President of the New York Prison Association, who went to Cuba on behalf of that and other organizations in the United States, has made a report to the Secretary of War in regard to the penal institutions on the island. He contends that this Government is responsible for their condition, and says that a truthful description of the prisons would arouse universal indignation.

What appears to be an interesting little mystery was placed in the hands of the police of the Butler Street Station, Brooklyn, last night by James Murphy, manager of a tea store at Court and Wyckoff Streets. The supposed mystery is in the shape of a traveling bag containing a number of articles of woman's attire of expensive make and fashionable cut.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The newspapers continue actively discussing and criticising the management, or rather mismanagement, of the campaign. The advent of horse sickness throws increased attention upon the question of transports and the want of wagons, which may tie the British forces to the railways.

Santa Claus was twenty-four hours late in getting around to the sick children in the New York Hospital, but that he had not forgotten them was proved by the beautiful silvery Christmas tree that blossomed in the nursery ward of the institution last night, every twig twinkling with colored lights and every branch bending low with its glorious fruit.

Within the past two weeks parts of the cargoes of three vessels bound from this port to Delagoa Bay, South Africa, have been virtually seized by the British authorities. The object of these proceedings was, it is admitted, the prevention of supplies reaching the Boers through Lorenzo Marques, the port of Delagoa Bay.

The question of refunding money to purchasers of tickets to the grand opera performances at the Metropolitan Opera House during the remaining part of this season has been the subject of serious consideration by Maurice Grau, Manager Frank Sanger, and the Directors of the Grau Opera Company ever since last Saturday.

Play in the intercollegiate chess tournament between Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton at the Columbia Grammar School was continued yesterday, when the eight competitors met in the second round of the series. The experience obtained by the players in the opening games on Monday proved to have had a beneficial effect, and in consequence there was a marked increase in steadiness observable in all of yesterday's contests.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 26. -- The Bank of Montreal to-day subscribed $10,000 to the relief fund for the British soldiers in South Africa. The Directors of the band added $7,500 to this amount in personal subscriptions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin's list of subscriptions to the Lawton home fund aggregated $15,000 at noon today. The committee announces that the subscription lists will be kept open until Jan. 5 next, when the money will be banked and placed to Mrs. Lawton's credit.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 26. -- At a conference of representatives of the Southern Railway Company and the Seaboard Air Line recently held in New York it was decided that the two companies will, during the coming year at least, maintain existing rates.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 26. -- The big Johnson Line steamer Noranmore arrived here this afternoon light from Liverpool after one of the most tempestuous passages on record. Capt. Richardson, her commander, reported having seen an unknown bark founder at sea with her crew of twelve men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Secretary of War and Mrs. Root gave their first entertainment of the season at their Washington home this evening, when they invited a distinguished company to meet Sir Henry Irving at supper after the play. The Root residence, at 1,626 Rhode Island Avenue, is one of the show mansions of the capital, and admirably adapted for entertaining.

FREEPORT, L.I., Dec. 26. -- An attempt was made this afternoon to kidnap the three-year-old daughter of Riley Raynor of this village. The attempt was led by Mrs. Raynor, the child's mother. One arrest has been made in the case, and another will be made as soon as the man wanted can be located.

As a reader of THE TIMES, and as a Catholic, I protest against the paragraph in to-day's issue headed "Father Malone in Peril." In peril of what? The innuendo is clearly conveyed that the Catholic authorities in Brooklyn are attempting to commit murder. The Catholic authorities are Bishop McDonnell, his Vicar General, Mgr. McNamara, and four or five of the senior priests of the diocese, all life-long friends of the dying priest.

We set forth yesterday the peculiar hardships and difficulties under which Great Britain labors in the present war by reason of the Portuguese ownership of Delagoa Bay. The "hinterland" of that piece of water is the South African Republic. It the owners of the hinterland and beneficiaries of the port were also the owners of the port, a blockade of it would already have been established and become effective.

When the Mazet committee meets to prepare its report to the Assembly as it will this week, John Proctor Clarke of counsel will present a resume of the evidence and a number of suggestions for emergency charter amendments, and this report will, it was said yesterday on good authority, be used by the committee in drafting its final report.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27. -- Archbishop Kane to-day received a communication from Mgr. Martinelli, the Apostolic Delegate at Washington, saying that the recent decree issued from Rome regarding indulgences and other favors from the Pope does not in any way abridge the privileges heretofore held by Bishops and Archbishops of issuing dispensations for mixed marriages.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 27. -- John Y. Dater, editor of The Ramsey's Journal, and his wife are once more members of the Christian Reformed Church. There is a possibility they will be the only recognized members of the church of that denomination which has been located at Ramsey's.

Col. Edward M. Hoffman of Gen. Roe's staff, to whom was tendered the office of Adjutant General, to succeed Gen. Andrews, resigned, telegraphed his acceptance of the position to Gov. Roosevelt yesterday.

A fire in a tenement house at 182 Avenue A early yesterday morning drove several families out of their rooms temporarily, and also proved that a Maltese cat owned by a German woman in the house is an exceedingly faithful animal.

The Produce Exchange Trust Company, which suspended payments Dec. 18, will open its doors and resume business on Wednesday morning, Jan. 10, 1900. This was made possible yesterday by Edwin Gould and Gen. Samuel Thomas advancing $2,500,000, each subscribing half, to enable the company to pay its depositors.

We observe that our esteemed contemporary The Sun differs from our interpretation of the treaty of 1794 as justifying the British seizure of American breadstuffs bound to Delagoa Bay. There is no dispute that the terms of the treaty justify the seizures, subject to the obligation of Great Britain to pay the value of the goods seized, including freight, demurrage, and a "reasonable mercantile profit."

The Berlin dispatch announcing that Germany has abandoned her intention to buy the Danish West Indies will be read with satisfaction in this country. The reasons why it will be better for us and better for Germany if she do not come into possession of St. Thomas, within forty miles of our own island of Puerto Rico and only a thousand miles from Key West, are many and convincing.

HAVANA, Dec. 27. -- Warrants are out for the rearrest of three of the Custom House Appraisers recently released. Two Custom House brokers and six other men were arrested to-day in connection with the charge of defrauding the Government, but were released in $2,000 bail each. The cases will be pushed to the uttermost.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- Winston Churchill's new arrival at Chievely Camp is perhaps responsible for some overcoloring of the gravity of the situation, but all to-day's news conveys the impression that Gen. Buller may be intending another attack upon the Boer position.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Controller of the Currency Charles G. Dawes passed through Chicago to-day en route for Springfield, where he will address a gathering of State Republicans. Concerning the recent financial panic and present conditions, the Controller said:

Jesse C. Bennett Co. have s01d for Alexander Cash to an investor the four-story brow.nstone front dwelling 148 West Seventy-fifth Street, 20 by 60 by 102.2. The house is now under lease at an annual rental of $2,400.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Senator Chandler, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections, said to-day that the committee would begin its formal inquiry into the contest over the seat of Senator Clark of Montana on Friday, Jan. 5. The counsel on both sides will be heard on that date, and they will be followed on Saturday and Monday by the witnesses for the complainants.

LIMA, Ohio, Dec. 27. -- James Poorman, arrested here to-day, has been conducting a school of crime, according to the stories of Aggie Scanlan, aged eight years, and of others to the police. The Scanlan girl said that Poorman instructed her and several others to mingle with crowds in retail stores, to pick up articles from the counters.

VIENNA, Dec. 27. -- At the Chess Club in this city the seventh round of the Kolisch memorial chess tournament was contested to-day. The pairing was Prock vs. Schlechter, Brody vs. Zinkl, Maroczy vs. Wolf, Schwarz vs. Albin, Kortc vs. Alapin, and Popiel vs. Marco.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Among the letters received to-day at the office of the Adjutant General of the Army containing subscriptions to the fund for the widow of Gen. Lawton, was one from Lewis Cass Ledyard of New York, as follows:

A special three hours' session of the Grand Jury was held yesterday to investigate the complaints made by William F. Sheehan, counsel for the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, concerning rumors circulated in Wall Street regarding a receiver for the company. Three witnesses testified before the Grand Jury last Friday and ten more were present yesterday.

HAVANA, Dec. 27. -- Gen. Wood says that one of the first things he looked into after his arrival was the management of Cuban prisons. Investigation has proved that, even among American prisoners alone, there has been an average detention of five months without trial. There are many things calling for immediate attention, particularly in the matter of sleeping accommodations.

ITHACA, Dec. 27. -- At the opening session of the twelfth annual meeting of the American Economic Association held here this morning President Arthur T. Hadley of Yale University, who is also President of the association, delivered his annual address, taking for his subject "Economic Theory and Political Morality."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Gen. Gilbert S. Carpenter, who was recently confirmed as Brigadier General in the regular army, has been placed on the retired list on his own application, after thirty years' active service. His last assignment was in command of the Eighteenth Infantry in the Philippines.

Harry Oppenheimer, nineteen years old, met a tragic death in an early morning fire yesterday in the apartment house at 579 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn. The young man, overcome with fear, leaped from a fourth-story window and was killed on the pavement below.

MANILA, Dec. 27. -- Col. Lockett, with a force of 2,500, including artillery, attacked this morning a strong force of insurgents intrenched in the mountains near Montalban, about five miles northeast of San Mateo. The enemy were completely routed, the Americans pursuing them through the hills, amid which they fled in every direction.

The Central Board of Education held its final meeting for 1899 yesterday afternoon. Thirteen Commissioners were present. Ninety teachers were retired on pension. This is said to be the largest number of teachers retired at one time in the history of the Department of Education. Each retirement is to date from Dec. 31, 1899.

BOSTON, Dec. 27. -- The Boston and Albany stockholders voted to-day in favor of the lease of the road to the New York Central, the vote standing: Yes, 186,652; no, 15,971 shares. This action was taken at special meeting of the stockholders held at the South Terminal Station.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Winston Spencer Churchill has cabled and The Morning Post publishes to-day an account of his escape from captivity with the Boers, after having been taken prisoner in the reconnoissance of an armored train at Estcourt.
PIETERMARITZBURG, Dec. 28. -Gen. Sir Charles Warren, commanding the Fifth Division, arrived here last evening with his staff, and immediately proceeded for the front.

Elliot Danforth, the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee, returned to the city yesterday from a brief trip through the South. Danforth conferred with Chairman Jones of the National Committee and other leaders and he comes back, he says, with the impression that the National Convention will be held either in Milwaukee or Kansas City.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Dec. 27. -- An appeal to the world to provide funds for the continuation of the work begun and for twenty years carried on by the late Dwight L. Moody was issued to-day by the Trustees of the Northfield Seminary. This plea will be the only action taken by the Trustees until their meeting a month hence. The plea is entitled "Moody Memorial Endowment," and begins:

BOSTON, Dec. 27. -- F.S. Monnett, Attorney General of Ohio, delivered an address to-night before the Twentieth Century Club on "Abdication of Sovereignty," in which he pointed out the necessity for controlling transportation in order to control the trusts.

Mrs. Annie Reinhardt of 2,251 Third Avenue, who was shocked Tuesday afternoon while riding on a Third Avenue trolley car, which took fire at Eighty-fourth Street, is still in an unconscious and critical condition at her home. Her physician, Dr. Pauer, insists that she displays undoubted symptoms of having received an electric shock.

Some opposition to the regular ticket named by the Nominating Committee of the New York Athletic Club has already appeared. The name of Walter S. Wilson was posted last evening on the bulletin board for the office of governor, and many favorable comments thereon were heard. Mr. Wilson has many friends, and his candidacy is considered very strong.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 27. -- This evening the first large ball of the season took place at Horticultural Hall, Philadelphia, given by the Benedicts. It was a representative affair, and the invitations were limited to only 300. For many years the Benedicts' ball has been regarded as the most exclusive function of the Winter in Philadelphia society, and the ball last night was no exception to those of former years.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27. -- Suit has been brought by Mrs. Ida M. Fraser of Pasadena against her husband, Dr. J.C. Fraser, for divorce. Mrs. Lucy S. Scribner of New York City is named as one of the co-respondents.

Corporation Counsel Whalen yesterday took exception to some of the language used by Gov. Roosevelt in his message to the State Land Board accompanying his approval of the grant to the Astoria Light, Heat, and Power Company.

It is pleasant to receive from all quarters such assurances concerning the capacity and integrity of the new engineer of the Aqueduct Commission, the successor of Mr. FTELEY. It is especially reassuring to know that Mr. HILL has been an associate of Mr. CROES. From that association the ideas of Mr. CROES about water supply can hardly have helped making their way into the mind of his former associate.
LONDON, Dec. 27. -- A special correspondent of The Daily Chronicle, telegraphing from Sterkstroom, Cape Colony, Dec. 21, says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Mrs. John A. Logan has just received a letter from Mrs. Henry W. Lawton, written at Manila after the death of Mrs. Logan's son. Its receipt just after the death of the writer's husband gives it pathetic interest. Mrs. Lawton wrote:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Mail advices have reached the War Department in regard to the crushing defeat administered by Wheaton's brigade to the insurgents near San Jacinto early in November, in which engagement Major John A. Logan lost his life.

BOSTON, Dec. 27. -- E.C. Hodges Co., bankers and brokers of 53 State Street, suspended business to-day. The firm is one of the largest in the city, with dealings principally in municipal bonds, and holds memberships in the Boston and New York Stock Exchanges and the Chicago Board of Trade.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 27. -- Col. J. Frank Supplee, City Register, to-day explained away the mystery surrounding the New York syndicate which has made an offer to Baltimore City for the Western Maryland Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The remains of 151 of the dead sailors of the Maine, brought from Cuba by the Texas, arrived here this morning, and were conveyed to Rosslyn, Va., opposite the District, and there transferred to wagons belonging to the Quartermaster's Department, which removed them to the burial site in Arlington Cemetery.

A report was printed yesterday to the effect that the Dewey arch was in a dangerous condition and that consequently danger signals were displayed to warn passers-by not to go near it. It is true that red lanterns were shown on Tuesday night and last night, but it is not correct to say that the arch, or any part of it, is in danger of falling.

Judging by the result of the conference held yesterday morning at the office of the Department of Public Parks between officials of the Manhattan Railway Company and Park Commissioner Clausen, the question of the removal of the elevated railway structure from Battery Park is still far from being solved.

SUMMIT, N.J., Dec. 27. -- The residents of this town have for several weeks been discussing the death of its leading jeweler, Louis Mandelstam, who died on Nov. 2 in the German Hospital in New York after a four weeks' siege of illness. His death was thought to be due to jaundice at the time. Since then a good deal of speculation has been indulged in.

I see frequent communications in your paper on the "Boer" and "Boers." That there will continue to be a diversity of opinion on the "Boer" question I don't doubt, but there is a kind of "Bore" that there can be no doubt about. I have in my mind the gentlemen who are invited to respond to toasts at the New England dinners.

Argument upon Warner E. Allen's application for an injunction restraining the officials of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company from offering, advertising, or paying a reward of $25,000 for the detection of the person who started the rumor which led up to the raid on the company's stock a few days ago, was heard by Justice Beekman in the Supreme Court yesterday.

Interest was heightened in the trial of Roland B. Molineux yesterday by the introduction of a new line of testimony by Assistant District Attorney Osborne. The jurors for three weeks had been listening to evidence relating to handwriting, and it was evident that they were wearying of the many technicalities introduced by the experts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- The committee appointed by creditors to investigate the accounts of Stahl Straub, brokers, who failed Nov. 29, report that the total liabilities amount to $1,221,308, and assets $927,478, leaving a deficiency of $293,830.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 28. -- Prof. Ferdinand Curtis, who conducts a private school at Brookfield, near this city, his son, and a driver had a narrow escape from being gored to death by a bull which a farmer was leading to Danbury to be butchered. The sight of the wagon maddened the bull, which suddenly broke from the man who was leading it and charged at the vehicle.

Prejudice dies hard, and hardest of all when it is inspired by envy and covetousness and based on ignorance. During the late debate in the House of Representatives on the Currency bill several members of the opposition denounced the National banks for their possession of a monopoly of note issues, and declared that these notes were a source of great profit to the banks and of real peril to the note holders.

The probabilities are that a hotel on the site of the old Brunswick, and facing on Madison Square, will soon be ill process of construction. New York, Boston, and Philadelphia capitalists have the matter in hand.

It is generally assumed that the Senate Finance bill does not differ materially from the bill passed by the House, except in its provision for funding. This is a mistake. A careful comparison of the two bills shows that they vary not only in some considerable details, but in the treatment of the radical purpose of both, the firm establishment of the gold standard. In this the House bill is much the better.

By all means the silliest of the rumors which have gained more or less currency about the war in South Africa is that which was yesterday published in New York. Probably it was not published in London, for its silliness would there have been at once apparent. It was a rumor that the South African Republic was preparing to seize Delagoa Bay, or to acquire it for its own uses.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The St. James's Gazette, in an editorial to-day on the Lokal Anzeiger's reported treaty, says it is "a mere patchwork of previous reports, some partly true and some entirely false."

SING SING, Dec. 28. -- Six keepers were discharged from the State prison here tonight. They are T.M. Cronin, John Durkin, E.T. Smith, John Corcoran, George Kirch, and Martin Croak. They are all Democrats. The reduction in the number of keepers is said to be necessary to keep within the appropriation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The transport Lennox arrived at Manila Dec. 20, and the transport Siam Dec. 22. These vessels took out a cargo of horses and mules, the Lennox from San Francisco and the Siam from Honolulu.

GALESBURG. Ill., Dec. 2. -- By a vote of 17,097 to 76 the Covenant Mutual Life Association of this city to-day decided to amalgamate with the Northwestern Life Assurance Company or Chicago. The 28,000 members of the Covenant Mutual Life Assurance Association, whose policies aggregate $45,000,000, will go over to the Northwestern Company in a body.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 28. -- Attorney General Wiley N. Nash, whose term of office expires in January, has created consternation in insurance circles by filing a bill of information in the Hinds County Circuit Court declaring that all insurance companies doing business in the State and acknowledging allegiance to the Southeastern Tariff Association have violated the State law regarding trusts and combines.

HAVANA, Dec. 28. -- Gen. Wood's office is besieged from early morn until after dark by a crowd of office seekers from all parts of the island. The applicants want everything or anything -- from Cabinet Secretaryships to Janitorships. Despite the fact that the Governor General receives on the average 200 people every twenty-four hours, he manages to find time to pay unexpected early morning visits to the asylums and jails.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Horatio Rubens, prominently identified with the Cuban cause, who was counsel for the Cuban Junta during the revolution, and is now associated with Senor Quesada in the Cuban representation here, returned this morning from a visit to Cuba. Speaking of the situation in the island, he said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Nothing is known here of the reported intention of Great Britain and Germany to partition Portuguese East Africa between them, Great Britain taking the country around Delagoa Bay and southward and Germany the northern half of the territory, which adjoins the German East African possessions.

In letters recently received from persons in Dublin by friends in New York it is stated that in recognition of Richard Croker's aid in raising funds in this city for the preservation of the Parnell estate at Avondale, County Wicklow, Ireland, the Lord Mayor of Dublin has suggested to the Municipal Council of that city the propriety of placing a bust of Mr. Croker in a prominent place in the Council Chamber.
LONDON, Dec. 29. -- A dispatch to The Daffy Mail from Pietermaritzburg dated Dee. 23 says:

The discreet indiscretion of Mr. Moss in a premature publication of what the Mazet committee had found out is likely to have some very amusing consequences. The apprehension and alarm with which the procedures of the counsel have been viewed by the committee and the committee's boss are readily explicable.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 28. -- The Senate late this afternoon killed the Pingree joint resolution for the submission of a Constitutional amendment permitting the amending of the State tax laws. It had been passed by the House, but was defeated in the Senate by a vote of 16 to 13. The large number of votes against the proposition was a surprise.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 28. -- The will of Daniel Sharp Ford, publisher of The Youth's Companion, filed for probate in the Middlesex County Probate Court to-day, disposes of an estate of about $2,500,000.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- The New York Central stockholders at a meeting at noon to-day voted on $68,500,000 worth of stock unanimously in favor of ratification of the lease of the Boston and Albany Railroad.

One of the largest deals ever closed, involving vacant property in the Borough of the Bronx, has just been concluded through Broker William M. Ryan. For the Simpson estate he has sold the large tract lying west of the Southern Boulevard and south of Westchester Avenue at a price reported to be about $375,000.

Actual charge of the affairs of the Produce Exchange Trust Company was assumed yesterday by Edwin Gould and Gen. Samuel Thomas, the new President and Vice President, respectively, of the reorganized company. They were at the offices of the company all day examining the books and looking into everything appertaining to the administration of the company up to the time of its suspension.

The fame of Schweighofer has spread and a full house was ready for his appearance in a new cast at the Irving Place Theatre last evening. Instead of flitting from one part to another, as in "Ein Blitzmadel," he has a consistent character to portray, that of the old, useless fellow on a Styrian farm, Annerl the "nullity," or nobody, in the well-known rustic drama by Carl Morre.

The December Grand Jury was discharged yesterday by Judge Cowing after returning a presentment in the matter of the investigation of Wall Street rumors regarding the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company. No indictment was found. The Grand Jury declared that the time at its disposal was too short for a proper examination of the charges before it, and recommended that they be taken up by the January Grand Jury.

As though it were not cold enough in the open air yesterday, Mrs. Sisrei Rischmond was locked in the icebox in her husband's butcher shop at 204 Madison Avenue in the forenoon and allowed to remain there for over two hours. The woman accuses her husband's business partner, JOseph Epstein, of having treated her with this coldness.

The fourth round of the annual intercollegiate chess tournament between Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton at the Columbia Grammar School yesterday was a battle royal between the representatives of Columbia and Harvard, who are rivals, as they have always been, for the honors of supremacy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- To-day the Inter-State Commerce Commission, in compliance with the request of the freight shippers and representatives of the commercial interests, transmitted to Attorney General Griggs a transcript of the evidence taken at the hearing last week respecting the new classification of freight made by the official Classification Committee.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- A correspondent of The Standard at Lorenzo Marques says: "Delagoa Bay is the residence of Herr Pott, a Hollander, who is Consul General for the Transvaal and Consul for The Netherlands. Pott is the principal medium between Pretoria and Dr. Leyds, in Europe. He controls The Netherlands Railway through the Transvaal, and is the head of the Transvaal customs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Objection to the proposed merging of the Wagner Palace Car-Company into the Pullman Palace Car Company, on the ground that it will create a trust in and a monopoly of the sleeping and parlor car business, is made in a bill filed to-day in the Circuit Court of Cook County by Truman A. Taylor of Alton, Ill., one of the shareholders of the Pullman Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Upon the windy heights of Arlington Cemetery the Maine dead, brought from Havana by the battleship Texas, to-day were laid away in their final resting place with simple religious services and the impressive honors of war in the presence of the President, members of his Cabinet, officers of the army and navy, and other representatives of the Government.

BERLIN. Dec. 28. -- The German press continues to comment upon the war in South Africa. The Militair-Wechenblatt, the military organ, contains a severe criticism by a high officer, in which the writer claims that hitherto the Boers, both leaders and men have proved far more efficient in every way than the British.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Senator Kyle of South Dakota, who has been classed in the Congressional Directory, presumably upon his own authority, as an independent in politics, but who repeatedly has voted with the Republicans, has come out in a declaration that will justify the makers of the Directory hereafter in classifying him as a Republican in name as well as in fact.

Final plans for the legislative campaign at Albany during the session which will begin next Wednesday were discussed yesterday morning over breakfast at the Fifth Avenue Hotel between Gov. Roosevelt, Senator Platt, and Chairman Odell. The talk lasted over three hours, and then the Governor hurried away to catch a train for Albany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Assistance Secretary of War Meiklejohn has written a letter to Representative Long of Kansas, defining the policy of the department regarding the commerce of the Philippines with especial reference to the opening of ports for the exportation of hemp.

The will of the late John I. Blair, who died at his home, in Blairstown, N.J., on Dec. 2, was probated yesterday at Belvidere, the county seat of Warren County, N.J. Surrogate Sharp, out of courtesy, went to the home of De Witt C. Blair, and there had the will proved.

Mrs. Lucy S. Scribner, widow of J. Blair Scribner, who resides at 763 Fifth Avenue, yesterday made a sweeping denial of the charge brought against her by Mrs. Ida M. Frazer in her application for a divorce from Dr. J.C. Fraser of Pasadena, Cal. The news that Mrs. Scribner has been made the co-respondent in the Fraser divorce case reached this city yesterday through a dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Prof. WOOLSEY is right. We had overlooked the fact that the last article of the treaty contained the agreement that "the first ten articles of this treaty shall be permanent, and that the subsequent articles, except the twelfth, shall be limited in their duration to twelve years, to be computed from the day when the ratifications of this treaty shall be exchanged."

Mr. Saunders and the editor have told us all in these columns what books we should read. Still better, they have told us how to read them. May a word be said now in suggestion of the importance of where we read? It makes a big difference, and particularly with poetry.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 29. -- Under a plan recommended to the stockholders of the Great Northern Railway by President James J. Hill and the management, the capital stock of the road will be increased 10 per cent. in February and the employes of the road given an opportunity to invest in the issue at par.

As a result of it investigation, the committee representing creditors of Harper Brothers, whose claims aggregate about one-half the total indebtedness of the company, has sent to every creditor a blank form of an agreement providing for deposit with the committee of all claims against the corporation.

SEATTLE, Washington, Dec. 29. -- In an attempt to rob a Ballard street car late last night a highwayman was shot and killed. There were eight passengers aboard when two men wearing masks boarded the car, one at the front and the other at the rear. One of the passengers named Plimpton opened fire on the highwayman entering the car from the rear, and three shots were returned.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The following telegram has been received by the Supervising Surgeon General of the United States Marine Hospital Service from Surgeon D.A. Carmichael, at Honolulu:

The December salaries of the public school teachers are payable on Jan. 15, but it is now said that there is danger of delay owing to a further muddle. The salaries are paid out of the general school fund and of the proceeds of the sale of revenue bonds under the provisions of the Ahearn law.

The members of the Council yesterday adopted a resolution denouncing the war in the Philippines. Subsequently, after a speech by Councilman Stewart M. Brice, who served as a volunteer officer in the Cuban campaign, the vote was reconsidered, and the resolution was placed on file, in effect, killing it.
We hear often of the cosmopolitan character of New York. Perhaps in no way is it more evident than in the number of periodicals printed within its borders in foreign tongues.

Some painter made a reputation for himself by depicting on canvas a deadly combat between a bear and a wild bull, but his reputation was ephemeral, so to speak, in comparison with that gained on the floor of the Stock Exchange yesterday by Charles Knoblauch, J.M. Shaw, William Coster, and H.M. Baruch, the committee appointed to get up the holiday festivities on the floor of the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The Adjutant General received a dispatch to-day saying that the transport Logan, bound for Manila, carrying the Forty-first Volunteer Infantry, arrived at Singapore to-day, with all well on board.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- The State Board of Canvassers met to-day and canvassed the vote cast at the late election for the four amendments to the Constitution, for the candidates for the seven vacancies on the Supreme Court bench, and for the candidates for Congressman in the Thirty-fourth District.

William Neufeld, whose trial for the murder of Mrs. Annie Kronman was completed yesterday, was sentenced to die in the electric chair in the week commencing Feb. 12 by Justice Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. A few hours later he started, with five other convicts, for Sing Sing, where he was placed in one of the cells assigned to condemned murderers.

At last some brave souls are unsheathing sword against the great Hugo myth. More power to them! Without offense to those who genuinely admire "Les Miserables," it is my experience and opinion that this one work is the innocent cause of more absolute hypocrisy, especially among the young, than any other in type, not excepting "Pride and Prejudice" and "Sense and Sensibility."

There is not a more thankless task than the attempt to prove that some gem of poetry or prose is, after all, nothing more than a clever plagiarism. That task shall never be mine. I am quite in accord with the philosophic view of Lowell:

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- A large German mall steamer, whose name has not yet been ascertained, but which is believed to be one of the Hamburg-American liners, has gone aground during a terrific gale in East Bay, about a quarter of a mile off Dungeness, the southern extremity of Kent.

Justice Wilmot M. Smith, in the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, yesterday dismissed the proceedings brought by stockholders in the Wallabout Bank to review the assessment of their shares of stock. There are 1,000 shares of the capital stock of the par value of $100 each. It was valued for assessment purposes at $114 a share, its market value.

To dispel once for all the impression created by attacks impugning the accuracy of my observations and surveys during my journey in Southwest Thibet in 1897, may I state that Sir Clements Markham, President of the Royal Geographical Society, properly anxious to establish the truth, ordered a new and thorough examination to be made into my geographical work by Mr. John Coles, professional expert of the society.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 29. -- Charles G. Dawes, Controller of the Currency, made a speech at the Republican State love feast in the Assembly Hall to-day, which was regarded by many as outlining the policy of the Administration on two points, the Philippine policy and the attitude of the Republican Party toward trusts.

My esteemed friend, Thomas G. Shearman, is by far the most zealous and exaggerated anti-Boer whom the present South African trouble has developed. It is a pity that one who is usually so careful in his statements should be misled by the partisans of "Joe" Chamberlain into such limitless use of adjectives and a surrender of some of the principles for which he has hitherto stood.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Secretary Furter to-day gave out the programme for the New Year's reception at the White House. It is as follows:

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29. -- M. Pierot was arraigned before United States Attorney W.E. Bundy to-day on a charge of violating the laws of neutrality. M. Pierot has been known as a recruiting officer here for the Boers for some time, and through him many men have been transported East.

The Central Club gave a splendid exhibition of tenpins in the Harlem League last night. The team won two games rolling scores of 978 and 899. There were some good individual scores turned out. Holl of the Centrals, in the second game, made a score of 244 on eight strikes and two spares, and Holt of the Standards, in the third game, got seven strikes and three spares for a total of 241.

In the far distant northern country these three letters, "H.B.C.," have been blazed on many a tree, cut into many a rock, and Indian and white man have respected them, for these letters stand for the Hudson's Bay Company. Mr. Beckles Wilson gives the history of "the Honorable Company of the Merchant Adventurers trading into Hudson's Bay," and a very interesting and curious story it makes.

After three weeks of wandering, Louis E. Goldsmith, cashier of the Port Jervis National Bank, who is alleged to have plundered that institution to the extent of $54,700 by falsifying the books, walked into the Federal Building yesterday morning accompanied by his lawyer, W.H. Crane of Port Jervis, and surrendered himself to United States Marshal William Henkel.

Arrangements are being made to supply the various prominent vacant pulpits in this city. Until pastors are chosen stated supplies will be secured. In Brooklyn the pulpit of the Rev. Dr. R.S. Storrs, in the Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, will be supplied by the Rev. Dr. M. Woolsey Stryker, President of Hamilton College.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- The annual reports of the two financial officers of the State, the Controller and State Treasurer, show that on Oct. 1, 1898, there was a balance in the Treasury of $3,973,804.45. The total receipts from all sources during the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1899, were $25,837,136.92, making a total of receipts and balances of $29,810,941.37.

Major David Banks, Jr., has been assigned from the supernumerary list as Inspector on the staff of Major Gen. Roe to succeed Col. Edward M. Hoffman, appointed Adjutant General. This arrangement will practically leave the position open for Gen. Hoffman to take it again when he lays down the duties of Adjutant General, in the event of his not being reappointed after Gov. Roosevelt's present term.

" Rejected Manuscripts Not All Unworthy." -- May it not be that magazine editors, book publishers, and even readers of manuscripts may not be able to see the good points in articles submitted to them, and still, as they pleasantly say, with their rejection, "This does not mean that the article does not possess literary merit?"

MAFEKING, Dec. 20. -- Lady Sarah Wilson is living in a bombproof shelter of her own construction under the private residence of Mr. Weil. There she is enabled to exist with some degree of comfort, and if she chooses to spend a part of the time in the house, her shelter is close enough to enable her to take cover between the ring of the warning bell and the arrival of a projectile.

WEBSTER CITY, Iowa, Dec. 29. -- A new point in insurance is involved in the case of the death of George W. Goodrich. He carried a $2,000 policy in the Ancient Order of United Workmen. Three days before his death his physician was dismissed and Christian Science treatment substituted. The order refuses to settle unless a physician's proof of death is submitted or the body is disinterred and a post mortem held.

The opportune appearance and confession of Charles Reilly, a waiter, yesterday morning, in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions, saved three men from a possible term of three years' imprisonment. The men who escaped sentence for a crime they never committed are James Kiernan of 167 Seventh Avenue, John Gallagher of 313 Third Avenue, and John Toohill of the same address.

Your correspondent from Arizona, who calls "itself" a "cactus flower," falls into a common error, as it seems to me, in confounding "loneliness" with "solitude," and when he asserts that "only a lonely man knows the true friendship of books" he is guilty of an Irish bull or something like it A man who "knows the friendship of books" never is and never was a lonely man, though he may be a solitary man.

What is regarded as the first move in a war to be waged upon Senator Michael J. Coffey, the Democratic leader of the Ninth Assembly District, Brooklyn, by the Willoughby Street machine, was made last night, when the sub-committee of the County Executive Committee appointed to consider the charges made against Coffey by his opponents in the Ninth District met in the Jefferson Building and organized.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 29. -- United States Circuit Court Judge Gray to-day granted a rule for cause to be shown on Jan. 11 why the lease of the trolley system of the Consolidated Traction Company to the North Jersey Street Railway Company should not be set aside as fraudulent. An order was also made temporarily restraining the payment of $150,000 on account of the lease, which was to have been paid on Jan. 1.

MONTREAL, Dec. 29. -- Within the course of another two weeks the second contingent of 1,000 troops which Canada is sending to South Africa, will sail from Halifax for Cape Town. It will be composed of cavalry, or mounted infantry, and field artillery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The War Department has accepted the challenge of Capt. R.W. Shufeldt, United States Army, retired, and has transmitted all the papers referring to the case of the officer to Major Gen. Merritt, commanding the Department of the East, at New York, for court-martial proceedings.

PRETORIA, Dec. 26. -- Commandant Swart reports from the laager at Alowyn's Kop, near Zeerust, that he had an engagement on Friday, Dec. 22, with Kafirs in the neighborhood of Derdorport. The Kafirs occupied a strongly fortified ridge and were well prepared for emergencies.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-night, when apprised of the death of Father Malone, paid the following tribute to his memory: "I desire to express publicly my appreciation of the loss the State has sustained. Father Malone was a good priest, a good man, and a good American.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Lord Rosebery writes as follows this morning to The Times:
New Year again! Time to turn over another new leaf! The old year dies out and you again have before you the spotless pages of another year. What will you write? What have you already written?

ITHACA, Dec. 29. -- The Committee on Colonies of the American Economic Association submitted a preliminary report at to-day's meeting of the association. The committee as constituted a year ago consisted of Jeremiah W. Jenks, Charles S. Harnlin, Prof. E.R.A. Seligman, Dr. Albert Shaw, and Prof. E.H. Strobel.
The name of this first library edition of Mr. Stockton's books is thus explained in the author's delightfully Stocktonian preface:

In your SATURDAY REVIEW of Dec. 16 there is a letter signed Emily C. Cobb, which is a criticism of my article on the subject above. The writer deplores the fact that the Brownings, who "have been so loved and honored in this country," should have any disturbing impressions attached to their memory.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 29. -- Old eighteen ninety-nine will be ushered out in great style to-morrow evening with the grand New Year's Eve ball to be given at the Lakewood Hotel, for which 1,000 invitations have been issued. The members of George J. Gould's country club have invited their friends to the clubhouse for a New Year's Eve dance, and the Laurel House will also entertain its guests the same night with a dance.

One of the most valuable books on Cuba which we have yet received is Charles M. Peter's "To-morrow in Cuba." Under this title the impressions of over two years of residence in Cuba as a newspaper correspondent are set forth in a comprehensive narrative. The observations here recorded commenced in the Spring of 1897 and cover the eventful period of recent Cuban history.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Another railroad to the Pacific Coast is a strong probability. Several Eastern capitalists and promoters have been in this city for two or three days, and it is said that they are considering plans for the construction of such a line. Among them is Warner Miller, and he has admitted that his business in Chicago at this time is in connection with traffic, matters and a new Western railroad.

Twenty years ago Mr. WILLIAM H. VANDERBELT remarked to the writer that with a well-equipped four-track railroad freight could be carried from Buffalo to New York at less cost than on the Erie Canal. That remark has been more than verified by the experience of the road and the canal since then.

It is not so long ago that Bishop Clement C. Moore's old residence in New York's Chelsea was torn down. I remember it well. The whole block bounded by Twenty-second and Twenty-third Streets and Ninth and Tenth Avenues was, as late as 1855, a hill, with high stone walls supporting it on the street and avenue sides.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29. -- To the great surprise of Mayor Hayes and others who have been trying to force the immediate sale of the Western Maryland Railroad, the New York syndicate representing the Vanderbilt interests, which wants the road for the tidewater outlet of a new trunk line from the West and the soft coal fields, to-day declined to appear at a public auction as a-bidder for the road.

A few weeks ago a kind friend in Maine -- Mr. L.T. Haines in Winthrop -- sent me your SATURDAY REVIEW of the 4th inst., containing a notice of John Sartain's "Reminiscences of a Very Old Man." Those reminiscences present another instance of the confusion and contradictions which the various biographers of Poe have contrived to huddle about the events in his life.
A clever Londoner told me that an American tickets himself with his nationality every time he says "very." "You all say 'vurry,'" he added, "and you all say 'Amurrican.'"

One of the strangest things revealed by a survey of the book publishing business for the year now drawing to a close is the fact that the books which have had the most pronounced success -- the sales in some instances mounting to figures which are indeed sensational -- have been the work of new writers.

In many parts of the market buoyancy ruled yesterday. To some extent this was attributable to purchases for the account of investors who are anticipating the extraordinary disbursements which are to be made at New Year's on account of dividends and interests. To a larger extent, however, the course of the market was doubtless due to the covering of short contracts.

When the civil war broke out the people of the North were rejoiced at the stand for the Union taken by many of the people of Tennessee. Particularly was that true of East Tennessee, which was the home of descendants of North Carolina and Virginia settlers whose families had been slave owners from colonial days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin reports to-day that contributions to the Lawton fund amount to $30,252.10, being an increase of about $4,000 since the last previous report. Following is a list of the subscriptions of $100 or more received since yesterday:

The seven-story wallpaper factory of William Campbell Co., 425 to 435 East Twenty-fourth Street, was completely destroyed by fire late last night. Fire Chief Croker at 2 o'clock this morning estimated the loss at $750,000. Half a dozen firemen were more or less seriously burned or other wise injured in fighting the flames, which were particularly fierce on account of the strong southwest wind that was blowing.

That the "Reminiscences of the Life of E.P. Roe," by his sister, Mary A. Roe, which has just appeared, will appeal to a wide audience, is evidenced by the great popularity of his books, same of which are said to have gone into twenty or more editions, the total number of copies sold in America aggregating more than a million.

Frederick Haberman, who recently purchased, through B.C. Barry, 665 to 671 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Sixty-first Street, as the site for a fifteen-story apartment house, has also bought, through the same brokers, 663 Madison Avenue, giving him a plot fronting 100.5 feet on the avenue and 109 feet on Sixty-first Street.

-- A real cyclone of excitement is raging at Chelsea, Mass. The storm began on Tuesday, when Mayor SETH J. LITTLEFIELD summarily removed from office Chief of Police WILLIAM P. DRURY, and it reached its fiercest height Wednesday evening, when the Aldermen met to hear the Mayor's reasons for his action and to decide, as is their duty under the Chelsea charter, whether or not the removal was to stand.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29. -- Florence Blythe-Hinckley, heiress to several million dollars, left by her father, Thomas H. Blythe, which was awarded to her after protracted litigation, has been quietly married to A.A. Moore, Jr., Deputy Attorney General of this State.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- James W. Paul, Jr., gave a ball at Horticultural Hall to-night in honor of his daughter, Miss Ellen Drexel Paul. It cost at a rough estimate upward of $20,000, and to exceed it in point of beauty subsequent ball givers will have to put on their thinking caps to devise new decorations.
" Old" New York is full of "nooks and corners" to-day that are of interest to the antiquarian and to the local historian.

The British military censorship is evidently close and effective. But it is not close enough to conceal the fact that really there is nothing going on. The three divisions of the British army of invasion have not yet had an armed man in Boer territory. They are all on British territory, and they are all on the defensive.

Yesterday's play in the fifth round of the annual intercollegiate chess tournament between Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton brought about an important change in the standing of the two rival colleges, and, instead of Harvard being a point behind in the race, as was the case Thursday night, the Crimson forged and took a similar lead as was held by Columbia on the day previous.

It will be a difficult task for the Democratic Party to prevent the re-election of a Republican war President by nominating a civilian. They should place in nomination the real hero of the battle of Santiago de Cuba, Admiral Winfield Scott Schley, who is not only a warrior, but a student of the science of government, well skilled in civil law.

Controller Coler yesterday sent to the members of the Board of Aldermen a statement in reply to allegations made recently by Alderman James of Queens in regard to the cost of constructing tunnels. In this statement the Controller said:

Some astonishing statements as to the feeling of the German people toward England are made in the January North American Review by Prof. HANS DELBRUCK, lecturer on history in the University of Berlin. If the professor has not mistaken tile sentiment of his countrymen they are inspired by a feeling of hatred toward the English.

A recent number of Caffaro of Genoa contains a curiously literal rendering in Italian of Rudyard Kipling's Poem, "The Absent-Minded Beggar." It is entitled "Il Mendicante Distratto." It will be seen that even in the title the spirit of the words has been lost, for although "distratto" is good enough for "absent-minded." "mendicante" signifies "beggar" in the most literal sense -- a mere taker of aims.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Alfred Morrison, a professor of languages, awakened suddenly early to-day and mistook his wife for a burglar. Without waiting to call out, he fired. The bullet took effect, and Mrs. Morrison is in a critical condition, and probably will die. Mrs. Morrison exonerates her husband from all blame, and he is almost insane from grief.

ANSONIA, Conn., Dec. 29. -- George Blakeman, the oldest man in Connecticut, died at his home in Derby this morning. He was 100 years and 2 months of age. Death was caused by exhaustion. Three weeks ago he was seized with a severe cold, and a complete collapse followed.

The most wonderful Johnsonian collection in the world is reposing in the fine library rooms of Mr. Robert B. Adam, 448 Delaware Avenue, Buffalo. In referring to it The London Speaker some years ago said that this fact made it appear possible that in thus furbishing up the New World with the relics of the Old Mr. Adam was largely contributing to make it fit for human habitation.

BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- United States Ambassador White, accompanied by Mrs. White, returned to-day, by way of Munich, from a two months' vacation passed at Alassio, in Italy. Both are greatly improved in health.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- State Engineer and Surveyor Edward A. Bond, in his annual report to the Legislature, will touch on the improvement of highways at some length. He will say:

The question of the adequate and systematic preservation of local records is being vigorously gone into in England at the present time, a strong committee having been formed -- appointed by the First Lord of the Treasury and consisting of the Bishop of London, Mr. Bryce; Sir H. Maxwell-Lyte, Sir Francis Mowatt, Sir C. P. Ilbert, and Mr. Stephen Spring-Rice.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- State Superintendent of Public Instruction Skinner thinks teachers are examined too often, and has provided new rules leading to permanent certificates. Under the revised rules, all questions of the second and third grades are abolished, and all examinations are based on the standard now required for certificates of the first grade.

In reply to the course of reading laid out in Walter Scott's romances for a young girl, I think the novels selected are his finest works, and in their order of perusal show careful thought and discrimination. For an older-mind perhaps "Rob Roy" might be more fascinating than "Quentin Durward," but from a moral standpoint it would not be so intellectual.

The promised reappearance of Mme. Calve as Marguerite in Gounod's "Faust" took place last night. When the eminent French soprano was first announced for this part she was taken ill, and Miss Adams was heard in her place. It was this change which caused so much complaint that Mr. Grau had to decide that hereafter money would be refunded in case changes were made in the allotment of the principal parts.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- Superintendent of Prisons Collins believes that the parole or ticket-of-leave system would work well in the State penal institutions if engrafted on the State's penal statutes and carefully managed. He will recommend such a measure in his coming report.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- A dispatch from Ladysmith, via Pietermaritzburg, Dec. 24, says...

For the last year I have noticed with some interest and not a sittle mortification the newspaper reports of the difficulties that exist between Mr. Maxwell, Superintendent of the public schools of the Greater New York, and the School Commissioners of the different boroughs, and of the unrest and dissatisfaction of the teachers and the parents of the children with both.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- The virtual seizure by British officials of vessels laden with American flour consigned to the Boers, and the statement of the Lokal Anzeiger regarding an alleged Anglo-German-Portuguese treaty for the division of Portugal's colonies between Great Britain and Germany, have aroused renewed interest in Paris.

The City of New York has always been the principal home of the Jews of the United States, and it was in connection with the Dutch enterprise in founding New Netherland that they were first brought here. It was from various quarters, but mainly from the Spanish Peninsula, that they had come to Holland.

Vroom thinks a few more Dutch nursery rhymes would be appreciated. While reading this the nursery rhymes began to bubble up in my memory, so I set to work to write them down.

A fire, which looked so threatening at the beginning, as to cause three alarms to be sent in, started on the first floor of the four-story brick stable at 156 East Fifty-seventh Street at 10:45 o'clock last night. The place is owned by A.J. Kaplan.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to --

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The seizure of cargoes of American flour off Delagoa Bay fail to excite much popular interest in England. It is generally rocked upon as a fine point of international law that will be amicably settled. So far no official steps in the matter have been taken owing to the non-arrival of the necessary papers from Washington.
A lawyer new to the immigrant smuggling trade, and a Syrian, probably a padrone, overreached their mark yesterday in the Barge Office and were $75 the poorer by their experience.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The martial spirit and universal desire to serve the country at the front shows no signs of abating. The action of England's Premier Duke, the Duke of Norfolk, who is Postmaster General, and by no means a young man, (he was born in 1847,) in volunteering for active service is he latest example of the spirit which pervades all classes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- John C. Covert, United States Consul at Lyons, in a report on the wine interests of France, says in part:

The letter of Mr. Columbus O. Johnson, ex-Water Register of New York City, in your issue of to-day, ought to be conclusive on the question of leakage and waste of Croton water, and again proves the contention of the City Club that what we need is not more water, but greater care and economy of what we have.

John Cavagnaro of the firm of J. F. Cavagnaro, general machinists, of 215 Centre Street, has been honored by King Humbert of Italy with the insignia of Cavaliere della Corona d'Italia. This decoration is a mark of the royal appreciation of the interest taken by Mr. Cavagnaro in the affairs of the Italian colony in New York.

THE APPEAL OF EX-CAPT. DREYFUS AGAINST AMNESTY. -- The Amnesty Committee of the French Senate is now drawing up the scheme of a general amnesty bill which, if it becomes a law, will wipe out the effect of all judgments that have been given in the Dreyfus case, and in cases growing out of this cause celebre, and will also prohibit all further prosecution of any person involved on either side.
The open season on black and gray squirrels, which ended in this State on the 15th, was of five days' shorter duration in New Jersey.

The following opinion from Brig. Gen. Haven of Connecticut on the future of the National Guard and the importance of defining its status will be found of interest at the present time, and will be indorsed generally as a common-sense view of the situation. Gem Haven says: "The future of Our National Guard can only be determined after Congress has taken action in the matter.

Piled up on a table in United States Commissioner Shields's office are twenty-six sets of papers, which by the binding and makeup appear to be legal in their character, but which are really the productions of a man, alleged to be a crank, who for over a year has daily disturbed the Judges and officials in the Federal Building.

Mrs. Frederick Nathan, in her article on tie position of women as wage earners, advance many sound ideas: but there is one that she failed to mention, which is one I have never seen written of in any of the many articles upon the equality of woman with man, either as a wage earner or in an intellectual capacity, and that is that to a great extent her personal appearance must be ignored.

Permit a very old reader of your esteemed journal to put in a word of protest against your editorial in to-day's issue entitled "Size and Sympathy." Any number of previous articles in THE TIMES have made it very clear to your readers that your sympathies are strongly enlisted on the side of England in the struggle between Boers and English.

It was a remarkable company that sailed yesterday from Pier 6 North River on the steamship Yarmouth. It consisted of men only -- over 800 in number and from all parts of the United States. There were lawyers, merchants, small tradesmen of all kinds, mechanics, and farmers. They expect to become the progenitors of future generations of colonial sons and dames in the Island of Cuba.
WELMINGTON, Del., Dec. 30. -- The attempt to launch the Winsor Line steamship Grecian at the Harlan Hollingsworth Shipyards to-day, was a failure, the new ship sticking on the ways.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The death is announced of Sir James Paget, in his eighty-sixth year.

VIENNA, Dec. 30. -- The results of the eighth round of the National Masters' Chess Tournament, played in this city yesterday, were: Wolf beat Schwarz, Popiel defeated Prock, Maroczy disposed of Zinkl, while Albin and Kortc, Schlechter and Brody, and Marco and Alapin drew.

Benjamin D. Greene, Col. John T. Gaynor, William T. Gaynor, and Edward H. Gaynor, members of the Atlantic Dredging and Contracting Company, jointly indicted with Michael A. Connolly and ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter, United States Engineer Corps, for conspiracy and having defrauded the Government out of $575,749.90 in connection with the Savannah River and Cumberland Sound contracts, appeared for examination yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Fire at an early hour to-day completely gutted the buildings extending from 216 to 222 Monroe Street, badly damaged the building at 212-214 Monroe Street, caused a loss aggregating $950,000, and resulted in the injury of nine firemen, two of them seriously.

Appraiser Wakeman said yesterday that he had nothing to add to his previous statements regarding the charges of the Merchants' Association against him. He was simply enforcing the law, he said, in returning certain grades of fancy cotton goods for a duty of 2 cents per square yard in addition to the ordinary duty, and if the importer thought such an assessment too onerous, he should go to Congress for relief.

The best strawberries, I am afraid, will be found at the top of this basket. There are two admirable episodes, or parts of episodes, in "The Cowboy and the Lady." In the first act the lovely heroine (and nobody with eyes to see can doubt the loveliness of this heroine) is saved from an imaginary death, off stage, by the hero, who is an American Lord Arthur Chilton in top boots.

I avail myself of your generous offer respecting the Boer Government and Mr. T.C. Shearman's letter of Dec. 21st. England's frequent appeals, by various devices to gain American sympathy in her efforts to crush the republic of the Boers, are as unbecoming as her slobbering conduct to impress the people of the United tSates of her love for us.

HAMBURG, Dec. 30. -- The Directors of the German East African Line have received news of the arrest of the imperial mail steamer Bundesrath. The commander of the port of Durban refused an explanation of the cause of the seizure, but it is declared here that there was no contraband of war on board, and when application was made to the German Foreign Office the latter immediately promised interposition with the British Government.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The reported sortie from Ladysmith, resulting in the capture of a Boer position, is not confirmed, and apparently is only a Kafir story. A Chieveley dispatch, dated Dec. 29, makes no mention of it. The same message shows renewed activity upon the part of the British, apparently preparatory to some action.
LIVERPOOL, Dec. 30. -- The Cunard Line steamer Lucania, which sailed from here for New York today, took among her passengers Mrs. Langtry, the actress.

BOSTON, Dec. 30. -- The final session of the Board of Aldermen of 1899 was held to-day, and the occasion became notable from the fact that Mayor Quincy sent to the board a valedictory message of remarkable length.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- New York has been well represented in the past week, and promises to have a conspicuous place in the social annals of the season opening to-day. The Secretary of War and Mrs. Root gave their first formal entertainment on Tuesday evening in the form of a supper party in honor of Sir Henry Irving.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- There are persistent reports in Nationalist circles that the Government has decided upon the arrest and the prosecution of Gen. Mercier before a second High Court immediately. It is added that an important debate respecting the conspiracy cases and the charges against Gen. Mercier will take place in the Chamber of Deputies as soon as the session begins, and it is said the Premier.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- About 300 of the Tuxedo set witnessed the defeat of Thomas Pettitt, amateur champion tennis player of America, by Eustace H. Miles, amateur champion of England, by a score of 4 sets to 0. The game, was an exhibition match to celebrate the opening of the new Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

Nobody doubts that Jones's wife has an imagination, not even Jones himself, who is the most prosaic fellow that ever put by a comfortable bank account. It all happened, the friends of the Joneses say, because of Mrs. Jones's imagination, an imagination, by the bye, that is strongly tinctured with a sense of the romantic and not at all humorous.

Forty-six golfers braved the rigors of the coldest day that Lakewood has seen this season yesterday and appeared on the links of the Lakewood Golf Club bright and early to compete in the first rounds of the New Year's tournament given by the club. This large aggregation of enthusiasts from many local clubs showed that golf was very much alive at the very end of the year.

ROME, Dec. 15. -- Yesterday a signed petition was presented to the Government by a confederation of hotel proprietors, representing 170 hotels in different parts of Italy, asking for consideration of a series of propositions lately drawn up by same society of proprietors, regarding the protection and encouragement of foreign travelers in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The negotiations opened by Secretary Hay with the great powers of Europe and with Japan toward obtaining a common understanding for a continued open-door policy throughout China have met with success. The State Department is unwilling at present to make public the nature of the replies received, as this information will be embodied in a special message to Congress.

Although the old rule applies that the best-dressed man is the one whose clothes pass unnoticed, yet there is a bit of individuality in every man's attire which distinguishes him somewhat from the great mass or crowd. Men are paying very much more attention to dress of late years than formerly, and there is really some effort at individuality.

Mrs. Emeline Jones is one of those famous colored cooks whom most people only know about from books. Of course she comes from the South, and it would read better it it was from Virginia, but in reality it was Baltimore. It is from there that she brings her reputation for terrapin, canvasback ducks, and cornbread, and she won't go back on her native place for anything.

The decision of the Ohio Supreme Court holding that the telephones of the Bell Company shall be taxed on their rental value instead of their actual cost, is one of the most important rulings on the subject of taxation that has been handed down since that which sustained the validity of the Nichols law, taxing franchises.

Mr. HENRY LOOMIS NELSON contributes to the current number of Harper's Weekly an interesting and suggestive article upon the peculiar situation in which we are put by the partition of the treaty-making power between the President and the Senate. His text is the alleged tripartite understanding which has been alleged chiefly, if not exclusively, by Mr. CHAMBERLAIN to exist between Great Britain, Germany, and the United States.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- We close the year in dogged mood, strong still in hope, but braced to meet further disappointments.

Miss Adele Tischler's ignorance of the game of chess, which resulted first in the arrest of her friend, Samuel Briskman, and then in her own arrest, was the indirect cause of he marriage to Briskman, which event was celebrated yesterday at her home, at 705 Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Attorney General Griggs to-day returned to the Inter-State Commerce Commission the transcript of the evidence taken at a hearing before the commission last week in the matter of the new freight classification, with the statement that the matter is one for action by the commission, and not by the Attorney General. I cannot believe that the number of writers for THE TIMES upon the Boer war pro and con furnishes a just ground for estimating the public sentiment. From the tone of the letters advocating the Boer side I judge that the writers are worked up to a much higher heat than are those on the other side. Evidently those entertaining their views are much more inclined to write than are others.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The Queen has approved the appointment of the Duke of Connaught as Commander in Chief of the British forces in Ireland.

MANILA, Dec. 30. -- The funeral of Gen. Henry W. Lawton, who was killed at San Mateo, Dec. 18, was held this morning with impressive ceremonies. The remains were conveyed from the Paco Cemetery down to the Luneta, to Pasig, and thence to the transport Thomas, which sails this afternoon.

Real estate dealing, even at the best, is bound to show so many periods of activity and depression, now in one section, now in another, that any attempt to characterize in a few words the business of an entire year will prove unsatisfactory. It may be better, then, instead of trying to call 1899 successful or otherwise, to go through it, not in great detail, but rather to recall its more important features.
