BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 30. -- When the census enumerator comes to Birmingham next year and collects for the Government the facts and figures required to make up the exhibit of the city's development in ten years he will secure some indisputable material, a surprising array of figures to show the increase of population and the growth in industrial activity, but there will be much about Birmingham that cannot be properly included in a census.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day rendered its report in the matter of the group of complaints lodged against the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company by associated bodies and citizens of South Brooklyn, together with miscellaneous grievances regarding the operation of the system.

The last meeting of the Board of Aldermen for the year 1899 took place yesterday. A new board will be organized Tuesday. According to an opinion of Corporation Counsel Whalen all business unfinished at yesterday's session must be introduced as new business next year. The opinion was a surprise to the Aldermen.

ADAMS, Mass., Dec. 30. -- The Berkshire Cotton Manufacturing Company dedicated to-night the new mill, No. 4, with a ball, at which nearly 10,000 persons were present, coming from all parts of Berkshire, and including delegations from Boston and Springfield. The affair took place in the new weave room, which is 530 by 225 feet, the largest in America. Two thousand persons danced in the big room at one time.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 30. -- Consolidation has been the order of the day so far as the industrial interests of this city are concerned during the last twelve months. The greatest combination of all, the Selling Committee of the Fall River Cotton Manufacturers' Association, controls practically all of the cotton cloth mills in this city.

THE record of Germany's progress in recent years reads like romance. The work done by the men who made the empire -- the old Emperor, Bismarck, Moltke, and von Roon -- has been ably supplemented by the efforts and tireless energies of William II., Hohenlohe, von Buelow, Thielmann, and Miquel.

Columns of smoke and steam arose all day yesterday from the ruins of the great wall paper factory of William Campbell Co., 425 to 435 East Twenty-fourth Street, which was destroyed by fire late Friday night, and as the heat died out in the ruined walls that still stood ice formed upon them in many fantastic shades where the streams of water fell.

PERMIT me to call the attention of the readers of THE TIMES to a few facts that are pertinent to the discussion now being had with regard to tunnel communication between the Boroughs of Manhattan and Brooklyn as compared to communication by bridges.

To-morrow we enter upon the last year of a century that is marked by greater progress in all that pertains to the material well-being and enlightenment of mankind than all the previous history of the race; and the political, social, and moral advancement has been hardly less striking.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- State Commissioner of Excise Lyman to-day announced that he had decided upon the appointment of Edward Dowling to be Special Deputy Commissioner of Excise for the Borough of Queens, pursuant to Chapter 184 of the Laws of 1899, amending Section 9 of the liquor tax law, at a salary of $2.500.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- The Tribune to-morrow will say:

EVERY financial crisis and the consequences which is brings have their peculiar characteristics and convey their special lesson, and a glance at the causes of the depression through which we passed from 1893 to 1897, and at the process of recovery, is necessary to a clear view of the prospect before us. The two years prior to 1890 were characterized by extraordinary speculations in Europe.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Arrangements have been completed for the fourth annual banquet of the William J. Bryan League of Chicago. It will be held at the Tremont House next Saturday night, and Col. Bryan will be the guest of honor and principal speaker. Plates will be laid for 500 people. Nearly all the tickets have been sold.

So much has been written about the piety of the Boers, they are so frequently compared with the early Puritans, that the opinion of the great African explorer and missionary, Dr. Livingstone, is of particular interest at this time. After speaking of the cruel treatment of the native tribes by the Boers Dr. Livingstone tells of the cold-blooded and cowardly way in which these Dutch "Pilgrim fathers" procured their domestic servants.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Dec. 30. -- Northern golfers are coming into Florida on every train. Among those of more or less prominence from the East now here are R.C. Watson, Sr., New York; C. Menzies Miller, New York, who won the cup at Ormond last Winter; Clayton Dixon, University of Pennsylvania golf team; Curwen Stoddart, Jr., Philadelphia; J.P. Greaves, Manhattan Club, and Major J.F. McLain, Pittsburg.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 29. -- An important proclamation, issued by President Kruger of the Transvaal, announces that owners or agents of dwelling houses have not the right to demand rent during the duration of martial law, and that they cannot after the repeal of martial law claim rent for the period it was in force.

Equestrians in New York are to have within a year the largest and most thoroughly equipped aiding academy in the world, for they will be housed in a building that is to cost half a million dollars, and the appointments throughout are to be in keeping with the lavish expenditure in erecting the building.

There was rejoicing among the faithful of Willoughby Street, in Brooklyn, yesterday. Two well-filled baskets of patronage plums were opened by District Attorney-elect Clarke and County Clerk-elect Huberty, and their contents distributed among the chosen of the auction room.

A horse and carriage dashed through the crowd at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue at 5:45 o'clock last evening and knocked down a man and a woman, killing the man. The victim was Gustavius F. Perrenoud, a public accountant, with an office at 57 New Street, and a residence at 697 West End Avenue.

The work of Miss Beatrix Jones as a landscape gardener is interesting. The daughter of Mrs. Cadwalader Jones of New York, she belongs in a social circle from which the workers of the world do not so often come, because there is not the incentive of necessity, which has so much to do with many accomplishments.
John Dola was a prisoner in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night. He had thrown a brick through one of the plate-glass windows of Mrs. Lynch's jewelry store in Union Square.

The arrival of the new year will be celebrated in many ways throughout the city to-day and to-morrow. Many of the Roman Catholic churches will take advantage tonight of the Papal permission for the celebration of midnight mass. At St. Patrick's Cathedral a pontifical mass will be celebrated by Archbishop Corrigan, and Father Lavelle, rector of the cathedral, will preach the sermon.

Justice Bookstaver, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, issued a decree directing the Union Trust Company, as trustee of the estate of the late Edmund Waring, to pay over to his grandchildren $130,446.25, which represents $72,875 originally transferred by Mr. Waring, with 6 per cent. interest from Oct. 27, 1886.

At the close of the evidence given on the trial of a suit by Grace McDonald, as administratrix, to recover damages from the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for the death of her son because of the alleged negligence of the gripman on one of the company's cars, the Court submitted three questions to the jury, directing them to give an answer to each.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- The South African War overshadows everything else here. A correspondent has just had an interesting interview with the Liberal leader, Dr. Barth, who is one of the most steadfast friends of Great Britain and America, but who also condemns this war. Dr. Barth said:

EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, Dec. 30. -- Eastern and Western general ware and porcelain manufacturers reached an agreement on the selling price for 1900 at a meeting of the Trenton and East Liverpool districts here to-day. The result is a uniform scale for the entire country, averaging 5 per cent. advance. The manufacturers issue a statement in which they say:
Martin Harvey will produce Herman Merivale's "Don Juan" at the Prince of Wales's Theatre in London about the middle of February.

No better subject of study could have been selected by the American Economic Association than the financial policy suited to our new possessions, and the report of the committee of the association will doubtless be considered carefully at Washington.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Lorenzo Marques, dated Dec. 29, says:

No one here knows what the real situation is. Business is much depressed and there have been and still are numerous failures, but almost nothing is permitted to be published. Hence no one knows what the real situation is. Witte, the Finance Minister, says that Russia is in good condition, but others say that it is not; that he is about to issue 450,000,000 paper rubles, and that will drive the gold out of circulation.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- "The boot and shoe trade is closing the most prosperous year since 1892," says W.L. Terhune, publisher of The Book and Shoe Recorder. A detailed review of the year's business is, they say in the trade, impossible owing to the diversified nature of the business and the territory embraced.

The present has been the best business year of West Virginia's history, and the new year foreshadows even greater success for our people. We are engaged now building five new railroads, and we have quite a number about to be begun next year, the purpose of which is to open up the vast coal fields that are at present distant from railroads.

The Rev. Thomas R. Slicer preached a sermon for the new year before a large congregation at All Souls' Church (Unitarian) in Fourth Avenue yesterday morning, taking as his text Romans xii., 1, and the CXVI. Psalm. Sharpcott Wensley's "Story of Bethlehem," sung by the full choir, was a special feature of the service.
The receipts and shipments of live stock at Chicago during 1899, and the killing and packing at this point during the same period, indicate Chicago's continued supremacy in the provision trade.

SYDNEY, Nov. 22. -- Regarding the general outlook in this part of Australia the outlook may thus be epitomized: All the colonies have largely recovered from the disastrous effects of the commercial and financial crisis of a few years back, and have begun a new epoch of exceptional industrial and commercial activity and prosperity.
The prospects of the tobacco trade and industries for 1900 are brighter than they have been for many years past.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 31 -- To-night's trains brought large additions to the crowd of political leaders already here. Among them was Gen. P. Wat Hardin, who opened headquarters and launched his Senatorial boom on an anti-Goebel platform.

In his speech at Cooper Union, replying to GAMALIEL BRADFORD, Prof. GROSVENOR of Amherst College declared that the people of Boston, as a whole, were in full accord with the sentiment of the country in respect to the policy of expansion. Some of the most prominent anti-imperialists live there, he said, but they are very much in the minority.

To literally comply with your request to furnish you a brief statement of the present condition and immediate future prospects of the citizens of this State is a difficult task, for to me, a native Missourian, the subject is an important and interesting one.

Several hundred persons yesterday passed in and out of the parish house at 69 South Third Street, Brooklyn, to view the remains of Father Malone. Telegrams of condolence continue to arrive from different parts of the State. Among those received yesterday was one from Bishop W.C. Doane of Albany, who expressed regret at his inability to attend the funeral.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- A stiff campaign against the Franco-American commercial treaty is about to be opened by the Parliamentary Opposition to the Government and by the agriculturists. Despite the favorable report of the Customs Committee, a hostile current has become manifest among the Deputies who represent the agricultural constituencies, as well as those who sit for certain industrial centres, against several clauses of the treaty.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Congress will resume its sittings Wednesday. The chief interest this week will be in the Senate, where the financial bill will come up for cansideration.

Policemen Maher and Meehan passed Isaac Schumlovitz's clothing shop at 2,333 Second Avenue yesterday afternoon. From force of habit Maher looked into the place to see if everything was all right. He noticed two men in the rear of the store who looked much stouter than the proprietor of the place and his clerk.

OYSTER BAY, L.I. Dec 31 -- The news that the Rev. John L. Belford of St. Dominic's Church had been named by Bishop McDonnell to succeed the late Father Malone in Brooklyn did not become known to all of his parishioners until this morning. Father Belford, who is thirty six years old, was born in Massapequa, South Oyster Bay.

Louisiana will enter the year 1900 under very promising auspices. The State finances and those of the municipalities, parishes, levee districts, , are in better condition than they have been since 1860. The bonds and other public obligations are considerably above par. The interest thereon is promptly met at maturity and the resources are ample to maintain these obligations in their actual sound condition.

The year 1899 will show the largest tonnage of manufactured products in the history of the Illinois Steel Company. This means that in the twelve months we have turned out the largest tonnage in pig iron and also the largest tonnage in finished products that the company has ever done in a corresponding period.

Just as the new year was ushered in Madison Square Garden presented a scene of noise and commotion. It marked the formal beginning of the Hungarian Peasant ball festivities. In the seats and boxes of the Garden fully 8,000 people looked down upon a quaint scene depicted by native costumed peasants in a little Hungarian village that had been erected in the east of the inclosure.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 31. -- The latest reliable figures concerning the trade of Germany are those for 1898, the statements received from United States Consuls for 1899 being general and indefinite. According to a recent report, the exports of Germany for the year would show a remarkable increase, based upon the improvement in the export trade to the United States.

Formal announcement is made by Dr. W. Seward Webb of the transfer to the Pullman Company of the property and business of the Wagner Palace Car Company. The transfer went into effect at noon on Saturday, and Mr. Webb ceased to be President of the Wagner company at that time.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- The great advance in prices of cotton goods has been the result of a steady upward movement through the year. Production has been heavy, both North and South, and is still heavy. The mills have contracts enough on hand to cover their production for the early months of 1900.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- For the present the worst is over in the money market. The week just passed was extremely trying, but the worst fears about stock market collapses were not fulfilled. Only eight failures have so far been declared on the Stock Exchange, but it is estimated that more than one hundred members have been helped, and the mass of half-digested rottenness remains great.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 31. -- The Rev. Dr. George T. Purves preached this morning to a large congregation at the First Presbyterian Church. At the close of the services he told his people that he felt it to be his duty to accept the call which had been extended to him by the Fifth Avenue Church of New York.

Unquestionably to the great body of business men the outlook on the threshold of the new year is extremely bright. It is shown in nearly every line of the contributions from able and experienced observers whicn make up the Financial Supplement of THE TIMES this morning. Their tone is uniformly hopeful and confident.

One hundred years ago yesterday public exercises were held in this city on account of the death of George Washington. The Masonic fraternity of which he was a member took a prominent part in the ceremonies, and yesterday its members commemorated the one hundredth anniversary of the occasion by attending special religious services.
This city and its extensive tributary country have for two or three years shown a steady strengthening and improvement.

Mr. Paderewski, the famous pianist, gave his only concert with orchestra in Carnegie Hall last night. To those who wish to sit under the spell of his sole personality perhaps the orchestral concert is not as attractive as the recital, but for those who desire to hear the player in the larger works of the pianist's repertory last night was a delightful occasion.

In no section or the country is the increased activity in trade more emphasized then within the borders of the State of Rhode Island. Prominently in this State are found the products of foundry, machine shop, and factory which the whole world looks to for a great portion of its supply.
The business of New Orleans for the past year, particularly the Fall business, has been good; the promise for 1900 is brilliant.

HAVANA, Dec. 31 -- Now that Gen. Wood has selected his secretaries he hopes office-seekers, for the most part, will transfer their attentions to those officials, giving him time to attend to necessary business. The entire press speaks favorably of the appointments, and the secretaries themselves are confident of a successful administration.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The Copenhagen correspondent of The Daily Mail says:

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 20. -- Twenty-five years ago there was but one railway in operation in the republic -- the Mexican -- connecting the port of Vera Cruz with the capital. To-day three trunk lines, with numerous branches, connect the northern frontier with the centre of the republic, while other iron roads traverse the rich tropical and semi-tropical regions lying to the south, east, and west of the capital.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 30 -- Judging from the information given cut by the cotton men of the South, the progress of cottonmill building in the Southern States during the past year has been marked, but it is anticipated that the coming year will eclipse the record made by that just closed. This is the view expressed by several of the men most prominent and best posted on the subject.

Special services in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the vicarate of the Rev. Philip A.H. Brown were held yesterday in St. John's Chapel. Trinity Parish. The old church was filled both morning and evening with members of the congregation, and many old communicants who have long since moved uptown.

The year 1899 has been one of great development for Chattanooga. Just before the advent of this year the mobilization of troops in this vicinity, and the consequent influx of visitors, so enriched the financial centres of the city that the bank clearings indicated a net profit of $1,000,000 as a result of the Spanish-American war.

In describing the business of the past year it is difficult to avoid the use of superlatives. In almost every line of commercial and industrial activity there has been a development far beyond the anticipations with which the year opened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- High-water mark has been reached in the trade of the United States. The exports and imports for the calendar year amount to $2,046,000,000, with the business for the month of December estimated on the basis of the trade for the preceding month, the actual figures not being accessible in the Treasury until about the middle of the month following that of which they are published.
Business throughout this section of the South has been excellent and collections more satisfactory than in many years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The Tribune to-day prints the text of Admiral Montojo's defense under court-martial proceedings for his defeat at Manila. The bulk of the blame is charged by the Admiral not to himself or his fleet, but to the Spanish Government for its unprepared conditions. He also claims that Admiral Dewey kept put of range of the Spanish guns -- a proceeding which Montojo refers to as "a retreat."

Business on the New York Stock Exchange during 1899 was far beyond anything ever known in the records of Wall Street. This was particularly true of the transactions in railroad and miscellaneous stocks, which were nearly 63,000,000 shares greater than those of 1898, and in only one month of 1899 did the dealings fall below those of the preceding year.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31 -- After an interval of twenty-one months the Legislature of Maryland will convene for a ninety-day session at the State House, in Annapolis, at noon of Wednesday of the coming week. The members of both branches will caucus on Tuesday evening at the State House, for the purpose of naming their candidates for the various offices.

It is hard to have to say anything in favor of the Municipal Assembly, as at present constituted. Controller COLER has been maintaining, with much plausibility, that the only method of converting that body into even a harmless adjunct to the Municipal Government was to abolish it entirely.
THE FINANCIAL SITUATION -- By H. Allaway, Financial Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

In many respects the year 1899 has been the most extraordinary which has ever come to the American iron trade. The dominating factor has been an expansion in the demand at a time when the really well equipped, well located, and modern works in the country had been under full pressure for a considerable period.
A prosperity panic -- such at the close of the year has been Wall Street's spectacle.

Once the ships for our foreign trade were built in American shipyards and shipbuilding and ship owning were among the most important sources of National wealth and prosperity. To-day the American merchant marine in the foreign trade has practically disappeared.

CAPE TOWN, Dec. 28 -- The colonial authorities are using every precaution to prevent an insurrection on the part of the disloyal Dutch in Cape Colony and to suppress a rising if it should occur. Everywhere the British colonists are being organized into home guards, drilled, armed, and ready to act in their respective localities should armed Dutch colonials gather.

The year 1899 was a year of wonders, a veritable annus mirabilis, in business and production. To paraphrase a celebrated epitaph, prosperity left scarcely any of our industries untouched, and touched nothing it did not enrich. It would be easy and natural to speak of the twelve months just past as the banner year were we not already confident that the distinction of highest records must presently pass to the year 1900.

The people of Wisconsin are having their fair share of the prosperity. The financial crisis of 1893, which so unsettled values and caused such timidity and lack of confidence in the business world, is a thing of the past. Values are restored, the timidness is broken, end general confidence prevails. To-day every factory and workshop, every farmer, every other kind of business, and every worker is fully employed.

I herewith submit a few facts showing the industries and business conditions of this State. Our chief industries are, and always will be, agriculture and stock raising. During the past year these have shown a very healthy development, and are now in a very prosperous condition.

THE year 1899 will stand marked in our National history as a period of unprecedented commercial and financial prosperity. It opened auspiciously upon a Nation bounding with life and industrial activity, with fresh confidence in the successful operation of all the established departments of trade, and with many new and promising enterprises springing into existence.

Compared with all other years in Utah's history, 1899 was by far the most prosperous. Accurate statistics are not yet compiled for the year, but the increase of general business compared with the preceding year in Salt Lake City is placed by conservative and well-informed business men at 50 per cent.

The stockholders of many of the prominent railroad and industrial corporations received substantial evidences of the growing prosperity of their companies during 1899 by in many cases resumption of dividends, in others increased payments, and in the newer enterprises the commencement of such disbursements.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- Amid the tolling of church bells and cheers rising from scores of thousands of throats in the dense multitude of joyous people who crowded the streets down town, the New Year -- and the new century, as the Germans elect to consider it -- came in.

The condition of trade, transportation, and leading industries in this city throughout the past year, and the situation at the close, may be briefly summarized as follows, and what is said of this city will generally apply to the State, of which Portland is the chief city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The total number of vessels built and officially numbered by the Bureau of Navigation during the calendar year just ended was 954, of 267,642 gross tons, compared with 955 of 237,600 gross tons for the year 1898. Steam vessels built during 1899 numbered 421, of 160,132 gross tons, compared with 550 of 169,602 gross tons for 1898.

Trade conditions and the outlook for the current year have been discussed by a large number of the foreign correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES. A number of their communications appear in the Financial Supplement, but several which arrived a little late are given herewith:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Several days ago Assistant Secretary of War Meiklejohn addressed a letter to Representative Long of Kansas, setting forth what had been done by the War Department toward opening the hemp ports in the Philippine Islands. The letter contained some errors made by the compiler in tabulating the figures.

The outlook for business conditions in Oregon the coming year seems to be good. The past year has been fairly satisfactory, and, with the exception of wheat and hops, prices for our staple productions have been remunerative. Oregon produces more wool than any other State in the Union, and the price per pound at present is above 20 cents -- higher than it has been before since the panic of 1893.

The year 1899 has been one of exceptional activity in the commercial and industrial affairs of Cincinnati. Labor has been more fully employed than for several years. While this city has a large general merchandising trade, its more conspicuous feature is the extent of its manufacturing interests, covering a wide range.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 30 -- Paul Morton, Second Vice President of the Santa Fe system, said to-day: "There has been but little change of importance in railroad circles during the past week. Business has been generally good upon all the lines running into Chicago, although a few of them complain of a slight falling off in the amount of trade they have been handling.

The widespread depression that followed the panic of 1893 was felt by the people of Colorado, but with less severity than by those of the Eastern and Middle States. Such of our mines as produced sliver alone were compelled to close down, and camps like Aspen, Creede, and Leadville suffered accordingly.

A review of trade conditions in Canada at present, accompanied by an attempt to forecast the immediate future, must turn upon the facts and prospects as regards the following chief items: 1 -- Agriculture; 2 -- Lumber; 3 -- Spruce, paper, and pulp; 4 -- Iron; 5 -- The precious metals; 6 -- Coal; 7 -- Fisheries; 8 -- Transportation; 9 -- Foreign trade; 10 -- Bank returns.

The residents within several blocks of the ruins of the wall paper factory of William Campbell Co., 432-435 East Twenty-fourth Street, which was destroyed by fire Friday night, were startled yesterday afternoon by an explosion which shook their houses and broke windows. Somebody said a boat must have blown up and then somebody said a boat "had" blown up.
The outlook for 1900 for Montana is for a much larger volume of business and generally better times. There are much improved conditions throughout the State.

Miss Barbara Frazie and Miss Jeanette Piroth of Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, will have an exciting tale to tell to their New Year's callers at the home of one of their friends at 45 Weirfield Street. Brooklyn. The story, which might be entitled "Lost in Brooklyn," is one of adventure, in which Miss Frazie and Miss Piroth figure as the heroines, and a gallant police Sergeant as the hero.

Brazil has passed through a serious crisis within the last year. Coffee, its great staple export, declined below the cost of production, owing to an enormous overproduction. In addition, the revenues of Brazil did not increase in proportion to her expenditures. The Government tried to appreciate paper money by causing the destruction by fire of a certain percentage.
BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- It is announced that the German protected cruisers Condor and Schwalbe are now on the way to Delagoa Bay.

The New Year's offering of THE TIMES to its readers to-day is its Annual Financial Review, and we may say with candor that it is no mean gift. In the extent, variety, authority, interest, and value of its contents it has never been equaled by any like publication. In its thirty-two pages it presents minute and accurate statistics of every security dealt in on the Stock Exchange.

Muffled in furs and looking more like Laplanders than New Yorkers, road drivers turned out in full force on the Speedway yesterday, and for a couple of hours in the morning there was some lively harness racing. The roadbed, although a little too hard, was in very fair condition, and several fast quarters were trotted and paced.

Frank L. Saxby, an insurance agent of Troy, was locked up in the East Thirtieth Street Police Station last night on a charge of assault preferred by George W. Moore, manager of the Gilsey House. Saxby entered the hotel at 5 o'clock yesterday and asked the clerk in charge of the desk for a package that he had left there.

A congregation which filled the great building to overflowing was present in St. Patrick's Cathedral at the solemn pontifical mass held at midnight by Papal decree to commemorate the beginning of the holy year. Admission to the cathedral was by ticket only, but in spite of this many hundreds of persons gathered outside each door, in the hope of being allowed to enter.

The general financial condition in the Mississippi Valley, and in all the country tributary to Chicago, is most healthy. During an experience of between thirty and forty years I do not recall any time when general conditions were more prosperous. This is true of all interests, commercial, agricultural, industrial, and transportation as well.

READING, Penn., Dec. 31 -- A review of the past year shows that, from an industrial standpoint, 1809 marks an extraordinary era in the history of East Pennsylvania. It is just about a year since the wonderful development of the iron business set in. Since the beginning of 1899 the advance in the iron business has been rapid.

For the fiscal year 1879, the aggregate sales of lager beep and ale amounted to 10,589,937 barrels; during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1899, the total sales were 36,581,114 barrels, an increase of 25,991,177 barrels, or nearly 260 per cent, during a period of twenty years.

The masonry for the new East River bridge tower at the foot of Mangin and Delancy Streets is about eight stories high at present, and the top is anything but a pleasant place on a cold day. Last evening Watchman Grogan, whose duty it is to watch the works about the projected bridge, discovered a fire at the top of the masonry.

The early months of 1899 will long be remembered for the most active, exciting, and buoyant speculation in Wall Street history. Nothing like it had been seen since the often-referred-to boom of 1879-80, and even that historical period was overshadowed by the phenomenal business that ushered in the past year.
In reply to your letter addressed to Gov. Steunenberg requesting a forecast of the coming year in Idaho. I beg leave to say that in all branches of industry the outlook is exceptionally bright.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- "A wonderful year to look back upon, and a year full of promise ahead." These were the opening words of a talk with Secretary of Agriculture Wilson, in response to a request to give to the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES some comments and opinions on the departing and arriving years.

While this town was a severe sufferer from the financial panic, which prevailed from 1894 in this city to 1898, the gain in nearly every description of industry has been particularly marked in the past year. Thus there were shipped from Duluth up to Dec. 16 17,613,652 bushels of grain, being a gain over 1898 of 465,233 bushels.

No very great assurance is needed to predict that, the year 1900 will be one of very large imports of foreign products, and may easily surpass all previous records. Past experience proves that years of heavy exports are accompanied or followed by heavy imports, and the condition of our domestic markets is such as to encourage purchases from abroad.

The great activity in almost every branch of business in the Kingdom of Denmark in 1898 has been followed in 1899 by a reaction, to a great extent due to the labor question. Workmen demanded considerable increase in wages, reduction in working hours, and many other points, and the employers' position became so intolerable that they had no alternative but to declare a general lock-out in the building trade and every branch connected therewith.

The Rev. Dr. David James Burrell preached yesterday in the Marble Collegiate Church, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, on the subject: "A Review of the Year," taking his text from several verses in Joel, ii., beginning with the words, "Fear not, O land; be glad and rejoice: for the Lord will do great things.

The general prosperity of the country the past year has been fully reflected in the shoe and leather trade. The production of shoes was never as great as in 1899. The shipments from Boston, whence the great bulk of the shoes made in New England are forwarded to their destination, were some 400,000 cages more than in 1898, an increase which is unparalleled in the history of the industry.

Record of curb market transactions during the past year is in many ways a counterpart of the more important market on the Stock Exchange, where dealings were in unprecedented amount. The phenomenal number of new incorporations, whether representing new capital or reorganization of established concerns, led to a condition where promoters, and afterward holders of stocks, sought a convenient place of sale for the new securities.

There was a long discussion at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union over a bill which is to be introduced in the Legislature, providing for the licensing of all engineers in the State by a State board. The stationary engineers have protested against the proposed measure, fearing that if it should be passed locomotive and marine engineers would be able to obtain licenses to run stationary engines and thus compete with them.
VIENNA, Dec. 31 -- This evening the ninth round of the Kolisch chess tournament was completed in his city. The pairing has been arranged to read as follows:

The condition of business in Tampa and contiguous territory is better with the close of the year than it has ever before been in the history of the city. Not only is the aggregate volume of business at this date larger than previously, but there is more of it when calculated per capita or measured by the capital employed.

Pittsburg is enjoying a phenomenal era of prosperity. Never before in its history at the end of the year have our manufacturing interests been so rushed with orders. Every plant is being pushed to its utmost capacity; labor is fully employed, and no one needs to be idle who really desires employment.

San Francisco, owing to its situation, being the metropolis, not only of the State of California, but of the Pacific Coast -- that portion of the United States facing the Orient -- has long been considered by thinking men to be the natural emporium of the Oriental trade with the United States, having always had more or less intercourse with the Far East.

News of the capture by a British cruiser in Delagoa Bay of the German steamship Bundesrath, alleged to have aboard recruits for the Boer Army, was the cause of considerable excitement in this city yesterday among members of the First Regiment, Irish Volunteers, the military organization established by the Clan-na-Gael several years ago.

During last Winter an experiment in giving dinners was tried in this city which may prove suggestive for resolutions appropriate to the season. It involved some considerations of morals as well as of hygiene and taste that might with advantage be studied, even to the verge of fasting and prayer, by thousands of the prosperous dwellers of our big town.

The large menacing wall at the Campbell wall paper factory ruins, on the East Twenty-fifth Street side, nearly six stories high, was pulled down by ropes yesterday. It fell with a tremendous thud that shook the buildings in the vicinity. The men, who were directed by John A. Dooner, Superintendent of Buildings, afterward blew down the partition wall on the west side.

MANILA, Jan. 1 -- Aguinaido's wife, sisters, and twenty-one Filipinos, three of them officers, have surrendered to Major March's battalion of the Thirty-third Infantry at Bontoc, Province of that name. The Filipinos gave up two American and two Spanish prisoners.

The City Hall was gay with flags and bunting yesterday in honor of the second anniversary of the birth of Greater New York. From the flag staffs on the roofs depended long lines of signal flags, which did duty during the Dewey celebration, and all over the facade were festoons of red white, and blue bunting, caught up by shields.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- A testimonial banquet was given to-night by 125 leading citizens of Newburg to Benjamin B. Odell, who is closing his sixth term as Mayor of Newburg. He has served as Mayor for a longer period than any other Mayor in the State, with one exception. Mayor Odell is the father of B.B. Odell, Jr., Chairman of the Republican State Committee.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 1 -- The University of Delaware was chartered at Dover to-day. It will be located in Wilmington

In the concluding, and far from least important, paragraph of his annual report to the Governor Major Gen. ROE earnestly calls attention to the "absolute necessity" for action by Congress, fixing beyond any possibility of misunderstanding the status of the National Guard in relation to both State and Federal authority.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The annual New Year's ball at the Tuxedo Club took place here to-night. It surpassed all others in gayety.

Republican leaders have begun to think of the State Convention to be held in the Spring to select the four delegates-at-large to represent this State in the Republican National Convention next June. No date has yet been selected for the holding of the State Convention, but many of Senator Platt's friends have expressed the opinion that the convention should be held during the last week in March.

A correspondent inquires if THE TIMES does not think that the Boston City Council ought to be censured for adopting resolutions of sympathy for the Boers. No doubt it does deserve censure; and it would have deserved an equally severe reproof if the resolutions had expressed sympathy with the British.

SING SING, Jan. 1 -- John C. Baldwin, the life convict who was pardoned on Saturday by Gov. Roosevelt, left the prison here this afternoon. He had served twenty-two years less two months for the murder of William H. Springstein in Port Jervis in October, 1877. He was at first sentenced to be hanged, but the sentence was commuted to life imprisonment.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Fire did damage to the extent of about $75,000 to-night in the Isham Building in this city. For a time it looked as if the flames would extend to the Clark Hotel, a big five-story building adjoining, but, although the south side of the hotel was badly damaged, the firemen saved the building.

A distressed poet makes to us an appeal upon behalf of his class which must appeal to every humane heart. It seems that one of our esteemed contemporaries last Summer opened a prize competition for poems, on a subject dictated by itself, which aroused a peculiar interest in poetical circles.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- The attempt of the Common Council to-day to organize resulted in a disorderly session, in which Daniel J. Kiley, a Democrat, and last year's Chairman, declared himself elected after the temporary presiding officer had announced an adjournment.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- A British firm, according to The Daily News, after keen competition with several American firms, has secured the Government contract for the new seven-span bridge over the Tugela River at Colenso.

The Queens County Grand Jury for January will begin its sittings to-day and District Attorney John B. Merrill, who took office yesterday, expects to lay before it the whole school muddle in Queens Borough. Mr. Merrill has been interested in school matters for many years, and prior to consolidation was a School Commissioner in the Woodhaven district.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- There was a close approach to a pitched battle here to-day between the forces of the town of Mamaroneck and those of the Union Railway. The Union Railway some time ago obtained a franchise from the local authorities to lay tracks through the town to Larchmont.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 1 -- The Connecticut Democratic League has started cut early to raise funds for the State campaign of 1900. The movement was inaugurated today by the issuing of a circular addressed to every Town Committee Chairman in the State. In the course of its appeal the League says:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Over 2,000 citizens stood in line at the White House gates to-day waiting to pay their respects to the President of the United States, after the brilliant official reception which ushered in the new year and marked the opening of the social season in Washington.

More than one young man who had gone to Lakewood for the New Year's season, with the idea of having a good time, and incidentally winning a golf prize or two, found that his enthusiasm in the latter respect was completely snowed under, when, with, surprise, he saw the stunted pine trees partially covered with a mantle of white, yesterday morning.

In influencing the security market much may depend at the opening to-day upon the vigor with which contesting forces assert themselves. To an exceptional extent there was "evening up" at the end of last month, and both bulls and boars resume business on the Stock Exchange to-day with relatively small speculative commitments.

There was comparatively little driving on the Speedway yesterday, as the driveway was too slippery for the horses and not sufficiently covered with snow to warrant taking out a sleigh. A few short brushes occurred in the morning, but attracted little attention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A plaintive wail comes from the Asiatic squadron, caused by a recent order of Rear Admiral Watson. The order grants special privileges to officers whose wives are on the station, allowing them to go ashore two nights a week and to be excused from the quarters by the permission of the Captain of the ship.

Attorney General MONNETT of Ohio is a tireless hunter of the trust demon. He is one of the demon's most formidable enemies, too, for he has used the powers of his office with such zeal and persistence in his attempts to expose the flagitious nature of combinations of capital that the men of the trusts have become very tired of him.

Among her associates at the Metropolitan Opera House Calve, the inimitable Carmen, has come to be known as "Crazy Jane," as she is a "faddist" of the most impressionable sort. Her latest fad is Esoteric Buddhism, and all her spare time is now devoted to studies of the subject and to reading everything she can find that has been published on this Oriental religion.

BOSTON Jan. 1 -- Assignee H.W. Chaplin of the John P. Squire Co. corporation and its score of allied concerns, is slowly succeeding in getting order out of chaos. In this task he is receiving the much appreciated co-operation of a large proportion of the creditors.

Arrangements are under way for the erection of a ten-story fire-proof dormitory at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue for the use of the officers and students of Columbia University. The project is being outlined by the Morningside Heights Realty Company, which is now in process of formation with a capital stock of $200,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Superintendent Frederick D. Kilburn of the State Banking Department has completed his annual report to the Legislature, covering the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1899. In Introducing the report he says:

Two children lost their lives and seven persons were injured in a fire which was discovered at 12:45 o'clock this morning in a six-story flathouse at 754 First Avenue. Three other children are reported missing and may have perished, and it is possible that there may have been an even greater number of fatalities, as no complete list of the occupants of the building is available.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 1 -- The continued absence of County Treasurer E.H. Hershey and the stories concerning his accounts which have been afloat for a week past prepared the public for the formal announcement to-day that he is a defaulter and absconder. Mr. Hershey's son was in charge of the office last week endeavoring to straighten out the books.

With the opening session of the new year to-day the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the killing of Katherine J. Adams in December, 1898, will be in its eighth week, and according to the best information obtainable from both sides it will be at least that much longer before the case is finally given to the jury.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 1 -- The weather turned out clear and bracing for the New Year's golf tournament, in which two prizes were offered by the St. Augustine Golf Club. Their links, locally known as the "Fort Links," are near Old Fort Marion, and were the first laid out in Florida.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Standard's correspondent at Frere Camp, telegraphing on Jan. 1 says:

PITTSBURG, Jan. 1 -- An explosion of sewer gas at Knoxville, near here, about midnight, wrecked a large number of houses and stables and tore up several streets for hundreds of feet. No one was, however, injured.

The Rev. Father Thomas J. Dueey, pastor of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, delivered a sermon after the special midnight mass to commemorate the coming in of the holy year of 1900, which, though brief, caused considerable surprise in the congregation, for the discourse was a fierce attack on the trusts.
HAVANA, Jan. 1 -- The newly appointed Cabinet will hold its first meeting to-morrow, when the following Secretaries will meet Governor General Wood:

Fire destroyed the freight shed of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad Company at St. George, S.I., yestevday morning. The building, which was a large frame structure, stood in the railroad yard near the water front, about 500 feet from the ferryhouse. One track ran through the centre of the building and one on either side.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The eastern half of the Island of Cuba is now without a permanent military commander. Gen. Wood is understood to be making plans for the reorganization of the military government. There were originally six departments in Cuba, and there are now four. It is believed that the four will be cut down to two, which will dispense with the services of two of the Brigadier Generals there.

JAMES MURRER died at his home. 28 Oakland Avenue, Jersey City, yesterday from pneumonia. He was born in the old Hudson City District in 1846. He was at one time Coroner of Hudson County. He leaves a family.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan, 1 -- The Kentucky Legislature will assemble to-morrow. Already nearly every member of both houses is on the ground, and to-night caucuses were held by the Democrats and the Republicans.

Controller Coler said yesterday that the reports given out at the headquarters of the Board of Education that the teachers' pay rolls of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx were being held up by him were unfounded. Previous to consolidation the teachers in the old city never were paid until the 15th of the month, but through his efforts their pay day was advanced as nearly as possible to the 1st of each month.

Gen. FRENCH'S engagement with the Boers was evidently not what is technic- ally known as a battle, but only an "affair." In the numbers engaged it would have been ranked as a battle in our own Revolution, but not in modern warfare. And in the number of casualties on the British side it would have been no more than a skirmish in any real war.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- President Hadley or Yale delivered the chief address at the Chicago University convocation to-day. He said in part:
BELMONT, Cape Colony, Jan. 2 -- A dispatch from Dover Farm, dated Jan. 1, says:

Charles MacRae. Charles MacRae, who died on Saturday at Seabreeze, Fla. and whose funeral took place yesterday morning at the Church of the Intercession, Broadway and One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street, was one of the oldest and best known real estate brokers in the city.

ILOILO, Panay Island, Philippines, Nov. 13. 1899 -- The geographical disposition of islands and coast line near Iloilo, and the proximity of the insurgent forces in need of provisions and contraband of war made the smuggling and blockade running of stores and munitions from Iloilo to the rebels a possible and profitable industry.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The success of Gen. French's column is confirmed officially, the War Office this afternoon issuing a dispatch from Cape Town, dated Jan. 1, as follows:
The New York Fire Insurance Exchange will meet to-day. The Home Insurance Company has reinsured in the inland marine business of the Washington Assurance Company of New York.

BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- Strict silence is maintained in official circles regarding the incident, but a correspondent learns that the affair has created an extremely painful im- pression in political circles. Energetic diplomatic steps were immediately taken in London and the inadmissibility of the right of a British cruiser to search a German mail steamer on the high seas has been emphatically asserted.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The Democratic organization of New York City has a gas bill, and it will be introduced in the Assembly by Assemblyman Harburger. He will ask unanimous consent to introduce the Bill from the floor as soon as the House is organized, but failing in this attempt will drop it in the bill box.

"I'll tell yer what, fellers. If dat Henry Irving comes ter Brooklyn agin I chucks up me Job. I ain't no Eskimo," remarked Patsy Kelly, of the force of boys in a Fulton Street, Brooklyn, messenger office yesterday morning, hugging the steam radiator in the office and looking about him with an air of deep disgust.

Better London quotations had effect here yesterday. The victory of Gen. French over the Boers gave London confidence which was reflected here. London buying of American stocks was, moreover, on a rather substantial scale. It is probable that London is now carrying a larger quota of the active American Stocks than at any time since last Summer.

The clear, crisp weather of the last few days has made country life so enjoyable that the many people who went out to the various suburban resorts for over the New Year's Day have not yet returned. There is skating at Tuxedo, and at Meadow Brook there have been some interesting games of hockey on the ice.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- There was considerable mystery surrounding the caucus of the Democratic Senators held here to-night. Such action was unprecedented. No Democratic Senator could be found before the caucus who could explain why they had been summoned. Senator Grady, the Democratic leader, said it was merely for an informal talk, to shake hands, and renew old acquaintanceship.

No one would have predicted several years ago, when the Fifth Avenue Stage Company and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were having so much trouble, that some day or other, and in all likelihood before the end of the century, horseless vehicles would take the places of the antiquated stages then running on Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- After an exciting and grotesque struggle stretching over miles of elevated railway track, the police to-day took entire possession of the whole line of the new Northwestern Elevated Railway in this city. The police acted under orders of the Commissioner of Public Works, Lawrence E. McGann.

VIENNA, Jan. 2 -- The pairing for the tenth round of the Kolisch chessmasters' tournament, which was played in this city to-day, had been arranged so that the contests were: Wolf vs. Alapin, Zinkl vs. Kortc, Schlechter vs. Schwarz, Popiel vs. Maroczy, Prock vs. Brody, Marco vs. Albin. In the play Wolf lost to Alapin, Zinkl and Kortc divided honors.

Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE'S splendid gift to Cooper Union serves purposes of high utility aside from the primary purpose of the donor to help young men to get an education in the mechanic arts. Mr. CARNEGIE justifies his wealth by this disposition of it. A millionaire who uses his money in a beneficent way is no longer on his defense.

Occupants of a rather pretentious apartment house on the upper west side of town are facing a curious sort of fate of which they knew nothing when they leased their quarters. Most of them know nothing of it now, for that matter, but there is an anxious look on the face of the janitor whenever there is the least flurry of snow.

Henry J. Steinberg, a German grocer, with a store at Gilmore and Georgia, Avenues, Brooklyn, was found dead yesterday in a bedroom back of the store, and his wife and clerk tell a remarkable story of his death.
Frank Jay Gould has bought, through Frederick Zittel, from the estate of Ralph Marsh the two lots, 50 by 100, on the north side of Fifty-seventh Street, 191 feet east of Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The monthly statement of the public debt issued to-day shows that at the close of business Dec. 30 the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,134,300,007, a decrease for the month of $5,791,824. This decrease is largely accounted for by the purchase of bonds during the month.

The Senate will take up the House Currency bill to-morrow or next day. To speak with entire accuracy it will take up the bill that the Finance Committee has reported as a substitute for the House bill. The general opinion is that the Senate will ultimately accept and pass the bill of its committee. It is believed that it has the support of all the Republicans and of one or two Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The State Department to-day received from United States Ambassador Choate at London by cable a statement of the facts he had developed in connection with the seizure by British warships of American goods on the three merchant vessels Beatrice, Mashona, and Maria.

The annual stockholders' meeting of the White Knob Copper Company was held at the offices, 34 Pine Street, yesterday, and the following Directors were elected: Edward J. Mathews, (President of the company;) Wilbur K. Mathews, E.C. Platt, (Treasurer of the Commercial Cable Company); William J. Hardy, and C.G. Funk.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The Daily Telegraph has received the following, dated Jan. 2, from Frere Camp:

The Trustees of the Cooper Union held a meeting last night at Cooper Union. Abram S. Hewitt said that the meeting was purely a formal one, and that there was no further statement to make in connection with the endowments of Andrew Carnegie, ex-Mayor Cooper, and himself.

United States Leather stocks continued strong and active yesterday, and the nature of the buying gives circumstantiality to the reports which Wall Street now hears in relation to the company and its affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Ellis H. Roberts, Treasurer of the United States, announces that the distribution of the Internal Revenue collections is going on according to the original plan, and probably will be completed as to the first group of additional depository banks in eight days. He says:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 58 1/2 @ 59 1/2. There were no sales.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- Eight hundred hogs were recently imported to Havana from the United States, but 600 died within three days. Major Davis says the animals died of cholera, and recommends that no more hogs be brought from the United States, as he considers that further importations would be dangerous to the health of Havana.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- Gen. Wood had a busy day with the public officials and the members of the conference of representative Cubans, inducing Gens. Rabi, Lara, Sanguily, and Betancourt and Senor de Castro. The conference will be in session three days. All the Cuban notables who were present at the meeting to-day speak with enthusiasm regarding the frankness with which Gen. Wood developed his plans for the benefit of Cuba.

Father Malone was buried yesterday in Calvary Cemetery after one of the most impressive funeral ceremonies ever held in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Clergy and laity of every creed and nationality went to the Church of Sts. Peter and Paul to pay the last tribute of respect to a man who more than any other had endeared himself to the community.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The caucus of Democratic members of the Assembly met in the Chamber at 8 o'clock, and was called to order by Assemblyman P.H. Roche of New York. Joseph Guider acted as Secretary. The session was chiefly notable for the distinct enunciation of the policy of the Democrats.

A meeting and dinner of the Architectural League of New York were held last evening at the headquarters of the league, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. About fifty members and guests were present. Among the guests were Gen. O.O. Howard, Robert B. Roosevelt, the Rev. Merle St. Croix Wright, Clarence Gordon, Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, Col. William C. Church, Everett P. Wheeler, the Rev. Thomas R. Slicer, Capt. Richard Henry Green, and Beverley W. Robinson.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- An attempt made to undock the new royal yacht at Pembroke this morning proved disastrous. Immediattly after she floated the yacht listed thirty decrees to port and her starboard bilge keel became jammed. The strain was so great that shores sixteen inches square, used in an attempt to prop her, were darbled up and snapped like matchwood.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The Legislature convened to-day about noon, but little business was transacted other than the formal election of officers, and after listening to the Governor's message both houses adjourned until Wednesday.

Mrs. Jane Verner Mitcliel. Mrs. Jane Verner Mitchel, widow of John Mitohel, the Irish patriot and Confederate leader, died on Sunday at her residence in Bedford Park. Her husband died in Ireland nearly a quarter of a century ago. Mrs. Mitchel was the daughter of Sir William Verner, an English baroriet.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Joseph H. Choate, the United States Ambassador, and Mrs. Choate, accompanied by the Bishop of London, the Right Rev Mandell Creighton, and Lord George Hamilton, the Secretary of State for India, opened the Free Library at Acton, given by John Passmore Edwards, a well- known publisher and founder of many libraries and institutions, this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 -- Capt. Peter Leary, United States Army, stationed at Fort McHenry, received a letter to-day from his brother, Capt. Richard P. Leary, Governor of Guam, in the Ladrone Islands, which contained a number of interesting documents pertaining to the affairs of the new possessions of the United States.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The latest advices from the Colesberg district tend to modify the self-congratulations on Gen. French's success. The predicted occupation of Colesberg had not been accomplished yesterday evening, while the Boers' guns, announced to have been silenced, were still active.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In printing seventeen columns of letters in Sunday's issue on this unhappy but apparently unavoidable appeal to arms, you performed a notable public service. Viewed as to its immediate results, you have gratified a legitimate desire on the part of those who wrote by anticipating the wants and interpreting the sentiments of those who read and are still reading these letters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If you will permit me to follow up the communication from Mr. Edw. W. Stitt, who points out a misstatement in The Nineteenth Century article, I might mention another slight error, and should be glad if you would correct the same.

The support of President GUGGENHEIMER for any worthy cause can be looked for with a high degree of confidence. We are glad that he has taken up the proposal to restrict the traffic on Fifth Avenue so as to make the Park more easily accessible than it has heretofore been to the only vehicles which are allowed to enter it at all.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Lacking news from the main British camps in South Africa, Whose future action can alone have an important effect on the larger issues of the campaign, the British public is making the most of Col. Pilcher's miniature battle. Unbounded tribute is paid to the prowess of the Canadians and Australians, and graphic accounts are published of the enthusiasm in Douglas as the victorious troops entered that place.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations of army officers for promotion:

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Dr. Mary Walker of Buffalo has been appointed physician at the State Custodial Asylum at Newark. She succeeds Dr. M. Alice Broell, who has been relieved by the Board of Managers of the institution by a vote of 5 to 4 on charges made by the Superintendent of the Institution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Foraker to-day introduced a bill providing a form of government for the island of Puerto Rico. The bill provides for the continuance of the laws and municipal ordinances now in force in the island until the Legislature provided for shall supplant them. THe President is empowered to appoint a Governor and a Supreme Court, and also seven heads of departments.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- It is reported at Durban that the captured German steamer Bundesrath had on board five big guns, 50 tons of shells, and 180 trained artillerymen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Surgeon General Wyman has no confirmation of the report that three suspected cases of bubonic plague have been discovered within the walled city of Manila, but no attempt is made to conceal the gravity of the situation should the report prove true. Still, it is said, a few sporadic cases need not necessarily result in an epidemic in the Islands.

Overcome by gas escaping from a detached gas stove tube, five persons had a narrow escape from death yesterday afternoon in a flat on the first floor of the house at 340 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street. They were Mary Guttentag, twenty-five years old; her children, Dora Guttentag, three years old; Pearl Guttentag, two years old; Ruth Guttentag, five months old, and her mother, Mrs. Nora Dreman, sixty-five years old.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 3 -- The joint committee which will hear evidence in the Goebel-Taylor'and Beckham-Marshall con- tests for Governor and Lieutenant Gov- ernor will be formed to-morrow. The law provides that the members of the committee shall be drawn by lot, three in the Senate and eight in the House.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 3 -- Duquesne Garden was well filled to-night by lovers of hockey to witness the initial game of the series the Yale team is to play this week against all comers. The game to-night was between Yale and the Bankers of this city. It was fast and well played, resulting in the score of 2 to 1 in Yale's favor.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- There was incorporated to-day with the Secretary of State the Terminal Railroad and Tunnel Company, with a capital of $50,000, which it is understood is to be increased to $5,000,000 very soon. The company is to build tunnels connecting the New York and Brook- lyn Rapid Transit lines and also to connect New York with New Jersey.

According to a cable dispatch from Paris published on Sunday, reports are persistent in the Nationalist press that the Government has decided to prosecute Gen. MERCIER, who was Minister of War at the time of the arrest and the first conviction of DREYFUS; it is even added that this action will be announced by the Premier, M. WALDECK-ROUSSEAU, when the Chamber reassembles.

The American Knit Underwear Association, comprising the principal fleece-lined underwear manufacturers of this State, held a meeting in the New York Life Insurance Building yesterday afternoon at which they raised the price of knit goods. The President of the association. Frank B. Harder, presided.

If a stranger to the Sammer traditions and Winter customs of the city that yesterday seemed only a suburb of Central Park had wandered in at the western Seventy-second Street entrance during any of the hours of daylight yesterday, he would have noticed first a long line of carriages moving in close locked funereal order along the drive instead of the smartly dashing procession usually seen there.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The financial situation is considered much more hopeful, on the general understanding that the bank rate will not be raised to-morrow nor, according to general expectation, in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Navy Department has been informed that the Marietta has arrived at Manila. The Brooklyn, New Orleans, Nashville, and Newark have all reached the main fleet, and the Marietta is the last of these additional ships sent to reinforce Admiral Watson, to arrive at the Asiatic station.

If negotiations which are not as yet designated official, but are under way with official sanction, are successful, the flag of the United States will in a few months in all probability float over the Danish West Indian islands of St. Thomas and St. John. Carl Fischer-Hansen, a lawyer of this city, whose name has been identified with the discussion of the subject, made the following statement last night:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As it is shown through a protest of the Society of Landscape Architects that the site fixed for the Soldiers and Sailors' Monument is impracticable, it seems not less than a duty the Monument Commissioners owe to the public to pause and consider.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The State Prison Commission to-day-adopted a report condemning the woman's prison at the Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn. The commission also adopted a resolution ordering that the authorities of New York City be notified and directed to take action to remedy the conditions, otherwise the State Commission threatens to secure an indictment of those responsible for the conditions in the jail.

Movements in the market for outside securities yesterday were less sharp than on Tuesday and the course of prices was also more irregular. Some reactions occurred, and here and there the previous day's figures were considerably reduced, but as a whole the market was firm, and among the day's net changes were a number that showed some improvement over the previous day's closing figures.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In the Senate today Mr. Pettigrew. (Silver, S.D.,) offered the following resolution:

It was a day of small details in the trial of Roland B. Molineux yesterday. Mr. Osborne switched again and began to take up the collateral matters intended to piece out the fabric he has sought to weave and to incorporate into it the elements necessary to make it a complete whole.

The weakening cold wave made it more attractive outdoors yesterday than it has been for some ten days past, and the avenue was quite gay at late morning and early afternoon with people driving and walking. As there was little going on, many women stopped on their way from the few "at homes" of the day to take afternoon tea at the Waldorf, Sherry's, and Delmonico's.
EAST MORICHES, L.I., Jan. 3 -- The three-masted schooner S.P. Hitchcock, Capt. Sorensen, of Bath, Me., ran on the outer bar opposite this place at 3 o'clock this morning. She is loaded with lumber.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- The break in the copper shares and a ten-point advance in Fitchburg preferred were the features of the trading in to-day's market. The turn in the coppers was due to the profit taking naturally following such an advance as these shares had had Tuesday and this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is reported that Denmark is ready and willing to sell her islands in the West Indies to this Republic for $3,000,000. If this report is true and the people of those islands desire political union with the United States, by all means purchase them without any unnecessary delay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your advocacy of the English cause in South Africa seems to have excited some of your readers, who have burst forth in letters of protest. Having before them in imagination the picture of a great power crushing the liberty of sturdy sons of the old Netherlander who gathered round Willliam the Silent, they cannot understand how you can sympathize with the liberty crusher.

PETER S. WILKES, an attorney, once a member of the Confederate Congress, died at his home, at Stockton, Cal., aged seventy-four years. He was born in Tennessee and removed to Missouri, where he was graduated from a university in 1852. A week afterward he was elected to the State Legislature.

The Fidelity and Casualty Company team added two more victories to its credit in the Life Insurance League at Starr's Tournament Hall last night, defeating the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance and the Equitable Life Assurance Society teams. The latter furnished a band of music for the occasion.

A testimonial dinner was given to James L. Raymond, President of A.A. Vantine Co. this city, by his managers and representatives, at the Hotel Manhattan last evening. The affair was in honor of Mr. Raymond's fiftieth birthday and to commemorate his twenty-five years' interest with A.A. Vantine Co.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- These bills have been introduced in the Senate:

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 3 -- Through a somewhat peculiar situation, the Republicans of South Norwalk became considered as advocates of an "open" policy in regard to Sunday observance. Mayor Bohannon was nominated on the Democratic ticket. He saw a golden opportunity of being elected by making a fight on the Sunday question, claiming that all laws should be enforced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The first of the formal dinners of the social season at the White House was given by President and Mrs. McKinley to-night, the members of the Cabinet and their wives being the guests of honor. Invited to meet them were members of the Senate and House, and a few other persons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Editorials and correspondence essaying to voice public opinion invite discussion and comment; therefore kindly permit a few words from a Long Island resident of the City of New York in regard to the proposed tunnels and bridges.

SAN JUAN DE PUERTO RICO, Dec. 26 -- Agriculture in Puerto Rico is in a languishing condition, and protective measures on the part of the Government are being called for by the people. The condition has been investigated by an expert, Lucas Amadeo, who has had an exhaustive report published in the columns of one of the local papers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Alien presented a resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury for all letters passing between the Treasury Department and the National City Bank and the Hanover National Bank of New York, also agreements made between the Treasury Department and those banks concerning the deposit of funds,

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Aldrich gave notice in the Senate to-day that he would call the financial bill up at 2 o'clock to-morrow. The Republican members of the Finance Committee authorized Senator Aldrich to present amendments to the bill which he offered to-day. The most important relate to the greenbacks, and are as follows:

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 3 -- A bill was filed to-day in the United State Circuit Court here by the Mercantile Trust Company of New York, as Trustee, to foreclose the senior mortgage on the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railway Company for the principal of the bonded debt of the company, $6,000,000, which matured Jan. 1.

J.H. Robinson and J.M. Fortier have withdrawn from the firm of Seymour, Johnson Co. The business will be continued by the remaining partners. Henry A. Seymour and Frederick W. Johnson, David Webster being a special partner.

That is really a remarkable diplomatic achievement which the State Department modestly records. It announces that in answer to our application for equal privileges of trade in any possessions, spheres of influences, or claims that may be gained or made by European powers in China, all the powers concerned have returned favorable answers except Italy, Italy's concern is comparatively slight, but her consent also is expected.

The recent action of the Passenger Department of the Erie Railroad in increasing local commutation rates on its New York, Susquehanna and Western Division has resulted in vigorous protest in the part of patrons. The change affects about 150 regular commuters between stations west of Jersey City.

The Superintendent of the Banking Department. Mr. KILBURN, whose report has been published this week, gives small comfort to those who are looking forward to any legislation this Winter restraining the field of operations of the trust companies.

Charles T. Barney, the active member of the syndicate which bought the Orphan Asylum block, said, yesterday that the only portions of that property which have been resold are the corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street to the Union Club and a 120-foot frontage on the south side of Fifty-second Street, 150 feet east of Fifth Avenue, to Henry G. Trevor.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The United States Ambassador, Joseph H. Choate, visited the British Premier, Lord Salisbury, at the Foreign Office this evening, for the purpose of making the first official representations on the subject of the Delagoa Bay flour seizures. Mr. Choate received no definite reply, as the Premier informed him that the British Government had not yet arrived at any decision as to whether or not foodstuffs were contraband of war.

During the last year, while the prices of most commodities, the cost of labor and materials, and the volume of traffic have been advancing, and while profits in most lines of business have increased very substantially, it has been a general complaint among men connected with the management of railroads that the rates for transportation have remained practically stationary.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Phonetic spelling was given a vote of approval by the University Congregation at the University of Chicago this afternoon. The following resolution was adopted:
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- A dispatch from Honolulu, Dec. 26, via San Francisco, Jan. 3, says:

It is rather a remarkaible fact that as a general rule the local traction stocks, Brooklyn Rapid Transit excepted, appear to move in more or less sympathy with each other. Not infrequently if one stock goes down the others do likewise, while if a rise be recorded in any one so is it likely to be in the others.

Happy is the nation that has no annals, and happier still the State that needs no new laws. That is substantially the present condition of the State of New York, if we may judge from the message of Gov. THEODORE ROOSEVELT. He is a man of notably positive opinions, yet his message is almost barren of positive recommendations.

A special meeting of the Republican County Committee was held in the Murray Hill Lyceum last night for the purpose of calling an "unofficial" primary election to select delegates to a convention to name a candidate for the Assembly from the Thirty-first District to fill a vacancy caused by the death of Edward C. Stone, who was elected as a Democrat over Samuel S. Slater, a Republican.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- It is stated positively and on good authority that Gov. Roosevelt has determined to nominate Cuthbert W. Pound of Lockport for the position of State Superintendent of Insurance, to succeed Louis F. Payn, whose term will expire next month. The report is accepted without reservation by the legislators who are still here, and there is much speculation as to Mr. Pound's chances for confirmation by the Senate.

The School Board for Manhattan and the Bronx, at its meeting yesterday afternoon, the first held this year, took issue with Controller Coler in regard to the making out of its pay rolls and adopted a resolution, offered by ex-Judge George M. Van Hoesen, which, unless the Controller recedes from the position he has assumed, will compel another resort to the courts to decide the question in dispute.

After showing much strength, and with many advances scored, the security mar- ket fell all of a sudden into weakness yesterday and final prices presented a long list of declines. Many sensational rumors were current upon which stocks were sold, not only for the short account, but in liquidation.

Manierre -- Welling. Charles Edward Manierre and Miss Elizabeth Hunt Welling, a daughter of the late Charles H. Welling, were married at noon yesterday in Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. The Rev. J. Lewis Parks, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 3 -- William L. Wilson, President of Washington and Lee University, will leave Lexington to-morrow for the Arizona Hot Springs, where he expects to remain until Spring.

The Taxpayers' Alliance of the Borough of the Bronx wants rapid transit. It wants it right away and lots of it. Such was the decision unanimously reached last night when delegates from the thirty associations making up the alliance met in Alliance Hall to discuss means and measures for the improvement of the Bronx.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 58 1/2 @ 59 1/2 . There were no sales.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- The German Foreign Office informed a correspondent this afternoon that Great Britain had not then answered Germany's note of protest regarding the seizure by the British, cruiser Magicienne of the German imperial mail steamer Bundesrath off Delagoa Bay. It appears that the British Foreign Office desires first to communicate with Durban on the subject.

Confirmation of a deal by which the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, with its National City Bank and Standard Oil interest, will acquire a dominant interest in the New York Gas and Electric Light, Heat and Power Company, now officially known as the Power Company, was had yesterday from the officers of the Consolidated Gas Company.
