WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In the House today Representative Sulzer of New York offered a resolution calling upon Secretary Gage for all letters and agreements entered into between him and the National City and Hanover Banks or New York relative to the deposit of public funds in those institutions.

State of New York, Executive Chamber, Albany, Jan. 3, 1900. To the Legislature of the State of New York: It is a very genuine pleasure to congratulate the Legislature upon the substantial sum of achievement in legislation and administration of the past year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- With the arrival at Manila of the transport Grant, which left San Francisco Dec. 21 with the Fortyeighth Volunteer Infantry, (colored,) Gen. Otis will have command of an effective force of about 65,000.
PARIS, Jan. 4. -- The High Court, (Senate,) in secret session to-day, condemned MM. Buffet, de Lur-Saluces, and Deroulede, to ten years banishment.

Controller Coler yesterday morning, when he learned of the action of the School Board for Manhattan and the Bronx on "Wednesday afternoon refusing to submit payrolls of the public school teachers for December in accordance with his instructions, sent a communication to the Mayor calling his attention to the matter and seeking to show that the School Board and not the Controller's office was to blame for the latest muddle in school affairs.

Fuller -- Muir. Mr. David J. Fuller and Miss Olive Beatrice Muir, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Muir, were married last evening in the Memorial Church, Washington Square South. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Judson. The bride was in a gown of white satin, trimmed with point lace, and her tulle veil was fastened with diamond ornaments and a coronet of orange blossoms.
CAPE TOWN, Jan. 3. -- The Duke of Westminster, it is announced, will remain in Cape Colony during the war.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 4. -- The Southern Presbyterian Board of Missions in this city received letters to-day from the Rev. L.C. Vass and the Rev. H.P. Hawkins, missionaries of the church stationed at Luebo, Congo Free State, Africa, giving accounts of the burning of fourteen villages and the killing of ninety or more natives by State troops.

In the very striking article of Mr. JAMES T. WOODWARD, in THE TIMES ANNUAL, FINANCIAL REVIEW, he spoke of the condition of trade throughout the land as "better than ever enjoyed by any people in any age, causing the United States to be the envy of the world."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The Roberts Investigating Committee resumed its sessions to-day. It was expected that ex-Secretary John G. Carlisle would be present to sum up the case against Roberts, and that Mr. Roberts in person would make the argument in his own behalf. Word came from Mr. Carlisle, however, that he had not understood his personal presence was desired, but he was ready to submit written arguments on any of the questions involved.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- "In Spite of All," the first dramatic effort of Edna Lyall. (Miss Ada Ellen Bayly.) was produced this evening at Eastbourne. It is a play dealing with the civil war of the seventeenth century, and was well received.

At a meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission, to be held next Tuesday, Controller Coler will discuss with the other Commissioners his plan of a rapid-transit system for the whole of the greater city. If his plans are carried out the Controller believes that the proposed bridges across the East River will never tie finished, as there will be no need of them.
ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Mrs. Chiara Cignarole, who murdered her husband in New York City in 1886, and who was serving out a life sentence in Auburn Prison, was to-day pardoned by Gov. Roosevelt.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The enrollment of the second contingent of London Imperial Volunteers this morning was the occasion for a scene of popular interest and enthusiasm. The approaches to the Guildhall were thronged with representatives of all classes, everybody cheering and the bands playing lively music.
ITHACA, Jan. 4. -- Prof. Cuthbert W. Pound says he has not heard from Gov. Roosevelt in relation to his appointment as Superintendent Payn's successor.

Whether John Schreyer's plain three-story frame house will be permitted to remain, as Lawyer Seward Baker declares, as an "eyesore" to his neighbors, on Morris Heights, who boast imposing looking dwellings with gables, conical towers, and other aesthetic accessories, depends on the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, which has decided the question against him once before.

The storm that had been brewing in the Court of General Sessions, where Roland B. Molineux is on trial for his life, broke yesterday morning, and the contending lawyers for the State and the defense were made to feel the weight of Recorder Goff's displeasure. It had been plain for several days that the Recorder was offended by the action of both Mr. Weeks and Mr. Osborne in constantly interrupting each other.

The weather conditions yesterday were so enjoyable, the bracing cold being tempered by the sun's warm rays, that there was as much social life outdoors as in, and the Avenue and other fashionable up-town streets were more gay and lively than they have been since the days when the Christmas shopping brought every one out of doors.

In yesterday's market for outside-securities the course of prices was somewhat irregular, but the net results of the day's trading were in most cases encouraging. Considerable net gains were recorded in a number of issues, and in nearly all quarters of the market the demand for stocks was fully equal to the supply.

From The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, (Rep.) Ex-Secretary Alger is reported by THE NEW YORK TIMES as saying that the financial plank of the Republican National platform of 1896 was written by Mr. Foraker and subsequently improved by himself (Alger) and then adoped. He is quoted as adding that he does "not believe any plank was prepared three or four days before."

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 4. -- The joint legislative committees which will sit in the contests for Governor and Lieutenant Governor were drawn by lot to-day, as provided by law. The drawing gave the Democrats ten out of the eleven members of the committee oh the Governor's contest, and nine out of eleven on the Lieutenant Governor's contest.

Meetings are now being held in this city from day to day for the purpose of effecting a consolidation of the various manufacturers of telephone apparatus, which are now being operated in opposition to the Bell Telephone Company. The capital involved in the new combination, which will be known as the American Telephone Manufacturing Company, will be about $10,000.00

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- The German Imperial mail steamer General has been detained at Aden and held by British troops. Although her manifests show there was no war material on board, she was compelled to discharge her cargo.

Special meetings of the stockholders of the Colonial Assurance Company and the Washington Assurance Company will be held on Feb. 5 for the purpose of taking action upon the approval of an agreement of merger of the two corporations, under the name of the Colonial Assurance Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- In accordance with the notice previously given by him Senator Aldrich to-day opened the discussion of the Financial bill in the Senate with a speech in explanation of the Senate substitute for the House bill. The speech was carefully prepared and was read from manuscript.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 4. -- A number of curious complications which have arisen in connection with the threatened water famine in South Norwalk have caused the opinion that a mysterious leak in the reservoir, which the South Norwalk Water Commissioners recently failed to locate, has been into the mains of the City of Norwalk through an open water gate.

Application was made recently to Judge Brown, in the United States District Court, to stay a suit brought In the State courts to foreclose a mechanic's lien for $1,700 due to Thomas Smith, under a contract with Emslie Co., bankrupts, and filed on April 28, 1899, the day before the petition in bankruptcy was presented to the United States District Court.

FLUSHING, L.I., Jan. 4. -- The Teachers' Association of the Borough of Queens will hold a meeting at the Flushing High School on Saturday for the purpose of formulating a programme of action in the matter of reduction of their salaries.

ALBANY, Jan 4. -- Gov. Roosevelt this afternoon made public the report of the commission appointed by him for the purpose of suggesting a plan for the unification of the educational systems of the State.

"I doubt if the arrest of the so-called 'Jack the Slasher' in Washington will put an end to the annoyance that women have suffered from so long," remarked one of the men who keeps his eyes and his ears open. "There must he several men with this, peculiar mania for slashing women's dresses, for my wife was probably a witness to the operations of one of them the other night.

Freeman D. Somerby. Freeman D., Somerby, Supreme President of the Iron Hall of Baltimore, is dead at his home in Philadelphia. His death was due to pneumonia, by which he was attacked on last Saturday. He was sixty-five years old, and leaves, a wife and three, children. Mr. Somerby was born in Boston, and was one of the organizers of the old Iron Hall, which passed into the hands of a receiver some years ago.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- The Board of Health has a young Austrian under observation at the Galloupe's Island Pesthouse, who has displayed symptoms similar to those seen in victims of the bubonic plague. The man's name is Freidele Rumpmar. He is twentyfour years old, and he came to Boston Friday last, stowaway on the British steamship Fitzclarence from Antwerp.

The interest in the series in the Harlem League last night centred on the meeting between the Morris and Harlem Wheelmen. These teams competed in the second game, and, as was expected, the game was close throughout, the Morris Wheelmen winning by thirty-three pins. The Boulevards won two games, defeating the Morris and Harlem Wheelmen. Scores:

Yesterday President Clausen of the Department of Parks announced in The City Record that he had advanced the salaries of a number of employes as follows:
More than 1,000 persons assembled in the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association Building last evening for the Moody memorial meeting held there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The Ways and Means Committee of the House, at a meeting to-day, considered the Sulzer resolution directing the Secretary of the Treasury to transmit to the House all information regarding the deposit of Government funds in the National City and Hanover National Banks of New York, and decided to recommend its adoption in a modified form.

The recommendations made by Gov. Roosevelt in his message, looking to legislative enactment for the preservation of the Palisades through joint action with the New Jersey authorities, have given much satisfaction to the various bodies which have carried on the agitation against the spoliation of this rare scenic gift which nature has bestowed upon the metropolis.

Some side lights on the customs and usages of people of wealth who seek to obtain prominence in society and are not to the manner born, were thrown in Part X., Trial Term, of the Supreme Court, yesterday, in the shape of testimony by a professional expert on society etiquette, to the undisguised enjoyment of a majority of the persons present.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- The committee having in charge the arrangements of the annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association has announced that the meeting will be held in the Common Council Chamber in the City Hall.

The corporation of the Church of Sts. Peter and Paul, in Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg, has-engaged a lawyer to look after the interests of the parish in the will of Father Sylvester Malone, who died on Friday last.

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- Exports from Berlin to the United States during the last quarter of 1899 were $1,678,840, which was an increase over the corresponding quarter in 1898 of $493,254. For the calendar year Berlin's exports were $6,633,882, or an increase over 1898 of $1,306,703.

Wall Street's erratic stock market does not much change. Activity continues, and some quotations jump around in curious ways. In yesterday's market Sugar Trust was the feature. After falling nearly a couple of points, it suddenly shot up over half a dozen, and then as abruptly receded half way back again.

The religious services held last night at the Metropolitan Temple on Seventh Avenue were conducted especially for policemen. It was called "Police Night," but less than a dozen members of the force responded to the invitations sent them. The greater part of the audience was composed of women.

Morris K. Jesup, presided yesterday at the January meeting at the Chamber of Commerce. After the election of six new members, Charles Stewart Smith reported that $150,000 is needed to complete the $1,000,000 which the new Chamber building is to cost, so that the Executive Committee felt that it should make no recommendation in regard to subscriptions from members to the Dewey Arch fund.

The sale of the Stepson tract in the Borough of the Bronx, it has developed, is only a part of a much larger deal involving a total of over $1,000,000. Mary S. Hoe, the widow of Robert Hoe of printing press fame, has sold the tract of fifty-three acres lying south of Westchester Avenue and east of the Southern Boulevard, and extending to the Bronx River.

BATH, N. Y., Jan. 4. -- The Soldiers' Home Committee of the State Board of Charities, with Deputy Attorney General Coyne and Deputy Controller Gilman, who are conducting the investigation of the administration of Col. Shepard as Commandant of the Home. convened this morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Representative Bingham of Pennsylvania to-day introduced the following joint resolution:

If Mr. W.J. BHYAN breaks off relations With Chairman JAMES K. JONES and causes him to be deposed from the Chairmanship of the Democratic Committee for the unpardonaoie crime of not being a fool all the time. JONES will have many precious compensations. It is worth much to a man to know and feel that he is not afraid to look the truth in the face.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- The early trading lacked feature, but this was replaced by activity and strength in the afternoon. Fitchburg preferred held within 1 of its highest selling, at 125@123, and closing at 124. The impression gains that the Boston and Maine will get the Fitchburg.

The negotiations which have resulted in the Consolidated Gas Company, with its Standard Oil and National City Bank interests, securing control of the New York Gas and Electric Liight, Heat and Power Company, which is to be known hereafter as the Power Company, and which has hitherto been entirely dominated by the Whitney-Elkins-Widener syndicate, are not regarded by that syndicate, it was learned yesterday, as putting it at a disadvantage.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 58 1/2@59 1/2 There were no sales.

Mr. Butler, who has both written and illustrated this very interesting book, is well known as a lecturer on architecture in the University of Princeton, besides being a Fellow of the American School of Classical Studies in Rome.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 5. -- The joint Committees on Contests for Governor and Lieutenant Governor have organized. Representative Hickman was elected Chairman of the committee on Governor's contest, and Senator Coleman Chairman of that on the Lieutenant Governor contest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- After a silence of several days, Gen. Otis to-day notified the War Department of the complete success of the military operations in northwest Luzon, the main object of which was the rescue of the American prisoners which the insurgents took with them in their flight.
At the meeting of the Brokerage Committee of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange yesterday only business of a routine character was transacted.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--Twenty-nine persons and firms paid more than $1,500 as penalties for violating the fish, game, and forestry laws during December, 1809. The largest amounts paid were for illegal fishing, hounding deer, and trespass on State lands, and the greater number of violations were in the Adirondack region.

Magistrate Worth, in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday dismissed proceedings in abandonment before him because the plaintiff did not produce a marriage certificate or record of the marriage. In this Magistrate Worth placed himself in opposition to decisions of the Supreme Court, in which common-law wives are recognized when sufficient evidence is produced to prove that the couple have lived together and been known as man and wife.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In reading your noble issues, (and I am careful, whatever I do, not to miss one,) I see a good deal cropping out among your correspondence about the everlasting Bacon-Shakespeare theory. I therefore take the liberty of sending you the within correspondence which I think may interest some of your readers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Dr. William A. Hammond, formerly Surgeon General of the army, died at his residence in this city tonight from an attack of heart disease, brought on by hurriedly ascending a flight of stairs. He expired before a physician could be summoned. Dr. Hammond had been in the house but a short time before the attack.

BOSTON, Jan. 5.--Joel G. Tyler, late teller of the Safety National Bank of Fitchburg, to-day was sentenced in the United States court by Judge Putnam to serve five years in Worcester Jail for embezzling the funds of the bank.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 5. -- W.W. Watt, a white man, was taken from the station house by a mob early this morning and shot to death for assaulting Mrs. T.M. Simpson, wife of an employe of the shipyard.

As many spectators as the courtroom could accommodate, among them being several fashionably dressed women were gazing with eager interest at the chief actors in the suit of Miss Mary E. Howe against Mrs. Frances Augusta Skinner when Justice Truax took his seat on the bench in Part X., Trial Term, of the Supreme Court, yesterday morning.

VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 5. -- The Chinese story of the battle between the French troops and natives in the Province of Qwang Tung, briefly noticed in cable dispatches, is given in The Hongkong Press in the shape of a translation from the Chun Ngoi San Po.

The papers were filed yesterday afternoon with the Clerk of the United States Circuit Court in a suit brought by G. Edgar Allen, trustee in bankruptcy, against William H. Gray, a bankrupt; Mary J. Gray, his sister, as executor and trustee under the will of their father, William Gray, and William R. Bishop, as assignee of the bankrupt.

Many of the books on China and the Chinese which have appeared during the past few years have failed to grasp the real situation, or portray that wonderful people as they actually exist in their ancient home. This is due largely to the ignorance of the writers rather than to an intentional desire to misrepresent the Chinese.

Reactions occurred in a number of stocks in the market for outside securities yesterday, and the course of prices was more irregular than on the earlier days of the week. Profit taking was in part responsible for some of the day's declines, while nothing like heavy liquidation appeared, except in one or two issues.

Frank Segila, twenty-five years old, married and living at 321 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, was stabbed to death last night by Pietro Pulize, forty-four years old, also married, living at One Hundred and First Street and First Avenue. The murder occurred in the saloon of Santo Reda, at 319 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street.

Did anybody ever speak a good word for the unfortunate guild of reviewers? Unless "The Sorrows of Satan" (which we have never read) should mayhap relate to the career of a critic, his woes have no recognition in literature. Yet the grievances of authors are as old as literature itself.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- The new Sienkiewicz novel, "The Knights of the Cross," can hardly be called a return to the manner of "With Fire and Sword" and its successors, for it is so much more intense and vivid that it begins where they cease, and the first part leaves the reader at a point of excitement beyond even that caused by the wonderful siege of the monastery.

The following story will show the high price that illustrators of reputation command for their work: A young woman who hail received treatment from Dr. S. Weir Mitchell of Philadelphia, and was very fond of him, decided, at a recent celebration of his birthday, that a fitting and appropriate gift would be the presentation of one of the original drawings of Mr. Howard Pyle for "Hugh Wynne."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I emerge from the welter of kicks and cuffs that your amiable correspondents are so ready to deal round the land on each they judge their foe with my fancy lightly turning to thoughts of arnica and court plaster, but still unconvinced that "Les Miserables" is anything but the "colossal inanity" that Mr. W.B. Dupree happily calls it.

Negotiations are pending which will probably result in the sale of the ten five-story flats recently erected by Daniel D. Lawson at 228 to 216 West One Hundred and Fourteenth Street. The broker representing Mr. Lawson, however, said yesterday afternoon that the deal had not yet been closed.

It is always interesting to have authentic details of the earnings of popular novelists. "John Strange Winter," the well-known English authoress, whose novel, "A Name to Conjure With," was favorably reviewed in these pages on Nov. 18, has for the first time publicly disclosed her actual earnings during her first fifteen years of study and work.

"The Letters to Washington," found in the second volume, published by the Society of the Colonial Dames of America, comprise the correspondence, mostly addressed to Washington, when his headquarters were at Winchester, and he was defending the frontier from the French and the Indians.

The series decided in the Harlem League last night was productive of high scores. In the first game the Empires rolled up a total of 999 pins, defeating the Phoenix team. This is the second best score made in the tournament. The Empires made the best score last November, a total of 1,103 pins, which is the world's record.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- There was considerable of a muss here last night over the formation of a lodge of Elks for Westchester County. It was given out by those interested in forming the lodge that the initiation fee for those joining at the first meeting would be $3.50. As a result there were applications from all parts of the county, and the lodge promised to start off with over 300 members.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 5. -- Mrs. William. H. Gootee of this city was made happy this week by the return to her of $752 which she lost on Nov. 30, 1898. On the afternoon of that day Mrs. Gootee went to the Tax Office in the City Hall, taking with her a package containing $752, which she intended to deposit in bank.

Three persons are known to have been burned to death and several more are missins as the result of a fire which was discovered in a five-story tenement at 305 East Ninety-second Street, at 12:10 this morning. The dead so far as known are two women and a child. Four firemen were overcome by smoke and gas.

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- Copper and the copper shares are uppermost in the Boston market. To-day's trading found the dividend payers still adding points to previous quotations, notwithstanding the efforts to choke off the current of prosperity that is ever with Broker Lawson. The coppers to-day had good company in Dominion Coal, New England Gas and Coke securities, and Chicago, Burlington and Quincy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day began its investigation of the charges of bribery made in connection with the election of Senator Clark of Montana. The proceedings were begun by arguments from counsel on both sides. Air. Clark himself was present with his counsel, ex-Senator Faulkner.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- The centre of attraction at Tuxedo is the tennis club. Many New Yorkers came out to-day to stay over Sunday and play a game of tennis with Champion Miles, the English expert, who is now playing in fine form.

To those having any personal experience in the gold fields of the world the idea of personal comfort is not suggested by the mention of any one of them. Gold digging, gold washing, or any of the other methods whereby gold is converted from its natural and usually unavailable condition into the gold that symbolizes the sum of all human happiness, signifies anything but luxury while the process used is going on.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: "My Beloved, the Author, Mr. William Shakespeare." This is no modern inscription. It is the phrase of the renowned Ben Jonson, published but seven years after the death of his beloved, and formed a part to the introductory matter of the first edition of Shakespeare's collected plays, printed at London in 1623.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The Roberts investigating committee continued its session to-day, with a large crowd of interested spectators present. Among these was Miss Roberts, the daughter of the Utah member-elect, who sat near him and followed attentively the argument presented by her father, who presented his own defense.

The Governor's Unification Commission has treated the question of the Regents of the University in a weak, temporizing, and evasive manner. There is a question of the Regents. The commission appointed by the Governor dodged it. Its plan will put the entire school system of the State in peril if it is adopted without change.
LONDON, Jan. 5. -- A dispatch from South Africa states that Col. Pilcher has returned to Belmont from Douglas. He was accompanied by many refugees.

Prof. Peck's style has the first-rate merit of lucidity and the further advantage of being highly sonorous. Both these qualities he knows how to value. He is clear because he never disturbs the bottom of a subject; all his ideas float easily, and eves gayly, on the surface. There is nothing we need, stop to think about.

The joint legislative Committee on Taxation, which was in session at the Murray Hill Hotel for many days, will submit its report to the Legislature, probably on the 15th inst., though it may he delayed several days thereafter. While neither Senator Higgins nor Senator Stranahan, when in the city, would make public the tenor of the document, they intimated that it would recommend some radical changes in the system of taxation.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: "Richard Carvel" was very fond of visiting at "The House of the Wolf," where he could plainly hear "The Choir Invisible" and "Trinity Bells." He had to pass through "June's Garden" and "Lost Man's Lane" to get there, and "Looking Backward," often saw "David Harum" riding on "Black Beauty," whereupon he gave him a "Rose in Bloom" and "Five Little Peppers" tied with "A Bow of Orange Ribbon."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 5. -- The trial of Julia Morrison, the actress charged with the murder of Frank Leiden, on the Opera House stage, in this city. Sept. 22 last, was resumed in the Circuit Court this morning. Miss Morrison appeared attired in black and sat with her attornevs. Mrs. George J. Antz, sister of Leiden, the murdered man, was also in court.

The controversy between Controller Coler and officials of the Board of Education as to the proper way in which the pay rolls of the public school teachers should be made out was continued yesterday with unabated vigor. The Controller left town to deliver an address in Boston, and it was said that he would not return to his office until Monday.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 5. -- Three girls were saved from death in Patchogue Pond last night by the action of several young men and the coolness of one of the girls. The pond was crowded with skaters. One part of it had been gone over by the ice cutters, and had but a thin covering of ice.

RAHWAY, N.J., Jan. 5. -- A run on the Union County Bank of this city was inaugurated yesterday, and to-day the bank was kept busy paying out money, mostly to small depositors. The bank was kept open until nearly 4 o'clock this afternoon, and paid every demand presented. Cashier terwood declared that there was money enough to pay all who might call tomorrow.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In view of the storm of protest which was raised by Henry A. Newborry's opinion of the prose writings of Victor Hugo, allow me to quote a short extract from a letter of Ivan Turgeniev to M. Stassov, which appeared in The Atlantic Monthly for November, 1899, to show that some writers of distinction, besides Mr. Newberry, do not rate Hugo's prose works very high.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Jan. 5.--Despite the threats of members of the congregation of the old Dutch Reformed Church at Port Ewan that they will force the pastor, the Rev. William Burton, to resign, the minister is still watching over his flock, or at least over the few who are still cleaving to him.

A large audience listened at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, last evening to an address by Mayor Samuel M. Jones of Toledo on "The New Citizenship." The affair was under the auspices of the Civitas and GetTogether Clubs. Mr. Jones was greeted with prolonged applause when he made his appearance on the platform.

When one thinks or the extraordinary spread of cilvilization during the past century, and especially within present memory, and compares his present knowledge with any old map of Africa and America of the arctic and antarctic zones or the vast spaces girdled by the South Sea, he wonders whether anything remains to whet the curiosity or satisfy the wanderlust of the explorer.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Reading Donald G. Mitchell's "English Lands. Letters, and Kings," is like sitting down with a dear friend and listening to delightful talk or his travels -- the people and things he has seen and the impressions they have left on his genial and cultured mind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Secretary Wilson, in an interview to-day, emphasized the great commercial significance of the "open door" agreement of the powers respecting China. He said that but for this action the United States would have been shut out from trade advantages in any provinces of which other nations might see fit lo take possession.

The Free Lectures to the People, which might be called the Department of Adult Education of the Public School System, began again on Jan. 4 in one centre, and by Jan. 8 the second course of the eleventh successful year will be in full operation in forty-six different neighborhoods; or in three more places than were in operation on Dec. 15, when the first course of this season came to an end.

Last year was not a good one for Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians, and Reformed Church people in New York City. According to their own official records, all of them lost in membership of both churches and Sunday schools. Baptists show an almost uniform loss in every part of the city. It was 845 last year, or 2 1-3 per cent.

The Rev. Father Sbarretti, Bishop-nominate of Havana, is spending the time until the arrival of his brief from Rome acquainting himself with the personal records of priests in this and other dioceses, whom it may be desirable to ask to go to Cuba to take the places of Spanish priests who may desire to return home.
LUDWIG WOLFF died last night at his home, 114 East Sixty-first Street. He was born in Bavaria thirty-nine years ago, and was a manufacturer of jackets. He leaves a wife.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The seizure of the Bundesrath remains the dominant topic of the German press. Influential papers like The Berliner Tageblatt, Cologne Volkszeitung, Berliner Neueste Nachrichten, Hamburger Correspondenz, and the semi-official Berliner Post strongly hint at the possibility of Germany forming an anti-British coalition with Russia and France.

RICHMOND, Jan. 5. -- Richmond this evening suffered the severest fire loss it has known for years. About 3 o'clock fire broke out in the Merchants and Planters' tobacco warehouse, which covered about a third of a block. In it were stored some 3,000 hogsheads of tobacco, 2,600 of which belonged to the American Tobacco Company.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: After reading Mr. Noyes's letter of Dec. 23, I could not help but wonder if a liking for "David Harum" really indicated a lack of refinement. I wondered why I had not discovered it to be "coarse" and "vulgar," a collection of "offensive" "nastiness."

"How Washington has been caricatured!" was the expression of one visitor to the Grolier Club after viewing the collection of Washington portraits that have been exhibited there during the last three weeks. This collection of about 300 pieces, mostly engravings, has been wonderfully interesting and instructive, not only to the lover of Washingtoniana, but to the more ordinary individual who has not made the man the subject of his thoughts and researches.

We have been much interested lately in reading the letter from "Cactus Flower" printed in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Dec. 23, in which the assertion was made that "only a lonely man knows the true friendship of books," and also that "you may gather in city streets the wisdom of humanity, but you must go to the desert to come at the heart of books.

The first of the Knickerbocker dances, otherwise known, as Mrs. Coe's class, was held last evening in the large ballroom at Delmonico's. The guests were received by Mrs. Coe, who wore a costume of white crepe de chine, with insertions and waist of French point, spangled in silver, and diamonds and opals; Miss Helen Gould, and other patronesses.

A School Trustee who is also an officer of the Ancient Order of Hibernians might be expected to find work for himself in these days, when even historians have become infected with the desire to pander to the accursed and so-called "AngloSaxon understanding." Such a school officer and Celt is Mr. KEATING of Chicago.

BATH, N.Y., Jan. 5.--Before the committee of the State Board of Charities investigating the charges against Col. Charles O. Shepard, the commandant, Capt. Otis H. Smith of Bath, Secretary of the Board of Trustees, swore that he was present in February, 1898, when champagne was served to the members of the legislative committee in the home chapel by order of Col. Shepard, and that the latter was intoxicated on that occasion.

Miss Fisher, the author of this book, in her preface makes an extremely modest claim to the attention of readers, simply stating that this book on American literature is the outgrowth of work in her classrooms, her pupils having been encouraged as much as possible to seek the author in his work and to grow familiar both with his thoughts and his manner of expression.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The Duchess of Marlborough, the Countess of Essex, Lady Georgiana Curzon, Mme. Von Audre, and the leading members of the Imperial Yeomanry Hospital Fund, appeal to the people of the United States and Canada in behalf of their efforts to equip and maintain a hospital, with a base at Cape Town.

We were saying yesterday that the sensitiveness the German press showed concerning the reported seizures and searches of German ships was undue and hyperaesthetic. But it seems that, if the facts are as they are reported to be, the seizure of the German liner General is an exception.
The spectacle afforded by the School Board of Manhattan and the Bronx is not edifying. It is not so, even when we take the officers' own statement of their action and their motives.

An opportunity for serious art study is offered by the Brooklyn Art Students' Association, which has just been organized by former students of the Brooklyn Art School. A studio has been secured in the Jefferson Building, on Court Square. Classes will be under the direction of Mr. Joseph H. Boston, who was for several years instructor at the Brooklyn Art School before that institution was closed.

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- The principal speaker at the regular monthly meeting of the Massachusetts' Reform Club to-night was Controller B.S. Coler of New York, who spoke on the "Reform of Political Machines." He said, in part:
LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The War Office has received, through Gen. Forestier-Walker at Cape Town, the following dispatch from Col. Baden-Powell, dated Mafeking, Dec. 26:
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5. -- Go See, a Chinese murderer, convicted of killing a countryman, was hanged to-day at San Quentin Prison.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 5. -- Dr. Henry A. Rowland, Professor of Physics at the Johns Hopkins University, has made a discovery of great importance to the scientific world. It is in the nature of an explanation of the cause of the magnetism of the earth.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your correspondent, F. J. Root, is right; our old school readers do indeed have a charm for us, as all of our schoolday books have. I was brought up on the "Sanders Series," and have often regretted that I do not possess these old friends.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. Morgan Rubertson has written much about the cruelty practiced upon seamen by officers of vessels, and defies contradiction. It is not my intention to controvert the position taken by him in your SATURDAY REVIEW of Nov. 18, but I would call attention to recent legislation which tends to prevent cruelty and to punish the Captains and males of whom he complains.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 5. -- There were a number of prominent players here to start in a tournament on the links of the Florida East Coast Club this afternoon, among them being W.H. Davis and A.W. Black of Lakewood, who arrived last night.

The present policy in the Philippines was the subject of a debate at a well-attended meeting of the People's Institute, at Cooper Union, last night. Edward M. Shepard took the negative position against Prof. B.R.A. Seligman of Columbia University, who supported the Administration's policy. That Mr. Shepard's announced appearance had drawn out a large number of supporters of his position was apparent from the greeting which was accorded him when he came upon the platform.

TRENTON, Jan. 6 -- The new Legislature of New Jersey comes into existence next Tuesday afternoon. The most distinguishing feature about it is that it is a "young man's Legislature." Three-fourths of the members of the entire body are under fifty years of age and one-half are under forty. The majority of the men in the House of Assembly are between thirty and forty.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- President Harper of the University of Chicago has again demonstrated his remarkable gifts as a money raiser by bringing in all but $315,000 of the sum necessary to secure the $2,000,000 proffered by Mr. Rockefeller. As the time in which he had to raise this money has been extended three month he feels certain that Mr. Rockefeller's gift will yet come to the university.

NOTWITHSTANDING the lurid descriptions of "desperate fighting" and "bloody work" in South Africa, it is a fact the British losses in actual killed and wounded in all their engagements up to date do not much if at all exceed their losses in the single battle of New Orleans with raw American volunteers, Jan. 8, 1815, the eighty-fifth anniversary of which occurs to-morrow.

ROME, Dec. 24 -- According to the report of the Ministry of Commerce and Agriculture, the total value of goods imported into Italy during the first ten months of the past year, exclusive of precious metals, amounted to 1,184,022,612 Italian lire, or about $256,804,522. The exports during the same period reached the total of 1,055,824,150 lire, or about $211,164,830.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of Jan. 3, under the title "The Justification of Wealth," in which you comment upon the splendid gift of Mr. Andrew Carnegie to the Cooper Union, end's with these words: "Riches justify themselves against all accusers when they are wisely employed by their possessor for the raising up of his fellowmen."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your justification of great wealth is that the original accumulator had to do some work or service for it, that he employed labor, and in some cases gives some of it away. No one denies Mr. Hewitt's statement that the accumulation of wealth is a blessing.

South Africa imports hides, wool, and mohair, and the ranchman would revel in riches were it not for the various pests that decimate his flocks and herds. The most deadly one is the rinderpest, a cattle plague which in the last ten years has been slowly creeping from Central Africa southward, leaving a wake of whitened bones.

January has come in with a hearty Winter welcome. The weather has been such as to require very heavy clothing and all sorts of protection from the cold. Skating is just now very much in vogue, and the hockey matches at Tuxedo and Meadow Brook occupy the attention of society.

THE contribution of Emma M. Hooper, enntied "Rational Dress for Women," published in THE TIMES of Sunday, Dec. 24, is an obvious and weak attempt to explain and to defend irrational dress. It is so far from being a reasonable, not to say considerate, reply to the well-timed address of Mr. Bush-Brown, that the present writer is disposed to add a few words in very plain language.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 6 -- The petition of Julia Marlowe Taber for a divorce, heard recently before Chief Justice Taft in the Lamoille County Court, was granted in a session of court held at Hyde Park this afternoon. The bill is granted for intolerable severity, and alimony of $3,000 accompanies it.

"There is one thing about calendars; you don't care at all how many you have," says the girl who has lots of friends. "Once in a while I have what I call a calendar year, and every one gives me one of some kind or description. But I love every one, and I wouldn't give away the meanest to my dearest friend.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 6 -- The approaching Gubernatorial campaign promises to be one of the most exciting ever waged in this State, unless there is a decided change of front on the part of either Morgan S. Bulkeley of Hartford or Samuel Fessenden of Stamford.

Interest in family history is by no means on the wane, if the statements of librarians, who have ample means of judging, may be believed. At the Lenox Library the call for genealogical works is constantly increasing, and numerous seekers into family records are inquiring for information almost daily at the rooms of the New York Historical Society.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Assemblyman Harburger of New York City will introduce on Wednesday next an excise bill in the House, providing for the regulation of traffic in liquors by the local executive authorities of the towns and cities of the State. These local boards shall prescribe the character and grades of licenses, the fees to be paid therefore and the hours and days during which liquors may be sold or exposed for sale.
For the skater who dislikes the congested condition of the lakes of the city's parks, and who has a little time at his disposal, the Shrewsbury River offers a splendid field for his exertions.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The annual report of the State Court of Claims, which will be submitted to the Legislature next week, will point out the fact that to date 707 claims arising from improvement work to the canal system under the nine-miilion-dollar appropriation act have been filed with that court.

Joseph Drew, agent, bookkeeper, and collector for the New Jersey Sandy Hook Pilots, whose offices are in the Chesebrough Building, in State Street, is missing. He was last at the office on Tuesday. He went to his home in Hoboken as usual that night after leaving the office, and left ostensibly to go to the office next morning.

Fire Patrolman Charles McCabe doesn't insist that all of his rescues be spectacular. He is willing to forego the slim heroine of Bowery melodrama and in her stead carry a fat colored woman down five stories. All this he will do and more, but when it comes to acting the porter for a colored star boarder and rescuing his trunk by the same method he does object.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day prices were weak at the opening, partly due to stories of Russia massing troops on the frontier of Afghanistan.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- A man registering as Benjamin J. Guerra of New York was found dead in the Lafayette Hotel today. By his side was found a half-emptied laudanum bottle and a revolver, which had not been used. The man arrived at the hotel on Friday afternoon. Nothing is known of him here, and he left no clue to show why he took his life.

The United States Treasury issues daily a statement of its condition at the close of business on the previous day. To this is added a statement of the receipts and expenditures for that day, for the current month up to and including that day, and for the expired portion of the fiscal year -- that is, for the year for which the annual appropriations are made, which begins on the first day of July.

The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor wishes to acknowledge the receipt of $200 from an elderly man, who refused to give his name or wait for a receipt. General Agent Frank Tucker said yesterday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a paper of yesterday, under the heading "Old Records of Long Lives," after giving the ages of Old Parr, Henry Jenkins, and a few others, it gives "Martha Rorke, who died at the age of 133 in 1840," ending with: "Some others there are who got well past the century mark, but not beyond the age of 125."

The bodies of Mrs. Mary Sutherly and her children, Frank, nine years of age, and James, twenty-two months old, who lost their lives in the fire in the five-story tenement house at 305 East Ninety-second Street early yesterday morning, were taken to the Morgue yesterday, where funeral services will be held to-day.

Golf for 1899 is finished, but by no means forgotten. In many respects it has been a red-letter year in the annals of American golf, and its memories will be kept alive long into future seasons. The year, however, was scarcely closed are preparations began for the coming activities. In official circles the next four or six weeks are as busy as any in the year.

The handsome edifice of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, at the southwest corner of Marcy and Gates Avenues, Brooklyn, was gutted by fire early last evening. The loss on the building and its furnishings is estimated at $50,000.

Peter Latham, the champion of the world, and Eustace H. Miles, the amateur champion of England, won the international match at doubles in racquets from George Standing, the American professional champion, and Quincy A. Shaw, Jr., the holder of the amateur championship of America, in the court of the Racquet and Tennis Club, on West Forty-third Street, yesterday afternoon.

State Senator Nevada M. Stranahan, Chairman of the joint legislative committee appointed to revise the tax laws, has received a letter from J.C Levi urging the committee to report favorably the bill for home rule in taxation by counties. The letter is as follows:
CINCINNATI, Jan. 6 -- A cablegram from Rome, Italy, received to-day, announces the death there of Judge John B. Stallo, formerly of this city.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 6 -- The wives and daughters of business men in several Kansas towns have inaugurated a movement that has endeared them to the wives and daughters of the farmers. In a dozen or more of the county seat towns of the State "rest rooms," or clubs, have been provided for the accommodation of the women who spend one day each week in town shopping.

The largest sale of rare postage stamps ever held in this country is to be begun on Wednesday evening in the Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building, 109 East Twenty-second Street. The sale will be continued on Thursday and Friday evenings of this week, and on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday evenings of next week.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 6 -- The hearing in the Julia Morrison case was resumed this morning, Miss Morrison being on the stand for cross-examination. The witness related her statements as to the epithets applied to her by Leiden leading up to the tragedy. The letter written by her to Manager Harris was introduced in evidence.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 6 -- The Rev. Dr. McLane, a leading Congregational minister of this city, made an investigation of the number of professing Christians in the freshman class at Yale shortly after they assembled last Fall. He found that 67 per cent, of the students at Yale in the freshman class are church members.

A large reception was given by Mrs. Whitelaw Reid yesterday afternoon at her residence, 451 Madison Avenue, for her niece, Miss Mary Crocker. This was really Miss Crocker's formal debut, although she has been going out considerably, as Mrs. Reid has not been at her Winter residence long enough to permit a formal affair of this kind earlier in the season.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 6 -- Congressman John J. Lentz of Ohio made a radical antiimperialist address to-night before a big audience in the Light Guard Armory. The meeting was the first of a series undertaken by the Mohawk Democratic Club, to be held at intervals previous to the general election next November.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- It is stated to-night that the British note in reply to the representations of the United States Government on the subject of the seizure of American goods by Great Britain will be given to Ambassador Choate on Monday.

If merriment and good fellowship be aids to digestion, then the choice wines and dainty viands of which the members and guests partook at the thirty-fourth annual banquet of the Cercle Francais de I'Harmonie, held at Sherry's last night, could only have been conducive to healthful sleep and pleasant dreams.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- There was a striking scene in the court room of the headquarters of the Honorable Artillery Company today, when the Lord Mayor, A.J. Newton; Sheriffs, and Aldermen attended in state to swear in the company, accompanying a four-gun battery, which is going to the front.

Julia Marlowe ended her ten weeks' engagement at the Criterion Theatre last night before just such a crowded house as has marked her every performance. Many were heard to express regrets that the run of "Barbara Frietchie" had gone its course for the metropolis, for Mr. Fitch's play was in the height of its success.

Prof. Alfred Morrison, teacher of languages in wealthy private families at Mount Vernon and Larchmont, and who shot and killed the woman with whom he lived as his wife at their home, 235 South Tenth Street, Mount Vernon, on the night of Dec. 28, had been leading a double life for several years previous to the shooting.

SYDNEY, Dec. 5 -- In Australasia the commencement of the year is during the height of Summer, in the middle of the wool season, and before harvesting operations have started, consequently there is invariably some degree of uncertainty in making industrial or commercial forecasts extending several months ahead.

The case of HOWE against SKINNER, which has been occupying the attention of Judge TRUAX'S court for several days, is one of a class which undoubtedly ministers to the enjoyment of all those not immediately concerned in it. Their enjoyment may be even heightened, according to the cynical observation of LA ROCHEFOUCAULD, by the sufferings of the parties to the controversies, of whom at least one is not in court of his own volition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Late developments in the South African situation have led to some discussion of the possible need for American naval representation in those waters. The State Department, it is understood, does not want American ships to be sent to Africa unnecessarily, while in the Navy Department there are some who believe that the service should be represented at the seat of war.

Wall Street markets at the opening of the year are erratic, sharp advances and equally sharp declines marking the course of prices, and few movements seeming to reflect any well defined business cause. Such a market course is not unnatural, as sequel to the extraordinary disturbance which overwhelmed Stock Exchange serenity during December.

Perhaps the most beneficial influence now working for the stage in this country is the new stock, company system which has lately gained much strength because of the comparatively small number of touring companies now presenting serious plays. Twelve of these organizations are enumerated as "important" by The Dramatic Mirror.

The fatal mistake of a hospital nurse in taking carbolic acid for tincture of delphino, or larkspur, was the cause of the death of Henry Smith, thirty-four years old, a musician, of 138 Ludlow Street, in the City Hospital Friday night. The nurse, James Gray, is under arrest.

SANTO DOMINGO, Jan. 6 -- The public subscriptions to liquidate the BoismareCaccavelli claim of 280,000f., payment of which is being pressed by the French Consul, largely cover the amount needed. A French fleet is expected to visit Santo Domingo, but the country is quiet, though considerable patriotic feeling is expressed throughout the republic.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I think the letter of Mr. Thomas G. Shearman in your columns should convince any one, even prejudiced Americans, that the Outlanders in the Transvaal needed a champion to sustain them in their just demands, and that Kruger and his associates are tyrants in disguise.

Morris Williams, a tile layer, of 120 West Ninety-eighth Street, who was locked up in the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, Friday night on a charge of shooting Dennis Farley, a coachman of 509 East Eightyfirst Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Mott in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning, and was held to await the result of Farley's injuries.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 6 -- Nathan Kirk, a farmer living in Ludingtonville, N.Y., a short distance from this city, was driving from his home to Mill Plain, several miles distant, and had allowed his attention to wander, when the horse went on a railroad track, which the road crosses. Kirk was aroused, from his reflections by the sound of an approaching passenger train behind him.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- "The men were crowding round the engines on the line offering the drivers fabulous prices for a cup of water," writes The Globe correspondent, describing the close of the battle at Enslin, "but it was useless. The drivers had been threatened with courtmartial if they supplied any, as there was great difficulty in keeping a sufficient supply for the engines.

[FROM A SPECIAL CONTRIBUTOR.] The great increase in the volume of life insurance shown by the latest reports, and the large accumulation of resources by the leading companies, are suggestive of the extent to which life insurance is used nowabays as a means of investing savings, apart from the consideration of the protection of families and dependent persons against the loss of their main support by death.

One hundred years ago notices similar to the following, taken from The Commercial Advertiser of Jan. 7, 1800, were regularly seen in the few newspapers that supplied the residents of New York with information of what was going on both at home and abroad:

Riley Grannan, the plunger who created a sensation on the American turf some years ago by making one of the largest wagers ever recorded -- on Henry of Navarre when the latter ran his famous dead heat with the black whirlwind Domino -- has been making matters interesting for the poolroom keepers in this city during the past few weeks.
Emil L. Beas, manager of the Hamburg American Line, discussing ocean freights recently, gave a shipping man's idea of the questions involved in the matter of canal improvements.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The departure of "The Belle of New York" company on the steamship St. Paul to-day attracted a crowd of their friends at the Waterloo Station, many of whom accompanied the company to Southampton.

The principal new play in to-morrow night's theatrical, programme will be a farcical comedy by David Belasco, who has been hitherto, except in his attempts at "comic relief," in serious drama, (and these have not been his happiest attempts,) grave, emotional, and "dramatic" But since the day of "La Belle Russe" Mr. Belasco has had very few failures.

No race of men can surpass the Chinese in habits of industry and thrift, says D.Z. Sheffield in the January Atlantic. With the introduction of Western civilization the vast resources of the country will be developed, the products of the soil and manufacture will indefinitely increase, and domestic and international trade will be multiplied in its proportions.

The West End Association held its annual banquet at the Savoy Hotel last evening. About 100 members and guests were present. In the absence of President Cyrus Clark, owing to a recent death in his family, First Vice President James Van Dyck Card presided. At the guests' table with him were Justice James A. O' Gorman, John S. Wise, the Rev. Dr. John Balcom Shaw, W.H. McElroy, George W. Plunkitt, and Lawson Purdy.

HAVANA, Dec. 31 -- One year ago to-morrow the American army marched into Havana and took formal possession of the island, as guardians until such time as it could be turned over to the Cuban people. Amid the shouts and cheers of the people the Spanish flag was hauled down and our flag raised.

The following claim for extra pay for service during the Spanish war will be found of interest to Guardsmen in general who served in the volunteers: When Company K, Second Regiment, of Glens Falls was mustered out of the United States service, after the Spanish war, there was a difference of opinion between the Captain, now Major, Loyal L. Davis, and the Army Paymaster as to the amount due the men.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Administration seems to be having as much trouble with Schley as the late Mr. Macbeth had with the ghost of the departed Banquo. There is no record that Banquo's ghost worried itself about what Macbeth was doins, and the parallel seems to hold even at this late day.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- Advices from Durban, Natai, say that the German steamer Herzog has been seized by a British warship and taken to that port.

"I know what 'leaders' are, for I have written them," said Benjamin Disraeli in the course of a speech in the House of Commons, and though all of us may not have written "leaders" for The Morning Post and other newspapers, like Disraeli, we all at least know the meaning of the term "leaders."

In a collision late yesterday afternoon in Gravesend Bay between the schooner Hattie T. Burns of Bath, Me., loaded with lumber, and the tugboat James A. Miller, two men were injured. The schooner under full sail had just passed the Government Pier at Fort Hamilton, and was about to make a tack, when the tugboat crashed into her.

RELATIVE RIGHTS OF WAGONS AND STREET RAILROAD CARS -- Richard Warren, sitting in a grocery wagon, the back and sides of which were inclosed by oilcloth curtains, was driving along White Plains Avenue, in this city, in the centre of which was the track of the Union Railway Company of New York.

QUINCY, Ill., Jan. 6 -- The safe in Judge F. William Heckenkamp's office was blown open to-day, and notes to the amount of $20,000 and $100 in cash were stolen. The notes, about twenty in number, belong to the St. Aloysius Orphans' Society.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- We begin the year in considerable soberness of mind. All the week the newspapers have been providing us with highly colored descriptions of marches, stormings, and surprises, followed, unfortunately, by retreats too often; but that sort of thing has begun to pall, and people's minds have all along been concentrated upon the coming struggle for the relief of Ladysmith.
RAHWAY, N.J., Jan. 6 -- The Union County Bank of Rahway suspended business this morning. The following notice was placed on the front door of the building:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to thank you for the report given in THE TIMES of the speech of President John W. Keller of the Department of Public Charities at the Seventh Assembly District meeting of the Tammany organization. This little speech is the most amusing of any I have read for a long time.

ZAMBOANGA, P.I., Nov. 19 -- The longlooked-for event has at last happened, and Zamboanga has fallen into our hands as easily and quietly as if there had not been a bitter, murderous war raging here for the past six months. The navy did it, and to Commander Very of the Castine the credit is due.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in this morning's TIMES on "The Justification of Wealth" was an able and plausible presentation of this question from the viewpoint of "The Man with the Millions." Will THE TIMES print the other side, as viewed by "The Man with the Hoe" ?

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 6 -- In New Milford, a town of 3,000 inhabitants, the unusual sight of nearly all the prominent citizens, church leaders, and temperance advocates in the roles of habitual frequenters of the saloons of the town may be seen now. This is the result of a novel crusade against the drink habit that has been instituted there.

After spending five weeks in examining witnesses for the prosecution in the trial of Roland B. Molineux, charged with the murder of Katherine J. Adams, Assistant District Attorney Osborne admitted yesterday that he had not been able to bring to light any motive for an attempt by the defendant on the life of Harry S. Cornish.

To the Editor of The New York Times:Your editorial of the 3d inst. under the above title would seem to do more for the Socialistic argument than anything usually advanced by its advocates. You say, "They treat ricbes as culpable in themselves," but your editorial from the caption given above to its finish is based on exactly that ground.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- In the belated report of the Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission, which has just come from the press, are several tracts over the signature of Col. William F. Fox, Superintendent of Forests, on subjects relating to forest protection and cultivation. He advocates that tree planting in cities should be under municipal control.

The contest of the will of George Starrett. brought by Mary Catherine and Anna Frances Starrett, his two daughters, came up yesterday before Surrogate Noble of Queens County. The proponent is Georga Babcock Starrett, son of the testator. The estate is valued at about $150,000.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- In the Boston market it was a day of light trading and general steadiness. Sugar was practically the only active stock, and that jumped up and down rapidly. The coppers continue to ignore the general market, and, inspired by the strong showing of Amalgamated, climb on their own account.

A rumor that Sir Thomas Lipton had issued another challenge for the America's Cup created considerable excitement in yachting circles yesterday. In the afternoon many members of the New York Yacht Club visited the Madison Avenue house, and commented upon the possibilities of victory for the latest cup hunter.
Three men were ushered into the room. One was tall and of strong, well-marked features and dignified presence. The other two were stout and florid and rather nervous in manner, brothers apparently.

Apart from the trading in one or two is sues, recently become prominent, transactions in the market for outside securities yesterday were not in very large amount and most of the day's net changes were relatively unimportant. Variations of a point or more were mostly on the side of advances, showing the market to be fairly strong.

MAMARONECK, N.J., Jan. 6 -- The war between the Village Trustees and the Westchester Electric Railway Company, which has been on for a week, was brought to a close to-day by the parties entering into a compromise by which the road will be completed and everybody will bo satisfied.

Martha Gradot, thirty-four years old, was found dead in her rooms at 3,935 Third Avenue on Dec. 27 last. In a crib close beside the woman's bed was her ten months' old daughter. The day before the woman died her husband, Thomas R. Gradot, deserted her, and nothing has been heard from him since.

The geologist poking about among the boulders or the botanist bending with his microscope over a weed gets no impression of the beauty of the landscape. If you give your time to the study of brush strokes, pigments, and the weave of the canvas, the meaning of the painter's composition escapes you altogether.

I knew Macaulay, of whom it was said and believed that he could repeat a leading article of The Times after having read it once: but I never had the heart to ask him to let me hear him do so. Prof. Conington at Oxford enjoyed the same reputation, but I never heard him either repeat a few pages after he had read them.
I was riding one day across an open grass plain in Matabeleland, with one native, scouting.

From the Athenaeum. The higher the pitch the greater the brilliancy of tone, would seem to be the chief argument of those who are opposed to the movement for reduction. Some, again, are influenced by the practical difficulties connected with any change, notably the expense with regard to the instruments of military bands.

VIENNA, Dec. 19 -- For almost two years now the Government has been carried on only by means of one paragraph of the Constitution, the notorious Emergency Clause 14, which provides that if a bill is not passed by Parliament the Government may sanction it. Last Autumn Parliament again was brought into working order, but that brief episode now threatens to terminate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6--Secretary Long has addressed the following letter to the Chairman or the Committee on Naval Affairs of the Senate and of the House, embodying the department's latest view as to the best means of rewarding the officers who participated in the destruction of Cervera's fleet, off Santiago:

The performance of the Brahms violin concerto by Miss Leonora Jackson at the Philharmonic concerts gave another opportunity to the opponents of the composer to have a fling at him. His violin concerto has long been one of the favorite compositions of his enemies. It is not music for the public, nor is it favorable to the business of the concerto in exhibiting the resources of the solo instrument.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 6 -- The Pittsburg and New Kensington (Penn.) tin-plate plants, which were closed down by the American Tin Plate Company about six weeks ago, will resume operations on Monday next. The resumption will give employment to 1,000 men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The State Department has published a report on labor conditions in Hawaii, secured by Agent Sewall from Wray Taylor, the Secretary of the Hawaiian Board of Immigration. Mr. Taylor's statement is devoted chiefly to contract labor, and he evidently considers free labor as an unimportant factor in Hawaii.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The hostile fury against England provoked by the Transvaal Was shows signs of wearing itself out. It was always limited to a small band of Nationalists who cannot forgive the English for their championship of Dreyfus. The government has no inclination whatsoever to be otherwise than on good terms with the greatest naval power in the world.

The Pittsburg Orchestra, founded by the Art Society, was organized in the Fall of 1895, following the dedication of Carnegie Institute. Mr. Carnegie's gift for education of a noble building that should contain a music hall was the incentive that brought the orchestra into life. Though existing in sympathetic alliance with the great work emanating from Carnegie Institute the orchestra is independent of it.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 2 -- Serious-minded men -- those so serious and gloomy as to be averse to new sensations, if they are merely innocent and playful -- may look upon the trip of the Gridiron Club of Washington to this city, to become the guests of the city, and to dine several times with their hosts, a frivolous and useless undertaking.

Two company matches for the Capt. Henry S. Steele and Halsted Trophies were shot last night at the Seventh Regiment armory ranges. The former event was the first of the series of two annual competitions for the possession of the Steele Trophy, which was won last year by Company C. The team from Company B, with a score of 314 out of a possible 350, won temporary possession of the trophy last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On various occasions recently THE TIMES, with its happy faculty of feeling the pulse of the public to diagnose its needs, has called attention in its columns to the unfortunate prejudice against the use of typewritten letters for private correspondence, with a reasonable plea for the removal of a ban which adds so largely to the constantly increasing burden of a busy man's up-to-date correspondence.

The gigantic deal in the Bronx, although, strictly speaking, not a part of the week's business, has for the time being completely overshadowed other transactions, and would doubtless have had the same effect even in a period of more active dealing than the present.

There was a very dark clay on Black Friday." 1745, when the Young Pretender, with the Highland clansmen, was at Derby, with nothing between him and London but Cumberland's half-organized, half-hearted force at Finchley, and when a French invasion, supported by a great Jacobite rising all over England, appeared imminent.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company of Eastern New York, with a capital of $10,000, filed articles of incorporation yesterday with the Secretary of State. The general route of the company takes in the Counties of Suffolk, Nassau, Queens, Kings, Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Columbia, Rensselaer, Saratoga, Washington, Warren, Essex, Clinton, Franklin, Schenectady, Albany, Greene, Ulster, Orange, Rockland, Richmond, and New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Six hundred Democrats gathered in the banquet hall of the Tremont House this evening to observe "Jackson Day" in an appropriate manner. William Jennings Bryan was the honored guest and chief orator of the occasion. Mayor Harrison of Chicago acted as toastmaster.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The decision of Edward Corrigan to bring over a great string of American horses is hailed here with interest and pleasure. One sporting authority writes that Mr. Corrigan never does things by halves, adding "it is safe betting that such a collection of racers as he will send has seldom, if ever, been gathered together by an American owner."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Secretary of the Navy has received a most interesting report from Capt. Leary, Governor of Guam, recording his achievements in the matter of civilizing the natives and cleaning up the island. The report begins with the statement that three of the marine guard, Privates D. O'Rourke, Paul Schoemig, and William P. Brown, attached to the Guam Battalion, have died and been buried with military honors.

They are going to have a revival of old English comedy at the Haymarket Theatre in London, beginning this week. "The Black Tulip" has failed to draw, and J.M. Barrie's new comedy is not ready. The supposition is that Mr. Barrie prefers not to risk launching a new piece in the present unsettled condition of the theatrical business in London.

It is to be hoped that Mr. GUGGEN-HEIMER will not allow to languish the excellent resolution which he introduced into the Municipal Assembly for regulating the traffic of Fifth Avenue. There is really only one side to the question raised by the proposal. If the public opinion of the city could be fairly brought to bear upon the question, it would be settled at once.

The Evangelical Alliances of the World have issued an invitation to all Christians to join with them, in making this week one of united and universal prayer. The letter sent out by the United States branch bears the name of the President, William E. Dodge, and those of many Secretaries. It contains the following notes of alarm and apprehension:
To the Editor of The New York Times: I became very much interested in the news Item in to-day's Issue headed "Thinks Honesty Doesn't Pay."

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Gov. Roosevelt stated to-day that Justice Laughlin of Buffalo, who has been designated as an Associate Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Fourth Department, has requested that his appointment be temporarily held up to see whether its acceptance would interfere with his desired transfer to New York City.

There will be practically the same entries for the Brooklyn and Suburban Handicaps this year, for the Suburban nominations, which were made public yesterday, include almost all of the Brooklyn Handicap candidates, the list of which was printed yesterday. The Suburban this year has a larger list of nominations than it has had for some years past.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A special dispatch from Frere Camp, dated Saturday, Jan. 6, 7:20 P.M., says:

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 7 -- The New Jersey Legal Aid Association, a society of women, through its attorney, Miss Mary Philbrook, has instituted proceedings in the Court of Chancery against the New Jersey Children's Home Society to secure the return to their mother of three Paterson children named Murray.

Congressman Charles N. Fowler of Elizabeth, N.J., has filed a complaint in equity against the City of New York and the Rapid Transit Commissioners, based on the allegation that the plans for the underground railroad infringe an invention which he controls relating to the arrangements for trackage facilities at stations, and the entrances thereto, and that these features have wrongfully been incorporated in the published advertisements calling for bids for the building of the road.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Gen. A.W. Greely, the Chief Signal Officer of the army and the well-known arctic explorer, lies in a serious condition at his home, 914 G Street Northwest, as the result of an assault committed on him about 8:30 o'clock to-night by Joseph C. Furnace, a messenger in the employ of the Adams Express Company.

The announcement that the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke would preach his last sermon as pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday morning attracted a congregation that filled the church to overflowing. They were disappointed, however, for Dr. Van Dyke was not even able to be present.

From The Engineering News. The construction of a bridge across the East River, barely a quarter of a mile from the present Brooklyn Bridge, has been approved by the New York Municipal Assembly, which has also authorized bonds to be issued and sold to the amount of $1,000,000 to provide the money for beginning work.

MONTREAL, Jan. 7 -- Lift up your eyes, French-Canadians, for the day of your redemption is at hand." La Semaine Rellgieuse, the organ of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the Province of Quebec, which is published at the Franciscan Monastery, in Quebec, and under the authorization and supervision of his. Grace Archbishop Begin, thus opens a long article in this week's issue on "Anglomania in Canada."

Senator ALDRICH'S explanation of the Currency bill of his committee has developed precisely the kind of opposition that we predicted would be offered, namely, an attack on the bill for its funding provisions and on the advantages offered to the National banks to induce them to invest in the new bonds.

Friends of the Seventy-first Regiment view, it is said, with apprehension the election in that regiment for Lieutenant Colonel and Junior Major. It has already resulted in a clash in the form of a formal protest against the election at the casting of the ballots Friday night, and those ballots are now sealed up, awaiting the decision which the Colonel announces will be made at the meeting of officers called for to-morrow night.

The aspiration to power ought to have a sobering effect as well as the possession of it. Four years of unflagging aspiration have had no effect on W.J. BRYAN. He is still, as he was in 1896, "ambitious, unsteady, unsafe." He never sobers up.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The National officers of the Ancient Order of Hibernians met In this city to-day, and later issued this statement to the public:

From early until late yesterday the SpeedWay was alive with horsemen with their fast steppers. The crowd of spectators also was unusually large and enthusiastic. They lined both sides of the stretch from Washington Bridge as far north as the eye could reach, and the favorites were lustily applauded.

Seth Low spoke yesterday before the Central' Federated Union on the subject "Some Characteristics of Our Times." Some fifteen years ago, the speaker said, an Englishman told him that the year 1848 was a year of unrest In Europe; that it was a revolutionary year; that the hopes of men were centred on good government, and men hoped that when democratic government was obtained there would be no more problems to solve.

It is reported that the Ship Subsidy bill will be pressed vigorously during the remainder of the session of Congress, and it is obvious that a powerful and skillful lobby is already at work for it. But there are signs that the opposition may be stronger than had been counted on in the last session or even at the opening of this.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 7 -- The police of this city this afternoon arrested an eloping couple just as they reached what they supposed was a safe haven. They had been chased for miles over the country roads, and escaped into Plainfield, but the telephone was quicker than they, and the police were awaiting them.
Mrs. CATHERINE McGUIRK, mother of exPolice Captain Charles H. McGuirk of New Rochelle, died yesterday. She was seventy years of age. Her son survives her.

The weekly statement of the New York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, showed an increase in the reserve of $589,630. The banks now hold a surplus of $11,757,725 above the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in the loans of $4,107,600, an increase in specie of $504,800, an increase in legal tenders of $2,311,400, an increase in deposits of $8,906,200, and an increase in circulation of $191,400.

THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day opposes the mooted measure [the educational unification plan] for the reason and project of political grab in it, but accounts for the character of the project by its estimate of the Board of Regents, whom it regards as an assorted or as an unassorted collection of "old fogies and political editors," the latter doing the business of the board and the former being pushed aside.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Radical and sweeping recommendations are made and changes urged in the management of the prisons of the State by the members of the Senate Prisons Commission in their fifth annual report to the Legislature. Briefly summarized, they are as follows:

"The King is dead! Lord rest hjs soul!" The ancient saying thus reverently amended passing from lip to lip early yesterday morning announced to the citizens of Fort Washington that "his Majesty" had passed out. It meant the end. of the dynasty. There are no heirs.

DR.
