LEYDS INTIMATES THAT THE TRANSVAAL IS READY FOR PEACE -- Dr. Leyds, the agent of the Transvaal Government, who has his headquarters in Brussels, recently, as was announced by a cable dispatch, paid a visit to Paris, concerning which European diplomatic circles have indulged in varied speculations and comments.

Several persons of both sexes declared last night at the Second Street Methodist Episcopal Church that they had been converted in the course of what was the most notable so far of a series of revival meetings by Mrs. Maggie N. Van Cott, the evangelist, whose name is identified with the records of many years of revival and camp meeting work in New York State and elsewhere, and who has just returned from the West.

The Merchants' Association of this city has mailed to 150,000 merchants throughout tie United States, a communication settins forth the urgency of action by Congress looking toward the betterment of the condition of Puerto Rico. The persons addressed are requested to write to members of Congress, from their districts, advocating a bill for the abolition of customs duties between the United States and Puerto Rico.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The British public is face to face with a critical moment in the campaign. It may safely be said that at no previous time have there been such anxious hours of suspense as will be passed through until the arrival of further news regarding the fate of Ladysmith.

The Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur began last night at the Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street, a series of Sunday evening sermons, in which he will appeal to those who are non-churchgoers. His topic last night was "Christ Through the Churches, the Regenerator of Society." Dr. MacArthur said, in part:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan., 7 -- This was a day of rest among the politicians, Absolute calm has succeeded the storm of the past week. His nomination at the Republican House caucus last night assures the election of D.H. Bowen as Speaker when the House meets to-morrow, and no one can be found to question the re-election of Senator Gear.

While the crowd in Broadway was at its height shortly after 8 o'clock last night, a stockily built. shabbily dressed woman about forty years old darted from the sidewalk in Longacre Square, and, drawing her old cape over her face, threw herself headlong before a north-bound cable car. Her action was seen by William Martin, a Postal Telegraph messenger, who dragged her from the track as the gripman tried to stop the car.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- This week In Congress will be devoted probably to financial discussions and to debate on the conduct of the Philippine war, which is expected to occupy considerable time in both houses.

RAHWAL, N.J., Jan. 7 -- There is nothing new to tell about the closing of the Union County Bank, after a two days' run. The examiners worked late last night, expecting to finish their reports, but were unable to do so. The officers of the bank refuse to say anything except that some of the people who participated in the run "tore the roof from over their own heads."

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Sir Thomas Lipton. It is understood, will defer action regarding another challenge for the America's Cup until the Distant Shore and another yacht now in course of construction according to designs by Watson have been completed for C.D. Rhodes.

The Rev. Father John L. Belford, appointed to succeed the late Father Malone, officiated for the first time yesterday at Sts. Peter and Paul's Church, Brooklyn. In addressing his parishioners he suggested the erection within the church of a suitable monument to his predecessor.
LONDON. Jan. S -- The Times publishes the . following dispatch from Lorenzo Marques:

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Smoking incessantly, Prof. Alfred Morrison, whose killing of his second wife a short time ago brought out the fact yesterday that he had another wife living, spent today at the boarding house at 7 Rich Avenue, to which he was taken after the tragedy by his aunt, Mrs. Cahen. He smokes all day, and, according to his story, spends most of his nights In the same way.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 -- The money market grew steady and easier throughout all of last week, private discount reaching 6 1/8 yesterday. The ease of the market is explained by the annual dividend payments, which holders hesitate to reinvest in securities, owing to the uncertainties of the situation.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 7.--The Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn, rector of St. Mary's Church, died at the rectory shortly after 5 o'clock this afternoon, after an illness of six weeks. Death was primarily due to Bright's disease. A minor surgical operation was performed on Dr. McGlynn last night by Dr. Charles E. Townsend, the attending physician, and Dr. Andrew V. Jova, but this did not affect the patient or contribute materially to his death.

Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, celebrated last evening the semi-centennial anniversary of the opening of the present edifice in Orange Street. It was a night of reminiscences for the congregation. Not the least interesting part of the programme was the musical service, which had been especially arranged for the occasion by the organist and director, G. Waring Stebbins.

A special meeting of the Presbytery of Brooklyn will be held in the Bedford Presbyterian Church, Dean Street and Nostrand Avenue, this evening to receive the charges against the Rev. George L. MacClelland, ex-pastor of Immanuel Church, and appoint a commission to try the case.

HAVANA, Jan. 7 -- Sefior Villalon, Secretary of Public Works, arrived to-day from Santiago and called upon Gov. Gen. Wood, with whom he had a long interview. Gen. Wood advises Sefior Villalon the first thing to be done is to repair the bridges throughout the island, and to make the roads passable, particularly the so-called Royal Road, which, although it was designed to extend the length of the island, really exists only in name.

Applications for injunctions to prevent the letting of the contract for building the rapid transit railroad need excite neither surprise nor alarm. The time is short. One week from to-day the bids will be opened. The interests that are hostile to the project are doubtless alert and probably ugly.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The War Office pubfishes the following dispatch from Gen. Forestier-Walker, commanding at Cape Town:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A pamphlet has just been issued by the Adjutant General's office under the title or "Statistical Exhibit of Strength of Volunteer Forces Called Into service During the War With Spain. With Losses from All Causes." The volunteer force consisted of 10,017 officers and 213,218 enlisted men, a total of 223,235, who were engaged in the war.

The second week of the new year opens with Wall Street traders watching for developments to give the stock market tendency. Enough of prosperity is in evidence on every side to warrant the fullest confidence in values, but the speculative contingent prefers to ignore what is clear and keep on the outlook for the coming of something sensational -- it matters not whether favorable or unfavorable, so long as there shall be the extraordinary involved.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The annual report of the State Railroad Commission, which will be sent to the Legislature this week, shows that the twelve months ending June 30, 1899, was an unusually prosperous season for the steam surface railroads of the State. The increase in gross earnings from operation, as compared with 1898, was about $6,000,000.

The movement of the cotton crop up to date shows a reduction as compared with the crop of 1896-7 of 507,000 bales. The total crop that season was 8,758,000 bales. The two succeeding crops being much larger, a comparison with that of 1896-7 seems only reasonably fair and proper.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 8 -- The bribery charge of State Senator S.B. Harrel against John H. Whallen, the political boss of Louisville, took a sensational turn to-day. Whallen admits the bribery in an affidavit. He to-day swore but a warrant of arrest against Harrel on the charge of obtaining money under false pretenses, in which he admits all the allegations of the Senator.

Frederick Pavel, employed in a restaurant at 249 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street making "hot cakes," was a prisoner before Magistrate Mott, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday, charged with annoying Miss Celia Schroer, nineteen years old, who lives at 304 East Eleventh Street, by threatening to kill her and then commit suicide for her coolness toward him.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Samuel Dana Greene, General Manager of the lighting department of the General Electric Company, was, together with his wife, drowned in the Mohawk River while skating this afternoon.
The Potomac Insurance Company of Georgetown, D.C., has been admitted to Massachusetts.

The originality and the piquantly captivating quality of the acting of Blanche Bates in "Naughty Anthony," the new farce by David Belasco, which was produced in a most elaborate fashion at the Herald Square Theatre last evening, ought to serve to make the performance much talked of and to grive the piece vogue for some little while.
HAMBURG, Jan. 8 -- Herr Adolph Woermann, one of the owners of the German vessels seized by the British, was interviewed to-day. He said:

The thirtieth annual meeting of the Marine Society of the City of New York was held yesterday afternoon at the Maritime Exchange. The election of officers resulted as follows: President -- Capt. Gustavus D.S. Trask; First Vice President -- Capt. Andrew J. Newbury; Second Vice President -- Capt. Benjamin F. Marsh; Treasurer -- Capt. James H. Chamberlain; Secretary -- Capt. Thomas M. Nichols; Counsel -- William Alien Butler.

RAHWAY, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Deputy State Bank Examiner Johnson completed to-day his investigation into the affairs of the Union County Bank, which suspended business Saturday. This statement was given out:

The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments have assessed the National City Bank $2,400,000 for the Custom House building, at Wall and William Streets, for which property the bank's bid of $3,265,000 was accepted on July 3. The bid was made in the name or the bank's President, James Stillman, who furnished a check for $150,000 in part payment.

The seventy-eight members of the New York Presbytery, who voted last month to drop the charges of heresy against the Rev. Dr. McGiffert, were disagreeably surprised yesterday afternoon when, at the January meeting, Dr. Birch, the Stated Clerk, gave notice of his intention to prefer further charges against Union's professor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Administration made known to-day through several of the Senators the disposition of the President and his advisers to gratify nearly every desire on the part of such opponents as Senator Pettigrew to have every particle of information concerning the course of the Administration in the Philippines.
Maclay Dayies have sold for the estate of Richard Arnold to Mrs. Edith Edgar McCagg the three four-story stone-front dwellings 23, 25, and 27 East Eighty-third Street, on a plot 56 by 69.2.

The service held in memory of Dwight L. Moody, in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, brought out an attendance that completely filled the hall and galleries. William E. Dodge presided and Ira D. Sankey led the singing, giving to the meeting the flavor of the old-time Moody and Sankey meetings.

The annual meeting of the General Society, United States Daughters of 1812, held yesterday at Delmonico's, was marked by the presentation of three flags by Mrs. Louis Hall, President of the Pennsylvania Society. These included a United States flag of the style of to-day, a flag of 1812, and the standard of the society.

Instead of leaving two wills, as had been supposed by some of those interested, it was declared yesterday that the Rev. Father Sylvester Malone, the late rector of the Church of SS. Peter and Paul, Brooklyn, left no will at all. Sylvester L. Malone, a nephew of Father Malone, filed an affidavit to that effect in the Surrogate's Court, Brooklyn.

The crop of rumors which arise spontaneously in London about the situation in South Africa, and which are promptly forwarded to New York seem unmistakably to denote two things. One is that there is no real news. The other is that public feeling is in a state of extreme tension.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- There was little in the stock market to-day that calls for special mention. Trading was quiet, with prices steady to firm. Changes in almost every case were small tractions, generally, however, in the way of improvement. United Gas was a weak feature, receding from 152 to 150.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 8 -- A three days' conference of the undergraduate officials of the Yale and Harvard Boat Clubs has just been concluded at Claverly Hall, Cambridge, as a result of which dates for the annual contests, officials, and the general plans for the annual regatta are announced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Ex-State Senator Whiteside of Montana continued his testimony in the Clark Senatorial case before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day. He was cross-examined by ex-Senator Faulkner. The examination brought out the fact that Mr. Whiteside, as a member of a committee to investigate the State Capitol Commission, had made a minority report charging corruption.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The President has created a military department consisting of the Territory of Alaska, and has assigned Col. George M. Randall, Eighth United States Infantry, to command it. Col. Randall is on duty with his regiment in Cuba, but will report here, en route to Alaska, on Jan. 15.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 8 -- The trial of Julia Morrison James for the murder of Frank Leidenheimer was resumed today in the Circuit Court. The spacious room was crowded with spectators when the prisoner entered, accompanied by a lady. She announced to her attorneys that she felt reasonably well, although having spent the greater part of yesterday in bed recovering from the nervous strain of last week.

The effort made by certain of the stockholders to have the New York and Westchester Water Company adjudged an involuntary bankrupt in the United States District Court so as to prevent it being disposed of for a small sum to the Ramapo Company, and if possible have it disposed of to the city for $2,000,000, which was asserted to be its real value, has fallen through by the decision rendered yesterday by Judge Addison Brown.

It was inevitable in the nature of things that one side or the other would be dissatisfied with the outcome of the suit brought by Miss Mary E. Howe against Mrs. Frances Augusta Skinner for $24,750 as compensation for services rendered as companion, but the sealed verdict rendered by the jury yesterday morning satisfied nobody.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Secretary Gage's response to the inquiries by Representative Sulzer and others touching the deposits in the National City and other banks has been prepared with satisfaction to those members of the Administration who have interested themselves in the matter. It will be a history of practices not new, but which the Sulzer resolution indicated must be new to many persons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Gen. Davis, Governor General of Puerto Rico, appeared before the Insular Affairs Committee of the House to-day and made a general statement regarding the situation of affairs in that island. The people of Puerto Rico, he said, were accustomed to arbitrary control, control of the King through Ministers or Secretaries in charge of several departments.

-- In a discussion of the sensational charges so often made against New York's ambulance system and ambulance surgeons. The Medical Record sets itself about midway between the accused and the accusers, and declares that there is need on the one side for juster recognition of much faithful and efficient work, and on the other for the immediate adoption of improved methods by which several real abuses of long standing could be remedied.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The plague has broken out in Manila beyond a doubt, as appears from the following cablegram received by Surgeon General Sternberg:

The complaints recently made as to the sanitary condition of the County Court House are declared to have been without avail. Justice Leventritt, who has been sitting in Special Term, Part III., for the last week, was compelled yesterday to abandon that courtroom on account of the odor arising from withdrawing rooms on the upper floors.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Gov. Roosevelt has designated Justice S. Alonzo Kellogg of Plattsburg as an Associate Justice of the Appellate Division of the Court of Appeals, Third Department, to fill the vacancy caused by the designation of Justice Landon as an Associate Justice of the Court of Appeals.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 58 1/2@59 1/2. There were no sales.

The second week of the new year has opened with considerable gayety. Testerday brought the first private ball -- that given at Sherry's last evening by Mrs. John R. Drexel, a large dinner of twenty covers given by Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish, and a number of luncheons and theatre and opera parties.

The entire Manhattan agency of the New York Life Insurance Company, including 10 offices and 400 agents, under the management of R.J. Mix, resigned yesterday and joined the forces of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. This action, which was unanimous, was taken at separate meet ings which were held yesterday morning in the different offices of the agency.

The Washingtons, by winning two games in the Harlem League last night, secured first place in the tournament. The Orientals lost two games, and as a result lost the lead, and are now in sixth place. Scores:

The steamer Georgian of the Atlantic Transport Line, Capt. Parker, which came in yesterday from London, brought Capt. Stenge of the German steamer Ella, together with his wife, two children, a nurse, and the officers and crew of the Ella, thirty-six in all. They were rescued from the the Ella twenty minutes after the vessel went down last Saturday in latitude 41.35 and longitude 64.04.

Trading was quiet in the market for outside securities yesterday, Amalgamated Copper, Electric Axle, and one or two other issues being the only stocks traded in to a greater extent than a few hundred shares. Early in the day there was some lack of buying orders, but stock offered was not pressed for sale and actual declines of importance showed in very few issues.
Controller Coler believes that, if Section 1065 of the charter were repealed, all the teachers in the various boroughs of this city could and would be paid promptly their salaries in full to Jan. 1.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- In the matter of the complaint of the Taxpayers' Alliance of the Borough of the Bronx. New York City, against the Manhattan Railway, the State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day made public its decision which recommends that the company, without delay, construct its railroad from One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street to Bedford Park.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 8 -- The discovery was made to-day of a remarkable situation existing in the board of officers of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company. At the time of the election of Vice President Merrill the official announcement was made that Vice President W.D. Bishop, who succeeded Judge John M. Hall, when the latter became President, had resigned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Gen. Otis to-day cabled the War Department of the movements of troops during the past few days. On Saturday at Binan, on the shore of Laguna de Bay, the column advancing under Schwan encountered the insurgents 800 strong, commanded by Gen. Noriel. The Fillpinos were driven west to Silong, leaving three of their six pieces of artillery in Schwan's hands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading in THE TIMES of Dec. 31 the interesting account of the Washington funeral parade in this city, I happened to take up Longworth's City Directory for 1801, and found in it an allusion to one of the commonplace incidents in Washington's life in the advertisement of John Greenwood, who was Washington's dentist.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 8 -- At the State Capitol to-day George K. Nash was inaugurated Governor of Ohio. Gov. Nash, in his inaugural address, said in part:
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Arthur J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury, delivered his annual address to his Manchester constituents this evening. An immense audience gave him an enthusiastic reception.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 8 -- The Republican joint caucus to-night nominated ex-Gov. William O. Bradley as the Republican candidate for Senator by acclamation, Congressman Boreing. the only other aspirant who had sought this honor from the minority, having instructed his friends not to present his name.
SALT LAKE, Utah, Jan. 8 -- This afternoon a signed address was issued by President Lorenzo Snow of the Mormon Church regarding polygamy and unlawful cohabitation. The address is as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 8 -- "At the Lower Harbor," ("A Basso Porto,") an opera in three acts, by Niccola Spinelli ana Eugene Checchi, was presented by the Castle Square Opera Company for the first time in America and for the first time in English on any stage at the Exposition Music Hall to-night. The interest of an audience, which tested the capacity of the auditorium, was awakened at the rise of the curtain.

There has nothing more pathetic been published in connection with the present troubles of England than the article from the Clerical organ in Quebec of which we gave an abstract yesterday morning. It is the passionate complaint of the belated and outstripped against those who have passed ahead, the nervous and petulant cry for revenge by the weak, the slow, the narrow, against the strong and swift.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The first account giving any adequate explanation of Gen. Buller's defeat at the Tugela River comes by mail from Mr. Benet-Burleigh, The Daily Telegraph's correspondent. It appears that the battle orders, drawn up by Gen. Clery, provided for the effective support of the artillery by Gens. Hart's, Barton's, and Dundonald's brigades.

In his brief address to the Central Federated Union on Sunday President Low of Columbia referred to the disappearance of the individual capitalist in the trust and of the individual laborer in the union. He thought that the individual had increased in importance politically, but economically he is not holding his own.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The resolution heretofore offered by Senator Pritchard (Rep., N.C.,) concerning racial restrictions on suffrage was modified by him to-day so as to provide that any State enactment confining the right to vote to those descendant from certain persons or classes of persons is in violation of the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments to the Constitution, and repugnant to republican institutions.

The session of the Molineux trial in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, which marked the opening of the ninth week of the trial, was for the most part given over to expert handwriting testimony, the witnesses being Edwin D. Hay of Washington, a professional expert, and Alfred H. Graham, the paying teller of the National Bank of North America, who admitted that this was his debut as an expert in disputed handwriting.

At the Vanderbilt offices at the Grand Central Station yesterday several important meetings having relation to the various plans for developing the Vanderbilt systems were had. Only one of these -- that of the Directors of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railway Company -- was formal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- In an opinion handea down in the United States Supreme Court to-day by Justice Harlan, the title of the Oregon and California Railroad Company to large tracts of land in the State of Oregon was confirmed. The main controversy was between the Oregon and California Road and the Northern Pacific.

OMAHA, Jan. 8.--Jackson Day was appropriately celebrated in Omaha to-day by the Jacksonian Club. Three separate functions were down on the programme, and each was a distinct and gratifying success. The first was an informal reception held at club headquarters this afternoon, at which W.J. Bryan, Congressman Carmack of Tennessee, Overmeyer of Kansas, Weaver of Iowa, and several other Democratic lights were the guests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Friends of education in Turkey, under American auspices, are pleased to learn that Minister Straus has recently prevailed upon the Sultan to extend a new indication of his favor for the United States. For about ten months Mr. Straus has been urging upon the Porte the propriety and justice of restoring the school and college buildings, eight in number, of the Euphrates College and mission schools at Harpoot.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- In to-day's stock market there was fairly heavy realizing in the Granger shares, and Sugar. The coppers also showed weakness, noticeably the Standard Oil group. A few Standard dividend shares like Quincy and Tamarack held their own fairly well. The market as a whole showed little that could be called strength, and became quite dull as the closing approached.

Belt Line Horse Car No. 122, bound down town, fell into a deep trench in First Avenue, between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, at 6:15 o'clock yesterday morning. The car, which contained fourteen passengers, was in charge of Conductor John Dunn, twenty-seven years old, of 235 East Seventy-sixth Street, and Driver George Young, aged fifty-five, of 1,623 East End Avenue.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The following dispatch was received to-day from Gen. Buller:

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- From an absolutely reliable source. It is learned that Emperor William will make an important and sensational speech to-morrow night at the Century festival of the Berlin Technical High School. His Majesty's remarks will be political, dealing especially with the naval question, and will touch upon the sensation of the hour, namely, the seizures of German vessels by British warships in South African waters.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Prof. Alfred d'Orthimand Morrison, linguist, somrambulist, and self-confessed bigamist, who shot and killed his second wife during the night of Dec. 28, in their room, at 235 South Tenth Avenue, while he was under what he alleges was an attack of somnambulism, was to-day placed under surveillance by the police.

The annual meeting of the Church Temperance Society was held yesterday in the Board Room of the Church Missions House, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. In the morning the session was devoted to business matters, Bishop Coleman of Delaware presiding.

In connection with the affairs of the American Steel and Wire Company and the visit to the city this week of President John W. Gates, it was reported on the Street yesterday that Mr. Gates is to retire as a member of the Executive Committee, his place to be taken by Mr. P.W. Moen.

The annual meeting of the Church Temperance Society was held yesterday in the Board Room of the Church Missions House, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. In the morning the session was devoted to business matters, Bishop Coleman of Delaware presiding.

MOUNT VERNON, Jan. 9. -- The dream story built up by Prof. Morrison to account for his shooting his second wife during the night of Dec. 28, at their home, 235 South Tenth Avenue, on the strength of which Coroner Banning exonerated him from all blame, has under two days of searching inquiry completely disintegrated.
LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Arthur J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury, speaking this evening East Manchester, said:

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided that the Gerry Society for the Prevention of Cruelty, to Children of New York City is not a charitable institution within the meaning of the Constitution, and that it does not come within the jurisdiction of the State Board of Charities. This is the end of a long controversy between Elbridge T. Gerry, the head of the society, and the State Board of Charities.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 58 1/2@59 1/2. There were no sales.

The cable dispatches have but vaguely informed foreigners concerning the industrial troubles in Spain which marked the first steps in the policy of reconstruction adopted by the Silvela Government. To be sure, people learned, over a month ago, that Spanish warships had been sent to collect the taxes at Barcelona.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 9. -- To-day's proceedings in the trial of Julia Morrison James for the murder of Frank Leidenheimer were characterized by considerable evidence of a sensational character, presented by the State in rebuttal. Witnesses were introduced for the purpose of showing that some of the witnesses for the defense could not have seen the shooting on the stage on account of the interference of curtains.

The decision of the majority of the Manhattan agents of the New York Life Insurance Company to join the forces of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, reached on Monday at ten different, meetings held at the various sub-offices, was followed yesterday morning by the presence of more than 600 agents of the New York Life, at that company's building, 346 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Senator Hoar of Massachusetts to-day introduced the following resolution:

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners held yesterday its final meeting prior to the opening of bids next Monday at noon for the construction and operation of the underground railroad. In the executive session of the commission there was discussion of the prospects for the bidding, and, while no names were mentioned, it was said that it was assured that there would be several bids presented.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- The One Hundred and Twenty-fourth New Jersey Legislature convened at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The corridors, galleries, and floors of both Houses were crowded, and there was a profuse floral display. The two houses organized by the election of the officers recently decided upon by the Republican caucauses.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- The market was dull to-day. There was some manipulation of Sugar and some profit-taking in the Granger group. The copper shares ignored the gain shown by the London opening prices. Amalgamated alone showed strength, rising on two or three sales to 85 1/2. Arcadian was somewhat firmer.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- Mail advices from the Carolines say that a typhoon on Nov. 9 destroyed much property in the islands, especially in the Island of Yap. The German warship Jaguar narrowly escaped destruction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Senate Committee on Finance had the nomination of W.D. Bynum to be General Appraiser at New York under consideration to-day, but failed to act, owing to the opposition of the Democratic members. They based their objection on the ground that he was named as a Democrat, which they claimed was a false designation.

NEWCASTLE, England, Jan. 9. -- The United States cruiser Albany, formerly the Brazilian cruiser Admiral Abrouall, purchased by the United States Government shortly before the beginning of the war with Spain, while under construction here, was given a successful official trial off this port to-day.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Jan. 9. -- Gens. Rabi, Miro, Lara, and Castro were received on their arrival yesterday from Havana with great enthusiasm. More than 5,000 persons met them at the wharf. To-day they attended receptions at the Cuban clubs, and this evening a large crowd gathered in the Plaza to hear speeches detailing the results of the conferences with Gen. Wood.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- The State Commissioners for the Fltchburg Railroad, stock of which aggregating $5,000,000 is held by the Commonwealth, filed their annual report at the State House to-day. The document assumes unusual importance, as it accuses the New York Central and Boston and Albany Railroads of entering into an agreement to divert traffic from the Fitchburg.

The third secular day of another busy week in the world of society brings with it a number of receptions, several luncheons and dinners, and again the opera. The most notable dinners of this evening will be given by Mrs. E. Livingston Ludlow of 6 East Seventy-sixth Street and Mrs. H. de Berkeley Parsons (Miss Walker of 294 Madison Avenue.)

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Senator Hoar of Massachusetts made public a long letter he had addressed to the editors of some Boston newspapers, in answer to a speech made by Representative Quigg at the Essex Club last December. In this speech Mr. Quigg referring to Senator Hoar's attitude on the Philippine question declared that the Senator "wants us to skulk from our duty."

The house of Joseph Pulitzer, proprietor of The New York World, at 10 and 12 East Fifty-fifth Street, was badly damaged by a fire which started at about 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Mrs. S.S. Morgan Jellett, the companion of Mrs. Pulitzer, and Miss Elizabeth Montgomery, the governess, lost their lives.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- State Controller William J. Morgan, in his first annual report to the Legislature, makes some important recommendations for legislation and advocates radical changes in the State's attitude toward corporations and in the financial system of the State. He asks for:

From The Railroad Gazette. The first bridge built across the Merrimac River, at Newburyport, Mass., was built by Timothy Palmer in 1792. The structure consisted of two bridges resting upon Deer Island. An arch of 160 feet span and 40 test above high water connected the island with the mainland on one side, and several spans did a like service upon the other.

Mayor Van Wyek sent his annual message to the Municipal Assembly yesterday. The document, which is a comparatively brief one, contains a summary of the city's financial condition, a statement of the bonds and corporatte stock issued during 1899, and a list of bond issues authorized by the Board of Estimate in the budget for the current year.

Anent the agitation aroused by President Guggenheimer's proposed ordinance restrict ing heavy traffic on Fifth Avenue, the, extent of the business traffic on the avenue from Madison Square to Central, Park has been made the subject of some study.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--A well-attended cauous of the Democratic members of the House of Representatives was held to-night. Mr. Newlands of Nevada of the Silver Party was present by invitation of Mr. Richardson, the Democratic floor leader, for the purpose of presenting a plan for united action by all the elements opposed to the Republican organization.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- The impatience of the public over the situation in South Africa pours itself into a discussion of the conduct of the war, fend of what might have been done or ought now to be done.
BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- Emperor William, when receiving the Rectors of the three technical high schools to-day, for the first time spoke openly about Socialism, saying:

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- At the opening of the Diet to-day Prince Hohenlohe, the Imperial Chancellor, read the speech from the throne, wherein it was shown that the finances of Prussia are in a satisfactory condition. The year of 1898-9 closed with a considerable surplus, and the current year, the Chancellor said, was expected to give favorable results.

The prizes were pretty evenly divided at the Carteret Gun Club's big shoot, yesterday between Harold Money, the twentyone-year-old son of the veteran Capt. Money, and H. Yale Dolan, the Philadelphia Gun Club's expert. Two cup events were decided during the day, and ten of the club's experts were contestants.

The State and National banks propose to make a vigorous fight against the trust companies. Assemblyman Trainor will introduce in the Assembly to-night two bills to restrict the privileges of the trust companies and place them on something of an equality with the State and National banks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Gen. Otis cabled the War Department this morning two casualty reports from Manila. The first embraces the losses incurred during the pursuit of Gen. Tino's command, which effected the release of Lieut. Gillmore and the other American prisoners. It is as follows:
The New York Fire Insurance Exchange will meet to-day.

Few stranger wills have ever been recorded in this city than that of Eugene G. Cruger, which has been filed for probate in the Surrogate's office. It is written in French in a tremulous hand on a piece of paper about the size of a halt note sneet, and, translated, is as follows:

BALTIMORE, Jan. 9. -- The annual meeting of the American Bowlers' Congress began to-day, and bowlers from all parts of the country came to participate in the proceedings or in the contests which form a part of the annual gathering. Following an oyster roast given the delegates and their friends by "Gus" Fenneman at Electric Park this afternoon the first business session was held this evening.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Mrs. Sarah E. Staples of Jamaica Plain was stabbed at her home last night, and her husband, Edward B. Staples, is under arrest charged with inflicting the injury. The trouble in the family occurred before midnight, but several hours elapsed before the police were notified. The woman's condition is critical.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 9. -- The failure of several prominent Democrats to attend the Jackson Day banquet of the Duckworth Club is causing much comment. The gentlemen who absented themselves were ex-Gov. James E. Campbell, Lou Reemelin, and Mayor Gustav Tafel. Reemelin has always been prominent at Democratic gatherings.

As a result of a conference under the ausplfies of the Inter-State Commerce Commission yesterday, held in the Equitable Building, representatives of fifty railroads of the country pledged themselves to live up to the inter-State commerce law, to observe all legal measures in the conduct of their traffic, and to make no secret rate, but to adhere to the regular published tariffs.

The residence of the late Richard Arnold, at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-third Street, a four-story stone dwelling, on a plot 50.2 by 100, which was Purchased by Daniel E. Seybel last Spring, has been resold by him, through Brokers Douglas Robinson Co., at a reported price of about $300,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Articles of incorporation of the New York and Nassau County Railway Company were filed to-day with the Secretary of State. The company, which is capitalized at $150,000, will operate its road by electricity. Its length will be seven rniles, starting at the intersection of Main and Front Streets, in the Village of Hempstead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The claim of Admiral Dewey and the officers and men of his squadron for bounty arising out of the destruction of Montojo's fleet in Manila Bay was argued before the Court of Claims to-day. William B. King and Herbert Micou appeared for the claimants and Louis A. Pradt, the Assistant Attorney General, for the Government.

Annual meetings of the stockholilers of the National and some of the State banks of this city were held yesterday. There were few changes made in the Directorates, while such changes as were made were not radical. Results of the meetings follow:

The Rev. Thomas Smith, the pastor for nineteen years of St. Mary's Parish, at Greenwich, Conn., died there yesterday of dropsy. He was in his sixtieth year. The funeral services will be held Friday morning, and Bishop Tierney has notified all the clergy in the State to attend. Father Smith was born in County Longford, Ireland, and his early education was received there.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- The stockholders of nearly all of the National banks in this city voted to-day for Directors for the coming year. Very few changes were made. The dropping off of the Globe and Broadway Banks reduces the capital of the twenty-seven banks in the city to $30,000,000. Two years ago it was about $50,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The bringing together of the gas and electric light and power interests in New York should result in great advantages to the public and to the interests so combined, provided the latest developments in gas and electric engineering are investigated and availed of.

LEVY UPON PLEDGED STOCK OF FOREIGN CORPORATION.--Under a warrant of attachment in a suit brought by Louis M. Simpson and another to recover $2,000 from the Jersey City Contracting Company, a foreign corporation, for professional services, a levy was attempted on 3,220 shares of stock of the New Jersey and Pennsylvania Telephone Company, which stock was pledged to the Produce Exchange Trust Company as security for a loan of $2,350.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- A tendency to let go, made a weak market to-day. Biscuit declined from 36 1/4 at the start to 35 1/2, closing at 35 5/8. After selling up one-fourth from the opening, at 54 3/4, Linseed closed at 53 3/4. Metropolitan Elevated preferred improved from the start at 75, and sold to 75 3/4, closing at 75 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Mr. Beveridge, the junior Senator from Indiana, to-day spoke at length upon the Philippine resolution which he introduced last week. The announcement that he would deliver an address embodying his observations in the Philippines attracted an unusually large number of auditors to the galleries.

"Terry" McGovern. who up to last night held the bantamweight championship of the world, won a new pugilistic honor in the arena of the Broadway Athletic Club by wresting from George Dixon, who had been the colored marvel in the featherweight division for many years, the featherweight championship of the world.

VERONA, N.J., Jan. 9. -- The Newark City Home was destroyed by fire to-night, and the 300 inmates were routed out. Some escaped from custody, but the majority of them are safe in the penitentiary and the branch insane asylum. The building was entirely destroyed. There was no life lost and no one was injured.

The inaction of Congress with reference to Puerto Rico is not creditable. It is positively and distinctly discreditable. Gen. DAVIS'S testimony does not raise that point. It merely and powerfully enforces the point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Mail advices are just coming to hand from United States Consul Macrum, explaining in detail the situation at Pretoria at the outbreak of the war and his own conduct respecting the representation of British interests in the Transvaal.

The Dreyfus, case was injected into the Molineux trial yesterday, and although Recorder Goff would not allow the proceedings on that line to go very far, they went far enough to create an impression in the courtroom and also to have spread upon the minutes the opinion of a Judge of the Court of General Sessions upon that cause celebre in which the unfortunate Captain of the French Army was the central figure.

Sylvester L. Malone, a nephew of the late Father Malone, made a statement yesterday in regard to the trouble at the parish house of the late priest in Brooklyn, between the Malone family and Bishop McDonnell during Father Malone's illness and after his death.

Under the impressively comprehensive heading of "England and America" The London Saturday Review prints a letter that is simply running over with useful and interesting information. As a prefatory revelation the genial correspondent announces that "newspapers in America, more than elsewhere, are commercial undertakings -- they write what they think will suit their readers."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of your paper I notice a statement regarding the great amount of money sent abroad through the Post Office as "Christmas gifts." From this statement it appears that the amount sent away this Christmas has been larger than ever before, aggregating $5,000,000 from New York City alone.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Concerning the subject of reversal of appealed cases, I note the remarks of your correspondent Mr. Scrugham. In which he questions the fairness of your comments thereon in THE TIMES of Jan. 1.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Little change is apparent in the position at Colesburg. Gen. French reported to the War Office Sunday morning, Jan. 7, that he had reconnoitred with a squadron of the Household Cavalry on the Boers' east flank, two miles from Achtertank, and drew a considerable force of the burghers, who, being anxious for their communications with Norval's Pont, withdrew.

The morning yesterday saw the avenue and the fashionable streets up town comparatively deserted, and the rain gave a good excuse for the devotees of gayety to stay indoors. The clubs were well filled with the men of leisure, and the women who are going out this Winter were glad of the opportunity to rest after the gayeties of the last few days.

What might have proved a serious fire at the Casino last night was prevented by the presence of mind of David Abrahams, Miss Kittle Mitchell, and Miss Clara Havel, of the "Little Red Riding Hood" Company. As it was, enough damage was done to prevent a performance, and Misses Mitchell and Havel were painfully, though not seriously, burned.

President Alexander E. Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday gave out a statement in which he discusses the public hearing of the day before, and points particularly to the fact that the city's debt limit will be extended this year from the $50,000,000 which has been given as the present limit by Controller Coler, to about $70,000,000 by the operation of the sinking fund and increase of real estate values.

We hope no reader of THE TIMES interested in the question of reserving Fifth Avenue for pleasure driving during certain hours overlooked the facts and figures given in yesterday's TIMES concerning the traffic of that avenue. Especially we hope that the showing was brought to the attention of every member of the Municipal Assembly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial last Saturday, speaking of a certain enthusiastic Hibernian of Chicago who objects to what he considers a biased version of English history, taught in the schools, you go out of your way to insult the memory of an eloquent and learned Irish priest by impugning his veracity and casting ridicule upon his statements.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- A resolution for the purchase by the State of the Boston and Albany Road was filed with the Clerk of the House of Representatives this afternoon by Representative Carey, (Soc. Dem.,) of Haverhill.
MIDDLETOWN, Jan. 10 -- The jury in the case of Frank L. Magar versus Stoddard Hammond of Binghamton has awarded a verdict to the plaintiff of $15,000 in the Supreme Court of Goshen.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Herbert Beerbohm Tree's production of "Midsummer Night's Dream." at Her Majesty's Theatre, this evening was received with the utmost enthusiasm. The mounting, costumes, and fairy scenes are very beautiful, although Puck's antics, in the hands of Miss Freear, are almost too prominent.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- The funeral of Dr. Edward McGlynn was held to-day in St. Mary's Church. The place was crowded to the doors, and many could not obtain admission. The services were impressive and were presided over by the Most. Rev. Archbishop Corrigan, head of the diocese of New York.

The Directors of the National Bank of Commerce and the National Union Bank have decided to consolidate. Their action must be ratified by the stockholders, but no doubt that such a ratification will be forth-coming is felt, and the decision of the two directorates means that another powerful banking institution is soon to enter the field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 --Miss Cecella Sherman Miles and Capt. Samuel Reber, United States Army, were married to-day at St. John's Church, the Rev. Dr. Alexander Mackay-Smith, officiating, assisted by me Rev. Dean Davis of St. Louis. A breakfast at which several hundred guests were present followed at the residence of Gen. and Mrs. Miles, after which Capt. and Mrs. Reber left for a Southern trip.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The following cablegram from Gen. Otis, received at the War Department to-day in answer to an inquiry from Adjt. Gen. Corbin, shows the prospects of reopening the hemp ports in the Philippines:

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Superintendent Payn of the Insurance Department devoted considerable time this afternoon to personal talks with various members of the State Senate, who will soon be called upon to vote on the nomination of his successor. The Superintendent refused to talk for publication, but his friends were loud in their assertions that he had won his fight, and that Gov. Roosevelt would find it impossible to remove him.

Clad in the purple robes of the priesthood, with beretta, stole, chasuble, and alb, and clasping in his hands a crucifix, emblem of salvation, the body of Father Edward McGlynn reposed last night in a black coffin in Stephen's Church, of which, from 1866 to 1888, he was rector, and was viewed by an immense throng, that filed through the church in continuous procession from 6:30 till after 10 o'clock.

The New York Fire Insurance Exchange, which includes in its membership nearly all of the 160 fire insurance companies doing business in the State of New York, at a meeting held yesterday in the rooms of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters, voted unanimously to repeal the 30 per cent. reduction in metropolitan fire insurance rates, which was made in the old tariff on March 8 of last year, when the Exchange was formed.

The life of five-year-old Minnie Ruppert, the daughter of a tailor living at 144 George Street, Brooklyn, was crushed out yesterday afternoon by Trolley Car 774 of the Flushing and Knickerbocker Avenue line. The accident occurred at Knickerbocker Avenue and Jefferson Street, Williamsburg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- There has been much talk, since the meeting of Congress, about an imminent reorganization of the Senate force of employes. The employes who are in have been not less anxious than the persons who desire to occupy the offices that would have to be filled, and the pressure has all been from the outsiders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Industrial Commission to-day received from John D. Rockefeller, President of the Standard Oil Company, replies to questions sent him by the commission.

The Vernon, Orchard, and Empire teams bowled their first games in the North Side National League last night. In the first game the Orchards bowled far below their average and were beaten by the Vernons by 11 pins. The Empires and Orchards met in the second game. The latter took the lead at the start, and holding it throughout won by 147 pins.

The Consolidated Exchange trading was active yesterday and the market was weak. A great deal of dealing in Sugar took place, and the tremendous break in this security was of course the feature of the market. Short selling of wheat was noticeable on the Produce Exchange, and the market declined, but later rallied and recovered most of its lost ground.

Philip Bissinger. Philip Bissinger, President of the German Savings Bank, and head of the diamond importing firm of Bissinger Co., 20 John Street, died yesterday at his apartments, 19 East Thirty-fourth Street. Mr. Bissinger was born in Flehingen, Germany, in 1827. In 1849 he came to New York as the agent of a German diamond house, and shortly afterward went into business on his own account.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- The Hartford, Admiral Farragut's historic flagship, sailed to-day on a cruise to New York in charge of Commander Hawley. The old warship has a complement of 540 men on board. She will first call at San Diego and then proceed to Valparaiso and Montevideo, and from there to New York.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Lady Alice Montagu, sister of the Duke of Manchester, died to-day at Davos-Platz, a health resort in Switzerland. She had been suffering from consumption. The Duke of Manchester was summoned from America to her bedside several weeks ago.

The reply of Secretary GAGE to the resolutions of the Senate and the House in regard to his course in depositing the internal revenue receipts with certain National banks is an evidently candid and straightforward statement of the general policy of the Treasury Department and of the facts specifically inquired into.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- This morning, in the beautiful Church of the Augustinian Fathers, at Villa Nova, near Philadelphia, a marriage of international interest took place. Miss Susan Tilghman, daughter of Mrs. Richard Tilghman, was married to Don Roderico Lante Delia Rovere. Owing to the recent death of the bride's father the wedding was a quiet one, the invitations being confined to the relatives and intimate friends of the bride's family.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 10.--Gov. Taylor told friends to-day that he intends to hold on to his office. He adds that Goebel, having all the best of the election machinery, failed to overcome the landslide which overthrew him, and that, failing to get enough votes, he then tried to have the County Commissioners Give him the best of the count, but failed even in that way to get enough votes counted for him.

MOUNT VERNON, Jan. 10 -- District Attorney Andrews of Westchester County put in a hard day's work in conjunction with the Police Department of this place in probing into the case of Prof. Alfred Morrison, who shot and killed his second wife on the night of Dec. 28 while under the influence of an attack of somnambulism, as he alleges.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The adjourned session of the Senate was opened at 8:30 o'clock to-night, Timothy E. Ellsworth presiding, in the absence of Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff, who is in New York. Conspicuous among the floral decorations was a gift of bridesmaids roses on the desk of Senator Ford from the Twenty-first Assembly District.

Miss Mary E. Howe, who sued Mrs. Frances Augusta Skinner for $24,750 as compensation for services rendered as companion, and was awarded $5,000 by the jury on Monday, has decided to abide by the verdict, and her counsel yesterday, before Justice Truax, withdrew his motion for a new trial.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Senator Frank Wayland Higgins, who represents the Fiftieth Senate District, comprising the Counties of Cattaraugus and Chautauqua, announced to-day that he would not be a candidate for re-election to the Senate next Fall. Well informed Republicans say that Senator Higgins will be nominated for Lieutenant Governor by the Republicans, to succeed Timothy L. Woodruff, whose higher aspirations are well Known.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Insular Committee of the House that has taken up the question of providing Puerto Rico with some opportunities to recover from the depression and dissatisfaction into which its people have fallen since their political condition was changed approaches very slowly the President's recommendation that all customs duties between Puerto Rico and the United States shall be abolished.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 10 -- Color lines are closely drawn on Neville Island, where the American Steel and Wire Company, the Wire Trust, is erecting an immense plant. Three hundred negro laborers working on the excavations for the buildings struck work to-day because they were forced to ride in the same trolley cars with Italians and other foreigners to and from the island.

Emma Elizabeth Miller, the young woman who, on Dec. 21, 1898, while an employe in the store of C. Hartdegen Co., in Newark, sold the silver bottle-holder which was Afterward sent to Harry Cornish at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club along with the bottle of poisoned bromo-seltzer, was the principal witness for the prosecution yesterday in the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Katherine J. Adams.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Miscellaneous business of minor importance occupied the attention of the House to-day until 1 o'clock, after which an hour was devoted to eulogies upon the life and public services of the late Representative Green of Nebraska. The House then adjourned until Friday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Ways and Means Committee of the House to-day held a meeting, at which the following resolution was adopted upon motion of Mr. Newlands of Nevada:

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 10 -- At Grace Episcopal Church to-night Miss Madeline Emma Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace W. Day of East Orange, was married to Vincent Strong Mulford of Montclalr, by the rector of the church, the Rev. Dr. Anthony Schuyler, assisted by Archdeacon Mann. The church was filled with society people.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Among the important bills proposed in the Legislature to-night were propositions for the relief of the New York school teachers. These measures are of great variety, and the different methods suggested will afford scope for wide discussion.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 10 -- The trial of Julia Morrison James for the murder of Frank Leidenheimer of the "Mr. Plaster of Paris" company, of which they were leading man and lady, on the stage of the Chattanooga Opera House on the night of Sept. 23 last, ended at 4 o'clock this afternoon when the jury returned a verdict of not guilty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The representatives of the shipping and shipbuilding interests were given a hearing to-day by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, on the measure generally known as the Shipping bill and entitled "A bill to promote the commerce and increase the foreign trade of the United States, and to provide auxiliary cruisers, transports, and seamen for Government use when necessary."

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 10 -- An explosion, which could be heard for a mile, occurred in the meter, purifying, and condensing house of the Essex and Hudson Gas Company's plant at 8 o'clock to-night. The building was torn to atoms, the windows in houses and stores for blocks were broken, and the alarm created spread to all parts of the city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although averse to "rushing into print," I cannot forbear to answer the palpably unfair statements in the communication published, in THE TIMES to-day over the signature "A.E.O."
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The War Office announces that the list of British casualties at Ladysmith last Saturday has not yet been received.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Mrs. Henry E. Eilinberger, sister of the dead wife of Prof. Alfred Morrison, whom he claims to have shot in a dream, to-day declared that she had had a dream in which Mrs. Morrison appeared to her. The apparition declared that her husband was guiltless of crime and begged her not to presecute the husband.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The session of the Senate to-day was devoted to the paying of tributes to the memory of the late Vice President, Garret A. Hobart. In a beautiful and impressive invocation the blind Chaplain at the opening of the session referred to the distinguished services of Mr. Hobart and called down the blessings of God upon the bereaved family.

Sporting men generally do not agree with Chairman Benjamin B. Odell of the Republican State Committee, who in a statement yesterday expressed the opinion that the battle at the Broadway Athletic Club on Tuesday night was a fake. They are to a man of the opinion that the fight between McGovern and Dixon was one of the best contests ever seen in this city.

There appears to be some public interest in the millionaire and his millions, how he sot them and what he does with them. THE TIMES pointed out the other day that Mr. CARNEGIE'S generous gifts to found libraries and endow schools of instruction in the mechanic arts constituted a justification of his wealth.

Judgment for $1,010,54 against Elisha Dyer, Jr., son of the Governor of Rhode Island, and William A. Haines in favor of the Sidney B. Bowman Cycle Company was given in the City Court on Tuesday by Justice Lewis J. Conlan. The judgment was for rent of the quarters formerly occupied by the Michaux Cycle Club, of which Messrs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much hilarity has recently been created in educational circles by the publication in the secular and educational press of the questions of the last Principals' examination. In view of the examination for Principals in March next, the questions, it is said, have a special interest for teachers.

The majority, and minority reports of the Mazet Investigating Committee were taken to Albany yesterday by Assemblyman Edward H. Fallows and Civil Justice Hoffman, respectively. The majority report was prepared by Messrs, Mazet and Fallows, while it is said that the minority report was written by Senator Thomas F. Grady and gone over by Corporation Counsel Whalen.

John Quincy Adams Hoyt, formerly one of the most prominent business men in this city and Chicago, and one of the original promoters of the present elevated railroad system of this city, died at his residence, 133 West Sixty-first Street, on Wednesday of heart disease.

A conference was held at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon between several of the persons who have become interested in the movement to eradicate the evidences of vice from, this city as far as possible, and Chief Devery and Police Commissioners York, Abell, and Hess; Deputy Chief Cortright, and Inspector Cross.

About 100 members of the New York City Association of the Alumni of Hamilton College met at the Savoy Hotel last night to hold their annual banquet and election, and incidentally to celebrate the birthday of Alexander Hamilton. The guest of honor was Secretary of War Elihu Root, who is himself an Alumnus.

John Ryan, a middle-aged man living at 336 South Third Street, Brooklyn, was arrested last night on complaint at Henry Kroncke, a grocer at Grand and Berry Streets, charged with stealing seven bars of soap displayed in front of the store. Ryan was taken into custody after an excihting chase for several blocks.

Bernard Wolfart, a German, sixty-one years old, killed himself at his home, 345 Seventh Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Wolfart lived with his wife, a married daughter, and a three-year-old granddaughter. The man up to nine months ago had been employed as a machinist in a West Twenty-ninth Street shop.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Mrs. Harry Eilenberger has determined that she will go to Mount Vernon to-morrow to testify against Prof. Alfred Morrison, who shot his wife, Mrs. Eilenberger's sister.

The voices of an Archbishop, a Bishop, a Vicar General, and over 200 priests raised in chanting; an audience, hushed, awed, immense; the glitter of twelve score tapers, and, finally, the harmony of organ and choir blended, characterized the obsequies held over the body of Father Edward McGlynn yesterday morning in the Church of St. Stephen, of which for so long he was the rector.

The Hooker, Swiss American, and Gotham teams each won and lost a game in the North Side National League last night. The final game of the night, between the Gothams and the Hookers, furnished some excellent sport. The teams were almost even until the final frame, when the Gothams, by good strike bowling, drew away, and won by twenty-nine pins.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Gov. Roosevelt has granted a respite to Squire Tankerd, the convicted wife murderer, until July 16 next. The respite is granted in view of a preliminary report received from Dr. Charles L. Dana and Dr. C.H.C. Steinsieck, who were appointed to examine him as to his sanity. The report is as follows:

Wall Street had more unhappy experiences yesterday. Almost the entire list declined, some recessions being not only substantial but sensational. Sugar Trust after opening around 120, dropped down to within a fraction of 112; Tobacco, from par, fell below 96; Brooklyn Rapid Transit lost half a dozen points and so did Metropolitan Street Railway, and some others not so conspicuous.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of some discussion in THE TIMES as to the expediency of using the typewriter for "personal" correspondence, let me say that a recent experience of my own burned into my intelligence a realizing sense of the situation there indicated.

Hallahan Ahearn have sold the sevenstory apartment house at the southwest corner of Central Park West and One hundred and Ninth Street, known as the Hartley, on a plot 100 by 100. The price is reported at about $335,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The following cablegram was received at the Navy Department to-day from Admiral Schley, commanding the South Atlantic Station:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- In the Senate to-day the resolution offered by Mr. Pettigrew (Silver, S.D.,) several days ago together with the substitute for it offered by Mr. Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) was taken up. This lead to a somewhat sensational debate, in the course of which Mr. Pettigrew fiercely attacked the Administration of President McKinley.

So serious are the prospects of a water famine in Brooklyn that the department authorities have arranged to pump from Baisley's and Springfield ponds near Jamaica. The use of the water of these ponds was once condemned by the State Board of Health on the ground that it was polluted and unfit for human use by the numerous nuisances existing along the streams which supply it.

The Coffee Exchange experienced an unusual flurry yesterday, as a result of report that bubonic plague had broken out in Rio Janeiro. The market made a net advance of from 15 to 25 points in various deliveries, after another erratic course, as the result of this report, and the day's transactions aggregrated nearly 77,000 bags.

MOUNT VERNON, Jan. 11 -- Prof. Alfred Morrison, who shot and killed his wife on the night of Dec. 28 at their home, 230 South Tenth Avenue, during an attack of what he called somnambulism, will be arrested to-morrow on a charge of deliberate murder. The warrant will be applied for to-morrow morning before City Judge Adam Schatz by District Attorney George C. Andrews of Westchester County.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 11 -- The three delegations recently appointed to lay before the Government at Washington the special needs of Puerto Rico sailed to-day for the United States on the Philadelphia. Senors Finlay, Luce, and Juncos go on behalf of the Chamber of Commerce; Senors Gonzales and Amadeo will represent the agricultural interests, and Senors Ames and Larriniga the Federal Party.

The annual election of the Union League Club, which was held at the clubhouse last night, resulted in the defeat of the "regular" ticket, headed by Henry E. Howland, and the choice of Frederick D. Tappen, President of the Gallatin National Bank, who had been placed in nomination as an independent, for President.

Mr. ROCKEFELLER and Mr. HAVEMEYER, the two greatest trust makers and trust managers in the country, have at last recognized the principle that the big industrial concerns they control can no longer be managed as a blind pool, but must admit their shareholders, and consequently the public, to a reasonable knowledge of their operations and their results.

Capt. Washington Willcooks, Company G, Ninth Regiment, Senior Captain in the regiment, has been placed under military arrest by Col. William F. Morris, for an alleged disobedience of orders, and it is said a court-martial is likely to follow.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Organization Republicans who are familiar with the situation in the Legislature express the opinion to-night that any bill seeking to reorganize the school system of the State along lines suggested by the Unification Commission, which plan has met with the approval of Gov. Roosevelt, cannot be passed at the present session.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- Dr. Elizabeth J. French, one of the most distinguished women in the medical fraternity of this country, died at the home of her daughter, Dr. Belle French Patterson, on Huntington Avenue, this afternoon, after a short illness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Mr. Campbell, attorney for the memorialists in the case of Senator Clark of Montana, began his redirect examination of Witness Whiteside before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day.

There was a bold hold-up which netted the robbers over $800 in the Long Island City section of Queens Borough last night. The robbers took what money was in sight and decamped, not waiting to rifle a safe in which were thousands of dollars, and the safe stood open in the office and the robbers passed it on their way in and out, but did not notice it.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The water company has notified the users of water motors and of water for purposes for which steam or electricity can be substituted that on and after Monday next the water will be cut off from them until such time as the supply available is larger.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The legislative committee to investigate the tax question will report to the Legislature that it recommends:

MONTREAL, Jan. 11 -- The article which appeared in La Semaine Religieuse of Quebec last Saturday, telling the French Canadiana the hour of their redemption was at hand, and predicting the humiliation of Great Britain and the United States, which was telegraphed to THE NEW YORK TIMES at the time, has been repudiated, so far as the sentiment of the Church of Montreal is concerned, by Archbishop Bruchesi of this city.

The gloomy skies and chill airs of yesterday morning, to which were added in the afternoon rain and sleet, prevented much social movement and life outdoors yesterday and had a deterrent effect upon general gayety. The day brought more of incident than its predecessors of the week, but still was not particularly lively.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Mr. Sanders introduced in the Assemly to-day an amendment to the Constitution providing for a public initiative and referendum. The bill provides that the legislative power of this State shall be vested in the Senate and the Assembly, and, in addition thereto, shall be vested in the electors qualified to vote for Governor.

Judge Cowing, who has been trying excise cases for a week or more, lost his temper yesterday in Part II. of the General Sessions, and after a severe rebuke to the jury, which almost resulted in an altercation, he abruptly adjourned the court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The notion which I imagine many Americans have that the Manhattan Office Building is a monstrous freak of art is one that can be easily shown to be erroneous. It bears numerous and evident marks of its legitimate and direct descent from the timbered street buildings of the mediaeval cities.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- State Treasurer Jaeckel to-day received from Controller Coler of New York City a check on the City Trust Company of New York City for $283,159.41. This check was for the money collected in New York City during the three months ended Dec. 31 under the taxable transfer act.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 11 -- News has been received here of the death in Peoria, Ill., of Gen. Dabney H. Maury, late of the Confederate army, and at one time Minister to Colombia. The remains will be brought to Fredericksburg, Va., for interment.

Frank R. Hitchcock submitted yesterday to The Jockey Club a number of amendments to the rules of racing, all of which are of vital importance. The amendments related especially to the racing of two-year-olds, and when copies of them were sent out in the racing calendar some weeks ago they were read and approved by almost every turfman who has at heart the best interests of the sport.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- A special cable to The Chicago Tribune from London says:

Two important bills relating to the schools of this city were introduced in the Senate yesterday. They are sound in principle, and if they stand the test of discussion as to their practical details, they should be passed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The following official statement was to-day given out by the State Department:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have seen an article in your edition of Monday last to the effect that the Merchants' Association and also the Board of Trade and Transportation have taken active steps to procure a new Post Office.

Alexander Williams. Alexander Williams, Boston's famous pioneer bookseller and publisher, died at his home in that city yesterday. He was eighty-one years of age, and for many years his place of business was at the "Old Corner Bookstore" on School and Washington Streets.
BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- Figures compiled at the Chamber of Commerce show that the Port of Boston is gaining fast in its foreign trade.

It is no wonder at all that the British public should have begun to show itself very weary of the military conduct of the war in South Africa. Two little republics, containing a total of not more than 50,000 men of arms-bearing age, have for three months, dating from the issue of the Boer ultimatum, succeeded in standing off the British Empire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Speaker Henderson is promising to be a strict man. His predecessor was a stickler for most of the rules of the House, and went so far as to turn out all the dealers in curfos, cigars, and refreshments who had "squatted" in the halls. Speaker Henderson has found other rules not strictly regarded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- At the expiration of the morning hour in the Senate today the currency bill was taken up and Mr. Stewart (Silver. Nev.) addressed the Senate, opening with an attack on the Republican Party for bringing in a measure "so utterly contradictory of the St. Louis platform."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Consideration of the census measure conferring additional authority upon the Director of the Census was taken up in the Senate to-day, Mr. Hoar withdrawing an amendment he had offered.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 11 -- The most largely attended funeral service that has ever been held in this city took place to-day, when the last religious rites over the bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dana Greene, who were drowned in the Mohawk River while skating on Monday, were held in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Despite the rain yesterday a large number of ladies were present at the monthly ladies' day of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. In the afternoon a musicale was held in the theatre, in which Miss Martha Miner, Florence Adele Mulford, G. Leon Moore, and Gwllym Miles appeared as soloists. The members of the New York University gymnastic team gave an exhibition in the gymnasium in the evening, under the direction of F.H. Cann.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- To many persons in Washington who have known of the wish of the President to keep Secretary Root in the War Department and not to let him get away to be Vice President, it did not need the publication of the Milwaukee dispatch of yesterday denying Mr. Root's alleged desire to be the candidate to set that report at rest.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 11 -- The Republican leaders, while not abandoning the fight against Goebel in the Legislature, are eagerly awaiting news from Washington as to what aid the Federal Government would give the Taylor administration in the event that Goebel is seated by the Legislature. They are advising Gov. Taylor to resist in case the Legislature decides in favor of Goebel, and are promising him support.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 -- There was a discussion in the Baltimore Presbytery to-day over severing the pastoral relations of the Rev. Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock, who has accepted a call to the "Brick Church," New York, from the Brown Memorial Church of this city. Some of the members of the Presbytery expressed the opinion that the call should have been brought before that body before it was finally accepted by Dr. Babcock.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In the news columns of to-day's issue you have an article headed "War on Trust Companies." It is descriptive of proposed changes in the tax laws to be made by the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- About the last of January the Philippine Commission will submit their full report to the President. President Schurman was at the White House to-day to announce that progress was being made and that before February the work of the commission will be completed. The report made in September was a general one, in which all the Commissioners joined.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Jan. 11 -- John E. Lance, a farmer living near High Bridge, has gone to the Pasteur Institute in New York for treatment. While engaged about the house a few days ago, his dog suddenly sprang at him and bit him in the hand. Lance had a glove on the hand, but the dog's teeth sank deep into the flesh, inflicting a serious wound.

The anti-imperialists appear to have clasped hands with the silver folks. Heretofore the American friends of AGUINALDO have contented themselves with declaring that his glorious cause was paramount in our politics, and that his triumph was more to be desired than BRYAN'S defeat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is amusing in the midst of all the dogmatic infallibility of THE TIMES concerning the mathematical inaccuracy of calling 99 years 100, in the midst of all its epithets "derisory or comminatory," which it will not withdraw, to see no flicker of historical intelligence penetrate so far as the editorial sanctum.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 -- The Cotton States Association of Commissioners of Agriculture to-day re-elected all its old officers to serve for another year.

Mr. HEPBURN'S letter to Secretary GAGE admits neither of excuse nor palliation. The request he had to make was a perfectly proper one. He desired the Secretary to continue the National City Bank, of which he was then Vice President, as one of the depositories of Treasury money.

Chief Engineer Birdsall of the Department of Water Supply yesterday took a pessimistic view of the effect of Thursday's rainfall, so far as it affected the shortage in the Brooklyn supply. The storm, he said, had added largely to the quantity of water in the reservoirs whence the supply for Manhattan and the Bronx is drawn, but the accretions in Brooklyn were only sufficient to give momentary relief.

Wagner's "Tannhauser" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The audience was a large one, and its applause was generous and fairly earned. The performance was admirable in its earnestness and the general conviction which it conveyed, and though it was not without its shortcomings, it may be set down as one of the successful achievements of the season.
The following memorial, urging a ratification of the treaty of The Hague has been forwarded to members of the United States Senate: To the Honorable the Members of the Senate:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- In the House to-day Mr. Sulzer (Dem., N.Y.,) presented for immediate consideration a resolution for the appointment of a special committee of nine members to investigate the relations of the Secretary of the Treasury with certain New York National banks and the transactions relative to the sale of the New York Custom House.

The British reply to our representations concerning the British seizures of American flour is what we were all sure beforehand that it must be. Food, it has been held by all the publicists from GROTIUS down, is "occasional contraband." It is contraband, according to these authorities, when it is used as munition of war.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court handed down yesterday a decision in the matter of the appraisal of the property of George M. Pullman within this State for the purpose of determining the amount of the transfer tax to be paid to the Controller of this city for the benefit of the State Treasury.
To The New York Times Saturday Review: I do not think there is so much danger or reading too much as there is of reading top fast the much or little that we do read.

Bigamy and probably forgery were the crimes, from the punishment of which the man registered at the Eastern Hotel, in Whitehall Street, as E.J. Fuller, sought escape by committing suicide in his room Thursday afternoon. Two women appeared yesterday to claim the suicide as their husband.
