WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A statement of the gross postal receipts for December, 1899, as compared with the receipts for the same month during the preceding year shows a net increase of $199,835, or 5 per cent. The total receipts for last December were $4,162,038.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 12 -- John McGraw, manager of the Baltimore team, has made up his mind to join the new American Association, should the National League drop Baltimore. In this move he will receive the support of Joe Kelley, Capt. Robinson, Clarke, and Jennings.

Andrew Blake, sixty years old, a lawyer, with offices at 108 Fulton Street and living at 131 West Thirteenth Street, died suddenly of heart disease at 7:15 o'clock last night on the platform of the elevated railroad station at Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and Fourth Street.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 12 -- Dr. Howard Ayres, the new President of the University of Cincinnati, intends to make a clean sweep of that institution by dismissing the entire Faculty. He will go before the Board of Directors next Monday with a recommendation that all chairs be declared vacant after June 1 next, which is the end of the college year.

The question of the restriction of traffic in Fifth Avenue, which is advocated in a resolution drawn by President Guggenheimer, now pending before the Council, was taken up by the Committee on Streets and Highways of that body yesterday. A large number of attorneys and business men, representing many interests, appeared betore the committee and presented their views on both sides of the case.

In a limited edition, on good paper, attractively printed and bound comes a new edition of what is probably the first book about books ever written, and also a strong plea in defense of book collecting. It seems to be very little known to book lovers in general, a fact most conclusively proved by the small number of editions published and the limited number of copies in each.

"Paolo and Francesca" is based upon that tragedy in Tuscan mediaeval life which is so beautifully told in the fifth canto of Dante's "Inferno," and which has furnished the theme for many other poets and novelists and dramatists. It seems proper, therefore, to supplement the foregoing review of Mr. Phillips's poetic drama with a translation of the verses which inspired his muse.

"The Bond of Black" is a peculiar title, and the story is, indeed, a peculiar story. It deals with an extraordinary phase of modern life in London and a subject hitherto untouched by English authors. What is here detailed will come to the majority as a startling revelation, and some may declare that no such amazing state of things exists in this the most enlightened age the world has known.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Committee on Commerce to-day began hearings on Senator Frye's bill to promote the commerce and increase the foreign trade of the United States and to provide auxiliary cruisers, transports, and seamen for Government use when necessary, the measure popularly known as the Subsidy bill.

The announcement that the acquisition of the control by the Vanderbilts of the Eastern trunk roads would be followed by the abolition of the differential rates, which have diverted from New York its natural share of the increase of traffic from the West to tidewater, was the cause of much satisfaction yesterday in mercantile circles.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The two questions suggested by the heading remain unsettled even now. A short time ago The Inter Ocean of Chicago, commenting upon "America's great poet," gave opinion thus: "The generally accepted information now is that Poe was born in Baltimore in 1811."

The millionaire is not wholly friendless. Hard beset and panting as he flees before his Socialistic pursuers, he hears now and then a good word said for him. Even from the pulpit, where the doctrines of Christian Socialism, whatever that may be, are reported to have effected a lodgment, a just and dispassionate estimate of the utility of millionaires in the scheme of creation may sometimes be heard.

The question of supremacy in the eagle cage in the Central Park menagerie was decided finally yesterday after as furious and destructive a fight as has ever occurred among any of its inmates. As a result of the battle, "Canuck," the baldheaded eagle, recently brought to the menagerie from the Thousand Islands, is now in the bird hospital, in the basement of the Arsenal building.

There is a certain fine suggestion of fitness in the report that the Mazet report has been "held up" by a threat on the part of the minority that they would outdo the majority in personal and political abuse if the latter persisted in indulging in it.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- John B. Cauldwell, Director of Fine Arts of the American Section of the Paris Exposition, has appointed the following jury to select paintings for the Exposition: E.A. Abbey, J.W. Alexander, W.T. Dannat, Alexander Harrison, Gari Melchers, F.D. Millet, J.S. Sargent, and Jules Stewart.

Followers of boxing who went to the Broadway Athletic Club last night to sea a boxing contest witnessed an exhibition in which there was not only one, but a couple of apparent knockouts "Kid" McCoy, the conqueror of Peter Maher, and "Joe" Choyuski, the California heavyweight, were to have fought twenty-five rounds, but they fought only three.

Social movement and life yesterday in the fashionable districts of the city was a little more noticeable and pronounced than on Thursday. This was due to the warm weather, the passing of the rainstorm, and also the fact that Friday is this year quite a favorite day for receptions and "At Homes."

Ernest Seton-Thompson, the author of "Wild Animals I Have Known." "The Trail of the Sandhill Stag," "The Biography of a Grizzly," and other charming tales of animal life and habits, is again in New York, after a prolonged trip in the West and South. The author spent a portion of his time on a wheat ranch in Southern California, studying and sketching the varieties of fauna peculiar to that region.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: For the benefit of your correspondent, R. T., Jr., from Eisenach, whose letter you printed Nov. 11, I copy a clipping relative to "Faust." It is from The Musical Courier, but I don't know of what date. I am positive, however, that it is not over a year old:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Gen. Otis has made a report to the War Department in regard to the military operations in Luzon south of Manila, showing the capture of several towns and a large number of prisoners with arms and ammunition. The message is as follows:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: My Dear SATURDAY REVIEW, may I also say a word about old songs and old memories? The article, signed E. Kayem, in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW for Jan. 6 was "right" pleasant reading. I, too, remember those old songs, and many more not quoted by the author.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- To the great variety of propositions for amendments to the educational section of the Greater New York charter another was added to-day which is more radical in its provisions than any yet proposed. This provides for a complete reorganization of the school department and the abolition of the Central Board of Education.

In the present life, of Stevenson, the secend issue in his Modern English Writers Series, Mr. Cornford disarms possible criticism by at once defining the scope of his volume. Long a student of Stevenson's work, he here essays a study "of his finished achievement and of his personality as expressed in that achievement."

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- British war correspondents are pouring in by means of the mails columns of descriptions of the operations in South Africa. Those recently printed refer chiefly to the battles of Graspati and Modder River, for it is yet too early for the publication of full accounts of Buller's defeat at Colenso.

SOUTH MANCHESTER, Conn., Jan. 12 -- The authorities to-day investigated a report that Mrs Augusta Moffett, aged fifty-five, and her daughter, Bertha, aged 30, were endeavoring to starve themselves to death. Selectmen C.G. Watkins and Henry Barrows visited the house occupied by the two women.

The five-story brick building 184 South Street, occupied by Darmstadt Scott as an assorting warehouse for rags and paper, was entirely gutted by fire yesterday afternoon. The twenty-five employes in the place at the time escaped by the stairway without injury.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- An eccentric old American woman, known at the United States Legation and Consulate for the last twentyyears under the name of Lady Livingstone, has died here under extraordinary circumstances, leaving a large fortune for unknown heirs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Mrs. John Corse, who lives in Dearborn Avenue, was seized by robbers shortly after midnight at Chestnut Street, near North Clark Street, thrust into a cab, and afterward robbed of diamonds valued at $600 and her pocketbook containing $5 in money and a draft for $250. She was brutally beaten, her hands lacerated, and her face bruised.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- Luigi Crispi, son of Signor Francisco Crispi, the distinguished Italian statesman and former Premier, was today sentenced to four years' imprisonment for the theft of jewelry from the Countess Cellere in April of 1896.

George Meredith holds that only two countries have produced the ideal woman of beauty, grace, wit, and art, one of these countries being France, where woman is pre-eminent and disturbing. "Thunder, destructive to insects, refreshes earth; so she," is one of his characteristic maxims in this connection, and when we recall the long line of women who have set their mark on French history, the comparison seems apt enough.

There is just this drawback to such a series of biographies as that of "Famous Scots," to which this belongs-that it may be said to be written of Scotchmen, by Scotchmen, for Scotchmen. There is therefore this obstacle in the way of perfect clearness of vision in the writers, viz., that clannish mutual appreciation which does not exist in an equal degree among any other people under the sun.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The War Office to-day received the following dispatch from Gen. Buller, dated Springfield Jan. 11, evening:

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a certain feature of patent litigation which might well be ventilated in your columns. Numerous impecunious inventors having meritorious patents lose the fruits of their inventions because of their inability under the present system of conducting patent suits to proceed against infringers.

A tradesman once said to an author: "I envy you; yours is the one profession that requires no capital." "Why don't you adopt it, then?" was the reply. "Oh, I couldn't," answered the business man. And this is the view any number of worthy members of society take of the profession of letters.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. Kipling's apparently inexhaustible supply of technicalities is a constant surprise and interest to his admirers, but I must admit that it is a cause of wonder to me that he should be so appreciated in this country, seeing how many of his phrases must be absolutely unintelligible to the majority of Americans.

There is a peculiar feeling among Senators of the United States about the petty offices connected with their body. Perhaps it would be rude to call it greed, but there is in it more of greed than of any other sentiment. This is not made any better by being mixed with considerable vanity, jealousy, and a curious fondness for intrigue.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It is interesting to learn from one who has observed and "made note of" that among the simple, more rural folk of our country who read novels Charles Dickens stands well and has a place above Thackeray.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The statement to the effect that the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company had signed a new contract with the trainmen granting what practically amounted to a 15 per cent. increase in wages, proves to be untrue. Certain inequalities have been ratified, but no change was made in wage rates.

Senator Depew gave expression to his views on the decline of churchgoing at the twenty-fourth anniversary celebration of the railroad branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, held at the headquarters in Madison Avenue last night. After paying a tribute to the work of the late Cornelius Vanderbilt.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 58 1/2 @ 59 1/2. There were no sales.

There are now on exhibition at the Fifth Avenue Auction Rooms, 238 Fifth Avenue, a collection of oil paintings by foreign and American artists, belonging to Mr. George E. Tewkesbury and Mrs. Henry Purton. These are to be sold at auction on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday evenings of next week.

Sugar Trust stock advanced about four points yesterday. It sold as low as 113 and as high as 118, closing within a fraction of the top point. Yesterday's transactions aggregated close to 100,000 shares, which, however, represents only about half the average aggregate of recent days.

The Rev. Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock and the Rev. Dr. George T. Purves preach for the first time to-morrow as pastors, respectively, of the Brick and Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Churches. Dr. Babcock comes for permanent service, and it is announced that he will preach morning and evening regularly.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Of "Charlotte Bronte at Home," by Marion Harland, published by the Putnams, let me pay it is really very remarkable that after more than forty-five years since the decease of the subject of this exceedingly interesting memoir, so bright, so fresh, so entertaining a book could be written.

The trial of Senator Michael J. Coffey, the Democratic leader of the Ninth Assembly District, Brooklyn, on the charges of disloyalty to the Democratic organization, preferred against him by his opponents in his district, was formally begun last night before the special committee of the County Executive Committee, appointed to hear the charges.

The Duke of Wellington is an inexhaustible theme to Englishmen. Perhaps to-day Englishmen are waiting anxiously for the coming of a second Wellington. Sir Herbert Maxwell's title to his volume is "The Life of Wellington: The Restoration of the Martial Power of Great Britain." That subtitle sounds a little curiously to-day.

William Rhinelander Stewart, President of the State Board of Charities, declined yesterday to talk on the subject of the decision by Justice O'Brien of the Court of Appeals that the State Board of Charities has no jurisdiction of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. "The Attorney General," said Mr. Stewart, "is my lawyer, and it is his business to talk."

A delegation of residents of the northern and northwestern sections of the city, under the leadership of ex-Alderman Collin H. Woodward, called upon Mayor Van Wyck yesterday to urge him to use his efforts to hasten the construction of the entire rapid transit system before anything is done looking toward the building of a tunnel to Brooklyn.

Reviews are here presented of the first volumes of two series of what are intended by their respective editors to be representations of the world's greatest and best orations. Each series has special and distinct merits. Both show that care, knowledge, and enthusiasm have been exercised upon the idea of furnishing the people of to-day with the most distinctive specimens of "the art that rules," in attractive and useful forms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Rapid transit across Russia, by the Trans-Siberian Railway, is some distance away yet, but the prospect, according to Consul Commercial Agent R.T. Greener, at Vladivostock, is that when the line is opened and the improvements made in portions of the system that seem to be demanded the journey will be not only cheaper than by any other route to the Far East, but will be also more comfortable.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Remarkable scenes of patriotism were witnessed in London last evening after a short service held for the volunteers in St. Paul's Cathedral. The vast audience was slow to disperse. Ladies stood upon the chairs beckoning and calling to brothers, sons, and friends in the ranks, the latter signaling back.

Mr. W. Broderick-Cloete, the grandson of the late Hon. Henry Cloetc, who edits his grandfather's lectures, writes in his preface that "just because the book is a condensed and dispassionate statement of facts, from which inference and comment have been excluded, with singular care, it requires to be read with intelligent attention.

The refusal of Assistant United States District Attorney Ernest B. Baldwin to accept Miss C.E. Kelleg of Syracuse, N.Y., as surety for Eugene L. Packer, pending an appeal of his case, led to a series of disputes between himself and Col. Robert A. Ammon in the Federal Building yesterday afternoon.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The Rev. John Price takes exception in last week's SATURDAY REVIEW to my "faultfinding with Marion Crawford's utterances on affinity.'" At the risk of being considered obdurate in error, and in the face of this clerical support, I am still inclined to believe that the author of "Via Crucis" was mistaken, even from the eleventh century point of view.

The author whose pen helps to mold the mind and heart of a boy into forms of manhood, patriotism, and honor does his country and the world a lasting service. The Italian writer ae Amicis has made himself famous by his works of travel. His pictures of Spain and Holland are masterpieces. His year in Holland has given delight to many thousands.
Major Henry S. Kilbourne, Surgeon, now on duty in New York City, as Medical Superintendent of Transports, is relieved from station at Madison Barracks, New York.

The gift of the Berrian collection of works on Mormonism to the New York Public Library by Miss Helen M. Gould is an important addition to the resources which that library can offer to the student of human errors. This collection was begun over forty years ago by Charles L. Woodward, the well-known bookseller of Nassau Street, and was sold by him in 1880, the catalogue being entitled Bibliothica (sic) Scallawagiana.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Let me thank "Cynic" for wrtting upon a subject which happens to be one of my particular hobbles. I can indorse his statement that "nowhere in this world are books better appreciated than in the 'busy haunts of men' by persons whose tastes and inclinations lead them away from the distractions and the follies of the crowds who find their delights in externals."

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Assemblyman Charles Dillon of New York will on Monday introduce in the Assembly a bill which seeks to amend the Code of Criminal Procedure so as to permit a person convicted of crime to move for a new trial on newly discovered evidence at any time before the expiration of the sentence imposed.

Russell Sage was "talked to" yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Directors of the Standard Gaslight Company, of which he is President, but nothing came of the sermons, whose text was taken from the financier's recent private deal in his holdings of Standard stock. The meeting was held in the company's offices, in the Bank of Commerce Building, and was more fully attended than is usual.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposition to change the name of Whitehall Street to South Broadway is one of the most senseless and uncalled for acts of vandalism ever perpetrated by our socalled city fathers, and should meet with the united protest of all citizens having a spark of reverence left for the few historical points in our city which have not been attacked by these busy-bodies.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Prof. James Martineau, the eminent Unitarian theologian, died to-day. He was in his ninety-fifth year.

The American reader will lay down this latest volume by the popular Italian author with a feeling akin to disappointment. The "Memories" of the writer of "Constantinople," "Holland," "Morocco," "Spain," and of that ever-delightful "Cuore," (the English title of which is "The Heart of a Boy,") should awaken almost as keen an interest on the other side of the Atlantic as in his native peninsula -- and probably will.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- In the market to-day the tone was generally firmer. The trading, however, was very light, showing a lack of confidence in the situation, notwithinding the fact of easy money and bargain prices. The coppers were more than dull, but developed no weak spots. United States Oil held above Thursday's lowest on a better understanding of the company's position.

HAVANA, Jan. 12 -- "Federico Mora, Fiscal of the Supreme Court, is hereby removed from office for the good of the public service. This removal is the result of an investigation into the conditions existing in the administration of justice under his administration."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections began its session in the Clark case to-day with a request from the prosecution to have the books of the Thomas Cruse Savings Bank, at Helena, Mon., showing the deposits of A.J. Davidson and a man named Toole brought before the committee.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Malietoa Tanus, in his letter to The London Times, published today, inclosing copies of the protests he addressed to the United States, Great Britain, and Germany against the Samoan treaties, characterizes the partition of Samoa as a gross violation of the treaties and as a crime against the law of nations, only equal to the dismemberment of Roland, Denmark, and France.

The ninth week of the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Katherine J. Adams closed yesterday, with the case for the prosecution still unpresented. It will take three or four days, and perhaps the whole of next week, to get in the restimony against the prisoner.

-- Rarely indeed is it profitable to seek an explanation for the acts of Police Justices, but mysteries, as a rule, are interesting in direct ratio to the improbability of solving them, and as the Magistrates mentioned indulge in frequent excursions beyond the realms of both natural and statute law, it is not at all surprising that their acts attract frequent and delighted attention.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Jan. 12 -- A considerable portion of the business section of Navesink Highlands was destroyed by fire this morning. The fire spread from the Post Office Building to the railroad office on the pier, and to the United States Express freight building. The Union News stand and Reiter Woodley's stores were also consumed.

MOUNT VERNON, Jan. 12.--Prof. Alfred Morrison, linguist, somnambulist and bigamist, who on the night of Dec. 28 shot and killed his wife in their room at 235 South Tenth Avenue while under the influence of an alleged attack of somnambulism and who was subsequently exonerated by the Coroner, is now a prisoner in the Westchester County Jail charged with deliberate murder.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Jan. 13.--The identity and character of the steamer wrecked on a reef in St. Mary's Bay are still matters of conjecture. The that she is an oil tanker is weakened by the fact that she is afire aft and has not exploded. The belief that she is a passenger steamer is strengthened by the fact there are a large number of ship's boats adrift in the bay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I say a few words in answer to Thomas P. McLoughlin, whom I think rather cheekily criticises your Saturday editorial? From the beginning to the end of the letter it is absolutely wrong.

In "The Colloquies of Edward Osborne," the late Miss Manning presents graphic pen pictures of London life during the reign of Edward VI, and Queen Mary. With her usual happy rendering of historical subjects, the author weaves around the sufferings of some English Church martyrs a simple, wholesome romance.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 12 -- James G. Batterson, President of the Travelers' Insurance Company, to-day stated that his company is considering the advisability of removing to New York to escape "unjust taxation at the hands of Hartford and Connecticut."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 12 -- When several hundred citizens demanded admittance to the House of Delegates to-day to protest against the action of that body in refusing to pass bills for lighting the city institutions, the delegates concluded it would not be wise to admit them. When the visitors insisted the delegates locked the doors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- It is said at the State Department that the attempt to secure some sort of reparation for the killing of Lenz, the bicyclist, in Turkey, is being steadily prosecuted. About two years ago the Turkish Government was addressed on this subject, and promised to punish the murderers.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The report of the Palisades Commissioners, appointed by legislative enactment to confer with like representatives of New Jersey for the acquisition of the Palisades of the Hudson River by the United States and making an appropriation therefor, has been submitted to the Governor, who has transmitted it to the Legislature.

The cable brings the news of a wedding, to be celebrated in Liverpool to-day, which is a veritable romance. The bridegroom is to be Mr. C.B. Ismay, a son of the late Thomas Henry Ismay, founder of the White Star Line, and the bride is to be Miss Constance Schieffelin of this city. Miss Schieffelin is a daughter of Mr. George Schieffelin.

The Right Rev. Joseph Rademacher, Roman Catholic Bishop of the diocese of Fort Wayne, Ind., died in that city yesterday. He was fifty-nine years old, and had teen identified with the work of his Church in the Middle States for the greater part of his life, until his last illness, which was of about a year's duration.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- Mayor Hart was waited upon to-day by J.J. Driscoll and a delegation from the Central Labor Union, who came to demand numerous things, and he gave them a decided set-back. Mr. Driscoll informed the Mayor at the outset that the committee represented 80,000 organized workers.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It seems somewhat ungracious to quarrel with anything which any member of the old Cambridge literary group may say, but after all they set up no claim to infallibility and are just as willing as any other close of people to have their statements and opinions put to the test.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 12 -- The Goebel-Taylor and Breekham-Marshall contest committees will each hold meetings to-morrow, at which they will arrange for the trial of the contests. The hearing of evidence will begin Monday. About 5,000 witnesses are expected. The arrival of about fifty men from Eastern Kentucky to-night created a big stir in Goebel circles, when it was charged that the new arrivals were militiamen in citizens' clothes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Wholesale merchants and jobbers in Chicago and west of here will be benefited by action just taken by the Western and Southwestern railroads in declining to accede to a request of the Merchants' Association of New York City to reduce round-trip rates to the latter city from Western points for Spring buyers.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Referring to the new books from Paris which you mention in your Issue of to-day, there is one the absence of which I regret and which I would like very much to commend to all readers of French who want to keep abreast of the contemporary literary movement in Paris.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in a decision handed down yesterday, sustained an injunction, pending action, granted by the lower court in the suit of the Society of the War of 1812 against the Society of the War of 1812 in the State of New York. The decision means that the latter society will have to find another name.

Isidore Goldman, who claims that he married his wife Gussie on April 1 last, when he was only a little over seventeen years old, was unsuccessful in his action to have his marriage annulled, which was tried before Justice Bischoff in the Supreme Court yesterday. The suit was brought on Isidore's behalf by his father, Hyman Goldman.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I must express myself as more than pleased with the editorial printed in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of the 6th of this month. The title was, "French Lectures at Harvard." I fully indorse every word found therein.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- John Fisher -- young, -- debonair and high-collared -- who claims to be the representative of a historical publishing house of New York, is in jail in Camden for trying to furt on a train near Atlantic City with Miss Lizzie Clark, a demure maid of fifteen, who looks elder. Lizzie lives at Dorothy, N.J.

Being still unwilling to advance into the unknown region before us while enshrouded in mist, we drew near a prominent mountain peak to make a debarkment. This peak was a perpendicular cliff, free of snow to the seashore. It was one of a number extending far into the southeast, as we learned on the following day.

Mme. Sembrich's charming rendering of Norina in Donizetti's "Don Pasquale" the other evening may have given people the idea that it is a role she has sung many times. They would not be reasoning without precedent in doing so, knowing Mme. Sembrich's affection for and belief in the Italian opera.
As a result of last Friday's meeting of the Directors of the Standard Gas Company, the appended notice was made public yesterday:

This is about the proper time in the year for the man who intends trying canoeing, to pick up a bargain in second-hand craft. The canoeist who proposed indulging in a new boat next season has placed his order, and is debating whether he will brighten up his old cruiser and sell her, or thoroughly overhaul her and retain her for second best.

John Sasel, twenty-two years old, applied for admission to the St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, Thursday. At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon an operation was performed on the man, and among other junk the following articles were removed from his stomach:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your late editorials on "The Suppression of the Individual" and on "The Justification of Wealth," and others touching on Socialism, seem to lack the precision, clear thought, and judicial temperament that usually characterize your editorial page. Yet the discussion would seem to be one in which these qualities were specially needed.
Felix Morris, the well-known actor, died yesterday morning at 42 Irving Place, from pneumonia, after a week's illness.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Capt. McCalla, commanding the United States ship Newark, has written a letter to the Chief of the Bureau of Navigation in which he makes the following statements:

Suicide has been very differently regarded by various peoples; treated as a venial matter by the Roman law, the subject of panegyric by some of the Stole philosophers, it is generally regarded by modern civilization as a heinous crime or as proof of insanity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce to-day resumed its hearing on the Hanna-Payne Shipping Subsidy bill. Thomas Clyde, of the Clyde Steamship Line, was recalled. He took up the cost of the construction of vessels, their maintenance and operation, showing that the figures under the American flag were much higher than under any other flag.

There has been some controversy recently as to the proper manner of dressing on Sunday. It has been frequently contended that a man should dress differently on that day from any other, simply because his daily routine is somewhat changed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your article this morning you state that the total Boer force is 50,000 strong, and if this included only the available men of the two republics the estimate would be correct. But there must be added:

ANSONIA, Conn., Jan. 13. -- Miss Elise Farrel, daughter of Franklin Farrel, the multi-millionaire, of this city, has become a stenographer and typewriter. Although already rich in her own name and one of five heirs to a fortune estimated at between $3,000,000 and $5,000,000, she has become one of the office force of the Farrel Foundry and Machine Company.

Take Joubert. The Daily Mail tells its readers to call it "Choo-bare," but House-hold Words gives it as "Yowbert." The former is a somewhat ineffectual attempt to indicate the French pronunciation: the latter is Dutch. We read about Viljoen, but few pronounce it properly, with the ending "joen" like the "yune" in "picayune," "Fill-yune."

The correspondence given below is taken from the report of Secretary of the Treasury Gage, in response to the resolutions of Congress calling upon the Secretary for the correspondence between his department and the National City Bank of New York:

THE question, Are the Americans an Anglo-Saxon people? Is usually answered in the affirmative. Most of the world takes it for granted as a universally accepted fact that they are Anglo-Saxon. But occasionally we hear a protest against taking this for granted, or a denial that it is so.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your excellent editorial in THE TIMES of yesterday under the above heading I think does not put the difficulties the British have to encounter strong enough. The wonderful improvements in rifled guns and small arms put the advantages of a battle very largely with the defenders of earthworks.

The death knell of boxing in New York was probably sounded Friday night by those who, it is maintained, have profited most by the permission under the Horton law to conduct boxing exhibitions, when Joe Choynski was, as it is said, deliberately robbed of the fruits of his victory over "Kid" McCoy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed in this morning's issue of your valuable paper and others an article entitled "Report on the Palisades." The article states that the commission has conferred with the New Jersey commission, submitted maps, c., advocating the taking of the Palisades by the Government as a military reservation.

The Department of Water Supply in Brooklyn announced yesterday that the water on storage had increased, about 4,000,000 gallons on Friday. The actual amount on storage on Friday was 152,061,000 gallons, while there was a reduction in consumption, temporarily at least. The department officials say that this relief will last for a week or ten days, not longer, if there is no more rain.

The scores made in the Wholesale Drug Trade Association tournament at Reid's alleys yesterday afternoon were not high. The games, however, were interesting. Parke, Davis Co. scored a double victory, as did Dodge Oicott. The Merck Co. team was beaten in two games and the Seabury Johnson team won and lost a game.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- Gen. Mercier is a candidate for election to the Senate for the Department of the Loire Inferieure, and he has considerable chances of success, for, though he poses as a Republican, he will receive all the support which the Royalists can give him, and they are very influential in that part of France.

It may have been noticed that woman is generally the dominant and irrepressible subject of this chronicle. The history of the stage since the Restoration of the Stuart Kings is very largely the history of certain women, anyhow, and in the daily records of the contemporary theatre woman seems fairly to dominate all else.

In the Union County Court, New Jersey, yesterday, Judge Vail sentenced John Louis Blackford, formerly a detective of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, to three years in State prison for bigamy. Counsel for Blackford presented a petition which was signed by many prominent men asking for leniency.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been much impressed by the suggestions of Mr. Westinghouse's letter of the 9th published in THE TIMES of the 10th inst. It suggests thoughts far more wide reaching than at first may appear.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Gen. James H. Wilson delivered an address at the Ebbitt House to-day before a number of members of the Cuban Provisional Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Senate Committee on Puerto Rico and Pacific Islands to-day heard Gov. Gen. Davis, who entered upon an exhaustive review of the conditions in the island, the Governmental policies of the Spaniards, and the Government under the United States. He also spoke upon the resources of the islands.

HAVANA, Jan. 7. -- The week just closed has been an exceptionally gay one. The new year was ushered in with many festivities, and from now until the beginning of Lent is the busiest season in Cuban society.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Louis F. Fayn said very curtly when asked to-night if he had anything to say regarding his loan from the State Trust Company, "I have no statement to make."

Officers and Men," by Col. Baden Powell. When in doubt as to whether to go on or to go back think of that, and of the Zulu saying: "If we go forward we die, if we go backward we die; better go forward and die."

THE CZAR EXONERATES THE RUSSIAN MINISTER OF FINANCE. -- It may be recalled that for the last month or two rumors have come by way of Berlin tending to show that M. Witte, the Russian Minister of Finance, was in disgrace. It has even been announced that his Government would prosecute him; that he had actually been arrested.

Mrs. Langtry, who has been seen in the theatres within the last week, will begin her engagement at the Garden Theatre tomorrow night, presenting Sydney Grundy's drama called "The Degenerates," which caused quite a sensation in London. It is a comedy of modern London life in four acts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- When the Senate Committee on Privileges and Election began its session to-day in the case of Senator Clark of Montana. M.L. Hewett, a miner, who was in Helena during the session of the Legislature in 1899, was called. He said that Charles Clark had asked him to see Senator Myers and offer him $10,000 for his vote for Mr Clark for Senator.

TRENTON, Jan. 18. -- The preservation of the Palisades is one of the problems that will consume some of the time of the New Jersey Legislature, now in session, and the outlook is not at this time encouraging. Gov. Voorhees has shown his great interest by his presentation of the subject in his annual message to the Legislature.
Three lives were lost in a fire at 11 o'clock last night in a two-story frame cottage on Pine Street, near Mulberry, Corona, L.I. The dead are:

In a paper published in The Independent President HADLEY of Yale discusses the changes which he thinks must be made in our standards of morality in business and in politics. His text is the remark of an English observer that the "standard of personal morality in America is decidedly higher than in England, that of commercial morality probably a little lower, and that of political morality quite distinctly lower."

DAMAGES FROM JAR, SMOKE, AND CINDERS. -- Justice Truax, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, granted judgment in favor of Sarah A. Bly in her suit against the Edison Electric Company restraining it from conducting its business at its power house, in Twenty-sixth Street, in such a manner as to constitute a nuisance, and the plaintiff is awarded $5,000 damages.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Jan. 13. -- Through the efforts of Principal Charles W. Armstrong of the Union School here, the reading of the Bible is to be resumed at the opening exercises in the schools. About fifteen years ago it was discontinued, owing to a controversy which arose between the different religious denominations.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Jan. 13.--The French Cable Company's repairing steamer Francois Arago, which, it was feared, might prove to be the vessel wrecked and burning in St. Mary's Bay, arrived here to-night. The Francois Arago is fourteen days from Havre, via Cherbourg. She met stormy weather, and is short of coal.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Jan. 13. -- A sensation was created here this evening by the arrest of William J. Affleck, ex-Secretary of the Water Works Board, and one of the best-known residents of this county, on the charge of having embezzled public funds. Affleck was formerly County Clerk, has been prominent in business and politics, and has always enjoyed an excellent reputation.

ROME, Dec. 26. -- The city is already filled with pilgrims, and even the most careless traveler cannot fail to be struck with the solemnity of the occasion -- the commencement of the year of jubilee, the end of a century and the beginning of a new one.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 13. -- Prosperity is not a stranger to Augusta. It has been a dweller in this fine old city these many years, thanks largely to the enterprise and conservatism that have controlled its large and expanding industries. When the general improvement in the business of the country began to be felt in the trade pulse here, it strengthened the life of business without exciting a flutter or provoking a " boom."

The business of the last week has been gratifying in at least one particular, in that if it did not show any marked increase in volume, it at least contained a number of deals of more than ordinary interest.

The Bank of England has reduced its discount rate. The Bank of France has reduced its discount rate. The Bank of Germany has reduced its discount rate. Money on call at the close of the week has been materially lower on the New York Stock Exchange, and time funds are offered by New York banks at substantial concessions.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 13.--The coming week will be an interesting one in tennis and racquets. Four champions will be present--Peter Latham champion of the world, of England; Thomas Pettit, professional champion of America; Lawrence Stockton, amateur champion of America, and Eustace H. Miles, amateur champion of England.

In view of the meeting of the Directors of the Third Avenue Railroad Company tomorrow, Wall Street yesterday was full of rumors to the effect that methods touching on the financial condition of the road would be thoroughly gone into at the meeting and that a reorganization would be one of the possibilities.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 13. -- James Aibertson, aged thirteen walked into the police station yesterday. To Day Sergt. Morgan he said:

THE widespread interest now existing in the common school system of this city is another illustration of how difficult it is to arrest the attention of the community by the statement of a general principle or a universal wrong, and how easy it is to arouse its interest by the presentation of an individual instance of distress or injustice.

PARIS, Jan. 2. -- One often hears discussed in America the question whether New York fashions are six months or a year behind those in Paris. From the present state of things one would say that New York is at least a year behind for those who frequent the large department shops. For those who patronize the smartest Fifth Avenue modistes and milliners there is comparatively little difference.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 13. -- The Republican State Committee, through its officers, and the organization formed by disaffected Democrats in the recent campaign, have issued statements reviewing the political situation and calling upon the people for their support. The appeal issued by the anti-Goebel Democrats says:

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 13. -- Announcement is made to-day of the scope of the boating plans decided upon for the Yale University crew at a meeting of prominent Yale graduates and former oarsmen just held in New York. Aside from the official appointment of Dr. Edson Gallaudet, who coached the crew last year, as the head coach for the coming season, the most important action taken is that which provides for the development of material.

The bank statement yesterday, issued shortly before the close of business, fully came up to the expectations and hopes of even the most sanguine, showing an increase in surplus reserves of little less than $5,000,000, the figures, to be exact, being $4,949,625. Legal tenders increased $3,768,800 and specie $1,264,400, while there was a decrease in loans of $1,558,900.

HAVANA, Jan. 13. -- The removal of Senor Federico Mora, Fiscal of the Supreme Court, continues the main topic of discussion in the city. All are apparently coming to the conclusion that the action of the Governor General is justifiable, the only question being whether Senor Mora should not be prosecuted.

The contest for the Edward Kemp and Col. Emmons Clark Trophies by teams from the various companies of the Seventh Regiment began at the armory ranges last night and will last over two weeks, the teams shooting on the drill nights of their respective companies.

Lucien Germain Gultry, the Paris actor, whose secession from the company of the Vaudeville and engagement at the Comedie Francaise was noted in this column last week, will not finish his fortieth year until the 15th of next December. He is a very handsome-looking man with dark hair and large, expressive eyes.

Most readers must have felt doubts as to the stories of eagles attacking men, even when their nests were being robbed. But an instance of such an attack, made in the open and not near a nest, occurred to Mr. Turner-Turner, a well-known sportsman and amateur fur-hunter in British Columbia.

There were two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday in accordance with time honored custom. In the afternoon Bizet's "Carmen" was given, and in the evening the opera was Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette." There was a discrepancy somewhere. In the afternoon the audience was the largest of the season; in the evening the assembly was of moderate size.
LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Mr. C.B. Ismay and Miss Constance Schieffelin of New York were married in London this morning by special license.

MOUNT VERNON, Jan. 13. -- Mrs. Eilenberger, Mrs. Morrison's sister, arrived in New York from her home, in Middletown, this morning, and came at once to this place to see Chief of Police Foley. Chief Foley had, however, gone to Manhattan, and Mrs. Eilenberger, after waiting at the police headquarters for over an hour, took a car for Tarrytown to see District Attorney Andrews.

Such a charming day as Saturday naturally brought to Central Park an unusually large number of strollers and riders, and the drives were thronged as they have not been in some time. Speaking comparatively, of course, the crowd was the greatest on the bridle path, and it is doubtful if there was a saddle horse in the city that was not in use some time during the day.

GORDO, N.M., Jan. 13. -- Details of the blizzard which swept over Southwestern Mexico Tuesday and Wednesday are coming in, and they indicate that it was the severest storm ever experienced in that region. A stretch of territory fifty miles in width, with White Oaks and Nogales for the centre, seemed to suffer the most, although the severity of the storm was fully felt throughout the Sacramento Mountain region.
This is what I saw in St. Paul's Cathedral on Tuesday afternoon at the memorial service for those who have fallen in the war:

Until last week I only knew Lord Dunraven as a racing and yachting man who had appeared two or three times at Spring Gardens as an amateur County Councilor. But in The Times on boxing day I found the best part of a column allotted to a letter from his Lordship on the lessons of the war, which leads me to suppose that his Lordship is also an expert on military matters.

DENVER, Jan. 13. -- Frederick G. Bonfils and H.H. Tammen, proprietors of The Evening Post, were both shot in their office to-day by W.W. Anderson, a prominent local attorney. It is not believed that either was mortally wounded. Both were able to walk to carriages that carried them home.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- District Attorney George C. Andrews when seen at his home to-day denied that Mrs. Eilenberger, Mrs. Morrison's sister, had made any statement disclosing new tacts in the case against Morrison. He refused to state the facts as presented by the woman this afternoon, and said that she had not even made anything in the shape of an affidavit.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 13. -- Arthur G. Vansittart, the British Consul to this city, entertains some very drastic views in reference to American methods generally and American friendships in particular, and he does not hesitate to express his opinions on the subject. Speaking to-day on the present attitude of the people of the United States on the war in the Transvaal, he said:

Some few years since I was invited to the house of a surgeon who had just returned from Ceylon, to see a freshly imported serpent of this species. Upon arriving at the house I found that the doctor was absent, and that his wife and maidservant were the only inmates.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The Statutory Revision Commission has completed its codification and revision of the laws and the result of its work will be presented at this session of the Legislature in the form of eleven bills. The plan of the Commissioners involves a separation of the code into different statutes, including a Code of Civil Procedure embracing practice applicable to the Court of Appeals, the Supreme Court, and the County Court.

A number of transfers of Inspectors, Captains, and Sergeants in the Police Department were made last night by Chief Devery. One of the most important was the ordering of Capt. James K. Price of the West Thirtieth Street Station, or the Tenderloin Precinct, to the head of the Detective Bureau in Brooklyn, to succeed Capt. James G. Reynolds, who is transferred to an obscure Brooklyn precinct.

The cultivation of currants and gooseberries was unknown among the Greeks and Romans and dates only from the sixteenth century. It has been a matter of dispute whether these shrubs should be considered as genuine natives of Great Britain, but, in the light of further research, this claim to be indigenous, at least in the north of England, will now hardly be denied.

The will of Dorman B. Eaton, who died on Dec. 23 at his home, 2 East Twenty-ninth Street, was filed yesterday for probate by George E. Gartland, attorney for the estate. According to the petition filed with the will the value of the estate is not known. An estimate that it amounted to $500,000 was said to be excessive.
HAVANA, Jan. 13. -- The receipts at the Custom House in Cienfuegos during 1899 were $1,159,000.

Mark Twain, in a magazine article published not long ago, insisted upon it that honesty was a prime qualification of commercial success, and that commercial success necessarily implied honesty. As a general rule that is no doubt true, and a very cheering truth it is. But, like some other general rules, it requires some exceptions to prove it.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- It is learned from an official source that Germany has addressed a second protest to Great Britain, urgently requesting the release of the German steamer Bundesrath and expressing astonishment at the undue delay. The protest also demands guarantees from Great Britain against a recurrence of such evident "wrongful and excessive application of a combatant's rights against neutrals."

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 13. -- The Czar has addressed a rescript to Count Muravieff, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, highly eulogistic of the eminent qualities displayed by the Minister in bringing about a happy solution, in conformity with the Czar's instructions, of the disquieting political events arising from the Cretan insurrection and the Turko-Greek war, thus showing true appreciation of the historic mission which has fallen to the lot of Russia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- It was reported at Gen. Greely's home to-day that he continues to maintain a steady improvement.

A few years ago, in Soho, London, there was a factory for antique coppers which is probably still in operation. The legitimate business of the place was the manufacture of stewpans and kettles; but when trade was dull in that way any sort of antiques for which there happened to be a demand was produced instead.

What has come to the art of singing? Is the old school of Italian song a thing of tradition or is it simply driven out of sight by new and pernicious ideas? To hear the singing teachers talk, one would think that every one and no one possessed the true Italian school. Each teacher claims it, and vehemently denies that any one else knows anything about it.

MANILA, Jan. 13. -- Advices from Cebu report a sharp fight on Jan. 8 between a battalion of the Nineteenth infantry and a body of insurgents occupying a strong position in the Sudlon Mountains. The enemy was routed, the Americans capturing a smooth-bore cannon, some rifles, and destroying the fortifications.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent re-revival of the Schley-Sampson question offers an opportunity to make query upon certain points that have not received the attention to which it seems to me they are entitled, and I shall esteem it a favor if you will give an expression of your views in the matter.

THE system of taxation in New York is the result of a long series of changes which have attempted, with only a moderate degree of success, to conform old methods to modern industrial conditions. The basis of the system is still the general property tax -- a tax which was originally a good one, and which sufficed fairly wel for the needs both of local and of State revenue.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13. -- The physicians and attendants in the obstetric department of Johns Hopkins Hospital have hit upon a happy solution of the difficulty they have always experienced in distinguishing one young baby from another. There are always from one to two dozen new-born babes in the obstetrical ward, and to the inexperienced eye they all look alike.

The ninety-fifth regular monthly meeting of the Schoolmasters' Association of New York and vicinity was held yesterday in the Brearley School. Announcement was made that at the meeting next month on amendment to the constitution would be offered reducing the annual fees of the association from $3 to $2.

TRENTON, Jan. 13. -- Gov. Voorhees has created a great stir by his condemnation of the members of the State Charities Aid. Men and women in nearly all the counties of the State who have made the watchful care of State and municipal institutions a service of love are preparing to resent the Chief Executive's criticism by resigning.

Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish gave the first of her series of three "Saturdays" last evening at her residence, 25 East Seventy-Eighth Street. The affair was a musicale preceded by a dinner. This was succeeded by a supper for 125 guests, many of whom arrived in time simply for the musicale which followed the dinner.

The constant references to the reconnoitring of the enemy's position by the British armored trains have created considerable discussion among military engineers and officers as to the actual value of these new engines of war. The first test of the armored train was made by the British in 1882.

In a speech before the railroad branch of the Young Men's Christian Association the other evening Senator DEPEW talked freely of the reasons why the churches are not better attended. In a manner perhaps a little flippant as well as awkward he elaborated the proposition that "if our churches were for people of common mind and common aspirations, then they would be a success."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like to indorse the article in your issue of to-day from "A Soldier in the Ninth corps." It is on the never-ending subject of Barbara Frietchie. The facts in the article are correct, and perhaps some facts as to the real Mrs. Frietchie may go far toward ending this discussion.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 14. -- The hearing of the evidence in the contests for Governor and Lieutenant Governor will begin at 9:30 o'clock A.M. to-morrow. The committee to try the contest in the case of the Governorship is composed of ten Democrats and one Republican. The committee in the case of the Lieutenant Governor is composed of nine Democrats and two Republicans.

In the very instructive article by Mr. AGAR in yesterday's TIMES on the school system of New York he pointed out very clearly the two chief defects in the system as it exists, the lack of central control and responsibility in the general managment of the schools and in the scholastic supervision, and the dependence of the school authorities in financial matters.

If the State Superintendent of Banks had as good reason to be satisfied with the methods of his examination of the State Trust Company as the trust company has to be satisfied with its results, the incident might pass without comment. We think, however, that Mr. KILBURX must see, as certainly all officers of financial institutions will see, that his procedure in this case was most unwise and unsafe.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Gossip is already rife among politicians as to the effect the contest between Gov. Roosevelt and Louis F. Payn over the Superintendency of the Insurance Department will have on the next State election. Mr. Payn's friends make no secret of their intention to oppose the Governor during the present session of the Legislature as well as in the State Convention, in the event of Gov. Roosevelt being a candidate for renomination.

George A. Sanford of the Young Men's Christian Association spoke yesterday afternoon at the patriotic service held in the Ninth Regiment Armory by Chaplain Madison C. Peters. He told of his experiences among the soldiers at Montauk. The Rev. Dr. Peters spoke for a few minutes on the report of the Prison Commission.

Certain diplomatic negotiations that are now being carried on in Lisbon add particular emphasis to the obvious fact that Delagoa Bay is the key to the situation in South Africa. It has been perfectly apparent that Delagoa, with its port of Lorenzo Marques only 349 miles from Pretoria, has, from the very beginning of the war, maintained a position far from neutral.

It is not improbable that speculative isues will be tighter drawn this week than for some time past. Toward the end of last week there seemed to be indications that interests with much money power were preparing for activity in the stock market: their representatives were making optimistic observations, and apparently many securities were bought for their account.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The rivalry between the great Atlantic and Gulf ports of the United States regarding their relative share in the export of the products of the country lends interest to a series of statements just completed by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, showing the exports of corn, wheat, and flour from the United States and from these ports during the calendar year 1899, compared with preceding years.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 14. -- A. Blanchard and his wife and a boarder by the name of W. Money, who resided in the town of Merrimac, were burned to death in their home last night. They were in the habit of using kerosene to light their fires, and it is thought that an explosion took place, setting fire to the house, so that they were unable to get away.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So much misunderstanding has arisen and so many false impressions have been disseminated about the delay in paying teachers' salaries for December, that I think it proper to make a plain statement of the facts.

The Corinthian Club has made a splendid record so far this season. Its team has the lead in the American National Tournament, is tied for first place with the Orientals in the Columbia League, and is a close second to the Metropolitans for first honors in the National League. The following tables show the standing of the clubs in the various tournaments:
BERLIN, Jan. 14. -- A leading official of the Reichsbank, in the course of an interview to-day, made the following statement regarding the financial situation:

For the last week heavy seas have been rolling in from the ocean along the shores of Rockaway Beach and Jamaica Bay. Great inroads have been made into the beach at Arverne and Edgemere. A wide channel has been cut into the beach, opening up the old inlet at Edgemere. At this place the water has almost reached the railroad tracks, and it is feared the big Summer hotel may be damaged.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- "Senator George F. Hoar's anti-expansion speech, delivered in the United States Senate and cabled to Hongkong at a cost of $4,000, was the culminating influence that brought about the insurrection against this Government by Aguinaldo and his followers."

The programme of last night's concert at the Metropolitan Opera House was varied from the former ones by the appearance of the pianist Arthur Friedheim. The other soloists were Mme. Sembrich, Miss Eleanor Broadfoot, M. Dippel, and Herr Bertram.

The question, "What Is the Use at Going to Church?" furnished the topic for the sermon of the Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage before a large congregation at the Church of the Messiah yesterday morning. He spoke, in part, as follows:

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- The Stock Exchange last week was quiet but expectant, with cheaper money. Any British successes in South Africa certainly would start a sharp upward movement. Should the British gain a decisive victory, there without doubt would be a veritable boom. Consols improved last week to 99 3/4; other gilt-edged securities followed suit, and the whole market, at the closing yesterday, showed great firmness.

Paul Schumann, husband and manager of Mme. Schumann-Heink, who is now singing at the Metropolitan Opera House, has been ill of erysipelas for the last week at the Belvedere Hotel, but last night was reported to be somewhat better, though still unable to see visitors. He is being attended by his wife, who rarely leaves his bedside, and by Dr. Richard W. Muller of 147 East Eighteenth Street.

The majority report of the Mazet investigating committee, it was announced yesterday, has been finally completed and will be submitted to the Legislature this week, probably to-night. In the new draft of the report, for it is admitted by all persons concerned that it has been redrawn, there are a number of important changes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Senate probably will resume consideration of the Pettigrew resolution making request for certain information concerning the beginning of the war in the Philippines Monday morning. This will be succeeded at 2 o'clock by a speech on the Financial bill by Senator Rawlins of Utah, if the present programme is followed.

Copyright, 1900, THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Jan. 14. -- It would be dishonest for me to say I had prepared your readers for the collapse in money discount rates that has occurred in the London market, because I never expected the decline to go to the extent it has done.

At the second annual conference of astronomers, held at Cambridge last year, several of the delegates criticised with some severity the present conduct of the Naval Observatory, and the immediate severing of all relations between that institution and the Navy Department was earnestly advocated.

A Polish wedding party in a hall over John Krimacsy's saloon, at 213 Forsyth Street, broke up in a riot yesterday afternoon. The wedding ceremony had been performed in the Church of St. Stanislaus, and the wedding guests, almost 100 in number, gathered to partake of the feast prepared for them.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman, at Temple Emanu-El, yesterday morning delivered a discourse upon "The Greatest Achievement of the Nineteenth Century." This the speaker declared to be the emancipation of the masses. He eulogized the United States for the "high motives of broad human sympathy" which animated the conduct of the war against Spain and kept the American Army still in the Philippines.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Discussion of the probable nomination for Vice President to be made by the Republican Convention has been revived by the presence in this city of members of the National Executive Committee. It is generally conceded in the discussion that the candidate will be from New York, and in this connection Gov. Roosevelt, Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff, and ex-Secretary of the Interior Cornelius N. Bliss are mentioned.

BOSTON, Jan. 14. -- The committee appointed at the Northfield Summer Conference of Christian Workers, Aug. 11, 1899, to investigate the statements of Prof. Atwater of Wesleyan University on the nutritive value of alcohol, has made an exhaustive report in a sixteen-page pamphlet, entitled "An Appeal to Truth," published to-day.

UTICA, Jan. 14. -- Cardinal Gibbons preached in St. John's Church this morning. He was heard by an immense congregation. In the course of his sermon, the Cardinal urged that all should take an active personal interest in all that concerns the welfare of the country.

At the annual meeting of the Civil Service Reform Association of Massachusetts, the President. Mr. R.H. DANA, stated in substance that in no other Administration since the passage of the civil service law had there been so lax an enforcement of the law and so much deliberate retreat from the ground previously gained as in this.
ADELAIDE, South Australia, Jan. 14. -- The health authorities report two cases of bubonic plague here, one being fatal. The victim was a runaway sailor from the British bark Formosa.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 14. -- The steamer Elmbranch brings news from Shanghai that French warships have taken possession of Kwong-Chau Wan Bay, where the boundary disputes have been pending for several months.

It would not be a bad idea for the city to spend a few dollars in the purchase of a new flag to fly from the staff on the knoll between Grant's Tomb and the city restaurant at the head of the Riverside Drive. That which now flies from the big pole is a disgrace, occupying so sightly a spot as it does.

The officers of the State Trust Company expressed satisfaction yesterday with the result of the examinations of its affairs made by Gen. Avery D. Andrews at the instance of Gov. Roosevelt and by Superintendent Frederick D. Kilburn of the State Banking Department, as the result of the petition of Abram Kling a stockholder, who questioned the propriety of some of the loans made by the company.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The War Office issued at midnight a dispatch from Field Marshal Roberts, dated Cape Town, Jan. 14, 8:30 P.M., saying:

Gen. George H. Sharpe, who resigned from the Board of United States General Appraisers last March, died at midnight Friday, at the house of his son-in-law, Ira Davenport, 31 East Thirty-ninth Street. Gen. Sharpe left his home in Kingston, this State, shortly before Christmas to Visit his daughter, Mrs. Davenport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The people of Brooklyn who have been so active in opposing the scheme for a consolidation of the Post Offices in Greater New York have won their fight. It is learned to-night on high authority that the bill as reported will be amended in such a manner as to exclude the Brooklyn Post Office from the consolidation.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- Letters from the soldiers fighting against the Boers are published in large numbers, and in many cases are just as interesting as the accounts by trained war correspondents. A medical officer under Lord Methuen, describing the battle of Modder River, writes:

Trading in the market for outside securities during the past week was very dull, except on one or two days. Conditions were not particularly unfavorable, but a general disposition was shown to await developments in Stock Exchange market conditions, and a lifeless curb market resulted.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Jan. 14. -- At Augusta, a small town in Pike County, last night Frank Purcell aged eighteen, shot and killed Rufus Ross, aged seventeen. The shooting, which was unprovoked, has caused great excitement in the community.

HAVANA, Jan. 14. -- At a meeting held in this city to-day under the direction of the Propaganda Committee of the National Party, Senor Pita said that Cuba would always be a bone of contention because of her situation, and that the Cubans, if they desired to preserve their Individuality, must unite as one man.

Sam Pryor, an aged hanger-on about Bellevue Hospital, was lured Saturday night from his bed to the Charities Dock at the foot of East Twenty-sixth Street by unknown persons and there nailed up in a dry goods box and left to his fate.
Prof. Felix Adler spoke at Carnegie Hall yesterday to the Society for Ethical Culture on "False Views of Marriage." There was a large attendance.

PUEBLO, Col., Jan. 14. -- Contracts have just been closed between the Minnesota owners of some newly discovered iron ore fields in the southern part of Utah and the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company of this city that are of great importance to the latter. They also call attention to a new ore district, and one that seems destined to be important.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day made public its thirteenth annual report. The feature of the report is the strongest plea made that Congress uphold the hands of the commission by amendments making the Inter-State Commerce law more effective. The report says that in vital respects the present law has proved' defective and inadequate, and that until further legislation is provided the best efforts at regulations must be feeble and disappointing.

The first performance of "The Degenerates," at the Garden Theatre, last evening, turned out, as might have been expected, to be largely a personal exhibition of Mrs. Langtry in gorgeous and daring attire -- Mrs. Langtry in flesh-colored satin with sapphires, Mrs. Langtry in pale-blue satin with diamonds in dazzling array.
The security market showed much disturbance at the opening of business yesterday. Many quotations fell materially and pessimistic views seemed to prevail.

The new Post Office arrangement by which persons living above Fifty-ninth Street in Manhattan, in the Bronx, and in the residential sections of Brooklyn may have letters registered by letter carriers went into effect yesterday. The scheme is being tried by the Post Office Department in various large cities with the hope of increasing the postal revenue and accommodating the public.
ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- The Mazet committee handed in the following bills to carry out the recommendations in its report:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- The stock market was absolutely featureless today. Trading was listless throughout, illustrations being within one-half of 1 per cent or nearly everything dealt in and trader and commission houses alike without others. The tone for the greater part of the day was heavy, and some of the acres dropped off from 1/8 to 1/2 of the down weight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few days ago the Board of Estimate struck from the budget the sum of $12,000 for the use of a most worthy Charity -- a maternity hospital, giving comfort yearly to thousands of mothers. No money for this, but plenty where votes can be caught. Here is a case in point:

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- The New York and Brooklyn union Transportation Company was incorporated to-day. It proposes to construct and operate a railway of ordinary gauge by either compressed air or electricity between the Boroughs of Manhattan and Brooklyn in the City of New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The novel question whether a man has a right to forge his own name came up before Judge Hutchinson today in the case of James H. Bird. The allegation against Bird was that he signed the name of James H. Bird of New York as an indorsement on a check, and thereby obtained $1,928.42 from the Continental National Bank.
LONDON, Jan. 16. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail, dated Saturday, Jan. 13, from Lorenzo Marques, says:

The statement made by Mr. JOHN BARRETT in his speech at Chicago on Saturday evening is interesting chiefly as showing the resources of the Filipino insurgents and the quite modern and civilized use they made of them.
The Moscow Fire Insurance Company of Russia has been admitted to Michigan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The reply of Mr. Louis Rhead to the Rev. Thomas P. McLaughiin in your issue of Saturday on the subject of the comparative civilization of Ireland and the other portions of the British Isles is the most extraordinary "Comedy of Errors" I have ever seen in a public print.
The people of Kentucky ought to see that under the impulse of political passions at Frankfort they are drifting pretty rapidly into a situation threatening civil strife and bloodshed.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 15.--In a Scotch foursome played this afternoon on the links of the Country Club, H.C. Watson, Jr., Westbrook Club, and A.H. Findlay, the professional, who has just returned from Scotland, were matched against the latter's brother, David Findlay, and Clayton Dixon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The President has nominated Charles H. Sherman of California to be Assayer of the Mint at San Francisco.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Mr. Gale of Queens County entered the School bill arena to-night with a bill to provide for the payment of the salaries of the Principals, teachers, and other employes of the public schools in the Borough of Queens, City of New York, and to legalize the action of the School Board thereof and the appointment of the teachers. The bill says:

PITTSBURG, Jan. 15. -- A strike of rod mill workers at the four plants of the American Steel and Wire Company in this vicinity was inaugurated to-day. There are about 800 employed, but only a portion of them quit work. The strike was hastened, it is claimed, by the discharge of three men at the Beaver Falls mill.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- The report of the minority members of the Mazet Investigating Committee was handed to the Assembly this evening. It is signed by Municipal Court Justice Benjamin Hoffman, who represented the Sixteeenth New York District in the last Assembly, and by Anthony J. Boland, who was elected to the present as well as the last Legislature from the First District of Erie County.

Side by side father and son were laid at rest in the Greenwood Cemetery yesterday afternoon. The father was John Gustav Perrenoud, ninety-one years of age, who died in Denver, Col., on Jan. 3. Gustav F. Perrenoud, the son, was killed in an accident on Dec. 30, at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--Next Friday the Republicans of the Senate will meet again in caucus to determine whether they will elect new officers for the Senate, and, if so, who those new officers shall be. It cannot be said that there is general anxiety to have a change made. There is difference of opinion among Senators.

The southwest corner of Broadway and Walker Street is to be the site of a new fifteen-story building, to be erected by Henry Corn. The plot includes 395 to 399 Broadway, 50 by 100, and 61 Walker Street, adjoining at the rear; about 25 by 100. Robert Maynicke is the architect of the new structure, and work upon it will be begun on Feb. 1.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- Mr. J.B. Robinson, the South African millionaire, in a signed article in The Daily News this morning relates conversations he has had with President Kriiger and describes several interviews in which the Jameson raid was talked over. On one of these occasions President Kruger said:

Very simple services characterized the funeral of Felix Morris, tlie actor, at All Souls' Unitarian Church, Fourth Avenue and Twentieth Street, yesterday morning. There was no music. Scripture reading and brief addresses by the Revs. Minot J. Savage and Thomas R. Slicer, followed by a prayer and benediction, formed the entire church service.

It is by no means proof of a lack of public appreciation of the Palisades that nothing has thus far been done to the purpose toward preserving them. The difficulty mainly is that the people who are outraged by their destruction, because it is brought to their notice, are inhabitants of New York, while the Palisades themselves are in New Jersey.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 15. -- The repeatedly postponed annual meeting of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company will be held in this city Wednesday. It has been postponed monthly since last November because of the big deals pending and the perfecting of the reorganisation scheme.

It was demonstrated last at a meeting of the East Side Republican Club that Superintendent of Insurance Payn will not be able to count on any support in the Twentieth Assembly District in his fight against Gov. Roosevelt to retain the position from which it is the intention of the Executive to oust him.

An original burglar was found by P.M. Shannon, a wealthy oil producer, of Pittsburg, Penn., in his room at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. When Mr. Shannon returned from the theatre and asked the clerk for the key to his room, No. 332, it was found missing from his box.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 15. -- United States District Judge Waddill this afternoon refused the injunction prayed for by Thomas F. Ryan of New York against the consolidation of the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad with the other roads of the Seaboard Air Line system, the Florida Central and Peninsular and the Georgia and Alabama Railways.

Miss Helen F. Clark, Director of the mission at 21 Mott Street, was the speaker yesterday at the Methodist preachers' meeting at 150 Fifth Avenue. Her theme was "The Religious Condition of New York City." She said in part:

The Transatlantic passenger steamship lines have begun advancing their rates for the Summer season, and expect an enormous rush of tourists to the Paris Exposition. It was generally said yesterday at the steamship offices that the advance was really the restoration of rates that had existed two years ago before the cut-rate war opened.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Spirited debate on the Philippine question occupied the attention of the Senate for nearly three hours to-day. Mr. Berry (Dem., Ark.,) first addressed the Senate in support of the resolutions recently introduced by Mr. Bacon (Dem., Ga.;) regarding the disposition of the Philippines.

Interest in the affairs at the State Trust Company is now practically confined to the loan made to State Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn. Superintendent Kilburn of the State Banking Department has declared the attack made against the company by Abram Kling a "closed incident."

The general advance of Gen. BULLER'S army seems without doubt to have been begun. In that case, it is not to be stopped except by a series of decisive defeats or repulses. We may accordingly expect that the campaign, if not the war, will be decided within the next few days or weeks.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- The first day of the Tuxedo tennis and racquet tourney at the new club was taken up by an exhibition match between T. Suffern Tailer, amateur champion of the Tuxedo Tennis Club, and Alfred Tompkins, professional champion of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club of New York.

The first scores in the Edward Kemp Trophy and the Col. Emmons Clark Trophy matches were made last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory by the teams from Company G. Each of the ten teams shoots on its company's drill night.

HALIFAX, N.S., Jan. 15. -- Some light was thrown upon the mystery of the wreck at St. Mary's Bay, Newfoundland, by Capt. Dawe of the steamer Glencoe, which arrived to-night from St. John's, N.F. Capt. Dawe is an old and experienced navigator and pilot who knows every rock, current, and sounding on the Newfoundland coast.

Reports differ as to the probable course of the Senate upon the claim of Mr. QUAY to a seat in that body, but on the whole the chances are against him. It is a pity that the question must be decided on the interpretation of a clause in the Constitution, and cannot turn on the moral issues involved.
