The friends of John Sabine Smith outwitted his opponents at the annual election last night of the Republican Club. On the ticket submitted by the nominating committee and posted by the club the name of John Sabine Smith was included in the five candidates for members of the Executive Committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- Alexander Majors of the old Western freighting firm of Majors, Russell Waddell died here last Friday night at the residence of J. Craig. 4,003 Drexel Boulevard. He was eighty-six years old. In his time he had been foremost among men possessed of wealth and power.

Charges of heresy against the Rev. Dr. Arthur C. McGiffert were formally presented before an adjourned meeting of the New York Presbytery, at the Old First Presbyterian Church, yesterday afternoon, by the Rev. Dr. George W.F. Birch, stated clerk. Dr. McGiffert was cited to appear before the body on Feb. 12.

Prof. Thomas Egleston, LL. D., founder of the School of Mines of Columbia University, and for thirty-three years Professor of Mineralogy and Metallurgy in the School of Mines, died yesterday morning at his home, 35 Washington Square. His death was not unexpected, as he had been suffering for several weeks with a complication of diseases.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- Henry C. Payne of Wisconsin, a member of the subcommittee of the National Republican Committee having in charge the arrangements for the holding of the National Convention in this city in June, left to-day for Washington. Before leaving he spoke or the question of the Vice Presidency:
ST. MICHAELS, The Azores, Jan. 15.--William K. Vanderbilt's steam yacht, the Variant, from New York, Jan. 8, has arrived here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day dismissed the suit of the State of Louisiana versus the State of Texas and its Health Officer, involving the right of the latter State to quarantine so rigorously against the former as was done during the recent prevalence of yellow fever in New Orleans.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent "I.W.K." has not quite grasped the purposes of the Church Temperance Society with regard to inebriates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Representative Needham (Rep., Cal.,) has introduced a bill for the inspection under the direction of the Secretary, of Agriculture of trees, fruits, plants, bulbs, nursery stock, , imported into the United States.

The transfer of Capt. James K. Price from the Tenderloin Precinct to the Brooklyn Detective Bureau has greatly disturbed the usual serenity of things in the police circles of that borough. The local headquarters is rife with rumor's, and every man is apparently speculating as to what the advent of the Tenderloin's commander portends.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 58 1/2@59 1/2. There were no sales.

COATZACOALCOS, Mexico, Jan. 15. -- The formal transfer of the Tehuantepec Railroad to Sir Weetman Dickinson Pearson by the Mexican Government under a fifty years' lease took place to-day. This road was more than fifty years in building, and has cost the Government over $25,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The Insular Committee of the House gave a hearing today to representatives of the Commercial Cable Company of Cuba, on the bill granting them the right to land a cable in Cuba. The representation included Gen. M.C. Butler, Thomas Ochiltree, and W.W. Cook, general counsel of the company.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 15.--Prof. Atwater of Wesleyan University when asked this afternoon if he had anything to say in reply to the statements published in "An Appeal to Truth," issued by the committee appointed at the Northfield conference of Christian Workers to investigate his statements on the nutritive value of alcohol, said he did not care to discuss the matter, one way or the other.

There seems to be a veritable craze for some sort of "physical-culture" this Winter. Possibly Gov. Roosevelt's introduction of a professional trainer into the Executive Mansion has had something to do with it, but probably the very general advice of physicians nowadays, "You need exercise, not medicine," is more responsible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- "What the friends of Quay are trying to do," said a Republican who is watching the Senatorial contest in which Mr. Quay is interested, with much concern, "is to smother the real issue under a blanket of goodfellowship."
LONDON, Jan. 16. -- The Standard gives prominence to the following dispatch, dated Saturday, Jan. 13, from Durban:

SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 15. -- A bill in equity on behalf of New York and Canadian stockholders of the Seattle, Lake Shore and Eastern Railway, was filed in the United States Circuit Court to-day against the Seattle and International Railway, asking for a receiver for the road, also asking for an injunction against the moving of the tracks of the company.

The Lotus team made a good showing in the Harlem League last night, winning two games. The Colonials finished their schedule. They were beaten in the first by Lotus. In the second game the Colonials downed the Cyclones, rolling their highest score of the tournament. Scores:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15. -- Col. William Jennings Bryan and President Hadley of Yale University were interviewed here to-day relative to the latter's Denver speech relating to trusts. President Hadley said, in response to a question regarding the remedy for some of the bad effects of trusts:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The arrival at New York of an accredited agent of the Danish Government charged with the sale to the United States of the Danish West Indian islands has not been, notified to the State Department as yet, except through the newspapers. There is visible reluctance to discuss the subject.

The feature of the proceedings yesterday at the Molineux trial was the evidence of Joseph Koch, the letter-box man of 1,620 Broadway, who testified that Molineux had called upon him in the week of Dec. 12, 1898, to inquire regarding arrangements for renting a box. It was a friend who wanted the box, Molineux had said, according to this evidence, one who would not receive much mail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters of all the Boer advocates display almost total ignorance of facts. They all assume that the ground of quarrel between the British and the Boers is over the question whether Britons and Americans should have the right of naturalization in the Transvaal without renouncing their allegiance to Great Britain or America.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems a pity that any one who read the letter from Mr. George Westinghouse in your issue of Jan. 10 should entirely miss the point therein clearly stated, and especially that such misapprehensions should be elaborated by way of response, as was done by Mr. Cary T. Hutchinson in Sunday's issue.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 23 -- Li Hung Chang was withdrawn from the Tsung li Yamen in 1898 at the demand of Great Britain, but he was not degraded. He continued to hold a higher position as a member of the Grand Secretariat.

We were assured some days ago that favorable answers to our application for an assurance that our treaty rights would not be attacked in China had been received from five out of the six powers to which it had been made. Italy was named as the one power which had not given in, its adhesion to the principle involved in our demand.

"Brother Officers," a new comedy in four acts by Leo C. Trevor, was presented for the first time in this city at the Empire Theatre last night, and cordially welcomed. The play is of a pleasing quality, if not exactly brilliant, and it contains some exceedingly refreshing and effective scenes. The hero, John Hinds, is a "ranker," an army officer who has risen by promotion from the ranks.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- In opening the session of the State Bar Association President Logan to-day made an address on "The Limitation of Inheritances," in which he said:
The ship of state yaws, her sails flap in the wind, and she seems to be getting ready to go stern foremost.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--Correspondence and circulars received at the National Democratic Campaign Headquarters indicate that ex-Justics Augustus Van Wyck of New York City is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.

We have at last got to the end of the Mazet committee and its so-called labors. We have a report from the majority which discloses nothing of any importance that was not already known, which discloses nothing whatever as to the part of its own party in the evils that are notorious, and makes no recommendations worthy of serious attention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Senate today ratified the Samoan treaty without division. The ratification occurred in executive session and after two hours of debate, which was participated in by a number of Senators. Messrs. Davis, (Rep., Minn.,) Foraker, (Rep., Ohio,) and Spooner, (Rep., Wis.,) advocated, and Senators Bacon, (Dem., Ga.,) Money, (Dem., Miss.,) and Tillman, (Dem. S.C.,) opposed ratification.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 16 -- A shooting affair in which the lives of three prominent men were sacrificed, and that of a fourth hangs by a slender thread, while others miraculously escaped with painful injuries, occurred here to-day. The principals in the tragedy were ex-Congressman David G. Colson of Middleborough, and Lieut. Ethelbert Scott of Somerset.

-- Fond as Englishmen are of telling us that their newspapers are different from -- they usually say "to" -- the newspapers of the United States, not one of them, so far as we have, noticed, ever called attention to what is perhaps the most important and certainly the most interesting point of dissimilarity between the journals of the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Secretary Long and Rear Admiral Bradford appeared before the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs to-day in advocacy of the construction of a Pacific cable by the Government. The Secretary's statement was general and related entirely to the feasibility of the plan and its advantage over doing the work by private enterprise.

An ordnance changing the name of Elm Street, Marion Street, and Lafayette Place, all continuances of the same thoroughfare, to Dewey Place, which was passed by the Aldermen last year, but was held up in the Council, was offered in the Board of Aldermen yesterday. After a long discussion it was decided to refer the matter to the Aldermen of the districts affected.

The charge that under the present municipal administration the lower east side has relapsed into a deplorable condition of material and moral uncleanliness was made at the annual meeting of the University Settlement Society, and of the Woman's Auxiliary, held at the settlement house, Eldridge and Rivington Streets, yesterday afternoon, at which Seth Low, President of the society, presided, and exSpeaker Thomas B. Reed was present and delivered an address.

VEHICLES AND CARS AT STREET CROSSINGS -- To William Petri, who was injured by being thrown from his light delivery wagon whole attempting to cross Third Avenue at the intersection of Sixteenth Street on the 21st of September, 1896, because it was run into by a car of the Third Avenue Railroad Company, a verdict for $1,100 was awarded on the trial of his suit against the company for damages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- With the opening of to-day's session of the Senate, Mr. Cullom, (Rep., Ill.,) presented a petition handsomely bound and signed by 3,200 colored persons asking for such legislation as will protect colored men of this country from the "barbarous practice of lynching and burning colored men."

Burton N. Harrison, Gen. J.S. Clarkson, Charles H. Swan, George Young, William H. Foster, and others appeared before the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund in the Mayor's Office yesterday to renew the application of the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company for the approval of the board as to the location of its approaches in New York.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Jan. 16 -- Everything goes to show that the wrecked steamer sunk in St. Mary's Bay is the Helgoland, the property of the Dutch-American Petroleum Company. Among a number of flags picked up this evening near Holyrood was one with the colors blue, white, and red, with the letter "R" in the centre.

The first of a series of monthly conferences, held under the auspices of the Charity Organization Society, to consider the evils of pauperism, was held at the united Charities Building yesterday morning, Miss Kate Bond presided.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The resolution of Mr. Pettigrew, (Silver Rep., S.D.,) calling for information regarding the conduct of the war in the Philippines, was again laid before the Senate to-day. Mr. Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) moved that the resolution and the one which he had offered as a substitute for it be laid on the table in order that that offered by his colleague, Mr. Hoar, might be adopted.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- Twelve Directors of the Fitchburg Railroad Company attended a meeting hare to-day, and considered the proposed lease of the property to the Boston and Maine Railroad Company. The meeting was devoted to an informal conference in which the Directors representing the stock held by the State enlarged upon their opposition to the consummation of the deal, and the Directors who favor the proposition presented their side of the case.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Superintendent Kilburn of the State Banking Department had a long talk to-day with Gov. Roosevelt over the report made by ex-Adjt. Gen. Avery D. Andrews regarding the State Trust Company. Neither the Governor nor Mr. Kilburn would discuss what had passed between them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the proposed change in the manner of raising State taxes through a direct tax of 5 mills on real estate mortgages, it will upon consideration be found that taxation of this nature, instead of falling upon the holders of the mortgages, as it is intended it should, will fall upon the owner of the property.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator Frye, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce in connection with the hearings on the Shipping bill, has received from exSenator Edmunds a letter giving the latter's opinion that the payment of export bounties on goods shipped abroad would be contrary to the treaties existing between the United States and a large number of countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The pressure upon members of the House, and particulariy upon those members who are regarded as the strongest protectionists, to prevent the adoption of the President's recommendation that free trade advantages be extended to Puerto Rico is admitted to be increasing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Navy Department is in receipt of inquiries from relatives of naval officers stationed at Manila respecting a report that the department intended to send the Buffalo to Manila and allow the ladies an opportunity to take passage. The Buffalo is not under orders for the Philippines.

Capt. Thomas McManus. Capt. Thomas McManus, who died yesterday, at his residence, 124 East Seventysecond Street, this city, was well known as a resident of the Nineteenth Ward, in which he had been three times elected School Trustee. He was also a Captain in the State militia, having served in the old Montgomery Troop for eleven years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--Representative A. J. Cummings, who has been for several years the member of the Democratic Congressional Committee from New York, will be succeeded by Representative Jacob Ruppert, Jr., upon the nomination of ten members out of eighteen. Mr. Cummings is deeply chagrined at the method adopted by those opposed to him in getting him out of the place he has held so long and which he expected to retain.

BATH, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The committee of the Stale Board of Charities to-day resumed the investigation of the charges made against Col. Charles O. Shepard, Commandant of the Soldiers' Home, by six of the nine Trustees.

The Washington Club, by winning two games in the Harlem League last night secured first place in the tourney. The club still has two games to play. The Audubons won and lost a game, and the Friendships lost two games. A. Shiman of the Washingtons made an average of 205 for two games.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The special committee of the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County appointed to examine into the affairs and conduct of the Commissioners appointed by the Supreme Court to open and construct Warburton Avenue, in the town of Greenburgh, issued its report to-day.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Assemblyman Maurice M. Minton will to-morrow introduce a bill "to regulate the transportation and insure the safety of the passengers on cars operated by cable and electric traction companies in the City of New York."

Improbable as it may seem to the aged and the skeptical, an underground railroad capable of carrying passengers to Harlem in fifteen minutes will very likely be built in this city within the next five years. Years ago the youthful and the sanguine fed and filled their minds with that delusive hope.

The Commercial Travelers and Hotel Men's Anti-Trust League, which has an office in the St. James Building, purposes holding an anti-trust convention, either in this city or in Washington, within the next few weeks. This meeting is the result of a falling out between the league and the persons who are managing the anti-trust conference to be held in Chicago on Feb. 12.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has just been called to your comments on my letter to The London Saturday Review of Dec. 23, 1899, in your issue of Jan. 3, 1900, in "Topics of the Times." Your article suggests the following reflections:

There was a good deal of trading in wheat yesterday, with results discouraging to those who were long of the product. It suffered a rather sharp break, from which it did not recover. This was felt to a considerable extent on the Consolidated Exchange, where wheat was the feature of the day's business, the market for stocks there being comparatively firm.

Total transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday aggregated less than 200,000 shares. This is a record low beyond any average for months past. During much of the day brokers' tickers stood practically still. Not only were transactions relatively few, but the number of shares involved in them was small.

Capt. W.v. Christmas Dirckinck-Holmfeld of Copenhagen, who has been at the Hotel Manhattan for a few days, left for Washington last night. He is one of the accredited agents of the Danish Government in the pending negotiations looking to the sale to the United States of the Islands of St. Thomas, St. John, and St. Croix, known as the Danish West Indies.

Women are such innocent creatures. A party of them were inspecting a display of gowns and Summer fabrics at one of the largest stores yesterday, and one of them showed a disposition to purchase then and there a gown that happened to strike her fancy and fit her most becomingly. "Don't do it," whispered one of her companions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to a local item in your issue of Sunday in relation to 150 colonists who sailed on Saturday evening for Nuevitas, Cuba, en route to "the new town of La Gloria, which has been founded by the Cuban Land and Steamship Company."

The contest over the will of Richard Tighe, the eccentric millionaire of Union Square, known as "Sir Richard," was revived yesterday when Surrogate Thomas directed two commissions to obtain information as to the parentage of Thomas A. Tighe, the latest claimant to the estate. One commission was delegated to A. Don Platt, United States Vice Consul in Dublin.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Jan. 16 -- The third annual convention of the National Livestock Association of the United States began here to-day with a good attendance of delegates.

PARCEL OF ABOUT 7 8/3 ACRES, KNOWN AS a tavern lot, at Throgmorton's Neck, Westchester, part of Abijah Hammond farm: also Whitestone Ferry Dock, adjoining land of Abijah Hammond and Thomas Ash, road leading from Westchester Village to Whitestone Ferry, situate on Throgmorton's Neck, containing about 60 acres; also land under water.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Clement A. Griscom, President of the International Navigation Company, which owns the American line of steamers, while discussing the shipping or subsidy bill, told the Senate Commerce Committee to-day that the company's big liners, the New York, St. Louis, St. Paul, and Paris, were vun at a serious loss owing to the heavy expenses in Winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The House Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads today took up the resolution of inquiry recently referred to it concerning charges that certain Federal appointees in Utah were polygamists. Representative Lentz of Ohio, who introduced the resolution, was present, and considerable excitement was caused by some of the statements made by him.

In regard to rumors involving the block front, 200 by 100, on Fifth Avenue between One Hundred and Sixth and One Hundred and Seventh Streets, James McCreery, owner of the property, said yesterday afternoon that there had been active negotiations for it recently, but that he was not at liberty to disclose the name of the prospective buyer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In view of the excess of revenue over expenditures, and the probability that receipts will be larger next year than now, and that the Treasury will not need the money for current expenses, the attention of the Ways and Means Committee has been directed to the subject of the internal revenue, with the idea of amending the law if reduction of taxes is favored.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- More money is needed to pay the expenses Incurred by the Mazet Committee during its investigation, of New York City's muncipal government. A bill will soon be introduced asking for an additional appropriation for this purpose, as the original appropriation of $50,000 is about exhausted, and there is yet to be paid the fees of Frank Moss, counsel to the committee, and his associates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The extended reply of your able musical critic in yesterday's TIMES to my published contention in your last Friday's issue that "for originality and granqeur Meyerbeer's coronation march surpasses all other opera marches," compels me to ask the courtesy of sufficient space in your widely read columns to briefly meet the issue.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 16 -- George F. Hollis, who was United States Consul at Cape Town under President Harrison, has written a letter to the committee in charge of the meeting to be held in Faneuil Hall tomorrow evening in support of the Boers in which he says:

DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- Through the purchase of a majority of stock of both companies the Michagan Telephone Company to-day closed a deal for control of the two independent companies of this part of Michigan, namely, the Detroit Telephone Company and the New State Telephone Company. The Michigan Telephone Company, which has thus regained control of what was formerly its exclusive field, is one of the factors of the Erie Telegraph and Telephone Company consolidation.

ALBANY Jan. 16 -- Members of the Legislature from Greater New York who are interested in realty are discussing to-day the 5 mills tax on mortgages which is included in the bill for a new system of taxation which was introduced in the Assembly last night, in company with the report of the legislative committee appointed last Winter to investigate the problem of taxation and make recommendations for legislation.

Interest in the State Trust Company's affairs still centred yesterday about the $435,000 loan made to Superintendent of Insurance Payn. A letter was made public last night through President Johnston of the company in which Mr. Payn asked W.C. Whitney for financial aid, his funds for margin having run short.

Capt. Charles J. Symmonds, Assistant Quartermaster, United States Volunteers, will proceed to New York City and report to the commanding General, Department of the East; on completion of the duty assigned him he will proceed to Puerto Principe, Cuba, and resume his duties at that station.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Senator G.A. Davis to-day introduced a bill for the establishment of a State Hospital for the treatment of incipient pulmonary tuberculosis in the Adirondacks, which is so earnestly urged by the State medical societies, and in behalf of whose passage a mass meeting of physicians from all over the State is soon to be held in this city.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16 -- Social Baltimore, or at least that portion of it that lives in the reminiscences of the past, is stirred to its depths over the question of what two renowned Marylanders shall be honored by the erection of statues to their memory in Statuary Hall in Washington.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- John C. R. Taylor, attorney for Dr. William T. Jones of Pine Bush, who is now in Goshen Jail, charged with killing Charles Lewis, his colored coachman, will have the body exhumed and a search made for powder marks and burns about a wound in the head.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- In the Reichstag today an interpellation signed by Herr Moeller, National Liberal, and all the members of the Reichstag except the Social Democrats and Independents, was introduced. It was as follows:

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 16.--The new racer built at the Herreshoff works for August Belmont, the New York banker, was launched to-day. Mr. Belmont and party, including Miss Natalie Schenck, Mrs. Tiffany, Miss Tiffany, Mr. Belmont's eight-year-old son, and A. Van Rensselaer Kennedy, arrived here in Mr. Belmont's private car this morning.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Official announcement was made at the Controller's office this afternoon that $48,066 had teen paid out up to date for bills incurred by the late Mazet Investigating committee which was appointed by the last Assembly to examine into the workings of the New York City departments.

A performance of an English version of "The Master Builder," which is, perhaps, the most obscurely symbolical of Henrik Ibsen's "social dramas," was endured with some unmistakable signs of dissent and impatience in Carnegie Lyceum last night. Yet it seems this ought to have been the most commendable effort this season of the enthusiasts who are giving these occasional performances of plays neglected by the commercial theatre.

Railroad stocks continue steady, but industrials fluctuate. For the time no general influence seems to be operating, however, to help or to hurt the quotations even of industrials. Yesterday's market was irregular, as has been the rule of most days recently. With scarcely an exception the maximum range of quotations was but a fraction beyond one whole point.

Judge Foster successfully resisted an attempt to hypnotize him, yesterday, in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions. John. D. Blanchard, a tall, thin, and pallid young man, with piercing black eyes and a tangle of long, unkempt black hair, who attempted to subdue the Judge by his hypnotic powers, says he failed because the Judge wore glasses, which shielded him from the baleful radiance of Blanchard's eye.

This evening will bring the sale at auction at the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street, of ninety-eight oil paintings by the well-known American artist Henry Mosler. This varied collection of studio effects and the two-score and more oils, water colors and drawings by foreign artists owned by Mr. Mosler will be sold at the galleries to-morrow afternoon.

The London Spectator is a paper that combines much good sense and a very unusual conscientiousness with a warmth and vigor of imagination occasionally embarrassing. It is a faithful friend to America, and has shown in many ways an intimate and sympathetic understanding of American ideas and motives which entitles it to the grateful regard of all intelligent people on this side of the Atlantic.

There is nobody connected with the present Municipal Government who is more deserving of the public sympathy than Mr. McCARTNEY of the Street Cleaning Department. We have every reason, part of it the personal testimony of the late Col. WARING, to believe that Mr. McCARTNEY entered upon his office with the honest purpose of keeping the efficiency of the department up to the point-to which Col. WAKING had brought it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An Eastern friend, who desires to straighten what he pleases to term my "crooked thinking," has kindly sent me a copy of your paper of Jan. 3, with the editorial on "The Justification of Wealth" marked large and well underlined. And still I am unconverted.

The advertisement signed George Alfred Lamb of Lamb Voss of the Equitable Building, which called on the stockholders of the Consolidated Gas Company for proxies to be used at the company's annual meeting next Monday to secure reform in administration, an insight into recent transactions of the company, and increased dividends, provoked comment in the financial district yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 17 -- Miss Mary Emma Woolley, M. A., professor in Wellesley College, has been unanimously chosen by the Trustees of Mount Holyoke College to succeed Mrs. Elizabeth Storrs Mead as President of that institution. Miss Woolley has accepted the post, and will enter upon her duties next July, at which time Mrs. Mead's resignation takes effect.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The State Railroad Commission to-day received from George J. Gould, President of the Manhattan Railway Company of New York City, a letter announcing that the road will extend its lines on the east side from One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street to the Bronx Park at Bedford Park Station.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 17 -- At a conference at the Galt House last night, lasting until well in the morning, a plan of campaign was mapped out by the Republicans and the Brown Democrats. The meeting was attended by Gov. Taylor, Senator De Boe, nearly all the minor State officers, and most of the Federal officers in Kentucky, together with leading Brown Democrats and the attorneys for the Republicans.

Nicholas A. Heckmann, who keeps a letter-box place at 257 West Forty-second Street, yesterday told the jury in the Molineux case that Roland B. Molineux was the man who had engaged a letter box at his place on May 27, 1898, giving the name Of H.C. Barnet, and that letters and packages addressed to H.C. Barnet had been subsequently received there, among the things being one package of Kutnow's powders and a package containing calthos.

LOCKPORT, Ill., Jan. 17 -- The dam separating the Chicago Drainage Canal and the Desplaines River was lowered to-day, and the water of the former rushed, through on its way to the Mississippi and the Gulf of Mexico. The ceremonies marking the consummation of the great enterprise were brief and marked with something like undignified haste.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 -- It is stated here that there are British warships within easy reach of the Mississippi assigned to the duty of escorting the mule transports when they shall have been loaded with animals at New Orleans for South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- At the conclusion of routine business in the Senate the resolution of inquiry introduced by Mr. Hoar (Mass.) and amended by Mr. Lodge, (Mass.,) calling for general information regarding the conduct of the insurrection in the Philippines, was laid before the Senate.

BATH, Jan. 17 -- The first witness before the Court of Inquiry at the Soldiers' Home to-day was Major Joseph P. Cleary. Chief of Police of Rochester, and a trustee of the home. He is a candidate for Colonel Shepard's place at the home.

It was learned yesterday that the Third Avenue Railroad Company, which has for some time, been carrying a floating debt of about $17,030,000, a good deal of it now carried by various banks and trust companies, has made arrangements with a body of prominent bankers to have this debt taken up as a whole, the interest on it to be paid in periodical fixed charges, and at a very low rate.

The Commercial Travelers and Hotel Men's Anti-Trust League, which purposes holding an anti-trust conference in this city or in Washington next month, yesterday made public the following letter from, exGov. William J. Stone of Missouri, the Vice Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, addressed to Joseph J. Urelett, the Chairman of the Committee on Legislation of the league:

About an eighth of a mile out in the river and swimming with bold strokes for the New Jersey shore the tug Nyack last night found a man, who was unwillingly pulled aboard and taken ashore. He was given over to a policeman of the steamboat squad, who called an ambulance from St. Vincent's Hospital.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The Marquis of Lothian, former Keeper of the Great Seal of Scotland, is dead.

The commission appointed at the instance of Gov. Roosevelt by the Hon. A.H. Green President of the Society for the Preservation of Scenic and Historic Places and Objects, to act on behalf of New York State in conjunction with a like commission of New Jersey, appointed by act of legislature, for the preservation of the Palisades, has made public its report.

A suit is now pending in the City Court in which Frank J. Van Order, cashier of the Gansevoort Bank, is sued as a partner in the defunct butter and egg commission house of Garner Co. of 844 Washington Street. The complainants in the action are Martin Murray, commission merchants, who seek to recover $517-40.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Standard publishes the following dispatch from Ladysmith, dated Jan. 6, by way of Frere, Jan. 17:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of Friday's issue criticising and reflecting upon British officers in general, and particularly those in command of the troops in South Africa at the present time, it seems to me that you have greatly overstated the case -- especially when you assume that British officers alone are Ruilty of making front attacks upon strong positions where it is possible to go around them.

BELVEDERE, N.J., Jan. 17 -- Three men were killed and six injured in a railroad accident in the Oxford tunnel on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad this morning. One of the injured men will probably die. The men, who were track workers, were run down by a locomotive which was bound south on the north-bound track.

EXPRESS AND IMPLIED WARRANTY. -- In June, 1898, John Cabot received from the American Ink Company an order for a quantity of carbon black, to be used in the preparation of ink. The goods were manufactured, delivered, and paid for. As soon as the carbon black was received, the company began to use it in making ink, which it sold to printers.

MANILA, Jan. 17 -- The Tagalos Gen. Mauricio recently landed at Negros from the Island of Panay and requested a conference with Col. Byrne. He proposed that the insurgents be let alone and permitted to wear side arms and uniforms in the towns until the war in Luzon was ended, when they would surrender.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Stryker, President of Hamilton College, paid a glowing tribute to Alexander Hamilton at the Hamilton Alumni dinner in New York Thursday night, but did he not go further than the facts will warrant, as he spoke with so much enthusiasm and eloquence, and did those who so warmly applauded give their approval?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Senate today decided that a vote on the Financial bill shall be taken Feb. 15. Mr. Aldrich, (Rep., R. I.,) Chairman of the Finance Committee, asked for an agreement for a vote on Feb. 1. Mr. Jones, (Ark.,) objected to that date, as the time would be too short for a full discussion of the bill. He said, however, that Feb. 15 would be satisfactory.

The bill introduced in the House by Congressman RUSSELL, to enable manufacturers using alcohol in the arts to recover the money due them as rebate touches only one aspect of a very serious question. The bill ought to pass. There can be no sort of question about that; for otherwise certain persons who have been wronged will be denied their just remedy.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Some of the most infant work in the way of descriptive writing ever done by British war correspondents has been appearing in the London papers during the last few days. Bennet-Burleigh's splendid description of the battle of Colenso, which was cabled in part, is not one bit finer than the account of Magersfontein by the correspondent of The Daily News.

The home of H.W. Ormsbee, advertising manager of a local newspaper, who lives at 55 Willow Street, Brooklyn, was invaded by a housebreaker early yesterday morning. The burglar subsequently distinguished himself by holding Up a girl on the street near Mr. Ormsbee's house and robbing her of her pocketbook.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Senator Platt did not seem to be acquainted with the whereabouts of Representative Sherman today when he was asked if he had received a reply from him concerning the invitation to become a candidate for Secretary of the Senate." It seems to me that the newspapers have got ahead of the caucus in this business," said the Senator.

The School Board for Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday afternoon held its last meeting in the old Board of Education Building on Grand Street. Early this morning all of its employes, including Superintendent Jasper, the Board of Associate Superintendents, and the clerks, will move, with their books, records, and belongings, into the new Board of Education Building, at Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue.

MANILA, Jan. 17 -- The presence here of Archbishop Chapelle, the Apostolic Delegate, to the Philippines, is greatly stirring the Catholics of all nationalities. The Filipinos have gained the impression that Mgr. Chapelle came as the joint agent of President McKinley and the Pope to reinstate the friars in their former power.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The New York State Bar Association at its meeting to-day adopted a resolution that the Legislature be required to provide for the completion of the work of revising the statutes, and for full examination and proper action as to the revision of the code of procedure by a commission to be selected by the Governor, the members to serve without compensation.

The organization of the Produce Exchange Trust Company was made permanent yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Trustees by the election of the temporary officers as follows: Edwin Gould, President; Gen. Samuel Thomas, First Vice President; George William Ballou, Second Vice President; William H. Taylor, Third Vice President; John A. Hilton, Treasurer; William M. Laws, Secretary.

A postponed series was bowled in the National League last night, the Orientals winning two games and the Standards one. The best score was made by Rothermel of the Orientals, six strikes and four spares, netting a score of 225. Scores:

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 17 -- The release of the two Lamb girls caused an exciting scene in court this morning. They were formerly inmates of the "Lord's Farm" at Woodcliff. They have been confined in jail for several months as witnesses against Huntsman T. Manson and others, who were arrested on a charge of keeping a disorderly house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read your editorial in THE TIMES of the 11th inst., commenting on the numerous letters you received concerning millionaires, and the general tone being of hostility toward them. I want to give you my opinion as briefly as possible why that is so.
LONDON, Jan. 18.--The Pletermaritzburg correspondent of the Daily Mail, telegraphing late Wednesday evening, Jan. 17, says:

Charles T. Barney has sold the block front on the west side of Broadway, between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets, 204.10 by 112 and irregular. Mr. Barney said yesterday that the price was $365,000. The buyer's name is withheld for the present, but it is understood that he is a builder, who will erect seven-story apartment houses on the property.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 17 -- A circular received in this city indicates that the Yaqui Indians have attempted to establish a form of civil government and proclaim the independence of Sonora. The circular is in the form of an appeal to the American people, and is signed by Manuel Sauveda, President, and Teresa Duryea, Jesus Escalente, Harry Herbot, John Dwyer, Tenebanto, and Julian Villa, members of the Junta.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 17 -- William Rockefeller a few days ago rode over from North Tarrytown to his Greenwich farm, in an automobile. He was accompanied by an engineer, who was giving the Standard Oil magnate points regarding the Tunning of the carriage, so that Mr. Rockefeller might secure a license as an engineer.

-- Certain individuals who call themselves "the New York Committee to Aid the United Republics of South Africa" assembled themselves and as much of their name as there was room for at the Morton House, Tuesday evening, and proceeded for several hours to aid the United Republics of South Africa by heaping superheated epithets on England and the English.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Senator Hanna, Senator Scott, Joseph H. Manley, and the architect of the Republican National Convention Hall at Philadelphia, together with Mr. Shields, Chairman of the Philadelphia Convention Committee, met this morning at the house of Senator Hanna to consider the preliminary plans for the arrangement of the convention hall.

(FROM A SPECIAL CONTRIBUTOR.) It may be advisable to divide the bill reported by the Joint Committee on Taxation into two separate measures, although it is intended to accomplish the one general purpose of raising sufficient revenue with the existing State taxes for the support of the State Government, thereby leaving for local purposes solely the direct assessment of real and personal property.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Capt. John B. Jeffery, who was an Acting Quartermaster of Volunteers, has been recommended for brevetship for gallant and distinguished service by Gen. Marcus F. Miller in a letter addressed to Quartermaster Gen. Ludington. The officer was attached to the staff of Gen. Miller as Brigade Quartermaster and afterward as Depot Quartermaster at Iloilo.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You have in your issue of the 10th two very interesting letters on electric wiring. Mr. Crackenthorpe's comments on Prof. Thomson's ideas are very just, yet it is a little singular that both have failed, apparently, to learn that electric wiring incased in iron ducts is extensively used, at least in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- So far as the House is concerned, the chances of Brigham H. Roberts of Utah to occupy the seat to which he was elected are gone. The special committee investigating his case reached a final conclusion to-day. It was unanimous on the question of his polygamous status and agreed upon a formal statement of facts, but upon the question of procedure the committee was divided.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 17 -- Mr. Bryan to-day addressed the members of the Assembly gathered in joint session in the house. He said he would not discuss politics. He could, not make the free silver Democracy stand any firmer and he had not time to convert a Republican.

Trading was a little more active in the market for outside securities yesterday than on the previous days of the week, yet the amount of business was small compared with the more active trading of a few weeks ago. In the early tracing the market was irregular, and inclined to recede from the previous day's closing bids, but the volume of transactions was so small that few movements of any consequence resulted.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- It is announced tonight that a conference of the Republican State leaders will be held in New York, probably at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, on Saturday, for the purpose of reaching some decision regarding the question of the insurance superintendency, which has caused Senator Platt and his lieutenants more trouble than anything which has taken place since the Republican organization obtained control of the State Government in 1895.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The correspondent of The Times at Lorenzo Marques, telegraphing yesterday, says:

It is a great pity that such a question, or, rather, such a series of questions, as was put by the Roberts case should not have received a more respectable and authoritative solution. The report of the majority, it will be agreed by all who have followed the case, is simply disreputable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me to call the attention of the readers of THE TIMES to the importance of the work being done by the George Junior Republic at Freeville, N.Y., in its bearing upon one of the problems growing out of our city life?

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Gov. Roosevelt will go to New York City to-morrow and in the evening he will dine with Col. Franklin Bartiett. On Saturday morning he will breakfast with Senator Thomas C. Platt and B.B. Odell. He will take luncheon with Gen. Francis V. Greene, Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, and Gen. Avery D. Andrews.

The marksmen of Company B made a strong argument last night, at the Seventh Regiment Armory, in favor of their being allowed to retain for another year the Edward Kemp and the Col. Emmons Clark Trophies. The scores made by the teams, while not very close to the records, nevertheless surpass those made thus far in the present competition.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Gov. Roosevelt announced to-day, that he would go to New York to-morrow afternoon, and he admitted that the object of his trip was to have a talk with the leader of the State organization in regard to the Superintendency of Insurance. It is believed that at this conference the man whose name is to be sent to the Senate to succeed Louis F. Payn will be decided upon.

An electric automobile, driverless, dashing down Fourth Avenue, around the curve of Union Snare into Fourteenth Street, finally brought to a standstill against the equestrian statue of Washington, where it continued the harsh grinding of its wheels as though in rage at having its course checked, furnished a spectacle that first alarmed and then amused a throng of people late yesterday afternoon, when the streets were most densely crowded.

Chief Croker of the Fire Department was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given at the Waldorf-Astoria by a committee of his friends, headed by Curtis Wigg and William G. Horner. During the dinner a beautiful silver water service was presented to Chief Croker.

There are signs that the Crumpacker scheme for reducing the representation of the South in Congress and the Electoral College is gaining some support among the Republicans, and that an organized effort will be made to get the idea of it included in the Republican platform at Philadelphia this Summer.
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- In the Senate this morning, after the introduction of bills, several nominations which were reported by the Finance Committee yesterday, were confirmed.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- Some of to-day's papers had more or less guarded reports as to alleged heavy losses in stock speculation on the part of Count Boni de Castellane, who married Miss Anna Gould of New York, and who, with his wife, is now on the way to the United States. It was even declared that the Count had been posted on the Bourse for failing to settle.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 @ 60. There were no sales.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 18. -- News has reached here that about 40,000 miners in the anthracite district of Pennsylvania, near Seranton and Shamokin, who have been in a restless state for some time, have decided to strike.

NEWARK, .N.J., Jan. 18. -- The thirteenth animal dinner of the Newark Board of Trade was held to-night in the drill room of the First Regiment Armory, in Orange Street. Thirteen tables in three columns of four and one cross table at the head were arranged to accommodate the 400 guests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The House today passed the Senate bill to extend the powers of the Director of the Census after striking out the committee amendment to authorize the Director to contract for extra printing with private contractors. The whole fight was upon that amendment. The influence of the Public Printer and the labor organizations of the country were employed against it, and after a lively debate of several hours, it was overwhelmingly defeated.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Senator White will reintroduce his Educational bill of last year in an amended form. An agreement has been reached between the Catholic schools and institutions, the State Department of Public Instruction, and the Statutory Revision Commission as to what the bill should contain.

Nobody, at least no civilized person, who read the report of the shooting of SCOTT by COLSON in Kentucky, and incidentally of several persons more or less remotely related to the quarrel between SCOTT and COLSON or not related to it at all, can have failed to experience the emotion of disgust as well as the emotion of regret.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Mr. Choate is prosecuting his efforts to learn just where the provisions are that were seized off Delagoa. Bay on the Mashona, the Maria, and the Beatrice. He has reported that the goods on the Maria are in the Custom House at Durban subject to the disposition of the owners.

Evidence that H.C. Barnet had received at his offlce in the Produce Exchange Building package from some unknown person, containing a powder, which was found after his death by Edmund Barnet, his brother, was introduced yesterday at the Molineux trial. This was the first time it had developed that Barnet had actually received a package of this kind.

Flower Hospital has just become richer by $200,000 through the generosity of Mrs. Roswell P. Flower and Mrs, Emma Flower Taylor, her daughter, each of whom has presented $100,000 to the institution on the sole condition that the name Flower Hospital shall be retained, in perpetuity. In addition, a legacy of $5,000 was received yesterday from the estate of Miss Ray.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- A distinguished gathering of public officials, including President McKinley and his entire Cabinet, representatives of the Senate and House of Representatives, the judiciary of the United States Supreme Court, and other branches of public life, participated to-day in exercises attending the unveiling of the colossal bronze statue of Daniel Webster, executed by the Italian sculptor, Trentanove, and presented to ihe United States by Mr, Stilson Hutching of the City of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Senators who attended the executive session of the Senate before which Senator Davis made a speech touching the acquisition of the Philippines and the purpose of the Government toward those islands have managed to let out some interesting explanations made by Senator Davis concerning the reasons that actuated the Paris Commissioners in deciding to take over the islands and the policy of the Administration toward them in the future.
FRANKFORT, Jan. 18. -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were active and firm on more reassuring war news and easier money. Foreign securities were harder, especially Spanish 4s. Americans improved.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- The promised interpellation of the Government's attitude toward the strikers of St. Etienne, directed against M. Millerand, (Socialist,) the Minister of Commerce, came up in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon, and resulted in a victory for the Government.
Dividends have been declared by the German-American Bank and the Pacific Fire Insurance Company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- Judge Townsend of the United States Court to-day handed down a decision in the case of the Government against Loeb Schoenfeld, New York importers. The importing firm brought into this country a consignment of embroidery, on which the customs Appraiser imposed duty charges in excess of the invoice.

That was a striking epigram which Senator WOLCOTT made in the Senate the other day, in reply to the bilious and pessimistic remarks of the Senator from South Dakota. To the contrary, of these observations, said the Senator from Colorado, the rich are growing richer and the poor are growing richer also.

TUXEDO PARK, Jan. 18. -- Those who saw the Tuxedo court tennis match at the fourth day's play at the new Tuxedo Tennis Club witnessed one of the grandest games of tennis of the season. Two Englishmen, Peter Latham, professional champion of the world, and Eustace H. Miles, amateur champion of England, were pitted against each other, and the latter defeated Latham in three sets to one The play was very fast.

CHICAGO, Jan., 18. -- It is stated that as a result of the recent consolidations and agreements among the owners of the great trunk railways east of Chicago, the entire transportation system between the Mississippi River and the Atlantic seaboard is to be reorganized, involving numerous important changes.

Henry Hart, of 95 Perry Street, Manhattan, yesterday called on District Court Judge Seymour, in Hoboken, and asked to be arrested on a charge of bigamy. He said that he married Mary E. Howe in a Methodist Church in New York on Jan. 27, 1888. Two years later she became addicted, to drink and he left her.

The increase in real estate values which Mr. HARNETT points out as one of the sure consequences of the operation of the underground rapid transit road is an effective and eloquent argument for the project.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 18. -- The tobacco growers of North Carolina, in State Convention to-day, adopted an agreement whereby they are not to sell the American Tobacco Company a pound of their leaf tobacco for five years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The transport Sheridan has sailed from Seattle for Manila with a cargo of forage for the army in the Philippines. She will make the trip without stoppage, if possible, but if necessary she will stop at Nagasaki.

The New York Athletic Club and Columbia Club of Hoboken played a series in the Athletic League at the former's alleys last night. The New Yorks won two out of three games, losing the Second by five pins. Geils of the Columbia Club bowled in splendid form, making an average of 205 for the three games.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The War Office has issued the following:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Teller (Silver Rep., Col.,) resumed his speech on the financial bill, in the course of which he arraigned Secretary Gagef for his negotiations with the National City Bank of New York. He had not concluded his remarks when he suspended them for the day.

John T. Williams has bought the four and Six story buildings 114 and 116 Liberty Street. running through to 117, 119, and 21 Cedar Street. These properties, Which are occupied by John Andersen Co., the tobacco dealers, and are owned by Alfred Wagstaff, the Secretary of that concern, ave frontages of 47 feet on Liberty Street and 68.7 feet on Cedar Street, with a depth of about 112 feet between streets.

Army. Major Henry S. Kilbourne. Surgeon, medical Superintendent of the array transport service, will proceed from New York City to the Norfolk Navy Yard on official business pertaining to the army transport service.

Nearly 400 members and guests sat at table at the fifteenth annual dinner of the Holland Society of New York, held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, in the grand ball room, which was decorated with the American and Dutch colors, with the arms of the society conspicuously displayed on an orange banner in rear of the Chairman.

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- From statements made to-day by President E.D. Codman of the Fitchburg Railroad, Robert Codman, the senior Director, and Joseph B. Russel, one of the Executive Committee, it appears that the Fitchburg Railroad will not be leased to the Boston and Maine, owing to the opposition of the Directors representing the State of Massachusetts, which holds $5,000,000 worth of Fitchburg stock.

Alexander E. Orr, President of the Rapid Transit Commission, said yesterday after-noon that the board had nothing further to do in the matter of the tunnel construction until John B. McDonald, the contractor, was ready with his cash and bonds of $7,000,000.

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- Business in the stock market was all but stagnant. There was no animation in any speciality or group of stocks. The Boston and Montana Company declared a quarterly dividend of $8 per share -- $1,200,000 -- payable Feb. 20, to stockholders or record Jan. 25. The total dividend payments, including to-day's declaration, by the Boston and Montana Company are $15,725,000.

The annual meeting of the American Protective Tariff League was held yesterday afternoon at its headquarters, 135 West Twenty-third Street. Ex-Mayor William L. Strong, the President, was in the chair, and among the others present were ex-Secretary Cornelius N. Bliss. Homer Laughlin of California, Charles E. Coffin of Maryland, Charles S. Landers of Connecticut, P.C. Cheney of New Hampshire, Le Grand B. Cannon, George J. Seabury, and F.S. Witherbee.

It is said that Prof. Arthur C. McGiffert of Union Theological Seminary will have his answer in printed form early next week, that it will be along the lines of the one sent by him last May to the General Assembly, and that it will end with an announcement of his-willingness to withdraw from Presbyterian Church membership.

NORTH BROOKFIELD, Mass., Jan. 19. -- Martin Bergen, one of the best-known ball players in the country and one of the Boston Club's catchers last season, killed his wife and two children with an axe and then cut his own throat with a razor, at his home, in the eastern portion of North Brookfield, this morning.

The Hon. Joseph H. Choate, the American Ambassador to England, supported by Lord George Hamilton, the Bishop of London, and many other gentlemen, on Jan. 3 opened the Passmore Edwards Public Library at Acton. The audience included Mrs. Choate and Mrs. Creighton, to the former of whom was presented a beautiful bouquet of orchids as she entered the building.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- A prominent official of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company said to-day there was no truth in the Chicago story that the railroads had agreed to abandon their ticket offices in the various large cities, to substitute joint offices in each city, and to do away with traveling and district freight and passenger agents.

TUXEDO PARK, Jan. 19. -- The Tuxedo tennis courts were crowded to-day. Two good matches were played, and were witnessed by a large and fashionable crowd. In the morning T. Suffern Tailor of Tuxedo met Morton Paton of New York. Mr. Tailer played with excellent service to-day. The game was decided a draw.

To New York Times Saturday Review: It THE TIMES is not one at the clique of newspapers that refuse their columns to Baconians, I do not think you will lose prestige by having the honesty to admit that Ignatius Donnelly (even if he be only Ignatius Donnelly -- let us grant that much to begin with) has in his last book proved some curious circumstances.

France, through something akin to fury in the blcod of her people, which loved to destroy monuments, remembering only the wrongs they had suffered, has been shorn of many of her most valuable literary and historical landmarks. The Revolution nearly completed the work which the religious wars and civil strife had begun.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have waited long and vainly for an utterance abler than mine can be from SATURDAY REVIEW readers on the subject of one of last year's books. If no one else will speak I must, and this is the speech:

The teachers in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx will receive their December salaries on Monday, according to the plan outlined by Controller Coler. Police stations will be notified when the checks are ready for distribution, and policemen on post will carry the word to the schoolhouses.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- Reports of trust companies made to the State Superintendent of Banking as of Jan. 1, and for the year 1899, show excellent conditions of the companies. From reports passed upon by the Superintendent are taken these abstracts:

Wiien President. S. R. Callaway of the New York, Central and Hudson River Railroad Company was shown the statement from Chicago, published yesterday, in regard to a reorganization of the entire transportation system between the Mississippi River and the Atlantic, seaboard and other results of recent trunk railway consolidations and agreements, he said: " I read that early this morning."
Reports to the commercial agencies of the country tell an interesting story of the general business condition.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 19. -- Ida M. Frazer has been granted a divorce from Dr. J. C. Frazer upon an amended complaint, in which no mention was made of Mrs. Lucy Scribner, widow of the New York publisher, against whom sensational charges were first preferred, and who sent a lawyer here from New York to protect her good name in court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- W. J. Bryan arrived in Washington, early this morning, and before 9 o'clock the hall near his room was thronged with friends who were anxious to see him, and who suggested important reasons for being at once admitted to his presence. Senator J. K. Jones, who was an early visitor, had the visitor all to himself for about an hour, after which the crowd was admitted.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 10. -- In Ridgefield, nine miles from here, William Cornish, a brother of Harry Cornish, made famous by his connection with the Mollneux case was arrested on a charge of theft, preferred by the Bridgeport Traction Company.

That was a very striking item of news which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday from Havana. This was the dispatch which set forth that Havana has a " Four Hundred," and which set forth also how the Four Hundred was to be chosen and composed. It is, it seems, to be a joint society of Americans and Cubans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Senator Platt was a witness to-day before United States Commissioner Thom of the District of Columbia, in a libel suit brought by Gen. Charles H.T. Collis against The New York World. Collis was Commissioner of Public Works in 1897 when the article complained of was published under the heading "Collis and Platt Work a Huge Grab."

Nearly thirty years have passed since Mr. Robert Buchanan gave the world, first in the pages of The Contemporary Review and later in book form, his "Fleshly School of Poetry." In magazine form the article was signed Thomas Maltland, but later, the next year, when the book appeared, Mr. Buchanan's own name was found on its title page.

Edgar A. Garbutt, thirty-six years old, of 204 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn, will leave the Seney Hospital, Brooklyn, to-day, after having undergone one of the most dangerous operations ever performed. Garbutt fell off his bicycle two years ago, and as a result leaves the hospital minus the whole of his left arm, his left shoulder blade, and the left side of his collar bone.

At a recent gathering of what Mark Twain would call "literary persons," of both sexes, one of the men present made the sweeping assertion that most, if not all, women were entirely devoid of a sense of humor.

Has the Educational bill prepared by the Governor's Unification Commission any friends? The Governor himself does not seem to be enthusiastic about it. Senator WHITE in the Senate and Assemblyman LEWIS in the Assembly have introduced it, but each said it was done " by request," which is equivalent to a disclaimer of all responsibility and liking for the bill.

The fast hockey team from Yale Uni- versity whitewashed the team from Princeton at the St. Nicholas Rink last night before 2,000 enthusiasts of the game. The admirers of the team were about equal in numbers, and there was a large number of women present.

The examination before United States Commissioner Shields of Col. John F. Gaynor, E.H. Gaynor, W.T. Gaynor, and B. D. Greene, on indictments alleging conspiracy to defraud the Government in connection with the Savannah River and Cumberland Sound contracts, was continued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections today resumed its investigation of the charges of bribery made against Senator Clark of Montana in connection with his election to the United States Senate. Mr. William F. Rector was again on the stand at the beginning of the day's session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The small doubt that remained as to the state of the cargo of the ship Maria, which was seized by British warships off Delagoa Bay, was dissipated to-day by the receipt of word from Mr. Choate that the agents of the owners of the goods had been informed from Lorenzo Marques that the goods had been landed there and were in their hands.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 1/2@60 1/4. There were no sales.

PERU. Ind., Jan. 19. -- The Commercial Bank of the town of Silver Lake, about twenty-five miles northeast of this city, was gutted early this morning by masked men blowing up the vault and safe with nitro-glycerine. As near as can be ascertained, about $4,000 in paper money was taken away by the burglars.

Members of the Confederate Veteran Camp of New York held their tenth annual banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria last night in honor and memory of Gen. Robert E. Lee, the leader of "the Lost Cause." Nearly 300 sons and daughters of the old South and the new were gathered with their guests at the flower-covered tables in the large dining hall, and revived again with rhetoric and song memories of "Dixie's Land."

The four and five story buildings at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fiftyfourth Street, known as the Hotel Bayard, have been sold toy Victor D. Depierris to C.S. Jaeger. The property has frontages of 75.1O feet on Broadway and 101.3 feet on Fifty-fourth Street. Nothing could be learned yesterday from those interested as to the price or regarding the future of the property.

Politicians and the public generally await with interest the result of the conference to be held this morning between Senator Platt, Gov. Roosevelt, and Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee.

John B. McDonald, the successful bidder for the rapid transit tunnel, will post his securities for the fulfillment of his contract with the city, and that document will be ready for signature not later than next Tuesday. Mr. McDonald walked into Controller Coler's office late yesterday afternoon and announced he would furnish his cash security of $1,000,000 on Monday.

How substantially the Catholic libraries of the city are contributing to the dissemination of good literature is nowhere more significantly recognized, perhaps, than in non-Catholic book and periodical publishing circles. Responsive to the intellectual awakening of the past ten years, they are reaching out on every side for the commercial patronage that was once almost wholly controlled by the Catholic publisher, who continues to cling tenaciously to the old order of things.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 17. -- A unique publication, which will be issued at no very distant date by Direxel Biddle, is Albert White Vorse's "The Laughter of the Sphynx." Drexel Biddle was a heavy loser by the Lippincott fire, and among other things this entire book was destroyed --plates, illustrations, and even the manuscript.

The coming exhibition to be held at the Grolier Club in commemoration of the five hundredth anniversary of the death of Geoffrey Chaucer should have for lovers of early English literature a special interest. Beginning with the first edition of "The Canterbury Tales." printed by William Caxton about 1478, all the important editions of Chaucer's chief work will be shown.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 19. -- Vice Consul Morrison, at Dawson City, reports to the State Department that the excitement caused by reports of the phenomenal richness of the Cape Nome goldfields has not by any means abated. Many miners will attempt to make the trip out of the Klondike this Winter down the river, which, the Consul says, seems a foolhardy undertaking.

The City Club discussed the subject of charter revision at its clubhouse last night after a dinner. There were some distinguished speakers, and a good many opinions expressed in positive language, but those who took part in the debate had many different views.

BATH, Jan. 19. -- Col. Charles O. Shepard, Commandant of the Soldiers' Home, who is on trial before a committee of the State Board of Charities, was recalled this morning at the opening of the session, and was on the stand until 5 o'clock this afternoon, at which time the committee adjourned the investigation until Tuesday, Col. Shepard's testimony was in the nature of a general denial of the charges against him.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Several of the London, morning papers omit editorial comment upon Count von Buelow's speech in the Reichstag yesterday in reply to Herr Moeller's interpellation. Others endeavor to minimize the yielding spirit displayed by the British Government by arguing that Count von Buelow was obliged to play to the gallery and to do his utmost for the naval plans of Emperor William.

Charles Lamb describes that sad feeling which comes about when looking over an old list of actors on a playbill. In one of his letters he writes: "Your communication to me of the death of Munden made we weep. Now. Sir, I am not of the melting mood. But in these serious times the loss of half the world's fun is no trivial deprivation."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Gen. Otis today cables the War Department of the movements of troops throughout the islands. He says the losses of the enemy have been large, while the American loss is small, mainly in slightly wounded. Large quantities of rebel arms and ammunition have been captured, together with numbers of Filipinos.

LONDON. Jan. 19. -- Gen. Buller has telegraphed the War Office from Spearmants Camp, under date of yesterday, as follows: " Lord Dundonald, with a body of mounted troops, came into action this afternoon with a force of Boers near Acton Homes, " After a fight he occupied several kopjes which he is still holding.

Dullness continued in the market for out side securities yesterday, the number of issues traded in was relatively small, and total transactions for the day were considerably below what was the average last month. Prices did not fluctuate very much and most of the day's changes were unim portant.

It is interesting to hear Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN, who has been accused of Americanizing the politics of England, greatly to the disgust of some of his conservative friends and his individual advancement, preaching to the people of Birmingham the need of following in the footsteps of the Americans in education and in commercial enterprise.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- State Controller Willam J. Morgan has compiled statistics showing the assessed valuation of real and personal property in the several counties of the State as returned to his office by Boards of Supervisors for the year 1899, and has issued a table setting forth the same. This shows the total valuation of real and personal property to be S.5,562,204,198, as compared with $5,186,635,964 in 1898, an increase of"$375,568,234.

It may be remembered by students of Church history, as an incident in a controversy of winder import between Mr. Gladstone and Cardinal Manning, that the former denied the Cardinal's claim of Maryland as a place where the Church of Rome had given religious toleration. Dr. Smith's very interesting and able volume is written with the purpose of emphasizing and substantiating Mr. Gladstone's assertion.

--Attention, company! (We mean the company of anti-imperialists, and throw in free the flattery implied by the assumption that there are enough of them to make a company.) The Yaqui Indians announce to the world -- a synonym for Massachusetts, of course -- that they have long been fightins bravely for liberty and independence and that they want sympathy and assistance in their holy struggle.

Assistant District Attorney Osborne failed yesterday to bring to a close the case of the prosecution in the Molineux trial, as he had expected, and his statement that he would have three physicians on the stand Monday was not regarded as tearing out his further promise that he would certainly close his case on that day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The House today passed the Pension Appropriation bill after amending it by providing that " the Commissioner of Pensions shall furnish all necessary blanks to claimants, and that said Commissioner may, in his discretion, refuse to pay the fee to an attorney of record when he is satisfied that said attorney failed to prepare the case under his or her personal supervision and did not discharge his full duty to claimant."
Part of an Address Before the Booksellers' League at the Aldine Club, on Jan. 17. by Francis W. Halsey, Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW.

The Washington Club had an excellent chance to win the Harlem League ehampionship last night by winning two games. The team however, after winning the first game easily, was beaten by the phoenix team. The Washingtons are now tied for first place with the Knickerbockers, each, having won fifteen games and lost five.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your columns open to correspondents have been so universally successful, I write to ask if it be possible therein to bring together quotations in regard to what constitutes a "gentleman" and a "lady." Of course. Sir Philip Sidney. Herbert Addlson, Scott, Thackeray, Tennyson, and Stevenson, Lowell, Emerson, Curtis, at once come to mind in connection with gentleman.

The fact that many of the London daily papers devoted considerable space to obituaries at Dwight Lyman Moody on the publication of the news of the death of the evangelist, is variously commented on by the literary journals over there. That The Daily News devoted nearly two columns to him and single lumn to the late Duke of Westminster is deemed very significant.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Fearing I may not have made myself clear in my communication of last week, at least, judging by the editorial heading, may I add a few words to a subject very near my heart?

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19. -- William Jennings Bryan's visit to this city to-morrow and the action of the Democratic majority in the lower house of the Legislature in shelving a resolution asking him to address that body has had the effect of dividing the Maryland Democracy and opening the fight, for control of the delegation to the National Convention.

HAVANA, Jan. 19. -- This morning 150 persons who had been imprisoned on excessive sentences or been held for an unreasonable time, awaiting trial, were released. On emerging from prison they were greeted by many friends, and an affecting scene ensued.

Mr. William A. Purrington, whose legal practice has been largely associated with the regulation of medical practice, and will has become a legal authority upon what is sometimes known as medical jurisprudence, has brought together in a volume of less than 200 pages a number of periodical as ticles and public addresses of his own on the subject of Christian Science and its relation to the law.

Charles A. Davison of this city died at Bon Air, Augusta, Ga., yesterday morning after a long illness. Mr. Davison was born May 21, 1824, at Saratoga Springs, and was educated at Williams College, from which he was graduated in 1845, and in which he retained a great interest, being a member of its Board of Trustees from 1878 until his death.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 13 I notice your interesting article on "Modern Bookbinding." I wish you had said a few words of disapproval of the late style of uncut edges. During the past, few months many books have been advertised, some in expensive bindings, with the alluring bait "gilt tops and uncut edges," as if a nice chromo were to be thrown in.

The meeting yesterday afternoon in the Bank of Commerce Building of the Executive Committee of the Standard Gaslight Company was attended by Directors Terry, Tilford, and McAlpin and President Sage. The absentee was Charles Dana, who is sick. Nothing happened.' Mr. Sage was not " talked to," as at the monthly meeting of the board, and the session was short.

Abram Kling's fight against the State Trust Company was enlivened yesterday by statements and counter statements. Gen. Andrews, who has hitherto been reticent in the matter, was drawn out by a previous statement of President Johnston of the State Trust Company, which struck him as being an insinuation that he, Gen. Andrews, had revealed secrets. He accordingly issued the following:

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night, Verdi's "Aida " was sung for the second time this season. The cast was the same as at the first performance, but the results were much better. Mme. Emma Eames was once more the Aida, and it is a pleasure to sav that her work showed great strides forward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The Senate today adopted a resolution calling upon the President, " if not incompatible with public interests," to furnish information whether any representative of the Transvaal had) applied to the United States Government for recognition, and if such application had been made if it had been accepted, and if not why not.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- The War Office is corning in for considerable criticism fur refusing to accept offers of private houses for the reception of the wounded from South Africa. This patriotic movement has been snubbed by the curt reply that the wounded would be retained in the hospitals until they were able to dispense with nursing.

"Golf is a wonderful game for rumors, isn't it?" remarked the Winter enthusiast as he arrived at his New Jersey club for a friendly game on the frozen greens. "Just notice in the course, of a year how many predictions of big things about to happen you hear, and then try to recall how few actually take place.

HAVANA, Jan. 15. -- It is interesting to note how various Americans live here -- many in a way that would be out of the question in a colder climate, others with all of the comforts that one could wish. Not long ago I made a round of calls and found my friends living in many and various ways.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- The tone of the British press comments on Count von Bulow's speech in the Reichstag yesterday gives offense here and is causing a fresh outbreak of bitter feeling. The Government is understood to be displeased with the reception of the Foreign Ministers' speech in England, and the news that another German ship has been captured adds fresh fuel to the name.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 20. -- As scheduled for this Winter, the series of events in the tournament to take place along the east coast of Florida is similar to the programme laid out last year. Last season's play brought together many of the best amateurs in the country, but a greater number will enter for honors this year, as several of them are now in the field practicing daily.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 20. -- Upon a warrant sworn to by Olive E. Burnham, wife of Capt. D.R. Burnham, retired, charging her husband with insanity, that officer occupies a cell in the insane ward of the county hospital. All efforts made by Burnham's friends to release him from custody proved fruitless, as the statutes forbid an examination until twenty-four hours of incarceration have elapsed.

Apparently the fate of Louis F. Payn. so far as it relates to the office of State Superintendent of Insurance, remains undecided. Senator Thomas C. Platt, Gov. Theodore Roosevelt, and Chairman B. B. Odell, Jr., of the Republican State Committee breakfasted at the Fifth Avenue Hotel at 8:30 o'clock yesterday and then were closeted in conference until a few minutes after 11 o'clock.
