ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 20. -- East Orange is to have a new public library, as a gift from Andrew Carnegie, who has agreed to give $30,000 for the purpose. The only condition imposed upon the city in accepting the gift is that a site shall be provided for the building and that the city shall appropriate $5,000 a year for its maintenance.

There was much gossip yesterday in the financial district about the local gas situation and it was evidently stimulated by the prospect of a lively meeting of Consolidated stockholders to-morrow. The opinion appeared to be general that if the interests represented by George A. Lamb of Lamb Voss do nut carry their point at the meeting.

When the chaffinch asks for cobweb she sees that she gets it. She is not to be put off with trash. And while her ladyship turns over its samples, the spinner of the stuff crouches itself out of sight, pretending it belongs to the corner, is, in fact, part of the corner, its extreme angle, and not a pottle-bodied, edible spider.

As a lover of Americana, he naturally went to the Grolier Club to see the collection of portraits of George Washington. As a collector, he was pleased; as an idealist, he was puzzled. "I have had a very distinct idea of what George Washington looked "like," said he, "and it was not the Stuart portrait that filled the bill.

Through the efforts of Theodore Von Bremsen, two men who, it is alleged, were convicted on perjured testimony are to-day enjoying their freedom. The men are Max Hustedt, nineteen years old, whose mother lives at 190 Chrystie Street, and John Sullivan, whose residence is unknown. Mr. Von Bremsen said last night:
The following remarks are on the Book Trade in England, not in Scotland, or in Ireland, where the conditions are in some respects different.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Investigation by the Committee on Privileges and Elections into the allegations of bribery against Senator Clark was resumed to-day.

An important change in the relations of Barnard College and Columbia University, by which the students and graduates of the former have been placed on a footing of absolute equality with the students and graduates of the latter, was announced by Seth Low, President of the university, at the seventh annual luncheon of the New York Wellesley Club, hold at the Hotel Manhattan yesterday.

TRENTON, Jan. 20. -- There is a movement on the part of a number of the Senators and Assemblymen to make an appropriation for the acquirement of some substantial memorial of the late Garrett A .Hobart. This is to be an act of the State, independent of the movement that has been begun in Paterson under the auspices of the citizens.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Jan. 20. -- George and Edward Meeks, the convicted murderers of Leopold Edlinger of Bates County, Mo., were taken from the jail in this city at 9:30 o'clock to-night and lynched by a mob of 500 men.

Let us take in England the crisis, not with pagan stoicism, but with Christian fortitude and resignation. But do not let us in our desire to show that we are still a God-fearing people -- which undoubtedly we are, and of which we need no ostentatious and public proof -- rush into an act that can only bring misunderstanding and misconstruction.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to correct a typographical error of some importance which occurred in my letter on the subsidy question printed in THE TIMES of to-day. Among the members of the House of Representatives who argued for free ships thirty years ago the name of "Addison" is mentioned.

"This has been a late season in some respects, but teas and receptions and dinners seem to have commenced earlier than usual, and we have been about swamped in our orders for cooks and waitresses," says the woman up town, who can supply a firstclass cook, at almost a moment's notice, to cook a dinner and an equally good waitress to serve it.

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners held a meeting yesterday afternoon and considered an amendment to the charter, the new provision being designed to permit the financial officers of the city, in connection with the Rapid Transit Board, to issue bonds for building the tunnel as they may be required.

Residents of the Borough of the Bronx have asked the Railroad Commitee of the Hoard of Aldermen to srive a public bearing on two ordinances introduced at the last meeting by Alderman Geiger, and which they say will add to the comfort and safety of passengers on transit lines, both surface and elevated.

Mrs. Mathilde K. Samuel, who believes the Pope is her grandfather, was yesterday adjudged insane by a Sheriffs Jury. She is the widow of R.H. Samuel, who left her a large estate. She has been confined in Bloomingdale Asylum since November, having been taken there from another institution for the insane in Brussels Belgium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see you pursue the subject of the proper distribution of wealth. It does seem to me that in your three or four atricles., and especially in a long letter from a friend of Mr. Carnegie's you argue only upon the surface of the question. Your first article testified the possession of great wealth by the generosity of the holder.

Mme. Marcella Sembrich has been engaged as the principal soloist of the Cincinnati Musical Festival, to be held during the second week of May. She will be heard for the first time in this country in Brahms's "Requiem," in the vocal part of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, and in concert numbers.

The bill to impose a tax of one-half of 1 per cent, on all mortgages, as reported by the Joint Committee on Taxation at Albany, is a matter of considerable discussion among lawyers and others directly interested in mortgage loans. The consensus of opinion is that the tax, if it should be imposed, would in the end be paid by the mortgageor.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 20. -- United States Senator John T. Morgan is in danger of losing his seat when the General Assembly of Alabama meets next November to elect his successor. In Gov. Joseph F. Johnston of this State he has met one of the shrewdest politicians the South has ever produced, backed by the strongest political machine ever created in Alabama.
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The War Office, shortly after midnight, posted the following dispatch from Gen. Buller, dated Spearman's Camp, Jan. 20, evening:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20. -- Extensive plans are oil foot to make boating at Yale this year the predominating feature in the athletic line. Capt. Alien of the Yale Varsity crew is determined to turn out a winning eight. He and Head Coach Gallaudet have devised a new training scheme from which they expect great results.
A dramatization of "Brumaire," a novel, by Jules Claretie, director of the Comedie Francaise, will soon be acted at the Paris Vaudeville.

The Patria Club met at the Hotel Savoy last night and heard President Schurman of Cornell University, who was one of the commission which visited the Philippines for this country, discuss the problem of those islands.

"The tremendous audience which was present at the Paderewski concert at Music Hall Monday night," says The Baltimore Sun, "has called forth much comment on the great planist's possibilities as a wage earner.

"You couldn't put down in a category any particular traits required to make up a good auctioneer," said a man of many sales yesterday, " for there are as many different methods of auctioneering goods as there are men who do it. There are two general qualifications that a man must have, a quick wit and a ready tongue, and your real auctioneer is born, not made.

My attention has been drawn to a controversy now being waged in your columns. I desire with your permission to say a few words on some of the matters in discussion. Some one'referred to Father Thomas Burke, O.P as a "great Irish scholarship surely some mistake here. He was a renowned preacher in the English tongue, whose knowledge of Ireland and Irish tory was acquired through an English medium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the recent decision of the Court of Appeals against 'the right of the State Board of Charities to control and direct this society, numerous articles have appeared in the daily papers containing assertions utterly false as to powers alleged to be exercised by its officers and as to laws which have no existence.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 20. -- Next week will be Yale's gala season of the year from a social standpoint. The junior promenade, bringing with it a score or more of minor events, such as germans and teas, has tended to make "Prom" week the gayest of the college year.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20. -- William J. Bryan delivered an address here to-night upon the political questions of the day to an audience which filled the Music Hall, the biggest auditorium in the city, and which greeted him and his remarks with the greatest enthusiasm.

That was an interesting address which Judge BROWN made at the meeting of the State Bar Association the other day on "The Liberty of the Press." It might have been found fault with on the ground that it aid not "got anywhere." But its author so frankly admitted this defect as to disarm criticism on that score.
In last Sunday's TIMES Mr. Agar, late member of the Board of Education, made an exhaustive review of the condition, defects, and possible remedies appertaining to the city school system.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 20, -- George Bayless, Mayor of Arlington, to-day confirmed the report of the sale of the old Arlington copper mine to a Boston syndicate. Mayor Bayless and Anthony W. Schuyler have turned over their interests to men interested in the Standard Oil Company.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- All the week the world has been on tiptoe, watching the de- velopment of events in Natal. The attitude of Europe might lead one to imagine that civilized countries were as one in the opinion that the fate of the British Empire hangs on the conflict now impending, if not actually raging as I write.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 20. -- A very thick fog in Buzzaid's Bay has delayed shipping, as there were no arrivals here today.
According to a recent issue of The Philadelphia Medical Journal, Dr. Abba, a distinguished bacteriologist, has discovered microbes in holy water in a number of churches in Turin, Italy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The American Continental policy of the United States is something very much larger than the platform in which President Monroe, in 1823, defined the attitude of the United Slates toward the schemes of the "Holy Alliance" With respect to this hemisphere.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being a regular reader of your morning paper, I have noticed lately a great many letters in regard to the great war in South Africa. As I am a Canadian, having come only recently to this city from Canada, I thought I would tell your readers how very enthusiastic we Canadians are over the war.

The fog lay heavier on the water yesterday at 2 o'clock in the afternoon than it did on Friday, and the result was a collision in the North River in the morning between two ferryboats of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the New Jersey, which runs to Cortlandt Street, and the Pennsylvania Brooklyn Annex Boat No. 4.

PARIS, Jan. 5. -- The High Court proceedings are finished at last, and everybody has been acquitted except MM. Buffet. Derouldde, and Guerin. A. M. Luc Saluce is sentenced as a runaway, hut there appears to have heen nothing against him, and had he put in an appearance he would certainly have been let go.

According to advices we have received from Washington, a canvass of the Senate and House of Representatives has placed it beyond dispute that Congress will not only pass the Nicaragua Canal bill, but will pass It in a form directly at variance with the Clayton-Bulwer treaty.

Our infantry fixed bayonets and opened with volleys at 400 yards. The twelvepounders and Maxims were hard at it; but in spite of this continuous fire, on came the Khalifa at the head of his men. Though firing incessantly, their aim was fortunately high, and the bullets whistled for the most part harmlessly over our heads.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- When the House met to-day Mr. Tayler. (Rep., Ohio,) Chairman of the Special Committee to investigate the case of Representative-elect B.H. Roberts, presented the majority report in favor of the exclusion of Mr. Roberts and gave notice that he would call the case up on Tuesday.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Mrs. Bertha M. Ruprecht of New York, widow of Harry Ruprecht, a New York stock broker and a former Batavian, who died in New York on Dec. 23 and was burled in Batavia, shot herself with suicidal intent at the Genesee House this morning, the bullet passing three-quarters of an inch below the heart.

There are several ways of approaching Selborne, and it is not easy to decide which is the most pleasant. Most people go to Selborne from Alton, a neat and prospering little town on the London and Southwestera Railway. It is a walk or drive of five miles through a country open and breezy, but not especially interesting till the great Hanger, which is the glory of Selborne, comes within sight.

Ten yea'rs have elapsed since Prince Albert ascended the throne of the Grimaldi amid a pageant which recalled the Middle Ages. The reigning sovereign, who is fiftyone years old. was educated as a naval officer, and has served in both the Spanish and French Navies, taking part in the Franco-German war of 1870.

A party of palu-fishers are ready to set out from the little Island of Nanomaga, the smallest but most thickly populated of the Ellice group. The night must be windless and moonless, the latter condition being absolutely indispensable, although, curiously enough, the fish will take the hook on an ordinary starlight night.

The Rev. Dr. Joachim Elmendorf, senior pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of Harlem, and Thomas Crawford, the Treasurer of the church, testified yes- terday in supplementary proceedings in the case of the Rev. Dr. William J, Harsha, held in Part II. of the Special Term of the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The invesigations of the Pension Bureau into frauds on the Government frequently result in the trial of Interesting cases. There was concluded recently in the Criminal Court a quaint, dramatic trial, which brought up a vanished phase of American life and history and filled the courtroom with figures from ante-bellum days.

In his little speech before the alumni of the University of the South on Friday evening, Gov. ROOSVELT remarked that the "greatest damage which can be done to our youth is to teach them that there must be a divorce between the ideal and the practical." He added as an illustration, drawn, we suppose, from his own recent experience:

IN a widely quoted letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 31, 1899, Mr. Robert P. Porter, Chief of the last census, vigorously attacked the city ownership movement in Great Britain, which is there known as municipal trading. Among other things, he says: "The immediate cause for alarm and dissatisfaction on the part of taxpayers is the increase of local indebtedness and taxes since the inauguration of municipal, trading.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Saturday issue, in the Topics of the Times, you relate some interesting incidents in the life of Gen. Dabney H. Maury. You may wish to give space for short story in two parts, in which he and a citizen of your State were the prinipal characters.

M. VALFREY SOUNDS A WARNING TO FRENCH ANGLOPHORES. -- Even more emphatic, than the opinion of M. Edouard Lqckroy, the ex-Minister of Marine, that Franco cannot hope to cope effectively on the open sea with Great Britain, is deemed a recent article in Le Figaro of Paris from the pen of M.J. Valfrey, a well-known litterateur.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For some time I have had in mind the writing of a letter to you to call attention to the management of the library of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, now at 18 to 24 West Forty-fourth Street. I have refrained until to-day, not knowing what were the resources of the society and thinking they were perhaps unable to do any better.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- A large crowd stood around the home of Mrs. Elizabeth Stahl in Riverside to-day waiting for the sign of the supposed "ghost" that is said to have created so much excitement in the Stahl household. They had their wait for nothing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I ask through the columns of THE TIMES of Mr. George Westinghouse whether the gas and power merger will eventually make it possible for a householder to run his furnace and range economically with the gas produced by the process he speaks of?

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- An unusually large crowd gathered this afternoon to witness the great international tennis match at the new courts at Tuxedo. E.H. Miles of Cambridge University, amateur champion of England, defeated Lawrence M. Stockton of the Boston Athletic Association, amateur champion, of America, by three sets to none.

I spent a wretched night in a room infested with vermin, but a busy night, and felt the utmost relief when I heard the clock strike the hoar of 5 A. M. * * * I betook myself to the dam, a large reservoir where the rainwater was stored for Irrigation purposes.

HELENA, Montana, Jan. 20. -- Marcus Daly's hostility has been stimulated by a report that ex-Senator Mantle, who has heretofore been neutral, is now friendly to Senator Clark. Recently Clark bought The Butte Inter-Mountain to further his political ambition. Now Daly is to re-establish the defunct Anaconda Chronicle, which is to be an anti-Clark organ.

The statement that E.D. Morgan has decided to begin to breed and race thoroughbreds on an extensive scale was a fruitful topic of comment among horsemen, during the last, day or two, but did not come as a surprise, as Mr. Morgan has been interested in race horses for several years and has had a small stable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some letters have appeared in THE TIMES in regard to the desirability of lessening the expenses of patent litigation. One correspondent suggests that the Government should assume the enforcement of a patent. This plan would rival the pension roll in cost, for every patentee, having nothing to pay would find an infringement case and call upon the Government.

To the Editor of the New York Times: The letter of Mr. Louis Rhead in your issue of the 13th inst., under the heading "A Reply lo Mr. McLaughlin," contains as many assertions not founded upon fact and as many false conclusion? arrived at from false premises as it would be possible to crowd into so small a space.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- The news of the death at Ladysmlth on Monday of G.W. Steevens, the special correspondent of The London Dally Mail, from enteric fever, has been received with genuine sorrow in London, where he had many friends in and out of his profession. Mr. Steevens had a distinguished career at Oxford.

A meeting of the National Association of Freight Commissioners was held in this city at the Waklorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon, with W. P. Trickett of Kansas City as President and L. B. Boswell of Quincy, lil., as Secretary, they being the new officers fleeted at the session held Friday. The meeting was largely attended by representatives of shippers.

ASHTABULA, Ohio. Jan. 20. -- Hundreds of marine men and thousands of other visitors witnessed to-day at Lorain the launching of the largest vessel ever placed upon the great lakes. She is the first 500foot ore carrier ever built, and the cargo which she will carry will be almost equal to two ordinary cargoes of two or three years ago.

The bill reported to the Legislature by the joint Committee on Taxation putting banks and trust companies on the same footing in the matter of taxation has been followed by another, introduced in the Senate, requiring trust companies to keep on hand at all times a cash reserve amounting to 15 per cent. of their deposits in this city and 10 per cent, in other cities of the State.

As a result of the conferences recently held by representatives of the public school teachers of all the boroughs in regard to the salary question a special meeting was held yesterday afternoon at School No. 1, in Henry Street, at which were present twenty officers of the various teachers' organizations in the live boroughs.
BUFFALO, Jan. 20. -- E. F. Van Hoesen. Chief Engineer of the Western Division of the New York Central, has tendered his resignation, to take effect Feb. 1.

ROME, Dec. 30. -- The much-talked of performance of Wagner's "Siegfried" at the Scala of Milan -- the first performance ever afforded the great work in Italy -- has at last taken place. The result has been, as was generally expected, a complete victory for the work of the great German master, and "Sieg-fried" is destined to make the round of the principal cities of Italy in the very near future.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 20. -- The Republican legislators here to-day declared that they had discovered a representative of Tammany here in the person of William H. Clark, who, they believe, was sent here to investigate the contest and see what bearing it could be made to have upon the national situation.

TRENTON, Jan. 20. -- A majority of the members of the Republican State Committee have expressed the opinion that the Republican State Convention, which will elect delegates at large to the National Convention, will be held about the second Thursday in May. There has been no formal conference on the subject, but individual members express that opinion.

At the present time, when the whole world is eagerly watching the progress of the war in South Africa, and the relative value of the various arms is being not onlyconsidered by experts but discussed daily among all elapses of the public, a novel contrivance for getting over the ground quickly is being actually tested by the French infantry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- An unlooked-for result of the Philippine war is the mild treatment accorded to deserters whose offenses were committed before the war. Desertion is a crime which is treated with leniency by the War Department just now. and it is quite common for a self-confessed deserter to be captured and to go without punishment, and even without trial.

ZAMBOANGA, Mindanao, P.I., Dec, 10. -- The arrival of Gen. John C. Bates aboard the Yorktown early in the past week was the sign that we had taken this place for keeps, and that Commander Very's hard vigil was receiving its proper recognition. Gen. Bates had some months ago been in charge of this district, where he had been remarkably successful in his dealings, with the natives.

It made the heart of an enterprising Yankee ache to look in at Delagoa Bay and see how a swarm of little ginger-colored officials were wasting the opportunities which a caprice of Providence had placed in their path. Their antics suggested the behavior of monkeys let loose amid the costly instruments of Greenwich Observa- tory.
The proposed team match between members of the Brooklyn Gun Club and the Crescent Athletic Club has fallen through for the present.

The Harlem and the Columbia Leagues will complete schedules during the week. In the Columbia League the Corinthians and Orientals, who are tied for first place, will meet and decide the championship. The following tables show the standing of the clubs in the various tournaments:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 1/2@60 1/4. There were no sales.

The steamer Maracaibo of the Red D Line, Capt. Hopkins, came in from Maracalbo yesterday. While in that harbor in December she happened to lie in the path of fire from the revolutionists and Government forces, and was hit about fifty-seven times. Bullets pierced her funnels and penetrated into the saloons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Mr. Cummings (Dem., N.Y.,) introduced a bill for the purchase of twenty torpedo boats of the Holland type, of which live are to be assigned for the protection of New York City.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 23. -- Quite a cyclonic wave in the form of Government reverses has swept over the Australian colonies within a few weeks past, carrying before it the defeat of no less than five Governments under our system of Parliamentary representation. This extraordinary political phenomenon originated in Tasmania, where the Ministry was defeated on a no-confidence motion and was replaced by another set of men.

The weather conditions yesterday caused the atmosphere in the Metropolitan Opera House to become almost unbearable for those who were crowded into the space alloted to patrons without seats. Several times ushers were called to the assistance of men and women who had been overcome by the heat.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: While the subject of taxation is being discussed, will you permit me to present an idea that will, in my opinion, be of value to New Yor real estate owners?

A visit to the library of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen was made by a reporter for THE TIMES. It was found that the catalogue used is a printed one, made in 1887, and the books are indexed in nine different parts according to subject matter. The parts are again subdivided into sections ranging from four to nine in number.
BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- William Jennings Bryan will be the guest of the Bryan Club of Massachusetts at a breakfast Jan. 30, a telegram accepting an invitation being received to-day.

ROME, Jan. 3. -- It is reported here, on trustworthy grounds, that Sarah Bernhardt has invited the famous Italian singer, Bellincioni, to be her guest for some time during the coming exposition at Paris, and to give a series of performances of Verdi's "La Traviata" and Umberto Giordano's now celebrated "Fedora," at the Theatre Sarah Bernhadt.
Brown, Eaton Co. have been appointed Boston agents of the Moscow Fire Insurance Company of Russia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- A pamphlet giving a complete history of the bubonic plague, together with mean's which have been adopted for its prevention, has been prepared and made public by Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service. It is shown that the plague, under various names, is a disease which has ravaged the several countries of Africa, Asia, and Europe almost from time immemorial.

"Our ministers." said M. Du Plessis, "have a very simple and yet forcible way of explaining the nature of the difference between us and those who are not of us. There is, they say, a kingdom of light and a kingdom of darkness. In the one God rules, in the other Satan.

Gong Hoar of Baltimore, Grand Master of the Lone We Tong Eng Ti, a sort of Chinese Masonic society, of which the headquarters are in this city, has arrived here, and will to-night initiate over a score of his fellow-countrymen at a meeting in the lodge room, at 16 Pell Street.
Judging from the editorial comments and from the letter of Mr. Conyngton there seems to be a confusion of thought as to what Socialism is.

That is not at all an inspiring picture of British politics which our London correspondent draws in his cable letter published to-day. It may be that it is overdrawn. He has shown before this that he is of those Englishmen who believe that the war might and should have been avoided.

A one-horse cab driven by Thomas Connors, in which were two men and a woman, caused considerable excitement and more damage on lower Fifth Avenue yesterday morning. The cab was bound down town. and between Ninth and Tenth Streets passed a hansom. The driver of the hansom was swinging his long whip, and the lash caught the cab horse on the nose, frightening him so that he got the bit in his teeth and bolted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article in to-day's TIMES on "The Mazet Reports" is both timely, truthful, and convincing. Whatever of good there may be in the majority report is doubtless nullified by the wretched record of the committee itself, and the minority has plainly lost its opportunity by descending to tirade and abuse.

The developments in the Molineux case yesterday were several. One story was that Mrs. M.A. Gelle, housekeeper at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, had suddenly disappeared. It was said that several days ago a subpoena had been served upon her, and that she tore it up and stamped upon it, declaring that she would never appear against Molineux.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 20. -- George Rife, a railroad man, was placed under arrest today charged with having attempted to burn to death Mrs. Susie Brobst. with whom he boarded, Mrs. Brobst, who is expected to die of her burns, made a sworn statement to-day that Rife had quarreled with her and that he had knocked her down, saturated her clothing with gasoline, and set fire to it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Beveridge's late speech on the Philippines and their future administration takes such high ground, is so truly in accord with the best traditions of Senatorial oratory, and is so superior to what we usually receive from his colleagues in these degenerate days that it seems ungracious to criticise, but it does seem that his optimism passes the bounds of any sane expectation.

Hush McLaughlin, the veteran Democratic leader of Kings County, left for Florida yesterday morning to spend the remainder of the Winter. His departure settled the question as to whether he would accept the challenge or Senator Michael J. Coffey and appear before the committee which is hearing the charges of party disloyalty against the South Brooklyn leader.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 20. -- The Texas Legislature will convene on Jan. 23 in special session, for the purpose of amending the tax laws of the State. The last Legislature passed a law creating the State Tax Commission and imposing upon it the work of revising the present tax laws. The commission has issued its report.

Few features other than dullness have marked the security market of the past week. On no day have transactions reached an encouraging aggregate, totals running only at about one-half of what are ordinarily recorded as a normal business showing -- being barely a quarter of the total for the corresponding week a year ago.
After an illness of three days, the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Sharpe, one of the most prominent ministers in the Presbyterian denomination, died yesterday at his home in Philadelphia.

BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- Money rates continued easier throughout last week. The reduction in London and Vienna had a favorable effect and led to an expectation of a further reduction at the Reichsbank. The difference between official and private rates is now over 2 per cent. Nevertheless, the large volume of discount -- 176,000,000 marks above the figures of a year ago -- renders caution necessary.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Jan. 21. -- This State and Montana are suffering from an epidemic of smallpox. It broke out here about a month ago, and it is claimed the first case was a man from Butte, Mon. The disease gradually spread in Utah until now it has attained quite alarming proportions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21. -- The prominence which Gen. Gatacre of the British Army has attained in South Africa, revives the story which is now being related among the British residents of Los Angeles, Santa Monica, and other Southern California communities.

The following is a comparison of the average of bullion in the principal European banks last week and at the corresponding date last year. The figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial chronicle:

How do the large colonies of citizens of foreign origin in New York, to whom Sunday closing laws are an abomination, spend the Sabbath? This is a question that is often asked. In the case of the Bohemians, at least, it can be said that they have provided themselves with facilities for spending the day agreeably and profitably.

The Rev. Dr. Farkhurst, from his pulpit in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, at the service yesterday morning again attacked the present city administration, blaming it for the vice that exists in New York and admitting that the churches and mission Houses are unable to cope with it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The Senate inquiry into the election of W.A. Clark of Montana is not yet ended, but the testimony intended to show that the election was brought about by the purchase of enough Republican votes to elect Mr. Clark Is supposed to he in. Other witnesses are to be heard, but the friends of Mr. Clark are treating the case as closed, so far as the opposition is concerned.

MANCHESTER, Jan. 21. -- The market last week was strong", with a fair business everywhere for yarns, American yarns being from 1/8@3-16 dearer, and the spinners holding the margin well. Bundles were fairly sold for Japan, China, and the Continent. Egyptian yarns were from 1/4@3/8 higher, and in good demand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Abraham E. Smith, United States Consul at Victoria, B.C., in a report to the State Department, predicts a great rush to the Cape Nome gold field in Alaska this Spring. He says that the transportation companies there and at the United States ports on Puget Sound are all engaged in preparing steamers for the trip.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The War Department has just made public a statement showing the imports at the Port of Manila for the months of July, August, and September last, being the first official data relating to imports during so long a period since American occupation.

The late Mrs. Abby L.A. Faulkner of Jamaica Plain. Mass., bequeathed all her property for the erection of a hospital there "for the people" on the death of her husband, Dr. George Faulkner. She had purchased a site for it.
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Richard Doddridge Blackmore, the novelist, died to-day.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- Gov. Roosevelt returned at noon to-day from New York, where he went to have a talk with Senator T.C. Platt and B.B. Odell, Jr., Chairman of the Republican State Committee, in regard to the selection of a man to succeed Louis F. Payn as Superintendent of Insurance.
Dr. HADLEY has made a correction and explanation of some remarks reported to have been made by him in regard to the remedy for evils connected with trusts. He says:

Easier money rates are reflected so far on the Stock Exchange only by increased bond market transactions, with some attending advances. Compared with the record of a year ago current transactions look small, but the fact that they make gains over recent averages encourages expectation that further progress can be counted upon.

Some passengers entering the elevated railroad station at Third Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street about 8 o'clock last night asked the ticket chopper, John Weigold, why he did not pick up the man who was lying on the north track at Sixty-sixth Street.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 21. -- Opposition to the acceptance of the proposition made by Andrew Carnegie to give East Orange a fifty-thousand-dollar public library will be manifested to-morrow night at the meeting of the East Orange City Council, when Mr. Carnegie's offer will be formally made known in a communication from Mayor Bruen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- In the sixteenth annual report of the United States Civil Service Commission, just submitted to the President, the commission refers to hitherto unknown phases of the service, and remarks in the importance of a merit system in our colonial possessions, and the necessity of providing for superannuated employes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. Personal colloquies involving the exchange of repartee are by no means as common in the Senate as in the House. when they are of daily and almost hourly occurrence, but they do occur now and then. Noteworthy was the battle of words between Senators Alien and Spooner on Friday.
On the Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, Jan. 20, total transactions included 1,582,317 shared of stock, $13,599,000 bonds, including $197,200 Government and $144,200 State bonds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The Grand Opera House, the largest auditorium in Washington, was packed to the doors to-night with in enthusiastic audience, which vigorously expressed its sympathy with the Boers in their fight with Great Britain. The meeting was held under the management of the united Irish societies, and a number of leading Germans of the city joined in the movement.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 21. -- The Commercial Gazette will say to-morrow:

The Standard Voting Machine Company, which is seeking to have its machine adopted by the Police Commissioners for use at the elections in this city, has one on exhibition at 170 Fifth Avenue, and also at the City Club, the Republican County Committee Rooms, Tammany Hall, the office of the State Superintendent of Elections, and the Republican and Democratic headquarters in Brooklyn.

ROME, Jan. 9. -- Considerable interest has been aroused of late concerning the attempts to recover the body of the celebrated Italian millionaire impressario Signor Antonio Tomoa, who died at sea some three months ago on board the Italian steamer Regina Margherita. found from Buenos Ayres to Genoa.

MANILA, Jan. 21. -- Mail advices from Negros bring particulars of the uprising last month in the southern part of the island, in which Lieut. Ledyard, Sixth Infantry, was killed. Instead of being an unimportant revolt of native police, as was at first reported. It appears to have been an attempt to overthrow American authority.
LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Gen. Buller cables to the War Office:...
Alexander Hamilton Tarbet of Salt Lake City, who is talked of for United States Senator from Utah, is at the Gerard House. Though not quite forty years old, he has had a remarkable career.

PARIS, Jan. 21. -- Gen. Mercier received an unexpected rebuff yesterday when the old students of the Ecole Polytechnique, which furnishes a majority of the artillery and engineer officers to the army, met in the school theatre to elect a President. Amid great excitement the ballot was taken, the result showing only 200 votes for Gen. Mercier against 1,000 for his adversary.

BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- There is the best authority for the statement that those parts of Count van Bulow's speech in the Reichstag last Friday, when replying to Herr Moeller's interpellation, which contained severe strictures upon British policy and a veiled warning to Great Britain, were due to Emperor William's expressed wish.

LEWES, Del., Jan. 21. -- The steamer which the Fenwick Island Life Saving Station reported last night as stranded on Fenwick Island Shoals, about eight miles off shore, proves to be the British steamer Sutton, with a cargo of iron ore from Carthagena, Spain, for Philadelphia. The Sutton stranded at 6 o'clock Saturday morning during a dense fog.

The pent-up enthusiasm of the Democrats of the East for W.J. BRYAN burst its bonds in the lower house of the Maryland legislature the other day, where the Democratic majority by vote refused to receive him, see him, or hear him talk.

NEWARK. N.J., Jan. 21. -- Several supposed tramps in jail here for fighting turn out to be members of a gang of burglars who are wanted by the Connecticut authorities for the shooting two weeks ago to-morrow night of Night Watchman Charles Morris at Bridgeport in the brewery which he was employed to guard.
ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- There has been so much misconstruction of the proposed new tax law that Senator Stranahan, the Chairman of the committee, has made this statement:
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The Daily Mail announces the death of his Highness Franciy Paul Louis Alexander, Duke of Teck, today, in his sixty-third year, at his home, White Lodge, Richmond Park, Surrey.

At the monthly meeting of The Young People's Association held last night in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in West Fifty-fifth Street, addresses were made by Lieut. E.W. Hearne of the Fifty-first Iowa Volunteers, lately returned from Manila, and W.B. Miller, who has charge of the army and navy work of the Young Men's Christian Association.

The energies of the protectionists are now being concentrated on the plan for subsidies to American-built ships. The American shipbuilding interest has enjoyed the highest degree of protection in the exclusive privilege of supplying the coastwise trade. It has had a rebate on the imported materials for its products.

The Rev. Dr. Madison C. Peters last evening under the auspices of the Actors' Ohureh Alliance preached at the Bloomingdale Reformed Church to the members of the dramatic profession on "The Ohurch and the Theatre." He said, in part:

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Another reduction in the bank rate was inevitable in the existing state of our money market, and I am not sure it is to be the last. All the same, the open market is poorer by u1,700,000 than a year ago, so that the glut of free credits cannot now continue long or go much further.

TOLEDO, Jan. 21. -- The Rev. Father Patrick O'Brien of the Good Shepherd Church, who recently presided at a pro-Boer mass meeting here, to-day made public a lengthy letter written in reply to the open letter of Herbert, Cardinal Vaughan, Archbishop of Westminster, London. This action was taken despite efforts of priests and laymen to have the reply, which quotes Catholic theology at length against the Cardinal's utterance, suppressed.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 21. -- There was a narrow escape from a fight at the First Baptist Church to-day, and it is expected there will be some lively sessions of the church in the near future. Miss Ida Davies whispered to a girl friend during the service.
LORENZO MARQUES, Jan. 21. -- A dispatch from Gaberones, undated, says:

William Coloe, a printer, twenty-three years of age, lies in the J. Hood Wright Memorial Hospital, with his right leg broken and experience enough to last him for the rest of his life as to dumb waiters as a means of approaching one's room in the upper story of a flat house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Shearman's excellent letter in your issue of the 17th inst. upon the merits of the controversy between the Transvaal and Great Britain, which has issued in the present war, does not mention one point of considerable importance in itself, but still more us illustrative of the Boers' ideas of justice.

MAGNOLIA SPRINGS, Fla., Jan. 22. -- With fair weather the West Coast golf tournament opened to-day, while the number of entries was smaller than looked for. It included the names of Willie Smith of Chicago, present open champion, and George Low of Dyker Meadow, Brooklyn. The event had been changed to an open one to include amateurs and players who are here from Jacksonville, Kissimee, and other places.

Dr. Loomis, however, admitted that Dr. Douglass, who attended Barnet, is well known as a pathologist, a careful man, and of good reputation. Dr. Douglass's testimony was a justification of his diagnosis of the case as one of diphtheria.

"The Surprises of Love," the new piece which took the place of the esteemed "Miss Hobbs" at the Lyceum Theatre last evening, begins with a situation suitable for burlesque or operetta and culminates in a perversion of the famous incident in Feuillet's "Roman d'un jeune homme pauvre."

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Gen. Buller has reported nothing of his operations on Monday, and official and press intelligence leaves the British bivouacked Sunday night on the ground they had won after two days' fighting. The War Office turned everybody out of the lobbies at midnight. Apparently Lord Lansdowne was as much without news all yesterday as other persons were.

Although Contractor John B. McDonald did not post $1,000,000 in cash yesterday in accordance with his announcement to Controller Coler last Friday, no doubt was expressed by city and rapid transit officials that he will do so within the next few days, and, in addition, will qualify in the $1,000,000 and $5,000,000 bonds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Senator Pritchard (Rep., N.C.,) to-day called up his resolution relating to the proposed amendment to the Constitution of North Carolina, which, if adopted, it is alleged, disfranchises a large class of voters of the State.

The Barney-Sheldon syndicate has sold, through Collins Collins, to William. H.S. Wood, the lot, 20 by 100.5, on the south side of Fifty-second Street, 100 feet west of Madison Avenue, adjoining the lot Recently sold to Robert Olyphant. Henry Lane Eno is the buyer of the thirty-foot lot on the Fifty-first Street side of the orphan asylum block, 192.6 feet east of Fiftn Avenue.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- A large and select public attended, yesterday afternoon, the first performance of Padre Hartmann's new oratorio "St. Peter," given in the great Church of St. Carlo al Corso, under the leadership of Signor Enrico Bossi, the well-known composer, organist, and Director of the Academy Marcello of Venice.

Economists and thinkers will be interested in Senator STRANAHAN'S defense of his Joint Committee Tax bill and in his penetrating forecast of its probable operation. We quote what he has to say about the proposed tax of one-half of 1 per cent, on mortgages:...

Theodore Bacon, a well-Known lawyer and politician, died yesterday in his home in Rochester. He had been ill for several weeks with a nervous disorder, and the end was not unexpected. He was born in New Haven in 1834. He was the son of the Rev. Leonard Bacon, who was for fifty-seven years pastor of the First Congregational Church of New Haven.

-- There be people who do not give much weight to the opinions of JOHN RUSKIN in practical matters, but there are others who either do or pretend to, and among them are a good many of the folks who induige in sweeping condemnations of war, simply as war, and without making any allowance for the motives of the fighters on either side.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 22. -- One of the most pathetic cases on record is that of Mrs. Arthur Frazee of 6 Hopeton Terrace, who has waited for six years vainly hoping for the return of her adopted son, who has been held by Dr. John Thelberg of New York. Mrs. Frazee has made a living since her husband's death, in 1882, by carrying on a lodging house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is all wrong. We are not running Augustus Van Wyck as our candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, nor are we launching any boom for ex-Gov. William J. Stone of Missouri. We are for the nominee of the Democratic Party, with a hope that the trust issue will be the chief plank in that party's platform.

The public hearing yesterday in the large meeting room of the Trunk Line Association to consider protests against the revised freight classification which went into effect the first of the year, called forth so large an attendance and so many protests, written and oral, that it was found impossible to conclude the hearing in a day and an adjournment was late in the afternoon, taken until to-day, when further protests will be presented.

Inherent, illogical hate for England, aided by amazing ignorance concerning foreign politics, as well as foreign civilization, must be the explanation of most of the Anglophobic articles that are appearing in the journals of Continental Europe. Suppose that for a long period all European news, save the bare announcements of great events, were withheld from the American public.

Count Boni de Castellane and his wife the Countess, who was Miss Anna Gould arrived here yesterday from France on the French Line steamship La Bretagne. The couple have not set foot on American soil since their marriage, five years ago. They have come back, they say, that the Countess may see her brothers and sister.
LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The Daily Chronicle has received the following, dated Jan. 22, 4:15 P.M., from Spearman's Camp:

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Alderman M.T. Cuff of this city arrived home this morning with the body of his brother, Attorney John F. Cuff, who died on Friday night at Suwanee Springs, Fla. Mr. Cuff went from Danbury last Wednesday in response to a telegram announcing his brother's Critical condition.

A story that reads like a chapter from such a work of fiction as "Kidnapped" was told to Magistrate Mott, in the West Side Police Court, yesterday by, Arthur Magnet, a boy of fourteen years, who, through the Gerry society, charged Dr. John T. Thelberg, a well-known blind practitioner of this city, with assault.

Ex-Senator John Potter Stockton of New Jersey died yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Hanover, Fifth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, from heart disease. He had lived there sines last October. On Sunday night he was taken suddenly sick while walking near the hotel.

The public school teachers received checks for their December salaries, yesterday day afternoon. At the Controller's office it was said that the increases under the Ahearn law in Brooklyn aggregate $292,123.30. The estimate of the Brooklyn School Board was $303,294, or $11,170.64 too much, which, in the Controller's opinion, is a moderately good guess.

PARIS, Jan. 22. -- The trial of twelve Assumptionist Fathers began here to-day before the Correctional Tribunal. It is alleged that they were involved in the so-called Royalist and anti-republican conspiracy. The court was crowded, and a number of ladies were present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The ex-slave pension swindle has taken deeper root and spread further than had been supposed. even by Government officials, The delusion that the United States Government is about to pension all the persons who were in slavery before the civil war is a fixed belief throughout the Southern States, thanks to the ingenuity with which the men behind the scheme have fostered it.

AN OLD WILL PROBATED. -- The will of George W.M. Briggs, which was recently admitted to probate by the Surrogate, had no full attestation clause, but it appeared by the last words of the instrument itself -- which was all in the handwriting of the testator -- that it was published and declared by him to be his last will and testament, and was signed, sealed, and delivered on Jan. 9, 1863.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The debate on the Raines law repeal resolution soon developed into an interchange of personalities between Assemblyman Harburger, the introducer of the resolution, and Assemblyman Rogers of Broome County, the Chairman of the Assembly Committee on Excise.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 22 -- The new application for an injunction by Thomas F. Ryan against the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad and others, which was set for hearing in the United States Circuit Court here to-morrow, was to-day, by Judge Waddill, continued and set for hearing on Friday. Feb. 2.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note your editorial in this morning's TIMES advocating the adoption of the Standard voting machine for use in this city. This machine is so constructed as to be applicable only to party column ballot, which ballot-reformers are unanimous in condemning as entirely vicious in principle.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Senator Timothy D. Sullivan will introduce on Wednesday a bill for the repeal of capital punishment. A similar bill has already been introduced in the Assembly by Assemblyman Maher.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The Kneisel Quartet of the Boston Symphony Orchestra gave its second concert of the season tonight in University Hall. The quartet was made up of Franz Kneisel, first violin; Karl Ondrick, second violin; Louis Snencenski, viola; Alwin Schroeder, violoncello. The assisting artist was Prof. Ludwig Breitner, who has been playing with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in New York City.

"The Standard Oil Company is reaching out in an entirely new direction down in our State," remarked Col. Seriven of New Orleans, while chatting at the Hotel Rivers. "Three or four different times during the past year they had prospecting parties going over the turpentine territory of our State, a field that has never been developed to any extent, compared with what has been done in the Carolinas and Georgia.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 22 -- Francis T. F. Lovejoy's resignation as Secretary of the Carnegie Steel Company, it was asserted to-day, was caused by a bid on steel work for the New York Rapid Transit $35,000,000 tunnel. Other changes are likely to be made by Andrew Carnegie.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- On Wednesday there is to be another caucus of the Republicans of the Senate, when another effort will be made to bring about a reorganization of the clerical force of that body. Owing to the declination of several candidates offered by Mr. Platt from the State of New York, and the discovery that Gen. J.S. Clarkson was not acceptable, excuses have been made for postponements of the reorganization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Office of the Governor of Havana, Havana, Jan. 18, 1900. Permit me to reply to your courteous and considerate article of Jan. 13, the critical part of which, however, as I believe, is based upon some misapprehensions of fact.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- In the case of the State of Missouri versus the State of Illinois, involving the petition for an injunction against the Chicago Drainage Canal Trustees, the United States Supreme Court to-day decided to permit the Attorney General of Missouri to file his bill making the summons to the defendants returnable April 2.
Does not the Rev. Dr. HILLIS think that 7 per cent, is rather a small proportion of fact to fiction in the statements of a clergyman?

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- The attention of State Superintendent of Public Instruction Skinner was called this morning to the trouble in the new public school at Piermont, where some of the Catholic parents living in the district object to the form of religious exercises which take place when school opens in the morning, on the ground that the services are not of a non-sectarian order.
If the simple-minded and inexperienced fathers of the Republic could have had a prophetic vision of PAYN they would have viewed their work with a good deal less complacency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Mr. Turner (Dem., Washington.) addressed the Senate to-day on the Philippine question. He said in part:

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Consolidated Gas Company, which was held yesterday at the company's offices in Irving Place, was a stormy one. While the old Board of Trustees was upheld for its work during the past year, including the cutting of the gas rates and the union with the New York Gas and Electric Light, Heat and Power Company, there was considerable opposition manifested by the minority interests.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 22. -- Dr. Howard A. Kelly, Professor of Gynecology in the Medical School of the Johns Hopkins University, was bitten on the third finger of the left hand by a large rattlesnake to-night. He was exhibiting the snake to a number of students in the course of a lecture.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have noticed the appeal in behalf of the Hamilton Memorial trees by Maud Scofield Beeson in your issue of the 21st inst., and similar ones to much the same effect from time to time.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Asemblyman Minton of New York offered a resolution prohibiting the employment of Italian cheap labor on the construction work of the proposed new $35,000,000 tunnel for Greater New York. The introducer endeavored to have the rules suspended for action on his resolution, but Mr. McKeown of Kings objected and it went over one week under the rules.

ALBANY, Jan. 22.-- A new report regarding the Payn situation is in circulation here to-night, and while everybody professes to know nothing definite about it, it is asserted on all sides that "it sounds probable."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The Senate Committee on Puerto Rico and Pacific Islands listened to additional statements of delegates representing the Chamber of Commerce of Puerto Rico to-day. All urged freedom of trade between the island and the United States, saying it was necessary to the rehabilitation of Puerto Rico and would be largely beneficial to their sugar, tobacco, and fruits.

FORT SCOTT, Kan,, Jan. 22. -- County Attorney Shephard, addressing the Court today regarding the lynching Saturday night of the Mecks brothers, said the officers were the people's servants, and that the people had simply taken the enforcement of the law out of their hands. He said he could not censure them for it.

It seems to be time to remind American constituencies that statesmen who are still "ferae naturae" are no longer useful, or even inoffensive, in the public life of the United States. It was not always thus. It was not so many years ago that Senator FRYE of Maine was demanding, either on the stump or in interviews for publication, an immediate war with England.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22. -- Miss Minnie Drexel Fell, daughter of Mrs. Alexander Van Reasselaer, was married at noon to-day to Robert Kelso Cassatt, son of Alexander J. Cassatt, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, Camp Hill.
ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- In the House to-night Assemblyman Bramley introduced a resolution sympathizing with the Boers in their struggle against English invasion. It was laid over for one week. It reads:

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- In the stock market today weakness and strength were exhibited at one and the same time, making in all an irregular market, which was neither hot nor cold. Boston and Montana opened 2 points up at 272, and advanced to 279, reacting to 273 on buying by brokers who represent the old crowd in this specialty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A decision was rendered in the United States Supreme Court to-day in the case of Harry W. Dickerman against the Northern Trust Company. This was a bill in equity filed in the Circuit Court for the Northern District of Illinois by the trust company against the Columbia Straw Paper Company to foreclose a trust deed on thirty-nine papermill properties situated in nine different States.

Though yesterday's stock market was dull, it was strong. All day long the speculators waited for South African news, counting confidently upon reports of British victories, and advices which came from financial authorities in London encouraged optimism, though of tangible foundation for British success nothing was actually provided.

The trial was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court, Special Term, Part VI., before Justice Bischoff, of the action brought by Joseph W. Pullar, through his attorneys, Benjamin Loeser, for the annulment of a contract by which he transferred property valued at $50,000 to ex-Gov. Thomas M. Waller of Connecticut and Alfred R. Page, at the Imperial Hotel, on the night of Oct. 14, 1897.

We give place, with pleasure, to Gen. LUDLOW'S explanation of his action in the cases of two scurrilous newspapers in Havana. Undoubtedly the explanation puts a different color upon the incident in several particulars from that which was given to it by the press accounts.
BERLIN, Jan. 23. -- Mme. Melba has the grip, and the concert arranged for to-night was postponed.

Evidently there is "nothing proven" as yet, by the advance of Gen. BULLER'S forces, as to their ultimate success. What can be paid with decisiveness is that the British have abandoned the tactics with which they began the campaign. These tactics proceeded from a contempt for the enemy which has cost them very dear.
The special election for Member of Assembly in the Thirty-first District turned defeat into victory for the Republicans. Samuel Scott Slater received a majority of 852 votes.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Jan. 23. -- The Glasgow steamer Ardandhu, on her first trip on a new line from Now London to Halifax and thence to Havana, was sunk by the Metropolitan liner Herman Winter, Boston for New York, off Robinson's Hole, Vineyard Sound, early this morning, and two men of a crew of thirty-one were lost.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 3/4@60 1/2. There were no sales.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- At the opening of to-day's session of the Senate Mr. Turley (Dam., Tenn.,) reported from the Committee on Privileges and Elections a resolution on the case of former Senator Quay. The resolution follows:

Milton H. Teator, a policeman connected with the Mercer Street Station, Capt. Chapman's command, was transferred to the East Twenty-second Street Station by order of Chief Devery last Saturday night, for the good of the service." This is the Usual information vouchsafed to the public when the Chief decides on transfers.

TRENTON, Jan. 23. -- Mr. Garrison (Rep.) of Morris introduced a resolution in the Sense to-day tendering the freedom of the State to William Jennings Bryan, who is to speak in Jersey City to-morrow night. Messrs. Benny and Abbett resented what they termed the ridicule the resolution contained.
Andrew J. White, the well-known politician, died yesterday at his home, at 6 Mount Morris Park West.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The New York State Museum has issued a statement to those interested in ornithology. It requests the co-operation of those interested in securing information to be incorporated in a bulletin on the birds of New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Charles P. Bacon, attorney for Abram Kling, appeared here to-day and conferred with Gov. Roosevelt. He brought copies of n letter which he says was sent by him to Frederick D. Kilburn, Superintendent of Banks. In this letter, which he made public, he reiterates the charge of criminal action against the State Trust Company.

No Increase in activity appeared in the market for outside securities yesterday, but some improvement in prices resulted from the day's trading. Again, Standard Oil was the stock that attracted most attention, but other issues to some extent shared its strength and ended the day with substantial net gains.

At a meeting of the Directors ou the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad to be held to-day D.O. Mills will he elected a member of the board. Some time ago Mr. Mills was approached on the matter and was asked if he would allow his name to he presented. His reply was in the affirmative and his election to the board will follow today.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- The Board of Aldermen of this city last night directed the Committee on Street Lighting to immediately investigate the cost and practicability of the city establishing a lighting plant and furnishing lights for street use and for commercial purposes. The project has the unanimous backing of the Aldermen, and in his last annual message Mayor Sutherland strongly urged the establishment of such a plant.

It is a pleasure to recognize that the German official procedures upon the seizure and detention of German ships by British cruisers have had nothing in common with the crassly ignorant talk of a large part of the German press upon the same subject. Count VON BUELOW'S statement in the Reichstag was quite unexceptionable, from the point of view both of international law and of international comity.

"Broadway to Tokio," the new-scenic and terpsichorean spectacle, a combination of operetta, burlesque, "vaudeville," and ballet, was produced with unmistakable success before a great crowd of spectators at the New York Theatre last night. The words, which are frequently amusing, were written by Louis Harrison and George V. Hobart, and the new music, which is lively and melodious, was composed by A.B. Sloane and Reginald De Koven.

CAPE TOWN, Jan. 23. -- The American women resident here held a reception at the Mount Nelson Hotel to-day. Lady Churchill and the entire staff of the American hospital ship Maine, Col. Stowe, the United States Consul, and other prominent Americans were present. The Governor, Sir Alfred Muner, proposes to visit the Maine, whose arrival here has aroused great interest.

Charles E. Schuyler Co. have sold for Le Grand k. Pettit the southeast corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Second Street, 75 by 100, to a builder, who will erect thereon a seven-story apartment house.

In the North Side National League last night, the North New York, Belvidere, ana Knickerbocker teams each won and lost a game. The Knickerbockers made the best average of the night and should have won two games. The team, howeyer, missed a number of easy spares in the second game, Scores:
LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The following dispatch from Gen. Buller, dated at Spearman's Camp, Jan. 23, was posted to-nignt:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The Shipping bill, which is still before the Senate Committee on Commerce, and which is also being considered in a committee of the House, begins to be talked about by its advocates as if there might be some doubt about getting it through the House. In the Senate it is assumed that it will have little difficulty.

Total transactions on the Stock Exchange still make relatively small figures. The public continues to hold aloof and Stock Exchange business is confined almost exclusively to the professional transactions of room traders. Among such speculators sensationalism is the one factor sought for; and so it is that extraordinary tales touching South African war affairs get attention and are counted as influence.

Capt. John K. Waring, Second Infantry, having been found by an Army Retiring Board physically incapacitated for active service by reason of disability incident to the service, is relieved from active service as a Major of infantry from Nov. 15,1899.

BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- In the market to-day the selling of long Arcadian continued, and it brought a further shrinkage of 3 points in its market value to 13 1/4. Arcadian was not the only soft spot. The whole group of coppers showed more or less of weakness. Montana was back to 270. Butte sold at 47 and 4S.

William Jennings Bryan put in another busy day at his apartments in the Hoffman House yesterday. From early in the morning until late in the evening a constant stream of callers, including personal friends and political admirers, surged through his room. For several hours he was in consultation with representatives of the Chicago Platform Democracy.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The question of who will succeed Louis F. Payn as Superintendent of Insurance and the time when Gov. Roosevelt will send a nomination to the Senate is the all absorbing topic here tonight. The situation is full of doubt, and the air is filled with rumors. The Governor declines to discuss the matter, and no one seems to know what he intends to do.

From the progress made in the trial yesterday of Roland B. Molineux there appeared to be more than usual justification for the announcement made by Assistant District Attorney Osborne that he would rest the case of the people to-day. His failure to finish his case heretofore, when promised, he has attributed to the developing of additional evidence and to the time consumed in cross-examination by Mr. Weeks.

BOER HEAD LAAGER, Ladysmith, Monday, Jan. 22. -- A battle has been raging along the Olivier's Hoek Road since Saturday between the Boers under Pretorius and 6,000 British. The fighting is in full swing at Spion's Kop. The Boers under Botha and Cronje have been sent thither.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23. -- The final function of Yale's social week, the climax of the Yale junior promenade, was held to-night in the Second Regiment Armory. Besides the students and graduates present, there was a big delegation of the University Faculty in attendance with wives and daughters.

It is probably true, as the gossip of Albany has it, that PAYN has given Senator PLATT to understand that if he is driven from the Insurance Department by votes that the Senator can control, he will make the life of the Senator very uncomfortable. In the face of such a threat, the Senator may feel extremely puzzled.

The body of Ying Hong, Grand Master of the Chinese Order of Lun Gee Tong in the United States and Canada, is on its way to this city from Toronto, where he died Saturday. The body will lie in state at the New York headquarters of the society, at 16 Peil Street, until Friday, when the funeral will be celebrated with a great feast.

Nobody who was unfamiliar with New York politics would ever suspect from the appearance or the behavior of W.J. BRYAN that he was not meeting the flower of the local Democracy on the occasion of his present visit. He puts up at a hotel where the Democrats have established their headquarters in the great political contests of the past.

-- No really good dog story was ever received, with such chilling indifference from our readers as was that recently presented in this column about the suburban collie Leo, who every day signals by leaps and barks the moment when his master takes the train for home at the Grand Central Station, some fourteen miles away.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- For three hours this afternoon the members of the Cities Committee of the Senate listened to arguments for and against the three emergency bills introduced in the Senate by Messrs. Ford, Grady, and McCarren to relieve the existing condition of affairs in Greater New York's schools, and especially the boroughs of Richmond and Queens.

We have received a considerable amount of literature in a convenient form for extensive circulation giving the arguments of the commercial travelers and hotel men with reference to trusts as an issue in the approaching Presidential campaign, and we published yesterday morning an enthusiastic letter from an official of the organization contributing this literature to the enlightenment of the voters.

FRANKLINVILLE, N.J., Jan. 23. -- Mrs. Mary Haskell of Needham, Mass., is dying here as a result of injuries she received last night at the hands of a burglar who entered the home of her sister, Mrs. Ellen Dennett. Mrs. Dennett is a widow and lives alone. She is credited with having considerable money about the house at all times.
The dinner given by John W. Keller, President of the Democratic Club, in honor of William J. Bryan, took place in the main dining room of the clubhouse last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Stephen B. Elkins has been "boomed" for Vice President. The mention of his name for that office, and the assertion that Senator Hanna has a most kindly feeling for the Senator from West Virginia, but thinks that he is better fitted for the floor of the Senate than he is to preside over that body, has been publicly made.

John H. Stephens, twenty-five years of age, of Mariner's Harbor, S.I., while on his way home early yesterday morning was attacked by two highwaymen. He was seriously injured and robbed of $100 in cash and his gold watch and chain.
LONDON, Jan. 23. -- At the opening of the new Town Hall at Chatham to-day, Lord Rosebery, referring to the war, said:

The men who represent minority stock-holders of the Consolidated Gas Company are determined to put up a good fight before they surrender their determination to get the company's affairs managed in their way. One suit at least will be brought on behalf of some of these stockholders to annul the vote taken at the stockholders' meeting of Monday, and answer one may be begun later.

The reading of a communication from City Superintendent Maxwell and Auditor Cook in regard to teachers' salaries led to a heated discussion at the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday afternoon. The document was dated yesterday, and was as follows:

The South, it should be remembered, is just now experiencing an exceptional period of prosperity. The cotton crop has afforded a reasonable profit to growers, for the reasons that prices have ruled higner than last year, the cost of raising is less than formerly, and the utilization of the seed for oil and cake has added materially to Southern resources.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Louis F. Peyn has been beaten in his fight to retain his place as State Superintendent of Insurance. For the first time since the fight began his friends are disheartened, and they no longer claim that Mr. Payn will finally balk the Governor's attempt to place another man at the head of the Insurance Department.

BOSTON, Jan. 24.--A local paper to-day published an interview with President Eliot of Harvard, in which he reiterated the statement which he made in a recent magazine article that the Jesuit colleges teach to-day the same as they did 200 years ago; that they had made no progress, and that with the exception of Georgetown University, their graduates were not admitted to the Harvard Law School wihout examination.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- State Superintendent of Banks Kilburn stated to-day that he had nothing to say relative to the demand of Attorney Bacon that he take charge of the State Trust Company, made on behalf of Stockholder Kling. He further said that he had not seen the letter addressed to him by Mr. Bacon until he saw it in the newspapers.

Archbishop Corrigan has appointed the Rev. William Lavingston, chaplain of the House of the Good Shepherd, pastor of St. Mary's Church at Newburg, N.Y., to succeed the late Rev. Dr. McGlynn. He will begin his ministry there on Feb. 1.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Gov. Roosevelt has decided to send in an emergency message to the Legislature to-morrow, asking for the passage of the amendments to the rapid transit law suggested by Controller Coler. Senator Stranahan and Assemblyman Davis will introduce the bills, which will be passed at once, probably.

The second of the preliminary athletic contests for the Banks' Cups was held yesterday afternoon at New York University. The events included pole vault, 175-yard dash, and three-quarter-mile run. In both track events new records were established, Denchfield covering 175 yards in 20 1-5 seconds and Trede running the three-quarters in 3 minutes 39 4-5 seconds.
PARIS, Jan. 25. -- The Figaro publishes this morning a fresh cablegram from Count Boni de Castellane to M. de Rodays, its editor, to which it appends the following:

Is W.J. BRYAN afraid to talk about free silver in New York? Is he willing to appear openly as a mere trimmer, adapting his principles to the views of the communities he visits? At his home m Populist Nebraska he insists that the 16-to-1 issue will be made prominent in the Presidential campaign.

BOSTON, Jan. 24. -- The market, while narrow, was not lacking in steadiness, and stocks when traded in were firm generally. The prospect that the Commonwealth will sell its holdings of Fitchburg Railroad common stock to the Boston and Maine caused an advance of $10 in Fitchburg preferred to 125, nearly 1,500 shares selling in the morning dealings; later there was reaction to 118.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the "special" to your paper dated Baltimore, Jan. 16, which related to the statues of Marylanders to be placed in Washington, I beg to be allowed, as a descendant of none of the parties under discussion, but as a lover of justice, to correct a mistake of your correspondent which makes a vast difference in the view to be taken in the present situation.

Walter S. Johnston, President of the State Trust Company, speaking of the efforts of Abram Kling, and his attorney, Charles P. Bacon, to cause the State authorities to take action against the Trust Company, said yesterday:

Capt. Oberlin M. Carter of the United States Engineer Corps, who was convicted by a court-martial of frauds in connection with the Savannah River and Cumberland Sound improvement, now a prisoner in Castle Williams, Governors Island, and who has been sentenced to a term of six years at Fort Leavenworth, must serve out that sentence unless the action of his counsel shall change the present situation.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- John Morley, addressing his constituents this evening at Forfar, made but little reference to the present aspects of the war in South Africa, confining himself chiefly to a renewal of his indictment of the "policy which led to hostilities."
ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The Senate Committee on Cities has received the following communication from President Low of Columbia University:

No wonder that London should have been all day yesterday in a fever of excitement and suspense. Gen. BULLER had telegraphed the day before that WARREN had gone far enough to get himself to an "impasse" from which he could deliver himself only by a direct attack upon the key of the Boer position.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- "Mr. Croker," said a New York Democrat to-night, "will not take part in any of the controversies about Bryan or the platform for 1900.

A report in Wall Street yesterday that the Carnegie Company has the contract to furnish to John B. McDonald the steel for the rapid transit tunnel was not confirmed by Mr. McDonald. The report, which came in the way of a publication, says:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The members of the National Board of Trade called at the White House this morning and paid their respects to the President. Gov. Stannard, the Chairman pro tem., speaking in behalf of the board, delivered an extended address to the President, in which he outlined the desires and purposes of the board, cocluding in these words:

Yesterday was not a particularly gay day, and was filled with incidents more than events. The afternoon was devoted to "at homes," and the most notable of these informal receptions were given by Mrs. James M. Varnum, Mrs. Alexander T. Van Nest, Mrs. Lewis F. Whitin, Mrs. J. Fred Pierson, and Mrs. Willard S. Brown.

HAVANA, Jan. 24. -- A complete report of the vital statistics of Havana for 1899 has just been issued. The deaths show an apparent excess over the births of about 4,000. Gen. Ludlow says, however, that a great many births were not recorded.

The Executive Committee of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York will meet in this city to-day. Presidents of various up-Stats savings banks, as well as those of the local institutions, will be present at the meeting to discuss the proposed mortgage tax law, which provides for a tax of one-half of 1 per cent. on mortgages.
"If the handsome landladies would only get rid of their star boarders they would not have so much trouble with their husbands," said Magistrate Brann, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday.

Trading yesterday in the market for outside securities was broader and somewhat more active than on the previous days of the week, but prices were more irregular, and among the net changes for the day were several substantial net losses. As a whole, however, the market showed considerable firmness, and in some quarters where bear attacks were made final figures showed little sign of the efforts to reduce prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Mr. Carter, (Rep., Mont.,) Chairman of the Census Committee, made a partial report of the conferrees on the bill conferring additional authority upon the Director of the Census. The partial report was agreed to.

Noting the reference to the lack of politeness on the part of certain savings bank clerks in Brooklyn referred to in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, a woman with accounts in a couple of savings banks in the city comes to the defense of the receiving tellers at the city savings banks with a statement that she never receives from them anything but the most courteous treatment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The resolution offered yesterday by Mr. Pettigrew (Silver Rep, S.D..) calling upon the President for the report of Gen. John C. Bates concerning the treaty made with the Sultan of Sulu was considered. The resolution recited the salaries paid to the Sultan and his officials and inquired what fund they were paid from and what services the officials rendered.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Jan. 24. -- Horace Boies, as the Democratic nominee for President, is the suggestion of S.H. Bashor. Those who know the close relations existing between the two men regard the declaration as a practical announcement of his candidacy by Mr. Boies himself. In discussing the question to-day, Mr. Bashor said:

The Bicycle and Automobile Show at Madison Square Garden attracted fully 15,000 devotees of the "silent steed" yesterday.
