From the viewpoint of an artist, the vast arena presented a better balanced picture than ever before, while from the point of view of a mechanic, the exhibit of wheels and automobiles is by far the most important that has ever been held.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The arrival of ex-Consul Charles E. Macrum in Washington from Pretoria is expected to solve some puzzling questions. It is admitted about the State Department that there will be no surprise if it should turn out that he has become a citizen of the Transvaal and that he left Pretoria for the purpose of reaching the United States as a consular or diplomatic representative of President Kruger.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Word was received to-day of the tragic death in South America of Ervin Hopkins, Jr., son of Ervin Hopkins, a veteran member of the Chicago Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The Senate Democrats held a caucus this afternoon and came to no resolution. They discussed many propositions in a desultory manner, principally touching upon the subjects upon which the party has been splitting apart for several years. The discussion brought forward no issue that promised to draw the party together against the common foe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If anti-imperialism gets no harder "hit" than you, with the aid of Senator Davis, gave it in to-day's TIMES, it will remain the liveliest corpse of which history has any record, simply because it is based upon the immutable and enduring principles of right and justice, which are so clearly and forcibly enunciated in the Declaration of Independence and in the Constitution.

Richard E. Mott, who was for ten years Deputy Clerk of the Board of Aldermen, died yesterday morning at his home, at 307 West Forty-seventh Street, after an illness lasting ten months. Death was due to Bright's disease. Mr. Mott was born in the old Twenty-second Ward in 1844. He was educated in the Forty-seventh Street Public School and the Free Academy.

STAMFORD, Jan. 24. -- On his way to New Haven William J. Bryan stopped here long enough to make a speech at the Town Hall, which was filled. Most of these were men, and many of them workingmen who had been allowed an hour off to hear Bryan.

One woman is dead and two Others are in Roosevelt Hospital suffering from severe burns as the result of a fire which started yesterday afternoon in a boarding house kept by Mrs. Anna Smith at 415 West Fifty-seventh Street. The victim was Natalie Miles, nineteen years old, who succumbed to her injuries last night in the hospital.

It seems to be clearly indicated from Albany that BOSS PLATT has made up his mind that he can no longer afford to carry Henchman PAYN, and that he will accordingly drop him. That announcement will be received with some gloom by reformers who hold that any real reform must begin with the "downing" of PLATT, and that anything short of that is illusory.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- A duel was fought yesterday at the village of Maisons-Laffitte between the well-known sportsman M. Jacques de Bremond, owner of the race horse Holocauste, which stumbled and broke his pastern at the English Derby last year, and a young clubman named Perier, partner in a champagne firm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent utterances of those who are trying to form a Government for Hawaii throw light on the annexation proceedings, and, incidentally, on all the plans for the management of our new possessions and dependencies. There is a distinct scheme to make them "white men's countries."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Representative Levy to-day presented a resolution in the House, the purpose of which was not at once apparent upon reading the paper. It called upon the Secretary of War for information concerning the expenditures that have been made on the long bridge across the Potomac.

MANZANILLO, Cuba, Jan. 24. -- Governor General Wood, with his party, arrived here at noon to-day on the Ingalls and spent three hours this afternoon in inspecting the city, which, according to a census taken with considerable care since the American occupation, has a population of 14,000. He expressed himself as greatly gratified with the police record, which showed only two cases untried.
The January meeting of the Fire Underwriters' Eastern Union has been called for to-day at the rooms of the Down-Town Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It appears quite natural that your correspondent, A.T. Mahan, should speak advisedly of "the Boer war controversy." In fact, I believe he is the author of "English Sea Power in History." And while he knows the greatness of England on the sea, he confesses he does not know the facts of the Boer war as a lawyer.
ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The report of the State Commissioner of Excise for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1899, shows:

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 24. -- William J. Bryan arrived here this afternoon. Contrary to plans at first announced, he was driven to the City Hall first, where a reception was planned for him. After a brief rest, Mr. Bryan, accompanied by Alexander Troup of this city, Homer S. Cummings of Stamford, and Philo S. Bantell, also of this city, repaired to Music Hall, where fully 2,000 people awaited his coming.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The second day's debate in the House in the Roberts case was less dramatic than that of yesterday. The galleries were almost as crowded, but the women were less demonstrative. Mr. Roberts was not present during the day. Had he been he would have heard the most scathing excoriation of the Mormons ever delivered upon the floor of the House.

Through the quick wit of a woman, a man believed by the police to be an experienced burglar was caught in the five-story apartment house at 202 West Eighty-second Street last evening. Mrs. Charles Herdling, who lives on the top floor, is the heroine of the adventure.

BOSTON, Jan. 24.--A proposition submitted by Gov. Crane to the Executive Council to exchange the 50,000 shares of the common stock of the Fitchburg Railroad held by the State for $5,000,000 in fifty-year 3 per cent. gold bonds of the Boston and Maine Railroad, was unanimously approved this afternoon.

DENVER, Jan. 24. -- The Colorado Editorial Association, just adjourned, has stirred all Western newspaper publishers to action by adopting resolutions demanding of Congress that it repeal the tariff on wood pulp and all materials entering into the manufacture of white print paper. The resolutions adopted are broad and far-reeaching.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Jan. 24. -- Either the proprietors or representatives of all leading circuses and menageries in this country are in attendance at what is probably the first menagerie auction ever held in America. Walter L. Main, owner of a large show, is going out of business on account of ill-health, and is going to travel abroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Gen. Otis reported to the War Department to-day that the western coast of the Island of Panay is now open for trade, and that the coast of Laguna de Bay and the neighboring sections of the country will also be opened to unrestricted traffic by the end of the week. He also reports several minor engagements with the Filipinos, in which the American arms met with the usual success.

The Molineux trial was adjourned yesterday because of the sickness of the tenth juror, Manheim Brown, who was laid up with rheumatism. Mr. Brown was in considerable distress on Tuesday, and when he left court was compelled to take a cab from the Criminal Court Building to the Eighth Avenue car line by which he reached his home, at 219 West Forty-fourth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As some of your contributors seem to really believe the somewhat sweeping generalization that no fortune of a million dollars could be honestly come by, it may be well to call their attention to the case of the late Daniel S Ford, the owner and publisher of The Youth's Companion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Commander Richard Wainwright, who was in charge of the Gloucester, the yacht Corsair, at the battle of Santiago, was presented a sword of honor and a silver service by a committee representing the citizens of the District of Columbia in the Columbia Theatre this afternoon.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 24. -- A.L. Wolff of the Kansas Midland Road to-day telegraphed the company's attorneys in this city from St. Louis that the Directors of the road had authorized the extension of the line from this city to Denison, Texas. The line will run southeast from this city through the McAlester (Indian Territory) coal fields, and from there to Denison.
MADRID, Jan. 24. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 75.90. Gold was quoted at 28.35.

When the suit against ex-Gov. Waller of Connecticut and others, brought by Joseph W. Pullar, to set aside a contract made under alleged duress by which he transferred a $50,000 interest in the will of his second wife, Johanna, to ex-Gov. Waller and Alfred K. Page, was resumed before Justice Bischoff in the Supreme Court yesterday, the plaintiff's first wife, Mary T. Pullar, took the stand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The Republican caucus of the Senate to-day decided definitely upon the reorganization of the elective officers of that body and nominated Charles G. Bennett of New York for Secretary to succeed William R. Cox, and Daniel M. Ransdellof Indaina for Sergeant at Arms to succeed Col. R.J. Bright.

The stock market yesterday waited upon news from London bearing upon the progress of the campaign in South Africa. And for the reason that nothing definite was forthcoming speculation halted and transactions were comparatively few. Operators were not inclined further to extend their commitments pending the results of a battle which might turn the speculative tide as readily against them as in their favor.
LONDON, Jan. 26. -- According to a special dispatch from Shanghai it is reported there that Emperor Kwang-Su has committed suicide.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Brigham H. Roberts gave out the following statement to-night in relation to his exclusion: Our griefs are past when remedies are ended, By seeing the worst which late on hope depended.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Senator Wagner has introduced a bill designed to fix upon an individual of a corporation the penalty for compelling street surface or elevated railway employes to work more than ten hours per day.
LONDON, Jan. 26. -- William St. John Brodrick. Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, speaking last evening at Newark, said:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25. -- A meeting of the National League baseball magnates, which has been in session here for two or three days past, and as to which, up to to-day, no definite information was obtainable, came to an end this afternoon and all but Messrs. Brush and Hart started for their homes.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 25. -- A fearful explosion of dynamite occurred in the yards of the Jersey Central Railroad at Ashley, a suburb of this city, to-night, which resulted in the killing of Frank McLaughlin of Mauch Chunk, aged twenty-seven; Michael Bird, aged twenty-two, of Ashley; William Buckley of this city, aged twenty-eight, all brakemen, and fatally injuring two unknown men.

A person signing himself "Democrat" takes more than a column of the space of The Evening Post to say a lot of undisputed things in a most solemn way. In his artless, prattling fashion he warns the Gold Democrats of New York that they can do W.J. BRYAN no harm by snubbing him.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- The abduction of Mary Meyers, eight years of age, from the home of Mrs. Mary Jonicka, 123 Locust Street, was reported to the police to-day and officers are making every effort to find the child. A mysterious, well-dressed woman is said to have enticed the girl away.

Yesterday's stock market was narrow and irregular. Less than a quarter of a million of shares made up the total Stock Exchange transactions, and market values fluctuated but slightly--announcement of British victory in South Africa exerting no influence whatever upon security market sentiment.
LONDON, Jan. 17. -- The following account of the battle of Colenso, written by an infantry officer present, was received by to-day's mail:

There was considerable speculation yesterday over the fact that John B. McDonald, the successful bidder for the tunnel contract, had asked President Alexander E. Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission to grant him the extra ten days allowed under the terms of the advertisement for bids in which to deposit his $1,000,000 in cash or securities and the $5,000,000 construction bond.

Prof. Paul Wiallard, a teacher of singing at 485 Fifth Avenue, was defeated on Wednesday in a suit brought against him by ex-Gov. Levi P. Morton in the City Court before Judges O'Dwyer and a jury. The action was brought to recover $330 alleged to be due for rent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- People who are not acquainted with the workings of the Pension Bureau imagine that its fraud-detecting machinery works chiefly against veteran soldiers. Many veterans have this idea themselves, and think of the Pension Office as at work to discover frauds on the part of pensioners.
The Manhattan Life Insurance Company has issued a statement relative to the alleged encroachment of its building on the adjoining property of George Crocker, at 70 Broadway. It is in part as follows:
Ruland Whiting have sold for Diedrich Luhrsen to an investor the four-story brick building 192 William Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Senator Ahearn today introduced in the Senate' a new school bill, which is understood to have the approval, not only of the school teachers and authorities, but also of Gov. Roosevelt, who believes that any amendment to the Ahearn law should come from Senator Ahearn.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Gov. Roosevelt to day transmitted to the Legislature a special message accompanied by the report of the Canal Commission. The Governor concurs with the recommendations made. The report was referred to the Finance Committee on motion of Senator Raines. The text of the message is as follows:

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was more active and prices were more irregular than on the previous day. A number of issues were traded in, in the majority of which closing quotations showed some recession from Wednesday's final figures, while a few stocks closed with substantial net gains.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- A German gentleman of high political and social status, who is fully empowered to express the views of Count von Buelow, the Foreign Secretary, upon Anglo-German relations, made the following statement to-day:

Mr. David Bispham, the popular baritone, gave last night what he called a "request" song recital at Mendelssohn Hall. He had prepared a programme of songs asked for by his admirers. His plan had at least one merit. It insured favor for the music offered. It was hardly to be expected that it would produce a programme of a symmetrical kind.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 25.--The State Democratic Committee set the pace for the Democracy of other States to-day by making Col. William J. Bryan its choice for the Presidency in 1900. This action was taken by the committee while Col. Bryan was on his way to Harrisburg from New York to attend the meeting and confer with the party leaders.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- In consequence of the death of the mother of the Empress at Dresden this morning, to-day's Court reception and all ceremonies in connection with the Emperor's birthday were abandoned.

MANILA, P.I., Dec. 19, 1899. -- There are other hospitals in the City of Manila, but the Santa Mesa Hospital, three miles out from Manila, is the main "field" hospital. It stands on high ground about a quarter of a mile from the Pasig River. The location is superb, as the hospital almost always has the benefit of a slight breeze.
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Senator Ellsworth today introduced a bill granting additional powers to street surface railroads in the extension of their lines.

The question of the canals is a question of the share of the State of New York, and particularly of the City of New York, in the commerce of the continent and of the world. The movement of trade is necessarily along the line of least resistance, and on the route that offers the least resistance of every kind the movement will proceed.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio. Jan, 25. -- Gertrude Ricksecker has committed suicide at Oberlin College by drinking an ounce and a half of laudanum. She had worried a great deal of late over her studies, and it is thought that she became temporarily insane.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your obituary notice of the late Mrs. Roswell Smith, nee Anne Goodrich Ellsworth, you allude to her as the author of the improperly called "historic telegraph message," "What hath God wrought?" and it as being the first telegram ever sent from Baltimore to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Secretary Hay was to-day advised by the United States Minister at Peking of the result of the convocation of Chinese notables there yesterday, his statement being that Pu-Chun, fourteen years of age, had been appointed heir apparent. It will be noticed that Mr. Conger does not indicate that the heir apparent has been named as Emperor, nor that he is to ascend the throne immediately.

Who could have expected to see the day when The New York Tribune, of all newspapers in these United States, should class the present President of the same with "some thoughtless Republicans"? Yet that is, in effect, what our esteemed contemporary had been doing. The characterization is made out of a survival of zeal for the once sacred tariff.

Lieut. Col. George M. Dewey, a charter member of the New York Cotton Exchange, and a veteran of the civil war, died Wednesday of consumption at St. Gabriel's Sanitarium, conducted by the Sisters of Mercy, at Gabriels, Franklin County, N.Y. The news of his death was conveyed in a dispatch from the Sisters of Mercy to President Thomas M. Robinson of the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Gen. Otis's cabled report under to-day's date received this morning indicates that Gen. Schwan is conducting the campaign in the south of Luzon with the greatest energy. He located what was probably the last considerable force of insurgents remaining in one command, and to-day's report shows that, with small loss to himself and heavy loss to the enemy, he managed to completely dissipate this force, probably beyond the possibility of reconstruction.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25. -- Count Leo Tolstoi, in an interview published in the Russki Listok. denounces the war in South Africa as showing the "sordid and soulless commercialism that rules the world." He says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Robert B. Roosevelt, who has shown a remarkably fair and candid spirit throughout this discussion, although he is not willing to answer any of my questions, puts one to THE TIMES, which, with your leave, I will answer in your place. He says: "You denounce Oom Paul, calling him an 'uncommonly adroit and sordid old reprobate.'

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Parkhurst, as reported in THE TIMES of Monday, takes a very pessimistic view of matters Christian and political in the great metropolis. His plaint has a hopeless tone about it, which is truly melancholy. Hear him:

Maps prepared in the Department of Bridges showing what lands must be taken in providing for the approaches to the East River bridge about to be constructed between Pike Slip. Manhattan, and Washington Street, Broklyn, indicate that the bridge will cost in the neighborhood of $23,000,000, inclusive of the expense of construction, estimated at $15,000,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The New York City Rapid Transit bill amendment passed both branches of the Legislature this morning with but little opposition. The bill is to expedite the ratification of the thirty-five-million-dollar contract.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in to-day's issue, "The Commercial Travelers and the Trusts," is in line with your usual clear perception of affairs. Your correspondent, William Hoye, to whom you refer, represents himself only -- possibly, of course, some others. He by no means represents the so-called Eastern traveling man.

The Marlborough Hotel dining room reverberated last night with the music of the bagpipe, and was gay with the colors of the plaid. The strollers in Broadway cutside caught echoes of the pipes droning the air of "Cock of the North," and heard 150 strong voices join in the chorus of "Auld Lang Syne."

New York business men who are abreast of the times will make short work of the report of the Schieren Commission on the decline of the commerce of the Port of New York. They will read with assenting minds these three paragraphs:
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners is sending to the Assessors of cities and towns the following circular relative to the operations of the franchise tax law:

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- The developments regarding the Fitchburg property naturally had sympathetic influence to-day on Boston and Maine, Central Massachusetts, and Rutland, all of which made slight gains. Rutland preferred was up 10 points on the bidding quotation to 80, while the best offering price was 81 1/2.
LONDON, Jan. 25. -- The War Office has issued the following dispatch from Spearman's Camp, dated Jan. 25:

The Crescent Athletic Club's hockey team defeated the team from the New York Athletic Club at the Clermont Avenue Ice Skating Rink, Brooklyn, last night, in one of the most closely contested games of the season. The final score was four goals to three, several additional minutes of play being necessary to change the tie of 3 to 3 which existed at the end of the second half.

The teams of the New York and the Knickerbocker Athletic Club met in the Athletic League at the New York Athletic Club alleys last night. The result was a clean string of victories for the New Yorks. They made an average of 928 for the three games, and are new tied with the Roseville Athletic Association team for first place in the tournament.
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Assemblyman Fancher has introduced a bill to provide for the compulsory education of Indian children on the Allegany and Cattaraugus Reservations.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 25. -- The will of Dempspy Butler, a negro who died two weeks ago, was admitted to probate to-day. It contains forty-two bequests, many of which are charitable.

DOBBS FERRY, Jan. 25. -- August Kallmeyer of Irvington was assaulted by an unknown man with a sandbag early this morning on Main Street, in this village. He is badly hurt, and it is feared there is a slight fracture of the skull. Robbery was not the motive and it is generally believed that the young man was a victim of some one jealous of him on account of the success of his love affair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When one man uses the letter of another as a peg on which to hang an argument, the least he can do is to quote with reasonable accuracy. Your correspondent of this morning, Mr. H.R. Ostrom, says Capt. Mahan "confesses he does not know the facts of the Boer war as a lawyer."

The official inquisition which Uncle Sam undertakes every ten years to determine the size and condition of his family, natural and adopted, will begin on June 1 of this year. This inquisition will. be known as the Twelfth Census of the United States. Blanks for the population schedule are now ready and explanatory blank forms are being issued by the District Supervisors to the trained corps which will undertake the work.
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day sent the following communication to the Legislature:
A paper purporting to be an authentic review of the Philippine revolution, written by Emilio Aguinaldo, the insurgent leader, appeared yesterday in The Springfield Daily Republican.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Money (Dem., Miss.,) replied to the speech of Mr. Pritchard (Rep., N.C.,) relating to the proposed amendment to the Constitution of North Carolina.

Trolley and cable cars, the sudden stops and starts thereof, the elevated structure in 'Battery Park, the difference between a "Raines law hotel" and a saloon, and the general desirability of reforming the west side, were some of the matters which received attention at yesterday's meeting of the West End Woman's Republican Association, held in the rooms of the West End Republican Club Broadway near Eighty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Robert J. Tracewell, the Controller of the Treasury, has rendered a decision to the effect that common carriers which do an Inter-State business and give "party rates" to theatrical and other organizations must give the same rates to the general public under similar conditions, and also to the Government in the transportation of troops.

John Hays Hammond, who, as a member of the Outlanders' Reform Committee, was imprisoned by the Transvaal Government after the Jameson raid, returned to this city yesterday from a business trip to Mexico, and in the evening was honored by a reception from the Plymouth League, the social organization of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Considerable interest has been aroused by the unusual influence of the Long Island delegation in this Congress. While this delegation does not number any men of National fame in its ranks, it has made itself felt and now has a weight and is received with a respect that have not always fallen to the lot of Long Island delegations.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Henry W. Hill, Chairman of the Assembly Canal Committee, said to-night that the recommendation of the Canal Advisory Commission for a barge canal is one of the most elaborate schemes ever proposed in this State.
SUEZ, Jan. 25. -- Osman Digna, the principal General of the late Khalifa, who was recently taken prisoner by the British, has been brought here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Mr. Chandler, Chairman of the Committee on Privileges and Elections, said he had expected to call up the Quay case this week, but owing to the absence of Mr. Turley, (Dem., Tenn.,) a member of the committee, the case would go over.

Another notable move in the gas war was made yesterday, when at a special meeting of the Board of Directors of the New Amsterdam Company, held at the office of August Belmont, 23 Nassau Street, it was decided to reduce the price of gas from the legal rate of $1.05 per 1,000 feet to 65 cents, the rate charged by the rival Consolidated and Standard Companies.

Instead of being $400 pooter, as "Kid" Miller, the confluence man, intended he should be, Owen McGivney, proprietor of a Raines law hotel at 220 West Eighteenth Street, says he is richer by a $100 bill. Last Tuesday, he says, a stranger came into his place and told him that he was "all right."

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Unless something unexpected happens it is believed that Gov. Roosevelt will send to the Senate next Monday night the name of a successor to Louis F. Payn as Superintendent of Insurance. All signs point to the selection of ex-Senator Francis Hendricks of Syracuse. Who has been agreed upon, it is said, by the Governor and the leaders of the Republican organization.

-- "Anti-medicine faith healers" are treated with entirely commendable severity, and no less commendable common sense, in the current number of The New York Christian Advocate, and it is a notable fact that quite as much of The Advocate's contemptuous denunciation falls upon those whom it calls "The Simpsonites" as upon the followers of more notorious perverters of reason and religion, like "Dr." DOWIE and Mrs. EDDY.
Transfers in the First Artillery: First Lieut. Harry E. Smith, from Battery N to Battery A; First Lieut. Frank W. Coe, from Battery A to Battery K.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- During the year 1899 ten new trust companies were organized in New York State, all but one having their principal office in New York City. Two, the Williamsburg and the Flatbush, have offices in Brooklyn Borough; the others do business in Manhattan. These are the Central Realty and Bond, the City, the Morton, the Trust Company of America, the Bankers', the Merchants,' and the International Banking and Trust.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- In the recent history of Punch, that was published in Literature, a list is given of the various rivals to Punch which have appeared in London from time to time. It is certainly a curious thing that Englishmen seem unable to support more than one paper of the character of Punch.

Yesterday, as is usually the case on a Friday during the season, did not bring much of incident or event in the social world of New York. The cold and blustering weather, which was all the more disagreeable as it followed so abruptly on the unseasonably warm weather of the past fortnight, kept people of leisure within doors, and the avenue and uptown fashionable districts were deserted until the afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The House to-day at 2 o'clock suspended public business to listen to tributes to the memory of the late Vice President Hobart.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- The New York State Republican Editorial Association, composed of editors of newspapers in the smaller cities, towns, and villages of the State, at their meeting this afternoon adopted resolutions antagonistic to the expenditure of $62,000,000 for the improvement of the State canals.

A new title insurance company is organizing to carry on business in this city, but which, it is presumed, will make Brooklyn its principal field of activity. The new company will be chartered by legislative enactment, and with this end in view Assembly-man Joseph Guider introduced at Albany a few days ago a bill providing for the incorporation of the Fidelity Mutual Title Insurance Company.

WRONGFUL CONVERSION OF A LIFE POLICY. -- Rosa and George Lissner, in July, 1890, borrowed $1,100 from Charles Bauer, pledging in writing, as security, a policy on the life of George Lissner in the Mutual Life Insurance Company, and made Charles Bauer their lawful attorney. On Oct. 13 following the policy was surrendered to the company, Bauer receiving $1,494.

"Of the interest we manufacturers take in the proposition to establish a Department of Commerce by the Government, with a Cabinet officer at the head of it, the public has no adequate idea," said the head of one of the largest malleable iron manufactories in this country yesterday. "Publication by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the reports of the Consuls in various parts of the world have perhaps led up to it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--A strange romance lies behind a commonplace looking private pension bill introduced by Senator Joseph V. Quarles of Wisconsin. The heroine, or rather victim of it, is Nellie A. West of Stevens Point, in that State, who has learned in her old age, years after her husband's death, of the deception practiced upon her by him in her girlhood, nearly forty years ago.

On a dreary, wind-swept slope of Evergreens Cemetery the body of Ying Hing, Grand Master of the Lone We Tong Eng Ti. the Chinese Masonic Order in North America, was buried yesterday afternoon with rites that were a fitting ending to a series of scenes which began in Chinatown, and the like of which for strangeness and splendor has not been witnessed in New York in many years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- The news of the death of Fred Roe Pratt, a lawyer of this city, at Manila a few days ago, was received yesterday. His twin brother, Frank Fay Pratt, maintains that an instinctive knowledge of his death flashed quicker than the cable's message to his mind through some strange telepathic sympathy the brothers had known to exist between them for years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with astonishment bordering upon amazement that the writer saw an editorial in this morning's issue of THE TIMES charging Mr. Bryan with silence on the money question and calling him a political trimmer. This charge is puerile and unfounded, altogether unworthy of so valuable a paper as THE TIMES.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As counsel to Senator Stranahan's Joint Committee on Taxation, and in the interest of open and fair discussion, I have the honor to request your assistance in bringing sharply and clearly before the public the true issues involved in the recommendation of the committee as to the taxation or mortgages.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Owing to the closing of the Canajoharie National Bank yesterday by order of the Controller of the Currency at Washington on account of the condition of affairs left by the late President A.G. Richmond, the run continued here to-day on the Farmers and Mechanics', Bank of which Richmond was also President.

A special meeting of the Board of Directors of the Standard Gas Light Company was held yesterday afternoon to receive the resignation of Russell Sage as President. The retirement of Mr. Sage was the direct result of his recent action in disposing of nearly all of his stock in the company, which was declared by other Directors and stockholders, to be an act of bad faith.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Prof. Worcester of the Philippine Commission to-night gave out the following statement:
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 26. -- Announcement was made to-day of an agreement on the Tillinghast bicycle tire patents which amounts to the forming of a tire trust that will include every manufacturer.

The exploit of Gen. WARREN in capturing and then abandoning Spion Kop recalls the tactics of that King of France who "marched up a hill and then marched down again." Gen. BULLER is "sorry to say" that WARREN has abandoned the position, as he may well be. Because Gen. BULLER had already given Gen. WARREN'S authority for believing that the capture of the hill had rendered the Boer position untenable.

The report of the Canal Committee sent to the Legislature by Gov. ROOSEVELT on Thursday is very favorably received by the press of this city, and as this city would have to bear the greater part of the expenditure recommended this is an important fact.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Jan. 26. -- From Noumea, New Caledonia, come the most alarming reports of the ravages of the plague, which has been prevalent there since early in December. There were sixteen deaths during the first ten days following the development of the malady.

News of British war disappointment cut as little figure in yesterday's stock market as on the day previous did favorable news. The market continued narrow and fluctuations were largely confined within the bounds of a single point.

It is possibly not an exaggeration to say that the last of what might be called the old-time booksellers has just passed away in the person of Alexander Williams, who, for many years, was identified with the famous "Old Corner Book Store" of Boston, where, in 1869, he succeeded E.P. Dutton Co., now of this city.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Francis Hendricks of Syracuse, long prominent in the offices of the Republican Party in this State, will succeed Louis F. Payn as State Superintendent of Insurance. Official announcement of this was made to-night by Gov. Roosevelt, who will send Mr. Hendricks's name to the Senate next Monday night.

W. Bourke Cockran has come out in favor of W.J. Bryan as the Democratic nomnee for President. Mr. Cockran still repudiates free silver, but proposes to support Mr. Bryan on the ground of his anti-imperialistic policy solely.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Secretary Hay has sent to Speaker Henderson for submission to the House copies of complaints of the German Government, presented by its Ambassador here. Dr. von Holleben, against the existing customs regulations of the United States applicable to merchandise imported from Germany.

Winter, which has been lingering for several months somewhere out in the wilds of the Northwest until New Yorkers got the impression that they were going to be neglected this year, got into town yesterday morning with a full assortment of plumbers' luxuries ready to do business at the old stand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The reorganization of the Senate is now an absorbing topic among the hundreds of employes about the North wing of the Capitol. Until a few days ago it appeared very doubtful that the reorganization would go very much beyond a change in the offices of Secretary and Sergeant-at-Arms.

It is not pleasant for any American to read that a contested election in any State of the Union is followed by the appearance of "the people," in their primary capacity, to the number of a thousand, with arms in their hands and a willingness to use them.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Dec. 23, 1899, your editor said some unsolicited but kind words of me and my works. A previous introduction to my brethren in the United States was from the critique of my book, "Passages from the Diaries of Mrs. P. Lybbe Powis," in the same paper, of Nov. 4.
Part of on Address Before the Washington Library Association, at Its January Meeting, by A. R. Spofford, formerly Librarian of Congress.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- The Danish steamer Livadia, Capt. Jorgensen, from Hamburg for Philadelphia, before reported ashore at Terschelling and a gale prevailing, has become a total wreck. The crew have been all safely landed.
LONDON, Jan. 26.--An official communication received here from Peking says:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: "Paradoxical as it may seem," said Dr. Emily Blackwell in a lecture last week, "change is the only fixed fact in life! " The truth of this dictum is microscopically clear to the reader of books. Authors come and go, novels have their short hours of life and die, the idol of yesterday is buried and forgotten.

Councilman Stewart M. Brice and Jocelyn Johnson, President Guggenheimer's secretary, had a lively discussion with a cab driver last night over an alleged over-charge, which was finally submitted to the arbitration of the Night Sergeant at the West Thirtieth Street Police Station.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 26. -- Gov. Sayers to-day received a letter from Secretary of War Elihu Root regarding the recent trouble between the negro soldiers at Fort Ringgold and the citizens of Rio Grande City. Judge Advocate General Lieber has held that the soldiers are not liable to answer in a State court for the offense.

To the Editor of The, New York Times: Bearing in mind the fate that befell Senor de Lome for expressing an honest opinion of President McKinley in a private letter to a friend, I have suppressed the name of the correspondent from whom I have just received the inclosed letter. I have only to say that no man stands higher in the estimation of his fellow-citizens in Salt Lake City.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Agreeable to your request in the last SATURDAY REVIEW, under the heading, "Women Among Humorists," I beg to mention a German authoress of highly humorous endowment. Helene Bohlau may be considered the foremost among the younger generation of German women authors.

This biography of Dr. and Prof. Lieber is more than a mere account of his life; it is a thesis upon the work and influence of one of the profoundest scholars and most substantial public counselors that ever was lost to Europe and gained by America.

Capt. Mahan says that he "has done a little editing" in reproducing the nine magazine articles included in his "Lessons of the War with Spain," but the earliest appeared only eighteen months ago, and was written not quite two years ago, and comparison with the original shows that it needed but very slignt revision.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court was occupied during its entire session yesterday in hearing argument upon the appeal of the Manhattan Railway Company from an order made by Justice Nash quashing a writ of certiorari and affirming the action of the Commissioners of Taxes in assessing the company's capital stock for taxation, for 1894 at $15,526,800.

The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company's Directorate was strengthened at a stock-holders' meeting in the company's offices yesterday by the election of the following board: Anthony N. Brady, Clinton L. Rossiter, Henry Siebert, John G. Jenkins, D. H. Valentine, T.S. Williams, H.C. Du Val, F.P. Olcott, Walter G. Oakman, Anson R. Flower, E.H. Harriman, August Belmont, and H.H. Porter.

One of the reforms recommended by the Joint Committee on Taxation is salutary and worthy of support. There is a wellnigh universal agreement, we suppose, that it would be wise to provide, means for raising all the revenue needed by the State by indirect taxation, in order to do away with the scandals of the State Board of Equalization.

BALTIMORE, Jan 26. -- Fourteen men met in the Eutaw House to-night, and formally organized the Baltimore Club of the American Association of Baseball Players. Officers were elected as follows: President -- Philip Peterson; Secretary and Treasurer -- Harry Goldman; General Manager -- John J. McGraw.

MANILA, Jan. 26. -- A dispatch from Sorsogon, dated Thursday, Jan. 25, says Brig. Gen. Kobbe's expedition occupied Sorsogon, Dunsol, Bulan, Logaspi, and Virac. The only resistance was at Legaspi, where five Americans were wounded, and forty-five dead and fifteen wounded Fllipinos were found.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Superintendent White of the Railway Mail Service said today that the United States officials, when they learned of the prevalence of smallpox at Spokane, had directed that all mail leaving that place should be disinfected, but as the disease has not appeared between Spokane and the Canadian border, it has not been deemed necessary to fumigate the mail after it leaves the infected city.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: "A Seeker After Knowledge" in your issue of this date takes considerable pains and more pleasure in ridiculing "When Knighthood Was in Flower," one of last year's successes, and asks for on explanation of what he calls a phenomenon -- the immense sale of that book.

Two of the games in the Harlem League last night were closely contested. In the first game the Empires turned out the best score of the night, 970, easily defeating the Premiers. The second game, between the Boulevards and Premiers, was close throughout, the Boulevards winning by three pins.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 26. -- Mrs. John D. Rich, the Chicago woman surrendered to Mexico to be tried for the murder of her husband in Juarez last May, was adjudged guilty to-day by the Mexican court and sentenced to serve fourteen years in prison. The finding of the court was read to the woman in her cell, she being unable to attend court owing to a broken leg.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--The Gazette to-day publishes a number of dispatches from Gen. Buller to the War Office, inclosing reports from Gens. White, Hildyard, Methuen, and other Generals regarding their various operations, but containing nothing later than the record of occurrences to the middle of December.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The following had already been written when your issue of Saturday last came into my hands. Your little citation, "Women Among Humorists," is so irritating that I place the manuscript at your disposal as an answer to the "literary person" quoted.

Found A "real" woman humorous writer I take pleasure in referring to Miss Marietta Holley of North Adams, N.Y., as a "real woman" and a "professedly" humorous writer. She is well known as the creator of Samantha Allen, Betsy Bobbett, Her half dozen books are "permeated" with fun and humor quite equal to Mark Twain or Bill Nye and others.

The ninth annual dinner of the New York Association of Alumni of Syracuse University was held at the St. Denis Hotel last evening. Chancellor James R. Day, who spoke on the future of the university, said that the only thing needed by Syracuse in order to "secure the most magnificent opportunity of any university in America is a million dollars of endowments at once."

TROY, Jan. 26. -- Archie S. Mull, convicted of the murder of Melville B. Lord of Nassau, was this morning sentenced by Justice Chester to die at Dannemora Prison during the week commencing March 4, 1900.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Louis Marshall of New York appeared before the Senate Committee on Commerce in behalf of the Eastern Extension and Australasian Telegraph Company, the British company which now operates the cable connections with the Philippines, and stated that he was present to submit a "caveat," or notice, of prior rights.

When did business, as it is understood in its proper sense, begin in New York? Was it when exchanges were made -- so many beads or shells being worth so many beaver skins? Was there ever a corner in siawant or shell currency? There might even have been a Mr. Bryan in those primitive times. The editor of "Financial New York" says that there was.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Admiral Watson has cabled the Navy Department an account of the part taken by the navy in the campaign now being made in Southern Luzon by Gen. Schwan. The Admiral's dispatch refers to the engagement, or rather series of engagements, which took place along the eastern and southern shores of Lake Taal a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce to-day gave a hearing to the representatives of a number of business organizations throughout the country in support of the bill to amend the Inter-State commerce law. The first statement was made by Mr. Frank Barry of Milwaukee.

The New York Unitarian Sunday School Union, at afternoon and evening sessions in the parish house of All Souls' Church, yesterday, discussed "The Sunday School and the World of Affairs." In the afternoon Rev. W.I. Nichols of Brooklyn read a paper showing now Sunday schools can co-operate to advantage in the work of local charities.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In a recent issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW the statement was quoted that women were destitute of the sense of humor, and that you might search the annals of English literature in vain to find a single humorist of the gentler sex.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: "Search the list of women writers from Mary E. Wilkins to Mrs. Aphra Behn, and you will not find a single professedly humorous writer." Therefore, "Most, if not all, women are entirely devoid of a sense of humor." And, "It may be that women are deprived of the humorous sense in the same manner that a person may be born without sight or hearing or speech."
LONDON, Jan. 17. -- The following account of the Modeler River fight was received to-day from one of the Argyle and Sutherland Highlanders.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE REVIEW of Dec. 30 appeared a "Call to Arms" from "C.H.M.," one of the lonesome anti-Hugoites. With Mr. Newberry's "gem of humor" shining on his shirt front, he marches straight out before the vast army of Hugoites and throws down his lionskin gauntlet, the while he brands the enemy as caitiff hypocrites, yet kindly admitting that there are some "who genuinely admire 'Lea Miserables.' "

In all estimates of the life work of John Ruskin particular emphasis must be laid upon a side of his character perhaps not generally recognized -- his great influence for good as regards the value and importance of books and reading, which was not at all his life work, which lay in the direction of art, architecture, and kindred subjects.
The passing of Ruskin and Blackmore, so near together in point of time, of the same generation and the same race, suggests a study of the sharp contrast that their attitude toward life exhibits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce to-day reconsidered the Nicaragua Canal bill, which had been reported with an appropriation of $140,000,000, and changed the appropriation section so as to make $10,000,000 available, with authority to contract for the entire excavation, construction, defense, and completion of the canal at a total cost not exceeding $140,000,000.
LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The Standard this morning alludes to the significance of Dr. Leyds's doings in Paris, remarking:

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- In a letter expressing his regret at his inability to be present at the annual meeting and dinner of the Republican State Editorial Association, held here to-day, Senator Thomas C. Platt said:
SUBJECT -- The First Disciples of Jesus. John, i., 35-46.

It is still necessary to remind readers who send letters for this department of THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW that their full names and addresses should be given. We are pleased to note the wide interest taken in the department and are glad always to receive our readers letters, but their contributions should be brief and should deal with books or value and interest. Members of the Catholic Club, comprising a sub-Committee of the Educational Legislation Committee, are holding meetings at which school legislation is being discussed. The proposed Educational bill, prepared by the Statutory Revision Commission, was the special subject of discussion Thursday night.

The fourth public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society took place at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The programme consisted of the overture to Wagner's "Flying Dutchman," Louis Saar's dramatic scena for contralto and orchestra, entitled "Ganymed," Beethoven's fourth symphony, three songs with piano accompaniment -- Schubert's "Der Kreuzzug," Schumann's "Der arme Peter," and Franz's "Er its gekommen" -- and Goldmark's overture to "Prometheus."

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Another school teachers' salary bill for New York City was introduced in the Assembly to-day by Assemblyman Fallows, which differs somewhat from the one introduced by Senator Ahearn yesterday. It provides for a different schedule of salaries, to take effect Feb. 1, 1900.

The President of the New York Central Railroad is quite justified in coming to the defense of the policy of his company against the "frontal attack" of the Schieren commission, and he shows more tactical intelligence than the commission in seeking, as recommended by the American Attache to Gen. METHUEN a "way round."

A.E. Gallatin, in an edition of one hundred beautifully printed copies, the work of the De Vinne Press, has compiled and published a list of Aubrey Beardsley's drawings, intended to supplement a list published by Leonard Smithers of London, in 1897, prepared by Mr. Vallance, and accompanying an album of Beardsley drawings.

The Count and Countess Castellane spent an uneventful day yesterday, there being nothing more exciting during their forenoon and afternoon than receiving and paying a few social calls and a limited shopping expedition, this last by the Countess. The Count's day was singularly free from annoying cablegrams from Paris editors, and he was consequently in a placid and contented frame of mind.

Songs led by Musical Director Herbert R. Thurston and college yells given with full strength enlivened the thirty-sixth annual dinner of the Dartmouth College Association of New York, held at Delmonico's last evening. Ex-Justice William N. Cohen, President of the association, presided. On his right was the Rev. Dr. William J. Tucker, President of Dartmouth College, and on his left ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 26. -- To-morrow a vote will be taken in the House of Representatives that is expected to foreshadow with some accuracy the strength that both sides will be able to muster when the Gubernatorial contest comes up. The vote will be on the contest brought by Van Meter, Democrat, for the seat now held by Berry, both being from Fayette County.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Another school teachers' salary bill for New York City was introduced in the Assembly to-day by Assemblyman Fallows, which differs somewhat from the one introduced by Senator Ahearn yesterday. It provides for a different schedule of salaries, to take effect Feb. 1, 1900.

The President of the New York Central Railroad is quite justified in coming to the defense of the policy of his company against the "frontal attack" of the Schieren commission, and he shows more tactical intelligence than the commission in seeking, as recommended by the American Attache to Gen. METHUEN a "way round."

A.E. Gallatin, in an edition of one hundred beautifully printed copies, the work of the De Vinne Press, has compiled and published a list of Aubrey Beardsley's drawings, intended to supplement a list published by Leonard Smithers of London, in 1897, prepared by Mr. Vallance, and accompanying an album of Beardsley drawings.

The Count and Countess Castellane spent an uneventful day yesterday, there being nothing more exciting during their forenoon and afternoon than receiving and paying a few social calls and a limited shopping expedition, this last by the Countess. The Count's day was singularly free from annoying cablegrams from Paris editors, and he was consequently in a placid and contented frame of mind.

The announcement was made in this city yesterday that Waldo O. Morse and J. James R. Cross of Yonkers, the two living of the three members of the Palisade Commission appointed in 1895, have resigned, at the request of Gov. Roosevelt. The resignation, it is said, was directly brought about by a notice from the Governor asking them to appear before him and show cause why they should not be removed.

During the past week Miss SUSAN B. ANTHONY has resigned her place at the head of the organization for the promotion of woman suffrage in order to devote her time and energies to raising a fund of $1,000,000 -- a sort of endowment of the movement to secure its continuous active agitation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 27. -- The young women at Vassar are highly pleased with an address made several days ago by President Taylor before the students of the Halstead School in Yonkers. They regard it as a distinct indorsement of the athletic side of student life at Vassar, to which much attention has been paid of late, and which has transformed the general appearance of the students.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 27. -- The first actual test of strength between the Republican and Democratic forces in the Goebel-Taylor contest came to-day, and by the admission of the Republican leaders, proved a victory for Goebel. The Democrats claim the result of to-day's struggle as decisive, with the Republicans, although admitting a defeat, declare that they will fight to the finish, and have still strong hopes of retaining Gov. Taylor in his seat.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 27 -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day in the case of the Mercantile Trust Company against the Pittsburg and Western Railway Company, A. Foster Higgins, John Harsen Rhoades, and Charles W. Baker filed a petition asking to be made defendants.

A letter sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES serves again to draw attention to the great need in this city for homes for old and indigent women who have been used to relined surroundings. A number of such homes exist, but the majority of them, hold but a very few inmates each, and all are full and have long waiting lists.

Why should Wall Street worry; why should American business interests be adversely affected by the course of the British-Boer war? Effects are shown, the popular Wall Street theory as to current Stock Exchange dullness and market value nervousness being that events in South Africa are damaging here.

Magistrate Hogan yesterday held an examination in the charge of criminal libel brought by Henry W. Ranger, the landscape artist, against David C. Preyer, editor and publisher of The Collector and Art Critic, published at 13 West Twenty-eighth Street, for an article published in the issue of that paper dated Jan. 17.

Over in the neighborhood of Carlton and Park Avenues, Brooklyn, last night Mrs. Rose McMahon was hailed as a heroine. Mrs. McMahon, who lives in an apartment house a 55 Carlton Avenue, proved herself a woman of nerve and muscle yesterday afternoon by capturing an alleged burglar single handed and dragging him off by the scruff of the neck into the clutches of the law.

Louis F. Payn, Superintendent of the State Insurance Department, it was said yesterday, realizes that he has to go, and at last believes that his successor will be named by Gov. Roosevelt to-morrow night and will be confirmed by the Senate at an early day. Mr. Payn was not in a talkative mood when he visited the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 31. -- Many sensational rumors have been current in St. Petersburg during the past fortnight concerning the international political situation. The one most worthy of comment is that Great Britain and the United States are on the point of joining forces with the Triple Alliance.

CANAJOHARIE, Jan. 27 -- Those who knew G. Richmond say the report sent out from Fort Plain that the late President of the Canajoharie National Bank, who died at his mother's home in New Woodstock, Madison County, Nov. 13, had not died, but is still alive, is untrue. Mr. Richmond's body is buried in the Canajoharie Falls Cemetery.

LONDON, Jan. 28.--Spenser Wilkinson, whose articles on the war situation have attracted such attention here and abroad, wrote the following review of the situation last night, after the War Office had given out a telegram from Lord Roberts, dated at Cape Town Saturday, saying there was no change in the situation:

READING, Penn., Jan. 27.--The Rev. Henry D. Strodarch, a well-known Lutheran clergyman, was found this morning lying unconscious in the City Park. An ambulance was summoned and he was taken to the City Hall, where he died.

UTICA, Jan. 27. -- The story that Ruth Conde, daughter of Swits Conde of Oswego, and Sergeant Major George B. Thorn of this city were married here yesterday by Rev. W.B. Coleman, rector of St. George's church, is true. Mr. and Mrs. Thorn are at the Butterfield at present, and intend remaining there a few days.

Parke, Davis Co. improved its position in the Wholesale Drug Trade Association tournament by winning two games at Reid's alleys yesterday afternoon. The best game of the series was the fourth, between Colgate Co. and Seabury Johnson. The latter team had a lead of 28 pins when the final frame began, but the Colgate Co. team, by good strike bowling, won out by a pins, Scores:

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, in a talk at his home last night on the moral and political conditions in New York, expressed himself to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES as in favor of permitting the sale of beer during certain hours on Sunday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- At the Marquette Club to-night Gen. Pingree of Michigan and Charles T. Yerkes debated the municipal ownership and operation of street railways. Gov. Pingree said in part:

As Governor of his State, George E. Lounsbury of Connecticut hasn't had much of a chance to attain prominence. He now proposes to secure a little bit of a niche in the Temple of Fame. To that end he contemplates calling a National convention of two delegates from each State to meet in New Haven some time in March or April to decide upon a National flower, which shall be recommended to Congress for adoption.

Fire and water did damage to the extent of $25,600 in the eight-story brick and granite fire-proof building, 15 to 19 West Fourth Street and 263 to 271 Mercer Street last night. The fire was discovered by Policeman Upham of the Mercer Street Station, who happened to be at Mercer and Fourth Streets, when he heard glass falling.

The husband is the head of the family and the dignitor persona. As there must be a home, the husband has the right to fix it where he pleases. The wife's domicile merges in that of her husband. If the husband proposes a radical change of the place of abode, it must be in good faith and upon reasonable cause, or otherwise a place might be selected entirely unsuited to the wife.

Wall Street is spending its energy in talk; of action there is practically none. Total transactions on the Stock Exchange last week fell short of a million and a half shares -- just about the average per day during the corresponding week of last year.

Aside from the knowledge that we are gradually being brought nearer the time of bright blue skies and warmer weather, the month of February has no very particular interest to us from an astronomical standpoint, for, with the exception of the zodiacal light that about this time makes its appearance in the western horizon, there are few features of special interest to attract us.

In point of large transactions and those to Which any general interest attaches the last week has made a rather poor showing. There has been a fair volume of business, however, and even if it has followed somewhat conventional lines, this is only to be expected and need not be made the basis for any apprehension as to the character of the Spring market.

NAAUPORT, Dec. 11. -- The loyal Colonial has been awakened to a peril of British supremacy that he has hitherto underrated with the assumption peculiar to the Britisher, especially the British Colonial. The apathy of the Cape is now past, and all loyal classes are rousing themselves for even heroic sacrifices to implant firmly and forever Crown control from the Cape to the Zambesi.

That is an interesting and a pregnant question which our London correspondent raises in his cable letter printed to-day. It is the question how far the Continental Governments really desire, or in their own interests ought to desire, to have Great Britain defeated or humiliated. We are prone to regard the Continent, which calls itself "Europe," as, for some purposes, a single political entity, having a common sentiment and a common interest.

The Metropolitan Street Railway Company is experimenting with new air motors for use on the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Street lines. The experiment will continue for several months in the hopes that a thoroughly satisfactory system may be found eventually. Ever since the present air motors have been in use there has been more or less trouble.

The failure of the Municipal Civil Service Commission to furnish eligible lists for promotions in the Fire Department has, according to Chief Croker, interfered with the workings of his department. About thirty officers are needed, and they rank from a Deputy Chief down to assistant foreman.
She stands as the years pass by her and views the grand parade, As it sweeps, resistless, onward through sunshine and through shade.
The physician who is attending Manheim Brown, the sick Molineux juror, said last night that his patient was improving, and would, he thought, be able to enter the jury box again to-morrow morning.

An ex-naval officer gives a hint for cooking fish and oysters which is perhaps more necessary for people on board ship in all sorts of waters than for people living on land with sea food supposed to come from places where the sanitary conditions are what they should be. The ex-officer says that while he was in service all fish and oysters cooked on board ship were cooked with a silver coin.

Charles Giles Foster, who was formerly the owner of The Kansas City Journal, and afterward conducted a special advertising agency in Chicago, died in the latter city yesterday. Mr. Foster became totally blind four years ago. Mr. Foster was a prominent Mason. He was born in Rochester, N. Y., Dec. 14, 1821.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The fifteenth annual dinner of the Gridiron Club was given at the Arlington Hotel to-night, and, like its predecessors, was the most successful event of the season. The club is composed of forty Washington correspondents, who each year give a number of dinners and make the last Saturday evening in January a notable occasion, as it is the anniversary of the organization.

The public hearing on the application of the Long Island Railroad Company for its tunnel under the East River will be heard in the Council Chamber to-morrow at 2 P. M., after about ten months of waiting on the part of the company, a delay which various members of the Council committee with which the application has slumbered interpret differently.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- The news of the death of Philip D. Armour, Jr., at Montecito, Cal., came as a complete surprise, as it was known that when he left for the Pacific Coast he was in the best of health. A telegram from a member of the party that accompanied young Mr. Armour from Chicago when he went to California to join his father conveyed the information to J. Ogden Armour, a brother.

"Tannhauser" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, end in the evening Gounod's "Faust" was given. At both performances the house was crowded, and it seems that by announcing exclusive single appearances of prima donnas Mr. Grau has found a plan by which the Saturday evening performances at popular prices may be made profitable.

WEST POINT, Jan. 27 -- There are a number of deep places in the Hudson, as every one is aware, but few know that spots ranging from a depth of twenty to twenty-four fathoms are frequently met with south of the Highlands. The deepest spot in the river is just north of West Point, where a fifty-fathom line failed to touch bottom.

When Harper's Weekly some years ago published a portrait of W. BOURKE COCKRAN as one of the Big Four of Tammany Hall -- an affront to civilization for which it was rebuked in a severe and magisterial manner by The Evening Post -- nobody could have foreseen that within the ensuing decade Mr. COCKRAN would be found twice acting with members of the Republican Party, with intervals of relapse into Democracy.

A Broadway cable car had bumped its way down to a point opposite Barclay Street yesterday morning when, amid the startled exclamations of women, a tall, lank young man slipped from his seat to the floor. His eyes rolled and froth lined his lips. The car stopped, blocking those behind, while all hands aboard held a consultation.

The carnival in Venice will be reproduced at the Arion ball with faithfulness of detail as to color and spectacular ceremony. The ball will be held at Madison Square Garden on the night of Feb. 9. There will be six entrances from the promenade to the dancing floor. Each will be lavishly decorated.

The Society of Friends, with others interested, held a conference yesterday afternoon at the Friends' Meeting House in Rutherfurd Place upon the subject, "Our Responsibility in Regard to the Abolition of the Death Penalty." All those who spoke unanimously condemned capital punishment and no word was spoken in its favor.

Again has the Hotel Rivers, on Broadway, near Forty-second Street, changed hands. Yesterday Col. Rivers disposed of his interest in the house to George T. Putney, who was one of the firm of Green Putney, who managed the house when it was known as the Rossmore. Mr. Green, after Mr. Putney's retirement, changed the name to Hotel Metropole.

First Lieut, John B. Bennet, Seventh Infantry, will report to Lieut. Col. Theodore J. Wint, Sixth Cavalry, President of the Examining Board appointed to meet at Fort Riley, Kan., at such time as he may be required by the board for examination as to his fitness for promotion.

Much is accomplished by the assured appointment of Mr. FRANCIS HENDRICKS of Syracuse to the Insurance Department in place of PAYN. In the words of The Evening Post, which deplores his selection as a "triumph of the machine," he is "a man of unsullied personal character, high business standing, and ambition to make a good record in public office."

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- Excepting that it was lacking in Court fetes, the Emperor's birthday to-day was kept in the usual way. Flags were displayed everywhere, and the papers published congratulatory articles, in which his Majesty was praised as the champion of peace, the promoter of civilization, and the vigorous helmsman of Germany's destinies.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Judge Gibbons of the Circuit Court to-day rendered a decision in regard to the anti-freak law passed by the last Legislature, which prohibited the public exhibition of persons who have become conspicuous through some criminal act or whose deformity is such as to attract pure curiosity.

The discussion of the art of singing which has been in progress in these columns may be said now to have reached the acute stage. In other words, the writer has now come to ground on which he must tread with the greatest caution, for in it are many pitfalls for the unwary. The musical editor of THE TIMES has on several occasions called attention to the fact that he is not a singing teacher.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 27. -- Willie Smith, the open champion for the United States, played phenomenal golf here to-day in the finals of the three days' tournament, thereby winning the purse of $100. He not only beat Harry Rawlins by six up and four to play, but lowered the record established by Rawlins yesterday by three points, making it 72.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Jan. 16 a bill was introduced into the Senate at Albany calling for an appropriation of $200,000 for the purpose of establishing a State hospital for the treatment of incipient pulmonary tuberculosis. This subject should be promptly brought to the attention of the taxpayers through the medium of your valuable paper.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to --

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- It was only a few days ago that Representative Payne of New York introduced a bill providing for the extension to Puerto Rico of the advantages of free trade with the United States, and reciprocal freedom, of trade in the other direction, and declared that the bill was to be passed.

THE report of the Secretary of War for the year 1899 touches vitally the most important needs of the armies and defenses of the Nation. It refers to nearly every essential point, but treats some by inference only. It is, however, the most businesslike and comprehensive consideration of a subject which has been heretofore treated in "spots."

The illness of Miss Nethersole and the postponement of "Sapho" left the first honors of the theatrical week "easy" between "The Belle of New York" and the new ballet spectacle at the big music hall called the New York Theatre. The recurrence of the first-named piece at the Casino kept that house crowded all the week, but by the least effusive and most discriminating audiences ever seen in the abiding place of burletta.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 27.--The experiment of running a Christian daily newspaper for a week will not be the first newspaper venture of the Rev. Charles M. Sheldon, author of "In His Steps." The Topeka Mail and Breese to-day recalled that he edited that paper one week in 1895. He introduced no innovations, nor did he change the tone of the editorial page.

In yesterday's market for outside securities the only stock that attracted much attention was New Amsterdam Gas. The rest of the market showed little change from the closing figures of the previous day, and the total transactions were very small. A little more firmness, appeared, and some few stocks advanced substantially -- in some cases without sales.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some of the letters on public questions printed in THE TIMES are quite as interesting and instructive as the editorials. That of Thomas Conyngton in THE TIMES of last Sunday, (Jan. 21,) in which he criticises a portion of Senator Beveridge's speech on the Philippines, makes the Senator's rhetoric look rather foolish.

The view expressed by the wardens and westrymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in a recent appeal to the members of the congregation for more liberal donations, that "in general a church is entitled to at least 4 per cent. of every man's expenditure," was criticised as unwise by prominent clergymen to whose attention the appeal was directed yesterday.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 27. -- The Post will say to-morrow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The latest official news received here regarding the condition of affairs in Guam, the mid-Pacific possession of the United States, is contained in a report just received by the Secretary of the Navy from Capt. Leary, U.S.N., Governor of Guam. The report is dated Government House, Agana, Guam, L.I., Dec. 7, 1899, and is as follows:

From The Contemporary Review. Considerable comment has been made on the alleged inability of English artillery to deal effectively with the Boer guns. Our field pieces are said to be outranged, to be of inferior metal, and altogether to be outclassed by the weapons of our opponents. A little calm consideration, however, may serve to allay the discontent which has arisen on these points.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- Max Stark, fourteen years of age, was arrested to-day on a charge of homicide. He shot his eleven-months-old brother Ernest Thursday and the little fellow died to-day. Coroner Banning, after making an investigation and hearing Max's story, was satisfied that the baby's death was accidental and the prisoner was allowed to return to his father's home at 141 Herriot Street after promising to appear when wanted.
W.S. James has been appointed Cleveland agent of the Hanover Fire Insurance Company.
In speaking of the teachers' bill, which he introduced at Albany last week. Assemblyman E.H. Fallows said yesterday:
The indoor baseball game played last evening between teams from the College of the City of New York and the Ninth Regiment at the armory in West Fourteenth Street ended in a riot.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 27. -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt and Potter Palmer, Jr., came to Newport to-day and visited the Vanderbilt farm known as Oakland, in Portsmouth, which was bequeathed to Mr. Vanderbilt by his father. Later they inspected several of the cottages which are offered for rental, and it was reported that he had selected one for the coming season.

PARIS, Jan. 27. -- The private secretary of the Archbishop of Paris, Cardinal Richard, says the Prelate's reply to the Premier, M. Waldeck-Rousseau, on the subject of the comments on the Cardinal's visit to the Assumptionist Fathers after the Correctional Tribunal had pronounced the dissolution of the order, was very simple.

AMONG famous satires of London life drawn by the graphic pencil of Hogarth is the well-known print, " Enraged Musician." Various noises of the London streets are concentrated in the figures passing before the open window of a distracted, composer, himself a conspirator against his neighbor's peace.

From The Cornhilll Magazine. "Old Mike and his wife lived in a little cabin on the mountain, one of a type which is happily becoming every day more rare. The walls were of mud, and the floor of the same useful material, with a gutter running down the middle to divide the family apartment from that of the cow and ass, for Mike did not rise to the dignity of a 'harse baste.'

Copyright, 1930. The Associated Press. LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Though criticism of the Government and its methods of handling the war is unabated, it is safe to say that when Parliament meets. Tuesday next nothing serious will result. There will be the usual motions of censure with, perhaps, more than usualy impassioned denunciations of the various departments of the Administration, especially the War and Colonial Offices.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 27. -- The trial of State Senator S.B. Harrell, charged by Col. John H. Whallen with securing money under false pretenses, was begun here to-day. The case grew out of Harrell's charge made at Frankfort that Whallen paid him $4,500 to vote against Goebel in the contest now before the Legislature.

John Brisben Walker bas addressed a letcer to Gov. Roosevelt in regard to what he considers the evils of the present taxation system of this State. He outlines in the communication the principles which in his opinion underlie just taxation. His letter is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The American shippers whose goods were on the British ship Beatrice, seized off the African coast by British Warships, have had news to the effect that the vessel was released six weeks ago, and that the goods which were landed at East London have in large part been sold. Therefore it is believed that this incident is closed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is altogether too much talk about the "under dog" in this Anglo-Boer controversy Carried to its logical conclusion, the inference to be drawn from H.R. Ostrom's letter is obvious. If we should see a burly wrongdoer resisting the attempts of five or more policemen to arrest him, our sympathies should all be on the side of the wrongdoer, because he is the "under dog."

A very few days after my arrival at Maritzburg, at the end of 1875, I was standing one afternoon in the shade of my little house on a hill, anxiously watching the picturesque arrival of an ox wagon laden with my boxes. It was in the very early Summer, and the exigencies of settling in left me no time to worry about the thunderstorms, of which, of course, I had often heard.

"We call ourselves the 'Children of the Microbes.' Pete Murphy doesn't like the name. He says there 'ain't no microbes in his family,' but Pete doesn't understand, and when you explain he isn't very polite. He says just what he thinks instead of agreeing, and then saying he doesn't like a thing after he gets home.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- It is now generally understood that Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee will take a hand in the dispute which threatens to interfere seriously with the success of plans for holding the Republican Convention in this city. Word was received to-day that the National leader had determined to do so, and an early visit to the city will follow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Society is discussing with animation the recent assertion of ex-Secretary Foster that it was a mistake for the United States to create the rank in diplomacy of Ambassador. A writer for The Star, taking up the current gossip and detailing some particulars of it that may have interest outside the capital, discusses them to-day with minute attention to details.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- New York County last year paid $1,980,560 in school taxes, and in the allotment just made received $1,44,887 from the State and $07,268 from the common school and United States deposit fund, making the return to the county $1,242,156, or $747,404 less than it paid. The difference in the sum paid and that received was greater than the sum any other county in the State paid into the school fund.

DUTY AND LIABILITY OF SHERIFFS. -- In June last William V. Malloy, Sheriff of Westchester County, having discharged Susan Slater Weeks from the county jail, where she had been committed by order of the Surrogate, he was adjudged, in a proceeding brought against him by Laura Leggat, to be guilty of contempt of court, and was fined $250.

The Rev. Alexander MacColl of Briarcliffe Manor, N.Y., a young Scotch preacher, told a story in reference to a citizen of his native town at a dinner at the Hotel Marlborough the other night, which shows that contentment is a virtue really existent in some cases.

A cab driver, known as Casey, in the employ of Fred E. Keppler, a liveryman at 164 East Eighty-second Street, fell from the seat of his cab last night, broke his right leg, and hurt his head. He had driven a man and a woman to the New York Theatre, and after his passengers had entered the theatre he took his place in the line of cabs, being known as No. 85.

The long names bestowed upon the horses owned by Hennan and Dave Morris in the last few years have created no small amount of adverse comment among racetrack followers. This criticism has been such that they have decided to give their yearlings names that were intelligible and pronounceable by the humblest enthusiast in the "sport of Kings."

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Jan. 27 -- Gov. Gen. Wood, Gen. Chaffee, and Col. Black arrived at noon after an overland trip from Manzanillo. Gen.
