Demetrio Castillo headed a party of Cubans who went by special train to San Luis and rode from there fifteen miles on horseback to meet Gen. Wood. A thousand persons were gathered at the station to meet the Governor General's party.

From the Gentleman's Magazine. Volumes might be written about the religious sentiment and the superstition of the Neapolitans. I will restrict myself here to a few remarks. Among the poor or criminal classes in Naples it would be impossible to find an atheist or materialist. The worst subjects are often the most devout, and Camorrists are generally found wearing a number of amulets and religious symbols.
From "The Letters of Faraday and Schoenbein." On March 18, 1846, Schonbein wrote to Faraday:

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Some of the afternoon newspapers associated the departure to-day of the new Japanese battleship Shikishima with possible complications in regard to the situation in China, especially as it was announced that the Shikishima would endeavor to traverse the Suez Canal by divesting herself of her armament.

TO the layman it is no doubt something of a mystery how the biologist can feel sure that animals so different from one another as fishes, frogs, or mammals are blood relatives having a common, descent from ancestors that must have lived many millions of years ago.

BOSTON, Jan. 27. -- At the Boston college games to-night in Mechanics' Building in team races Harvard beat Columbia, Bowdoin beat Amherst, Georgetown beat another Harvard team. Cornell beat Brown, Williams beat Wesleyan. Eddie Duffey, Georgetown University, won the 40-yard invitation dash in 0:04 3-5; C. J. Sweeney, Holy Cross, won the 40-yard handicap dash (7 feet) in 0:04 3-5; J. H. Shirk, Harvard, (8 feet) won the 40-yard handicap, hurdles, in 0:05 3-5.

LANDON, Jan. 27 -- "As the fleets and armies of England went forth to consolidate arbitrary power, the sound of war everywhere else on the earth died away. Kings sat still in awe and nations turned to watch the issue."

FISHKILL LANDING, Jan. 27 -- The storage capacity of the Sodom and Carmel reservoirs for supplying New York City with water will be increased 300,000,000 gallons during the coming Summer by improvements which have been ordered by Commissioner Dalton, upon plans drawn by Chief Engineer Birdsall, at comparatively small expense.

Eugene V. Brewster, one of the leaders of the Chicago Platform Democracy in Brooklyn, declared yesterday that that borough was the headquarters of a conspiracy to deprive William Jennings Bryan of the Democratic nomination for President. Mr. Brewster alleges that Hugh McLaughlin wants to have either ex-Justice Augustus Van Wyck or ex-Senator David B. Hill head the Democratic ticket.

Show the average man a new bicycle, and the first thing which, he does is to spin the edals. Hand him an unloaded gun, and he immediately snaps the hammer. The first operation does him no particular amount of rood, but it doesn't hurt the wheel, while the latter bit of playfulness raises the very mischief with firearms.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 1/2@60 1/2. There were no sales.

The friends of Abraham Gruber, the Republican leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District, met in the assembly hall at the southwest corner of One Hundred and Sixth Street and Broadway last night, to express their preference for him in the fight which George C. Austin is making against him with the district leadership as a prize.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Clarke, the counsel of the Stranahan Committee on Taxation, says "mortgages are now taxable by the law of the State" and that "the committee's proposition is to change the rate so as to make it low." He suppresses all mention of the other change which the law makes, namely, that under the Stranahan law mortgages are taxable WITHOUT DEDUCTION FOR DEBT.

The bank statement issued yesterday shortly before the close of the market was, as had been anticipated, a very favorable one. Surplus reserves increased more than $5,000,000. while specie increased $5,154,700, legal tenders $3,689,600, deposits $15,008.000, and loans $7,515,600.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary of the Navy Long said to-night that he had not heard of the story about the destruction of the Maine, published to-day in The New York Herald upon the authority of an alleged spy of the Spanish Government, whose affidavits allege that the destruction of the vessel was brought about by arrangement and by the explosion of a submarine mine operated from Fuerza Battery.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- The election of ninety-nine Senators yesterday resulted in a practical rout for the Nationalists, only three out of their thirty candidates being elected.
A runaway horse belonging to the grocery firm of Stemmermann Rademacher at Broadway and Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn, caused considerable excitement yesterday morning before it was caught by a policeman.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- In his annual report to be submitted to the Legislature to-morrow State Superintendent of Prisons Collins devotes some space to the increase in the number of insane criminals. He says there are now confined at Matteawan nearly 200 more than the hospital was designed to accommodate, it having been built to house 550 patients, while 719 are now crowded into it.

Whether or not Wall Street has "cut loose" from the British-Boer war and its influences is likely to be tested this week. They who hope for stock market improvement are earnestly desirous that such independence can be shown; but not all the authorities are agreed.

Within the past few weeks Dr. PARKHURST has shown a marked tendency to re-enter the field of active political labor, from which he had for a long time almost completely absented himself. He has published in The Independent a strongly condemnatory article on the work of the Mazet committee.

There is a New Jersey clergyman with a well-deserved reputation as a sportsman, who was one of the early frequenters of the Richardson and Rangeley Lake regions, in Maine. His tall, athletic figure has always been seen at the Sportsman's Shows at the Garden, and the Maine guides have always been glad to welcome him, as they knew and admired his skill.

BOER HEADQUARTERS, MODDER SPRUIT, Upper Tugela, Wednesday, Jan. 24, Midnight, (via Lorenzo Marques, Thursday, Jan. 25.) -- Some Vryheld burghers from the outposts on the highest hills on the Spion Kop group rushed into the laager, saying that the kop was lost and that the English had taken it.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Assemblyman Jean L. Burnett of Ontario County, a member of the Public Health Committee, said to-day there was little doubt in his mind that the proposition to regulate by statute the making and disposition of fermented liquors in this State would be brought to the notice of the Legislature during the Winter.

In his very interesting speech before the Lotos Club on Saturday evening, Mr. CARNEGIE made the prediction that the centre of the shipbuilding industry would be transferred to this country, and would be on the Atlantic Coast. He also quoted with approval the statement of the historian GREEN that the home of that interest might be on the Hudson.

Prospects for the speedy erection of the magnificent new Mount Sinai Hospital, which is to cover the entire block bounded by Fifth and Madison Avenues, One Hundredth and One Hundred and First Streets, received the principal attention at the annual meeting, held at the Training School for Nurses, attched to the present hospital in Lexington Avenue, yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The difference of opinion among Republicans about the course to be pursued in dealing with the people of Puerto Rico is admitted by members of the Cabinet as being rather embarrassing.

The question of labor on the rapid transit tunnel which is being agitated by the trades unions of this city came up again for discussion before the Central Federated Union yesterday in the form of a resolution that citizens only should be employed on the work.

It is not surprising that the account given by Gen. BULLER of the withdrawal of his left wing under Gen. WARREN across the Tugela River is received in London with little satisfaction and some impatience and incredulity.

Bad weather materially affected the attendance at the Church of the Eternal Hope, in West Eighty-first Street, last evening, When the Rev. Dr. W.S. Crowe lectured on "Christian Science." Those who were present, however, seemed to enjoy the manner in which he approached the new creed as applied to healing, and more than once faintly audible expressions of approval rippled through the church.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28 -- Not even a cigarette or a selditz powder could be bought in Baltimore to-day. For the first Sunday in many years every cigar store, corner grocery, bakery, and the like were closed UP tight. Few drug stores kept open, and those that did displayed placards informing the public that the soda fountains were closed and that absolutely nothing would be sold without a prescription.

ROME, Jan. 13.--The trial of the brigands and their "accomplices," captured or arrested during the energetic operations against these disturbers of the peace in Sardinia last year, is to take place at Saroari before very long, and bids fair to be handed down in history as unique among modern trials, as far as the numbers of the witnesses and accused are concerned.

When Brig. Gen. Hamilton S. Hawkins, United States Army, retired, reviewed the Seventy-first Regiment last Tuesday night at the armory, after the military ceremonies he met the officers of the regiment and a few special guests in the Colonel's room, and there made some remarks on the campaign against the Spanish in Cuba, and particularly as to the part played by the Seventy-first Regiment.

The recent report of the Colonial Committee of the French Chamber not only gives an illuminating view of the actual working of the French colonial system, but is filled with unhappy indications of its ultimate effect upon the republic maintaining it, and the colonists who are shackled to its principles.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 28 -- The Populists of Texas publicly announce that W.J. Bryan will accept the Populist nomination for President if it is tendered him. A circular letter outlining the plan of action for the coming campaign was issued to-day by Chairman J.H. Foster, who says the propositions he outlines come direct from the national Populist headquarters.

Mrs. Mary Gray Mexia, a niece of Parke Godwin of this city, will testify to-day at Dallas, Texas, in the contest of the will of her husband, Gen. Enrique A. Mexia, a millionaire Mexican soldier and statesman. Mrs. Mexia, according to her own statement, was married to the General by proxy in this city on July 30, 1867.

The weekly statement of the New York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, showed an increase in the reserve of $5,092,300. The banks now hold a surplus of $29,277,975 above the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in the loans of $7,515,600, an increase in specie of $5,154,700, an increase in legal tenders, of $3,689,600, an increase in deposits of $15,008,000, and a decrease in circulation of $342,500.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Jan. 28 -- James Jubb, an Englishman, aged twenty-eight, in a fit of insanity, committed suicide this morning by gashing his throat with a carving knife. It is said his insanity was the outcome of constant brooding on the war in the Transvaal.
Net changes for the week of 1 point or more in the more active securities were:

FARGO, N.D., Jan. 28 -- The trial of the Chinamen, who have been in jail here two or three months awaiting a hearing on the charge of violating the exclusion act, will commence to-morrow. United States District Attorney Rourke has been in Green Bay, Chicago, and other points for some time taking testimony.

LONDON, Jan. 29.--The week has opened with the utmost gloom for the British public, and the reaction is all the stronger because of the high hopes that were reposed in Gen. Buller's turning movement and of his announcement that there would be "no turning back."
BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- An official of the Reichsbank, who was interviewed to-day regarding the financial situation, said:

David E. McClure, twenty-eight years old, who, it is believed, lived in Glasgow, Scotland, died yesterday morning in the Homeopathic Hospital, Brooklyn, from the effects of "knock-out" drops. He also showed evidences of having been beaten. It is believed by the police that he fell into the hands of thieves, who, after dosing and beating him, robbed him of his money and jewelry.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Jan. 28 -- From reports brought by the Hamburg steamer Volumnia it appears that the arrival of the vessel at Tumaco, Colombia, where she touched on the way up, had the effect of saving the place from capture by Colombian rebels. The latter had demanded the surrender of the town, and the Governor was at his Wits' end.
Bishop Satterlee of Washington preached in Trinity Church yesterday morning in support of his plea for the establishment of a National cathedral in the capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Col. William J. Bryan attended divine service this morning at the First Presbyterian Church, on Four and a Half Street, of which the Rev. Donald McLeod is pastor. After the service he went to see William M, Springer, who Mr. Bryan says was "my guardian when I was in Congress."

-- An editorial article in the current number of The Medical Record begins with the following statement; "The announcement made in several British lay journals that Prof. METCHNIKOFF of the Pasteur Institute has discovered the means of almost indefinitely prolonging life, will be received by the medical profession with feelings akin to disgust."

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Jan. 28 -- John Dagel, supposed to be insane from cigarette smoking, last night attempted to murder his mother and sister. Seizing a knife he first attacked his sister, who escaped from him unharmed. He then turned upon his mother and inflicted several long but not deep gashes on her face and body.

Public school teachers eagerly discussed yesterday a report to the effect that at the meeting of the conference committee at the City College last Wednesday there was a lively difference of opinion and a sharp exChange of words.

ROME, Jan. 15 -- After many postponements and delays, Maestro Giacomo Puccini's long-awaited music-drama "La Tosca" was given at the Costanzi Theatre last night in the presence of one of the greatest audiences which have ever filled that theatre. The work was enthusiastically received from beginning to end, amid a constantly increasing amount of attention and admiration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The magnificent home of Thomas Nelson Page the author was thrown into great excitement to-day by the announcement from New York of the elopement of his young step-daughter, Miss Mina Field, and Preston Gibson, son of the late Senator Gibson of Louisiana, and nephew of Justice White of the United States Supreme Court.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The anti-English feeling has not been so rampant here during the past few days as it was at the beginning of the Boer war. The principal reason of this is that the French temperament easily tires of any one point of view, but there is also another consideration which has its importance.

One of the most interesting persons at the Barge Office yesterday was Peter Bacon, seventeen years old, who, despite his rather prosaic name, is a full-blooded Burmese, with a luxuriant crop of black curly hair and line eyes. He speaks English and several other languages fluently.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The Grand Lodge of improved Order B'nai B'rith went into biennial conclave this morning at Maenherchor Hail. The sessions will continue to-morrow. The order was founded in 1887, and held annual conventions until 1898, from which time it was decided to hold biennial sessions.

When the estate of Mary E. Hetner comes up for division and her will is offered for probate there will probably be a contest, as she appears to have had a habit of making wills. It is expected that some time during the week there will be a will offered for probate before Surrogate Daniel Noble.

"Brooklyn Mediaeval Theology'' was the subject of the sermon preached by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton at the Church of the Divine Paternity yesterday morning. Dr. Eaton took as his text the twenty-first verse of the seventh chapter of Matthew: "Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of Heaven, but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in Heaven."

It is reported of a canny Scotsman that he said of the old maxim that honesty is the best policy: "I ken it weel, for I have tried them, baith." The people of the State of New York can echo the sentiment as to honesty and dishonesty in the public service, though much is left to be desired in their experiment with the former.

QUINCY, Ill., Jan. 28 -- Quincy police officers last night killed two expert safe blowers, supposed to be from Chicago, and seriously wounded another. The men are believed to be the same who recently operated in Galesburg, Freeport, and other Illinois cities, making a specialty of cracking safes in building and loan association offices.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Have we got to the bottom? That is the question of most interest in the money market. I am disposed to think we have, for after the bank rate was reduced to 4 per cent, on Thursday, the open market began to harden. On Wednesday three months' bank bills could now and then be discounted at a fraction under 3 per cent.;
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The War Office has received the following from Gen. Buller announcing that Gen. Warren has retreated to the south side of the Tugela River:

Despite the inclement weather the Academy of Music was fairly well filled last evening at the Father McGiynn memorial meeting, held under the auspices of the Rev. Dr. McGlynn Memorial Association. The exercises consisted of addresses by Roman Catholic, Protestant, and Jewish ministers, music rendered by an orchestra, and a trombone quartet, and vocal selections by Edward O'Mahony.

Several of the most spirited races witnessed on the Speedway this Winter took place yesterday morning. The roadbed was in excellent condition. Both sidewalks from Washington Bridge north were lined with spectators, who were as enthusiastic as though they were at a track meet, and warmly applauded the winners of the various contests.

The Anti-Saloon League began a crusade yesterday in New York. The northern part of the city was selected as the scene of the initial efforts, the plan being to cover the entire territory of the Greater New York, taking one district at a time. Nine services were held yesterday morning, two in the afternoon, and nine in the evening in churches and halls in the territory above Eighty-third Street.
LONDON, Jan. 30. -- A special dispatch from Frere Camp, dated Friday, Jan. 26, 9:10 P.M., says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Can you give me a little space to say a few words for some women. There are many hinds of us, but from a few articles which you have published lately one could gather the idea that we are all of a sort for which many of us have deep dislike, not to use any stronger expression.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 29 -- Dr. Seaver announced to-day that all strength tests must be sent in to the Collegiate Test Committee by May 1. The college whose fifty men score the highest number of points is to be champion. An individual championship will go to the man with the highest score. Last year it was won by C.G. Herbert of Harvard.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Charles P. Bacon, attorney for Abram Kling in his action against the State Trust Company, to-day addressed another letter to State Superintendent of Banks Kilburn, reiterating his charges of misconduct on the part of the Directors, and demanding a copy of the report of Gen. Andrews.

The heavy gales and rough seas that have prevailed during the last few days have delayed even the fastest liners, and as for the slow-going steamers, they are all several days late. The steamer which is the longest overdue is the State of Nebraska of the Allan State Line, which left Glasgow on Jan. 11, and for which relatives and friends of passengers on board have been anxiously looking for nearly a week.

A number of diverse reports were published in Wall Street yesterday relative to the taking of the Third Avenue Railroad Company's floating debt of $17,000,000. One of these was to the effect that Metropolitan interests were coming in to the Third Avenue on the basis of an exchange of one share of the former corporation's stock for two shares of that of the latter.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 29 -- Col. William Jennings Bryan began a week's tour of New England for the purpose of discussing the questions of the day to-day, speaking at Pawtucket and Woonsocket in the afternoon, and this city in the evening. As the State of Rhode Island is just on the eve of a Gubernatorial campaign, which will close with an election in April, Mr. Bryan's coming is regarded as timely by the Democrats.

One of the most disastrous, as well as picturesque, fires with which the department has had to cope since the big fire in Whitehall Street last Winter occurred soon after 7 o'clock yesterday morning in the chair factory of the Heywood Brothers Wakefield Company, at 297 to 303 Cherry Street, and extending through to 546-550 Water Street.
BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- An official agency has communicated the following to the press:

The crescent-shaped cold wave, with one extremity over the upper lakes and the other in the vicinity of Southwestern Georgia, arrived at New York in the early hours of yesterday morning on the wings of an icy gale, blowing at the rate of sixty miles an hour. The mercury dropped 20 degrees in twelve hours, and reached its limit at 10 o'clock last night, when the official thermometer registered 16 degrees above zero.

Nothing could be more complete and sweeping than the admission by The London Times of the total failure of the British campaign against the Boers. Such an admission from that source is especially significant. Its significance proceeds not only from the peculiar position of The Times, which, in spite of all its mistakes, has managed to hold a more representative position than that of any other British newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- In accordance with previous announcement, Mr. Tillman (Dem., S.C.,) delivered an address upon the Philippine question to-day in the Senate. He dealt particularly with the resolutions offered by himself and other resolutions before the Senate.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29 -- Lieut. Col. M. Stephens, a representative of the British Army, has come to St. Louis to purchase an additional 1,000 mules for use in South Africa. The commission to which he is attached has been ordered to buy several thousand cavalry horses in this country. Most of this order is being filled in this vicinity.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- It has been learned that the Queen's speech at the reassembling of Parliament to-morrow will be colorless. There will be a short reference to the war, chiefly confined to regrets at the terrible bloodshed and encomiums of the men who have laid down their lives for the country.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 29 -- The profits made by the Louisiana rice growers have been phenomenal this season. H.J. Sanders, a prominent planter of the Crowley district, said:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 29 -- A decision which will close two-thirds of the saloons in Iowa was handed down by the Supreme Court to-day. It is considered the most generally important decision given out in ten years.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Assemblyman Sullivan of New York said to-night that he had collected statistics which proved that more persons had been seriously injured and killed in football contests than in boxing bouts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The extraordinary display of force by the two Boer republics is the more astounding when we consider their resources in men. The white population, according to The Statesman's Year Book of the South African Republic in 1884, was 50,000, of which 40,000 are stated as of Dutch descent.

President Bernard J. York of the Police Department and Commissioner Henry E. Abell were both questioned last night as to the alleged presence in numbers of poolrooms in Brooklyn, a condition of things charged by a Brooklyn newspaper to be the fact, and both declared that such poolrooms would be promptly raided if discovered.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Press and public alike, while depressed over the defeat of Gen. Buller, unite in insisting that more troops must be sent to South Africa.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Assemblyman George Metcalfe of Richmond to-night offered a resolution in the House in the interest of the school teachers of Richmond County, which reads:

The still further postponement of the beginning of Miss Nethersole's engagement at Wallack's left last night free from "novelties" in the theatrical field. Yet there were a number of incidents calling for record. Mrs. Langtry's first recitation of "The Absent-Minded Beggar" in khaki at the Garden Theatre, in the circumstances, attracted a large number of first nighters.

Hiss Beatrice Herford's entertainment at the Lyceum Theatre yesterday afternoon was attended by a numerous and appreciative audience. Miss Herford writes her own plays, from observation of life, and serves as her own dramatic company. She acts only one part in each of her little comedies, but in such a way as to make the doings and sayings of the other characters easily imagined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Nothing is known at the White House of Louise Berger, who is on trial in New York for shoplifting. The statement that she was Mrs. McKinley's maid up to November last is declared to be false. Mrs. McKinley has the same maid now that she had before she came to Washington, and there has been no change since her arrival here.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Trading was neither particularly active nor excessively dull in to-day's market. There was more strength than weakness. The coppers, although quiet, were firm, and had one or two fair gains to show at the closing. The railroad shares and United States Oil were the best spots in the list.
The school bills which come up this afternoon before the Cities Committees of the Senate and Assembly deserve serious consideration.
Joel I. Hart committed suicide last evening in Central Park, near Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Tenth Street, by shooting himseff in the head with a revolver.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 29 -- Veteran Capt. Horace C. Lanphear, formerly of the Norwich Line Sound steamers, and Mrs. Lanphear to-day celebrated their golden wedding at their comfortable house in Waterford. The couple's many friends from New London, New York, and Boston, and from as far away as Philadelphia, were present or else sent some token of their regard.

"Unbalanced bids" are familiar enough, to contractors and to those having to deal with public works, but the term may not be understood by many readers who nave noted the importance given to the remedy for this mischievous practice in the report of the Canal Committee, which has attracted such wide attention.

HOLDEN, Mo., Jan. 29 -- John Jackson, a detective of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad, was shot through the head by a man whom he was endeavoring to arrest here on suspicion of being a train robber.

The weather, which must perforce be mentioned in any daily review of the doings of the New York social world, in as much as at this period of the year it has much to do with the present movements and plans of the members of the gay world, promises to repeat its performances of last Winter.

The Populists need not have the slightest fear that BRYAN will desert them. He is flesh of their flesh and can no more shake off their wild principles than he can reason rightly or talk little or do any other thing that nature has made impossible for him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day heard a number of witnesses on minor points involved in the charges against Senator Clark of Montana. The protestants took occasion during the day to withdraw all intimations against J.K. Toole, who withdrew from the Montana contest for United States Senator under circumstances which the protestants at first were inclined to consider suspiciously favorable to Mr. Clark.

The Crescent Athletic Club bowling team created a surprise last night in the Brooklyn interclub tournament by running up the unusual score of 1,031. None of the other seven clubs in the league came up to the Crescent Club's scores. Summaries:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- An extraordinary exodus of Americans toward Europe is in progress, according to the figures of the Passport Bureau of the State Department. Up to date the number of passports issued during January was 1,383, and 125 more will be sent out before the end of the month.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- Baseball men from various sections of the country who are interested in the new American Association, which is to meet here to-morrow for the purpose of organizing and to lay out a circuit, began to arrive to-day. Most of them are now on the ground.

HARTFORD, Jan. 29 -- The experiments as to the food value of alcohol which are being made in the respiration calorimeter at Wesleyan University by Prof. L. Atwater have been the occasion of much comment in temperance circles and this afternoon a conference of representatives of different societies throughout the State was held at Memorial Hall under the auspices of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union.

Not infrequently in the past Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH has written about America and the Americans in a way that justified the suspicion of an intention on his part to perpetuate as long as possible every remnant of hostility between the United States and England, and, if he could, to arouse new animosities.

Though yesterday's security market was dull it was not weak, and they who theorize that values here are no longer to be affected by foreign war developments were elated. Europe sold stocks at the opening of our market. But all the offerings found not merely ready takers at what were Saturday's figures, but at advances.

BABYLON, L.I., Jan. 29 -- Frank Thurber, a merchant of Bay Shore, while riding his bicycle along the South County Road in front of the Ford place yesterday, was attacked by a five-hundred-dollar-prize bloodhound owned by Malcolm W. Ford, the former all-round athletic champion.

At a meeting of the Board of City Magistrates, held at the West Side Police Court last evening, the annual report of the clerk of the board, for the year 1899, was read by the President, Magistrate Deuel.

Preston Gibson, the Princeton student, and Miss Mina Field, stepdaughter of Thomas Nelson Page, the author, who were clandestinely married, will be received with open arms at the Washington home of the Pages. Mr. Page, who came to the city on Sunday, on hearing of the marriage, said yesterday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this date you reprint from The Springfield Republican a statement from Aguinaldo. It hardly seems possible that an intelligent American could read the first article of that statement and not conclude the writer incapacitated for any participation in the government of any people.
J.J. Courtney, New York resident manager of the Imperial Insurance Company of London, has returned from England.

Although a good many of the City Magistrates are in favor of the project for a separate court for children, such as has been advocated by Commissioner Keller of the Charities Department and by the Gerry society, it seems to be the general opinion among them that there is no likelihood of the plan ever materializing.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The expected nomination of ex-Senator Francis Hendricks as Superintendent of Insurance, to succeed Louis F. Payn, attracted the largest audience seen in the Senate chamber this session. This was the one topic of interest, arid the importance of the assemblage was clearly manifest as the routine business proceeded.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Judge C.C. Kohlsaat, in the United States Circuit Court, to-day decided the Anti-Trust act of the Illinois Legislature in 1893 void on the ground that the statute contains both class and special legislation, and is in contravention of the Federal and State Constitutions. The opinion of the Court bears more directly on the ninth clause of the act of 1893, but the validity of the whole act is also denied.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- There was little interest manifested in the market to-day outside of the dealings in Western New York and Pennsylvania securities, all of which were strong, touching the highest prices made on the present advance. The unfavorable war news from South Africa seems to have spent its force as far as its effect upon the local market is concerned.

The construction company which John B. McDonald will form to build the rapid-transit tunnel and enable him to qualify with the surety companies will he backed by the banking firm of August Belmont Co. This firm, it is understood, will head a syndicate to give Mr. McDonald the necessary support to go on with the work.

Trading in the market for outside securities was more active yesterday than it had been in many days, but by far the larger part of the day's business was supplied by one stock -- Bay State Gas. In a few other issues also transactions were in fairly large amount, but the market generally was little different from that which prevailed all last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From the comments of all the English newspapers without exception it would seem that the British are exceedingly prejudiced in favor of courage. They tell of how the officers, disdaining cover, were killed; how the men charged through an open space in a storm of lead, and how the Boers kept themselves hidden.

"We had stewed burglars and burglar steak for dinner last evening," casually remarked one of the residents at a fashionable up-town apartment house yesterday, "and we are not cannibals at that." The rather startling assertion certainly needed the explanation that was forthcoming when a look as of incredulity spread over the faces of the listeners.

Mrs. Astor gave last evening at her residence, 842 Fifth Avenue, her annual reception, with dancing. This ball -- as it is one of the most largely attended private functions of the year -- is looked forward to by society. It is considered as the climax of the season, and it has taken place with unfailing regularity, except when deferred by years of mourning, with each recurring season.

The annual curling match for the Gordon Medal, the twenty-third in the history of the Grand National Curling Club of America, began at the Hoboken Skating Rink yesterday afternoon. Ten clubs entered rinks. In the first round the Van Cortlandt, Jersey City, Yonkers, Thistle, and Empire City Clubs were victorious.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Setting aside all questions as to the rights of car passengers, it is difficult to understand as a business proposition why the conductors are directed to keep open windows in the cars during all kinds of weather. Frozen passengers must succumb to sickness or death, or, escaping that result, at least protect themselves by finding more comfortable means of conveyance.

The application of the New York and Long Island Terminal Railway Company for a franchise for a tunnel between the intersection of Maiden Lane and Broadway, in the Borough of Manhattan, under the East River, to the present location of the Long Island Railroad station at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues in the Borough of Brooklyn, was considered at a hearing before the joint Committee on Railroads of the Municipal Assembly yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The speech of the Queen, read at the opening of Parliament to-day, was substantially as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through the medium of THE TIMSS I would like to ask Mr. William J. Bryan, the apostle of 16 to 1, how he reconciles his opposition to "trusts" with his advocacy of the most stupendous, monstrous, and damaging trust to this country yet proposed, viz., the free-silver trust.

Panic, with narrow escapes from disaster, was caused yesterday by a small fire in the five-story flat house at 332 Kast One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, one of the most crowded tentments in Harlem. Twenty-three families, numbering about 125 persons, live in the building.

Rocco de Fina yesterday applied to Justice Andrews, in the Supreme Court, for an injunction, pending trial, to restrain Albert H. Woods and Patrick H. Sullivan, brother of Senator Sullivan, from producing the drama "The Bowery After Dark" in this State, and from removing the play and its scenery outside the jurisdiction of the court.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- The work of placing the new American Association of Baseball Clubs on a firm and permanent foundation was begun here to-day. Fair progress was made and thus far everything is apparently moving along smoothly. Seven-eighths of the circuit was laid out, and the eighth city will probably be selected tomorrow.

Cotton developed exceptional strength yesterday in the face of large receipts. The continued strong and active demand for spot cotton in the South and good Liverpool cables, combined with the fact that the increased receipts had been discounted to a certain extent gave the market its strength. Cotton opened 2 points up, and steadily improved, closing with a net gain of from 6 to 7 points.

Conferences were held yesterday between John B. McDonald, who expects to build the thirty-five-million-dollar tunnel; the firm of August Belmont Co., his financial backer, and representatives of the surety companies which will probably go on Mr. McDonald's bond. So far as is known, nothing of a definite nature was accomplished, but shortly after 6 o'clock last evening De Lancey Nicoll, counsel for Mr. McDonald, made this brief statement:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last Friday afternoon, after riding in an unheated Boulevard (Broadway) trolley car (No. 226 or 227, I forget which,) from Fifty-ninth Street to One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street until chilled through, I alighted, with others, at the corner of the Boulevard and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street to transfer to a Cross-Town and then to an Upper Amsterdam Avenue car.

A legacy of $20 left to Abraham Gruber by the will of a former client, Mrs. Esther Aaron of 272 West One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, drew a number of Mr. Gruber's friends to his office yesterday with inquiries as to what he was going to do with it. Mr. Gruber said he had loaned that amount of money to Mrs. Aaron a year or more ago.

That was very good counsel which Capt. MAHAN gave to the American public through our columns the other day. It was not to hold any meetings, either of sympathy or of indignation, with reference to the war going on in South Africa. Capt. MAHAN avowed his own sympathy to be with the British.
W.J. BRYAN kept pretty mum about silver while he was in this city, but in the outlying districts he sits publicly at the feet of his old idols and worships them.

The season progresses, and has now only four weeks to run. The continuance of good weather, for yesterday, although cold, was really a bracing Winter day, has delayed the departure of many people who otherwise would before this have departed for the Southern resorts. There are still few arrivals of people at all well known here at the Florida hotels, and, although there are many people at Aiken, matters there are still dull.

ROME, Jan. 14-- I had a talk yesterday with his Eminence Cardinal Miecislaw Le- dochowsky, Prefect of the Sacred Congre- gation of Propaganda Fide. The conversa- tion related somewhat to the operations and outlook of the Catholic Church in Puerto Rico and the Philippines. In response to an inquiry as to these islands the Cardinal said:

In the market for outside securities yesterday trading was broader and more active than it has been on any day in two weeks or more. Transactions were not limited to a few stocks, but extended to a fairly large number of issues, several of which supplied several thousand shares to the day's total.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- Boston's particular specialties were as dull as ever, but the trading in Sugar, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and Federal Steel increased considerably and made up a good aggregate of business. Perhaps mining stocks were ignored more than ever; it certainly seemed so, although price changes were slight.

Dixon-Hiltner. Mr. Walter Nimer Dixon and Miss Jessie W. Hiltner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hiltner of 125 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, were married yesterday afternoon at the residence of the bride's parents by the Rev. M.R. Nichols of Holy Trinity Church.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- At the opening of Parliament severe attacks were made to-day in both houses on the policy of the Government in South Africa, the occasion being the discussion of the Speech from the throne.

PRETORIA, Jan. 27 -- A dispatch from Colesburg, Cape Colony, says Commander Delaroy reports that a large body of British advanced Thursday, Jan. 25, and he attacked them, causing the British to retire after suffering severe loss. The Boer casualties were two men slightly wounded.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Assemblyman Stewart will to-morrow introduce a bill aimed at the Gerry society. It compels it to make and file statements of all moneys received and disbursed with the Secretary of State annually.

The credibility of Anthony Comstock as a witness was attacked yesterday by counsel for the defense in the trial for alleged "green-goods" operations of George Morris and John Reedy, the former Postmaster, station agent, and telegraph operator at Pocantico Hills, N.Y., which was being continued before Judge Thomas, in the Criminal Branch of the United States Circuit Court.

New Jersey has another pair of youthful desperadoes in two brothers, almost of the same age. The police of Jersey City are anxious to put a stop to the criminal career, for a time at least, of Charles J. Jensan, nineteen years of age, and his brother William, two years younger, who on Saturday last assaulted and robbed their stepmother in their father's house, at 131 Highland Avenue, and who have so far eluded capture.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Spenser Wilkinson, the war expert, reviewing the military situation in The Morning Post, says:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senator-elect Blackburn of Kentucky, who was one of the first in Washington to receive word of the shooting of Mr. Goebel, made the following statement to-night:

Wall Street men are watching with something of interest the outcome of a bit of business transacted yesterday under unusual conditions. One of the members of the Exchange appeared on the floor apparently under the influence of liquor and began buying a certain stock liable to startling fluctuations.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Not a single vote was cast against Francis Hendrieks at the caucus of the Republican Senators, which met immediately after the adjournment of the Senate to-day, and there is now no doubt that he will succeed Louis F. Payn as Superintendent of Insurance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- By a decision of the Branch Appellate Court, the International Committee of Young Women's Christian Associations was forbidden to use that name. This action was taken on the request of the Young Women's Christian Association, which claims that the former organization has deceived the public by its name into believing that it is affiliated with the plaintiff association.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Charles P. Bacon, attorney for Abram Kling, this afternoon filed with Attorney General Davies a petition for the revocation of the charter of the State Trust Company. He asks for the revocation on the allegations of fact set forth in his first letter to State Superintendent of Banks Kilburn, and on the report of Gen. Avery Andrews, now in the possession of Superintendent Kilburn.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- The Legislature in joint session to-day re-elected State Controller William S. Hancock and State Treasurer George B. Swain for a term of three years each. Both are Republicans and have already served two terms each. The Governor sent to the Senate the name of Samuel A. Atkinson for Prosecutor of Burlington County.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- A joint hearing on the bills of Senators Marshall, Elsberg, and Ford was given before the Cities Committees this afternoon. Senator Marshall's bill carries with it the decentralization of the system by giving to the Borough Boards the powers of the present Board of Education.

At last the joint committee of the Municipal Assembly has consented to give a hearing on the tunnel under the East River connecting the heart of the business down-town district of Manhattan with Brooklyn and Long Island. At this hearing on Monday the testimony was ample that the opinion of Brooklyn is unanimous for this project, and that it would be of the greatest advantage to the entire community.

The examination in the case of Julius Price, Henry Allen, and Samuel Goodman, arrested by Capt. Killilea and detectives from the Old Slip Station on the charge of conducting a bucket shop at 51 New Street, who were arraigned before Magistrate Olmsted, in the Centre Street Police Court, was concluded yesterday before that Magistrate, sitting in Jefferson Market Police Court.
Dividends have been declared or the Bank of the Manhattan Company and the Jefferson and Clearfield Coal and Iron Company.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 30 -- While William Goebel lay at the point of death in his room as the result of an assassin's bullet, the contesting boards, which for two Weeks had been listening to the evidence in his contest for the Governor's chair, declared him entitled to the seat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Navy Department has made public a letter from Gen. Bates strongly commending the officers of the navy who co-operated with the army in the capture of Zamboanga. He mentions Commander Very of the Castine. Lieut. Commander Nazro of the Manila, and Commander Sperry of the Yorktown.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I venture to direct the attention of THE TIMES to the bill introduced in the Legislature yesterday conferring on the Justices of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in this city the great and extraordinary power of appointing fifty referees, to whom the courts shall refer all cases hereafter to be tried before referees.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Gov. Roosevelt will not reopen the court of inquiry of the Seventy-first Regiment on the statements made by Gen. Hawkins. He said this morning that he had absolutely no interest in the controversy between Gens. Kent and Hawkins, and that so far as Gen. Hawkins's statement went it confirmed the testimony taken before the court of inquiry rather than disproving it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The hearing on the Shipping bill before the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries was unusually spirited to-day, owing to the criticisms of the measure presented by John De Witt Warner of New York and some counter criticisms by members of the committee on a letter issued by tHe New York Reform Club, of which Mr. Warner is a prominent member.

It is some five years now since there was established the American School of Classical Studies in Rome. As it is not the habit of our country to support institutions of this sort at the expense of the public Treasury -- a wise policy undoubtedly -- the school was necessarily something of an experiment and planned on a modest scale.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- A large delegation of New York City school teachers, accompanied by several members of the Legislature, including Senators McCarren, Elsberg, and Davis, and Assemblyman Fallows, conferred with Gov Roosevelt to-day on New York City school legislation. The Governor told them that what should be done was to pass a bill to make the Ahearn law effective, and that other needed legislation could follow.

Business grew brisk on the Stock Exchange yesterday, and total transactions of half a million shares were recorded. American Steel and Wire, Sugar Trust. Brooklyn Rapid Transit, and the coal stocks were notable features, the trading in this group aggregating much more than all the rest of the 150 shares on the list put together.

When the lady parliamentarians who compose the New York Society for Political Study yesterday afternoon reached the outer door of the Tuxedo, the building in which all their meetings are held, there was a sudden pause, which for a time threatened to block the hallway, for there in the doorway stood, of all people in the world, a policeman.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 30 -- William Goebel, the Democratic contestant for Governor of Kentucky, was shot by an assassin this morning while on his way to the Capitol. One ball struck Mr. Goebel, and latest reports are to the effect that he has very little, if any, chance of recovery.

William Wake. William Wake, a pioneer in the manufacture of pianoforte hardware in the United States, died Monday at his residence, 40 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, after an illness of ten months. He was in his eighty-fifth year. Mr. Wake was born in the old Reynolds house, in Thames Street, which stood in the rear of Trinity Church.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senators who do not approve of the manifestly prolonged avoidance of pending treaties say that there is inexcusable indolence shown in the refusal of the Senate to take up and ratify the important treaties now pending, and that the neglect of the Puerto Rican situation in particular threatens to disturb and annoy the country.
BERUN, Jan. 30 -- The British defeats in South Africa continue to engross public attention. Gen. von Bogustiawsky who is a leading military writer, said to-day:

Meeting of the shareholders of the National Union Bank called for March 5 to vote upon the proposed increase of the capital stock to $5,000,000 by the issue of 38,000 shares at $150 per share, with a view of consolidation with the National Bank of Commerce.

The attacks that are made in and out of Congress upon the present Secretary of the Treasury, whose capacity and integrity can hardly be questioned by really fair minded men, illustrate the difficulty of the tasks which our financial system at times puts upon that officer. The Sub-Treasury operations are a cause of complaint whenever there is any material discrepancy between the receipts and expenditures of the Government.

The feeling is growing in National Guard circles that the making public of the remarks made by Brig. Gen. Hamilton S. Hawkins, United States Army, retired, at a social gathering of the officers of the Seventy-first Regiment may cause some serious complications. Col. W.G. Bates, commanding the Seventy-first Regiment, expressed that feeling when he said last night:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- With her flags at half mast, the United States transport Thomas entered this harbor to-day, bearing the bodies of Gen. Henry W. Lawton, Major John A. Logan, Jr., Lieut. Bennett, and Dr. J.J.L. Armstrong. In the cabin of the Thomas were about twenty passengers, including Mrs. Lawton and her children.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- All sections of the Irish Nationalists were absent from the opening of Parliament, owing to their attendance at a meeting in Committee Room 16, Room 15 being avoided owing to its association with previous discords of the party. Timothy Harrington, member for the Harbour Division of Dublin, presided.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The news of the shooting of William Goebel was received at the White House while the Cabinet was in session. Upon reading the bulletin the President expressed his sorrow, and remarked that it was a great calamity. He was much distressed at the news, and so were all the members of the Cabinet.

SERVICE OF PROCESS UPON THE DEAFMUTE WAS VALID -- Justice Beekman, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday refused the application of Henry Jansen Haight, the deaf-mute, whose marital troubles recently occupied the attention of the courts for several weeks, to set aside the service of a summons upon him on Nov. 13 in a suit by Horace M. Cake.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- A tabulation of the statements of the savings banks of New York and the adjacent counties for the year ended Dec. 31, 1899, shows the following percentages of increase in the amount due to depositors and in the total surplus:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- When the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day adjourned its hearing of the charges made against Senator Clark of Montana in connection with his election to the United States Senate, it was understood that the defense would be prepared to proceed with its witnesses not later than Monday next.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 30 -- President Castro, the members of the Cabinet, and fifty officials visited Admiral Farquhar to-day on board his flagship, the New York, and later the Admiral gave a dinner in honor of United States Minister Loomis and Mrs. Loomis. Late this afternoon the New York sailed for Carthagena.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The teachers of Queens and Richmond will be paid in a very short time. Gov. Roosevelt will send in an emergency message to the Assembly tomorrow, and Assembly Fallows's bill, which now meets everybody's approval, will be reported favorably by the Cities Committee in the Assembly.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- It is now known that the Cabinet devoted much of its discussions on Saturday to the mobilization of the fleet. Nothing was settled except that, until further security to the home coasts has obtained by naval preparations, the Eighth Division shall not be sent to South Africa.

A select audience, including many women, gathered in Mendelssohn Hall last night to enjoy the programme of music and addresses on literature and art arranged for the first public meeting of the National Institute of Arts and Letters. The addresses were by Horatio William Parker, head of the musical department of Yale University, and the Rev. Dr. Henry van Dyke.

American Steel and Wire common yesterday again showed exceptional strength and was extensively traded in. At one time the quotation marked a pain of over three points, but toward the close of the day, by reason of profit taking, the figure sagged somewhat, and the close was at a net gain of 2 5/3 points.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A joint meeting of the Senate and Assembly Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment will be held at the Assembly parlor on Wednesday next, Feb. 7, at 2 o'clock P.M., to hear any opposition to the bill of the joint Tax Committee relating to the taxation of mortgages and banks, now pending before the Legislature.

The plans for the new buildings of the Mount Sinai Hospital are being completed rapidly by Architect Arnold W. Brunner. Most of the money has been raised, and the remainder, it is expected, will be obtained without difficulty. The excavations will begin early in the Summer. The total cost will be considerably more than $1,000,000.

The Board of Public Improvements yesterday received the report of its special committee, which was charged with the preparation of a uniform schedule of water rates to be applied to all parts of the city. Action was deferred on the report until a statement showing the receipts and expenditures for water supply can be obtained from the Controller.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 31 -- The following statement was to-night issued by the Democratic members of the Legislature:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Debate in the Senate, ordinarily calm and dignified, burst to-day into passionate utterances and bitter recriminations. Senators hurled denunciations at one another until the auditors quivered with excitement. The debate grew out of a phase of the Philippine question, and no scene has been witnessed since the discussion of the war resolutions in the last Congress which, in sensational features, compared with that of to-day.

Regarding a report that an addition to the Grand Union Hotel will be erected on the car stable property running through from Forty-first to Forty-second Street, just east of the hotel's present site, Simeon Ford said yesterday that it was not without foundation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to suggest that the larger part of the controversial articles on the great subjects of the day which have of late appeared in your excellent paper, though often written with ability, are tiresome reading. And for this reason, because they assume as premises facts and conditions that are denied.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee seem to have awakened to the fact that the hearings on the proposition to extend free trade to Puerto Rico offer some opportunities for insisting upon a policy that is Democratic, and a course that will lead the Puerto Ricans to value rather than regret the assumption of power over the island by the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The Cities Committee of the Senate met this morning and agreed to report the Ford bill providing for the payment of the salaries of the public school teachers in the boroughs of Queens and Richmond. This bill is identical with the Fallows bill which the Assembly Cities Committee last evening agreed to report.

The continuing strong demand for spot cotton in the South was responsible yesterday for noteworthy strength in the cotton market here, following, as it did, Tuesday's upward movement. As was the case on Tuesday, the advance was in the face of good receipts and the next crop months closed strongest.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Assemblyman S.S. Slater of New York to-day introduced another School Teachers' bill for New York which amends the Ahearn bill schedule of salaries between the minimum, figures of last year and makes provision for Boards of Superintendents to give time credit to teachers in schools other than the public schools of the city.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- The market to-day was relatively quiet. Prices, as a rule, were well sustained, and good advances were scored in several instances. In the coppers, Parrot was in excellent demand, and sold up to 42. Amalgamated was firm at 83 and 83 1/4. Centennial lifted to 16 1/2. Calumet and Hecla sold again at 740. Isle Royale brought from 21 to 21 1/4. Old Dominion gained a fraction.

Amid the strains of Irish melody and green in rich plenty the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick last night gave a dinner to the retiring President, Justice Morgan J. O'Brien. Justice O'Brien was President of the society for three terms. The dinner was held in the banquet hall at Delmonico's, and there were covers for nearly four hundred.

General relief was occasioned in shipping circles yesterday by the arrival, in port of the Allan State Line steamship State of Nebraska and the Anchor Liner Ethiopia. Both steamers sailed from Glasgow on Jan. 11 and were long overdue.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- It is announced that the German Government will add the shipyard at Bremen to the list of private yards for building the new navy. Other private yards are the Vulkan at Stettin, the Schichau, the Germania, and the Blohm.

Two uncommon letters are those which recently passed between Louise Hepner, the comic opera singer who is now singing the leading role in "The Princess Chic" at the Columbia Theatre, in Boston, and her husband, William Hepner, a wigmaker, of this city. The letters will be introduced in a petition for divorce which Mr. Hepner is about to file.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In order to appreciate the true significance of the amendments to the tax law proposed toy the joint legislative committee, of which Senator Stranahan is Chairman, it is necessary to understand the present method of taxation.

The suspension of the Stock Exchange house of Tunstall Co., whose heavy purchases in Sugar Trust stock on Tuesday had occasioned much wondering comment in Wall Street, was announced on the board yesterday soon after the opening of the market. The only official explanation for the failure came in the form of an announcement put out from the offices of the company, 52 Broadway, as follows:

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was even more active than on the previous day, and prices also continued to improve. Though the bulk of the day's business was supplied by Bay State Gas, many other issues were fairly active, and the broader character of the market that was noted on Tuesday remained as an indication that the public is taking greater interest in the market than it had recently.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 31 -- This State to-night has two Governors. One is intrenched in the State House, surrounded by blue-coated and shivering soldiers; the other lies on a bed in the Capitol Hotel, weak and wan, suffering from a gunshot wound that may prove mortal, yet on his determined face is the smile that comes with ambition satisfied.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Marquis of Queensberry is dead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Much interest centred in the meeting of the Ways and Means Commute to-day on the understanding reached among the Republican members of the committee favorable to applying the American tariff to Puerto Rico with a reduction of 75 per cent, on the regular rates.

Does any one believe that this desire for empire will be sated with the acquisition and retention of the Philippine Islands? Why should it? The thirst of empire is no new thins. It is like the desire for human blood. It was a wrong step for us to take Hawaii. It was much worse for us to acquire the Philippine Islands.

It is certainly questionable whether AGUINALDO'S lies are fit matter to be printed at the public expense for dissemination as an anti-imperialistic campaign document. The privilege of such publicity has never been accorded to any other enemy of the United States, we believe, at least to no other enemy in arms against the Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Navy Board on Construction has submitted a report to the Secretary of the Navy explaining why it has reversed its position and modified its judgment in the matter of sheathing the new battleships, and now believes it will be more advantageous not to undertake to sheathe them.

ALBANY, Jan. 31.-- A large delegation of residents of Suffolk County appeared before the Judiciary Committee of the Senate this afternoon to protest against the repeal of a bill passed three years ago to prevent the Borough of Brooklyn from invading the streams of Suffolk County for its water supply.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A joint hearing of the Senate Finance Committee and the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly was held this afternoon to discuss the bill introduced by Senator George A. Davis, calling for an appropriation of $200,000 for the purpose of establishing a State Hospital for the treatment of incipient pulmonary tuberculosis.

The United States and the United Kingdom are the two most conspicuous and successful examples now furnished in the world of parliamentary government. It is curious that they should now be suffering from the same trouble. That is, the want of an intelligent, organized, patriotic opposition.
LOUISVILLE, Jan. 31 -- A man has been arrested in Louisville who says he knows all about the Goebel assassination. He is James L. Sutton, Sheriff of Whitley County.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The House of Commons to-day resumed the debate on the amendment of Lord Edmund Fitzmaurice, Liberal, to the address in reply to the Queen's speech. The amendment, which is virtually a vote of censure on his brother, the Marquis of Lansdowne, Secretary of State for War, is worded as follows:

The Rev. Dr. W.W. Eddy, who had been an American missionary in Syria since 1851, died Monday at Beirut. With his children, he had taken a leading part in making the American Presbyterian missions in Syria among the most flourishing of any in the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Capt. Wilde, the senior naval officer at Cavite, in the absence of Admiral Watson, to-day reported upon the accident on board the Wheeling whereby one sailor was killed and several wounded at Hongkong while firing a salute in honor of Emperor William's birthday anniversary.

When the entries for the Brooklyn, Suburban, and Brighton Handicaps were announced a few weeks ago the amateurs at once set to work to figure out the handicap weights that should be assigned to the candidates, in most cases the choice lay between Imp, the speedy Western mare that captured last year's Suburban, and Banastar, who was left at the post in that event, but who won the Brooklyn Handicap.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Assemblyman Brennan of Kings to-day introduced a bill to establish a separate department of elections in New York City. The department is to be called the Board of Elections, and is to consist of four persons to be known as Commissioners of Elections, who are to be appointed by the Mayor, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Senate Committee on Puerto Rico to-day continued consideration of the bill to frame a government for Puerto Rico, but did not conclude its labors. The committee practically decided, however, to leave in the bill the provision for a delegate in Congress, who shall be a resident of the island, own taxable property there, and read and write the English language.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- It is not considered at all probable that the Administration will go to the relief of the Kentuckians now divided and in contention over the respective claims of Goebel and Taylor. This has been asserted by the President several times, to visitors from Kentucky who came here to secure, if possible, some assurance that when necessary the Federal Administration would extend help or countenance to the Republican Administration at Frankfort.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 31 -- The following proclamation was issued to-night by Mr. Goebel:

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Gen. Buller's additional casualty lists of the battle of Spion Kop, Jan. 24, and of the engagements at Venter's Spruit, Jan. 17 and Jan. 20, shows 139 men killed, 391 wounded, and 63 missing, a total of 593.

PORTLAND, Me.; Jan. 31 -- The Democracy of Maine gathered in Portland to-night in honor of William J. Bryan, and much enthusiasm was shown at the banquet tendered to Mr. Bryan at City Hall by the Maine Democratic Club. Col. Bryan, with Congressman Lentz of Ohio and ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld of Illinois, left Boston early this morning, each speaking at a mass meeting in the City Hall at Lawrence at noon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Secretary Hay has received assurances from all of the South American countries which have diplomatic representatives in Washington of the most favorable reception by them of President McKinley's suggestion that a congress of Pan-American nations be reconvened, this time preferably at the City of Mexico, because the first congress was held in Washington.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- At a meeting of the Colonial Society to-day Herr Schmeisser, a mining engineer who visited the Transvaal in 1893 for the German Government, spoke of the mineral wealth the country contained -- iron, coal, and limestone deposits, and lead, silver, zinc, manganese, tin, and antimony ores, all of which must in future be worked.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- At the conclusion of the Philippine debate in the Senate Mr. Berry (Dem., Ark.,) was then recognized, and delivered nis announces speech upon the pending Financial bill. He charged that the proposed change to a gold standard was to be made simply because the holders of the bonds deemed gold the more desirable.

There is no civilized community where the crime committed at Frankfort on Tuesday, would not be universally condemned. If there is any citizen of Kentucky who looks upon this atrocious breach of the peace merely as a point gained in a desperate political battle, his existence and his opinions are evidence that he is a savage and not a civilized human being.

"I assure you that both the venison and the birds are imported," said the head waiter at one of the Broadway restaurants when a patron protested against the service of game out of season. "It is brought over in the French steamers, and is not American game at all, though we do not tell our patrons of that unless they make objections, as you have done."

The first evening's sale of William T. Evans's collection of paintings by American artists was prolific in surprises. Some pictures sold for considerably less than had been expected, but more brought prices far in excess of those which, judging from previous sales, seemed probable. The highest price of the sale was $4,750, paid by Cottier Co. for Homer D. Martin's large work, "Westchester Hills."

The effect of the tax on mortgages proposed in the bill of the Joint Committee on Taxation is already felt in this city. Mortgages given for moneys loaned by investors residing outside the State and now falling due must be renewed, if at all, with some understanding in regard to the proposed tax of one-half of 1 per cent.
LOUISVILLE, Jan. 31 -- A dispatch from Frankfort says:

The Board of Trade and Transportation gave its annual banquet last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, when nearly three hundred members and their guests partook of the board's hospitality. The dinner was given in the large banqueting hall which was profusely hung with greens and which presented a brilliant appearance, the guests being assembled at small tables.

FRANKFORT, Jan. 31 -- The condition of Mr. Goebel just before midnight to-night was better than at any time during the day. He was resting comfortably, no unfavorable symptoms had appeared, and it was announced that he would unquestionably get through the night.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 1/2 @ 60 1/2. There were no sales.

According to a letter written by Justice Van Brunt of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to John Henry Hull, who prepared a bill providing for the appointment of a Board of Referees, the Justice is not in favor of the measure. "I do not think," he says, "the Legislature has any power to compel the Appellate Division to act in making such appointments, and I, for one, would not act."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- While the House to-day, in Committee of the Whole, was considering the Indian Appropriation Bill, Mr. Cooney (Dem., Mo.,) took occasion to deliver an argument against imperialism. He would open the door to every channel of trade, he said, but close it to every attempt at expansion.

The second drama of Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungren" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before an audience of good size. It was the third performance this season of "Die Walkure," and the fates seemed to have conspired to make it an off night for Wagner.

Smiling, and with an air of confidence, as if a great load had been lifted from his mind, John B. McDonald, contractor for the rapid transit tunnel, announced yesterday afternoon that he had withdrawn his application for bonds from all the surety companies, and that he would build the road "as sure as guns."

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 1 -- Cashier Henry R Hardlin of the Rutherford National Bank has been dismissed from that position, and in a card published in a Rutherford newspaper to-day the Directors make the statement that the action was taken for "good and sufficient reasons." The supposition is that the dismissal is due to Mr. Hardlin's receiving drafts deposited and drawn against Hamilton Miller, recently arrested for forgery.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Daniel (Dem., Va.) discussed the pending financial bill.

Another consolidation of big financial corporations has been decided upon after weeks of planning and negotiation. The Morton Trust Company, which was incorporated last July, with ex-Gov. Levi P. Morton at its head, is to absorb the State Trust Company, the institution which has lately figured so much in the newspapers through the fight instituted by one of its stockholders, Abram Kling.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The increase in the cost of steel and iron for building purposes, and of some other building material, has caused Gen. Wilson, Chief of Engineers, to revise his estimates of the cost of the new building for the Government printing office. Originally it was designed to cost $2,000,000.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1 -- The news wired from Washington that Gov. Taylor had sent a message to President McKinley, asking for support, had an enlivening effect upon the Democrats here, and to-morrow Senator-elect Blackburn and other Kentucky Democrats will call upon the President and give him the Goebel side of the case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Attorney General Griggs recently received a copy of a circular signed and sent out by Margaret Dyee Ellis, Superintendent of Legislation for the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, to which he has made a reply to the writer of it, in which he substantially repeats the contents of the letter criticised by him in very caustic terms.

Julius Schroeter, a middle-aged, respect-able-looking German, with a residence at 7 Tiffany Park, Forest Hill, N.J., is now locked up in the Tombs on a charge of having swindled the banking firm of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. out of $38,000 by means of old, worthless forms of bonds of the State of Virginia, with forged signatures.

ANNAPOLIS, Feb. 1 -- The Democratic managers are planning legislation which will oust all Republicans from the County School Boards throughout the State and disfranchise all negroes who cannot read and write in the eastern and southern counties. At a quiet conference of Democratic politicians held last night Robert Moss said that Maryland was a Southern State, and the Democratic Party should rule.

One of the anticipated developments in the affairs of the Baltimore and Ohio came to pass yesterday, when at a meeting of the Board of Directors of the company, S. M. Prevost, Vice President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was elected a Director in the place of Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, resigned.

People on Broadway in the Tenderloin district early last-evening saw a handsomely gowned young woman walk hurriedly up that thoroughfare as if she wanted to catch a train. About twenty feet behind her they saw a well dressed but rather older man whose actions made it obvious that he wanted nothing better than to catch her.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- H.W. Chaplin, receiver of the John P. Squire corporation, the failure of which was followed by the suspension of the Broadway National Bank, said to-day that after having looked carefully into the situation he had learned that the bank had, prior to its total suspension, a surplus of $225,000, and the total amount of squire paper which could be presented for payment was only $160,000.

Third Avenue Street Railroad stock and Tennessee Coal and Iron shares contributed the most notable features of yesterday's security market. The iron stock rose about 10 points, the traction dropped about 10. The iron stock gained in market value on semi-official disclosures that extraordinary dividends are being earned; the street railway price went down because it becomes more and more plain that dividends are, for a considerable time in the future, out of the question.

Brooklyn Police Inspectors and Captains are very much wrought up over the activity shown by Chief Devery in holding them to a strict accountability for the large number of poolrooms and other gambling resorts which, it is alleged, are in operation in that borough, and among the rank and file of the force all sorts of rumors of impending changes are circulated.

Two firemen were overcome with smoke at a fire which gutted the five-story and basement brick and stone building at 421 Fifth Avenue at midnight last night. The building was occupied as a wholesale house by D.S. Hess Co., decorators and manufacturers of artistic furniture. Chief Croker estimated the damage at $250,000.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Winston Churchill sends a long dispatch from Pietermaritzburg, and, in addition to details respecting the position on the Tugela, he gives a most interesting survey of the general position. He says:

There was no change in the rapid transit situation yesterday, though there were persistent rumors that an effort would be made to obtain a still further reduction in the amount of the bond. Corporation Counsel Whalen said that he knew of no reason why the bond should not be reduced.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Feb. 1 -- Suits aggregating $1,700,000 have been brought against the Joseph Banigan estate by the United States Rubber Company and the Woonsocket Rubber Company.

The Presbytery of Brooklyn met in executive session in the Bedford Presbyterian Church yesterday, and for five hours considered the case of the Rev. George D. MacClelland. At the end of the meeting the members present admitted that they had accomplished nothing, although the session was a warm one by reason of contested points of procedure.

The second evening's sale of the collection of paintings by American artists formed by William T. Evans resulted in a larger aggregate amount being realized than at the sale on Wednesday evening. Mr. Evans, however, can hardly have been so well pleased as after the first evening's sale, since among the lots disposed of were some of the choicest pictures that he owned.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- The announcement was made to-day that the necessary money had been secured to support a club to represent this city in the new American Association of Baseball Clubs. Adrian C. Anson and John McGraw held a lengthy conference with several Philadelphians, whose names are not yet public property, and at its conclusion announced to the promoters of the new organization that their efforts had been successful.

Paintings and other art objects, the market value of which is estimated at $35,000 or $40,000, were destroyed yesterday morning in a fire which was confined to the top floor of the four-story studio building at 106 and 108 East Twenty-third Street. The pecuniary loss, however, represents but a portion of the real misfortune to Thomas R. Congdon and August R. Romes, who occupied the burned apartments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The resolution of Mr. Allen, (Pop., Neb.,) discharging the Finance Committee from further consideration of his resolution calling for information from the Secretary of the Treasury with reference to his transaction with the National City Bank and the Hanover National Bank of New York, was laid before the Senate to-day.

A gray-haired and bent old woman, shivering with the cold, was noticed at the corner of Barclay Street and West Broadway yesterday afternoon by Policeman Cohen of the Church Street Station. He asked the woman where she lived, and scratched his head at her reply that she was twenty years old and lived in Cork, Ireland.

The tournament of the Associated Cycling Clubs of Long Island began at the Harlem Palace, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, last night. The Century, Morris, and Bowling Green Wheelmen were scheduled to bowl. The Bowling Green Wheelmen did not appear, and forfeited their two games.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 1 -- The United States Canal Commission has arrived here. All the members are in good health.

A typical American Winter day, with bitter wind, a steely blue sky, and brilliant, if cold, sunshine, did not interfere yesterday with the carrying out of the day's social programme. There was, however, very little going on during the day, with the exception of a few "at homes," some women's luncheons, given by Mrs. Walter Watson, Jr., and Miss Mary Hopeton Drake, and a small reception at Mrs. Wilbur Bloodgood's.
