An exhibition of a novel character was held yesterday at 1,775 Broadway, the headquarters of the Household Economic Association. The exhibition, the first held by the association, was for the purpose of arousing interest in its work, and to give to wage earners an opportunity to display their skill in various lines of household industry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to express my thanks for your recent very able discussion of the proposed tax upon mortgages. Every intelligent man knows that the only effect of the tax would be to increase toy one-half of 1 per cent, the rate of interest upon every mortgage in the State, and that this result would follow as surely as the night follows the day.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 1 -- In compliance with a resolution of inquiry the President to-day sent to the Senate a copy or the report and all accompanying papers of Brig. Gen. J.C. Bates in relation to the negotiation of a treaty or agreement made by him with the Sultan of Sulu last August.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Investigations begun by the sanitary district engineers have shown the probability that the level of the Chicago River at Bridgeport will fall to five or six feet below Chicago datum if the full flow of the drainage canal is turned on. The assertion was vouched for to-day by Sanitary Trustee Alexander J. Jones.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve increased, L29,000; circulation increased, L232,000; bullion increased, L261,141; other securities decreased, L441,000; other deposits decreased, L359,000 public deposits decreased, L999,000; notes reserve increased L142,000; Government securities decreased.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 1 -- A.H. Campbell of Brooklyn and Mrs. Phoebe Osborn of Plainfleld, N.J., were married here this morning. The groom is seventy-four years old and this was his fifth marriage. The bride was a widow of fifty-five years. Both are much younger in appearance than in years, and after the ceremony they blushed as though it was the first time they had taken a principal part in such an event.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- St. James's Theatre, which was entirely remodeled during George Alexander's absence from London, was reopened this evening with Anthony Hope's "Rupert of Hentzau" before the most brilliant audience that has been seen there since the outbreak of the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Late to-night it is admitted at the White House that a communication has been received from Gov. Taylor of Kentucky, but no further information is given regarding it. The subject is one that will not be discussed for publication by those who have access to the President, Secretary Root alone venturing the admission that an appeal has been received and that it will not be answered at once.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- While no official confirmation has been received of the report printed in The St. James's Gazette, on what is said to be good authority, that Gen. Buller has crossed the Tugela River at three places and that fighting has been proceeding all day long, there is a disposition to credit it here in trustworthy quarters.

The meeting yesterday afternoon of the West End Woman's Republican Association looked for a time as though it would develop from a gathering to discuss vacation schools and playgrounds into an indignation meeting. After the reading of a paper by Mrs. Clarence Burns, Mrs. Cornelia S. Robinson, who presided, read a post card which had been addressed to the club.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 1 -- A fast passenger train on the Plant system was wrecked twenty miles north of this place last night. Engineer Kennedy was instantly killed. One passenger also was killed, but the body was so badly mutilated that it is impossible to identify it at this time. The son of S.P. Hernden, mail agent, of this city, died this morning at the Sanford Hospital.

Morris K. Jesup has sold to Alexander Walker the vacant block front on the east side of St. Nicholas Avenue, between One Hundred and Fourteenth and One Hundred and Fifteenth Streets. The plot measures 236.6 feet on the avenue, 141.11 feet on One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, and 93 feet on One Hundred and Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Representative Joseph Sibley of Pennsylvania, who attained prominence in the Fifty-fourth Congress by his earnest championship of free silver, assailed his Democratic colleagues to-day for their opposition to expansion in a speech that made the floor and galleries roar. Mr. Sibley has recanted his views on free silver and is now generally out of line with his colleagues on the Democratic side.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Jan. 31 the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,125,636,227, a decrease, as compared with last month, of $8,663,780. This decrease is accounted for by a corresponding increase in the amount of cash on hand.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1 -- The news from Mr. Goebel's room at 11:30 to-night is serious, and indicates that he may possibly die before morning. The action of the heart has grown weaker, and as circulation through the right lung is retarded by his wound, but little blood is received by the heart.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1 -- Lawyers representing the Republicans and Democrats held conferences to-day in an unsuccessful effort to arrive at a peaceful means of settlement of the existing trouble. The suggestion which led to these conferences came from the Republican side, and just before noon T.L. Edelen of Frankfort, one of Taylor's attorneys, appeared at the Capitol Hotel to meet Judge Pryor, Louis McQuown, and Col. William Scott, the legal advisers of the Democracy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- At the meeting of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day William Alden Smith of Michigan brought forward a proposition to provide for a diplomatic representative to the Transvaal, in place of the limited Consular representation now provided. The suggestion was discussed, but Mr. Smith did not submit a formal motion, and the proposition did not take form in the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill as finally agreed upon.

Triumphant notes of victory from the blue ribbon winners were the prevailing tones of the symphony that kept the residents in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden awake from dawn until the last electric spark in Madison Square Garden proclaimed the end of the third day of the eleventh annual exhibition of the New York Poultry and Pigeon Association.

That the railroads of this State would be helped and not hurt by the construction of an adequate waterway from the lakes to the ocean was the contention of Gen. FRANCIS V. GREENE in his speech at the Board of Trade dinner on Wednesday evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A number of the lawyers of the House of both political parties spent part of to-day in consideration of the legal phases of the situation in Kentucky.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Mr. Wyndham's remarkable declaration in the House of Commons that Great Britain will have in a fortnight 180,000 regulars in South Africa; 7,000 Canadians and Australians, and 20,000 South African volunteers is received with wonderment. Of this total of 213,000 troops, with 452 guns, all are now there, with the exception of about 18,000 that are afloat.

Simon Fatman, a cotton broker fifty-two years old living at 205 West One Hundred and Seventh Street, and having offices at 72 Beaver Street, committed suicide in Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the back of the head.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1 -- The conference between attorneys of Taylor and Goebel to-day has been accepted in certain quarters as an indication that Taylor was disposed to yield. In a statement made this morning Gov. Taylor made clear his position.

A conference in the interests of united action by churches and Christian workers throughout the United States opened yesterday afternoon in the Young Men's Christian Association rooms in Twenty-third Street. Representatives of over sixty churches and religious organizations ranging from Chicago to Boston are present in the city, and are participating in the furtherance of the federation of the denominations in non-denominational lines of activity.

BANGOR, Me., Feb. 1 -- The Bangor House to-night was the scene of a banquet tendered by the Penobscot bar to Justice John A. Peters, on the occasion of his retirement from the Supreme bench of Maine, after twenty-six years of service, sixteen years of that time as Chief Justice. Among the guests was United States Senator Hale, who made a speech.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- In the House of Commons to-day the Government parried most of the questions in regard to the war in South Africa. George Wyndham, the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for War, maintained that the information furnished by the Intelligence Department was generally accurate, and he added that information in regard to the forces remaining in the United Kingdom would tie included in the statement which the Government would make shortly.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- The special train bearing the remains of Major Gen. Henry W. Lawton, Major John A. Logan, Jr., and Surgeon L. Armstrong to their last resting place started east this afternoon. The departure of the bodies of the three officers was marked by fitting honors. The caskets containing the remains of the three officers wore borne by twelve noncommissioned officers of the Third Infantry and placed on flag-draped gun caissons.

The purchaser of the Standard Gas Light Company stock which Russell Sage, then its President, sold over five weeks ago, was William C. Whitney. Mr. Whitney controls not only this block, of some 5,700 shares, but the former Andrews estate holdings, amounting to about 12,000 shares, and other lots which swell the total to between 25,000 and 30,000 shares.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The oath of office of Francis Hendricks of Syracuse, the newly appointed State Superintendent of Insurance, was filed to-day with the Secretary of State. Mr. Hendricks will take office Feb. 12.

At last Buffalo is to be congratulated on a visible progress in culture. Blessings like misfortunes, rarely come singly, and after years and years of waiting, in a sordid devotion to affairs of commerce and industry that had attracted attention by its single-heartedness Buffalo takes a sudden and long leap forward in the visible civic fruits of culture.
The awards of honors for the sixty-ninth annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts have been announced in Philadelphia as follows:

Mrs. Annie Wittemeyer. Mrs. Annie Wittemeyer, who became famous as an army nurse during the civil war, and is known throughout the country as an author and lecturer, died yesterday at her home at Sanatoga, Penn., near Philadelphia. Mrs. Wittemeyer was born in Kentucky seventy-two years ago.
FRANKFORT Feb. 2. -- On the Boerse today local securities were easier. Americans were fairly firm.
Reports to the commercial agencies of the country, telling of business conditions, note some interesting facts:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The "Seeker After Knowledge" who speaks so slightingly of "When Knighthood Was in Flower," in your SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 20, seems to have been singularly unfortunate in his quest.
The report of the Chamber of Commerce committee of which Mr. A. FOSTER HIGGINS is Chairman, in favor of "the objects" of the Ship Subsidy bill, contains this remarkable statement:
The events of the past twenty-four hours confirm the wisdom of the President in refusing to intervene in the affairs of Kentucky.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- The Passaic County Grand Jury handed up a batch of indictments this afternoon. Among the lot were indictments against officials and employes of the Lackawanna, Railroad in connection with the wreck near the Barclay Street Station here on Thanksgiving Eve, when seven persons were killed.

That was a curious interview that was "given out" a day or two ago by Mr. BIRDSALL, the chief engineer of the Croton Water Bureau and the official expert of the interesting and remarkable Mr. DALTON, the official head of the Water Department. Mr. DALTON, as everybody knows, is up to his ears in the Ramapo job.

Although yesterday seemed warmer, even during the morning hours, with the disappearance of the biting winds of Thursday, the arctic weather made its presence felt, and had a marked effect upon social doings. Fortunately there was comparatively little going on in the morning hours, and as the younger element had danced itself weary at the Charity Ball of the preceding night, it was glad of the rest.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: At the request of several of the most prominent artists of this city, I write besging you will kindly insert the following in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of your much esteemed and admired paper:
To The New York Times Saturday Review: We sometimes read of unkindness to authors, of heartless criticism; but yet how little in point of fact there is of it as measured by the past!

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Nearly the entire time of the Cabinet meeting to-day was taken up in a discussion of the situation in Kentucky and the rights and duties of the President in connection therewith. Almost immediately upon the receipt of Gov. Taylor's message last night, the President took up the question and consulted authorities on points with which he was not familiar.

There is reason to rejoice over the fact that Henrl de Regnier, the distinguished French poet, will deliver next March, before the Cercle Francais of Harvard University, a series of lectures on "Contemporary Poetry in France." Both the lecturer and the lectures will, beyond any doubt, prove unusually interesting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Representative Talbert, (Dem., S.C.,) who gave notice during the consideration of the Pension Appropriation bill last week that he proposed to block all special pension legislation at Friday night sessions unless a quorum of members was present, carried out his threat at to-night's session.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The defense in the case of Senator Clark of Montana before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day began the presentation of its side of the controversy.
Dr. Charles A. Pickhardt, a dentist of 210 Central Park South, and his wife, Minnie W., have brought counter actions for separation in the Supreme Court. Each charges the other with cruel treatment.

Persons whose memories go back to the time of the appearance of the first edition of Gen. Lew Wallace's "Ben Hur," may wonder why the gifted author was moved to alter in a small but significant degree the wording of the dedication inscribed in the book. Copies of the first edition bear the legend. "To the Wife of My Youth."

It is said that the Central Congregational Church, worshipping at 230 Amsterdam Avenue, will be given up. A short time ago the Sunday school and the mid-week prayer meeting were abandoned on account of the poor attendance. A man thoroughly acquainted with the affairs of the church says that there is but little money left in the treasury.

Senator HANNA on Wednesday night made a passionate appeal to New York merchants to support the ship subsidy bill. He had the bad taste to declare that the arguments against the bill were "paid for by our competitors," but in this community that is a statement which Mr. HANNA'S authority will hardly suffice to sustain.

The announcement yesterday that Edmund Clarence Stedman, broker, as well as poet and critic, has sold his seat on the Stock Exchange aroused a great deal of interest among its members. His long connection with the Exchange, his many friends there, and his prominence as a literary man, combined to render the transfer of his membership an occasion of more than ordinary note.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., Feb. 2. -- Thomas R. Bard of Ventura was nominated United States Senator to-night by a rump caucus composed of fifty-four Republican members of the Legislature.

The fight between the Jenkins and Lord families at Clifton, S.I., relative to the Lord stable has broken out afresh, and a suit is now probable. Dr. William T. Jenkins, one of the city's health commissioners, and who married a sister of Richard Croker, was formerly Health Officer of the port.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 2. -- The condition of William Goebel is to-night considered better than at any time since he was shot. The iron will and the determination of the wounded man that he will not die by an assassin's bullet is, however, still considered the main factor in sustaining him, but to-night the attending physicians, for the first time, hold out some hope for his ultimate recovery.

The discussion now going on at Washington over the details of legislation for Puerto Rico shows that the Congressional mind has not yet got a firm grasp of the principles upon which action must be based.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Sensational rumors are current that the Militia Ballot act will be put in force Feb. 14, and that Gen. Lord Roberts, the Commander in Chief of the British forces in South Africa, has cabled for 90,000 additional men, which, it is added, the Government has promised to give him, sending 50,000 militia and volunteers and 40,000 militia reserves.
About six months ago The Sun published this communication from a distinguished resident of this town, who has preferred that his name should be known only to ourselves:
A panting little cockney coachman, dropping his h's as he ran, rushed up to a member of the Broadway Squad yesterday afternoon near Thirtieth Street.

At the first public meeting of the National Institute of Arts and letters, held at Mendelssohn Hall in this city on Tuesday evening, an address by Charles Dudley Warner, the President, was read by Hamilton W. Mable, owing to Mr. Warner's illness, and an address was made by Dr. Henry Van Dyke.

Though commission house customers were not yesterday much in evidence, the security market's course was encouraging to traders who declare themselves confident that Wall Street is to have new good times -- is not to continue the one blue spot of the country. Most of the professional traders on the Stock Exchange have become bullish and join in the agreeable performance of bidding up prices.

The Rev. Dr. Madison C. Peters, who has resigned as pastor of the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, after occupying the pulpit for eleven years, because he has accepted the doctrine of baptism for believers only, yesterday said that since he became convinced of the truth of this teaching, he had objected strongly to baptizing the infant children of members of the church, and for the last three months had refused to officiate upon such occasions.

Public handshaking and eloquent speeches and the return of "confiscated" property are far less significant signs of perfectly renewed brotherhood than the appearance of such a book as Mr. John S. Wise's. "The End of an Era," bearing the imprint of the publishers of Mrs. Stowe and Lowell, for in it one finds the Virginian of the past described and defended by one of the youngest survivors of the race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The President to-day transmitted to Congress the first volume of the report of the Philippine Commission. It is a volume of 264 pages, including the appendix, and is signed by Prof. Schurmann, Admiral Dewey, Col. Denby, and Prof. Worcester.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- At a special meeting of the Ways and Means Committee to-day it was decided to report a bill establishing a tariff system for Puerto Rico on a basis of 25 per cent. of the rates in the regular tariff law, goods coming to the island from foreign countries to pay the same rates as if entered at a port of the United States.

Senhor Oliveira Lima, a prominent author of Brazil, a member of the Brazilian Academy, and at present First Secretary of the Brazilian Legation at Washington, has embodied the result of his observations of our country in a volume entitled "Nos Estados Unidos. Impressoes Politicas e Sociaes," ("In the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- What was probably the last official report of the late Gen. Lawton, embodying an account of the remarkable campaign conducted by him in the Province of Cavite, the home of Aguinaldo last June, has been received at the War Department from Gen. Otis. Gen. Lawton says:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I can heartily call the attention of your correspondent, "L.E," to Cardinal Newman's definition of the true gentleman, which can be found in his "Idea of a University," edition of 1891, pp. 209, 210. Thus:

The year 1899 left the impression of being an abnormally busy one with the publishers -- an impression created chiefly, perhaps, through the concentration of the business of the year into its last three months.

In the first public meeting of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, held in this city on Tuesday evening, ought to be found an inspiration to better things in literature. The addresses of Charles Dudley Warner and Dr. Henry Van Dyke, given elsewhere in this issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, sound a note of warning in terms not to be mistaken.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 2. -- Late last night fire broke out in the McElroy Furniture Company's store and extended to J. M. Euwer Son's store of dry goods and to the adjoining block, occupied by G.M. McKelvey Co.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The Society of Authors, of which Sir Walter Besant is the head, has begun the collection of a fund for the payment, of pensions to old and needy authors. The money-needed is to be raised by voluntary contributions, and a dozen or so authors have already subscribed sums varying from two hundred to five pounds.

After a life of nearly four years, the United States Church Army, a Protestant Episcopal organization, has reached the end of its career. The Lay Director of the army, Gen. Henry H. Hadley, has resigned his post, and his resignation has been accepted by the Church Army Commission, consisting of Rev. Dr. E. Walpole Warren of New York City and the Rev. Dr. William M. Hughes of Morristown, N.J.

According to tradition yesterday was the day of the year when that astute weather sharp, the ground hog, strolls out of his Winter quarters to have a look at the weather. If he sees his shadow, according to this hoary superstition, he retires again for an extra nap of six weeks or so, awaiting the coming of balmy Spring.

The sale of the collection of paintings by American artists, belonging to William T. Evans, was brought to a close at Chickering Hall last evening. The collection consisted of 270 pictures, which brought slightly over $158,500. The only sale of works by native artists which can be compared to the dispersal of the Evans collection in importance is the Thomas B. Clarke sale of a year ago.

A goodly number of the creditors of F. Tennyson Neely, the publisher who failed recently, attended a Hearing yesterday at the office of Referee in Bankruptcy Morris S. Wise 52 Exchange Place. It evolved a good deal of warm argumentation, and nearly broke up in a row, but harmony was finally restored.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Whatever may be the hope of the Republicans in Kentucky there is no sort of doubt that the Washington Administration has come to the conclusion that Gov. Taylor has blundered desperately and destroyed the prospect that he had a few days ago to throw the odium of the scandalous situation at Frankfort completely upon the Democrats.

In one of the most attractive covers of the season, designed and signed by Charles Robinson -- the illustrator of the book, reproduced in soft reds, browns, yellows, and greens, which with a small amount of gold blends into a most harmonious whole -- comes a romance by Norman Garstin. "The Suitors of Aprille," which in its narration proves itself worthy of its delightful cover.
Montagu White, who represents the Boers in this country in an unofficial capacity, and who since his arrival here has refused interviews, gave out the following statement last night:

Stevenson's many friends -- and what a group of well-known names in modern letters they comprise! -- have written affectionately and appreciatively of him, but nothing that has been said by them has expressed the idea of his personality and its charm as much as the recently published volumes of his letters.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: We are all admirers of the genius of Marlon Crawford, but when it becomes a question of the accuracy of the theory upon which the plot of any one of his novels is founded, I feel that if the facts were supported by accompanying affidavits it would be well to have the witnesses indicted for perjury.
The seven-story apartment house, known as the Sans Souci, 31 and 33 West One hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, facing Mount Morris Park, has been sold to an investor through Broker Frank R. Sharrott.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day notified all National bank depositories that no further deposits of internal revenue receipts will be forwarded to New York for distribution to banks which have deposited bonds as security, under the Secretary's offer of Dec. 18 last.

Patrick Mahoney and James Mallon, two policemen, until yesterday attached to the East Thirty-fifth Street Station, were last evening transferred, Mallon to the Madison Street Station and Mahoney to the East Thirtieth Street Station, on the initiative of Chief Devery.

Sir Walter Besant's article on the "Problems of Bookselling in England," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday, Jan. 21, is an interesting statement of the condition of affairs in the book world in England at the present time. But this condition is so very different in every respect from that governing the book trade in America that Sir Walter's criticisms in general do not apply here.

The Sun at once guaranteed the good faith of "Responsibility's" offer, and likewise his ability to redeem his promises. At the request of this gentleman we received, until Oct. 15, manuscripts submitted in competition. About one thousand poems were sent. They came from nearly every State of the Union, and from several foreign countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- The meeting of the American Association of Baseball Clubs came to an end to-day. Six cities, Baltimore, Boston, Milwaukee, Detroit, Chicago, and St. Louis, have signed the agreement, each furnishing a $1,200 bond. Providence and Philadelphia have not yet signed, but the former has pledged itself to furnish the bond as soon as this city registers.

One evidence that this country has passed its first youlh and acquired memories is seen in the great number of historical and memorial societies that have been formed in the last ten years. Women to whom the inventions of the century have tended to give leisure have contributed largely to this, and the record of their self-denying labors connected with this work makes an interesting and impressive total.
"I do not know what poetical is; is it honest in deed and word? Is it a true thing?"

It was reported on Wall Street yesterday, on what was considered reliable authority, that all arrangements had practically been completed for the transfer of the control of the Western New York and Pennsylvania Railroad to interests chiefly represented by President Cassatt of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Senator Pettigrew to-day called up the resolution he offered yesterday to print as a public document a compilation of matter bearing the title "The Philippine Commission."

-- There is a very appreciable amount of inaccuracy in applying, as does our neighbor The Sun the name "round robin" to the declaration in favor of GOEBEL for Governor made by the Democratic members of the Kentucky Legislature. A round robin is a document signed in such a way as to divide equally among all the signors the responsibility for drawing up and presenting it.

Both in several large transactions and in the average run of dealings the business of the last week showed marked improvement. The improvement, moreover, was general in character, nearly every class of property figuring in the results, while the presence of the investor was perhaps more noticeable than it has been for a long period.

VIENNA, Jan. 16. -- The more Germany pushes forward, the mere decidedly her friend and ally, Austria-Hungary, remains behind; the more German trade and political influence extend in the world, the more do those of this country shrink and diminish. People ask themselves here why we are a great power and with empty hands run by the side of Germany's triumphal car.

A comparison of the amounts paid to the city by street railway companies for car license fees and percentages for the years 1808 and 1899 shows that there has been only a small increase in the gross receipts of such corporations and that few new cars have been placed upon the local lines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is inconceivable to me that any person with the military knowledge that Gov. Roosevelt is supposed to have can say that the remarks of Gen. Hawkins before the officers of the Seventy-first "contain nothing to warrant a reopening of the Court of Inquiry in the case of that regiment."

"It's a bloomin' outrage, and I'll 'ave justice on every one responsible for my bein' in this disgraceful predicament," said a tall, florid-faced man who, puffing his broad chest, filled the entire space back of the door of a narrow cell in the Yorkville prison yestarday afternoon and rubbed his hands through the mass of yellow hair that covered his head.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 3. -- The possibility of a passage at arms between the forces which are guarding Gov. Taylor in the State House and representatives of the authority of the State courts was increased to-night by the action of the Republican Executive and his Adjutant General. Neither side shows any sign of yielding, and the situation is rapidly approaching a crisis.

The much-talked of play founded on the religious novel called "In His Steps" will be produced at the London Adelphi Theatre shortly. It is entitled "The Better Life," and was put together by those two expert melodramatists Sutton Vane and Arthur Shirley. The interest lies between Mark Verner, an earnest young clergyman; John Haddon, a Socialist; Bessie, his wife; Mary Penfold, a worker in the slums, and Constance Howard, described as "a woman of pleasure."

There have been some interesting developments in the baseball situation during the past week. The prospective new American Association held a meeting at Philadelphia, but it is having a rather rough time in getting organized. The vast amount of capital that the Philadelphia combination had in sight two weeks ago seems to have suddenly vanished.

"The Ambassador," by John Olive Hobbes, as the English novelist, Mrs. Craigie, likes to call herself, will be acted for the first time in this country at Daly's Theatre to-morrow night. There are sixteen women in this play, and fourteen of them wear fashionable dresses, some of them four or five in the course of the action.

PUERTO PRINCIPE, Feb. 3. -- Governor General Wood and his party arrived list evening at Nuevitas, and a special train brought them to Puerto Principe, where a large crowd blocked the station, greeting Gen. Wood with loud "Vivas" as he alighted from the carriage.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 3. -- Judge D.M. Key died in this city to-night, aged seventy-six years. He was born in Greene County, Tenn., and was one of the most distinguished men in the South. He was a Colonel in the Confederate Army, in 1865, when he was appointed United States Senator, to fill the unexpired term of Andrew Johnson.

The unlooked-for postponement in the Sixty-ninth Regiment for the election of field officers has given rise to considerable comment among a number of its officers, some of whom are of the pronounced opinion that regimental politics have again taken control of the regiment to an extent which is liable to prove detrimental to its interests.

Postmaster Van Cott said, yesterday that the Committee on Public Buildings of the House of Representatives will visit this city next Saturday in order to examine into the necessity for a new General Post Office in New York. Mr. Van Cott has long contended that the present building is inadequate, and has expressed his views in Washington.
William C. Whitney made public yesterday the following statement regarding his purchase of Standard Gas Light Company stock:

ZAMBOANGA, Dec. 18. -- Brig. Gen. Bates and Lieuts. Reeve and Cowin of his personal staff have just returned from visiting the various ports in Southern Mindanao, at which it is proposed placing garrisons composed of various companies of the Thirty-first Regiment of Infantry, United States Volunteers.

"I must begin some time to count up all the people I have played with; just to name them all would nil a book," said little Mile. Bauermeister, talking about the operatic stage the other day. "For I have played in almost every opera," she went on, "and at one time or another almost all the roles except the heavy Wagnerian roles.

BOSTON, Feb. 3. -- The Boston Athletic Association games in Mechanics' Hall, the most important of the several indoor athletic events of the Winter in New England, was witnessed by fully 6,000 enthusiastic admirers of the contestants and clubmen. From beginning to end the events were keenly fought out, the interest, however, as last week at the Boston College games, centring in the inter-collegiate team races.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- L.L. Wright of Missoula, Mon., was the first witness in the Clark case before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much interest your able and timely editorial of Feb. 1, 1900, and Mr. Nathan Bijur's letter on, the Stranahan tax report, showing the incidence of the proposed mortgage tax to rest on the borrower or Real estate owner, and that otherwise the effect will be to drive away capital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Naval Register for 1900, just issued by the Bureau of Navigation, is a more voluminous one than that of a year ago by twenty pages. The changes incidental to retirement and promotion for all reasons are many in number. Of officers in the regular service, there were 44 resignations, 63 retirements, 43 deaths, 2 dismissals, and 1 revocation of rating.

The Woman's Aid to the George Junior Republic held a meeting in the church rooms of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday, for the purpose of interesting women in the work of the institution, at Freeville, N.Y., and obtaining substantial assistance.
BOSTON, Feb. 3. -- Boston had a good market to-day. There were some buying orders, and the market, from being a better market on which to sell, is becoming a good market to buy.

Mrs. Francis Buckland Hart, said to be the oldest native-born New Yorker on Manhattan Island, has been stricken with pneumonia and lies at death's door. If she lives until March 14 she will round out a century. Her son, Councilman Harry Hart, the Tammany leader in the Thirtieth District, and her other numerous relatives have for months been preparing to celebrate the event.

THE reports of the New York Commerce Commission, appointed by Gov. Black, and of the Committee on the Canals of New York, appointed by Gov. Roosevelt, which were expected about the first of January, were presented to the Legislature on the 25th ult., acompanied by messages from the Governor substantially, if not enthusiastically, indorsing their conclusions.
Congratulations may be extended this week on anniversaries of their weddings to-

The phenomenal activity of the past year in this country in the production of iron and steel is generally recognized as an index of the prosperity of other industries, because these materials enter so largely into the structures and appliances of all kinds of manufacture and trade; and now men prominently connected with the iron and steel interests declare with the utmost confidence that there is no sign of abatement in that activity.

One must be careful how he, expresses himself in these days. A reader of this weekly review of theatricals found something: amiss in my perfectly innocent remark last Sunday that the new spectacular show at the New York Theatre, beins free from immoral suggestiveness or gross vulgarity, ought to be considered a good show for the children.
LONDON, Feb. 3. -- We are in full swing with the debate on the address, and the public up to now has not been very well satisfied with it.

The electric searchlights introduced by Chief Croker as one of the modern equipments of the Fire Department got another working test last evening at a fire which occurred in the Hamberger Building, 94 to 98 Mott Street, and proved a great aid to the men. The special engine which operates the searchlights arrived at the fire in response to the second alarm which was sounded.

The managers of the Brooklyn Institute have formed the project of securing for the museum under their charge the Tissot collection of paintings illustrating the life of CHRIST. For this purpose they will require some $60,000, and are asking subscriptions, conditioned on at least $50,000 being raised.

IN an article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES three weeks ago attention was called to the general problem of tax reform in this State and to the paramount importance of the separation of State and local revenues. Since that article appeared the specific proposition of the legislative Committee on Taxation has been made public.

H.N. Pillsbury, the American chess champion, is still touring in the Far West, the latest report locating him at St. Paul, Minn. He has been giving exhibitions steadily for the past month, and his list of engagements is understood to be full up to March 18.
IT has rather teen borne in upon me, as the result of some experience with the nervous type of humanity, that religion is a good thing for this class, both as a helpful and a preventive force.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- A dispatch has been received from Lady Randolph Churchill, who is on board the American hospital ship Maine, at Durban, saying the vessel will be stationed there for the present. The Maine was filling with wounded men, including numbers from the battle of Spion Kop.

Our London correspondent bears cumulative testimony, in his cable letter published to-day, to the disappointment, and even disheartenment, which were produced, in the minds of anxious and patriotic Englishmen, by Lord SALISBURY'S remarks on the Queen's speech. These emotions related to the matter of the speech, and even more to the manner.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Jan. 31. -- Prosperity could not have marked for special favor a prettier town in South Carolina than Greenville. The face of nature is fairer here, possibly, than it is at Spartanburg, a few miles east and north, but also a little further away from the noble Blue Ridge that walls Greenville to the north.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 3. -- Two attendants at the College of Physicians and Surgeons in this city, named Denine and Rupp, were arrested to-day, charged with having stolen the body of the unknown man, which was received in Sioux City, Iowa, a few days ago in a packing box.

Although John B. McDonald said yesterday that he would apply to Alexander E. Orr, Preslient of the Rapid Transit Commission, for an extension of time over and above his twenty days, no notice of such a request had bean received by Mr. Orr. at the close of office hours yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Feb. 3. -- Sir Thomas Grainger Stewart, the noted Scotch physician, died in Edinburgh this morning, aged sixty-three years.

After enjoying their third annual dinner at the St. Denis Hotel last night, the members of the New York Commercial Teachers' Association listened to speeches by J.L.N. Hunt, Associate Superintendent of the Public Schools of Manhattan and the Bronx, and other guests? about the modern requirements of a commercial college curriculum.

Henceforth the improving and beautifying of the streets and sidewalks of Riverhead, L.I., will be in the hands of the women of that place. At the annual meeting of the Riverhead Village improvement Society yesterday the men who have held office stepped down and women were substituted.

Two perils, in the opinion of Revivalist LEON G. BROUGHTON, beset this community and threaten its moral destruction. One is the woman typewriter in the inner office. The other is the social club. The ravages of the typewriter are authorized by her fatal gift of beauty; of the social club by its whisky and cognate forms of the demon:

Patrons of the Third Avenue Railroad are making many complaints about the new cars which were lately introduced. They are much longer than the ordinary cars, and the seats are arranged as in a passenger coach, seating two persons each.

My heart gave a great jump when, rounding a bend in the narrow road, I saw a few hundred, yards off a crumbling battlemented wall, and a little further off a, high gateway. It was the wall, it was the gate, of Khiva. The horses of the drosky and of the jigitas threw up great clouds of white dust.

Dr. Albert S. Ashmead, who was largely Instrumental in causing the detention of the coffee ships, down the bay recently on the suspicion that their cargoes might be infected with the bubenic plague, sounds another note of warning in regard to leprosy in this city. He said, at his office, at 65 West Twelfth Street, yesterday, that there are at least one hundred lepers going daily about the streets without restraint.

By the stroke of a pen, John F. Carroll, leader of Tammany Hall in the absence of Richard Croker, was put in the position of making several hundred thousand dollars yesterday. By another stroke of the same pen, thirty minutes later, he lost all chances of obtaining one of the richest receiverships ever in the gift of the local courts.

The tank statement issued shortly before the close of business yesterday was, with the exception of the loan item, about what was anticipated. Surplus reserve inreased $1,593,300, specie $5,002,000, and leal tender $438,500 The increase of $11, 49,800 in the loan accounts was however, ather more than was generally expected, though it had been apparent that during he week there had been a considerable exension in speculation and therefore a greater demand for money.

The public mind is in a state of more or less confusion regarding motor-carriage problems, which, during the last year, have been presented in many forms. During this coming year these various impressions will be differentiated; many that are very wild will be rejected, and the merits of the several systems more fully comprehended.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Among the applicants for Government assistance in the management of woodlands is William Rockefeller, who owns a tract of 60,000 acres at Bay Pond, Franklin County, N.Y., on which he has built a hunting and fishing lodge. Much of the land has been logged over, but there is a large tract of virgin timber which has passed the stage of greatest production in a natural state, and lying idle.

Edward M. Shepard addressed the Citizens' Union Club of the Ninth Assembly District last night at the home of O.R. Lamb, 356 West Twenty-second Street. Mr. Shepard said the theory on which the charter had been constructed was that the people of this city could not be trusted to govern themselves.

From Longman's. New Zealand Is a country rich in the great variety of its forest trees; most of them useful, all beautiful, but none to compare with kauri pine, either for stately beauty or commercial value. This noble tree attains a height of nearly 200 feet, and a diameter of 15 or even more.

William Stanley Haseltine. William Stanley Haseltine, an artist, whose home was in Boston, died of pneumonia in Rome, Italy, yesterday. He was sixty-five years old. He was a member of the Century Club and the National Academy of Design of this city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his communication under the above caption Mr. Saul objects to the phrase, "subordination under State Socialism," and says that under Socialism proper the whole people will form the Government under the principles of the initiative, referendum, imperative mandate, and recall, and that this is the only true Socialism.

The thinnest of Summer goods usually, come in with the coldest weather, and they are so tempting that it looks as if the dry goods shops might be in league with the railroads, for every woman who sees the pretty light stuffs feels like starting at once for a warmer part of the country where she can wear them.
FRANKFORT, Feb. 3. -- Mr. Beckham tonight issued the following proclamation:

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- In "The Messenger Boy," produced at the Gaiety Theatre this evening, George Edwardes has a piece Which, in the opinion of critics, promises to rival in popularity the greatest successes of this house. Edmund Payne, Katie Seymour, and Connie Ediss all have parts admirably suited to their talent, and they and other favorites were cordially received.

FRANKFORT, Feb. 3. -- William Goebel, by his partisans called the Governor of Kentucky and by his enemies termed a usurper, died in his room at the Capitol Hotel at 6:44 o'clock to-night from the effects of the gunshot wound received Tuesday morning. As little is known now as then whose hand it was that fired the fatal shot, but whoever it was his work is well done.

The unspeakable dullness of the musical season does not encourage comment on the current attractions at the places of musical entertainment. Novelties in the line of instrumental music are few and far between and those which are produced do not stimulate the thought of the commentator.

With visions of money to be made in Paris during the forthcoming Exposition, three lads from the east side disappeared from home last Monday. Two of them had excellent reputations and were pupils in the High School on East Twenty-third Street. The other lad was an electrician's apprentice, and had disappeared on two or three occasions, on one of which he remained away from home for over six weeks.

A five-hundred-thousand-dollar mortgage was filed in the Suffolk County Clerk's office yesterday from the American RealtyCompany to the Farmers Loan and Trust Company of New York. The instrument covered property recently sold to the firstnamed company by ex-Judge Henry E. Howland.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 3. -- There now threatens to be a physicalas well as a legal struggle between the League and the Association over the Union Park ball grounds here. The Association forces have begun their battle for actual as well as technical possession, and the clash of arms may be expected at any moment.

In every city of the land the newspaper man is an outcast. He knows more people to be a stranger to than any other being in the world. He has no holidays. His Christmas is the record of other men's joys. His Thanksgiving is a restaurant. Even the Fourth of July and Sunday, servants of the commonest man, refuse him their cheer.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- The German Foreign Office denies that Dr. Leyds, the Diplomatic Agent of the Transvaal, is attempting to induce Germany to join in an intervention movement Dr. Leyds declines to discuss possible intervention, and denies that he is going to St. Petersburg He is under medical treatment and still without information as to why former United States Consul Macrum left Pretoria.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 3. -- The contest over the will of Maria Van Sickle continued before Judge Fort to-day. The estate, which is valued at $100,000, was left to John K. Van Sickle, her nephew. Albert L. Van Sickle of Chicago, who is not yet of age, is contesting the will on the ground of mental incapacity.

The biennial State convention of the Young Men's Christian Association will be held at Kingston from Feb. 15 to Feb. 18, inclusive. It is hoped that at least 400 business men, representing the Young Men's Christian Association of this State will be present in addition to the delegates. The Executive Committee has determined that the subjects discussed shall be related to each other, so that continuity of thought may be obtained.

The other day I received a letter from a reader of this column who stated that he had a hammerless revolver, and found that it was not up to his requirements for target shooting. He requested me to denounce small arms of this variety so that future purchasers of revolvers might shun them and avoid the disappointment which he had experienced.

There will be a public hearing in Albany Wednesday on the bill introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Fallows and drawn by Theron G. Strong, which amends Section 344 of the Penal Code of the State relating to gambling, and which is mainly intended to give the police a leverage by which they can suppress the policy playing evil.

THE ACTUAL STATE OP THE GREAT FAMINE IN INDIA. -- When the famine which ravaged India three years ago had reached its most fatal period, in January, 1897, Lord Elgin, in a speech before the Viceroy's Legslative Council, in Calcutta, said that the occasion had no parallel in history, and he cited the fact that there were 1,250,000 persons on the relief lists.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 3. -- Another tornado swept the coast Monday night. Lark Harbor was devastated, and twenty houses were blown down, including the custom station and the residence of the customs officer. All the families took refuge in their cellars. A French lobster factory, one of the largest on the coast, with all its contents, boats and fishing gear was demolished, being blown to pieces.

Nearly thirty years ago Dr. Gallon, in his "Hereditary Genius," pointed-out how rarely a man got into the dictionaries of contemporary biography before the age of fifty, and his statement is true, even to the present day; the mean age of the persons mentioned in "Who's Who" is no less than fifty-five, even though several names are included of persons who have had greatness thrust upon them in the first decade of their life.

The feature of the bowling in the Wholesale Drug Trade Association tournament at Reid's alleys yesterday afternoon was the game between the Dodge Olcott and the Colgate Co. teams. The latter led until Colgate, the last man, took his turn in the tenth frame. He made a break, missing a difficult spare.

Sitting in a chair beside his wife's coffin, mourning for the helpmeet who for thirty years had shared his joys and sorrows, and who had been suddenly taken from him, Edward Mathews, with equal suddenness, also passed away. This was on Friday afternoon. To-day the bodies will be buried in the same grave.

An appeal is made to American Protestants to contribute money to defray the expenses for the completion of a handsome memorial church at Speyer-on-the-Rhine to commemorate the first princely support given in Germany to the reformation begun by Martin Luther. This support was the famous protestation of the minority at the session of the Imperial Diet at Speyer-onthe-Rhine against the edict of the majority for the suppression of the reformatory movement.

Golfers in the metropolitan district will have more time to practice for their annual championship tournament than was the case last year, as the meeting of the Metropolitan Golf Association last Thursday evening changed the time for that competition from April to May, Judging from, the sentiments expressed at the meeting the tournament will not tie held earlier than May 15.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- A special to the Tribune from Bisbee, Arizona, says: A dispatch was received here last night from Guaymas conveying news that Gen. Lorenzo Torres, Commander of the Mexican forces in the Yaqui war, had been killed in the Bacatete Mountains. The report is lacking in detail and has not been confirmed.

A centuy has passed by since the first meteorological society of Europe published the "Ephemerides Mannheimensis," containing weather observations at many stations. From these records Brandes subsequently made and studied the first weather maps. Now every civilized land has its dally reports by telegraph and cable.

Trading was less active in the market for outside securities, yesterday than it was during the early part of the week, and relatively few changes of importance showed in the closing quotations. Interest was practically confined to a sharp advance in Electric Vehicle preferred, a substantial rise in Amalgamated Copper and a fractional reaction in Bay State Gas.

The amateur billiard tournament, fourteen-inch balk-line game, for Class A players, will begin at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, to-morrow night. There are six entries this year for the championship honors. including Wilson P. Foss of Haverstraw, N.Y.; Wayman C. McCreery of St. Louis, Dr. L.L. Mial of New York, J. De Mun Smith of St. Louis, C.F. Conklin of Chicago, and C.G. Threshie of Boston.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Upon reading the complaint of "Citizeness," as one of the "up-town" residents, about the cold cars we are obliged to put up with these bitterly cold days, it seems to me a fitting time to bring before the minds of the "powers that be" the abuses the "down-town" people have to stand.

Health Commissioner William T. Jenkins said yesterday that his fight with his neighbor, George O. Lord, at Clifton, S.I., over the latter's stable, which is near Dr. Jenkins's house, would now be pushed to the end. The noises made by the animals in the stable at night, the Commissioner alleges, make sleep impossible in his home.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- While the theatrical business generally is about as bad as it could be, the number of London theatres is fast increasing, and they are reaching a point of splendor and convenience which quite outclasses the older houses. To Beerbohm Tree's and Charles Wyndham's new theatres and the gorgeous Hippodrome must now be added George Alexander's, as the St. James's has been so enlarged and rebuilt as to be practically new.

The Lasell Club of New York held its seventh annual meeting and luncheon yesterday at the Waldonf-Astoria. The club is composed of graduates and former pupils of Lasell Seminary, at Aubumdale, Mass. Especial interest attached to the meeting because of a letter from the Principal, Prof. C.C. Bragdon, which was read by the President of the club, Mrs. Grace Garland Etherington.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 3. -- Another Florida cup has gone to R.C. Watson, Jr., the last being the President's prize, played for in the two days' tournament here Friday and Saturday. His opponent in the finals this afternoon was Joseph P. Greaves, who is playing very good golf, having reduced his game twenty points since the season opened.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 3. -- The citizens of the town of Hartland, Litchfield County, expect to take a holiday next Saturday and go to Hartford in a body to urge Judge S. Oscar Prentis of the Superior Court to favor the laying out of a highway to West Hartland Pond.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- To the police of the United States and England Alexander Haviland Gildersleeve, who has been entertained and feted by the wealthiest families of Chicago for the last two months, is known as "No. 6,220." Three days ago Mr. Gildersleeve disappeared, leaving bills unpaid and with thousands of dollars worth of stolen jewelry in his possession.

Here is a question for a parliamentarian, or at least the members of the Sotiety for Political Study considered that it was at their meeting last week. Other people might consider that it could be settled easily by other than parliamentary laws. An amendment to the constitution had been read to the effect that no one could be elected an officer until she had been a member of the society for two years.

MASTER AND SERVANT. -- J. Francis Murray, twenty years old, was injured March 24 1894, by the falling of a pulley block at the warehouse of Harvey A. Dwight, at Albany, N.Y. Murray was employed by J. McManus, who sent him with a horse to hoist at the storehouse, at the request of Reed Co., who usually did that sort of work for Mr. Harvey.

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 3. -- A dispatch from Monterey, Mexico, says that Gen. Bernardo Reyes, formerly Governor of the State of Nuevo Leon, but who was recently appointed Minister of War by President Diaz, has formed plans looking to the early subjection of the rebellious Yaqui Indians. He will first make a reasonable proposition to the warring tribe for peace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A constant reader of your paper, I was gratified to see in the issue of Jan. 31 that New York has at last developed a kickeress and a kicker, who have made bold to accuse the street car companies of abuse of their patrons in two well-written articles signed "Citizeness" and "B.F.," respectively.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 3. -- Exactly one hour after the death of Mr. Goebel, J.C. W. Beckham was sworn in as Governor of the State, the oath being administered by S.J. Shackelford, Clerk of the Court of Appeals.
LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The energetic Ladysmith correspondent of The Standard thus describes Christmas Day in the beleaguered camp:

Considerable, talk has been occasioned in oharch circles in Brooklyn by the action of the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, pastor of Plymouth Church, in consenting to preside at one of the local revival meetings this week. It was thought by many that Dr. Hillis's action was in the nature of a disavowal of the course taken by Plymouth Church with regard to the revival movement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The report of Chief Statistician W.A. King, in charge of the Mortality Division of the Census Office, shows that 130 cities have agreed to adopt the uniform return of deaths suggested and recommended by him, and that twenty other cities will do so at an early date. These cities are all outside of registration areas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the compositors employed on The City Record during the rush of publishing the enrollment or voters for primaries, I would suggest that the city employ a competent corps of typewriters to prepare copy for the printer. I can recall a dozen instances or more where father and son, registering from the same house, had their names spelled differently in the copy.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Many unsuccessful attempts have been made to obtain the release from the State prison at Trenton of Libbie Garrabrandt, who twenty-five years ago was sentenced for life for the killing of a man named Burroughs. Prominent persons have interceded for her, but the vote in the Court of Pardons has always been against her.

The large auditorium of Carnegie Hall was well filled yesterday when Prof. Felix Adler lectured on "The Ethics of Suicide." Prof. Adler began with a description of the faith of the Stoics, which not only permitted but enjoined suicide under certain, circumstances.

That part of the report of the Philippine Commission where the Commissioners point out that the problems of civil government in the Philippine possessions are too complex, new, and difficult to be intrusted to any but men of proved ability and high character is deserving of the careful attention of President McKINLEY.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4. -- Cardinal Gibbons preached to-day at high mass at the Cathedral to the largest congregation assembled in the historic edifice for a long while. His Eminence's text in part was the well-known portion of the marriage service. "what God has joined together let no man put asunder."

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4. -- There was a fire to-night in the three-story double tenement house at Adams and Ferry Streets, where about a year ago two children named Carroll were suffocated. The only means of reaching the ground floor of the building from the apartments above is a stairway running through the middle and opening at both the upper floors into the halls, on either side of which are apartments.

RAMSEYS, N.J., Feb. 4. -- The Rev. J.N. Trompen, pastor of the Christian Reformed Church of this place, who was suspended by the Classis of Bergen and Passaic last Tuesday, preached as usual to-day, while the minister sent to fill the pulpit sat in a pew in the church and listened. The Classis directed the Rev. E.O. Van Duyn of Montvllle to come here and conduct services.
ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- Attorney General Davies has made a statement as to the present status of the various election cases in New York.

The English, who are otherwise about as un-Grecian a people as ever lived, have at least the Athenian quality of unreadiness. DEMOSTHENES once compared the policy of the Athenians to the manner in which a barbarian boxes. His attention is wholly taken up with the blow he has just received, and he never seems to have any idea beforehand of what to expect the next moment or where he ought to be upon his guard.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4. -- All last night and throughout to-day until a heavy rainstorm this evening drove them to shelter the opposing baseball forces occupied the disputed grounds at Union Park, and the camp fires burned brightly on either side of the diamond. A squad of policemen patrolled the grounds and more of the bluecoats guarded the entrance to prevent any further invasion and keep the crowds of "rooters " and curious people outside.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Mrs. Kate Murray of this city will not have to fight to recover the custody of the three children who were taken away from her nearly a year ago by the Children's Home Society. The society has receded from its position.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Hon. Joseph J. Willett, the President of the Alabama Bar Association, as well as the general legal adviser and Chairman of the Committee on Legislation of the Commercial Travelers and Hotel Men's Anti-Trust League, has declined to deliver an address before the anti-trust conference to be held at Chicago Feb. 12.

NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 4. -- Fire was discovered by the watchman at the Hopkins Allen Arms Company's building at 6 o'clock this morning, and by noon the entire factory, where guns, rifles, and smaller firearms were manufactured, were in ruins. It is thought the fire originated from an explosion, as the watchman claims he heard a loud report in the centre of the building, which was immediately followed by a sheet of flame.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Jan. 30, under the heading, "Aguinaldo's Statement," a correspondent quotes Aguinaldo's "After a year's fighting * * * I concluded a treaty of peace on the following terms * * * the payment of $800,000 indemnification money * * *."

Mrs. C. Jackson Taylor of Mount Malcolm, Australia, who arrived here Saturday with her five-year-old daughter on the Cunard Line steamer Lucania, complained of a peculiar case of robbery of which, she claimed, she was the victim just before the vessel reached her pier. According to Mrs. Taylor's story she was robbed of $900 in bills, which were taken from her jacket pocket.
Joseph Lyman Partridge, father of John N. Partridge, State Superintendent of Public Works, died at his home, 125 Montague Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. His critical illness had already been announced.

-- Among the reasons given by the amiable RICHARD FRANKLIN PETTIGREW, the Senator from South Dakota -- or is he from the Alcaldia Mayor de la Pampanga? -- in support of his demand that a certain document which may or may not have been written by his revered friend, AGUINALDO, should be printed at the expense of the United States Government, there was one reason of a very peculiar nature.

The growing popularity of the Speedway as a Sunday morning resort for horsemen and their fast steppers, as well as those who delight in seeing good harness racing, was evident yesterday from the crowd which lined both sides of the drive from Washington Bridge as far north as the eye could reach.

From almost all sections of the country, but particularly from the Middle Western and Southern States, come reports that smallpox is epidemic. The disease manifests some peculiar features, too, for it is much less virulent than usual, and in many cases delay in combating it has resulted from its being at first taken for chicken pox.

The Reorganization Committee of the United States Flour Milling Company, composed of Samuel Thomas, Chairman; Edwin Gould, J. Edward Simmons, Warner Van Norden, Brayton Ives, William Lanman Bull, and Thomas A. McIntyre, has submitted a plan for the readjustment of the securities of that corporation, which it is asserted permanently provides for the purchase of the properties of the Northwestern Consolidated Milling Company, and will furnish adequate working capital to carry on the business.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- The report of the Superintendent of the New York State Free Employment Bureau, which is located in New York City, will be transmitted to the Legislature to-morrow night. The report says in part:

The appointment of the lieutenant and personal representative of RICHARD CROKER as receiver of the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company by Justice FITZGERALD was an act for which it is not easy to imagine any justification, and which is open to explanation by motives that, if allowed to influence judicial discretion, must shake the confidence of the public in the courts.

It is not without significance that such an address as that of Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD on Saturday evening should be made to a Citizens' Union club, one of the Assembly district organizations of that sort that now exist in healthy condition in more than half the districts of the old City of New York.
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 4. -- It is announced to-night that the Democratic seat of government for Kentucky will be established here to-morrow.

ORANGE, N.J, Feb. 4. -- Crowds in Main Street last night were treated to the spectacle of a fashionably dressed man who was recognized as one of the most prominent citizens of Orange, being dragged along the street under arrest by a negro policeman. Both men were angry, and talked in loud tones.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4. -- Property estimated in value between $1,000,000 and $2,000,000 was destroyed to-day by a fire that burned over portions of three blocks and resulted in the death of Charles Mappes, a fireman, and injury to eight other firemen, one of whom is probably fatally hurt. The following buildings were wholly or partially destroyed:

PLATTSBURG, Feb. 4. -- The call for the Republican Congressional Convention for the Twenty-third New York District has been issued. The convention will meet in Plattsburg March 15. Congressman L.W. Emerson of Warrensburg, Warren County, will be renominated by acclamation. Delegates to the National Republican Convention will also be chosen at this convention.

If the market is to continue its encouraging pace of last week, it is probable that leadership will still stay with the iron and steel stocks. That extraordinary dividends are being earned upon most of the issues of that group is not longer a matter of dispute -- their progress in that particular rising superior to all other securities in the market.

Harry Vardon, the champion golfer of Great Britain, was among the passengers arriving here yesterday, on the steamship St. Paul. He will spend a few days in this locality before starting on his tour of the Southern links, and later in the season will be seen in exhibition and competitive matches on several of the metropolitan courses.

The Rev. Dr. Madison a Peters, pastor of Bloomingdale Reformed Church, as it was announced that he would, read his resignation to his congregation yesterday morning. Many women in the congregation wept and men were affected. After the sermon, when a tenor solo, "Shall We Meet Beyond the River," was sung, several women left the church hurriedly, too deeply moved to remain.

Charles E. Macrum, ex-United States Consul at Pretoria, who, soon after the breaking out of the Anglo-Boer war insisted that he be recalled, arrived here yesterday on the American liner St. Paul. Mr. Macrum, accompanied by his wife and young daughter, is on the last stage of his journey to Washington, where, as he has stated, he has something to lay before the State Department.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- According to reliable authority Gov. Roosevelt intends to go to New York City soon to have a personal talk with Senator Platt and Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee. Close friends of the Chief Executive say that his purpose in making this trip will be to impress on Messrs.

It would be too bad if the miscreants who mutilated the sculptured figures of the Heine Monument should go uncaught and unwhipped. Indeed, a public whipping would be a good beginning of their punishment. Some thirty-nine lashes well laid on, to be followed by a prolonged seclusion in a secure jail, would be about the right penalty for such misdoing as theirs.

Capt. Alvin O. Collins of the canalboat Thomas Slowery, who is accused or being implicated in the death of Elmer Kipp, Captain of the canalboat C.A. Voorhis, and Joseph Victor, a deckhand on the canalboat Thomas Slicer, was arraigned before Magistrate Deuel yesterday in the Essex Market Court.

Several thousand people witnessed a contest between Hook and Ladder No. 16 from Fire Headquarters and Hook and Ladder No. 54 of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon at the Brewster Building, Forty-seventh Street and Broadway. The contest was for the purpose of testing the merits of two styles of fire trucks, concerning which there had been a difference of opinion among the experts.

LONDON, Ky., Feb. 4. -- Fifteen Republicans, of whom twelve are Representatives and the others Senators, arrived here this afternoon from Frankfort to attend the coming meeting of the Legislature which will be convened in the old seminary building here on Tuesday noon.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 4. -- Several high Union Pacific officials will leave New York this week for Tacoma to secure terminals here for the entrance of that railroad to Puget Sound. This news comes in telegrams received to-day. The party will include E.H. Harriman, Chairman of the Union Pacific Directorate, and Vice President Cornish.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The United States and Great Britain, it was definitely learned to-night, have reached an amicable agreement respecting the operations of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty as affecting the right of construction and control by the United States of the proposed Nicaragua Canal.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 4. -- It practically has been decided that the body of Senator William Goebel will be buried in Frankfort in the cemetery overlooking the Kentucky River, where lie the remains of Daniel Boone, Vice President Richard Johnson, and several Kentucky Governors, eminent jurists, and soldiers.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 4. -- Armed conflict between the civil authorities of Franklin County and the National Guard of the State of Kentucky has been averted and unless new causes should come to the front there is small likelihood that the political situation in this city will again become as

HELENA, Mont., Feb. 4. -- The belief seems to be spreading in Montana that United States Senator W.A. Clark will be excluded from his seat by the Senate, whose Committee on Privileges and Elections is now investigating the charges of bribery and corruption in connection with his election one year ago.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 4. -- In deference to the desire of the British Cabinet, the Newfoundland Legislature will meet in special session Feb. 15 to renew the Anglo-French modus vivendi respecting the treaty shore. The session will probably occupy only one day, as the country is unanimous in supporting such a proposal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Accept the thanks of a Connecticut churchman for your deserved criticism of the meeting held in Boston on Jan. 30 to honor the memory of King Charles I. The Episcopal Church has few enemies more effective than those women and men who are fastening upon her the commemoration of the King whose word could never be trusted.

William and Charles Stark of Canal Street, Stapleton, are missing, and it is feared they have been carried to sea and have perished, either through the wrecking of their boat or from hunger and exposure. About the only hope entertained for them is that they were picked up by some outward-bound vessel.
Ernest H. Crosby is to be the next President of the People's Club, according to the announcement that was made yesterday afternoon.

In connection with a meeting to be held in Chicago Feb. 6 for the purpose of hearing complaints of shippers concerning the workings of a new schedule of freight rates, known as Western Classification No. 30, put into effect by the Western Classification Committee, the Merchants' Association of New York has sent a communication to the committee setting forth its objections to the new schedule.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The Currency bill will continue to hold its place on the calendar as the unfinished business each day after 2 o'clock during the present week. No speeches on it are formally announced. Some of the friends of the bill, including Senator Allison, have indicated a purpose to address the Senate on this measure, but they probably will defer their remarks until the following week.

After a delay of two weeks, caused by her sickness, Olga Nethersole acted Daudet's wicked but repentant Sapho in Fitch's adaptation of the French novel at Wallack's Theatre. There was no disturbance and there was not much enthusiasm.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Gov. Roosevelt said this morning that he had been misunderstood in his statement concerning the Goebel-Taylor matter. He had made no allusion to the death of Mr. Goebel, but simply desired to say that if further bloodshed is to come it must be at the doors of those who conspired to accomplish by force what they failed to accomplish by fraud.

John and William Stark, the two fishermen of Stapleton, Staten Island, who Had been reported missing from their homes since Wednesday of last week, returned shortly before midnight Sunday, after a battle with wind and sea and ice lastingfour days. Their relatives and friends had about given them up for lost when their stanch little craft, bruised and scarred, limped in after her tussle with the treacherous waters off Coney Island.

The Molineux trial was resumed yesterday after more than a week's delay on account of the illness of Juror Manheim Brown. The prosecution finished its case with the morning's session. The trial was begun Nov. 14, and in addition to twelve flays consumed in getting a jury, the prosecution has taken more than two months in the presentation of its case.
The General Fire Insurance Committee of Twenty-five will hold its next meeting about three weeks from to-day.

The first two games in the North Side National Tournament last night were closely contested. In the first game the Pontiac Wheelmen defeated the Dolando team by the close score of 857 to 830. Up to the ninth frame it looked as though the Dolando team would win. In the two last frames, however, the Pontiacs did some effective strike bowling, and secured a winning lead.

Police Chief Devery yesterday afternoon issued an order transferring to precincts the sixty-three detectives who on Saturday were remanded by the Police Board from the Mulberry Street headquarters bureau to patrol duty. These men were instructed by Chief Devery to report for duty, at 8 o'clock this morning.
L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Schuyler Quackenbush two lots, 50 by 100, on the north side of Eighty-sixth Street, 100 feet east of Riverside Drive.
ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- In his annual report Attorney General John C. Davies says, under the head "A Suggestion as to the Time of Taking Effect of Statutes":

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- When the President turned over to the Congress the task of providing a government for the Philippines, it was not very much expected that the Congress would speedily agree upon a measure for that purpose.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- At a meeting of the Building Trades Council, held here to-day, labor difficulties reached what is thought to be a crisis. The business agents of the Hod Carriers' and Building Laborers' Union were ordered to call off the men at work on every building in Chicago where the new rules of the Building Contractors' Council were posted.

The morning hours yesterday were comparatively free from incident in the social world, and many people of leisure, housed during the rainstorm of Sunday, took advantage of the bright skies and brilliant sunshine for a stroll or a drive, although it was necessary to brave a blustering wind, like that of March, to enjoy these.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The State Railroad Commission has not referred to the Attorney General the motion of President Rossiter of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Road in declining to accept the suggestions of the commission regarding the granting of transfers at various points on the roads of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Senator Caffery of Louisiana in a discussion of the Philippine question in the Senate to-day broke new ground in developing his position as an anti-expansionist. In response to an inquiry as to what in the present circumstances he would do with the Filipinos, he said with characteristic courage of conviction:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 1/2@60 1/2. There were no sales.

(FROM A SPECIAL CONTRIBUTOR.) The Classification Committee of the railroads is to begin at once in this city a hearing upon the complaints against the revised classification of freight which was recently adopted, and it may be well for those interested in the matter to understand just what is in question.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Democrats of the House continued their assaults upon the Philippine policy of the Administration, during the general debate upon the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill to-day. Two speeches were made by Democratic members of the Foreign Affairs Committee, Mr. Dinsmore (Ark.) and Champ Clark (Mo.,) opposing the retention of the islands.

Secretary HAY is entitled to the congratulations of his friends and the thanks of his countrymen for his successful correction of a blunder in pur diplomacy made half a century ago. During almost the whole of that long period the Clayton-Bulwer treaty, ratified in 1850, has been regarded in his country as a mistake.

Activity of encouraging character was manifest in yesterday's security market. The industrial list continued conspicuous In the business of the day, some of the leading trust stocks scoring further material advances. What was notably favorable appeared in the fact that transactions in the standard railway list grew larger and that the prices of many prominent issues advanced on what seemed to be commission house purchases for the public's account.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- The Daily Chronicle says: "There can be no question that this agreement regarding the canal between two friendly nations is a matter for congratulation, not merely to themselves, but to the world at large which will materially benefit by the constructor of this great waterway.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Military opinion in London continues to assume, from very slender materials, that Gen. Buller is again throwing his army against the Boer works.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- Gov. Roosevelt, who has relieved District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner from duty in the prosecution of the alleged detractors of Brooklyn Rapid Transit in New York, said to-day:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections has not yet completed its examination of the case of W.A. Clark of Montana, but already it is being intimated by Senators that there can be only one outcome of the case.
