WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Hay-Pauncefote treaty, amendatory of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty, relating to the construction of the Nicaragua Canal, was signed at the State Department to-day by Secretary Hay, for the United States, and Lord Pauncefote, for Great Britain.

Not since the old days and before the Lexow Investigating Committee came down to New York and shook the police force to its foundations have the Chief, Inspectors, and Captains of the department felt equal to one of their old-time social gatherings, which were known as the Captains' dinners, until last night, when the first annual dinner of the New York City Police Endowment Association was held in the gayly decorated ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Assemblyman Weekes of New York introduced a concurrent resolution in the Assembly to-night amending the Constitution. Though general in character, it is intended to relieve the congested trial term calendars in the First Judicial District.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The heroic bearing of the audience at the Casino Theatre fire on Saturday night stamps American citizenship with high character for bravery and self-possession. The scene from the auditorium when the entire curtain was aflame from footlights to ceiling was terrifying to the utmost.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 5. -- The end of the war in Kentucky is now near. To-night, after hours of heated argument in a conference at the Galt House, the hostile political factions came to an agreement by which the clogged wheels of legislation may again move and the tangle in the executive affairs of the State be adjusted.

MANILA, Feb. 5. -- Brig. Gen. Kobbe's expedition in the islands of Luzon, Leyte, and Samar has occupied permanently and garrisoned nine towns with the Forty-third and Forty-seventh Regiments, and placed on the market 180,000 bales of hemp.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The annual report of Commissioner McMackin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which has just been issued, contains the results of a special investigation into accidents and injuries sustained by employes of twelve different manufacturing industries in this State. The number of employes covered in this investigation is about one-half of the total number employed.

Whatever the grounds on which Gov. ROOSEVELT has concluded to relieve District Attorney GARDINER of the charge of the proceedings before the Special Grand Jury in the case of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit rumors, it has the effect of permitting the uninterrupted attention of Mr. GARDINER to the hearing of the charges against himself before the Commissioner appointed by the Governor for that purpose.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Capt. Leary, Naval Commander of Guam, has made the following report to the Navy Department, dated Agana, Guam, Doc. 23, 1899:

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The debate on the address in reply to the speech from the throne was resumed in the House of Commons today by Sir William Vernon-Harcourt Liberal. The House was packed, and several members of the United States Embassy were present.

An entirely different story of the shooting of William P. Moore than that of the police and firemen came out yesterday, and several persons asserted their belief that instead of its being an accident, the man was deliberately shot down by Policeman Henry Haverkamp as he ran from him through Staple Street Sunday afternoon.

Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry gave last evening at her residence, 2 East Sixty-first Street, her annual dance, for her daughters, the Misses Mabel and Angelica Gerry, and her son, Mr. Robert Goelet Gerry. Last Winter this dance had as the guest of honor Miss Cavendish Bentinck, a niece-of Mrs. Ogden Mills, and at it Mr. Robert Goelet Gerry made his first bow to society.

"I would like to ask, your Honor, if there is a dignified way of pulling another man nose?" This was the question put by Thomas B. Connery, the author, who had misunderstanding with Charles F. Rideal at a hearing of creditors of the bankrupt publisher, F.T. Neely, which culminated an encounter between the two men in the hall of the building 114 Fifth Avenue, where they both have offices, on Saturday mornleg last.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Machias has arrived at Puerto Cabello. Commander Logan is keeping a watch on American interests in Venezuela, owing to reports of continuous revolutions in that country.

The collection of oil paintings belonging to Austin H. King of Providence, R.I., were sold at auction by Samuel P. Avery, Jr., in Chickering Hall last evening, James P. Silo acting as auctioneer. The hall was well filled, and the bidding was spirited. Fifty-seven paintings in all were sold for a total of $77,375, or an average of $1,356.14 for each painting.

Under an order signed by Gov. Roosevelt on Saturday the investigation of the alleged conspiracy, against the Brooklyn Rapid Transit was taken out of the hands of District Attorney Gardiner yesterday, and Attorney General Davies was directed to present the evidence in the case to the Special Grand Jury, which had been empaneled to consider it.

The "gentleman burglar," not unfamiliar as a stage character, has made his appearance in real life in Brooklyn. This Chesterfield of the jimmy and dark lantern presented himself on Saturday, but the fact of his appearance did not become known until yesterday. He introduced himself to Mrs. John E. Volck, who lives at 246 Jefferson Avenue.

Four white horses, attached to an open carriage, were used by John Pokorny, a hotel keeper of Astoria, L.I., to take his wife home after they had quarreled. Mrs. Pokorny insisted on this, because she wanted to show the neighbors that she had won in the family quarrel.

OIL CITY, Penn., Feb. 5. -- The Derrick will to-morrow publish the following letter from Congressman Joseph C. Sibley, written in response to a call from friends in the various counties of the district, asking him to be a candidate for Congress on the Republican ticket:

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday afternoon, at the request of John B. McDonald, the successful bidder for the tunnel, gave him a further extension to Feb. 20 to complete the terms of the contract in the furnishing of the $1,000,000 cash security, and the $6,000,000 in bonds for the construction and operation of the road.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Spenser Wilkinson, in to-day's Morning Post, says:

LONDON, Ky., Feb. 5. -- The fact that there was not the slightest display of animosity among the citizens of London when it became a certainty to-day the Legislature was to convene here, and that the twenty-five legislative members who arrived on the afternoon train were met by a welcoming crowd at the station, can safely be taken as an assurance that no opposition will be manifested when the session begins tomorrow.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 5. -- Chaotic is the only word that will describe the political situation as it existed to-day in Frankfort. This condition arose not so much from anything that was done by either side, as from the countless stories and rumors that were spread broadcast during the day.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Extended accounts of the British reverses at Stormberg, Magersfontein, and Colenso are coming in by mail from war correspondents. From these a realistic impression may be gained of what defeat really means. "I have seen in my life," writes the correspondent of The Times, "one or two ticklish fights, but at Stormberg for the first time I was enabled to realize what actual defeat means.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 5. -- Mr. Henry Watterson to-day gave out a statement in which he declared that the head and front of the present troubles in Kentucky is the Louisville and Nashville Railway Company. He asserts that in the recent State campaign the railroad "supplied material resources in such abundance as to draw out all the dangerous elements of society and put into activity all the forces of political adventure."

Norfolk and Western shares were easily conspicuous among the railway stocks yesterday by reason of their activity and strength, the common stock appreciating 3 1/8 points on sales of 63,570 shares -- the largest of any on the list -- and the preferred 1 1/2 on transactions involving 7,300 shares.

CAPE TOWN, Feb. 5. -- President Kruger and President Steyn have communicated with Field Marshal Lord Roberts, the British Commander in Chief, protecting against the destruction of farmhouses and the devastation of property.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The labor agitation against the system of using "trade checks" as money has borne fruit in the introduction of a bill by Senator Nelson of Minnesota, making the use of such a medium of exchange punishable. Complaints have come from different parts of the country, and particularly from sparsely settled sections where large bodies of men have been employed by corporations.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The Fallows School Teachers' bill, which provides for the immediate relief of the unpaid school teachers of Queens and Richmond Counties, was passed by both the Assembly and the Senate to-night, there being no opposition to the measure in either house. Immediately after the bill passed the Senate it was handed to the Lieutenant Governor for his signature, and a special messenger was dispatched to carry it to Mayor Van Wyck.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Philippine question was again before the House today. The feature of the debate was the speech of Mr. Williams, (Dem., Miss.,) who presented an argument against the annexation of the Philippines. It was devoted almost entirely to the commercial aspects of the acquisition, holding that the absorption of the islands would be ruinous ultimately to American producers of cotton, rice, tobacco, hemp, and sugar.

There is grave need of a campaign of education to prepare the American mind for adoption of the policy of highest wisdom in respect to the isthmian canal; and it is plain that the campaign should begin at once in the Senate of the United States.

BERLINS Feb. 6 -- With reference to the attempt of French diplomacy and journalism to induce Germany to join in a movemet against Great Britain in Egypt, a high personage at the Foreign Office made the following statement this evening:

BOSTON, Feb. 6 -- The copper shares were the "card" to-day, with Amalgamated the big card. This stock rose easily above 90 on confident talk of par this week. As went Amalgamated, so went the whole copper list, almost without exception. There was a report that the recent Calumet sale was not yet a fact; that Superintendent Kidwell of the Arcadian had resigned, and that London was fearing a break in copper prices.

-- I must respectfully but urgently renew," writes Capt. RICHARD LEARY, Naval Commander of Guam, to the Navy Department," my request that a good library be sent to this station, and also that the musical instruments asked for be sent at the earliest possible date." Now, what the greatest of Learys wants of a good library we cannot even guess.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Feb. C -- Thomas K. Bard was to-day elected United States Senator to succeed Stephen M. White. In the Senate the vote was as follows: Thomas B. Bard, (Republican,) 26; James D. Phelan, (Democrat,) 10. In the Assembly the vote stood: Bard, 59; Phelan, 20; White, I. Bard was declared elected in both houses.

COVINGTON, Ky., Feb. 6 -- This has been the most memorable day in the history of Kenton County. The great crowds of people continued all day and all night around the Odd Fellows' Hall. During the afternoon several women fainted.

The American "Woolen-Company held its annual meeting yesterday at its office, in Jersey City. Charles R. Flint and Frank Jones of Portsmouth, N.H., were elected members of the Board of Directors in place of Joseph Ray and Joseph F. Fletchers, two of the retiring Directors. J. Clifford woodhull and Frank Kittridge, retiring members of the board, were re-elected.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- By consent of all parties interested, the hearing of the bills affecting the Ramapo Water Company of Brooklyn before the Cities Committee of the Assembly was to-day further postponed until Feb. 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly give space to a few serious reflections occasioned by the article in THE TIMES of Feb. 2, Page 12, headed "Boy Prodigal's Welcome; Police and Firemen Witness a Mother's Wrath and a Little Runaway Suffers"? Reading the abovementioned article is enough to make every mother who has reared sons in a humane way cry out in protest.

The German-American Company team gave a splendid exhibition in the Fire Insurance League at Reid's alleys last night, winning two games, with scores of over 800. The team's score of 888 in the first game against the London and Liverpool and Globe team is one of the highest made in the tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The differences of opinion among the members of the Industrial Commission concerning the subjects investigated by them will prevent early reports on most of these subjects and will insure slight consideration for some of the reports.
BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- Emperor William has prohibited the performance of a drama by Herr Bonn, the actor, which shows Frederick the Great in character.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Excellent as is the report of the Special Commission on Canals recently made public, it is here submitted that they have not proposed the best method for the prompt and permanent correction for the evil which they prove is threatening our trade through discrimination against this State by traffic rates on the railroads.

Gov. Roosevelt came to the city yesterday, and if his presence did not clear the political atmosphere it was the means of bringing out statements from himself. State Chairman Odell, and County Chairman Quigg concerning the Vice Presidential nomination.

They are telling a rather funny story about William Dean Howells's experience with a magazine proprietor who had engaged Mr. Howells to edit his magazine for him. Mr. Howells has not been in the habit of having a time watch kept on him when at his literary work, and, like all men of that sort, writes only when he is in the mood, and then accomplishes a great deal in a short time.

Criminations and recriminations between combatants upon alleged violations of the rules of civilized warfare are invariable accompaniments of modern wars. During our war with Spain, some part of the Spanish press got itself into an excitement over the story that American men-of-war had flown foreign flags to deceive the enemy, though this stratagem is allowed by all the authorities.

The object of Mr. William A. Brady in producing at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night a play in four acts called "The Countess Chiffon" was to introduce conspicuously on the local stage Miss Grace George, whose acting as the young wife in "Mile. Fift" last season was pleasing and promising.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Senate Finance Committee to-day reported a new section to the Financial bill as follows:

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 6 -- The peace conference held at the Gait House last night between sever representatives of the Republican Party and seven representatives of the Democratic Party resulted in the unanimous signing of an agreement embodying seven specific propositions, which promise a settlement of the party differences which have brought about two State governments in Kentucky. This agreement is, in substance, as follows:

Never was there so large a crowd at a meeting of the Riverside Republican Club at its house. Ninety-seventh Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, as that which attended the gathering there last night of the Assembly District Committee of the Twenty-first District. The rooms on the main floor were densely packed, while the hallways and stairway were filled with interested spectators.

By a decision of Surrogate Thomas given yesterday, at the end of a will contest, a young woman's identity was fully established, and she was declared to be the heir to about $25,000 from her grandfather's estate. The contestant was Maude Ernestine Banks of Waltham Mass., who is now recognized as a cousin of Maud Banks, the actress.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The hearing on the Municipal Gas Plant bill for New York City was held to-day before the Senate Committee on Cities. Senator Donnelly made the only argument in favor of his measure. No one appeared against the bill. Senator Donnelly said there was no opposition to the bill so far as the New York City officials were concerned, as they favor the measure.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Gen. Macdonald, with 4,000 infantry, cavalry, and artillery, threatens the Boer right at Magersfontein. This is the first sign of activity on the part of Lord Methuen for some weeks, and doubtless has relation to the movements of the British further east.

The Senate is going very deliberately through the process of investigating and considering the law and precedents in the case of Mr. QUAY. It is the only tribunal before which the claims of that gentleman and of the State of Pennsylvania can be brought, and it is proper enough that they should be carefully weighed.

Oscar Hammerstein, the theatrical manager, showed his temper yesterday while under examination in his suit against the New York Life Insurance Company before Judge Wheeler and a jury in the United States Circuit Court. Mr. Hammerstein is seeking to recover $70,000 for the scenery, engines, dynamos, mirrors, and immense chandeliers which the New York Life took possession of at the time it foreclosed the mortgage on the Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- It is learned to-night that under the terms of The Hague treaty, which was ratified by the Senate yesterday, an effort will be made before long to exert such offices as may properly be extended to the belligerents to bring about a termination of the war in South Africa.

In one of the fastest games ever played between amateurs, Wayman C. McCreery of St. Louis last night broke the world's record for amateur billiardists, held by himself, at fourteen-inch balkline, two shots in balk, in the Class A amateur billiard championship tournament held in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.

They are in a state of considerable anxiety at the Woman's Exchange, Madison Avenue and Forty-third Street, just now. There is nothing in the line of woman's work that they do not keep constantly on hand, but the other day they received a demand which they could not supply -- it was for a real live baby.

The investigation of the charges made against District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner by members of the City Club was opened with a brief but lively session in the library of the Criminal Court Building yesterday. The hearing lasted little more than half an hour, and resulted in an adjournment of the investigation until Feb. 19, when it will commence in earnest in the room of Trial Term, Part VIII., of the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- In the Senate today Mr. Caffery resumed his speech on the Philippine question. He quoted from eminent authorities on Constitutional law in support of his position that the Filipinos by the extension of the Constitution over them became citizens of the United States. He then said:

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- In the House of Commons to-day the session was devoted principally to discussion of the proposed amendment to the address in, reply to the speech from the throne, which was lost by a vote of 139 against 352. Incidentally Mr. Chamberlain was again attacked and was defended by A.J. Balfour.

LONDON, Ky., Feb. 6 -- The little twostory brick Laurel County seminary building, which has stood upon a knoll in the outskirts of London for almost fifty years, to-day added another page to its history when the brief session of the Kentucky Legislature was held within its walls. The two rooms are about twenty feet wide by forty long and are filled with school desks.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 6 -- The regular Republican State Committee to-day rejected a proposition for harmony submitted by the Union Republican (Addicks) State Committee. The reply framed by the regulars, which was adopted by a vote of 14 to 2, states that there will be no further consideration of propositions to harmonize the party until J. Edward Addicks is repudiated by the Union Republican faction.
HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- For the first time in months Havana is clear of yellow fever. No case has been officially reported for some days.

JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN spoke like an Englishman when he addressed the House of Commons in reply to the Opposition critics of the Government on Monday evening. The sturdy English qualities of courage, frankness, and rugged determination were all there. He admitted that mistakes had been made and manfully took upon the Ministry the blame for them.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The hearing on Senator Wagner's Barren Island bill, down for to-day before the Senate Cities Committee, was adjourned until Feb. 13 upon request of De Lancey Nicoll of New York, who was unable to be present. William H. Amerman, President of the Anti-Barren Island League, and A.E., Karelsen, Secretary, were present to speak in behalf of the bill.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Answering a question this evening in the House of Commons, Mr. Balfour said there was no truth in the story that Major Gen. Sir William Butler, the former commander of the British forces in South Africa, objected to reinforcing the border garrisons and said 50,000 men should be in hand at the outbreak of war, even if it was confined to the South African Republic.

Application was made to the Municipal Council yesterday for a franchise for a system of tunnels connecting the Boroughs of Manhattan and Brooklyn, to be constructed and operated by the New York and Brooklyn Union Transportation Company. The petition, which is signed by George Wilson, as President, and Frank N. Glover of 55 Liberty Street, as counsel, was referred to the Committee on Railroads.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 6 -- Col. William Jennings Bryan to-night finished his New England trip here, and will leave, to-morrow for New York. He was warmly greeted at all the cities and towns at which he stopped on the way from North Adams to this city, and in his address at the Park City Theatre here to-night Mr. Bryan announced that he had eliminated New England from the "enemy's country."

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb 6 -- James Whitcomb Riley's poem written on the occasion of Gen. Henry W. Lawton's body lying in state in the Capitol of Indiana was published here to-day. It is entitled "The Home Voyage."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The rooms of the House Committee on Judiciary were crowded to overflowing to-day with the representatives of many religious, missionary, and social reform bodies, to urge the need of Constitutional amendment prohibiting polygamy.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- When the Treat bill, to tax individual depositors in excess of $1,000 deposited in savings banks, was reached on the Assembly calendar to-day, a dozen members were instantly on their feet to object to its advancement to third reading.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- The Board of Directors of the Reading Company met to-day and declared a dividend of 1 1/2 per cent. on the $28,000,000 first preferred stock of the company, pursuant to the recommendation of the Executive Committee, which met yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The President to-day appointed Judge William H. Taft of Cincinnati, and United States Judge of the Sixth Judicial Circuit, to be President of the new Philippine Commission. Judge Taft's place on the bench will be filled by the appointment of Judge Henry F. Severens of Grand Rapids, Mich.
James McCartney, Commissioner of Street Cleaning, died at his home, 1,199 Fulton Avenue, at midnight. He had been ill since early in the Winter.

The stewards of countless millions dined last night in the Waldorf-Astoria, Prosaically they are known as Group VIII. of the New York State Bankers' Association, otherwise the Manhattan Bankers, and, including their guests, nearly five hundred men were gathered about the banqueting tables.

MANILA, Feb. 6 -- The insurgents attacked the first battalion of the Forty-fifth Infantry near Niac. A Major and a Captain were wounded and one Sergeant killed, but details of the engagement are lacking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Secretary Hay is determined that the State Department shall observe with the most scrupulous fidelity whatever obligation may rest upon it toward Nicaragua and Costa Rica in the matter of the construction of the Nicaraguan Canal. It has not been possible to move in that matter pending the removal of the obstacle in the way of canal building presented by the Clayton-Bulwer treaty.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The election in York City yesterday for a successor in the House of Commons to Rear Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, recently appointed to the command of the Second Division of the British Mediterranean Fleet, resulted as follows: George Faber, Unionist, 6,248; A. Murray, Liberal, 4,818; Faber's majority, 1.430.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The Rev. John Kennedy, former Chairman of the Congregational Union of England and Wales and Professor of Apologetics at New College, London, died yesterday in his eighty-seventh year.

Business in the market for outside securities yesterday was even more active than on Monday, and further net gains were recorded In a number of issue. Interest in the market has of late very much increased, and the buying of stocks assumed a broader character than it has shown for many weeks.

The concert which was given in Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of the Dewey Arch Fund attracted an audience that completely filled the building, gave several thousand New Yorkers an opportunity to make a short-range study of the Admiral of the navy, and his bride, and, what is more to the purpose, increased the fund by nearly $5,000.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 6 -- Whether it shall be war or peace in Kentucky rests tonight with Gov. Taylor alone. The question has been in his mind all day, and tonight he declared that he has reached no decision and would announce none before to-morrow.

William A. Brady, on behalf of Jeffries, and George Considine, Corbett's manager, met yesterday at Brady's office and agreed to accept the bid of the National Athletic Club of San Francisco for the Jeffries-Corbett fight. The bid is 75 per cent. of the gross receipts. The club is backed by, Brady, and its offer was the only one outside of that of the Seaside Athletic Club, which was 60 per cent, of the gross receipts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A discussion of the Philippine question was unexpectedly precipitated in the Senate to-day by Mr. Depew, (Rep., N.Y.,) who called attention to some remarks made a few days ago by Mr. Pettigrew, (Silver, S.D.) In the course of those remarks Mr. Pettigrew quoted an alleged interview with President Schurman of the Philippine Commission, which appeared in a Chicago newspaper and in which he was quoted as saying that Aguinaldo was honest.

Trains going out of New York which provide letter writing accommodations in the buffet cars have clearly hit the adolescent fancy to a nicety. Whether or not the railroad people expected that their supply of stationery and desk would help out business travelers is not disclosed, but the persons whom they do help out bear signs of tennis and golf rather than of mercantile development.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 1/2 @ 60. There were no sales.

Edwin Lawrence Godkin, until recently editor of The Evening Post, who was seized with an attack of vertigo on Sunday at his home, 36 West Tenth Street, was much better fast night and the following bulletin was shown to friends who called to inquire during the evening:

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Gen. Buller recrossed the Tugela River on Monday morning and assaulted the Boer positions on the north side. The British carried several positions, and at last accounts were still holding them.

The list of subscribers to the fund for perpetuating the Dewey Arch is being prepared at the offices, in the St. Paul Building, of the Citizens' Committee, and it will be published within the next three days. It was announced after a meeting of the Executive Committee, some weeks ago, that the list would be made public when the total sum subscribed reached $250,000.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The following bills were introduced in the Legislature to-day:

As a result of the recently renewed interest in the market for outside securities trading in that market yesterday was very active and prices were much advanced. From the opening of the week transactions showed notable increases over recent averages, but neither on Monday nor Tuesday was the trading as active or as broad as it was yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment of the Senate and Assembly gave a joint heaving this afternoon in the Senate Chamber on the bill to impose a tax of one-half of 1 per cent. on mortgages. Those heard to-day spoke in opposition to the measure. Next Tuesday at 2 P.M. another hearing will be given, at which representatives of the Savings Banks Association will be present.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Col. William Jennings Bryan reached this city this afternoon from Bridgeport, Conn. He did not remain in New York for any length of time. After taking luncheon with James E. Martine, Col. Bryan delivered an address in Music Hall, which was crowded to the doors.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- John E. Redmond, Chairman of the United Irish party, was loudly cheered by all sections of the Irish members, when he rose in the House of Commons, to-day, to move an amendment to the address in reply to the speech from the throne, representing that the time had arrived to bring the war to a conclusion on the basis of recognizing the independence of the Transvaal and the Orange Free State.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Representative McClellan of New York to-day introduced a bill for the acquisition of the Erie Canal by the United States Government and its enlargement to a capacity sufficient for the largest vessels of war, at a cost not exceeding $75,000,000.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 7 -- The existence of a hitch in the peace negotiations and speculation as to its probable duration occupied the minds of politicians to the exclusion of everything else to-day.

That was a peculiar question which Mr. T.B. CONNERY asked of a Police Magistrate the other day. "I would like to ask your Honor if there is a dignified way of pulling another man's nose?" It is strange that a literary person, even one of the very late F. TENNYSON NEELY'S "reliable authors," should have occasion to ask such a question.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The eleventh annual report of the State Commission in Lunacy shows a decrease in the per capita cost of maintaining the insane during the past year, from $185 per annum in 1898, to $178 in 1899. The net annual increase of cases was but 529, the smallest in five years.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 7 -- So far as the situation in the controversy over the Governorship of Kentucky is concerned, there was practically no change to-day. Gov. Taylor has not yet affixed his signature to the Louisville agreement, and, although the general opinion is that he will ultimately do so, the probabilities are that he will not sign it until some time to-morrow, if then.

FLUSHING, Feb. 7 -- The Queens Borough School Board held its last meeting before reorganization yesterday afternoon at Flushing. William J. Drummond, Principal of the school at Middle Village, notified the board that his school had been closed for over a week. Over 190 pupils were receiving no instruction whatever.
MADRID, Feb. 7 -- The gold quotation to-day was 28.57.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- In the House to-day Mr. Shafroth (Sil., Col.,) was allowed forty-five minutes in which to complete a speech he made last week in favor of mediation by the United States in the South African war. Under The Hague treaty, he contended that England could not consider an offer of mediation an unfriendly act.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Henry A. Holcomb of New Bedford, a manufacturer, filed a petition in bankruptcy to-day. Liabilities, $1,351,438; assets, none. The unsecured claims amount to $67,806; the notes and bills which ought to be paid by other parties to his transactions, $1,283,631.
MONTEVIDEO, Feb. 7 -- Numerous sunstrokes have occurred here, many proving fatal.

Several times yesterday the plea of Bartow S. Weeks for the life of Roland B. Molineux was marked by incidents more dramatic than are often seen in court or upon the stage. More than once jurymen were seen to shift their eyes from the earnest gaze of the lawyer or drop their heads and rest them in their hands.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- By a vote of 9 to 3 the Assembly Committee on Codes decided to report favorably to-morrow the Lewis bill, providing for the entire repeal of the so-called Horton law, which permits prizefighting in the State in regularly incorporated athletic clubs. The bill has been amended, however, so as to make it take effect Sept. 1, 1900, instead of immediately.

HAVANA, Feb. 7 -- Robert P. Porter arrived here this morning, accompanied by Lieut. Col. Joseph P. Sanger, Director of Census. He says he will set down to hard work immediately and endeavor to arrange a satisfactory tariff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Machias sailed to-day from La Guayra for San Juan. She probably will stop at Santo Domingo, as there have been indications that the Americans there would be reassured at the sight of an American man-of-war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- "The chances of failure are so many and so great that I have considered the possibility of success worth striving for, and so I am going to the Philippines." This was the explanation made to-day by Judge W.H. Taft, who has just surrendered a life position on the Circuit Court bench to accept the position of President of the commission to the Philippines.

Opposition to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty rests upon three leading propositions. Protest is made that England surrenders nothing, and that therefore we gain nothing. The advocates of an extreme interpretation of the Monroe Doctrine object to the provision which invites. European nations to "interfere" in the affairs of the New World to the extent of joining with the United States in guaranteeing the neutrality of the isthmian canal.

A consumptive-looking intruder, a suspicious matron, a valiant maid, a call for a messenger boy, a half-hour wait, and then a policeman whose arrival the burglar meekly awaited, were the principal features of a comedy enacted in Dr. J. Riddle Goffe's private hospital, 22 East Thirty-fifth Street, last night.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 -- Cardinal Gibbons's caustic criticism of woman suffrage, club-women and some society eaders in a sermon on "Christian Women" last Sunday has stirred up a tempest of indignation among the suffragists and club-women of Maryland. Some of them are excitedly talking about holding meetings and sending a protest to the Cardinal.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 7 -- The body of William Goebel was brought back to Frankfort to-day from Covington and laid in State in the ladies' reception room in the west wing of the Capitol Hotel. There it will remain until noon to-morrow, when the relatives and intimate friends will take a last look at the features.

It is evident that Gen. BULLER has made another attempt to force the passage of the Tugela. But nothing beyond this can be said with certainty. It is not even certain that the attempt was a real and desperate attempt. The futility of attacking the Boers in their own chosen and carefully fortified positions has twice been brought to the attention of the British commander so pointedly that he cannot ignore it.

The injunction obtained by A. Emerson Palmer to restrain the Board of Education from discharging him from his office as its Secretary except for cause, and by a threefourths vote, was dissolved yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Justice Woodward, who wrote the decision, bases his opinion principally on the ground that "public policy forbids that the jurisdiction of equity be extended to protect public officials from threatened removal.

Mrs. Elizabeth Barnard, who has not seen or heard from her husband for eighteen years, applied to Justice Freedman, in the Supreme Court yesterday for a decree of separation. The legal presumption is that the woman's husband is dead.
We should like to know to what element in our population Senator ALDRICH thought he was pandering when he reported from his committee this amendment to the Currency bill:

TESTIMONY OP DECEASED WITNESS -- An appeal taken by the Metropolitan Street Railway from a judgment secured against it by Anne M. Gumby, in the United States Circuit Court, for the loss of services of her five-year-old son, George Gumby, who was injured by one of defendant's cars on May 22, 1897, has been sustained by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in an opinion by Judge Lacombe.

Until recently the "Metropolitan Investment and Security Company (Incorporated") occupied offices at 62 Wall Street. Many persons interested in the company are now thirsting for information as to its present whereabouts. The company on or about Sept. 25, 1899, started in business, and sent prospectuses broadcast through the land telling in glowing terms of the exceptional benefits sure to accrue to those placing faith and money in the concern.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The evils of policy in New York City were vividly portrayed in, the hearing before the Assembly Committee on Codes to-day upon the Anti-Policy bill introduced by Mr. Fallows, which is so rigidly drawn as to make the owner of property leased to a person conducting a policy shop and the person who purchases a policy slip equally guilty with the person, who conducts the business itself.

At the instance of Wheeler H. Peckham, President of the City Club, at the regular meeting of the club last night, that organization decided to take active steps for the investigation of the action of Justice James Fitzgerald of the Supreme Court in his recent appointment of John F. Carroll as receiver for the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Business continues brisk and industrials are active. Linseed common opened to-day at 15 7/8, sold to 16, dropped a point, and closed at 15 1/4. The preferred started at 59 1/4 and fell under steady selling to 58 1/4, closing at 58 3/4. Biscuit advanced to 40 1/4 from 4O at the start, but declined to 38 3/4, and closed at 39 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Representative Dolliver says that on Feb. 12, if the Committee on Rules approves the suggestion, the House will enter upon a discussion of the Puerto Rican Tariff bill, and that two weeks will be devoted to that subject and the consideration of the question of the rights of Puerto Rico under the Constitution, which is involved in the tariff question.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Senate to-day listened to a discussion of the financial bill. The debate was opened by Mr. Turner, (Fusion, Washington,) who said the power of the bill would be a deliberate blow to silver, and would enhance the value of money and depreciate in value of things produced by farmers and laboring men.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The third and last of the series of dinner dances which have added so much to the gayety of the Winter was given to-night at the residence of Senator Depew. As usual the dance was preceded by a number of dinners, the hostesses of the evening being Mrs. Bates, the Misses Patten, Mrs. Harriet Blaine Beale, Mrs. Hugh Legare, Mrs. Wallach, and Mrs. Warder.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 -- In the bogey handicap tournament here to-day over eighteen holes, the scores were: L.F. Brigham, 1 up; William Gordon Brown, 1 down; A.S. Carpenter, Philadelphia Country Club, 1 down; L.B. Miller, 2 down; T.M. Cook, 3 down; A.H. Revell, Chicago, 4 down; A. E. Kennedy, Chicago, 5 down; G.F. Kenny, 7 down; D.A. Loring, Jr., 1 down; T.E. Howe, 7 down; C.G. Powers, 7 down.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- Charles M. Stoever Co., paper dealers of this city, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of creditors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Assurances have reached the State Department from the German Governmest that the Samoan treaty, which was ratified by the United States Senate about a week ago, will receive the ratification of the Bundesrath and the Reichstag within a weeK. There is said to be practically no opposition to the treaty in the German legislative branch.

M. JEAN DE BLOCK is reported to have said in the Neue Freie Presse of Vienna that the present struggle in South Africa would be long, but that Great Britain would eventually ask for arbitration. M. DE BLOCH is the author of a book entitled "The Future of War." It has been said, not without authority, that it was to this work that the Czar owed the initial idea of The Hague Peace Conference.
BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- The large clothing firm of Miner, Beal Co. of this city assigned to-day, with liabilities placed at $450,000. The assets are not stated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Calmer talk about the modified Clayton-Bulwer treaty has prevailed to-day, since the meeting this morning of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. That meeting assembled with the gossip of the corridors ringing in its ears against the ratification of a convention that some of its critics declare to be "infamous and outrageous."

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- It Is said here to-night that the New York City officials may not approve the bill which Senator Ahearn has introduced to make the salaries of the school teachers in New York mandatory. Senator Ahearn's bill, which has the unanimous indorsement of the teachers of New York, provides that the salaries in effect on Sept. 1 of last year shail toe continued.

Edwin A. Lawson. Edwin A. Lawson, who was formerly the New York Superintendent for Siegel, Cooper Co., died yesterday at his home in Chicago from exhaustion following an operation. Mr. Lawson was a consumptive, and his health had been bad for some time. He was born in Chicago in 1862 and was manager for several publishing houses there until 1892, when he became manager of the stationery department of Siegel.

By the action of the Rapid Transit Board yesterday the building of the tunnel by Contractor John B. McDonald is assured. The board received proposals for a construction company to be formed by August Belmont, who has associated with himself some of the strongest financiers of the city, unanimously voted to accept the proposals, and is now in a position to go rapidly ahead and complete the details for the contract.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- The Kansas City Southern Railway Company will be the title of the reorganized Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad, which is to be sold under foreclosure sale March 19. William F. Harrity of this city. Chairman of the Reorganization Committee, said to-day that the new company probably would be organized fully and in possession of the property some time in April.

Members of the Society of the Genesee dined last night at Sherry's. It was the second annual dinner of the society, and the large attendance of members and guests showed how the ranks of the society have swelled during the two years of its existence.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company to-day officially announced that plans have been perfected for the erection at Reading of an immense plant for building locomotives. The estimated outlay, it is expected, will reach nearly $1,000,000, and will result in vast improvements in that city.

The security market had to stand a severe test yesterday. Buoyancy attended activity to an extent recently unusual till a London bulletin came along in the afternoon reporting that Gen. Buller had met yet another disaster in South Africa. The whole market fell quickly and materially.
Mrs. Mary Ehart was married when she was twelve years and eight months old. She has not lived with her husband, John Ehart, for thirteen years, and she wants a divorce from him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The President himself is referred to to-day as setting at rest the report of last night, emanating from those who have been anxious to have the United States extend its good offices for the termination of the war between Great Britain and the Boers, by declaring that there is no present intention of gratifying that desire.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- When the downward movement became pronounced in Wall Street prices here began to yield, though the only loss of note was a drop of 1 3/4 in Marsden, and even that fall was for independent reasons too well known to need recital. A prominent exception to the general trend was seen in Electric Company of America.

Application for the modification of the, terms of the bond to be given by John B. McDonald, the contractor for the rapid transit tunnel, will be made to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to-day, and it is confidently expected that as soon, as the motion has been heard the decision will be handed down.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- A fierce snowstorm, driven by a strong north wind, which at some points reached a velocity of forty-two miles an hour, has prevailed in Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Wisconsin, Iowa, Michigan, Minnesota, and Indian Territory since last night. At many points trains are several hours late, and telegraph and telephone wires have suffered severely.

The alumni of the New York University Law School held their sixteenth annual banquet last night at the Hotel Savoy. Among the guests and members of the Faculty occupying seats at the table on the dais were Ernest Hall, who presided; Chancellor MacCracken, Justice James A. O'German, Justice Willard M. Bartlett, and District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner.

The late Mr. McCARTNEY was a useful official, and his death is a public loss. When the present Municipal Administration came in the demonstration was fresh which Col. WARING had made, for the first time within the memory of living man, that the streets of New York could really be cleaned.

Whitenouse Porter have sold for Flake Dowling to a client the vacant block front on Fifth Avenue, between-One Hundred and Sixth and One Hundred and Seventh Streets, 201.10 by 100. This is part of the property taken by the sellers in trade for the Nevada apartment house. The various deeds and mortgages incidental to this trade went on record yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Assemblyman Wissel's bill, permitting all school teachers in the boroughs of New York City holding certificates of qualification prior to the Consolidation act to teach in the public schools of the city, has been reported favorably by the Cities Committee of the Assembly.

After nearly three years' search, William H. Stiles of Mamaroneck, who was wanted on the charge of embezzling $38,000 from the estate of Samuel Halstead, and who was located in South Bend, Ind., a few days ago, is in the hands of the New York police. Detective Sergt. McNaught of the District Attorney's Office having arrived in this city with Stiles in his custody last night.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The largest number of National Guard officers ever in attendance at the State National Guard Association annual meeting gathered this morning at the State Armory here.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Willie Smith and Willie Hoare engaged in a fourball match here to-day with two local players over thirty-six holes, in which the feature was Smith's work with the clubs. He lowered the best nine and eighteen hole records, making three rounds under the record of 35 and staking out eighteen holes in 67.

Flags of many nations pending from the orchestra balcony -- conspicuous among them those of Japan and China -- and the release of dozens of red, white, and blue air balloons which ascended to the ceiling and clung there were among the features of the twenty-eighth anniversary banquet of the Silk Association of America, held at Delmonico's last evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The most interesting witness testifying to-day before the Senate Elections Committee in relation to the Montana Senatorial contest was ex-Gov. S.T. Hauser, who said in the beginning that he thought-he "could take the credit or discredit of inducing Mr. Clark to assist us in the campaign and afterward to become a candidate for the Senate."

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day signed the New York City Rapid Transit bill permitting the city to issue tunnel bonds at various times, as they may become necessary. A hearing was to have been given at 11:30 o'clock this morning on the bill by Gov. Roosevelt in the belief that there was opposition to the measure.

The inquiry into the conduct of Justice FITZGERALD in the appointment of JOHN P. CARROLL as receiver of the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company is an entirely proper one for the City Club to undertake. On the statement of its President, a lawyer of long experience and high reputation, as to the facts that had came to him, the club could hardly do less than to take up the matter.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The American hospital ship Maine, filled with wounded soldiers, has started from Durban for Cape Town.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 8 -- Unless some action regarding the Louisville agreement is taken by Gov. Taylor to-morrow, or some word sent to them concerning his intentions, the Democrats will proceed upon the hypothesis that he does not intend to take any action, and will go ahead with the organization of their State Government at Louisville.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The reports on the bill framed by the Ways and Means Committee imposing duties equivalent to 25 per cent, of the American tariff on goods imported into Puerto Rico from the United States and vice versa were submitted to the House to-day.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Col. William J. Bryan arrived in Paterson this evening at 7:30 o'clock, and was greeted at the station by an immense crowd. After dinner at the Haledon Club he was driven to the County Democratic headquarters, and later to Turn Hall, where he delivered an address lasting two hours and a half.

It seems that the subsidy hunters in the Senate are afraid of the farmers. They are reported to intend to secure a favorable report on the Payne-Hanna-Frye ship subsidy bill and then to drop it for the session.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve decreased u104,000, circulation increased u110,000, bullion increased u14,314, other securities decreased u493,000, other deposits decreased u1,794,000, public deposits increased u1,129,000, notes reserve decreased u212,000, Government securities increased u4,000.

William Ryan of 209 Clinton Avenue, West Hoboken, built a chicken coop on Tuesday morning. He laid the floor and nailed it securely, and then started on the walls. Mr. Ryan stood on the floor he had made and nailed up the side boards from, the inside. He worked quickly and in a short time the four walls were up.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8 -- The local police authorities discredit the statement that Miller was arrested in Montreal. Capt. Reynolds was in Montreal some time ago and made an unsuccessful search for Miller with the assistance of local detectives. It is the belief here that Miller has always been in the vicinity of New York.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Senator McCarren's bill to permit the Borough of Brooklyn to take a water supply from Suffolk County was reported adversely in the Senate to-day by the Judiciary Committee. The Senator appealed from the decision of the committee and asked that the bill be advanced to a third reading. This motion was beaten by the overwhelming vote of 8 to 32, thus effectually killing the bill.

BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- The first reading of the Naval bill took place in the Reichstag today. The House and galleries were crowded. The Secretary of the Admiralty, Admiral Tirpitz; the Secretary of the Interior, Count von Posadowsky-Wehner, and the Secretary of the Treasury, Baron von Thielman, were present.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 8 -- The Republican State officers of Kentucky, other than Gov. Taylor and Lieut. Gov. Marshall, have appealed to Judge William H. Taft of the United States Circuit Court here for a restraining order against the three members of the Kentucky State Board of Election Commissioners and the Democratic contestants for State offices.
Miss ELIZABETH HERLIHY, a teacher in the primary department of Public School No. 2, Jersey City, died Wednesday at her home at 211 Fourth Street, in that city, from pneumonia.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Members of the two Taxation Committees of the Legislature were surprised this morning when copies of the following resolution were handed to them:

William F. Miller, the head of the defunct 520 per cent. Franklin Syndicate, is in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn. Miller was found on Wednesday night in Montreal, where he had spent the greater part of the time since he became a fugitive from justice by Capt. James G. Reynolds, formerly head of the Brooklyn Detective Bureau and now Captain of the Atlantic Avenue Police Station.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Feb. 8 -- The steamship Gate City of the Ocean Steamship Line, bound from Savannah to Boston, went on the outer bar three miles east of the Moriches Life Saving Station at 9 o'clock to-night. The Gate City had on board forty-nine persons, three of whom were women.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The Bedell Stationary Engineer bill for New York City, providing that persons who have served as marine or locomotive engineers for five years and who have been residents of the State for two years, shall be eligible for examination for a license to act as engineer, was passed by the Assembly to-day after a brief debate.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 8 -- The Democratic attorneys will have a meeting with Judge Taft in Cincinnati to-morrow. Judge J.A. Scott and Judge Pryor will leave here in the morning.

The testimonial to the memory of the late "Smiling" John Kelly will take the form of a non-sectarian ward of ten beds in St. Vincent's Hospital, and at a meeting of friends of the dead man at the Hoffman House last night more than half of the amount needed was subscribed and paid. Corporation Counsel John Whalen presided. Commissioner Henry S. Kearney was chosen Secretary, and Deputy Chief William McLaughlin Treasurer.

The campaign of education in the Senate has been prompt and effectual. Already the opponents of the ratification of the Hay-Peuncefote treaty acknowledge that the Senate will approve the treaty. Senators who hastily and without knowledge began to oppose ratification are either discreetly silent or announce their support of the treaty.

LONDON, Ky., Dec. 8 -- That some action was discussed and decided upon to-day in the executive sessions of the two houses of the Legislature, looking toward the issuance of warrants for the arrest and enforcement of attendance of a sufficient number of the absent members to constitute a quorum in each branch is apparently a certainty.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Feb. 8 -- Chief Carpenter B.F. Markham, United States Navy, who has been stationed at the Portsmouth Navy Yard for the last two months, died at the Naval Hospital on Seavey's Island to-day. Carpenter Markham was one of the best known men in his division of the naval service.

The first monthly meeting of the Union League Club since the election of Frederick D. Tappen as President, was held last nignt. There was a large attendance. Among the twenty' men who were elected to membership was Frank J. Could Elihu Root, Secretary of War, who retired from the Presidency of the club a month ago, was unanimously elected as an honorary member.

Though not as active as on Wednesday trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was in much larger amount than the average for last week. With the continued activity the market remained fairly strong, though in some quarters a reactionary tendency, appeared, and closing bids showed a number of recessions from the previous day's final figures.

The wedding of George Briggs Fredenburg, a nephew of Gen. Otis, and Miss Grace Johnson, which was to have taken place on Wednesday evening at the bride's home, 150 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, has been indefinitely postponed, as already announced in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Brokerage Committee of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange will meet to-day. The work of renewing the brokerage certificates, which has been encasing the attention of the committee for the last month, has been largely accomplished, and will, it is said, be soon completed. Several charges against licensed brokers for alleged violation of the rules are likely to be heard by the committee to-day.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The Daily Telegraph has received the following dispatch, dated Tuesday, Feb. 6, from Spearman's Camp:

Among the passengers on the Hamburg-American Hamer Fuerst Bismarck, which arrived yesterday from Genoa and Naples, was Oscar S. Straus, United States Minister to Turkey, who has left his post to visit this country on leave of absence for the first time since his appointment, in September, 1898, Mr. Straus was accompanied by Mrs. Straus and their children, Miss Aline and Master Roger Straus.
LONDON Feb. 9 -- The only news received up to midnight is contained, in a cable dispatch received in this city from Spearman's Camp, under yesterday's date, which says:

Over half a million shares were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday and some developments were of more than passing significance. Effects of the December panic are still in mind -- as was yesterday shown in the general Wall Street disposition to be ultra prudent. The moment the market lagged, profit taking was apparent and commission house buying suddenly ceased.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The sum of u20,000, the balance of u60,000 stolen from Parr's Bank a year ago, has been mysteriously returned. The notes were found this morning inclosed in a customer's passbook.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 8 -- Mr. Conried manager of the Irving Place Theatre, in New York City, has been secured by the German department of Harvard to produce Goethe's "Iphigenie" in Sanders Theatre on March 22.
MADRID, Feb. 8 -- The gold quotation today was 28.82.

Frank McKee, lessee of the Madison Square and Garrick Theatres and former partner of Charles Hoyt, returned from Europe yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Fuerst Bismarck, after a two months' absence abroad, during which time he visited many of the principal cities on the Continent.
ADELAIDE, South Australia, Feb. 8 -- The wheat harvest of South Australia is estimated to average six bushels an acre, leaving an exportable surplus of 185,000 ARCHITECTURAL LEAGUE DISPLAY.

A true parallel between the Suez and Nicaragua Canals could only be presented if, while allowing the free use of the latter waterway to all powers with which we should be at peace, we should assert and exercise the right for which American statesmen have repeatedly contended, the right, namely, of fortifying the canal and of closing it in time of war against a public enemy.

What a wonderful and blessed change a personal interview with Jesus makes! Two weeks ago we saw two fishermen -- Andrew and John -- go. in and sit with Him for a few hours, and they came out with new hopes and new motives, to enter upon a new life of joy and peace. Last week a member of the Sanhecrim -- Nicodemus -- sat with Him one evening, and he was "born again."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Shades of Sairey Gamp, Mrs. Nickleby, Mrs. Malaprop, and other feminine unconscious humorists! Why, oh, why, should that bright and lively writer Kate Sanborn stultify herself and unconsciously (or was it consciously?) confirm the statement that women have no sense of humor by publishing such a list of alleged funny writers of her own sex as appeared in last Saturday's REVIEW?

In its report for the year 1899, which has just been sent to the State Civil Service Commission, the Municipal Civil Service Commission gives some figures as to the number of persons in the classified service of the local government. The total number of employes subject to the civil service rules is 30,190, and there are, besides these, about 450 exempt positions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a reader of THE TIMES, I would like, through your paper, to express my opinion in regard to some editorials you publish about Col. William Jennings Bryan. It is my candid opinion that the writer of these editorials will be surprised, at the result of the coming election.

It has been a busy week in the New York art world, and in fact in all the American cities, particularly those of the Eastern seaboard, where artists, auctioneers, and dealers, as well as club art committees have come to believe that the Winter months are those best fitted for art displays and sales.

And the Book of the Year? By which is meant, of course, not the year's best book, but the book whose sales are heaviest, and whose readers are most numerous. It is again a question of publics, and I fancy that Mr. Silas Hocking (say) would give most of those whose quotations run highest in recognized markets an Indefinite number of "pounds and a beating."

Among the bills earliest introduced at this session of Congress was one by Mr. BROSIUS, formerly Chairman of the Civil Service Committee, for the retirement with pension of employes in the service of the Federal Government. It is being urgently pressed, and it has strong claims on the favorable attention of Congress, but there is a good deal of opposition to it, most of which is unreasonable.

In the debate in the Senate on the currency bill, which is dragging its slow length along, after the fashion of that leisurely body, the only argument in opposition that appears to have any force or arouse any interest is that based on the alleged favoritism to the National banks.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: As examples of broad humor of the quality known as "professional," would not the "Widow Bedott Papers," by F.M. Whitcher, and the various books of Marietta Holley ("Josiah Allen's Wife") be accepted? In the learned and laboriously achieved classification now in use in large libraries they are classified with the books of Mark Twain, Bill Nye, and others of established fame as "humorists."

Of all the men who occupied important places in the public eye during ante-bellum, civil war, and reconstruction days, none has received such scant treatment at the hands Of biographers as Salmon Portland Chase, who from 1841 to 1873 filled many of the highest positions in the gift of the State and Nation.

Park Board Secretary Hurlbut has received letters from abroad which show that salt water fish can be kept in the proposed new aquarium on Belle Isle at a cost no greater than that required for the maintenance of fresh water fish. In Berlin, Germany, the water which was originally transported from the ocean, has not been replaced by other salt water for twenty-five years.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Feb. 9 -- Arrangements for one of the largest colonization schemes ever engineered in the West have been completed, whereby a portion of the Big Horn Basin, in Northern Wyoming, will be settled by Mormons.

The Belvideres carried off the honors last night in the North Side National League, winning two games. It was expected that the Gothams and Belvideres would furnish a good contest, but the Gothams bowled an unsteady game when they met the Belvideres, Morris and Eltrich particularly bowling low scores.
MADRID, Feb. 9 -- Gold was quotod to-day at 28.92.

The present condition of the tenement houses of this city is so serious and the evils arising therefrom are such a menace to the welfare of the community, the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society says, that it has decided to give a two weeks' exhibition for the purpose of stimulating public interest in the question.
LONDON, Ky., Feb. 9 -- The following message from Gov. Taylor was received to-day by a member of the Legislature now here:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It seems to me that the discussion which has been invited in your columns concerning woman's endowment with a sense of humor, leading directly to the quest for an out-and-out woman humorist, is especially timely. "Do women write strictly humorous books -- if not why not?"

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Sir. Robert Hichens's last book -- "The Slave" -- is not lacking in many of the qualities of a good novel, but it attracts especial attention because of the fact that its characters are, with a few exceptions, men and women well known in the world of London.

BOSTON. Feb. 1 -- The Boston Public Library has just bought in London what appears to be a Benjamin Franklin prize. It is possibly the earliest impression of the little pamphlet "Advice to a Young Tradesman. Written by an Old One." The text consists of only four pages. It was printed at the New Printing Office of Benjamin Mecom.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Sept. 16, 1899, under the head of "Bargain Hunting in Rare Books," some instances of scarce volumes picked up "for a song" each in this city were given. The collector was told not to believe the current assertions that the days of "finds" had gone by, and was advised to "be a hero in the strife."

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 9 -- The Democratic Legislature met here to-day, having present in each house a quorum of the total membership. Mr. Beckham made the announcement this afternoon that he is prepared to protect the legislators from arrest. The developments of to-day mark the first steps taken toward carrying out the plans of the Democrats to set up a State Government here.

John N. Golding has sold for the Gleason estate of Syracuse the plot at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, having a frontage of 5O.8 1/2 feet on the avenue and of 140 feet on the street, together with the lot on the north side of Eighty-seventh Street, 150 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 25 by 100.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- A special dispatch from Spearman's Camp, dated yesterday (Friday) noon) says that owing to the Boer crossfire and the impossibility of intrenching Vaal Krantz, Gen. Buller's force withdrew.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I fully agree with several of your recent correspondents on the subject of "uncut edges." I presume that there was a reason originally for sending out books with their edges not trimmed, and no one can blame the magazine publishers even now for not trimming the edges, for by this means they prevent casual visitors to bookstores from reading without buying.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Professional medal play over thirty-six holes for positions in finals occupied the day. The spectators showed keen interest in the play of their various favorites, and applauded phenomenal puts.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 9 -- Gov. Taylor did not sign the Louisville peace agreement to-day. He announced, moreover, that he had no intention of doing so for some time, and did not know whether he would sign it at all. On the other hand, the Democrats were confident that he would affix his signature to the document.

Recessions were the rule in yesterday's market -- not because any bad news was disclosed or apparently for any other reason than that traders were inclined to "even up" their contracts over the impending holiday.
Charles P. Bacon of 96 Broadway, attorney for Abraham Kling, who seeks to bring suit for dissolution of the State Trust Company, said last night:

Mr. A.R. Spofford, in a very interesting paper on the conditions which contribute toward making certain books scarce read become the Washington Library Association as its January meeting and recently reprinted in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, says:

--Gen. SHAFTER ought to expand into a formal essay the few critical remarks about the progress of the Anglo-Boer war made by him at Indianapolis this week. Almost any magazine or review editor would joyfully accept and generously pay for such an article, and under the inevitable heading of "Shatter on Buller," it would be read with consuming interest by every connoisseur of solemn and unconscious humor.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your recent enumeration, in answer to a correspondent, of the titles composing the "Sherlock Holmes" series, causes me to predicate thereon some comment on what promises to become a Dupin-Holmes (or Poe-Doyle) controversy.

A number of lawyers friendly, to Justice Fitzgerald met in conference yesterday afternoon at the law office of Maurice B. Blumenthal, at 271 Broadway. The declared purpose of the meeting was the discussion and adoption of come plan to discipline Wheeler H. Peckham, President of the City Club, who on Wednesday night made charges against Justice Fitzgerald in connection with the receivership for the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Independent press of this city has on frequent occasions expressed its surprise and disappointment at the so-called "apathy" of the people to the attacks and criticisms of the City Club, Bar Association, and other anti-Tammany organizations upon our Judges and public officials.

I was sent back to New York the next Autumn for another Winter's schooling. I landed from the steamer at the foot of Cortlandt Street on the morning after the first great fire of New York, that known as the Custom House fire, from the Custom House having been included in it, and I saw the ruins still smoking and the firemen playing on them.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The report of State Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn on fire and marine companies has been submitted to the Legislature. It shows that during the past year the fire insurance companies operating in this State conducted business at a great loss. In this connection the report says:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 9 -- Leading grain men of this city charge that Baltimore is suffering by railroad discrimination. The head of one of the large exporting houses says that the railroads have made the situation desperate. Competing ports have been securing cut rates despite the frequent announcements of railroad officials that rates are being maintained.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Gov. Roosevelt will go to New York to-morrow for the purpose of having a conference with Senator Thomas C. Platt. The object of the Chief Executive in making this trip is to inform Mr. Platt as leader of the Republican organization in this State that under no circumstances will he accept the nomination for the Vice Presidency, which some persons believe Mr. Platt wishes to force upon him.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Metropolitan took an upward spurt to-day. After opening at 78 3/4, the preferred advanced steadily to 80 1/4, and closed at 79 5/8. It round its greatest strength around 79 5/8 and 79 3/4. The certificates brought 27, and $22,000 of the bonds sold at 96 1/4. Linseed preferred opened at 58 1/8, declined to 57 5/8, recovered to 5, and closed at 57 3/4.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: A correspondent, (J.J. Arnaud,) in your issue of Jan. 13, inquires after a good commentary to "Faust," saying that he has found Owen's "Five Great Sceptical Dramas of History" inaccurate and unsatisfactory, and that this was the only commentary that he had at hand.

I have been requested to touch upon books, but in the limited time at our disposal I can do so only as a swallow touches upon the water, as a swallow might touch upon the ocean. Life is embosomed in mystery. Our very words have their mysteries. There is a mystery attached to the meanings of words which gives them a subtle individuality.

The Continental Chapter, Daughters of the Revolution, gave what they called "an afternoon of palmistry" yesterday in the hall of the Genealogical and Biographical Society, 226 West Fifty-eighth Street, at which I. Sumner Willette read the palms of the members and their guests.

HONOLULU, Feb. 2 -- Capt. W.L. Kneedler of the United States hospital ship Missouri, en route to San Francisco from Manila, with nearly 300 sick soldiers, says that he made a tour of Southern Luzon in company with Gen. Young just before leaving Manila. The conditions there show a complete cessation of war.

A book lover hardly knows which way to turn first as he stands in front of the "kidney table" in the library of the late Augustin Daly. Here in this second-floor room, with its southern exposure to the sun, the dead bibliophile kept his chiefest book treasures. A merely superficial view makes it evident that until the catalogue is issued the world will know but little of the important collection contained within these four walls.

Dr. Milo R. Maltbie delivered the second of a series of lectures on municipal government in England to an audience of about 1,000 members of the People's Institute last night at Cooper Union. The lecture related chiefly to the municipal ownership of gas and water systems, and went to show that the cities in the United States were behind the English cities in this particular.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. William Hyatt Farrington's letter referring to Hemstreet's "Nooks and Corners of Old New York " in the last SATURDAY'S REVIEW, was no doubt read with care by all your readers who are interested in the city's landmarks and their history. Corrections and information of this kind are very welcome to the increasing numbers that are studying local lore.

The Tale and Brown Universities' hockey teams met in the St. Nicholas Skating Rink last night. The game resulted in a score of 7 to 2 in Yale's favor. Both teams played with snap, but the Brown men were clearly outclassed from the start, and the number of scores made by the winners was largely due to the poor defense of Brown's goal by Chase.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In looking over the list of humorous writers by Kate Sanborn in THE SATURDAY REVIEW, I am surprised to see how many there are. I should unhesitatingly put a large interrogation mark against most of the names, but as I am somewhat lacking in that "mysterious sixth sense" I refrain.

It is impossible not to respect Mr. Harrison's courage in contributing to what he has called the "cataract of printed stuff," which the eloquent expression of his opinions has thus far not availed to stem. That he still maintains his prejudices against the "incessant accumulation of fresh books" is hardly to be doubled, as a tendency to alter his point of view is the least of his defects.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 9 -- Senator Aldrich, in undertaking to state what should be the programme for Congress up to the time of adjournment, said to-day: "It seems to me that we should pass the Currency bill, provide such legislation as is imperatively necessary for Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and the Philippines, pass the appropriation bills, and go home."
WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 9 -- Major Gen. Henry W. Lawton was buried to-day in the National Cemetery at Arlington.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Assemblyman Cooley of Westchester will introduce several corporation bills. One will provide that stockholders owning 1 per centum of stock in a one-million-dollar corporation may be allowed to make an inspection of the books and accounts of such company.

Many reminiscences of John Ruskin arc to be found in the leading English journals. Some of these are novel. Ruskin's grandmother was the landlady of a tavern called the "King's Head" An aunt of Ruskin's had married a Croydon baker. Ruskin's mother was a disciplinarian of a fairly strict character.

Apropos of book collecting in general, we wonder if it has ever occurred to any one what an interesting collection could be made of books containing inscriptions, books of no special value in themselves, and containing names usually quite unknown to fame? It has long been a custom of a friend of our own to secure such books whenever discovered on the shelves of second-hand book shops.

The Molineux trial was resumed yesterday, Manheim Brown, the juror who has been ill, being well enough to be again in court. Assistant District Attorney Osborne continued his address to the jury throughout the morning and afternoon and during a special two hours' evening session. This was done to enable the Recorder to deliver his charge and give the case into the hands of the jury to-day.

The question of the power of Congress over the territory acquired by us from Spain is distinctly raised in the reports from the Ways and Means Committee on the proposed tariff for Puerto Rico. It comes up distinctly in the form of a party question. This aspect of it is not concealed, it is even emphasized, by the fact that one Republican, from Massachusetts, is found to stand with the Democrats.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- An application was made to-day to Attorney General Davies for the dissolving of the George W. Lederer Company of New York City by George B. McLennan, who was Vice President of the company. Mr. McLennan declares the company insolvent to the amount of several thousand dollars.

The annual banquet of the Crockery Board of Trade of New York was given last evening in the large ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. There were about 200 members of the board and guests present. Among the latter were a number of members of the American China Jobbers' Association, which has been meeting in this city.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your correspondent would suggest in aid of the quest for humorous women writers the anonymous author of "The Widow Bedott Papers," known to be a woman. Her book caused many a laugh, and was for a time very popular with the class of readers that enjoy laughing now, with the "Nasbys" and "Billings" of literature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- There was a scene at the night session of the House to-night which recalled the stirring and exciting days of the Fifty-first Congress. An irate member rushed down the main aisle waving his arms and shouting for recognition while half the Democratic members were on their feet execrating the occupant of the Chair for what they termed his arbitrary course, and from several places in the hall came loud hisses.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 9 -- "The Greatest Thing in the World," a drama in four acts by Harriet Ford, who formerly lived in this city, and Mrs. Henry C. De Mille, had its initial performance at the Hyperion Theatre, in this city, to-night. The theatre was packed, and Mrs. Sarah Cowell Le Moyne, for whom the play was especially written, was given an enthusiastic reception.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 9 -- Burglaries are again nightly occurrences in Norwalk and vicinity. During the past few days the railroad stations at Cannon, Wilton, and South Wilton have been entered, while at Irwing Lockwood's coal yard at South Norwalk the safe was again blown open last night.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Had the men readers of THE SATURDAY REVIEW been polled before Kate Sanborn's list appeared, it is safe to say that, in the language of the sporting fraternity, you could have named "your own price, with no takers," regarding the number of humorous writers -- female -- dead or living.

HAVANA, Feb. 9 -- Alexis Frye, Superintendent of Cuban Schools, in his report to the Governor General upon the development of the school system since the work of reorganization began, six weeks ago, says that the whole country seems on lire with enthusiasm for education.

August Horrmann, the President of the Rubsam Horrmann Brewing Company of Stapleton, S.I., committed suicide by cutting his throat with a razor shortly after noon yesterday at Dr. Max Wilcke's private sanitarium at 588 West One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street, where he had been under the care of the house physician and a trained nurse for the last two weeks.

William Jennings Bryan spoke in Brooklyn last night before an audience that filled the Academy of Music from gallery to orchestra, crowded the stage and placed standing room wherever obtainable, at a high premium.
