The lecture, "Pending Problems," was delivered under the auspices of George L. Ricord Post, Grand Army of the Republic, of which Patrick Hayes, Warden of the Kings County Penitentiary and one zation, is a prominent member.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- Musicians and ethnologists have about equal interest in "Indian Story and Song in North America," to be published by Messrs. Small, Maynard Co. this month. The author, Miss Alice C. Fletcher, has studied the Indians through their women, learning in long hours passed in the guest's place things seldom told to strangers and never to white men.

William R. Merriam, ex-Governor of Minnesota and Director of the Federal Census for 1900, who is perfecting the details for the task he is about to begin, is in New York consulting with the local manager in charge, Charles S. Wilbur, as to the most accurate and complete system of taking the census of the city.

CHICAGO, Feb 9 -- Prank O. Lowden today announced the details of the reorganization of the Shelby Steel Tube Company, which recently acquired the assets, patents, and processes of all of the plants in the country engaged in the manufacture of seamless tubing. The concerns are the Newcastle Tube Company, Auburn Nut and Bolt Works, Hercules Seamless Tube Company, the Pope Tube Company.

Early in 1843 my father, the late Henry Vizetelly, received from Mr. Nickesson, the publisher, who succeeded Fraser, the founder of the magazine bearing his name, a letter of introduction to William Makepeace Thackeray, whose services he wished to engage as art and literary critic on The Pictorial Times, once a formidable rival to The Illustrated London News.

The latest fashion of entertaining on Saturday seems to have crowded, the social calendar and to-day and this evening the world of society will be occupied from noon until far into Sunday morning. Perhaps the event of the day which has been most discussed is the dinner and musicale to be given by Mrs. George J. Gould at 857 Fifth Avenue.

A great and a grand life was Lyon Playfair's. There were many men of his day who were his superiors in scientific ability, but not one of them was his equal in practical usefulness. Endowed with an immense amount of energy, and singularly industrious, the benefits he conferred are countless.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Nothing like the flood of private pension bills, which is being poured in on this Congress, has ever been known before in American history. Within two months after the opening of the session as many bills have been introduced as are usually offered in a whole session, and the flood is increasing instead of diminishing.

The more closely we examine the new convention offered as a substitute for the Clayton-Bulwer treaty, the more unacceptable it appears. Among the objections to the ratification of the instrument, which, as The Sun has pointed out, while ostensibly a substitute, is essentially a revival of the most obnoxious features of the former treaty, these are insurmountable:

Nine of every ten men who saw the fight between Joe Gans, the colored lightweight of Baltimore, and "Spike" Sullivan of Boston, at the Broadway Athletic Club last night, expressed the opinion that the deathknell of prizefighting in New York had been sounded. The exhibition was one of the wildest disorder, and for a time it looked as if there would be serious trouble in the place.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- A lone robber, well dressed, with money in his pockets, and with a silk mask to cover up his features, was shot and killed in C.H. Woerner's Park Pavilion late last night by Frank Barnum, an Oak Park lawyer, and Edward Sommerfeldt, the barkeeper.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Assemblyman Bedell of Orange to-day introduced a bill for the protection of life and property against loss or damage from the operation of steam boilers or steam engines wherever used for power by incompetent persons.
Reports to the commercial agencies of the country this week tell of a generally excellent condition of affairs in the business world.

A Plagiarism and Its Sequel. Some months ago a young man who represented himself to be an unpublished English author in sore straits submitted a manuscript to G.P. Putnam's Sons. After the usual formalities the work was accepted. The author desired that his name should appear upon the title page as "George L. Myers."

The war news is very puzzling as well as very meagre. What has been the result of Gen. BULLER'S latest advance we do not yet know. But that is less puzzling than the question why it should have been made. For apparently it was made practically along the same route which he had attempted twice before, only to find it impassable.

Mrs. George J. Gould gave last evening at her residence, No. 857 Fifth Avenue, a large dinner in honor of the Count and Countess de Castellane. The dinner was one of sixty-eight covers, and was served at seven oval tables. The dinner was followed by a musicale and this in turn was followed by a handsome supper.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 10. -- At 4 o'clock this morning, while the freshmen were peacefully sleeping, the class of 1902 at Vassar held their tree ceremonies. At the appointed time groups of red-coated Amazons with helmets and shields gathered silently about the big elm between Strong Hall and the main building, where the weird gleanings of a multitude of red lights fell upon them.

Charges of cruelty against officers of the United States Army transport McClellan which arrived here on Friday from Puerto Rico and Cuba, were preferred by A.S Barnwell, a member of the crew, yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields. Barnwell was accompanied by another member of the crew as a witness.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- There, exists to-day what practically amounts to an offensive and defensive alliance between Great Britain and Portugal. For the past week and longer there has been circulating through the English press, irrespective of party lines, a nervous apprehension of European opposition, and a still more nervous appreciation of the fact that Great Britain at the present moment is unable to face it with honor to herself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The War Department has made public Gen. Schwan's report upon his expedition in the second week of October last in the province of Cavite, which resulted in the capture of Cavite, Viejo, Novaleta, Rosario, San Cruz, San Francis de Malabon, and Das Marinas. This expedition, according to Gen. Schwan, accomplished the objects for which it was set on foot with thoroughness and dispatch.

The efforts of the police in the Franklin Syndicate case are now directed especially to the capture of the accomplices of Miller. Whether or not they have any clue or how many persons they believe to have been concerned in the swindling operations of the syndicate the police will not say.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The serious illness of Gen. Sir William Lockhart, the Commander in Chief in India, will probably oblige him to return home. He has not been well since he went out, and his duties have to a great extent devolved on Major Gen. Sir William G. Nicholson, the Adjutant General, who has now gone on Lord Roberts's staffs.

SING SING, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- James Finn, a convict, serving a five-year term in Sing Sing Prison, escaped last night. This morning when Keeper John O'Keefe went to Finn's cell he found a dummy on the cot, with the bed covering drawn over it, exposing only the stuffed head.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The War Department has made public Gen. Schwan's report upon his expedition in the second week of October last in the province of Cavite, which resulted in the capture of Cavite, Viejo, Novaleta, Rosario, San Cruz, San Francis de Malabon, and Das Marinas. This expedition, according to Gen. Schwan, accomplished the objects for which it was set on foot with thoroughness and dispatch.

Under a decision which has just been handed down by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court all street railways which control or lease other street railways must transfer passengers from one line to the other, provided that the second line was in the control of the company at the time it acquired the first one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Among other reasons that are given by Republicans to account for what has been called the shelving of the Hanna-Payne Subsidy Shipping bill is the desire to be economical in expenditures. The necessity for economy is not found in diminished receipts of the Government, for they are daily in excess of current expenditures, and the Treasury balances are constantly increased.

Gov. Roosevelt opened the Tenement House Exhibition, which has been prepared by the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society, at 404 Fifth Avenue, last evening. What was formerly the ballroom at Sherry's was crowded to and beyond the doors, and a large number of the visitors were unable to gain admittance.

MODDER RIVER, Feb. 9. -- Gen. Macdonald scored a distinct success at Koodoosberg. His original orders were to hold the drift and construct a fort. The position, however, was extremely difficult, a long range of high hills running northwest and terminating close to the drift, on the north bank of the river.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 10. -- The collapse of the peace negotiations through Gov. Taylor's rejection of the Louisville agreement and his action in calling off the London Legislature and partially withdrawing the troops have left the fight over State officers divested of many of its warlike features, but in a worse legal tangle than ever.

The annual Winter athletic meeting and indoor carnival of sports of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, which was held last night in Madison Square Garden, proved to be the most important amateur and intercollegiate athletic contest that has been seen in this city during the Winter season in many years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Under the auspices of the United Irish Societies of Chicago thirtynine young soldiers will leave the Lake Shore station to-morrow morning bound for New York, whence they will sail for Lorenzo Marques to act as an ambulance corps in the Boer army. They will be joined by eleven volunteers from Boston before leaving New York.
Dodge Olcott'e team won two games yesterday afternoon in the wholesale drug trade tournament at Reid's alleys, while the Roessler Hasslacher Chemical Company lost two games. Scores:

MORE LIGHT ON THE RUSSO-PERSIAN LOAN. -- According, to belief in European diplomatic circles, the new Russian loan to Persia places the latter country absolutely dependent upon Russia. It is generally considered that, although Russia will very likely lose the 22,500,000 rubles in question, yet her ultimate political gain will far outweigh the financial loss.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 10. -- The Spanish steamer Niceto, which came to Lambert's Point to-day for coal, reported sighting off Charleston the gasolene yacht Ida Belle Lowndes of New York.

The position, however, was extremely difficult, a long range of high hills running northwest and terminating close to the drift, on the north bank of the river.

Mrs. George J. Gould gave last evening at her residence, No. 857 Fifth Avenue, a large dinner in honor of the Count and Countess de Castellane. The dinner was one of sixty-eight covers, and was served at seven oval tables. The dinner was followed by a musicale and this in turn was followed by a handsome supper.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Seven thousand workingmen who have been engaged on buildings in course of construction here quit work at noon to-day. This act, it is asserted, marks the real beginning of a war between labor and the contractors which will suspend building operations in Chicago until present differences are settled.

This act, it is asserted, marks the real beginning of a war between labor and the contractors which will suspend building operations in Chicago until present differences are settled.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 10. -- The Spanish steamer Niceto, which came to Lambert's Point to-day for coal, reported sighting off Charleston the gasolene yacht Ida Belle Lowndes of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Secretary Long has sent to the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs all correspondence in his department relative to the question of sheathing and coppering the new battleships and cruisers ordered by the Naval Appropriation bill of the last session. A majority of the Board of Construction unite in a recommendation for the repeal of the provision.

The harmony dinner of the National Civic Club in honor of the Democratic members of the New York State delegation in Congress and of Congressmen who are prominent in the leadership of the party in other States, took place at the Pouch Gallery in Brooklyn last night. Edward M. Shepard, the President of the club, presided, and on the floor were more than 300 members of the party who reside in Kings County.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Outside England the old proverb that "Bad news travels fast," still holds good, but here it is no longer true. Paris knew on Thursday that Gen. Buller's third attempt to relieve Ladysmith had failed, and sold South African shares all day with such steadiness that our buyers became exhausted, and yesterday, when it attempted to continue, the market could only put down prices and refuse to buy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Friends of Commander Wainwright, while rejoicing at the honor extended to him by Secretary Long in offering him the position of Superintendent of the Naval Academy, are wondering how a way can be found to gracefully decline that office and yet obtain the recognition of high service which the Secretary intended to give him in making him the successor of Rear Admiral McNair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Only one matter came up before the Senate to-day before it took up the consideration of the Financial bill. That was the resolution of sympathy for the Boers offered by Mr. Allen, (Dem., Neb.) Immediately upon its disposal the Chair recognized Mr. Chandler, (Rep., N.H.)

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- A dispatch received from Headquarters Camp, at Springfield Bridge, dated Feb. 9. says:

President Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission announced yesterday that he will probably call a meeting of the board on Tuesday. The argument before the Appelate Division for a modification of the bond conditions will be presented on that day, and if there is no opposition a possibility exists, it is said, that a decision may be rendered immediately, but it is quite as likely that none will be handed down until Friday.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Outside England the old proverb that "Bad news travels fast," still holds good, but here it is no longer true. Paris knew on Thursday that Gen. Buller's third attempt to relieve Ladysmith had failed, and sold South African shares all day with such steadiness that our buyers became exhausted, and yesterday, when it attempted to continue, the market could only put down prices and refuse to buy.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Great Britain's status in Egypt as affected by the revolt of the native troops is treated here as extremely serious. This news, which was first announced from Cairo, Jan. 31, has now become an important feature in the French press and receives full confirmation. Its significance will be realized when it is explained that Egypt is a tinder box whence a spark may set into flame the Anglo-French animosity.

Taylor's rejection of the Louisville agreement and his action in calling off the London Legislature and partially withdrawing the troops have left the fight over State officers divested of many of its warlike features, but in a worse legal tangle than ever.

A majority of the Board of Construction unite in a recommendation for the repeal of the provision.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The Anglo-American Convention which permits American construction of the Nicaraguan Canal, has not yet attracted the keen attention here which its importance warrants, considering the heavy French financial interests thereby affected. The Panama Canal has been a well in which nine French peasants out of every ten, attracted by specious promises, invested some part of their savings wrung from French soil.

NYACK, Feb. 10 -- There was an exciting scene at the handsome mansion of Mr. M. B. Sherman, one of Nyack's wealthiest residents, last night, when Mr. Sherman's son-in-law, Edwin B. Quackenbush, of Balston Spa, threatened to shoot his wife. The young man was placed under the surveillance of an officer from 7 o'clock last night until 7 o'clock this morning.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 10 -- Gov. Taylor for the first time in several days, spent the night at the Mansion. To-night several shots were fired in that locality, and the soldiers guarding the house claim they were fired at them. They returned the fire. The affair created some excitement, and a detail of soldiers from the State House was added to the guard at the Mansion.

Charges of cruelty against officers of the United States Army transport McClellan which arrived here on Friday from Puerto Rico and Cuba, were preferred by A.S Barnwell, a member of the crew, yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields. Barnwell was accompanied by another member of the crew as a witness.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 10 -- G.B. Patterson, Postmaster at Key West, has been nominated for Congress from the First Congressional District of this State by the Republicans. J.N. Coombs of Appalachicola and J.F. Herr have been named as delegates to the National Convention. Resolutions indorsing the McKinley Administration were adopted.

Feb. 5 to seek a conference cooking for a settlement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- State Senator Tierney of Montana continued his testimony in the Clark case before the Senate Committee on Elections to-day. He said he had never been asked to vote for Mr. Clark for the United States Senate, and therefore never had been offered any consideration for his vote.

In the current number of The Post Graduate, Dr. D.B. St. John Roosa has an interesting article on the old New York Hospital, which he read before a recent meeting of the Society of the Alumni of the New York Hospital. The history of the hospital, the doctor said, had been written years before in classical English by the pen of G. C. Verplanck.

Practice has shown that it can be profitably employed at or near the generating point only, and there is no commercial effort to extend operations beyond territory already in hand.

It was the third performance of this attractive combination of operas, and the house was one of sufficient size to testify to the satisfaction of the public with Mr. Grau's latest arrangement.

The old church property of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, at 57 1/2 West Forty-sixth Street, will this week be transferred to a colored congregation of the Baptist Church. For several weeks the colored congregation has been holding services in the church. While the members of the colored church are jubilant over the prospective possession of a church home in such a desirable neighborhood, the property owners nearby are greatly depressed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 10. -- At 4 o'clock this morning, while the freshmen were peacefully sleeping, the class of 1902 at Vassar held their tree ceremonies. At the appointed time groups of red-coated Amazons with helmets and shields gathered silently about the big elm between Strong Hall and the main building, where the weird gleanings of a multitude of red lights fell upon them.

The argument before the Appelate Division for a modification of the bond conditions will be presented on that day, and if there is no opposition a possibility exists, it is said, that a decision may be rendered immediately, but it is quite as likely that none will be handed down until Friday.
The Ohio Society of New York met at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, and the Board of Governors announced the election, among others, of Frank Rockefeller and Charles Dick to non-resident membership.

Enoch L. Fancher, formerly well known as a Justice of the Supreme Court, died Friday night at his home at 141 Madison Avenue. He was born eighty-four years ago in Dutchess County, and was educated at the Wesleyan University, which conferred upon him the degree of LL. D. Upon being graduated he took up the study of law in the office of David Graham, Jr.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- There, exists to-day what practically amounts to an offensive and defensive alliance between Great Britain and Portugal. For the past week and longer there has been circulating through the English press, irrespective of party lines, a nervous apprehension of European opposition, and a still more nervous appreciation of the fact that Great Britain at the present moment is unable to face it with honor to herself.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- Money in the open market grows easier, and the situation is better than it was at the corresponding date last year. Nevertheless yesterday's bank statement shows unusual tension for this time of the year, the discounts being 147,000,000 marks above the figures of 1899.

MONTREAL, Feb. 11. -- Plans long cherished for the growth of Canadian waterway commerce, and especially for the development of trade at this port, will have a practical test in the coming season, which will, be closely watched by shipping interests on both sides of the boundary line and throughout the grain and lumber regions tributary to lake commerce.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners yesterday decided to proceed with the enforcement of its recommendation that the suburban residents of South Brooklyn should be granted transfers by the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company to other surface or elevated lines at the Thirty-sixth Street and Sixty-fifth Street Stations of the elevated railroads controlled by the company in Brooklyn.

Roland B. Molineux, who was pronounced guilty on Saturday night of the murder of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams, passed a quiet and uneventful Sunday in his cell at the Tombs. The cell is No. 36, Tier 2, in the old part of the prison.

-- According to common report Secretary HAY not only drew up with his own hand the Nicaraguan Canal treaty now before the Senate, but he devoted an enormous amount of care to its wording, in order that it might be a perfect expression of the understanding reached by himself and the British Ambassador.

The interest shown by the people of New York and New Jersey in the efforts to save the Palisades from further spoliation will be increased to-morrow by an argument to be made at Tenton before the joint committees having the matter in charge by Franklin W. Hopkins, President of the NewJersey Palisades Commission.

Asa Warren Parker, a well-known lawyer and real estate operator of Brooklyn, died on Friday at his home, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue, that borough. The day on which he filed was the fifty-ninth anniversary of his birth. He was born in Morristown, N.J., and was descended from the Parkers who figured prominently in the early history of New Jersey.
HAVANA, Feb. 11. -- The Heraldo tells Samuel Gompers to return to the United States, declaring that he came here with the intention of creating disturbances.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In one of your recent thoughtful leaders you invited expressions upon the treaty now before the Senate.
It is not to be denied that the verdict of" Guilty of murder in the first degree" against MOLINEUX was a surprise and a shock to the public mind.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

OPINION OF A FRENCH DIPLOMATIST ON EUROPEAN INTERVENTION. -- A former French Cabinet Minister, who is generally believed in Paris to be M. Ribot, has made a statement for publication which is considered of more than ordinary importance as representing the views of most European statesmen regarding possible intervention in the present war.

The passing of the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company into the hands of a receiver is an event of no small significance with reference to the commerce of the Port of New York, and little dissent can be found to the opinion that it is a somewhat alarming symptom of the crippling effect of a number of curable evils.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis surprised his congregation last evening in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, by giving them in lieu of a sermon of the usual character an exhortation of the type of the evangelist. Dr. Hills spoke on "Man-Winning and Man-Building." He called upon all who had in the past year visited nine persons who did not attend church to raise their hands.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- There was not in today's business the difference of a point in the sales of any stock. The volume was small, and the range exceedingly narrow.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- The Senatorial elections which took place on Sunday have resulted in the return of two interesting men to Parliament, namely Gen. Mercier and M. Francis Charmes. M. Ranc, who has been an active political figure ,for many years, failed to be re-elected, and as he is now getting old, this is in all probability the end of his career.

HAVANA, Feb. 11. -- The strike of cigarmakers was settled this morning. The men asked on what conditions they could return to work, and the masters replied, that they could return on the conditions existing before the strike. This reply they accepted, and on Tuesday they will return. The cost of the strike to the manufacturers has been practically nothing.

Pereival E. Nagle, the newly appointed Street Cleaning Commissioner, was seen by a TIMES reporter yesterday afternoon, as he was making his way west on One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, to avoid the many persons watching for him in the neighborhood of his residence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial in to-day's TIMES, "A Weak and Needless Concession," I beg to be allowed to state as follows: The powers that be in the Republican Party, the Hanna syndicate, a couple of months ago decided to at last try to appease the Gold Democrats by passing a positive gold bill, setting the date of Feb. 15 for passage of the same in the Senate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So far the discussion of the expediency of the Stranahan bill has been almost entirely devoted to the principles involved. The bill is so important and so far reaching that I think its administrative features should be well understood by those affected before they decide for or against it.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 11. -- William Metcalf, aged fifty-one, well known in this city and Western Massachusetts as an ex-, pert printer, committed suicide in his home to-day by shooting himself through the head. He died almost instantly.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Controller Dawes, who was in the city to-day on his way to Peoria, where he will speak to-morrow night at the Lincoln Day banquet of the Kickapoo Club, said there was little doubt that the National Republican Headquarters would be established in Chicago.

Gov. Roosevelt spent yesterday in Yonkers, where he was in consultation with F. W. Holls and Dr. Albert Shaw in reference to pending legislation regarding public schools and the municipal ownership of public utilities. Upon returning to the city the Governor went to the home of his uncle, James A. Roosevelt, at 4 West Fifty-seventh Street, where he remained overnight.
The Rev. W.S. Crowe of the Church of the Eternal Hope on West Eighty-first Street, delivered, a lecture last night on "Abraham Lincoln as a Politician." The Rev. Mr. Crowe said in part:

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- In consequence of the death of the Dowager Duchess of Schleswig-Holstein, mother of the Empress, the Court ceremonies planned in honor of the Emperor's forty-first birthday were abandoned, and while the City of Berlin was Illuminated in a manner which caused the sky to assume a ruddy glow, the royal castle remained in darkness.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on the Federal and State Governments, in Sunday's paper, you conclude that "the intervention of the United States Government in the affairs of the States rests on very narrow ground, and cannot be resorted to except on closely defined conditions."
PORT ARTHUR, Texas, Feb. 11. -- James Sweeney, (white,) was lynched at 1 o'clock this morning.

Charles E. Witherell, a window dresser, twenty-five years old, died yesterday morning at 151 West One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, and it is thought by the police that he committed suicide by taking morphine.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 11. -- The forging department of the Atha Illingworth Steel Works, on the line of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in Harrison, which was visited by fire at midnight, was a scene of chaos today. The upper portion of the big building was entirely gone and much of the valuable machinery had been destroyed.

ST. JOHN'S. N.F., Feb. 11. -- At the forthcoming special session of the Newfoundland Legislature, called for Feb. 19, the Government will propose a vote of $20,000 toward the Imperial Patriotic Fund, as the colony is unable to send any Volunteers to South' Africa.

In the centre of a large crowd, some kneeling reverently, others gazing curiously, two priests of the Roman Catholic Church, late yesterday afternoon administered the last rites of their religion to a man who lay injured on the sidewalk near the foot of the stairs of the up-town station of the Second Avenue elevated railroad at Twenty-third Street.

The case of Edward Clifford, the New Jersey murderer, is regarded as the most noted in the criminal annals of that State. The extraordinary fight which has been made to save him from the ignominy of death upon the gallows and the success which has followed the efforts of his friends, to secure for him reprieve., after reprieve have attracted general attention.

This is a Wall Street holiday more thorough than has recently been usual. No developments of consequence impending here, the broker and his customer will be without nervous watchfulness for for- eign quotations. To-morrow a variety of business factors may be disclosed, and included in the list are some matters of exceptional importance.

MANILA, Feb. 11. -- Of late the insurgents in Albay Province, Luzon, have adopted harassing tactics against the towns which the Americans have garrisoned. They encamp in the hills and maintain a constant fire upon the American outposts. When the troops sally against them, they scatter, returning when the Americans retire.

RENSBERG, Feb. 11. -- A picket or five Victorian Rifles, after holding a post for some hours yesterday, was forced to retire, the Boers getting on a hill and firing Sown upon them. Three were slightly wounded, one is missing, and one escaped unhurt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If I understand the case, there are no grounds for criticism of Justice Fitzgerald growing out of his refusal to appoint one person receiver of a corporation and his appointment of another instead. The facts, as I have read them, are briefly these: A corporation was in such difficulty that the appointment of a receiver was proper.

We do not understand the motives of Mr. TAYLOR, the Republican claimant to the Governorship of Kentucky, in refusing to sign the agreement made at Louisville last week. So far as we can see he has lost one substantial advantage for his party and for the State, since the Legislature will not now be bound to pass the non-partisan election law to which the leaders of the majority were fully committed in that agreement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11. -- Since President Hadley became the head of Yale University, the duties of the office have made it impossible for him to coach Yale's debating teams. As the time approaches for Yale's forensic battles with Harvard and Princeton interest in the matter increases, and there is, much speculation as to who will give Yale's debaters their final "trimming up."

William J. O'Brien of the Granite Cutters reported yesterday to the Central Federated Union on the strikes of men of his union on works conducted by Contractor John Pierce. He said that Mr. Pierce had promised to pay the men who worked at one of the quarries that supplies stone for the Chicago Post Office $3.60 for an eight-hour day, but did not keep his word, and the strike was renewed.

There may be nothing new in fish-net handbags, but the passengers in an elevate car recently evinced as much interest in one of them as if nothing of the kind had ever been seen before. It was carried by woman in whose family some one evidently had the faculty of turning scraps to us without needless expense.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- The only influence of the Government on our market last week, apart from the war, was the absorption by the Treasury of the capital of dealers in credit. Including the amounts paid over by the collectors since the bank return was made up at least u2,500,000 net has been withdrawn from the market balances in the last six days.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- An attempt is to be made at the present session of the Legislature to establish a reformatory asylum, under State management, for habitual users of alcohol and narcotic drugs. Mr. Weekes of New York has a bill which has been prepared by the Church Temperance Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church, which he will offer in the Assembly some day this week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your two editorials, that of yesterday and that of to-day, on the subject of the modifications of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty contain such convincing arguments as to the necessity for the neutrality of the canal, instead of the control of it, and the fortification of its banks, by the United States Government, that I cannot refrain from sending you this word of praise from an old reader.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Representative W.S. Kaox of Massachusetts, Chairman of the House Committee on Territories, has completed his report upon the bill for the creation of a territorial form of government in Hawaii, and it will be submitted to the House to-morrow The report is a very voluminous document of 103 pages, going exhaustively into all The questions involved and thoroughly covering every phase of the bill.

ALBANY, .Feb. 11. -- While the usual predictions have been made that the Legislature will adjourn sine die about March 25, the great number of bills of vast importance as yet unconsidered and which call for protracted debate seem to indicate that the Legislature will hardly conclude its labors by that time.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 11. -- The gift is announced to Yale University of the valuable musical collections of Morris Steinert of this city. Conditional on the gift of Mr. Steinert has been the necessity for Yale to secure funds sufficient to build a structure for the collections, and it is announced that this has been done, and that a proper edifice will be constructed to meet the demands of the donor.

BOSTON, Feb. 11. -- The movement by disaffected students against the doctrines of Methodism as taught at the Boston University School of Theology, which was formerly directed against Prof. Hinckley W. Mitchell, has now taken the form of an organized attempt by the dissenting students to weaken the standing of the school, and an attack has been made upon W. R. Warren, Prof. Henry Sheldon, and Dr. Borden P. Browne.
LONDON, Feb. 11. -- It is reported from Durban that Gen. Joubert is marching with a column of 6,000 men to outflank Gen. Buller.

The recent course of the copper market and the activity displayed have led to inquiry as to the outlook for the future and the conditions governing the matter generally. Discussing the situation, John R. Stanton, statistician of the Producers' Association and President of several of the producing mines in the Lake Superior district, says:

The New York Presbytery, by its action yesterday afternoon, evinced just as strong a reluctance to try the Rev. Dr. Arthur C. McGiffert on charges of heresy as it did in December, when by a good majority vote it decided that, inasmuch as the General Assembly of 1899 had sufficiently disavowed the teachings of the Union Theological Seminary professor, for the best interests of the Church the proceedings against him had better be dropped.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his speech before the New York Board of Trade last night, I should have said at the dinner, or better still, after the dinner, when the wine was red in the cup and effervesced in the champagne glass, Senator Hanna became oblivious of his relation to his own crying baby, and attributed it to Senator Frye.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- The Assembly to-night by a viva voce vote defeated the Minton resolution calling upon New York State Representatives in Congress to safeguard the interests of this State from threatened allen invasion, and that the President of the United States cause a rigid enforcement of the immigration laws.

Yesterday was the first anniversary of he second memorable blizzard in the annals if New York, and the comparatively mild airs and open weather that greeted the holiday makers was in strange contrast to the orgy of wind, snow, and sleet that a year ago almost buried the town, which for two days cut off all railroad communication with Philadelphia, and that was accompanied by zero temperature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The return of the Turkish Minister, Ali Ferrouh Bey, who reached Washington to-day after three months' leave of absence, and accompanied by his wife and sister, is a matter of general social interest, inasmuch as the coming of Mme. Ali Ferrouh marks a distinct departure from Turkish traditions and for the first time brings a woman to the Turkish Legation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- It is not considered an assurance of success to subsidies by the opponents of subsidies for ships of the merchant marine, that the President directed attention to the importance of the legislation, and so indicated his approval of it. Said a Republican, who is in favor of free trade with Puerto Rico, agreeing with the President in his view of that matter:

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- Frank Harris, former editor of The Saturday Review, in a pamphlet published to-day, reiterates the view which The St. James's Gazette has been insisting on that "quality and not quantity is what England needs to beat the Boers," and that "England always fails to learn by experience."

We remember remarking, two or three years ago, on the occasion of the anniversary of LINCOLN'S birth, that the memorableness of a great man was by no means the only thing to be considered in making his birthday a public holiday. Another thing is the extent of the probability that it will be generally observed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The first day of the final week in the discussion of the Currency bill in the Senate was occupied by the speeches of Mr. Wolcott, (Rep., Col.,) Mr. Elkins, (Rep., West Va.,) and Mr. Butler, (Pop., N.C.) The greatest interest was manifested in the argument of Mr. Wolcott, Chairman of the International Bimetallic League of 1897, who voiced the sentiments of many Republicans who adhere to bimetallism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Owing to the sad news from the seat of war and the state of mourning in England, the British Ambassador and Lady Pauncefote have abandoned the several evening entertainments which were planned to precede the marriage of their daughter to Mr. Bromley on Feb. 24.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- Lord Roberts has gathered 35,000 men, with whom, according to the best military opinion in London, he purposes turning the left of the Magersfontein lines, near Jacobsdal, entering the Free State, compelling Gen. Cronje to raise the siege of Kimberley, and thus making his first step toward Bloemfontein.

There seems no reason to doubt the authenticity or the accuracy of the report that, after the death of Pro DEL PILAR, such of the insurgent leaders as were left concluded that there was no use in further resistance to the forces of the United States. The report is intrinsically probable.

Dr. John Russell Wilde, who escaped from the Rivercrest Sanitarium in Astoria, Borough of Queens, a few days ago, and for whom his friends and the police have been hunting, was accidentally discovered to be in the workhouse, to which he was committed for one month. The discovery was made by Daniel Sullivan, Clerk of the Essex Market Court, who read about Dr. Wilde's disappearance on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- For the first time since the advocates of woman suffrage began to, appeal to Congress in person in order to secure universal suffrage they will be opposed to-morrow by women, who will address arguments to the Suffrage Committees to induce them to refuse to extend the boon of suffrage to women as well as to men.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 12. -- The efforts of the Democratic lawyers were directed to-day toward mapping out plans to secure the adjudication of the claims of Taylor and Beckham to the office of Governor. There is danger of a clash as long as the present positions are maintained.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- The House of Commons was crowded to-day in anticipation of the statement of George Wyndham, Parliamentary Secretary of the War Office, in regard to army measures. Joseph H. Choate, the United States Ambassador; Henry White, the Secretary of the United States Embassy, and W.T. Baker, the President of the Chicago Board of Trade, were among those present in the distinguished strangers' gallery.

BABYLON, L.I., Feb. 12. -- Urged on by a charm, in which the Bible played a part, a large searching party worked all day today searching for the body of Capt. Jesse Muncey, who disappeared just before Christmas. The search was made on the Harry Rencen Place at West Babylon. The men dug in every possible place on the farm but failed to locate the body.

Just how Jones's wife got Jones to go to the wax-works exhibition with her on a Sunday evening is a matter that that little woman alone knows, and she hasn't told about it But Jones went. Now as a consequence he is in a fair way of becoming an inebriate.

A Virginia correspondent with the good old Scotch-Virginian name of GORDON gently criticises THE TIMES for some of its statements as to the intervention of the United States Government in the affairs of the States. He regards our remark that this "rests on very narrow ground, and cannot be resorted to except on closely defined conditions," as "the beautiful theory of the verdant old makers of our Constitution."

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- The most radical gas-reduction-of-price bill that has yet been put in the Legislature will be introduced to-morrow by Senator Coffey in the Senate and Assemblyman Cain in the House. It applies only to Brooklyn Borough, and makes the price 75 cents per thousand cubic feet.

Before the end of the present week the United States Senators are expected to be through with their rather desultory discussion of the pending Currency bill, and to come to vote upon the proposed amendments, none of which, except those agreed upon by the Finance Committee, are at all likely to be adopted.

Attracted by banners printed in red, and with large type, announcing that the "real thing" was to take place in Morrisania Hall, One Hundred and Seventieth Street and Third Avenue, a crowd of about 4,000 people assembled in that place last evening to listen to what were supposed to be "warm" songs and living pictures, but the performance was not allowed to go on.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12. -- The Musurgia of New York, under the able direction of Mr. Walter Henry Hall, gave a very successful concert here in Alexander Hall this evening. Mr. Hall conducted, with his usual skill and spirit, a programme of unusual interest, which was listened to by a representative Princeton audience.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day gave out a statement containing his reasons for displacing Dr. Backus as a member of the Board of Managers of the Long Island State Hospital. In part it is as follows:

Louis Waas, four years old, was fatally burned yesterday afternoon while playing near the kitchen fire in the apartments of his uncle, Tobias Schwartz, on the third floor of the tenement 207 East One Hundred and Fourth Street. The boy's mother was deserted by her husband. She lives in the Schwartz household and goes out daily to work.

The "The Concert" to be given this afternoon at Sherry's by Mrs. Langtry, or, as she prefers to be called in connection with social and philanthropic functions, Mrs. Hugo De Bathe, received the attention of the Executive Committee of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union at a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the Institute for the Blind, at Ninth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Mrs. Lillian M. Stevens, President of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union; Miss Anna A. Gordon, Vice President at Large, and Mrs. Margaret Dye Ellis, Superintendent of the Department of Legislation for the society, had an interview with President McKinley this afternoon.

Honors were evenly divided between J.S. Williams and W.S. Edey when darkness came on the grounds of the Carteret Gun Club, at Bergen Point last night, and the fast-flying pigeons could scarcely be discerned. During the day two cup contests and an equal number of miss-and-out sweeps were decided.
LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The political outlook in Cape Colony comes in for a good deal of attention in recent letters or correspondents. The Cape Town representative of The Daily Telegraph says:
Arthur Roussin, twenty-three years old, a coppersmith, is a prisoner in Hudson Street Hospital on a charge of attempted suicide. His home, he said, is at 8 Seminary Street, Charlestown, Mass.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- The meeting of the promoters of the American Association of Baseball Clubs, called for this afternoon by Acting President Harry Quin of Milwaukee, was postponed until to-morrow morning, and the organization of the new league put off another day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A bill for the relief of Mrs. Emmet Crawford is now under consideration by the Senate Committee on Military Affairs. It was introduced by Senator Teller of Colorado, and recites that Mrs. Crawford's husband was killed by Mexicans while in the service of the United States and acting under the orders of his superiors.

More than 200 members of the Atlantic Yacht Club attended the annual meeting of that organization, which was held in the Waldorf-Astoria last night, and at which the entire ticket headed by Commodore David Banks, as previously published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, was unanimously elected.

BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- In introducing in the Reichstag to-day the draft of a law authorizing the abrogation of the treaties with the Tonga Islands of 1876, Samoa of 1879, and a portion of the Zanzibar treaty of 1885, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Count von Buelow, made a speech, during which he said the legislation was necessitated by the recent Anglo-German and German-Anglo-American agreements dividing the islands.

"Curiosity led me into a meeting in one of the city churches the other evening, the attraction being the announcement that there would be singing by the Fisk Jubilee Singers. Here is a chance, I thought, to hear some thoroughly characteristic negro singing such as I heard while in the South during the days of the war.

The recent remarkable upward movement in cotton has given special interest to the conditions governing the situation, and in Wall Street one hears much speculation as to probable future developments -- in some quarters even higher prices being predicted.

Harry Vardon, the three-year open golf champion of Great Britain, made his formal debut before the American golfing public yesterday at the Laurence Harbor Country Club, a few miles beyond Perth Amboy, N.J. The club is a comparatively new one, but its name has been occasionally before the public.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 12. -- This was another day of unbroken calm in Frankfort. The Republican members of the Legislature met at noon, and after appointing committees to inform Gov. Taylor that, pursuant to the terms of his proclamation, adjourning the Legislature at London and calling it to Frankfort, they had come to this city, and were prepared to transact such business as might come before them.

The Union League Club of Brooklyn gave its eleventh annual dinner in memory of Abraham Lincoln yesterday, and the occasion was one of enthusiastic indorsement of the policy or the National Administration. Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith made the address of the evening on Lincoln.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The Socialists tried to hold a pro-Boer, or peace, meeting at Mile End, London, last evening. A hostile crowd invaded the hall, shouting "Down with the Boers," and singing the national anthem.
The British ship County of Edinburgh went ashore at about 10 o'clock last night close to Manasquan Life Saving Station, on the Jersey coast, near Point Pleasant.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 12. -- In the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Judge W.H. Taft heard arguments this afternoon on the applications for injunctions against the Kentucky State Board of Election Commissioners and the contestants for the State offices other than Governor and Lieutenant Governor.

Joshua Gregg, the Sixth Avenue furniture dealer, who made an assignment on Saturday, and then evaded the inquiries of his friends, was found yesterday at the Adams House, near Gansevoort Market. Later in the day he again changed his temporary quarters. His friends when questioned professed that they were entirely ignorant of his whereabouts.

BERLIN, Feb. 12. -- To-day began in Berlin the conventions, held annually at this time of the year, at which all the important agricultural interests of Germany are represented for purposes of report and discussion. Foremost among these is the Federation of Husbandmen, which assembled 5,000 strong.

At the Casino last night a new operetta entitled "Princess Chic" was performed for the first time in this city. The book is by Kirke La Shelle and the music by Julian Edwards. The production was witnessed by one of those audiences which are always to be found at the Casino on a first night, and its applause was of a cordial, indeed a most generous, kind.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- To-night at the close of the first day's proceedings of the antitrust conference called by the National Anti-Trust League good progress had been made with the set speeches, of which a dozen or more were delivered. The resolutions Committee was busy this afternoon and to-night, while the main body of the delegates were listening to the speeches.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Stickler of this city have offered to give the Orange Young Men's Christian Association $40,000 for the erection of a new building. The offer was made to Charles T. Killborne, the President of the association, on Saturday, and will be submitted to the Board of Directors this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A statement of the gross postal receipts for January, 1900, as compared with the receipts for the same month last year shows an unusually large percentage of increase. The total receipts were $4,037,919, an increase of $389,653, or 10.6 per cent. The offices at which the largest increases are shown are Lowell, Mass., 43 per cent.; Syracuse, 40 per cent.; Jersey City, 27 per cent., and Nashville, Tenn., 27 per cent.

United States Senator William A. Clark of Montana has stolen a march on the opponents to the reorganization of the United Verde Copper Company. While Prof. George A. Treadwell, one of the stockholders, was trying to get the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of this State to declare still in force an injunction that had been dissolved, Senator Clark had the company's propert sold at auction and a new corporation organized in West Virginia.
Quotations at London yesterday were strong, Americans being above the parity. Aside from this, no security market developments came on the holiday.

Severe criticisms of the manner in which the Board of Education's books and records have been kept are made in a report which has just been handed to Mayor Van Wyck by the Commissioners of Accounts, who, at the request of Controller Coler, straightened out the tangle over the question of teachers' salaries.

District Attorney Clarke of Brooklyn late yesterday afternoon authorized the statement that Cecil Leslie, who was the press agent for William F. Miller's Franklin Syndicate, would very soon surrender himself to the authorities. Leslie was indicted jointly with Miller in November for conspiracy.
ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Gov. Roosevelt to-day gave out a statement relative to the Vice Presidency, in which he declares that he will not accept the honor under any circumstances. His statement follows:
LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The War Office is waking preparations to continue the stream of troops for South Africa. Four large steamers have been chartered.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 12. -- There were several friendly matches played at the Country Club links to-day. Little out of the ordinary was expected, for after the game Saturday, which proved to be one of the finest matches ever played in this country, it was thought the scores would not soon be repeated.

The appearance of Lord ROBERTS on the Modder indicates that the theatre of war is suddenly to be shifted from the extreme east to the extreme west. It confesses and emphasizes the failure of the campaign in Natal, and it seems to denote the abandonment of Ladysmith. Doubtless this was a hard decision for a General to come to.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- State Superintendent of Banks Frederick D. Kilburn has completed a statement of the aggregate condition of savings banks doing business in this State on Jan. 1, 1900. It shows that the total resources of these institutions have increased $36,788,237.69 over their amount on Jan. 1, 1899.

Activity in yesterday's market for outside securities was confined to three or four issues, while the majority of the stocks on the list were almost entirely neglected. Prices followed a somewhat irregular course, but the majority of stocks traded in at all showed strength, and ended the day with net gains that in several cases were fairly large.

The persistent performance of the music of Bach cannot but work for the bettermen of the appreciation of the tone art in any community. Of course this statement mus be coupled with a proviso that the music is to be performed in a manner as near to the design of the composer as possible and animated by the presence of the vital flame of a true spirit.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Feb. 13. -- The Nashua River was a rushing torrent to-day, and threatened to do great damage, not only to property, but to life. From a stream which in Summer is little more than a foot deep, it grew to a flood, overflowed its banks, started the abutments of bridges, and almost totally stopped the industries of the city by invading business premises.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- In the House of Commons to-day Thomas Hedderwick, Advanced Liberal, Member for the Wick District, gave notice of a resolution calling attention to the fact that the colonies are without representatives in the Imperial Parliament. The resolution was set down for a month hence, but it is not likely that time will be found for its discussion.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- Mrs. Arthur Paget's entertainment of stage tableaus at Her Majesty's Theatre, which concluded after midnight, netted more than u6,600 for the benefit of the Household Troops. The theatre presented a beautiful sight. It was filled with well-known people, the ladies being fairly ablaze with jewels.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- The new American Baseball Association was formally organized with seven clubs to-day. John McGraw and Phil Peterson of Baltimore were appointed as a committee to secure the eighth city. As the circuit now stands, it includes, in the West, Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Louis, and Louisville; in the East, Boston, Philadelphia, and Baltimore.
ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- The Assembly Committee of Commerce and Navigation to-day gave a final hearing on Mr. Brennan's bill for two bridges and two tunnels to connect the boroughs of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The financial debate in the Senate reached its climax today. Two speeches, one in favor of the pending Senate substitute measure and the other in opposition to it, were delivered and both were listened to by Senators with close attention. The first was delivered by Mr. Allison, (Rep., Iowa,) the ranking member of the Finance Committee.

-- In a long and impassioned editorial article devoted by The Springfield Republican to a modest paragraph which recently appeared in this humble column vehement attack is made on our contention that the arguments of the self-styled anti-imperialists are gratuitous and useless, however logical, since there are in the United States no imperialists for them to confuse or convict.

PARIS, Feb. 13. -- The troubles in the Island of Martinique were again brought up in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon, when M. Duquesnay, Deputy from Martinique, demanded that the Government recall the Governor of the island, who, he said, was deceiving the Government regarding the electoral situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your admirable editorial of this date, "The Molineux Verdict," will no doubt commend itself to the good judgment and approval of every thinking reader of your excellent paper. From the published reports of the reasons why the jurymen reached their hasty conclusions, it would appear that all the evidence, arguments, and charge might as well have been submitted or laid before twelve wooden Indians.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Representatives of the Barren Island garbage reduction plant were heard in opposition to Senator Wagner's bill for the removal of the plant before the Senate Cities Committee to-day. De Lancey Nicoll and William W. Gouch appeared for the company.

Mr. WYNDHAM'S statement in regard to the proposed increase of the British Army is a very striking showing of the effect produced upon Great Britain by what was expected, when it began, alike by its advocates and its opponents, to be a "small war." It has already stripped the British Islands of all troops in a condition to serve abroad.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- The Senate Committee on Banks to-day reported favorably Senator Wagner's bill providing that corporations formed for the purpose of loaning money on personal property shall be under the supervision of the Superintendent of Banks, and prohibiting excessive charges for short period loans.

Roland B. Molineux's monotony of prison life was broken yesterday by a visit from his wife, his father, Gen. Molineux, and his counsel, George Gordon Battle. Gen. Molineux made a morning call upon his son, and again late in the afternoon accompanied his daughter-in-law to the Tombs. They arrived at the prison in a closed carriage and remained about forty minutes.

A will contest which promises to be bitterly fought by both sides was begun yesterday in Part XII. of the Supreme Court, before Justice Stover. The heirs at law of Mrs. Mary Johnson are objecting to her disposal of about $550,000 worth of real and personal property, alleging undue influence. David McClure appears for the contestants and ex-Justice Augustus Van Wyck for the proponents and executors.

Prof. James H. Hyslop, Secretary of the New York section of the American brand of the Society for Psychical Research, read a paper to a large audience last night in Havemeyer Hall, Columbia University, on "The Trance Manifestations of Mrs. Piper." Mrs. Piper is the medium who has created such a stir in psychical circles, and Prof. Hyslop some time ago went to Boston to investigate her and her methods for the society.

Various persons, some wise and some foolish, some who ought to know better and some who know nothing at all about the matter, have declared that the Hay-Pauncefote treaty is in conflict with the Monroe doctrine. We cannot admit European nations to join in the guarantee of the neutrality of the canal because the Monroe doctrine forbids us to sanction their meddling in purely American affairs, say these persons.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 3/4@61. There were no sales.
LONDON, Feb. 14. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Rensburg, dated yesterday, says:

The mystery which surrounded the disappearance of two Harlem boys last August was cleared up yesterday afternoon, when their bodies were discovered in a three by five closet of an unoccupied house at 108 Edgecombe Avenue, where they had lain ever since, within a stone's throw of their grief-stricken homes.

Indefinite rumors that have been current in Wall Street for some days past concerning the establishment of a shipbuilding plant in this city in association with a great iron and steel foundry were yesterday found to ave good basis. It was at first reported that the plant was to be controlled by Andrew Carnegie, but Mr. Carnegie, declared that he did not propose to engage in any business other than his own.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- The Assembly Cities Sub-Committee to consider all school teachers' bills for New York City has decided to report favorably the Fallows bill increasing the teachers' salaries, with amendments which are intended to simplify the measure by absolutely fixing the salaries to be increased in the various grades.

Dispatches from Baltimore yesterday to the effect that the formal consolidation of the Seaboard Air Line, the Florida Central and Peninsular, and the Georgia and Alabama would be achieved within the next two months, have created the impression that the decision of Judge Waddill of Richmond, denying the application of Thomas F. Ryan for a preliminary injunction, had finally disposed of all impediments in the way of the proposed consolidation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Currency bill is expected to be out of the way in the Senate to-morrow or the next day, and the necessity will then arise for deciding what the order of business shall be for the session. There are many important subjects awaiting treatment in the Senate, and some of them are regarded as more important than others, something depending upon the point of view of the Senate.
PITTSBURG, Feb. 13. -- Henry Clay Frick filed a bill in equity to-day in the Court of Common Pleas No. 1 of Allegheny County against Andrew Carnegie and the Carnegie Steel Company, Limited, praying:

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- As the conviction grows in Great Britain that the war will be long, the efforts for providing for the sick and wounded and the families of the soldiers at the front are redoubling. There is scarcely a woman in England, who, in addition to making articles of clothing for those in the field and in the hospitals, is not working for and contributing to some special fund.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Gov. Roosevelt has under consideration and Assemblyman Allds will probably introduce this week a business man's law, prefaced by Prof. Jenks of Cornell University, and which is designed to bring all corporations under State laws, whether they be foreign or otherwise.

The objective point of the convention of the advocates of woman suffrage which is about to concentrate its influence on Congress is the elision of the word "male" from the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

GOT OFF WHILE THE CAR WAS IN MOTION. -- A judgment secured by Marie Harris against the Second Avenue Railroad Company in her suit for damages for injuries she received while alighting from one of the company's cars has been set aside by the First Appellate Division on the ground that the verdict was against the weight of evidence.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- The Committee or resolutions of the National Anti-Trust Conference to-night, after a stormy meeting, finally agreed upon a report which will be submitted to the conference for adoption to-morrow morning. The discussion was caused by a difference of opinion among the members as to the details of how the Government should obtain control of the railroad, telegraph, and telephone lines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13. -- A sensation was created, to-day by the testimony of Mrs. Hettie R. Craven in a suit against the estate of the late Senator Fair for $5,036 a month widow's allowance since the Senator's death.
BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- The gales of the equinox have scarcely ever exceeded in force the storm which swept over New England to-day, leaving in its wake damage by flood that is almost incalculable.

One of the largest suburban development enterprises ever undertaken in the neighborhood of New York is that which is now being carried forward by the recently in- corporated Altonwood Park Realty and Investment Company. This corporation has recently purchased for about $3,000,000 a tract of about 1,000 acres at Mamaroneck, Westchester County.

The decision the Governor of this State has come to in respect to the Vice Presidency must have been expected by everybody who knows him, or who has observed his public course. One can imagine nothing less to his tastes or to his aptitudes than the duties of the Vice Presidency.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13. -- The spirit of discontent which has long been manifest at Yale because of sophomore societies came to a head to-day. Yesterday at 4 o'clock a petition was circulated throughout the senior class asking the Faculty to abolish sophomore societies. The petition was headed by twenty of the most conservative and thoughtful non-sophomore society men of the senior class.

BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- By a vote of 7 to 6 the directors of the Fitchburg Railroad to-day refused to ratify the proposition of a lease to the Boston and Maine Railroad, and decided to leave the entire matter of the lease to the stockholders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention was called several times during the progress of the Molineux trial, in your editorial columns, to what I consider a very just condemnation of the policy of certain city papers to prejudice the rights of the defendant by printing such matter as tended to influence and inflame the public mind.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- In the Senate to-day the Banking Committee reported favorably the McEwan bill allowing savings banks to invest in bonds of the Chicago and Alton Railroad, Senators Wagnor and Norton dissenting. Senator Wagner's motion that the bill be recommitted provoked a discussion.

The Society for Political Study had its hands full yesterday. It was up to its ears in missionary work, and when that consists in straightening out the tangled affairs of one's fellowman it means business

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Feb. 13. -- The four-masted British ship County of Edinburgh, which went ashore here Monday night, now lies broadside to the beach, but in a favorable position. The wind has shifted so as to blow off shore, and there is no immediate danger of the vessel going to pieces.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 13. -- The first sign or a break in the Democratic lines was noticeable to-day. It came in the shape of a resolution offered by Senator Triplett, providing that upon adjournment Thursday the Legislature name Frankfort as its next meeting place.

We are glad to see a Senator from Colorado supporting a bill establishing the single gold standard of value in our currency system. Silver, disguised as bimetallism, has been the idol of Senator WOLCOTT. He now advocates the pas- sage of the Currency bill, in which gold is declared to be the standard unit and measure of value.

With the names of the best-known society leaders of the United Kingdom and the United States beaming, as it were, upon the enterprise, it was to be expected that the "The Concert" at Sherry's yesterday afternoon would be a great success, and Mrs. Langtry, its organizer, must have been extremely well satisfied with the sum of money collected for the hospital ship Maine.

SAN JUAN DE PUERTO RICO, Feb. 7. -- Somebody has said "The people of Puerto Rico do not know enough to vote." He might better have remarked "They know too much to vote." From the following instance it can be seen that even leading New York politicians might learn a thing or two in Puerto Rico about politics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Members of Congress were greatly shocked at the news of Representative Chickering's violent death in New York City this morning. The first information came in a dispatch to Representative Gillett, the close personal associate of Mr. Chickering, and was communicated to Sergeant at Arms Casson of the House.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- The savings banks interests of the State were arrayed before the Joint Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment of the Senate and Assembly this afternoon to interpose their objections to the Mortgage Tax bill, which proposes to impose a tax of one-half of 1 per cent. on real estate mortgages of the State.

Brig. Gen. Henry Horatio Wells, Military Governor of Virginia after the close of the civil war, died Monday night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. James T. Walker, in Palmyra, N.Y., after a long illness. Gen. Wells was born in Rochester, N.Y., Sept. 17, 1823, and was educated at Romeo Academy in Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The National American Woman Suffrage Association to-day elected Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt of New York President of the association for the ensuing year, to succeed Susan B. Anthony, who has been active in the battle for woman suffrage for nearly half a century, and declined a re-election to office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Representative Levy has introduced his bill to permit the other maritime nations of the world to join with the United States in constructing and maintaining the canal to be built across the isthmus. He does not insist that the canal shall be constructed by the Nicaragua route.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Two delegations -- one appearing to favor the extension of the suffrage to women and the other to remonstrate against that extension -- appeared this morning, before the Senate Committee on Woman Suffrage and the House Committee on the Judiciary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After carefully looking over the political field I have arrived at the conclusion that William Jennings Bryan will not be nominated by the Democratic Party in the next National Convention. Although my conclusion does not necessarily settle the matter, let us see if a great many good reasons cannot be given to show why my prediction will come true.

The officials of the District Attorney's of fice, Brooklyn, seem to attach little if any importance to the alleged expose of the Franklin Syndicate made yesterday after noon by Cecil Leslie, who was press agent for William F. Miller and his confederates in the so-called syndicate. Several official were asked their opinion of Leslie's statement, and all who had read it said that they failed to see wherein it revealed anything of importance.

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners met yesterday afternoon and passed two resolutions, one approving the names of the subscribers to the stock in the company organized by August Belmont Co., and the other appointing a committee to submit a plan of organization for the working force of assistant engineers and other employes, to expedite the work of the tunnel.

BERLIN, Feb. 13. -- Prince Henry of Prussia, brother of Emperor William of Germany, arrived here this morning. He was welcomed at the railroad station by his Majesty and a large suite. Immediately after the train stopped. Prince Henry jumped out and hurried to the Emperor, who met him half way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- From day to day, for a week or more, there have been intimations that presently the Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries of the House was about to vote on the HannaPayne Subsidy bill, and put it on the calendar of the House, to rest there until after the next election.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I fear that your editorial of Monday on "The Molineux Verdict" may create in some quarters an unduly unfavorable impression of the reliability of trial by jury in murder cases. It seems to me that the verdict of "Guilty of murder in the first degree" against Molineux was not only justified, but was imperatively called for by the evidence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The statement was made to-day at the War Department that the total exports of coffee from the Island of Puerto Rico from the date of the American occupation to Nov. 30, 1899, was 53,243,025 pounds, valued at $6,139,955. Of the amount exported during the period mentioned.

F. Wellington Ruckstuhl held the interest of attendants at the National Sculpture Society's February meeting last night with a description of his design for a great peace monument on the Palisades. As the site he proposed a point one mile north of Fort Lee, which he predicted would be the centre of a great city of 10,000,000 inhabitants fifty years hence.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 13. -- M. Verande, a member of the New Orleans French Opera Company, was Discharged from the troupe yesterday under somewhat sensational circumstances, which involved no less a person that Maurice Grau of the New York Metropolitan Opera Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Gen. A.W. Greely, Chief Signal Officer, United States Army, said to-day that all of the energies of his department are at present being directed toward the establishment of a thorough telegraph and telephone system in the Philippines to meet the constantly growing demand for such service, incident to the military operations in the islands.

The first portion of the paintings which belonged to the late Judge Henry Hilton were sold at Chickering Hall last evening, and $56,465 was realized for the eighty-three lots offered. The average price was not a particularly high one. It would have been still lower had not four paintings brought an average of over $5,000 each.

Company F, Sixty-ninth Regiment, commanded by Capt. Anthony J. Griffin, was disbanded last night on the floor of the armory, under orders from the Adjutant General, the cause being officially given as small attendance at drills, and because the company membership was below the legal limit.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- The National antitrust conference ended its sessions here tonight. The principal business of the day was the adoption of the report of the Committee on National Organization. The plan outlined provided for the formation of local leagues of not less than five members, five local leagues to constitute a county league, these in turn to be formed into a State league, delegates from which to be the National league.

The special committee of the General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church appointed to draft a canon on marriage and divorce was in secret session yesterday at Trinity Chapel, in this city. The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, rector of Trinity Church, is Chairman of this committee.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Following to-day's hearing on the Treat bill to tax deposits in savings banks in excess of $1,000 before the Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, Mr. Treat gave out a statement explanatory of his reasons for introducing the measure. In part, he said:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The monthly statement of the imports and exports of the United States, issued by the Bureau of Statistics, shows that for January, 1900, the figures are as follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- According to prominent State Republicans it is the desire of the organization to adjourn the Legislature for good on March 23. It is asserted that the machine programme includes the postponing of all "important" legislation, such as the canal improvements, the taxation bills, the State unification scheme, the Ramapo bills, and the charter revision bills, etc., until next year.

The School Board for Manhattan and the Bronx completed its organization yesterday afternoon for the next twelve months by electing a President, Secretary, and delegates to the Central Board. The meeting was held in the board room of the new building, at Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 14. -- Suit was filed in the Circuit Court to-day by counsel for Gov. Taylor, seeking to restrain J.C.W. Beckham from acting as Governor and Gen. John B. Castleman from attempting to discharge the duties of Adjutant General. Summonses were served on the defendants this afternoon.

We get no explanation of the riots in Martinique. But the facts we do get show that the disturbances are very threatening. They threaten, indeed, the fate which overcame Haiti a century ago, when the French were expelled and the blacks, under the lead of TOUSSAINT, won for themselves the freedom, which they have ever since been progressively engaged in showing that they do not know how to use.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times, remarking that "it will not do to place overmuch reliance upon Russia's official assurances that nothing will be done to embarrass England in the present situation of affairs," gives additional details showing that the delays in the ordinary traffic on the Central Asian Railway are not caused, as has been officially stated by snowfalls.

Our readers will bear us witness that we have endeavored to keep an open mind on the Puerto Rican question. When the President, with the strong approval of the Secretary of War, recommended in his message the abolition of tariff lines altogether between ourselves and the island, we assented.

A number of valuable properties will be brought into the market by the partition of the estate of Bradish Johnson, proceedings for which have just been begun. The most important parcels are the buildings at the northwest corner of Broadway and Twenty-first Street and at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- A landslide on the West Shore tracks, a mile south of here, to-night came near wrecking the Montreal express that left Weehawken at 6:15 o'clock and reached this station at 9 o'clock. The train was a heavy one, and for a time 300 persons who occupied the coaches and sleeping cars were in danger.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Bad as the tangled Nicaragua Canal situation is becoming, it seems certain that, whatever may be done with the treaty, the Nicaragua Canal bill will be pressed to a vote. The friends of the measure are paying no attention to the conflict of opinions and announcements about the action to be taken on the treaty.

The second night's and concluding auction sale of the pictures owned by the late Judge Hilton took place at Checkering Hall last evening. A total of $62,250 was realized for eighty-seven paintings, and this, added to the total of $56,465 obtained for the eighty-three canvases sold on Tuesday evening, makes a grand total of $118,715 for 170 pictures.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- The Record says that big holders of olive oil are attempting to corner the output for this year. The gross amounts of last year's production was only about 50 per cent. of that of former years, and this shortage will have a tendency to make the price of the real article ascend. Cablegrams have been received in Chicago giving the "tip" that America holds the key to the olive oil situation.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 14. -- Gov. Taylor to-day gave out an authorized statement defending his action since William Goebel was shot. He prefaces the statement with a review of the election and the work of the contest boards.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 14. -- The fight in this State has lost its warlike aspect and resolved itself into a contest in the courts. To-day both Gubernatorial claimants filed actions, each to restrain the other from exercising the functions of the office of Governor. Gov. Taylor's suit is filed in Louisville and J.C.W. Beckham's in Frankfort.
