The return of sunshine and seasonable Winter weather after Tuesday's heavy rainstorm had yesterday an almost magical effect on the social life of the town. A year ago the streets were piled high with snow and a sleighing carnival was in full blast. Lent also began a year ago to-day and the season was a marked contrast to the present one.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 15. -- It is given out here that Attorney W. B. Rogers is preparing another suit to be instituted against the Carnegie Steel Company by the minority stockholders of the H. C. Frick Coke Company for an accounting regarding the furnishing of coke to the steel company at less than the ruling quotations.

The Boers have acted with promptness and decision upon the first notification by Lord ROBERTS of his line of advance. They have struck directly at his communications, and that in a vital spot. An advance in such force as he now commands cannot be sustained without the use of all the railroads that are available.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- For about half an hour to-day Senator Pettus of Alabama, the oldest man in the Senate, held that body at bay, blocked public business, made all the leaders of the body on both sides of the chamber ridiculous, and created a scene of confusion that has not been paralleled during this session.
The Royal Exchange Assurance Company of London has been admitted to New Hampshire.

In yesterday's stock market strength showed at the opening and at the close, but at times during the day business seemed almost at a standstill upon the Stock Exchange, and some material recessions were scored. Commission house transactions during most of the day were insignificant.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Three men have lost their lives and half a million dollars' worth of damage has been done to property along the Hudson River by the worst freshet which this city has seen since 1857. The men who were drowned were William Rhinehart of New York. Thomas Shea of Bath, and Joseph Vogel of Van Rensselaer Island, three miles below the city.

BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- Amalgamated at 96 and Butte at 70 were the features of the Boston market to-day, which generally was dull. Contributing features were found in a raid on Cochiti and weakness in Sugar. There was no particular strength in the copper list, outside of Butte and Amalgamated.

Only two objections, so far as we have observed, have been urged against the voting machine which the Police Board has been asked to adopt for use in this city, and neither of these seems to us to have much force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- It was the intention of the Republican leaders of the House to call up the Puerto Rican Tariff bill to-morrow, but there was such a demand for time to discuss various questions during the general debate upon the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill, which was called up to-day, that Mr. Payne gave notice that he would allow the Puerto Rican bill to go over until Monday.

Maurice Untermyer has sold the four lots, 100,11 by 100, at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Ninth Street. The peculiar feature of this plot is that it is virtually a block front, its northerly side having an additional frontage of 100 feet on the circle at the northeast corner of Central Park.

Frederick Mather, the well-known fish culturist and writer and lecturer on fishes, died yesterday at Lake Nebagomain, Wis. Mr. Mather was born in Greenbush, N.Y., Aug. 2, 1833. After finishing his education at Albany, N.Y., he spent several years hunting and fishing in the Far West. At the outbreak of the civil war he enlisted as a private in the One Hundred and Thirteenth New York Volunteers.
LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Just before midnight the War Office issued the following message from Lord Roberts received yesterday evening:

CINCINNATI, Feb. 14. -- In the Circuit Court of the United States, Judge W.H. Taft to-day denied the motion for a preliminary injunction in both of the cases from Kentucky. While the court held that no injunctions would issue under these bills, yet it also held that after the cases had been heard in the State courts they could get in on error for review in the United States Supreme Court.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 14. -- Chairman Joseph G. Donnelly of the Milwaukee Democratic Convention Committee gave out a statement to-day showing that thirty-two members of the National Democratic Committee have expressed themselves as favoring Milwaukee as the city for holding the National Convention.

"BINDING SLIP" AS A RENEWAL OF INSURANCE. -- In a suit originally brought by Emory N. Van Tassel, to recover from the Greenwich Insurance Company for a loss under an alleged insurance contract, which has been three times tried, the Court of Appeals recently reversed a judgment given for the plaintiff, which was affirmed by the Appellate Division.

J.B. Oatman, a broker, of 107 West Eighty-second Street, fell down stairs in the New York Athletic Club at 1 o'clock this morning and fractured his skull. An ambulance was summoned from the Roosevelt Hospital, but when it arrived the man was dead:

The Commissioner of Internal Revenue at Washington is reported to have placed a new interpretation on the first paragraph of Schedule A of the war revenue law, in order to collect the tax on call loans, about which there has been a good deal of controversy ever since the Government first made a demand for the payment of a stamp tax on stocks and bonds pledged as collateral.

The case against Louis H. Miller, Jr., brother of William F. Miller of the Franklin Syndicate, was dismissed yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, Judge Keady presiding. Louis Miller was charged with having secreted the property of his brother's creditors.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Superintendent of Ejections John MeCullagh has submitted his annual report to the Governor, reviewing in detail the work of the department. He charges that "the active opposition of the Police Department of New York City has been encountered and the District Attorney and his assistants have utterly failed to give any sympathy or co-operation."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- A signed statement was given out to-night by Charles E. Macrum, ex-United States Consul at Pretoria, in which he explains in detail the motives for his departure from that place and the conditions there at the time. The statement is, in part, as follows:

The Board of Trade and Transportation met yesterday and took action on several public questions, after considerable discussion. The subject of allowing trucks on Fifth Avenue wag talked over, and G. Waldo Smith offered a resolution, which advised regulations prescribing qualifications as to age, , of drivers of vehicles, and condemning the Weekes bill before the Assembly (which is designed to regulate traffic on Fifth Avenue) as being subversive of home rule.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14. -- Intense excitement has been caused all over the Yale campus by the news that a petition asking for the abolition of the sophomore societies was handed to President Hadley last night.

The Mutual Benefit Life team scored another double victory in the Life Insurance League at Start's Tournament Hall last night, defeating the Mutual Life and the Ge-mania teams. The Germanias won a game from Mutual Life. Scores:
BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The students of the University of Strassburg have sent a dispatch of sympathy to President Kruger.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Throughout its session to-day the Senate had the Financial bill under discussion. After 2 o'clock the debate proceeded under the ten-minute rule, end at times became spirited and interesting.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 14. -- Late this afternoon the papers in the suit of H.C. Frick against the Carnegie Steel Company, Limited, were served on the attorneys of the Carnegie Company, Dalzell, Scott Gordon. The defendants have fifteen days in which to file a demurrer or an answer to the bill, and it is expected a demurrer will be filed within a few days, and if an answer is necessary it will be filed later.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- An official dispatch from Gen. Buller at Chieveley, dated Feb. 12, announces a reconnaissance at Springfield, resulting in no gain of ground on either side, but causing the wounding of Capt. Hamilton Russell. Lieut. G. Church-ill and ten men. In addition, Lieut. Pilkington and six men were captured.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 15. -- Harry Vardon, the British champion golfer, arrived here to-day accompanied by Charles S. Cox of New York. After luncheon they drove to the golf links of the Country Club, which are situated about three quarters of a mile from the hotels. Both were rather pleased with the appearance of the course, and started at once for a couple of rounds.

The Pacific Mall Steamship Company's dividend policy is to be changed -- and that, according to the most conservative authorities, very much to the advantage of the property. Instead of maintaining cash payments to the stockholders for the immediate present, and so consuming the company's earnings, the new policy contemplates the investment by the corporation of surplus earnings into new vessels or other improvements, which will in the long run prove advantageous to the shareholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Shipping bill was considered at some length by the Senate Committee on Commerce at its meeting to-day, and a number of amendments suggested toy the sub-committee were agreed to. Among them wore the following:

Yesterday's stock market had much of Interest in it. Some fluctuations were more than ordinarily suggestive. Some operators of importance seemed more than ordinarily alert. An event of consequence on the inspiriting side would seem now to have opportunities for exerting influence exceptionally effective.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- A hearing on Senator Marshall's bill providing for the establishment of exterior pier lines in Brooklyn was given to-day before the Senate committee. President Horton of the Brooklyn Wharf and Warehouse Company appeared in behalf of the measure. There was no opposition, and another hearing will be given March 1.

The award of prizes for plans of model tenement houses in the competition authorized by the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society was announced yesterday as follows: First prize, R. Thomas Short; second prize, Israels Harder; third prize, Covell Smith, Joseph Wolf, Israels Harder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Mr. Grosvenor (Rep., Ohio,) brought before the House to-day the question of the civil service law, basing his remarks upon the statements of Mr. Heminway yesterday that the departments were full of incompetents. He adduced statements of chiefs of bureaus and heads of departments to show that in 1883, when the civil service law was passed, the civil service of the Government was a model of efficiency and effectiveness.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 15. -- A split in the Democratic Party in Maryland on Bryan and the free-silver question is now inevitable. Secretary Beveridge of the Free Silver Democratic Association threw down the gauntlet to-day by declaring that the freesilver men had no faith in German's statement made yesterday in Washington that he favored the nomination of Bryan.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 15. -- Following the lead of Gov. Taylor, who yesterday brought suit for an injunction against Gov. Beckham, claiming to be Governor of Kentucky, and Gen. John B. Castleman, claiming to be Adjutant General of Kentucky, Lieut. Gov. John Marshall to-day filed suit for an injunction against Gov. Beckham and against Lillard H. Carter, President pro tem, of the Senate now meeting in this city.

The State Railroad Commissioners continued at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday the hearing on the application of the Delaware Valley and Kingston Railroad Company for permission to build a road along the line of the abandoned Delaware and Hudson Canal from Lackawaxen to tidewater at Kingston.
Pension Commissioner EVANS put his finger on the rotten spot in our system in his speech before the Middlesex Club of Boston. He said:

The Chemical National Bank team bowled in good form in the Bank Clerks' League, at Reid's Alleys, last night, and won two games. Its first same with J.P. Morgan Co. was close throughout, the Chemical team winning in the last frame by 10 pins. J.P. Morgan Co. won the second game from Chase National Bank's second team. Scores:

Army. Acting Assistant Surgeon George L. Cable will proceed from Fostoria, Ohio, to Fort McIntosh, Texas, and report to the commanding officer of that post for duty to relieve Acting Assistant Surgeon James T. Arwine. Acting Assistant Surgeon Arwine will proceed to Vancouver Barracks, Washington, and report to the commanding General.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 15. -- The Despatch states to-day that General Superintendent Stuart of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Road, who severed his connection with that line to-day, will become General Superintendent of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, with jurisdiction over the lines of the road west of the Ohio River, Mr. Stuart was asked if the rumor was true, but begged to be excused from talking at this time.

It is no wonder that London should be cheered by the news from Lord ROBERTS. It seems that he has concentrated all the most mobile part of his force, including cavalry, horse artillery, which is very much swifter of movement than ordinary field artillery, and mounted infantry, for a raid around the left or eastern flank of the Boer army.

Twenty-four claims, aggregating $13,165.40, for differences between the amounts of wages received by city employes and the prevailing rate paid to men in the same occupations, were filed in the Controller's Office yesterday. These claims ranged in amount from $200 to $1,500, three of them being for the latter sum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Responding to the resolution of Jan. 17, the President to-day sent to the Senate a report from the Secretary of State, with accompanying papers, showing the steps that have been taken to obtain the restitution of property of American citizens seized by the military authorities of Great Britain in and near Delagoa Bay, South Africa.

The Naval Arch project ought to appeal to the people of New York in two ways. They ought to take pride, in the first place, in erecting a monument to commemorate the victories of our navy in the Summer of 1898, the victory of DEWEY in Manila Bay, the victory of SAMPSON and SCHLET at Santiago, and all the brilliant minor exploits of our sea forces in the Spanish war.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- The relatives and friends of the late Congressman Charles A. Chickering of Copenhagen, who was found dead on the sidewalk in front of the Grand Union Hotel, New York City, Tuesday morning, are of the opinion that the Representative did not leap to death with suicidal intent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A new difficulty about the new canal treaty has been brought to the attention of those who favor it. It is the contention that the treaty does not assure to the United States such perfect, freedom to construct the canal across the Isthmus of Darien at Panama as it does across Nicaragua.

BOER LAAGER, NEAR LADYSMITH, Feb. 13. -- Yesterday Gen. Botha, with a small force, crossed the Tugela to a deserted British camp, where he encountered fifty Lancers, of whom thirteen were killed, five wounded, and nine taken prisoners. One of the prisoners was sent to tell the British to fetch their wounded.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve increased u499,000, circulation decreased u272,000, bullion increased u227,016, other securities increased u212,000, other deposits decrecised u701,000, public deposits increased u1,467,000, notes reserve increased u316,000, Government securities unchanged.

The Republican County Committee last night indorsed the administration of Gov. Roosevelt, approved his refusal to be a candidate for Vice President, and pledged him the support of the Republicans of this county in securing a re-election as Governor.

The amateur boxing and wrestling championship tournament of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, was continued at the Broadway Athletic Club last night before a crowd of about 2,800 persons.

PARIS, Feb. 15. -- The Minister of the Colories has received a telegram from the Governor of the French Congo, announcing the defeat in battle of Rabah, the principal chieftain of the Central Soudan, by a French expedition.

Boehm Coon have bought from the Bergh estate, through Richard V. Harnett Co., the five-story business building at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, 23.9 by 100. The premises are now rented for a total of $15,000 a year.

As a result of the testimonial tendered yesterday afternoon by brother managers, actors, and personal friends of Edward E. Rice, in celebration of his completion of twenty-five years of management at the Metropolitan Opera House, about $6,500 was presented to Mr. Rice.

A LONG WILL CONTEST. -- The contest over the will of Kate L. Laudy, which apparently will not reach d determination for some time longer, has had a prolonged and varied experience. The testatrix by the will, made ten years ago, left a considerable legacy to the Woman's Hospital and to the Peter Cooper Union, and it is mainly upon the appeal of these institutions that the controversy has been continued.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Chairman B.B. Odell of the Republican State Committee, who has been here since Tuesday, left for New York to-day in response to a message which, he said, called for his immediate presence in New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Neither the Internal Revenue Bureau nor the Attorney General can be prevailed upon to discuss officially the dispute about the proposed tax on call loans. The Attorney General is not at liberty to discuss, in advance of a decision, a question upon which he has been asked by the Secretary of the Treasury to give an opinion.

Mrs. Alice Kellogg Tyler, the well-known artist, died late Wednesday night at Chicago. She was reputed to be the foremost woman artist in the West and was the only Western woman honored with a membership in the Society of American Artists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- In the House to-day Mr. Boutell (Rep., III.,) had something to say about the approaching Presidential contest.

-- Apprehensive as were the foreigners resident in Japan that the new treaties abolishing the international and Consular courts, and placing Europeans on a level with natives before the local tribunals, would result in many annoyances and possibly in some injustice to the former, very little trouble of the kind anticipated seems to have followed the change.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15. -- Dr. John D. St. C. Hillis, a physician and writer of the unfinished biography of ex-Vice President Levi P. Morion, died in West Haven this morning. It is generally understood here that had he lived he would have come into the possession of a large amount of money.

The present Corporation Counsel of this municipality has done several strange things during the period of his official incumbency. But he has done nothing stranger than to announce that he will confess judgment in all cases of claims against the city for back pay under the "prevailing rate of wages" law.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- In the House of Commons to-day, during the course of a reply to a question relative to the probable Boer invasion of Zululand, the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, said that the Government had decided, if the native territories were invaded by the Boers, the natives "will be encouraged and assisted in every way in defending themselves."

There is a portly broker in the Wall Street district who has for years prided himself on the beauty of his mustache. Personally he considered it one of the most interesting of the sights of the Street, especially to the ladies who occasionally drift flown there where the bulls and bears have their daily wrangles.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, Feb. 15. -- M. Hayot, a Petit Bourg planter, who came here yesterday with the members of his family, having abandoned his plantation and effects, parleyed for forty-eight hours with the rioters before leaving. They wanted to kill him.

Direct charges of bribery in connection with the hold-up by the Municipal Assembly's joint Railway Committee of the resolution granting a franchise for a tunnel under the East River to the New York and Long Island Terminal Railway Company were made yesterday by Edward F. Linton, Secretary of the Atlantic Avenue Improvefent Commission, who is one of the foremost advocates of the tunnel scheme.

Wall Street had a surprise yesterday in the announcement, made by Kuhn, Loeb Co., that they had dropped negotiations for taking up the debt of the Third Avenue Railroad Company. The news was particularly sudden, because it had been preceded by days in which continual official announcements were made of satisfactory progress in the negotiations, and rumors of hitches which had cropped up now and then were almost invariably denied with promptness.

In the Assembly yesterday Mr. Fallows's bill, providing for the elimination of one of the lists of officials printed in The City Record of New York City, on order of second reading, was made a special order for next Tuesday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Two Judges of the Supreme Court of Montana testified today before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections, in the Clark case, that they had been offered bribes to throw out of court the proceedings against Wellcome, the man since disbarred for corrupting members of the Legislature.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 15. -- Attorney H.B. Mackey, with ex-Gov. Bradley and other attorneys interested in the Kentucky election contest cases, appeared to-day before United States Circuit Court Judge William H. Taft in chambers and filed notice of an appeal from the decision rendered by the Judge on Wednesday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- The National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen to-day relinquished control of racing and abolished the amateur membership clause. All other references to amateur wheelmen were stricken from the constitution.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- In the House of Lords yesterday the Earl of Dunraven raised a question on the Government's military proposals and expressed a doubt as to whether these, were sufficient.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Representative Wheeler of Kentucky to-day introduced in the House a resolution directing the Secretary of State to inform the House whether ex-Consul Macrum reported that his official mail had been opened and read by the British censor, and, if so, what steps had been taken to obtain an explanation and apology from the British Government.

NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 15. -- Miss Alice Brooks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brooks of this city, was married to-day to Robert Stanley Gunn of Springfield. The ceremony took place in the Grace Episcopal Church, and was witnessed by over 400 invited guests. The service was performed by the Rev. Dr. G.W. Shinn, rector of the church.

William J. Harmon, a clerk of 2,226 Second Avenue, was convicted of bigamy before Judge Cowing in Part III. of General Sessions yesterday, and sentenced to four months' imprisonment. Before sentence was pronounced his wives, both of whom were in the courtroom during his trial, had a heated argument concerning the punishment he deserved, and gave their views on that subject to the Judge at some length.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Senator Elsberg today introduced a proposed amendment to the tax law which was prepared by the Committee on Taxation of the West End Association of New York City. De B. Wilmot, Chairman of the committee, in explanation of the bill. says:

George Walker, a nineteen-year old husband, who was arrested Tuesday on a charge of abandonment made by his seventeen-year-old wife, Helene, was arraigned before Magistrate Crane in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday afternoon. Walker was arrested at the home of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Smith, of 258 West Twenty-fifth Street, whither, he said, he had been decoyed from Philadelphia by a pathetic letter from his wife.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Miss Paulding held a brilliant reception this afternoon at the Corcoran house, when she was greeted by a large number of callers. Assisting her in the drawing rooms were Miss Hegeman of New York, a niece of Senator Depew; Miss Rochester, Miss Alice Ward, Miss Merriam and Mme. Henri De Sibour.

It was announced yesterday at the Coroner's office that the death of John B. Oltman, who died early yesterday morning in the New York Athletic Club, after falling down a marble stairway, was caused by a fracture of the skull.
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- Yesterday Lord Roberts reported to the War Office in a series of dispatches as follows:

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 16. -- Assistant District Attorney Osborne, who is resting at his old home, read the telegraphic report of the statement made by Molineux in court to-day. He read it to his mother, and she was much affected by it.

HAVANA, Feb. 16. -- The policy to be adopted by the Spaniards at the coming elections is a cause of anxiety to many Cubans. The Cubano calls upon the National Party to bring all the influence it can to bear upon the Spaniards, pointing out that, as the Spaniards are very compact and inclined to act together, they might turn the scale against the Cubans, in case the latter were divided.

The friends of Fire Commissioner John Scannell will give a dinner in Mr. Scannell's honor on Washington's Birthday at the Democratic Club that will eclipse, they say, anything of the sort ever given there. It will be in marked contrast to the simple dinner served for William Jennings Bryan when he was President John W. Keller's guest a few weeks ago.

There has been nothing in our political history since the close of the civil war more remarkable than the change in public sentiment and opinion that has taken place with regard to finance and currency within the last eight years, and especially in the last three years. On Thursday the United States Senate passed the bill declaring and establishing the gold standard, thus making secure the enactment of a law embodying this principle.

When the Ways and Means substitute for the President's proposition comes up in the House next week it will behoove somebody to show what will be the practical difference between the two measures. It is quite true that the Puerto Ricans, in the first place, demanded the abolition of the tariff as to them altogether.

The fifth public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The programme consisted of the overture to "Coriolanus," by Beethoven; the Brahma variations on the "Choral St. Anthonl " of Haydn, Chopin's F minor piano concerto, and the fifth symphony of Tschaikowsky.
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The War Office last night made public Gen. Roberts's report on the retirement from Rensburg, which is as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: A Connecticut churchman is needlessly alarmed over the cult of "St. Charles, King and Martyr." In England, I might say only in London, a very limited number of cranks observe the thirtieth day of January as the day on which to keep his memory green, and on that day the hideous statue of the beheaded monarch is be-bouqueted and bewreathed by his few admirers.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Word came here today from New York that the leaders of the Republication State organisation had decided to hold the State Convention in New York instead of Albany. It is said that the reason the change was made was because William Barnes, Jr., Chairman of the State Executive Commoittee, had informed the machine leaders that there was no hall in Albany sufficiently large to accommodate a State convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- It is said General Manager Prick of the Carnegie Steel Works is to represent in this country an English nickel steel syndicate which will erect a plant even bigger than Carnegie's.

The fifth public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The programme consisted of the overture to "Coriolanus," by Beethoven; the Brahma variations on the "Choral St. Anthonl " of Haydn, Chopin's F minor piano concerto, and the fifth symphony of Tschaikowsky.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The following dispatch from Gen. Roberts fills the gaps in the earlier dispatches:

Edwin C. Sturges died at his home, at 141 East Eighteenth Street, yesterday afternoon, after a short illness, from pleuropneumonia. Mr. Sturges was sixty-one years old. He was a son of G. Sturges. a prominent shipping merchant of this city. He was a veteran of the civil war, and was a member of the Loyal Legion and the Century Association Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- It is said General Manager Prick of the Carnegie Steel Works is to represent in this country an English nickel steel syndicate which will erect a plant even bigger than Carnegie's.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- J. Rindall Youatt of Ravenswood, a well-known dog fancier, author, Third Vice President of the Press Club, and auditor of the Associated Press, is convinced that long-distance attacks upon Gen. Buller should emanate from the British War Office if at all.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16. -- In the suit of Mrs. Nettie Craven, who claims a portion of the $20,000,000 estate left by James G. Fair, Mrs. Craven recently testified that in addition to being married by contract to Senator Fair, a marriage ceremony had been performed by Justice of the Peace Simpton of Sausalito.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Governor or Vice President" is to the point and should do good. Gov. Roosevelt is very popular with the masses of the people of this State, and I trust from every primary they will declare with one voice for his nomination to the Governorship.

OUTSIDE JACOBSDAL, Orange Free State, Feb. 15. -- Jacobsdal is now in possession of the British, Yesterday a small cavalry patrol entered the place, and found it full of wounded, including several British from Rensburg. The place was only occupied by a small force, which fell back before the patrol.

Lieut. Col. Russell B. Harrison. Inspector General United States Volunteers, is relieved from further duty as Inspector General of the Department of Santiago and Puerto Principe, and upon the expiration of his present sick leave of absence will proceed to New York City and report to the commanding General. Department of the East, for duty.

Roland Burnham Molineux, convicted of the murder by poison of Katherine J. Adams, was sentenced by Recorder Goff yesterday in the Court of General Sessions to die in the manner prescribed by law in the prison at Sing Sing during the week beginning March 26. Sentence was pronounced at 11 o'clock in the morning, after a dramatic scene in which Molineux protested his innocence, denounced his accusers, and defended the good name of his wife.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The correspondent of The Associated Press at Ladysmith, from which place he escaped Feb. 10 and arrived at Durban Feb. 14, sends the following, written before he left Ladysmith:

The twenty-third annual dinner of the American Paper and Pulp Manufacturers' Association on Thursday night was one of the jolliest of the Winter. It was given at the Waldorf-Astoria, for when they are on pleasure bent the papermakers have not a frugal mind. A dinner in Yonkers or East New York would not be at all to their taste.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The caucus of Senators of the Republican Party to-day was ostensibly to arrange the order of business, but was occupied for most of the time of its session in considering the report of Senator Carter's (Mont.) patronage committee suggesting a division of the Senate patronage.

Politicians, turfmen, men about town, and others who know ex-Corporation Counsel William H. Clark were astonished yesterday to read that the once brilliant lawyer's mind as well as a splendid fortune he had amassed since he had come into political prominence were both wrecked, and that Mr. Clark is under the strict watch of his physician and nurses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The interesting editorial on "England's Justification" in to-day's TIMES seems to me too hasty an agreement with Mr. Chamberlain's position in the South African troubles. It takes for granted that such defense is a complete warrant for the prosecution of the war, whatever that may necessitate, until every English demand is granted, such demands Being warranted by her world-wide reputation for civilization and disinterestedness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The resolution of Mr. Bacon, (Dem.,Ga.,) declaring the policy of the United States toward the Pilippine Islands, was laid before the Senate today, and Mr. McEnery (Dem., La.,) addressed the Senate thereon, in accordance with previous notice. He said the question presented to Congress was a difficult one, and time alone could solve it.

At a special meeting of the Yale Club held at the clubhouse, 17 East Twenty-sixth Street, last evening, the members by a unanimous vote, accepted a proposition of the Council to buy the plot of ground at 30 and 32 West Forty-fourth Street and erect upon it a fine towerlike structure for their new club home.

PARIS, Feb. 16. -- There was a lively debate in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, as the outcome of a speech made by M. Pelletan, Socialist, when he reported the war budget yesterday, in which he called attention to the many abuses and anomalies existing in the army. He spoke of the "kind of Freemasonry" existing among the officers to shield any wrongdoers.

RIET RIVER, Orange Free State, Feb. 14. -- Gen. French, in command of the cavalry division, and with a strong force of horse artillery, left Modder River Sunday morning for Rambam, twelve miles cast of Enslin, where the whole division concentrated. The next day he made a rapid march to Riet River, where a party of Boers contested his passage at Dekiel and Waterfall Drifts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The exchange of ratifications of the Samoan treaty took place to-day at the State Department, and it is presumed that similar exchanges Recurred at the Foreign Offices in London and Berlin. This is the last, ceremony necessary to give full effect to the Samoan agreement, though as a matter of form and of public information, here in the United States at least, it may be necessary to proclaim the treaty.

Kantrowitz Esberg, attorneys for August Sliz, the game importer of 85 Barclay Street who was convicted on Thursday, in the Court of Special Sessions, of having in his possession and selling ten carcasses of venison, on complaint of the League of American Sportsmen, said yesterday that an appeal has been taken to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.
A.D.T. Boy No. 955 met A.D.T. Boy No. 1,432 at Thirty-second Street and Sixth Avenue late yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Mr. Minton's bill empowering Commissioners of Correction to remove from that department to that of Charities any person committed as a vagrant upon certification that the person is "aged, feeble, and infirm, or mentally and physically unfit to perform manual labor," to be held during the time of the commitment, will have a hearing before the Assembly Cities Committee on Feb. 22.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The first detachment of Milwaukee boomers arrived here to-night to inaugurate that city's campaign for the Democratic Convention. There is a prevalent impression that Milwaukee has practically secured the convention already, but the boomers do not seem to be acting on that assumption.

BROOKSVILLE, Fla., Feb. 17. -- On his arrival here to-day William J. Bryan was met by a large crowd, which gave him a rousing welcome. He was at once driven to the home of his cousin, Judge Jennings, where an informal reception was held.
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- Following is the text of a dispatch from Lord Roberts to the War Office:
JACOBSDAL, Feb. 15. -- Lord Roberts s troops to-day entered this town, which has been in possession of the British since yesterday.

HAVANA, Feb. 17. -- In a cable dispatch received to-day by Mr. Alexis E. Frye, Superintendent of Schools. President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard University has offered to provide, free of charge, for 1,000 Cuban teachers during six weeks of the Summer at the Harvard Summer School for Teachers.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Herbert R. Limburger of New York City, counsel for the Ramapo Water Company, who yesterday had an interview with Gov. Roosevelt, said to-day of the matters pertaining to New York's water supply:
LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Spenser Wilkinson, the military expert, reviewing the situation in South Africa at midnight, says:
Wheeler H. Peckham has addressed an open letter to the Joint Committee on Taxation of the Legislature, in which he calls attention to some points on the proposed mortgage tax. He says, in part:

BANGOR, Me., Feb. 16. -- Mrs. Fannie T. Achdoff, whose husband is a merchant in South Africa, is now visiting friends in Waterville, Me., and in Benton, her native place, after an absence of twenty years, and she brings some interesting information concerning the Boers and the war. Her husband, who is a German and friendly to the Boers, is now somewhere in the vicinity of Colesburg, from which place his last letter was dated.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 17. -- The agitation of the sophomore society question among the Yale undergraduates that has come to a head this week marks what is probably the first step toward a solution of a problem that has stirred Yale student circles for over a decade.
Mr. Chamberlain, who was received with loud Ministerial cheers, said:

"If good, honest reform is intended in the affairs of the Sixty-ninth Resident," said an officer conversant with its affairs, "the military authorities will not stop with the disbardment of Company F. commanded by Capt. Griffin, but will go further and take other heroic measures. But, mark my words, they won't do it, for political reasons.
"When da peop" t'ink Nic hav-a da heart lik-a da chick', mak-a da beeg mistak'!"

BANGOR, Me., Feb. 16. -- Mrs. Fannie T. Achdoff, whose husband is a merchant in South Africa, is now visiting friends in Waterville, Me., and in Benton, her native place, after an absence of twenty years, and she brings some interesting information concerning the Boers and the war. Her husband, who is a German and friendly to the Boers, is now somewhere in the vicinity of Colesburg, from which place his last letter was dated.

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- Theatregoers in Paris have been so annoyed by the class of ticket scalpers such as frequent the entrances to so many American places of amusement that a crusade has been organized against this practice. The police made a raid this week, and arrested several ticket vendors on the ground of interfering with traffic, and fines and imprisonment were imposed upon them.

Belfer Flash of Brooklyn, attorneys for the petitioning creditors of William F. Miller, and their counsel, Francis A. McClosky, also of Brooklyn, are confident that in the bankruptcy proceedings against Miller many of the mysteries of the Franklin Syndicate will be explained. They will have subpoenas issued to-morrow for every one who is thought to know anything of the Miller case.

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- Colonial interests now furnish a topic which for the moment attracts more attention than the covert intentions of other nations as to the world's map, or England's present entanglement. This week brought important news from one of France's oldest colonies and from her newst -- Martinique and the Soudan -- a serious upheaval in the first case, but the happier intelligence of a victory for French arms from the latter.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Feb. 17. -- Bessie Titsworth, six years old, now an inmate of St. Christopher's Home, in this place, was sold by her parents to the Rev. W.R. Neff of the Port Jervis Methodist Episcopal Church, for the sum of $1. The child is to be brought up in the institution. Her purchaser rescued her yesterday from a miserable existence with her father and stepmother in Milford, Penn.

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- Theatregoers in Paris have been so annoyed by the class of ticket scalpers such as frequent the entrances to so many American places of amusement that a crusade has been organized against this practice. The police made a raid this week, and arrested several ticket vendors on the ground of interfering with traffic, and fines and imprisonment were imposed upon them.

The Knickerbocker Telephone Company has started in actual and open competition to the Bell telephone system. Exchanges have been established and the names of subscribers are on file. The exchanges now doing business are at 119 East Twentythird Street and 416 to 422 Broome Street. The President of the company, Col. W.H. Eckert, is one of the pioneers in the telephone business.

Serious objection is raised by public accountants to what is known as the Jenks bill, or the New York Business Companies' act, introduced on Friday by Senator Brackett, which provides for the incorporation and regulation of business companies. The bill was prepared after several conferences with Gov. Roosevelt, who approves it.

The usual two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday were diversified in style. In the afternoon Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" was performed and in the evening Verdi's "La Traviata" was sung. This was a decided contrast in styles, but of course it was one noted by a very few.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The State Library annual report shows that reports for 1899 have been received from 985 libraries, of which 431 are free for lending; and that 491,964 volumes have been added in a year, making the total for the State 5,846,519, the free circulating libraries having 1,979,319 volumes.

ITHACA, Feb. 17. -- Cornell called out her crew candidates earlier and the training has been carried on with more rigor this Winter than for several seasons. The navy authorities at Ithaca are beginning to appreciate the fact that Cornell's long series of victories at Poughkeepsie, Saratoga, and New London previous to 1898 will not maintain her reputation forever if an occasional victory is not thrown in to refresh the memories of her enemies.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 17. -- Arthur E. Stillwell, promoter and former President of the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Gulf Railroad Company, is the moving spirit in an ambitious railroad scheme that was announced here to-day. His plan contemplates a new international railway system 1,800 miles in length, stretching from Kansas City to the Gulf of California.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 17. -- The Abbott-Downing Company, manufacturers of coaches, carriages, and wagons, with salesrooms and repair shops at 114 to 120 West Thirtieth Street, New York City, and at 52 Oliver Street, Boston, made an assignment to-day to Gerald Wyman of Boston and Abbott Treadwell of Concord.

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- Colonial interests now furnish a topic which for the moment attracts more attention than the covert intentions of other nations as to the world's map, or England's present entanglement. This week brought important news from one of France's oldest colonies and from her newst -- Martinique and the Soudan -- a serious upheaval in the first case, but the happier intelligence of a victory for French arms from the latter.

CITY OF MEXICO, Feb. 17. -- The laws of Mexico have always been strict in regard to marriages and divorces. Recently a case has been decided in this city which attracted attention on account of the plaintiff's prominence in society and the legal points involved. In fact, the Civil Court found it necessary to establish a precedent, as no case of the same character has been tried in the republic.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17. -- Announcement was made here to-day of the plans for the campaign of the grand trotting circuit the coming season of the largest stable of horses with the best records ever gathered in the history of the turf. It is practically a combine to win all the big prizes on the circuit.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 17. -- The agitation of the sophomore society question among the Yale undergraduates that has come to a head this week marks what is probably the first step toward a solution of a problem that has stirred Yale student circles for over a decade.

Lakewood is a place of perpetual Sundays. The trees sing hymns, and even the white sand paths through the pine forests look as if they had put on their Sunday garments. The bicyclists on the street have to new comers the appearance of wicked city Sunday bicyclists, and the women patrons of the drug store soda fountains look as if they were breaking commandments.

The fourth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of Brokers was held last night at the Hotel Manhattan. Covers were laid for 140 and but few places were vacant.

The Rev. Dr. Moses J. Gries of Cleveland preached yesterday morning at the Temple Emanu-El. His sermon was mainly devoted to a discussion of religious decadence among the younger generation at Jews, who, he says, are neither deeply interested in matters of worship nor properly instructed in the Jewish belief.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17. -- Announcement was made here to-day of the plans for the campaign of the grand trotting circuit the coming season of the largest stable of horses with the best records ever gathered in the history of the turf. It is practically a combine to win all the big prizes on the circuit.
JACOBSDAL, Feb. 15. -- Lord Roberts s troops to-day entered this town, which has been in possession of the British since yesterday.

Serious objection is raised by public accountants to what is known as the Jenks bill, or the New York Business Companies' act, introduced on Friday by Senator Brackett, which provides for the incorporation and regulation of business companies. The bill was prepared after several conferences with Gov. Roosevelt, who approves it.

There was slugging a-plenty at the National championship boxing and wrestling tournament of the Amateur Athletic Union, which was continued at the Broadway Athletic Club last night. About 3,000 persons were present.

DEPLORABLE STATE OF THE KITCHENS OF PARISIAN HOTELS AND RESTAURANTS. -- Prior to July, 1894, the kitchens of Paris eating houses were under Government surveillance. A Ministerial circular then declared restaurants to be entitled to the same privileges as private houses, and the surveillance was abolished.

The all-absorbing topic in the barbers' shops of the city yesterday was a paragraph in the newspapers announcing briefly that Assemblyman Brennan's bill licensing barbers and providing for a State Board of Examiners, with an amendment that the applicant for a certificate must be examined within thirty days after making application, had been reported favorably in the Assembly.

There were two daring rescues at the fire early yesterday morning at Thirty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue. In spite of the snowstorm a large crowd collected on the slippery pavements around the burning building, watching the work of the firemen and the movements of Archie Gunn, the artist, who lives next door to the house in which the fire occurred.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17. -- A.P. Hotaling, a well-known capitalist of this city, is dead from heart disease. Mr. Hotaling, who was a native of New York, was seventy-three years old. He leaves an estate worth between $7,000,000 and $10,000,000. His wife and two sons survive him.

CALCUTTA, Feb. 17. -- The Viceroy of India, Lord Curzon of Kedleston, presided to-day at a meeting inaugurating a famine fund, at which the leading Maharajahs and British officials were present. The announcement that the Queen had opened the fund with u1,000 was enthusiastically cheered, whereupon the Maharajah of Darbhanga contributed u7,500, the British India Company u5,000, Lord Curzon u1,000, and other subscriptions raised the total to u50,000.

BROOKSVILLE, Fla., Feb. 17. -- On his arrival here to-day William J. Bryan was met by a large crowd, which gave him a rousing welcome. He was at once driven to the home of his cousin, Judge Jennings, where an informal reception was held.

The fact that Mrs. Ottilie C. Steinway, widow of George Steinway, a son of the late William Steinway, the piano manufacturer, had obtained a divorce from her husband and remarried before his death, in 1898, only became public yesterday, when a motion was argued before Justice Russell in the Supreme Court.

HAVANA, Feb. 17. -- In a cable dispatch received to-day by Mr. Alexis E. Frye, Superintendent of Schools. President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard University has offered to provide, free of charge, for 1,000 Cuban teachers during six weeks of the Summer at the Harvard Summer School for Teachers.

The usual two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday were diversified in style. In the afternoon Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" was performed and in the evening Verdi's "La Traviata" was sung. This was a decided contrast in styles, but of course it was one noted by a very few.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES has for years possessed one characteristic which distinguishes it from any other New York paper, in the extended and thorough treatment it gives to topics which are of world-wide rather than of local interest; and the editorial page corresponds in this respect with the news columns.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17. -- According to news brought by the Coptic, pirates are causing much trouble in Chinese waters. The Government seems powerless to stop their depredations.

BERLIN, Feb. 17. -- Colonial matters engrossed the attention of the Reichstag this week, the debate unmistakably showing the unprofitable state of the colonies hitherto, even in the case of the most promising, like the Cameroons. It likewise showed the growing appropriations, with stationary or diminishing exports and imports.

The members of the syndicate that controls the destinies of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company put their heads together one day early last week, and determined to draw on their personal bank accounts with the view of making a present to H.H. Vreeland, President of the company, that would show him how they appreciated his work.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The State Library annual report shows that reports for 1899 have been received from 985 libraries, of which 431 are free for lending; and that 491,964 volumes have been added in a year, making the total for the State 5,846,519, the free circulating libraries having 1,979,319 volumes.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The Scriptural phrase, to "rejoice with trembling," fitly expresses our first attitude toward the news of the relief of Kimberley. So many times have loudly trumpeted tales of magnificent triumphs been followed by reluctantly admitted disasters that we hesitate now to accept telegrams even from Lord Roberts as full statements of the facts in their latest development.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Feb. 17. -- Ex-Gov. Sylvester Pennoyer to-day gave out the following statement regarding the financial bill which has been passed by the Senate:

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 17. -- With heavy clouds for a start, the day looked anything but promising, but there was a large gallery gathered on the links of the Country Club to-day when Harry Vardon, the British champion, defeated our champion Willie Smith, by 2 up and 1 to play. Every one was expecting great things from both.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 19. -- On Saturday, Jan. 14, notes of the value of 1,000,000 milreis were burned, according to the terms of the funding loan of June 15, 1898; on acount of the loan made to the Bank of Brazil, another million was destroyed, and at the same time 1,000 bonds of the public debt of the value of 1,000 milreis each were consigned to the fire.

This indorsement was extended to-day in a very brief speech in the House of Representatives, which has been spoken of by those who heard it as quite the most artistic utterance that ever dropped from Mr. Cannon's lips.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Chairman Hepburn of the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce to-day submitted the report of the committee in favor of the Hepburn bill for constructing the Nicaragua Canal. The report says, in part:
"When da peop" t'ink Nic hav-a da heart lik-a da chick', mak-a da beeg mistak'!"

SAN JUAN DE PUERTO RICO, Feb. 17. -- Several of the leading merchants of San Juan unanimously express the opinion that immediate Congressional action is absolutely essential to the interests of the island. They say that the crops are immovable, the proposed duty on sugar and tobacco, under the Foraker bill, being prohibitive.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The mails from South Africa bring many interesting details of the war, among them a series of letters from Col. Baden-Powell to his relatives, extracts of which are published in an illustrated weekly. The defender of Mafeking writes:

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 17. -- Thomas M. Bram, the mate of the barkentine Herbert Fuller, who in July, 1896, murdered Capt. Nash and his wife and the second mate of that vessel and who is now serving a life sentence, may soon be set at liberty, not because of any newly discovered evidence, but because of the lapse of a law.

The members of the syndicate that controls the destinies of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company put their heads together one day early last week, and determined to draw on their personal bank accounts with the view of making a present to H.H. Vreeland, President of the company, that would show him how they appreciated his work.

Belfer Flash of Brooklyn, attorneys for the petitioning creditors of William F. Miller, and their counsel, Francis A. McClosky, also of Brooklyn, are confident that in the bankruptcy proceedings against Miller many of the mysteries of the Franklin Syndicate will be explained. They will have subpoenas issued to-morrow for every one who is thought to know anything of the Miller case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The conferrees of the Senate and the House met this morning to take up the Currency bill, and continued to consider it until 5 o'clock this afternoon. The members are silent about the particulars, but privately they agree that the meeting was satisfactory and the spirit on both sides was reasonable.

The Knickerbocker Telephone Company has started in actual and open competition to the Bell telephone system. Exchanges have been established and the names of subscribers are on file. The exchanges now doing business are at 119 East Twentythird Street and 416 to 422 Broome Street. The President of the company, Col. W.H. Eckert, is one of the pioneers in the telephone business.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 17. -- The acceptance of service by attorneys for the defendants in the Frick-Carnegie equity suit clears the way for the actual beginning of the fight in the courts between the two steel kings. The recognized adherents of each are doing all in their power to marshal their respective forces for the contest, and consultations on campaign plans are being held night and day.

The regular ticket of the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, which is headed by Robert B. Roosevelt, is to be met by an opposition ticket headed by Gen. Horatio C. King of Brooklyn. The annual meeting for the election of officers will be held on Tuesday evening at Sherry's.
Wheeler H. Peckham has addressed an open letter to the Joint Committee on Taxation of the Legislature, in which he calls attention to some points on the proposed mortgage tax. He says, in part:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- S.E. Nott was today appointed Postmaster at Cheshire, N.Y. The office is of the fourth class.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.-- Forty-eight hours in advance of the arrival of the 100 boomers from Milwaukee, everything looks so much as if the democratic Convention would go to that city that their visit seems unnecessary, and their traveling expenses a waste of money. Admittedly they have no serious rival, except in Kansas City, and that city does not seem to be making a great effort.

JACOBSDAL, Feb. 16. -- Lord Roberts's combinations for the movement of the corps dovetailed with precision, although obstacles that had not been foreseen had to be overcome.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 18. -- The Gallaudet Home for the Deaf and Dumb, situated about seven miles south of this city, was destroyed by fire about 10 o'clock to-night. The twenty-six inmates were safely rescued and taken to a farmhouse a quarter of a mile away. The fire started in the south-western portion of the building, and the origin is unknown.

Roland B. Molineux spent his first Sunday in the death house at Sing Sing Prison without any consolation fom members of his family or friends, for the rules of the prison forbid all Sunday visits to those condemned to death, except in the case of those who are to be executed during the week, who may see their relatives and spiritual advisers oh their last Sunday on earth.

Samuel Schwab, known on the east side as "Yellow Simon," was a prisoner yesterday morning in the Essex Market Police Court. His mode of operations is much the same as that of Fagin. whom Dickens portrayed as the typical London thief of his time. Schwab does not work alone, but has had a half dozen small boys to find victims for him.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- It is reported from Chieveley, under date of Sunday, that Gen. Buller has established his headquarters on Hussar Hill. Heavy artillery firing was maintained at intervals by both sides from Wednesday until Friday. The British slowly pushed the advance, and their infantry occupied intrenched new positions in front of Hussar Hill with slight losses.

LEXINGTON, Feb. 18. -- H.B. Durham has announced that he will race in the East this season. His good filly Merito is not engaged in the Oaks event in the West, and will be trained especially for competing with the youngsters of her age on The Jockey Club tracks. She is a filly of much merit.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 18. -- Many of the Democratic legislators returned here tonight and numerous conferences were in progress during the evening relating to the political programme to-morrow, when the Democratic and Republican branches of the Legislature will meet together for the first time since the assassination of Goebel.

OAXACA, Mexico, Feb. 18. -- Gen. Bravo's force of Government troops has driven back the Maya Indians and taken possession of several important towns that were occupied by the rebels during the week. The country occupied by the Mayas is lit tle known to the outside world. Its natural riches are great.

When Mrs. Marie Dellia, forty years old, returned to her apartment in the five-story building at 131 West Twenty-eighth Street last night, after visiting friends, she was surprised to find the outside door unlocked. The house had been entered by burglars severals times within the last year, and Mrs. Dellia at once concluded that her home had been robbed.

John Bacis, twenty-five years old, a Greek cigarette maker living at 73 Roosevelt Street, was assaulted by a crowd of young men yesterday afternoon and is likely to die of his injuries. Bacis was taken to Hudson Street Hospital with a fractured skull.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18. -- A dispatch from Greensburg, Penn., says:

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 18. -- Arthur Sewall, candidate for Vice President on the Democratic ticket in 1896, arrived at the St. Charles Hotel last night. Before he leaves this part of the country he will hold conferences with the party leaders and with William Jennings Bryan. Col. Bryan is How in Florida, and this morning Mr. Sewall got into telegraphic communication with him for the purpose of arranging a meeting.

PARIS, Feb. 18. -- The sensational newspapers of Paris publish a story with regard to a sub-chief of one of the bureaus of the Ministry of Marine named Philipp, who is said to have been detected in an offer to furnish Great Britain information relating to the freighting of vessels for the Transvaal in French ports.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Feb. 18. -- President Samuel Strong of the Free Coinage Mining Company of Cripple, Creek was joined in marriage on the 6th inst. to Miss Regina Neville of Altman, Cripple Creek district. Just after the marriage ceremony he was served with impers in a breach of promise suit brought by Miss Vance of a neighboring town.

The snowstorm which held sway over New York on Saturday ended at about 4 o'clock yesterday morning, when the total fall measured 10.9 inches. This city and the territory immediately adjacent seems to have caught the brunt of the storm in this part of the country, as above Peekskill the snowfall did not exceed two or three inches.
