LEXINGTON, Feb. 18. -- H.B. Durham has announced that he will race in the East this season. His good filly Merito is not engaged in the Oaks event in the West, and will be trained especially for competing with the youngsters of her age on The Jockey Club tracks. She is a filly of much merit.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- It is reported from Chieveley, under date of Sunday, that Gen. Buller has established his headquarters on Hussar Hill. Heavy artillery firing was maintained at intervals by both sides from Wednesday until Friday. The British slowly pushed the advance, and their infantry occupied intrenched new positions in front of Hussar Hill with slight losses.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 18. -- Arthur Sewall, candidate for Vice President on the Democratic ticket in 1896, arrived at the St. Charles Hotel last night. Before he leaves this part of the country he will hold conferences with the party leaders and with William Jennings Bryan. Col. Bryan is How in Florida, and this morning Mr. Sewall got into telegraphic communication with him for the purpose of arranging a meeting.

The expected attack upon Controller Coler by labor organizations for his alleged opposition to the enforcement of the labor law in regard to the payment of the prevailing rate of wages to men employed on public works was made yesterday at the meeting of the Central Federated Union.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- 3:45 A.M. -- A member of the Cabinet told Henry W. Lucy to-night that the War Office had received a telegram announcing that Gen. Cronje was hopelessly surrounded.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The net profits in 1899 of a certain corporation engaged in the manufacture of steel and iron are said to have exceeded $21,000,000, and they are expected to reach $42,000,000 in the current year, 1900. Concerning that corporation, Mr. Abram S. Hewittt is quoted in your issue of this morning as saying that it makes nearly one-half of the steel manufactured in this country.

A writ of habeas corpus will be served this morning on Sheriff Walton of Kings County ordering him to present William F. Miller before Referee Augustus J. Koehler at the United States District Courtroom, in Broklyn, to-morrow morning to give evidence in the bankruptcy proceedings brought by Belfer Flash of Brooklyn, attorneys for the creditors of the Franklin Syndicate.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. -- "American securities will not suffer appreciably from the Boer war, no matter what setbacks the British forces may receive," said Secretary of the Treasury Gage to-day. "The same, indeed, may be said of English securities. The financial condition of England is recognized by financiers as so Strong that every demand for the prosecution of the war can easily be met.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Representative Richardson of Tennessee, the minority leader of the House, after consultation with some of his Democratic colleagues, to-day introduced two resolutions aimed at the Sugar Trust. The first is as follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- Senator Ford to-night introduced a bill amending the insurance law so as to enable assessment life insurance associations to reorganize as regular mutual companies. The bill is intended to open the way for the reincorporation of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Senator Clark of Montana to-day was again a witness before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections. He necessarily went over much of the ground covered by him in his testimony Saturday. He was cross-examined by Mr. Campbell, and insisted that he had spent no money for corrupt purposes during the Montana Senatorial campaign.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- There was a large attendance this evening at the Authors' Club dinner, where the United States Ambassador, Joseph H. Choate, was the guest of honor. Among those present were James Bryce, Sir George Lewis, Anthony Hope Hawkins, and J.R. Carter of the United States Embassy.

A good deal of irregularity showed in yesterday's market for outside securities. Most of the stocks traded in, to a large extent, were strong and ended the day with substantial net gains, while among the stocks less actively dealt in were a number in, which closing quotations showed considerable recession from Saturday's final bids.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- In the House to-day Mr. Dolliver, (Rep., Iowa,) from the Committee on Ways and Means, moved the passage under suspension of the rules of the bill reported from that committee to amend Sections 3,339 and 3,341 or the Revised Statutes, relating to internal revenue tax on fermented liquors.

BOSTON, Feb. 19. -- Erie Telephone's advance to 114 was the feature, and practically the only feature, in to-day's market. The advance was credited to scarcity of stock. The copper shares were at a standstill. There was a slightly improved showing for United States Oil, General Electric, and Westinghouse.
A dividend has been declared by the American Linseed Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19. -- Arthur Magnet, a young lad who about a month ago caused the arrest of his guardian. Dr. Thelberg, in New York for cruelty, arrived here last night. His passage to the Pacific Coast was paid by the Gerry society, and Dr. Thelberg gave him ten dollars for traveling expenses.

Col. Benjamin S. Lovell, President of the John P. Lovell Arms Company of Boston, and well known throughout the New England States, died at his home, at Weymouth, Mass., yesterday afternoon. Col. Lovell was born in Weymouth, July 10, 1844. He enlisted in Company A, Forty-second Regiment, Massachusetts Volunteers, in 1862, and served during the remainder of the civil war.

It was learned yesterday that Armour Co. are to be incorporated in the State of Illinois. They will consolidate all their industries in one corporation, which will be capitalized at either $20,000,000 or $25,000,000, all common stock. There will be no bond issue. Chicago will remain the headquarters of the firm.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- A special dispatch from Madrid saying that Premier Silvela recently declared in the Senate that previous to the war with the United States the British Government consented to let Spain have 8,500 shells which were being manufactured for her at the Maxim factory at Placentia meets with vigorous denial in London.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 19. -- It is expected that this will be an important week in the Frick-Carnegie controversy. Word, it is said, has been received from Andrew Carnegie, at the Carnegie Steel Company's offices, that he will be in Pittsburg this week. He is expected to personally oversee the final preparation of the answer to Mr. Frick's bill of particulars, and make the last corrections to it before the paper is filed.
Sonn Brothers have sold the plot running through from Riverside Drive to Claremont Avenue, 337 feet north of One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 50 by 200.

A committee of five representatives of the Central Federated Union called upon Mayor Van Wyck yesterday to protest, as they said, against the attitude assumed, by Controller Coler in reference to the payment of claims under the prevailing rate of wages law. The delegation was composed of Philip Kelly, James P. Archibald. Edward Hanna. Eugene Johnson, and Patrick McNulty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- While Mr. Cullom (Rep., Ill.,) was explaining to-day to the Senate the bill for the government of the Hawaiian Islands and was speaking particularly on the provision for property and intelligence qualifications for voters he was interrupted by questions which led him to say that an educational qualification for voters was a necessity.

The annual report of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was presented at the quarterly meeting of the Board of Trustees, held at the museum yesterday afternoon. Henry G. Marquand, President of the museum, presided, and the following Trustees were present: William E. Dodge, D.O. Mills, John Crosby Brown, E.D. Adams, Heber R. Bishop, John Bigelow, J.S. Kennedy, Salem H. Wales, F.W. Rhinelander, William L. Andrews, and Hiram Hitchcock, with Gen. L.P. Di Cesnola, the Director.
Money on call was 2 1/4 @ 2 1/2 per cent., closing at 2 1/2 per cent.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 19. -- The impression that the contest over the Governorship will not be ended till it is fought to a finish in the courts is not lessened by the action taken by the Democratic Senators in their session to-day ratifying their former action by which Senator Goebel was declared Governor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19. -- Yale's representatives in the National Indoor tennis tournament of the United States, which will be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory, in New York City, from Wednesday until Saturday. Feb. 21 to 24, will be H.H. Hackett, 1900, and J.A. Alien, 1900, S.

Yesterday's stock market was not broader than those which reflected the dullness of last week. In only two or three instances was there any notable activity whatever, even the trading in Sugar and Tobacco trusts falling below 25,000 shares apiece. Norfolk and Western common, in point of trading, was the most conspicuous feature of the day; it rose over 2 points on transactions passing 40,000 shares.

"The Evolution of Industrial Combination" was the subject discussed by the People's Institute last night at the conference on trusts in Cooper Union. The meeting was the second of a series to be held this week, at which all phases of industrial combination will be discussed. About 1,500 persons listened to the arguments, and many of them showed their deep interest in the subject by the questions they propounded to the speakers.

The Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company, formed by August Belmont Co., as the promoting organization of the tunnel to be built by John B. McDonald, filed articles of incorporation at Albany yesterday with a capital of $6,000,000. This and a further extension of time to Mr. McDonald, granted by the Board of Rapid Transit Commission during the afternoon, were the important developments yesterday toward the actual construction of the underground railroad.

The final bouts in the boxing and wrestling championship tournament of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States at the Broadway Athletic Club last night furnished excellent exhibitions by the best amateurs in this country and Canada. In wrestling Max Wiley of the Rochester Athletic Club earned a reputation at this tournament that no amateur has ever made before.

QUEBEC, Fob. Edwin Forrest Mayo of the "Puild'n Wilson" company dropped dead in the Chateau Frontenac at 2 o'clock this morning. Mr. Mayo and his wife were stopping at the Frontenac. Mr. Mayo was chatting with Edwin Varney, the manager of the Academy of Music, untill about 2 o'clock.

Edward Winkelman was considered one of the brightest pupils in his class at the public school in East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. He was the pride of his parents, who live at 243 East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, and of his uncle, Commissioner of Jurors Charles Welde.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19). -- The Secretary of War has sent to the Chairmen of the Senate and House Military Committees a draft of a bill that the department claims greatly strengthens the military system and remedies defects developed during the Spanish-American war. The bill was introduced in the House to-day by Chairman Hull.

Meyerbeer's most popular opera, "Les Huguenots," was brought forward at the Metropolitar Opera House last night for the first time this season. Custom has familiarized the public with the French title of the opera, but as it was sung last evening in Italian it should have been announced as "Gli Ugonotti."

The work of removing the snow from the city streets was pushed yesterday with great success, and Street Cleaning Commissioner Nagle said that he expected to have the streets cleared up by to-night. More loads of snow were removed than on the day before. The number was 46,995.

The first of the series of conferences on the tenement house problem planned for each evening of this week by the Charity Organization Society, was held last evening at the Tenement House Exhibition. 404 Fifth Avenue. The conference was addressed by Lawrence Veiller, Secretary of the Tenement House Committee of the society, on "The Exhibition and Its Meaning."

The Merchants' Association is trying to take one of the kinks out of the city charter. It has caused a bill to be introduced in the Assembly. Its scope and purpose are very clearly set forth in this extract from a memorial prepared by the association:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The debate upon the Puerto Rican Tariff bill, which is to continue throughout the week, and possibly longer, opened in the House to-day. Interest in the bill is intense among the members on both sides, and there is urgent demand for time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Progress was made to-day toward agreement of the conferrees of the Senate and the House on the Currency bill. To-night it is ascertained that the House conferrees made the offer to the members from the Senate to accept the refunding provision of the Senate bill if the Senate conferrees will take the House declaration of its purpose to assure the maintenance of the parity.

William S.M. Rideout, whose father has been Inspector in the Boston Custom House for nearly thirty years, is locked up in tho Adams Street Police Station, Brooklyn, under the technical charges of vagrancy and disorderly conduct. The real cause of his detention is alleged bigamy, and it is probable that he will be removed within a few days to Hoboken, where he is charged with having contracted a second marriage on Feb. 11.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Representative Tompkins (Rep., N.Y.,) to-day announced his purpose to vote against the pending. Puerto Rico Tariff bill, as he holds the island should be given the same rights as the States or Territories.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- Gov. Roosevelt will leave for New York City at 9:25 A.M. Wednesday. In the evening he will attend the banquet of the Harvard Club of New York City and that of the New York Press Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- By direction of the President, the following changes have been made in the authorized enlisted strength of certain organizations of the regular army:

We wish all the advocates of the legislative restriction of trusts and monopolies would discuss the matter with the candor and open-mindedness that characterized Dr. HEBER NEWTON'S paper, read at the Cooper Union conference of the People's Institute on Sunday evening. The anti-trust crusade, especially among the Populists, has taken on the character of a denial of the right to do business.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19. -- More and more serious becomes the health situation in Philadelphia, menaced as it is by the dark-colored. foul-smelling, germ-laden Sehuylkill water, which a million, and a quarter persons are forced to use. There is extreme danger that the typhoid fever epidemic is increasing in proportion, and there is general alarm.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 19. -- Some four hundred and fifty members of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and the Civic Federation to-day made the life of Mayor Mack a burden in their protestations against the production of the drama "Sapho," bined at Jacobs's Theatre the 23d inst. and at the Lyceum Theatre March 3.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. -- Notice of a suit to recover $3,000, said to be due in stock deals, was served to-day on William H. Crane, the actor, now playing at a Chicago theatre. The plaintiffs in the case are L. T. and H.P. Watson, stock brokers at Minneapolis. The brokers declare that Actor Crane owes them $2,261 and interest for purchasing and selling 200 shares of Delaware.

The hearing of the charges preferred by the City Club against District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner began yesterday before Ansley Wilcox, the Commissioner appointed by the Governor for the purpose. Attorney General Davies, who is, officially, the prosecutor of the charges, was represented by his deputy, John H. Coyne, and Horace E. Deming and Arthur F. Cosby.
George W. Van Sielen, American Treasurer of the fund for the widows and orphans of the Boers, has just received the following official letter:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 3/4@60 3/4. There were no sales.

To the Editor, of The New York Times: It appears to me that Mr. Moreton Frewen is inaccurate, not to say unfair, in his criticism of Dr. Baton's sermon on the South African war. He says: "Dr. Eaton is apparently not aware that the African diamond mines are in our Cape Colony."

The tug Nathan Hale of the Thames Towboat Company of New London, Conn., came into port yesterday afternoon with the barge Marion Chappell. Both vessels showed the effects of having been in a terrible storm, and Capt. Stevens of the Hale reported the loss of the barge Oakland, which parted her hawser and sank with her crew of four men off Absecom Light at 5 o'clock Sunday morning.

"How easy it is to forget history," remarked the man who keeps posted on the events of early New York days, as well as upon the things of the present. "Probably not one in a thousand citizens recognized in the recent sale of the house at 63 Prince Street, the old residence of President Monroe when he retired from the White House after his eight years of service as President.

The President has come to the parting of the ways with respect to the dogma of Protection. His position upon it has changed amazingly within the last four years. Then he tried his best, so long as he could with safety and even a little longer, to make upon that superannuated warhorse his campaign for the Presidency.

The floating debt of the Third Avenue Railroad, it was officially announced yesterday, is to be funded. There is much speculation in Wall Street as to whether or not the negotiations for the funding of this $20,000,000 of notes (held mainly by financial institutions) are to come to naught, as did those in which Kuhn, Loeb Co. were interested, or are to progress till contracts are actually signed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The Democratic Convention fight is to be really a fight, after all. An unexpected display of vigor by Kansas City has dissipated the talk of a walk-over for Milwaukee, and both sides say that between now and the meeting of the Democratic National Comittee on Thursday there will be an exciting struggle.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The House of Commons yesterday was crowded everywhere when David Alfred Thomas, Liberal, member for Merthyr Tydvil, rose to move the reopening of the inquiry into the origin and circumstances of the Jameson raid. Among those present in the Diplomatic Gallery was the United States Ambassador, Joseph H. Choate.

TRENTON, N.J.,Feb. 20 -- The Senate this morning passed the House bill authorizing the Mayor of New Brunswick to appoint Commissioners to revise the ward lines of that city. The Democratic Board of Aldermen had refused to carry out last year's act for the redistricting of the city, and this bill puts the matter in Republican hands.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- A correspondent of The Daily Chronicle, telegraphing Sunday, thus describes Gen. Cronje's retreat with the Boers at Magersfontein on learning of Gen. French's success:

The result to the Sixty-ninth Regiment of the visit Monday night of Major Putnam Bradlee Strong, Inspector of the Fifth Brigade, is the subject of considerable conjecture among members of the National Guard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- While the House of Representatives was engaged today in discussing the Puerto Rican Tariff bill the Republican members were a little nervous and much more interested in the talk of the smoking rooms and corridors concerning the possibility that the Ways and Means Committee might suffer a defeat when the bill came to a vote.

The second team of the Chase National Bank won its first game in the Bank Clerks League, defeating the Kountze Brothers' team at Reid's alleys last night by a score of 665 to 635. The United States Sub-Treasury team also defeated Kountze Brothers, and then won a game from the Chase National Bank bowlers. Scores:
Sliver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 3/4 @60 3/4. There were no sales.
Two coal roads -- the Lackawanna and the Jersey Central -- yesterday issued their annual statements, and in each case the showing was exceptionally good -- phenomenal, in fact.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- At a hearing on Senator Ford's street cleaning bill for New York City before the Senate Cities Committee to-day, Deputy Commissioner Gibson of the Street Cleaning Department of New York City opposed the measure for Commissioner Nagle, who was unable to be in attendance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The undersigned, delegates from Puerto Rico, charged with the duty of representing before Congress its material and political needs, have noticed in your issue of yesterday the very reasonable request you make for "some exposition from an authoritative source of the practical difference between one-quarter of the Dingley tariff and no tariff at all" as affecting Puerto Rico.

Through the sharp advance in the price of structural work, electric wiring, and iron, and the consequent failure of the Armstrong Bolton Company, which had the contract to equip the new Tombs with steam heating and other apparatus, the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company stands in a fair way to lose about $75,000, the sum in which it acted as surety for the Armstrong Bolton Company.

Another effort will be made to break the will of Mrs. Anna Drake Seaman. The contest involves about $2,000,000 worth of real estate. This time James W. Drake has started the contest by bringing an action for the partition of the estate on the grounds that he is next of kin.

The new freight yard which the New Haven Road is to build on a recently acquired piece of land near Poquonoc, on the Shore Line Division, will be used as one of the principal points for distribution for east and west bound freight. Tracks will be laid to permit the handling of over 600 cars.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 20 -- The midwinter sale of trotting horses began here today at Tattersall's. Scores of turfmen and breeders from all sections of the country were present and the demand for good horses was great.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- The Yale Faculty has consented to the petition of the senior class asking for the abolition of the sophomore societies, and, while no formal vote has been announced, the leaders of the movement have been advised that the Faculty prefers to have the students settle among themselves, if possible, this purely undergraduate difficulty.

Louise M. Clayton, wife of Congressman Bertram T. Clayton of Brooklyn, has begun an action in the Supreme Court that borough, for a separation from her husband, charging Unkind treatment and non-support. Yesterday her attorney, William D. Gaylor, moved before Justice Dickey for $30 a week alimony and $150 counsel fee.

The Conference on Trusts before the People's Institute, in co-operation with the Cooper Union, was continued last night in the hall of the union, when "The Economic Effects of Industrial Combination" formed the topic for discussion. There was a large attendance, and the addresses were followed with great interest.

The Special Grand Jury for February, in charge of Deputy Attorney General John Proctor Clarke, was rebuked yesterday by Justice Fursman of the Criminal Term of the Supreme Court. The jurors were told plainly to devote more time to the investigation of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company charges.

Weeks -- Smith. Mr. Harry T. Weeks, son of Mr. Henry Weeks of Bayside, L.I., and Miss Lily Loring Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Waldo Smith of 313 West Forty-sixth Street, were married yesterday morning at 11:30 o'clock at the residence of the bride's father.

The irregularity that marked the beginning of the week in the market for outside securities continued yesterday. Among the net changes for the day were a number of declines, while relatively few issues closed higher than on Monday. Transactions were not in large amount, except in two or three issues, chief of which was National Tube.

Cornelius Vanderbilt made several statements last evening to a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES at his Fifth Avenue home in regard to his membership in the Board of Directors of the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company, which are important in that they dispose of various stories in relation to interests that Mr. Vanderbilt has been credited with representing in the board.

William F. Miller, the Napoleonic young financier of the Franklin Syndicate, who is in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, is alleged to have denied late yesterday afternoon that he had been in Canada. Miller is claimed to have made a declaration to this effect to a Brooklyn newspaper man, who gained access to him by accompanying, as a witness, a lawyer who visited the jail to serve papers on the 520 per cent, operator.

Some time ago the Rev. Percival Pyle, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, at Ocean and Pearsall Avenues, in the Greenville district of Jersey City, made an effort, so some of his parishioners allege, to promote the practice of auricular confession in the parish. Many members were opposed to the practice and threatened to leave the parish if it was not discontinued.

William H. Beard, famous as a painter of animals, died from apoplexy last night at 11:53 o'clock at his home, at 54 West Tenth Street. His illness began Jan. 27. There were with him when the end came his son, Wolcott Le Claire Beard, the writer, and his wife. They are the only surviving members of the family.
James A. Burden of 908 Fifth Avenue yesterday received a dispatch from London from his son, James A. Burden, Jr., announcing the death in that city of his second son, Richard Irvin Burden.

ORMOND, Fla., Feb. 20 -- One of the surprises of the year came to-day when Bernard Nicholls of the Philadelphia Country Club defeated Harry Vardon, the British golf champion, five up and four to play. Every one asked " How do you account for that?"

By an ancient trick, which has apparently lost none of its strength by reason of its age, the Municipal Assembly yesterday defeated the efforts of the advocates of the Long Island tunnel plan to relieve the joint Committee on Railroads from consideration of the application for a franchise, and, moreover, did it in such a way as to indicate its hostility to the plan.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- There are two cases of smallpox in New Rochelle. As a result the Board of Education has closed the schools and the Board of Health yesterday purchased an acre of land just outside the city and to-day carpenters were at work erecting an isolation hospital, to which the two patients will be removed some time to-morrow.

Society didn't go to the dogs to any great extent yesterday, though the dogs were ready to receive it at Madison Square Garden. The day was devoted, to judging the animals in the seven inclosures in the middle third of the Garden, and many persons gathered about the breast-high railings and picked the work of the judges to pieces as fast as the decisions were rendered in the several classes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- In a speech before the Senate to-day Mr. Kenney (Dem., Del.,) argued against the retention of the Philippines, and urged that the Filipinos should have independence, under the protection of the United States. In the course of his speech he said:

The American Steel and Wire Company Held its annual meeting yesterday at the New Jersey Corporations Trust Company's affice, Grand and Greene Streets, Jersey City. J.W. Gates, Chairman of the Board of Directors, presided.

In yesterday's security market there figured few elements beyond the transactions of speculators on the outlook for fractional profits. Two or three groups of traders tried to lift a variety of stocks; some others, more or less numerous, were intent upon marking down quotations; the net result reflected pretty fairly the calibre of the "operators" at work.

The closing days of the season are busier than were their predecessors. Yesterday was filled with incidents and events, and to-day will be equally as crowded. There were several weddings celebrated yesterday, the stories of which will be found in another column, and to-day will bring, among others, the wedding of Mr. Leonard S.R. Hopkins and Miss Margaret Macdonald Barstow at St. Thomas's Church this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A large part of the Senate debate on the Hawaiian bill today was devoted to the question of abolishing slavery in the Islands. That description was applied by Mr. Teller to the system of contract labor in vogue there, and this view seemed to be concurred in by most of the Senators, to judge by the way in which they vied with one another in offering stringent provisions against it.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- This has been a day of conferences between Chairman Odell of the Republican State Committee, Gov. Roosevelt, and the Republican legislative leaders. Mr. Odell reached here this morning, and from the time he appeared until midnight he has been kept busy.

Lawyer Ernest M. Welch, who is on trial for subornation of perjury before Justice Fursman in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, went on the stand yesterday in his own defense. His testimony was a complete denial of the charges made against him. Assistant District Attorney Gerald Hull Gray conducted the cross-examination, and in his anxiety to throw doubt on some of Welch's statements went over the ground of his testimony several times.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage was the guest of honor at a dinner given this evening in the Auditorium by the National Association of Merchants and Travelers. More than 300 members of the organisation and invited guests were present.

MISS MORGAN'S WILL PROBATED. -- The will of Miss Annie Taylor Morgan, who lost her life at the Windsor Hotel fire, was admitted to probate yesterday by Surrogate Thomas. The main ground of contest was that there was no proof of the death of the testatrix. The Surrogate decides that the evidence of her death, though circumstantial, was entirely sufficient.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Mrs. Wilfred Powell, the wife of the English Consul at Philadelphia, has the British soldiers' benefit in charge. She was to have been aided by several Philadelphia women prominent in society. At the concert to be given at the Broad Street Theatre on the 26th inst., Mrs. Langtry is to appear, and recite Kipling's "Absent-Minded Beggar."

District Attorney Gardiner was on hand all day yesterday at the hearing of the charges against him made by the City Club, before Commissioner Wilcox, in Part 12 of the Supreme Court. A number of his assistants, including Assistant District Attorney Uuger, were present, and Mr. Untermyer of his counsel looked after his case throughout the day.

SING SING, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Roland B. Molineux received no visitors to-day in his cell in the death house. His mother and wife, who called yesterday, can visit him only once more this week, under the prison rules. Any relative of a condemned person is not allowed to visit the condemned cells oftener than twice a week.

MODDER RIVER, Feb. 19 -- Although the rapid march of Gen. French's division was marked by a number of conflicts, his actual entry into Kimberley was unopposed. When the British were still eight miles off the Signaling Corps intercepted a heliograph message from the beleaguered garrison to Modder River, saying:

The Treasurers' Club of America, an organization composed of the Treasurers of the various theatres of this city, will give its annual entertainment for the benefit of its relief fund at Wallack's Theatre next Sunday evening.

The men who have charge of the arrangements for funding the debt of the Third Avenue Railroad issued a statement yesterday, after a conference in the office of J.S. Bache Co., the firm which acted as the brokers in the recent transaction by which James R. Keene and others bought a large block of the Third Avenue stock sold by Henry Hart.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Men wearing big red badges, inscribed "A Bright Spot," are seen in all the principal streets and hotel corridors northwest of the Capitol. They are from Milwaukee, and to-night every one of them is as hoarse as a crow. They have been talking about the superior attractions of their city as a site for the Democratic Convention until only those with powerful lungs can speak above a whisper.

We are not aware of the circumstances in which the codicil to the will of the late Marquis of QUEENSBERRY came to be published. It may have been in consequence of the record being open to the inspection of the reporters, or it may have been in accord with the wishes of the dead man or of his heirs.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- In the House of Lords, during the discussion yesterday of the motion of the Earl of Wemyss favoring an amended Militia Ballot act, Lord Lansdowne, Secretary of State for War, said he thought it would be inexpedient to have recourse to the militia ballot except in the case of a complete failure, of the voluntary system.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The Boers are leaving all the positions held by them on British territory and are concentrating for the defense of their own. Sir Redvers Buller thinks they are about to raise the siege of Ladysmith. This is the principal news of the day.

For twelve long hours, with an occasional recess for food and well-earned rest, the New York County Woman's Christian Temperance Union yesterday discussed in solemn conclave various weighty problems of world-wide interest. The war in the Transvaal, English barmaids and their habits, and the advisability of suppressing the drama of "Sapho" received their share of consideration, besides all the usual questions relating directly to wines and winebibbers.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 20 -- The Democratic members of the two houses of the Legislature met in joint session at 3 o'clock this afternoon, and by a vote of 74 to 2 ratified the former proceedings by which William Goebel was declared Governor, and J.C.W. Beckham Lieutenant Governor, and through which Beckham, since the death of Goebel, claims title to the office of Governor.

-- A reader, who has evidently devoted considerable, though as evidently not quite enough, attention to the subject, is troubled because THE TIMES and, as he admits, a majority of the newspaper press prefer to spell, the name of our new possession "Puerto Rico" rather than "Porto Rico." He declares that this is a blunder, and supports his opinion by several assertions, some of them true.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 20 -- There will be two Populist National Conventions. The Middle-of-the-Road element, which yesterday bolted, decided to meet at Cincinnati May 9, and to-day the remaining Populists in session fixed on the same date for a convention in Sioux Falls, S.D.

Danger to the community from tuberculous diseases emanating from the tenements was the principal subject considered at the second of a series of conferences on the tenement problem at 404 Fifth Avenue last evening. Mrs. C.R. Lowell of the Charity Organization Society, which is conducting the Tenement House Exhibition were, presided, and there was a fairly large attendance.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- Boston continues to manifest a desire for Erie Telephone and White Knob. Erie touched 120 to-day, on what looked to be fairly heavy buying. White Knob was up to 36. The news regarding these stocks is decidedly meagre. Burlington was sold freely. Bell Telephone recovered well from Tuesday's setback, selling above 33.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- William Mitchell Bunker of San Francisco, who since March last has been traveling in the interest of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, is now in Berlin, on his way to the United States. In the course of his journey in the East he made a close study of the TransSiberian Railroad as related to American trade.
BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- The Rutgers College freshmen spoiled the annual dinner of the sophomore class to-night and caused the diners to flee the banquet hall before the second course was reached.

The thirty-fourth annual dinner of the Harvard Club of New York City was giver at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening, about 300 members of the club and guests being present. The dinner was notable among these annual gatherings for more than one reason.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 21. -- The Post to-morrow will say: "One gigantic combine is to fight another in the electric supply business. Contractors, who have taken work for the business of the year, have taken steps to protect themselves against the combination of supply houses, now forming in New York.

An action which may defeat the attempt to reorganize the so-called Flour Trust was brought before Justice Dickey, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday by bra M. Jewell, one of the bondholders and stockholders of the Hecker-Jones-Jewell Milling Company, to break the trust agreement, which she signed, and for a surrender to her of her shares and bonds of the company, which she turned over to the Franklin Trust Company, the Trustee for the trust.

There was a rather better attendance at the dog show yesterday than, on the opening day, and there is still room for improvement. That will come with to-day's holiday, for Washington's Birthday always brings out a crowd. Society looks upon it as a sort of duty to show itself at the Gardon annually on this anniversary.

The controversy between Corporation Counsel Whalen and Controller Coler over the payment of claims under the prevailing rates of wages law started afresh yesterday, when Mr. Whalen returned to the Controller 430 such claims, which had come to him from the Finance Department. Will these returned claims a letter was sent in which the Controller was asked to give his reasons for refusing to settle them.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Distinguished jurists and educators from all parts of the United States and from England to-day took part in the formal dedication of the new Law Building of the University of Pennsylvania, the ceremonies incident to Which will be carried over until to-morrow, when the university formally celebrates Washington's Birthday, with Wu Ting Fang, Chinese Minister to the United States, as chief orator.

Miss Olga Nethersole appeared at Wallack's Theatre last night in Clyde Fitch's dramatization of Daudet's novel, "Sapho," despite the fact that she had been arrested, with Hamilton Revelle, her leading man; Marcus Mayer, her manager, and Theodore Moss, lessee of Wallack's Theatre. The audience was the largest that has thus far witnessed any performance of "Sapho" since it was put on the stage over three weeks ago.

We are at a loss to discover, by a reading of the speech of Representative DRIGGS of the Third New York District, delivered on Thursday last, with an editorial article of THE NEW YORK TIMES as a text, the occasion for the intemperate language used to characterize that article, and none whatever for the member's several misrepresentations of it.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Senator Malby to-day introduced a bill carrying out the recommendations of Superintendent McCullagh providing more rigid penalties for crimes against the elective franchise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- For the first time in the debate upon the Puerto Rice Tariff bill the voice of a Republican was to-day raised against the measure. Mr. Bromwell (Ohio) spoke against the bill. He opposed it on the ground of policy and not of constitutionality. His hostility, however, was not absolute, and he announced his intention of voting for it if the substitute failed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Senators Depew and Carter made addresses this evening before the Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Senator Depew said he knew of nothing in the recent development of social organizations which had done so much for patriotism, for history, and for love of country as the organization of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The St. James's Gazette this afternoon says the stolen Hawkesley letters, which Mr. Chamberlain yesterday evening referred to in the House of Commons as having been sold to Dr. Leyds for u100, "were purchased from the thief, for what sum we do not know, by no less a personage than Dr. Clark, M.P."

To the Editor of The New York Times: It may be pardonable by way of an illustration to speak of lineage and to say that I am a direct descendant of Revolutionary stock, and that on both sides of my family they were all thoroughbred, double-distilled Democrats, and their descendants have followed the same faith as conscientiously as though they were going to church.

Hopkins -- Barstow. Mr. Leonard Stuart Robinson Hopkins and Miss Margaret Macdonald Barstow, daughter of Mrs. J. Whitney Barstow of 15 Gramercy Park, were married yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock in St. Thomas's Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Wesley Brown, rector of the church.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The Senate and Assembly Committees on Tax and Retrenchment this afternoon gave a final hearing on the bill imposing a tax of one-half of 1 per cent. on real estate mortgages. The arguments against the measure were along the line of argument presented at previous hearings.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- On Oct. 13 of last year W.M. Morrison of the American Presbyterian Mission, with headquarters at Nashville. Tenn., forwarded documents confirming the stories of a reign of terror in the Free State and of events which "may lead to international representations," to the King of the Belgians.

A three-cornered will contest, in which spirits, both alcoholic and ethereal, figure to a large extent, is on trial before Surrogate Thomas. The will is that made by Clara Teresa Hewitt, who at one time was quite celebrated for her beauty both here and abroad. She and her sister Agnes were known as the De Forrest sisters.

Benjamin Wood, who served three terms in Congress and once as Senator of this State, and who was editor in chief of The New York Daily News and its properties, the Tages-Nichrichten and The Sunday News, of which he was, until the Winter of 1898, a majority stockholder, died yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

-- Jersey commuters are raising again their familiar complaint against the constant interruption of their Journeys between home and city by the opening of railroad drawbridges for the passage of sloops and schooners. Why action was not taken in this matter long ago it is impossible to understand.

Why is it that the Committee of Ways and Means has gone back upon the recommendations of the President and the Secretary of War and the matured opinions of its own members, as embodied in a bill for the relief of Puerto Rico?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- In view of the persistent circulation of the rumor that the Government of the United States has reached an agreement with the German Government, through its representative here. Baron von Holleben, to intervene between the combatants in South Africa, a statement of the present position of the Government in this matter has been secured from the highest authority.

"Evening up" processes over the holiday contributed some features to yesterday's security market; but the rule was dullness. Commission house transactions were unimportant; the public is evidently not yet persuaded that times are ripe for activity.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The Cape Town correspondent of The Daily Mail says:

"Hearts Are Trumps," the cartoon drama from the vast stage of Drury Lane Theatre, in London, was presented at the Garden Theatre last evening and held the attention of a crowded audience from before 8 o'clock until nearly midnight. There was no doubt, after the stirring scene in the picture gallery, that the play was a "go."

While our amazing HEPBURN in the House of Representatives is urging the treatment of the isthmian canal as a purely American channel for the development of American shipping, the Ministry in England is being sharply criticised for surrendering the rights secured to Great Britain in the control of such a canal under the Clayton-Bulwer treaty, without obtaining any compensation in such matters as the Alaskan boundary.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- The local list was very quiet, although prices were in the main well held. There was a fair demand for Biscuit common at the opening at 37, and several fifty-share lots changed hands at that price. Tube common improved to 20 1/4, but closed at 18. Linseed was steady at 15 1/4 for the common and 59 @ 59 1/4 for the preferred.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- It is said to-night on excellent authority that while there will probably be no direct legislation regarding the canal improvements at this session of the Legislature, it is the plan of the Republican organization to have a legislative commission appointed to examine closely the canal question during the recess and make recommendations to the next Legislature for such legislation as may be deemed necessary.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Mayor Ashbridge, At a. meeting to-day of the Citizens Republican National Convention Committee, of which he is Chairman, told his fellow-members of the committee that when he visited Washington last week to confer with Chairman Manley of the Republican National Committee's sub-committee, in charge of the convention arrangements, he found that the National organization was contemplating changing the place of meeting of the convention from this city to New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The answer of the State Department to the House resolution calling for information regarding certain charges made by ex-Consul Macrum was transmitted to the House to-day by the President. The document is signed by Secretary Hay, and after reciting the resolution says:

Mr. MCDONALD, under his contract with the Rapid Transit Commissioners, will presently begin to tear up Elm Street and Fourth Avenue. He will encounter water pipes, gas pipes, and sewers. What will he do with them? Why, he will move them to one side, out of the way of the underground railway tunnel, and carefully cover them up with earth, just as he found them.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- It is considered strange that, when sending his casualties, Lord Roberts gives no information as to the result of the fighting. If he has sent such, a report, the War Office is withholding it.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 21 -- Leslie E. Keeley, the inventor of the "Keeley cure for the liquor habit," died in this city today of heart disease. Dr. Keeley had been ill with a severe cold for two days, but nothing serious was feared from it. This morning, while going to his bathroom, he had an attack of heart failure, but recovered and later said there was nothing serious the matter with him.

The Investigation in the case of the charges of the City Club against District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner was continued before Commissioner Wilcox yesterday in Part XII. of the Supreme Court. The examination of Fulton McMahon of counsel employed by the Attorney General by Mr. Untermyer of counsel for the District Attorney took a considerable portion of the time.

A donkey engine boiler on the lighter Captain Rafferty, lying at Prentice Stores, Brooklyn, exploited yesterday and startled the residents of that portion of Brooklyn Heights overlooking the river. Besides causing alarm in the neighborhood, the explosion broke many windows, and a piece of the boiler was hurled a thousand feet, crashing through the side of the frame house at 8 Remsen Street, on the bluff.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The women who, the police say, have been systematically swindling lodging houses and restaurants for the last to years, were arrested last night and will be arraigned in court to-day. The women, who claim to be sisters, give the names of Teresa Donaldson and Jeanette Underhill, and state their ages to be fifty and fifty-two respectively.

The first and second teams of the Holy Cross Lyceum and the Cathedral Club team were the competitors in the Archdiocesan Union League at Starr's Tournament Hall last night. In the first game the first team of Holy Cross easily defeated the second team. The latter, however, secured a vie- tory in the second game, defeating the Cathedral Club.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Henry Duff Traill, editor of Literature and a well-known English newspaper man and author, died to-day in this city of heart disease.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "A Churchgoer," one of a deplorably large percentage of churchgoers, it is to be feared, presents himself in your issue of the 17th in a letter headed "Ministers and Their Congregations," as one who resents the right of ministers to assume the attitude of teachers or pastors toward their congregations.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The Special Committee on School Bills of the Senate Committee on Cities has agreed upon a schedule for teachers' salaries in New York City, with the exception of the high school teachers, over which there is a division of opinion whether they snail obtain their maximum salaries in three or six years.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The entire afternoon was devoted toy the Judiciary Committee of both houses to the hearing of arguments upon the bills designed to place the Gerry Societies for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children under the general supervision of the State Board of Charities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May a voice from a neighboring State avail of the columns of his daily paper to record, at this propitious moment, his abhorrence of capital punishment? That capital punishment should be tolerated in this land and age is a blot upon us all, and when we read to-day of the sentence of a fellow-man, the shock is too great to withstand.

Yesterday's market for outside securities was without particular feature, and few changes of importance resulted from the day's transactions. Prices moved irregularly -- some disposition to sell resulting in a number of fractional declines, while some issues showed advances over Tuesday's bids, which in a few cases were substantial.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The President to-day sent the following nominations in the volunteer army to the Senate:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The conference last night at the house of Senator Hanna of the three "kicking" Republicans and the Senator whose name is attached to the Ship Subsidy bill came to something, but not much. As reported last night. Stevens, Minor and Jones, who were present, were anxious to obtain concessions.

HAVANA, Feb. 21 -- Salvador Cisneros, Marquis of Santa Lucia, first President of the Cuban Provisional Republic, presided last night at a meeting called to protest against the appointment of Mgr. Sbarretti to the Bishopric of Havana.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The War Office has received the following from Gen. Buller:

There will be a general social flight to the country to-day, although there are several notable entertainments in town, among them the annual reception and dinner at the Metropolitan Club. House parties will be given by Mrs. Pierpont Morgan at Highland Falls, by Mr. and Mrs. Ogdon Mills at Staatsburg and Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt at Biltmore.

Leopold Well has sold for Boehm Coon to Erasmus D. Garnsey the two old sixstory buildings 51 and 53 Maiden Lane, north side, about 135 feet west of William Street. The area of the plot occupied by the buildings is about 7,000 square feet, having a frontage of 39.6 feet, a rear line of 65 feet, and a depth of 139 feet.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 21 -- The contests over the State offices are very much simplified by an agreement entered into today between the attorneys for the Republicans and the Democrats in the injunction suits relating to the Governorship.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Mrs. Lawton has made the following acknowledgment of the receipt of the home fund:

Policeman Thomas Everett of the Morrisania Police Station made a reputation for himself yesterday by killing a chicken thief. It was only after a prolonged struggle, in which the thief displayed conspicuous dodging ability, that a bullet from the policeman's revolver struck him in the heart.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The Director of the State Library is sending out flat printed circulars to blind persons throughout the State suggesting that they might like to enjoy the opportunities offered by the New York State Library for the blind, and giving the information that "through the liberality of friends interested, books will be sent for the present without charge for expressage either way."

The Morgan Line steamer Winifred, Capt. Langhorne, from New Orleans, arrived in port yesterday, having in tow the three-masted schooner Henry R. Tilton, Capt. Cobb, from Savannah, Feb. 9, for New York, which had been picked up in a sinking condition on Tuesday morning in latitude 38.13 longritude 72.25.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- To-morrow the National Democratic Committee will meet and decide whether the boisterous campaign of Milwaukee or the silent work of Kansas City is to be crowned with success. The Milwaukee men are uneasy to-night, and are not so ready with figures. They still claim that there is nothing that can prevent them from winning, but they are much more subdued in manner, and there is no more talk of a walkover.
LONDON, Feb. 21--The following dispatch has been received at the War Office from Lord Roberts:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- The Brunswick Traction Company, the New York and Philadelphia Traction Company, and the New Brunswick City Railway Company have been consolidated as the Somerset and Middlesex Traction Company. Gottfried Krueger of Newark is President of the company, Andrew H. Radel of Bridgeport, Conn., is Vice President, and Edward H. Radel of this city is Secretary and General Manager.

In accordance with their time-honored custom, the Sons of the Revolution last night celebrated the birth of Washington by a dinner at Delmonico's, when nearly 300 of the descendants of Revolutionary notables and their guests assembled and partook of the society's hospitality. Frederick S. Tallmadge, the President of the society for many years, presided, and the toasts of the guests lauding the Father of his Country were addressed to a distinguished gathering.

PALM BEACH, Pla., Feb. 22 -- With a Vardon-Findlay golf match on, and the largest crowd ever known at Palm Beach, Washington's Birthday came in as a gala day in earnest. The professionals here are Vardon, Smith, Low, Hoare, Findlay, and Penn. A. W. Black of Lakewood acted as referee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- "The outlook is blue" said a Republican friend of the Puerto Rican Tariff bill to-night. "I shall be surprised if the bill does not pass." said Representative Russell of Connecticut, a member of the Ways and Means Committee. The two statements convey a very good idea of the different feelings, that prevail among Republicans.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 22 -- Convention Hall, where the National Democratic Convention will be held in July next, is situated at Thirteenth and Central Streets, four blocks from the retail district of the city. It has been classed by travelers as one of the largest and most perfectly constructed auditoriums in existence.

For the first time in the history of the pigeon shooting tourney for the amateur championship of America, the title and the handsome trophy goes outside of New York and its vicinity. Charles A. Painter of Pittsburg won the title yesterday at the Carteret Gun Club's traps, on Hempstead Plains, near Garden City, with a score of 94 kills.

To the Editor The New York Times: Allow me to reply to two letters in to-day's TIMES on the contributions by American women to the hospital ship Maine. Your correspondents scornfully ask for instances of British aid for the sufferers in the Spanish-American war. I am a Scotchwoman, and I gave gladly and freely as my means permitted to the Red Cross fund, and I can certify to many generous contributions from other Britishers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Timothy L. Woodruff, Lieutenant Governor of New York, received a rousing welcome to-night when he rose at the Washington Day banquet of the Union League Club of Chicago to respond to the toast "The East and the West."

The formal presentation of the new hall of the Board of Education, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, to the city took place yesterday afternoon, the exercises being conducted in the assembly room of the new building. This room, which has a seating accommodation of more than 1,200, was crowded.

Fortifications? Why, of course not. As I understand it, the canal is to be, and should be, a neutralized commercial pathway between the two great oceans. To fortify it would simply result in making it a battleground in case of war. Fortifications would be enormously expensive and ought not to be erected.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The so-called "Raines law" is probably the worst measure which has ever been enacted in this State. It was deliberately drawn with the intention of making the liquor interest directly dependent upon the political boss. The amount of revenue to be raised under its provisions was used as a pretext to blind the people to its true character.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Representative Fitzgerald (Dem., Mass.,) has introduced a bill limiting the charges on sleeping cars to 50 cents a hundred miles for a lower berth, and 25 cents a hundred miles for an upper berth. A total charge of $1.25 for a lower and $1 for an upper berth is allowed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The next National Democratic Convention will be held at Kansas City, Mo., July 4. This was the decision of the Democratic National Committee, which met at the Hotel Raleigh today to fix the time and place of holding the convention.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 -- A step was taken tonight in the direction of a project through which, if carried to completion, Detroit will possess one of the finest monuments of architectural and artistic skill on the American Continent. For several months a movement has been on foot toward the erection of a permanent memorial of the bicentenary of the founding of Detroit.

The annual tournaments of the New York State Chess Association, which are held every year on Washington's birthday in this city, took place yesterday in the Assembly Hall in the United Charities Building, play lasting from 10:30 o'clock in the morning until 11 o'clock at night. Thirty-four competitors took part in the two contests, one of which was for the State championship and the other was a free-for-all affair.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The conferrees of the Senate and the House on the Currency bill will report an agreement to-morrow, probably before 2 o'clock.

"The Political and Social Effects of Industrial Combination" was the subject last evening at the fourth meeting in the series of the conference on trusts, which is being held this week at Cooper Union under the auspices of the People's Institute. The hall was filled, and Charles Sprague Smith Presided over the meeting.

Henry Clay Miner died suddenly yesterday afternoon at his home at Riverside Drive and West Seventy-sixth Street. More familiarly known as "Harry" Miner, he was in active touch with the theatrical world for years. He began life as a drug clerk, served on the police force, and during the active portion of his business life he is said to have controlled more playhouses than any other individual manager.
ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The Senate to-day, by a vote of 33 to 12, passed the bill of Assemblyman McEwan allowing savings banks to invest in the bonds of the Chicago and Alton Railroad.

It must be becoming manifest to every man in Congress that the bill imposing a tariff on Puerto Rico is the most dangerous measure for the peace and welfare of the Republican Party that has been introduced into Congress, under the authority of a committee, for many a year.

The fourth evening concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra took place last night at Carnegie Hall. The audience was precisely what one would have expected from the presence of Leonora Jackson as the solo performer. This young and immature violinist has such a strong social backing that a large and well-garbed audience was a foregone conclusion.

The plan announced by Secretary ROOT for organizing the War College is virtually a part of his plan for reorganizing the army. The difference is that this part of the plan does not depend upon legislation, but can be carried out by an Executive order.

-- Massachusetts anti-vivisectionists are using all their influence to secure the passage by the State Legislature of a bill to render illegal practically all experiments on animals. The petitions they are circulating for signature are worded with great care and apparent moderation, and to many the object of the bill seems to be merely to prevent the infliction of unnecessary suffering, without interfering materially with the advancement of medical and surgical knowledge.

Col. Edward Duffy has set the evening of next Thursday for the election of a Lieutenant Colonel and two Majors in the Sixty-ninth Regiment. Col. Duffy, when seen yesterday, said: "The regiment has been long enough without field officers. I find. I cannot devote the time to drilling battalions that should properly fall to the Majors."

George Montgomery Davie, one of the most eminent members of the Louisville bar and a prominent supporter of the Palmer and Buckner ticket in the Presidential campaign of 1896, died of sareema yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Hotel. He had been ill since last October and was brought to New York for treatment by a cancer specialist in December.

Among the various bicycle dealers in Greater New York, ye-sterday was observed as the opening day for the bicycling season of 1900. All the dealers held open house, so to speak, and to a certain extent the opening was like the recent bicycle show, only on a smaller scale. In nearly every case the dealers furnished some form of entertainment, and in many places refreshments were served and the visitors received souvenirs.

Washington's Birthday -- the one hundred and sixty-eighth anniversary -- was ushered in with a snorting gale from off the ocean following a rain which had come down hard at times during the night, but had quite cleared up by the time that would-be celebrators looked out and sought for signs of a day of fair promise in the skies.

Archbishop Corrigan sent to the clergy of this city yesterday a circular letter in which he tells what are the regulations to be observed by the Roman Catholic laity during the Lenten season, which begins on Wednesday next, and ends on Easter Sunday, April 15. The rules prescribed by the Archbishop are as follows:

Prof. F.W. TAUSSIG of Harvard has a peculiar talent for comprehensive and illuminating statement. He has rarely used it to better advantage than in an article in the current number of The Quarterly Journal of Economics, published for the university, on "The Iron Industry in the United States."
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Daily News has the following dispatch from Modder River, dated Wednesday afternoon, Feb. 21:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Gen. John McNulta of Chicago, well-known throughout the West because of his identification with the receiverships of railroads and other great corporations, died suddenly here shortly after 6 o'clock to-night in his apartments at the Hamilton House, from angina pectoris.

Various attempts to get bills against the department stores passed have been made in this and other States. By some Legislatures, notably that of Missouri, restrictive laws have been enacted. The Missouri Supreme Court on Tuesday rendered a decision that the anti-department law passed by the last Legislature of that State is unconstitutional.

PAARDEBERG DRIFT, Feb. 20 -- Gen. Cronje's magnificent night march from Magersfontein now appears likely to end in disaster. The main body of the Boers is inclosed in a terrible death-trap. The enemy is hiding in the bed of the Modder, commanded by the British artillery, and inclosed, on the east and west, by the British infantry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- The British flag, flying over the home of Consul Capt. William Wyndham, in honor of Washington's Birthday, came near being hauled down this afternoon. A crowd of fifty or sixty young men and boys gathered about the British Consul's home, and spying the banner of Great Britain, they immediately began to throw snowballs and sticks at it.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Globe says: "The spirit in which a brave, strong nation should meet trial is admirably illustrated by the temper displayed by Canada. The war, if it has done nothing else, has killed political bitterness and mere party strife in all the colonies. The contrast between Ottawa and Westminster is painful and humiliating."

Many specialties will figure conspicuously in the stock market for some time to come -- if plans that are well supported can be successful. The iron and steel and coal shares are especially in favor with the managers of a number of pools. What Lackawanna and Reading did last week is an example of the rule, as some influential traders would have it.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve increased L251,000, circulation decreased L266,000, bullion decreased L14,284, other securities increased L2,317,000, other deposits increased L1,108,000, public deposits increased L1,447,000, notes reserve increased L347,000, and Government securities were unchanged.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 4 -- Some friction is occurring between the Maritime Canal Company of Nicaragua and the Government in regard to the personnel of the proposed Court of Arbitration to settle disputed points between them.

Announcement of an important step in the matter of the heresy charges against the Rev. Dr. Arthur C. McGiffert, Professor of Church History in the Union Theological Seminary, was made yesterday. The Rev. Dr. G.W.F. Birch, the Stated Clerk of the New York Presbytery, declared his intention to appeal the case to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President McKinley attended the eighteenth annual banquet to-night of the District Commandery of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States. Brig. Gen. John M. Wilson of the army presided. In the course of some remarks, the President said:

Definition is a good thing in an argument. If the disputants who are taking part in the great continental debate on the trusts would rant less and define more their arguments would make a better impression. It is your ignoramus that rants. Full knowledge gives the power to make statements that bear recognizable relation to facts, and in a discussion that is the only kind of statement worth listening to.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- C.W. Clark, son of Senator Clark, was before the Clark investigating committee to-day. Mr. Clark said he had taken an active part in the Montana legislative campaign in 1898 and in the Senatorial fight following.

A Boston dispatch, printed in THE TIMES yesterday, and dated from London by mistake, told of the arrest of two women charged with systematically swindling lodging houses. They gave their names as Teresa Donaldson and Jeanette Underhill, stating that their ages were fifty and fifty-two, respectively, and that the latter was the widow of an ex-District Attorney who practiced law in Brooklyn in the sixties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The prospect is that the Republicans and the Democrats of the Senate may give the Finance Committee some trouble before that committee will be permitted to get possession of the French reciprocity treaty.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The Assembly Cities Committee gave a hearing to-day on Mr. Weekes's bill prohibiting trucks, excepting for delivery purposes, on Fifth Avenue, New York City, between Twenty-fifth Street and Fifty-ninth Street, between the hours of 2 and 7 P.M., from Oct. 1 to June 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of the 14th inst. you devote nearly a column and a half to an effort to prove that the enfranchisement of woman would be "a danger and an evil." If female suffrage had never been tried you might with reason oppose argument to argument against it, and the controversy might with equal reason be determined by the preponderance of argument.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The Municipal Government of Syracuse is to be subjected to an investigation by a special legislative committee in order to ascertain the causes responsible for a deficiency of over $400,000 in the finances of that city. A resolution was passed to-day in the Assembly empowering Speaker Nixon to appoint a sub-committee of the Committee on Cities to go to Syracuse and make such an investigation.

A daylight robbery, with many unusual features, occurred yesterday in the annexed district. A woman was bound and gagged in her own home, her life threatened, and her little three-year-old son roughly handled. The two robbers were captured within an hour and their booty recovered.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 22 -- President C.M. Schwab of the Carnegie Steel Company arrived in Pittsburg to-day from New York and was at his office all day, receiving but few callers. He declined to express any views on the equity suit brought against the company by H.C. Frick to recover $10,000,000, and the result of his conference with Andrew Carnegie in New York remains a matter of conjecture.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- An "Eastern conference " of anti-imperialists began here to-day and will remain in session two days. The leaders say that a show of hands in Philadelphia a few months in advance of the Republican National Convention will have weight in inducing the delegates to recognize their claims.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- This year the Academy has "crowned" six books, each representing a department of literature. With the exception of the awards for poetry and for fiction, little fault will be found with the choice made by the conductors of the Academy. As to poetry and fiction, no matter what choice the Academy might have made, there would have been those who would have found fault with it.

PAARDEBERG DRIFT, Feb. 20 -- As night fell, after the terrific fighting which lasted all day Sunday, there was a sudden cessation of fire, as both sides were thoroughly tired and glad to rest. The work of collecting the dead and wounded proceeded, and the men slept where they had fought the whole day.
BOMBAY, Feb. 23 -- The Times of India announces that a large Russian cruiser has arrived at Bandar Abbas, on the Straits of Ormuz, which connects the Persian Gulf with the Arabian Sea.
